title: JAPAN'S TDK LEADS MARKET IN VIDEOTAPE
description: In the late 1970's, when videotape recorder sales began rising throughout the world, two Japanese companies saw an opening. Where there are recorders, the reasoning went, there will be tapes. And while the Fuji Photo Film Company was probably the first to begin production of videotape cassettes for retail sale, it did not remain the largest producer.

title: Nets Top Clippers By 110-95
description: The Nets' 110-95 victory over the San Diego Clippers before 14,313 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena this afternoon was not a stylish one. It was achieved against a struggling and battered team reminiscent of the Nets before they became playoff contenders.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 1, 1982
description: International El Salvador's election next month is regarded gloomily by President Reagan's senior advisers. They are also doubtful about the ability of the Salvadoran Government to achieve a military victory over the rebels. Administration officials said President Reagan had been receiving increasingly pessimisitic reports that the guerrillas would succeed in reducing participation in the March 28 election by threats and confiscatng voter identification cards at gunpoint. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Central America's problems are being exaggerated by the international press and by some United States politicians, the President of El Salvador's junta, Jose Napoleon Duarte said in an interview. He Duarte said in an interview. He said the international attention is harming the ''little countries,'' including Nicaragua and El Salvador. He also said that if his Christian Democrats win the March 28 elections they will not negotiate with the ''extreme left'' or the ''extreme right'' over a share of the power. (A1:4-5.)

title: Ways to Save the Thrift Industry; Economic Analysis
description: The nation's ailing savings industry is approaching the ultimate crunch, and there are a variety of proposals on to how to deal with it.

title: Women Studying Law Double Total 7 Years Ago
description: The number of women attending law schools has more than doubled in the last seven years, the American Bar Association reports.

title: 'INVISIBLE MAN,' AS VIVID TODAY AS IN 1952
description: RALPH ELLISON is 68 years old today. Relaxing in his art- and book-lined apartment on Riverside Drive above the Hudson the other day, he took a little time away from his electric typewriter to talk about his working life.

title: MUSIC: MISS HOLLANDER SINGS
description: GISELA HOLLANDER, a soprano from Venezuela, and her pianist, Walter Moore, performed songs by Beethoven, Schubert, Verdi, Nicolai Medtner, MacDowell, Liszt and Hugo Wolf before a sparse audience at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon. What bound all this music together were the words, the texts in every case derived from Goethe.

title: Cheerful Expressions
description: The crowd doesn't reach the decibel level as it does at Carrier Dome in Syracuse, but there is a respectable amount of bellowing when the cheerleading squad at the Montana School for the Deaf and Blind asks the crowd to support the boys high school basketball team.

title: Swiss Duo First
description: Erich Schaerer and Toni Ruegg took advantage of a course-record first heat to win the Budweiser Diamond Trophy International bobsled race today at Mount Van Hoevenburg.

title: F. Lee Bailey Is Arrested
description: F. Lee Bailey, a defense attorney in some of the nation's most celebrated criminal cases, was arrested today for investigation of drunken driving, the authorities said. The 48-year-old Boston-based lawyer refused to take a sobriety test after the 1 A.M. arrest, said a sheriff's deputy. Mr. Bailey was also booked for failing to stop his car at a stop sign, and released on $500 bail three hours about 4 A.M., according to the authorities.

title: 90 HOSTAGES ARE FREED IN BRITAIN
description: BISHOP'S STORTFORD, England, Feb. 28 - A 48-hour hijacking drama that began in East Africa ended tonight at an airport 25 miles northeast of London with the surrender of four young terrorists and the release of more than 90 hostages.

title: THE DARK SIDE OF FORD'S CONTRACT
description: Ever since the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company reached agreement on a contract, optimists have heralded a new era of harmony between labor and management. The U.A.W. is praised for acting responsibly in giving up annual pay increases; Ford, it is said, displayed enlightenment by taking steps toward increased worker participation and lifetime employment. Amid the glow, the overall result of both negotiating parties' serving self-interest is seen, somehow, as a numbing blow to foreign competition.

title: Carter Hurts Neck
description: Gary Carter, who recently signed a multiyear contract with the Montreal Expos worth $15 million, has been sidelined for two or three days with a minor but painful neck injury. Carter was hit on the right side of the neck with a thrown baseball Saturday in drills. When he reported today he was unable to turn his head or to talk, so he was ordered to rest.

title: CITY OPERA: JUDITH FORST IN LEAD OF 'CARMEN'
description: EVEN for the longest running of Broadway shows there comes a time to close up shop for 10 years or so and wait for a revival. That was the feeling Saturday afternoon as the New York City Opera presented its first ''Carmen'' of the season.

title: LOS ANGELES ALERTS TOURISTS ABOUT CRIME
description: This city of fantasies, where tourism brings in more than $6 billion a year, is trying, as gingerly as it can, to warn tourists to watch their hats and coats and everything else they own when they come to visit.

title: Brandeis's New Goal
description: Ice hockey on the college level has thrived for many years in the Boston area. Teams from Boston College, Boston University, Harvard and Northeastern have played the game well, often challenging for national honors. So it has been a bit odd that at Brandeis University in nearby Waltham, Mass., a college that has enjoyed successful programs in most other sports, hockey has not had a varsity program since the birth of the school in 1947.

title: Still Welterweight, Hearns Insists
description: Emanuel Steward, Thomas Hearns's manager and trainer, says he is upset at the World Boxing Association and World Boxing Council for removing Hearns from the list of contenders for Sugar Ray Leonard's welterweight crown.

title: Bridge: New York Grand National Won by Becker Foursome
description: It is safe to say that the New York City final of the Grand National Teams, played Saturday at the New York Hilton Hotel, has more top-ranked players than any comparable event in North America. So tough was the field that one group of stars, headed by Alan Greenberg, failed to make the cut.

title: RANGERS BEATEN BY PENGUINS, 4-2
description: The Rangers played one of their weaker games of the season last night, losing, 4-2, to the Pittsburgh Penguins at Madison Square Garden.

title: AMERICAN EMBASSY'S ROLE IN THE 1973 BOMBING IN CAMBODIA
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA SLAYING TASK FORCE IS EXPECTED TO DISBAND SOON
description: The special task force investigating the deaths of young blacks here is expected to be disbanded this week after the conviction of Wayne B. Williams in two of the slayings, lawenforcement officials said today.

title: S.E.C. VOTE ON CITICORP QUESTIONED
description: Bevis Longstreth, one of three Securities and Exchange commissioners who voted against bringing an enforcement action against Citicorp for inadequate disclosure of its foreign currency trading practices, says he once represented the bank and was a partner until last year in a law firm that has long had Citibank as a client.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Le Anne Schreiber HUNGER OF MEMORY: The Education of Richard Rodriguez. By Richard Rodri- guez. 195 pages. David R. Godine. $13.95.

title: MORGENTHAU SAYS '80 FELONY CASES SET RECORD
description: Felons in Manhattan were indicted, convicted and sent to state prison in record numbers last year, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said in a report released yesterday.

title: SUNS 103, SONICS 98
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Dennis Johnson broke out in the fourth quarter with 12 points to pace the victory.

title: BRIEFING
description: Disclosure Studied

title: Juvenile Crime
description: In the face of increasingly violent juvenile crime, the Family Court in New York City is being misused as a haven for young muggers and marauders, according to interviews with judges, lawyers, court officials and family-law experts. They say the traditional policies of anonymity and leniency given to young offenders in the court have become outmoded. The court's judges, acting in secret with suspects who are not identified because they are under 16 years old, dismiss charges, set youths free and even send those who have been convicted back to parents, foster homes or the streets in overwhelming numbers.

title: WATER RESTORED AROUND THE SITE OF BROKEN PIPE
description: Water service was restored by yesterday to all residents and businesses in midtown affected by the rupture Friday night of a major water main south of Times Square, according to the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: TO PROTECT A CAR'S YOUNGEST PASSENGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAMBER MUSIC: ROGERI TRIO
description: ONE of the dangers in performing the way the Rogeri Trio did Wednesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall is that audiences get used to error-free playing, good intonation and beautifully meshed ensemble, and start to take it all for granted. When that happens, there is nothing left to do but concentrate on the music.

title: A Rating For City Notes
description: New York City's scheduled $100 million issue of revenue anticipation notes has been rated A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. It was the first time the rating agency had rated city notes.

title: Canadiens 5, Whalers 0
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Denis Herron, the Montreal goalie, turned in the shutout, the second he has been involved in this season.

title: UPSETS HAVE LITTLE IMPACT ON N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT OUTLOOK
description: Surprising results last weekend such as upsets of Virginia, Kentucky, Tennessee and West Virginia attracted attention but had little effect on those teams' chances for a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. The games that really count for these teams begin this week when they compete in their conference playoffs, whose champions earn automatic bids to the N.C.A.A. tourna-

title: GENERAL ASKS REAGAN TO OVERHAUL U.S. MILITARY COMMAND STRUCTURE
description: A former top military field commander, Gen. Volney F. Warner, has urged President Reagan to order far-reaching changes in the nation's entire military command structure.

title: DEEP CUTS IN STUDENT LOANS PREDICTED BY ALBANY PANEL
description: Federal regulations that took effect last year could reduce by more than $200 million the amount of guaranteed student loans - now totaling $1.1 billion -granted next fall to New York State residents, according to a state survey.

title: HIGH RATES CALLED DRAG ON RECOVERY
description: The recession has deepened, and the prospect for some visible recovery this spring is disappearing under the weight of persistently high interest rates and bad winter weather, leading economic forecasters now say.

title: No Headline
description: DOLE SAYS PRESIDENT MAY HAVE TO REVISE TAX-REDUCTION PLAN

title: A Thank-You Party for a Benefactor of the Arts
description: About 150 notables from the arts and business staged a lively surprise thank-you party in honor of Mortimer Levitt's 75th birthday and his contributions to the performing arts. He is the chairman of Young Concert Artists, which has launched the careers of such artists as the pianist Emanuel Ax and the violinist Pinchas Zuckerman since Mr. Levitt helped to start it 21 years ago. Mr. Levitt has been chairman of its board for about eight of those years.

title: ATLANTANS' FEELINGS MIXED ON VERDICT
description: In the rows of public housing units in the Thomasville Heights projects on the city's southeast side, it is no surprise that many people say they were tuned in to their radios and televisions Saturday to hear the verdict in the case against Wayne B. Williams.

title: U.S. Court Backs Order On Homes for Retarded
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit has upheld a lower court ruling directing Pennsylvania to begin moving retarded people from the Pennhurst Center back to their communities.

title: 7 YOUNG PEOPLE KIDNAPPED IN SALVADORAN SLUM
description: Seven young people were kidnapped today from a slum area here by armed men in civilian clothes. The victims, ranging from 15 to 20 years old, were forced into a green van by 10 to 12 men, who sought them out at their homes and a nearby soda fountain.

title: 2 LEADERS OF HIGHER EDUCATION REACT TO CUTS IN GOVERNMENT AID
description: Virginia B. Smith, the president of Vassar College, warns that private colleges and universities are losing ground in their effort to maintain social and economic diversity, in part because they were ''seduced'' into becoming too dependent on Federal student aid programs.

title: ORWELL IN POLAND
description: The unfortunate hero of ''1984,'' Winston Smith, worked at the Ministry of Truth. His job was rewriting history. Under instructions sent to him on slips of paper, he changed stories in back newspapers to make them correspond with later party policy. Then he dropped the instructions into the Memory Hole, where they were sucked into giant furnaces.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday President Reagan goes on the road again this week, selling his budget and proposals that states take over certain Federal programs. But there will be plenty of action in his absence, especially when the Senate debates whether to expel Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, and when top Administration officials go to Capitol Hill to talk about military spending, foreign policy and civil rights. The President is to leave Tuesday for Cheyenne, Wyo., Albuquerque, N.M. and Los Angeles, then heads for his ranch Thursday evening for a long weekend before returning to the capital next Monday. Parent Power: Nancy Reagan is to discuss drug abuse at a meeting of the annual legislative conference of the National P.T.A. 11 A.M., Quality Inn-Capitol Hill. Student Power: More than 1,000 students rally in a one-day protest against proposed cuts in financial aid programs affecting them. 9:15 A.M., Room 304, Cannon Office Building. Ballot Power: Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds is to discuss the Administration's reservations on the House-passed voting rights bill. Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on the Constitution, 9:30 A.M., Room 2228, Dirksen Office Building. Spy Watch: The Senate is to take up the Intelligence Indentities Protection Act of 1981, which would make it a crime to publicly identify an American intelligence agent. Progress Report: Leading Economic Indicators for January will be released. Tuesday Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger will defend the Administration's military budget today and tommorrow in closed hearings before the Senate Appropriations Committee and the Senate Budget Committee. On Thursday he will appear in open hearings before the House Budget Committee. 10 A.M., Room 210, Cannon Office Building. Money Matter: The Senate and House Budget committees will be holding hearings throughout the week on the First Budget Resolution for Fiscal 1983, which both committees are required to adopt by April 15. Foreign Affairs: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. goes before the House Foreign Affairs Committee at 9:30 A.M., Room 2172, Rayburn Building. He'll probably be questioned about El Salvador, Poland and the Middle East. On the Docket: The Supreme Court will hear arguments on the question: Did the Board of Education of the Island Trees School District of Long Island violate First Amendment rights of students by banishing nine books from a high school library? Filibuster Finale: With close to 60 Senators apparently in support, the Senate is expected to vote final passage of the most stringent antibusing legislation ever to pass Congress. Peace Now: The first order of business for the House is House Concurrent Resolution 226 that urges elections and a negotiated settlement in El Salvador. Wednesday One of the toughest questions the Senate will face this year comes up at 12:30 P.M. when debate begins on whether Senator Williams should be expelled because of his conviction on charges growing out of the Abscam investigation. Last Chance: The Supreme Court is to hear an appeal from the N.A.A.C.P. on a ruling that made the organization financially liable for the business losses caused by a boycott 16 years ago in Port Gibson, Miss. Thursday Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is to be the first witness at an economic overview session conducted by the Senate Appropriations Committee. 9:30 A.M., Room 1114, Dirksen Office Building. Friday That old war horse of liberal causes, Americans for Democratic Action, holds its annual business meeting and begins a three-day F.D.R. Centennial Convention at the National Education Association Building. Leading Indicator: Despite a drop in unemployment from 8.9 percent to 8.5 percent in January, the unemployment figures for February, due out today, are expected to show a rise.

title: SPANISH SOCIALIST, SENSING VICTORY, SOFTENS STANCE
description: ''Would you trust the Socialists to govern Spain if Felipe Gonzalez were not their leader?'' With the polls showing the Socialists in the lead, the marketing men employed by Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo's center-right party have been testing this question for use in parliamentary elections that will probably take place in the autumn.

title: Execution of Child-Killer Stayed by U.S. Court
description: A Federal appeals court granted a stay of execution to a convicted child-killer today, two days before he was scheduled to die in the electric chair in Florida.

title: POSSIBLE REVISIONS IN THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT
description: In the last few years disputes over a species of tiny fish, a snapdragon plant and two kinds of butterflies have delayed or caused plans to be changed for a city-sized housing development and two huge dams in the United States.

title: DE PAUL BEATS NOTRE DAME
description: Terry Cummings scored 28 points today as De Paul wore down Notre Dame with its superior inside play for an 81-69 victory.

title: Wide Boycott Marks End of O.A.U. Meeting
description: The Organization of African Unity ended a weeklong ministerial meeting today with more than a third of its 51 members boycotting the closing session to protest the admission of the Polisario guerrilla front.

title: GAYLORD PERRY: THE LONELY QUEST FOR VICTORY NO. 300
description: WILLIAMSTON, N.C. THE lavender blue telephone rang and Gaylord Perry, the elderly spitball pitcher without a team, picked it up before it had a chance to ring again. Any call now could be the one. It was late morning, and he was sitting at his desk in his home here, having recently come in from performing considerable chores on his peanut farm. He still wore a yellow cap that covered a baldish head, and a plaid shirt, blue jeans and work shoes, which he had washed off with a hose before entering the house.

title: AMERICAN EMBASSY'S ROLE IN THE 1973 BOMBING IN CAMBODIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Valenzuela Pact Talks to Continue
description: Representatives of the Los Angeles Dodgers and Fernando Valenzuela met today without reaching agreement on a contract, but both sides reported progress and agreed to resume negotiations Monday.

title: Tennis Doubles
description: Glasses were raised in toasts at Alex Mayer's home in Mendham, N.J., last week. For the first time in their careers, his two sons were ranked together in the world's top 10 of tennis. Gene, 25 years old, was No.8 and Sandy, 29, was No.10. No other pair of brothers has achieved such a distinction.

title: Ala.-Birmingham 94, Va. Commonwealth 83
description: Oliver Robinson scored 24 points to lead Alabama-Birmingham to a victory that clinched the Sun Belt Conference championship. For Alabama-Birmingham (23-5), it was the first conference title in three years in the six-team league. Virginia Commonwealth (17-11) suffered its first loss ever in Sun Belt tournament play.

title: REAGAN IS GETTING GLOOMY ESTIMATES ON SALVADOR VOTE
description: President Reagan's senior advisers say they are not optimistic about the chances of a successful election next month in El Salvador, or about the Salvadoran Government's ability to achieve a military victory over the rebels.

title: The Editorial Notebook Soaking Up Europe's Money
description: For President Reagan, high interest rates are a serious embarrassment. For his European counterparts, embarrassment is the least of it. As German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt recently put it, ''The fabric of the economy and society is endangered by the deepest recession since the middle 30's.'' Europe will be unable to cope, he implied, until America eases its tight money policies.

title: Leah Joan Miller Bride Of Jesse Lee Matuson
description: Leah Joan Miller, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Miller of Woodbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Jesse Lee Matuson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Matuson of Lake Worth, Fla. Rabbi Julius Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury.

title: NEW ISSUES SMALL BUT COULD RISE
description: Only slightly more than $400 million of new corporate debt securities are scheduled for public sale this week, but investment bankers said the amount could increase quickly.

title: TRYING DAYS AT CONTINENTAL
description: Continental Air Lines, struggling with slipping revenues, costly labor agreements and impatient lenders, is weighing stern measures to relieve the mounting pressure.

title: Carbon Industries Promotes 2 Officers
description: William J. Scullion, 49 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of Carbon Industries, a metallurgical and steam coal company based in Charleston, W. Va. He succeeds James R. Thomas 2d, 57, who was appointed chairman of the company, which has been a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation since 1977.

title: News Analysis
description: Three conferences held in Warsaw last week drew a distinct line between the dominant forces in Poland under martial law. Although both the church and the state appealed for unity, the conditions they set augured the opposite.

title: No Headline
description: GRETSKY GETS TWO AS OILERS WIN, 4-1

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch last Thursday about Arthur F. Burns, United States Ambassador to West Germany, incorrectly reported his age. He is 77 years old.

title: 2 FIREMEN INJURED AND SCHOOL DESTROYED IN SEPARATE BLAZES
description: A suspicious two-alarm blaze destroyed a Hasidic school and synagogue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn early yesterday, a spokesman for the Fire Deparment reported.

title: Leonard to Meet Stafford
description: Sugar Ray Leonard will make the next defense of his welterweight boxing title May 21 against Roger Stafford, the promoter Dan Duva announced here today.

title: Howard, Coaches Cast Big Impression
description: Frank Howard downs a hearty breakfast at the Mets' hotel here at 7 o'clock each morning before springing out of his chair with the kind of bounce that might not be expected from a 6-foot-8-inch, 45-year-old who weighs 270 pounds. Looming over his fellow coaches at the table, Howard then takes a swing with an imaginary baseball bat in much the way Johnny Carson wields his golf club during his monologue. ''Post time, fellas!'' Howard shouts, and his voice booms throughout the dining room.

title: THE TUMULT IN TV NEWS
description: WHEN William J. Small was forced to resign as president of NBC News last week, it was just the News Analysis latest upheaval in the fastest growing, fastest changing and most hotly debated area of television.

title: Johnny Carson Is Arrested
description: Johnny Carson, host of the ''Tonight'' show on NBC, was arrested Saturday on suspicion of drunken driving, the police said today. The 56-year-old entertainer was arrested about 1:30 A.M. on La Cienega Boulevard in an area known as ''Restaurant Row.'' He was released on his own recognizance.

title: RECITAL: WEGREN PIANO DEBUT
description: working musical artists need room to perceive gradually their shortcomings and to grow. We owe them our forbearance. Thomas Wegren's piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night, however, stretched good will to its breaking point.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Signed Rick Cerone, catcher, to one-year contract at $400,000, the annual salary he was awarded in arbitration last year.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 1, 1982; The Economy
description: Prospects are fading for an economic recovery in the spring as the recession deepens and interest rates remain persistently high. Economists still say that an upturn should start in the second half, but at a much slower pace than previously expected. (Page A1.) The recovery then could increase credit demands by business and consumers, sending rates back up after a dip in the spring. (D7.)

title: EXCHANGES ARE HIT
description: A series of at least four explosions ripped through the Wall Street area last night and early this morning, shattering windows and damaging ground-floor facades of several large buildings that house major financial institutions.

title: ACCOUNTING FOR PRICE VOLATILITY
description: FOR decades, economists have looked to commodity futures markets to tell them which way the overall economy was headed. They still do. But many now are questioning the validity of these indicators because of the increased price volatility in the markets.

title: HOW KOCH IS DOIN' IN EDITORIALS ACROSS THE STATE
description: With cries of derision, words of welcome and scattered suggestions to wait and see, Mayor Koch's prospective race for Governor has drawn a mixed chorus of newspaper editorial voices in across New York State in recent days.

title: LIFE AND LOVE AFTER DIVORCE
description: ''Divorce has become depressingly commonplace,'' said A. Alvarez, making depressingly commonplace gestures with his hands. ''It's the one certain experience of pain that is democratically available to everyone.''

title: BALLET: BONNEFOUS 'OVERTURES'
description: ALTHOUGH the Metropolitan Opera Ballet has a most obvious New York home at the Metropolitan Opera House, it is actually more difficult to see - as an independent company - in New York than other ballet troupes.

title: E.P.A. WANTS TO ALLOW BURIAL OF BARRELS OF LIQUID WASTES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed a reversal of rules that ban the burying of drums of hazardous liquids at landfills for waste disposal. It wants to permit such sites to fill up to 25 percent of their capacity with barrels of toxic liquids.

title: Chunk of West Side Highway Falls to the Ground at 52d St.
description: A chunk of the West Side Highway crumbled yesterday, forcing the closing of more than a mile of the roadway's northbound lanes for three hours, the police said.

title: RECITAL: MISS VON STADE
description: LISTENING to Frederica von Stade at Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon involved something of a trade-off. Her unusually flutelike mezzo-soprano lacked perhaps the breadth and resonance for the five songs she chose from Mahler's ''Des Knaben Wunderhorn,'' but Miss von Stade had much to offer in recompense - purity of tone, litheness of articulation and acute responsiveness to all the varying musical messages of her program.

title: BEAN WINS DORAL BY A SHOT WITH 69-278
description: Andy Bean won the Doral-Eastern Open today by one stroke, the last one of the tournament, a three-foot putt. Bean had dropped to a tie with Jerry Pate with bogeys on the 14th and 15th holes, but Pate gave back the lead with a bogey at 16. On the 18th green Pate had a chance for a tying birdie on a 12-foot putt, but he missed. Bean had a putt from 30 feet. He read the putt to break right, but it broke left, leaving him three feet wide.

title: Nykanen, a Finn, Wins Ski Jumping
description: Matti Nykanen of Finland became the youngest Nordic champion today by winning the 90-meter jump on the last day of the world Nordic ski championships.

title: THE WRONG LABEL FOR THE ABORTION ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIS MCDONALD
description: Willis McDonald 3d, a former senior vice president of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, died Friday of heart failure in Litchfield Park, Ariz. He was 83 years old.

title: McCall's Ad Director Takes Gannett Position
description: Joseph R. Welty, 52-year-old vice president and advertising director of McCall's magazine, is leaving to become vice presidentadvertising of USA Today, Gannett's proposed national newspaper.

title: PIANO: BELLA DAVIDOVICH PLAYS CHOPIN AND BRAHMS IN RECITAL
description: DEPENDING on how one chose to look at it, Bella Davidovich ended her Carnegie Hall piano recital yesterday afternoon with a major work by Chopin - the complete waltzes - or with 14 encores. In a sense, the Soviet emigre did both.

title: Is 'No-Lose' the Policy in Salvador?
description: In the cold coin of security, a case can be made for what the Reagan Administration seems to be doing in El Salvador.

title: Rain Postpones Carolina 500 Race
description: A steady, misty rain today forced postponement of the Carolina 500 Grand National stock car race.

title: Captain of Rockies Asks for a Trade
description: Rob Ramage, a defenseman, has resigned as captain of the struggling Colorado Rockies and says he wants to be traded.

title: Olson, Exhausted, Ends His Season
description: Billy Olson says his cross-country travels and pole-vaulting are over for this indoor season. ''I'm so tired I can't stand up,'' he said Saturday night after establishing a world indoor best by clearing 18 feet 10 inches in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics championships here.

title: No Headline
description: Bird Shaken Up, but Helps Beat Bucks

title: Cox Captures Golf
description: Kurt Cox won the $130,000 Cathay Pacific Hong Kong Open golf tournament in a three-way sudden-death playoff today.

title: Quake Reported in Greece
description: A moderate earthquake shook an area near the Albanian-Greek border this afternoon but no damage was reported, according to the Yugoslav press agency. The agency said the earthquake measured between 4 and 5 on the Richter scale and occurred about 2 P.M. local time.

title: Going Out Guide
description: CHAPEL TIME

title: BRUNSWICK'S BAILOUT PLANS
description: THE golden parachutes that the Brunswick Corporation has woven for its top people in the fight to avoid a Whittaker Corporation takeover are widely regarded as uncommonly generous.

title: Former Astronaut to Head N.A.A.C.P. Campaign; N.A.A.C.P. Selects
description: The commander of the Gemini 4 and Apollo 9 space missions, James A. McDivitt, will head the 1982 campaign by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to raise $2.5 million from 1,300 corporations. Mr. McDivitt, a retired Air Force general, is now with Rockwell International in Pittsburgh as senior vice president of strategic planning.

title: Unions at Daily News Urged to Forgo Raises
description: Theodore W. Kheel, an adviser to New York's newspaper unions, will urge the 3,800 employees of The Daily News today to have a 10 percent wage increase due March 31 placed in escrow for possible use in an employee stock purchase plan to help save the financially ailing paper.

title: The U.N. Today; March 1, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 3 P.M.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOLS SHOW BIG DROP IN MINORITIES
description: Black and Hispanic enrollment in medical schools in New York State has fallen by more than a third in the last five years, reversing gains made since 1960, according to a report to Governor Carey.

title: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: If a ball is in the strike zone as it first crosses home plate, but then drops below the zone at the last point of home plate, is it a ball or a strike?

title: 4th Ocean Title For Conner Likely
description: Dennis Conner, with a victory in the Nassau Cup race, appears to have won a record fourth Southern Ocean Racing Conference title.

title: Cablevision President Sees Growing Market
description: John Tatta, 60, who has spent more than 20 years working in cable television, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, L.I., one of the larger entities in the business. He succeeds Charles F. Dolan, 55, who founded the company in 1973 and is its 100 percent owner. Mr. Dolan, still very active in the business, now steps into the vacant positon of chairman.

title: PACERS 112, PISTONS 101
description: INDIANAPOLIS (UPI) - Indiana won its fourth straight game, as Johnny Davis led the way with 25 points, including 14 in the final period. The Pacers took the lead for good at 46-44 on a jumper by Billy Knight with 8:34 left in the second quarter.

title: MUSIC: EAST MEETS WEST
description: ENCOUNTERS between 20th-century Western composers and the Orient have not been merely flirtatious. In fact, from Debussy and Stravinsky through Satie and Cage, the influence of the Orient is intimately connected with European musical modernism.

title: Bonn Leader Affirms Backing for Pipeline
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt today reiterated West Germany's commitment to the project for a natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: Japanese Wins
description: Ayako Okamoto sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff with Sally Little to win the $125,000 Arizona Copper Classic today.

title: Sandra D. Sanderson is Married to Bruce T. Swan
description: The marriage of Sandra Denise Sanderson, administrator of the New York Choral Society, to Bruce Thomas Swan, vice president and director of Starbuck, Tisdale & Williams, investment counselors in Santa Barbara, Calif., took place in New York City yesterday. The Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr., assisted by the Rev. Susan Schaeffer, performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity.

title: Ack's Secret Wins Santa Margarita
description: Ack's Secret scored a 2 1/2-length victory over Track Robbery today in the $250,000 Santa Margarita Handicap, the 45th running of the race that determines the champion filly or mare of the Santa Anita meeting. The favored Jameela was fourth after falling behind early.

title: TENNIS PRO FAMILIES HIT TOURNAMENT TRAIL
description: It is traditional in most big-time sports for the wives to stay at home while their husbands go on the road with the team. But in tennis, the only sport where love is an official part of the game, more and more wives and children are tagging along to the tournaments.

title: ISRAELIS SAY MUBARAK IS NOT WELCOME UNLESS HE WILL VISIT JERUSALEM
description: Israel's Cabinet announced today that Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, would not be invited to visit Israel if he refused to include Jerusalem in his itinerary.

title: TRUDEAU PREACHES HIS OWN 'NEW FEDERALISM'
description: Canada also has a new federalism, according to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, and it has generated as big a furor as President Reagan's brand.

title: Lakers 103, Cavaliers 101
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Kareem Abdul-Jabbar hit a 15-foot skyhook from the right baseline with two seconds remaining, giving Los Angeles its seventh victory in a row. The Lakers overcame a 19-point deficit late in the second quarter.

title: Law vs. Order for the Police
description: What are the police supposed to do? The answer seems obvious: enforce the law. But that's not the only or even the best answer. The police are also supposed to preserve order. The two functions are not the same, and focusing on law at the expense of order may be a serious mistake.

title: FOR PARA-SKIERS, SKY IS THE LIMIT
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. MOMENTS after Kay Griep jumped from an airplane high above Butternut Basin here in the Berkshires Saturday, a small rectangular patch of nylon attached to her parachute failed to slide in place, causing her main chute to fail.

title: Military Analysis
description: Gen. David C. Jones's proposals for restructuring the Joint Chiefs of Staff have provoked an expanding debate on United States military leadership. Some military and civilian authorities would go beyond General Jones's proposals and establish a general staff. Others believe that the general has gone about as far as he can, given the national political atmosphere. The most significant point is probably that without exception those involved in the debate believe that the present system must be changed. General Jones, who is to retire as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in June, has illuminated a serious issue that has been ignored by the Pentagon for a decade.

title: Daniel Maggin Is Dead at 83; Ex-Chairman of Diebold Inc.
description: Daniel Maggin, retired chairman of Diebold Inc., makers of bank vaults and office equipment, died Friday of a heart attack at his apartment in the Carlyle Hotel. He was 83 years old.

title: A BELGIAN FINANCIER EXPANDS
description: Somehow, Albert Frere does not really fit into the silver-plated, slightly tarnished world of Belgian banking or of one of its noble figures - Baron Lambert.

title: Olympian Teaches Yanks How to Run
description: Like thousands of other people, Harrison Dillard is in Florida on vacation this week. Except his is a paid vacation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The recovery is in the numbers. Auto sales are so low that you are bound to have some snap-back just from replacement demand.

title: Gymnastics' Toy Tiger
description: WHEN he was small, Bart Conner was always doing handstands or cartwheels around the house. And as a fourth-grader in Morton Grove, Ill., near Chicago, he discovered tumbling mats. One day his gym teacher, Les Lange, took him to nearby Niles West High School where he gaped at the gymastics equipment.

title: POLISH LEADER IS DUE IN MOSCOW TODAY FOR TALKS
description: The arrival here Monday of a delegation headed by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski will provide the Polish leader and his Soviet hosts with their first face-to-face discussions since martial law was declared in Poland Dec. 13.

title: CROCUSES AND CROWDS BLOSSOM IN RIVERDALE
description: There was still melting snow in the deep shadows and spring was weeks away, but the staff at Wave Hill in the Bronx got a taste yesterday of busy weekends to come.

title: UNCLE SAM MEET AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: The Federal Government has committed itself to a big dose of the same affirmative action medicine it has been prescribing for the private sector. And, like some private employers, it seems to be having trouble swallowing the remedy.

title: OH, YE GATES
description: With the 10th anniversary of the Watergate break-in rushing toward us (have you reserved your suite in that Howard Johnson's for the big celebration?)the time is ripe for a review of the state of political scandalmongering. In ascending importance:

title: For Love of Broadway
description: ''It all started out so innocently,'' Ellen Moscou said with some astonishment yesterday. She was explaining how she - in association with a top dog - had brought Broadway professionals into the lives and career planning of students at Northport (L.I.) High School.

title: FORD WORKERS ACCEPT CONCESSIONS IN NEW CONTRACT BY WIDE MARGIN
description: Union workers at the Ford Motor Company overwhelmingly approved a new labor contract today that for the first time in the history of the automobile industry traded wage and benefit concessions for assurances of increased job security.

title: TV: DRAMA OF DIVORCE LAWYERS
description: ''DIVORCE WARS,'' a movie on ABC-TV at 9 o'clock this evening, is not so much a cautionary tale about divorce as a warning about overcompetitive divorce lawyers. In the desire to win their cases, we are told, these lawyers transform even ''friendly'' divorces into embittered brawls.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Friday incorrectly described the relationship of Unimation Inc. to the Condec Corporation. A November public offering of Unimation stock left Condec with an 80 percent stake in the robot-producing company.

title: HUSSEIN SAYS HE WILL SOON ASK U.S. FOR ARMS
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that Amman would soon ask to buy advanced weapons from the United States, and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger commented that the Reagan Administration was considering the request.

title: POLITICAL ACTION GROUP FOCUSES ON THE ELDERLY
description: In offices all over the capital on any given morning, scores of bright young men and women are trying to breathe life into newborn political movements. Most of them will fail, but a few of their offspring may survive to wield real influence, perhaps even to help shape a national election.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary Feb. 15 of Mark Ferree, an executive of the Scripps-Howard newspaper chain, misstated the chain's relationship to the E.W. Scripps Company. E.W. Scripps is the parent company of Scripps-Howard.

title: BREAST CANCER AND SEXUALITY
description: W HEN a victim of breast cancer recovers from a mastectomy, said Regina Kriss, ''the message she gets from family and society is: aren't you lucky you're alive!''

title: TRANSIT TAX BREAK IMPERILED
description: With Republican and Democratic tax writers driving to repeal the leasing provisions of the 1981 tax cut act, New York and other cities could lose a tax subsidy for mass-transit rolling stock that was enacted with almost no debate.

title: 'BUY ME,' 230 LEGGY BABIES BECKON
description: Time was, the old-timers here remember, when you could watch a 2-year-old breeze on Sunday, buy him at the Hialeah Open Sales on Monday and watch him carry your colors to victory in a three-furlong baby race on Tuesday. That was before the thoroughbred industry came to the consensus that racing horses a month or two after they reached the age of 2 was unkind to their developing bone structure. Most 2-year-old racing now commences later in the spring, but at Hialeah you can still watch one on Sunday, buy him on Monday and - with a little luck -get your investment back by the Fourth of July.

title: IF YOU DON'T BELIEVE IN FISH POWER, THIS MAY SEEM AN IMPROBABLE TALE
description: There are some practiced piscators who believe that certain wily fish can laugh, that they make a thin, silvery, tinkling sound. This story accepts that premise.

title: WHY LEAD SHOULD NOT BE ADDED TO GASOLINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Vanity Fair Ad Discount
description: Joseph E. Corr Jr., publisher of Vanity Fair, which Conde Nast plans to revive next year, has devised an interesting discount inducement for a certain class of advertiser.

title: Peat Moss Winner by a Neck
description: Peat Moss, who came within a head of upsetting the champion John Henry in the Jockey Club Gold Cup last year, took the first step toward a rematch by rallying to win yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: SUPPORT GROWS FOR ALTERNATIVES TO REAGAN BUDGET
description: Congress is rallying behind two alternatives to President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1983 that have been proposed by the chairman and the ranking minority member of the Senate Budget Committee.

title: RATE DROP THIS SPRING SEEN
description: Interest rates should decline this spring, many analysts say, but they readily add that the trend to lower rates may not extend into the second half of the year when the economy's recovery is expected to increase credit demand from business and consumers.

title: No Headline
description: LENDL TOPS GERULAITIS IN FINAL; MISS JAEGER BEATS MRS. LLOYD

title: U.S. SAYS IT HAS BROKEN AN I.R.A. RING THAT CROSSED FROM CANADA TO BUY WEAPONS
description: Federal immigration officials say they have broken an international munitions conduit of the Irish Republican Army that had been sneaking its members into the United States to buy arms for shipment to Dublin and Belfast for as long as eight years.

title: Pentagon's V.I.P. Costs Rise Sharply in 4 Years
description: The Pentagon's expenditures for entertaining foreign military visitors has quadrupled over four years, a news magazine reported today.

title: SCHMIDT'S BID FOR PABST MARKS LATEST TOUGH FIGHT FOR BREWER
description: William H. Pflaumer, who began helping his father deliver beer to local taprooms when he was 13, has since risen from a tough-talking beer distributor in Philadelphia's rowhouse neighborhoods to a powerful figure in Pennsylvania's beer industry.

title: Sports World Specials; A Dynasty in Brooklyn
description: ''We're a dynasty along the lines of U.C.L.A. or the Boston Celtics,'' said Jay Heller last week, perhaps a bit carried away by Brooklyn Tech's recent runaway victory in the Public Schools Athletic League girls indoor track and field championships at Manhattan College.

title: Article 255619 -- No Title
description: Refunds totaling more than $87.5 million are being made to users of natural gas in New York State as a result of a United States Supreme Court decision last year that invalidated a tax imposed by Louisiana, the source of half of New York's natural gas.

title: MINORITY PARENTS FIGHT MARYLAND SCHOOL PANEL
description: Here in Montgomery County, Washington's most affluent and genteelly liberal suburb, the county school board's decision to close six public schools is being challenged before the State Board of Education amid bitter charges of ''resegregation.'' Whether the state board decides to support or overrule the county board's conservative majority, the issue is considered likely to wind up in the courts, an echo of the nation's major segregation cases of the past.

title: Iranian Clergyman Is Slain
description: A clergyman who was a member of the revolutionary police was assassinated overnight and four leftist guerrillas were killed in gun battles with the police in Teheran, according to Iranian news reports today.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN MYTHS
description: The regime of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, has much in common with that of Prime Minister Pieter W. Botha of South Africa.

title: Zimbabwe Premier Says Nkomo Must Stand Trial
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe was quoted today as saying that Joshua Nkomo, whom Mr. Mugabe ousted from the Cabinet after charging him with plotting against the Government, must stand trial for his acts.

title: FOUR STAFF MEMBERS OF THE TIMES TO GET GEORGE AWARDS
description: Long Island University yesterday announced the winners of the 34th annual George Polk Awards in Journalism. The Polk prize for foreign reporting went to John Darnton of The New York Times ''for reporting the complex story of the Polish crisis with discernment and clarity.''

title: FLETCHER IS WINNER, KEEPING RING TITLE
description: This time they fought on the outside. Twice before, in 1979, Frank (The Animal) Fletcher and Tony Braxton met in Rahway State Prison, where Braxton was serving time. The first bout ended in a six-round draw and Braxton won the second on a sixround decision.

title: Louisville 80, Marquette 68
description: Derek Smith scored 20 points as Louisville won its sixth straight game and finished its regular season 18-8. The Warriors, who have two games remaining, fell to 20-8.

title: Washington Watch; Austerity And the Fed
description: WASHINGTON WHILE Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, has been lecturing Congress on the need for far greater austerity by the Federal Government, Congressional watchdogs have ferreted out records of the central bank itself to find that it may not be practicing exactly what it preaches.

title: Getting Started
description: Beginners have to tackle two relatively expensive sports to become a proficient para-skier. No one with less than 100 jumps was allowed to enter the national championship.

title: Knicks Lose, 113-110, After Leading Bullets by 5 in Overtime
description: Maurice Lucas, an orange towel wrapped around his head, sat in the Knicks' dressing room at Capital Centre today, contemplating the consequences of what he considered a crucial missed opportunity.

title: DUARTE SAYS PRESS AND POLITICIANS HAVE EXAGGERATED THE LATIN CRISIS
description: The President of El Salvador's junta, Jose Napoleon Duarte, said Saturday that the crisis in Central America was being blown out of proportion by the international press and by some United States politicians.

title: Research on Customers Studied at Lady Arrow
description: Thomas L. Hall, 33, has been named president of Lady Arrow, a unit of Cluett, Peabody & Company in New York that makes women's blouses and shirts. He succeeds Herbert H. Weissman, who died last month at the age of 52.

title: Ridership on Amtrak Drops From 1980 to '81
description: There were fewer riders on Amtrak trains in the fiscal year 1981 than in 1980, but 10 percent more of them were getting where they were going on time, Amtrak says.

title: Karen Marie McArn Bride Of Armand Assante, Actor
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan yesterday, Karen Marie McArn was married to Armand Assante, a stage and screen actor.

title: 2-Rm Apt Abv NJ Pzaria
description: MANY New Yorkers are angry with Gulf and Western Industries for threatening to move the Rangers and Knicks out of the city. But a few season-ticket holders are so concerned about the corporation's money problems that they have chipped in to hire a major relocation firm to advise about the move. This is a top-secret report that may eventually be forwarded to Gulf and Western's chairman, Charles G. Bluhdorn.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * All-Steel Inc., Aurora, Ill., has appointed Thomas M. Trybus vice president of marketing.

title: KEEP BANKS AFFORDABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: POPE DENOUNCES 'FRATRICIDAL WAR' IN EL SALVADOR
description: Pope John Paul II today condemned El Salvador's ''fratricidal war that shows no signs of abating'' and expressed hope that its people might be allowed to resolve their problems without foreign interference.

title: Jets 5, Blues 2
description: Two goals and an assist by the right wing Willy Lindstrom paced Winnipeg and moved the team within 2 points of St. Louis for second place in the Norris Division.

title: U.S. Seeking to Restore Aid to 3 Latin Nations
description: The Reagan Administration has formally asked Congress to approve an $8.7 billion military and security aid program for fiscal 1983, including $166 million for El Salvador. The appropriation would provide the first money for Argentina, Chile and Guatemala since aid to those countries was halted in 1977 because of human rights violations.

title: STUDY FINDS SERVICES IN CITY HAVE WORSENED SINCE 1978
description: The most critical services in New York City - mass transportation, law enforcement and firefighting - all deteriorated in the last four fiscal years, according to a study released yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.

title: ARCADIUS KAHAN, A PROFESSOR OF ECONOMICS AT CHICAGO U.
description: Arcadius Kahan, professor of economics and history at the University of Chicago, and an expert on Soviet bloc agricultureal economics, dies Friday of a heart attack at his Chicago home. He was 62 years old.

title: Advertising; New Bowl Cleaners On the Way
description: PROCTER & Gamble, the packaged goods master of marketing, is in test market with a toilet bowl cleaner called Brigade. It has told retailers, according to trade sources, that the $200 million market for the category could expand dramatically because so many households have yet to try such a product. And getting new product users is an area where P.& G. has excelled.

title: FOSTER GETS START ON EARNING SALARY
description: The Mets' most promising season in more than a decade began today when George Foster, carrying a weighted aluminum bat, walked into the clubhouse at the Payson Complex here followed by a jostling parade of camera crews.

title: BIG-BAND LEADER OF THE 40's
description: Charlie Spivak, who won fame as an orchestra leader during the big-band era of the early 1940's even though he was unable to develop his own potential as a trumpet player, died today. He was 77 years old.

title: The U.N. Today; March 2, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc intergovernmental working group on the financing system for sci- ence and technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PRIEST AND 3 CHARGED WITH SMUGGLING ART INTO U.S.
description: Four men, including a priest identified as a staff member of the Vatican's Observer at the United Nations, were charged yesterday with smuggling stolen Italian paintings into the United States. All four men were arrested in Manhattan yesterday afternoon and were released last night on personal bail bonds ranging from $25,000 to $35,000. They were charged in an arrest complaint filed in Federal District Court by an agent of the United States Customs Service.

title: Dr. Y.R. Chao, Expert On Oriental Languages
description: Dr. Yuen Ren Chao, a linguist who was an expert on Chinese and other Oriental languages, died last Wednesday while visiting relatives in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89 years old.

title: BROCK WARNS JAPAN ON TRADE
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said today that Japan had moved ''at best only 15 to 20 percent of the way'' to meet demands for greater access to its markets, and warned that without further action ''within three or four months'' world trading relations may take a ''serious backward step.''

title: SALVADORAN REBELS' AIM IS TO 'DEFEAT' ELECTION
description: The current guerrilla offensive in El Salvador is aimed at ''defeating'' this month's elections and forcing the United States-backed junta to initiate negotiations with the opposition, according to two top rebel commanders.

title: SOME AWAKE AT 5 TO RIDE 125 MILES TO JOBS IN CITY
description: Some people, it seems, will do almost anything to continue living in the Philadelphia area. Unlike others who have fled Philadelphia, more than 260,000 people in the last decade, they are willing to face marathon commuting, and daily travel costs that are higher than some people's wages, to get to New York.

title: Early Capote for Sale
description: ''The noise became louder,'' reads the 45-year-old manuscript. ''Then I peeked around the corridor. There was my daddy putting the gifts under the Christmas tree.''

title: ANDERSON, IND., SCRAMBLES TO KEEP ITS PEOPLE GOING
description: The streets of this city are clean and, after the sun goes down, quiet. Residents are friendly, dress simply, go to work early and get home before dark.

title: UNITED CANADIAN SHARES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including equity in earnings of Canadian Indemnity Co of $5.2 million for the latest yr and $6.3 million for the previous yr

title: News Analysis
description: The bribery investigation of three leading members of the Government appears to be not only a new factor in the erosion of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's authority but a problematical element for the entire West

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: ABOUT 1,800 prescription drug products are now marketed in the United States, yet in a given year the average practicing physician orders fewer than 100 of them for his patients, and probably as few as 25, according to the American Medical Association.

title: Philip Morris Spending Plans
description: Philip Morris Inc. said it expects capital expenditures to total $3.5 billion in the five-year period between 1982 and 1986, an increase of about $200 million over the 1977 to 1981 period.

title: Teachers Strike In Englewood
description: Englewood's public school teachers, who have been without a contract for eight months, walked off the job after an all-night bargaining session failed to narrow differences over wage demands.

title: Talking Business with Loucks of Baxter Travenol Ambulatory Patient Care
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., a Deerfield, Ill., supplier of products used in intravenous feeding and therapy, in the treatment of kidney disease and in blood treatment, recently reported record operating results for 1981. It earned $150.6 million, up 18 percent from 1980, on sales of $1.5 billion. Earnings per share, up for the 27th consecutive year, were $2.15, after a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: DEPENDABLE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 TV CREW MEMBERS INJURED IN EL SALVADOR
description: Three members of an NBC camera crew suffered minor injuries today in southeastern El Salvador, apparently in an ambush.

title: PAPANDREOU SEEKS INTERNATIONAL CYPRUS TALKS
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece said here today that he had agreed with the Greek Cypriot leadership that an international conference should be called on the deadlocked problems of Cyprus.

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 2, 1982; The Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell 0.6 percent in January, the ninth consecutive decline. The December figure was revised to a 0.3 percent decline; it had been reported earlier as a rise of 0.6 percent, and the first sign that the recession was ending. The January decline would have been steeper had officials not omitted one of the 10 components, the average manufacturing work week. They said this figure had been distorted by cold weather. (Page D1.)

title: LOGISTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IONA DEFEATS ARMY
description: Steve Burtt had 27 points tonight as Iona scored a 69-53 victory over Army in the opening round of the Metro Atlantic Conference playoffs.

title: ROCKAWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect credits equal to 10 cents a shr for the qr and 14 cents a shr for the yr for the adoption of new accounting rules regarding foreign currency translations

title: CONCERT: OPERATIC DUETS
description: THE house lights were up and the television cameras on at the Metropolitan Opera Sunday night. ''In Concert at the Met'' was being taped for broadcast over the Public Broadcasting Service, and the star attractions were Tatiana Troyanos, mezzo-soprano, Placido Domingo, tenor, and the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra conducted by James Levine.

title: VW America Sales PLunge
description: Sales of Volkswagen of America Inc. from Jan. 1 to Feb. 10 plunged by 54.5 percent, to 8,414 units, from 18,483 in the comparable period in 1981, a spokesman for the parent company, Volkswagenwerk A.G., said today.

title: UNITED CITIES GAS CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $830,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting adjustment

title: DESPITE FRAUD CONVICTION, MARGIOTTA REMAIMS A POLITICAL POWER
description: Despite his conviction in December on Federal mail fraud and extortion charges, Joseph M. Margiotta remains one of the most powerful political leaders in New York State, according to Republican and Democratic officials.

title: RATE OF VACANCY FOR RENTALS FELL 30% IN 3 YEARS
description: City officials yesterday released a report on the 1981 rental housing market showing that only 42,000 of New York City's 1.9 million apartments were vacant and available. The citywide vacancy rate, according to the report, dropped sharply in a three-year period, to 2.13 percent from 2.95 percent in 1978.

title: THEATER: 'FIFTH HORSE,' BY RIBMAN, AT HARVARD
description: When people draw up lists of talented contemporary American playwrights, they tend to forget about Ronald Ribman. In part, it's because Mr. Ribman is not tremendously prolific - he hasn't been heard from in New York since ''Cold Storage,'' five years ago - and in part because there's no such thing as an easily categorizable ''Ribman play.'' This writer's work ranges far afield, from medieval England (''The Ceremony of Innocence'') to present-day California prisons (''The Poison Tree''), rarely settling down in familiar terrain. He has yet to write a major play about average, middle-class Americans who live their lives in living rooms.

title: Pact Renewal For Valenzuela
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers announced tonight that they had unilaterally renewed the contract of Fernando Valenzuela for 1982 after failing to reach a salary agreement with representatives of the 21-year-old pitching star.

title: NL Gives President Added Post of Chief
description: Theodore C. Rogers, the 47-year-old president of NL Industries, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective May 1. He will succeed Ray C. Adam, 62, who will continue as chairman.

title: CANCER EXPERTS LEAN TOWARD VIGILANCE, BUT LESS ALARM, ON ENVIRONMENT
description: AFEW years ago, scientific concern over cancer-causing substances in the workplace and the general environment was running especially high. Experts from three Government health agencies estimated for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration that poisons in the workplace might play a role in 20 percent to 38 percent of all future cancer deaths in the United States, an astonishing leap from previous projections. And other scientists worried that poisons escaping from smokestacks, toxic waste dumps, nuclear reactors and hazardous products would cause numerous deaths among the general public as well. Hardly a week went by without some politician or environmental speaker warning of a ''cancer epidemic'' that was either already upon us or shortly on the way.

title: E.E.C. Inquiry Into I.B.M.
description: Secret hearings last week on the European Economic Community's antitrust proceedings against the International Business Machines Corporation broke no new ground, commmunity sources said here today.

title: Rollin G. Osterweis, 74, Dies; History Professor and Author
description: Rollin G. Osterweis, professor emeritus of history and oratory at Yale University, died Sunday at Connecticut Hospice in Branford, after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: No Headline
description: A.& P. to Close 29 More Stores

title: EMPIRE AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-The company changed its yr-end from a fiscal yr ended Sept 30 to a calendar yr and, therefore, comparable yr-ago figures are not available

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Index; International
description: Tanzania, in sticking to its socialist path, stumbles A2 Papandreou urges international conference on Cyprus issue A2 Weinberger is cautious on Jordanian bid for advanced arms A3 Around the World A4 Excerpts from toasts by Brezhnev and Jaruzelski A5 Red Cross says its aides met with Walesa in private A5 Government/Politics Deep South is cool to new Reagan budget plans A10 Justice aide warns of voting rights measure A11 Transportation chief backs new revenue sources for transit A12 Supreme Court Roundup A15 President reorganizes his Office of Policy Development A17 Koch in Albany to Mend Fences With Upstate Democrats B3 Senator says Reagan's outlook hurts Republican Party D22 Washington Talk Briefing A14 The Presidency: Assessing jokes about Reagan A14 National Zoo houses an endangered species A14 Required Reading A14 General Around the Nation A10 Contradictory testimony emerges on Air Florida crash A10 New York students win top prizes in national science contest B1 City is assailed on hiring of special-education teachers B2 Metropolitan Museum to mount Israeli exhibit B3 Wall Street explosions said to mark resurgence of F.A.L.N. title: 'REAGAN JOKES' STIR AIDES' CONCERN
description: The boom in Reagan jokes is making itself felt both inside and outside the White House these days. Inside, Presidential advisers are chuckling about the new comedy record that depicts Mr. Reagan as an amiable muddler who based Reaganomics on the mistaken belief that the economic pie has three halves. Even junior aides, who rarely have the temerity to criticize the President, have taken to mimicking his speech by beginning every sentence with, ''Well . . . , ' and top aides laugh uproariously at the suggestion that if the helicopter carrying the senior White House staff to Camp David crashed, Mr. Reagan would finally take charge.

title: BARYSHNIKOV EXTENDS BALLET THEATER CONTRACT
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov has renewed his contract through the 1985-86 season as artistic director of the American Ballet Theater, the company has announced.

title: Louisa Kearney Named Publisher of Harper's
description: Another chapter began for Harper's magazine yesterday when Louisa D. Kearney was named publisher of the 132-year-old monthly as part of a major reorganization. The 31-year-old Mrs. Kearney, who came to the magazine as a junior accountant 10 years ago, has been the magazine's associate publisher and director of finance since 1980.

title: Water-Main Work Still Blocks Traffic
description: Workmen replaced a broken water main in the Times Square area , but repairs to gas and telephone lines will block traffic lanes until the end of the week, according to a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: COURT GETS PRICE CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear an appeal that could produce an antitrust ruling in a case involving the Robinson-Patman Act, which prohibits sellers from charging different prices to different purchasers.

title: CITY'S STUDENTS WIN TOP 3 PRIZES IN A NATIONAL SCIENCE COMPETITION
description: New York City students won the top three prizes today in the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search, one of the most prestigious competitions in the nation for teen-age scientists.

title: HOW AND WHEN TO CUT BACK
description: ''It is really very difficult to turn a business on and off like a faucet,'' observed Richard M. Smith, vice chairman at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in Pittsburgh, which is operating at about 60 percent of capacity. ''We can't just turn the taps on our steel blast furnaces.''

title: SHOOT THE MESSENGER
description: A column I wrote three weeks ago about the disturbing echoes from Indochina that were turning up in Government pronouncements about El Salvador has inspired more of those echoes. I hope the similarities are apparent rather than real, but because the credibility and common sense that were lacking in Indochina are crucial to a sane foreign policy in Central America, the new echoes deserve an examination here.

title: Mobil's Spending
description: The Mobil Corporation said it would invest an estimated $4.9 billion in capital and exploration projects in 1982, up 11 percent from 1981. Mobil said that about $3.9 billion of the 1982 total would be allocated for energy operations. It said domestic energy projects would account for about half of worldwide energy spending.

title: President Says No
description: A system under which those who contributed at least $550 to a booster club had the first selection of season tickets to Boise State's home football games has been voided by the university's president, John Keiser, and the Athletic Director Mike Mullally, who announced the plan last week, has resigned.

title: COLGATE MEET EMERGES AS SHOWCASE FOR FEMALE TRACK STARS
description: When the Colgate Women's Games began in 1975, the finals attracted only a few hundred relatives and schoolmates of the competitors, even though tickets were free.

title: CONDEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After a nonrecurring charge of $3 million for the qr and 6 mos, minority interests of $227,000 for the qr and 6 mos and an extraordinary credit of $181,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $1,196,000

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split effective May 26, 1981

C-Net income...D-Including gains of $194,000 for the qr and $385,000 for the yr from operations sold, discontinued or held for sale and an extraordinary charge of $424,000 for the y
