description: B-Including tax credits of $248,300 for the qr and $291,600 for the yr...C-Net income

title: Juvenile Crime Third of six articles on the han-dling of delinquents by the schools, the courts and the po-lice, and on some new ap-; proaches to the problems.
description: Judge Aileen H. Schwartz of Family Court in Manhattan began the day with polite requests that gradually became firmer. By day's end, she was fuming. No one, it seemed, could verify the alibi of a 16-yearold charged with destroying a car who had missed a court appearance a month earlier. The youth said in his morning appearance that he had been attending a school for troubled children on the day of the previous hearing. But his lawyer knew nothing about it. The Probation Department knew nothing about it. And his mother could not be found. As the long court day drew to a close, Judge Schwartz demanded the answers by the next morning. And ''to be certain he just doesn't disappear,'' she ordered the youth held overnight.

title: TWO BRAODWAY THEATERS GIVEN A REPRIEVE BY APPEALS JUDGE
description: The effort to save two Broadway theaters from being torn down to make way for the proposed Portman Hotel saw action yesterday on different fronts.

title: W.J. MAHONEY DIES AN EX-G.O.P. CHIEF
description: Walter J. Mahoney, a former leader of the Republican majority in the New York State Senate and a retired justice of the State Supreme Court, died yesterday at the Erie County Medical Center in Buffalo after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: GARDEN IN PROFIT RIFT
description: Madison Square Garden Center, perhaps the world's most famous and busiest arena, contends in court papers that it has not made a profit any year since the present building opened in 1968.

title: NOLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income and includes various gains of $728,000 or 30 cents a shr not attributable to normal operations...C-Various gains not attributable for normal operations increased net income by $214,000 or 9 cents a shr for the latest yr and $1,154,500 or 47 cents a shr for earlier yr; a substantial yr-end LIFO adjust ment to inventory in the latest qr reduced net income by $371,0 or 15 cents a shr; Noland said that the results include those o its Noland-Tropical Supply Co subsidiary which began operations August

title: VANDERBILT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Italians Issue a Protest Over Intrusion by Sub
description: Italy protested today against the intrusion last Wednesday of a nuclear-powered submarine, presumably Soviet, into its territorial waters. The vessel escaped into the open sea after an 18-hour chase by Italian ships, planes and helicopters.

title: TV: 'INNOCENT LOVE,' STUDIES
description: HARRY (Doug McKeon) is a nice boy and Molly (Melissa Sue Anderson) a nice girl, but the problem - on television there is always a problem - is that he is five years younger than she. ''An Innocent Love,'' a very down-to-earth, engaging television movie, is about the good luck that befalls Harry when Molly decides she needs a math tutor.

title: General Tire Plant To Close
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company announced today it would close its tiremaking operation here within a year. The plant is the last major tire factory in Akron, a city once synonymous with rubber.

title: No Headline
description: HARTFORD OUSTER SOUGHT BY CO-OP ON BEEKMAN PL.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable be savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: N.F.L. Appeal Rejected
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit rejected today the National Football League's request that the new trial of an antitrust suit brought by the Oakland Raiders be moved from Los Angeles. The trial is scheduled to begin March 15.

title: PINIELLA WINS BATTLE OF SCALES, AVERTING $7,000 FINE
description: His teammates had a lot of fun joking about it today, and so did he, to a certain extent. But his weight was not really a laughing matter to Lou Piniella. When he stepped on the scale this morning, $7,000 or more was at stake. That was serious business.

title: L.M. Powell, Ex-Chief Of Dictaphone, Is Dead
description: Lloyd Maledon Powell, former chairman of the Dictaphone Corporation and an economic adviser to two United States Presidents, died Saturday. He was 81 years old.

title: GROSS TELECASTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HAMILTON INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $1,028,853 for the qr and $3,265,941 for theyr...C-Net loss...D-Including extraordinary gains of $3,519,928 for the qr and $6,397,880 for the yr

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: * Diamond Shamrock Corp. said its board had authorized the purchase of 2 million of the company's common shares.

title: Conviction of Williams Ends 23 Slaying Inquiries
description: Twenty-three of the 30 slayings or disappearances of young Atlanta blacks investigated by a special police task force have been ''cleared'' with the conviction of Wayne B. Williams in two of the cases, Public Safety Commissioner Lee P. Brown said today

title: Nuclear Panel Imposing Fines on Several Plants
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today began imposing fines of $1,000 a day against the owners of nuclear plants that failed to meet two deadlines for installing accident warning devices.

title: FIFTH SOVIET CRAFT LANDS ON VENUS AND IS FIRST TO SAMPLE PLANET'S SOIL
description: A Soviet spacecraft landed gently on Venus yesterday, transmitted the first color pictures of the surface and scooped up a soil sample for the most detailed analysis thus far of the planet's chemistry, the Soviet news agency Tass announced.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Republican Party has just about written off those women who work for wages.

title: Computer Picks Ore. State
description: Oregon State, which has won the Pacific-10 Conference championship for the third straight year, was rated No. 1 yesterday in The New York Times computer ranking of the nation's 273 major college basketball teams.

title: WHEN FEAR IS THE BURGLAR
description: With double-cylinder dead-bolt locks secured (check), magnetic window alarms on (check), passive infrared intrusion detector system activated (check), guard dog in position, basement windows nailed shut and the remote ''panic button'' in her purse, a local resident is off to pick up a quart of milk and two green peppers.

title: Bird May Miss 3 Games
description: Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics underwent minor surgery yesterday to help repair a cheekbone that was fractured by an elbow thrown by Harvey Catchings of the Milwaukee Bucks during a game Sunday. Bird is expected to miss the Celtics' three-game road trip to Texas this week although a brief announcement by the team described the surgery as ''basically cosmetic.''

title: State, on Time, Moves Its Prisoners From City
description: New York State met a deadline yesterday for moving its prisoners from the city's jails. Under an accord that expired yesterday, the state had been housing prisoners in city jails and was compensating the city for those held more than 48 hours after processing.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC. By Robert Lud- lum. 630 pages. Random House. $15.95.

title: Calcium-Loving Crabs
description: The hermit crab, naked and homeless without the shell that it had rudely been evicted from, was looking for a new abode. In front of it on the aquarium's sandy bottom were two shells, identical in size and shape. One was a natural shell, the other was made of plaster of Paris. Carefully feeling both shells with its palps and making sure they were not already inhabited, the crab made its choice by crawling into the plaster of Paris shell.

title: Republic Air Posts a Loss
description: Republic Airlines said yesterday that it had lost $7.8 million in the final quarter of 1981, compared with a profit of $111,000 in the fourth quarter in 1980. Revenues rose 16.9 percent, to $355.2 million, from $336.8 million.

title: INGLIS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TELESCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a research and development tax credit of $342,000 resulting from passage of the Economic Recovery Tax Act

title: 17 Announcers Strike WINS After Talks Stop
description: Announcers at WINS-AM walked off the job early yesterday after their contract expired and negotiations for a new agreement collapsed, spokesmen for both sides said.

title: EGYPTIAN TELLS U.S. OF RISING TENSIONS WITH THE ISRAELIS
description: Egypt expressed concern to the United States today over growing problems with Israel - in particular the Israeli threat to cancel the visit of President Hosni Mubarak if the Egyptian leader does not travel to Jerusalem.

title: NEW AID FOR SALVADOR: IS IT WISE AND WILL IT WORK?
description: The Reagan Administration, believing that the ''decisive battle for Central America'' is being fought in El Salvador, is preparing to ask Congress for about $35 million in additional military aid and about $100 million in new economic assistance.

title: Inmate Found Hanged in His Cell
description: A 31-year-old inmate at the Brooklyn House of Detention hanged himself in his cell yesterday morning within hours of a court hearing on robbery and weapons possession charges, the Department of Correction said.

title: SWORDS INTO PLOWS
description: With the Reagan Administration's a cceleration in military spending well under way, and a 35 percent i ncrease in annual military expenditures projected by fiscal year 1 984, it seems an odd time to plan for possible curtailment of m ilitary contracts and closing of military bases. Actually, such p lanning makes a great deal of sense.

title: DUCOMMUN INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,302,000 and a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $5,640,000 C-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,088,000 Shr earnings reflect a 20 percent stock divd distributed Feb 28, 1981; all results include operations of Aerochem Inc acquir on June 30, 1981 and accounted for on a pooling of interests basis; sales figures include sales from discontinued operations

title: EXCERPTS FROM TOASTS BY BREZHNEV AND VISITING POLISH LEADER IN MOSCOW
description: Following are excerpts from the toasts by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, at a dinner in honor of the Polish delegation, as translated by Tass, the Soviet press agency, from the Russian and the Polish: Brezhnev Toast

title: Economist Backs Away From Reagan Program
description: Morris Cohen, a 62-year-old economist who has vocally supported President Reagan's programs since his inauguration, has drawn the line with the President's budget proposals. And Mr. Cohen, who operates a consulting firm bearing his name in Hackensack, N.J., contends that the Reagan deficit must be quickly reduced if the projected midyear recovery is to occur.

title: ROLLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including a special gain of $3,311,000 for the qr and yr

title: Mile Races Planned
description: An international series of at least seven one-mile road races, patterned after New York's Fifth Avenue Mile, is planned for this year. Fred Lebow announced the series yesterday, saying there were preliminary commitments from racing officials in New York, San Francisco, Baltimore, Montreal, Toronto, Paris and Rome for races from September to November. Lebow is president of the New York Road Runners Club and director of its Fifth Avenue Mile.

title: PREPARE FOR THE NEXT OIL SHOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: Pabst Rejects Bid
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said its board had rejected the previously announced $131 million unsolicited acquisition proposal from C. Schmidt & Sons Inc., a Philadelphia brewer. Pabst said the board had determined the $16-a-share Schmidt proposal was financially inadequate and not in the best interest of Pabst or its shareholders.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Last Western Reporters In Uganda Are Expelled

title: PRESTON TRUCKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $490,672 for the qr and yr...C-After extraordinary charges of $222,028 for the qr and $969,034 for the yr

title: 3M to Market Olivetti Line
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company and the Olivetti Corporation announced that they had reached an agreement under which 3M would market a line of electronic typewriters made by Olivetti, a worldwide supplier of office equipment.

title: ICAHN LINK TO FIELD MAY GROW
description: The Icahn group of investors is expected to report that it has acquired an additional 100,000 shares of Marshall Field & Company common stock in an apparent move to seek control of the Chicago-based retailer, industry sources said yesterday. That would bring Icahn's holding to 22.8 percent.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc.'s outstanding senior long-term debt rating was lowered to BBB+ from A+ by Standard & Poor's. The company's commercial paper was lowered to A-2 from A-1, and cumulative convertible preferred stock was lowered from BBB+ to A.

title: Bridge: Jersey and L.I. Teams Gain In Grand National Contest
description: The top-ranked players in New Jersey and Long Island took a step forward Sunday in the long quest for Grand National Team honors. Heading the 14 teams in New Jersey that will advance from a field of 56 were Mark and Roberta Epstein of South Orange, Barbara Tepper and Lester Sokolower of Verona and Bob Sartorius of Cedar Grove.

title: PRODUCTIVITY OFF 6 1 2% IN PERIOD
description: Productivity for all private business, including farming and nonfinancial corporations, fell a revised 6.5 percent in the fourth quarter from the level a year earlier, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: PITTSBURGH-DES MOINES STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INARCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cosmos, Sting in Cup
description: The Cosmos and the Chicago Sting will represent the United States in competition with teams from Italy and Uruguay in the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup series in May, officials said yesterday. The two foreign clubs are F.C. Napoli of the Italian First Division and Nacional.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Owners Protest Pay Disclosure
description: The National Football League Management Council filed a grievance with the Players Association yesterday over the union's having made public last week the salaries it said were paid by the teams.

title: STANLEY HOME PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect the adoption of an accounting change for foreign currency translations

title: Four Children Die In Farmhouse Fire
description: Four children died when flames broke out on the first floor of a two-story farmhouse near this Madison County village, state troopers said.

title: The Unpopular Case for Tax Leasing
description: All Companies Should Share in Subsidies

title: 2 Oil Concerns Join Price Cut
description: Two major American oil companies yesterday cut the price they pay for crude oil in the United States by $1 a barrel, accelerating a downward trend that reflects an oversupply of oil on world markets.

title: 'Sholom Aleichem,' Starring Gilford, Closes
description: ''The World of Sholom Aleichem,'' the revival of the play by Arnold Perl that starred Jack Gilford, closed after Sunday evening's performance in the Rialto Theater.

title: SIGNODE AGREES TO SELL ITSELF TO GROUP OF PRIVATE INVESTORS
description: The Signode Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell all of its 8.1 million shares of common stock outstanding to a private group of investors for $53 a share, or a total of $429 million.

title: Strangling a Voice for Civil Rights
description: The Civil Rights Commission was created in 1957 as an advisory, fact-finding agency to observe and study the treatment of minorities and recommend improvements to the President and Congress. The commission performed that role superbly in its early years. More recently, it has lost much of its function as Government itself gained the power to enforce new anti-discrimination laws.

title: Haydn Birthday Recital
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will play Haydn's ''Birthday'' Divertimento in Alice Tully Hall on March 12 at 8 P.M. and on March 14 at 5 P.M. Haydn was born 250 years ago this month. There will also be music by Mozart, Janacek and Barber.

title: Panel Accuses Union County Jail
description: The Federal District Court released a report Monday that said the overcrowding at the Union County Jail violated the constitutional rights of pretrial detainees, who are forced to sleep on mattresses on the floors of small cells.

title: CITY SPECIAL-EDUCATION HIRING TESTED
description: More than 40 employees of the state's Education Department covertly sought jobs as special-education teachers last August to test New York City's contention that it was unable to hire enough teachers to provide court-ordered programs for all handicapped yougsters.

title: BATTLE LOOMS ON DECONTROL OF CABLE TV
description: The Federal Government has already deregulated the trucking and airline industries. Now, a growing number of legislators and Administration officials say that it is cable television's turn.

title: VULNERABLE KNEES: INJURIES INCREASE, BUT DIAGNOSIS AND THERAPY IMPROVE
description: THE knee, long the ''Achilles heel'' of professional athletes, is becoming the painful focus of attention among ever-growing numbers of ordinary Americans who have taken up jogging, tennis, skiing, volleyball, basketball and other activities that pound or twist this highly vulnerable joint.

title: A CLAIMING HORSE, 13, JUST CAN'T STOP RUNNING
description: On May 19, 1973, the eighth race at Pimlico was the Preakness Stakes, and the winner was Secretariat, a 3-year-old son of Bold Ruler who went on to win the Triple Crown. The seventh race that day was an allowance contest for older horses, won by Port Conway Lane, a 4-year-old gelding by Bold Commander, another Bold Ruler son.

title: NEW WORLD COMPUTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net loss; rev for the latest second qr included $500,000 of license fee revs received by New World from Olympia Werke Ag, the company's foreign manufacturing and marketing license for the Mikro-Disc product line

IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $1.5 million

title: REUBEN FRANK NAMED PRESIDENT OF NBC NEWS
description: Reuben Frank will be named president of NBC News today, replacing William J. Small, who was forced to resign last Friday, knowledgeable sources at NBC News confirmed yesterday.

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After extraordinary tax credits of $20,000 for the qr and $120,000 for the yr

title: U.S. CITIES' LEADERS PROTEST ON DEFICIT
description: The country's municipal leaders protested President Reagan's proposed budget deficit and program cuts today, but the President and the Vice President advised them to bear the pain.

title: Seven Elected to Theater Hall of Fame
description: Seven Broadway notables have been elected to the Theater Hall of Fame, it was announced yesterday. Elected by the nation's drama critics and drama editors, the seven will be inducted into the Hall of Fame March 29 at the Uris Theater.

title: WESTCOAST PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
New Test for Fetal Safety
description: A novel technique that may enable researchers to test drugs and other substances for their potential harmful effects on human fetal tissues has been developed under grants from the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation and the National Institutes of Health.

title: Venezuela Cuts Price Of Some Oil
description: Venezuela lowered the prices of its heavier grades of crude oil by $2.50 a barrel yesterday, according to Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, putting the prices of those oils at $18.90 to $26.50 a barrel.

title: MINI-COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: Results for the latest yr reflect a foreign currency translatio loss of $400,000

title: SANDINISTS' 'FOREIGN DEVIL'
description: The tragedy of the Nicaraguan revolution is that the Sandinists have come to power with a set of attitudes, shaped both by Nicaraguan history and Latin American leftist myths, that are alienating Nicaragua from the United States and driving it down the Cuban path.

title: China Mill Pact Revised
description: A West German-led consortium signed an amended agreement today to supply China with a $460 million steel mill once threatened by Chinese economic cutbacks.

title: Cunniff Gets More Clout
description: Larry Pleau, the Hartford Whalers' coach and general manager, yesterday named John Cunniff coach on a temporary basis because of Pleau's continued illness with a rare blood disorder.

title: DEBT TALKS THIS WEEK
description: Richard B. Black, chairman of AM International Inc. since last February, resigned over the weekend, the office equipment company said today. Analysts termed his departure another setback for the debt-ridden company.

title: Chess: Hippopotamus Skewered In a Netherlands Victory
description: John Nunn, a British grandmaster, and Yuri Balashov, a Soviet grandmaster, tied for first place in the 44th Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk aan Zee, the Netherlands, each scoring 8 1/2-4 1/2.

title: SHOREWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEW CONSTRUCTION OFF 1.5% IN JANUARY
description: New construction by American builders declined 1.5 percent in January from December's already low level, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Q&A
description: Q Why does water become lighter when it freezes? Are there other substances with the same property?

title: DYLAN THOMAS IS HONORED BY BRITAIN
description: Twenty nine years after his death, Dylan Thomas, the fiery Welshman who wrote of the need to ''rage against the dying of the light,'' has been commemorated by a plaque, unveiled today, in one of Westminster Abbey's most tranquil nooks, Poets' Corner.

title: New Building Contracts Up
description: Contracting for new construction increased by 4 percent in January, but the rise was heavily influenced by the inclusion of a $1.6 billion segment of the Alcan gas pipeline, according to figures released yesterday by the F.W. Dodge Division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company.

title: REAGAN REJECTS ADVICE TO ALTER BUDGET PROPOSAL
description: President Reagan today renewed his commitment to his own basic economic recovery program despite more advice to the contrary from Congressional allies and even one of his own economic consultants.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Italian Police Uncover Red Brigades Prison Plot
description: The police uncovered a prison-break conspiracy by a branch of the Red Brigades terrorists who assisted in the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, the chief state prosecutor announced today.

title: STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings have been retroactively adjusted for a 50 percent stock distribution paid on Dec 1, 1981

title: A.M.C. Said to Ask Supplier Price Cut
description: The American Motors Corporation has joined the other American auto makers in asking suppliers to reduce prices by 2 percent, according to industry sources.

title: AWACS ACCORD IS DENIED BY SAUDI
description: Saudi Arabia denied today that it had signed an agreement with the United States on conditions governing the use of the five United States Awacs surveillance aircraft to be delivered to the Saudis in 1985.

description: The LTV Corporation, the steel, food and aerospace conglomerate, announced that its Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation subsidiary will close a coke oven battery and lay off 225 workers at its Indiana Harbor works in East Chicago, Ind., within the next few weeks.

title: Business School Dean Appointed by Columbia
description: John C. Burton, 49, a former Deputy Mayor of New York City and chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been appointed dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business in New York, effective July 1. He succeeds Boris Yavitz, 58, who has been dean since 1975 and who will become the Paul Garrett Professor of Public Policy and Business Responsibility.

title: ENERGY RESERVES GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $2,222,000 from the sale of assets C-Net income including a gain of $762,000 from the sale of assets

title: E.E.C. Prices Up 12.5%
description: Consumer prices in the European Economic Community rose 12.5 percent in the year ending Jan. 31, the community announced today.

description: B-After a special loss of $15.2 million

title: THE DINNER FOR KEN BOYER
description: PHOENIX WHEN the Oakland A's were in Texas late last season, two of the Boyer brothers, Clete and Ken, had a few laughs together. Ken was there scouting the A's for the St. Louis Cardinals, and Clete was there as an A's coach.

title: REAGAN REORGANIZES POLICY OFFICE, GIVING AIDES NEW POSITION
description: President Reagan today announced the reorganization of the Office of Policy Development in a move that his aides said was intended to correct faults in the domestic policy operation at the White House.

title: DEATH ON MOUNT WASHINGTON: PRICE OF A RESCUE IS DEBATED
description: Farther down the mountain, in the dense woods of birch and spruce and fir, there are fox, deer, bobcat and bear. But in the winter, only one animal climbs this high to brave the bitter cold and howling winds that make Mount Washington as alien and dangerous as another world. That animal is man.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Michael Spinks will defend the World Boxing Association's lightheavyweight title against Murray Sutherland on April 11 at the Playboy Club in Atlantic City. ... Tracy Austin has withdrawn from a $150,000 Avon tournament in Los Angeles, saying she was scalded by boiling water in an accident at a restaurant last Saturday night. Miss Austin, who was top-seeded, was reported to have suffered first-and second-degree burns.

title: MOVE JUICE, NOT COAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Eskimos Allowed to Kill 19 Bowhead Whales
description: Eskimo whalers along Alaska's west and north coasts will be allowed to harpoon 19 endangered bowhead whales this year under an agreement between Federal officials and the Alaska Eskimo Whaling Commission.

title: Treasury Is Optimistic On Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation is bouncing back from its financial troubles with Government help and has a good chance of breaking even this year, the Treasury Department told Congress today.

GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Auto Output Sags in U.S.
description: Last month's production at the five major auto makers in the United States was the lowest for any February in 34 years with just 323,661 cars turned out, according to industry reports released today.

title: WALL STREET BOMBINGS LAID TO RESURGENCE OF F.A.L.N.
description: The police and F.B.I. officials said yesterday that the bombs that exploded in the Wall Street area late Sunday and early yesterday appparenty marked a resurgence of the F.A.L.N., the Puerto Rican terrorist group.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the latest yr shr earnings includes reduction of 46 cents a shr resulting from a nonrecurring charge in connection with the issuance of stock to a newly employed senior executive; the shr earnings for both 1980 periods includ reduction of 21 cents a shr resulting from a nonrecurring charg in connection with the issuance of stock under the company's restricted stock purchase plan

title: STATEN ISLAND WINS CITY U. TITLE AGAIN
description: The College of Staten Island won the City University of New York conference basketball championship for the second straight season with an 83-77 victory over Baruch last night.

title: NEW TAXES SOUGHT TO ASSIST TRANSIT
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to consider ways to raise new tax revenues for highways and public transit, Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said today.

title: Takeover of Cuisine
description: Charles D. Colletti, publisher of Cuisine magazine, says that although the magazine is having trouble paying its current printing bill, it expects to be acquired by the end of the week. The magazine, which began in 1968 as Betty Crocker magazine, has a circulation of 750,000. Ad revenues for the first quarter, he says, are up 43 percent.

title: CLC OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,692,000 for the qr and $1,642,000 for the yr and an extraordinary gain of $1,027,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinue operations of $528,000 for the qr and $968,000 for the yr and an extraordinary loss of $2,491,000 for the yr; yr-ago results have been reclassified to conform to current presentation

title: TEAM OF OBSERVERS FOR SALVADORAN VOTE ANNOUNCED BY U.S.
description: The State Department announced today that Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum would head an official United States delegation to observe the elections in El Salvador on March 28.

title: OHIO FERRO-ALLOYS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SERIOUS MAN, SERIOUS JOB, SERIOUS FOE
description: The strain of being up all night sifting through the debris left by four explosions in the Wall Street area left Lieut. Charles Angelo Luisi drained. His face was sallow and his voice descended to a lower and scratchier level than usual.

title: Penney Net Up 29.4% In Quarter
description: The J.C. Penney Company, the nation's third-biggest retailer, announced yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter ended Jan. 30 advanced 29.4 percent, to a record $207 million, or $2.94 a share, compared with net income of $160 million, or $2.29 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

title: MINNETONKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After a writedown of approximately $100,000 for the qr and 6 mos in the book value of the company's marketable securities and a charge of approximately $250,000 for the 6 mos for the LIFO method of inventory accounting...C-Net income including a gain of $6,819,000 or $2.84 a shr, for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of an Italian subsidiary; results for the yr-ago periods include operations of an Italian subsidiary which was divested in Nov 1980

title: CITY OFFERS TO AID THE DAILY NEWS WITH 'FINANCING TOOLS' AND LABOR
description: Deputy Mayor Karen N. Gerard has told the owners of The Daily News that New York City could provide ''tax incentives and other financing tools'' to help them or a new owner shift the paper's midtown printing operations to a new location in the city.

title: Red Cross Aides Meet With Walesa in Private
description: Delegates of the International Committee of the Red Cross were able recently to visit Lech Walesa, the interned leader of Poland's Solidarity trade union, ''under satisfactory conditions,'' the committee's president, Alexander Hay, said today.

title: Islanders Trounce Leafs, 9-5
description: In their last appearance in Canada until the playoffs, the Islanders left their mark tonight with a convincing 9-5 trouncing of the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest qr and yr contained 13 weeks and 52 weeks respectively while the yr-ago periods had 14 weeks and 53 weeks for qr and yr respectively

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AIDE WARNS SENATORS ON PASSING THE VOTING RIGHTS BILL
description: A senior official of the Justice Department warned today that enactment of voting rights legislation passed by the House of Representatives would virtually require ''proportional representation'' of blacks and other minority groups in Federal, state and local elections.

title: INVERNESS PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SULLAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $1,580,000 for the qr and $1,927,000 for the yr...C-Net income... D-After a loss of $45,000 for the qr and yr from discontinued operations

title: Raytheon Contract
description: The Raytheon Company said that it had received a $605 million contract from Saudi Arabia to continue work on the country's Hawk air-defense system. A. Newell Garden, a Raytheon spokesman, said the new contract was a continuation of a $1 billion contract for the improved air-defense system signed in 1976. He said much of the manufacturing work would be done at the company's Missile Systems division in Andover, Mass.

title: 'TO SET THE RECORD STRAIGHT' ON COUNCILMANIC REDISTRICTING
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Synopsis and Classification of Living Organisms Sybil P. Parker, editor in chief. 2,398 pages in two volumes, illustrated. McGraw-Hill Book Co., $149.50.

title: WEINBERGER CAUTIOUS ON JORDAN ARMS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger suggested today that the Administration's response to any Jordanian request for purchases of advanced weapons would depend on whether Jordan reconsidered its military supply arrangement with the Soviet Union.

title: WE NEED REALISTIC GOALS FOR EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Japanese Light Up Times Sq.
description: WHEN the Times Square building that carries the huge Budweiser sign is torn down to make way for the Portman Hotel, it will mark the end of what is believed to be the largest outdoor ad in the world (275 feet by 58 1/2 feet), and the disappearance of an advertiser that has been part of the Great White Way since before Prohibition.

title: Whittaker Profit Up
description: The Whittaker Corporation, currently engaged in a struggle to acquire the Brunswick Corporation, today reported improved fiscal first-quarter earnings. Whittaker said net income for the quarter ending Jan. 31 increased 23.8 percent, to $18.2 million, or $1.14 a share, from $14.7 million, or 95 cents a share, a year ago. The Los Angeles conglomerate said sales were up 5.9 percent, to $404.4 million, from $382 million.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PRAIRIE SKIRT SWEEPING THE FIELD
description: It began selling quietly as long ago as last summer, picking up momentum as winter vacationers put resort wardrobes together. Except for Ralph Lauren, who is widely credited with encouraging the trend with his Western-inspired collection last fall, no major designer has given it special attention.

title: TEAMSTERS RATIFY A NEW AGREEMENT WITH WAGE FREEZE
description: A new contract freezing the basic wage levels of unionized truck drivers and warehouse workers for at least two years was ratified today by members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Required Reading Democrats' Course
description: Former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida, a Democrat, speaking to the Tulsa County Democratic Executive Committee, Tulsa, Okla. Feb. 18, 1982:

title: COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALSO AN INSTRUCTOR AND CRITIC
description: Julian Levi, a painter and an instructor in painting at the Art Students League since 1945, died in St. Vincent's Hospital on Sunday after a short illness. Mr. Levi, who was 81 years old and lived at 79 West 12th Street, was also the director of the art workshop at the New School. Until his retirement in 1977, he was also associated with the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, first as a student and later as an instructor and general critic.

title: STUDENTS LOBBY IN CAPITAL AGAINST CUTS IN U.S. LOANS
description: Thousands of college students found allies in both parties as they converged on Congress today to protest sharp cuts in Federal grants and loans.

title: Saudi-Mitsubishi Deal
description: A consortium of three Mitsubishi companies has received a letter of intent from Saudi Arabia for a large thermal power plant worth about $800 million, industry sources said here today. The three companies are Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd., the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation and the Mitsubishi Corporation.

title: THE DEEP SOUTH IS COOL TO NEW REAGAN BUDGET
description: President Reagan's fiscal policies, particularly his most recent budget proposals, are receiving a cool reception in the Deep South, despite support in the region for some reorganization of the administration of many Federal programs.

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-net income...C-including income from discontinued operations of $575,209 for the qr and $1,282,322 for the yr...D-Including a gain of $2,259,740 on the sale of discontinued operations

title: Excerpts from remarks, page A5.
description: The Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, arrived here today to an effusive welcome and a strong endorsement from Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: A COMPARISON OF I.R.A. WITH SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS PLAN MAJOR CHANGES
description: Fading playoff hopes, coupled with the largest attendance loss in the National Basketball Association, have prompted the Knick management to pursue front-office changes for next season.

title: TV: SANDBURG PORTRAIT IN 2 HOUR FILM ON PBS
description: ''ECHOES AND SILENCES,'' a two-hour documentary on WNET-TV tonight at 9 o'clock, is an unabashed, not to mention largely uncritical, celebration of Carl Sandburg, who died in 1967 at the age of 89. Produced and directed by Perry Miller Adato, whose credits include television portraits of Pablo Picasso and Georgia O'Keeffe, the film is being presented as part of PBS's ''American Playhouse'' series.

title: SOUTH TEXAS DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-The company changed its yr-end from a fiscal yr ended Apr 30 to a calendar and, therefore, no comparable yr-ago results are available

title: Chapman Breaks His 26-Day Fast
description: Mark David Chapman, the convicted killer of John Lennon, voluntarily broke his 26-day fast Monday, only hours after a State Supreme Court justice had authorized the state to force-feed him if necessary.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $446,000

title: CONNELLY CONTAINERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a pretax gain of $260,400 on the sale of equipment

title: LEADING INDICATORS DOWN 0.6%
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, which is being watched for a sign that economic recovery is near, declined six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline would have been much greater if the index had not been adjusted to remove the impact of winter weather on the number of hours logged by factory workers.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: IN his recent inaugural address as the ninth president of the City College of New York, Bernard W. Harleston was upbeat, with a bite. Both attitudes are currently rare among academic leaders, who tend to be downbeat and rather toothless lest they offend potential benefactors.

title: MUSIC: DOPPMANN PLAYS RACHMANINOFF, BARTOK
description: WHAT happens to all those gifted youngsters who win piano competitions and blaze across the skies for a few seasons before our keenest instruments lose track of them? Not all of them join monastic societies and take vows of musical silence. Some, like William Doppmann, who gave his first New York recital in 10 years last night at Alice Tully Hall, continue to work at the task of becoming interesting artists. Theirs is a lifelong occupation requiring the dedication of a saint and the staying power of a racing turtle. If young musicians suspected what lay ahead for most of them, the ranks of aspiring concert artists in any year would be depleted sharply, you can bet.

title: KOCH GREETED BY BOOING AT RECEPTION IN ALBANY
description: Mayor Koch was booed when he walked into a reception of county officials tonight, and upstate legislators sported gingham ribbons to protest the Mayor's recent disparaging remarks about rural life.

title: Horn & Hardart To Close Hotel
description: The Horn & Hardart Company, a New York-based food services and catalogue merchandising concern, said it had decided to close its Royal Americana Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev. Munir Saltoun, chief financial officer, said the closing would not adversely affect the company's financial position or earnings.

title: FEDERAL PIONEER LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a special charge of $378,435...C-Including a special gain of $692,000

title: H.U.D. Drops Rate Ceiling
description: The Government is lowering its interestrate ceiling on federally backed single-family home loans to 15.5 percent from 16.5 percent, officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty, Hartford, has appointed G. Ralph Guthrie chairman and chief executive officer of its real estate development subsidiary, the Urban Investment and Development Company, Chicago.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
PEKING SETS TONE FOR IMPROVED TIES
description: China's Prime Minister has promised President Reagan that his Government is willing to try to overcome the deadlock on Taiwan that has soured Chinese-American relations.

title: U.N. Lists Names
description: The United Nations Special Committee Against Apartheid announced its 1982 list of some 350 sports figures from 30 nations who have competed in South Africa. Among the more prominent names were those of three tennis players - Vitas Gerulaitis, Eddie Dibbs and Virginia Wade.

title: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a provision of $1,060,000 for the qr and yr for the restructuring of computer services segment...C-Net income

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
450 Expected to Testify In Coast 'Strangler' Case
description: After three months of jury selection for the trial of Angelo Buono, who is accused of killing 10 women and girls in the ''hillside strangler'' case, testimony is expected from as many as 450 witnesses.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GOODY PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
LINDAL CEDAR HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Market Place; Czechoslovak Bonds' Status
description: TONS of gold were flown from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to Switzerland last weekend. The metal was destined for an account of Czechoslovakia's Government.

title: THEATER MUSEUM OPENS IN HEART OF BROADWAY
description: THE Theater Collection of the Museum of the City of New York, which has been playing Off Broadway, so to speak, in its regular home on 105th Street and Fifth Avenue for many years, is starting a satellite collection right in the heart of big-time Broadway.

title: Palme Says Talks Fail To End Iran-Iraq War
description: The United Nations special envoy, Olof Palme, said today that he had failed for the fifth time to convince Iran and Iraq to call a cease-fire and end their 17-month war. He left Teheran after two days of talks with Iranian officials.

title: APECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,254,000 for the qr and $3,653,000 for the yr and losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $6,390,000 for the qr and $6,621,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,170,000 for the qr and $2,438,000 for the yr and an extraordinary gain of $600,000 for the qr and yr on the settlement of Chapter 11 liabilities

title: REAGAN'S CONCEPT OF AMERICA HURTS PARTY, PACKWOOD SAYS
description: Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, says he is sometimes dismayed in meetings with President Reagan because the President responds to the concerns of Republican leaders ''on a totally different track.''

title: CRUMP, E H, COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CREDIT MARKETS
description: Short- and long-term rates fell yesterday as market participants raised prices, encouraged by a light supply of new issues in all sectors and by the expectation that short-term rates might fall slightly in the near future.

title: BRIEFING
description: Aquarium Casualties

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: NEW YORK (AL) - Signed John Pacella, pitcher, to one-year contract.; FOOTBALL

title: THE COMEBACK IN EUROBONDS
description: After several years of relentless competition and low profits, investment bankers who specialize in bond offerings outside the borrower's home country are once again sounding happy.

title: Argentine Bank Move
description: The central bank of Argentina said today that it had raised the minimum cash reserve requirement for Argentine banks to 16 1/2 percent from 16 percent effective immediately. The move is aimed at holding down domestic liquidity in line with the Government's program for controlling inflation, the bank said.

title: Steel Import Inquiry Set
description: The Commerce Department agreed today to investigate charges that imported steel pipes and tubes are being sold in the United States at illegally low prices.

title: HIGH COSTS LEADING PREP SCHOOLS TO GIVE MORE STUDENT LOANS
description: With the cost of tuition, room and board now as high as $8,000 a year, private secondary schools are following the lead of colleges and universities and setting up loan programs to help parents pay for their children's education.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 2, 1982
description: International

title: Trade in Services Up
description: World trade in services, a category ranging from banking to insurance and tourism, grew by 17 percent a year in the past decade, compared with an average growth of 6 percent for world trade as a whole, according to a United Nations report released today. The report said the gross value of services trade rose to $620 billion to $650 billion in 1980 from $70 billion to $90 billion in 1967, making it equivalent to about three-quarters of the value of trade in manufactured goods between industrialized and developing states.

title: Topics List, Missed; Count on Washington
description: Population affects civic pride, not to mention distribution of Federal dollars. Small wonder, then, that New York City and municipalities around the country were furious when the 1980 census showed they had lost population by the thousands.

title: TANZANIA, IN STICKING TO ITS SOCIALIST PATH, STUMBLES
description: For the third year in a row, Tanzania is importing food donated by outsiders to feed mainly those city dwellers who do not have access to their country's own produce.

title: O-T-C Link Test Delayed
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers has postponed for at least a month the scheduled start of its experimental National Market System for Over-the-Counter trading.

title: LIST, MISSED; Building Block
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development says it wants to promote housing for the elderly and handicapped, but it is pursuing an odd route to that goal. In late January it ordered regional offices to cancel subsidies for any project not begun within four weeks.

title: UNION SPECIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-After a loss of $750,000 on the sale of equity interest in a Japanese affiliate; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statemen No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: ISRAELI ARTIFACTS TO BE SHOWN AT METROPOLITAN, AFTER ALL
description: Officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art said yesterday they would go ahead with plans to mount an exhibit of artifacts from the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River similar to one originally proposed. And they pledged to keep politics out of future decisions about exhibits.

title: POLYSAR LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LUNCH WITH STRINGS

title: B C RESOURCES INVESTMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $34.6 million on the sale of the company's interest in MacMillan Bloedel Ltd

title: OVERHEAD DOOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JUSTICES CONSIDER THE 'NEW DRUG' POLICY
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether generic drugs can be marketed without the approval of the Food and Drug Administration if their active ingredients are identical to those in drugs that have already won the agency's approval.

title: WOMEN'S HOUSE WORK
description: In choosing not to seek re-election in November, S hirley Chisholm, who has served since 1968, has become the latest a mong a half-dozen important women to leave the House in the last sixy ears. For the women's movement, this pattern is disturbing.

title: Steel Output Up 2.8%
description: Steel production rose to 1.808 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, up 2.8 percent from the previous week's 1.759 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: 1,000 Afghans to Go to U.S.
description: One-thousand Afghan refugees in Pakistan will be given permission to go to the United States this year, a spokesman for the United States Consulate General said here today.

title: THOUSAND TRAILS (SEATTLE, WASH) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-Including a gain of $236,000 or 9 cents a shr on the sale of investment property

title: LIST, MISSED; D'Oyly Carte
description: There's been a mix-up. Not the misplacing of babies, which Gilbert and Sullivan always had a way of putting right, but of whole operas and troupes.

title: REPUBLIC AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NOLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $23,000 for the latest qr and $8,000 for the yr-ago qr

title: INSURANCE INDUSTRY IS EXPANDING, BUT LARGELY AWAY FROM CITY
description: New York City's insurance industry is expanding - but mostly outside of the city. High rent, often burdensome energy costs, lack of space and labor problems are the main reasons cited in a report on the insurance industry here issued by the Real Estate Board of New York.

title: S.& P. Reduces 2 Sohio Ratings
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said today that it was reducing the ratings for the senior debt and preferred stock of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) because of the company's recent acquisitions.

title: Stocks Advance Moderately
description: Stock prices advanced moderately yesterday in heavier trading despite further evidence of a weakening economy. Trading opened on schedule at both the New York and American Stock Exchanges after bomb blasts at both exchanges during the night resulted in minor damage to the buildings. A Puerto Rican nationalist group, F.A.L.N., asserted it was responsible for the explosions.

title: THE LATEST IN ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: The nation's capital now has its very own endangered species. It is not, as one might easily leap to conclude, Democrats, liberals, environmentalists or even the unneedy poor.

title: P.L.O. IS A FRIEND OF THE NEWS MEDIA
description: To the Editor:

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
NOTES ON FASHION
description: IF Ralph Lauren has his way, this fall men will be wearing the kind o f tweedy, British clothing that almost stole ''Chariots of Fire'' f rom the actors and has certainly done so with ''Brideshead R evisited.'' His new fall men's collection has, he said the other d ay, been in large part inspired by ''Chariots.'' There are hacking j ackets, which means the flapped pockets are cut on the diagonal; c hecked Norfolk jackets, which means belted; graceful d oublebreasted, six-button, peaked-lapel suits in Prince of Wales p laids. And underneath all this tweediness, patterned vests with l apels. The shirts are crisp with blue bodies and white collars. T here are even ascots, perhaps best worn while being photographed w ith golden retrievers.

title: Budweiser Light
description: Anheuser-Busch, which already has Michelob and Natural brand light beers, has introduced Budweiser Light into seven states and parts of two others, and said it would be in thirty-seven states and parts of three more by the end of the month. Most of first markets are in the South and West, but there will be some distribution in Pittsburgh and upstate New York. The ad theme is ''Bring Out Your Best,'' created by Needham, Harper & Steers, which also has the assignment to handle Busch, a regional beer brand.

title: S.I. Man Convicted In Extortion Plot
description: A Staten Island man was convicted of posing as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to extort $200,000 from John M. Crawford Jr., an art collector.

title: CONFLICT EMERGES IN AIR FLORIDA CRASH TESTIMONY
description: The National Transportation Safety Board brought forth contradictory views today on whether visible snow or ice had accumulated on an Air Florida Boeing 737 jet before it took off in a snowstorm and crashed here on Jan. 13.

title: DEPRESSION IS UNLIKELY TO VOLCKER
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today rejected the notion that the economy faced the risk of a depression, a concern that has been expressed by a few economists.

title: All Oscar Nominees Will Get a Certificate
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences next week will present for the first time a special certificate to all 141 Oscar nominees.

title: Topics; Doggedly; Drape Flap
description: Christo, the artist who wraps cliffs and curtains canyons, is talking up his Central Park plan again. The year-and-a-half-old proposal consists of stringing a 27-mile-long flapping of orange and nylon cloth on 11,000 to 15,000 steel gates.

title: ATLANTIC METROPOLITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $346,000 for the qr and $769,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $22,727,000 for the qr and 6 os on the restructuring of debt

title: CUOMO ASSAILS KOCH, SAYING HE CHANGES MIND TOO OFTEN
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo attacked Mayor Koch today, saying the Mayor ''had the ability to go back and forth on subjects and make people like it.''

title: City, Garden 'Close' on Accord
description: The city and the Madison Square Garden Corporation are ''very close'' to an agreement that would keep the Rangers and the Knicks from moving, Mayor Koch's chief negotiator in the talks between the two sides said yesterday.

title: HELP FOR MOTHERS WHO ABUSE THEIR CHILDREN
description: They seemed to have little in common, except that all three bragged a bit about their children. There was Janet, with her perfect oval face and dark brown eyes, Lucille, gangly and giggly as an adolescent, and Miranda, in a ruffled blouse and heavy shoes, the middle-aged woman already emerging around the young girl's eyes.

title: Siege Charges for Convicts
description: Four inmates of the Graterford State Prison will face charges stemming from a hostage-taking incident at the prison last fall, law-enforcement officials said Monday. They said Joseph Bowen, who is said to have led the prisoners in the five-day siege that ended Nov. 2, would be among those charged with assault, attempted escape, kidnapping and other offenses.

title: GOLD TRADERS AT WORK SHRUGS OFF BOMB BLAST
description: When a bomb exploded outside the 1 Liberty Plaza headquarters of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith last Sunday about 11:15 P.M., Larry E. McPartland, a 24-year-old gold trader, was on duty in the firm's commodity arbitrage group.

title: Careers; Guidance For Law Students
description: ADELPHI UNIVERSITY was recently host to an all-day workshop for college advisers in the metropolitan New York area on the job outlook for lawyers and on the new Law School Admission Test, which will be given for the first time on June 16.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-There are no comparable yr-ago results because the company began operations in 1981

title: WELCOME TO THE CAPITAL OF BLUEGRASS, OF COURSE
description: A few years ago, a bartender, a Library of Congress employee, a business machine company executive and a procurement manager for the Goddard Space Flight Center formed a group called Foggy Bottom, which had nothing to do with the State Department. Before that, a cartographer for National Geographic, a mathematician, a surgeon and a graphic artist came together as The Seldom Scene.

title: Deputy Minister to Miss Flamingo on Saturday
description: The trainer of Deputy Minister, last year's 2-year-old champion, told Hialeah Park officials today that the colt would not run in Saturday's Flamingo Stakes, an important test for Kentucky Derby hopefuls.

title: 1. For Smaller Feet
description: Susan Giordano wears a size 5 shoe and comes from a family whose women have small feet. When she was the manager of a shoe store, she could sympathize with customers who needed small sizes but couldn't be fitted, since most stores concentrate on the 7-to-9 range of sizes and have limited selections of smaller shoes. Miss Giordano decided to rectify the situation by opening her own shoe store and by carrying only sizes 4 to 6 1/2. The two-week-old Giordano's carries brands such as Anne Klein and Andrew Geller at prices Miss Giordano says are comparable to those at other stores: $60 to $220, with most prices in the $70-to-$90 range. There are high heels and flats and lots of sandals for spring and summer. Giordano's is at 1118 First Avenue (61st Street).

title: Hartford Savings Draws 3 Bids
description: At least three banks, including People's Savings Bank of Bridgeport - New England's largest - have submitted bids to a Federal agency to acquire the financially troubled Hartford Federal Savings and Loan Association, officials report.

title: Strangers in the Night
description: It was night, the gate was locked and there was nobody around to let them in. Just about anybody else would have gone to find someone or waited until morning, but these fellows were from the White House.

title: WORKERS MAY GET WEIRTON STEEL UNIT
description: The National Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was weighing the sale of its Weirton Steel division to Weirton employees, while at the same time ''substantially limiting'' further investment in the division.

title: Last Word in Guns for the Discriminating
description: The ultimate gift for the man who was everything - and who wants to keep that everything safe from thieves - will be offered by the Los Angeles designer for men, Bijan Pakzad, and the Colt Arms Company.

title: INFOTRON SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in Feb 1981

title: WALLACE, SAM P, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
New Incentives By Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation today extended its rebate program through March and expanded the sales incentive plan to include free scheduled maintenance on front-wheel-drive vehicles.

title: Bridge: Experts Offer a Few Tips For Intermediate Players
description: If you are an intermediate player anxious to improve, there are various ways to go about it. It might not occur to you to ask 24 of the world's best players for a piece of advice, but you can do that for a modest $9.95.

title: PEKING OFFERS FIRST DETAILS OF PROPOSED SHAKE-UP
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang today offered the first details of the cutbacks that he plans to make this year in the Chinese Government bureaucracy as part of a campaign to make it more efficient.

title: THE MAN BEHIND THE SETON HALL STAR
description: When his wife or one of his 11 sons and daughters wishes to get the attention of the patriarch, Michael Callandrillo, age 84, it is necessary to stamp on the floor.

title: BOOK-BANNING ARGUMENTS ARE HEARD
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the Constitution allows school boards to remove from school libraries books that they deem offensive.

title: Q&A
description: IN response to a reader's inquiry about something called monkey bread, I pointed out that it is the hard-shelled, fleshy fruit of an African tree known as the baobab. I added that I was not aware of an actual bread by that name. Numerous readers wrote and telephoned to point out that there is, indeed, a loaf known as monkey bread, made with yeast and filled with currants.

title: SOUTH AFRICA WOULD YIELD 'HOMELAND' TO NEIGHBOR
description: Two of the cardinal principles that govern the diplomacy of virtually all black African countries may be challenged as a result of intensive negotiations now under way between South Africa and the adjacent kingdom of Swaziland.

title: KNICKS TURN BACK CLIPPERS BY 108-101
description: Marvin Webster's statistical line for last night's game was not impressive. In 19 minutes he made one of four shots, scored 2 points, grabbed five rebounds and had one assist.

title: Helms Introduces Bill to Bar Federal Money for Abortions
description: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, has introduced another an@tiabortion bill, apparently signaling a breakdown in his attempts to resolve an impasse with Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Utah Republican, over attempts to unify foes of abortion.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MOST people have chicken pox as children. It is the one remaining common, contagious, serious childhood disease for which there is no vaccine, and it often passes from one child to another in families, play groups and preschool and elementary classrooms.

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $116,000 for the qr and $702,000for the yr...C-After income from discontinued operations of $288,000 for the qrand $846,000 for the yr; the results for both rs reflect the operations of Millipore's Worthington Diagnostic division as a discontinued operation

title: SALVADORAN SOLDIERS ABRUPTLY PULL BACK FROM BIG OFFENSIVE
description: The Salvadoran Army today abruptly ended one of its most ambitious offensives of the war, and the commander of the 2,000-man force conceded that a number of guerrilla encampments had resisted the 10-day assault.

title: Sonics Ordered to Give A Physical to Johnson
description: The National Basketball Association has ordered the Seattle SuperSonics to give a physical examination to John Johnson, a forward, and, if he is healthy, to return him to the roster or waive him.

title: NETS WIN IN DOUBLE OVERTIME
description: In a game that was marked by 38 lead changes and 28 ties, the Nets defeated the Washington Bullets, 130-124, in double overtime tonight.

title: GETTY'S MUSEUM GIFT CLEARED
description: The museum that the oil magnate J. Paul Getty built on a bluff overlooking the Pacific has officially been granted more than $1 billion that Mr. Getty left it in his will, making it the world's richest art museum.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: UNION AND MINER'S WIDOW ASSAIL SAFETY UNIT
description: The Reagan Administration's conduct of the Federal coal mine safety program came under renewed and often emotional attack before a House subcommittee today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news analysis article on Jan. 23 about the the tax-exempt status of church-related schools where theology requires racial discrimination incorrectly quoted a brief concerning Bob Jones University in Greenville, S.C. The brief said, ''An Orthodox Jewish congregation may not be required by the state to open its membership to Baptists.''

title: BRITISH CRICKETERS DEFY BAN TO PLAY IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa has scored a major victory in its effort to combat the various sanctions imposed on it because of its policy of apartheid by persuading some of England's most famous cricket players to appear in a series of matches there this winter.

title: FINE ITALIAN HAND IN STUFFED FOODS
description: THE use and preparation of stuffed foods know no national boundaries - the appeal is universal. But if I were asked to name the one country in which stuffed foods have the greatest and most imaginative uses, it probably would be Italy.

title: DEL LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results include pretax proceeds of $4.5 million from business interruption insurance, net of settlement costs and specified fire-related expenses

title: MARINE MIDLAND IN PACT TO GAIN CENTRAN STAKE
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc. has reached an agreement with the Centran Corporation of Cleveland under which Marine could eventually obtain a 37.5 percent interest in the Ohio bank holding company, the two banking concerns announced last night.

title: G.M. and Auto Union Plan Concession Talks
description: Negotiators for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers will meet in the ''next 24 to 48 hours'' to discuss reopening the concession talks that collapsed earlier this year, F. James McDonald, the company president, said today.

title: REAGAN STUMPS IN WEST AND DEFENDS HIS BUDGET
description: President Reagan, carrying his economic message to some boisterously friendly audiences in ''the great American West,'' today denounced ''so-called alternatives'' to his budget program as ''political documents designed for saving certain legislators' political hides rather than saving the economy.''

title: Negotiators Race Clock at Macy's
description: Negotiators for management and a union bargaining for 6,000 sales clerks in five Macy's department stores in the metropolitan area sought yesterday to work out terms for a new contract to avert a strike scheduled for midnight last night.

title: Stafford Knocks Out Madrid in First Round
description: Roger Stafford tuned up tonight for his title shot in May against the world welterweight champion Sugar Ray Leonard with a knockout of David Madrid, the former Mexican champion, at 2:45 of the first round.

title: Work of Chinese Artist At Abrons Arts Center
description: Brush paintings by Wang Dawen, a Chinese artist whose work on rice paper is based on classical Chinese poetry and mythology, will be on view from March 19 to April 12 at the Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center of the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street.

title: METHADONE MAINTENANCE IS A LIFESAVER
description: To the Editor:

title: BIRD WATCHERS ALIGHT IN MORNING CHILL-FOR THE LOVE OF IT
description: DAWN didn't crack one recent frigid Saturday - it peeped briefly through the clouds and went back to bed. The dozen bird watchers huddled on Long Island's easternmost tip were not so lazy. Up since 5:45 A.M., they continued to scan the frigid Atlantic from their windswept perch at the foot of the Montauk Point lighthouse.

title: BANKS PRESSING POLAND
description: Western banks with loans outstanding to Poland stepped up pressure today for that country to complete overdue interest payments. The 500 banks put off the formal signing of an agreement to reschedule Poland's debt because the Bank Handlowy, the state bank, still owes about $75 million of the $500 million that was due in 1981, West German and Swiss banking officials said today.

title: SIERRA PACIFIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CANADIAN PROVINCE IN GAS PACT
description: Canada's federal Government and Nova Scotia laid aside their differences today over who owns offshore resources and signed an agreement on management of the province's potentially large gas reserves and revenue sharing from it.

title: Broker Loan Rates Up
description: Marine Midland Bank and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company said yesterday that they were raising their broker loan rates to 15 percent from 14 1/2 percent, effective immediately.

title: Black Scholars Unveil An Urban Policy Paper
description: Representative Parren J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maryland, asserted today that the national urban policy was in disarray, and he said the condition of the cities would not be aided by President Reagan's proposed Urban Enterprise Zone program, which is designed to encourage business development of inner cities through tax incentives.

title: HIJACKER IS SUBDUED AT MIAMI
description: The hijacking of an airliner to Cuba was foiled Monday night when a passenger and crew members subdued a man armed with a bottle of liquid who was yelling, ''Cuba, Cuba, Cuba!'' officials said.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: VIRTUALLY every first-rate French chef loves the food of his childhood, which most often turns out to have been bourgeois: chicken in the pot, a simple lamb stew or meat cooked and served with dried beans or peas.

title: TIPS FOR FISH BUYERS
description: Whole fish: The surest signs of fresh fish are bright, clear eyes; gills showing red underneath; firmness; skin with luster, and no fishy odor. The eyes may not be quite as clear in winter because of the cold, but they should not be clouded over, bloodied or sunken. Freshly caught fish retain a protective mucouslike film on the skin for several hours - look for it if you ever buy fish directly from a fishing boat or at the docks.

title: VOLUNTEER CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RETAIL CHIEF NAMED AT BANK OF AMERICA
description: The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, has grouped together its worldwide retail banking and consumer-service activities under one officer, James B. Wiesler, a 54-year-old executive vice president. Mr. Wiesler will be responsible for all of the San Francisco-based bank's present and future retail functions in California, the rest of the United States and overseas.

title: Carey Approves a Bill On Sale of S.I. Ferries
description: Governor Carey signed a bill today that allows New York City to sell or transfer its interest in Staten Island ferries to private industry, which could then lease the boats back to the city while claiming the depreciation as a tax write-off.

title: FILM: REVISITING CIVIL-RIGHTS SOUTH
description: TWENTY years after the tumultuous civil-rights struggles in Birmingham and Selma, Ala., Atlanta and other parts of the South, James Baldwin, the novelist and playwright, revisted those cities as well as Washington, Jacksonville, Fla., and Newark in an attempt to get a fix on those events and on the progress made, if any, since then.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
PLACER DEVELOPMENT LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an unusual gain of $30.1 million from the sale of Noranda Mines Ltdshrs held by an affiliate...C-Including a special gain of $8.1 million on the sale of Australian cattle interest

title: Jets' Lindstrom Scores 5 Goals
description: Willy Lindstrom scored five goals and added an assist tonight to lead the Winnipeg Jets to a 7-6 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: MX'S AS DETERRENTS ARE INDEFENSIBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS INTEREST GAVITT
description: One day after a high Madison Square Garden official said that Red Holzman would not return as the Knick coach for next season, Dave Gavitt, the Providence College athletic director, said yesterday that he would be interested in the job ''under the right circumstances.''

title: MAZZILLI IS DOUBTFUL ABOUT JOB WITH METS
description: Manager George Bamberger met with Lee Mazzilli today and told him that he would have a chance to compete for the Mets' center-field job, but Mazzilli did not seem convinced that the assurance was sincere.

title: Whittaker Offer For Brunswick
description: The Whittaker Corporation, which is bidding for a share of the Brunswick Corporation in competition with the American Home Products Corporation, said that stockholders could now withdraw their shares under its offer until next Monday.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Bruce Berenyi, pitcher, and German Barranca, infielder, to one-year contracts; agreed to terms with Charlie Leibrandt, pitcher.

title: PRIEST ARRESTED IN SMUGGLING OF ART IS SUSPENDED FROM HIS U.N. DUTIES
description: A Roman Catholic priest, one of four men accused of smuggling stolen Italian Renaissance paintings into the United States, was suspended yesterday from his volunteer duties on the staff of the Permanent Observer of the Holy See to the United Nations.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $150,000

title: U.S. HAILS REPORT OF PROGRESS ON PAKISTANI ATOMIC DISPUTE
description: Administration officials say they are encouraged by a report from the International Atomic Energy Agency that progress has been made in efforts to persuade Pakistan to accept improved safeguards at its nuclear reactor near Karachi.

title: Spurs 119, Rockets 117
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - George Gervin scored 38 points and Mike Mitchell had 22 to lead San Antonio. Moses Malone led Houston with 43 points and 14 rebounds.

title: Exxon in Alaska
description: The Exxon Corporation expects to double or triple the $3 billion it has invested in Alaskan projects by the end of the century, Randall Meyer, president, told the Anchorage Chamber of Commerce. He said 21 percent of Exxon's net investment through 1981 has been in Alaskan operations. If the large resource estimates on Alaska made by the National Petroleum Council prove accurate, the oil industry could spend nearly $300 billion, in 1981 dollars, during the next 40 to 50 years for Alaskan oil and natural gas development, he said.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the last week (Monday, Feb. 22, to Sunday, Feb. 28), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets. Rating Program Network 1 30.0 Dallas CBS 2 25.2 Little House on the Prairie NBC 3 24.9 60 Minutes CBS 4 24.6 Love Boat ABC 5 23.8 Too Close for Comfort ABC 6 23.3 Archie Bunker's Place CBS 7 23.1 M*A*S*H CBS 8 23.0 TV's Censored Bloopers NBC 9 22.8 Three's Company ABC 10 22.8 Dukes of Hazzard CBS 11 22.6 Hart to Hart ABC 12 22.2 Falcon Crest CBS 13 21.6 Real People NBC 14 21.4 Muggable Mary-Street Cop CBS 14 21.4 A Wedding on Walton's Mt. NBC (P)remiere (R)epeat (S)pecial

title: Canadian Reserves Fall
description: Canada's foreign reserves fell to $3.5 billion (United States funds) last month from $4.3 billion at the end of January, the Finance Department said today. The decline resulted mostly from foreign-exchange intervention by the Bank of Canada to defend the weakening Canadian dollar.

title: Historians Oppose Cuts In Budget for Archives
description: Historians, led by Alex Haley, the author of ''Roots,'' today denounced budget cuts for the National Archives as ''an atrocity'' that could lead to ''sheer destruction'' of documents from America's past.

title: A 'BASIN' MARSHALL PLAN
description: Though President Reagan's proposal for economic assistance to the Caribbean Basin is constructive, it should go further. It has been compared to the Marshall Plan, and indeed we should examine that successful program for European economic recovery after World War II and apply its key features to Central America and the Caribbean islands.

title: A TRICKLISH SITUATION
description: President Reagan says that his economic policy will do the trick. All he asks is patience. He has made powerful medicine. If it takes longer to work than anticipated - well, he never promised a miracle, did he?

title: CONRAIL SAYS NO TO MORE TRAINS FOR LARCHMONT
description: The Village of Larchmont got an answer Monday from Conrail to its request for more seats on commuter trains. It was not the one it wanted.

title: Philip K. Dick, Won Awards For Science-Fiction Works
description: Philip K. Dick, an author of science fiction, died yesterday in Santa Ana, Calif. He was 54 years old. Mr. Dick, author of 35 novels and 6 collections of short stories, received the Hugo Award in 1963 for ''The Man in the High Castle'' and, in 1974, the John W. Campbell Memorial Award for ''Flow My Tears, the Policeman Said.''

title: CANVAS PASTRY BOARD
description: In recent years I have had to cook under circumstances that are nothing short of primitive. No kitchen at all, sometimes. Such circumstances -they crop up during travel for cooking demonstrations - do have their positive aspects. They call on every resource of a cook and every bit of portable equipment that can reasonably be taken along, equipment that probably would not be tested otherwise.

title: UNILEVER LTD AND UNILEVER NV reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BILL TO PROTECT AGENTS' NAMES NEARS VOTE IN SENATE
description: The Senate is moving toward almost certain passage of a bill that would make it a crime to expose the identities of intelligence agents working under cover abroad, but lawmakers appear to be closely divided over a proposed amendment that would make it easier to convict people under the legislation.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 3, 1982
description: International Salvadoran rebels are controlled from abroad, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said in House testimony. He said the United States had ''overwhelming and irrefutable'' evidence that the insurgency was not an autonomous Salvadoran operation, as the rebels contend. (Page A1, Column 1.) A setback for the Salvadoran Army was confirmed. The Government troops abruptly ended one of their most ambitious offensives of the war, and the commander of the 2,000-member force acknowledged that a number of rebel encampments had resisted the 10-day assault. (A1:1.)

title: Losing an Honor
description: Quintin Dailey, a guard from the University of San Francisco, was removed from an all-America basketball team after the selection committee learned he had been charged with sexual assault. Frank Boggs, the president of the United States Basketball Writers Association, said yesterday that Dailey, a junior, was removed from the list of 10 all-Americans on Feb. 22, the day he was arrested and one day after he had been selected.

title: 2 SENATORS WEIGH BID TO CUT U.S. TROOPS IN EUROPE
description: Two leading Senators threatened today to propose withdrawal of some American troops from Europe to protest continued Western European support for a Soviet natural gas pipeline despite the martial law crackdown in Poland.

title: SEOUL REDUCES LIFE SENTENCE OF TOP DISSIDENT TO 20 YEARS
