description: The South Korean Government announced today that the prison term of the nation's leading dissident would be reduced from life to 20 years. It said amnesty or reduced sentences would also be granted to 2,862 other prisoners, 297 of whom it said were political offenders.

title: AFTER 11 WEEKS OF TRIAL, VON BULOW OPENS DEFENSE
description: Claus von Bulow returned today to the cramped old courtroom where he has heard so much damaging prosecution testimony since Jan. 11. Now it was the turn of the defense lawyers to make the best case for their client, who is accused of twice trying to kill his wife, the heiress Martha (Sunny) Crawford von Bulow, by injecting her with insulin.

title: THREE BIG AUCTIONS OF WINE SCHEDULED
description: Three significant wine auctions -two in Chicago and one in Boston -have been scheduled for the spring season. Christie's plans to offer the wine collection of the late Dr. George H. Rezek for sale April 17 at the Drake Hotel in Chicago. The 2,300-bottle collection is believed to be one of the most important to come on the market in the United States in recent years. The wines date from the mid-19th century.

title: Will Gives $4 Million To Columbia Students
description: A trust fund of more than $4 million has been left to Columbia University by a retired Wall Street stockbroker who died at the age of 93 in 1980, the university announced yesterday.

title: THE DEPRESSION SHAPES A VIEW OF MONEY
description: FOR 25 years my mother worked as a clerk in the New York Public Library. In addition, two nights a week she taught English to foreigners at a high school in Manhattan. On Mondays and Wednesdays she left the house at 8:30 in the morning and got home after 10:30 at night. After answering questions all day at the Inquiry Desk at the 42d Street Library, where at least she could sit down most of the time, she was on her feet in the classroom for three hours, coaxing, cajoling, encouraging a group of eager immigrants: 20-year-old Ecuadorean villagers, quick learners who would soon be running art galleries on Madison Avenue; Polish grandmothers who would return shyly to her beginners' class year after year.

title: Turkish Military Closes Ex-Premier's Magazine
description: Turkish military authorities today closed the weekly magazine founded by former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit and continued the crackdown on leftist intellectuals.

title: LET MISS BELLAMY HOLD THE REINS
description: To the Editor:

title: GUATEMALA'S 4 MAIN REBEL GROUPS JOIN FORCES
description: After years of squabbling over strategy and ideology, Guatemala's four main guerrilla groups have called on all opposition forces to join them in a broad political front to topple the army-backed regime of Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia.

title: PATH RIDERS NEED NO SUBSIDY
description: To the Editor:

title: O'NEILL THEATER IS SOLD
description: Jujamcyn Theaters, increasingly prominent among Broadway theater owners, has acquired the Eugene O'Neill from the playwright Neil Simon, raising the number of its New York theaters to five.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary charge of $81,000 which is now being reported as anordinary expense

title: Economic Scene; Is Depression Lurking?
description: BELOW the surface of daily events, as noted here two weeks ago, deeper anxieties are growing that the economy is suffering worse ailments than those of a conventional business cycle. Increasingly one hears the question, ''Could we have another depression?'' And some businessmen, fighting for their companies' survival, have started to worry that we already have one.

title: LUMBER INDUSTRY WOES DIM GOOD LIFE IN OREGON
description: They wonder here in the timber country if this is when the good life ends in Oregon and the nightmare begins.

title: JULIUS F. SEEBACH JR.
description: Julius F. Seebach Jr., a radio and television programmer who was in charge of programs at WOR-TV when the station took to the air in October 1949, died Sunday at a nursing home in New York City. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Wartime Polish Priest Will Become a Saint
description: The Rev. Maximilian Mary Kolbe, a Polish Franciscan who died at Auschwitz to save another prisoner, will be proclaimed a saint by Pope John Paul II on Oct. 10, church officials said today.

title: AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISRAEL HARDENING ITS STANDON VISITS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin was reported today to have said that he would not visit Egypt until President Hosni Mubarak came to Israel and included Jerusalem in his itinerary.

title: WINE TALK
description: THIS is the story of a gastronomic calamity - not a calamity of monumental proportions, but one that is memorable because it could so easily have been avoided if only somebody had known better. It involves the president of the Comite Interprofessionel du Bourgogne, four bottles of rare and fine Burgundy and an excellent French restaurant in Manhattan.

title: DEFIANT SALVADORAN
description: A quick smile of recognition flashed across the face of Guillermo Manuel Ungo as he heard the question common to almost every interview: Won't you be dumped when your Marxist allies in the Democratic Revolutionary Front seize power in El Salvador?

title: GAMBLE'S SPEED IN A SPRINT WORKOUT IMPRESSES THE YANKEES
description: ''What'd you run?'' Larry Milbourne asked Oscar Gamble. ''Five-one-nine,'' Gamble replied. ''He ran five-one-nine?'' Milbourne repeated incredulously. ''That's what he says,'' Willie Randolph said, ''but I don't believe him.'' ''I got to check that - five-one-nine,'' Milbourne said. What Milbourne, Randolph and almost everyone else among the Yankees were awed about today was Gamble's time in the 45-yard sprint races that were conducted by Harrison Dillard, the team's part-time running instructor.

title: Tiant Wants to Play
description: Luis Tiant, at age 41, is searching for a job again. ''Wherever I end up, I'll feel lucky,'' the pitcher said in Boston, where he owns an industrial maintenance concern. Last year Tiant began the season with the Portland Beavers of the Pacific Coast League, compiling a 13-7 record. He ended the year with the Pittsburgh Pirates. Tiant, who began his major league career with Cleveland in 1964, was 2-5 with Pittsburgh, and in the opinion of the team's general manager, Harding Peterson, was the Pirates' most effective pitcher the last six weeks of the season. The Pirates invited him to spring training, but told him he would have to earn his way onto the roster. Tiant pitched for Minnesota after Cleveland, then went to the Boston Red Sox in 1971, where he was 122-81 in seven years. He won 99 games from 1972 to 1976. Then it was on to the Yankees for two seasons before landing in Portland. His lifetime major league record is 227-170. ''I just want to play,'' he said. ''I'm not trying to fool anybody. I wouldn't go to the mound if I thought I couldn't win.''... Carl Yastrzemski, who is a year older than Tiant, said at the the Red Sox camp in Winter Haven, Fla., that he was looking forward to a ''fun'' season, This is his 22d year with the team. He said he had worked out regularly over the winter. ''How long am I going to play?'' he said.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL TOURNAMENTS: L.I.U. OUSTS ST. FRANCIS, 56-53
description: Long Island University held off a late rally by St. Francis of Brooklyn and scored a 56-53 victory in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro-South playoffs last night at Schwartz Athletic Center.

title: NEW HOME SALES OFF BY 22.8%
description: Sales of new single-family houses in the United States fell 22.8 percent in January from December's level, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 353,000, the second-lowest rate in nearly two decades, the Government reported today.

title: ANTHONY STILL THROWING STRIKES
description: HE was rushing over to cover first base, a play he had made a thousand times. This time his feet tangled on the base and he could feel the ankle tearing apart.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Comings and Goings
description: Argentina's Davis Cup hopes received a jolt when Jose-Luis Clerc said he would not play in the series with France this weekend; no reason was made public. ... The Minnesota North Stars obtained Mark Johnson, a 24-year-old center who was the leading scorer for the 1980 United States Olympic hockey champions, in a trade with the Pittsburgh Penguins. ... Yesterday was the 20th anniversary of one of the most memorable moments in professional basketball history - the day Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia Warriors scored 100 points against the Knicks at Hershey, Pa.

title: STATE STAYS A JOB SHIFT TO ALBANY
description: Governor Carey's chief aide today asked the state's Department of Social Services to reconsider a decision to move its Medicaid billing operation from New York City to Albany. The current contractor has 675 employees in its lower Manhattan office.

title: I.L.O. Cautions Poland Against Isolating Labor
description: A United Nations agency told the Polish authorities today that they could not solve their economic and social problems by ''isolating trade union organizations and suspending their activities.''

title: NOT TO WORRY, NOT TO WORRY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK, ETC.
description: AT least 101 hazards must be hurdled at large parties, ranging from plain boredom to repeated elbow jabs in the ribs and clothes sloshed with wine and onion dip. All that pales in comparison with the greatest hazard of all: the boor who marches over and, in a challenging tone of voice, says, ''I'll bet you don't remember me.''

title: The U.N. Today; March 3, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have a saying out West: It's good to be among friends, even if they aren't your own.'' - Education Secretary T.H. Bell. (A21:1.)

title: ISLANDERS TRIUMPH, 6-3, AS TROTTIER GETS 3 GOALS
description: Bryan Trottier scored three goals tonight to lead the Islanders to a 6-3 victory over the Calgary Flames at Nassau Coliseum. For Trottier, who has 48 goals, it was the 21st consecutive game in which he has scored at least a point.

title: Donald Hayworth Dies at 84
description: Donald Hayworth, who was a Democratic Congressman from Michigan's Sixth District from 1954 to 1956, is dead at the age of 84. Mr. Hayworth, former chairman of the speech department at Michigan State University, died of a heart attack while walking near his suburban Washington home last week, relatives said Monday.

title: Juvenile Crime Fourth of six articles.
description: He was a small-time robber from the Lower East Side, but Kenny Spulka had little fear of the police. They were, he said, simply ''pests.'' As the 19-year-old mugger talked in the state prison in Coxsackie, N.Y., about his life and crimes, he described the criminal-justice system as though it were little more than an annoying inconvenience.

title: LAWMAKERS ASSAIL STUDENT LOAN CUTS
description: House Republicans as well as Democrats made it clear to the White House today that they opposed sharp reductions in college loans and many other education programs.

title: ARCO, STRESSING PRICE, TO END CREDIT CARD USE
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, convinced that price has become more important to gasoline buyers than service, said today that it will stop accepting purchases on its credit cards on April 15.

title: MOSCOW REPORTS PAUSE ON MISSILES
description: A high Soviet official said at a disarmament seminar today that the Soviet Union had not deployed any new SS-20 intermediate-range nuclear missiles in the western part of its territory since last November. His statement was dismissed as meaningless by a State Department official.

title: THE SMOKING HAZARD IS A CLOSED QUESTION
description: To the Editor:

title: German Rate Outlook
description: Otto Lambsdorff, West Germany's Minister of Economic Affairs, sees no hope of lower United States interest rates in the foreseeable future. He told a meeting of his Free Democratic Party Monday night that West Germany would have to try to reduce domestic rates itself. One way, he suggested, is to narrow the nation's balance-of-payments deficit.

title:
METROPOLITAN DIARY;
RUBIKQUITY WITHOUT END
description: FELICIA LAMPORT

title: A HOLLINGS SAMPLER
description: On obstinacy:

title: Rockefeller Said to See Hope for Angolan Ties
description: David Rockefeller, on an African tour, says his visit to Angola could help toward normalizing relations between Angola and the United States, the official Angolan press agency reported today.

title: State Clears Bank Sale
description: After four years of effort, a group of private Arab investors yesterday cleared the last hurdle necessary for their acquisition of Financial General Bankshares Inc., based in Washington, the only multistate bank holding company in the Eastern half of the United States.

title: DENTSPLY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,577,309 for the qr and $4,932,089 for the yr and a provision of $5,522,000 for the qr and yr for estimated losses of future divestitures...C-Net income...D-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,210,984 for the qr and $1,889,842 for the yr; results for the latest yr have been restated for the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regardingaccounting for foreign currency translations

title: DISPUTE IS SAID TO SLOW SAVINGS BANK MERGERS
description: The effort to find merger partners for failing savings banks has been hindered by a behind-the-scenes battle between Muriel Siebert, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, and William M. Isaac, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Jordanian Volunteers Leave for Iraq
description: The first group of Jordanian volunteers left for Baghdad last night to join Iraqi troops in the war against the Iranians, the Amman radio reported today.

title: HOLLINGS AND HIS ATTENTION-GETTING BUDGET PLAN
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings is not a man of few words. In fact, he is a man of many words, great gushing waterfalls of words and Southernisms that flood the Senate on a regular basis.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: AND-ROLL isn't always a matter of big bucks, arenas full of screaming teen-agers and $100,000 stage sets. The music first flourished in the 1950's in juke joints and seedy, run-down theaters, and when a modern rock-and-roll band connects with its own special audience in the sweaty dance-rock clubs that are the modern-day juke joints, special things can happen.

title: THEATER: 'KING LEAR' PRESENTED BY C.S.C. REP
description: DURING his distinguished career, and especially during his four seasons as the leading actor of the C.S.C. Rep, Robert Stattel has been earning his way toward ''King Lear.'' His performance in Christopher Martin's new production is, to a certain extent, a synthesis between his tormented ''Oedipus'' and his all-too-human ''Woyzeck.''

title: Monument of Sound
description: At Alice Tully Hall tonight, the Clarion Music Society will feature, in its 25th anniversary concert, the world premiere of ''A Celebration for Julia,'' by the Cuban composer Joaquin Nin-Culmell. Mr. Nin-Culmell is 73 years old and now lives in California.

title: On the Road to Jerusalem
description: President Mubarak Is Losing His Way

title: SHIFT ON MONEY DATA WEIGHED
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, raised the possibility today that the nation's central bank might stop releasing weekly money supply numbers, something the chairman has said before that he would like to do.

title: THE HAPPIEST POLITICIAN
description: The happiest politician in the United States today, without question, is Gerald Rudolph Ford, the 38th President, who lives and works on a golf course here in the beautiful Coachella Valley between the San Jacinto and Little San Bernardino Mountains.

title: ANDREW WARWICK
description: Andrew Warwick, former president of a New York stevedore contracting company, died Sunday in Punta Gorda, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived in Mahwah, N.J.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 3, 1982; Energy
description: Britain reduced the price of its North Sea oil by $4 a barrel, to $31 a barrel, its second cut in a month. The move put sharp downward pressure on world oil prices, analysts said, making a major break in oil prices likely. (Page A1.)

title: Seven-Up Kicks Off Campaign vs. Colas
description: The Seven-Up Company held a press conference yesterday to release the timely news that it had already started a new campaign positioning its popular soft drink in its war against the more popular colas as the drink that contains no caffeine.

title: UNIONS HAIL SUCCESSES IN WHITE-COLLAR FIELDS
description: At a time when the nation's old industrial unions are experiencing membership and contract setbacks, unions active among professional and white-collar workers are scoring successes in organizing and reporting innovations in negotiating.

title: Haydn Birthday Recital
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will play Haydn's ''Birthday'' Divertimento in Alice Tully Hall on March 12 at 8 P.M. and on March 14 at 5 P.M. Haydn was born 250 years ago this month. There will also be music by Mozart, Janacek and Barber.

title: GREAT AMERICAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A CONSUMER'S GUIDE TO FRESH FISH
description: MORE than 175 million pounds of fish pass each year through the barnlike structures of the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan, making it the largest central clearing house for fish in the country. According to an official of the Fishery Council, the public relations arm of the market, most of this fish is consumed within the New York metropolitan area.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM IS PLANNING $479 MILLION COMPUTER OVERHAUL
description: The Social Security Administration's antiquated computer and data processing system, now barely able to get 36 million checks in the mail every month, is to be modernized at a cost of $479 million.

title: DOW OFF 2.57
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday in heavy trading with some energy-related issues registering the largest losses. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was ahead more than 8 points at 1 P.M., finished off 2.57 points, to 825.82. However, the overall market did better, with advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscoring declining stocks by 834 to 653.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TESTIMONY BY HAIG BEFORE HOUSE PANEL
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s testimony today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: 2 SOUTH AFRICANS RESIGN POSTS
description: Two Cabinet ministers leading a right-wing rebellion in South Africa's ruling National Party resigned their posts today, Prime Minister P.W. Botha announced.

title: CENTRAL MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WILLIAMS BACKERS IN SENATE URGE CENSURE RATHER THAN EXPULSION
description: WASHINGTON March 2 - Senator Alan Cranston, the Democratic whip, said today that he would sponsor a resolution to censure Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. rather than expel him from the Senate.

title: FOUNDER-DIRECTOR OF PENNSYLVANIA BALLET RESIGNS
description: Barbara Weisberger has resigned as director of the Pennsylvania Ballet, the highly regarded company she founded in 1963. Benjamin Harkarvy will continue as artistic director. Mrs. Weisberger's resignation follows a request on Thursday from the company's board of directors that she take a leave of absence through April 1, to return as a member of the management staff with special emphasis on fundraising activities.

title: SARGENT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $772,000 for the qr and $2.8 million for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $935,000 for the qr and $2.7 million for the 9 mos

title: IN ENGLAND, CHEF BROTHERS GET 3D STAR
description: LONDON THEY come from Charolles, a small town in the hills of central France. As youngsters, they tasted the superb gastronomic specialties of the region - Charolais beef, Beaujolais and Burgundy wines, Bresse chickens, Auvergne cheeses.

title: Ulster's Chief Justice Survives Guerrilla Attack
description: Irish nationalist guerrillas tried today to assassinate Northern Ireland's top judge, Lord Lowry, firing four shots at him, but missing as he was getting out of his car at Queen's University.

title: Ukrainian Couple Force Way Into U.S. Embassy in Moscow
description: A young Ukrainian couple rammed their car through the iron gates of the United States Embassy before dawn today but left the compound five hours later.

title: Cunningham to Discuss Making of Video Dances
description: Merce Cunningham, the choreographer, will discuss the making of video dances on two programs to be presented as part of ARC Video Dance's ''Eye on Dance'' series.

title: Shearson in $77 Million Merger
description: Shearson/American Express Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with the Robinson-Humphrey Company, a regional brokerage firm based in Atlanta with revenues of about $80 million. The transaction is valued at about $77 million.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: Oilers 3, Canadiens 3
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Wayne Gretzky set up two goals, including the tying goal for Edmonton in the second period. The Oilers extended their unbeaten streak to 11 games.

title: Long-Term Bonds Advance; Short-Term Prices Mixed
description: A lack of supply helped raise long-term bond prices a point or more yesterday, but was not much help to the shorter-term markets, where prices rose slightly or declined in some cases.

title: MOVIE: ZANUSSI'S COMEDY 'CONTRACT'
description: ''Contract'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival in Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of Oct. 3, 1981. The film is at the Film Forum 2, at 57 Watts Street.

title: BRIEFING
description: Peace Corps Problems

title: BUCKHORN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; results for the latest periods include operations of New Idria Inc acquired in Dec 1981 and accounted as a purchase

title: A TYPICAL TAXI RIDER DESCRIBED IN SURVEY
description: The typical user of medallion taxis in New York City is a 35-yearold white woman who earns $27,250 a year, lives in Manhattan below 96th Street and is unhappy with the city's mass-transit system, according to a city-sponsored survey released yesterday.

title: Xaverian Beats Stepinac
description: Roger McCready's 19 points led Xaverian to a 71-58 victory over Archbishop Stepinac in the first round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championships at Holy Cross High in Queens last night. The victory moved the Clippers into tomorrow night's second round against Tolentine, the defending champion.

title: MARATHON PROTEST SET AT PORTMAN SITE
description: Prominent theater personalities, including the playwright Arthur Miller, will participate in a marathon reading of prize-winning plays at a rally starting tomorrow at 12:30 P.M. on 45th Street west of Broadway to point up the historical significance of two theaters that face demolition to make room for the Portman Hotel.

title: FRESH SALMON FROM FARM IN A FJORD
description: THE most magnificent-looking fish on the market lately have been the Atlantic salmon flown fresh from fish farms in Norway: big, plump and firm, their skins of gleaming silver dappled slightly in black and their eyes bright and sparkling. Put them in water and you would expect them to swim. They are excellent eating, a rosy-colored delicacy that has been available here only since the end of December.

title: WILLIAM H. LOGUEN
description: William H. Loguen, a former acting justice of the State Supreme Court and a former Criminal Court judge in Manhattan, died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: JUDGE IN I.B.M. CASE BIDS CONGRESS STUDY U.S. AIDE'S CONDUCT
description: A Federal judge called yesterday for a Congressional investigation to determine whether the chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division had acted improperly in dismissing the Government's case against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Kennecott Plans Utah Copper Cuts
description: The Kennecott Corporation said it plans to lay off 530 employees at its Utah Copper Division unit beginning Sunday, or about 10 percent of the company's work force.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alfa Romeo Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has named Luigi Zucchet executive vice president.

title: U.S. Pays 2 Banks Polish Debt
description: Two American banks were paid a total of $3.35 million today after they notified the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corporation that Poland had failed to meet scheduled repayments of part of the $1.5 billion that Poland owes the United States for Government-guaranteed grain purchases.

title: Sob Sisters
description: President Reagan ridicules critics of his budget as ''sob sisters'' because they portray his desire to control Government spending ''as a hard-hearted attack on the poor people of America.'' We don't accept the label (''persistently sentimental do-gooder,'' says Random House.) But we plead guilty to the charge. We have repeatedly criticized Mr. Reagan's budget precisely because it is a hard-hearted attack on the poor people of America.

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREECE SEEKS WEAPONS AND AN ARMS INDUSTRY
description: The Socialist Government is seeking cooperation from Greece's allies to supply its weapons for the next decade and to develop a national defense industry.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four decreased 19 cents to $107.19 during the period of Feb. 15 to Feb. 26, according to the City's Department of Consumer Affairs. Fresh fruits and vegetables helped to bring down the price of the 41-item market basket. There are now abundant supplies of produce that was scarce last month because of bad weather. Lettuce, spinach, escarole, chicory, broccoli and citrus fruits are plentiful, and prices are low.

title: HITACHI TO HELP HEWLETT-PACKARD
description: Hitachi Ltd., a leading Japanese semiconductor maker, announced today that it had agreed to supply the Hewlett-Packard Company with production technology to manufacture sophisticated semiconductor chips in the United States.

title: DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ACCENT ON YOUTH

title: SCOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $338,593 for the qr and $1,992,425 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $189,418 for the qr and $68,802 for the yr

title: Citicorp Funds Unit
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved Citicorp's application to underwrite and deal in Government securities and money market instruments through Citicorp Securities Inc., a new subsidiary. The new nonbank subsidiary will be required to adhere to the same restrictions that apply to underwriting activities by Citibank, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: O'OKIEP COPPER CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; results have been translated from South African rands into U.S. dollarin accordance with generally accepted accounting principles as described toF.A.S.B. Statement No 8

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Bonn Deficit Widens
description: West Germany had a balance-ofpayments deficit of 2.31 billion marks in January, compared with a provisional deficit of 895 million marks in December and a surplus of 85 million marks in January 1981, the nation's central bank reported today. The mark is worth about 42 cents in United States currency.

title: PARKS DEPT. URGES AERIAL SPRAYING FOR GYPSY MOTHS
description: The Department of Parks and Recreation, expecting a mass infestation of leaf-eating gypsy moths in some city parks this year, yesterday recommended aerial spraying with insecticides.

title: CALIFORNIA CUISINE: ASSESSING ITS STATE
description: From Santa Monica to the Napa Valley, from vegetarian restaurants to bastions of nouvelle cuisine, in California nearly everyone is ''doing'' goat cheese.

title: ANTIBUSING MOVES PASSED BY SENATE AFTER LONG FIGHT
description: The Senate voted today to adopt legislation that would virtually eliminate school busing for racial integration, ending an eight-month argument spiced by a filibuster.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard OH WHAT A PARADISE IT SEEMS. By John Cheever. 100 pages. Knopf. $10.

title: EXOTIC VEGETARIAN DISHES FROM THE EAST
description: THE most obscure herbs, spices and exotic produce are taken for granted these days. There is hardly a recipe for which the right ingredient cannot be found somewhere in the city. And the easy access to foods both new and long-neglected means that meals are becoming more creative, and so are some cookbooks.

title: MCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Beatrice Foods Vs. Inflation
description: managed companies in America, appears to have stubbed its corporate toe over the years. Through an aggressive acquisition program, Beatrice has become the nation's largest food company, with revenues of $9.4 billion in the fiscal year ended last month, up from $2.7 billion a decade ago.

title: Walesa's Release Urged
description: The Senate called upon the Polish Government today to release Lech Walesa, leader of the Solidarity labor union, and involve him in talks on the future of Poland.

title: Zinc Prices Cut
description: Noranda Mines Ltd. of Canada reduced its export price for zinc to $900 (United States) a metric ton, from $950, the company announced yesterday. It also reduced its domestic Canadian price by a half cent a pound.

title: RESOLUTION ON INFORMATION ACT SEEMS DISTANT
description: The main figures in the eight-month Senate battle to revise the Federal Freedom of Information Act indicated today that they were trying to negotiate a compromise. But the two sides are still expressing different views on how wide the Government's file cabinets should be opened to the public.

title: CRITICS SAY REAGAN MEDICARE CUTS WOULD ONLY SHIFT HOSPITAL COSTS
description: Reducing the reimbursement for hospitals treating Medicare patients, as President Reagan has proposed, would ultimately drive up the cost of health care for everyone, Congressmen, hospital administrators and insurance executives warned today.

title: Photographer Cited for Contempt
description: The photographer Ronald E. Galella was cited for contempt yesterday when a judge said he had violated a court order designed to prevent him from annoying Jacqueline Onassis and her daughter, Caroline Kennedy.

title: WATERGATE BEAUTY SALON HAS A RODEO DRIVE TINT
description: The Californians call it the ''Gossip Salon.'' In one corner, Mary Jane Wick, a longtime friend of Nancy Reagan and the wife of the director of the International Communications Agency, is sitting under a hairdryer. In another, Ramzieh Majali, wife of the Jordanian Ambassador, is getting a pedicure.

title: CCI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a gain of $1,784,000 or 28 cents a shr from the repurchase of subordinated debentures

title: IN ALBANY, CANDIDATE KOCH IS LOBBYIST KOCH ON TAXING
description: Mayor Koch, the candidate for Governor, yielded today to Mayor Koch, the lobbyist for New York City, and sought more state aid and authority from the Legislature to raise taxes on commuters and city residents.

title: WHITE-COLLAR LAYOFFS IN STEEL
description: William O. Sievertson, former Mayor of Glendale, W.Va., brother-in-law of a former governor of West Virginia and a white-collar worker for Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel for 20 years, never thought it would happen to him.

title: Advertising; 2 Is Better Than 1 for Hallmark
description: IF you have seen the first of the Young & Rubicam advertising for Hallmark Cards on any of the three television networks, where they began running on Feb.15, then you only know half the story.

title: Penn Central To Add Cooper
description: The Penn Central Corporation, which gets nearly 60 percent of its revenues from the energy business, said that it had reached tentative agreement to buy the Cooper Manufacturing Corporation of Tulsa, Okla., for $25 million in cash and $225 million of preferred stock.

title: N.A.S.L. Opposes Bill It Says Favors N.F.L.
description: The North American Soccer League said yesterday that it was opposing proposed Federal legislation that would grant the National Football League limited antitrust immunity.

title: Excerpts from testimony, page A12.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States had ''overwhelming and irrefutable'' evidence that the insurgents in El Salvador were controlled from outside that country by non-Salvadorans.

title: SWIFT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
From Riches to Rags
description: Former players on the Nebraska Wranglers of the defunct professional Women's Basketball League say the team owes them $5,000 to $20,000 each.

title: PATTERN FOUND IN KNIFEPOINT ROBBERIES OF WOMEN
description: Antoinette Rennick was walking to her home in Ozone Park, Queens, on the evening of Jan. 23 when a man jumped out of a Ford Thunderbird and attempted to steal her pocketbook. When the 38-year-old woman, who worked in a knitting mill, resisted, the man fatally stabbed her and sped away.

title: French Rightist Paper Admits Misuse of Picture
description: A senior editor of the right-wing French newspaper Figaro said today that the paper had ''erroneously'' used a four-year-old photograph of blazing corpses in Nicaragua to illustrate a report on what it said was a Nicaraguan massacre of an Indian tribe in neighboring Honduras.

title: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHAT 'RAIN'?
description: It is hard to fathom what the Administration is up to with its repeated charges of Soviet chemical and biological atrocities in Asia - other than justification for its program to spend $4 billion to $7 billion on a new generation of nerve-gas weapons. For all its shrillness, the Government's case would not suffice to convict a purse snatcher.

title: WAITER GOES ON TRIAL FOR FIRE AT STOUFFER'S THAT KILLED 26
description: The Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial began today. Luis Marin, the defendant, was described by the prosecution as ''the only person with the means, the opportunity and the reasons for setting the fire that took 26 lives and cost hundreds of thousands of dollars.''

title: UNITED KENO HILL MINES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a writeoff of Venus Mine project of $10,577,000...C-Net income; the company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: RUSSIAN GAS COULD KEEP THE PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON BUSING ISSUE

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The latest qr figures reflect adoption of new accounting change for foreign currency translation

title: BELL PARES BORROWING FOR 1982
description: Charles L. Brown, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said yesterday that the Bell System would be able to reduce its planned external financing needs by at least $500 million during 1982 because of the weakening economy and the resulting drop in demand for new telecommunications construction.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ogilvy & Mather Ad Wins $25,000 Award
description: Ogilvy & Mather's magazine advertising campaign for Paco Rabanne Pour Homme men's fragrance won the first $25,000 Stephen E. Kelly Award, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon sponsored by the Magazine Publishers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: CREDIT UNION RATE RISE LIKELY
description: A Federal agency is expected to vote on Thursday to lift interest rate ceilings on most credit union passbook accounts and interest-bearing checking accounts.

title: News Analysis
description: A seemingly noncontroversial action by the Landmarks Preservation Commission last fall has generated an unusual dispute between two mayoral agencies over the proper balance between protecting architecture and encouraging development in New York City.

title: Amy Carter Returning to Washington, as a Page
description: Amy Carter is going back to Washington, but without her father this time. Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat, said yesterday that he was sponsoring the appointment of Miss Carter, now 14 years old, to work as a Senate page this summer.

title: AUTODYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1981;yr-ago results have beenrestated to comply with F.A.S.B. Statement No 43 regarding accounting for compensated absences

title: MET MUSEUM'S LETTER PRAISED BY ISRAELI MAYOR
description: A conciliatory letter from Douglas Dillon, chairman of the Metropolitan Museum, to Mayor Koch regarding a proposed archeological exhibition from Israel, has been praised by Teddy Kollek, Mayor of Jerusalem.

title: BRITISH REDUCE THEIR OIL PRICE BY $4 A BARREL
description: Britain reduced the price of its North Sea oil today by $4 a barrel, to $31. It was Britain's second cut in a month and it put dramatic downward pressure on world oil prices.

title: Egypt Spurs Gas Search
description: The Egyptian Government has set new terms for oil companies finding gas in Egypt because the previous terms discouraged exploration, Mostafa Kamal Ayouty, deputy chairman of the Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation, said today.

title: GENERAL CINEMA BID BY HEUBLEIN GROWS
description: In what might be billed the battle of the bottlers, a two-way ownership fight continues between two companies that own each other's shares.

title: 'Princess Turandot' Set For March 17 Opening
description: ''Princess Turandot,'' a comedy by Carlo Gozzi, will open March 17 at the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway.

title: CHAMPION SPARK PLUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 100 percent stock distribution made in Feb 1982

title: Itel Payment Data
description: The Itel Corporation of San Francisco, a marketer and leasor of transportation and computer equipment, said that preliminary information on its January operations, filed in accordance with Chapter 11 bankruptcy requirements, showed that its unrestricted cash balance decreased by about $9 million, to about $287 million, as of Jan. 31. The company said it had made secured debt and lease payments in January of $11.6 million, compared with $4.5 million in December. It noted that the amounts paid in January include the retirement of $9.2 million of secured obligations.

title: DOGGEDLY; Man Bites Word
description: There must have been a similar adjective before ''feisty'' came along, but at the moment it's rather hard to remember what it was.

title: HONG KONG FOUND TO TOP MANHATTAN IN PRIME RENT
description: It is hardly a revelation when a survey shows that office space in midtown Manhattan commands a fancy price. But if research done by Richard Ellis, a London-based real estate and consulting concern, paints an accurate picture, the highest rents in the world for prime commercial locations are in Hong Kong, not New York. The survey covered office rental levels in 23 cities throughout Europe, the United States, South America, Asia and Australia.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Acting Chief for Bias Panel
description: President Reagan on Monday designated Cathie A. Shattuck, a member of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, to serve as the panel's acting chairman until a permanent chairman takes over. On Feb. 12, Mr. Reagan said he would nominate Clarence Thomas, a 33-year-old assistant Secretary of Education, to be chairman of the commission, the Government's top agency dealing with job discrimination.

title: Lendl to Skip Wimbledon
description: Ivan Lendl, ranked behind only John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors among the world's top tennis players, said today that he will not play in the Wimbledon championships starting June 21.

title: CAPITOL AIRWAYS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $592,000...C-Net loss; Capitol Air was formerly Capitol International Airways

title: NURSING SCHOOL PLANS CLOSING
description: The board of trustees of Skidmore College has approved a resolution directing the college's administration and faculty to close its nursing school, primarily because of a sharply declining enrollment.

title: Massachusetts Freeze On Taxes Is Reaffirmed
description: The mandate to keep down property taxes in Massachusetts has been reaffirmed by voters in six communities, who rejected all proposals to increase local taxes.

title: Moscow Grain Deal Financed
description: The Soviet Union last month bought 1.35 million metric tons of United States corn and one million metric tons of Australian wheat with short-term credit, apparently reflecting the lack of foreign currency available to Moscow, Administration and grain trade officials said today.

title: LEASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mystery Cloud Sighted Circling the Earth
description: Scientists doing a routine weather scan discovered a huge cloud orbiting the earth and have tracked it for five weeks but are at a loss to explain what it is, a scientist said today.

title: JARUZELSKI ENDS HIS VISIT WITH A PLEDGE TO SOVIET
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, flew home today after having assured Soviet leaders in two days of talks that any further attacks on Communist rule in Poland ''will be cut short.''

title: 3 BACKED BY MAYOR, A SOCIALIST, ELECTED IN BURLINGTON, VT.
description: Voters here in Vermont's largest city today elected three candidates supported by Mayor Bernard Sanders to the Board of Aldermen. Elsewhere, many of the state's smallest towns took a strong stand against nuclear weapons.

title: PINKERTON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SEISMIC DATA CONCERN APPOINTS TOP OFFICER
description: Frank E. Lasater Jr., 31, has been named president and chief executive officer of Flare Inc., a seismic data company that provides information to the petroleum industry in exploring for oil and gas. He succeeds George J. Dallas 3d, 38, who continues as chairman of the company, based in Midland, Tex.

title: French Joblessness Up
description: Unemployment in France rose 1.9 percent last month, to 1.96 million (seasonally adjusted), from January's 1.92 million, the Labor Ministry said today.

title: PACKWOOD APOLOGIZES TO REAGAN FOR SAYING HE IS HARMING G.O.P.
description: Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon apologized to President Reagan and fellow Republican senators today for having said that the President's ''concept of America'' had hurt the party and that Mr. Reagan was sometimes unresponsive to the concerns of Republican Congressional leaders.

title: KNIGHT ROYALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WARM UP TO CUBA
description: It is time for a new policy toward Cuba.

title: The U.N. Today; March 4, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THERE'S LONG LEAP FROM ACROBATICS TO DANCE
description: SUPPOSING the dancer had the requisite stamina, what do you suppose the reaction would be if he created a solo entirely out of fouettes (those brilliant whipping turns in ''Swan Lake's'' Black Swan pas de deux)? Of course, in ''Swan Lake'' they are surrounded by other steps. But this hypothetical solo would consist of nothing but fouettes. The dancer would simply turn and turn, pause for a breath, perhaps, then turn some more. What might people say of such a solo?

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: FORETASTE OF SPRING
description: Festival of Spring Flower Show, Horti- cultural Society of New York, Web- ster Hall, 128 West 58th Street, 757- 0915.

title: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
5 Inches of Water Left At 3 Mile Island A-Plant
description: Technicians have reached a ''major goal'' in draining the vast pool of highly radioactive water in the basement of the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear plant, officials said today.

title: SOVIET PIANIST'S U.S. DEBUT BOOKED, BUT DOUBTFUL
description: AVERY FISHER HALL has been booked on June 14 for the American debut recital of a pianist who in all likelihood will not perform. The pianist is Vladimir Feltsman, a 30-year-old Russian Jew. Mr. Feltsman was one of the Soviet Union's most promising young artists. He had won the Maguerite Long competition in Paris at the age of 19, and had been lavishly praised by critics in both Russia and the West.

title: D'Accord Is Headed For Races at Aqueduct
description: D'Accord, a leading prospect for the Kentucky Derby, will be shipped to New York next week to prepare for the spring races.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York has elected Sheldon Harrison, Deno D. Papageorge and Gregory W. Spurr Jr. senior executive vice presidents.

title: Senators on Trial
description: The Senate majority leader, Howard Baker, has stationed guards at the doors of the Senate chamber and strongly encouraged attendance and close attention to the floor debate that began yesterday. He's determined that his colleagues consider carefully the resolution to expel Senator Harrison Williams of New Jersey, convicted of bribery in the Abscam investigation.

title: Thrift Units Seeking U.S. Aid
description: Two trade groups representing the savings and loan industry today proposed a sweeping $10 billion Federal assistance program to help the industry and provide mortgages to home buyers at considerably less than prevailing rates.

title: Amoco to Close Third Refinery
description: The Amoco Oil Company said it would close its Sugar Creek Refinery in suburban Kansas City because of declining demand for petroleum products.

title: Fires Damage Former School And Two Piers on the Hudson
description: A three-alarm fire destroyed the interior of the former St. Francis Prep High School in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday, according to a Fire Department spokesman.

title: SONY INTRODUCES VIDEO PRINTER
description: The Sony Corporation displayed a color video printer yesterday for use with its previously announced camera that records still pictures without conventional photographic film.

title: DYNALECTRON CORP reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
SWISS BANK SECRECY REVIEW
description: After two days of talks in Bern, American and Swiss authorities said today that they hoped an accord would be reached on relaxing the bank secrecy here that has hindered investigations of insider trading in the United States. A joint statement at the conclusion of the first round of talks suggested two possible approaches.

title: NEW MEXICO & ARIZONA LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,320,000 for the qr and $3.6 million for the yr...C-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $359,000 for the qr and $892,000 for the yr

title: ESMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Including income of $242,000 from discontinued operations

title: TIMES OF LONDON GETS BACKERS
description: A group of British investors promised today to ''insure the survival'' of The Times of London as an independent newspaper, but did not extend the offer to the daily's sister publication, The Sunday Times.

title: WHEN PICKING A PROGRAM
description: Unlike summer camps, which are evaluated by accrediting organizations such as the American Camping Association, there is no guide to overall quality for travel, adventure and wilderness programs.

title: CONFIDENCE IN THE WEST
description: Underlying the great foreign policy argument, straining the Atlantic alliance and provoking top-level dogfights in Washington is the question of Western confidence.

title: A $40 MILLION GIFT OF BRITISH HISTORY TO NATIONAL TRUST
description: known Dorset lawyer, has left a $40 million estate to the National Trust, the independent foundation dedicated to preserving Britain's heritage.

title: Block Asserts Milk Supports Will Cost $2 Billion This Year
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that the Government's milk price support program will cost $2.2 billion this fiscal year, more than 40 percent above the budget estimate sent to Congress a month ago.

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
DOMESTICATING THE ROBOT FOR TOMORROW'S HOMES
description: DALLAS AVATAR is 30 inches tall, weighs 85 pounds, moves around on a tricycle base, has a body made out of a 1940 Picker X-ray machine and lives in a frame workshop behind Charles Balmer's brick house just outside Urbana, Ohio.

title: 15 Citicorp Aides Sued
description: A Citicorp stockholder has filed a shareholder derivative suit in New York that charges 15 senior Citibank and Citicorp officials with causing the bank to engage in illegal foreign exchange transactions and with failing to disclose these transactions.

title: ROBOT HISTORY IN FICTION AND FACT
description: From Pygmalion of Greek mythology to R2-D2 of ''Star Wars,'' one of man's fantasies has been to replicate himself mechanically. For most of history that has taken a benign form, such as an 18th-century French craze for musical automatons.

title: Advertising; Changing At the Top At D'Arcy
description: THE pair of copywriters-turned-ad moguls arrived very early yesterday morning at the spanking new Madison Avenue offices of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, a worldwide operation with more than $1 billion in billings. There was much to do.

title: HEAD BOWED, WILLIAMS AWAITS FATE
description: It was one of those rare scenes in the history of the often sparsely attended, frequently noisy Senate: Members sat quietly in their seats, listening attentively to every word. In their midst, his head bowed much of the time, was a colleague on whom they were sitting in judgment.

title: FOOD GROUP OFFERS SAFETY GUIDELINES
description: The Food Safety Council, an industry-sponsored research group, released a report today that proposed new guidelines for the way the Government determines whether a food or a food additive is safe.

title: A P.L.O. VOICE FOR PEACE (1)
description: Dr. Issam Sartawi, a longtime moderate voice in the Palestine Liberation Organization, thinks the P.L.O. and Arab governments should make fresh peace moves looking toward a Palestine state side by side with Israel. He thinks the next Arab summit meeting should approve that formula in the Fahd plan, and also endorse talks with any Israelis who will recognize Palestinian national rights.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WEINBERGER AND THE PRESS: POINT, COUNTERPOINT
description: At breakfast with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, a reporter was asking a question about news articles when Mr. Weinberger interrupted to quip: ''They're probably wrong.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt NOBODY'S ANGEL. By Thomas McGuane. 227 pages. Random House. Hardcover, $14.50; paperback, $6.95.

title: Funds Curb Sought by Fed Member
description: A member of the Federal Reserve Board, Lyle E. Gramley, urged Congress today to authorize the Fed to impose reserve requirements on money market funds to the extent that they are used for transaction, or checking account, purposes.

title: Cyclone Rips Across Tonga
description: A cyclone ripped across the kingdom of Tonga, near Fiji, destroying property and bringing widespread flooding to the southwest Pacific islands, according to information reaching here today. The extent of destruction was not known, but two deaths were confirmed.

title: PROSECUTION'S POOR DEFENSE IN THE CASE OF THE JOB-SEEKING JUROR
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for the conversion to LIFO inventory accountin

title: Mrs. Kissinger Pleads Not Guilty to Assault
description: Nancy Kissinger, wife of Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, has pleaded not guilty to a charge of simple assault brought against her last month by a Manhattan woman. A trial date of May 26 has been set in Municipal Court in Newark, according to Mrs. Kissinger's lawyer.

title: A FIREMAN TELLS OF FINDING BODIES AT STOUFFER'S INN
description: An off-duty fireman, the first to enter the blazing Stouffer's Inn just over a year ago, today described what he called the ''unbelievable'' conditions that caused the deaths of 26 businessmen.

title: SAN DIEGO BANCORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $228,000 resulting from the acquisition in July of First Affiliated Securities Inc on a pooling of interests basis...C-The holding company said that no comparable figures for the previous yr were available

title: 'DID NOTHING CRIMINAL,' HE INSISTS
description: Members of the Senate gathered in somber session today to judge the fitness of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. to continue as one of their peers.

title: CHILDREN'S WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DISABLED PUPILS TERMED VICTIMS OF LEGAL ACTION
description: Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola charged yesterday that litigation designed to upgrade services to tens of thousands of handicapped New York City students had in fact worked to their detriment.

title: HERS
description: IN a recent magazine article, Billie Jean King was quoted as favoring the new trend among teen-agers, who turn pro at younger and younger ages. Contrary to most of those interviewed, who felt that such pressures would harm not only the youngsters' athletic development but also their chances of leading a normal life, Miss King said: ''The critics don't realize that their world is as unreal to me as mine is to them. Sure tennis is demanding and it creates some tunnel vision. But I'm not really a believer in the well-rounded individual; it often means that a person has no particular distinction.''

title: No Headline
description: Reagan Trades Notes With Syrian President

title: Board of Trade Files Dow Suit
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said that it had filed a request for a declaratory judgment against Dow Jones & Company in the State Court of Cook County over the plan by the exchange to trade futures contracts based on the stocks in the various Dow Jones averages.

title: STRINGS: AMADEUS QUARTET
description: The four original members of the London-based Amadeus Quartet have been playing together for a precedent-setting 35 years. Fittingly, they have chosen to mark their long collaboration with a monument, a cycle of the Beethoven quartets in six concerts at Alice Tully Hall this month, the first of which took place on Tuesday evening.

title: New Macy's Pact
description: The union representing 6,000 employees at five of Macy's department stores reached agreement with the company on a new contract early yesterday, averting a threatened strike.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BIG BEAT

title: MEDIA 'FIELD DAY' OVER KOCH'S PREFERENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: The Economy
description: The Business Roundtable rejected the budget deficits projected by President Reagan as too large and asked Congress to reduce his proposed military buildup. The 46-member policy committee of the group, which represents 200 big corporations, was also said to have backed a deferral of the 1983 tax cut for individuals. (Page A1.) Mr. Reagan, stumping the nation on behalf of his program, warned that a move to rescind the tax cut would prolong the recession. (A1.)

title: NETS WIN FOURTH IN ROW, BEATING LAKERS BY 111-103
description: In truth, the Nets should have been mentally and physically exhausted. Less than 24 hours ago they had solidified their credentials as a playoff team by enduring a heart-wrenching double-overtime victory in a road game against the Washington Bullets.

title: Texaco Oil Stake
description: Texaco Inc. said it had agreed to acquire about 40 percent of the Kerr-McGee Corporation's interest in 31 deep wells to be drilled on leases held by Kerr-McGee and others in the Fletcher area of the deep Anadarko Basin in Oklahoma.

title: House Passes Bill to Allow Control of Oil
description: Legislation giving the President emergency powers to ration crude oil and impose price controls in case of a severe disruption of supply was passed by the House of Representatives late today, 246-144, and sent to the White House.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HAWAIIAN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $8 million for the qr and the yr from the sale of taxcredits and a pretax gain of $14 million for the yr on the sale of aircraft...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $217,000 for the qr and $2,780,000 for the yr; yr-ago results have been restated

title: Ad Panel Speaker Sees Consumer Discretion
description: As keynote speaker of the 28th annual conference of the Advertising Research Foundation, Leo Bogart, executive vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, offered a scary prediction Tuesday - the future could hold a time when consumers, thanks to the wonders of telecommunications, could be asking for the advertising they want to see.

title: CFS CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Jan 23
description: Yr-ago results are for the period ended Jan 17, 1981

title: MUSIC: RAPHAEL'S BEETHOVEN
description: THE Raphael Trio began a series of concerts devoted to Beethoven at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night. Charles Castleman, violin, Susan Salm, cello, and Daniel Epstein, piano, played the Trio in E flat (Op. 1, No.1), an E flat trio from Beethoven's adolescent years and the famous ''Ghost'' Trio from Opus 70.

title: RCA Dividend To Be Cut 50%
description: The RCA Corporation, parent of the NBC television network, said yesterday that it would cut its quarterly dividend in half to reduce costs and improve its financial position.

title: CORRECTION
description: A roundup of quarterly earnings in Business Day on Feb. 22 incorrectly reported the results of Continental Group Inc. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1981, Continental had revenues of $1.2 billion and net income of $42.4 mil- lion.

title: SCIENCE MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary loss of $5,000 for the qr and an extraordinary gain of$83,000 for the yr...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $85,000 for the qr and yr; the results for the latest yr include a benefit of $143,000 or 6 cents a shr from the restatement of foreign currency translations for F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Dale Murphy, outfielder, to a one-year contract.

title: Military Analysis
description: A major debate has been developing among American military officials and experts over the strategy to be followed in defending Western Europe in the event of Soviet attack.

title: U.S Fines British Unit
description: A British company has been fined $15,000 for violating a United States Government ban on sales of certain American-made goods to South Africa, the Commerce Department said today. International Computers Ltd., Britain's biggest computer concern, agreed to pay the fine, although it neither admitted nor denied guilt, the department said. The Commerce Department charged that in 1978 International Computers included American-made computer disk drives in two computer systems shipped to South Africa, thus violating a United States ban on the sale or resale of certain hightechnology items to South Africa.

title: COCA-COLA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,000 for the qr and $5,641,000 for the yr and a gain of $29,071,000 for the yr on the sale of discontinuedoperations...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $6,287,000 for the qr and $15,790,000 for the yr

title: REFUGEES RESISTING MOVE IN HONDURAS
description: Every evening after dark, refugees from El Salvador's civil war gather in the makeshift chapel near the entrance to the camp here to pray for peace back home and for protection from Salvadoran soldiers who occasionally cross into Honduras to harass them.

title: Frank Mankiewicz's New Cause: Saving National Public Radio
description: Frank Mankiewicz, the president of National Public Radio, is sitting in a Washington coffee shop, toying with his two poached eggs and doing what few people in this city do better. He is telling stories.

title: No Headline
description: ST. JOSEPH'S ELIMINATES HOFSTRA

title: INTERFAITH GROUP ASSAILS CITY'S LANDMARKS LAW
description: Hundreds of churches and synagogues in the city are burdened with the obligation to preserve old buildings that were capriciously designated as landmarks, according to a study released yesterday by a group of New York religious leaders.

title: LTV to Settle Suit
description: The LTV Corporation said it had agreed to pay $7.75 million to settle a stockholders' class action suit that contends that LTV misstated its earnings and financial condition between 1974 and 1977 to inflate its stock value. Judge Patrick Higginbotham of United States District Court scheduled a hearing for May 10 to decide whether to approve the agreement in the suit, filed on behalf of more than 50,000 LTV stockholders.

title: JERSEY DISTRICTING IS VOIDED BY COURT
description: A three-judge Federal panel today declared New Jersey's Congressional redistricting plan unconstitutional and ordered the Legislature to enact a new plan by March 22.

title: Market Place; Scrutinizing Dayco Stock
description: THE Dayco Corporation, the dominant producer of fan belts for the automotive industry, has been regarded as an investors' asset play. Dayco's shares have languished since mid-1979 when automobile sales began to sag more deeply than anyone had expected. Earlier this year the shares traded at 11 3/8.

title: U.S. SEEKING RIGHT TO USE AIR BASES IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: The State Department said today that the United States was seeking the right to use air bases in Colombia and Honduras, apparently as part of an effort to bolster the defenses of non-Communist nations in the Caribbean area.

title: CONSERVATIVE NORTH DAKOTA STUNNED BY OVERNIGHT BOOM FROM GAMBLING
description: Kyle Good is standing under the cut-glass chandeliers in the casino in the Doublewood Motel and Lounge. Behind him, dealers wearing black ties and vests slide cards across the green baize tables while cocktail waitresses circulate among the crowd.

title: LILIAN S. HESTER
description: Lilian Scharman Hester, an outstanding tennis player in the 1920's, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 80 years old. Mrs. Hester, who was ranked No.4 nationally in 1923 and 1924, was on the United States Olympic team that competed in Paris in 1924.

title: Grace Chief to Head Federal Study Panel
description: President Reagan yesterday announced the appointment of J. Peter Grace, the chairman and chief executive officer of W.R. Grace & Company, as chairman of a new private-sector study group that will report to the President on ways to cut Government operating costs. The new group will be modeled on a similar one that Mr. Reagan established while Governor of California. It will be called the Private Sector Survey on Cost Control.

title: BAXTER ASKS DEPARTMENTAL INQUIRY
description: William F. Baxter, chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said today he had asked the department to examine his decision not to disclose a brief link with a law firm representing the International Business Machines Corporation. A Federal judge has said Mr. Baxter's lack of disclosure raised questions of impropriety.

title: SQUATTERS IN SINAI EVICTED BY ISRAEL
description: Israeli troops began removing militant Jewish squatters from Sinai today as permanent residents announced that they would leave peacefully as soon as the Government paid them compensation.

title: SOVIET SIDE OFFERS DRAFT OF ARMS CUT
description: The Soviet bloc has presented a draft agreement for the reduction of forces and arms in Central Europe and has accused the West at arms talks here of stalling in its consideration of the document.

title: SOME SUMMER OPTIONS FOR TEEN-AGERS
description: WHILE some older teen-agers have already settled the question of what to do this summer, others are wondering how to spend the long vacation. The problem is that many high-school juniors and seniors consider themselves caught in the middle - too young to land decent summer jobs and too old for or not interested in attending traditional or specialty camps. But there are many opportunities for them as well, and it is not too late to sign on.

title: NEW YORK SELLS SHORT-TERM NOTES BY BIDS FOR FIRST TIME SINCE 1975
description: For the first time in seven years, the city yesterday sold shortterm notes to investment houses competitively, rather than through a negotiated interest rate.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-After a loss of $10,400 from discontinued operations; results reflect gains from the sale of securities equal to 74 cents a shr for the latest yr and 18 cents a shr for the previous yr

title: DANCE: RACHEL HARMS GROUP IN 'DE KOONING: WOMAN I'
description: RACHEL HARMS can make interesting dances. Yet she has a tendency to adorn some of them with choreographic whipped cream. The best works on Sunday night's program by the Rachel Harms Dance Company at the Emanuel Midtown Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. were the ones that remained undecorated.

title: LEAK-PROOF CUBANS
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'HIBAKUSHA,' AFTER HIROSHIMA
description: ''WE must go on talking about these things and not fall into silence,'' says a character in Steve Friedman's new play, ''Hibakusha: Stories From Hiroshima.'' It's an unassailable statement when what's being talked about is the horror that American atomic bombs brought to Japan in World War II.

title: AEGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $1,347,000 from the company's oil reclaiming activity which was sold in Jan 1982 and which included a provision of $671,000 for loss on the disposal of the operations

title: CENTRAL MAINE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRADITIONAL JAPANESE DESIGN MEETS NEW WAVE AMERICAN
description: HE is a fabric designer and she is an artist who has just begun to design children's clothing. Yasushi and Kiyoko Suzuki met in New York, returned briefly to Japan and finally settled here about nine years ago. A visit to their loft in the East 20's, where they have been living with their twin sons since 1976, is a lesson in crosscultural interior design.

title: RESEARCHERS REPORT FIRST SUCCESS IN ANTIBODY TREATMENT OF CANCER
description: Doctors have reported their first success in using an experimental antibody treatment to achieve a long-lasting remission of B-cell lymphoma, an uncommon type of cancer.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Coke's Net Rose 10.8%
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that its net income rose 10.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, to $106.2 million, or 86 cents a share, from $95.8 million, or 78 cents a share, in the last quarter of 1980.

title: S.E.C. Adopts Stock Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a proposal today aimed at making it easier for small businesses to raise money through securities offerings.

title: Broker Loan Rate Up
description: The Bankers Trust Company of New York said yesterday that it had raised its broker loan rate by a full percentage point, to 15 1/2 percent, from 14 1/2 percent, effective immediately. The rate, which is considered to be a reliable indicator to future changes in the prime lending rate, ranges from 15 to 15 1/4 percent at other major banks.

title: Mobile Phone Use Widened
description: The Federal Communications Commission formally issued orders today to put into effect its new cellular radio service, listing greater New York City as the largest market available for this new mobile telephone system.

title: JAPANESE CHIP SALES STUDIED
description: The Reagan Administration has begun an informal investigation to determine whether domestic manufacturers of the most advanced semiconductor chips should get some protection from intensified Japanese competition, Administration officials said today.

title: Article 230112 -- No Title
description: The Barbican Center, a $275 million cultural complex on a site devastated by the Luftwaffe during World War II, was opened with a regal flourish tonight by Queen Elizabeth II. She described it as ''one of the wonders of the modern world.''

title: Wyeth and U.S. Recall Cans of Baby Formula
description: The Food and Drug Administration today announced the recall of more than half a million cans of baby formula that lacked vitamin B-6.

title: MORTON MAY SELL DRUG UNIT TO FOIL ANY TAKEOVER BID
description: Faced with the possibility of fending off an unfriendly takeover bid, Morton-Norwich Products Inc. is now thinking about putting its profitable pharmaceutical unit on the auction block.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Gain
description: The price rally in Government securities that blossomed three weeks ago continued yesterday, despite an increase in some short-term rates.

title: FIRST FARWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: EVENING OF REITI
description: Aside from the ponderous masterpieces of the last century, the refined complexities of modernist efforts and the banality of populist scribbling, there is another sort of repertory, often lost in the shuffle. It is music that does not pretend to ''greatness'' but that circumscribes its territory with such genial wit, refined sensibility and largeness of spirit that it deserves an honored place in our worn concert life.

title: What the Fly Might Say
description: Can extinct creatures be recreated, at least in part, by the new techniques of manipulating genetic material? The possibility is prompted by the discovery, reported in Science magazine, of a fungus gnat, much of whose soft tissue has been preserved in a drop of amber that congealed some 40 million years ago in a Baltic forest.

title: Voters in Alabama Back Governor's 'New Deal'
description: Alabama voters have given overwhelming support to Gov. Fob James's ambitious plan, known as ''Fob's New Deal,'' to harness oil tax money to build roads and bridges, schools and prisons.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a gain of $87,000

title: GRAND CENTRAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After a charge of $341,694 from an accounting adjustment

title: SOUTH KOREA UNDER CHUN: A NEW SENSE OF VIGOR
description: President Chun Doo Hwan, completing his first year as head of state under South Korea's new Fifth Republic, appears to have won the confidence of his allies abroad and much of the military and business elite at home.

title: ENDED: BIG ANTITRUST
description: The era of the big antitrust case is over, leaving a legacy of frustration and defeat for the Government's antitrust l awyers. No longer will the courts have a chance to restructure h ighly concentrated industries or oligopolies for more efficiency, i nnovation, and competition in pricing. Now, the forum for deciding i ndustry-wide deconcentration questions will be Congress.

title: DISPUTE FLARES IN ARGENTINA OVER ROLE IN SALVADOR
description: Persistent reports that Argentina has sent or is considering sending military advisers to El Salvador have provoked a major controversy here.

title: BELL PLANS TO OPEN 2 COMPUTER CENTERS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today that it was creating two computer centers to provide planning, programming and data processing services for a new subsidiary.

title: KYSOR INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Philadelphia National
description: The Philadelphia National Corporation said today that it had sold its 7.5 percent interest in Banque Worms, a French commercial and investment bank that is being nationalized, for an after-tax gain of $2.05 million, or 35 cents a share. It said it would record the gain in its first-quarter earnings. A bank spokesman said the stake had been sold for $7 million on the Paris Bourse but the company did not know who bought it.

title: STUDY OF TOXIC SHOCK PLANNED
description: Researchers at the national Centers for Disease Control are planning a new study on the possible long-range effects of toxic shock syndrome, a rare disease linked to tampon use, officials said today.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are for 16 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and 17 and 53 weeks for the yr-ago periods

title: VERMONTERS CALL FOR A FREEZE ON NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: Vermonters voted overwhelmingly at town meetings this week to support a mutual freeze on nuclear weapons by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: HANNAFORD BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ford Negotiator Sees Period of Labor Peace
description: After the United Automobile Workers overwhelmingly approved a new labor contract with the Ford Motor Company last Sunday that, for the first time in the history of the industry, traded wage and benefit concessions for assurances of increased job security, Peter J. Pestillo, Ford's vice president for labor relations, breathed a sigh of relief.

title: NATIONWIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Iran Is Planning to Sell Treasures of Past Shahs
description: Iran has decided to raise money for its war against Iraq and for its budget deficit by selling the treasures of the former shahs.

title: LEGISLATURE APPROVES A BILL TO BAR LIBRARY DISCLOSURES ON BORROWERS
description: The State Senate has given final passage to a bill that would protect public and private libraries from having to disclose information on borrowers and the books they read.

title: THE DOVETAIL JOINT: STRIKING AND USEFUL
description: Michael Varese restores furniture for antiques dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: ARABS ASSAIL MITTERRAND TRIP
description: France came under sharp criticism in the Arab world today for the visit to Israel by President Francois Mitterrand. There were calls here and in Saudi Arabia for a reappraisal of Arab relations with the French.

title: No Headline
description: Oilers' Streak Halted

title: Deminex's Alberta Pact
description: The Alberta Energy Company said today that Deminex (Canada) Ltd., an affiliate of Veba, had agreed to participate in the Ipiatik Lake oil sands project.

title: CONCERT: MUSICA SACRA PERFOMS ORFF
description: MUSICA SACRA is known for inventive programming, but its concert Monday night in Avery Fisher Hall was more inventive than most. The first half consisted of a cappella pieces: three ''Lamentations of Jeremiah'' by Ginastera, ''Sechs Spruche'' plus ''Heilig'' by Mendelssohn and Schoenberg's ''Friede auf Erden'' (not the orchestrated version of 1911, but the unaccompanied original of 1907). The second half was devoted to Orff's ''Carmina Burana,'' the first time Richard Westenburg had done this 20th-century staple with Musica Sacra.

title: South African Party Expels 16 Rightists
description: South Africa's ruling National Party expelled 16 members of its rebellious right wing today for refusing to back Prime Minister P.W. Botha's policies.

title: Auto Union Panel Said to Ask Restart of Talks With G.M.
description: A bargaining unit of the United Automobile Workers voted unanimously today to reopen contract talks with General Motors, The Detroit Free Press reported.

title: CADENCE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $750,000 for the qr and $135,000 for the yr and extraordinary credits of $83,000 for the qr and $386,000 forthe yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $511,000 and an extraordinary credit of $217,000...D-Net income after a loss of $1,034,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $540,000

title: Columbia Pictures
description: The Coca-Cola Company and Columbia Pictures Industries announced separately that their respective boards had approved the acquisition of Columbia by Coca-Cola. The companies said completion of the $750 million transaction still required regulatory review and shareholder approval.

title: BROAD CHANGES IN CAREY'S BUDGET PREDICTED BY 2 COMMITTEE HEADS
description: The chairmen of the Legislature's budget committees said today that Governor Carey's $17.3 billion spending plan for the coming fiscal year would be substantially revised.

title: VW's and Audis Are Recalled
description: Volkswagen of America said today that it was recalling about 700,000 Volkswagens and Audis to repair fuel pump wiring that made the cars hard to start. The cars affected are 1975-81 water-cooled, fuel-injected models, but not Audi 5000's or dieselpowered vehicles, Volkswagen said.

title: The Jesuits Regain Right to Pick a Leader
description: Jesuit leaders, called to Rome to hear Pope John Paul II's criticisms of political activism by some priests, ended a weeklong meeting today with their traditional right to select the order's leader restored.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Pronouncement Backfires

title: NELSON FENDING OFF YANKEE TRADE TALK
description: A year ago, 20-year-old Gene Nelson impressed the Yankees so much he won a job on their pitching staff. This year not only is 21-year-old Gene Nelson fighting for a job on the Yankee staff but he is also fighting off reports that he could be traded.

title: HARD WORK MARKS ST. PETER'S SUCCESS
description: The basketball season at St. Peter's College shaped up as a disaster. Last season's two leading scorers and rebounders had graduated. William Brown, the best player remaining, underwent surgery in August on a left shoulder that kept popping out of the socket. One player left the team for disciplinary reasons, another because he was homesick. Of the nine remaining players, the tallest was 6 feet 5 inches.

title: MET IS GIVEN $60 MILLION LINSKY ART COLLECTION
description: A New Yorker who says she bought ''everything on impulse'' has given the Metropolitan Museum of Art one of the greatest private collections in this country of European art from the Renaissance and later periods.

title: Bridge:; Once in a While, a Bromide Seems Almost a Revelation
