description: Many players who have learned the game from friends or relatives, rather than from books and expert teachers, are convinced that one should ''always lead the highest of partner's suit.''

title: 2 PRO FOOTBALL PLAYERS ARRAIGNED IN RAPE CASE
description: Greg Roberts and David Overstreet, former Oklahoma football start now with professional teams, were arraigned today on charges of raping an Oklahoma student.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: THE MAKING OF A SOVIET PARTY CHIEF
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Affairs Office Told To Reduce Expenses by May
description: The United States Office of Consumer Affairs has been ordered to cut its expenses within the next two months or furlough all of its 38 employees for 22 working days.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH a nail may be adequate for hanging a small picture on a hollow plaster or gypsum-board wall, it is scarcely adequate when you want to hang something larger: a heavy mirror or picture, a set of shelves or a cabinet. You might happen to find a wall stud just where you need it so you can drive nails or screws into solid wood. Of course, nails won't work when you are dealing with walls of brick, concrete or cement block.

title: PANEL IN SENATE REBUFFS PENTAGON ON ARMS CUTS
description: Member after member of the Senate Budget Committee told Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today that the Reagan Administration's proposed military budget for the next fiscal year was going to be cut by Congress and that the only question was where.

title: ROBOTS ENTER THE LIMELIGHT
description: Although the International Business Machines Corporation prides itself on leading the way in the computer industry, it is following a path well trodden by others to enter the field of robotics.

title: Association to Rule On Magazine Dispute
description: C. John Kirby, ad director of Scientific American magazine, took his case on the need for more complete subscriber data on demographic editions of magazines to the consumer magazine committee of the American Association of Advertising Agencies yesterday.

title: Hunger Pains
description: Pembroke State and North Carolina-Charlotte were tied at 8-8 after nine innings of their baseball game Tuesday in Pembroke, N.C., when the game was called because of hunger.

title: A Modest Life at 10 Downing Street; Life on Downing St.
description: The address is as chic as they come, but according to a new behind-the-scenes account, life at 10 Downing Street is distinctly declasse.

title: HOME BEAT
description: TWO young entrepreneurs with a special interest in architecture and design, Mark McDonald, below left, and Ralph Cutler, have opened a shop to offer ''primarily American, interesting pieces from the 1930's through the 1950's.'' Mr. McDonald, sitting on a late 1940's Knoll design by Pierre Jeanneret ($950), said, ''They're not antiques.'' His was sitting in a 1937 Herman Miller chair by Gilbert Rohde ($2,000).

title: HOUSE SPEAKER SAYS HE WON'T ACT ON SENATE SCHOOL BUSING MEASURE
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that, unless he was asked to do so by either one of two key House committee chairmen, he would take no action on the most sweeping antibusing legislation ever to pass the Senate.

title: Entrepreneurial Geffen Disparages Bureaucrats
description: David Geffen, one of the current crop of Wunderkinder in the entertainment industry, established a new concern last month, the Geffen Film Company, in conjunction with Warner Bros. Inc. The move follows by about a year the creation of another Geffen-Warner joint venture, Geffen Records, which already has an album and a single that are high on the charts. And it came shortly after ''Dream Girls,'' a Broadway show that he co-produced, became one of this season's major hits.

title: Changing Her Name, but Not Her Signature; Cutting Costs
description: Angela M. Buchanan will be getting a new name, but the nation's currency won't be getting a different signature. That was the word yesterday from Miss Buchanan, the Treasurer of the United States, whose signature, along with that of the Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan, has adorned currency issued since last year.

title: RANGERS SET BACK FLAMES, 4-2
description: Statistically, at least, the Rangers proved at Madison Square Garden last night that they are a better team than last season. The current team gained its 31st victory of the season, defeating the Calgary Flames, 4-2, on goals by Ron Duguay, Mark Pavelich, Eddie Johnstone and Mike Rogers.

title: JANUARY FACTORY ORDERS OFF A SHARP 1.2%
description: New factory orders fell a steep 1.2 percent in January, the Government reported today. It was the fifth decline in six months and yet another sign that the end of the recession is not in sight.

title: BONN INVESTIGATES SECURITY OFFICIAL
description: The chief federal prosecutor today ordered an investigation of a West German security officer described by a magazine as having arranged with the Central Intelligence Agency to suppress documents in the United States about the Nazi connections of former Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger.

title: Japanese Spending Off
description: Japanese household spending in the calendar year 1981 fell eight-tenths of 1 percent, after adjusting for inflation, from the preceding year, when it was down six-tenths of 1 percent, the Prime Minister's office said today.

title: JET CRASH LINKED TO DE-ICER DEVICE
description: Tests show that the spray equipment used to clear snow from the Air Florida plane that crashed here Jan. 13 may have been faulty, producing a weaker de-icing solution than maintenance workers thought was being sprayed.

title: CITIBANK GROUP TO GET THE PINEHURST RESORT
description: Pinehurst, the luxurious golfer's resort, rises out of the arid sand hills of south-central North Carolina like some desert oasis. Without warning, the bleak scrub brush landscape gives way to emerald fairways and vaulting pines.

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS TOWNS ON REGULATING HEAD SHOPS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that communities may regulate the sale of drug paraphernalia, such as pipes, clips and cigarette papers, as long as the regulations do not restrict free speech and provide ''fair warning of what is proscribed.''

title: VISUAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PACESETTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 2
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $4,375,525 from discontinued operations which included a loss of $2,970,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations

title: Treatment for Kramer
description: The Minnesota Vikings said yesterday that their No.1 quarterback, Tommy Kramer, had entered the Care Unit Hospital in Orange, Calif., for treatment of alcoholism. The team said that Kramer, the latest of a number of athletes whose problems with drugs or alcohol have come to light in the last several years, would be under the care of Dr. Joseph Pursch, a recently retired admiral who headed the Navy Alcohol Rehabilitation Service and has treated Betty Ford and Billy Carter. ... The quarterback situation at Los Angeles appears as muddled as ever. Yesterday, the Rams waived Dan Pastorini, reducing the number of quarterbacks on the team to three: Pat Haden, Jeff Rutledge and Jeff Kemp.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERCRAFT INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
CHRISTIAN COOPER IS DISQUALIFIED
description: The World Cup ski tour came to the White Mountains today, where 49 women competed in the slalom on a bald face of Mt. Tecumseh.

title: GOOD PLANTS FOR CITY TOPIARY
description: FEW garden practices have generated as much controversy as topiary. Although the creation of fanciful plant forms -cubes, spheres, pyramids, birds or animals - has been part of estate gardening since the Roman Empire, it has been both ridiculed and revered through the centuries.

title: No Headline
description: Kings Defeat Pacers

title: Lawyer's Bribery Trial Separated From Judge's
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the bribery trial of William A. Borders Jr., a prominent Washington lawyer, moved to Atlanta, separating Mr. Borders's case from that of his co-defendant, Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's like saying that in the lifeboat everyone suffered malnutrition of 18 to 25 percent, but some would live and some would die because of their state of health when they got in.'' - Gov. Richard A. Snelling of Vermont, on plan to cut Federal grants. (B16:4)

title: FOR ABDUL JABBAR, AGE IS THE ENEMY
description: After more than 12 seasons as perhaps the most productive player in the National Basketball Association, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar could view player-of-the-week honors as somewhat trivial. After all, he was named the league's most valuable player for six seasons.

title: Suit on Sale Of Marathon
description: A lawyer for the Marathon Oil Company argued in Federal court here today that an internal study of company operations cited by some shareholders trying to block a bid by the United States Steel Corporation is useless.

title: LONGTIME BASEBALL EXECUTIVE
description: William O. DeWitt Sr., a longtime baseball owner and executive who was affiliated with nine pennantwinning teams, died today at his home. He was 79 years old.

title: The Spy Bill Wrapped in the Flag
description: The closer the Senate gets to voting on the ''Intelligence Identities Protection Act,'' the clearer it becomes that this bill dangerously exceeds its announced purpose. It was prompted by former agents who break their oaths and expose American secret agents in risky intelligence work. But Congressional anger soon spread to individuals who never worked for the Government but engage in similar exposures using publicly available information. And that, in turn, has raised concern about the possible use of the act against news organizations.

title: WITNESS SAYS MRS. VON BULOW TALKED OF SHOTS
description: A New York exercise instructor testified today that Martha von Bulow suggested to her that an injection of insulin or vitamin B would help her lose weight.

title: Juvenile Crime Fifth of six articles.
description: For much of the last five years, Darryl Witherspoon has lived in institutions for young criminals. He has lived in big ones and small ones, in the city and in the country. He has been in some for a year or so and slipped away from others shortly after being assigned a bed. At the age of 19, he has sampled nearly the entire range of institutions that deal with youths who get into trouble in New York. Across the state, from Long Island to Buffalo and along the wooded frontiers with Pennsylvania and Vermont, there are more than 100 of these institutions that house - and in most cases, try to rehabilitate - young criminals. Some are run by cities and counties, some by the state and still others by religious and charitable organizations. Together they hold more than 6,000 young criminals and have annual operating costs of about $120 million.

title: REAGAN SAYS OTHER BUDGET PLANS WON'T CUT DEFICIT
description: President Reagan, declaring again that deficits were ''a necessary evil in the real world,'' warned today that proposals in Congress to rescind portions of the tax cut enacted last year would prolong the recession and provide no significant help in balancing the Federal budget.

title: NORTHGATE EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago figures are restated

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 4, 1982
description: International U.S. base rights in the Caribbean are being sought by the Reagan Administration. The State Department said the United States wanted the right to use air bases in Colombia and Honduras as part of an apparent effort to bolster the defenses of non-Communist countries in the region. (Page A1, Column 1.) An offer to Poles detained under martial law was announced by the authorities. They said that the detainees could apply to leave the country permanently with their families. At least 4,000 people are under detention, according to official figures. (A1:5.)

title: MAINE NEWSPAPER TESTS CANADIAN COURT CURB
description: A reporter for a Maine newspaper is facing criminal charges in Canada for writing about a pretrial hearing in a Canadian murder case after a judge barred news reports about the proceeding.

title: FEB. 21-28 AUTO SALES FELL 26.9%
description: Despite price rebate programs, new car sales by the nation's Big Three manufacturers declined 26.9 percent in the final 10 days of February, largely because of a 35.3 percent slide by General Motors, the No.1 domestic auto maker. Ford's sales were down 10.5 percent and Chrysler's fell 8.2 percent.

title: PETROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Chancellor of Duke Named
description: Dr. Keith Brodie, a professor of psychiatry and a member of the law school faculty, will become the new chancellor of Duke University. The board of trustees approved the appointment on the recommendation of Duke's president, Terry Sanford. Dr. Brodie, 42 years old, will take office July 1, succeeding A. Kenneth Pye, who will return to the law school faculty and will direct international studies at Duke.

title: Big Labor Settles for Less
description: It's been a dramatic week for American labor. The auto workers at Ford swallowed their pride and ratified a contract revision that gives up wage increases in return for job protection. Then the oncemighty Teamsters approved a contract that settles for modest improvements in wages and benefits without even the guarantee that this will save jobs.

title: TAKING THE CREAKS OUT OF OLD RECORDS
description: IN the current climate of cultural nostalgia, record collectors comb attics and antiques shops for those long-forgotten records that summon up the sounds of yesteryear. Opera fans rediscover the bygone glories of Lauritz Melchior and Lily Pons, while others revive youthful memories with audible mementos of Glenn Miller, Tommy Dorsey, early Sinatra or maybe the Andrews Sisters.

title: OPEC SETS REVIEW OF OIL MARKET
description: The president of OPEC, reacting in part to Britain's big cut in its oil prices on Tuesday, said today that the oil group would hold a consultative meeting this month to discuss the effect on prices of a worldwide oversupply of oil, according to reports from Abu Dhabi.

title: PIANO: SCHENLY PLAYS MUSSORGSKY
description: PAUL SCHENLY'S piano recital in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night was uncommonly satisfying for a listener not needing to be dazzled constantly by technical bravura and thundering sound.

title: SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: Ron Jackson, a free-agent first baseman, has changed his mind about rejoining the Detroit Tigers for a reported guaranteed salary of $250,000 a year. Jackson says he wants a better offer. ... Alexis Arguello of Nicaragua, who won the World Boxing Council's lightweight title last June, will make his fourth defense April 3 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: POP: STEVE ALLEN, PIANIST
description: WHEN Steve Allen sat down at the piano for his opening set of a two-week run at Michael's Pub on Tuesday evening, he promised that he would not be funny - ''Just,'' he added, ''as Woody Allen is not funny on Monday nights,'' a reference to Mr. Allen's weekly appearances at the Pub as a jazz clarinetist.

title: ERIC FLOYD KEEPS OPPONENTS AWAKE
description: For the leading scorer in Georgetown basketball history, there is a small identity problem. His given name is Eric, but years ago, when as a Little Leaguer in Gastonia, N.C., he appeared inattentive as a baseball flew past him, another name was born.

title: NBC News Appoints Pettit Vice President
description: NBC has named Tom Pettit, Washington correspondent since 1959, as executive vice president of NBC News.

title: WALBAR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUNSHINE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including adjustment for deferred tax benefit of $595,000

title: Truck Overturns Near Tunnel
description: Morning rush-hour traffic on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway was blocked for four hours yesterday when a tractor-trailer truck loaded with slaughtered beef cattle overturned near the Battery Tunnel. The driver, James Strife of Holland Patent, N.Y., was making a turn at 5:15 A.M. when the accident happened, the police said.

title: SEARS OFF IN QUARTER; FULL YEAR UP 6.6%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company reported yesterday that net income slipped 1.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, while revenues advanced 5.3 percent. It said higher income expense was a major factor.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: SEVERAL products have been introduced recently to promote luxurious bathing at a modest price. To create the atmosphere of a steam bath without building one, there are two attachments that replace the typical shower head.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by saings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A Race Track Strikes It Rich
description: Hollywood Park, which made a $4 million profit on horse racing in 1980, could earn millions more from oil discovered on its 335-acre property.

title: SPEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $149,021 from discontinued operations

title: Nelson Ogden, 92, Manager Of Naval Equipment Concern
description: Nelson Ogden, former general manager of the Kingsbury Machine Works of Frankfurt, Pa., a naval equipment manufacturer, died Sunday at All Saints Hospital in Philadelphia, where he made his home. He was 92 years old.

title: THIEVES TEAR HOLES IN 2 WALLS AND STEAL $100,000 IN STAMPS
description: Thieves tunneled through two walls on the floor occupied by a major philatelic auction house on the East Side and stole stamps worth $100,000, Robert A. Siegel, president of the concern, said yesterday.

title: 3 SIESED IN WOUNDING OF DETECTIVE
description: Two teen-age brothers were arrested in Puerto Rico yesterday in the slaying 11 days ago of an off-duty police officer in the Bronx, the police said.

title: CHROMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including special gains of $1,412,000 for the qr and $1,570,000 for the yr...C-Net loss...D-After a writedown of $7,596,000

title: SOPRANO: NAN NALL
description: THERE were empty seats at the recital given by the soprano Nan Nall in the Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday night, but there shouldn't have been. Miss Nall is an unusual musician and singer.

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
South African Pact
description: South African Breweries Ltd. said today that it had gained control of Edgars Consolidated Investments Ltd. through the purchase of a further 2.8 million common shares. The shares were bought from Liberty Life Association of Africa Ltd. and its subsidiary First Union General Investment Trust Ltd.

title: U.S., in Reversal, to Keep 45 Weather Offices Open
description: The Reagan Administration, after numerous complaints, has reversed a budget-cutting decision to close 45 weather reporting stations, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.

title: Saving a Valuable Score in the Nick of Time; In the Nick of Time
description: By means of some quick thinking and fast telephoning, John Mauceri, a conductor, has apparently been able to save a valuable musical document that was about to be thrown away.

title: 8 COLLEGE HEADS PROTEST PLANNED CUTS
description: Eight college presidents testified today that the Reagan Administration's plan to reduce aid to education programs would jeopardize the quality of their universities.

title: Valenzuela Rejects Pact
description: The pitcher Fernando Valenzuela rejected today the Dodgers' renewal of his contract and said through his agent that he would not report to spring training until an agreement was reached.

title: CANADIAN TIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a special loss of $17,000 for the qr and a special gain $2,212,000 for the yr...C-Including special gains of $19,000 for the qr and $901,000 for the yr

title: MITTERRAND PICKS HIS WORDS IN JERUSALEM
description: President Francois Mitterrand arrived on a state visit today, offering Israel a highly welcome gesture of friendship and a less welcome message on the Palestinian issue.

title: REAGAN VS. TWO MILLION NEEDY STUDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGISLATURE VOTES REDISTRICTING PLAN FOR PENNSYLVANIA
description: The Republican-controlled Pennsylvania Legislature, spurred by the threat of a Federal District Court to redistrict the state, voted early Tuesday morning to reduce the number of Congressional districts in Pennsylvania to 23 from 25.

title: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $113,000 for the qr and $929,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $271,000 for the qr and $483,000 for the yr; the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: Callandrillo Honored
description: The Big East Conference named Dan Callandrillo, a senior guard from Seton Hall, its player of the year and Pat Ewing, a freshman center from Georgetown, rookie of the year. Conference coaches and administrators chose an all-league team of Callandrillo, Eric (Sleepy) Floyd of Georgetown and John Bagley of Boston College at guard, John Pinone of Villanova at center and David Russell of St. John's and Corny Thompson of Connecticut at forward. ... The 11 head coaches of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Metro South Division have named Riley Clarida, Long Island University's senior forward, conference player of the year.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We had aluminum storm windows installed outside our regular windows, which are also aluminum, in order to solve a serious problem with condensation on the inside during cold weather. However, we still have a problem with this. It seems the storm window frames touch the main window frames. Would it help if I took the storm windows off and put a thin wood slat between the two so there is no direct conduction between the two metal frames? - A.E.G., Falls Church, Va.

title: Union Oil Gas Find
description: The Union Oil Company of California said it made a multi-reservoir gas discovery in the Gulf of Mexico on West Cameron Block 536, 100 miles south of Cameron, La. It said two exploratory wells had encountered five gas condensate zones indicated to be productive by electric log analysis between 6,500 and 8,200 feet.

title: INTERSTATE MOTOR FREIGHT SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-After charges of $6,036,000 from the writeoff of certain trucking operating rights...C-Including a tax credit of $3,042,000...D-Net loss

title: State Sues Concern On Brokerage Fees
description: The State Attorney General filed suit against J. I. Sopher & Company yesterday, charging that it had fraudulently collected brokerage fees from thousands of apartment seekers without doing anything to help them find apartments.

title: F.B.I. REOPENS BACKGROUND CHECK OF NOMINEE FOR CIVIL RIGHTS POST
description: The White House has asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to reopen an investigation into the background of Clarence M. Pendleton, president of the San Diego Urban League, delaying Senate action on his nomination as chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: REAGAN VS. TWO MILLION NEEDY STUDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN UGANDA: VIOLENCE, VULTURES AND A HINT OF HOPE
description: Shortly after insurgents attacked Kampala's main barracks this week, President Milton Obote of Uganda gave an interview, asserting that the assault was an act of desperation that might prove to be his opponents' last fling.

title: Warrant Issued In Brink's Case
description: An arrest warrant was issued for Cynthia Boston after she failed to appear in response to a subpoena by a Federal grand jury investigating the Oct. 20 Brink's robbery in Rockland County.

title: KOCH SAYS PRESS MISREPRESENTS PLAYBOY INTERVIEW
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that press accounts had misrepresented what he told Playboy magazine in an interview he has had to defend almost from the day he announced his candidacy for Governor.

title: 2 Photographers From U.S.  Are Wounded in El Salvador
description: Two American photographers were wounded today in fighting between Salvadoran troops and guerrillas.

title: ARA to Purchase Means Services
description: ARA Services Inc. and Means Services Inc. said they had entered a definitive merger agreement under which ARA would acquire the common shares outstanding of Means for $37 a share.

title: RADIANT TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOME SIRENS ARE SILENT IN INDIAN PT. SAFETY DRILL
description: The Indian Point 3 nuclear plant in Buchanan simulated a major accident this morning to test emergency plans. The exercise was marked by the failure of warning sirens and a hot line, and by numerous communications errors.

title: JAPAN MOVES ON ZERO COUPON BONDS
description: The sale of so-called zero coupon bonds to Japanese investors has come to a virtual halt at the request of Japan's Ministry of Finance, bond traders in Tokyo said today.

title: Under the Influence
description: Hours after he was formally charged with driving under the influence of alcohol, Johnny Carson joked on his late-night television program about his arrest. But he also said, dead seriously, ''You will never see me do that again.''

title: CALIFORNIA FACES REVENUE SHORTAGE
description: State tax collections have declined so rapidly in a worsening economic environment that California faces the possibility of being unable to meet state expenses in June unless spending cuts are made and steps taken to accelerate tax collections, state officials told the Legislature today.

title: House Studies I.R.A. Ads
description: A House subcommittee said today that it had begun an investigation into advertisements that promise investors that they can become millionaires through Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: BILL ON BINDING ARBITRATION IN TRANSIT TALKS IS BLOCKED
description: A bill providing for binding arbitration in Transit Authority labor negotiations was blocked today, just one day before talks are scheduled to open.

title: BIG DISPARITY IN IMPACT ON INDIVIDUAL FORESEEN IN U.S. CUTBACKS TO STATES
description: President Reagan's proposed cuts in Federal grants would take similar bites in purchasing power from most states but would bring great state-to-state disparities in the average impact on individuals, according to an analysis by the National Governors Association.

title: 4 Abscam Defendants Move for a New Trial
description: Four Abscam defendants have filed motions for a new trial based on information supplied by the late wife of Melvin Weinberg, who helped the Federal Bureau of Investigation set up the operation, court papers showed yesterday.

title: Cairo Court Dismisses Sadat Case Defense Team
description: The supreme military court dismissed the entire team of defense lawyers today in the trial of 24 people accused in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat today and announced that it would deliver its verdict in the case on Saturday in an open session.

title: BUSINESS LEADERS OBJECT TO DEFICITS IN REAGAN BUDGET
description: The Business Roundtable, composed of the chief executives of 200 major corporations, today rejected President Reagan's projected budget deficits as unacceptably large and invited Congress to reduce Mr. Reagan's proposed military build-up.

title: AMERICAN MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SUITCASE BOMB CAUSES ARREST
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that an Air Force enlisted man planted a bomb in his wife's suitcase and the device passed undetected through security at two airports as she flew from Washington to Texas.

title: STAGE: FULL 'IPHIGENIA AT AULIS'
description: The production of Euripides's ''Iphigenia at Aulis'' at the McCarter Theater Company marks the American debut of the Greek director Spyros A. Evangelatos. Although the evening has its shortcomings, especially in terms of performance, Mr. Evangelatos has a chimerical sense of theater and appears to be something of a link between the classic and the experimental.

title: Playtex to Buy Skin Care Concern
description: Esmark Inc., a Chicago-based conglomerate, said that its International Playtex Inc. division had agreed to acquire Jhirmack Enterprises Inc., a maker of skin care and hair products, in a cash transaction valued at about $28.3 million.

title: Technology; Municipalities Saving Money
description: NO musical ever had a song claiming ''everything's up to date in New York City.'' It's just as well. New York City is well known among urban officials for its interest in new technology. But, like the rest of the 40,000 or so villages, towns and cities in the nation, it frequently is unable to compete with private industry and powerful public entities, such as the Defense Department, for prompt access to the fruits of modern technology.

title: Peruvians Storm Prison And Free 230 Inmates
description: Guerrillas throwing dynamite and firing submachine guns overpowered guards early today at a prison in the Andean city of Ayacucho and freed 230 inmates, the Government said.

title: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  EVEN in the midst of their World Series celebration last October, each knew he was wearing his Dodger uniform for the last time. Reggie Smith planned to join a Los Angeles advertising agency, but Davey Lopes wanted to continue playing elsewhere.
description: Now these two ex-Dodgers in exile are staying at spring training motels here, only a few blocks apart - Reggie Smith with the San Francisco Giants and Davey Lopes with the Oakland A's.

title: DEVICE MEASURES INSULATION FUMES
description: Homeowners worried about formaldehyde fumes from foam insulation are buying a silver-dollar-size badge that can help determine if they have a health problem.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After capital osses of $655,798 and a tax credit of $1,354,172...C-Includingcapital gains of $606,845; the yr-ago results reflect the adoption of an accounting change for foreign currency translations

title: SEARS ROEBUCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net income includes capital gains and other income of $140 million for the latest yr and $48 million for the previous yr and a nonrecurring charge equal to13 cents a shr for the previous yr primarily from early retirement allowance

title: TV: 'POLICE SQUAD!' BEGINS
description: WAS ''Airplane!'' a one-shot for Zucker, Zucker and Abrahams? Absolutely not. ''Police Squad!'' premieres this evening, written and directed by this threesome (Jerry and David Zucker and Jim Abrahams), and it is every bit as wickedly funny as their movie.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Financial Corp. said it had raised its holdings in Penn Central Corp. to the equivalent of 14.2 percent of its common stock through the acquisition of 80,000 shares and options to purchase 195,000 shares.

title: Mehta to Lead Tribute To Stokowski April 18
description: On what would have been the 100th birthday of the conductor Leopold Stokowski - April 18 - Zubin Mehta, music director of both the New York and Israeli Philharmonics, will conduct the symphony orchestra of the Curtis Institute of Music at Philadelphia's Academy of Music in an anniversary tribute.

title: DOW FALLS BY 10.66 ON BIG VOLUME
description: A sharp sell-off in energy-related issues and growing concern over interest rates and the declining economy sent stock prices sharply lower yesterday in very heavy trading.

title: IMS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a nonrecurring charge of $713,000 representing the accrued cost of an employment contract with the deceased former chief executive of the company; results for the latest yr reflect the adoption of an accounting change for foreign currency translations; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: Term for Mobster
description: A 69-year-old Long Island man identified as an organized-crime leader was sentenced to 18 months in prison on income-tax charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: U.S. LISTS 111 PROBLEMS AT COAST REACTOR
description: Officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that ''hundreds'' of changes might be required in the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant before the plant could operate safely.

title: Women Then and Now
description: Women's search for their own history is curiously analogous to that of adoptees for their biological parents. But adoptees cherish specificity (Does my being fair mean I'm Scandinavian? What was my father's name?) while women searchers look for its opposite.

title: COLLEGE PRESIDENT'S PROPER ROLE IN SPORTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Portugal's Port Pilots Strike
description: Portugal's harbor pilots began a 72-hour strike today, virtually paralyzing the country's ports. The pilots, who have been stepping up action in a three-week-old dispute over overtime payments, pledged to go on indefinite strike next week if their demands were not met.

title: Atom Radiation Blamed For Canadian's Death
description: Exposure to radiation in the workplace is the most probable cause of cancer that killed a worker employed by Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., a spokesman for the Government agency said Wednesday.

title: UPSTATERS' WINTER WEIGHS HEAVILY
description: A canopy of gray skies overshadows the seemingly endless winter in the upper Hudson Valley as the villagers and farmers trudge through their fourth month of snow in a season many are regarding as especially scratchy on their senses.

title: Index; International
description: At the seaside in Argentina, economy casts a chill A2 Sky falls on a longtime British M.P. A3 U.S. returning to Law of Sea Con- ference at U.N. A3 Around the World A5 Pole says a dozen internees ask for emigration A8 Salvador's land program: fervor on both sides A10 Government/Politics New Soviet weapons are cited in bid for arms buildup A4 Governor O'Neill announces candidacy in Hartford B3 Contract talks between the state and prison guards break down B4 Coast Guard opens hearing on tanker explosion B4 G.O.P. leader questions Pack- ard's party loyalty B7 Fink orders inquiry into P.S.C. ruling on 9 Mile Point 2 plant B8 Washington Talk Briefing A16 Selwa Roosevelt, the new Chief of Protocol A16 General Around the Nation A12 A doctor testifies on Martha von Bulow's medical history A14 Southern home for girls sued by former inmates A15 Industry/Labor Auto union and G.M. prepare to negotiate again B7 Health/Science City health officials test and treat prostitutes for gonorrhea B1 New York importing corneas from other states B9 Features/Notes Sports People A21 Notes on People B7 Man in the News: John W. Vessey Jr., nominee for top soldier B9 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Greenwich Village is again a magnet for folk singers C1 Folk dancing available almost every night all over town C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FOXBORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split; yr-ago results have been adjusted for an accounting change

title: Publishers Seek Access To Phone System Lines
description: Even though the Bell System is to be broken up, legislation is needed to guarantee newspapers access to telephone lines for the electronic distribution of news, the American Newspaper Publishers Association told a House panel today.

title: SANDINIST, ON VISIT, ASSAILS, U.S. 'TUNNEL VISION'
description: Nicaragua's Minister of Agriculture accused the Reagan Administration today of pursuing a policy toward Central America based on ''cold war tunnel vision'' that ignored the underlying causes of instability in the region.

title: BOYCOTT OF NBC-TV AND RCA URGED
description: The Coalition for Better Television called today for a boycott of NBC-TV and its parent company, RCA Corporation, after charging that the television network had promoted sex, violence and scorn for Christian values.

title: AUTO UNION MOVES TOWARD NEW TALKS WITH G.M.
description: The United Automobile Workers, under pressure from plant closings and a new contract at Ford, is moving to resume negotiations with General Motors.

title: European Steel Outlook
description: Steel production in the 10-nation European Economic Community is expected to stabilize at 31.5 million tons during the second quarter of 1982, a spokesman for the Common Market Commission said today. This figure compared with 32.3 million tons for the 1981 period and was unchanged from production in the last quarter of 1981, the commission said.

title: Bank of Scotland Issue
description: The Bank of Scotland Ltd. said today that it planned to enter the United States commercial paper market with an initial issue of up to $100 million. The bank, which is 35 percent held by Barclays Bank Ltd., said formalities had been completed for an issue in the near future.

title: PUBLIC TV TO RECEIVE $5 MILLION
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting voted today to allocate $5 million in interest income to public television stations through challenge grants as a way of mitigating sharp cuts in Federal funds for the stations.

title: ST. PETER'S ELIMINATES FAIRFIELD
description: Iona defeated Fordham, 58-55, tonight and moved into the final of the Metro Atlantic Conference tournament with St. Peter's, which defeated Fairfield, 56-50.

title: Indian Rights, Rediscovered
description: The U.N. delegate, Jeane Kirkpatrick, calls it ''more massive than any other human rights violation that I'm aware of in Central America today.'' President Reagan was so upset he used a major address to deplore the Nicaraguan junta's forced relocation of 8,500 Miskito Indians. And Secretary Haig illustrated his charge of ''atrocious genocidal actions'' with a photograph of a bonfire of Indian corpses.

title: LIBYA WARNS U.S. TO STAY OUT OF GULF
description: Libya will go to war with the United States if American planes return to the Gulf of Sidra, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said in remarks distributed today by the Libyan press agency.

title: LYNDEN TRANSPORT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After gain of $262,438 from change in accounting principle... C-After gain of $279,630 from tax writeoff of the company's interstate operating rights and for carryforward of prior yr's operating losses by Canadian subsidiaries...D-After charge of $338,392 from writeoff of company's interstate operating rights and gain of $262,438 from accounting change

title: One More Grandchild
description: Make that three grandchildren for former President Gerald R. Ford. According to a spokesman for Mr. Ford and his wife, Betty, No. 3 arrived Feb. 26 at Forsyth Memorial Hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C. Their son Michael, the father, is director of student affairs at Wake Forest University.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ST. JOHN'S BEATS CONNECTICUT ON LAST SHOT
description: Chris Mullin's twisting 18-foot jump shot with three seconds to play pushed St. John's past Connecticut, 54-52, tonight in the first round of the Big East tournament at the Civic Center. Boston College scored the last 10 points in a shocking 94-92 victory over Syracuse, and Villanova and Georgetown won easily in the other games.

title: ARTISTS' SHOW REVITALIZES 5TH AVE. ACADEMY
description: IN the period that saw the modernist avant-garde rise to a position of surpassing influence and prestige on the international art scene, it was probably inevitable that an institution firmly and unequivocally identified in the public mind with ''tradition'' would fall into a somewhat somnolent state. For many years this seemed to be the unhappy fate of the National Academy of Design, which was founded in 1825 and is thus the most venerable of the city's art institutions. While its members found a comfortable shelter from modernist outrages and innovations in the academy's staid programs and exhibitions, the rest of the art world hardly gave these activities a thought. For decades at a stretch - in the 1950's and 60's, say - it was possible to feel completely informed and up to date about contemporary art in New York without ever entering the august premises that have served as the academy's home since 1940.

title: S.E.C. EXPLAINS DECISION ON CITICORP
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today took the unusual step of officially explaining why it had failed to take action against Citicorp after allegations by the S.E.C. staff that certain foreign-exchange transactions by Citicorp had been improper.

title: WHERE TO TEXAS TWO-STEP OR CZARDAS ANY NIGHT
description: THE setting was a modern loft in Lower Manhattan, the music was traditional Bulgarian, and the atmosphere was electric. More than 100 dancers, ranging in age from the late 20's to the early 60's, each grasping a neighbor by the belt, swirled around the spacious dance floor of the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, stamping out a dance called the kopcheto. As soon as it ended, a lilting Russian ballad began, and the dancers chose partners for a graceful waltz.

title: Advertising; New Head At Inside Sports
description: INSIDE SPORTS magazine has a new publisher. The magazine yesterday announced the appointment of Valerie Salembier, the 36-year-old associate publisher of Ms. magazine, a crackerjack advertising saleswoman and a lifelong sports fan.

title: Unions to Hear Report On Garden Negotiations
description: Officials of the Madison Square Garden Corporation are scheduled to meet this morning with representatives of the 17 labor unions whose members work at the Garden and tell them how the corporation stands in its negotiations with the city.

title: I.R.A. SUSPECT ESCAPES IN FRANCE
description: Edward Howell, an Irish citizen charged by the United States with conspiring to buy arms for the Irish Republican Army, escaped from his escort at Orly Airport in Paris today while being deported to Ireland from Canada, Canadian officials said.

title: CLASS-ACTION FEES UNDER FIRE
description: Harold Kohn recycles his paper clips, and he expects everyone else who works at his law firm - Kohn, Savett, Marion & Graf - to do likewise.

title: OPERA: WAGNER 'RIENZI' IN CONCERT PERFORMANCE
description: WAGNER specifically designed his third opera, ''Rienzi,'' with the spectacle-loving Parisian audience in mind. It is unrelentingly grandiose in the style of those old Hollywood biblical epics starring Charlton Heston and is peopled with cardboard characters who seem to be unable to express any thought at less than a bellow.

title: Investors Buy Block of Times Stock
description: The Atalanta Capital Corporation, a New York investment counseling concern, said yesterday that it had acquired 1,076,000 shares, or 9.32 percent, of the class A common stock of The New York Times Company.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Poland's Debt Extended
description: A group of Western banks agreed today to allow Poland more time to repay interest that came due last year, a spokesman for Dresdner Bank said. The move postpones from today to early April a signing date for the agreement rescheduling payments of $2.4 billion in interest and principal that came due in 1981. Poland failed to meet a Feb.15 deadline for repaying the remaining 1981 interest, estimated at $50 million to $75 million.

title: STAGE: AT NEW FEDERAL, 'WHO LOVES THE DANCER'
description: ROB PENNY'S ''Who Loves the Dancer'' at Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater is a disarming new play about a boy growing up in Philadelphia in the 50's. The hero, played by Giancarlo Esposito, dreams about a career as a professional dancer, but he is trapped by expectations of his mother, his social environment and racism.

title: West German Jobless
description: The number of unemployed in West Germany dipped slightly last month from a 25-year high, falling to 8.1 percent of the work force, the federal labor office reported today.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: PROSECUTION IN ATLANTA TRIAL FLUNG A WIDE NET
description: Prosecutors in the Wayne B. Williams murder trial went to such extraordinary lengths to prepare their case against unexpected witnesses and surprise developments that they sent investigators to find and interview more than 200 women in the country with variations of the name Cheryl Johnson.

title: No Headline
description: NEW SOVIET WEAPONS CITED IN BID FOR MILITARY RISE

title: Broadway; Langella is joining renowned roster in 'Amadeus' role.
description: FRANK LANGELLA will replace John Wood in ''Amadeus'' late next month, and thereby become the first American actor to play Antonio Salieri. Mr. Wood, who is British, replaced Ian McKellen, who followed Paul Scofield in the role in London and then moved with it to Broadway. Meanwhile, other actors are being auditioned for the roles of Mozart and Constanze, his wife. Peter Firth, who replaced Tim Curry as Mozart, and Caris Corfman, who was the understudy to both Jane Seymour and Amy Irving and then took the role full time, will leave the play at about the same time as Mr. Wood. The trick now, of course, is to keep ''Amadeus'' bright and shiny. It is one of the few straight plays in recent seasons to become a hit, and even now, 15 months after it opened, it does fine business while other plays close all about it.

title: Javits, in Florida, Taken to Hospital
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits was stricken by ''respiratory distress'' yesterday while vacationing in West Palm Beach, Fla., and was taken by ambulance to St. Mary's Hospital.

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 5, 1982; The Economy
description: The F.C.C. agreed to let TV stations broadcast at low power. The decision could lead to the licensing of 3,000 to 4,000 new stations across the nation in the next three years. The stations would have a radius of only 10 to 15 miles. But they could be linked by satellite, creating new networks that could compete with the existing networks. (Page A1.) The F.C.C. also refused to consider a proposal to prohibit co-ownership of AM and FM radio stations in the same city. (D.5)

title: HOME'S EX-INMATES TELL OF BEATINGS
description: Former residents of a ''Christian home'' for troubled girls have asserted in a lawsuit here that they were beaten, denied adequate meals and ''brainwashed.''

title: WILSON, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd paid July 24, 1981

title: HUDSON HOAGLAND, PIONEERED IN STUDIES OF THE BRAIN'S WAVES
description: Dr. Hudson Hoagland, a leader in neuroendocrinology who helped start a foundation that developed the birth control pill, died today. He was 82 years old.

title: SCREEN: SOVIET 'LOVE AND LIES'
description: MOST of ''Love and Lies'' is set at an apartment complex near Moscow, where a placard announces that the local drama troupe is putting on a play. A subtitle on this new Russian film maintains, somewhat improbably, that the play is ''West Side Story.'' In any case, the placard signals that this will be a story of star-crossed young love. Such tales are hardly rare, and the details of this one aren't altogether fresh, but its setting should hold the interest of American audiences.

title: McCLANAHAN AND THE SYSTEM
description: WHEN his career stumbled again this winter, Rob McClanahan allowed himself to dream about the Rangers. There was no sentiment in the dream, no misty nostalgia for the days in Lake Placid when he and Dave Silk and Mark Pavelich all won Olympic gold medals.

title: OF CITICORP AND THE S.E.C. COMMISSIONER
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Manager Testifies About Stouffer's Fire
description: Eric Ewoldt, who was general manager of the Stouffer's Inn near here when 26 executives died in a fire, testified today about the apparent speed and intensity of the blaze.

title: Cabell for Summers
description: In a move to bolster their right-handed hitting, the Detroit Tigers yesterday acquired Enos Cabell and a player to be named later from the Giants for Champ Summers, a 33-year-old outfielder. Cabell, 32, who played for Baltimore, Houston and San Francisco, can play at either corner of the infield, but he became expendable to the Giants, who needed outfield help, when they signed Reggie Smith, a former star right fielder whose frequent injuries will apparently limit him to first base in San Francisco.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 23
News Summary; FRIDAY, MARCH 5, 1982
description: International The Administration was challenged to prove its contention that the Salvadoran insurgents were being directed by foreigners. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. replied at a House hearing that a ''a Nicaraguan military man'' who was helping to run the guerrilla operation was captured yesterday in El Salvador. (Page A1, Col. 6.) A Nicaraguan leader denied that rebel forces in El Salvador were being financed, armed or directed by foreign advisers based in Nicaragua. Jaime Wheelock Roman, Nicaragua's Minister of Agriculture, charged that the Reagan Administration was ignoring the basic causes of instability in Central America. (A9:1-3.)

title: Columbia Is Ready to Roar
description: Just inside the entrance to the Marcellus Hartley Dodge Physical Fitness Center, there had been a line for more than two hours when Buddy Mahar, the Columbia basketball coach, arrived for work at 11 o'clock Monday morning.

title: MUSIC WORLD HONORS BASIE AT MUSIC HALL SUNDAY NIGHT
description: ALTHOUGH the differences between contemporary pop-soul music and swing are enormous, there also is a striking continuity between these traditions. As Quincy Jones, the producer-arranger who won five Grammy awards last week, points out, dance music at the height of the disco boom and dance music during the peak years of swing, share a solid ''four-to-the-floor'' beat.

title: HAIG SAYS CAPTIVE PROVES NICARAGUA HAS SALVADOR ROLE
description: Challenged to prove his contention that the Salvadoran insurgents were being directed by foreigners, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. told a House committee this afternoon that a ''Nicaraguan military man'' who was helping run the guerrilla operation had been captured today in El Salvador.

title: Gophers Gains N.C.A.A. Berth
description: Minnesota beat Michigan State, 54-51, tonight and gained an automatic berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship as the Big Ten representative.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Home Section yesterday incorrectly attributed certain proposals for food safety guidelines. Plans to increase the flexibility of the process to determine whether a food is safe and to permit the sale of low-risk foods containing cancer-producing substances were made by Senators Orrin F. Hatch, Republican of Utah, and Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee.

title: O' NEILL SAYS HE'LL RUN FOR A FULL 4-YEAR TERM
description: William A. O'Neill, who was thrust into the Connecticut Governor's office 14 months ago with the resignation of the late Ella T. Grasso, today announced his candidacy to seek a full four-year term.

title: Pee Wee, Kenny and Darryl
description: The Times's series on juvenile crime portrays a dismaying complex of institutional failure. Public schools ignore the early signs of trouble. The police are ineffective; one young criminal boasted that he considered them no more than ''pests.'' Family courts are overwhelmed, entangled in red tape and lacking programs to deal with the chaos that passes through their revolving doors each day. Nor do criminologists offer any answers. No one knows, even in theory, how society should try to reduce juvenile crime.

title: MITTERRAND URGES PALESTINIAN STATE
description: President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Menachem Begin aired their differences over the Palestinian issue publicly but cordially today as the French leader conducted an intensive series of meetings and appearances during his second day in Israel.

title: 2 Papers Seek Early Talks
description: The city's two daily newspapers have asked their unions to negotiate new three-year contracts more than a year before the current contracts expire. Don Kummer, administrative officer of the Detroit Newspaper Guild, said the publishers of The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press did not threaten layoffs or specify what concessions they might seek.

title: No Headline
description: POLE SAYS A DOZEN OF 4,000 DETAINEES CHOOSE EXILE

title: ELLMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
THOMSON NEWSPAPERS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $3,804,870...C-After a special charge of $7,677,022; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: Pan Am Nominates A Unionist to Board
description: Following up on a provision of an agreement on wage cuts that was signed last fall with most of its major labor unions, Pan American World Airways yesterday nominated to its board of directors Robert L. Gould, a 43-year-old pilot and union official. Mr. Gould, a first officer who flies Boeing 747 jumbo jets from his base at Kennedy Airport in New York, will be added to the management slate of 15 directors who will be presented to stockholders at their May 11 meeting.

title: 'EVIL UNDER SUN,' NEW CHRISTIE
description: THE setting is an island in the Adriatic and a small, exquisite, extremely expensive resort hotel that once was the summer palace of the reigning king of Tyrania. It's the late 1930's, just about the time of the Anschluss, though no one at the hotel could care less about Hitler, National Socialism, Austria's sovereignty or an era's imminent end. They're all too busy with their intramural assaults on friendship, marriage, reputation, character and, when pushed to the limits, life itself.

title: Funds' Assets Rise Slightly
description: The assets of 174 money market funds, including two new ones, rose $133 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $186.36 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The institute said that individual investors accounted for the modest increase, while institutional investors moved money out of the funds and into shortterm securities to get higher yields.

title: EL SALVADOR'S LAND PROGRAM: FERVOR ON BOTH SIDES
description: It has been two years since the Government of El Salvador, facing a leftist-led insurrection and under pressure from the United States, announced what President Reagan recently called an ''unprecedented'' land redistribution program.

title: TROUBLED SYSTEM OF JUSTICE AND CITY'S TROUBLED YOUTH
description: In a series of articles this week, The New York Times has examined the field of juvenile delinquency, exploring the lives of a series of adolescent offenders and assessing the efforts of courts, schools, the police and the many public and private institutions that house and seek to rehabilitate delinquents.

title: TECHAMERICA GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Economic Scene; What Causes A Depression?
description: FINANCIAL markets are haunted these days by the threat of depression. While there is no standard quantitative definition of depression, it signifies a spell of high unemployment and idle industrial capacity lasting for several years and more likely to be marked by falling prices than inflation.

title: NEW YORK GLITTERS AT NEWTON OPENING
description: For more than 300 New Yorkers, the Marlborough Gallery at 40 West 57th Street was the place to be Wednesday night - at least from 6:30 until 8. The occasion was the opening of Helmut Newton's photography exhibition, and a show by Mr. Newton, whose new book, ''Big Nudes,'' will be published this spring, doesn't happen every day.

title: FOR PROTOCOL: 'A 4th OF JULY AMERICAN'
description: Evan Dobelle, who held the position for part of the Carter Administration, used to compare being the United States Chief of Protocol to being the mayor of a small city - except, he would add, ''you don't get the 3 A.M. phone calls about getting out the snowplows.''

title: Japanese News Official Dies
description: Shinkichi Iwanaga, former executive director of Kyodo news agency, died of cancer at a hospital today, Kyodo said.

title: Pistons 122, Bulls 97
description: Terry Tyler's shooting and Bill Laimbeer's rebounding led Detroit. The victory gave the Pistons the season series with Chicago, 6-0, helped their chances of making the playoffs in the Eastern Conference and ended the Bulls' four-game winning streak.

title: At the Movies; Busy director turns out his first movie.
description: ''I'M DANCING as Fast as I Can,'' starring Jill Clayburgh as a television producer hooked on Valium, opens today (For a review, see page C10), and since it is the director Jack Hofsiss' first movie, he's nervous. ''But I'm in the middle of doing a play,'' he says, ''and I'm really happy about that. Because I'm not sitting by my telephone waiting for someone to call and say, 'I was at the screening last night and -' ''

title: Landlord Jailed; Term 'Indefinite'
description: A Bronx landlord was jailed and told he would not be released until he had corrected violations in four buildings, city officials announced.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard KAHAWA. By Donald E. Westlake. 459 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Home Products Corp. said the waiting period under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act applicable to its intended acquisition of 14,166,666 shares of Brunswick Corp. had expired with no request from the Justice Department or the F.T.C. for additional information.

title: TV Weekend; SERIES ON TOUGH GUYS WITH FEELINGS
description: DOES anyone ever ask television's policemen ''Hey, officer, are you having a nice day?'' Does anyone ever wonder whether these hardboiled heroes are happy, lonely or blue? Does anyone care? Maybe no one did previously, but these days a TV cop's feelings are liable to be explored. ''Chicago Story,'' a cop-doctor-lawyer series that will have its premiere tomorrow night at 8:30 on WNBC, is full of tough guys who inquire about one another's sensitive thoughts at the drop of a hat - even quicker than you can say ''Hill Street Blues.''

title: New Award to Honor Envoys' Wives
description: ''Avis Bohlen stood out as a remarkable human being, and whether she was living in Moscow, or Paris, of the Philippines, she was always the right kind of American abroad, representing the best that America has to offer,'' Pamela Harriman said yesterday.

title: Scientific American Loses Data Decision
description: The consumer magazine committee of the American Association of Advertising Agencies has concluded that the data it considered necessary to judge demographic editions of magazines were already in the hands of publishers, who have not properly communicated the fact that it existed to the people who buy media. This follows meetings with C. John Kirby, ad director of Scientific American, and representatives of news magazines.

title: DIXON, JOSEPH, CRUCIBLE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $1,195,000 from the settlement of litigation

title: ROCK: NEW-WAVE ENSEMBLE
description: based art-rock septet, has been performing intermittently in New York for three years. In that time, they have developed from an often sloppy cabaret-oriented rock troupe whose songs traded heavily in sexual double-entendres, into a tightknit new-wave ensemble comparable to U2 and the Talking Heads.

title: 2 JEWISH GROUPS FIGHT BEQUEST TO P.L.O.
description: A journalist who died last year has left $30,000 to the Palestine Liberation Organization, and two major Jewish organizations are trying to block the bequest in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan.

title: Accounts
description: * The magazine division of the Whitney Communications Corporation to Gregory & Clyburne Inc.

title: THE CAREY-KOCH 2d AVE. WESTWAY
description: ''The greatest social need of adults in New York City is a ...reliable and safe transportation system.'' This is William Jovanovich, explaining why Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, one of the nation's largest publishing houses, is fleeing New York City. That's what many other corporations have done, and for the same reason.

title: STATE CORNEA SHORTAGE FORCES NEW YORK TO RELY ON IMPORTS
description: There was a small plastic box inside the cockpit of Eastern Airlines Flight 32 when it arrived at La Guardia Airport at 10:05 P.M. Tuesday. The box contained a bottle buried in ice to keep an alkaline solution inside at 36 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: THE BUCK NEVER ENDS
description: The moment had come for a momentous Presidential decision. At issue was the Kremlin Pipeline, the natural-gas link to Western Europe desperately sought by detenteniks.

title: Mitterrand to Meet Reagan Next Week During U.S. Visit
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France will meet with President Reagan in Washington on March 12, the White House announced today.

title: U.S. Expands Inquiry In Highway Bid Rigging
description: The Justice Department has quietly expanded into five new states its hunt for builders who rig their bids on highway contracts.

title: 'Cure' Upheld By Stockman
description: High interest rates and unemployment, an unexpectedly severe recession, business failures and record budget deficits ''are all part of the cure'' for ending inflation, the budget director, David A. Stockman, told the United States Chamber of Commerce here today.

title: PRESSURE FOR BUDGET CHANGES
description: There is a widespread feeling among top corporate executives that President Reagan must - and eventually will - compromise with Congress in its demands for spending cuts and tax adjustments that would help close the $91.5 billion budget deficit projected for 1983.

title: Avant-Garde Photos From Germany on View
description: Works by early German avant-garde photographers and a retrospective of the photographs of Heinrich Kuhn form the second section of ''When Words Fail: German Photography from Its Origins Through the Avante-Garde (1840-1940)'' at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street. This section of the three-part exhibition continues until March 21.

title: AMADEUS QUARTET, AT 35, PLAYS BEETHOVEN CYCLE
description: Long before Peter Shaffer wrote a play called ''Amadeus,'' Norbert Brainin, Siegmund Nissel, Peter Schidlof and Martin Lovett had chosen the name for their newly formed string quartet. Thirty-five years later, they are still at it, still making music, still the Amadeus Quartet.

title: NEW YORK: A CITY OF RENTERS AND SMALL HOUSEHOLDS
description: By law New York City officials must conduct a housing survey every three years to justify continuation of the city's two-tiered rent system. A citywide vacancy rate of 5 percent determines that a ''housing emergency'' -and thus the need for rent regulation -exists.

title: VON BULOW HEALTH HISTORY IS TOLD
description: A doctor testified today that the medical history of Martha von Bulow was that of a woman with excessive vices and ''potentially serious psychiatric problems.''

title: JILL CLAYBURGH IN 'FAST AS I CAN'
description: ''I'M Dancing as Fast as I Can,'' the story of a high-powered career woman with a Valium habit, is a forceful and involving film. But it's not an especially revealing one. We never quite learn why Barbara Gordon, who is played earnestly and vigorously by Jill Clayburgh, has gotten into trouble. Although the film describes her illness and recovery in harrowing detail, it simply presents the symptoms.

title: Recognition Equipment Finds a New President
description: William G. Moore Jr., 55, will join Recognition Equipment Inc. on Monday as president and chief executive officer. The post at the financially troubled Dallas-based company, which makes optical character recognition equipment, has been held on a temporary basis by John Lawrence, 71, who continues as chairman.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Monday on decreasing minority enrollment in medical schools in New York State incorrectly reported the minority enrollment at New York University Medical School for 1980-81. The correct figure is 6.6 percent.

title: Epple Sisters Are 1, 2
description: Irene Epple, from the Bavarian mountain town of Seeg-Allgau, won the giant slalom today, and her younger sister Maria was second, as the two-day World Cup competition ended at this White Mountain ski resort. But it was also a day to wave the American flag.

title: Allied Sells Converse Unit
description: An investor group led by management of the Converse division of the Allied Corporation has purchased Converse, an athletic footwear manufacturer, from Allied for $100 million.

title: Nursing-School Plans Changed by Skidmore
description: Skidmore College has amended its decision to close its nursing school so that 75 students who are not seniors can complete their four years of training.

title: WHAM-O MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW MUSIC: ALLIANCE FOR SONG PROGRAM
description: THE Alliance for American Song's ''Voice and Percussion'' concert Wednesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall was full of spirit and charm. It also had its dry and incongruently awkward moments. But the spirit prevailed.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC PLAYS HONEGGER, ROUSSEL
description: WORKING out the program for an orchestral concert is something like planning a dinner for a couple of thousand people. No matter how conservative or imaginative, the menu will be sure to displease some, while others will find every dish to their taste. However, there are certain types of menu that are drab even on paper and therefore stand a stronger chance of failure than others. Charles Dutoit, who is currently guest-conducting the New York Philharmonic, put one such mixture together for his concert last night.

title: Auctions; Faberge From Forbes.
description: FIVE works by Carl Faberge from the Forbes magazine collection are among the stars in a sale of Russian art at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. next Wednesday at Sotheby Parke Bernet's York Avenue galleries, at 72d Street. The five works are a double frame in agate, arched panels embellished with beaded and reeded ribbonlike decoration, containing likenesses of Czar Nicholas II and the Czarina Alexandra Feodorovna, executed by Anders Nevalainen around 1900 and expected to sell for as much as $25,000; a gold-and-translucent-enamel miniature 1890's frame (up to $12,000); an enamel-and-silver-gilt bud vase from 1900 (up to $1,000); a pair of three-leaf clover cuff links set with cabochons (up to $6,000), and a lapis lazuli hatpin embellished with a sapphire and a pink pearl (up to $1,800).

title: A GALA IN WASHINGTON FOR AMERICAN INDIAN GROUP
description: The State Department's diplomatic reception rooms were a colorful scene as American Indian tribal leaders -some in ceremonial dress, others in long braids and black tie - mingled tonight with corporate heads and Washington celebrities.

title: TOLENTINE GAINS, 59-41
description: With 6 minutes 17 seconds left and the score tied at 32, nationally ranked Tolentine went on a 27-9 tear last night and ousted a tough Xaverian team, 59-41, in the second round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship at Mount St. Michael High School in the Bronx.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Transco Coal Deal
description: The General Energy Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its Kentucky coal subsidiaries to the Transco Companies of Houston for about $60 million.

title: Long and Short Rates Decline; Analysts Cite The Economy
description: Short- and long-term rates declined yesterday, as traders and investors continued to buy debt securities in anticipation of further drops in short-term rates.

title: Work to Stop on 3 Reactors
description: The board of the Tennessee Valley Authority voted today to stop work on three partly constructed nuclear reactors that a staff report said would not be needed for the rest of the century. The 2-to-1 vote by the Federal agency will halt work on two reactors at the Hartsville Nuclear Plant in middle Tennessee and one at the Yellow Creek plant near Iuka in northeast Mississippi.

title: RECITAL: MISS PRICE IN BROOKLYN
description: WHEN Leontyne Price sang Ned Rorem's ''Ferry Me Across the Water'' at Brooklyn College Wednesday night, her voice coldly chanted the words' allusions to Charon, the ferryman of Hades. The soprano drew out the phrases, free from vibrato or ''feeling''; she suspended the final tone in a thin thread of pianissimo sound. It was an effective vocal display that sustained the haunted, breathing pulse of the music.

title: Walker's Option Play
description: Herschel Walker says the chances are roughly ''70-30'' that he will take legal action against the National Football League over the league rule that bars the drafting of undergraduates. But he would have to be careful in doing so, says an official of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, or he might forfeit his collegiate eligibility.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Bel Canto Opera Offers 'Simon Boccanegra'
description: The Bel Canto Opera will present Verdi's ''Simon Boccanegra'' tomorrow evening at 7:30 and Sunday afternoon at 3 at the Robert F. Wagner School, 220 East 76th Street. The opera, set in Renaissance Genoa, is a tale of love, loyalty, treachery and political intrigue.

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUBLISHING: A 'LIVE AT 75' PARTY FOR WILLIAM TARG
description: FOR William Targ's 75th birthday, his wife, Roslyn, offered him a choice between a trip to Japan or a rip-roaring party. ''At my age, the trip was unthinkable, so I said let's have the party,'' explained Mr. Targ, a book editor for 45 years. That explains why some 100 friends, former colleagues and well-wishers jammed the Targs' gaily decorated penthouse apartment in Greenwich Village last night. ''The theme of the party is 'Live at 75,' '' Mr. Targ said, ''and we're thinking of having another in five years in which everybody who was at the 75th is invited automatically.''

title: KNICKS TOP LAKERS BY 10 IN OVERTIME, LED BY RICHARDSON
description: Michael Ray Richardson, Reggie Carter, Bill Cartwright and Marvin Webster each played a key role last night as the Knicks scored a 129-119 overtime victory over the Los Angeles Lakers at Madison Square Garden.

title: UNR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $834,000 for the qr and income of $259,640 for the yr from discontinued operations and a gain of $9.7 mill for the yr from the sale of cable-television interests...C-Incl income of $60,779 from discontinued operations...D-Net loss inc income of $345,828 from discontinued operations

title: Sovern Joins Shubert Fund
description: Michael Ira Sovern, president of Columbia University, has been named to the board of directors of the Shubert Foundation, which makes grants to regional theaters, repertory companies and dance companies. Dr. Sovern, formerly dean of the Columbia School of Law, fills the vacancy caused by the death of Helen Hollerith.

title: SIDNEY MASON
description: Sidney Mason, former vice president of the International United Electrical Workers Union, died Tuesday after being struck by an automobile in Queens.

title: FIRST MATE TIES TANKER EXPOLSION TO BRIDGE REPAIRS
description: Construction work on the Williamsburg Bridge was linked yesterday to the explosion last Friday of a gasoline tanker passing under the bridge. The explosion killed the tanker's chief engineer and sank the vessel in the East River.

title: WILLIAM POLLOCK, UNIONIST, IS DEAD
description: William Pollock, general president of the Textile Workers Union of America from 1956 until 1972, died Wednesday at his home in Ocean City, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: DOW FALLS 7.61 POINTS, TO 807.55
description: The stock market was pounded anew in very heavy trading yesterday with computer and other technology issues coming under particular pressure. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 7.61 points, to 807.55, the lowest close in almost 22 months.

title: First Woman Named to Canada's Top Court
description: It took a little nudge from south of the border, but a woman has finally been named to the Canadian Supreme Court.

title: MONUMENT ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
E.P.A. to Reconsider Decision on Dumping
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would hold a hearing next week to reconsidser its recent decision lifting for 90 days a ban on the disposal of drums of liquid chemical waste in landfills.

title: THE BIG LOOPHOLE FOR DEFENSE LOBBYING COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: STATEMENT BY WILLIAMS AT SENATE PROCEEDING ON EXPELLING HIM
description: Following is the text of an opening statement read to the Senate today by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. More than 23 years ago, I stood proudly in this Senate chamber and raised my hand to take an oath - an oath I have never violated - as I became a member of this august body. Today, as I stand before you, I know that I am completely innocent of all crime or impropriety and am therefore totally confident that I will be fully exonerated in the Appeals Court.

title: GOLD DROPS BELOW $350
description: Gold, which has been falling steadily for many weeks, broke through a new barrier yesterday, falling $7.25 an ounce in London, to $346.50. It was the first time in two and a half years that gold has gone below the $350 level.

title: ADMISSIONS TO WELLESLEY REMAIN 'AID-BLIND'
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH AMERICAN ROYALTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FOR EUROPE, A BUILDUP IN CONVENTIONAL FORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Texan Given Probation In Brother's Mercy Death
description: An elderly man who said he killed his terminally ill older brother in an act of mercy was placed on 10 years probation today with orders to work 10 hours a week in a home for older citizens.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Thousands Homeless After Storm Hits Tonga

title: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISLANDERS TROUNCE LEAFS BY 10-1
description: The Islanders wanted a lot of things to happen in tonight's game with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Nassau Coliseum. After beating the Leafs, 10-1, all of their goals were fulfilled.

title: PAKISTANI JOB DECISION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. FUND CUTS REDUCE NURSING HOME CHECKUPS
description: Health officials in many states say that Federal budget cuts have forced them to curtail surveillance of nursing homes at a time when the Federal Government is moving toward relaxing or eliminating many of its own regulations on the industry.

title: LONGTIME BRITISH M.P. LOST IN SHUFFLE
description: Fred Mulley is 63 years old. The son of a common laborer, he left school at 18 to go to work as a clerk, then served as a sergeant in World War II, spending almost five years as a German prisoner of war.

title: U-2 TEST MYSTERY CLOUD
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is preparing a U-2 spy plane to fly into and take samples of a mysterious cloud that is circling 10 miles above the earth.

title: Celtics 110, Spurs 101
description: SAN ANTONIO (AP) - Robert Parish, with 26 points, including three slam dunks in the last three minutes, and M.L. Carr, the reserve guard who got a season-high 22, led Boston.

title: DATA GENERAL STOCK DROPS $10 A SHARE
description: A flurry of selling sent the stock of the Data General Corporation plunging $10 a share yesterday in response to the minicomputer maker's announcement that its second-quarter earnings will fall well below earlier expectations.

title: GREENWICH VILLAGE IS AGAIN A MAGNET FOR FOLK SINGERS
description: THE founder of the Byrds and the former lead guitarist of Jefferson Airplane are performing in town this weekend, but not as members of rock bands. In the early 1960's, before they were rockers, Roger McGuinn of the Byrds and Jorma Kaukonen of Jefferson Airplane were folk musicians. Now they are returning to their roots as unaccompanied, guitar-picking folk singers. Tonight Mr. McGuinn is at the Bottom Line in Greenwich Village; tomorrow night he is at My Father's Place in Roslyn, L.I., and Mr. Kaukonen is at the Bottom Line.

title: Replacing U.S. Attorney in New York Area
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has recommended two possible replacements for Edward R. Korman, who is leaving the office of United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York in August.

title: E.E.C. SEES U.S. RATES SLOWING ITS '82 GROWTH
description: Economic growth in the 10-nation European Common Market is likely to average only 1.5 percent this year, as a result of the latest upsurge in United States interest rates, the Common Market's Brussels-based Commission predicted today.

title: HEALTH OFFICIALS TEST PROSTITUTES FOR GONORRHEA
description: New York City health inspectors have been going into brothels in recent months to test and treat prostitutes for a penicillinresistant strain of gonorrhea that has been increasing in the five boroughs.

title: Dispute Rises on Payoff To Ex-Clemson Player
description: A dispute arose yesterday whether Wayne (Tree) Rollins, the 7-foot-1-inch center of the Atlanta Hawks, received $60,000 in illegal payments while playing basketball for Clemson University between 1973 and 1977. Rollins, who at first was said to have confirmed the payments, is now quoted as having said he never received money.

title: Baldrige Says Japan 'Unfair'
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige last night told the Foreign Policy Association that the United States was in danger of ''losing its position as the world's premier industrial'' power, and that to ensure its future, the country ''simply had to export more.''

title: U.S. IS EASING CURBS ON PLANES FOR SYRIA AND SOUTH YEMEN
description: The State Department confirmed today that the Reagan Administration was easing controls on aircraft sales to Syria and Southern Yemen, even though the two were on its list of countries supporting terrorism.

title: BRIEFING
description: Security Council 'Subjects'

title: RELEASING INTELLIGENCE DATA: A 'NO WIN SITUATION'
description: For better than a year, the United States has trained the eyes and ears of its intelligence agencies on the small nation of El Salvador. That effort, according to top officials of the Reagan Administration, has produced an abundance of ''irrefutable'' and ''unquestionable'' information about arms, money and advice flowing to guerrilla forces in El Salvador from the Soviet Union, Cuba and Nicaragua.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
