description: YANKEES (AL) - Signed Curt Kaufman, pitcher.

title: Phyllis Diller Retiring, in One Sense
description: Phyllis Diller is retiring Sunday -not as a comedienne, but as a concert pianist. Yes, a concert pianist. It's been a secondary career, one that Miss Diller started at the suggestion of Jack Benny, a comedian who used to have a secondary career of his own, as a concert violinist people liked to laugh at.

title: Credit Union Rates
description: The National Credit Union Administration voted today to lift interest rate ceilings on most credit union passbook acccounts and interest-bearing checking accounts. The agency also proposed raising the ceiling on loan interest rates to 30 percent a year.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Alvin Benedict, 58, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of MGM Grand Hotels Inc., effective April 1. He will be succeeded as president and chief operating officer by Bernard J. Rothkopf, 63. The moves will follow the retirement at 65 of Fred Benninger, a longtime associate of Kirk Kerkorian, the multimillionaire who owns about 50 percent of the corporation. MGM Grand operates hotel-casinos in Reno and Las Vegas, Nev., the company's headquarters.

title: HOCH AND SOLI LEAD GOLF FIELD WITH 65's
description: Two little-known professional golfers, Scott Hoch and Mick Soli, upstaged the most distinguished players today by taking the lead after the first round of the Bay Hill Classic. They scored 65, six under par for the impeccably prepared golf course of Arnold Palmer's Bay Hill Club.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mario Andretti and the Patrick Racing Team said yesterday for the first time that they had reached the end of the appeal road and would take no further action to overturn Bobby Unser's victory in last year's Indianapolis 500. ... Commissioner Larry O'Brien of the National Basketball Association said that the Indiana Pacers' proposed transfer of managerial responsibility from Sam Nassi, the principal owner, to Frank Mariani would require approval by threefourths of the league's board of governors. ... The United States opens defense of its Davis Cup title today against India. John McEnroe will play Vijay Amritraj in the opening singles match of the three-of-five series. Eliot Teltscher meets Ramesh Krishnan in the second match.

title: Laker Route Shift Barred
description: Britain's Civil Aviation Authority rejected today the application of British Caledonian Airways to take over the license that is held by Sir Freddie Laker to fly the London-Los Angeles route. Public hearings must be held, the authority ruled, and the process could take move than a year.

title: Yacht Sets Record
description: Buccaneer, the Australian yacht, set a world record when she crossed the finish line of the Xerox Sydneyto-Rio race today, regatta organizers said. The yacht, skippered by Joel Mace of Sydney, covered the 8,370-mile course in 39 days 7 hours 34 minutes 55 seconds. That was 30 hours faster than the previous record for the course, the organizers said.

title: CITY TEMPORARILY SHELTERING OVER 700 HOMELESS FAMILIES
description: Burned out of their homes by arsonists or frozen out by negligent landlords, more than 700 homeless families are getting temporary shelter from the city in a handful of hotels and rehabilitated apartment houses.

title: Ford Robotics Unit
description: The Ford Motor Company said it will open a robotics center in the Detroit suburb of Dearborn later this year to help coordinate the use of robots in auto-making plants. The center will include a qualification, training and development laboratory.

title: CITY OPERA: A NEW RODOLFO
description: THE spring season's first performances of ''La Boheme'' at the City Opera this week brought Jerry Hadley, as Rodolfo, and Charles Long, as Marcello, into the company's production for the first time.

title: PREPARE OTHER PLANS
description: Senate Republican leaders sought today to discount their differences with President Reagan even as they prepared budget alternatives that Mr. Reagan has said he does not want.

title: 3 Yanks Ask: Who's on First?
description: In the Abbott and Costello routine the infield lineup was: Who's on first, What's on second and I-Don't-Know's on third. For the Yankees, the only issue is: Who's on first?

title: PIONEER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
TRANSIT UNION SEEKS 2-YEAR 25% RISE
description: The Transport Workers Union asked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday for a 25 percent wage increase over two years as negotiations for a new contract began. Both sides said they were optimistic about prospects for avoiding a strike this year.

title: F.C.C. CLEARS WAY FOR A BIG INCREASE IN NEW TV STATIONS
description: The Federal Communications Commission today opened the way to the licensing of 3,000 to 4,000 new television stations across the nation in the next three years.

title: F.C.C. Acts On AM-FM
description: The Federal Communications Commission, by an unexpectedly narrow margin, refused today to consider a proposal to prohibit broadcast companies from owning AM and FM radio stations in the same city.

title: News Analysis
description: As the Senate decides whether to expel Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., a second issue runs through the debate: the conduct of the F.B.I. in organizing its Abscam operation.

title: Auto Output Off in Week
description: Domestic auto production this week is down 9.4 percent from a year ago, Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry journal reported today.

title: U.S. IS RETURNING TO SEA TREATY TALKS
description: After a year's absence, the United States is returning Monday to a global conference that is drafting a treaty with rules for passage through the seas and for the mining of the mineral wealth on the ocean floor.

title: REAGAN CHOICE FOR NATION'S TOP MILITARY POST
description: On the Anzio beachhead in Italy in May 1944, John W. Vessey Jr. was the first sergeant of an artillery battery. Next July 1, after 41 years of military service, General Vessey is scheduled to become the nation's top soldier as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: DON'T AID SOMALIA
description: When President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia visits Washington next Tuesday, the Administration should treat him warily. More aid for Somalia, burdened with a staggering number of Ogaden refugees from the war with Ethiopia, and a tottering economy, may sound desirable to the White House. Mr. Siad Barre's offer of a base at Berbera, an Indian Ocean port near the troubled Persian Gulf, may appear attractive. But there is more involved than Mr. Siad Barre may care to admit in his talks with the Administration.

title: YOUTH CRIME PUZZLE DEFIES A SOLUTION
description: Juvenile Crime Last of six articles. By PHILIP M. BOFFEY

title: Market Place; Home Lending In California
description: LOS ANGELES THE mortgage market is alive - but not particularly well - in California. Even so, the Financial Corporation of America here is aggressively lending to home buyers, unlike most of the state's thrift institutions.

title: AT THE SEASIDE IN ARGENTINA, ECONOMY CASTS A CHILL
description: The crowds are here at this seaside resort as usual, for this is summer in the Southern Hemisphere, but the restaurateurs and hotel and shop owners are bitter.

title: REICHHOLD LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $6,675,000 from discontinued operations... C-Net income after a loss of $1,167,000 from discontinued operations

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airco Inc., Montvale, N.J., has elected Brian T. Downing treasurer.

title: FELMONT OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr include a gain equal to 43 cents a shr from the sale of investments

title: U.S. Envoy to Chile Sworn In
description: James D. Theberge, a former Ambassador to Nicaragua, was sworn in today as United States Ambassador to Chile. ''We share with the Chilean people a commitment to Western ideals and values, and my task will be to devote all of my energies to the deepening and strengthening of this relationship,'' he said at the ceremony.

title: Lone Star to Buy G.&W. Subsidiary
description: Lone Star Industries announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to buy the Marquette Company, the cement subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, for $245 million in cash, preferred stock and notes.

title: No Headline
description: KENTUCKY ROUTS AUBURN, 89-66

title:
DECISION FILE;
Auto 'Hotline' Is Expanded
description: The Department of Transportation has decided to expand its ''hotline,'' which has been providing consumers with information about automobile recalls for several years.

title: OWENS & MINOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a net gain of $300,000 or 35 cents a shr for the qr and a gain of $950,000 or $1.10 a shr for the 9 mos

title: Civil Rights Aide Confirmed
description: Mary Louise Smith of Iowa, former chairman of the Republican National Committee, was confirmed today by the Senate to be a member of the United States Civil Rights Commission, succeeding Stephen Horn.

title: GENERAL NAMED NEW CHAIRMAN OF JOINT CHIEFS
description: President Reagan today nominated Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., vice chief of staff of the Army and a combat veteran, to be the new Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: The U.N. Today; March 5, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WILLIAMS PLEADS WITH COLLEAGUES IN 4 HOUR SPEECH ON SENATE FLOOR;
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. took the floor of the Senate today to appeal to his colleagues not to expel him.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; GREAT GOD PAN ON FIFTH AVE.
description: Before humans talked, they used their hands and facial expressions - indeed, their whole bodies - to communicate. That is a reasonable conjecture, and it provides the starting point for a lighthearted look at the history of mime as seen by the god Pan in ''Tales of the Goat-Man,'' which opens tonight at the Vital Arts Center, 78 Fifth Avenue, between 13th and 14th Streets. The full-length play, conceived by Moni Yakim and presented by the New York Pantomime Theater, uses some dialogue and music composed for the production. Performances are at 8 P.M., Fridays through Sundays, this month and next. Tickets are $6. Reservations: 242-4273. FILM CLASSICS IN CHAPPAQUA

title: Stearns Sees His Role As a Leader With Mets
description: For John Stearns, this is the season when he hopes to become a fully mature catcher who effectively handles the pitching staff and inspires the rest of the team as a clubhouse leader. With Alex Trevino's departure to Cincinnati in the George Foster deal, Stearns, in his sixth major league season, is the unchallenged No.1 catcher, and with that status, he says, comes extra responsibility.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Grace Action Noted by U.S.
description: Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, said today that Administration officials had been aware of J. Peter Grace's dealings with a convicted Nazi war criminal before naming Mr. Grace chairman of a Presidential task force to study ways to cut Government operating costs.

title: U.S. Eyes Valenzuela
description: The United States Immigration and Nationalization Service says it is keeping a close eye on the negotiations between the Los Angeles Dodgers and Fernando Valenzuela, their star holdout. Valenzuela, a Mexican, has a permit allowing him to stay in the United States to play baseball until the end of the season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''How can the P.L.O., for example, which speaks in the name of fighters, hope to sit at the negotiating table as long as it denies the main thing for Israel, which is the right to exist and the means to maintain security? Dialogue presupposes mutual recognition of the other's right to exist, the mutual renunciation of direct or indirect warfare, it being understood that each regains his freedom of action in case of failure.'' - President Francois Mitterrand of France. (A7:1.)

title: TESDATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $746,000 for the qr and yr from the sale of writedown of Network Systems Corp... C-Net income; results for the latest periods reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: The Editorial Notebook Souvenirs
description: Last fall, while crossing 42d Street, I slid into a pothole and fell to my left knee. I might have avoided the fall if my eyes had been on my feet, but then they wouldn't have been on the traffic. The scar is horizontal, just below the kneecap.

title: ART: ASIAN TREASURES OF A JAPANESE COLLECTOR
description: THE Japanese hanging scroll reproduced here is by a late starter in art, Sengai Gibon (1750-1837). Sengai was a Zen priest, famous in his day, who took to art in his 60's and before long had an enormous audience. In his paintings, art went on the rampage, and quite often he had subject matter to match - as here, where an immensely fat monk called Hotei is baying at the moon.

title: LEADER OF G.O.P. BIDS PARTY OUST PACKWOOD FROM POST
description: Richard Richards, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that Republican senators should consider ousting Senator Bob Packwood as chairman of their campaign committee because of the ''question of loyalty'' posed by his charge that President Reagan was destroying the party's appeal to blacks, Hispanic Americans, Jews and women.

title: NEW AX, OLD SHIELD
description: The emergence of the welfare state was a momentous development in United States history. It meant that people could turn to the Government to shield them from the insecurities and hardships of an unrestricted market economy. The changes that led to this development may also protect it from the assault being led by President Reagan and his big-business allies.

title: PIONEER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After nonrecurring losses of $1,965,000 for plant closing and relocation costs at its Vogart Crafts Sewing Equipment division and a charge of $2,331,000 for writedown of goodwill and related inventories at the company's Gellman Sewing Equipme division...C-Net income

title: GUARANTEE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: Addendum
description: * FCB International, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, has acquired an interest in Gnomi Advertising and Marketing in Athens.

title: BROADWAY STAGES A DRAMA TO SAVE 2 THEATERS
description: The theater community tried to win a reprieve for the Morosco and Helen Hayes Theaters yesterday. In a sometimes moving, often passionate plea to prevent demolition of the theaters to make way for the Portman Hotel, actors, actresses and playwrights stood on a wind-blown platform outside the Morosco on West 45th Street and read aloud, to hundreds of onlookers, from eight Pulitzer Prize plays. Seven of the plays had been presented at the Morosco; the eighth, ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' was done at the Helen Hayes.

title: BONN CHALLENGES PHILIP MORRIS MOVE
description: Can West German antitrust officials undermine a purchase by an American company of a stake in a London-based company owned by a South African?

title: Tin Price Below $12,775
description: For the second consecutive day, the price of tin metal today closed below $12,775 a metric ton on the London Metal Exchange.

title: U.S. AND ANGOLA OFFICIALS HOLD MEETINGS IN PARIS
description: Secretary of State Chester A. Crocker and Foreign Minister Paulo Jorge of Angola conferred in Paris today and will possibly meet again Friday, United States Embassy officials said.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JONES & VINING INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The shr earnings adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in Jan 1982

title: DISMAYED CALIFORNIANS FIND STATE ISN'T IMMUNE TO SLUMP
description: California, whose diverse economy ranges from agriculture and aerospace to movies and microchips, has long been regarded by many of its citizens as nearly recession-proof. But it is discovering that it is vulnerable after all.

title: A STEEL DRUM FAMILY IN CALYPSO AND MOZART
description: STEEL BANDS can produce some of the sweetest, the most mellifluous, the most joyous and the most uplifting music in the world. Believed to have been invented as a percussive musical instrument by Trinidadians about four decades ago, the steel drum, or pan, is now heard solo in churches in New York or in aggregations of more than 100 marching thunderously through the Queen's Park Savannah in Portof-Spain.

title: CARTWRIGHT'S RECORD SURPASSED BY DAILEY
description: Quintin Dailey scored 27 points tonight to break Bill Cartwright's school record for points in a season and lead San Francisco to a 91-83 victory over Santa Clara.

title: No Headline
description: Scot Lad to Buy 60 A.&P. Stores

title: Bridge: Down in Australia, Things Seem to Be Ahead of Time
description: Since journalists are not prophets, newspapers do not normally describe events before they happen. But the bridge deal shown today might qualify as an exception.

title: STATE AND PRISON GUARDS BREAK OFF PACT TALKS
description: A state mediator met separately today with negotiators for the state's correction officers and with state officials after contract talks broke off.

title: L.I.U., Down by 15, Triumphs
description: Long Island University, trailing by 15 points near the close of the half, rallied last night to beat Siena College, 94-84, and remained in the running for a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: RANGERS TIE FLYERS, 4-4 ON DORE'S GOAL
description: The Rangers took the lead three times and then lost it tonight, but managed to tie the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-4, on a goal by Andre Dore with 2 minutes 10 seconds to play.

title: FINK ORDERS STUDY OF P.S.C. RULING ON 9 MILE PLANT
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink today ordered a staff investigation into the Public Service Commission's decision to allow the completion of the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power station on Lake Ontario.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS FEAR RAID INTO LEBANON
description: As President Francois Mitterrand of France concludes his visit to Israel and the muddy season in southern Lebanon moves toward an end, Reagan Administration officials are increasingly fearful that a sizable Israeli assault on southern Lebanon has become virtually inevitable.

title: SANDSLIDE KILLS SUBWAY TUNNEL WORKER IN QUEENS
description: A sudden sandslide killed a worker on a subway tunnel construction job in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday, despite efforts by firemen and police officers in a cramped space to dig him out with their bare hands.

title: Restaurants; Artful Japanese, Art-Deco French.
description: OMEN is a dish of broth, noodles and vegetables that dates back 300 years in Japan's culinary history. It is also the inspiration for the three-month-old Omen restaurant on Thompson Street in SoHo. In a long, narrow dining room where brick walls are accented by Japanese accessories, Mikio Shinagawa, the owner, oversees the serving of the fragrant and bracing broth dish as well as the light, bright and entertaining smaller dishes that are also on the menu of his family's two restaurants in Kyoto.

title: U.S. ALUMINUM PRODUCERS DEPEND ON BAUXITE
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUCORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
MICHELIN UPGRADES 34, DEMOTES 52
description: The l982 Guide Michelin to France, published today, leaves the lineup of 21 top-rated three-star restaurants unchanged while upgrading 34 restaurants in France and Switzerland. The hotel and restaurant guide also demoted or deleted 52 restaurants.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard Bodily Harm. By Margaret Atwood. 266 pages. Simon and Schuster. $14.50.

title: IVY TO PENN
description: As time ran out on Columbia's surprising basketball season last night, the school band was still playing ''Who Owns New York?'' but for another year at least, New York will own no Ivy League title.

title: AIR FLORIDA SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including pretax gains on the sale of tax benefits of $11,089,000 for the qr and $15,949,000 for the yr and pretax gains on the disposition of equipment and securities of $1,052,000 for the qr and $11,546,000 for the yr...C-Net income including pretax gains on the disposition of equipment and securities of $1,523,000 for the qr and $2,767,000 for the yr, an extraordinary charge of $278,000 for the qr and extraordinary gain of $37,000 for the yr

title: ARAB OIL MEETING SET
description: Arab oil ministers will consult here over the weekend on a possible date and site for an emergency OPEC meeting to discuss the worldwide oversupply of oil and tumbling crude oil prices, Algeria's oil minister, Belkacem Nabi, said today.

title:
Patents;
Fee Rise Sought for Processing
description: WASHINGTON THE Administration is asking for substantially higher fees from owners of patents and trademarks. Gerald J. Mossinghoff, the Commissioner in charge of the Patent and Trademark Office, told a House subcommittee this week that legislation is being recommended that would make the processing of patents entirely self-supporting, half through filing and issuance fees and half through maintenance fees payable over the 17 years of patent life.

title: For Sir Freddie Laker, Still Another Blow
description: First Sir Freddie Laker lost his Laker Airways to bankruptcy and receivership, and now comes what may be the unkindest cut of all: He's also lost his right to ride free on other airlines.

title: Poland Imprisons 2 Priests; Cases Seem to Be Unrelated
description: The Polish authorities announced tonight that they had detained a Roman Catholic priest in connection with the killing of a policeman.

title: News Analysis
description: The battle over the Helen Hayes and Morosco theaters, and their possible replacement by an immense hotel designed and built by the architect John Portman, is no simple landmarks preservation struggle. It does not just pit advocates of the new against advocates of the old, as is frequently the case where historic buildings are concerned. Rather, it involves a possible new building, two old buildings that will be demolished if that new building is built, and another version of the new building that can be erected around and over the old buildings, assuring their preservation.

title: Panel Votes to Censure A Judge in California
description: A judge who is otherwise ''honest and moral'' should be censured because of slurs he made in chamber conferences about blacks, Jews, Iranians, Chinese, Arabs and women, the state judicial commission says.

title: Two Players Charged With Sexual Assault
description: Two members of the Syracuse University basketball team were arrested today and charged with sexual assault against a woman who was identified by the police as a student at Villanova University. The players, Andre Hawkins, 18 years old, a freshman from Malverne, L.I., and Ron Payton, 22, a senior from Trenton, were released on $25,000 bail each this afternoon.

title: Doctor Identifies Illness In Suit as Toxic Shock
description: Dr. Alice Harvey, a specialist in urinary tract disorders at Swedish Medical Center, testified today that Deletha Dawn Lampshire was a victim of toxic shock syndrome and rebutted defense assertions that Miss Lampshire had suffered a reaction to medication given while she was hospitalized in 1980.

title: ONCE AGAIN, CHIEF TRANSIT NEGOTIATORS MAN RAMPARTS
description: The Richard Ravitch who sat down Thursday with union leaders to start talks on a new transit contract was, in many ways, quite a different person from the Richard Ravitch who approached the same task two years ago.

title: U.S. Military Buildup Is Criticized in Report
description: President Reagan's five-year $1,600 billion program to build up America's military power would come at the expense of the nation's economic health, a report prepared for critics of the buildup said today.

title: SUFFOLK OFFICIAL IS FOUND GUILTY IN PERJURY CASE
description: The Suffolk County Labor Commissioner was convicted yesterday of perjury in connection with his testimony before a county grand jury on kickbacks from contracts awarded by his agency.

title: FRANK CAPRA GIVEN AMERICAN FILM INSTITUTE'S 10th LIFE ACHIEVEMENT AWARD
description: Frank Capra marched in to the rollicking tune of ''High Hopes,'' and it was obvious that the American Film Institute's 10th Life Achievement Award dinner Thursday night was going to have some of the overtones of a Frank Capra movie - energy, warmth, laughter and a satisfying ending.

title: Perry Gets a Chance
description: Gaylord Perry, who is 43 years old and only three victories short of joining 14 other major league pitchers who have won 300 games, yesterday signed a minor league contract with the Seattle Mariners. Perry, who has lost 239 games in a 19-year career with six major league teams, will join the Mariners today at their training camp in Tempe, Ariz.

title: Company News
description: The GMC Truck and Coach division of the General Motors Corporation is offering rebates of between $800 and $4,200 on medium- and heavy-duty trucks, the company announced.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: 'HONEST ICE': MORE THAN MEETS THE EYE By MIMI SHERATON

title: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $56,000; shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd to be paid Apr 19

title: TENACIOUS JUDGE IN I.B.M. CASE
description: When President Harry S. Truman picked a young Justice Department lawyer named David Northon Edelstein to become a Federal judge some 30 years ago, the idea did not sit too well with many lawyers because, they said, he lacked trial experience.

title: Can a Free Market Cut Health Costs?
description: President Reagan has a remedy for sharply rising health costs: the free market. He wants to encourage competition among providers for price-conscious consumers. To spur the transformation, he would promote new ways to deliver health services and shift more of the cost to patients.

title: JUDGE, CITING BIAS, ORDERS RELEASE OF EIGHT HAITIANS
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Immigration and Naturalization Service must release a group of detained Haitian refugees within 10 days unless it proved that ''any or all of them pose a risk of absconding.''

title: LOCKHEED TO ISSUE STOCK
description: In a major step to ease its debt and offset consequences of its decision to end the L-1011 program, the Lockheed Corporation said yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of two million shares of common stock.

title: SAUNDERS LEASING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $239,000 or 4 cents a shr from the early retirement of debt

title: RATING PRINTS OF SLIDES AT FAST PHOTO SHOPS
description: The shops abound in the city, individually or as links of a chain, and they promise high-quality photographic processing in the shortest time. Most will tell you that you can deliver a roll of film and have it developed and prints made within one business day. One concern even calls itself 7 Hour Photo.

title: AND NOW, BARYSHNIKOV'S REPLACEMENT IS SIDELINED
description: After Mikhail Baryshnikov suffered an injury to his left knee in Chicago last month, Fernando Bujones was called in to replace him in his American Ballet Theater performance of ''Swan Lake'' in San Francisco. He had to cancel all performances for the next several weeks.

title: JOHN BELUSHI, MANIC COMIC OF TV AND FILMS, DIES
description: John Belushi, the manic, rotund comedian whose outrageous antics and spastic impersonations on the ''Saturday Night Live'' television show propelled him to stardom in the 1970's, was found dead yesterday in a rented bungalow in Hollywood, where he had launched a film career in recent years.

title: Let Transit Arbitrate
description: Although no one wants another bruising transit strike, New York's Legislature cannot bring itself to pass a simple bill that would avoid the confrontation of two years ago. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its union leaders are ready to submit to arbitration in case of impasse. But the legislators have stumbled into a pointless deadlock and tied up the necessary authorization.

title: RAGAN, BRAD, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

Patents;
System to Tell Pilots Of Climatic Conditions
description: A system for telling an aircraft pilot what the current climatic conditions are at an airport has been patented for the Dais Corporation, Warrior, Ala. John H. Whitfield, one of the company's organizers, obtained patent 4,318,076 this week.

title: JAPANESE WOMEN MEET NEW YORK
description: When Reiko Sassa first arrived in New York from Japan, she dreaded her volunteer job answering telephones in the office at her child's school. ''I used to sit and pray the phones wouldn't ring,'' she recalled.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
G.O.P. FIGURE IRKED BY HOUSE FORECAST
description: Representative Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, has accused James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, of damaging Republican chances in the 1982 House elections by saying that the Administration hoped to hold its losses under 38 seats.

title: QUESTIONABLE ALARM OVER FORMALDEHYDE
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN WIN RULING ON FIRE DEPT. TEST
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the physical test for applicants to New York City's Fire Department discriminates against women. He said that a new test must be developed and that up to 45 women must be appointed to the department.

title: C.A.B. SETS AIR TICKET PROTECTION
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday approved a plan under which tickets of airlines that go into default will be honored by other carriers, which will be reimbursed for one-fourth of the price of the ticket.

title: PEKING TO FREE THE LAST OF THE JAILED NATIONALISTS
description: China will soon release its remaining Nationalist military and civilian prisoners, many of whom have been imprisoned since the Communists came to power more than 32 years ago, the country's senior security official said today.

title: Company News; Sedco Favors Marathon Merger
description: Sedco Inc, a Dallas-based oil services concern, said it would vote its stake in the Marathon Oil Company in favor of the proposed merger of Marathon with the United States Steel Corporation.

title: Bridge: Even the Fast Slow Down When Play Gets Complex
description: Most players of moderate experience play quickly - too quickly. They would perform better if they forced themselves to slow down, since the obvious plays they make are not always the right ones.

title: SALEM CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 26
Head of Girls' Home Defends Its Operation
description: A Mississippi Baptist preacher who runs a home for troubled girls told a Federal court here today that ''it is our total being to the end to present our belief in God to young people.''

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE MITTERRAND JUGGLING ACT
description: In a side room at a hotel here, just before plunging into a crowd of French residents who had eaten a 60-foot buffet lunch while waiting for him, President Francois Mitterrand reflected on the two-day visit he was about to end.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $783,000

title: RALLY BEATS BULLS, 107-90
description: Darwin Cook, Mike O'Koren and James Bailey, three substitutes, combined for 45 points, 6 steals 11 assists and 14 rebounds tonight as they helped the Nets rally from a 6-point deficit after three quarters to a 107-90 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: METS GET WINNING DESIGN
description: Today was ''fundamentals day'' at the Payson Complex, with Frank Cashen, the Mets' general manager, addressing the full team and George Bamberger, the manager, separating the infielders, outfielders and pitchers into groups for impasssioned speeches from the coaches about what was expected of them.

title: EDITORS DON THE GARB OF LOBBYISTS
description: Lobbying is an ancient and accepted method of trying to affect what Congress does, but for the newspaper editors who were trudgeing the corridors of the Senate office buildings last week it was still a novel, and somewhat controversial, approach to molding opinion.

title: BRIEFING
description: Looking Ahead, Practically

title: ANIXTER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Business Digest; SATURDAY, MARCH 6, 1982; The Economy
description: The February jobless rate rose three-tenths of a percentage point, to 8.8 percent, the Labor Department reported. The rate, which had slipped to 8.5 percent in January, was the same in December. Last month more than 9.5 million people were out of work, up 280,000 since January and up 1.8 million since July, when the recession began. (Page 1.) New York State's unemployment rate rose six-tenths of a point, to 8.4 percent. New York City's rate showed little change. (7.) Senator Bob Dole plans to seek new curbs on tax evasion, including a requirement that brokers report customers' capital gains profits on stocks and commodities to the I.R.S. Mr. Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, released new I.R.S. estimates that $76 billion in income taxes went unpaid in 1981, compared with $21 billion in 1973. (1.)

title: Mortgages Up to 17.49%
description: After three months of declines, the average interest rate charged Americans for new mortgages rose in February to 17.49 percent, the Government said today.

title: Alouettes Waive Scott
description: The Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League have placed James Scott, a receiver who once played for the Chicago Bears of the National Football League, on waivers.

title: Status of Westphal To Be Decided Today
description: Arthur Stark, an arbitrator, will rule today on the disputed playoff clause in the Knicks' offer sheet that Paul Westphal, the free-agent guard, signed Feb. 23. If the Knicks or the Seattle SuperSonics win the National Basketball Association championship, Westphal would earn $430,000 in playoff bonuses under the Knick offer sheet.

title: VERMONT GOVERNOR HAS KEY ROLE IN BID TO SHIFT POWER TO STATES
description: While others talked of school taxes and local expenditures, a retired local businessman said at Monday night's town meeting here that President Reagan's ''new federalism'' was like the New England institution of the town meeting itself - a way of making sure that government stays close to the people.

title: DSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $227,000 for the qr and $3,267,000 for the yr...C-After losses from dis- continued operations of $203,000 for the qr and $345,000 for the yr...D-Net income

title: JAZZ: NEW WIDESPREAD
description: During the last year, the nine-piece instrumental group that was once known as the Widespread Depression Orchestra has gone through a number of changes. It has changed its name to the Widespread Jazz Orchestra (a method of getting rid of a Depression that politicians might consider) and there has been almost a 50 percent turnover in personnel. The band still has its roots in the big-band music of the 1920's, 30's and 40's but its playing has become looser, more flexible and, with the help of its new members, much stronger and more distinctive in its solos.

title: THE PAPER WARRIORS
description: To the Editor:

title: CARLOS, LONG SOUGHT TERRORIST, THREATENS TO ATTACK FRENCH OFFICIALS
description: Carlos, the Venezuelan-born international terrorist, has threatened to attack France's Interior Minister and other Cabinet members unless they release two recently arrested terrorist suspects within a month, officials disclosed today.

title: HERSCHEL WALKER'S RIGHTS
description: AN American citizen named Herschel Junior Walker is being deprived of his right to earn a living - and by people who say, essentially, that they're doing him a favor.

title: Holdup Man Surrenders After Taking Hostages
description: A would-be robber with a shotgun whose price tag was still hanging from the trigger guard took 60 people hostage in a bank today but quietly handed his weapon over to one of his captives seven hours later, the authorities said.

title: BARRINGER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TIMES OF LONDON PACT WITH UNION IS REACHED
description: A spokesman for The Times and Sunday Times announced late today that an agreement on staff cuts had been reached with the clerical workers' union-apparently a breakthrough for the survival of the two newspapers.

title: Canada Energy Law
description: A program to speed oil and gas exploration and development became law today. The law, opposed by the petroleum industry, the United States and, to some degree, the coastal provinces, provides an 25 percent share for Petro-Canada, the national oil company, in all discoveries not already in commercial production, a move that some in the industry have called confiscation. It also puts federal lands off limits to companies that are not at least 50 percent Canadian-owned.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration, having found the construction of low-income housing prohibitively expensive, wants to get out of the business.

title: MEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AFTER A DECADE, CITY RESUMES PRUNING STREET TREES
description: For the first time in almost a decade, the city's street trees are being pruned and more than 7,000 stumps are being removed. The $1.5 million project should eliminate all stumps on city streets and trim more than 15,000 trees in the five boroughs, according to Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis, who refers to the program as ''Horticultural D-Day.''

title: Petty's Close Call
description: Richard Petty, the Nascar driving star, came within 1 mile per hour of driving too fast and endangering his racing eligibility. He was arrested in Greensboro, N.C., for speeding in a 55-m.p.h. zone. Jackie Carter, the state trooper who made the arrest, said that he had clocked Petty at 69 m.p.h. If Petty had been going 70, his license could have been suspended, causing him problems with Nascar, which requires that drivers have valid licenses in their home states.

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31
Company News; Beckman Merger
description: Shareholders of Beckman Instruments Inc. have approved the company's merger into the Philadelphiabased SmithKline Corporation, with the new company to be called the SmithKline Beckman Corporation. More than 16.8 million of Beckman's 20.7 million outstanding common shares were voted in favor of the merger at a stockholders' meeting at company headquarters. Beckman is a leader in biotechnology, and SmithKline a major marketer of health care services.

title: Company News; AT AILING BRANIFF, SACRIFICES HAVE BECOME PART OF THE JOB
description: Making sacrifices to help keep Braniff International from failing is nothing new to the airline's employees. Since 1979, Braniff has lost a total of $335 million, and many of the troubled company's remaining employees - the ranks have been thinned by furloughs, layoffs and attrition - seem convinced that, without their concessions, they would have been out of work long before now.

title: New York; AS THE SAP RISES
description: Spring is nearing, the air grows sweeter, the frozen parks soften - and our roads and bridges crumble in the thaw. It is good that there are eternals you can always count on. We get disoriented when they change things too fast on us.

title: Satellite Put Into Orbit
description: Intelsat 5-D, the world's largest communications satellite, was successfully lofted Thursday night on top of an Atlas Centaur rocket. The two-ton craft lifted off 53 minutes late because of a problem in the ground support system, a space agency spokesman said. It was sent into elliptical orbit and will be put into its permanent orbit Sunday.

title: NICARAGUAN IS AT MEXICAN MISSION
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met today with the second-ranking member of the Salvadoran junta as the State Department continued to insist that Nicaragua and Cuba were directing the guerrilla operation in El Salvador.

title: ARMY SAYS TANK PROVES ITSELF
description: Army officials said at a Senate hearing today that their M-1 tank was not so durable as they would like it to be, nor was it being produced so quickly as they would like, but that it passed muster in every other way.

title: PRESTIGIOUS LAW FIRM ON WALL STREET TO SPLIT
description: The 50-person law firm of Casey, Lane & Mittendorf, for the last 30 years an illustrious name on Wall Street, is splitting up, an increasingly frequent occurrence in the legal world today. But while its lawyers and clients disperse, no one is quite sure what will happen to the names on the top of the letterhead.

title: Letter: On Judicial Ethics In Defense of Justice Brandeis
description: To the Editor: A major issue presented by the Times news story of Feb. 14 and editorial of Feb. 18 is the ethics of Supreme Court Justice Brandeis's sending his longtime friend Felix Frankfurter, then a Harvard Law School professor, an annual sum of money for Frankfurter to use for social causes of the type they both favored. The editorial brands this financial arrangement as unethical, pointing to its ''covert nature.''

title: AT N.Y.U., HOUSE PANEL GETS PLEAS ON THE BUDGET
description: A daylong parade of witnesses - actresses and college presidents, dancers and executives of major corporations -appeared before a Congressional subcommittee here yesterday to decry the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts in education, the humanities and the arts.

title: Air Florida Reports Losses
description: Citing fare wars and a disastrous fourth quarter, Air Florida, once one of the industry's fastest-growing carriers, reported a loss for 1981 yesterday and said it would restructure its routes.

title: OPERA: 'NOZZE DI FIGARO'
description: The New York City Opera is known for its sometimes dizzying cast changes; if this is an ensemble company, as it likes to think, it must be still very much in the process of gelling. The performances of Mozart's ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' this week, for instance, have seen newcomers in almost every part. There are imperfections and signs of underrehearsal. But it is to the company's credit that several of the performances are distinctive, and the John Copley-Carl Toms production still looks like a production, not a mere arena for individual improvisation. Dramatically, however, the opera suffers by not being sung here in English.

title: THE LAST NOTICE COMES FOR TIME CARD 80421
description: Tubby Clinton left his steel-toed boots in the kitchen, padded over to the front room and handed his wife the little slip of paper.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 23
OPTIMUM HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss on investments of $2,000 for the qr and a gain on investments of $5,000 for the yr

title: BRADFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,570,000 for the qr and $10,129,000 for the yr, a charge of $258,000 for the qr and yr from the cumulative effect of an accounting change, a nonrecurring gain of $3,666,000 for the yr on the sale of real estate option, a charge of $3,110,000 for the yr for equipment lease obligatons and income of $196,000 for the yr from equity in the earnings of an affiliate sold during 1981...C-Net income including gains from discontinued operations of $362,000 for the qr and $1,668,000 for the yr

title: THOMPSON TO WITHDRAW FROM TV BARTER DEALS
description: J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. said yesterday that it would withdraw from the business of bartering syndicated television programs in exchange for commercial time on television stations.

title: Company News; New Malaria Drug
description: Hoffman-La Roche Inc., the United States unit of Hoffman-La Roche S.A., said it had developed a new drug, Fansidar, that will protect travelers from developing malaria while visiting tropical climates. The company said the sulfadoxine pyrimethamine compound had undergone clinical trials at Walter Reed Army Institute of Research and proved effective as a preventive and as a treatment for malaria.

title: Company News; S. & P. DEBT RATING ON FORD LOWERED
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered the debt rating of the Ford Motor Company and its financing subsidiary today, saying ''the timing and magnitude of a recovery in U.S. auto sales is increasingly uncertain.''

title: DEMOCRAT SEEKING SIGNAL BY REAGAN ON TAX PROGRAM
description: The chairman of the House Budget Committee said today that the Democrats needed a signal that President Reagan would compromise on the already enacted tax cuts before they could really work on a bipartisan budget alternative.

title: 4th Suspect Held In Holdup Gang
description: City detectives and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents arrested a 21-year-old Brooklyn man whom they described as the last of four young men wanted for two daylight holdups of armored trucks in which a total of more than $1 million in cash was taken.

title: ANGER MOTIVE ATTACKED AT STOUFFER'S BLAZE TRIAL
description: Eric Ewoldt, the former manager of Stouffer's Inn, testified today in Westchester County Court that he had kept a list of ''disgruntled'' employees, but that Luis Marin's name had not been on it. He also said he knew nothing adverse about Mr. Marin's work habits.

title: NUCLEAR PANEL IS PESSIMISTIC ON GLOBAL INSPECTIONS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded that international inspection alone could not ''reliably'' warn that a country was diverting reprocessed or highly enriched fuel for use in atomic weapons.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MYSTERY CLOUD LAID TO ERUPTION OF VOLCANO NOT YET LOCATED
description: The ''mystery'' cloud circling the earth is not really a mystery, according to a scientist at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration who has been collecting worldwide observations of the phenomenon.

title: Company News;
description: In a new round of fare cutting on transcontinental routes, three airlines slashed the price of a one-way New York-to-San Francisco ticket to $99 yesterday - the lowest level in three years.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE ROSE IN FEBRUARY TO 8.8.% FROM 8.5%
description: As layoffs continued in the nation's heavy industries, the rate of unemployment in February climbed threetenths of a percentage point to 8.8 percent.

title: AMERICAN BANCORP (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ORROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
FERRE'S NEW YORK ENCORE
description: One of the hardest things for a fashion designer to do is to restage a collection that he has shown before and to present it to many of the people who saw it the first time. But that is what Gianfranco Ferre, the Milanese designer, did Wednesday night at the new Knoll Showroom at 105 Wooster Street when, with more than a little help from Bergdorf Goodman, he showed the collection he presented in Milan in October.

title: AMICON CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Company News; Coal Port Halted
description: The Savannah Coal Port, a jointly owned development enterprise, announced suspension of construction on its coal storage and shipping facility on Hutchinson Island at Savannah, Ga. The port unit is owned by Elk River Resources Inc. and Harbert Coal Terminals Inc., a subsidiary of the minerals subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the Amoco Minerals Company. A spokesman for Harbert Coal Terminals said the company would probably seek partners for its interest in the port before construction on the facility was resumed.

title: Penthouse Attorney Is Cited for Contempt
description: The chief attorney for Penthouse magazine was ruled in contempt of court today for a two-word expression of exasperation during a dispute over a witness in the $522 million libel suit of La Costa resort against the magazine.

title: LEAD IN GASOLINE ON THE RISE AGAIN
description: The amount of lead added to the nation's gasoline supplies has risen substantially over the last year despite Federal restrictions on lead use and the requirement that all new cars be built to run exclusively on unleaded fuel.

title: A WITNESS LINKS WORK ON BRIDGE TO TANKER BLAST
description: A deckhand on a tugboat in the East River testified yesterday that ''in my opinion'' sparks falling from construction work on the Williamsburg Bridge caused the explosion that sank a gasoline tanker passing under the bridge. The explosion, on Feb. 26, killed the tanker's chief engineer.

title: Visa's Fund Plan Denied
description: Visa U.S.A. said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission has turned down its plan to start a money fund that would buy certificates of deposit from its member banks. Richard Rossi, a spokesman for Visa, said that both Visa's proposal and Mastercard's proposal were presented to the commission yesterday and that Visa's was not approved.

title: Ex-Police Officer Slain In Attempted Holdup
description: A retired New York City police officer was fatally wounded and one of two holdup men died in an exchange of gunfire last night on Eighth Avenue between 29th and 30th Streets, the police said.

title: LITTON CHALLENGES UNION
description: In an unusual twist on a longstanding management-labor fight, executives at a Litton microwave oven plant are trying to get the union that represents its workers decertified for supporting the striking air traffic controllers.

title: VILLANOVA IN FINAL
description: A neutral crowd at the Big East Conference tournament decided tonight that the Georgetown Hoyas were the villains and that Patrick Ewing, their 7-foot freshman, was the biggest one.

title: North Carolina, Virginia Gain
description: Ralph Sampson, the 7-foot-4-inch Virginia center, saved a 56-54 victory over Clemson in the first round of the Atlantic Coast Conference playoffs tonight when he stretched his arms over his head to block Horace Wyatt's desperate final shot with 3 seconds left.

title: MADISON SQ. GARDEN OFFERED CITY TAX CUT AS PART OF AID PLAN
description: Negotiators for New York City have offered to cut Madison Square Garden's real estate taxes by about 75 percent, almost $3 million a year, as part of a package to keep the Rangers and Knicks from leaving for the suburbs, a source involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: MASSMUTUAL MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Miss Kitty Wants Stronger Warning on Cigarettes
description: She retired as an actress in the mid-1970's, after appearing as the bighearted saloonkeeper Miss Kitty in the ''Gunsmoke'' television series for 20 years.

title: JOHN DICKINSON, 63, DESIGNER
description: John Dickinson, an interior and furniture designer, died Feb. 12 in San Francisco. He was 63 years old and lived in San Francisco. Mr. Dickinson was known for his often surprising combinations of textures and natural materials, innovative borrowing from the past, spare but striking rooms, monochromatic palette and sometimes quirky furniture designs.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on March 4 about Nancy Kissinger's pleading not guilty to a charge of simple assault incorrectly described the political affiliation of the Fusion Energy Foundation, an antinuclear group. It is affiliated with the U.S. Labor Party.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
'MANIPULATIVE WRITING'
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR FLORIDA WORKER SAW SNOW ON CRASH PLANE
description: The man assigned to oversee pre-takeoff maintenance work on the Air Florida Boeing 737 that crashed into the Potomac River in a snowstorm Jan. 13 made clear in testimony today that he had limited knowledge about aircraft de-icing, although that task was performed for Air Florida by another airline.

title: VON BULOW DOES NOT TESTIFY AS HIS DEFENSE RESTS CASE
description: The defense rested today in the trial of Claus von Bulow on charges of twice attempting to murder his wife, and Mr. von Bulow was not called to testify.

title: TV Boycott Coalition Apologizes to Company
description: The Coalition for Better Television, which called Thursday for a consumer boycott of Gibson Greeting Cards Inc., today withdrew the boycott and apologized to the company.

title: JOBLESSNESS UP IN NEW YORK STATE, STEADY IN CITY
description: New York State's unemployment rate rose from 7.8 percent in January to 8.4 percent in February. New York City, with little change in its jobless rate, showed continued resistance to the national recession.

title: CONDORS, IN FOUL FEATHER, KILL AN EGG
description: The only California condor egg known to have been laid this breeding season was knocked off a cliff by the parents, who were fighting.

title: BROOKLYN, STATEN I. TRIUMPH
description: Superb shooting from the free-throw line was the key factor last night as Brooklyn College beat Ithaca, 50-47, in the National Collegiate Athletic Associaiton Division III Eastern regional tournament opener.

title: No Headline
description: Questions appear on page 21. 1. They agreed to play in South Africa, which, because of its policy of apartheid, has for 12 years has been isolated from topclass international cricket contests. 2. Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. defended himself before his colleagues in proceedings to determine whether he should be expelled from the Senate for misconduct.

title: JACK GORDON
description: Federal District Judge Jack Gordon died of a heart attack today at East Jefferson General Hospital.

title: Begin, Feeling Better, Is Returning to Work
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, who fell ill Thursday at a dinner given by President Francois Mitterrand of France, was reported to be feeling better today.

title: Legal Services Chief Picked
description: President Reagan's 10 nominees to the 11-member board of the Legal Services Corporation today elected William Harvey of Indiana University as chairman and Gerald Caplan of George Washington University as president, effective April 1. Both law professors will serve pending Senate confirmation of the nominations. Congress rejected a move by the Administration last year to disband the legal aid agency for the poor.

title: LATIN IS ALIVE-AND COMES IN HANDY
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Opens Fire on Ship And Seizes Marijuana
description: The Coast Guard stopped a Colombian vessel with gunfire this afternoon and seized the ship, 12 people aboard it and 20 tons of marijuana, the office of Vice President George Bush announced.

title: No Headline
description: Kentucky and Alabama Gain

title: Oregon State Athlete Dies After Skull Injury
description: An Oregon State baseball player died today, three days after having suffered a skull fracture in a collision during a chase for a fly ball.

title: E. DAVID ROSEN
description: E. David Rosen, president and chief executive of TVC Image Technology of New York, a film processing company, died of a heart attack Sunday while on vacation in the Virgin Islands.

title: THE CITY
description: A man 50 to 60 years old was killed by a Brooklyn-bound subway train at the Essex and Delancey Street station of the IND line at 7 P.M. yesterday. The police said it was unclear if the man jumped, fell or was pushed in front of the F train. The victim's name was withheld pending a check his identity papers.

title: Hearing on Expelling Williams Is Recessed
description: The Senate last night recessed its deliberation of the proposed expulsion of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. until Monday so seven members could attend a conference of United States and Canadian lawmakers in Key Largo, Fla.

title: Vietnam Is Said to Jail Two Buddhist Monks
description: Two leaders of Buddhism in Vietnam have been jailed in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnamese Buddhists in Paris said today.

title: News Analysis
description: The major question in Cairo diplomatic circles and in the corridors of Egyptian ministries is what is going to happen after April 25?

title: CHINA'S SOVEREIGNTY AND TRADING POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $197,000 or 9 cents a shr

title: The Secret of the Westminster Choir's Pitch
description: When Zubin Mehta planned the program for tomorrow's gala 10,000th concert of the New York Philharmonic, it must have seemed only natural that he'd choose the Westminster Choir to perform in the Mahler ''Resurrection'' Symphony.

title: DON'T HOBBLE THE SUPREME COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: REASON FOR OPTIMISM
description: As I lie here in a hospital bed in my 81st year, I am more convinced than ever that life can be celebrated and enjoyed under the most trying and humble of circumstances.

title: NUCLEAR REGULATORY PANEL REJECTS REQUEST TO SPEED BREEDER REACTOR
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today rejected the Reagan Administration's request for accelerated construction of the $3.2 billion Clinch River Breeder Reactor.

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
EVALUATION RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: In his first match in more than five months, Bjorn Borg will play Vitas Gerulaitis in a five-set exhibition on March 23 in Copenhagen. ... Harvey Catchings of the Milwaukee Bucks and Cedric Maxwell of the Boston Celtics were fined yesterday by the National Basketball Association. Joe Axelson, the N.B.A. president of operations, assessed Catchings $1,250 for elbowing Larry Bird of the Celtics on Feb. 28 and Maxwell $1,000 for elbowing Bill Hanzlik of Seattle on Feb. 21. ... Because bronchitis has interrupted his training schedule, Tony Ayala has been forced to withdraw from a scheduled junior-middleweight fight against Steve Gregory on March 14 in Atlantic City. Instead, Wilfred Scypion and James Green, middleweights, will fight in the featured 10-round bout.

title: NELSON, L B, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MASSEY-FERGUSON LOSS IS NARROWED IN QUARTER
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the financially beleaguered farm equipment producer, reported yesterday that it lost $73.5 million in the first fiscal quarter of 1982 ended Jan. 31, less than the company had expected and substantially less than it had lost in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title:
Patents;
Spacers to Support Vacuum-Filled Panels
description: Richard K. Rathmell, a professional engineer in Ramsey, N.J., reports that vacuum-filled building panels offer excellent insulation but are likely to collapse under air pressure.

title: AFTER SUSLOV'S DEATH, A STRING OF SOVIET SURPRISES
description: The death six weeks ago of Mikhail A. Suslov, the Kremlin hard-liner who stood guard over ideological orthodoxy here for 30 years, seems to have injected a new element of instability into Soviet public life.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MARCH 6, 1982
description: International A high-level U.S.-Salvadoran talk was held in Washington. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. conferred with Col. Jaime Abdul Gutierrez, the vice president of the ruling junta, as the State Department continued to insist that Cuba and Nicaragua were directing the insurgents in El Salvador. (Page 1, Column 2.) A young Nicaraguan detained by the Salvadoran police escaped into the Mexican Embassy Monday, according to Mexican officials. Salvadoran officials said the man was sent to El Salvador to command a guerrilla platoon after terrorist training in Mexico. Mexico said he is a university student and asked El Salvador to guarantee his safety in leaving the country. (1:3.)

title: U.S. Leads In Cup, 2-0
description: John McEnroe survived a penalty point in the final set and defeated Vijay Amritraj, 6-4, 9-7, 7-5, and Eliot Teltscher posted a 6-3, 6-3, 6-4 victory over Ramesh Krishnan as the United States took a 2-0 lead over India in firstround Davis Cup play today.

title: Protestant Militants Lose In Belfast Election
description: The Rev. Ian D. Paisley and his militant Protestant movement suffered a setback today in returns from a parliamentary by-election Thursday in southern Belfast.

title: News Analysis
description: With crime a major concern of most New Yorkers, the reliability of police crime statistics is a vital issue. The Police Department reported recently that the city had its worst year for crime in 1981, but that the crime rate for the year had risen by 2.2 percent, significantly less than the 14.3 percent increase in 1980. Are these figures reliable? How accurately do these statistics reflect the extent of crime on the streets?

title: Gabriel Isaharov, 100; Became a Citizen at 99
description: Gabriel Isaharov, a Russian immigrant who achieved his dream of becoming an American citizen at the age of 99, died Wednesday at his home in Queens at the age of 100.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS SEEKS SCA SERVICES TAKEOVER
description: Browning-Ferris Industries said yesterday that it had made an offer to the board of SCA Services Inc. to acquire the company. Both are leaders in the waste services business.

title: LATIN IS ALIVE-AND COMES IN HANDY
description: To the Editor:

title: The Still-Precarious Eagle
description: One of the thermometers that measure the nation's health is the Mississippi, draining a million and a quarter square miles. And one barometer of the Mississippi's own health is the number of bald eagles that winter along its banks. These are mostly Canadian birds seeking a patch of open water where they can fish, and lately the annual count from St. Louis north has averaged a precarious 1,300.

title: ORIGINALA PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MEXICO GIVING U.S. LATIN PLAN DETAILS
description: Foreign Minister Jorge Castaneda flew to New York today to discuss Mexico's peace initiative in Central America with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: CRAM EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ABOUT NEW YORK
description: This is a story about running, and about altruism, about being handicapped, or maybe about not being handicapped at all. It is a sports story, and it is a love story.

title: Your Money; Bad-Check Notification
description: WASHINGTON WHEN a bank decides not to pay a check drawn on an account with insufficient funds, it has two ways to notify another bank that its customer will not get the money.

title: IN THE GUATEMALAN ELECTION, ALL CANDIDATES TALK TOUGH
description: In the midst of a growing civil war, Guatemalans will vote for a new President Sunday from among four conservative candidates who have pledged to restore peace to the country by wiping out a powerful leftist insurgency.

title: ATLANTIC ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
4 Are Convicted In Smuggling Case
description: Four men were convicted in a Manhattan trial involving $5 million in stolen securities that had been smuggled out of the United States.

title: Union May Ask G.M. Talks
description: The United Automobile Workers announced today that its General Motors Corporation council would meet here next Thursday to vote on whether to revive talks, broken off Jan. 28, on concessions with the automobile maker.

title: IONA BEATS ST. PETER'S IN OVERTIME, 66-61
description: Iona stalked favored St. Peter's, tied the score at the buzzer and went on to a 66-61 victory in overtime tonight in the final of the Metro Atlantic Conference tournament.

title: Observer; SITTING TIGHT
description: Everybody wanted the President to do something. There was no agreement on what the President ought to do, but everybody thought he ought to do - well, something.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We had so many members on layoff hoping to get back.

title: Company News; Pemex Oil Find Is Announced
description: Petroleos Mexicanos, the Mexican state oil company, said today that it had discovered another onshore oilfield in Tabasco state that could eventually yield up to 8,000 barrels of high-quality light crude daily.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UPDATE

title: SALMON IN CANS IS SUSPECT
description: The Food and Drug Administration today advised consumers who have b ought any brand of salmon in small cans to examine the cans c arefully for holes or other defects that would allow entry of b otulism-producing organisms.

title: LATIN AND GREEK ARE GOOD FOR YOU
description: A discussion of the value of Latin in learning English is much in the air. Unfortunately, most of the debate takes place in ignorance of numerous studies conducted since the late 1960's that present decisive evidence that Latin's contribution is significant.

title: Cofield Quits Badgers
description: Bill Cofield Thursday announced his resignation as basketball coach at Wisconsin.

title: SECOND SOVIET CRAFT TAKES PICTURES AND SAMPLES SOIL
description: The Soviet Union landed another spacecraft on Venus yesterday, the second this week, and reported that the vehicle had transmitted new high-resolution color pictures and chemical assays of the planet's cloud-shrouded surface.

title: FIAT LAYOFFS SET
description: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian auto maker, said it would lay off about 40,000 workers from its car division for nine days, starting today, in a continuing effort to reduce unsold inventory. The production cuts affect all Fiat car plants except one, the company said. The company said earlier this year that stocks of unsold cars totaled 60,000, compared with a seasonally normal total of 40,000, making further production cuts inevitable.

title: PEAK STOCK VOLUME
description: Capping the heaviest-volume week in New York Stock Exchange history, prices retreated again yesterday amid investor concern about the recession.

title: DOLE PROPOSES BROKERS REPORT CLIENTS' PROFITS
description: Reporting that tax evasion appears to be increasing, Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Finance Committee, announced today that he was sponsoring new enforcement measures, including a requirement that brokerage firms report customers' profits in the stock market to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: FORD ENDORSES WEICKER AT A CONNECTICUT BENEFIT
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford came to Connecticut today to endorse Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in his fight for renomination against Prescott Bush Jr., the brother of Vice President George Bush.

title: LUISA M. STOJOWSKI
description: Luisa M. Stojowski, a pianist originally from Peru, died yesterday in New York City. She was 92 years old. Mrs. Stojowski was the widow of Sigismond Stojowski, a Polish pianist, composer and teacher who became an American citizen in 1939 and died here in 1946.

title: Italy Blames Soviet For Submarine Intrusion
description: Italy's Defense Minister said today that a nuclear-powered Soviet submarine was responsible for the violation of Italian territorial waters last week. He said the vessel deliberately entered the Gulf of Taranto, probably to gather information useful in wartime.

title: Storm Interrupts Play In 2d Round of Bay Hill
description: The Bay Hill Classic has the most illustrious field of this nine-week-old professional golf season, but it has not had the weather to match. The start of the second round was delayed 1 hour 8 minutes today because of fog, and an electrical storm halted play at 2:23 P.M. During Thursday's first round, play was suspended 55 minutes because of rain.

title: PACIFIC STANDARD LIFE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating loss...C-Including gains of $10,896 for the qr and $37,667 for the yr on the purchase of debentures and an extraordinary tax credit of $182,076 for the yr... D-Net loss...E-Including a gain of $16,127 for the qr and the yr on the purchase of debentures

title: Sweatshops Rise, Chaikin Charges
description: American garment employers face unfair competition because of cheaper priced clothing made in ''the new emerging sweatshop,'' which often uses illegal immigrants, Sol C. Chaikin, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, said yesterday.

title: PROTEST IS CALLED OFF
description: A New York Court of Appeals judge yesterday extended until March 22 the order that prevents the demolition of the Morosco and Helen Hayes Theaters to make way for the new Portman Hotel on Broadway. At that time the full court will decide whether to take up the case.

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BOSTON (AL) - Signed Dave Stapleton, infielder, to a one-year contract.

title: ADDING TO URBAN PROBLEMS
description: Further budget cuts and other features of President Reagan's economic program would make it even harder for the nation to solve its urban problems. In addition, changes in the tax code enacted last year will heighten disparities between central cities and suburbs and strengthen market forces that lead to decentralization of industry and jobs.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SOUTHERN FLORIDA'S CURIOUS ECONOMY RELIES HEAVILY ON THE UNDERGROUND
description: The boom in south Florida came early in the 1950's, when barber chairs had ashtrays, people wore hats and a decal proclaimed from many storefronts, ''It's Kool Inside,'' advertising a cigarette while telling patrons the establishment was airconditioned.

title: DOWNHILL TITLE TO PODBORSKI
description: To the cheers of his countrymen who were crowding the finish line and waving the red-and-white flag of Canada, Steve Podborski today became the first North American skier to win the men's World Cup downhill title.

Lawe, president of transit workers 27

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28.

title: Megan Mulcahy Engaged
description: The engagement of Megan Seton Mulcahy to Stephen William Garvey, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Garvey of Woburn, Mass., has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James P. Mulcahy of Short Hills, N.J. The wedding is planned for next October.

title: Zermatt
description: To the Editor:

title: ON BEING ADMITTED TO LAW SCHOOL
description: Following is the text of a letter written recently by Peter Simmons, dean of the Rutgers Law School in Newark, to an alumnus whose daughter was denied admission despite her parents' gift. The recipient's name has been left blank.

title: BYRD SEEKING TO BAR U.S. COMBAT TROOPS FROM SALVADOR WAR
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the minority leader, said today that he would introduce legislation to bar the President from ordering combat troops to El Salvador without the approval of Congress.

title: TV Mailbag; WHAT'S WRONG WITH LOCAL TV NEWS?; Commercial Influence?
description: To the Editor:

title: ERICA LINDENBAUM IS ENGAGED TO STEVEN TISHMAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Lindenbaum of New York and East Hampton, L.I., ave announced the engagement of their daughter, Erica Dale Lindenbaum, o Steven Tishman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tishman of Hollywood. summer wedding is planned.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE announcement last Thursday by Governor O'Neill that he will be running for a full term in his own right may not have been the surprise news story of the year. But the steps leading up to the formal announcement managed to preserve enough elements of suspense to keep the news coverage flowing at every step of the way.

title: HAGLER IS WEARING HIS MEAN LOOK
description: THE baby had been born just two weeks before and her father, the middleweight champion of the world, had not seen her since the first day when, surprising his training camp, he skipped a sparring session to visit his wife in the Brockton, Mass., hospital. When Marvelous Marvin Hagler is getting ready to fight, he doesn't like being ''mushy, mushy.''

title: No Headline
description: MINNESOTA TAKES BIG 10 TITLE

title: Ayn Rand, Fountainhead Author, Dies
description: Ayn Rand, the writer and philosopher of objectivism who espoused ''rational selfishness'' and capitalism unbound, died yesterday morning at her home on East 34th Street. She was 77 years old and a longtime resident of New York.

title: OPEC SAID TO AGREE TO HOLD OIL PRICES BY CUTTING OUTPUT
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have apparently reached agreement on a last-ditch effort to prop up sagging oil prices and will hold a special meeting in two weeks to ratify it.

title: CONTRASTS IN EXERCISE
description: By Jane Ogle ranted, more people are spending time exercising regularly. But variety is also the spice of exercise. And as women get deeper into physical improvement, many are likely to be interested in more than one method of achieving fit bodies. The question is, ''What works best with what?''

title: EDINBURGH
description: To the Editor:

title: ...AGAINST CURRENT LAW
description: To the Business Editor:

title: AROUND THE WORLD IN 80 TO 92 DAYS
description: SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON is a reporter on the Style Section of The Times. By SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON

title: The World in Summary; Going Bluntly Into Israel
description: The fact that Francois Mitterrand was visiting Israel - a first for a French President - probably was more important than anything he might say there. Prime Minister Menachem Begin evidently thought so, hoping the visit would bring new economic and technological cooperation and thereby free Israel from the Western European freeze that developed after the 1973 Arab oil embargo.

title: THE FASTEST GAME IN TOWN
description: P.S. Wood is a freelance writer who plays squash racquets. By P.S. Wood It may be said there are things of more importance than striking a ball against a wall - there are things, indeed, that make more noise and do as little good, such as making war and peace, making speeches and answering them, making verses and blotting them, making money and throwing it away. - WILLIAM HAZLITT - 1810. True, some silliness attends the sport of racquets, the ultimate game in which a ball is struck against a wall. The prescribed black-tie stag dinner, for instance, held at New York's Racquet and Tennis Club on the eve of the most recent world championship might well have been staged by Monty Python. And surely that irreverent troupe would have carried off to perfection the flap that was raised the next day - along with half a dozen patrician eyebrows - when a female reporter happened through the wrong door of that august Park Avenue men's club.

title: GRAND GUIGNOL WITH MUSIC
description: PINBALL By Jerzy Kosinski. 287 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95. By BENJAMIN DEMOTT

title: ...AGAINST EMPLOYERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: M.J. Shapot to Marry Chaye E. Zuckerman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Karl Zuckerman of Longmeadow, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Chaye Elaine Zuckerman, to Michael Jonathan Shapot, son of Hal Shapot of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Debbi Shapot. An October wedding is planned.

title: Volume Rises On El Salvador
description: Victory in El Salvador, from the Reagan Administration's point of view, will take a lot more fighting there and a lot of explaining in Washington. Last week, despite stepped-up activity on both fronts, Reagan officials were claiming no big advances.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
BUILDERS OFFERING NO-INTEREST LOANS
description: MOST industry pundits say that we will never return to homemortgage interest rates below 12 or 13 percent, much less to the single digits.

title: LIBYA AND SAUDIS RENEW THEIR WAR OF WORDS
description: A new war of words has broken out between Libya and Saudi Arabia, with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi heaping personal abuse on members of the Saudi royal family and drawing sharp retorts from the Saudis' Government-controlled press.

title: Follow-Up on the News; The Hanigan Case
description: In the late 1970's, the case of Patrick and Thomas Hanigan was a cause celebre among Mexican-American civil-rights groups. The brothers, members of a wealthy Arizona ranching family, were tried three times - once locally and twice in Federal Court - on charges of robbing and beating three Mexican farm workers who had entered the United States illegally.

title: Jane Dissin Engaged To Peter S. Knobler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bert Dissin of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Ellen Dissin, to Peter Stephen Knobler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Knobler, also of New York.

title: HAIG AND MEXICAN DISAGREE ON FLOW OF SALVADOR ARMS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Jorge Castaneda of Mexico met in New York yesterday to discuss the situation in Central America. But they disagreed over the issue of Nicaraguan arms shipments to leftist insurgents in El Salvador.

title: KAREN ELEDER AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stillman Brown of West Hartford, Conn., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Brown's daughter, Karen Elizabeth Eleder, to Philip Vincent Spinelli, son of Mrs. Rita Ann Spinelli of Yonkers, and the late Dr. Vincent Spinelli. Miss Eleder is a daughter also of Frank Walter Eleder of Ocala, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: by Ruth Tirrell
description: Ruth Tirrell is a gardener who grows most of her own vegetables. BY RUTH TIRRELL

title: CUTS IN HEATING AID FOR ELDERLY ARE OPPOSED
description: The Reagan Administration's proposals to cut Federal spending that helps elderly poor people heat and weatherproof their homes have got a distinctly chilly reception in Congress.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Omega Ensemble Plays Brahms and Messiaen
description: The Omega Ensemble made a promising New York debut at the Abraham Goodman House Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night. Its members are Peter Sacco, violin, Andre Emelianoff, cello, Jean Kopperud, clarinet, and Doris Konig, piano - all busy and successful players in a number of New York's best ensembles.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC The Blasters call the music they play ''American music'' and leave it at that. In the past, the Los Angeles-based quintet has been called a rockabilly band and a punk-rock band, but they perform obscure country, honky tonk, blues, and rhythm-and-blues songs as well as their own numbers, so the ''American music'' label may really be the best.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Weighty tomes. The pundits who call the past two decades ''America's age of narcissism'' often cite as evidence the raging popularity of books with such titles as ''Calories Don't Count,'' ''The Doctor's Quick Weight Loss Diet'' and ''Cellulite: Those Lumps, Bumps and Bulges You Couldn't Lose Before.''

title: The Nation in Summary; Big Unions Buy Security
