description: When the outline of a federally imposed wage concession agreement between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Auto Workers was released in 1980, Douglas Fraser, president of the U.A.W. called it ''the worst economic settlement we've ever made.'' He added: ''The only thing worse is the alternative -which is no jobs.''

title: JAPAN'S DEFICIT SPURS DEBATE: IS IT TOO LOW FOR COMFORT
description: In Japan, as in the United States, the size of the budget deficit is a touchy political issue and a focus of public debate. Japan's ''deficit problem'' is very different from the American version, however.

title: FLOWER SHOW TO OPEN A PHILADELPHIA FESTIVAL
description: A deerskin hut stood beside a forest thicket, the trees reaching for the sky and the wild underbrush thrusting from the trackless woodland floor.

title: Round the World
description: To the Editor:

title: YEAR-ROUND CROPS UNDER LIGHTS
description: BANTAM ABOVE him, 10 powerful electric lamps were creating an artificial version of high noon in mid-July, causing Dana Mortensen to squint as he spoke of the ''year-round summer'' he hopes to achieve in his greenhouse.

title: The Chevy Blazer Still Resists Change
description: CONSIDER the changes: Cadillac is marketing an econobox J-car. Chrysler's ''big'' New Yorker is really an intermediate LeBaron. The average car has shrunken drastically, and the four-cylinder engine has replaced the V-8 as America's sweetheart. Even today's pickup trucks look like half-scale toys. Detroit is awash in red ink and the good old days are gone for good, right?

title: The Nation in Summary; Epilogue In Atlanta
description: The authorities in Atlanta attempted last week to ring down the curtain on a grim chapter in its history - the killings of 28 young blacks.

title: No Headline
description: As a woman who grew up with the women's movement, I read Linda Flayton's ''Men Can't Feel Guilty Forever'' with great interest. Indeed, many women are still testing their options and many men are becoming impatient. Both sexes are confused by sudden, partial liberation. Linda Flayton asks us to admit our interdependence while admonishing women to let men be. It is fitting, in this era of fundamentalist philosophy, that after a single decade of consciousness, a woman is already championing the plight of the besieged male. Let one woman's story illustrate:

title: Theater Mailbag; DEBATING THE PORTMAN PROJECT
description: To the Editor:$

title: Camera; THE FUTURE IS HERE; by Jack Manning
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a staff photographer and author of several books on photography.

title: HELPING YOUNGSTERS MAKE A MOVE
description: The 13-year-old girl from Batavia, N.Y., looked a trifle uneasy as she said, ''I'll have to get used to a new school and new friends. I'd rather stay where I am.''

title: LUTOSLAWSKI-A POLISH INNOVATOR REDISCOVERED
description: We seem now to be enjoying more frequent performances of music by Witold Lutoslawski and others of the 1960's Polish school than we did just recently. The Juilliard School ended its 1982 Contemporary Music Festival in late January with a performance of Lutoslawski's Symphony No. 2, which in many ways sums up his response to the innovations of the 1960's. This Friday, at Carnegie Hall, Heinz Holliger and his wife will offer the local premiere of Lutoslawski's Oboe and Harp Concerto with the Minnesota Orchestra under Neville Marriner. And on March 25, Christopher Keene and his Syracuse Symphony will present Lutoslawski's Concerto for Orchestra.

title: The World in Summary; South Korea Lightens Up
description: President Chun Doo Hwan's decision last week to reduce the sentences or restore the civil rights of several hundred political prisoners was intended to show how far South Korea had come in Mr. Chun's first year as head of state. It also indicated how far the country has to go.

title: DR. JAMES FERGUSON FIANCE OF IRENE AUTERI, NURSE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore P. Auteri of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Irene Stephanie Auteri, to Dr. James W. Ferguson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Ferguson of Garden City, L.I.

title: Politics; POLITICAL OVERKILL AND HOW IT FAILED
description: TRENTON THE state's Democrats were caught overreaching last week when a three-judge panel in Federal District Court here ruled, 2 to 1, that the Congressional districts designed by the last Legislature and signed into law by former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne were unconstitutional.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: That Man From Berlin S.T.V., Scottish Television, was represented here several seasons ago with the seven-part series ''The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie.'' A new S.T.V. offering concerns one of the oddest and most baffling stories of World War II. The docu-drama ''Hess'' will be shown on Channel 5 Sunday from 9 to 10 P.M.

title: ON THE HUSTINGS, NAME-DROPPING
description: HARTFORD THE endorsement season is in full swing these days for the 1982 elections. At this stage of the campaigns, with delegates yet to be chosen for the state and district nominating conventions, the best way for a candidate to try to demonstrate his support is by announcing endorsements or the names of supposedly influential supporters.

title: How the Mind Works
description: Cognitive studies are useful and, indeed, inevitable (''How the Mind Works,'' by Morton Hunt, Jan. 24). As the construction of computers becomes more sophisticated, attention will naturally be drawn to the workings of like processes in our own minds.

title: No Headline
description: Morton Hunt argues that cognitive psychology puts philosophy back into science. This represents a serious setback for science and not, as we would have it, an occasion for rejoicing.

title: The High Art of Primitivism
description: Hilton Kramer's article ''The High Art of Primitivism'' (Jan. 24) reminded me of my own experience in Papua, New Guinea, recently. After living among the natives in the mountains of the Enga district, I visited their National Museum in Port Moresby.

title: REAGAN AIDE GETS AN APOLOGY
description: A White House spokesman said today that Representative Newt Gingrich had apologized to James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, for Mr. Gingrich's assertion that Mr. Baker had damaged Republican electoral chances.

title: REAGAN WEIGHS VETOING BILL ON ALLOCATING OIL
description: Sometime in the next few days President Reagan will find on his desk a bill that represents a direct challenge by Congress to his contention that the only effective way to deal with a future energy emergency is to rely on the unfettered workings of the free market.

title: The World in Summary; Jaruzelski Gets A Hug; Dissidents Get an Invitation
description: Poland under martial law has come to resemble the Soviet Union more closely, in some ways that are superficial, in some that are not. Last week, Warsaw authorities borrowed an old Russian method to deal with dissidents. The regime announced that people interned under martial law could apply to leave the country permanently with their families.

title: Other Business; TRADE TALK TALK TALK TALK TALK
description: The United States and Japan have been arguing for some time over questions of trade, particularly over Japan's reluctance to admit American goods into its markets and the country's considerable success in opening American markets. Lately, the Japanese been conveying an impression of utmost earnestness in trying to help. Here, for example, is the unabridged January diary of the countries' trade negotiations as published in the Japan Economic Survey, a Washington publication of the Japan Economic Institute, which is, in turn, an agency of the Japanese Foreign Ministry:

title: AN OLD PLAYHOUSE MAKES PLANS FOR A NEW SEASON
description: IVORYTON THE wooden seats were a symbol - certainly of discomfort, and possibly of failure. But now, the director of the venerable Ivoryton Playhouse, in its heyday billed as Connecticut's ''first and oldest'' summer stock theater, says that the old chairs will be torn out and replaced by a new set of movie-theater type seats, their cushions upholstered in gray and blue.

title: WINE
description: BELOVED ZINFANDEL Sava is a sun-drenched town in the region of Apulia that lies on the heel of the Italian boot. There the climate is Mediterranean, with hot summers, little rainfall and mild winters, enabling the grapes cultivated in the nearby vineyards to achieve great ripeness and intense flavors. Interspersed among the vines are trees bearing olives and almonds, but it is the local wine that has put Sava on the map for a certain brand of oenophile in the United States.

title: Administration's Doughboys Draw Fire on the Hill
description: With the President toughing it out in the bully pulpit, the Adminstration's good soldiers were left to slog up Capitol Hill last week, defending the virtues of his economic program and explaining the vagaries of the economy.

title:
GARDENING;
A POTATO GROWN FROM SEED
description: THIS widely used vegetable was so taken for granted that one seldom saw a reference to it. Garden writers almost totally ignored it. Suddenly the unsung hero of the dining table, the potato, is making gardening headlines because of the release of a new variety called the Explorer, the first potato that can be grown from seed by the home gardener.

title: by Harlow Robinson
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Harlow Robinson teaches at SUNY-Albany and is writing a biography of Sergei Prokofiev. By HARLOW ROBINSON

title: Man Dies as Tornadoes Strike Southern Florida
description: Severe thunderstorms and several tornadoes hit Dade County early today, killing a man, damaging 100 homes and ripping down power lines, the police said.

title: ROCKLAND JURY CALLS FOR REPLACING JAIL AND REFORMING MANAGEMENT
description: A grand jury has sharply criticized security at the Rockland County Jail, saying the 54-year-old structure is poorly ventilated, poorly heated and cooled, dirty, noisy and frequently overcrowded.

title: Lendy G. Smith To Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard R. Smith of Chicago have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lendy Grant Smith, to Mark Jeffrey Muller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eddie A. Muller of Baldwin Harbor, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: TWO REPRESENTATIVES OF A VIOLENT PAST AND A HOPE-FILLED PRESENT
description: J ust as the King David Hotel is a symbol of Jerusalem, so two men who are part of the hotel's past and present are symbolic of the violence and pathos of Israel's birth and of that nation's quest for peace.

title: OFFICIALS QUESTION STATE'S ABILITY TO RUN TRAINS
description: ARECOMMENDATION by the NJ Transit staff that the state take over the operation of New Jersey's commuter railroad lines is generally being accepted as the most sensible way out of a tough situation.

title: L.I.U.  Is Upset By 85-84
description: Robert Morris, who is better known in college history classes than in athletics, was a signer of the Declaration of Independence, a Philadelphia merchant who was known as the ''financier of the American Revolution.''

title: Daphne A. Riker To Be June Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. David E. A. Riker of Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Daphne Ann Riker, to Kevin Frederick Hagan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Hagan of Sands Point, L.I., and Woodstock, Vt.

title: Tottenham Wins by 3-2 And Gains Semifinals
description: Tottenham Hotspur, the English Cup defending champions, beat Chelsea of the Second Division by 3-2 today for a berth in the cup semifinals.

title: ECONOMIC DEMOCRACY
description: President Reagan asks critics, ''What's your alternative?'' Indeed, there is a different economic path that has the virtues of being progrowth, productive, and progressive. It is ''trickle up'' economic democracy.

title: PIA ZADORA RELISHES HER STARDOM
description: AT 17, she was an ingenue on the way up, accustomed to being a loner and liking it. But suddenly she was on tour, in a musical in the Middle West, without her mother at her side, and she was confused - and lonely.

title: HIGH SCHOOL RADIO STATION STRUGGLES TO SURVIVE
description: WESTPORT ITS annual budget of about $5,000 is less than half of what Earvin (Magic) Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers receives for each game in the National Basketball Association.

title: No Headline
description: When George Bamberger became manager of the Milwaukee Brewers in 1978, he set out to rescue Mike Caldwell's career. Caldwell, a left-hander who had a 14-5 record for the San Francisco Giants in 1974, underwent arm surgery in 1975, had been traded twice and lost twice as many games as he won in the three years before Bamberger arrived.

title: Fiction in Brief
description: FEVER By Robin Cook. 365 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $13.95.

title: FACT VS. FICTION IN BEIRUT: A REPORTER VIEWS 'CIRCLE OF DECEIT'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Volker Schlondorff's new movie, ''Circle of Deceit,'' (reviewed above by Vincent Canby) uses the civil war in Lebanon as a backdrop. Following is an appraisal by John Kifner, who has covered the war as the Beirut-based correspondent for The Times. By JOHN KIFNER BEIRUT

title: MAKEUP BY DESIGN
description: By Deborah Blumenthal here are probably as many viewpoints on makeup as there are on fashion design. Many clothing designers are in the makeup business, and even those who aren't, see makeup as an extension of the clothes they design. Their opinions may vary, but they agree on a surprising number of points.

title: AFTER 111 YEARS, FEDERAL RIGHTS LAW FACES GRILLING
description: While the fate of the Voting Rights Act continues to unfold in Congress, another Federal civil rights law faces a critical test, less heralded but no less consequential, before the United States Supreme Court. It is the Civil Rights Act of 1871, a Reconstruction-era act that, despite its antiquity, is one of the most potent weapons in the Federal civil rights arsenal. It allows private lawsuits for injunctions or damages against state and local officials, local governments and school boards which, acting ''under color of state law,'' violate ''any rights'' protected by the Constitution or Federal law.

title: THE AFTERMATH OF THEFT ON A HIGHWAY
description: SPEEDING over the Cross-Westchester Expressway to visit the children's grandparents in Boston, we suddenly heard a thud on the roof. After one bewildering moment we knew what it was and our hearts sank. The elastic lash had slapped against the top of the car as a suitcase flew off the roof rack. The suitcase tumbled across the highway like a kicked football and came to rest by a squat metal median fence.

title: SPRIGHTLY NADELMAN SHOW AT WAVE HILL
description: RIVERDALE IT is a small event, the show of Nadelmans at Wave Hill through March 31. But the nine bronze, stone and ceramic sculptures and three drawings are very typical of the artist, who died in 1946, and they come at the right time, on the centenary of his birth. Also, they are manifestly in the right place - close to the estate the artist bought in 1920 and where, no doubt, he made most of them. Besides, the art looks so sprightly, displayed in a room with French windows giving onto a view of the Palisades. Itself a stately residence at one time, Wave Hill is gearing up for spring, and its maple trees will be ceremonially milked of their syrup on Saturday.

title: Donald C. Whitehead Will Marry Nancy Waterous
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Waterous of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Elizabeth Waterous, to Donald Charles Whitehead, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Whitehead of Albany and Peru, Mass.

title: Editor's Choice
description: Irish writer. A BIGAMIST'S DAUGHTER, by Alice McDermott. (Random House, $13.50.) A first novel about a young woman who works for a vanity press.

title:
ANTIQUES;
WOMAN FINDS A CAREER IN RUBBLE
description: ANSONIA LAST Christmas, Edward Reece gave his wife, Darien, a pair of construction worker's steel-toed boots. ''I really wanted a bottle of perfume, but the boots had a special significance,'' Mrs. Reece said last week as she and her business associate, David Miller, dismantled an 18th-century house at 37-39 Jewett Street.

title: DRINKING WATER PURITY DROPPING, G.A.O. SAYS
description: America's drinking water is getting more dangerous, with 28,000 community water systems, or 43 percent of the total, reporting violations of Federal health standards in 1980, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: MARRIAGE TALK
description: Marriage Talk I thought Russell Baker's ''Sound Advice'' (Sunday Observer, Jan. 31) was going to be an article on decaying marriages when he wrote, ''Gradually there became less and less to say. Eventually almost everything had been said at least once, most things had been said many times, and many things had been said thousands of times.''

title: 17 OTHER CONVICTED AND 2 CLEARED
description: Five of the 24 Moslem fundamentalists accused of involvement in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat were sentenced to death today.

title: The World in Summary; Trouble for One' Trouble for All
description: Watergate disgraced Richard Nixon and cost the Republican Party dearly. But a political scandal in West Germany threatens all three major parties, strengthening factions which seek to tilt Bonn's foreign policy to the left and undermining some pillars of the political process.

title: GUATEMALA VOTES BUT IT HARDLY SEEMS TO MATTER
description: Both countries are engulfed in warfare between Government armies accused of repression and leftist guerrillas accused of obtaining their weapons from Cuba. Both countries are holding elections this month. The Reagan Administration is strongly backing El Salvador's elections March 28, but it has virtually ignored today's voting in Guatemala.

title: WHERE HAVE ALL OUR YOUTH GONE?
description: THE recession that is damaging so much of the country appears largely to have spared Connecticut. Data from the state's Department of Labor indicated an unemployment rate in November of 6.8 percent, compared with 8.4 percent for the nation.

title: Theater Mailbag; DEBATING THE PORTMAN PROJECT
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Al Held will be 54 this year. Like every other artist in his 50's, he has a long history that is worth knowing about.

title: BLUEGRASS COUNTRY
description: JOSEPH W. WARD is a staff writer with the Louisville Courier-Journal. BY JOSEPH W.WARD

title: About Westchester
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS TWO teen-agers - one with long, thick hair and dramatic lavender eye makeup, the other in a calf-length skirt and black leotard - are getting ready for a lesson. They go through a series of stretching exercises, help each other on with leg warmers, do a few preliminary whirls of a dance they have choreographed. Then, they begin to sing a recent popular hit. ''Please don't let this feeling end,'' they intone in yearning, slightly strained voices. ''It's everything I am, everything I want to be.''

title: IN INDIA, BIRTH CONTROL FOCUS SHIFTS TO WOMEN
description: India's national birth control program is gaining momentum, and all over the country thousands of people, mostly women, are lining up at medical camps for surgical sterilizations.

title: INTENSE HOUSE RACE SEEN IN NEW DISTRICT
description: THE new Congressional district lines on Long Island have not been set yet, but the candidates are already lining up for what is likely to be the most hotly contested House election on the Island this year - in a new Nassau-Suffolk district.

title: PANEL DENOUNCES WASTE OF GLOBAL RESOURCES
description: An international group of intellectuals that set off a worldwide debate a decade ago by warning that mankind was endangered by overpopulation, excessive industrialization and pollution called this week for a worldwide effort to create a sustainable global balance.

title: THE PHILHARMONIC ON DISK: THE MAESTRO IS THE MESSAGE
description: America's oldest permanent orchestra plays its 10,000th concert today. It has one name - the New York Philharmonic, but its personalities have been many. From the first appearance Dec. 7, 1842, at the Apollo Rooms on Lower Broadway to this afternoon's performance of the Mahler ''Resurrection'' Symphony under Zubin Mehta at Avery Fisher Hall, the Philharmonic has grown and solidified as an institution. Still - as the history of its recordings shows - its identity is elusive.

title: HOW THE MIND WORKS
description: One example from Morton Hunt's excellent article on cognitive science demonstrates a relevant point, I believe, better than intended. The problem of symbolic logic which purports to show the ''creative leap'' the human mind is capable of, by asking which of five figures ''does not fit with the others,'' actually demonstrates something more profound.

title: PUBLIC TO SEE REVISIONS AT MODERN ART MUSEUM
description: The Museum of Modern Art announced its ambitious expansion plan in 1976, and construction began on the vastly enlarged building and the condominium tower rising above it in 1980.

title: Around the Nation; Texas Redistricting Plan Upheld by Federal Panel
description: Citing the ''overriding necessity'' of holding 1982 state elections on time, a three-judge Federal panel decided Friday to let a Texas redistricting plan remain nearly intact.

title: Around the Nation; Belushi Autopsy Fails To Yield Cause of Death
description: An autopsy was performed today on John Belushi, the comedian, who was found dead here Friday, but the coroner said the cause of death ''has not yet been established.''

title: Dr. B.M. Malloy Weds Patricia Davidge
description: Patricia Appel Davidge, a psychotherapist, and Dr. Bernard Mathis Malloy, assistant clinical profesor of psychiatry at the Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington, were married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the ceremony.

title: Cura,cao
description: To the Editor: In the Advisory article entitled, ''A Special Place in Cura,cao'' (Travel, Jan. 17) the synagogue mentioned fascinated me because of its design and color and because it is one of the first synagogues (if not the first) in the Western Hemisphere and has been unaltered since 1732. v. alking to the rear of the synagogue, one will see a beautiful sight -the sea dashing against the rocks -nature competing with a special place in Cura,cao. MILDRED STARRS Douglaston, L.I.

title: TV Mailbag; WHAT'S WRONG WITH LOCAL TV NEWS?
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: PIMSLER'S 'GLORY'
description: Man's inhumanity to man seems to be the subject of ''Glory Portraits,'' a new work performed by Stuart Pimsler Dance and Theater on Friday at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio - or at least man's inhumanity to baby daughters and unsophisticated Army recruits.

title: ADDING COMFORT BY TIGHTENING CASEMENT WINDOW SLASHES
description: IN older houses that have metal casement windows, there is often a problem with drafts because the windows do not really close as tightly as they should - even when the handle is locked shut on the inside.

title: JAPANESE FOOD WITH INVENTIVENESS
description: PERHAPS the location is a problem, because despite the extremely fine Japanese food served at Asahi Tokyo, a fairly new restaurant in the Glen Cove Village Square shopping complex, the place seems to be having trouble filling its tables. Asahi Tokyo is certainly worth discovering, especially since it is the only Japanese restaurant in the immediate area.

title: PATIENT QUESTIONED IN 8TH AVE. SLAYING OF A RETIRED OFFICER
description: A man with a gunshot wound in the abdomen was questioned by the authorities yesterday at Harlem Hospital in connection with the fatal shooting Friday of a retired New York City police officer during a holdup in Manhattan.

title: AIRPORT HOTELS
description: T he jetliners whiz by as they land and take off - almost one a minute, it seems. Yet you hardly hear them. Instead, you enjoy the gentle melodies of a guitarist and chanteuse across the skytop lounge. Soon you will retire for the night and sleep soundly before leaving for Miami at 8:15 A.M.

title: Cooperative Bidding For School Supplies
description: The article ''School Bidding Co-op Formed'' (Feb. 14) states that the purchasing cooperative formed by the North Shore, Manhasset and Harborfields School Districts is ''the Island's first cooperative bidding system for general school supplies.'' I must take exception to this statement.

title: JOYCE CENTENNIAL CELEBRATION BEGINS THIS WEEK AT RUTGERS
description: ON Page 302 of James Joyce's novel ''Finnegans Wake,'' there is a footnote that says, ''I loved to see the Macbeth-Jerseys knacking spots of the Plumpduffs Pants.''

title: Can Williams Shift the Guilt?
description: The other shoe is due to fall this week for Harrison A. Williams Jr., the Abscam inquiry's most prominent target. But there are those who favor letting him continue to serve as New Jersey's senior Senator. He and they have tried to make the conduct of his Government pursuers seem more reprehensible than his failure to walk away from temptation.

title: Judith Newman Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Morton B. Newman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Ann Newman, to Jeffrey Edward MacGregor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald MacGregor of Clifton, N.J. Miss Newman is senior public-relations specialist at Delacorte Press in New York. Mr. MacGregor is general-accounting manager for Dell Publishing Inc. in New York.

title: Gail Karlsson Married To Edward A. Oldfield
description: Gail V. Karlsson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Edward Karlsson of New York City, was married yesterday to Edward Arthur Oldfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Oldfield of Bay City, Mich. Justice Theodore R. Kupferman, Appellate Division, State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony in the bride's apartment.

title: BRITISH TROOPS IN KENYA FOR SPECIAL TRAINING
description: Among the thousands of visitors who occasionally visit Nairobi's nightclubs or shop-lined streets at this time of year are dozens of lean Britons whose disciplined manner contrasts with the casual amiability of ordinary tourists.

title: TIMELY WRITER WINNER
description: Last fall, Dominic Imprescia took a gamble. Timely Writer, the outstanding 2-year-old colt he trained, had won the Hopeful and Champagne Stakes and could have wrapped up the 2-year-old championship with another stakes victory. But Imprescia decided that his colt was tired and would be better as a 3-year-old if he were rested for the winter. Deputy Minister then won two lateseason stakes and was voted the championship.

title: Topics; ENDORSEMENTS; Flower Power
description: Many Americans have grown up believing, from the wayside evidence, that Kleenex was the national flower. Not so, but neither has a real one been designated.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Inside Story ''Between your ears,'' said James Burke recently, ''you have more than all of the computers in the world joined together and I don't care where you come from or how good your education is.'' Mr. Burke is the host and co-writer of ''The Neuron Suite,'' a program that will explore the human brain and the central nervous system. It will be broadcast Monday at 9:05 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: CHEEVER COUNTRY
description: OH WHAT A PARADISE IT SEEMS By John Cheever. 100 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10. By JOHN LEONARD

title: NEW DATA PUSH DEFICIT ESTIMATE TO $96.4 BILLION
description: Budget Director David A. Stockman has informed Congress that he now calculates the budget deficit for the fiscal year 1983 at $96.4 billion, almost $5 billion more than President Reagan originally projected.

title: TOURISM SLOGAN OFF TO A SLOW START
description: IN the beginning there were the words, ''Better Yet Connecticut.'' They were followed by a blue and green logo and the production of thousands of bumper stickers and T-shirts for distribution at the Eastern States Exposition, a large fair in Springfield, Mass., last September.

title: Future Events; Cocktails and Dinner
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Matter of Taste March 10 - An exhibition of 90 paintings and mixed-media sculpture by British artists in the style that has come to be known as ''superhumanism'' opens at the Arnold Katzen Gallery, 11 East 57th Street. Although Paul McCartney, the former Beatle, and Francois Truffaut, the film director, are among the collectors who have been capitvated by the art, it is not to everyone's taste. Some consider it vulgar and erotic. Sixteen artists, along with Nicholas Treadwell, their promoter, will mingle with guests at a cocktail opening from 6 to 9 P.M. to benefit the education and research programs of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. Tickets are $15. The show is open March 11-May 1.

title: N.C.A.A. Tourney Field To Be Unveiled on TV
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, which has expanded faster than any other American sports event in recent years, takes another big step Sunday when the 48-team field is announced on nationwide television.

title: NEW HAVEN PLAYER NOW SOUGHT AFTER
description: point victory over West Haven last month and said, ''If I hadn't seen it with my own eyes, I never would have believed it.''

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS SQUEEZED INTO CAREER PATHS
description: American college students, long a reflection of the country's affluence and achievement, face a financial squeeze that is increasingly channeling them in a narrow, career-oriented direction and profoundly altering the university experience.

title: ON THE WISDOM OF WINNIE
description: For some people, heaven on earth might sound something like this: To sail a yacht around the blue Mediterranean, charting your own course, with a group of intelligent and lively companions, swimming, sightseeing and, at night, playing bridge.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Taffanel Wind Quintet Show Flutists' Paris
description: To flutists, the name Taffanel means roughly what Hanon does to pianists. But Taffanel did more than write the exercises that are de rigeur for all flutists; he was one of the patriarchs of the modern French school of wind playing.

title: FOREIGN POLICY WITH A BIG STICK
description: BITTER FRUIT The Untold Story of the American Coup in Guatemala. By Stephen Schlesinger and Stephen Kinzer. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $16.95.

title: Mailbox; History Lesson
description: To the Sports Editor: Doubtless Prof. Stanley W. Page has his credentials in general history but he is way out of bounds in his reference to football (Mailbox, The New York Times, Feb. 28, 1982). He writes that football has remained the same game fundamentally, ''allowing coaches like Bear Bryant to go on.''

title: A BELATED LESSON IN THE RECOGNITION OF PEKING
description: To the Editor:

title: WALL STREET'S NEW SUPERBROKERS
description: CAN Sears, Roebuck & Company, the new owner of Dean Witter Reynolds, sell stocks with socks? Will Shearson Loeb Rhodes, one of Wall Street's liveliest, most acquisitive firms, be stifled by its marriage to solid old American Express? What about that broker from the Bache Group, immortalized in television ads as a hard-boiled hustler who neither eats nor sleeps? Can he be turned on by selling life insurance policies for the Prudential Insurance Company? And what can Salomon Brothers, Wall Street's pre-eminent securities trader, get out of its new owner, the Phibro Corporation, a master commodities trader?

title: SLIDES AND SONGS FROM THE FORTIES
description: ''THE Fabulous Forties'' is the second of two evenings devoted to the songs of a decade sung in front of slides of the period. The management of An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford calls these productions ''multimedia variety musicals.'' The first one was ''Charles A. Lindbergh vs. the Roaring 20's,'' and both were first seen at Bridgeport's Downtown Cabaret Theater. I much prefer the current show, because it is what it is -slides and songs - without even a pretense of a book, which the first show offered in its occasional returns to the life of Lindbergh.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Firing Line

title: TV Mailbag; WHAT'S WRONG WITH LOCAL TV NEWS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hilary Hallas to Be Bride Of Paul Mitchell in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Hallas of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Ann Hallas, to Paul Caron Mitchell of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Mitchell of London, formerly of Stamford, Conn.

title: WALESA EXPECTED HOME FOR DAUGHTER'S CHRISTENING
description: The wife of Lech Walesa said today that the martial law authorities would allow the detained union leader to attend his daughter's christening in Gdansk in two weeks and let him stay through Easter.

title: Flowers
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OUTLOOK: CONTRASTS
description: By Carrie Donovan

title: THOUSANDS PROTEST IN LISBON
description: Thousands of protesters marched through Lisbon today as part of a nationwide drive organized by Communist unions to oust Portugal's right-wing Government.

title: PROSECUTION OF POLITICIAN STIRS QUEBEC
description: An extraordinary outpouring of sympathy has emerged for Claude Charron, the former majority leader of the Quebec Assembly, who was fined last month for shoplifting in a Montreal store. And the incident has brought out all the old tensions that have characterized English-French relations in Montreal.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 7, 1982
description: International U.S.-Mexican ministerial talks were held in New York on the civil war in El Salvador. The conferees, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Jorge Castaneda, disagreed over the issue of Nicaraguan arms shipments to the leftist insurgents in El Salvador, and Mr. Haig termed Mexico's peace proposals ''inadequate.'' (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: A.D.A., AT PARLEY, SEES REAGAN REUNITING LIBERALS
description: Members of Americans for Democratic Action met here this weekend for their annual convention, expressing renewed pride in their liberal, progressive tradition and sharp criticism of President Reagan's economic program.

title: THEATER: HOLT'S BLONDES
description: Casting Lola Pashalinski and Crystal Field as the twins Sherrie and Cherrie Trifle, the first, ''the most famous lesbian of all time,'' the second, a working-class mother, is a clever idea. The two actresses could be sisters, but they have distinctive stage personalities. Miss Pashalinski is the Mae West of the Ridiculous and Miss Field is a billowy Bo Peep. However, in the case of the ladies' shared vehicle, Stephen Holt's ''The Blonde Leading the Blonde,'' at Theater for the New City, cleverness just about ends with the casting.

title: STATE TO TRY USING EAGLE FOSTER PARENTS
description: THE persistent breeding failures of New Jersey's only known pair of wild bald eagles have prompted state wildlife officials to lend Mother Nature a helping hand.

title: Prospects
description: The False Bottom

title: CLASS COMBINES ARCHITECTURE AND FRENCH
description: WHEN Allan Anderson, the architect, presents his lecture and slide show on French architecture to the French classes at White Plains High School, he is synthesizing several of his strongest enthusiasms: architecture, French culture and civilization and teaching young people.

title: Theater Mailbag; DEBATING THE PORTMAN PROJECT
description: To the Editor:$

title: No Headline
description: Rockies Stop Gretzky, Beat Oilers, 5 to 2

title: ABNORMAL ICY TAKEOFFS CITED FOR 3 MORE 737 JETS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today disclosed three incidents since December in which Boeing 737 airliners were thrown into abnormal maneuvers while taking off in ice-producing conditions like those that evidently contributed to the crash of an Air Florida jetliner here on Jan. 13.

title: BALANCING THE BUDGET- BY LAW
description: WASHINGTON IN what would surely be a delicious irony, it may be the fiscal policy of Ronald Reagan that drives Congress and the states to adopt a constitutional amendment ''requiring'' that the Federal budget be balanced.

title: MIAMI MARKET READJUSTS AS SURGE IN BUYING ENDS
description: The luxury condominium market in the greater Miami area is wobbling in the aftermath of a speculative buying spree. Only two years ago, people were lining up to reserve apartments in high-rise waterfront buildings whose construction had not even started. At one development, Brickell Key, 275 persons each left $5,000 deposits on a building that had not yet announced prices.

title: Joan Adrian Is Affianced
description: Capt. Robert N. Adrian, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Adrian of Annapolis, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Bernard Adrian, to Michael Paul Morgan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Morgan of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Adolescence has been an American luxury, but we can't afford it anymore. It's an awful thing that students more and more have to weigh the cost of every little thing rather than think, 'Is this something I want to study or to do?' '' - Paula Schimpf, a junior at Ohio State University. (1:4.)

title: HOW THE SIMULATED DISASTER UNFOLDED
description: PEEKSKILL FOR Larry Auterino, last Wednsday morning began with a pretended dose of radiation and a possibly broken leg, continued with an ambulance ride from a nuclear power plant at Indian Point and ended about 11:15 in Peekskill Community Hospital with the ''patient'' missing a shoe but feeling ''great, just great.''

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Sylvia Lindenstrand, Mezzo-Soprano
description: Sylvia Lindenstrand's introduction to American audiences Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall was a warm and winning one. Miss Lindenstrand, a mezzo-soprano from Sweden, may not overwhelm us with the opulence or voluptuousness of her voice, but within its own confines this is an instrument of charm and persuasiveness.

title: 'NO,NO, NANETTE' DANCES BACK TO 1925
description: ''NO, NO, NANETTE,'' boasts the rare distinction of having been a Broadway hit twice, in 1925 and in 1971. One reason is the delightful Vincent Youmans score that includes, among other good numbers, the standards ''Tea for Two'' and ''I Want to Be Happy.'' The second reason, at least for the 1971 version, was the presence of Ruby Keeler. Miss Keeler, not a great singer nor an exceptionally graceful dancer, somehow is the symbol of the great 30's movie musicals, and Broadway fell all over itself in welcoming her back, as it did that wonderful comic Patsy Kelly, who also appeared.

title: A GRAND HOTEL AS SYMBOL
description: LUCINDA FRANKS, winner of a Pulitzer Prize for national reporting, lives in New York. By LUCINDA FRANKS

title: JILL CLAYBURGH-ACTING ON THE EDGE
description: ''Iguess people look at me and they think I'm a ladylike character,'' said Jill Clayburgh, ''but it's not what I do best. I do best with characters who are coming apart at the seams.''

title: BIG EAST CROWN TO GEORGETOWN
description: With a Big East Conference championship and an automatic bid to the national collegiate tournament at stake, the Georgetown Hoyas followed their coach's best laid plans this afternoon.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH still under construction, the long, low Yonkers building being converted into a garage and maintenance facility for county buses is ''probably 85 to 90 percent complete'' structurally and will be ''fully operational'' by July 1, said Arthur Bernacchia, president of Liberty Lines.

title: FRESH MUSIC TALENT WINS HIS EAR
description: ''IDON'T want people who are new not to have hope that somebody will sit and listen to their music and give them a break,'' said Ron Alexenburg of Woodbury.

title: ETHICAL EDUCATION, YES
description: Prayer in public schools, no. Ethical education, yes. However, let outsiders provide the teaching, let experience be the spokesman. As a clergyman and teacher for 30 years, I have tried to know and share the religious and secular, rational bases for ethical values. It hasn't been easy.

title: 'RED RYDER' COMES BACK VIVIDLY
description: LINDENHURST STUDIO THEATER is presenting an excellent staging of ''When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?'' It is tough, it is tense, it is tight. It has drive even when the play dawdles. Under Jeanne DeVito's and David Cohen's commanding direction, the production is a case example of community theater at its best, and it's a persuasive account of a work that's dimmed in less than a decade, and dated beyond that.

title: B.B. Kopp, Jean S. Rath To Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Stearns Rath of New York and Litchfield, Conn., of the engagement of Mr. Rath's daughter, Jean Stearns Rath, to Bradford Burnett Kopp, son of Ruth P. Kopp of New York and Norfolk, Conn., and W. Brewster Kopp of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: REAGAN AIDES TERM COMPROMISE LIKELY ON BUDGET FOR '83
description: White House officials, while wary of making predictions, nonetheless say privately that President Reagan's acceptance of some cuts in his military budget and some increases in taxes is virtually inevitable.

title: SAVING ON ROOMS, WORKING FOR SCIENCE; Caribbean Hotels Plan Spring Sale
description: The winter season may be in full swing in the Caribbean, but the thoughts of resort operators are turning to their spring sale. When the sun climbs higher in the North, prices go down in the islands. The ''season of sweet savings'' is the label the Caribbean Tourism Association is giving this year to the period from April 15 through Dec. 15, the islands' off season. To minimize the number of empty rooms in these months, many hotels will cut their rates drastically.

title: Andrea Bockman, Gregory M. Stack To Wed April 17
description: Eugene James Bockman of New York and Pauline McDermott of New City, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Emily Bockman, to Gregory Michael Stack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin A. Stack of Wauwatosa, Wis.

title: Men and Women And Understanding
description: Linda Flayton's recent article, ''Men Can't Feel Guilty Forever'' (Opinion Page), left me wondering: Why do women need to write articles for men? It amazes me to see that some women have this extraordinary need not only to state both sides of an issue but to state the men's side with more understanding and poignancy than they do their own. Surely we can let men speak for themselves as we can for ourselves. JOAN BRENNER Huntington

title:
Economic Affairs;
INVESTMENT IS THE BUSINESS OF BUSINESS
description: THE recently reduced level of confidence in conservative nostrums f or our economic troubles is causing a return of courage to liberal t hinkers, and a return of interest in their thoughts.

title: Smith Fees Rise to $10,850
description: The Smith College trustees have approved increases in tuition and charges for room and board that will bring the annual cost for a student to $10,850 next fall. Jill Conway, president of Smith, cited inflation and proposed Federal aid cutbacks in the 14.2 percent increase.

title: SAGE FOUNDATION, AT 75, DOING INNOVATIVE RESEARCH
description: At the age of 75, the Russell Sage Foundation is starting out to break fresh ground in social-science research while preserving its deeply rooted traditions as one of the country's oldest private philanthropies.

title: Brooklyn Sets Back Staten Island, 60-67
description: Brooklyn College stubbornly held on to a slim lead for most of the second half last night to defeat the College of Staten Island, 60-57, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III East Regional final at Staten Island.

title: NEW FACILITY FOR AGED TO OPEN
description: The Menorah Home and Hospital for the Aged and Infirm will open a new $10 million building tomorrow in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn.

title: Westchester Planning To Test Airport Noise
description: County officials have agreed to a 60-day test of the noise from planes landing at night at Westchester County Airport, at Purchase.

title: NICARAGUAN IS EXPECTED TO RECEIVE SAFE-CONDUCT PASS FROM SALVADOR
description: The head of El Salvador's national police said today that a young Nicaraguan, described by the Salvadoran authorities as a guerrilla leader and by Mexico as a student, would probably be given a safe-conduct pass to leave the country.

title: TRUE GRITS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WAR ON ABORTION MUST NOT START AGAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: THE JOYS OF WINTER
description: If one has the freedom to lie abed on a cold, winter morning, doing nothing more than contemplating the beauties of the icy landscape, then winter might well be a season of delight. For those of us, however, who must ''delight'' in rising at 5:30 A.M. to plow out a driveway, take the dogs for a slippery run through frozen-solid woods and arrive at our desks by 7:30 A.M., winter is a season to be endured, rather than enjoyed. JUDITH ZION Laurel Hollow, N.Y. ------

title: HE MAY JUST BE TODAY'S BARNUM
description: Five days before the edited tape of ''Night of 100 Stars'' must be delivered to ABC, Alexander M. Cohen, whose left ear suffers withdrawal symptoms when deprived of a telephone, is on the line dealing with emergencies.

title: CONVERSION LAW UP FOR RENEWAL
description: ALARMED at the hardships faced by tenants who are forced to vacate their rental apartments due to condominium conversions, the Connecticut General Assembly passed a bill in May of 1980 that established more stringent regulations for conversions.

title: REPORT FROM EUROPE
description: By Carrie Donovan

title: Theater Mailbag; DEBATING THE PORTMAN PROJECT
description: To the Editor:$

title: Around the World; Newspaper Publisher Abducted in Guatemala
description: Guerrillas abducted a leading newspaper publisher here Friday, and today newspapers in Guatemala, Mexico and Honduras complied with demands from the rebels and published a leftist manifesto condemning Guatemala's elections on Sunday as a fraud.

title: BROADWAY ECONOMICS-CAN SHOW BIZ GET ITS ACT TOGETHER?
description: The first, worrisome signs of recession have reached Broadway. After five years in which attendance has climbed steadily, to a record of 11 million tickets sold in the 1980-81 season, ticketbuying this year has slipped by four percent - an admittedly small but ominous decline. Furthermore, only a handful of musical hits accounts for the bulk of sales; many straight plays have folded after runs of a few weeks, or days. And while the recent spate of closures has darkened several theaters, the next opening is not scheduled until March 25, an uncommonly long lull at a time of year when Broadway is usually bustling with new arrivals.

title: Christine Costello To Wed July 31
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Costello of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Ann Costello, to Jeffrey DuVall Lewis of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Lewis of Newton, Mass.

title: GREECE IS PURSUING PRAGMATIC COURSE
description: Greece's Socialist Government, which swept into power last October with a program for socialization and neutralism, has preferred pragmatic economic recovery measures to striking out on revolutionary paths.

title: Headliners; Best Things in Life
description: A lot of people say they love New York, but few have the wherewithal to show it as Belle Linsky did last week. She donated her private collection of European Renaissance art valued at $60 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. A Romanesque bronze of a monk seated on a dragon (detail in photo at left) is one of the pieces acquired over the years by Mrs. Linsky and her late husband, selfmade millionaires in a ''stationery business'' that once included the Swingline staple company.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Dumping of Toxic Wastes Reconsidered
description: Love Canal is a case history in two words. In Atlantic City, N.J., to choose a more recent example, toxic chemicals are seeping toward the drinking supply; it will cost the Government and the companies accused of dumping the hazardous wastes more than $10 million to rectify the damage. Such incidents led the Federal Government, under the 1976 Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, to establish a ban on burying barrels of toxic liquids at landfills.

title: THE PRIME MINISTER'S VICTORY CREATES A NEW OPPOSITION
description: South Africa's National Party, to judge by its record on civil rights and economic justice during nearly 34 years in power, would seem to qualify for any roster of extreme right-wing political movements. But last week, the body slipped into center position on the attenuated spectrum of white politics in South Africa.

title: THE BRIDGEPORT SYMPHONY, A LONG-PLAYING STORY
description: AFTER the New Haven Symphony, which is the sixth-oldest orchestra in the whole country, the Greater Bridgeport Symphony boasts the Connecticut longevity record: It is now in the midst of its 36th season.

title: AN ERROR ON SALVADOR
description: The Administration's policy of increasing the United States' military involvement in El Salvador is producing an outcome that is exactly the opposite of the one intended.

title: THE DAY THE HOUSE WENT OUT TO SEA
description: THAT first week of March 1962, all seemed so right with our world. In Baldwin, my wife and I were making plans for our spring trek to Ocean Beach, Fire Island, as my brother and his wife and my mother were doing in their homes in Forest Hills. Our oceanfront house out there would need a lot of touching up to recover from winter, as all beach houses do.

title: MEDAL OF MUSICAL NOTE; by Ed Reiter
description: The latest medallic issue from the Jewish-American Hall of Fame in Berkeley, Calif., pays tribute jointly to famed violinist, Isaac Stern, and Carnegie Hall, the historic New York concert hall which Mr. Stern was instrumental in saving from demolition in 1960. Since then he has been president of Carnegie Hall Corporation, the nonprofit agency that operates the facility.

title: AFLOAT ON A SEA OF SUDS
description: ICAN still see my grandmother, her gray head bent over her ironing, t ears falling in rivulets down her cheeks. Why was she crying? What w as the reason for her sorrow? The voices issuing from the huge w ooden radio in the corner had brought on her tears. Her favorite s oap opera was on, and as always, Grandma suffered along with the h eroes and heroines.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; New TV Stations: Network Power
description: The Federal Communications Commission last week allowed the licensing of low-power television stations, clearing the way for 3,000 to 4,000 new stations within the next three years. Although the individual territories will be small, the collective stakes could be enormous.

title: Brideshead
description: To the Editor: The article ''Visiting Brideshead'' identifying Castle Howard as the location for the television series ''Brideshead Revisited'' neglected to mention the fact that most of the interiors were photographed at another magnificent English estate -Tatton Park in Cheshire.

title: NEW YORK LAWS STYMIE SUITS ON TOXIN AILMENTS
description: Stan Rosenberg worked in the dusty boiler rooms of ships under construction or repair in the Brooklyn Navy Yard for 14 years. When he died of mesothelioma, or cancer of the lining of the lungs, at the age of 48, his doctors and his wife, Barbara, blamed asbestos fibers that filled the area.

title: CONGRESS OFFERED A TAX COMPROMISE
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Reagan Administration might support repeal of a new adjustment to the income tax if it gained assurances from Congress that the revenue saved would be used to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: OTHER ATTRACTIONS
description: Vietri sul Mare/SalernoSalerno, a resort city, is well supplied with hotels and restaurants in all categories. Lloyd's Baia Hotel, on the road to Vietri, has 120 rooms; a double, with bath, is about $60 a night.

title: A DOCTOR TO DIFFICULT CASES
description: PSYCHIATRIST OF AMERICA The Life of Harry Stack Sullivan. By Helen Swick Perry. Illustrated. 462 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $20.By ROBERT COLES

title: 4 Rob the Warehouse Of TV Rental Concern
description: The Brooklyn warehouse of Granada TV, a television and video rental company, was robbed of an estimated $50,000 worth of equipment yesterday by four men, one of whom was a former employee, the police said.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review of Feb. 28 incorrectly identified the most recent Mayor of New York City to become Governor. He was John T. Hoffman, in 1868.

title: Ugandan Army Training Set
description: The Ugandan Government has announced agreement for a 36-man Commonwealth military team to train its army, the Uganda radio reported today. The team was agreed on at last year's Commonwealth conference in Melbourne, Australia, as one way of curbing lawlessness in sections of the Ugandan Army.

title:
Men's Style
FANCY FOOTWORK (set as art)
description: Stepping out is a reptilian experience. Not that there's anything sneaky about it, but men are again slipping into shoes made from the skins of alligators, crocodiles, lizards and snakes, or leather facsimiles thereof.

title: California Repeals 1872 Law On Closing Pretrial Hearings
description: California's 110-year-old law closing preliminary hearings to the public at a defendant's request has been repealed. Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. signed a bill letting the judge decide whether such hearings should be open.

title: Art; WHAT IT IS LIKE TO BE AN ART JUROR
description: SUMMIT SERVING as a juror for an art exhibition is never easy. Many works have to be examined, often quickly, and snap judgments must be made. A qualified juror can be certain about many acceptances that he has made, as well as rejections. However, there are always those purgatorial pieces among both the accepted and rejected ones that are surrounded by doubt, thus causing anyone who has to select a certain amount of malaise.

title: LITTLE LINGERIE
description: Just about five years ago Lida Orzeck, a social psychologist, and Gale Epstein, a sportswear designer, formed a company called Hanky Panky to make cotton underwear from embroidered handkerchiefs. Their timing was right, because women were rediscovering the comfort of natural fibers.

title: Marjorie Danziger Wed
description: The marriage of Marjorie Ann Danziger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton K. Danziger of Livingston, N.J., to Stuart Neil Blacker took place yesterday at the Braidburn Country Club in Florham Park, N.J. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony. The bride is a copywriter with the Atlantic Record Corporation, a division of Warner Communications. Mr. Blacker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Blacker of Reading, Pa., is a vice president with the international institutional area of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Corrections Problems In 2 Counties Cited
description: I believe that James W. Kearns 3d, in ''A Call for a New Corrections Policy'' (Jan. 31), is asking for some definite guidelines so that the state's Department of Corrections can function efficiently. My compliments to him.

title: Peter D. Besen, Engineer, Will Marry Lisa Antupit
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel N. Antupit of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Antupit, to Peter D. Besen, son of Judith Silverman of Sarasota, Fla., and Dr. Lester Besen of Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Frank and Fruitful Exchange KIMBLE MEAD

title: Sound; RICHES FROM OLD DISKS
description: Since the days of Ponce de Leon, the search for the Fountain of Youth has taken many different directions, most of them futile. It is something of a surprise, therefore, that - at least for recordings - an effective way has been found to give fabled performances of bygone years a new lease on life.

title: SUFFOLK LIBRARIES EXPANDING
description: THE day of quiet librarians making do in crowded buildings seems to be over in Suffolk County, where voters have approved seven major expansions or new building programs in the last year.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Nassau County Board of Supervisors will vote tomorrow on a new weighted voting plan that will incorporate changes in population resulting from the 1980 Census.

title: UPDATE NEEDED ON THE HISTORY OF WOMEN
description: ICANNOT drive along the ''Hutch'' without thinking of the woman after whom the river and parkway were named. Anne Hutchinson was killed by Indians at Pelham Bay near the mouth of the river. One cannot read the little that is known of her life without being deeply moved by her vision and her courage. Her martyrdom on behalf of religious freedom, the sanctity of the individual and the rights of women has a special significance for us today. Yet how many of us have ever heard of her?

title: ESKIMOS ARE SHOWING NEW MILITANCY
description: After decades of meek submission to the white man, Eskimos are showing new signs of militancy. Increasingly organized to fight back, they are making new political and financial demands on the intruders from the south and exercising greater influence in the defense of the fragile Arctic environment.

title: HAIL TO THE CHIEFLETS
description: Hail to the Chieflets PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: JOHN PUTZ FIANCE OF MISS JOHNSON
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Frederick Johnson of Basking Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Arnold Johnson of West Los Angeles, to John Rodney Putz of La Jolla and Los Angeles, son of Mrs. Eloise Anderson Putz and Mr. Robert R. Putz, both of San Diego.

title: MARCHING TO UTOPIA
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE FUNDS SOUGHT FOR ENVIRONMENTAL UNIT
description: A bipartisan effort to add a substantial amount to President Reagan's proposed budget for the Environmental Protection Agency is rapidly gaining strength in Congress.

title: Koch Backs Monument To Veterans of Vietnam
description: A mayoral task force has recommended that New York City honor the servicemen and women who served during the Vietnam War by building a monument to them in Manhattan and establishing service programs for those who need help.

title: Scientologists Lose Appeal
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on Friday upheld the convictions of two members of the Church of Scientology, Jane Kember and Morris Budlong, who were convicted in 1978 of planning a burglary of Government offices here to steal documents concerning the church. The two, each sentenced to 26 years in prison, said in their appeal that a lower court had not sent the case to a District of Columbia court. They said that the charges were local rather than Federal.

title: BORDEN CAPTURES WEIGHT THROW
description: Bill Borden stands 5 feet 10 inches and weighs 240 pounds. He has blond hair, excessive muscles and an excitable personality.

title: VIRGINIA VICTOR-N. CAROLINA WINS
description: Ricky Stokes, who was looking to pass the ball inside, was instead forced to take a 12-foot jump shot that banked off the backboard and dropped through the basket with one second left in overtime today to give Virginia a 51-49 triumph over Wake Forest in the semifinals of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.

title: ANDREA L. POPIK, LAWYER, FIANCEE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Selig Popik of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Lynn Popik, to Kenneth William Taber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Taber of Lyndhurst, Ohio.

title: TV Mailbag; WHAT'S WRONG WITH LOCAL TV NEWS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Tour
description: To the Editor: The Lincoln pilgrimage ''From Hodgenville to Washington,'' by Herbert Mitgang (Travel, Feb. 14) might have started a little earlier and a few miles to the east. There is, at Harrodsburg, Ky., on the grounds of the restored ''Old Fort Harrod'' what is called the Lincoln Wedding Chapel, a log cabin in which Lincoln's parents were married. If one is making the Lincoln tour, why not start there? THE REV. LAURENCE J. JAMES Eastern Orthodox Chaplain, Ohio University, Athens, Ohio

title: Theater Mailbag; DEBATING THE PORTMAN PROJECT
description: To the Editor:

title: A YOUNG GYMNAST'S HOPES ARE DASHED
description: Four days ago, Gina Stallone was working out in a gymnasium in Allentown, Pa., trying to develop her Tsukahara vault technique in preparation for a gymnastics meet next week in Atlantic City.

title: ...FOR LEGISLATION
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Susan Gilbert Affianced
description: Mrs. Emily Pepper Gilbert of Waterford, Conn., and Dudley Adrian Gilbert of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Iselin Gilbert, to Carter Reynette James, son of Mrs. Denis Noel Reynette James of Englewood, N.J., and the late Mr. James. The wedding is planned for Aug. 14.

title: The Nation in Summary; Conservatives Have Their Day On Busing Bill
description: The United States Senate last week accorded its new conservative bloc a first full victory - approval, 57 to 37, of legislation limiting the authority of the Federal courts.

title: Lucy Dillon to Be the Bride of Chemist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney G. Dillon of Gladstone, N.J., and Siasconset, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Sands Dillon, to Dr. William Harry Rastetter of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Rastetter of Williamsburg, Va.

title: 'ADULT' FILMS ARE ASSAILED BY PICKETERS
description: Outside the Sheraton Centre on Seventh Avenue, in yesterday afternoon's rain, six women circled the entrance in a picket line chanting ''It's a lie, pass it by'' and ''No more profits from our bodies, no more pleasure from our pain.''

title: Peggy Isham Sets June 5 Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Trumbull Isham of Newport, R.I., formerly of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Dorothy Isham, to Christian Weston Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Scudder Hughes of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.

title: Patricia A. Diamond Bride Of William Kennedy Dodds
description: Patricia Ann Diamond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Diamond, was married yesterday in Manhattan to William Kennedy Dodds, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hector Dodds of Washington. Rabbi Charles G. Agin of Flushing, Queens, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Around the World; Ireland to Try Suspect For Offenses in Britain
description: An Irish citizen suspected of being an Irish Republican Army terrorist today became the first person to face trial in Ireland for offenses in Britain.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: 3 Overtimes And 337 Points
description: George Gervin scored 50 points, 24 in overtime periods, and Mike Mitchell added 45 as the San Antonio Spurs scored a 171-166 triple-overtime victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight.

title: TOPPING IT OFF HATS By Andre Leon Talley
description: number of designers in collections this spring showed a renewed interest in hats. Well, what about hats? Will they really be worn as a finishing-off accessory? Here is what a group of fashionable women of different ages and professions say about hats: Some have always worn them and even sleep in them, others are just now reconsidering the idea, and still others collect them, but wouldn't think of wearing them.

title: SILICON VALLEY'S MATERNITY WARD: HOW A COMPANY WAS BORN
description: ON Jan. 8, Dr. Allan Rosencwaig, 40 years old, resigned his position as a manager and researcher at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in Livermore, Calif. As even his employers knew, Dr. Rosencwaig's resignation was a formality - in spirit, he had left the laboratory long before. Dr. Rosencwaig (pronounced ROSE-en-swag) wasn't the first scientist to walk out and start his own company. But few have what Dr. Rosencwaig had: a technological breakthrough for a product and $1.5 million of investors' venture capital in the bank.

title: AIRPORT PERMIT DEBATED
description: RIVERHEAD FEW in this rural town of 22,000 are without opinions about whether Joseph W. Brush Jr. should be allowed to operate an airport and flight school on his 200-acre farm on Sound Avenue.

title: Article on Violence Called Clear Analysis
description: I can't remember when last I came across writing that is such a clear analysis as was ''We Must Attack Violent Behavior at Its Source'' (Opinion Page, Feb. 7).

title: House Taken to Task For Wasting Energy
description: Must every solar house, like the one illustrating the solar development in Tewksbury (Feb. 14), use heat-squandering cathedral ceilings? Do potential buyers insist on them? Would special local user taxes on such designs help discourage them? JAY L. CHURCHILL Dover

title: JERSEY'S BUILDERS DIFFER ON 1982
description: By DONALD JANSON

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Local Control And Free Speech
description: When it comes to school books, no Federal law delineates where the power of local authorities ends and the free speech rights of individuals begin. So it was the United States Supreme Court that heard arguments last week in a test case on school book banning.

title: Oshkosh Wins Title
description: Dan Nekich swept half the individual events and the all-round individual title, leading Wisconsin-Oshkosh to a second consecutive National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics gymnastics championship Friday. In winning the title, Oshkosh totaled 211.70 points to 196 for Fort Hays, Kan.

title: POPE CALLS FOR IMPROVED TIES WITH JEWS
description: Pope John Paul II urged Christians today to overcome the ''misunderstandings, errors and even offenses'' that Christians of the past have inflicted on Jews.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Mamaroneck Gift Shop Offers Wide Variety
description: The Phyllis Victor gift shop has been on East Boston Post Road in Mamaroneck for 30 years, and most merchandise is at full retail price. However, there are always 20 percent discounts on the suggested retail price of handbags and luggage, with winter bags now 40 percent off.

title:
Comment;
THE POTHOLED ROAD TO ENTERPRISE ZONES
description: DURING the past few years there has evolved an attractive plan to r evitalize, or at least stop the deterioration of, many of our aged u rban areas. The plan, known as ''Enterprise Zones,'' is the result o f an alliance in many states and Washington between urban and s uburban elected officials. It is designed to offer to private i nvestment and industrial entrepreneurs tax and loan incentives to e xpand or relocate some of their business to designated Enterprise Z ones.

title:
Dining Out;
FIRST WINE BAR OPENS IN COUNTY
description: OPEN only three months, Saint Martin's Wine House in Mount Kisco, the first wine bar in the county, follows a fashionable and welcome trend. Although at 900 bottles the bar is only half-stocked, 90 types of wine are represented, a selection more than ample for both diners and tasters. (Special informal wine tasting takes place on Fridays and Saturdays).

title: A NEW STYLE MAKING ITS MARK
description: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe once told an architect, ''You should never build a building until you are 50.'' Eli Attia, who is 45 years old, will have completed several important buildings before he is 50: a 46-story glass tower at 101 Park Avenue and 41st Street, the world headquarters for the Republic National Bank of New York in Manhattan and Banco Safra in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and a major redevelopment in Atlanta.

title: Rio Tearoom
description: To the Editor: The article on ''Rio's Venerable Tearoom'' (Travel, Feb. 7) represented a wonderful moment of nostalgia to me. In the spring of 1939 my late husband, my son and I arrived in Rio as immigrants from Germany.

title: ONE BATTLE LOST, CREATIONISTS REGROUP FOR SECOND ROUND
description: There is no question that advocates of ''creation science'' suffered a wounding setback in January in Little Rock, Ark. After a closely watched Federal trial, Judge William Ray Overton ruled that a state law requiring public schools to give the teaching of creation science ''balanced treatment'' alongside evolution was unconstitutional, since ''creation science'' was based on religious beliefs and its teaching would violate constitutional requirements for the separation of church and state.

title: Miss Haverbeck Becomes Bride Of Carson Reid
description: Jeanne Marie Haverbeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Haverbeck of Windmill Point, Va., was married yesterday to Carson Reid, son of Joan Grynbaum of New York and Whitelaw Reid of Purchase, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by State Supreme Court Justice John C. Marbach at Ophir Farm, the Reid home in Purchase.

title: The Region in Summary; Grist for Two Mills
description: There seems no question that rent controls have some effect on apartment availability in New York City. But with the release of a report last week that apartment vacancy rates had declined more than a quarter since 1978, making the rental market the tightest in a decade, debate grew over whether controls exacerbate the squeeze or, to the contrary, keep it from becoming a stranglehold.

title: REPORT SHOWS 4 AMERICANS IN 10 ARE UNDER 25
description: About four Americans in 10 are under the age of 25, and as young adults they tend to marry later, have fewer children and are less likely to vote than their parents, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: AID SOUGHT FOR WORKERS AS FACTORIES SHUT
description: TORRINGTON AS the Pheoll of New England plant ground toward its demise here last week, Peter Kantor, like most of the 105 employees, received his walking papers and his final compensation. He got $50 in base severance pay, another $20 for each of his 26 years on the job, and two boxes of the fasteners the company manufactured.

title: CRAFTS
description: A SPACIOUS EXHIBIT OF ARTISTRY IN GLASS AND NEON By RUTH J. KATZ SPARKILL THE open space of Thorpe Gallery, in the basement of one of the Dominican Convent buildings here in the Palisades, is a luxury that many commercial gallery directors would envy. It is an environment that allows for shows of unusual scale. In the gallery through next Sunday is an exhibition that requires just such an area: ''Glass and Neon Sculpture,'' which highlights the work of 17 artists in the New York City area.

title: CUTS MAY MEAN SPLIT-LEVEL COLLEGE EDUCATION
description: Elizabeth Jones, a high school student from Clearwater, Fla., wants to attend Vanderbilt University in Nashville. There's only one problem. The cuts Congress made in Federal student aid programs last spring cut her family out of a Guaranteed Student Loan.

title: KNICKS ARE BEATEN BY PISONTS, 115 TO 111
description: Before last night's game against the Detroit Pistons, several of the Knicks were closely checking the National Basketball Association standings.

title:
Other Business;
800,000 SEARS, ROEBUCK SUITS, PLUS ONE
description: In the purveyance of men's haberdashery, it may never be disclosed whether Sears, Roebuck & Company has any thoughts of displacing Brooks Brothers or Savile Row. But among the owners of Sears, Roebuck suits is the resident of one of New York's most elegant homes, Gracie Mansion. The man, of course, is Mayor Koch, who as of last week is the owner of a $169, brown polyester model, size 44 long.

title: A Fire Damages Main Building Of Boricua College in Brooklyn
description: A three-alarm fire on Wednesday severely damaged the new main building of Boricua College in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The building, at Bedford Avenue and North Sixth Street, was not occupied. The four-year college, which is nine years old and has 900 students, had been in the process of moving from its location at 9 Graham Avenue to the Sixth Street building, formerly the St. Francis Prep high school.

title: DRAMA: PINTER'S LONG-DORMANT 1958 'HOTHOUSE'
description: ''The Hothouse,'' the long-dormant 1958 Harold Pinter play now having its American premiere at the Trinity Square Repertory Company, is set in an oppressive, incompetent, governmentrun ''rest home'' where the incarcerated patients are all identified by numbers and where the staff spends full time engaged in vicious, Machiavellian infighting.

title: GERARD R. SCHAUMBER
description: Gerard Robert Schaumber, vice president of Drexel, Burnham, Lambert & Company, the stock-brokerage concern, died of a heart attack yesterday in Sharon Hospital in Sharon, Conn. He was 47 years old and a resident of Manhattan and Pine Plains, N.Y.

title: Kensico Plaza Needs More Than Money
description: The plan to improve the Kensico Dam Plaza (''$4.3 Million Plan Offered to Improve Kensico Dam Plaza,'' Feb. 21), while being a sensible and necessary idea, will be absolutely meaningless unless the present unsocial conditions are investigated and improved, said conditions being:

title: Index; International
description: Pope exhorts Christians to seek better relations with Jews 3 Communist unions lead protest against Lisbon Government 3 Eskimos are showing new signs of militancy 3 Around the World 5 Swedish pop group no longer a hit at the Kremlin 7 Politician's shoplifting prosecu- tion stirs Quebec 8 British troops in Kenya for spe- cial training 10 Uganda creates new obstacles for Western reporters 11 Lech Walesa's wife expects him home in two weeks 13 Libya and Saudis renew their war of words 15 Government/Politics A.D.A., at convention, feels Rea- gan is reuniting liberals 26 Congress is cool to proposals to cut programs for elderly 27 Gallup Poll finds Democrats fa- vored as party of prosperity 29 Drive to increase environmental agency's budget grows 30 State to reconstruct junction of 3 major roads near Albany 37 General Around the Nation 22 Women's pay still lages behind men's, report shows 25 Press Notes: Aga Khan considers starting news service 31 Children and elderly work to- gether in drama program 33 Feminist group protests at Adult Film Association meeting 34 Rockland jury urges replacing county jail 38 A ''Chorus Line'' dressed in hos- pital whites 42 The Intrepid, victor again, nears final birth 43 Sage Foundation, at 75, doing in- novative research 46 Education/Welfare ''Superteacher'' in Chicago stands up to her critics 22 Summer seminars suggested for teachers in humanities 44 Health/Science Scholar denies trying to mislead in altering hieroglyphics 19 Arts/Entertainment ''The Blonde Leading the Blonde,'' a sex farce 47 Visitors to get glimpse of new Modern Art Museum 48 Maurizio Pollini gives piano re- cital at Fisher Hall 49 Harold's Pinter's long-dormant ''The Hothouse'' 49 Stuart Pimsler Dance Theater of- fers ''Glory Portraits'' 52 The debuts of young musicians are reviewed 52 Daniel Lewis troupe in main- stream modern dance 52 Film celebrates reunion of song team, the Weavers 52 Style Helping youngsters face a move 53 Lingerie for little girls 53

title: THEATER PROGRAM A HIT WITH YOUNG AND OLD
description: When Frank Zimmerman, a gregarious 89-year-old former salesman who sold everything from antiques to women's wear, entered a nursing home in 1977 after a bad fall, he found a new love - acting. He has since learned pantomime and appeared on television in a program about the elderly.

title:
Dining Out;
NEW FACES AT THE SHORT HILLS MALL
description: IN THE last few months, two attractive restaurants have opened at the recently expanded Short Hills Mall. Strikingly different in decor, yet similar in their wildly eclectic menus, both The Bakers Garden and Meriwether's are well suited to this up-market shopping center.

title: Vivian Wayne To Wed in June
description: Oscar Wayne of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Vivian Wayne, to Brian Carlisle McKee Henderson, son of Lieut. Col. Frederic M. Henderson, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Henderson of Javea, Spain. A June wedding is planned.

title: HOW ST. PATRICK PARADES ARE LINING UP
description: TODAY, the Irish-American Society of Nassau, Suffolk and Queens will sponsor the largest parade on the Island to celebrate St. Patrick's Day. The parade, which features 100 contingents, starts in Garden City and will march a 1.4-mile route to Mineola. Next Sunday, St. Patrick's Day parades are scheduled in Islip and Huntington.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Winter Survey of Education, published Jan. 10, incorrectly reported the number of degree programs offered in the ABLE program at Adelphi University. It offers Bachelor of Arts, Bachelor of Science and Associate of Arts degrees. Most of the 1,500 ABLE students are working toward one of the bachelor's degrees.

title: Deborah Rubin Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Len S. Rubin of Maywood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Kim Rubin, to Thomas Andrew Banker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Banker of West Orange, N.J. Mr. Banker is assistant business administrator of the city of Newark. Miss Rubin's parents are publishers of Our Town, a newspaper in Maywood.

title: Miss Mulford Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Mulford of Westport, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Fordyce Mulford, to Ronald Drew Wawra, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Rudolph Wawra of Pompton Plains, N.J. A summer wedding is planned. Miss Mulford, a graduate of the Columbia University School of Nursing, is a student at the surgeon's assistant program at the Cornell Medical School. Her fiance, an alumnus of Rutgers University, is an account supervisor at McCaffrey, McCall Inc., a New York advertising agency.

title: LITERARY ARCHEOLOGY
description: MONUMENTA BRITANNICA Or a Miscellany of British Antiquities. By John Aubrey. Edited by John Fowles. Annotated by Rodney Legg. Illustrated. 646 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. 125. Deluxe edition, $250.

title:
SPRING CRUISE ISSUE;
A COMPREHENSIVE LIST OF SPRING CRUISES
description: W hat follows is a comprehensive listing of cruise ships listed by destination rather than port of departure. It covers sailings throughout the world for the period from March 8 to June 30 and represents a departure from past practice when the Travel Section published one cruise directory for a full 12 months. This year it is the intention of the Travel Section to publish cruise directories four times a year. The next one is scheduled to appear on May 16.

title: Film View; MANKIND'S FOLLY-THE DARK SIDE OF THREE MOVIES
description: It used to be thought that science fiction films were the most revealing and the least self-conscious indicators of what was going on in our collective soul. The Aesop's fables of our time, it was said, are sci-fi tales that contain moral lessons and, hidden within them, all sorts of dark suspicions that we dare not acknowledge openly.

title: Open Letter to Madison Square Garden
description: Gentlemen: I am driven to write this letter, after 15 years of patronage, by the ''potential'' transfer of the New York Rangers to the Meadowlands.

title: The Region in Summary; O'Neill Running At Full Speed
description: It seemed for a time that William A.
