O'Neill's heart attack in December, followed by a two-month convalescence that sidelined him at the height of sensitive budget negotiations with the Legislature, might discourage him from seeking a full term as Governor of Connecticut. Mr. O'Neill cleared up whatever doubts remained about that last week with the announcement that he would mount a ''very vigorous'' campaign for the job.

title: TV Mailbag; WHAT'S WRONG WITH LOCAL TV NEWS?
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Big Apple Galaxy Stars will be all over television this week in three different programs taped for the home screen. Performers of note will be assembling from the worlds of film, television, music, dance and theater.

title:
Business Forum;
HOW NOT TO MEASURE PRODUCTIVITY
description: ''P RODUCTIVITY anxiety'' is now afflicting many economic observers in this country, possibly as a result of a faithful reading of the Government's Productivity Index. This is the index of output per employee hour, which lately has shown a decline after a steady climb since 1947.

title: TOWN OUT TO DIVERT YOUTH FROM DRUGS
description: OLD SAYBROOK WHEN William J. Martin, the Superintendent of Schools here, declared a year ago that alcohol and drug abuse had become a problem for some of the town's young people, many of the 9,300 people who live here year-round and regard this community as a coastal oasis free of the crime and other urban ills were stunned.

title: FOOD
description: OMELETS: NOT JUST A FLASH IN THE PAN

title: THE FUTURE LIES WITH CABLE TV
description: IT HAD the makings of a fairy tale: A young, newly elected and idealistic President determined to alter the mediocrity of the past. The year was 1961, and Newton Minow had been appointed by President John F.Kennedy as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. Mr. Minow approached his new position with sincerity and candor, challenging the broadcasters to watch television and declaring that the environment they had created was a ''vast wasteland.''

title: DRAMATIST WITH LENS EMPHASIZES COLOR
description: PORT WASHINGTON WALKING into the current exhibition of photography by Arthur Ollman at the Port Washington Library is somewhat like walking into a dark room in which radiant lights are suddenly turned on, causing the eyes to grow large with glowing luminescence, or like witnessing the lighting of a Christmas tree at night, with its brilliance suddenly assaulting our vision.

title: THE COLOR OF ITALY CAPTURED
description: ARTURO VIVANTE was born in Rome; his latest book is ''Run to the Waterfall.'' By ARTURO VIVANTE

title: BRITAIN'S NEW POP-SYNTHETIC BANDS
description: Synthesizers, computers, and the latest microchip technology have recently given pop musicians some versatile new toys. With various combinations of these devices, it's possible to reasonably approximate the sounds of guitars, bass, drums, and all the other instruments in a conventional rock band, and it doesn't take a bunch of people throwing switches and fingering keyboards. One musician and the requisite amount of hardware can impersonate an entire orchestra, and that's just what has been happening in Great Britain during the past few months. The English pop charts have been dominated by new ''bands'' like Soft Cell and Depeche Mode that are not really bands at all. Soft Cell is just two people, a singer and an electronics expert, and Depeche Mode is a vocalist and a collection of synthetic ''instruments.''

title: PRESCRIPTION ABUSE STIRS CONCERN
description: A27-year-old Bethpage man who works as a licensed registered nurse at a Hempstead nursing home was arrested recently and charged with falsifying business records. It was the third time in two years that the nurse was accused of illegally diverting drug prescriptions.

title: 'SUPERTEACHER' IN CHICAGO UNDER FIRE FROM PARENTS AND PRESS
description: For the last five years, Marva Collins, a teacher who started a private school upstairs in her home, has been described as a ''miracle worker'' and ''superteacher'' in dozens of articles in national publications. Television programs, including the CBS News program ''60 Minutes,'' have shown her and her students, almost all of whom are black and many of whom were once labeled uneducable, poring over Shakespeare, Tolstoy and Plato.

title: MEDICAL EXAMINER ON 24-HOUR CALL
description: FARMINGTON ''QUINCY? Wouldn't hire him.'' The woman sitting behind the desk considered the question about television's medical examiner-sleuth as she stacked glass slides labeled ''Liver Reticulum'' and ''Liver Trichome.''

title: WHAT TO DO IN A NUCLEAR ACCIDENT AT INDIAN POINT
description: WHITE PLAINS IN case of a nuclear accident, those within 10 miles of Indian Point would hear special sirens sound for about three minutes, a signal to tune in for an emergency broadcast on WABC radio, 770 on the AM dial, or WABC-TV, Channel 7. The message would be re-broadcast on 21 other stations, including WFAS-AM, 1230 khz, in White Plains, and WHUD-FM, 100.7 mhz, in Peekskill.

title: THE ALL-ELECTRONICS DEPARTMENT STORE
description: THE way things are going at the brick faced Audio Design store along Mamaroneck Avenue, who knows what will come in next? The television of tomorrow has already arrived. It's a Sony component system that incorporates a high-quality monitor, a tuner, a video recorder and stereo speakers. If that doesn't grab you, there's a Zenith set that you can make phone calls through. There's audio gear that begins at $10,000 and ends at personal bankruptcy. There's a video cassette system that tapes off its own 7.5-inch screen. There's a telephone dialer that remembers 30 numbers.

title: Tonga Isles Devastated
description: Nearly 90 percent of the houses in this South Pacific kingdom's outlying Haabai island group were destroyed by a cyclone, an Australian Air Force officer said today after flying over the area.

title: THE STORY OF A SUPERFLUOUS MAN
description: NOBODY'S ANGEL By Thomas McGuane. 227 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $14.50. Paper, $6.95.

title: A LANGUAGE REMAINS
description: PELAGIE By Antonine Maillet. Translated by Philip Stratford. 251 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.

title: Cissy Smith To Be Wed To Executive
description: Edward James Smith of Upper Marlboro, Md., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Cissy Patterson Smith of Washington and New York, to Samuel Kirk Millspaugh of Timonium, Md.

title: COACHING WAYNE GRETSKY: THE EASIEST JOB IN SPORTS
description: THE first time I saw Wayne Gretzky play was when I was playing with the Cincinnati Stingers of the World Hockey Association and he was with the Edmonton Oilers. It was the 1978-79 season. I had met him the night before the game and he seemed nice, refreshing. But as the game went on, I guess, I expected more.

title: Alan Meisel Weds Linda S. Serody
description: At Temple Sinai in Pittsburgh yesterday Linda S. Serody, director of personnel for the Pittsburgh Symphony, was married to Alan Meisel, an associate professor of law and psychiatry at the University of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Mark Staitman performed the ceremony.

title: Power of Incumbency Shown Again in 1980
description: Even in a year noted for upsets, the powers of money and incumbency were proved again in the 1980 elections.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Tracking a Pest
description: A nationwide search for the potentially devastating khapra beetle began in November 1980 when the prolific grain pest was found lodged in cracks and crevices of a Newark warehouse filled with imported spices.

title: SHARING A ROOKIE'S DOWNS AND UPS
description: FOR the last 11 months, along the way to an agonizing rookie season as a National Basketball Association fan, I spent a fair amount of time with Al Wood. Our relationship began before he left Chapel Hill last March to lead North Carolina to the Final Four of college basketball. I was at the Spectrum in Philadelphia, dazzled by his record-breaking performance of 39 points in the semifinal game, and there on the grotesque night of the final, feeling seedy and sullied, as the lives of President Reagan and James Brady hung in the balance.

title: SUMMER SEMINARS SUGGESTED FOR TEACHERS IN HUMANITIES
description: William J. Bennett, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has called for the creation of summer seminars for those who teach humanities in high schools.

title: THE PHYSICAL AND THE PSYCHICAL
description: WINDOWS ON THE MIND Reflections on the Physical Basis of Consciousness. By Erich Harth. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.50. THE UNIVERSE WITHIN A New Science Explores the Human Mind. By Morton Hunt. Illustrated. 415 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.75. THE ENCHANTED LOOM Mind in the Universe. By Robert Jastrow. Illustrated. 183 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: Michigan Town Sets Training For People Purchasing Guns
description: People who want to buy guns here must either prove a knowledge of gun safety or take six hours of police-supervised instruction.

title: Business Conditions; FINANCIAL FUTURES RISE
description: Declining prices and sluggish international economic conditions resulted in a drop in trading volume in commodity futures last year, the first such decline since 1968. However, according to figures compiled by ACLI International, a commodity service firm, the drop was not enough to prevent overall activity in the futures markets from experiencing another year of growth.

title: Captain Reagan and the Icebergs
description: It's hard to stop thinking about that interview with Senator Bob Packwood last week. ''I really think the President has an idealized concept of America,'' the Oregon Republican said. ''The Republican Party has just about written off those women who work for wages. We are losing them in droves. You cannot write them off and the blacks off and the Hispanics off and the Jews off and assume you're going to build a party on white Anglo-Saxon males over 40. There aren't enough of us left.''

title:
GARDENING;
A POTATO GROWN FROM SEED
description: THIS widely used vegetable was so taken for granted that one seldom saw a reference to it. Garden writers almost totally ignored it. Suddenly the unsung hero of the dining table, the potato, is making gardening headlines because of the release of a new variety called the Explorer, the first potato that can be grown from seed by the home gardener.

title: WINNERS AND LOSERS IN CHINESE-RUN TIBET
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW SHIPS, AND WHAT THEY OFFER
description: If a cruise is in your vacation plans, your choices are greater this year than in the past, and next year they will be greater still. One new ship has already entered service in 1982, and another is due next month. Two others are scheduled to begin sailing by next winter, and three are under construction for introduction in 1983 or 1984. Meanwhile, an older vessel has recently been cut in half and lengthened with a new midsection, and others have been completely or substantially refurbished.

title: AD HOC MUSEUM OF FINNISH DESIGN
description: R. W. APPLE Jr. is chief of The Times London bureau. BY R.W.APPLE Jr.

title: AYN RAND, 'FOUNTAINHEAD' AUTHOR, DIES
description: Ayn Rand, the writer and philosopher of objectivism who espoused ''rational selfishness'' and capitalism unbound, died yesterday morning at her home on East 34th Street. She was 77 years old and a longtime resident of New York.

title: Linda L. Oliver Fiancee of Doctor
description: Mr. and Mrs. S. Roger Oliver Jr., of Moorestown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Louise Oliver, to Dr. Peter Ashton Grape, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Hamilton Grape of Fairfield, Conn. A May wedding is planned in Moorestown.

title: Reading and Writing; THE INCOMPLETE FICTION
description: In ''Sounding the Territory,'' Laurel Goldman concludes her promising first novel by sending her protagonist on a bus trip to California. Since he has no particular reason to go to California and the bus never reaches its destination in any case, one can only assume that the author wished to leave him in a state of ambiguous transit. Like everything else in the novel, this is a typically contemporary effect.

title: Dance View; IS GRETZKY THE NUREYEV OF SPORTS?
description: We know that dance has really made it when Peter Pocklington, owner of the Canadian hockey team, the Edmonton Oilers, calls his 21-year-old center player, Wayne Gretzky, ''the Nureyev of sport, the superstar's superstar.'' Mr. Gretzky, otherwise known as The Great Gretzky, is receiving more attention than usual lately as a result of having broken the National Hockey League's regular-season scoring record.

title: ALMOST A DROPOUT, AND THEN...
description: WHEN my daughter Nan was 17, her high school principal called me to his office. ''We're asking you to take your daughter out of school,'' he said. ''She's been in trouble on and off for the last year, been cutting classes and getting poor grades, and now she's verbally assaulted the gym teacher. We don't feel we can put up with this behavior any longer.''

title: Point of View; LANDMARK AUTHORITY IS WISELY APPLIED
description: In a Point of View article two weeks ago, W. Bernard Richland, City Corporation Counsel from 1975 to 1977, contended that the Board of Estimate should restrain the ''binge'' of landmark designations by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The following reply is by the president of the Municipal Art Society, a partner in the law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel. By RALPH C. MENAPACE

title: THE CASE FOR COUTURE
description: By Bernadine Morris hanks to petrodollars and perfume, the Paris haute couture - the made-to-order sector of the fashion industry - is having a banner season. The oil-producing countries are now providing a new reservoir of customers, for whom price is no object. The perfume and other subsidiary products, from home furnishings to automobiles, have also helped to provide a solid financial foundation for this most luxurious branch of the fashion business.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE ANGOLA RECORD
description: David Rockefeller, with charming simplicity, said last week in Africa that ''We (Chase Manhattan Bank) have found we can deal with just about any kind of government, provided they are orderly and responsible.'' Further, he said he does not consider African Marxism a threat to the U.S. or to American business interests.

title: The Week in Business; EROSIONS IN REAGAN'S BUSINESS SUPPORT
description: Businessmen broke ranks on President Reagan's fiscal policies. The Business Roundtable, made up of top executives, rejected his proposed budget deficits and was said to have backed a deferral of personal tax cuts.

title: Around the World; Israeli Troops Shoot 2 Youths in West Bank
description: Two Arab youths were shot today by Israeli troops in the northern town of Nablus in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. They were among a group of about 40 high school students who threw rocks at an army jeep carrying four soldiers, an army spokesman said.

title: Dr. Barbara A. Zehnbauer Is Bride of Dr. Timothy G. Buchman, Surgeon
description: Dr. Barbara Ann Zehnbauer, a post-doctoral fellow in viral oncology in the Laboratory of Genetics at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, was married in New York yesterday to Dr. Timothy George Buchman, an assistant resident in surgery at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: CONSUMER RATES
FAR NEW HORISONS FOR ROBOTS WITH VISION
description: Just two years ago, the robotics industry's fourth annual trade show drew a handful of exhibitors and a collection of observers better described as a huddle than a crowd. Last week in Detroit, the sixth exhibition, swollen by the displays of giant newcomers such as General Electric Company and I.B.M., and by a horde of smaller companies, spilled out of Cobo Hall and into the neighboring arena. The crowd, estimated at 15,000 over three days, waited in line to get in.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Hotel de Ville
description: Last October, New York City and a Canadian developer announced a tentative agreement to convert the former New York Police Headquarters on the edge of Little Italy into a luxury 125-room hotel.

title: A WRITER'S EDUCATION
description: In his book on Franz Kafka, Elias Canetti says that ''there are writers, admittedly only a few, who are so entirely themselves that any utterance one might presume to make about them must seem barbarous.'' Milton Klonsky affected me that way. Though he was my closest friend for many years, his originality was such that from time to time I would suddenly perceive him as a stranger. It seems to me that one approaches people through their compromises, but Klonsky was either unwilling or unable to compromise. Not because he was a saint, but because as a poor man he knew that being himself was his only luxury.

title: E. Bruce Hallett 3d Will Marry Deborah Donahue
description: Mr. and Mrs. George William Donahue of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Donahue, to E. Bruce Hallett 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Bruce Hallett of Bernardsville, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: LOCAL and county planning officials have been meeting with key state representatives to decide the future of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission, which is scheduled to go out of business on April 30 because of Connecticut's withdrawal from the agency. New York and New Jersey, the other states in the commission, have not yet indicated what action they will take.

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF THE RAILROADS
description: THE history of railroads in New Jersey, leading up to the imminent takeover of the state's commuter lines by NJ Transit, is as long and varied as any other, although the rise and proliferation of rail lines was perhaps more spectacular than most and their decline that much more dramatic.

title: FLEEING BROOKLYN, HE MAKES IT IN COHOES, N.Y.
description: Cohoes - and it is owned and run by a man who once stood near the zenith of a career in the nation's biggest department store chain, one where the loser in the industry's perennial struggle with thin profit margins is often customer service.

title: Vivian Lok, a Paralegal, Is Bride of William Ying
description: Vivian Lok, a paralegal with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, was married yesterday to William Ying, director of systems and operations for the New York Blood Center. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: The Region in Summary; Redistricting Fails Court Test in Jersey
description: In attempting to increase the party's edge in New Jersey's Congressional delegation, Democrats in Trenton enacted a redistricting plan that stretched a few lines. Last week, a Federal court said it also bent the rules to the breaking point.

title: Limousine Service To the Airports
description: The article ''Travel to Airports: Cost Rises'' (Feb. 7) presented an inaccurate summary of our services. The article completely omitted the door-to-door service that our company provides and is an important portion of our operation.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. OUSTS INDIA IN DAVIS CUP

title: A Mere Gesture Against Libya
description: It's almost official: after months of well-publicized indecision, President Reagan has resolved to stop American oil trade with Libya.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Soviet Scores Again on Venus
description: Since 1975, four Soviet spacecraft have survived the dense, hot carbon dioxide atmosphere of Venus to land on the surface and send back pictures and elementary soil sample analyses. But Venera 13 and 14, which last week became the fifth and sixth Venus landers, may prove the most productive yet.

title: THE PROBLEM OF OVERCROWDED JAILS
description: IT'S a new year, and new administrations have taken over at the state and county levels in New Jersey. However, many of the old problems persist and are likely to remain unsolved because of the fiscal constraints that all governments operate under today.

title: The Joys of Winter
description: It was with nostalgia that I read Eleanor Perenyi's ''A Kind Word for Winter'' (Jan. 31).

title: RYE BROOK VILLAGE: TO BE OR NOT TO BE?
description: IN the beginning, there was the town of Rye, and it was in Connecticut. The year was 1660, when a band from Greenwidge, or Greenwich, sailed down to purchase Manussing Island, now Manursing Island. Twenty-three years later, Rye was ceded to New York State, and the legislature defined its boundaries.

title: DESIGNERS' VIEWPOINTS
description: Contrasts are the rule this season - sometimes in the same collection. What, then, do designers think about the directions in which fashion is moving? Although every designer has a unique signature, evident throughout each collection, they agree that there are underlying trends influencing their clothes. Some endorse slim lines, others, separates, and many more talk about practicality and a modern approach to dressing, although each has his own idea of what this means.

title: FIRE IN HOUSTON AT A NEW HOTEL LEAVES 10 DEAD
description: Ten persons died of suffocation early today when a fire in one room of the Westchase Hilton sent thick smoke billowing through the 16-month-old high-rise hotel on Houston's affluent West Side.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER ''Forbidden Broadway'' is a fiendishly funny musical revue that takes merciless advantage of famous leading ladies and gentlemen, hit shows and sacred cows -from ''Annie'' to ''Amadeus.'' It is a bellylaugh at the expense of Broadway.

title: NOnfiction in Brief
description: THE ISLAMIC BOMB The Nuclear Threat to Israel and the Middle East. By Steve Weissman and Herbert Krosney. 339 pp. New York: Times Books. $15.50.

title: Personal Finance; HOW THEY RATE THE MONEY FUNDS
description: IT was bound to happen. Just as the Reserve Fund spawned an industryw hen it set up shop as the first money market fund a dozen years ago,s o William E. Donoghue has spawned an industry in selling informationa bout money funds. Now, a competitior has one-upped Mr. Donoghue by d eveloping a rating system that ranks the money funds in much the s ame way Moody's and Standard & Poor's ranks bonds.

title: FIRE I. EROSION: NEW STRATEGIES
description: TO help planners and homeowners protect private property during storms, scientists are pursuing new strategies in their efforts to understand the geologic forces that are changing the face of 32-mile-long Fire Island.

title: SAVING ON ROOMS, WORKING FOR SCIENCE; Where Remington Captured the West
description: The painter Frederic Remington loved the West but most of his pictures recording the wild frontier were painted at his eminently Eastern estate in New Rochelle, N.Y. All that remains of his world there is a street called Remington Place. The pilgrim who seeks a glimpse of the surroundings in which Remington created his buttes, camps, horses and Indians must go to Cody, Wyo., where the Buffalo Bill Historical Center reopened for the season last week.

title: Environews
description: IDENTIFICATION of many chemicals suspected of fouling the environment in New Jersey often has presented a problem. Time and government bureaucracy, it was said, often stood in the way of getting quick and reliable information on a toxic spill or exposure to a hazardous chemical or determining what Government agency had the appropriate authority.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
The Suhrstedts Offer A Piano-Duet Program
description: The repertory available to duo pianists is substantial, for it includes both the two-piano literature as well as everything for piano, four hands. The latter category even has its own specialists, who go by the name ''piano duettists.''

title: PRIVATE, PUBLIC EDUCATORS MEET
description: THE function of private schools, Donald Barr, headmaster of the Hackley School in Tarrytown, told an educational symposium last week, ''is to keep public school administrators honest.''

title: Children's Books
description: AIRPORT Written and Illustrated By Byron Barton. Unpaged. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $9.95. (Ages 3 to 5) HARBOR Written and Illustrated By Donald Crews. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $9. (Ages 3 to 5) THE CITY Illustrated by Douglas Florian. Unpaged. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $8.95. (Ages 3 to 5)

title: GOVERNORS' ISSUES RANGE FROM TAXES TO TECHNOLOGY
description: AS legislatures around the country have been settling in for a new year's business, they've heard their governors tick off a familiar litany of leftover challenges. But far and away the greatest concern for most governors seems to be making ends meet - and with good reason. Last week, in once-flush California, officials disclosed that the economic slump has caused tax collections to fall off so drastically that the state might not be able to pay its bills by June. In Washington, an analysis prepared for the National Governors Association said that if Congress goes along with the Administration's proposal to spend $81.4 billion on grants in fiscal year 1983, the states would have to make up a difference of some $16 billion to maintain services at their current levels. Following are excerpts from eight governors' recent messages, which highlight some revealing variations on the major fiscal theme. Nevada

title: The Region in Summary; Catcall of The Wild
description: Humble pie isn't Mayor Koch's favorite dish. But that didn't prevent him from consuming a generous helping of it last week during his first gubernatorial campaign trip upstate since his caustic comments about life north of the Bronx and east of Queens were published in Playboy.

title: EURIPIDES COMES TO THE MCCARTER
description: PRINCETON PERHAPS the most gratifying news about the McCarter Theater Company's production of ''Iphigenia at Aulis'' is that it transcends mediocrity.

title: 498 GIRL SCOUTS 'CAMP OUT' AT A MALL
description: EAST BRUNSWICK IT HAD been billed as a ''slumber party'' to celebrate the Girl Scouts' 70th birthday, but at 1:30 in the morning most of the 498 girls camping at the shopping mall here were still wide awake.

title: NASSAU, THE PROMISED LAND
description: COTTON candy is falling from the sky, and it trembles slightly in the breeze and lands gently on the ground. I become mesmerized as I watch it, and tremble slightly too as I feel surrounded with its slow motion and dance of descent.

title: THE VANISHING LOON
description: The cry of the loon, a night sound implanted in the memory of anyone who went to summer camp in New England, has been stilled almost completely, particularly in Connecticut. ''Loons have been extirpated, driven out of the state by development that destroyed their lakeside nesting places,'' said Scott Sutcliffe, naturalist from the Cold Spring Nature Conservancy on Long Island. He will play recordings of loon calls and show slides of the birds with his lecture at 8 P.M. Friday in the Fairfield Audubon Center, 2325 Burr Street.

title: A MASTER OF THE CRANKY OBOE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Andrew Adler writes frequently about music and musicians. BY ANDREW ADLER

title: Elizabeth B. Fannon, W. F. O'Leary to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marcy B. Fannon of Bronxville, N.Y., and Saunderstown, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Barat Fannon, to William Francis O'Leary, son of Dr. and Mrs. James J. O'Leary Jr. of Johns Island, Vero Beach, Fla., and Oyster Harbors, Mass.

title: 675 MEDICAID JOBS TO LEAVE THE CITY
description: New York State's Commissioner of Social Services has said that despite opposition the state will go ahead with a plan to move its Medicaid billing operation from New York City to Albany.

title: A RISING TIDE OF LURES FOR PASSENGERS
description: N ever before have the major cruise lines offered so many incentives to attract passengers. The primary reason for them is an excess of space. New ships - and some elongated old ones -are entering service at a time when a flagging economy and rising costs have inhibited cruise travel.

title: Headliners; Unfinished Business
description: After the Justice Department dropped its antitrust suit against International Business Machines Corporation Federal Judge David N. Edelstein, who presided over the case, questioned whether William Baxter, the chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division, had acted properly in dismissing the case. Last week the judge called for a Congressional investigation into the matter, saying that Mr. Baxter's failure to disclose consulting work he had done for I.B.M. in a previous case raised ''very serious questions'' about the Government's decision. Mr. Baxter received $1,500 for evaluating prospective witnesses in an antitrust suit involving I.B.M. in the mid-1970's.

title: Business Conditions; DISTRESSED ALUMINUM
description: With demand from once-strong customers like automobile manufacturers and home builders still at depressed levels and the once-bouyant overseas markets drying up, these are difficult times for aluminum producers.

title: REGGIE JACKSON: NOW A BORN-AGAIN ANGEL
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz. ON the jukebox Willie Nelson was singing ''I can't wait to get on the road again'' and when he heard the lyrics, Reggie Jackson laughed. ''That's a good song for me,'' he said. ''On the road again.'' The road has put Mr. October here among the cactus and the tumbleweed between Phoenix and Tucson in the Arizona desert where the California Angels conduct spring training workouts before settling in Palm Springs, Calif., for their exhibition games.

title: STORE MANAGER'S 'SUICIDE AID' STIRS CONCERN
description: For more than a month, the manager of a Brooklyn clothing store has been accidentally receiving telephone calls intended for a defunct suicide-prevention service and has been attempting to help some of the callers.

title: A NEW CONFERENCE STIMULATES 7 SPORTS
description: NEW to New Rochelle this academic year is the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, which was host of its own women's intercollegiate basketball championship - semifinals and finals - at the Iona College gymnasium last weekend.

title: DISPELLING MENSTRUAL MYTHS
description: When a New Guinea tribesman found his wife lying on his blanket at the time of her menstruation, he divorced her. When he continued to feel her evil influence, he killed her with an ax. It was sanctioned behavior, based on a belief central to his culture: Any contact a man had with menstrual blood -or even with a menstruating woman - would, as one anthropologist put it, ''corrupt his vital juices, permanently dull his wits and eventually lead to slow death.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

description: Shimatoree, the favorite, equaled the stakes record for six furlongs in scoring an 11-length victory in the 81st Swift Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct.

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lawrence K. Grossman is president of the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: IN POLITICS, A CARELESS WORD CAN BE A SELF-DESTRUCT BUTTON
description: Fresh out of Harvard Business School, Bruce Caputo became a Pentagon ''whiz kid.'' Moving to the New York State Assembly, he was known as one of the Republicans' shrewdest debaters. And when he served in the 95th Congress, he quickly made a name for himself by pressing the ''Koreagate'' investigation.

title: COURT DENIES EFFORT TO HALT SMITHVILLE
description: TRENTON THE Appellate Division of State Superior Court denied a motion last week to order the state's Department of Environmental Protection to review construction permits for the Towne of Historic Smithville in Atlantic County.

title: by Michael Elkins
description: Michael Elkins has been the British Broadcasting Corporation's correspondent in Israel for 16 years. It is written: ''Out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.'' The place befits its destiny. For Jerusalem is stone and light, and light on stone, and at the lift of dawn and the fall of dusk there is no other place in the world as beautiful. The city then is a rose - deeper than pink, softer than red, a stone flower in the sheltering cup of the Judean hills.

title: SCULPTURES POSE A CHALLENGE
description: STONY BROOK ALTHOUGH the making of discrete and precious objects still continues as an important aspect of sculptural expression, the vanguard is now preoccupied with space, time and sequential progression, with exploring the potential of new materials and the possibilities of placing sculpture in the realm of real human experience.

title: ASBESTOS: THE ARGUMENT FOR A FUND...
description: To the Business Editor:

description: The first world conference on the human environment was held in Stockholm a decade ago. It lead to the creation of the United Nations Environment Program to develop sound worldwide practices.

title: The Nation in Summary; This One's for Agent John Doe
description: Nearly a half year after the House acted, the Senate is expected this week to make it a crime to blow the cover of a United States intelligence agent stationed abroad.

title: ORIOLES ARE FACING A PITCHING PROBLEM
description: Some starting pitchers came to the Baltimore Orioles' spring training camp with questions left from last year. If the pitchers brought positive answers with them, the Orioles could have too many starters and somebody would be unhappy.

description: The pace of business failures, which last year reached levels not seen since the early 1960's, has accelerated during the first two months of 1982.

title: Chess; A GAMBIT
description: The most important new gambit to surface in the Reykjavik International Tournament occurred in my last-round game with Lars-Ake Schneider, a Swedish international master. It was awarded the theoretical novelty prize offered by the British journal ''Modern Chess Theory.''

title: ENDING AN ADDICTION TO SOAP OPERAS
description: FRIENDS and family warned me that watching the soaps could be an addictive experience. They reminded me how depressed I felt at the end of ''Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman.'' But my teen-ager had mononucleosis, and the days of her illness stretched slowly before us. After reading, writing, knitting and needlepoint there were still too many quiet hours ahead. Just to keep her company, one day I curled up on the sofa and asked: ''What show is this?''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Jesuits Back In Good Graces
description: Whatever the nature of its transgressions, Pope John Paul II last week apparently decided that the Order of Jesus had been chastened enough. After a meeting with more than 100 Jesuit leaders and provincial superiors, he announced that the largest religious order in the Roman Catholic Church would again be allowed to name its own superior general.

title: DATA SHOW WOMEN'S PAY STILL LAGS BEHIND MEN'S
description: The median weekly earnings of women were much lower than those of men doing essentially the same work in many occupations last year, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CRITICS WONDER IF REAGAN IS PLAYING FOR KEEPS OR FOR TIME
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT Reagan was in a feisty mood as he swung through the West last week, derisively denouncing ''born-again budget balancers'' in Congress and stoutly digging in his heels to protect his tax package, budget and military spending proposals. But his tart mixture of sarcasm and stonewalling fed the mood of revolt in Washington, leaving even his Republican allies wondering why he took such a hard line.

title:
Speaking Personally;
LEARNING TO COUGHP WITH PRONUNCIATION
description: THE TV series ''Brideshead Revisited'' is fascinating, both for its brilliant performances and its reconstruction of a life style that has vanished forever.

description: ''Suddenly, It's Spring.'' This is not an authoritative weather report, but the theme of the Long Island Flower Show, now in full bloom at the State University College at Farmingdale. Sponsored by the school, its alumni association and its horticultural club, the show, with its 40,000 square feet of exhibits and demonstrations, will run from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. today through Saturday and 11 to 8 next Sunday at the college's Nold Exhibit Hall. Admission is $4; for children 6 through 12, $2. 'GRANDMOTHER'S ATTIC'

description: Seventeen leftists, including a woman, were executed in three Iranian towns last week after being found guilty of armed rebellion and membership of opposition groups, the Teheran newspaper Ettelaat reported today.

description: ORANGE THE proliferation of Chinese restaurants in Connecticut continues. Relatively new to the scene - within three or four years - are restaurants that feature Hunan, Sichuan and Peking dishes, along with the more familiar Cantonese.

title: John J. Bertrand, 76, Is Dead; Headed McKesson Liquor Co.

title: Q&A
description: Question:My husband and I want to go to Hawaii and we would like to know when they have a rainy season, and how much the weather varies, in general. - I.F., White Plains, N.Y. Answer:Temperatures average in the 70's during winter and in the 80's during summer. According to a publication of the Chamber of Commerce of Hawaii, the average annual rainfall for Honolulu is 25 inches, with November through March as the wettest months. About 10 days of appreciable precipitation are expected in each of these months.

title:
GARDENING;
A POTATO GROWN FROM SEED
description: THIS widely used vegetable was so taken for granted that one seldom saw a reference to it. Garden writers almost totally ignored it. Suddenly the unsung hero of the dining table, the potato, is making gardening headlines because of the release of a new variety called the Explorer, the first potato that can be grown from seed by the home gardener.

title: HOW TO KEEP WINNING THE WEST IS A CHALLENGE

Perhaps there didn't need to be. Mr. Reagan was visiting the region of the country that most likes him and his party.

Geophysics Division, a newly formed subsidiary of Gulf, is occupying 10,000 square feet at One Blue Hill Plaza in Orangetown, N.Y., at nearly $15 a square foot, according to Edward S. Gordon, president of the Gordon Company. The company took over the management of the complex for the owner, Abko Properties of Wichita, Kan., four months ago.

title: New and Noteworthy
description: OFF THE RECORD: The Private Papers of Harry S. Truman, edited by Robert H. Ferrell. (Penguin, $6.95.) Selections made by a historian from the diaries, memorandums, letters and other papers that the 33d President kept from April 12, 1945, when he moved into the White House, to 1971, a year before his death. They illuminate such events as the Potsdam Conference, the decision to use the atom bomb, the firing of Gen. Douglas MacArthur and the rise of Joe McCarthy, and they add up to a self-portrait of an honest, feisty man, the last President to serve when the office was still on a human scale.

title: Atlantic Salmon Get a Helping Hand
description: NEVER has there been such promise of the return of once-great spawning runs of Atlantic salmon to the Connecticut River. Once so numerous in the stream that indentured servants petitioned to be fed them less often and farmers used them for fertilizer, the salmon were virtually eliminated within a few years after the first dam was built on the river at Hadley, Mass., in 1797.

title: Film Mailbag; More About Moviegoing
description: To the Editor:

title: TISSOT'S RELIGIOUS WORKS REDISCOVERED
description: One of the more enlightening of recent exhibitions is the one devoted to the Biblical paintings of J. James Tissot at the Jewish Museum. If ever a show can be said to ''fill a gap,'' it is this one. It is for that matter one of the curiosities of art-book publishing that there has never been a definitive Life and Times of the French painter James Tissot (1836-1902). The last life of him was by James Laver, came out in London in 1936, and was pretty thin stuff. The last (and only) museum retrospective of Tissot's paintings was at the Rhode Island School of Design in 1968. Yet almost everyone who loves 19th-century painting carries at least one Tissot around in his head, and Tissot in life was one of the oddest and most fascinating of men.

title: STUDENT MUSICAL READIED
description: Six hundred Chappaqua school children from the sixth through 12th grades will participate in a musical revue titled ''The Best of Broadway'' at Horace Greeley High School beginning Thursday at 8:30 P.M..

description: To the Editor:

description: MALGUDI DAYS By R. K. Narayan. 246 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: CHALLENGE OF CHANGE
WAS RUTGERS' SMITH HALL HAZARDOUS TO THEIR HEALTH?
description: For at least two years, Smith Hall, the largest classroom building on Rutgers University's Newark campus, has been the source of mounting tension between faculty and administration. Professors, graduate students and others who work in the building have complained - some as far back as five years after the building opened in 1968 - that potentially harmful substances could be leaking into the building's atmosphere from contaminated water that spilled from the Institute of Animal Behavior, which occupies the top two of Smith's five floors. The plumbing leaks have since been repaired, but subsequent studies showed there were indeed excessive cases of cancer - at least two of them fatal - and other serious illnesses among those at Smith Hall. Last month, after tests revealed possibly harmful concentrations of a known carcinogenic hormone in the building, Rutgers officials ordered it closed pending further tests. Last week, a spokesman said results of those tests were expected by April.

title: Eye Hospital in Jetliner Leaves on Foreign Tour
description: A converted jetliner, equipped for eye surgery and the teaching of ophthalmology, has left the United States on its first foreign tour. The flying eye hospital, the result of a program called Project Orbis, will tour Latin America in the coming weeks, North Africa this summer and possibly China in the fall.

description: Riot policemen jailed 50 youths who seized a vacant building and threw bricks, bottles and sacks of red paint at them during a housing protest here today. Two policemen were injured.

Antiques;
IT'S THAT TIME OF YEAR AGAIN

On today's schedule is a show that combines antiques and crafts. It is being held at Don Bosco High School, Route 17 and Franklin Turnpike, Ramsey, and provides the visitor with an opportunity to inspect the booths of 60 dealers in country antiques and the crafts that complement them.

description: AT the end of 1981, municipal bonds languished in Wall Street's dog house - and with good cause. Investors had w atched with dismay as raging inflation and rising interest rates e roded the market value of their tax-exempt bonds by nearly 50 p ercent in three volatile years.

title: Design; DIGGING DOWN IN TUSCANY
description: On a hilltop in Tuscany, an abandoned farmhouse became a summer retreat for Fred and Muszka Jacobson, an American couple who divide their time between this home in Italy and their apartments in New York and Munich. In 1971, when the Jacobsons purchased this 12-acre property on a winding road in the heart of the Chianti Mountains, just 25 minutes from Florence, the stone dwelling had been empty for almost a decade and its vineyards and olive trees were barren. Originally, the two-story building accommodated horses and cows on the main floor and the farmer and his family on the floor above, a level that could be reached only by an outside staircase situated inside the archway at the front of the house.

title: Washington; THUNDER ON THE HORISON
description: At the beginning of this winter, the protest movement against the nuclear arms race resounded through the streets of Europe. Now we are beginning to hear it in the U.S., like the vague rumblings of distant thunder before a storm.

title: HER SKATING CAREER TAKES A NEW TURN
description: SANDS POINT LAST year, 16-year-old Amy Grossman was contemplating retirement from the world of figure skating. She felt that her preoccupation with the ice had become a lonely, expensive and time-consuming proposition. But last summer, she unexpectedly found a skating partner in Robert Davenport, 17, of the Bronx. Since then, they have become one of the more prominent skating teams in the United States.

description: In the article on ''How the Mind Works,'' the sequence 2,3,5,6,8,9 is given, and the next number asked for. The answer is easy to obtain because the sequence separation is 1-2-1-2.

title: Frances Prout Engaged to Russell Selby
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Prout of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Wall Prout, to Russell MacLeod Selby, son of Mrs. James Stacey Coles of New York and Woods Hole, Mass., and Dr. Henry M. Selby of New York and Westhampton, L.I.

title: BROADENING THE REACH OF THE ARTS
description: HUNTINGTON SALLY and Jennifer Fox are taking piano lessons; Matthew McDonald is involved in an after-school video workshop; the Quinones brothers - Juan, Patrick and Anthony - are learning that sports and dance are closely related, and Cory Walters is into arts and crafts.

title: Miss Waltrip To Be Bride
description: The engagement of Karen Kay Waltrip to Daniel Thomas Bennewitz has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Waltrip of New York and Westport, Conn., parents of Miss Waltrip. Her fiance is the son of Beatrice Smoot Bennewitz of Westport and the late Don H. Bennewitz.

title: Architecture View; A SUPERB SCHEME FOR THE RENOVATION OF CARNAGIE HALL; by Paul Goldberg
description: There are few buildings in Manhattan as beloved, and as frustrating, as Carnegie Hall. It is so vital a part of the city's cultural and social history that it seems inconceivable that it was almost demolished for a garish red skyscraper two decades ago; New York without Carnegie Hall is something akin to New York without the Plaza or New York without Grand Central Terminal.

title: WHEN THE GRASS IS 'BLUE' IN KENTUCKY
description: JOSEPH W. WARD is a staff writer with the Louisville Courier-Journal. BY JOSEPH W.WARD

title: The Nation in Summary; 'Soldier's Soldier' Is Reagan's Man
description: For the general who is the Army's Vice Chief of Staff, the caisson has usually rolled about as far as it will go. Accordingly, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr. had planned to retire this summer.

title: EDINBURGH
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIAN POINT 3 PLANT EARNS 'GOOD' RATING ON EMERGENCY DRILL
description: The emergency preparedness at the Indian Point 3 nuclear plant is ''generally good, although there are areas that need strengthening,'' Federal officials said today.

title: U.S. SAID TO AID IRANIAN EXILES IN COMBAT AND POLITICAL UNITS
description: The United States is secretly aiding Iranian paramilitary and political exile groups and beaming radio propaganda into Iran, according to Western intelligence officials and other sources. They said the program was designed to counter growing Soviet influence in Iran and to give the United Statesa role of its own in the event that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic regime falters.

title: ...FOR ALTERNATE MATERIALS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: THE INTREPID, VICTOR AGAIN, NEARS FINAL BERTH
description: During World War II, in Leyte Gulf in the Philippines, she appeared on the scene early in what would become one of the greatest naval battles in history. She survived attacks from Japanese kamikaze pilots and went on eventually to destroy 80 enemy ships and 800 aircraft.

title: Film Mailbag; MORE ABOUT MOVIEGOING
description: To the Editor:

title: PIANO: POLLINI IN A VARIED PROGRAM
description: It might have seemed one measure of Maurizio Pollini's appeal Friday night that he could fill Avery Fisher Hall to the last seat and the stage as well for a program that contained music by Bartok, Schoenberg and Luigi Nono, yet, the last being a work for piano and tape. Of course, Mr. Pollini was sold on a Lincoln Center Great Performers series on the basis of his name, and there were grumbles in the audience at the indignities to which he was subjecting them. A number of people marched out, loudly, during the Nono. But it is still admirable to try to confront piano buffs with the music of our time, and perhaps some who stayed had their ears opened.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT RANGERS BY 6-4
description: The Rangers continue to lose hockey games at Nassau Coliseum. With a 6-4 victory tonight, the Islanders defeated their Parkway rivals for the ninth straight time at home, as well as for the 17th time in their last 18 meetings on Long Island.

title: DANCE: DANIEL LEWIS TROUPE, MAINSTREAM MODERN
description: So many young modern dancers today are seen in the reduced vocabulary or intricate patterning of the works labeled as ''post-modern'' that one wonders who is left who can still master the styles and techniques of mainstream modern dance.

title: HILARY IRIS WIENER TO WED
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Hilary Iris Wiener, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Wiener of Fresh Meadows, Queens, to Scott Foreman Zarrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Okla.

title: WORLD'S RICHEST LITTLE ISLE
description: Few islands in the South Pacific look less promising from the air. Instead of the usual verdant atoll -all palm trees and beaches - the island is more like a chunk of gray lunar landscape encircled by a thin ribbon of green along the shoreline. In the interior, a few sparse clumps of vegetation stand out amid stark rock pinnacles. Clearly, this is not an ordinary tropical paradise.

title: ESTROGEN BENEFIT IS INDICATED
description: The death rate among women between the ages of 40 and 69 taking estrogen after hysterectomies may be one-third that of women in the same age range not using the hormone, according to a study made public today at a conference of the American Heart Association.

title: LINCOLN TOUR
description: To the Editor: Having traced the path of our 16th President this past summer, I would like to add another item to your Lincoln article.

title: THE JOYS OF WINTER
description: It's great to have the delights of winter so beautifully expressed by Eleanor Perenyi.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Alex Ogle, Flutist, In Ensemble Works
description: When a debut artist surrounds himself on stage with a variety of accompanists in a variety of ensemble works, he is presenting himself not just as an instrumentalist with a technique to be soberly judged, but also as a chamber musician. Alex Ogle, in his flute recital last Sunday afternoon at the Merkin Concert Hall succeeded both technically and musically with his varied program.

title: WHERE SCHOOLCHILDREN WOULD BE TAKEN
description: IF an evacuation were ordered during school hours, children at schools within 10 miles of Indian Point would be bused from their schools directly to ''school reception centers'' beyond 10 miles. As the evacuation of children and adults was completed, buses would shuttle between the Reception Centers and Congregate Care Centers for adults and the School Reception Centers, allowing parents without cars to retrieve their children.

title: ONCE MORE, SYMBOLS CLASH OVER JERUSALEM
description: The city of Jerusalem, symbol to so many competing faiths and sects and national movements, has also become a symbol of the anxiety with which Israel and Egypt are entering the next phase of their process of peace.

title: THE PHYSICAL AND THE PSYCHICAL
description: Robert P. Geroch is a professor of physics and mathematics at the University of Chicago. His latest book is ''General Relativity From A to B.''THE COSMIC CODE Quantum Physics as the Language of Nature. By Heinz R. Pagels. Illustrated. 370 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. 17.50.By ROBERT P.GEROCH

title: Capital Hotels
description: To the Editor: Mimi Sheraton in her article ''Five Special Washington Hotels'' (Travel, Feb. 7) describes the Hay-Adams Hotel as being on the site of the homes owned by John Hay and John Quincy Adams. The double dwelling on this site was built by John Hay (1838-1905) and Henry Adams (1838-1918), not by John Quincy Adams, who was Henry Adams's grandfather. FRANCIS ADAMS Harrisonburg, Va.

title: POSSIBLE TAX CHANGE PERILS TRANSIT PLAN
description: IT was a way of getting back some of the Federal aid that the Reagan Administration is squeezing from local governments. And it had the added allure of being in concert with the trend to involve private enterprise.

title: NEWS SERVICE CONTEMPLATED BY AGA KHAN
description: The Aga Khan, the spiritual leader of 20 million Ismailian Moslems in the Middle East, is considering starting an international news service, largely devoted to covering events in developing and underdeveloped countries.

title: SERVICE FOR AGED IMPERILED
description: WITH cutbacks in Federal funds for social services a virtual certainty, state and local officials expect programs for the aged, including those at county hospitals, to suffer.

title: Headliners; Doublespeak
description: Intrigued by the symbols used to represent ideas, Reena Beth Gordon began a project last July to determine how English was understood when spoken.

title: TV Mailbag; WHAT'S WRONG WITH LOCAL TV NEWS?
description: To the Editor:

title: FIVE CRUISES
description: Here are the offerings for the next world cruise season, which begins in January: Cunard Line Queen Elizabeth 2: Capacity 1,450; 13 passenger decks, 67,000 tons. Casino, shopping arcade, miniature golf course, one acre of open deck space.

title: COUNTY CELEBRATING WOMEN'S HISTORY
description: MAE MORGAN ROBINSON is a 77-year-old former social worker from Yonkers who has worked for civil rights and for women's equality for many years.

title: A WHIRL IN PETER USTINOV'S BUSY,BUSY WORLD
description: He stars as an eccentric Belgian detective in a new movie that opened this weekend. He has just finished writing a play, for which he anticipates a London opening in the fall - with himself as the star, of course, and playing no lesser a personage than Beethoven. In the next few months, he reports, he will - among other things - put together a movie based on a screenplay he's just completed about a Turkish bandit, finish writing his literary work in progress, ''a coffee table book about Russia,'' direct ''a couple of operas at La Scala,'' and do a television play.

title: New Jersey Guide; RAMPAL IN MONTCLAIR
description: Aficionados know how difficult it can be to get tickets to hear Jean-Pierre Rampal, but they'll have a chance in Montclair. Tickets to the March 26 recital are going fast, so reservations should be made quickly.

title: Theater Mailbag; DEBATING THE PORTMAN PROJECT
description: To the Editor:$

title: CAPITAL HOTELS
description: To the Editor:

title: GALLUP POLL SHOWS DEMOCRATS FAVORED AS PROSPERITY PARTY
description: As the recession wears on, the American public has abandoned a briefly held view of the Republican Party as the party best able to insure the nation's prosperity, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: EGYPTOLOGIST SAYS HE DID NOT MISLEAD
description: A prominent Egyptologist has denied that he made misleading alterations in a hieroglyphic text to support his hypothesis that the Exodus of the Israelites occurred about 200 years earlier than previously assumed. His statement, prompted by charges of deception, was the latest development in a controversy that has been simmering for months.

title: HAWKS TROUNCE NETS BY 112-92
description: The Nets fell rudely back to earth tonight. After rallying from a 14-point deficit to beat the Bulls Friday in Chicago, New Jersey ran out of miracles, falling behind by as many as 22 points in the final period and receiving an old-fashion trouncing from the Hawks, 112-92, at the Omni.

title: The Region in Summary; Fighting Fire With Women
description: It is a popular belief that no city job consistently requires more physical strength and agility than that of firefighter. But whether or not the job requires those qualities, the physical exam for it certainly does -so much so, in fact, that it unfairly discriminates against women, a Federal judge ruled last week.

title: A Correction
description: The Week in Review of Feb. 28 gave an incorrect date for the conviction of Juan V. Corona. He was found guilty in January 1973 of murdering 25 itinerant farm workers.

title: Topics Endorsements Sanitizing Guatemala
description: Guatemala has a mournful distinction. It is the hemisphere's worst offender against human rights. According to State Department figures, there were as many as 300 political killings a month in 1981, triple the level in 1980, with the blame divided between Government forces and guerrillas.

title: Stage View; IS THERE EVER A 'PERFECT' PERFORMANCE?; by Walter Kerr
description: If there's one experience a reviewer becomes inured to down the years it's the experience of having friends come in from out of town, as apple-cheeked and bustling as though they were bringing Chicago weather with them, and, after a fur-lined handshake, ask with great exuberance ''Well, what shows shall I see?''

title: WIRETAPS FOCUS OF BATTLE
description: A PAIR of proposals to liberalize the use of telephone wiretaps and to permit placement of electronic eavesdropping equipment in public or private locations could become one of the General Assembly's fiercest battles this spring.

title: LANDLORDS' OBJECTIONS TO CO-OP BILL
description: ''TENANTS are easy to organize, because they're all right there together,'' said George Frank, a member of the board of Apartment Owners' Advisory Council.

title: Art; NEW PERSPECTIVES AT NABISCO
description: EAST HANOVER QUITE a bit is happening at Nabisco these days. For one thing, there's the American eagle, a steel-and-chrome creature that is 14 feet tall, 18 feet long and has a wing span of 28 feet. It stands imperially, guarding the front door of the corporation's headquarters at the junction of Ridgedale and DeForest Avenues.

title: Islamic Group Sending Envoys to Iran and Iraq
description: Islamic mediators trying to halt the conflict between Iran and Iraq decided today to send envoys to the warring capitals.

title: Second of two articles.
description: The nation's colleges and universities are being forced by economic pressures to change their policies on who they hire and promote, which courses they teach, what kind of research they conduct and which students they admit. The schools, in adjusting to fiscal realities, may soon have more in common with business and industry than many educators thought possible.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CURTAIN RAISER

title: FIREMEN WARY ON HIRING OF WOMEN
description: The No. 1 topic of conversation in a lower Manhattan firehouse this weekend was the possibility that women may be joining the firefighting ranks in New York City.

title: Beth Daniel Wins
description: Beth Daniel sank a 5-foot birdie putt on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff today to win the $100,000 Sun City Classic.

title: AFTER 69 YEARS OF SILENCE, LYNCHING VICTIM IS CLEARED
description: New but long-held secret information was disclosed today in one of the most disputed trials in American history, the murder conviction and subsequent mob lynching of Leo Frank almost 70 years ago.

title: IT'S NOT THE BUS. IT'S US.
description: Political opportunists in the Senate want to turn the Supreme Court's school-desegregation decision in Brown v. Board of Education into an Indiary treaty - a law on the books, but unenforceable.

title: MOROCCO ASKS O.A.U. TO REVERSE SAHARA DECISION
description: Morocco today urged African leaders to rescind the decision of the Organization of African Unity to admit the Polisario Front guerrilla organization.

title: NEW JET AMERICA LINE STRESSES SERVICE AND PERIPHERAL AIRPORT
description: Since 1965, when Alan H. Kenison helped found Air California, a regional air carrier now called AirCal, ''all I ever wanted to be was president and principal stockholder of my own airline,'' he said.

title: Washington Watch; Writers Vs. Printers
description: WASHINGTON A CONFRONTATION between authors and those who print and bind the books they write has broken out over an obscure provision of the Copyright Act designed to protect domestic jobs.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIA, WITH FIVE CHORUSES
description: MYTHS, morals and madness were portrayed in the Great Hall of Cooper Union on Friday night in a concert devoted to choral theater, part of the Brooklyn Philharmonia's ''Meet the Moderns'' series. The event, which brought five choruses to the facility's stage to ''enact'' - with the help of costumes, props and lighting - choral works by five 20th-century composers, was the brainchild of Hugh Ross, conductor of the Schola Cantorum, and the composer Frank Ledlie Moore.

title: MRS. REAGAN'S INCOMPLETE CONCERN
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Sabina Shalom didn't have to disappear into a phone booth to find herself donning a new identity. It took only a backpack and a paid ''sabbatical'' from her 30-year marriage, she said, to transform her from a ''fat little housewife in Coral Gables, hooked on TV'' to a round-the-world traveler and occasional hitchhiker, covering 55,000 miles, two dozen countries and a half-dozen states on her own.

title: HAGLER KNOCKS OUT LEE IN 67 SECONDS
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler scored the first one-round knockout in a world title fight today in more than three and a half years, covering more than 275 championship bouts, and it was hardly a surprise.

title: STOCK RALLY HOPES TIED TO RATE DIP
description: With the stock market battered to a 22-month low in some of the heaviest trading in the history of the New York exchange, Wall Street's leading money managers say no sustained improvement is likely without a sizable drop in interest rates.

title: IRT Train Derails Downtown, Forcing Removal of 96 Riders
description: A train on the Lexington Avenue IRT line derailed yesterday in lower Manhattan but there were no reported injuries, the Transit Authority said.

title: MUSIC: A MILESTONE FOR PHILHARMONIC
description: THE New York Philharmonic's 10,000th concert was celebrated in Avery Fisher Hall yesterday with champagne, speeches, special exhibits, a slide show, a photograph of the audience and, not least, a spectacular performance of Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony under the direction of the orchestra's music director, Zubin Mehta.

title: NICKLAUS'S 67-203 LEADS BY STROKE
description: There are jokes made about the irony of ''Jack's winning Arnie's tournament,'' but both Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer would like nothing better - Nicklaus because he considers the Bay Hill Classic a well-managed tournament on a superb golf course, and Palmer because a Nicklaus victory would assure the return next year of this tournament's most distinguished defender.

title: CORRECTION
description: A correction Saturday incorrectly described the Fusion Energy Foundation. It is a group that favors the use of nuclear power.

title: GUATEMALANS VOTE FOR NEW LEADERS
description: As soldiers with automatic weapons stood guard, Guatemalans voted today in elections for President, Vice President, members of Congress and municipal officials.

title: So Gladly She Hails
description: The way I see it, I'm 35 years old (who lies about their age anymore?), make $27,500 a year (thank heaven I took that typing course) and deserve the occasional cab. I mean, if you don't treat yourself right, who will? Sure some cabs are dirty, and sure a lot of the drivers don't understand English very well, and sure they're not too hot on geography either.

title: Petrofina Sets Refund Pact
description: The Government has announced an agreement with American Petrofina Inc. under which the Dallas-based oil company agreed to refund $14.1 million in settlement of pricing violation accusations totaling $262 million.

title: EXTRADITION IS SOUGHT
description: Robert L. Vesco, the financier who fled the United States more than 10 years ago, has surfaced in Antigua, a small island in the West Indies, according to The Atlanta Constitution.

title: CAMPAIGN WORRY: REAGAN INFLUENCE
description: ''Politicians are a bunch of Nervous Nellies,'' Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware and a candidate for re-election, said the other day. ''Six months ago they were all scared to death of inflation; now they're all frightened by the recession. If the economy starts turning up, you'll see everybody endorsing the President's program again.''

title: Town Meeting
description: Town meetings are held in town halls, school auditoriums, movie theaters - any place that's big enough to house a group of people voting on their lives. The issues are not described so grandly; nonetheless, deciding whether or not to change a zoning law, hire additional teachers, levy a tax or fund a new snowplow is a way of organizing one's future.

title: Sites, Draws For N.C.A.A.
description: The sites, pairings and seedings for the 1982 National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I basketball championship: East

title: Khomeini, Meeting Athletes, Urges Spread of Revolution
description: In an apparent effort to combat rumors that he is seriously ill, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini welcomed a group of Iranian soccer players today at his residence in northern Teheran and urged them to spread the Islamic revolution to other nations.

title: Auto Race Drivers Accept Sanctions
description: Grand Prix drivers in conflict with the International Auto Sports Federation accepted today the sanctions imposed by the sport's highest court, but called for the resignation of F.I.S.A.'s president, Jean-Marie Balestre.

title: B.& S. WINS BETAMAX BID
description: The quality client list of Backer & Spielvogel is growing again. And again it is at the expense of McCann-Erickson, alma mater of most B.& S. top management.

title: Israel and France to Discuss Possible Atom Reactor Deal
description: Israel and France will hold talks in Paris next month to discuss the possible sale of a French nuclear reactor to Israel, a Government official here said today.

title: HEALTH STUDY INVOLVING MINE FIRE IN PENNSYLVANIA CANCELED BY U.S.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has canceled a $20,000 research grant to measure levels of carbon monoxide in the blood of residents of a Pennsylvania town where a fire has been burning for 20 years in an abandoned underground coal mine.

title: M.T.A. SETS CONDITIONS FOR RUNNING RAIL LINES
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that the state agency was prepared to take over the operation of three Conrail commuter lines at the end of the year - as long as it did not cost the M.T.A. any extra money.

title: The U.N. Today; March 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not going to say the energy crisis is over, but we are certainly heading in the right direction.

title: Suit on W. C. Fields
description: The story goes that the comedian W. C. Fields once suggested that he wanted to have on his tombstone the epitaph ''On the whole, I'd rather be in Philadelphia.''

title: U.N. Report Says Starvation Threatens Many in South Asia
description: Poverty, unemployment and chronic trade deficits continue to blight the countries of South Asia, according to a United Nations survey published today.

title: EDWARD L. PATTON OF ALYESKA IS DEAD
description: Edward L. Patton, the man who led construction of the 800-milelong Trans-Alaska oil pipeline, died Friday at Overlake Hospital in Bellevue, Wash. He was 65 years old.

title: Sports World Specials; High-Scoring Team
description: Manhattan College did not fare well on basketball courts during the season just ended, but, more importantly, its players managed handsomely in the classroom. The Jaspers won only 11 of 26 games and 3 of 10 in the Metro Atlantic Conference. But the 12-man roster compiled an average grade of 3.0075.

title: Tolentine Moves To Semfinals
description: Ernest Myers scored 29 points and grabbed 16 rebounds as Tolentine, the defending champion, advanced to the semifinals of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association playoffs by defeating All Hallows, 79-66, at Fordham yesterday.

title: Gymnast 5th After Reprieve
description: Time and fortune ran out yesterday for a Cinderella in leotards. Gina Stallone, a last-minute replacement in the American Cup gymnastics competition, had been mistakenly eliminated in the trials Saturday because of a scoring error and then restored at midnight by the judges. But she finished only fifth in the championship round when an American teammate and a Bulgarian tied for first place.

title: YEAR'S PLANS ARE LAID FOR TIMELY WRITER
description: The 15 horses who were quickly led off the track after the Flamingo Stakes Saturday were covered with mud and looked exhausted. Timely Writer, who was responsible for their bedraggled state, stayed on the track a few extra minutes to have his picture taken. He had kicked mud in their faces and exhausted them, and now he was pawing and snorting as if he wanted to take on all comers for a few more furlongs.

title: REAGAN'S ANECDOTAGE
description: Does a single speech matter? Can one discourse really change minds? Reminds me of a story: Paul Muni, the star of several great movies of the 30's, received his training as an actor on the Yiddish stage. In a play about a labor organizer's defiance of a skinflint boss, the intermission lasted an abnormally long time. After the show, the star was asked the reason for the delay between acts.

title: A 3-ZONE ZOO WITHOUT BARS IS PROPOSED FOR CENTRAL PARK
description: There are penguins, polar bears and red pandas, but there are no elephants, antelopes or zebras. And there are no bars in the plans for a new Central Park Zoo - moats and glass will keep people and animals apart.

title: NATO Exercise Starts Today
description: A major command exercise of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is to start Monday with a scenario featuring anti-Soviet moves in eastern Europe, NATO sources said today.

title: HIGHLY-RATED TEAMS TO HIT THE ROAD FOR N.C.A.A. TOURNEY
description: Instead of waiting by the telephone, as they did in the old days, the top college basketball coaches waited in front of television sets yesterday. They had to sit through the commercials, with everyone else, to learn the final selections and pairings of the 48 teams that will compete for a spot in the national collegiate championship game in New Orleans March 29. ''Like the Emmys,'' said Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach. ''It's getting to be more and more of a production.''

title: In the College Money Bowl
description: ''We're not even really part of the school anymore, anyway. I work for the N.C. State Athletic Association. That has nothing to do with the university. Our funding is totally independent. You think the chancellor is going to tell me what to do? Who to take into school or not to take into school? I doubt it.''

title: IONA, MIFFED, TAKES N.I.T. BID
description: The Iona College Gaels cut down the nets after an overtime championship game victory against St. Peter's in the first Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament last Friday. But yesterday, with more victories than all but 14 of the teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament field, the Gaels (24-8) remained on the outside, looking in.

title: U.S. Winds Up Davis Cup Victory
description: Vijay Amritraj beat Eliot Teltscher, 6-3, 7-5, today to give India its only victory over the United States in first-round Davis Cup play.

title: N.C.A.A. at Work On Clemson Case
description: Clemson, which won the national collegiate football championship, could be charged with recruiting violations by the end of next month, according to a published report.

title: 2 Medals for Braa At Lahti Games
description: Norway's Oddvar Braa won the men's 50-kilometer cross-country World Cup ski race in the Lahti Games today.

title: REMOVAL OF WAYWARD-CHILD CASES FROM FAMILY COURT URGED
description: The Mayor's Criminal Justice Coordinating Council has urged that one category of cases involving wayward children - the so-called persons in need of supervision - be removed from the jurisdiction of Family Court, except as a last resort. As an alternative, the council suggested that neighborhood social-service centers be set up to handle the cases.

title: 'A VERY, VERY POOR PLACE IN WHICH TO DIE
description: 'To the Editor:

title: WHAT DO THE YOUNG OWE THEIR COUNTRY?
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. MARCIA DALE KASS WED TO DAVID M. WAITZMAN
description: The marriage of Dr. Marcia Dale Kass to David Myles Waitzman took place yesterday at the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn. Rabbi Alvin Kass, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: SANTA ANITA TO JOHN HENRY
description: John Henry became the first horse to win the Santa Anita Handicap twice when he won the 45th running today on a disqualification, after having finished second by a nose to Perrault.

title: Huffy Official Sees Strong Spring Sales
description: Harry A. Shaw 3d, 44, president of the Huffy Corporation, a major manufacturer of bicycles, has been appointed to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective July 1. He will succeed Stuart J. Northrop, 56, who will remain chairman of the Dayton-based company.

title: AINGE HELPS TO DEFEAT KNICKS
description: Larry Bird, the Boston Celtics' top scorer, was recovering from surgery on a fractured cheekbone and missed his fourth consecutive game. Nate (Tiny) Archibald, the playmaker, had damaged ligaments in his right wrist and was out for nine games. So when Gerald Henderson, Archibald's understudy, left today's game against the Knicks with three personal fouls and 5 minutes 34 seconds remaining in the first quarter, it appeared the Celtics would have another disadvantage.

title: Race Is Put Off Again
description: The Carolina 500 Grand National stock car race, which had been rescheduled for today, was rained out for the second straight week.

title: Newark Fire Kills 1, Hurts 4; Firemen Investigating Cause
description: Firemen today were investigating the cause of a rooming-house fire that killed one person, injured four and left 36 homeless.

title: BLUE-COLLAR WORKERS' SUPPORT FOR REAGAN DECLINES
description: ''I hear all sorts of people saying, 'To think I voted for Reagan,' '' said James M. Seidelman, a 37-year-old union pipefitter at the Oldsmobile plant in Lansing, Mich. ''Well, I'm one of them.

title: Mima Jausovec Wins Tennis Title
description: Mima Jausovec of Yugoslavia used steady ground strokes today to score a 6-2, 7-6 victory over Sylvia Hanika of West Germany in the final of a $150,000 Avon tennis tournament.

title: METS ARE ALERTED ON SWITCHING POSITIONS
description: George Bamberger reached into the pocket of his uniform, brought out the dollar bill and made his debut in the Mets' annual spring training pool.

title: DUARTE HAILS REPORT OF 'AGENT'
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte today endorsed a police report identifying a captured Nicaraguan who later got away and entered the Mexican Embassy as a soldier sent to train guerrillas here.

title: SOVIET REPRISALS ON AFGHANS CALLED FIERCE
description: Armed resistance to the Soviet military presence in Afghanistan is continuing, but on a smaller scale than that reported by the insurgents, and Soviet forces appear to be responding with a much heavier hand, according to United States and British analysts.

title: Sports World Specials; Going to the Dogs
description: John Baum was a big winner at Madison Square Garden in 1969 when he led the Temple Owls to the National Invitation Tournament title. Last month, Baum, No.2 in Temple career scoring behind Guy Rodgers, again triumphed at the Garden. This time, though, Baum's victory came as the owner and handler of Raheims Hasani Azzizi, a 2-year-old Great Dane, at the Westminster Kennel Club Show.

title: Quake Shakes Kashmir
description: A strong earthquake rattled windows in Kashmir today, but there were no immediate reports of major damage or casualties, the seismological office here reported.

title: SYRIA'S CHIEF SAYS U.S. SENDS ARMS TO INSURGENTS
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria accused the United States and Iraq today of providing weapons to Moslem militants who are seeking to topple his Government.

title: From the Pulpit, a Call for Nuclear Disarmament
description: With the fragrance of Lenten incense in the air at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Paul C. Warnke mounted the pulpit yesterday to call for nuclear disarmament.

title: Commodities; Emerging Index Futures
description: THE sharp price declines in the stock and nonfinancial commodities markets in recent weeks could not have occurred at a more propitious time for the newest entry into the futures industry -stock-index futures.

title: Gomez Is First
description: Rodolfo Gomez of Mexico won the Golden Marathon today in 2 hours 11 minutes 49 seconds. Vladimir Kotov of the Soviet Union was second in 2:13:34.

title: Pope Prays for 'Stable Peace' And 'Liberty' for Guatemala
description: Pope John Paul II devoted a major part of his sermon today to Guatemala, praying for ''stable and secure peace, liberty and justice'' for ''that tormented country.''

title: MUBARAK SURRENDERS TO THE HARD-LINERS
description: To the Editor:

title: RATE DECLINE SEEN DURING RECESSION
description: The good news in the credit markets is that interest rates are expected to decline in the near future. The bad news is that the declines are expected to last only as long as the economy is in a recession.

title: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF A NONCONFORMIST AFRIKANER
description: Frikkie Conradie was raised on a farm in the western Transvaal in a typical Afrikaner household. It was a place where no one ever questioned the divinely ordained right and need of whites to rule over blacks in this land.

title: Mini Meets Grandma
description: EVERY week there are more of them - Billie Jean's spiritual granddaughters. They struggle into the satellite tournaments or they blast right into the major Avon circuit, the way Andrea Leand did last week.

title: The Bullets of Capitalism
description: It's the first good Polish joke since the coup in December: General Jaruzelski visits Moscow to get the Russians' blessing for his dictatorship and beg their help in overcoming the opposition of his people. In conclusion, they jointly declare that the West's failure to keep supporting bankrupt Poland would be rank ''interference'' in its internal affairs.

title: NICARAGUA WOOS ITS BUSINESSMEN WITH A PACKAGE OF 'CAPITALIST' INCENTIVES
description: Nicaragua's revolutionary Government has decreed a package of ''capitalist'' economic measures that some officials describe as a ''last effort'' to persuade the local private sector to participate more fully in the country's mixed economy.

title: DALI GETS A MUSEUM IN FLORIDA
description: The conjunction of Salvador Dali and the City of St. Petersburg sounds like the theme of a Dali painting at its most wildly surreal. But now it is a fait accompli.
