On Wednesday, a $2 million museum devoted to the controversial Spanish artist will open in this winter-baseball capital and retirement haven, and there is hope that it will soon develop into a major tourist attraction.

title: Goldwater Introduces Cable TV Bill
description: Senator Barry M. Goldwater has introduced a comprehensive cable television bill that would permit cities to own and operate cable systems. The bill also contains numerous provisions that are expected to stir debate in the broadcasting community.

title: 45 WEATHER POSTS GIVEN A REPRIEVE
description: A Reagan Administration austerity program that called for closing 75 of the Government's 348 weather stations has run into unpredicted protests, forcing Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige to reverse the plan in part.

title: THE STRESS IN DOCTORS' FAMILIES
description: They are the spouses and children of doctors, and they have always been envied for their high status, their high income and their highachieving style of life. But according to researchers who have studied them, and in the opinion of psychiatrists who have treated them, life in the medical family isn't always a permanent vacation in Camelot. These investigators have found that the stress in doctors' lives can be damaging not only to their children and their marital partners, but also may may affect all of us in the quality of patient care and the level of medical costs.

title: OIL CONCERNS LEAD LIST OF MAJOR PROFIT MAKERS
description: Oil companies continued to dominate a list of the nation's 25 largest nonfinancial concerns in 1981 in terms of revenues, but profits of the big biggest petroleum producers were lower across a broad front as a worldwide oversupply kept a lid on oil prices.

title: JAZZ: BASIE IS HONORED
description: THE Black Music Association paid tribute to Count Basie at Radio City Music Hall yesterday evening. Although the evening had its ups and downs, it built to a blistering five-song set by Stevie Wonder and a single, riveting number from Lena Horne. Mr. Wonder's warmth, energy and lyricism, and Miss Horne's musicianship and charisma, were what made ''To Basie With Love'' really special.

title: SUSAN LEON MARRIED TO ANDREW DAVID FREDMAN
description: Susan Leon, an editorial assistant with the Viking Press in New York, and Andrew David Fredman, an architect wih the New York firm of Beyer, Blinder, Belle were married yesterday in the Helmsley-Palace Hotel. Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky of White Plains performed the ceremony.

title: Hepler Takes Golf
description: Denny Hepler of Illinois beat Hsieh Ming-nan of Taiwan and David Ogrin of the United States in a sudden-death playoff to win the $150,000 Malaysian Open golf championship today.

title: Bridge: Authorities Will Take Up Issues of Professionalism
description: Professionalism will receive considerable attention when the board of directors of the American Contract Bridge League meets in Niagara Falls, N.Y., next week. In North America, unlike Europe, there are virtually no tournaments with cash prizes, so professionals cannot exist as they would in golf or tennis. Instead they make a living, or part of one, by hiring themselves out to players of lesser ability as partners and teammates.

title: TRIBUNAL SET UP TO ADJUDICATE U.S.-IRAN CLAIMS APPEARS TO BE BOGGED DOWN
description: The international tribunal set up to deal with claims arising from the hostility between the United States and Iran is still hacking its way through procedural thickets, seven months after it began its work and before it has settled a single case.

title: 7 ON WAY TO CHURCH DIE IN NEWARK CRASH
description: Two women and five girls who were on their way to church services were killed this morning in a fiery crash between their car and a fuel-oil truck. Among the victims were a mother and her three daughters.

title: NO BARTERING FALLOUT
description: THE J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. announcement Friday that it would be getting out of ''time banking'' for more than one client at a time, will apparently have no effect on the other five agencies in the TVprogram syndication business.

title: Belgium Gas Cutback
description: The Belgian Government has decided to limit its future imports of Soviet natural gas, sources close to the Government said.

title: THOSE WHO RECRUIT CANDIDATES SAY THE PARTIES ARE RUNNING ABOUT EVEN
description: Eight months before Election Day, the Democrats have come from behind and caught up with the Republicans in the first round of the 1982 races, the contest to find strong candidates.

title: THE AIDES ARE SHAPING UP, LITERALLY
description: It takes a while to notice that something is unusually austere on this latest trip by the White House staff accompanying President Reagan to his ranch here.

title: NATIONALIST FACTION OF BLACK MUSLIM MOVEMENT GAINS STRENGTH
description: Six years after a split in the World Community of Al-Islam in the West, formerly known as the Black Muslims, membership in the main faction has eroded and a splinter organization has gained strength.

title: The Economy
description: Plunging stock market prices are linked directly to high interest rates, according to top money managers. Unless rates come down sharply and soon, they fear a further deterioration in corporate profits and the value of shares in the affected companies. (Page D1.)

title: SURVEY FINDS RECESSION RATE EASING
description: The rate at which the economy is declining has eased, according to the February survey of the purchasing managers at some of the nation's largest industrial companies.

title: Brenda Mines Cut
description: Brenda Mines Ltd., a unit of Noranda Mines Ltd., a major minerals producer, said it would shut its British Columbia copper and molybdenum mining operation for six weeks because of poor markets and low sales.

title: EXPANDING ROMANCE MARKET
description: The stuff of dreams is big business, and today the romance business, at least in its paperback variety, is becoming especially big.

title: DEBRA S. GREENFIELD BECOMES BRIDE OF DR. SOLOMON GENUTH
description: Debra Shira Greenfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Greenfield of Monsey, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Solomon Genuth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Genuth of Brooklyn. Rabbi Max Schreier performed the ceremony at the Sands of Atlantic Beach on Long Island.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1982
description: International Guatemalans voted in what are widely being referred to as the country's ''last chance'' elections. Guatemalans say that if the elections for President and Vice President, for the national Congress and for municipal officials are not tainted by massive fraud, and if the army allows the people's choice to assume the presidency, then there is a possibility of a peaceful solution to the civil war. (Page A1, Column 1.) Iran is receiving military equipment and arms worth millions of dollars from Israel, North Korea, Syria, Libya, the Soviet Union and Western Europe to wage war against Iraq, Western intelligence sources said. These countries, along with the United States, are struggling openly and covertly for influence on Iran's future and over the balance of power in the Middle East. (A1:2-3.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday misstated the position of J. Walter Thompson USA on bartering syndicated television programs. The agency plans to continue to barter programs in exchange for commercial time on television stations for individual clients. An explanatory article appears in the Advertising Column on Page D9.

title: WHAT DO THE YOUNG OWE THEIR COUNTRY?
description: To the Editor:

title: 24 Silver Dollars, but a Wealth of Honor
description: The Museum of the City of New York's highest honor is its $24 Award, which symbolizes the Dutch purchase of Manhattan for the equivalent of $24. It may be a paltry amount, but recipients of the award - given annually to an outstanding New Yorker - are always happy to get it, because it's the thought that counts.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Required Reading Trickle-Down?
description: David E. Bonoir, Democrat of Michigan, speaking on the floor of the House of Representatives concerning President Reagan's budget proposals. Feb. 9, 1982:

title: ADOLESCENTS, PARENTS AND BIRTH CONTROL
description: Do parents have the right to know that contraceptive drugs or devices have been prescribed for their adolescent children? Or do teen-agers have the right to obtain birth control without the knowledge - and possible disapproval - of their parents? Do they have the same rights as adults to confidentiality in sex-related matters?

title: Launching Pad Is Prepared For Space Shuttle's 3d Trip
description: Technicians finished loading volatile fuels into the space shuttle today and began securing a launching pad in preparation for Columbia's third launch, March 22.

title: No Headline
description: 76ERS ON TOP; 46 FOR TONEY

title: WILLIAMS TO RESUME DEFENSE IN HIS EXPULSION CASE TODAY
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. is to resume his defense today when the Senate reconvenes to complete debate on whether to expel him for his conviction in the Abscam investigation.

title: 'Part of the Job'
description: The car was in flames, a couple were trapped inside, and it was, in short, the kind of emergency that calls for quick thinking and courage.

title: FUR LINES POCKETS FOR MICHIGANDERS
description: Tyrone Ewig is a heavy-equipment operator at construction sites during the brief summer on Michigan's Upper Peninsula, a job he unenthusiastically describes as ''pushing dirt from point A to point B.''

title: Market Place; A Close Look At Servico
description: SERVICO INC., which runs Holiday Inns and other motels and hotels, has tried to retire its outstanding shares twice. Now it seems resigned to public ownership, only to find that its shares have languished.

title: Pennsylvania Museum Names a New Director
description: Robert H. Dyson Jr., dean of the faculty of arts and sciences of the University of Pennsylvania, has been appointed director of the school's 95-year-old University Museum.

title: Surgery Separates Twins, Born Joined
description: Twin sisters joined at the side and chest were reported in good condition today after a 10-hour operation to separate them, only four days after their birth.

title: Defendant Found Guilty In '80 Miami Riot Death
description: A former garbage collector has been convicted of murder and arson for setting fire to a car with an elderly man trapped inside. The incident took place in May 1980, during three days of race rioting in which 18 persons were killed.

title: VALUE OF 2 DOLPHINS SET FREE IN '77 AT ISSUE IN HAWAII CASE
description: How do you set a value on two lost female Atlantic bottlenosed dolphins whose intellect was ''comparable to humans''?

title: Israelis Start to Remove Equipment From Sinai
description: Seven weeks before the deadline for their evacuation of Sinai, the Israelis started today to remove equipment from the prosperous desert farms they set up there.

title: OUTDOORS: SINGING THE PRAISES OF TODAY'S AIR GUNS
description: MY acquaintance with air guns began over 40 years ago on a rural island off Cape Cod. Then, I couldn't wait to own my first powderpowered .22 rimfire so I could earn some extra cash by shooting, for 25 cents each, the rabbits intent on devouring Mrs. Johnson's flower garden.

title: FOR ISLANDERS, A BIG FINISH
description: The Islanders are putting on their annual rush to the National Hockey League finish line, and Saturday night the Rangers were just another team they had to beat to keep up the momentum.

title: LAWYER FOR DEFENDANT IN SADAT TRIAL ARRESTED
description: The defense attorney for one of five men sentenced to death for the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat was arrested early today on charges of disclosing details of the closed military trial, Cairo newspapers said.

title: Bobbie Brooks Inc.  Appoints President
description: Maurice Saltzman, 63 years old, will step down as chief executive officer of Bobbie Brooks Inc., a leading women's apparel concern that he co-founded in 1939, around May 1, the end of the fiscal year, the Cleveland-based company announced. Although he will continue as chairman, Mr. Saltzman will be succeeded as president and chief executive officer by Lawrence Halpern, 47, currently president of the corporation's Bobbie Brooks division.

title: JACKSON, FRANKLIN GAIN P.S.A.L. FINAL
description: Although Andrew Jackson High School has not won a Public Schools Athletic League basketball title since the mid-1940's, when Bob Cousy played, it has been in the playoffs almost every year in Coach Chuck Granby's 13-year reign. And now it has another chance to win the title, gaining the final yesterday with Benjamin Franklin.

title: Sports World Specials; Bonus Babies
description: The Yankees have spent millions of dollars on players in recent years and have baseball's biggest payroll. But Dave Righetti, their 1981 rookie wonder, is not sharing in the cascade of riches.

title: CUOMO WON'T AGREE TO SUPPORT NOMINEE OF DEMOCRATIC PARTY
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo refused yesterday to say whether he would support the winner of the Democratic primary for Governor, and, when asked to explain, used the opportunity to attack Mayor Koch, a potential opponent.

title: Bonn Young Democrats Back Nuclear-Free Zone
description: A national convention of a political youth group closely allied to the Free Democratic Party called today for a nuclear-free zone in Europe and for the resignation of Bonn's Minister of Economics, Otto Lambsdorff, a Free Democrat.

title: 'SLOW-START' GUIDRY IS OFF TO A FAST START
description: Ron Guidry, one of the Yankees' new millionaires, kicked off the spring schedule today with three hitless innings in the Yankees' 1-0 loss to the Atlanta Braves, and characterized his outing as ''the best I've ever thrown this early.''

title: Harvard Study Supports Rise In Limits on Campaign Funds
description: A Harvard University study today recommended a dramatically increase in the amount of money available to Presidential candidates, both from the Treasury and from individual contributions.

title: VW Rabbit Move
description: Volkswagen of America has begun shipping a less expensive, more fuel-efficient Rabbit model to dealer showrooms, a company official said.

title: Topics  Stacks / Hacks Archive Gap
description: ''It's like burning the Library of Alexandria,'' Barbara Tuchman, the historian, complained to a House committee, protesting the Administration proposal to cut the budget of the National Archives.At the behest of the Arab general who captured Alexandria, the contents of the city's great library were packed off as fuel to heat the public baths.

title: BASIC SHIFTS IN CONSUMPTION CITED
description: The energy crisis, the source of so much personal discomfort and national anxiety during the 1970's, has eased materially. Almost every day brings new announcements of price reductions for gasoline as world oil prices slide. And supplies - barring an upheaval in the Middle East - appear increasingly available.

title: 'WHIRLPOOL' IN MILKY WAY MAY POINT TO BLACK HOLE
description: Long a mystery to astronomers, the dust-obscured inner core of the relatively placid Milky Way Galaxy appears, from newly reported observations, to be a region of extreme turbulence, with a ''whirlpool'' whose velocities reach 4.5 million miles an hour and where periodic explosions blow giant ''smoke rings'' outward.

title: FARLEIGH DICKINSON CAPTURES IC4A TITLE
description: Fairleigh Dickinson, winning only one of the day's 16 finals, gained its first team title today in the IC4A indoor track and field championships.

title: STATE TO SAVE $88 MILLION FROM PAYROLL 'LAG' IN NEW UNION CONTRACT
description: New York State will save about $88 million in the coming fiscal year because most of its employees have agreed to forgo two weeks' pay until they resign or retire, according to Meyer S. Frucher, director of the state's Office of Employee Relations.

title: HOCKEY OLD-TIMERS HELP OUT
description: Twenty years ago, Camille Henry, a very small man with a great knack for putting the puck in the net despite the battering he took from larger hockey players, led the Rangers with 37 goals.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Centuri Inc. has sold at face value $10 million of its 10 percent convertible notes due 1988, convertible at $5 a share.

title: THE MARKS OF RACISM IN U.S. FOREIGN POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt TOWARD A NEW COLD WAR. Essays on the Current Crisis and How We Got There. By Noam Chomsky. 498 pages. Pantheon. Hard cover, $20.50; paper- back, $8.95.

title: SALVADORANS ARE ACCUSED OF MORE MASSACRES
description: Guerrillas and villagers in San Vicente Province say that Government security forces murdered a total of 124 people in this Salvadoran hamlet and two nearby hamlets in January, but the charges could not be verified on a visit to El Campanario today.

title: SCREEN: 'SPECIAL TREATMENT,' A COMEDY
description: ''Special Treatment'' was shown as part of the 1980 New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Sept. 30, 1980. The film opened yesterday at the Film Forum 2, at 57 Watts Street.

title: A Bichon Frise Is Best in Show
description: The dogs - 2,489 of them - took over the grandstand of the Meadowlands Race Track today as the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey staged its 39th annual show, and the best turned out to be a bichon frise, Ch. Hillwood Brass Band, owned by Ellen Iverson of Chevy Chase, Md., and handled by Ted Young.

title: FOR OFF-HOURS, SUBWAY ZONES FOR SAFER WAIT
description: Reasoning that there is strength in numbers, the New York City Transit Authority recently began setting aside special areas on subway platforms where passengers could congregate late at night while waiting for trains.

title: NORTH CAROLINA WINS TITLE
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference championship basketball game started as a thriller between two fine teams today, but became a bore when North Carolina used its four-corner stall in the last eight minutes to preserve a 1-point lead and beat Virginia, 47-45.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bangor Punta Corp., Greenwich, Conn., has elected L.J. Deters a senior vice president, and Morgan C. Brown 3d a vice president.

title: WHAT DO THE YOUNG OWE THEIR COUNTRY?
description: To the Editor:

title: RUMANIA IN TALKS WITH I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund, now playing an active role in rescheduling negotiations between Western banks and Rumania, has begun working with Bucharest on a new economic reform package, banking sources have reported.

title: 7 STATES DISPUTE LIBRARY AID CUT OF 28% BY U.S.
description: It's a ''mix-up,'' says the Reagan Administration. It's a ''power grab,'' says New York State's Attorney General. It has left the nation's libraries wondering if they will lose nearly $20 million - 28 percent - in this year's Federal aid. New York and six other states have just gone to court in what has become an unmerry-goround.

title: HABIB RETURNS TO ISRAEL FOR TALKS
description: President Regan's special Middle East envoy, Philip C. Habib, returned to Israel today after a week of meetings in Arab capitals on Lebanon and other Middle East issues.

title: No Headline
description: Secord Gets His 42d Goal

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a report on Saturday of the route of travel of a Nicaraguan detained in El Salvador was incorrect. The Nicaraguan, Ligdamis Anaxis Gutierrez Espinosa, was on his way from Mexico to Nicaragua at the time of his detention.

title: NEW BONDS' VOLUME UP
description: The volume of new corporate bonds is rising as borrowers are attracted by the lower interest rates. This week's volume could total $1 billion, but it may vary widely since only one issue is scheduled for competitive sale to underwriters.

title: A PORTRAIT OF THE JERSEY MASS KILLER AS AN OLD MAN
description: Just after breakfast on Sept. 6, 1949, Howard B. Unruh - a brooding, dark-eyed veteran of World War II - loaded his souvenir German Luger and stepped into the neighborhood shoemaker's shop here to begin a lethal agenda he had set for himself the night before.

title: A P.L.O. VOICE FOR PEACE (2)
description: Anyone who travels in the Arab world knows that Egypt is not the only country to have become more realistic about Israel in recent years. Many say, however grudgingly, that they would be prepared to accept the Jewish state as a permanent part of the Middle East if it withdrew from the Arab territory occupied in 1967.

title: Tough Stance on Auto Thefts Is Ordered by Miss Holtzman
description: The policy of prosecuting all auto thefts in Brooklyn as misdemeanors has been halted, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman announced yesterday.

title: REAGAN ENTERTAINED BY SINGER HE ONCE PARDONED
description: The country-western singer Merle Haggard, who spent nearly three years in San Quentin Prison for attempted burglary and who was later pardoned by the Governor of California, sang today for the man who pardoned him, President Reagan.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With one out and the count two balls and one strike, a batter objects so strongly to the umpire's call of a second strike that he is ejected from the game. Is he also the second out?

title: Race to Brown
description: Marty Brown of Deep River, N.Y., scored a 200-yard victory over Kevin Ruch today in the Long Island Road Racers' Club 20-kilometer run.

title: Run Record Set
description: Cathie Twomey of Los Angeles beat Akemi Masuda of Japan in a 20-kilometer race in Nagoya today with a record time of 1 hour 6 minutes 52 seconds.

title: BUDGET CHAIRMAN SAYS BOTH PARTIES WILL SEEK CHANGE
description: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee expressed optimism today that Congress would put together a bipartisan budget as an alternative to President Reagan's proposal.

title: French Oil Surplus
description: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine and CFP Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles, France's two biggest oil companies, said on Friday that they have an oil surplus of about 20 percent of their normal stocks and are seeking ways of reducing it. A spokesman for Elf Aquitaine said his company had begun talks with Saudi Arabia aimed at cutting the surplus but declined to elaborate. A CFP spokesman said his company was considering ways to cut the surplus, but would not say if they entailed talks with suppliers on cutting deliveries.

title: Semperit's New Chief Studies Radial Market
description: O.A. Pat Martin, 59, has joined Semperit of America, the United States subsidiary of Semperit, a big Austrian rubber manufacturer, as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Franz J. Leibenfrost, 42, who continues as chairman of the Northvale, N.J., company, which markets industrial rubber products such as conveyor belting, hoses and specialized items, as well as tires.

title: IRAN SAID TO GET LARGE-SCALE ARMS FROM ISRAEL, SOVIET AND EUROPEANS
description: Iran is receiving military equipment and arms worth hundreds of millions of dollars from Israel, North Korea, Syria, Libya, the Soviet Union and several countries in Western Europe to support its war against Iraq, according to Western intelligence sources.

title: THICK FOG SMUDGES CITYSCAPE
description: Thick and wet and woolly, fog wrapped the city and the harbor yesterday morning, circling the Apple like Saturn's rings. Low cloud ceilings and zero visibility in some spots brought mysterious marine signals and changed plans and schedules all the way from airports to Manhattan brunches with a view.

title: BRIEFING
description: Forbidden Word

title: FOREIGN FARM LOANS BY U.S.
description: When the Commodity Credit Corporation paid two American banks a total of $3.35 million on Poland's debt last week, it was the first time that the agency had ever had to cover delinquent payments on a foreign commodity loan guaranteed by the Department of Agriculture.

title: UNIONS DIVIDED ON REVISION OF CLEAN AIR ACT
description: Organized labor is divided into at least three antagonistic parts over what to do about the Clean Air Act. As Congress considers revisions in the antipollution statute, the construction unions of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. have endorsed a bill being drafted by the House Energy Committee that would make substantial changes in it. But many of the industrial unions in the federation are fighting the proposed legislation.

title: CREATING TUNISIAN INSECURITY
description: Habib Bourguiba, the grand old man of Arab politics, President of Tunisia since 1956, the staunchest friend of the West in North Africa, is passing, as old men must, from the political scene.

title: 3 Held in Fire Deaths of 8
description: Three men were arrested today and charged with arson and eight counts of murder stemming from a tenement fire that killed five children and three adults. The three suspects were identified as Felix Garcia, 31 years old, Edgardo Garcia, 19, and Victor Rosario, 24, all of Lowell.

title: S.I. COAL-REFUSE POWER PROJECT GETS U.S. AIR-QUALITY PERMIT
description: A Federal environmental agency has given a final air-quality permit for construction of a state-operated coal-and-refuse-fired power plant on Staten Island.

title: Fire Releases Toxic Fumes
description: A fire today at a plant where herbicides and insecticides were stored released toxic fumes that forced the evacuation of the area and sent 35 people to a hospital, the state police said.

title: CITY OPERA: 'L'AMORE DEI TRE REI'
description: ''L'AMORE DEI TRE RE'' is one of those tantalizing operas that once were staples of the repertory but for this or that combination of reasons have dropped out of sight and hearing. Except for a rare attempt at resuscitation, such as the noble effort put forth last night by the New York City Opera, Italo Montemezzi's three-act tale of courtly life in 10th-century Italy has been a dead issue for about half a century. But it is still remembered fondly by veteran operagoers as a sensational vehicle for divas such as Mary Garden, Lucrezia Bori and Claudio Muzio. When once a work has enjoyed that kind of public acceptance, it will always fascinate opera enthusiasts and therefore have a chance to attract a new audience.

title: World Best in 400
description: Jarmila Kratochvilova of Czechoslovakia ran a world indoor best in the women's 400-meter race today, clocking 49.59 seconds during the finals of the European championships. Miss Kratochvilova bettered the mark of 49.64 that she set in Vienna in January 1981.

title: PENSION STUDIED IN CODY CASE
description: The Chicago Sun-Times reported today that the nation's largest Roman Catholic archdiocese submitted false insurance documents so that John Cardinal Cody's lifelong friend, Helen Dolan Wilson, could receive an unearned pension.

title: TV: 'NIGHT OF 100 STARS' IN A 3-HOUR VIDEOTAPE
description: AS it turned out, more than 200 stars showed up for the spectacular bash Alexander H. Cohen whipped up a few weeks ago at Radio City Music Hall to mark the 100th anniversary of the Actors' Fund of America. But, arguing that poetic license can also be invoked by producers, Mr. Cohen is sticking with ''Night of 100 Stars'' as the title for the television version of the evening. It runs for three hours this evening, beginning at 8, on ABC-TV.

title: Red Brigades Terrorists To Go on Trial Today
description: Sixteen Red Brigades terrorists charged with the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier go on trial Monday in a heavily protected courthouse two miles from where the general was abducted.

title: TO MARTIN, YANKEES ARE 'BEATABLE NOW'
description: Dave Anderson

title: D.D.B. Earnings Rose 16.7% in 4th Quarter
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International last week released its fourthquarter and year-end earnings statement.

title: ALL ALONE: LIFE IN THE GOAL
description: AROUND the National Hockey League, when the conversation turns to goaltenders past and present, the tone of speech genuflects to awe. Goaltenders, like those who open soup kitchens in farflung outposts, are viewed as either heroic or mad. For the most part, the goalies themselves do little to dispel the myth.

title: O'Malley Expects Valenzuela Soon
description: Peter O'Malley, president of the Los Angeles Dodgers, in his first public comment regarding Fernando Valenzuela's week-old holdout, said today that he expects Valenzuela to arrive in spring camp and to honor his contract.

title: New Farmer Option Urged
description: The commodities futures industry needs to be more informative and innovative when it comes to serving farmers, Kalo A. Hineman, the first farmer to become a commodities industry regulator, said here Friday.

title: Academic Restrictions Assailed as 'Damaging'
description: Restricting academic research to try to stop unauthorized disclosures of technology to the Soviet Union is ''unnecessary'' and ''damaging,'' the president of Stanford University said today.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Books Of The Times
description: By Michiko Kakutani EDWARDIAN FICTION. By Jefferson Hunter. 280 pages. Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $536,000 for the qr and $525,000 for the 6 mos and a net gain of $424,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the disposal of real estate Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 6 percent stock divd paid in Nov 1981

title: Chess: Poor Opening Spoils a Bid For a Grandmaster Norm
description: At the start of the last round of the Reykjavik International Tournament in Iceland, the grandmaster Lev Alburt of New York and the international master Bosko Abramovic of Yugoslavia held the lead with 7 1/2 points each. But Abramovic, refusing to jeopardize the first grandmaster norm he was achieving, quickly drew as White against Leonid Shamkovich, a Queens grandmaster. Thus, the door was left open for Alburt.

title: MARATHON OIL MERGER: $6 BILLION CLIFFHANGER
description: Some of the big names on Wall Street - all major stockholders in the Marathon Oil Company - are lining up on opposite sides of the fence on the question of whether Marathon should complete a $6 billion merger with the United States Steel Corporation.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JAPAN'S 'CONCESSIONS' ARE BACKFIRING BADLY
description: The Japanese are eroding Americans' sense of t rust.

title: Advertising; Eisaman's Cadillac Ad Test
description: EISAMAN, JOHNS & LAWS ADVERTISING of Los Angeles, New York and Houston, whose client list includes 18 Chevrolet dealer associtions, is next going to be working for General Motors' Cadillac Motor division. It will be doing an advertising test with four dealer associations in four widely separated markets.

title: RESEARCHERS PONDER ITS USES FOR MAN
description: SOME time this month, the woodchuck wakes for good. Instead of emerging from its burrow for a brief look-see, as it is apt to do on Feb. 2 or any other randomly chosen day in midwinter, the woodchuck - along with bats, ground squirrels, hedgehogs, dormice and several other rodents and insectivores of cold and temperate zones -has come to the end of his winter hibernation and rejoins the world of the full-time mammals.

title: ACID IS FOUND IN CLOUD SAMPLES
description: The analysis of samples collected from a stratospheric cloud circling the Earth indicate the cloud is made up of tiny droplets of sulfuric acid, the remnants of a volcanic eruption, scientists said today.

title: N.I.T.'s FIELD OF 32 OFFERS A MIXED BAG
description: The National Invitation Tournament begins tonight with 32 college basketball teams, some with excellent records, some that barely had winning seasons and some that would prefer to be somewhere else.

title: SWAYING OF PATCO VOTE DENIED
description: A member of the Federal Labor Relations Authority said today that he had spoken with a labor leader before voting to decertify the striking air traffic controllers' union, but that he had not been threatened or intimidated.

title: Business and the Law; Jury Research: Ethics Argued
description: TAKING a case before a jury is risky and a new business has sprung up designed to eliminate some of that risk. Using a blend of marketing techniques and applied social sciences, several jury research companies say they can tell a lawyer how a jury is likely to respond to his case - and how to improve that response.

title: Belushi to Be Buried Today In Martha's Vineyard Rites
description: John Belushi is to be buried Tuesday on an island hillside near the Martha's Vineyard summer home he bought three years ago, The Cape Cod Times reported today.

title: THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Stipanovich Ailing
description: Steve Stipanovich, the star center for Missouri's basketball team, will miss practice this week because of a sprained foot, and the Tigers say they don't know whether he'll be ready Saturday to play in the national championship tournament against the winner of the first-round game between Marquette and Evansville. Stipanovich was injured Sunday in an informal workout. ... Quintin Dailey of San Francisco has been restored to the all-America team selected by the United States Basketball Writers Association.

title: LEFEVER'S VIEWS ON RIGHTS PREVAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Plans TV Programs
description: The New York Times Company yesterday announced the formation of NYT Productions, a new venture to produce television programs. NYT Productions will draw on the resources of The New York Times and Times Company affiliates.

title: GOLD COIN FAVORED BY U.S. BOARD
description: The United States Gold Commission today completed all but the final details of its recommendations to Congress. The recommendations reject a gold standard for the United States, while favoring the minting of a new gold ''coin'' that would be sold at the market value of its gold content but would not be used as currency.

title: Ford in Venture For Plastic Motor
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would enter a joint program with privately held Polimotor Research Inc. to develop and perhaps manufacture a plastic car engine by the late 1980's.

title: FROM MAJORITY LEADER TO MINORITY LEADER
description: At first, when the Senate fell to the Republicans, the Democrats seemed about as organized as a hive of smoked bees.

title: MICHIGAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,038,000 for the qr and $2,929,000 for the yr and extraordinary credits of $93,000 for the qr and $1,278,000 for the yr...C-Net income after a loss of $1,044,000 from discontinued operations... D-Net loss after a loss of $7,591,000 from discontinued operati

title: Gore Vidal Challenges Brown For Hayakawa's Senate Seat
description: Gore Vidal, the writer, said today he would challenge Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. for the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat being vacated by S.I. Hayakawa, a Republican.

title: Illinois Thrift Units Merged
description: Two Chicago-area savings and loan associations have been given permission to merge in the seventh such federally assisted merger so far this year, the Government announced today.

title: Cool Cat Gets a Gig in Play About Colette; Cool Cat Gets a Gig
description: A play about Colette, the French writer, would seem unbelievable, indeed, if there weren't at least one cat in it. Colette was, after all, one of the world's best-known cat-lovers.

title: PARTICLE BEAMS USED TO TREAT RARE CANCERS
description: CYCLOTRONS at two universities are being used successfully to treat rare cancers that appear near the spinal cord and that have been fatal in the past because they are virtually impossible to remove surgically and do not respond to conventional radiation therapy, researchers at both institutions said in interviews yesterday.

title: State-by-State Asbestos Fight Seen in Wake of Court's Move
description: Lawyers familiar with asbestos litigation said yesterday that the Supreme Court's refusal to decide which insurance companies were liable and the extent of their liability would force the companies and policyholders to fight such matters out on a state-by-state basis.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an error by the New York City Department of Health, a listing of restaurant violations on Feb. 28 incorrectly described the status of the Roy Rogers restaurant at 1286 Broadway. The restaurant was found free of violations.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT RED WINGS BY 6-3
description: Mikko Leinonen, the 26-year-old rookie center from Finland, scored two goals within 33 seconds and assisted on a third to lead the Rangers to a 6-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: UNITED PRESIDENTIAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
WOLVERINE WORLDWIDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STRONG GROWTH IS PREDICTED AT WAL-MART AND TOYS 'R' US
description: Peering at the murky retailing situation, analysts are trying to find the standouts, the growth companies of the 1980's. What they have come up with is a handful of discounters.

title: Key Rates
description: ** Maximum rate payable by savings insitiutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ARMY-BACKED CANDIDATE IN THE LEAD IN GUATEMALA
description: The Government's Presidential candidate took a substantial lead today in incomplete returns from Sunday's elections. But charges of wide-scale fraud and misconduct were raised by two major parties.

title: M.T.A. SEEKING JAPANESE CARS FOR IRT SYSTEM
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is close to a deal with a Japanese company for the purchase of 325 subway cars, sources close to the talks said yesterday. It would be the first purchase of foreign-made passenger cars for the New York system.

title: Units of Wickes On Credit Watch
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said it had placed the Wickes Corporation and Gamble-Skogmo Inc., both retailing units of the Wickes Companies, on its Credit Watch, a move that usually presages a credit downgrading.

title: NOISE SEEMS NO BOTHER TO THE F.A.A
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; March 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

title: British Back Canada Charter
description: A bill to give Canada final control over its own constitution was approved by the British House of Commons tonight by a vote of 177 to 33. The measure, which was requested by the Canadian Government, now goes to the House of Lords and the Government hopes to pass it into law in the next month.

title: MOST CARAEY OFFICIALS ARE STICKING AROUND
description: Stanley Kramer, one of Governor Carey's policy makers on transportation issues, has left the administration to run for the House of Representatives. Mr. Kramer, who resigned Feb. 1, is the first of Mr. Carey's appointees to leave office since the Governor said he would not run again.

title: POP: ENGLISH BAND NAMED ORCHESTRAL MANOEUVRES
description: THERE is a continual tug in pop music between innovation and tradition - between wanting to sound fresh but leaning on the past. In fact, with so much pop today, it seems as if originality is defined mostly as how deftly new bands succeed in combining influences.

title: TOYOTA AND G.M. STUDY JOINT PLANT
description: The world's two largest auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Company, are discussing joint production of small cars in the United States, Toyota said today.

title: CANADIAN PARLIAMENT ON HOLD AS PARTY BLOCKS ENERGY BILL
description: Bells have been ringing for six days in Canada's House of Commons, where it is still last Tuesday. That is the day when the bells began calling members to a roll-call vote. The opposition Progressive Conservative Party, however, has refused to heed them as a way of blocking consideration of a 149-page bill on energy matters and of challenging the Liberal Party's long rule over Canada.

title: Bid to Limit Coverage Of Raider Trial Denied
description: A Federal judge today rejected a motion by the National Football League to restrict news coverage at a retrial of the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the league.

title: REVERING IS EAGER TO SWING HIS BAT
description: Dave Revering, waiting for his turn at the batting cage Sunday at the West Palm Beach Municipal Stadium, gazed toward a grove of trees beyond the right-center field fence, where he had homered last week in a Yankee B game.

title: Savin's Low In New Post
description: Robert K. Low will step down as president of the Savin Corporation after the Canada Development Corporation completes its purchase of a majority interest in Savin for $75 million, the company said yesterday. Mr. Low, who has been with Savin 23 years, will assume the newly created position of vice chairman of the board of directors and will also remain as a director of the company, Savin said.

title: TOUCHE ROSS FILLS 2 KEY U.S. POSTS
description: Two executives of the international accounting and consulting firm of Touche Ross & Company, David Moxley and W. Grant Gregory, have been elected to key posts in the firm's United States branch, it announced yesterday. Mr. Moxley will be managing partner, and Mr. Gregory will be chairman of the board.

title: DEREGULATION OF BUSES
description: The Reagan Administration urged deregulation of the intercity bus industry today as a Senate panel considered legislation dealing with this last of the major commercial transportation modes still under Federal rules.

title: Federal Workers Start Series Of Furloughs to Cut Expense
description: The Government began one-day furloughs for tens of thousands of employees today in response to President Reagan's order to cut expenses.

title: REAGAN REPORT UNSETTLES BRITONS
description: Over the weekend, the White House told reporters that President Reagan would address both Houses of Parliament in June. The disclosure has embarrassed the British Government, aroused complaints from the opposition and prompted a formal apology from the American Ambassador.

title: GREATER OUTLAYS ON U.S. ARMS URGED
description: Senior military planners say it will take more than the $1,600 billion President Reagan has proposed for the next five years to carry out the armed forces' broad mission, it was disclosed today.

title: Markets
description: Several leading banks reduced their prime lending rates by half a point, to 16 percent. It was the lowest level for the prime in three months, and hopes rose in banking circles that interest rates would continue to fall. One forecast was for a 14 percent rate within 30 to 45 days. Chase Manhattan also reduced its residential mortgage rates by a quarter point. (Page A1.)

title: The Editorial Notebook Beaten at Our Own Game
description: Japan has won a stunning victory in computer memory chips, a hightechnology product in which American companies were supreme until only a few years ago. The victory illustrates a difference in industrial policy: Japan protects and encourages its new industries, the United States only those that are failing.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE public schools are engaged in a desperate battle to regain public confidence by improving their quality. Their efforts, however, are undercut by proposals to subsidize parents who send their children to private schools, with nasty undertones about the public schools' inferiority.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Securities, Philadelphia, has elected Jack Farber, chairman, to the additional post of president.

title: No Headline
description: COACHES POLL

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES CHIEF ON LEAVE OF ABSENCE
description: Irving T. Tague, the founder and chairman of Midway Airlines, started a leave of absence March 1, the company announced yesterday. When Congress approved airline deregulation in 1978, making it easier to establish new airlines, Mr. Tague was one of the first out of the gate. He raised most of the necessary capital and lined up enough planes to start flying by November 1979. Midway is the first interstate jet carrier formed under the new rules.

title: BRIEFING
description: Rumors at State

title: PEKING LEADERSHIP BEGINS STAFF CUTS
description: The Chinese leadership embarked on a long-awaited overhaul of its administrative apparatus today by whittling a dozen of its ministries and commisssions down to six and selecting slightly younger people to run three of the enlarged ministries.

title: Users' Praise Of Permalens
description: According to John H. Williford, vice chairman of Cooper Laboratories, Palo Alto, Calif., one of the conditions for assigning the Permalens account to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners was the assurance that Jerry Della Femina himself would write the copy.

title: CAPUTO QUITTING RACE FOR SENATE OVER INACCURACY
description: Bruce M. Caputo, his campaign for the United States Senate damaged by his inaccurate claims of having been a Vietnam-era draftee and an Army lieutenant, quit the race yesterday.

title: 11.89 DROP PUTS DOW AT 795.47
description: The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled below the 800 level for the first time in almost two years yesterday as the stock market, under pressure because of the weakening economy, continued its plunge in active trading.

title: GREAT SOUTHWEST INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company began business in the fourth qr of 1980

title: SUPREME COURT REFUSES TO REVERSE WESTCHESTER BAN ON 'HEAD SHOPS'
description: The Supreme Court today refused to hear a challenge to a law banning the sale of ''drug paraphernalia'' in New York's Westchester County. The law was upheld last year by a Federal appeals court.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Sept 1981

title: LASER WEAPONS: RENEWED FOCUS RAISES FEARS AND
description: DOUBTS By PHILIP M. BOFFEY

title: An Appreciation
description: Ayn Rand wrote two big-selling novels, the second 25 years ago. Yet, ''She never got taken seriously as a novelist; she was always thought of as somebody with a message,'' said Hugh Kenner, professor of English at

title: ABA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings figures has been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split on Jan 5

title: News Analysis
description: Congressional resistance to President Reagan's proposal to cut student aid demonstrates one of the fundamental truths of American politics: Programs with a broad constituency including the middle class are much harder to cut than programs for poor people.

title: FLUTE SOLOIST: PAULA ROBISON
description: PAULA ROBISON and the American Symphony Orchestra under Michael Tilson Thomas offered some refreshing music at Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon. Miss Robison was soloist in the New York premiere of Leon Kirchner's Music for Flute and Orchestra and also in the Griffes Poem for Flute and Orchestra. Mr. Thomas conducted Schoenberg's transcription of the Brahms G minor Piano Quartet and Brahms's Academic Festival Overture.

title: SYNANON FOUNDER ADVOCATED VIOLENCE AGAINST OPPONENTS
description: A tape recording of the founder of Synanon, Charles E. Dederich, suggesting violence as a means of dealing with troublesome lawyers and reporters, has been played to a jury in the organization's $21 million slander suit against KGO-TV, the San Francisco affiliate of ABC, and six staff members.

title: TECH-SYM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Carol Lawrence Reweds
description: Carol Lawrence, the singer and actress who became an overnight star in 1957 as Maria in the Broadway musical ''West Side Story,'' was married for the third time over the weekend.

title: Italians Open Trial In Kidnapping of General
description: A member of the Red Brigades urban guerrilla group said he had been tortured by policemen as the trial of the alleged kidnappers of an American general opened today.

title: OPERA: 'CONTES D'HOFFMAN'
description: WHEN it comes time to add up the agonies and the ecstasies of this Metropolitan Opera season, the new production of ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' that went on display last night will likely lead the ecstasy list.

title: Western Union Ordered To Refund $74.6 Million
description: An administrative law judge for the Federal Communications Commission found today that the Western Union Telegraph Company had charged unlawful rates for nearly three years to overseas carriers for international telex service, and ordered the company to refund more than $74.6 million in fees.

title: ARMY DENIES MURDERING PEASANTS
description: Guerrilla forces, which have promised a ''final offensive'' before the Salvadoran national elections scheduled for March 28, today attacked two provincial capitals.

title: Heinz Net Up 15% in Quarter
description: The H.J. Heinz Company said today that net income for the third quarter ended Jan. 27 rose 15 percent from a year earlier on a 6 percent sales gain.

title: Stepien Ousts Daly
description: Ted Stepien, owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, changed head coaches once again yesterday. This time he removed Chuck Daly, only three months after Daly had taken over, and replaced him on an interim basis with Bill Musselman, whose coaching had displeased Stepien sufficiently to have him remove Musselman last year and put him in the post of vice president and director of player personnel.

title: CASPER: WYOMING'S FIRST METROPOLIS
description: ''Tired of the downtown hassle?'' asks a billboard advertisement for a new branch of a local enterprise in this city of 51,000.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Results reflect a net LIFO credit of $2,698,000 for the qr and a net LIFO charge of $4.1 million for the yr; results for the previous yr reflect a net LIFO charge of $6.8 million

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Transactions; COLLEGES
description: Tom Heckert, football c oach and athletic director, resigned to be- c ome regional scout for Cleveland Browns ( NFL). ARIZONA STATE - Relieved Ned W ulk, basketball coach, of duties and n amed him to an administrative post.

title: PERJURY CHARGE DOES NOT MAR ABSCAM CASES, U.S. CONTENDS
description: Justice Department prosecutors are arguing that even if a key Abscam undercover man perjured himself, the convictions of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. and other defendants in the investigation should not be thrown out. In fact, the prosecutors assert that the perjury, if it occurred, would not even warrant a new review of the cases by the trial judges.

title: 4 HELD IN NORWALK VANDALISM
description: Four teen-agers have been arrested on 1,284 charges of vandalizing cars and homes in Norwalk since November, and the police said today that they were also suspects in hundreds of other destructive acts in a wave of ''totally indiscriminate'' vandalism in several Fairfield County communities this winter.

title: Finns Seek Oil Price Cut
description: Directors of Finland's state-run oil company, Neste, left for Moscow today to seek a reduction of the price of the crude Finland buys from the Soviet Union, officials said. Finland has paid more than $35 a barrel for the Russian crude, which is about $5 above the spot market prices. This year, Finland will buy more than eight million tons, or about 62 million barrels, of Russian crude, well over two-thirds of its annual need.

title: TAX EXEMPTIONS URGED AT SESSION ON KOCH'S PLAN
description: The chairman of the City Council Finance Committee urged yesterday that New Yorkers earning less than ''somewhere between $25,000 and $50,000'' be exempt from Mayor Koch's proposed income-tax surcharge.

title: Organic Meals for Mussels
description: More organic material is dissolved in the oceans than is contained in all the plants and animals on earth. Though these nutrients are present in extremely low concentrations, biologists have long supposed that some marine organisms can extract them and use them for food.

title: Eve Queler Will Present Retrospective March 22
description: Eve Queler and the Opera Orchestra of New York will present a retrospective concert at Carnegie Hall on March 22 at 8 P.M. The program will consist of excerpts from the 25 unusual operas that the group has presented in concert form since it began in the 1971-72 season. The proceeds will benefit the Opera Orchestra.

title: Brett Wants a Raise
description: Pointing to the multimillion-dollar contracts signed by George Foster of the Mets and Gary Carter of the Montreal Expos, George Brett has told the Kansas City Royals that he wants more money. The 28-year-old third baseman said he would like to finish his career with Kansas City but also wanted parity with the top-paid stars.

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Off-Duty Jail Guard Is Shot
description: An off-duty state correction officer was shot last night when two men tried to rob him while he was sitting in his car in Brooklyn, the police said. The officer, 44-year-old Alvin Walker, was taken to Greenpoint Hospital after being attacked at about 7 P.M. at the corner of Park and Throop Avenues. He was listed in serious condition.

title: Antigua Officials Say Vesco May Have Fled
description: ST. JOHN'S, Antigua, March 8 (UPI) - Robert L. Vesco, sought for a decade as the mastermind of a huge financial fraud, appears to have eluded a police search and fled the Caribbean island of Antigua, the authorities said today.

title: POLAND SAYS DETAINEES MAY FACE FORMAL CHARGES
description: Polish Government officials said today that some of the 4,000 detainees under martial law could be placed on trial. At a news conference called by Justice Minister Sylwester Zawadzki, the officials said that an amnesty decree issued before the imposition of martial law Dec. 13 did not cover all offenses.

title: MISS ASHLEY REPLACES LEE REMICK IN 'AGNES'
description: Elizabeth Ashley has been signed to replace Lee Remick in the leading role of ''Agnes of God,'' a mystery with psychological overtones by John Pielmeier, playing in Boston before coming to New York. Miss Remick's departure from the drama was ''by mutual consent,'' and none of the parties involved offered further explanations. Miss Remick will leave the production after its final performance in Boston on Saturday night.

title: JUSTICES DECLINE NEW YORK APPEAL ON CENSUS FIGURES
description: New York City and State lost their final appeal yesterday in a legal challenge of the 1980 Federal census, which they insist failed to count hundreds of thousands of black and Hispanic residents.

title: FOUNDERS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income figures reflect securities transactions

title: FORD'S LANDMARK CONTRACT HAS NO DARK SIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Ayn Rand: Novelist With a Message
description: Ayn Rand wrote two big-selling novels, the second 25 years ago. Yet, ''She never got taken seriously as a novelist; she was always thought of as somebody with a message,'' said Hugh Kenner, professor of English at Johns Hopkins University. But the message she propounded in ''The Fountainhead'' (1943) and in ''Atlas Shrugged'' (1957), as well as the novelist's own forceful personality, made her a strong if controversial presence in both literature and philosophy.

title: RANGERS' HICKEY IS YIELDED TO NORDIQUES
description: Pat Hickey, a 28-year-old forward whom the Rangers reacquired in October after having traded him away two years before, was assigned yesterday to play for the Quebec Nordiques. Hickey's transfer was ordered by the president of the National Hockey League, John Ziegler, who acted to settle a dispute between the teams.

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $318,933 from discontinued operations

title: O.E.C.D. SEEN KEEPING CHIEF
description: Emile van Lennep is likely to be reappointed to the $75,000-a-year post of secretary general of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, officials of the organization reported today.

title: THE CASE OF A WOULD-BE EXPONENT OF U.S. POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: India Oil Import Cut
description: India will reduce its imports of crude oil to an average 290,000 barrels a day in 1982 from 320,000 last year, Petroleum Ministry sources said here today. The reduction would stem from an expected increase in domestic output, to 429,000 barrels a day in 1982-83 from 340,000 in the financial year ending March 31, they added. The sources also said that India agreed last week to import 50,000 barrels of crude oil a day from the Soviet Union this year in exchange for agricultural products.

title: Responsibility Quiz
description: The first question is easy. Which President said the following: I am proposing a major effort to restore American federalism. ... Essentially, I believe the Federal Government should assume full responsibility for the Medicaid program which assures adequate health care for the poor.

title: ALLEN'S ROLE UNSURE
description: George Foster hit his first home run for the Mets today, a two-run shot off Pete Falcone in the second intrasquad game of spring training. But the beauty of the Mets' new power was eclipsed by an old problem: pitching.

title: Stahr Takes Eastern Mile
description: Mike Stahr, a junior at Carmel (N.Y.) High School, completed an undefeated indoor season tonight when he won the mile run in 4 minutes 19.56 seconds at the Eastern States schoolboy track and field championships in Jadwin Gym.

title: W.B.A. Given Deadline
description: A Federal judge today gave the World Boxing Association until March 31 to show why it should not be restrained from conducting a junior middleweight title fight between the champion Davey Moore of New York and Charlie Weir of South Africa in Johannesburg on April 24.

title: ISRAELIS SURVIVE STORM OVER BEDOUIN BABY'S DEATH
description: The Israeli authorities involved in driving @seminomadic Bedouins off their ancestral lands in the Negev desert appear to have weathered a controversy over the death of a Bedouin baby after an eviction on a cold morning in December.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why are the tiles on the bottom of the space orbiter Columbia black? Wouldn't white dissipate the heat faster? A. = Once hot, other things being equal, a black surface will radiate heat faster than a white one. But the black coating, which is very thin, has been applied to the black tiles because of its optical characteristics. The bottom of the Columbia is the hottest part of the spacecraft when it re-enters the atmosphere, and much of the heat is present as infrared radiation from incandescent air. The black opaque coating prevents this radiation from entering the tiles, which are more or less transparent inside, and thus prevents some radiant heat from being transferred to deeper levels of the tiles.

title: CHIEF QUITS AT KAISER STEEL CO.
description: James F. Will, president and chief executive officer of the Kaiser Steel Company, resigned yesterday. He was the fourth Kaiser president since 1979 to leave after serving less than a year.

title: IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $1,220,000 from discontinued operations... C-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $322,

title: GOV. BROWN SEEKS HIS OLD POPULARITY
description: Edmund G. Brown Jr., whose style and fresh ideas propelled him to national prominence when he was elected Governor of California seven years ago and who later saw his political star tumble, says he will begin this week to try to recapture his old political momentum, with a new image.

title: Texas Air Backs Continental Loan
description: Continental Air Lines said that the repayment date for a $25 million loan it obtained two weeks ago has been extended to Dec.31 from April 30.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ned Wulk, the Arizona State University basketball Coach whose team suffered its first sub-.500 season since 1977-78, has been relieved of his duties and named to an administrative position.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Avon Products Inc., in a joint announcement with Mallinckrodt Inc., said that the merger between the two companies had become effective.

title: Corning to Enter Sunglass Market
description: Corning Glass Works, a leading producer of glassware and high-technology glass and fiber-optics products, said that it intended to enter the sunglass business with its own brands of nonprescription eyewear.

title: Social Democrats Suffer In West German Voting
description: Social Democrats suffered severe losses and Christian Democrats made slight gains in municipal elections in northern Germany over the weekend that both parties said were a reflection of shifting national political trends.

description: Oklahoma (19-10) at Oral Roberts ( 18-11), 9 P.M. Tomorrow Western Kentucky (19-9) at Purdue ( 14-13), 7:35 P.M. Connecticut (17-10) at Dayton (19-8), 8 P.M.
