title: NEW EFFORTS TO SHARPEN STUDENTS' WRITING SKILLS
description: AFTER years of neglect, the teaching of writing is receiving new attention in many elementary and secondary schools as educators seek ways to sharpen the skills of youngsters who are accustomed to writing little more than their names.

title: Fatal Houston Hotel Fire May Be Ruled Accidental
description: An unattended cigarette that ignited an overstuffed chair probably caused the fire at the Westchase Hilton hotel here that killed 10 persons early Saturday, a fire department official said today.

title: VW SHIFT: GERMANS UNEASY
description: Heinrich Nordhoff, who rebuilt Volkswagen after World War II, is viewed with awe in the West German business world. Similarly, Toni Schmucker received accolades for steering the company back to profitability after oil price increases shook it badly in the mid-1970's.

title: FIRST CITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $11.7 million on the sale of stake in Canada Permanent Mortgage Corp and tax reductions

title: U.S. ACCUSES SOVIET OF POISONING 3,000
description: The Reagan Administration asserted today that Soviet forces had killed at least 3,000 people in Afghanistan with poison gas and other chemical weapons in violation of an international treaty the Soviet Union signed.

title: WITNESS SAYS STOUFFER'S FIRE DEFENDANT WAS TOLD OF DISMISSAL
description: On the day before the fatal blaze that he is accused of setting at Stouffer's Inn, Luis Marin was told he was about to be dismissed but perhaps be rehired, his supervisor testified today in Westchester County Court.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SENATE STATEMENTS BY WILLIAMS AND ETHICS PANEL HEAD
description: Following are excerpts from statements by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. and Senator Malcolm Wallop, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Ethics, at the Senate hearing today on the proposal to expel Mr. Williams: By Senator Williams

title: MILWAUKEE WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $155,000 for the qr and $404,000 for the 9 mos

title: BIZARRE VIRUSES PROVE DEADLY BUT
description: ELUSIVE By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr. BETHESDA, Md. IN the search for new answers to old diseases, scientists are giving special attention to familiar viruses that act in strange, deadly ways and other viruses that are so bizarre they seem to defy laws of nature.

title: LAST WITNESS TESTIFIES AT TRIAL OF CLAUS VON BULOW
description: The final witness in the trial of Claus von Bulow testified today that she never heard his wife, Martha, tell a hospital technician about trying to kill herself.

title: ASBESTOS DAMAGE CLAIM DENIED
description: A Federal jury in Hartford decided yesterday that 20 manufacturers and suppliers of asbestos were not responsible for the lung problems of a 71-year-old man who worked with asbestos for 18 years at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, Conn.

title: DELTA QUEEN STEAMBOAT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Addendum
description: * The Fidler Group has been purchased by Junius R. Clark 3d and will now be called Clark Direct Marketing Inc.

title: HIGH COURT JUSTICES DIFFER ON ADMITTING LAWYERS TO THE BAR
description: A dispute flared in the Supreme Court today over admitting lawyers to the Supreme Court bar, providing an unusual public glimpse of disagreements among the Justices involving the day-to-day administration of the Court.

title: Celtics Win 8th Straight
description: Cedric Maxwell and Robert Parish accounted for 52 of Boston's points tonight as the Celtics rallied and beat the Detroit Pistons, 111-101, for their eighth straight victory. That equaled the Celtics' longest winning streak of the season and stretched their lead over the idle Philadelphia 76ers to two games in the Atlantic Division.

title: MASTERCARD CLEARED TO OFFER FINANCIAL SERVICES VIA BANKS
description: Commercial and savings banks that are members of the Mastercard system will start next month to offer card holders discount brokerage services, money market funds and other investment services, Mastercard International and the Fidelity Financial Services Group announced yesterday.

title: Rights Proposal Backers Lose Virginia Lawsuit
description: The Virginia Supreme Court today rejected an attempt by supporters of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment to get the measure through the State Senate.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Outdoors column in SportsMonday yesterday gave an incorrect telephone number for Beeman Precision Airgun in San Rafael, Calif. The correct number is (415) 472-7121.

title: THIRD WORLD PACT ON SEA IS PLANNED
description: Third world nations said today that they would soon complete a treaty governing the seas even if the United States and other industrial nations refused to sign.

title: Joseph Lang, 83, Ex-President Of Distributor of Newspapers
description: Joseph Lang, former president of the Lang News Company, a newspaper distributing company in Queens, died of a heart attack Sunday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: News Analysis
description: The battle to preserve the Helen Hayes and Morosco Theaters has raised an extraordinary number of legal issues. Some have been argued in Federal courts and others in state courts; between the two jurisdictions there has been a good deal of overlapping. The next move will take place on March 22, when the New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, will decide whether to take up the case. Meanwhile, the forces fighting for the preservation of the two theaters say they will appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

title: A NUCLEAR OVERSEER AND HIS FEARS
description: Peter A. Bradford, an articulate and outspoken critic of the nuclear industry, was appointed by President Carter to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission five years ago. Because Mr. Bradford's term expires on June 30, he agreed to discuss his fears about nuclear safety in the United States. He is leaving his post next week to become public advocate in the Cabinet of Gov. Joseph E. Brennan of Maine. He was interviewed as he lunched on beef curry at his favorite Indian restaurant in downtown Washington.

title: VIEWS OF 3 AGENCIES CONFLICT ON ENDANGERED SPECIES LAW
description: The Reagan Administration is divided over provisions for renewing the Endangered Species Act, the heavily debated law designed to protect wildlife threatened with extinction.

title: HAIRY VET%CH GIVES SYNTHETIC A RUN FOR THE MONEY
description: WILLIAM H. MITCHELL has believed for more than 30 years that Hairy Vetch was destined to become an American hero. Hairy Vetch? The name evokes visions of the San Francisco cop Clint Eastwood played in the movies, or perhaps one of the barroom bad guys in ''Star Wars.'' Dr. Mitchell's hairy vetch, however, is a modest legume, often dismissed as a weed, now seeking stardom in an increasingly popular production sometimes referred to in rural Delaware as ''dirty farming.''

title: Bridge: Sam Gold Built Reputation In Organizing and Playing
description: In the past half-century North America has had many great players and a rather smaller number of great organizers. Very few indeed have belonged in both categories.

title: News Analysis
description: Since the 19th century Russia and Britain, and since World War II the Soviet Union and the United States, have maneuvered for the dominant role in an Iran that was either caught up in revolution or on the brink of it. Their methods have included military occupation, bribery, encouragement of separatist movements, trade and coups. It was a game of power politics in the grand tradition. No one ever won with any permanence, and the game has never stopped.

title: INDUSTRY AS PARTNER
description: President Reagan, big business' representative, has s aid on a number of occasions that society ought to ''look to p rivate industry'' to improve the quality of life in neighborhoods. B ut for more than a year now, the United States has seen little or noe ffort by corporate America to help to solve the nation's problems. O n the contrary, neighborhoods are slowly being killed in favor of s oaring profits for the few.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FACE THE MUSIC

title: ENEL Seeks Big Loan
description: Italy's state electricity concern, Ente Nazionale per l'Energia Elettrica, or ENEL, is seeking a Eurocredit of up to $500 million, banking sources said here today. The loan would make ENEL Italy's second major public sector borrower in the Euromarket in recent weeks, following syndication of a $250 million, eight-year loan for Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale.

title: DRAMA: MARGARET KEILSTRUP AND 'WONDERLAND' LEFTOVERS
description: IF you start to hallucinate in the middle of ''Wonderland,'' Margaret Keilstrup's play at the Hudson Guild, there may be a good reason for that. In tone, form and ambitions, ''Wonderland'' is virtually indistinguishable from a motherlode of failed plays that have turned up at some of our worthier theaters over the last season or so. A partial list would include ''Scenes and Revelations'' at the Circle in the Square, ''Grace'' at the American Place, ''Threads'' at the Circle Repertory Company and ''The Whales of August'' at the WPA. Not to mention Broadway's ''Come Back to the 5 & Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean,'' which began its career at the Hudson Guild several seasons back.

title: BENDIX BUYS STAKE IN RCA
description: The Bendix Corporation, in a move many analysts saw as the prelude to a takeover attempt, announced late yesterday that it had acquired more than 5 percent of the RCA Corporation's stock outstanding and might buy up to 9.9 percent.

title: Karpov Taunts Fischer
description: It was one of those weighty editorial comments in a prestigious chess magazine, so why did the passage sound like a playground taunt designed to draw a reluctant adversary into a scrap?

title: No Headline
description: Basketball Ratings; WRITERS POLL

title: The Energy Crisis Crisis
description: ''I'm not saying the energy crisis is over,'' cautions Energy Secretary James Edwards. But many others are. Oil prices have fallen in the wake of the slump in world demand. And it is possible that prices will not recover for years, as exporters scramble for shares of a declining market.

title: Clifford Case
description: He reached the Senate in 1954 by defeating the McCarthyites on the extreme right of New Jersey's Republican Party. He was ousted, finally, in a 1978 party primary by a new political right.

title: Market Place; How to Spot Market's Nadir
description: STOCKS are slogging through their worst bear market since 1974, and the prevailing view in Wall Street is that equity prices will probably get worse before any genuine recovery sets in.

title: KAPLAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
ANTIWAR ROLE PLAYED AGAIN BY ROSENTHAL
description: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, New York City's senior Congressman, came here 20 years ago and soon made his mark as a liberal gadfly in the House of Representatives.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $63,000 for the qr and $423,000 for the yr and gains from the sale of real estate of $26,000 for the qr and $110,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $90,000 for the qr and $240,000 for the yr and a gain of $58,000 for the qr and yr from the sale of real estate

title: SCREEN: '25, FIREMAN'S STREET'
description: The 1973 Hungarian film ''25, Fireman's Street'' that opens today at Joseph Papp's Public Theater, is an ambitious, elaborately photographed memory-movie, but one that will be almost incomprehensible to anyone who hasn't lived through the last halfcentury of Hungarian history.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * General Telephone and Electronics said the commercial paper of its new subsidiary, GTE Leasing Corporation, had been rated A-1 by Standard & Poor's and P-1 by Moody's and would begin sales next month through Salomon Brothers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If a Secretary of Agriculture endorsed better meat inspection, you wouldn't have a debate of near religious fervor about whether that person was pro- or anti-meat, whether he had sold out to the vegetarians.

title: Sinai Discord Narrows After Survey in Copter
description: Disagreements between Israel and Egypt over the final border in Sinai narrowed today after a helicopter flight over the frontier area by Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali of Egypt and Defense Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel.

title: COURT REFUSES TO HEAR INSURERS' ASBESTOS PLEAS
description: The Supreme Court today declined once again to involve itself in the nationwide legal battle over who should compensate the thousands of workers who contracted chronic and often fatal diseases from their on-the-job exposure to asbestos.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 100 percent stock divd paid June 1, 1981

title: Bond Prices Decline Sharply
description: Prices of long-term bonds fell as much as two points yesterday, as securities dealers were deluged with sell orders from investors and speculators who decided to take the profits they had earned over the past three weeks.

title: Kite Captures 3-Way Playoff
description: Jack Nicklaus, Ray Floyd and Denis Watson spent the day trying to give the Bay Hill Classic to one another, but they wound up giving the tournament to Tom Kite.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article Sunday incorrectly described the route through El Salvador taken by a Nicaraguan who was detained by Salvadoran authorities. The Nicaraguan, Ligdamis Anaxis Gutierrez Espinosa, was on his way from Mexico to Nicaragua.

title: LOCAL VS. LONG-DISTANCE CALLS: THE SUBSIDY ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: HEINICKE INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
VAN DORN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $320,000 or 11 cents a shr from sale of a plant and a gain of $239,000 or 8 cents a shr from accounting changes

title: OFFICE COMPLEX PLANNED ON AMERICAN CHICLE SITE
description: The American Chicle Company factory in Long Island City, Queens, whose giant ''Dentyne'' and ''Chiclets'' roof signs were a familiar sight to millions of New Yorkers, is to become the core of a new $100 million office center.

title: U.A.W. to Reopen Talks With American Motors
description: The United Automobile Workers today agreed to reopen negotiations with the American Motors Corporation, but turned down a company proposal that employees invest 10 percent of their wages in a product development plan.

title: New Presidents Named At S.& H., Henderson
description: There are new presidents at both Sudler & Hennessey, the health care subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, and Henderson Advertising, the pride of Greenville, S.C. Neither is top dog, however. At S.& H. Matthew J. Hennessey, chairman and chief executive worldwide, remains top dog, and at Henderson, it is James H. Henderson, chairman.

title: GAS WARS PUT 'SERVICE' BACK IN STATIONS
description: Attendants at gasoline stations here are washing windshields, checking oil and, in one reported instance, even saying ''thank you'' as the price of gasoline falls and stations try once again to curry favor with motorists.

title: ITT Rayonier Product
description: ITT Rayonier, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said today that it had developed a new wood-derived product that can be used as an additive in food, pharmaceuticals and cosmetics. It said the product, microfibrillated gellulose, could be used in food as a noncaloric binder, bulk extender, thickener and moisture retainer.

title: Allen Advising Republicans on National Security; Allen Advising Again
description: He was forced to resign not long ago as national security adviser to President Reagan, but yesterday Richard V. Allen got a new job as a national security adviser - to the Republican National Committee, no less.

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary item of tax benefit carryforward; all shr earnings figures have been retroactively adjusted to reflect a 100 percent stock distribution in Oct 1981

title: BOWNE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings reflects retroactive effect given to 2-for-1 stock split distributed in June 1981

title: Fluor Up 12.7% In 1st Quarter
description: The Fluor Corporation, an international energy engineering company, said today that its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 12.7 percent from a year earlier.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE decision last month by Giorgio Armani not to show his fall c ollection to the press has provoked everything from rage to ennui a mong fashion journalists. And Women's Wear Daily seems more miffed t han anyone. John Fairchild, its publisher, has vowed never to give t he Milanese designer coverage again.

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $438,000

title: FASHION FOR FALL: LONG AND SHORT OF IT
description: It's called Fall I. It's the opening salvo in an intense schedule of fall fashion presentations that begins this week on Seventh Avenue, then moves on to Milan, Florence, London and Paris, in that order. The finale takes place in New York in the last two weeks in April, when designers show their big collections of clothes for fall and winter, called Fall II.

title: SCHEIB, EARL, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $950,000 for the qr and $1.2 million for yr

title: Distinctive Pro Scores
description: Distinctive Pro created the largest minus pool in the history of Gulfstream Park today when he won by seven lengths in the $58,250 Hutcheson Stakes. One unidentified bettor wagered $95,000 to show on the speedy Kentucky Derby prospect, who paid only $2.40 for $2 to win and $2.10 to place and show in the seven-furlong race. Center Cut lasted by a neck over the fastclosing Real Twister for second place in a field of six.

title: Talks to Keep Rockies In Denver Are Faltering
description: Negotiations that would leave the Colorado Rockies in Denver after the season are on shaky grounds, according to Fred Jager, a Denver financier who was the prime force in putting together a group of investors that is trying to buy the team from Peter Gilbert.

title: Air Deliverer Officer to Quit
description: Arthur C. Bass, vice chairman and former president of the Federal Express Corporation, will resign from the company's active management on May 31, the air freight company announced today.

title: IN REAL LIFE AS IN FAULKNER, MEMPHIS IN MANY WAYS REMAINS THE SAME
description: The psychic properties of the region remain the same: the violent and the genteel; the grotesque and the patently absurd. The reader will remember it from William Faulkner, be reminded of it by Eudora Welty, be unable to escape it if on a raw winter's day there is the opportunity to reflect beside the Mississippi River.

title: Abscam Informant Marries
description: Mel Weinberg, 58, the key informant in the Abscam bribery investigation, today married Evelyn Knight, 39, an English-born friend of 14 years, in a civil ceremony.

title: Disk System Losses at RCA
description: The RCA Corporation lost $106.8 million in bringing its new Selectavision videodisk system to market last year, the company said in its annual report. RCA lost $55.5 million on the system in 1980 and $21.4 million in 1979, for a three-year total of $183.7 million.

title: News Analysis
description: Last week, Mayor Koch announced the formation of an 18-member Task Force on Youth - the second task force created by the Mayor in recent months to link the city's schools with other city agencies that come up against juvenile crime.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: Two armed robbers stole nearly $2.5 million worth of rare coins and precious metals from a coin show Sunday, the police said today. Some dealers said the loss might reach $5 million.

title: IRELAND TO PICK PREMIER TODAY
description: The Irish Parliament will meet Tuesday to select a Prime Minister, with the outcome still uncertain. Former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey is regarded here as the most likely winner. But some politicians think that Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald might be able to retain the office, which he has held since last June.

title: BONN OFFICIAL URGES NATO TALKS TO SORT OUT DIFFERENCES
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany, reflecting his Government's concern about a seeming deterioration in relations with the United States, proposed today that the foreign ministers of the Atlantic alliance meet periodically for informal talks about their political differences.

title: WOMEN BEGIN OBSERVANCES
description: International Women's Day, observed yesterday, coincided with the first national Women's History Week, designated by Congress to begin March 7. In New York, the week was extended to one month, proclaimed by Mayor Koch's Commission on the Status of Women. The observances are being marked by protest, progress and pedigogy.

title: TV: 'BETWEEN TWO BROTHERS,' THIEF IN CANDIDATE'S FAMILY
description: TV, a movie comes along with a plot so outlandish that no amount of cosmetic tinkering can fend off a reaction of chronic irritation.

title: PALM BEACH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
BANKS CUT PRIME RATE TO 16%, SAY THEY EXPECT MORE TRIMS
description: Several major banks reduced their prime lending rates yesterday by a half point, to 16 percent, raising hopes in financial circles that all interest rates would continue to fall.

title: CONFIDENCE COMES TO DUGUAY
description: After four years of acquiring a reputation as a charismatic but erratic hockey player, Ron Duguay has changed. He still has the long, curly brown hair and the piano-keyboard smile. He still goes to trendy discos and restaurants once or twice a week, mixing with celebrities, being a celebrity himself. And he still rushes around the ice at Madison Square Garden as if it were burning his feet.

title: Manhattan Cable Adds Performing-Arts Service
description: Arts, a one-year old cable service featuring programs on the performing and visual arts, will begin on Manhattan Cable beginning Sunday at 9 P.M.

title: Want Ads Off In January
description: Help-wanted advertising volume, as measured in 51 major newspapers, declined again in January as the recession continued to grip the economy, the Conference Board, a business-sponsored research group, reported yesterday.

title: KNUDSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
APPEAL ON VAGRANCY LAW ACCEPTED
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution permits the police to arrest as a ''vagrant'' someone whose behavior arouses their suspicions and who refuses to identify himself.

title: IVACO INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $3,111,000

title: U.S. INQUIRY IS SET IN KLAN SHOOTINGS
description: A Federal grand jury will conduct ''a full and complete inquiry'' into the violence in 1979 that left five demonstrators dead at a ''Death to the Klan'' rally in Greensboro, N.C., the Justice Department announced today.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 9, 1982
description: International Soviet forces killed 3,000 Afghans with poison gas and other chemical weapons in violation of a treaty signed by Moscow, according to the Reagan Administration. Deputy Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr. told a Senate committee that the information came from Afghan defectors who had been trained by Soviet experts in chemical warfare and from refugees in Pakistan who were victims of the attacks. (Page A1, Column 1.) Salvadoran rebels attacked two provincial capitals. The assaults paralyzed both towns for much of the day, and Government forces said that the fighting was widespread. (A4:3-4.)

title: ETHICS CHIEF SAYS ROLE OF WILLIAMS, NOT F.B.I., IS ISSUE
description: The chairman of the Senate committee that is recommending the expulsion of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. argued today that ''the issue before us is the conduct of Senator Williams and not those of law-enforcement authorities involved in the Abscam case.''

title: HCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A.M.C. Cutbacks
description: The American Motors Corporation said it had recently discontinued production of two of its Eagle models because of low demand. A spokesman said the models, which were produced at its Kenosha, Wis., plant, were the the Eagle Kammback and its Eagle Kammback DL. The company did not elaborate.

title: Turkey Denies Exiles From Iran Use Country
description: Turkey today denied a report that Turkish soil is being used by paramilitary groups composed mostly of Iranian exiles opposed to the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: G.O.P. SENATORS FAIL ON ALTERNATIVE TO BUDGET
description: Senate Republican leaders, protective of their powers and constituencies, failed today to agree on an alternative to the budget proposed by President Reagan for the fiscal year 1983.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WINDOWS ARE BREAKING
description: No responsible public official or scholar pretends to have the answers for stemming the crime epidemic here or nationwide.

title: OFFICER AT G.E. HEADS ITS NEW TRADING UNIT
description: Taking a cue from Japan's giant trading companies, such as Mitsui and Mitsubishi, the General Electric Company said yesterday that it would form a trading company to market some of its products, as well as those of other American companies, around the world.

title: By Sports of The Times; Time Bomb Ticks For the Padres
description: YUMA, Ariz. WHEN the manager was dismissed by the Montreal Expos last year, ''lack of communication'' with his players was mentioned as a reason. When the shortstop was suspended and hospitalized last year for psychiatric treatment, before he was traded by the St. Louis Cardinals, ''depression'' was the medical explanation, and ''he only plays when he wants to'' was the clubhouse explanation.

title: Almay Returns to TV With a Song and Dance
description: Almay Inc. returned to television advertising last night with a lively song and dance commercial that may not quite have a cast of thousands, but does have at least three.

title: AUDITORS FEARFUL ON BLOCK GRANTS
description: State auditors, fearing that their states will be penalized for misuse of Federal funds, have become frustrated by the failure of the Reagan Administration to clarify the requirements for auditing block grants.

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PLUMMER: 'THANK GOD, I'M NOT A SUPERSTAR'
description: On stage he is the embodiment of falsity and menace, his ingratiating protestations of friendship transformed in an instant to the most fearsome malice. His Iago ''gives us an evil so pure - and so bottomless -that it can induce tears,'' said Frank Rich in The New York Times.

title: AMERICANS WANT ARMS CONTROL
description: ''It is a fallacy to think that nuclear war can b e won. I support and encourage the establishment of learning centersb y the world's nations to study alternatives to war.''

title: Brunswick Unit Target of Offer
description: The American Home Products Corporation said it would begin buying Brunswick Corporation stock now that a Federal court had cleared the way for its $425 million purchase of Brunswick's coveted medical unit.

title: '80 Sales to Soviet Assailed
description: The European Parliament today censured the European Economic Community for undermining a United States grain embargo against the Soviet Union in 1980. The Parliament approved a resolution criticizing the Common Market for allowing an increase in subsidized sales of products like grains and butter to the Soviet bloc after Moscow's military intervention in Afghanistan.

title: TALKS IN MADRID WILL RECESS ON FRIDAY TILL LATE IN YEAR
description: Communist, Western and neutral delegations to the deadlocked Madrid Conference on European Security and Human Rights agreed today to recess until autumn after a session on Friday.

title: People
description: * Gene Messinger appointed an executive vice president of Nadler & Larimer Inc.

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including gains of $850,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the yr on the sale of discontinued operations

title: Sockers Win Title
description: Julie Veee scored three goals and Kaz Deyna and Jean Willrich scored two each for San Diego as the Sockers won the North American Soccer League's indoor championship with a 10-5 victory over the Tampa Bay Rowdies tonight.

title: New Twist in Bid By General Cinema
description: The bidding war between Heublein Inc., the distiller, and the General Cinema Corporation, the world's largest movie theater chain, took on still another dimension today with the disclosure that General Cinema plans to buy back up to 3 million shares of its common stock.

title: Austrian Aides Say Qaddafi Will Visit Country This Week
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya will arrive Wednesday for a four-day visit to Austria, Government sources said today.

title: EMERY TO STRESS THE LOCAL ISSUES IN ALBANY RACE
description: After a meeting about the traffic problems on Route 110 - the sort of local issue that he believes he has mastered better than any of the other candidates for Governor -James L. Emery came here the other day to talk with some local politicians.

title: Vietnamese Attacked 3 Boats, Chinese Say
description: China has lodged a strong protest with the Vietnamese Embassy in Peking, charging that Vietnamese gunboats attacked three Chinese fishing boats on the high seas, the Peking radio reported today.

title: VF Names Its President As New Chief
description: Lawrence R. Pugh, the 49-year-old president of the VF Corporation, a major apparel manufacturer, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer. Robert H. Andrews, the 69-year-old vice chairman, has been promoted to chairman.

title: NICARAGUA LOAN TALKS REPORTED
description: An international banking syndicate is seeking American bank participation in a $130 million loan to Nicaragua, according to bank officials and an official of the Government of Nicaragua.

title: Unified FCB Gets President
description: Abbott C. Jones, 47-year-old presidentof Foote, Cone & Belding Advertising, his company's domestic advertising operation, has had his job reorganized out from under him. He was not without responsibility for long, however, because now he has been named president of FCB Associated Communications Companies, a worldwide unit that is made up of eight newly unified communications companies, none of which are in general advertising.

title: BOOKLET OF NUTRITION
description: The New York City Bureau of Nutrition's pamphlet ''Eat to Lose Weight'' is available free to those who send a stamped, selfaddressed envelope to the Bureau of Nutrition, New York City Department of Health, 93 Worth Street, Room 714, New York, N.Y. 10013.

title: LORD BUTLER DIES IN BRITAIN AT 79: A LONGTIME CONSERVATIVE LEADER
description: Lord Butler, a leading figure in Britain's political and educational life for half a century, died last night at his home in Great Yeldham, Essex. He was 79 years old.

title: CASINO FRAUD CHARGED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had charged several New Jersey developers with securities violations involving Atlantic City land that was bought for a casino complex, and then sold for about 10 times its purchase price -without a casino being built.

title: Hamilton in 2d Place In Figure Skating Event
description: Scott Hamilton of Denver was well placed to retain his world figure-skating title after the compulsory figures at the start of competition today.

title: Interest Rates Hold Steady; Sales Good In New Issues
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday, as credit market participants concentrated on absorbing new corporate and tax-exempt bond issues. Sales of the new issues were good, dealers said, but not brisk enough to bring assurances that bond yields will continue to decline.

title: MOVE TO CENSURE WILLIAMS IS SAID TO LACK SUPPORT
description: The Senate majority leader said today that there was ''almost no support'' among Republicans for a resolution to censure rather than expel Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: VULCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MONDALE ASSAILING PRESIDENT, SEEKS REPEAL OF 10% TAX CUT
description: Walter F. Mondale urged Congress today to repeal the 10 percent income tax cut scheduled for next year and to cut $10 billion from the military budget to help overcome the Reagan Administration's ''colossal mistake in economic policy.''

title: U.S. Said to Authorize Anti-Nicaragua Force
description: President Reagan has authorized a $19 million Central Intelligence Agency plan for covert operations against Nicaragua, which the Administration says is a staging area for rebels in El Salvador, it was reported late today.

title: FILM: 'COMMENT CA VA?' OPENS GODARD FESTIVAL
description: THE Agee Room at the Bleecker Street Cinema, currently sponsoring a Jean-Luc Godard retrospective, opens today with his ''Comment ,Ca Va?'' (''How's It Going?''). It was made in 1976 with Anne-Marie Mieville when Mr. Godard was living in Grenoble, France, and after his Maoist period. It's a comparatively short (78 minutes), technically complex, typically Godardian inquiry into the nature of things, this time into mass communications and the truth or falsity of the information communicated.

title: Variety and Enthusiasm With Charlotte Bergen
description: Love of music is often more evident not in the professional but in the amateur - the musician undistracted by managements, advertising and reviews, who approaches his avocation with amatory enthusiasm.

title: THE I.L.O. COULD HELP SAVE POLAND'S CRISIS
description: To the Editor:

title: VESSEY'S VIEW OF DEFENSE
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., nominated to become the nation's senior military officer on July 1, believes that ''America needs to wake up and make up its mind that there could well be a war and to prepare for it.''

title: EASY ON DOOMSDAY
description: An unusual planetary alignment occurring today has a lot of people expecting catastrophe. All nine planets are lined up on the same side of the sun within a 96-degree arc. It's something like having them all located between the pitcher's mound and the outfield fences in a cosmic baseball park.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest qr and yr include a nonrecurring gain of $926,000 or 16 cents a shr on the sale of an investment

title: No Headline
description: The Seattle SuperSonics have until 5 P.M. tomorrow to match the Knicks' offer to Paul Westphal, the free-agent guard. Under the right of first refusal, a team has 15 days to match an offer or lose the player. Since Westphal did not deliver the Knick offer sheet to the SuperSonics until Wednesday, Feb. 24, at 4 P.M., the lawyers for all sides have agreed not to count that day.

title: SUIT FILED IN TANKER BLAST DEATH
description: A $50 million negligence suit was filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday on behalf of the wife of the chief engineer who died in the explosion of a gasoline tanker as it passed under the Williamsburg Bridge on Feb. 26.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The 1981 figures were restated to reflect the adoption in the fourth qr of fiscal 1981 of LIFO accounting for valuing the company's inventories than aerospace and aerospace related and company-produced media inventories

title: Norway Cuts Oil Price by $4
description: Statoil, the Norwegian state oil company, today announced price cuts averaging $4 a barrel for its North Sea oil.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, March 1, to Sunday, March 7), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating refers to the percentage of all United States households with television sets tuned to a specific program. Rating Program Network 1 29.6 60 Minutes CBS 2 28.4 Dallas CBS 3 24.0 The Jeffersons CBS 4 23.9 Three's Company ABC 5 23.0 "Alligator' (S) ABC 6 23.0 Alice CBS 7 22.8 "Divorce Wars" (S) ABC 8 22.4 Archie Bunker's Place CBS 9 22.3 Magnum, P.I. CBS 0 22.0 One Day At A Time CBS 1 21.9 Love Boat ABC 2 21.9 To Close For Comfort ABC 3 21.8 Dukes of Hazzard CBS 4 21.8 Dynesty ABC 5 20.6 Happy Days ABC

title: TOKYO AIR CRASH: WHY JAPANESE DO NOT SUE
description: On the morning of Feb. 9, the skies were clear and the weather balmy when a Japan Air Lines DC-8 plunged into Tokyo Bay 300 yards short of the Haneda Airport runway, killing 24 people.

title: Bridge: If the Spirit Is Competitive, Is It Because of Heredity?
description: Whether competitive spirit can be inherited is a matter for biologists to argue. Those in favor of the proposition can point to William O. DeWitt Sr., longtime baseball executive who died last week, and his daughter, Joan DeWitt of Chicago.

title: 4 in Family Sentenced For Mining Violations
description: Kenneth Crawford, the 41-year-old head of a family that operated illegal coal mines in which accidents killed five persons in 1980, was sentenced today to 18 months in prison and fined $25,000 for safety violation convictions.

title: YOU READ IT IN THE TIMES FIRST
description: ''To govern is to choose,'' said a senior White House official, who declined to be named, after the decision was made. The story of the process by which the decision was reached can now be told.

title: CAREY URGES PLAN TO LIMIT ACID RAIN
description: Governor Carey yesterday proposed a quick ''minimum program'' to reduce what he called ''the mounting scale of damage to our soil and water'' by acid rain.

title: 6-Alarm Chemical Plant Fire
description: A six-alarm fire today at a large Allied Corporation chemical plant injured at least 13 persons and sent dense, black smoke billowing over parts of the city, officials said. The fire, which may have been triggered by an explosion, appeared to be centered in the middle of the 37-acre Allied complex near Interstate 95. The police closed the highway, causing traffic jams as the afternoon rush hour began.

title: SENATORS AND THE SENATE ON TRIAL WITH WILLIAMS
description: ''The people out there, how will they view the institution?'' asked Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is the Senate minority leader. ''Do they have confidence in the Government or not? Do they have confidence in elected officials or not? How the institution handles this situation will be very closely watched by the American people.''

title: SEVERAL INTEREST GROUPS PREPARED TO ACCEPT CURBS ON U.S. BENEFITS
description: Several interest groups for the elderly and others now say they might accept smaller Federal benefits than planned so long as the reductions were part of a broad effort to curb spending that shared the sacrifice fairly.

title: Ronald Smith Presents Alkan Piano Symphony
description: More people probably know how Charles-Valentin Alkan died than have ever heard his music. A bookcase fell on the 19th-century Jewish composer as he reached for a volume of the Talmud on the top shelf.

title: City Ballet Schedules 2d Stravinsky Festival
description: A Stravinsky Centennial Celebration will highlight the New York City Ballet's 76th New York season, a nine-week engagement opening May 4 at the New York State Theater.

title: Small-Business Research Bill Diluted by House Committee
description: Under pressure from big universities and corporations, a House committee today watered down a controversial bill that was intended to allocate hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal research grants to small businesses, particularly in hightechnology fields.

title: Hickey Confused By Shift
description: Pat Hickey, the Rangers' 28-year-old forward, said yesterday that he was formally protesting the deal that is forcing him to leave New York and play for the Quebec Nordiques.

title: STOUFFER'S WITNESS SAW A FIGURE 'STOKING FIRE'
description: A witness to the fatal blaze at Stouffer's Inn just over a year ago testified today that he ''had the impression that someone was stoking the fire'' when he discovered it as a ''bundle of flame'' more than 100 feet away in the center of a carpeted hallway. But he said later he could not be certain it was a ''person'' he saw.

title: Canadiens 4, Bruins 2
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Mark Napier and Guy Lafleur had a goal and an assist apiece to power Montreal to victory, extending the Canadiens' undefeated streak to seven games.

title: News Analysis
description: A fundamental disagreement over whether the Constitution and civil rights laws are ''color-blind,'' as the Reagan Administration contends, runs through the increasingly bitter disputes between the

title: Wrestler Redeemed
description: Dan Gable, coach of Iowa's top-ranked wrestling team, found his star, Barry Davis, in the checkout line of a supermarket with a box of doughnuts before the flight to Ann Arbor, Mich., for the Big Ten championship tournament. Davis, seven pounds over the limit of 118 for his class, had become discouraged and left a note saying he would not make the trip.

title: REX-NORECO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes $255,000 tax credit...C-Restated to increase net income by $104,000 because of a change in the income tax provision

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about romance publishers incorrectly identified the parent company of Avon Books. Avon is a division of the Hearst Corporation.

title: HOW TO CLEAN SQUID
description: 1. Twist and pull off the head of the squid. As you do this you will also pull out much of the interior of the body.

title: New York Air Moves to Chiat/Day
description: New York Air has left Ketchum New York and assigned its $2 million account to the New York office of Chiat/Day of Los Angeles. The move comes on the heels of the arrival of Michael E. Levine as chairman of New York Air from his post as executive vice presidentmarketing of Continental Air Lines in Los Angeles.

title: COMPROMISE URGED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A multiracial commission, including influential white business figures, has concluded that the coastal province of Natal faces a future of worsening instability and racial conflict unless its all-white administration is speedily merged, under black leadership, with that of the fragmented Zulu ''homeland'' called KwaZulu.

title: Market Place; Food Stocks: A Close Look
description: THERE'S a saying in Wall Street that new group leadership - the stocks to own for the next upswing - develops in down markets. If that holds true this time, it seems abundantly clear that energy, technology and precious-metal issues, which once served as inflationhedge favorites, are not destined to lead the ultimate parade to higher prices.

title: NOVUS PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including extraordinary income of $19,624,000 which equaled $9.90 a shr for the qr and $9.87 a shr for the yr

title: SANDINIST DEFENDS MILITARY BUILDUP
description: One of the members of the Nicaraguan junta said today that the military buildup here was ''exclusively defensive'' and that the United States was making charges to the contrary to justify a possible intervention.

title: Clinics Report Sharp Rise In the Abuse of Cocaine
description: The number of cocaine users treated at clinics financed by the Federal Government has more than tripled since 1977, a drug abuse expert said today.

title: YANKEES TOLD OF PLAN TO AID IN ARBITRATIONS
description: Marvin Miller, who is touring the spring camps for the 16th time as executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, told Yankee and Ranger players today that the association planned to establish a panel of experts who would be available to represent any major leaguer involved in salary arbitration hearings. Miller said the panel would be composed of lawyers with ''direct union experience in arbitration cases,'' who would make their services available at an hourly fee.

title: EMERY JOINS 3 OTHERS IN G.O.P. GUBERNATORIAL RACE
description: James L. Emery, the Assembly minority leader, announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor yesterday and declared that he would emphasize the state's economy and crime as key issues in his campaign.

title: China Starts Releasing 4,237 Who Spent 33 Years in Prison
description: The police have started releasing 4,237 lowlevel officials of the Nationalist Party, soldiers and spies who were arrested after the Communists took over 33 years ago, the radio reported today.

title: Anderson Yielding Post as Arco's Chief
description: Friends recall that Robert O. Anderson started his career in the oil business with only a broad-brimmed hat and $50,000 of borrowed money. He is gliding to its end as the builder of the 14th-largest company in the United States, the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: RESTAURANT AT WOLLMAN RULED OUT BY PARKS UNIT
description: The Parks Department has decided against building a 150-seat restaurant at the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park, Commissioner Gordon J. Davis announced yesterday.

title: Ticket Sales at U.S.C.  Under N.C.A.A. Inquiry
description: Southern California's football team could be placed on probation and put out of the bowl picture next year, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICALS CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31
description: B-After a loss of $289,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $310,000 on the disposition of discontinued operations...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $419,000; results have been restated to include operations of S-G Diesel Power Inc, acquired effective May 28, 1981 and accounted for as a pooling of interests

title: UNITED CANSO OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income after extraordinary gain of $500,000; the yr-ago figures were restated for accounting change

title: A 'New Federalism' Abortion
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee will vote this week on a bit of New Federalism that is the special project of Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah. He would amend the Constitution to restore the power of state legislatures over abortion rights.

title: Protest by North Korea On War Games Rejected
description: The American-led United Nations Command today rejected a North Korean demand that the United States and South Korea stop joint exercises.

title: MARCOS TO VISIT SAUDI ARABIA TO EASE MOSLEM-REBEL ISSUE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos is scheduled to visit Saudi Arabia this month for the first time. It is a country with which the Philippines has been developing close ties.

title: BRIEFING
description: Anti-Nuclear Effort

title:
MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
Trio di Trieste Plays Haydn Piano Trios
description: The Trio di Trieste performed piano trios by Haydn and Schumann in the Hunter College Assembly Hall Sunday afternoon, and was joined by Piero Farulli, the former violist of the Quartetto Italiano, in Brahms's Piano Quartet in C minor (Op. 60). In all three works, the trio's violinist, Renato Zanettovich, and its cellist, Amadeo Baldovino, cultivated a characteristically sweet Italian string sound that went well with the group's decidedly lyrical approach to interpretation - one in which the emphasis was on achieving a long, unbroken musical line rather than dramatic or kinetic effect.

title: FRESHNESS OF MILK PRODUCTS
description: THE consumer who pays attention to freshness should find shopping for milk and milk-related products relatively simple. The highly perishable products displayed in the dairy case are usually marked to indicate the last date on which the product can be sold. In certain areas some dairy products are dated according to local restrictions; otherwise the date is determined by the manufacturer.

title: LAWMAKERS ASSAIL WELFARE BUDGET
description: Senators of both parties complained today that the Reagan Administration budget would sharply reduce incentives for welfare recipients to work.

title: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: AT A MODERN HENHOUSE UPSTATE...
description: MOST laying hens spend their lives in cages -usually five to a cage - in temperature-and light-controlled houses that may hold 30,000 to 100,000 birds. Uncaged chickens kept in heated houses are known as floor birds and, like the caged birds, are fed a diet that is twothirds corn, with other substances added, often including fish meal and dried meat for protein.

title: Venezuelan Eurocredit
description: The Venezuelan state power company, Edelca, has selected the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company to raise a $300 million, eight-year Eurocredit for it, banking sources said here today.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including gains from the sale of real estate of $17,429 for the latest first qr and $247,419 for the yr ago first qr

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration has launched an information campaign to persuade Congress, the press and the public that it has been telling the truth when it says vital American interests are threatened by a military buildup in Nicaragua sponsored by Cuba and the Soviet Union.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: LOU REED'S new album ''The Blue Mask'' is stark, harrowing, and ultimately uplifting rock-and-roll. It is the most powerful and the most consistent album Mr. Reed has made since his 1967 recording debut with the Velvet Underground - and he knows it.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate 16.00-16.50** Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: More on Face Lifts
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I would like to correct an error you made in an otherwise excellent article on face lifts (Personal Health, Feb. 3). In the section about choosing your surgeon, you categorically exclude the ''ear, nose and throat specialist.''

title: F.A.A. UNDER CRITICISM ON GAP IN SAFETY RULES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has been slow to adopt safety recommendations on such problems as protecting planes against icing, retarding cabin fires and strengthening passenger seats, the acting chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board asserted today.

title: HAUGHEY IS CHOSEN IRISH PRIME MINISTER
description: The Irish Parliament chose Charles J. Haughey, a millionaire Dublin businessman, today to be the country's Prime Minister.

title: BENEFICIAL STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr include an approximate nonrecurring gain of $5.2 million or 90 cents a shr in connection with the settlement of a reinsurance agreement

title: RECOTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Matters of Gravity; Sit Down
description: Should you feel an unusual spring in your step today, or an unexplained lightheadedness, as if invisible forces are straining to draw you into the sky, don't rush to a doctor or a psychotherapist. See an astrologer.

title: ST. PATRICK'S? IT'S FOR LIONS
description: Forget about all those storied cultural differences between East and West, and consider Ah Pat and Ai Leen. The two Singapore ''lions,'' sporting shamrock insignias on their backs, will cavort up Fifth Avenue on St. Patrick's Day, alternating Chinese dances to the sound of gongs and drums with Irish reels. They will be accompanied by a marching band of young Christian, Buddhist, Moslem and Hindu students.

title: GRIDIRON DINNER: WHITE TIE AND JEST
description: The public's right to know, the battering ram of reporters in this town, sometimes stops at the strangest places. It stops, for example, at the door to the Gridiron Club's annual Spring dinner, where the President of the United States is a regular speaker, and it stops at the Library of Congress, where the club's official papers are deposited on the condition that they be off limits to the public for 25 years.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: MANY people have asked me if I distinguish between varieties of shrimp that are gray or brown or pink and so on. The answer is no. If there is any difference in these shrimp other than the waters from which they have been taken, I am unaware of it.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TRIPLE PLAY

title: SOME BRITISH TAXES CUT IN A 'RECOVERY' BUDGET
description: Britain's Conservative Government today presented a budget for the next fiscal year that promised to achieve at last its goal of lowering taxes on industry and reducing the Government's need to borrow in order to cover its deficits.

title: STEELMET INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-Net income; in Mar 1981 a fire partially destroyed the company's Port Vue facilities and in Dec of same yr Steelmet negotiated a settlement for damages with the insurer of $6.6 million of which $2.3 million related to a recovery of damages for business interruption; the balance of the proceeds relating to the damages to the facility in excess of net book value of the assets destroyed was $3.3 million; these items are included in the 1981 results of operat

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 10, 1982; Companies
description: World Airways asked the C.A.B. to regulate fares again because, it said, they are too low. The airline, whose early success was based on the cut-rate fares that followed deregulation, said that heavy operating losses and declining passenger traffic had produced a crisis in the industry that only the C.A.B. can resolve. (Page A1.)

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,957,000 for the latest yr and $114,000 for the previous yr

title: Economic Scene; Interest Rates Must Be Cut
description: HOW can another depression be avoided? A strategy for getting the nation out of the present crisis and back on a path of stable growth must be based on a correct analysis of what has led to the threat of a crackup in the domestic and world economies.

title: HALIFAX DEVELOPMENTS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
VOLUME UP
description: A late rally, led by some of the depressed blue-chip, technology and transportation issues, enabled the market to post a moderate gain yesterday in the fourth-heaviest trading in history.

title: Advertising
description: THE young man from the client's office was chatting the other day with the young man from the agency's office about the difficulty in reaching the audience they were both trying to attract: ''high networth individuals.''

title: Ashland, Carboex In Coal Accord
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said that it had entered into an agreement to sell a 10 percent interest in Ashland Coal Inc. for $44.3 million to Sociedad Espaola de Carbon Exterior S.A., or Carboex.

title: TRIDENT II'S ROLE AS A KEEPER OF THE PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 100 percent stock divd payable Mar 16

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The yr-ago shr earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 1981

title: Allen Picks Coach
description: George Allen, the new president of the Montreal Alouettes, named Joe Galat as coach, putting to rest speculation that the 59-year-old Allen might choose to coach the team himself. ''This one kept me awake nights, trying to find a way whereby I could coach and keep a handle on things upstairs,'' Allen said. ... The San Diego Chargers have acquired Ricky Bell, the first player chosen in the 1977 National Football League draft, from Tampa Bay for an undisclosed draft choice. Bell, a 6-foot-2-inch, 220-pound running back, rushed for 1,263 yards in 1979 but was hampered by a knee injury in 1980 and missed most of last season with a shoulder injury. ... The Green Bay Packers' offer to Bruce Clark, the defensive tackle from Penn State who played for Toronto the last two seasons, has been rejected by his agent, Richard Bennett.

title: LESLIE FAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Holding Haitians Hostage
description: Now and then, a Federal court can rescue the other two branches from the stupidities of their own paralysis - which is just what Federal District Judge Robert Carter may have done concerning the Haitians.

title: RICE TRADE DISPUTE INTENSIFIES
description: Charges of a multimillion-dollar bribery scheme in which American and European rice traders were said to be paying off South Korean officials have sounded alarm bells in Congress.

title: I.R.S. WINS ON TAX STRADDLES
description: The Internal Revenue Service has won a legal battle to prohibit the use of commodity futures straddles to postpone tax liabilities, but the victory appears to be largely symbolic because the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 banned the use of commodity tax straddles anyway.

title: Voices for Victims
description: Recent efforts to maintain standards of decency in prisons result in an anomaly: A convict is thereby eligible for many state-paid benefits - psychological help, education, vocational training and medical care. But not his victim. The victim, who may desperately need some of the same services as a direct result of the crime, usually must fend for himself.

title: A SOUPCON OF SPRING: FRESH GOAT CHEESE
description: A sign of spring in France has just crossed the Atlantic: fresh goat cheeses made from new milk, that is, the milk from animals grazing at pasture rather than feeding on a winter diet of stored fodder.

title: CITY HALL WANTS CORRECTION ON CRITICISM OF CITY SERVICES
description: The Koch administration, stung by recent criticism, took the unusual step yesterday of demanding that a civic group publicly ''correct'' its unflattering analysis of city services.

title: I.T.T. to Cut Staff
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation disclosed that it was reducing the size of its headquarters staff both here and in Brussels as part of a program that has resulted in the divestiture of 25 companies over the last two years. The company said that about 250 employees would be affected including management, middle management and clerical personnel. I.T.T. has more than 320,000 employees worldwide, with 130,000 in the United States.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. said it had acquired 10 percent, or 119,900 shares, of cumulative preferred stock series C of the Allis-Chalmers Corp. with a total value of $5.14 million. In addition, Bass said it had a short position of 104,200 common shares of Allis-Chalmers.

title: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Feb 12
Transactions; BASKETBALL
description: HOUSTON (NBA) - Signed Larry S priggs, forward on the Rochester Zeniths o f the C.B.A., to 10-day contract to replace B ill Willoughby, who is on injured reserve. COLLEGES DUQUESNE - Dismissed Mike Rice, basketball coach. FLORIDA - Named Jack Rhine head baseball coach. NAZARETH - Named John Beilein, former coach at Erie Community College- North, basketball coach. RICKS - Named Ron Haun, assistant for the last three years, head football coach. SAINT LOUIS UNIVERSITY - Named Larry Preo, director of physical recrea- tion at Marquette the last eight years, ath- letic director. SOUTHERN ILLINOIS - Announced it was eliminating men's wrestling and water polo programs because of a lack of funds. SOUTH CAROLINA - Named Terry Kelly women's basketball coach on a per- manent basis.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some recipes for meat dishes recommend sprinkling the meat with salt and pepper before browning the meat and adding liquid. Others do not. They simply add salt and pepper to the liquid. Is there a difference or does it matter?

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FOR some months now, Stanley B. Winters has been amassing a curious collection. He has culled a harvest of quotations from student papers and exams that have crossed his desk since the beginning of the fall semester. Dr. Winters (that's his real name) is a professor of history at a college in the metropolitan area. He prefers that it remain unidentified, he explains, ''because the scholarly or academic nature of this contribution is not of such a level as to warrant, I think, listing my institutional affiliation.'' Indeed. Nevertheless, the collection has its own academic charm. All entries are authentic, and the spelling is as it originally appeared:

title: 2 AILING THRIFT UNITS ACQUIRED
description: Two savings and loan associations in New York City have been acquired by the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rochester after Federal regulators granted permission yesterday for the merger.

title: Oklahoma Wins, 81-73, In Opener of N.I.T.
description: David Little scored 33 points and Chucky Barnett hit 18 of his 24 in the second half as Oklahoma overcame a sluggish start to eliminate Oral Roberts, 81-73, in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament tonight.

title: Reagan to Visit 3 States
description: President Reagan will travel to Tennessee, Alabama and Oklahoma next week to promote his ''new federalism'' program before the state legislatures, an Administration official said today.

title: Egg Drop
description: The condor is a strange bird: so big an eater that it routinely sleeps off its meals in trees, yet so graceful a flier that it seems to ride the air. But very few people have ever seen the California condor either snoozing or soaring because there are only about 30 left in the world.

title: EXPANSION POSTPONED BY ARMCO
description: Armco Inc. said yesterday that it had delayed indefinitely a $671 million expansion of its facilities to manufacture steel pipe and tubing for the oil and gas industry.

title: 5 Seized, Loot Recovered In Alabama Coin Theft
description: Stolen coins and precious metals valued at $2.4 million were recovered today from a rental van, and the police arrested three men and two women outside a motel.

title: MORE ON FACE LIFTS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I read with interest your article on face lifts. You state that only a board-certified plastic surgeon should be consulted for this surgery.

title: HERE'S ONE VOTE AGAINST THE PARADE
description: To the Editor:

title: LOW-COST AIRLINE NOW SEEKS FARES CURB IT ONCE OPPOSED
description: World Airways Inc., whose rapid growth was built on the cut-rate fares permitted under airline deregulation, called on the Government today to regulate fares once again because they are too low.

title: Early Warning System In U.S. Found Faulty
description: America's first line of defense against a Soviet missile attack, the Air Force's computerized early warning system, is ''dangerously'' outmoded and unreliable, according to a Congressional report released today.

title: FINNISH LEADER, IN MOSCOW, VOWS TO MAINTAIN CLOSE TIES TO SOVIET
description: President Mauno Koivisto of Finland pledged today that his nation would continue to pursue a policy of friendly relations with the Soviet Union.

title: ISLANDERS BEAT BLUES, 6-4, SPOILING FRANCIS'S DEBUT
description: Emile Francis returned to coaching tonight, but his St. Louis Blues fell before the Islanders by a score of 6-4. Francis, the Blues' president and general manager, had released Red Berenson as coach earlier today.

title: The Complexities of Legalese Bite Back; Legal How-Not-To
description: Legal documents, with their long-winded and often arcane brand of writing, have long been the brunt of jokes. But last month, a group of young would-be lawyers got an early sample of such writing - on their bar examination, of all places.

title: Value of Rand Falls Below $1
description: South Africa's rand fell today to less than $1, for the first time, largely as a result of the recent collapse of international gold prices.

title: The U.N. Today; March 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Greece Seeking Soviet Gas
description: The Greek Government said today that it was sending a delegation to Moscow on May 11 to negotiate for the delivery of Soviet natural gas to Greece.

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
description: Mr. Inman: Thank you, John. We're dealing today with the military buildup in Nicaragua and the question of the efforts to displace, in as classic a human rights violation as you can find, a substantial body of Indians from the eastern part of Nicaragua. We're ready to answer your questions.

title: FRASER INC (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Harvard Advances In Eastern Hockey
description: Playoff hockey returned to Harvard University for the first time in seven years last night at Cambridge, Mass., where the Crimson shut out Boston College, 2-0, to advance to the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I semifinals Friday night.

title:
MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
Elly Ameling, Soprano, Sings Italian Arias
description: Last Saturday evening the Dutch soprano Elly Ameling appeared as the soloist on a program of the Musica Aeterna orchestra at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In an evening of thoroughly remarkable music-making, Miss Ameling's radiant singing of four 18th-century arias stood out the way great masterpieces inevitably do -and left the musicians and audience alike looking for ways to express their appreciation.

description: B-Including income of $293,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $4,663,000 on the sale of discontinued operations results for the latest yr include a gain equal to 26 cents a sh on the disposition of minority interests

title: A Tall Problem
description: The length of the bed was the problem for George Bell, who is 7 feet 8 inches tall and is a reserve center for Biola University's basketball team. When at home in California, he sleeps on a mattress that is 8 feet 6 inches long.

title: News Analysis
description: As interest rates begin to fall again, some leaders on Capitol Hill, some economists and some officials at the Federal Reserve are worried that what is good for the economy now may not help them achieve Federal budgets with narrower deficits than those that have been projected by President Reagan.

title: Alston Top Candidate
description: Walter Alston, who led the Dodgers to seven pennants and four World Series championships in his 23 years as manager, appears to be the leading candidate to be voted into the Hall of Fame today by the veterans committee. The committee, which may choose no more than one former player or manager and one former executive a year, is also likely to consider Phil Rizzuto, the shortstop on nine Yankee teams that won American League titles; Babe Herman, a Dodger star of the 1930's, and Charlie Grimm and Jimmy Dykes, best remembered as managers of the Chicago Cubs and the Chicago White Sox.

title: WEST CHEMICAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $390,000 for the qr and $684,000 for the yr, a $5,000 nonrecurring loss for the qr, a $144,000 nonrecurring gain for the yr and a net increase for the yr of $766,000 from LIFO inventory reductions. C-Including income of $241,000 for the qr and yr from discontin operations, tax credits of $285,000 for the qr and $813,000 for the yr, nonrecurring income of $207,000 for the qr and $479,000 for the yr and a net increase of $684,000 for the yr from LIFO inventory reductions

title: TRANSCRIPT OF STATEMENTS AT STATE DEPT. ON THE MILITARY BUILDUP IN NICARAGUA
description: Following is a transcript of the statements and excerpts from the questions and answers at a briefing on the military buildup in Nicaragua given yesterday at the State Department by Adm. Bobby R. Inman, Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, and John T. Hughes, Deputy Director for Intelligence and External Affairs for the Defense Intelligence Agency, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network:

title: Datapoint Delays New Building
description: The Datapoint Corporation, citing an ''adverse business climate,'' said it had indefinitely postponed its plans to build a $50 million headquarters here.

title: JURY IS SWOREN IN AT CORONA TRIAL
description: The stocky, dark-haired man sat expressionless as the interpreter whispered the Spanish translation of the judge's statements to the jurors. The panel was about to be sworn in to try the charges that this quiet, impassive man murdered 25 itinerant farm workers more than a decade ago.

title: News Analysis
description: In New York, a juvenile's criminal and court records are kept secret because state policy and law have been based on the premise that confidentiality is essential to a juvenile's rehabilitation.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Newspaper reports in Chicago say that the Bulls are considering Al McGuire, among others, as their next coach, and that McGuire has said he is interested. Previously, he had responded to pro teams' approaches by saying he had two conditions: He must be paid $1 more than the highest-paid player, and he must be a part-owner of the franchise. ... Duquesne dropped Mike Rice as basketball coach after an 11-16 season and a four-year mark of 62-49.

title: STAGE: 'VACUUM,' SATIRE ON SALESMANSHIP
description: ''VACUUM,'' a production of the Antenna Theater of Sausalito, Calif., is a satiric exploration of the life of a salesman. Everyone, including Willy Loman, should recognize the territory.

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Elizabeth Taylor Makes Debut on London Stage
description: Elizabeth Taylor made her debut on the London stage last Friday night to a standing ovation by a sell-out crowd.

title: IN CENTRAL AMERICA, A CHALLENGE FOR TGHE O.A.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After plant relocation and closing costs of $858,000 for the qr and $1,094,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income; the company recently changed from a fiscal yr ending in Mar to a calendar yr

title: SHOPPING FOR NEW YORK'S BEST
description: THIS is a report on egg quality found in New York City stores in the last four weeks. Although one can vouch only for the eggs actually tasted, and quality may vary within and between shipments, at least two dozen were tested from each source, most bought at intervals of one to three weeks.

title: LUCAS PROPELS KNICKS, 126-112
description: According to Maurice Lucas, the Knicks' drive for a playoff berth started last night with a 126-112 victory over the Utah Jazz at Madison Square Garden.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Based on the pace of new airfield construction, and the development of new ground force installations, it is evident to us that the Sandinistas are achieving military force levels in excess of those normally required purely for defensive purposes.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press published on Dec. 23 incorrectly described a statement by Otto von Bolschwing, a former Nazi, in an agreement in which he surrendered his United States citizenship. Mr. von Bolschwing did not acknowledge that he had been an adviser to Adolf Eichmann or that he had persecuted Nazi victims. An obituary of Mr. von Bolschwing, who died Sunday, appears today on page B5.

title: Louisville Holds Raffle For 'Windfall' Tickets
description: With scalpers reportedly selling tickets for $400, the University of Louisville held a drawing today for 350 student tickets to a possible National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament game between Louisville and Kentucky.

title: FREQUENCY CONTROL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CENSURE RESOLUTION AND EXCERPTS FROM CRANSTON'S COMMENTS
description: Resolution

title: JUDGE ALLOWS MARATHON VOTE
description: A Federal judge today cleared the way for shareholders of the Marathon Oil Company to vote this week on the company's $6.2 billion merger with the United States Steel Corporation.

title: MIXED-USE DEVELOPMENT UNDER CONTRACT IN TEANECK
description: It might seem that the concept of mixed-use development in which residential, retail and office properties share space would fly in the face of the suburban ideal of distinctly separate zones for residential and commercial development.

title: Somali Leader in U.S.  To Seek More Assistance
description: President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia arrived here today to seek more economic and military assistance from the United States.

title: REAGAN SEES NEED FOR WIDE SUPPORT ON A BUDGET PLAN
description: President Reagan, in a peacemaking visit to Capitol Hill, told Senate Republicans today that he would not consider any budget alternative that did not have broad bipartisan support in both houses of Congress.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A CHAMPION'S ROCKY ROAD
description: The older brother had just asked the future light-heavyweight champion of the world for money to buy heroin. That was eight months ago, five months before Dwight Braxton knocked out Matthew Saad Muhammad to win the World Boxing Council title.

title: 60-SECOND DEBATE
description: The Senate passed an amendment last week that would prohibit Federal courts from ordering the busing of students more than five miles or l5 minutes from their homes to promote classroom integration. The measure now goes to the House of Representatives, where it is almost certain to become a major issue. Two House members with strong views on the subject were asked to comment on the question: Should Congress forbid Federal courts to use busing as a means to desegregate public schools? John M. Ashbrook Republican of Ohio

title: ASTRONOMERS SCOFF AT SOOTHSAYERS PREDICTING WORLD WILL END TODAY
description: Despite widespread rumors, the world is unlikely to end today as a result of an unusual alignment of the Sun, the planets and the Moon, known as a syzygy. Astronomers do not expect anything unusual, except for the fact that all of the other planets will be visible at the same time from the Earth,

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results for the yr-ago 9 mos include a net capital gain of $2,575,000 or 41 cents a shr, from the sale of 370,000 shrs of Boston Digital Corp stock

title: Transit Report
description: SUBWAYS: Some delays were reported on the Brooklyn-bound IRT trains for about an hour in the morning rush while No. 2, 3, 4 and 5 express trains were being rerouted onto the local track between Atlantic and Franklin Avenues in Brooklyn because of a problem on the tracks. There were no serious delays in the evening.

title: 2 Youths Sought In Killing for Radio
description: A police hunt was under way yesterday for two youths, believed to be between 17 and 19 years old, who killed a Queens high school student with a rifle on Monday when he refused to give them his radio.

title: WHAT BENDIX BRINGS TO RCA
description: Since William M. Agee took over the Bendix Corporation in 1976 at the age of 38, the company's earnings have steadily increased, despite its close links to the depressed automobile industry.

title: ARLEN REALTY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Phibro Names President Of Phillip, a Subsidiary
description: The Phibro Corporation, the nation's 14th-largest nonfinancial company last year with revenues of $25.1 billion, has simplified its organization chart by converting its Phillip Brothers unit from a division to a subsidiary. And At the same time, it named one of its key executives, Thomas D. O'Malley, 40, as president of the new subsidiary, an international trading organization for some 150 commodities.

title: Robinson's 35 Points Spark Suns' 103-95 Victory over Bullets
description: Len Robinson scored 35 points, including the first 7 of the fourth quarter, in leading the Phoenix Suns to a 103-95 victory over the Washington Bullets tonight.

title: DAVID ROCKEFELLER SAYS AFRICANS LOOK TO U.S.
description: David Rockefeller has said here at the end of a 10-nation African tour that left-wing countries like Angola, Guinea and Zimbabwe have become disillusioned with Soviet aid and are seeking closer ties with the United States.

title: Mets Put Bets on 2 Sluggers
description: In his third intrasquad game, and in his ninth time at bat, Dave Kingman got his first long hit of spring training today: A home run that carried high over the head of the left fielder, George Foster, the man whose arrival on the Mets is supposed to make Kingman a better hitter.

title: JUDGING QUALITY: EXPERTS' TIPS
description: ANYONE judging the quality of an egg first looks for a shell that has no checks (small hairline cracks) or leaks (breaks through the inner membrane), the latter being dangerous because of possible salmonella infection. The shell should have a regular shape with no distortions, and those who are experienced also check freshness by feeling the weight of an egg in relation to its volume. As an egg ages, it loses moisture and so becomes lighter; it also loses carbon dioxide, which influences flavor.

title: Phillips to Shut A Refinery
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, the nation's 12th-largest refiner, said it will shut its 80,000-barrel-a-day refinery here on Aug. 1 because of declines in demand for its products.

title: RISE IS REPORTED IN OUTSIDE DIRECTORS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has released a staff report that discloses a decline in the number of corporate directors who are either employed by or affiliated with the companies they serve.

title: EX-CAPTAIN IN NAZI SS
description: Otto von Bolschwing, a former German SS captain who voluntarily surrendered his United States citizenship last year after a Justice Department investigation of his Nazi past, died Sunday in a Sacramento hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: MOOKIE WENT TO MOUNTAINTOP
description: WHEN pilgrims seek the true meaning of life, they may seclude themselves with a spiritual teacher in a mountain monastery or an ashram deep in a forest.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
Barnard Increases Costs to Students
description: Tuition at Barnard College will increase 15 percent and room and board charges will increase 13 percent for the 1982-83 academic year, the college's trustees have announced, bringing total expenses for a resident student to more than $12,000.

title: U.S. FIGHTS JERSEY TEAMSTER LOCAL
description: The Federal Government moved today to strip Teamster Local 560 of its leadership and have a trustee take over its affairs and conduct a new election for officers.

title: LINCOLN INCOME LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV: 'POLAR BEAR ALERT' ON WNET
