description: THE National Geographic Society took many years to take the plunge into television. Since it has, though, it has taken advantage of the medium's ability to project entertainingly a magazine format of information into the home. Tonight at 8 o'clock, the society offers a beautiful pictorial essay, ''Polar Bear Alert,'' on WNET-TV, Channel 13. It is an essay that parallels but differs from the article running in its current magazine issue.

title: REPORT SAYS MILLIONS IN INDUSTRIAL REGIONS ARE RISKING DISEASE
description: Millions of Americans risk cancer, lung disease and other life-threatening illnesses by living near 312 industrial plants that pollute the air with three billion pounds of toxic substances yearly, environmental groups said today.

title: A 1976 BAXTER MEMO ABOUT I.B.M. EMERGES
description: Two months ago William F. Baxter, the Justice Department's antitrust chief, dismissed the Government's 13-year-old case against the International Business Machines Corporation. In December 1976, while he was a Stanford law professor, Mr. Baxter wrote a memo to the incoming Carter Administration's transition team, saying that the case should never have been brought.

title: EFFICIENT DRUM GRATER
description: IT has always seemed better to grate Parmesan at the moment pasta is dished up, the way restaurants have been doing it for years. Freshly grated cheese is infinitely better than store-bought and even better than cheese you might have grated that morning. It transforms the plainest dish. It can be used on all homemade pasta, including manicotti or lasagna and on risotto.

title: An Actor's Luck
description: For Matthew Broderick, the teen-age actor who recently won rave reviews Off Broadway, ''everything's coming up roses,'' to borrow a line from the Broadway musical ''Gypsy.''

title: FRENCH SELL CONGDON PUBLISHERS
description: A group of American investors has purchased Congdon & Lattes, a New York book-publishing company, from its French owners, Lattes Publications Inc.

title: DR. LAZAR MARGULIES, 87, SURGEON
description: Dr. Lazar Margulies, a surgeon and gynecologist-obstetrician who helped develop the plastic intrauterine device for contraception, died Sunday at the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Moving Up at C.& W.
description: Warren E. Albright and Arthur R. Meranus, who are in charge, respectively, of account management and the creative department at Cunningham & Walsh, have both been promoted to executive vice president. They will continue to report to Horace Malfa, executive vice president and general manager. Roger D. Groves has been named to the board at C.& W.

title: GUATEMALA REGIME CLAIMS VICTORY IN ELECTION
description: Victory in Sunday's presidential election was claimed today by the Government's candidate, and his three opponents were detained by the police as they were marching to the presidential palace to present what they said was evidence of fraud.

title: PARISIANS JOIN CAPITAL OPERA FOR MOZART
description: The Washington Opera and L'Orchestre de Paris announced Monday that they would jointly produce three Mozart operas at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here and at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees in the next three years.

title: Pope Refuses to Receive Kung, Rebel Theologian
description: The Vatican has refused to give Hans Kung, the liberal theologian, an audience with Pope John Paul II until he gives a sign that he has changed opinions that led to his dispute with the church, the West German Roman Catholic Church said today.

title: BANK OF MONTREAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: BEST BUYS
description: WE can expect to pay more for some fresh fruits this spring, according to a United States Department of Agriculture report. The Florida freeze, a smaller California orange crop and smaller apple supplies have led to higher prices in certain items. If the Florida orange crop turns out to be 21 percent less than last season, as expected, it would be the smallest crop since 1968-69, the department said. The California orange crop is estimated at 26 percent below last season's record. Stocks of fresh apples were 19 percent less and prices higher.

title: TWO NATURAL GAS BILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: N.F.L. and Coliseum Explore Accord on Suit

title: Wickes Plans Sale Of Two Holdings
description: Wickes Companies, a leading retailer of lumber and building products, announced separate agreements to sell a controlling interest in its Red Owl-Snyder supermarket and drugstore unit and its MacGregor Golf Company unit for $77 million, consisting of $72 million in cash and $5 million in notes.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net income including a gain on the sale of an excess plant

title: On Juvenile Diabetics
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I am a 12-year-old insulin-dependent juvenile diabetic. I read your Personal Health column (Feb. 17) about high-carbohydrate, high-fiber diets for diabetics.

title: Article 240863 -- No Title
description: The Colonial Penn Group Inc., a major insurer, said today that it lost $29.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1981, compared with net income of $12.8 million, or 80 cents a share, in the 1980 final quarter. Fourth-quarter revenue climbed to $311 million from $206.6 million in the last quarter of 1980.

title: BENDIX MOVE SPURS RCA STOCK ACTIVITY
description: Investors, sensing a takeover bid for the RCA Corporation, propelled trading in RCA stock to the most active spot on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, although some Wall Street analysts cautioned that they did not believe RCA would become a takeover target any time soon.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE paper profits that can be calculated by intrepid wine buyers who purchase wisely and well are enormous, dwarfing the returns available in stocks, bonds, gold and other traditional investments. When the gains are so large, the temptation is almost irresistible to cash them in, and many oenophiles are doing so.

title: ASSESSING THE 'I LOVE NEW YORK DIET'
description: AT a medical meeting some years ago, a group of science writers concocted a recipe for a sure-fire, best-selling diet book. They knew, though, that none of them would ever write it because, to captivate the victims of dietmania, it would have to make promises that ranged from medically questionable to scientifically impossible. Ingredients were:

title: MET OPERA: 'LES CONTES D'HOFFMANN'
description: WHEN it comes time to add up the agonies and the ecstasies of this Metropolitan Opera season, the new production of ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' that went on display Monday night will likely lead the ecstasy list.

title: OPERATORS OF HOME DENY BEATING WAYWARD GIRLS
description: In quiet, impassioned testimony, operators of a home for wayward teen-age girls declared their love for the former residents who have accused them of abusive treatment.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt HOW I COMMITTED SUICIDE. A Reverie. By C.L. Sulzberger. 216 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $11.95.

title: NORTH CAROLINA GOES TO NO.1
description: North Carolina, the Atlantic Coast Conference champion and topseeded in the national collegiate tournament, was placed No.1 yesterday in The New York Times computer ranking of the nation's 273 major-college basketball teams. The Tar Heels beat out Oregon State, the Pacific-10 Conference champion ranked first last week.

title: IRISHMAN WHO IS DOING AN ENCORE
description: Eleven years ago Charles James Haughey's political career was in ruins, and the chances for recovery seemed very slim indeed. After a fast start in politics, he had been abruptly dismissed from the Irish Cabinet because of accusations of involvement in gunrunning for the Irish Republican Army in the North. Although acquitted of the arms charges, in a sensational trial in 1970, Mr. Haughey was consigned by almost everyone to remain in the wilderness.

title: SQUID: A DELICACY IN ANY LANGUAGE
description: BROWSING through the international sections of a number of cookbooks recently, I noted that almost every one of them lists recipes for squid. That interested me because Americans seem to have a very small appetite for squid, a delicacy that I would place in the highest category of good things to eat from the sea.

title: BACHE TO ACQUIRE BATEMAN BROKERAGE
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said yesterday that it has agreed in principle to acquire the brokerage business of Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., of Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Diplomat Arrives For Talks in Lebanon
description: President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, arrived here today and reportedly told Lebanese leaders that he had done everything possible to avert an Israeli invasion of Lebanon. But he is said to have warned that an incident might still touch off an invasion.

title: PLAYBOY UNFIT FOR GAMING LICENSE, JERSEY ATTORNEY GENERAL CHARGES
description: The Division of Gaming Enforcement urged the Casino Control Commission today not to license Playboy Enterprises Inc. and its principal owner, Hugh M. Hefner, to operate a casino in Atlantic City.

title: LAMBRUSCO RATES HIGH WITH U.S. CONSUMERS
description: The American consumer's infatuation with lambrusco is turning into a full-blown love affair. Millions upon millions of bottles of the semisweet, lightly effervescent wine from Italy are consumed in this country annually, and the volume keeps rising in quantum jumps.

title: HOW BEST TO FOCUS A TAX ON GASOLINE
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Under Secretary General From Jamaica; New Aide at U.N.
description: The United Nations has named Lucille Mathurin Mair, a former Jamaican Ambassador to Cuba who later served as Secretary General of the United Nations World Conference on Women in Copenhagen in 1980, as an Under Secretary General.

title: ATLANTA COMMISSIONER GETS POLICE CHIEF JOB IN HOUSTON
description: Lee Patrick Brown, Atlanta's Commissioner of Public Safety, has resigned to become Chief of Police in Houston.Mr. Brown, whose decision to leave Atlanta came as a surprise to officials here, emerged as a national figure in law enforcement as he led an investigation into a string of unsolved deaths of young blacks here over a 22-month period. The investigation into the 28 slayings and one abduction resulted in the arrest last summer of Wayne B. Williams, a 23-year-old talent agent, who was convicted of murder in two of the slayings late last month.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT INVESTIGATING $100,000 FEE
description: The State Department and a Senate committee are investigating consulting fees of nearly $100,000 for a Washington lawyer who was retained by the department to advise on the Law of the Sea negotiations, Administration and Senate officials said today.

title: HOW TO TELL WHEN THEY ARE FRESH EGGS
description: EVER a source of mystery and wonder, eggs have been regarded as miracles throughout the history of civilization, inspiring awe in scientists and spiritualists, artists and designers. But perhaps the most bewildering mysteries posed by the egg are those facing the consumer: how to tell if an egg is fresh before you buy or eat it, and where to find eggs that are both fresh and flavorful - questions almost as puzzling as the old which-came-first enigma.

title: BALDWIN-UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including securities gains of $2,309,000 for the qr and $6.2 million for the yr...C-Including securities gains of $1,264,000 for the qr and $8,902,000 for the yr; shr earnings are fully diluted

title: CARIBBEAN BASIN SECURITY
description: Tiny El Salvador, about the size of Massachusetts and 15 times smaller than Vietnam, looms larger and larger in the eyes of the United States. Indeed, events in Central America have been pushed to the front page, and leaders around the world are justifiably concerned.

title: ANTHONY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $51,000 for the qr and $67,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discont operations of $364,000 for the qr and $735,000 for the yr; yr-a results have been restated to reflect a net loss of $735,000 fr a business segment as being from discontinued operations and to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding fore currency translations which reduced net income by $689,000

title: TV: THE MARX BROTHERS,NARRATIVES AND FILM CLIPS
description: ''THE Marx Brothers in a Nutshell,'' a 90-minute documentary on WNET-TV at 9 o'clock tonight, is precisely the kind of project favored by public television executives during the system's fundraising periods. PBS might talk a great cultural game, but when pressed it rushes to repeats of old movies such as ''Auntie Mame'' or ''Gigi'' and, whenever possible, to razzle-dazzle show-business salutes.

title: British Car Output Up
description: British car production in February rose 25.7 percent, to 88,000 units, from 70,000 in January. February's production was 14.2 percent higher than the 77,000 units produced in the same month last year, according to provisional figures released by the Industry Department today. Commercial vehicle production rose to 22,800 in February, from 17,400 a year ago and 17,600 in January, the department said.

title: Qaddafi Due in Austria; To Ask Exiles to Return
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, plans to meet with exiles here during a four-day visit starting Wednesday and will try to encourage them to return home, a Libyan diplomat said today.

title: Tin Council to Step Up Price Support
description: The International Tin Council agreed today to more than double the amount of tin it can buy on world markets to help support prices.

title: 1. The Return of the Hat
description: The fashion pundits are predicting that women will be wearing hats this spring, after years of going bareheaded. Perhaps so, since Liz Claiborne, who normally designs sportswear, is putting her label in millinery. Miss Claiborne likes a brimmed hat made of thin straw banded with striped grosgrain ribbon, which comes in a wide array of colors such as yellow, red, turquoise and natural. It's $26 in Macy's main floor accessory department.

title: Miss Salz Promoted
description: Leni Salz, the head of broadcast spot buying services at J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., who replaced Marie Luisi in one of her jobs, has been promoted to senior vice president. With the company since 1966, when she joined as a secretary, Miss Salz worked her way up in the media department from buyer to negotiator, regional supervisor and then manager of all spot buying. Now she is director. Mrs. Luisi was suspended last month without pay after an audit disclosed possibly fraudulent entries totaling $24.5 million in assets had been entered in JWT Syndication's computer system.

title: Slashing Suspect Ruled Mentally Unfit for Trial
description: The man who the police believe was responsible for a series of throat-slashing attacks last summer that left two men dead and 13 wounded was found mentally unfit to stand trial yesterday by Acting Justice Benjamin Altman in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: DON'T PUSH, LITTER OR HONK, THE CHINESE ARE TOLD
description: Early on the morning of Sunday, Feb. 28, a minibus arrived at the eastern gate of Beihai Park and disgorged the Communist Party Chairman, Hu Yaobang, three Deputy Prime Ministers and some other prominent officials. As cameras clicked, they picked up brooms and vigorously swept down the walks.

title: American Home Completes Bid
description: The American Home Products Corporation said it had completed its $425 million acquisition of the Brunswick Corporation's Sherwood Medical Group.

title: Warriors 92, Pacers 85
description: INDIANAPOLIS (AP) - Golden State was led by Bernard King, who scored 28 points; World Free, who had 20, and Larry Smith, who grabbed 20 rebounds.

title: OLGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
U.S. OFFERS PHOTOS OF BASES TO PROVE NICARAGUA THREAT
description: The Reagan Administration made public today aerial reconnaissance photographs that intelligence officials said proved Nicaragua, with Cuban and Soviet assistance, was assembling the largest military force in Central America.

title: SAFETY MUST RANK FIRST IN THE NUCLEAR INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAIL HEARS STUDIES ON TAMPONS' EFFECTS
description: Seven studies of toxic shock syndrome, including three that link the disease to Rely tampons, can be introduced as evidence in a teen-ager's $25 million lawsuit against Procter & Gamble, maker of the tampon, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Cessna Sets Employee Cuts
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company said that it would lay off about 1,000 workers at its Wallace division in Wichita, Kan., and halt the production of its Conquest and Corsair propjet models because of declining demand.

title: LOBLAW COMPANIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Jan 2
description: B-Including a tax credit of $9,175,000 and a gain of $2,882,000 on the sale of an investment...C-Including a tax credit of $12,112,000; the company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges; results are for 52 weeks for the latest yr and 53 weeks for the previous yr

title: SPLASHES OF COLOR TO HURRY SPRING
description: WINTER weather may still be here, but the calendar says that spring is less than two weeks off and it's time to think about getting some spring clothes. A dash of pretty color or a splash of starchy white will not do much to raise the temperature but can go a long way toward lifting the spirits, especially if the clothes have an aura of individuality - and don't look like what is already hanging in the closet.

title: AT YANKEE STADIUM, AN AIR OF EXPECTATION
description: There was snow yesterday, and there was cold, but it was a fact beyond disputing that in some ways winter was on the wane. This was manifest up in the Bronx, where Jim Esposito was making ready the stuff of spring, as he has done for 37 years. The hallways were thick with the heady smell of paint, dark blue for the bottom half of the cinder blocks, white for the top; the ammonia and water was applied, along with the requisite elbow grease, to the bright blue padding for the outfield walls.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Telegraph Company, the principal subsidiary of the Western Union Corporation, announced it had purchased a substantial minority interest in Cellular Communications Inc. of New York, a company that will be applying for authority to build and operate cellular mobile radio telephone systems in selected metropolitan areas around the country. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change relating to oil and gas exploration activities

title: JUDGE ASKS MERCY FOR WAR VETERANS
description: A Federal district judge in Boston has proposed that the nation's parole boards give ''special consideration'' to imprisoned Vietnam veterans because of the traumatic effects of their war experience.

title: FOLLOWERS OF AYN RAND PROVIDE A FINAL TRIBUTE
description: Ayn Rand's body lay next to the symbol she had adopted as her own - a six-foot dollar sign. Outside the funeral home, her followers, some in jeans and some in furs, stood in the cold waiting to pay her tribute.

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Guilty of Extortion In Threats to Businesses
description: A Federal jury returned guilty verdicts tonight in the extortion trial of two men accused of sending ticks, explosives and threats to major corporations.

title: Red Wings Are for Sale
description: Bruce Norris, who recently celebrated 50 years of his family's ownership of the Detroit Red Wings, put the team up for sale today and said through a spokesman that it would probably change hands before next season.

title: Non-Dream Fulfilled
description: To hear Mickey Rooney tell it, when ''Sugar Babies'' opened in San Francisco three years ago, he never had ''the slightest dream'' that he would one day be celebrating its 1,000th performance on Broadway.

title: SERVICES ARE HELD FOR CLIFFORD CASE
description: The family, friends and political kinsmen of Clifford P. Case gathered in a stone chapel on the campus of Rutgers University here today to take part in a funeral service for the former Senator.

title: Hawks 120, Nuggets 106
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Dan Roundfield led the way with 34 points and 19 rebounds.

title: Lo and Behold! An Optimist!
description: This city is in such a pessimistic mood these days - about the economy, the alliance, Central America and the Russians - that it doesn't quite know what to make of a visitor like the Foreign Minister of West Germany, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who has been going up and down town recently here suggesting we take things a little easier.

title: BASALT COVERS VENUS, SOVIET SCIENTIST REPORTS
description: Much of Venus is covered with a kind of rock found deep inside the Earth, a prominent Soviet scientist was quoted as saying today.

title: COCAINE LINK IS HINTED AS JOHN BELUSHI IS BURIED
description: Funeral services for John Belushi were held today on Martha's Vineyard off the coast of Massachusetts as there were reports here that the 33-year-old actor's death last Friday was a result of a large dose of cocaine or other drugs.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Company has named Alger B. Chapman Jr. vice chairman of the American Express International Banking Corporation subsidiary.

title: AT NASSAU LUNCH, KOCH FINDS MEDIA OVERDONE
description: It was a gray day, too gray to tell through the car window whether this was a sterile suburb. Mayor Koch came out here anyway today on an excursion that was billed in advance as one part policy discussion and one part politics. In the wood-paneled back room of the Gum Ying restaurant, it turned out to be many parts of one of Luis Bunuel's more elliptical movies.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 10, 1982
description: International A Nicaraguan military buildup is being pressed and has upset Central America's military balance, according to the Reagan Administration. It made public aerial reconnaissance photographs that intelligence officials said proved that Nicaragua, with Cuban and Soviet aid, was assembling the largest military force in the region. (Page A1, Column 6.) Nicaragua's buildup is defensive only, according to one of the three members of the Sandinist junta. He charged that Washington was making charges to the contrary to justify possible intervention. He conceded that the size of the Nicaraguan armed forces had been increased, but asserted, ''There is not a single foreign soldier in Nicaragua.'' (A1:5.)

title: AN INNOVATOR IN CAFE DECOR AND IN FOOD
description: JOHNNY NICHOLSON, the restaurateur, window dresser and set designer, has been known to many New Yorkers for more than 25 years as the owner of the Cafe Nicholson, which is now closed. If it had not been for War II he might still be living in St. Louis: he came to Manhattan because he was 4F.

title: SOVIET FRUSTRATED IN COURTING IRAN
description: The Soviet Union expressed frustration today that, despite its efforts to court Iran, the Islamic rulers remained cool.

title: Careers; A Need For Fire Experts
description: DR. DOUGAL DRYSDALE, a busy teacher from Edinburgh, Scotland, keeps one jump ahead of his class while he writes a basic book on fire dynamics, the subject of a semester course at Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $220,000

title: 2 JUSTICES' BUDGET TESTIMONY SEEN AS HINT TO KEY DECISION
description: Two Supreme Court Justices appeared before a House Appropriations subcommittee today to present the Court's $14.9 million budget request and in the process may have foretold the decision in an important case.

title: Rescued Youth Loses Legs
description: A youth who was rescued after wandering for several days on a New Hampshire mountain in January has had both legs amputated because efforts to repair frostbite damage failed, a hospital announced Tuesday. Doctors performed the surgery Monday on Hugh Herr, 17 years old, of Holtwood, Pa., at Presbyterian-University of Pennsylvania Medical Center.

title: GENERAL REFRACTORIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; results for the latest yr reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translat which decreased the net loss by $1,951,000

title: How to Wrap a Peanut
description: For new product introductions in February, the 1982 edition was a boomer - 98, up from 78 in February 1981, according to the New Product News, a newsletter from Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

title: CHILEAN'S WIDOW PURSUES HIS CAUSE
description: At the recent opening here of ''Missing,'' a movie about the 1973 military coup in Chile, a diminutive, darkhaired woman talked quietly but earnestly with Sissy Spacek, the actress who portrays the wife of an American who disappeared in the takeover.

title: Technology; Weird World Of Robotics
description: THE ''factory of the future'' may not be here yet, but the jargon to describe it flows freely whenever the nation's manufacturing executives and engineers gather. Last week's robotics trade show in Detroit, for instance, was just the place to get an earful about ''control hierarchy'' and ''group technology.''

title: LIMIT PUT ON DEFICIT IN FRANCE
description: Concerned over rising Government spending, President Francois Mitterrand today ordered the Government to hold next year's budget deficit to 3 percent of total economic output, about half of current projections for the deficit.

title: 2 Papers Cutting Prices
description: The Chattanooga Publishing Company announced today that it was cutting the price of the city's two daily newspapers to 10 cents from 25 cents to determine whether the lower price attracted readers. Roy McDonald, chairman of Chattanooga Publishing and publisher of The Chattanooga News-Free Press, said the price change would be effective Monday for The Chattanooga Times, the city's morning paper, and for the afternoon newspaper, The News-Free Press.

title: ENDERS AND CHILEAN CHIEF MEET
description: The Under Secretary of State for Latin American Affairs, Thomas O. Enders, met with President Augusto Pinochet today to discuss the political turmoil in Central America and human rights in Chile.

title: Sports People; Denny Crum's Luck
description: The possibility of a Kentucky-Louisville match Saturday in the second round of the national championship tournament has brought much anticipation because of the Wildcats' longtime refusal to play Louisville during the regular season. But now that Coach Denny Crum of Louisville has the Wildcats where he wants them, he may miss the game.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to Feb 7
description: Shr earnings reflect 10 percent stock divds issued Nov 15, 1980 and Nov 15, 1981

title: Critic's Notebook; INTELLECTUALS JUST WON'T PUT THEIR MINDS TO MUSIC
description: SOMETIME during the late 1940's, according to William Barrett's recently published memoir, ''The Truants,'' the Juilliard String Quartet visited a loft on Eighth Street known as the Club. It was where Willem de Kooning, Jackson Pollock and other painters who were later called Abstract Expressionists or Action Painters gathered to socialize, lecture and argue.

title: STATE TO DRAFT PLAN TO CONTROL CAUSES OF ACID RAIN
description: New York State said yesterday that it would draft a program to combat acid rain and would take the lead in pressing for Federal legislation and an interstate mediation panel to help control the spread of pollution that causes it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In my judgment, our role for now and for the future is purely limited military assistance.

title: STOCKS UP IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: The stock market ended slightly higher yesterday for the second consecutive session in active trading with some of the energy-related issues registering the best gains.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Up
description: The 117 magazines that are members of the Publishers Information Bureau had a 3 percent increase in ad pages in January over the same month last year, with a total of 8,143, up a fraction of a page less than 200 pages. Ad revenues, thanks to increased rates, rose $24.1 million, or 13 percent, to $211.2 million.

title: A New Chairman At Dollar Savings
description: Wilmot F. Wheeler Jr., 58 years old, will join the Dollar Savings Bank, New York City's sixth-largest savings bank, as chairman and chief executive officer, effective April 1. He will succeed Robert J. Zeller, 64, who will retire from the bank.

title: NO PLANS TO SEND G.I.'S TO SALVADOR, GEN. JONES ASSERTS
description: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. David C. Jones, said today that he did not ''see any circumstances under which we would intervene with United States forces'' in El Salvador.

title: BROADER JOB FOR BUCKLEY EXPECTED
description: James L. Buckley, the former New York Senator, will soon move from his present position as an Under Secretary of State to a different State Department job that will involve him in a wider range of foreign policy issues as a close assistant to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Administration officials said today.

title: COLT PLANS TO SELL CRUCIBLE UNIT BY '83
description: Colt Industries said yesterday that it plans to sell its Crucible stainless and alloy division operations in Midland, Pa., by the end of this year.

title: BRAQUE SHOW SETS FOR 4 U.S. MUSEUMS
description: The United States and French Governments are to cooperate on a four-city exhibition of the works of the modern French painter Georges Braque, it was announced today. The exhibition will be mounted by the Phillips Collection,

title: Bridge: Wise Use of a Splinter Bid Can Help Team to Victory
description: There is no doubt whatever that Blackwood, in its various forms, is the world's most popular convention and that Stayman, also in several varieties, is a close second. But what ranks next?

title: MIME: IVCICH'S 'SOLITARE'
description: STEVEN IVCICH'S ''Solitaire,'' an hourlong abstract mime piece performed Tuesday at the Tyson Studio, had the fascination of a swim class for newborns. Absorbing at first because of its seeming lack of artifice, it palled after a time because of that very lack.

title: Rangers, Leading by 5-2, Are Tied, 5-5, by Flyers
description: The Rangers squandered a three-goal lead in the third period and allowed the Philadelphia Flyers to tie them, 5-5, at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: The Rev. Mitchell Dahood, 60, A Scholar of Semitic Studies
description: The Rev. Mitchell Dahood, an American Jesuit and an authority on Semitic studies, has died in Rome, friends reported Tuesday. He was 60 years old.

title: The Region
description: The Nassau County Board of Elections has decided that Joseph M. Margiotta is eligible to vote while he appeals his conviction on Federal charges of mail fraud and extortion.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Diplomatic R.S.V.P.

title: ALIENS WHO STAY IN CLUSTERS ARE SAID TO DO BETTER
description: A study of Cuban and Mexican migrants suggests that aliens may achieve more economic success if they are clustered together rather than scattered throughout the United States.

title: IN RURAL JAVA, FOREIGN INVESTMENT CAN HURT
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $105,000 for the qr and $230,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $100,000

title: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change for compensated absences

title: 2 Oil Concerns Set Merger
description: The Oasis Petroleum Corporation of Culver City, Calif., and the USA Petroleum Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., said they had agreed to merge to form a new company that would be one of the nation's biggest independent oil producers.

title: ABORTION CURBS ENDORSED, 10-7, BY SENATE PANEL
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved a proposed constitutional amendment that would enable Congress and individual states to adopt laws banning abortion.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 16.00-16.50** Maximum rate payable by savings institutionsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ILLINOIS SETS RECORD
description: Playing against the team with the highest scoring average this season, Illinois became the highest scoring team in the 45-year history of major college postseason tournaments tonight when it posted a 126-78 victory over Long Island University in an opening round game of the 45th National Invitation Tournament.

title: Corning Glass Ratings
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday lowered its senior long-term debt rating of the Corning Glass Works to double A-minus from double A and assigned a double A-minus rating to the proposed $100 million, 7 percent debentures due 2007. The debt rating service said that the company, based in Corning, N.Y., ''has been and continues to be subject to cyclical influences.'' Standard & Poor's said the company's A-1 plus commercial paper rating was being maintained.

title: MITTERRAND DOES BATTLE WITH ENRAGED BUREAUCRACY
description: Last week a high-ranking social security official in Marseilles committed suicide. Tuesday, 400 police commanders held an angry protest meeting at the police headquarters here, on the Quai des Orfevres.

title: Notes on People; Piraeus Revisited
description: The waterfront of the port city of Piraeus is one of the most picturesque settings in Greece. So picturesque, in fact, that it served as the setting for the movie ''Never on Sunday.''

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All per shr figures reflect 6-for-4 stock split paid Jan 5, 198

title: The City; Javits Is Reported In Stable Condition
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits, who has been hospitalized in West Palm Beach, Fla., since last Thursday, was reported in stable condition in the respiratory-care unit of St. Mary's Hospital.

title: Fetal Surgery Is Hailed As a Hope for Unborn
description: Doctors, giving the first detailed account of how they operated on a 5-month-old fetus outside the womb, say such surgery ''offers new hope'' for the unborn who may otherwise die or suffer birth defects.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
OFFICIAL SHIFTS ROLE IN U.S. SEA-LAW DELEGATION
description: A key official in the United States delegation to the Law of the Sea Conference, who has been under attack on charges of conflict of interest, said today that he was temporarily leaving his Washington law office.

title: TOP SOVIET SOLDIER URGES READINESS
description: The Soviet Union's top professional soldier has issued a stern warning that the Soviet Union must keep its military machine, economy and people in total readiness and that any letup in weapons development could have ''serious consequences.''

title: BUSINESS EXODUS HURTS MINNESOTA BORDER CITIES
description: The Red River, an ice-choked channel that separates this western Minnesota city from neighboring Fargo, N.D., seems well-named these days. To some residents here, it accurately describes the ink that has been spilling from companies on this side of the river, where taxes and the overall cost of doing business are many times higher than in North Dakota.

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $6,000 for the qr and $1 million for the yr from the exchange of debentures... C-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $410,000

title: Hospital Concern Sets Purchase
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire the First Washington Group Inc., a 13-state psychiatric hospital chain, in a transaction valued at $100 million.

title: Market Place; Strategists' Viewpoint
description: SINCE the fourth quarter of 1980, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has embraced the disinflation theme as a main prop of its investment strategy, says Burton Siegel, research director for this major brokerage house.

title: WILLIAMS'S CHIEF ACCUSER IN SENATE
description: In late 1979, when Senator Malcolm Wallop agreed to fill a Republican seat on the Senate's Select Committee on Ethics, he recalls, Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate minority leader at the time, told him, ''It should be an easy tour.''

title: Israeli Troops Shoot Arab in West Bank
description: Israeli troops breaking up a disturbance in the West Bank town of Nablus shot and wounded an Arab demonstrator today. He was the fourth Arab shot by soldiers in Nablus in five days of clashes.

title: WITNESSES DIFFER ON WHERE TANKER EXPLODED
description: The gasoline tanker that blew up in the East River on Feb. 26 exploded before it reached the Williamsburg Bridge, according to testimony by eyewitnesses yesterday at a hearing into the causes of the blast.

title: Strike in London Shuts All Subways and Buses
description: London's subway and bus network was shut down today in a transport union protest over the court-ordered doubling of fares. Officials said it was the first total shutdown of transportation services since the 1926 General Strike.

title: TWO NATIONALISMS COMPETE IN DACCA
description: Using terms that reflect the fundamental split in this nation of 90 million people, Prime Minister Shah Azizur Rahman declared in Parliament this week that there should be no conflict between Bengali nationalism and Bangladesh nationalism.

title: CHANDLER, JACKSON TO JOIN HALL
description: Albert B. (Happy) Chandler, who was voted out of office as commissioner of baseball 30 years ago, was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame today along with Travis Jackson, the shortstop and captain of John McGraw's New York Giants.

title: I.R.S. DEALT SETBACK IN TAX CASE
description: An appeals court has ruled that the Internal Revenue Service can be required to return property seized from a company that is seeking financial reorganization under the bankruptcy laws.

title: LITTLE IMPACT SEEN FROM LIBYAN BAN
description: The decision by the United States to boycott Libyan oil is expected to have virtually no effect on prices or supplies but might cause Libya a painful loss of revenue if it cannot sell the oil elsewhere, Government and private analysts said today.

title: Japan Vows Trade Steps
description: United States and Japanese Government delegations concluded trade discussions here today, with the Japanese side vowing to take additional steps in May to open Japanese markets to foreign goods.

title: THE TAX THAT BINDS
description: To the Editor:

title: FARMERS BACK TOBACCO PLAN THEY WOULD FINANCE
description: At Congressional hearings packed with hundreds of tobacco farmers, a consensus has emerged for making sweeping changes in the Federal tobacco program that would eliminate subsidies paid through general taxes.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Combustion Research and Technology postponed its offering of 2 million common shares.

title: The U.N. Today; March 11, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Commitee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The City; City to File Appeal On Fire Dept. Test
description: Fire Commissioner Charles J. Hynes said yesterday that he would appeal a court ruling that the department's physical test discriminated against women.

title: THE CITY OPERA: 'LA TRAVIATA'
description: JUNE ANDERSON, singing Violetta for the first time at the City Opera on Tuesday night, was more pretty and fragile than sensuous and fallen. But if her light, flexible voice lacked some lyric body, it compensated with a dramatic sympathy and refined understanding.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The sales for all periods exclude sales of leased department stores; the 1981 results restated to reflect a change in accoun relating to compensated absences from work which reduced fourth qr net by $111,000 or 2 cents a shr and full yr net by $441,000 or 9 cents a shr

title: Poland Releases 110 At a Detention Center
description: The military Government released all 110 internees held at a detention center in southern Poland on Tuesday, the state television said tonight.

title: PARSONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nets Win for 6th Time in Last 7 Games
description: There was an unusual post-game ambiance at the Bryne Meadowlands Arena tonight after the New Jersey Nets, winners for the sixth time in their last seven games, defeated the Phoenix Suns, 113-105.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: SEATTLE (AL) - Announced the signing of seven players: Dave Henderson and Al Chambers, outfielders; Rich Bordi and Steve Finch, pitchers; Orlando Mercado and Dave Valle, catchers, and Todd Cruz, shortstop.; COLLEGES

title: CHROMALLOY AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $24,877,000 for the qr and $29,833,000 for the yr...C-Net income after a loss of $1,097,000 from discontinued operations...D-Including a gain of $2,727,000 from discontinued operations; the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations and a change in accounting for cost of certain compensaton benefits

title: THE DANCE: BY POLA NIRENSKA
description: Pola Nirenska, a Polish-born dancer and choreographer who first came to the United States with Mary Wigman's company from Germany in 1932, presented ''An Evening of Choreography'' Tuesday night in George Washington University's Marvin Theater.

title: Morocco Plant Contract
description: A consortium led by the Mitsui Company of Japan and the Fomento del Comercio Exterior (Focoex) Company of Spain has been selected to build a $2.5 billion sulfuric-acid plant with a capacity of 140,000 tons a day near Jorf el-Asfar. Morocco plans to double annual phosphate exports to 40 million tons by 1990.

title: UTILITY CONSUMERS GAIN NEW RIGHTS
description: PEOPLE who feel they are being overcharged by a utility or those threatened with a cutoff of service have extensive new rights under a state law affecting residential consumers of electricity, gas and steam in New York.

title: HECK'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HAIG SAYS SOVIET, PRESSED ON POLAND, SELLS OFF GOLD
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the Soviet Union was so hard-pressed for foreign exchange, in part as a result of the Polish crisis, that it sold more gold in January - 60 metric tons - than in any other recorded month.

title: SCOTT'S LIQUID GOLD INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a tax loss carryforward of $126,000...C-Net loss and after a loss on discontinued operations of $623,726

title: GOLD COMMISSION TAKES AIM AT FED'S MONOPOLY
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI ULTRANATIONALIST
description: Rabbi Zvi Yehuda Kook, spiritual mentor of Israeli ultranationalists, died this morning in Jerusalem. He would have been 91 years old next month.

title: SAVINGS BANK MERGER BELIEVED NEAR
description: In an unusual procedure, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is negotiating with groups of banks in its efforts to find a merger partner for the deeply troubled New York Bank for Savings, sources in Washington said yesterday.

title: PPG Gas Discovery
description: PPG Industries has discovered a field containing more than 60 billion cubic feet of recoverable natural gas, according to data filed yesterday with the state Public Service Commission by the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company.

title: Swan Hurls Painlessly Again
description: Craig Swan continued his comeback today by pitching three more shutout innings and reporting no pain in the damaged right shoulder that threatened his career with the New York Mets.

title: ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
C.A.B. DISCLOSES INQUIRY ON AMERICAN AIRLINES
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that it was investigating complaints that American Airlines may have tried to aggravate a cash-flow crisis at Braniff Airways by tampering with the ticket-clearing process.

title: BRUNSWICK MINING & SMELTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a writeoff of $15 million of an investment in the Beaufort Sea drilling program and a gain of $7.6 million from the company's shr of gain made by Zinor Holdings Ltd on the issue of Noranda Mines Ltd treasury shrs

title: EXILE GROUP SEEKS TO OUST SANDINISTS
description: A group of Latin American exiles offered today to provide several hundred volunteers for any efforts by the Reagan Administration to disrupt the Nicaraguan Government.

title: The Region; Policeman Seized With Cocaine
description: An 11-year veteran of the Jersey City Police Department, and a member of its narcotics squad, was arrested in uniform early yesterday carrying an estimated $12,000 in cocaine, aspokesman for the Hudson County Prosecutor's office said.

title: FAIRMOUNT CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
ARRESTS SEEN SOON IN COCAINE SEIZURE
description: Federal officials said today that arrests were expected ''soon'' in what they described as the largest single seizure of cocaine in the nation's history. Customs agents intercepted 3,748 pounds of the drug Tuesday at Miami International Airport.

title: Soviet Assails U.S. Charges On Nicaragua as 'Fantastic'
description: The Soviet Union said today that United States allegations that Nicaragua had engaged in a major military buildup threatening Central America were ''dirty insinuations'' and ''fantastic charges.''

title: BONN OFFICIAL LEAVES FOR NICARAGUA TO REVIEW AID
description: West Germany's Minister for Economic Cooperation left today for a fact-finding tour of Nicaragua that will help determine whether Bonn will continue economic aid to the Sandinist Government.

title: The City; 5 Men Arrested; Bogus Bills Seized
description: Five men who were said to be part of a ring of counterfeiters trying to peddle more than $1.5 million in counterfeit bills in the New York area were arrested in the parking lot of a Brooklyn White Castle Hamburger stand last night as they attempted to sell $100,000 in counterfeit money to Secret Service Agents, according to the Secret Service.

title: Notes on People; Billy Graham to Get $200,000 Religion Prize; Prize to Graham
description: The Templeton Foundation Prize for Progress in Religion will go this year to Billy Graham, it was announced in New York yesterday. Mr. Graham, the elder statesman of modern-day evangelists, will receive the $200,000 prize, the largest in the world, in London on May 11.

title: NU-WEST INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 6
description: The shr earnings figures restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split effective Aug 1981; sales for the latest qr include results of the 146 store Skillern Drug Store chain acquired in Feb 1981

title: PEACE WITHOUT JOY
description: Occupied Sinai - As we approached the l ittle town built by Israel at this southeastern tip of the Sinai P eninsula, soldiers blocked the road. There would be an explosion in t he next hour, they explained, and we would have to wait. A military i nstallation was being blown up.

title: ATLAS VAN LINES INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss...C-After a charge of $2,900,801 for the qr and yr...D-Including a credit of $1,322,484

title: 64 Flee Jet With Engine Afire
description: A fire engulfed a jet engine moments before a Jet America DC-9 airplane was to take off for Chicago tonight. The 64 passengers aboard evacuated the plane without injury.

title: JOHN CASSATO JR.
description: John Cassato Jr., vice president for public relations of the Jim Walter Corporation of Tampa, Fla., died of cancer Monday at Memorial Hospital in Tampa.

title: U.S. REPORTEDLY SENDING MILLIONS TO FOSTER MODERATES IN NICARAGUA
description: The Reagan Administration is providing millions of dollars in covert financial aid to individuals and private organizations in Nicaragua in hopes of bolstering moderate elements there, according to senior Administration officials.

title: BankAmerica Post
description: Daniel W. Costello has been named executive vice president in charge of the real estate division at the BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's largest bank holding company, the bank disclosed yesterday. Mr. Costello, 52 years old, was recruited from the American Express Company, where he was senior vice president in charge of real estate and general services. At BankAmerica, he will manage a $2 billion global real estate portfolio. Mr. Costello succeeds Raleigh DeBow, a senior vice president who resigned last year,

title: Tentative Meeting Is Set On General Motors Pact
description: The United Automobile Workers has tentatively agreed to meet Friday with the General Motors Corporation, but the union says no new negotiations can begin unless its General Motors council gives ''solid backing'' to emergency contract talks.

title: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS TO HAVE A NEW CHIEF
description: At Reichhold Chemicals Inc., a leading specialty chemicals producer based in White Plains, C. Robert Pow@ell, 54, will come aboard on April 13 as chairman and chief executive officer. He will succeed Henry H. Reichhold, 80, who will retire after dominating the company since he founded it 54 years ago.

title: HOME BEAT
description: MANY artists and craftsmen are turning their hand to household objects. In the case of Suzanne Bruner, an abstract painter represented by the Kornblee Gallery, her shower curtains grew out of her experimentation with a vinyl material she was thinking of using for windows at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Nicaragua Denounces U.S. Planes' Intrusion
description: Nicaragua today protested American flights over its territory as a flagrant violation of international law.

title: AUTO WORKERS CAN'T DO MANAGEMENT'S JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK GROUP CHARGES RACISM IN HIRING HALL
description: James Haughton, director of Fight Back, a group that seeks construction jobs for black workers, yesterday blamed racism and sexism in the union hiring halls for lack of progress in getting blacks employment in the building industry.

title: Index; International
description: Mitterrand doing battle with bureucrats A2 Broader job expected for Buckley A3 Spanish court-martial brings lies on King's role in coup attempt A3 Soviet sentences man who sued K.G.B. A4 Mercenaries go on trial in South Africa in Seychelles hijacking A6 Two nationalisms compete for power in Bangladesh A7 Foreign press is making its power felt in Salvador A18 U.S. policy on Salvador is criticized in Europe A19 Government/Politics Governor Brown announces candidacy for U.S. Senate seat A28 Nassau County and U.S. reach accord on police hiring B2 Fink threatens to block new funds for Westway B3 Gains cited in New York metro- politan region's economy B4 Washington Talk Briefing B12 Decision File B12 Chilean's widow carries on his cause B12 The White House: The Battle for Reagan's Mind B12 General The Everglades Commandos, exiles in search of a war A18 Around the Nation A20 The night the planets were aligned with Baltimore lunacy A20 Minnesota border cities seek to stem business exodus A20 3,748 pounds of cocaine seized at Miami airport A22 Chemist calls Stouffer's Inn blaze ''toxic'' B2 Mobil to transfer Scarsdale, N.Y., office to Pennsylvania B6 Coast therapy group believes wishful thinking comes true B11 Home Section Home Top-drawer spring cleaning: Experts the decorators call on C1

title: 139 IN CONGRESS URGE NUCLEAR ARMS FREEZE BY U.S. AND MOSCOW
description: Seventeen senators and 122 members of the House of Representatives joined today in sponsoring a resolution calling for a freeze in the levels of Soviet and American atomic arsenals.

title: The City; Defects Found In 40 Ambulances
description: Serious defects in 40 ambulances recently purchased by New York have caused recurring repair problems and pose questions about passenger safety, City Council President Carol Bellamy charged yesterday.

title: JUDGE FACING CHARGES IN COIN-FLIPPING CASE
WOOLWORTH NET DECLINES 46.8%
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company reported yesterday that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter plunged 46.8 percent, the biggest drop reported so far by the nation's retailers for the most recent earnings period. Revenues edged up five-tenths of 1 percent.

title: News of Music; CARNAGIE HALL NAMES ROSEN ARTISTIC DIRECTOR
description: CARNEGIE HALL has completed the restructuring of its management with the appointment of Seymour Rosen as artistic director, effective July 1. Mr. Rosen joins Edward H. Michaelsen, the recently appointed managing director and chief executive officer, to replace Stewart J. Warkow, who has resigned as executive director. Mr. Michaelsen formally assumes his duties on Nov. 1.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results reflect a 3-for-1 stock split effective in June

title: ELDERLY BENEFIT DRIVE PLANNED
description: The American Association of Retired Persons said today that it was mounting a major campaign to convince the Reagan Administration and Congress that budget-balancing efforts ''must not rob older Americans'' of Government benefits.

title: PLANT PROBLEMS CAUSED BY AIR POLLUTION
description: PITY the poor insects, blamed for plant problems even when they are innocent. Take the case of the plant whose leaves develop a white, stippled appearance.

title: EQUITABLE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOLD COMMISSION TAKES AIM AT FED'S MONOPOLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Sleepers
description: Sleeping Beauty awoke young and beautiful after 100 years; Rip Van Winkle, white-haired and rheumatic, after 20; Woody Allen, unmistakably Woody Allen after his 200, wrapped in aluminum foil. All of them had been hibernating.

title: HINES, EDWARD, LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Space Shuttle's Flight Dedicated to Afghans
description: President Reagan today dedicated the next flight of the American space shuttle to anti-Soviet insurgents in Afghanistan and promised to keep a spotlight on Kremlin intervention in that country.

title: APPLIED DATA RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
London Exchange Rescinds Measure To Halt Tin Losses
description: The world of tin is showing signs of exhaustion with the commodity's wild fluctuations in price since last July. Tin prices continued to fall today despite yesterday's announcement by an emergency meeting of the International Tin Council that member nations would contribute $180 million to help support the commodity's price.

title: EVANS-ARISTOCRAT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid in Jan 1982

title: Ditching the Conrail Commuter
description: Conrail, the railroad commuters love to hate, is turning its commuter service over to Federal and local authorities. But there's a hitch: the public agencies aren't prepared to run the commuter lines. Money and leadership from Washington are needed to save badly deteriorated service from further decay.

title: HOUSE UNITE BALKS OVER FURTHER CUTS IN SOCIAL PROGRAM
description: The Democratic-controlled House Appropriations Committee, defying President Reagan, rejected further cuts in spending for social programs today.

title: SALVADOR'S TOLL? SO?
description: Seventeen years ago, I witnessed what at the time was considered an obsolete monstrosity: the landing of United States Marines in the Dominican Republic. In retrospect, the situation bore quite a few similarities with contemporary El Salvador: a civil war; on the one side, the army, and on the other, the rebels (a mixed bag, militarily led by Castroites), atrocities, and exaggerations by both sides. There was no proof of foreign instigation, though Washington hinted darkly about the danger of ''another Cuba.''

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 11, 1982
description: International No plans to send G.I.'s to El Salvador have been prepared, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General David C. Jones, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee. He testified that ''We do not have plans to go into El Salvador with military forces,'' but he refused to speculate on Washington's next move if present efforts by the Salvadoran Government to eliminate the guerrilla threat were unsuccessful. (Page A1, Column 6.) Covert aid to Nicaraguans is being provided by the Reagan Administration, according to senior Administration officials. They said that millions of dollars were being sent to individuals and private organizations in hopes of bolstering moderate Nicaraguan groups. The officials said that the effort, begun late last year, was being managed by the C. I. A. (A1:4-5.)

title: Iran Moves to Sell Wealth of the Shah
description: Iran's Council of Guardians cleared the way today for the Teheran Government to dispose of the late Shah's wealth, the Teheran radio reported. It said the council approved a bill enacted by Parliament that allows the Government to auction off the Shah's Persian carpets, antiques and paintings.

title: MAGIC CIRCLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BROWN, OPENING RACE FOR SENATE, CALLS FOR A 'NEW ECONOMIC VISION'
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., who told Californians in 1974 that they should prepare for an ''era of limits,'' declared his candidacy for the United States Senate today by promising to work for economic growth and revitalization of the nation.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Disney Channel Names Alan Wagner President
description: Alan Wagner has been named president of the Disney Channel, an operation of Westinghouse Group W Statellite Communications and Walt Disney Productions. Dan Ruth, a spokesman for Westinghouse, said that beginning March 21 Mr. Wagner would oversee a $100 million budget for original programming.

title: Continued Oil Saving Urged
description: Oil-consuming nations risk another oil shock in the late 1980's if they allow the current decline in oil prices to lull them into complacency, the director of the International Energy Agency warned today.

title: New Hampshire Towns Urge a Weapons Freeze
description: New Hampshire residents, agreeing with their Vermont neighbors, have used the annual town meeting to urge Washington and Moscow to put a hold on nuclear arms.

title: Edward Garrett, 64, Chairman Of Instrument Systems Corp.
description: Edward J. Garrett, chairman and president of the Instrument Systems Corporation of Jericho, L.I., died yesterday at New York University Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Queens and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Dow Severs Asahi Link
description: The Dow Chemical Company and Japan's Asahi Chemical Industry Company are ending a 30-year joint venture to allow both companies to pursue their respective operations in Japan, Dow announced.

title: PORT AUTHORITY CITES ECONOMIC GAINS
description: A cautiously optimistic annual report on the economic health of the metropolitan region was issued yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Notes on People; What It Costs After the Presidency; After the Presidency
description: Providing for former Presidents can be expensive, but some former Presidents, it seems, are more expensive than others. That was the word from Raymond A. Fontaine, an assistant administrator of the General Services Administration, who reported to a House subcommittee on Government expenditutes to provide offices, staffs and travel costs for the nation's three former Presidents.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including investment gains of $2,181,000 for the qr and $22,881,000 for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,309,000 for the qr and $4,731,000 for the yr and an investment gain of $271,000 for the qr and $9,907,000 for the yr

title: News Analysis
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, in an almost insouciant move, has made a bold bid to snatch victory for the Administration's public lands policy from the jaws of what appeared to be approaching political defeat.

title: ISLANDERS RALLY FOR A TIE
description: The Islanders and Minnesota North Stars played a 4-4 tie tonight that enabled both teams to extend unbeaten streaks, nine games for New York and 10 for the Stars.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Deferring That Career
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I'd like to offer another view on childbearing versus career in the over-30 female (''Women Reconsider Childbearing Over 30,'' Feb. 25).

title: HEARING FRANCE'S VIEW
description: At President Reagan's request, President Francois Mitterrand has advanced his planned trip to Washington to tomorrow. White House talks are expected to focus on relations with the Soviet Union and Central America.

title: BRASCAN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $9.2 million for the qr and yr C-Including a tax credit of $8.7 million for the qr and yr

title: FOREIGN PRESS IS MAKING POWER FELT IN SALVADOR
description: From a village bandstand in the small seaside town of La Libertad, Jose Napoleon Duarte, President of El Salvador's ruling junta, exhorts the crowd to vote in the elections scheduled for March 28. He tells them that the future of El Salvador will be decided by them, not by the American press. Afterward, he holds a news conference in English.

title: A WAGE FREEZE WOULD MAKE MATTERS WORSE
description: To the Editor:

title: NICKLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $274,000 for the qr and yr...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $270,000 for the qr and yr

title: CHEMIST WHO SURVIVED THE BLAZE AT STOUFFER'S INN TERMS IT 'TOXIC'
description: A chemist who survived the Stouffer's Inn fire testified today in Westchester County Court that the blaze was ''toxic, of a solvent nature, in the category of benzine.''

title: DRANETZ ENGINEERING LABORATORIES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
N.A.B. Unit Approves Appeal of Code Ruling
description: Still stunned from a Federal judge's decision last week that one of its broadcast codes that it perceives as being for the public good violated antitrust laws, the executive committee of the National Association of Broadcasters decided yesterday to appeal the decision and also to suspend the enforcement of all of the codes until the litigation was completed ''or until further notice.'' Final action will be up to its full board.

title: ABKCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $165,695

title: Allright Accepts Bid
description: Allright Auto Parks Inc. of Houston, a major parking lot owner, said it had agreed in principle to be acquired by Deanlake Investments Ltd., a group of Hong Kong investors, for $101.6 million.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $6,802,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary net gain of $1,222,481 on the sale of oil and gas properties

title: Libby to Sell Canning Business
description: Libby, McNeill & Libby Inc., a unit of Nestle Enterprises Inc., and the S.S. Pierce Company of Dundee, N.Y., announced that they had signed a definitive agreement for Pierce's purchase of Libby's canned vegetable operations in the United States.

title: LABOR DEPT. ASKS $1.8 BILLION JOBS PLAN
description: A new job training program primarily for disadvantaged young people, designed to replace the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, was proposed today by the Reagan Administration.

title: General Motors Institute To Be a Private College
description: The General Motors Corporation will withdraw a large part of its financial backing for the 63-year-old General Motors Institute over the next three years and the school will become a private college beginning this summer, the automobile maker announced today.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Cubs' New Tradition
description: OUTSIDE the little stucco clubhouse, the familiar red

title: Decision File; Rabbit Redux
description: The Volkswagen Rabbit and its relatives are being pursued by yet another Federal agency. The National Highway Traffic Administration recently announced that it was investigating electrical problems on 750,000 Volkswagens and Audis made from 1975 to 1980.

title: A Price-Horne Concert To Be Given March 28
description: The soprano Leontyne Price and the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne will present a joint concert at the Metropolitan Opera House on March 28 at 5 P.M. The program will include arias and duets from ''Cosi,'' ''Le Nozze di Figaro,'' ''Rinaldo,'' ''Aida'' and ''Norma.''

title: Air Force Man Indicted
description: Martin Thomas Bradley, an Air Force enlisted man, was indicted Tuesday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of planting a bomb in his wife's suitcase before she flew from Washington to a Texas air base, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. The bomb did not explode.

title: 76ers 134, Warriors 114
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Maurice Cheeks scored 18 points and had 10 assists to lead Philadelphia to its fourth consecutive victory and 14th in the last 17 games. The 76ers, leading 86-75 late in the third quarter, went on a 15-2 spurt and took its biggest lead, 101-77, on Mike Bantom's jump shot with 55 seconds left in the period.

title: INVESTMENT BANKS' NEW DAY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission simply calls it Rule 415, a blandly written change in the Federal regulations governing underwriting procedures. Investment bankers call it dynamite.

title: AIDES BATTLE TO CHANGE REAGAN'S MIND ON BUDGET
description: In the second engagement of The Battle for Reagan's Mind, the President's men have adopted a more cautious strategy for manuvering him into compromising on his 1983 budget.

title: SALVADOR STIRRING CONCERN IN EUROPE
description: American policy in El Salvador is becoming an important element in the continuing tensions between Washington and the governments of Western Europe, along with Poland, intermediaterange nuclear missiles and high American interest rates.

title: Marathon Merger Prospects; Marathon Merger Vote
description: A leader of dissident Marathon Oil Company stockholders conceded today that the group probably had insufficient votes to block the $6.2 billion merger between Marathon and the United States Steel Corporation.

title: Federal Official Found Dead
description: William H. Smith Jr., 46 years old, a regional director of the Federal Department of Energy, was found dead today in a car near a highway service road, officials said. An autopsy was planned.

title: ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Bulls 101, Bucks 98
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Ricky Sobers scored 13 of his 17 points in the fourth quarter, and Artis Gilmore scored 23 points and David Greenwood 20 to lead Chicago. Sobers scored 9 of the Bulls' first 11 points as Chicago took an 81-75 lead. Milwaukee lost its fourth consecutive game, its worst losing streak in three seasons.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Financial Corp. said it had acquired 6.3 percent, or 544,064 shares, of Hart Schaffner & Marx common stock for $10.2 million for investment purposes.

title: VON BULOW TRIAL GOING TO THE JURY
description: As a reservation-only crowd faded away after the final arguments in the courtroom here today, the jurors in the trial of Claus von Bulow for the attempted murder of his wife took home with them two ringing and totally different summations of the 24 days of testimony.

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Esquire Begins Drive To Broaden Its Appeal
description: To ''broaden our appeal'' to fragrance and fashion advertisers, Esquire magazine will run a magazine within a magazine called The Esquire Collection in September and March at 5 percent to 35 percent below the ad rates in the rest of the book.

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 11, 1982; The Economy
description: Retail sales increased 1.6 percent in February, the biggest increase since last June, Government figures indicated. The gain was hailed by most analysts as encouraging news for the economy, although officials noted that for the most part it merely recouped January losses attributed to bad weather. (Page D1.)

title: A NEW XEROX SYSTEM PRINTS GAPHICS DATA IN COMPUTER
description: The Xerox Corporation, which is intensifying efforts to push into the related printing and publishing business, yesterday announced a system to print graphics material as well as text stored in computers, bypassing typesetting machines, printing presses and other conventional printing equipment.

title: RETAIL SALES ROSE 1.6% LAST MONTH
description: Retail sales jumped 1.6 percent in February, the biggest gain since the 2.2 percent surge last June, the month before the recession began, the Government reported today.

title: EDNA C. ROCKSTROH
description: Edna C. Rockstroh, a public health nurse for 47 years in Europe and this country, died on Feb. 27 at her home in Santa Cruz, Calif.

title: WESTPHAL EXPECTS TO BECOME A KNICK
description: Paul Westphal, the free-agent guard who has been in a crossfire involving the Knicks and Seattle SuperSonics, said last night that he expected to become a Knick today. Westphal signed a Knick offer sheet Feb. 23, and the SuperSonics, under the right of first refusal, have until 5 P.M. today to match it or lose Westphal to New York.

title: Books of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE ROCK POOL. By Cyril Connolly. In- troduction by Peter Quennell. 135 pages. Percea. Paperback, $5.95. THE UNQUIET GRAVE. A Word Cycle by Palinurus. (Cyril Connolly.) 142 pages. Percea. Paperback, $5.95.

title: NASSAU AND U.S. REACH ACCORD ON POLICE HIRING
description: Officials of Nassau County and the Justice Department reached agreement today on a hiring program designed to resolve a five-year-old legal battle in which the county was charged with discrimination in the hiring of police officers.

title: DANCE: BULL TROUPE IMPROVISES
description: DO Richard Bull's dancers know what they look like in their improvisations? They have two quite different looks, and one is more attractive than the other.

title: Steinbrenner Plans To Control Temper
description: George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, today assembled his team for what he called his ''first and only'' pep talk of the exhibition season.

title: CONSUMER ADVICE
description: Here are some tips worth keeping in mind if you have decided to use a housekeeping service or specialty cleaner:

title: U.S. BANS IMPORTS OF OIL FROM LIBYA
description: The Reagan Administration, charging that Libya is still supporting terrorist and subversive activities, imposed an embargo on Libyan oil imports today and curtailed exports of high technology to Libya.

title: THEATER: SPIDERWOMAN PUTS ON 'THREE SISTERS'
description: SPIDERWOMAN Theater is a radical feminist troupe that draws its name not from comic books but from a Hopi goddess of creation. The company was founded by Muriel Miguel, a Cuna-Rappahanock Indian, and in the past it has dealt with folkloric material as well as such subjects as women and violence. For its latest piece, at the Theater for the New City, Spiderwoman assails a classical source, ''The Three Sisters.'' The result is as aimless as its title, ''The Three Sisters: From Here to There.'' The destination is nowhere.

title: Kings 3, Oilers 2
description: Greg Terrion of Los Angeles scored what proved to be the winning goal with 1:53 remaining in the second period.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including increases of $627,000 or 8 cents a shr for the qr and 1,522,000 or 20 cents a shr for the yr from a change in accounting for foreign currency translations... C-Including unrealized foreign currency translation gains of $887,000 or 16 cents a shr for the qr and $1,262,000 or 23 cents a shr for the yr

title: AIDES MINIMIZE REAGAN'S REMARK
description: The Reagan Administration and the Federal Reserve today sought to play down the President's apparent breach of confidence Tuesday when he said that Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, had told him that interest rates would drop by three to four percentage points by summer.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: THE simple act of dining by candlelight can be made even simpler with the help of a few accessories. For example, a candle sharpener ($1.25) to shave down the base of a candle will help it sit better in its holder.

title: Celtics 121, Pacers 100
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Larry Bird, who had missed five games with a broken cheekbone, returned and scored 21 points, and Cedric Maxwell added 20 to lead Boston to its ninth consecutive victory.

title: The Region; Jersey Seeks Loan For Jobless Aid
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The New Jersey Department of Labor asked the Federal Government for a loan of $35 million so the state could continue payment of extended unemployment compensation benefits to over 30,000 jobless residents.

title: MERCENARIES' HIJACKING TRIAL STARTS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A band of 43 white mercenaries who were involved last November in a bungled coup in the Seychelles, an island republic in the Indian Ocean, crowded together in a specially constructed dock here today and pleaded not guilty to four charges of hijacking.

title: BELUSHI'S DEATH ATTRIBUTED TO HEROIN AND COCAINE
description: John Belushi died because of an overdose of heroin and cocaine administered intravenously, the Los Angeles County Coroner's office announced today.

title: AT IONA, THEY COUNT (24-8) BLESSINGS
description: The Iona College basketball team starts three freshmen and two sophomores, and its first two players off the bench are freshmen. Gary Springer and Steve Burtt are the sophomores, the stabilizing influences at the ages of 20 (Springer) and 19 (Burtt).

title: LIGHT THOUGHTS FROM THE BAUHAUS PERIOD
description: THE mystique of the work created in the period of the Bauhaus - the influential and innovative German architectural school of the 1920's - is an enduring part of modern design history.

title: Notes on People; Mormon Leader, on the Mend, Attends Dedication; Mormon Celebration
description: On the advice of his doctors he didn't make a speech, but as 19,000 people can attest, Spencer W. Kimball, the 86-ye r-old president of the Mormon Church, was up and around on Tuesday.

title: NEW CHINA-TAIWAN DISPUTE: SOFTBALL
description: The controversy over the status of Taiwan has spilled over into the game of softball, with angry complaints in the Chinese press today over plans for the women's world softball championships, scheduled for July in Taipei.

title: COAST GROUP'S NOVEL THEORY: WISHING CAN MAKE IT SO
description: The young woman sitting in a workshop with 23 people passed around the latest Mercedes-Benz catalogue, pointed at a 300SD Turbo-diesel model in chocolate brown, priced at $38,000, and said loudly, ''That's the one I want to manifest right now.''

title: Going Out Guide
description: DELAYED OPENING

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Re-Insurance Co. has appointed S. Lennart Barkinge and Jon W. Niggeman senior vice presidents.

title: 3 Held in Plot to Ship Helicopters to Mideast
description: Three men have been charged with planning to transport helicopters from the United States to the Middle East in violation of Federal neutrality laws, officials say. Private individuals are prohibited from exporting military arms or munitions.

title: British Aerospace Missile Agreement
description: The United Technologies Corporation has agreed to produce the Rapier antiaircraft missile in the United States for sale to the United States Army, British Aerospace Ltd., the missile's designer and prime manufacturer, announced here.

title: 'Hers' on Careers
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The ''Hers'' column (Feb. 11) by Molly Haskell disturbs me very much. In it Miss Haskell purports to bemoan Hollywood's ''mistyeyed'' view of the father-child relationship as portrayed in such films as ''Ordinary People'' and ''Kramer vs. Kramer.''

title: Sports People; Ax Falls on Lemons
description: Coach Abe Lemons, whose quick wit brought him as much fame at Texas as his ability to mold basketball teams, was dismissed yesterday after six seasons in which he had compiled a 110-63 record. The school said a search for a successor would begin immediately.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joseph Giovannini is an architecture critic living in Los Angeles.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our Danish teak furniture, which is now about 20 years old, has darkened with age. What can we do to freshen it up and bring back its original youthful appearance? -L.E., New York.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Colombia Seizes Suspect In Killing of American

title: BENDIX PUTS RCA STAKE AT 7.4%
description: The Bendix Corporation said today that it had acquired about 5.5 million shares of stock in the RCA Corporation, or about 7.4 percent of the shares outstanding, and that it had ''no intention'' of buying any additional RCA stock.

title: THE NIGHT THE PLANETS WERE ALIGNED WITH BALTIMORE LUNACY
description: It was an agglomeration of the absurd with a dash of arcane astronomical fright. With delirious deliberation - in fact, with four years of planning for the astronomical ''happening'' - several hundred young Baltimorians succumbed Tuesday night to an epidemic of temporary lunacy at an all-night party in a Charles Street bookstore and bar.

title: Dorothy Eden, 69, the Author Of 18 Gothic-Historic Novels
description: Dorothy Eden, author of 18 novels in the historical, suspense and Gothic genres, died last Thursday in her home in London, according to word received here by her agent, Dorothy Olding, and her publisher, William Morrow. She was 69 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs; Tolentine Gains Final With Power Memorial
description: Tolentine turned back a determined St. Francis Prep team, 53-41, and Power Memorial beat LaSalle, 62-55, in double overtime in the semifinals of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball tournament at Fordham University last night.

title: CENTURA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Buddy Amendola, the assistant at Yale whose defensive teams have had the best records in the Ivy League for the last decade, was named head football coach at Central Connecticut State in New Britain. . ...
