Joe Lavender, the cornerback who had been a free agent, rejoined the Washington Redskins by signing a series of three one-year contracts. ... Ken Singleton, the Baltimore outfielder, won the annual Roberto Clemente Award. The award, presented by major league baseball, goes to the player best exemplifying Clemente, who was killed on a mercy flight to aid flood victims in Nicaragua.

title: SCAASI'S 'PERKY, SNAPPY' CLOTHES
description: ''IT'S not the time for fashion revolutions,'' Arnold Scaasi said before his spring and summer showing of custom-made clothes yesterday. In fact, if clothes get too revolutionary, they look strange, he says.

title: WOOLWORTH, F W, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Walter G. O'Connor Is Dead; Founder of Box Office Union
description: Walter G. O'Connor, a founder of the Treasurers and Ticket Sellers Union in 1939 and its president for 40 years, died in Doctor's Hospital last Saturday after a short illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sports People; Red Wings Pick Dea
description: One day after Bruce Norris had put them up for sale, the Detroit Red Wings changed coaches for the 15th time in the last 14 years. Wayne Maxner, 38, who succeeded Ted Lindsay a year and a half ago, was dismissed in favor of his assistant, Billy Dea. Detroit, at 18-39-12, has the second-poorest record in the National Hockey League.

title: DRAMA: JOE PINTAURO'S 'SNOE ORCHID'
description: ''SNOW Orchid'' may sound like a cryptic title for a play about a warring Italian-American family in Brooklyn, but it proves not nearly cryptic enough. The explanation is announced in Act II, just after the father's prized collection of potted orchids has been thrown into a snow-covered garbage can. ''Orchid plants are tough,'' we're reassured, ''and have been known to live over a hundred years.'' As the orchids will survive, so will the battered Lazzara family of Greenpoint.

title: Accounts
description: * WNEW (Channel 5) to Berenter Greenhouse Elgort Inc.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PROTECTING AND FIXING CANE FURNITURE
description: OWNERS of cane furniture often find it needs repair. Although professional caners in New York disagree on how long cane should last, they agree on what is considered harmful: dry air, using a chair as a stepladder and carrying it by the seat instead of the frame.

title: The Region; Increase Approved For L.I. Utility
description: ALBANY (AP) - The state's Public Service Commission approved a request by the Jamaica Water Supply Company to increase its revenues by $4.5 million, or about 18 percent.

title: Mobile Cuts Credit Line
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had sharply reduced a credit agreement it established last year with a group of banks, to $1 billion from $6 billion.

title: BRADLEY ADVISES WILLIAMS OUSTER IN FLOOR SPEECH
description: Senator Bill Bradley told the Senate today that it should expel his fellow New Jersey Democrat, Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $28,251 for the qr and $1,363,260 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $509,679 for the qr and $1,937,094 for the yr

title: Reagan Security Plan Assailed
description: Critics of President Reagan's proposal to broaden the Government's power to classify documents as secret charged today that the plan amounted to giving Federal officials a ''blank check'' to hide mistakes and manage the news.

title: THEATER: REVIVAL OF SHAW'S 'DOCTOR'S DILEMMA'
description: NEW HAVEN IN his preface to ''The Doctor's Dilemma,'' George Bernard Shaw issues a bitter diatribe against the ''infamous character'' of the medical profession, excoriating doctors for their lack of honor and conscience - as well as for their high fees. The play, revived at the Long Wharf Theater in a production directed by Kenneth Frankel, extends the criticism, dissecting medical pretenders with a satiric scalpel.

title: Sports News Briefs; East Germans Win Title In Figure Skating Pairs
description: Sabine Baess and Tassilo Thierbach of East Germany won the pairs title in the world figure skating championships tonight, the first time the event has been taken by East Germans.

title: Sposrts News Briefs; Raider Attorney Sees New Los Angeles Team
description: Joseph Alioto, attorney for the Oakland Raiders, said today that a professional football expansion team might end up in Los Angeles, with the Raiders staying in Oakland.

title: NEW YORK ASSEMBLY PASSES TRANSIT ARBITRATION MEASURE
description: The Assembly approved a bill today that provides for binding arbitration in the New York City Transit Authority contract negotiations.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
description: B-Net income; results were translated from Philippines pesos at the rates of 8.1 and 8.2 pesos per $1 for the latest qr and yr, respectively, and 7.5808 and 7.6 pesos per $1 for the yr-ago qr and yr, respectively

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After gains from discontinued operations of $140,000 for the qr and $366,000 for the 9 mos; currency translations increased earnings in the latest third qr by $227,000 and in the yr-ago period unrealized currency translation adjust- ments reduced earnings by $520,000; in the latest 9 mos currenc translations reduced earnings by $477,000 and in the yr-ago per currency translation adjustments reduced earnings by $923,000; the yr-ago qr and 9 mos shr earnings adjusted for a 5 percent common stock divd paid Jan 1982

title: Sports News Briefs; Exhibitions Planned To Keep Holmes Sharp
description: Because the television networks were not interested in a Larry Holmes-Jimmy Young match, Holmes will instead prepare for his June 11 heavyweight title defense against Gerry Cooney with a series of exhibitions, Don King said yesterday.

title: A Top Shearson Officer Has New Responsibility
description: Shearson/American Express Inc. has given Peter A. Cohen - Shearson's 35-year-old second-ranking officer with the title of vice chairman and chief operating officer - the job of supervising all of the company's units. Mr. Cohen's move follows that of Sanford I. Weill, chairman and chief executive officer of Shearson, who on Jan.1 took over the responsibility for financial and capital planning at the parent corporation, the American Express Company.

title: KOCH PLANS WORK CAMP FOR MINOR CITY OFFENSES
description: Mayor Koch, who has talked for more than a year about wanting the state to build prison work camps, said yesterday that New York City would set up such a camp on Rikers Island for criminal defendants sentenced to fewer than 15 days.

title: LA SCALA HAS PREMIERE AND SOME TRADITIONS FALL
description: La Scala, the temple of bel canto, was host last night, in its 393d season, to electronic amplification of voices, the New Swingle Singers, acrobats, a superstar of Italian popular song, electric guitars, an onstage accordion and the usual cast of sopranos, tenors and choristers.

title: CLAIBORNE, LIZ, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WARNER IS OUT OF BIDDING TO BUY THE DAILY NEWS
description: Warner Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had withdrawn as a potential purchaser of The Daily News. Martin Payson, general counsel for the New York-based entertainment company, said Warner could not deal effectively with the paper's unions as long as there are other possible buyers who might not require contract givebacks as extensive as Warner believes are needed. He said that Warner could conclude a deal only if the unions understood that it was ''the purchaser of last resort.''

title: AUTOMATED MARKETING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes income from discontinued operations of $92,000 or 11 cents a shr...C-Net loss after a loss of $3,287,000 from discontinued operations

title: MAN WHO SUED K.G.B. IS JAILED
description: A 36-year-old auto mechanic who sued the K.G.B. paid for his temerity today when a Moscow court sentenced him to a year in jail for parasitism and forbade him to live in Moscow for five years after he is released.

title: The Region; G.O.P. Convention For New York City
description: ALBANY (AP) - The State Republican Party will hold its nominating convention in New York City in June, it was announced by George Clark, the state chairman.

title: U.S. Steel Layoffs At Ohio Plant
description: The United States Steel Corporation will lay off about 600 hourly workers from its Lorain-Cuyahoga Works next week, a company spokesman said.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
THE PLIGHT OF WORLD AIRWAYS
description: It was the pugnacious chairman of World Airways, Edward J. Daly, who unleashed the transcontinental air fare wars in 1979. Today it appears that Mr. Daly is scrambling to avoid becoming the first fatality of the deepening ticket discounts.

title: SNAG IN CABLE TV TALKS MAY STOP PLAN IN 4 BOROUGHS
description: New York City's cable-television negotiations have hit a snag that could delay and perhaps endanger efforts to bring cable television to the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN faced with the job of fastening shelves or cabinets to a solid masonry wall, or when it becomes necessary to attach some type of bracket, sign or other piece of hardware to such a wall, the do-ityourselfer can use any of a number of different types of anchoring devices or special fasteners. In most cases the choice will depend on the size or weight of the load to be supported, but it may also depend on the type of masonry and its condition (hard or soft, solid or crumbling, etc.) Broadly speaking, the most common methods used in the home for fastening to walls made of brick, poured concrete, cement block and other forms of masonry fall into one of two categories: (1) Specially hardened nails or threaded studs driven directly into the masonry with a heavy hammer or with a special tool; (2) expansion-type anchors inserted into a hole bored in the masonry. A screw or lag bolt is then inserted in the anchor to fasten the shelf bracket or other hardware in place. The hardened masonry nails, which can be driven directly into the masonry with a hammer, are mainly used for fastening wood strips or 2 by 4's to a wall prior to putting up paneling or insulation (or to nail 2 by 4's to a concrete floor when framing out an unfinished basement). A small sledge or extra-heavy hammer is required for best results. These nails are quite brittle and will break or snap off (instead of bending) if not hit squarely with each blow, so safety goggles must be worn. Masonry nails are generally used where only a moderate amount of stress will be encountered, and where a heavy load is not involved. Even then, they will hold properly only if the masonry is solid, and they tend to shatter bricks unless driven into the mortar joints - and even then they may cause the bricks to loosen. When there are many masonry nails to be hammered in, a special tool can be used to make the job easier. Often called stud drivers, these tools are similar to the gunpowder-actuated tools that professional contractors use for driving masonry fasteners into concrete and steel. (A controlled explosive charge drives the fastener into the surface, much as a bullet is expelled from a gun's nozzle). For do-it-yourselfers there is a less expensive (and safer) hammerin type of stud driver with a snug-fitting hardened steel anvil that slides in through the center. It projects out at one end so that a special nail (or threaded stud) can be inserted in the other end with its head against the anvil. The projecting point of the nail or stud is then pressed against the wood or material being fastened in place while the anvil is struck several hard blows with a heavy hammer. The tool concentrates all the power of the blow against the head of the fastener, driving the hardened nail through the wood and into the masonry. The sleeve in which the nail fits keeps it from bending or breaking and makes it much easier to drive the nail straight in. For supporting large shelves and for hanging cabinets and other heavy loads on a masonry wall, one of the various expansion-type masonry anchors, similar to the styles illustrated above, are generally recommended instead of using masonry nails. These provide a stronger grip and are less likely to pull loose under heavy stress, and all work on basically the same principle: The anchor itself consists of a hollow sheath or sleeve that is inserted into a hole drilled in the masonry beforehand. A screw or lag bolt (a type of heavy-duty screw) is inserted into the center of this anchor, then tightened. This causes the anchor to split or expand so that it locks itself firmly in place inside the masonry as it presses against the sides of the hole. As a result, tremendous pressure is required to pull it out, and it is even harder to apply enough stress to shear it off. To drill the necessary hole in the masonry - the size hole required is specified in the manufacturer's literature - an ordinary electric drill can be used with a carbide-tipped bit that is made for use in masonry. These bits come in all popular sizes, and are best used with a slow-speed three-eighth-inch or half-inch drill, or with a variablespeed quarter-inch drill (the typical quarter-inch drill is too fast for use with carbide bits, unless it has variable speed control). When drilling in masonry with a carbide bit, steady and constant pressure must be applied on the drill handle. Allowing it to slip inside the hole will cause the bit to dull rapidly. Holes can also be drilled by hand, using a hammer and a special type of cold chisel called a star drill, so named because it has a star-shaped point that consists of two cutting edges that cross each other at right angles, as illustrated. This is hammered into the masonry while rotating it slightly (about one-fourth of a turn) after each blow, until the hole is as deep as required. The three most common types of expansion anchors that are designed for use in solid masonry are those made of plastic, impregnated fiber or some type of metal (metal anchors are usually made of a lead alloy, so they are often referred to as lead shields, rather then as anchors). Plastic anchors (much the same as the plastic anchors sold for use in hollow walls, described in last week's column) accept regular wood screws of the proper size. Self-tapping screws, which have threads all the way to the head, will grip even better when attaching metal brackets or other thin materials. Fiber anchors, which also accept conventional wood screws, will also hold better if self-tapping screws are used in most applications. Both of these anchors are fine for most medium-weight loads where regular wood screws are adequate to support the load. However, for heavier loads, metal shields or lead anchors are generally preferable. These are split shields that are designed so they can expand inside the hole when a large, heavy-duty lag bolt is inserted and tightened (a lag bolt is a large threaded screw with a square or hex-head instead of a slotted head, so it can be tightened with a wrench instead of a screwdriver). In addition to this type of lead shield, there are also a number of other types of metal and hard plastic anchors that are split into two sections and come with regular threaded bolts so that no lag screw is required. These work in the same manner as the ones just described - the anchor is inserted into a hole in the masonry, then the bolt is tightened. The anchor splits or expands inside its hole as the bolt penetrates (or as a nut on the outside is tightened), locking it into place inside its hole.

title: Finn Ends Moscow Visit
description: President Mauno Koivisto of Finland left Moscow for Leningrad today after a two-day visit that included meetings with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. It said Mr. Koivisto planned to stay in Leningrad until Thursday night, when he is to return to Helsinki.

title: Antibusing Bill to Reach Vote On House Floor, O'Neill Says
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today there was ''no question'' that antibusing legislation would be voted on by the House.

title: GENERAL EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $4.8 million...C-Net loss after a loss of $100,000 from discontinued operations; the rev figure for the latest yr includes a gain of $23.1 million on the sale of a division

title: SAFETY TIPS FOR CHILDREN
description: In their self-defense courses, instructors with the Safety and Fitness Exchange offer several tips for children. These are some of them:

title: BONN BANKING CHIEF IN U.S. AS DIPLOMAT
description: Karl Otto Pohl, the president of West Germany's central bank, the Deutsche Bundesbank, is in the United States in an unusual role - as a diplomat seeking to reduce some of the strain in relations between the Governments of the two countries. He explained at a breakfast interview yesterday that for many years he had had excellent relations with America's financial leaders, so he hoped that his visit could achieve its purpose.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ST. PATRICK'S SALE
description: Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Wash- ington Avenue, Brooklyn, 622-4433.

title: BIRD POPULATIONS RISE AFTER DDT BAN
description: Bird populations previously threatened with extinction by DDT, including the bald eagle, have made a comeback since the insecticide was banned by the Government 10 years ago, the Interior Department reported today.

title: The Editorial Notebook Let the Students Choose
description: Talk of tuition tax credits has subsided, but interest lingers in the idea of competition for public schools. Why not give students more choice over which public school to attend?

title: JERSEY'S DISTRICTING
description: In rejecting New Jersey's new Congressional district map and ordering a new one drawn, a three-judge Federal panel relied upon dubious data to support its decision of unconstitutionality.

title: MARATHON MERGER ENDORSED
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, one of the major institutional investors holding a large block of stock in the Marathon Oil Company, plans to vote its shares in favor of a merger with the United States Steel Corporation, David J. Sherwood, president of Prudential, said yesterday.

title: WESTON, GEORGE, LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a $6,187,000 gain on issue of shr capital of a subsidiary and a $2,510,000 gain from sale of investment and a $7,436,000 tax credit...C-After a $2,541,000 gain on sale of investments and $10,548,000 tax credit; the company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: WARMING ON MICROWAVE PORK COOKING
description: Microwave ovens should not be used to cook some meat because they sometimes fail to kill larvae of trichina-infected pork, according to an expert of the Centers for Disease Control.

title: Florida Lets Banks Fight
description: Florida's House of Representatives today defeated a bill that would have made it illegal for an out-of-state banking company to own more than 25 percent of a Florida bank's stock.

title: KEAN ASKS RISE IN CONSUMER TAXES AND FARES
description: Governor Kean announced today that he wanted to extend the state sales tax to gasoline and cigarettes, raise masstransit fares 25 percent and increase tuition at state-run colleges 10 percent.

title: HERS
description: IN New Jersey an estranged husband goes home one night with a gun and shoots and kills his wife and two children. In ''Shoot the Moon'' a divorced husband (played by Albert Finney) comes home and with his car as a weapon, demolishes his ex-wife's newly built tennis court, risking the lives of sundry children as he does so.

title: People
description: * Marc Fredericks, Charles A. Buck and William P. Croasdale have been elected senior vice presidents at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc.

title: IN SPAIN'S COUP TRIAL, LIES ABOUT KING
description: The two star defendants in the court-martial arising from the military coup that failed last year have taken the stand, and at least one of them is lying about the involvement of the King, to whom both declare their loyalty.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: TED TURNER, the pride of Atlanta and the talk of the cable industry, has an advertising card up his sleeve that should double the amount of talk.

title: The Nicaraguan Picture
description: The debate will continue about exactly why Nicaragua is building airfields, multiplying training camps and buying Soviet-made tanks. But that the buildup is going on need no longer be a matter of argument. President Reagan was wise to overrule skittish intelligence officials and release aerial photographs so that everyone can finally examine the tangible evidence for American charges against the leftist revolutionaries in Managua.

title: MOBIL SHIFTING ITS SCARSDALE OFFICE TO PENNSYLVANIA, BLAMING TAXES
description: Blaming high New York taxes, the Mobil Oil Corporation has decided to move a 380-employee office from Scarsdale to Pennsylvania. ''The question is why are we consolidating in Pennsylvania instead of New York,'' John Flint, a Mobil spokesman, said yesterday. ''And the answer is because there's a tax problem in New York.''

title: TOP-DRAWER SPRING CLEANING: EXPERTS THE DECORATORS CALL ON
description: NEVER mind the nip in the air, spring is almost here, and it's time to plan the annual spring cleaning rites: washing walls and windows, waxing floors, buffing furniture and shampooing rugs. To take the drudgery out of these tasks, the less ambitious may take advantage of housekeeping services that provide elbow grease for a price and specialists who clean everything from heirloom chairs to chimney flues. And New York has an extraordinary assemblage of such specialists.

title: BATHE-IN KITCHENS: A TUB WITH A VIEW
description: WITHIN reach of my stove and refrigerator, without a room of its own, stands my bathtub. Not one to stir the pot while taking a bath, I was slow to discover the charms of bathe-in kitchens, a common feature of tenements built before 1929. Initially I thought the old four-footed fixture an obstacle, a vulgar antique, but now I see it in a modern mode: my Hell's Kitchen apartment, no tub-in-kitchen flat, is ''open bath'' living space.

title: SENATE UNCOVERS WASTE IN S.B.A.'s BONDING AID
description: Senate investigators said today that a Small Business Administration program, intended to help small-business and minority contractors, had lost millions of dollars because of lax managemment and fraud.

title: FINK THREATENS TO BLOCK NEW FUNDS FOR WESTWAY
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink threatened today to stop new state appropriations for the Westway project until he was assured that the state would not have to cover cost overruns or make up any shortfalls stemming from cuts in Federal assistance.

title: WITNESSES CLASH OVER RULE ON BUYING OF TOXIC WASTE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, now considering whether to reimpose a ban on burying barrels of toxic liquids in hazardous waste landfills, heard vehement arguments on both sides of the issue today.

title: TAPE IN MONTEFIORE BEATING ORDERED GIVEN TO GRAND JURY
description: A state appellate court ruled unanimously yesterday that a Bronx grand jury could listen to one of two tapes made by a surgeon at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center to determine if the tape contained evidence implicating the physician in the attempted murder of his aide.

title: Net at G.& W.  Declines 14.1%
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that its earnings fell 14.1 percent in the second quarter of the fiscal year 1982, to $60.5 million, or 79 cents a share, from $70.5 million, or 91 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year. Sales declined two-tenths of 1 percent, to $1.369 billion, from $1.373 billion.

title: Boy, 11, Accidentally Hanged On Playground Sliding Board
description: An 11-year-old boy was accidentally hanged on a playground slide in Queens while friends watched yesterday afternoon, the police said. The boy, Calhoun Leshawn, was hanged when a knapsack under his jacket caught on a rail at the top of the slide and the straps of the bag caught his neck as he started down the slide, a police spokesman said.

title: College Basketball Tournaments Kentucky Eliminated in Upset
description: Rick Campbell scored 19 points to pace Middle Tennessee to a 50-44 upset of Kentucky in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Mideast Regional tournament tonight.

title: F.D.A. ASKS WYETH TO RECALL INFANT FOOD SHORT ON VITAMIN
description: The Food and Drug Administration asked Wyeth Laboratories today to begin an immediate, high-priority recall of a defective infant formula.

title: Canada's M-1 Advances
description: Canada's narrowly defined money supply, M-1, rose $526 million to $23.42 billion in the week ended March 3, the Bank of Canada said today.

title: TIMES OF LONDON IS SAVED, BUT EDITOR MAY DEPART
description: The shutdown of The Times, Britain's most prestigious newspaper, has been averted, but its editor, Harold Evans, apparently faces an uphill struggle to save his job.

title: Albert King Awaits Rematch With Bird
description: It was early December, more than a month after Albert King began earning a living as a rookie for the New Jersey Nets. It was not an easy time.

title: SENATOR'S ABRUPT FALL CLOSES LONG CAREER OF STEADY GAINS
description: Tenacity always seemed to be the watchword for Harrison A. Williams Jr. In 23 years in the United States Senate, he championed the causes of organized labor and migrant workers, fought for a range of social welfare laws, campaigned tirelessly for himself and numerous Democratic colleagues and nurtured his reputation as an influential, tough and hard-working legislator who could get things done.

title: BUSINESSES AGAIN CURB '82 OUTLAYS
description: Despite the Administration's investment tax incentives, American business is scaling back its 1982 spending plans in real terms by 1 percent from last year's level, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Sex Shop Ban May Continue
description: The City Council has voted to extend for six more months its suspension of permits to operate such sexrelated businesses as pornographic movie houses, massage parlors and sex-oriented bookstores.

title: FOOTE, GULDEN COMPETE TO BE BACKUP CATCHER
description: The Yankees have not forgotten how ill-prepared they were last season when Rick Cerone broke his thumb and spent five weeks on the disabled list. Now, with Cerone healthy but eligible to become a free agent after the season, one of the team's significant decisions this spring will be to find a backup catcher.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; RODEO IN HARLEM
description: One-hundred-fifty black cowboys and cowgirls from across the country - all professional rodeo competitors - will demonstrate riding and roping skills today at 11 A.M. and 8 P.M., tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the 369th Infantry Regiment Armory, Fifth Avenue and 143d Street in Harlem. The participants in this first ''Bill Pickett Memorial African American Cowboy Circuit'' will ride bucking broncos bareback, wrestle steer, ride bulls and wild horses, and race in and around barrels. Also on the program will be a pageant on the history of black cowboys dating back to the Old West. Some of the proceeds are to be used to start an ''Urban-Western'' program for black youths and adults to teach horsemanship. Tickets are $6 to $15. Information: 293-5882. LATIN FILMS AT N.Y.U.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Thrift Unit Merger Planned on Coast
description: Financial Federation Inc., a Los Angeles-based holding company with assets of more than $2.4 billion, announced yesterday that it had decided to merge its 11 separate savings and loan associations into one unit to be named United Savings and Loan Association. The action is subject to Federal and state regulatory agency approval.

title: 13 FREE HOURS OF JOHN CAGE
description: JOHN CAGE is still very much with us, but already he has become an icon on the landscape of our cultural life. As the unchallenged father figure of American experimental music, Mr. Cage wields an influence that extends far beyond sound alone to embrace the graphic arts, poetry, philosophy, religion and even mycology, the branch of botany that deals with fungi, in this case mushrooms, on which the composer is a foremost authority. Indeed, the entire American avantgarde would be unthinkable without Mr. Cage's music, writings and genially patriarchal personality.

title: AFTER APRIL 25
description: The reported preoccupation in certain news media circles in both Israel and the United States with the prospects of ''Egypt's return to the Arab world'' after April 25 is indeed very odd.

title: BANK AMERICA PROBLEM LOANS SURGE
description: The BankAmerica Corporation's problem loans surged to $1.6 billion in 1981 from $577 million at the end of 1980, the bank holding company said yesterday in its fourth-quarter analytical report.

title: U.S. TO OPPOSE MINERAL CARTEL AT SEA-LAW PARLEY
description: The United States will call, at the Law of the Sea conference, for the scrapping of a proposed global cartel designed to curb exploitation of the oceans' mineral wealth.

title: Easter in the Village
description: St. Joseph's Church in Greenwich Village will celebrate Easter a month early on Sunday evening at 7:30 with a concert of rarely heard choral music performed by Cappella Nova.

title: THE CRUDE SOLUTION
description: Here's a fairly simple way to cut next year's deficit in half, thereby slashing interest rates and starting a rapid return to noninflationary prosperity, without raising taxes or touching defense spending or imposing a freeze on increases in human services.

title: Tax Plan Rejected By General Tire
description: The General Tire and Rubber Companpy has rejected the plan of Mayor Roy L. Ray of Akron to keep the city's last large-scale tire plant open. The closing will eliminate more than 1,600 jobs and end tire production in a city that was once known as the nation's ''rubber capital.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM WILLIAMS STATEMENT IN THE SENATE
description: Following are excerpts from a resignation statement Harrison A. Williams Jr. made in the Senate today: In this chamber, the chairman and the vice chairman of the Select Committee on Ethics and some others urged you to expel me ''out of respect for the Senate.'' If I had believed for a moment that my resignation would prevent this distinguished body from becoming involved in the vile history of Abscam, I would have resigned long ago and spared all of us this pain.

title: MCCORMICK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After a charge of $2,250,000 for the effect of the devaluation of the Mexicanpeso

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change for foreign currencytranslations in accordance with F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: FILM: '69 SELLERS AT THALIA
description: IN the wildly erratic career of Peter Sellers, every triumph was matched by a correspondingly grand mistake. Of these, ''Hoffman,'' which was made in 1969 and opens today at the Thalia, is a humdinger. ''Hoffman'' is a strained, talky two-character drama about a man who forces a reluctant young woman to spend a week as his prisoner. Why? His motive at first seems to be sexual - Mr. Sellers does a lot of leering at this stage - but it proves to be sentimental, and honorable, too. Every night, when the much-anticipated ravishing is scheduled to begin, Mr. Sellers's Hoffman takes a sleeping pill and conveniently passes out until dawn.

title: RUTGERS RALLY BEATS IONA IN N.I.T., 55-51
description: The first 6 minutes 11 seconds of the second half determined the outcome of tonight's first-round game between Rutgers and Iona in the National Invitation Tournament. In that stretch, Rutgers outscored Iona, 10-0, gave up a field goal and then outscored Iona, 9-0.

title: RYAN INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The shr earnings reflect 4-for-3 stock splits in June 1980 and Feb 1981; results for the latest periods include operations of James S. Kemper Co since its acquisition on Apr 1

title: CETA Jobs Restriction Challenged in Lawsuit
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit today against a law that withholds Federal education and training funds to anyone advocating violent overthrow of the Government.

title: GIRL SCOUT TROP LEADERS: MEN WELCOME TO APPLY
description: By day, Judge Gerald Levy dispenses justice as an adminstrative law judge for the New York State Department of Labor. By night, he is a co-leader of three Girl Scout troops on the West Side.

title: MARATHON HOLDERS VOTE MERGER WITH U.S. STEEL
description: Stockholders of the Marathon Oil Company today approved a $6 billion merger of the nation's 17th-largest oil company with the United States Steel Corporation.

title: REGAN TO DROP OUT OF G.O.P. RACE FOR NEW YORK GOVERNOR, AIDES SAY
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, who has been the leading candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York, has decided to drop out of the gubernatorial race and seek re-election as Comptroller, three of his top aides said yesterday.

title: KELLY CALLED KEY FOR ST. JOHN'S
description: For most of the last two decades, one St. John's basketball player has been designated as part liaison to the team and part strategic informant to the coach. From Carmine Calzonetti to Frank Alagia, and with all the other point guards before and since, Lou Carnesecca, the short coach, has always searched for that one player with whom he can see eye-to-eye.

title: Prices Rise In O.E.C.D.
description: Average inflation in the 24 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in January, the O.E.C.D. said today.

title: QUIET REIGNS AT THE POLISH EMBASSY
description: Outside the Polish Embassy, the two entrances to the oval driveway are padlocked and the wrought-iron front gate is sealed. Inside, Lucjan Mieczkowski, the press counselor, strolls into the mirrored second-floor dining room, and says, ''There's not much business in the dining room these days.''

title: K MART DROPS 12.3% DESPITE SALES GAIN
description: The K Mart Corporation reported yesterday that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter fell 12.3 percent while sales advanced 17.5 percent.

title: HOW STOCKS OF YESTERDAY DRAW COLLECTORS TODAY
description: Anyone with some money to drop into the stock market who finds Exxon or I.B.M. too tame can go for some shares of the Lake Torpedo Boat Company or the Waimanalo Sugar Company. There are also buys in the Baldy Sour Mining Company and the Brown Wire Gun Company. For those who favor the bond market, securities are up for grabs in the Schuylkill Bridge and the Territory of Montana.

title: READING CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After nonrecurring expenses of $15,842,000 for reorganizationdiscontinued operations and $2,366,000 from the company's shr of the reduction in equity of its Imperial Clevite affiliate...C-The company emerged from Chapter11 bankruptcy proceedings on Jan 1, 1981 and no comparable yr-ago figures were available

title: Fund Assets Rise $1.6 Billion
description: The assets of 174 money market funds rose $1.6 billion in the week ended Wednesday to a total of $187.96 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Prospective Buyer Sued
description: A prospective buyer of the Colorado Rockies hockey team, Robert Hutchings, and two of his companies have been sued for $2 million because, according to the plaintiffs, bad checks were written for the purchase of a resort at Lake of the Ozarks, Mo. Hutchings is the president and chairman of Eagle Pacific Holding Inc., one of the companies named in the suit and the one that would be the principal owner of the Rockies if the proposed sale of the team by Peter Gilbert, a Buffalo businessman, is completed.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Monday incorrectly reported United States oil imports from Arab countries. The United States receives about one-tenth of the oil it consumes from Arab countries.

title: THE CITY;
description: Jewelry, rugs and art objects valued at $400,000 were stolen in an overnight burglary at a jewelry store in the Grand Hyatt Hotel at Pershing Square, the police said yesterday.

title: JAMAICA WATER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,265,000 from the retirement of certain debt obligations

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
CORRECTIONS
description: Articles in Business Day Wednesday and Thursday incorrectly re ported the statements of William Agee, chairman and chief executive of the Bendix Corporation, regarding his relationship with Mary E. Cunning ham. Mr. Agee has consistently stated that there was no romantic relationship at the time Miss Cunningham was employed by Bendix.

title: 'CONSCIENCE' OF CONSERVATIVES GOES ON THE ATTACK
description: ''If they don't like it,'' Senator Barry Goldwater was saying, ''to hell with them.'' This is the senior Senator from Arizona talking, the man who has served as the ''conscience'' of the conservative movement for a generation. But these days, his ire is aimed at his fellow conservatives, or at least that faction that is trying to strip the courts of jurisdiction over such social issues as abortion, busing and school prayer.

title: Study on Caffeine Finds No Link to Deformities
description: By The Associated Press A new large-scale study of caffeine use among pregnant women has failed to find any link between caffeine use and birth defects, researchers said yesterday.

title: Dr. Hyman Grinstein; 40 Years at Yeshiva U.
description: Dr. Hyman B. Grinstein, a former director of the Hebrew Institute for Men at Yeshiva University, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHINA SEIZES VIETNAMESE BOAT NEAR DISPUTED ISLAND GROUP
description: China has seized a Vietnamese boat near the disputed Paracel Islands in the South China Sea after an incident in which Vietnamese gunboats fired on three Chinese boats and set them on fire.

title: POVERTY'S VOGUISH STIGMA
description: Homeless men and women, young and sometimes violent street criminals, unwed teenaged mothers, long-term welfare recipients - all represent serious social problems. What, besides poverty, do they all have in common?

title: Priest Falsely Accused Has Suit Dismissed
description: A follow-up: Although he was brought to trial after being falsely charged with robbery, a Roman Catholic priest can't sue the state of Delaware or a magistrate who committed him to a state hospital for psychiatric examination.

title: ADOBE OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: House Panel Puts Off Vote on Salvador Aid
description: A House committee today postponed until after El Salvador's elections a resolution to block further United States aid to the Salvadoran junta.

title: BRITAIN WILL BUY NEW U.S. MISSILES
description: The British Government announced today that it had decided to buy from the United States a costly and advanced new missile system for its nuclear submarine fleet so Britain would have an independent nuclear deterrent into the next century.

title: CONCERT: RADU LUPU, PIANIST, PLAYS 4 SCHUBERT IMPROMPTUS
description: born pianist, is an invariably interesting artist, even when he is playing in a rather absent-minded way, as he sometimes was in his recital last night at Alice Tully Hall. Rumor had it that he was unhappy with the piano he had selected (a tuner came on at intermission and worked over the upper octaves) and he could not have been overjoyed with the program book, which mistakenly printed along with his biography the picture of a rival pianist. Nevertheless, Mr. Lupu found the courage to go on and managed to give a fascinating performance.

title: MEXICAN URGES U.S. TO PURSUE CUBA DIALOGUE
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico said Wednesday night that better relations between the United States and Cuba would ease tensions throughout the Caribbean Basin and facilitate solutions to the crises in El Salvador and Nicaragua.

title: Paterno on Priorities
description: Addressing an audience of 1,000 at the Allegheny Club in Pittsburgh, the Penn State football coach, Joe Paterno, said that he did not begrudge Jackie Sherrill the $1.7 million, six-year contract that Sherrill has received from Texas A & M. But he added a caveat. ''There's nothing wrong with making money,'' Paterno said.

title: JURY IN VON BULOW TRIAL RETIRES AFTER ITS FIRST DAY OF DELIBERATIONS
description: The jury received the case against Claus von Bulow at noon today and, almost five hours later, went to its hotel without reaching a verdict.

title: POLICE, IN MIX-UP, BUILD UNUSABLE $258,000 OFFICE
description: The Manhattan District Attorney says it is all a misunderstanding: He is not moving his prosecutors into those little offices over in Police Headquarters, and he never said he would.

title: PUBLISHING: A UNIVERSITY PRESS BEATS THE DRUMS
description: THE American branch of Oxford University Press publishes more than 100 original titles a year, but in common with other scholarly publishers, its books rarely sell more than a few thousand copies. A recent book from Oxford, however, had a prepublication printing of 50,000 copies, and a promotion campaign on its behalf includes the kind of press kit usually associated with blockbuster novels.

title: CBS-TV SETS 2-5 A.M. NEWS REPORT
description: CBS News yesterday announced plans to begin a three-hour news and information service from 2 to 5 A.M. each weekday, which would be the longest news program on a commercial television network.

title: No Headline
description: BARNEY SEIBERT

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: Results for the latest periods reflect gains of $17.8 million or 24 cents a shrfor the qr and $11.1 million or 15 cents a shr for the 6 mos from a change in accounting by a life insurance subsidiary as to the valuation of future policy benefits

title: CARIBBEAN BILL TO BE PRESENTED
description: Officials of the Reagan Administration said today that they would present legislation early next week to put into effect trade and investment incentives for economic development in the Caribbean Basin. They said the White House remains committed to the initiative as a key part of its Caribbean strategy.

title: Studies of Space Lasers Said to Be Progressing
description: The Advanced Research Projects Agency of the Department of Defense is working on a laser warfare system to be based in space and has all the money it needs, an official said today in Congressional testimony.

title: WASHINGTON BALLET: 'SYLVIA' AND 'IN GLOW OF NIGHT'
description: Among the dance season's most attention-worthy announcements, the Washington Ballet's intention to stage a version of the 19th-century French ballet ''Sylvia'' seemed high on the list.

title: 3 DRAMAS ON JAPANESE-AMERICAN INTERNMENT DAYS
description: In 1942, Lionelle Hamanaka's father was forced to leave his comfortable life as a student in Fresno, Calif., to live in a series of tarpaper barracks in camps surrounded by barbed wire. He lived this way until nearly the end of World War II. During that time, Miss Hamanaka's brother got pneumonia, and her sister, who lived for a time with the family in a converted stable in Santa Anita, Calif., contracted tuberculosis.

title: Gift Horses; Today Only
description: The economists patiently teach that there's no such thing as a free lunch, but they keep forgetting about California. In the San Francisco area now, a free lunch is nothing; some people there think you can have a free Mercedes.

title: SHORT TALL HAPPY
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MARCH 12, 1982
description: International Support for nuclear arms control was expressed by the Reagan Administration. It said it shared the concern of 139 members of Congress who have urged a freeze on the levels of Soviet and American weapons arsenals, but asserted it could not support the proposal because it would ''freeze the United States into a position of military disadvantage and dangerous vulnerability.'' (Page A1, Column 1.) A big U.S. arms sale to Britain was announced by London and hailed by Washington. The British Government has decided to buy an advanced new nuclear submarine fleet designed to take its independent deterrent into the next century. The Trident 2 missile system, which Britain said would cost $14 billion over 18 years, will replace Polarismissile submarines. (A1:1.)

title: FOR STARGELL, GRAND START TO LAST SEASON
description: Willie Stargell, who turned 41 years of age last week, confirmed today that this was his 21st and final year in the major leagues, and said:

title: Who'll Get Gas in a Pinch?
description: What would happen if oil imports were cut off by war in the Persian Gulf? An uneasy Congress has passed a bill giving the White House emergency authority to set prices and allocate available fuel. But President Reagan, arguing that free markets can allocate more efficiently than regulators, opposes the legislation and threatens to veto it.

title: BURTON AND BROADWAY
description: The fierce pride Richard Burton takes in being a Welshman is well known, and now he's made known his intention to come back to New York to play ''the only Welshman of any interest that Shakespeare wrote about.''

title: Index; International
description: Cracow, Poland's intellectual center, is defiant but subdued A2 Zulu leader reaffirms principle of nonviolence A3 U.S. eases curb on visits by South African officers A3 Times of London is saved, but editor may go A4 Around the World A5 U.S. to oppose mineral cartel at Law of the Sea Conference A8 Qaddafi calls Reagan a terrorist A10 China seizes Vietnmese boat A10 Argentina says there are fewer people missing than reported A11 Government/Politics Administration endorses stronger smoking warnings A15 Excerpts from Williams statement in Senate B2 Seven from Congress were convicted in Abscam investigation B2 Owner of New York housing projects in accord with state B3 An exhibit dramatizes plans for new fire museum B3 Moon wants to waive trial by jury on tax charges B5 Reagan to name more blacks to federalism advisory panel D14 G.O.P. freshmen in House accuse Democrats of stalling D14 President urged to approve budget compromise efforts D14 Washington Talk Briefing A18 Working Profile: Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona A18 Life at the Polish Embassy drones on A18 Required Reading A18 General Around the Nation A12 Von Bulow trial jury completes first day of deliberations A13 ''Misunderstanding'' leads police to unneeded renovation B3 Town may abolish itself to bar guru's dominance B8 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Exploring Stuyvesant Square and environs C1 Old stocks and bonds on auction block C22 Theater: ''Forbidden Broadway'' spoofs musicals C1

title: PAINTER CONVICTED OF ARSON
description: A house painter who was apparently upset over losing some tools has been convicted of arson in a $6 million fire that left 119 people homeless. Otis J. Bloom, 39 years old, of Milbare, Calif., was found guilty Wednesday by Judge Edward Stern of Superior Court after two days of testimony in a nonjury trial.

title: BOXER DIES AFTER CRASH
description: The former South American welterweight champion, Joao Henrique of Brazil, died early today after a bus in which he was riding crashed.

title: BMT Fire Upsets Evening Service
description: A fire in an equipment room at the Prospect Avenue BMT subway station in Brooklyn disrupted service on the RR, B and N lines for an hour and a half just before last evening's rush hour.

title: News Analysis
description: President Francois Mitterrand sets out on a oneday trip to Washington Friday to try to reduce some of the obstacles to a closer French-American partnership.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SPAR AEROSPACE LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
WORKER RECALLS TANKER PASSING BEFORE THE BLAST
description: A construction worker who was suspended from the underside of the Williamsburg Bridge on the day a gasoline tanker exploded below in the East River testified yesterday that he had seen ''nothing unusual'' happening on the vessel as she passed under the bridge.

title: ART: THE DEFT HAND OF KIM MACCONNEL
description: AS to the paintings of Kim MacConnel, opinion is much divided. There are people who find them about as demanding as nougat. ''The thinking man's shower curtain,'' they say, when faced with the tall narrow brightly colored panels that form up in fours. The idiom, they think, treads a spongy middle ground somewhere between late Matisse and superior batik. The final effect, in their view, is both facile and glib.

title: American Television Fills 2 Executive Posts
description: At the nation's largest cable television company, the American Television and Communications Corporation, Trygve E. Myhren, 45, has been named chairman and chief executive officer and Joseph J. Collins, 37, will succeed him as president, effective March 31. The promotions follow the resignation as chairman and chief executive of Monroe M. Rifkin, 51, a founder of the concern in 1968, to become a partner in a cable TV business with Marvin Davis, a Denver oilman who recently purchased the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation. Their partnership will explore new opportunities in the cable industry.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I announce my intention to resign.'' - Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. (A1:6.)

title: RICHARD PRYOR ON SUNSET STRIP
description: IT'S not easy to get a fix on Richard Pryor as he performs before a wildly appreciative audience at the Hollywood Palladium in his latest solo film, ''Richard Pryor Live on the Sunset Strip.''

title: TOWN MAY ABOLISH ITSELF TO BAR SECT'S TAKEOVER
description: The people of Antelope, population 40, will vote next month on abolishing their tiny town in an effort to keep it out of the hands of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, an Indian guru who lives in a double-wide mobile home and has 280 followers.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Assigned Dave Stegman and Tom Dodd, outfielders, and Jeff Reynolds, infielder, to the Hollywood, Fla., farm team.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,328,000 for the qr and $1,537,000 for the yr, each of which includes a charge of $840,000 representing the estimated loss on the disposal of assets of discontinued operations and closedown costs...C-Net income...D-After losses from discontinued operations of $139,000 for the qr and $297,000 for the yr; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a retroactive change in accounting for certain compensated absences to comply with F.A.S.B. Statement No 43 and to reflect discontinued operations

title: Bridge: 240 Newcomers Will Join Experts in Annual Contest
description: An annual treat for the least experienced players in the New York tournament community is the Newcomer-Life Master Pairs event. Some 240 players with fewer than 20 master points will sit down tonight at 7:30 at the New York Hilton Hotel for the event. Each is to be provided with an expert partner determined by lot, but 20 life masters, or other experts, are still needed to correct an imbalance. Volunteers should telephone 796-3967.

title: New Citibank Mortgage Set
description: Citibank said it would offer a new adjustable rate mortgage designed primarily to meet the needs of first-time home and apartment buyers who want unchanging monthly payments, particularly in the first years of the loan.

title: Audrey Hayes, Eugene Brinker Wed in Plaza Hotel
description: Audrey Hayes and Eugene Brinker, both of New York, were married yesterday in the Plaza Hotel. Justice Vincent A. Lupiano of the Appelate Division, First Department of State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony.

title: Y RECITAL: LORIMER'S 2 GUITARS
description: IN a recital at the 92d Street Y Wednesday evening, Michael Lorimer, the guitarist, gave engaging and idiomatic performances on two remarkably different instruments - both of which were guitars. During the first part of each half of his program he offered music written for the Baroque guitar, which he played on a replica of a period instrument.

title: Israeli Troops in Sinai Level Illegal Settlement
description: Israeli troops leveled an illegal settlement in Sinai today after clearing it of squatters for a second time in eight days. The squatters, who were detained for questioning, are trying to block the return of the area to Egypt on April 25.

title: STAMFORD'S NEW MALL HEIGHTENS PLANNING WORRIES
description: The Stamford Town Center, the largest shopping mall in the New York metropolitan area and the centerpiece of this city's downtown urban renewal, will open tomorrow without fanfare and with an underlying note of uneasiness.

title: Restaurants; South Italian fare in the old tradition.
description: AT a time when many owners of Italian restaurants seem to feel that they can only succeed with overrefined versions of dishes from such northern regions as Piedmont, Lombardy and Tuscany, it is encouraging to see a frankly southern kitchen achieve a large and loyal following. Eating would be much less fun if, because of fashion's whim, we lost such southern Italian specialties as linguine with white clam sauce, clams Posilippo or oreganate, the bitter broccoli di rape affogato (literally ''suffocated'') with garlic and oil, shrimp fra diavolo and even veal Parmigiana, a dish whose time may have come again.

title: Broadway; A show with a yen to be the biggest in country musicals.
description: ''PLAY ME A COUNTRY SONG,'' a title that more or less describes the show, goes into rehearsal in a month, begins previews in late May and is scheduled to open on Broadway June 17. The director is Milton Moss, and the choreographer is Margo Sappington. The book is by Jay Broad, and the score is by Harry Manfredini and John Briggs. The producer - the only producer, a distinction in this time of consortiums of producers - is Frederick R. Selch. He has never been connected with Broadway before. Is he daunted? ''I've spent all my life in broadcast advertising, but I've always had a sideline in music,'' Mr. Selch says. ''I thought this music was so strong that I couldn't pass it up. I wish I did this 10 years ago.''

title: DEEP SOUTH'S ECONOMIC SURGE FOUND SLOWING
description: The economic revival of the Deep South, characterized over the last 20 years by a dramatic shift to manufacturing from farming, appears to have slowed considerably, long before many parts of the region have reaped the benefits.

title: SELLING PUSHES RATE HIGHER
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday as securities dealers tried to reduce their inventories in advance of the Federal Reserve's money supply announcement today.

title: Westphal Joins Knicks
description: For two weeks, a Knick uniform with ''44'' and ''Westphal'' sewn on it has been hanging in the team's office. Paul Westphal will finally have the chance to wear the uniform today at a noon practice and again tomorrow night when the Knicks play the Washington Bullets at Madison Square Garden.

title: B. Meredith Langstaff Dead; Lawyer and Brooklyn Leader
description: B. Meredith Langstaff, a lawyer and longtime community leader in Brooklyn, died Feb. 28 at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. Mr. Langstaff, who lived in Brooklyn Heights, was 96 years old.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain on the disposal of assets of $1.2 million which equaled 45 cents a shr for the qr and 47 cents a shr for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $140,000 or 6 cents a shr; yr-ago results have been restated

title: General Cinema
description: The General Cinema Corporation, which is involved in a bidding war with Heublein Inc., said that it had entered into a new revolving credit agreement providing a maximum line of $300 million. The new agreement, which complements an existing $160 million credit line, will extend to November 1893. The original credit line extends to January 1989, and about $65 million has already been borrowed under it, the company said.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Defends Plan to Honor Reagan
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today vigorously defended her Government's decision to ask President Reagan to address Parliament during a visit here in June.

title: MOON WAIVES RIGHT TO A JURY, BUT PROSECUTORS FIGHT MOVE
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon wants to waive his right to a jury, preferring to have a trial judge decide the tax-fraud charges against him, but the prosecutors have objected.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net loss; results for the latest 9 mos reflect the restatement of the first qr results for a change in accounting to the full cost method from the successfulefforts method

title: No Headline
description: In percent Yesterday Previous Day Year Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 16.00 18.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 14.40 15.21 14.61 3-MO.

title: WOULD JAPAN'S ECONOMIC SOLUTIONS FIT THE UNITED STATES?
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LIVING BY FICTION. By Annie Dillard. 192 pages. Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: LFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $467,000 for the qr and$1,806,000 for the 9 mos...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $215,000 and a gain of $2.4 million from the sale of real estate

title: Required Reading 'Hunger Is . . . '
description: The Rev. William T. Cunningham, director of Focus: HOPE, a Detroit project that provides meals for the elderly, testifying before the Senate Special Committee on Aging, Feb. 25, 1982:

title: City Bond Issue Planned
description: New York City officials announced plans yesterday to sell $75 million of bonds next week through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Tentative interest rates for the bonds are expected to be announced on Tuesday.

title: Hershey Prices, Weight Rise
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation announced that it would increase the weight and price of its candy bars with a resultant lower cost per ounce. It said the increases were in response to retailers' problems in dealing with different-priced candy bars.

title: Buddy Parker Ill
description: Buddy Parker, who coached in the National Football League for 14 years and directed the Detroit Lions to consecutive championships in 1952 and 1953, was stricken by a ruptured ulcer and underwent emergency surgery last weekend in Kaufman, Tex. Following the surgery, the 66-year-old Parker was unconscious for three days, which he spent on the critical list. Yesterday, his condition was upgraded a bit but still guarded.

title: Art Muscles Flexed
description: An interested visitor at the opening of ''Athlete as Artist,'' a two-man show at the Spectrum Fine Art Gallery on West 57th Street, was Chuck Sullivan, co-owner and executive vice president of the New England Patriots professional football team.

title: PAPER'S OWNER ADMITS ERROR IN USE OF RELEASE
description: The owner of The Trenton Times, Joe L. Allbritton, has told readers that the management of the paper erred in ordering a business reporter to use verbatim a press release from a local advertiser in financial trouble.

title: Marquette and Houston Advance
description: Dean Marquardt scored a career-high 21 points, and three other Marquette players scored in double figures as the Warriors posted a 67-62 opening-round victory over Evansville in the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional tonight.

title: GRAM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $165,000 for the qr and $715,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $240,000...D-Including a tax credit of $360,000

title: Energy Dept. to Handle Damage at Nuclear Plant
description: The Federal Department of Energy has agreed to take full responsibility for disposing of the entire damaged reactor core at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, Gov. Dick Thornburgh said today.

title: ARGENTINA DISCOUNTS ESTIMATES ON MISSING PEOPLE
description: Argentina's Interior Minister says that the Government is considering issuing its own study of the thousands of Argentines who disappeared during the civil unrest of the 1970's.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Break From Williams

title: MILLER, H, & SONS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
CHARLES P. IVES 2d
description: Charles P. Ives 2d, a former associate editor of The Baltimore Sun, died Wednesday at his home in Baltimore. He was 80 years old. Mr. Ives began his journalism career at The New Haven Journal Courier as a reporter in 1928, and went on to become editor of the newspaper in 1932.

title: ALTER TAX PLAN, DEMOCRATS TELL KEAN
description: Democratic legislative leaders said today that they would consider Governor Kean's proposal for applying the 5 percent sales tax to gasoline only if the Governor changed his plans to cut state aid to municipalities and reduce business taxes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has appointed Edward A. Rytter vice president-design and construction.

title: Stock Group Options Set
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange is planning to introduce trading in options based on groups of stocks in various industries.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LEGISLATIVE PLAN TO TAX VIDEO RECORDING GEAR
description: In a high-stakes battle set off by a court decision last year, makers of videotape machines and producers of movies are squaring off over a legislative proposal to tax the machines and tapes, with the proceeds going to the entertainment industry.

title: RANGERS CLINCH SPOT IN PLAYOFFS
description: For the fifth consecutive season, the Rangers qualified for the Stanley Cup playoffs tonight, defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 4-1, at Joe Louis Arena.

title: EXHIBIT DRAMATIZES PLAN FOR NEW FIRE MUSEUM
description: Evoking Currier & Ives images of fire horses and bucket brigades, a display of antique equipment filled a firehouse behind Lincoln Center yesterday to dramatize plans for a $1.5 million museum of fire-service memorabilia.

title: A PIPE BREAKS CAUSING LEAK AT ATOMIC LAB
description: About 10 quarts of low-level radioactive water leaked from a burst pipe today at the Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory near Schenectady, officials said.

title: INVENTORY RATIO ROSE IN JANUARY
description: The inventory-to-sales ratio for American companies - a measure of the time needed to sell off the backlog of goods held by manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers - rose to 1.51 in January, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the highest level since the 1.52 ratio of June 1980, the end of that year's recession.

title: THE PRESIDENT AND THE ERRING REPORTER
description: To the Editor:

title: LOOK PAST INFLATION
description: Inflation, as most Americans now know, is a great distorter of seemingly fixed economic ideas and benchmarks. Interest rates, wage increases, and prices of homes all mean something different today than they did in an earlier era of price stability. Now, preoccupation with inflation is also distorting our national debate about the economic policy choices we face.

title: A PEEK AT POLISH CAMPUS LIFE: DEFIANT BUT SUBDUED
description: This ancient and genteel city, the spiritual capital of Poland and the seat of its royal dynasty, has always taken the long view. It has survived something like 25 major fires, 5 earthquakes, 13 floods and 17 sieges or invasions in its recorded history.

title: SCIENCE ACADMEY' CLEAR WARNING ON MARIJUANA
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK: NEIL DIAMOND IN JERSEY
description: LIKE a barnstorming evangelist in gladiatorial garb, Neil Diamond roared onto the stage of the Brendan Byrne Arena Monday in the first of three sold-out performances. Mr. Diamond and his eight-man band then proceeded to bring off the sort of swashbuckling extravaganza that only Elvis Presley, in his Las Vegas prime, might have attempted.

title: BUILDING OF A FORCE TO ATTACK NICARAGUA DENIED BY ARGENTINA
description: A Foreign Ministry official said today that, contrary to continuing reports, Argentina was not working with other Latin American countries to assemble a paramilitary force that they planned to infiltrate into Nicaragua for hit-and-run attacks.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 100,000 metric tons of American corn for delivery this year, the Agriculture Department said today, raising total grain purchases for this year to more than 13 million tons.

title: BLUE-COLLAR DRAMA: 'WEEKENDS LIKE OTHER PEOPLE'
description: LAURIE (Rose Gregorio) and Dan (Kenneth McMillan), the middle-aged, blue-collar couple of David Blomquist's ''Weekends Like Other People,'' might well be Edith and Archie Bunker of ''All in the Family'' or Alice and Ralph Cramden of ''The Honeymooners.'' Dan is pot-bellied, short-fused and childish. Laurie is the perky, uncomplaining homemaker who forever picks up after her husband's mess. They work in anonymous jobs and live in a Chicago flat full of cheerless, mass-produced furniture that is probably identical to that of their neighbors. Their existence is defined by piled-up bills, frozen foods and the nightly listings in TV Guide.

title: Supreme Court Justices on the Line
description: Sandra Day O'Connor, the soul of discretion throughout her confirmation hearings last fall, slipped slightly the other day when testifying in House appropriations hearings on the judicial budget. She may have tipped off the Court's vote in a pending case - a minor matter. But she and her fellow witness, Justice Lewis Powell, also suggested that Congress amend the civil rights laws in a certain way, which is reason for concern.

title: STATE DEPT. CALLS ARMS FREEZE PLAN 'DANGEROUS' TO U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it shared the concern of members of Congress who advocated a freeze in Soviet and American nuclear arsenals but that it could not support the proposal because it would ''freeze the United States into a position of military disadvantage and dangerous vulnerability.''

title: Stocks Mixed; Dow Up 0.67
description: The stock market's attempt to continue its recent rally ran out of momentum yesterday as prices ended mixed in slower trading. The main casualties were some of the technology issues, which have been hardhit recently because of lower earning estimates.

title: THE PRESIDENT AND THE ERRING REPORTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Gas Exploration Names New President
description: John F. Schwarz, 46, has been named president of the Texas Gas Exploration Company, an oil and gas exploration and production corporation based in Houston. He succeeds W.J. Wooten, 57, who took early retirement from the subsidiary of the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation to pursue personal business interests.

title: ANTIDEMOLITION ACTORS TO PLAY STREETS
description: Members of the Broadway community begin a nine-day demonstration of street theater today to save the Helen Hayes and Morosco Theaters from demolition.

title: A WOMEN'S SWING BAND
description: IT was almost as if the string section of a major symphony orchestra had been lopped off and set down on the small stage of a nightclub on Columbus Avenue. All the musicians were women, and the six violinists, four violists, three cellists, one bass player and the drummer looked almost demure in black trousers and black velvet vests over peach-color silk blouses as they tuned their instruments.

title: KENNETH KINGDON, LEADER IN RESEARCH ON ATOM, DIES AT 88
description: Dr. Kenneth H. Kingdon, retired assistant director of the General Electric Company's research laboratory and a leader in the development of atomic energy, died Tuesday at the Silver Haven Nursing Home in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 88 years old and lived in Schenectady.

title: Rutgers in Newark Schedules Joyce Day
description: A full day of James Joyce is on the agenda tomorrow on the Newark campus of Rutgers University, part of the Rutgers celebration of the Joyce centennial. Joyce scholars will speak, starting at 9:30 A.M., on a variety of topics connected with Joyce. Prof. Hugh Kenner of Johns Hopkins University will examine the influence of Joyce on a New Jersey poet in a talk titled ''Modernism in New Jersey: William Carlos Williams.''

title: 7 FROM CONGRESS GUILTY IN ABSCAM
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. was one of seven members of Congress indicted and convicted in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam investigation. He was convicted May 1, 1981, on nine counts of bribery and conspiracy and was sentenced to three years in prison and fined $50,000. He is appealing his conviction.

title: SCIENCE ACADMEY'S CLEAR WARNING ON MARIJUANA
description: To the Editor: I am concerned that your front-page article of Feb. 27 summarizing the National Academy of Sciences Report on marijuana and health, ''Study Reaffirms General Doubts Over Marijuana,'' will have an unfortunate impact on the nation's teen-agers.

title: RLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a realized investment loss of $40,961 for the qr, a realized investmentgain of $21,464 for the yr and a charge of $675,000 for the qr in connection with the need to increase reserves and reinsure certain property and liability reinsurance programs which have been terminated...C-After a realized investment loss of $1,187 for the r and a realized investment gain of $33,162 for the yr

title: STILL ASSERTS HE IS INNOCENT; Text of farewell speech, page B2.
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. resigned from the Senate today as it prepared to expel him for his conduct in the Abscam investigation.

title: ZULUS' LEADER REAFFIRMS NONVIOLENCE
description: Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, the Zulu leader who sponsored a commission that this week recommended a plan for multiracial power-sharing for the coastal province of Natal, said today that he would continue to adhere to nonviolent tactics despite the Government's swift rejection of the commission's proposals.

title: Premium Offer
description: If savings banks give away appliances to attract depositors in a tough credit market, perhaps unemployed scholars should do the same thing in a tough job market.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was as it had been 40 years ago. Well, almost. ''Alfred Lunt and I washed dishes together,'' r eminisced Vincent Sardi. ''I'd do it again but I can't get to the b ar.'' He was right. It was packed the other night as they c elebrated the 40th anniversary of the Stage Door Canteen, that WorldW ar II creation of the American Theater Wing that had celebrities p erforming for and dancing with servicemen and women and serving c offee, doughnuts and sandwiches.

title: States Turn to Courts On Redistricting Plans
description: By The Associated Press Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court yesterday refused to block a California redistricting plan. Republicans challenged the plan, saying it could give the Democrats six extra seats in the United States House of Representatives.

title: REAGAN SUPPORTS LAW TO BALANCE BUDGET
description: In an initial sign of Administration sentiment, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan expressed his support today for a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget.

title: Books: On Subways; LABYRINTHS OF IRON: A History of the World's Subways.  By Benson Bobrick.  352 pages.  Newsweek Books. $13.95.
description: HERE is a book about subways that takes a somewhat different route from others on the subject. Benson Bobrick gives us the wealth of detail that went into the building of subways in London, Paris, New York, Moscow and other cities, but he also plumbs the mystique of man and the underworld of darkness and fear.

title: No Headline
description: General Manager Maurice Filion of the Quebec Nordiques said today that he would wait for the results of a meeting in New York Friday before making any further efforts to convince Pat Hickey to report to the Nordiques.

title: Economic Scene; How to Avoid A Depression
description: THE job of avoiding a depression and setting the economy back on a course of stable growth cannot be achieved by some ''quick fix.'' It will require a balanced combination of policies commanding broad national support.

title: SCHRADER, ABE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock divd paid on Jan 29

title: Dome Completes Hudson's Bay Deal
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the Canadian oil and gas producer and pipeline operator, said it had completed its acquisition of Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas.

title: THREAT TO PUBLIC BROADCASTING SEEN
description: Entertainers, station managers and financing executives asserted today that proposed cuts by the Reagan Administration could kill public broadcasting and that greater reliance on commercialism would be dangerous and probably unworkable.

title: Cardinal Cooke to Miss St. Patrick's Day in City
description: Next week, for the first time since he became Archbishop of New York in 1968, Terence Cardinal Cooke will miss the St. Patrick's Day celebrations. He has been summoned to Rome by the Pope to take part in a meeting of a special Council of Cardinals that is studying Vatican finances.

title: Prison Guards in State Reach Contract Accord
description: A New York State mediator announced today that the state and the union representing its correction officers had ''reached agreement in principle'' on a new contract nearly a week after talks broke off.

title: Demonstration in Yugoslavia
description: The police broke up demonstrations today by several hundred youths on the campus of Pristina University on the anniversary of riots that broke out last year, the Tanyug press agency reported.

title: STATE AGENCY STARTS S.I. PAPER
description: Staten Island got a new newspaper yesterday, paid for by the State Power Authority and intended to counter what its editor called ''rotten'' reporting by The Staten Island Advance.

title: THEOBALD NEXT CITICORP CHIEF?
description: If the financial community were to vote today on who should be the next chief executive officer of Citicorp, Thomas C. Theobald, now senior executive vice president, would be a shoo-in.

title: U.S. EASES BAN ON SOUTH AFRICAN OFFICERS
description: The Reagan Administration, in order to help negotiations on obtaining South-West Africa's independence from South Africa, has quietly eased a long-standing practice of not allowing high-ranking South African military officers into this country on official business, State Department officials said today.

title: 7 HOUSING UINTS AND STATE AGREE ON ARREARS PLAN
description: The owner of seven Mitchell-Lama projects in New York City whose mortgage payments had fallen in arrears has agreed to pay the state $11 million and make capital improvements over the next 12 years, Governor Carey's office announced yesterday.

title: JAZZ: CECIL TAYLOR AND BAND AT CLUB
description: FOR more than 25 years, Cecil Taylor has been playing his energetic, aggressive, often volcanically eruptive music as piano solos or with small groups. Now, on each Sunday evening in March, Mr. Taylor is playing, ''for the first time anywhere,'' with a large group - 12 pieces - at Lush Life, Thompson and Bleecker Streets.

title: Shell Group Posts Decline
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies said today that earnings fell 19.3 percent last year because of the worldwide slowdown in economic activity and depressed demand for petroleum products.

title: Market Place; Heublein Fight With Suitor
description: IN the late 1970's, Curtiss-Wright purchased 4.5 million shares of Kennecott. The copper producer, as a result, became fearful of a possible takeover attempt by Curtiss-Wright, which produced the famous P-40 fighter plane during World War II.

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Paris Pilot's $800 Stunt
description: A French pilot was fined $800 today for flying his single-engine plane through the Arc de Triomphe last Oct. 18. The pilot, Alain Marchand, a 47-year-old flying instructor, flew his plane, with a 31-foot wingspan, through the 47-foot wide arch to draw attention to what he said was the financial plight of light aviation.

title: Plethora of Pitchers
description: The Cleveland Indians may be in a position to challenge the premise that a major league team can never have too much pitching. At their training camp in Tucson, Ariz., four newcomers with major league experience, Silvio Martinez, Lary Sorensen, Rick Sutcliffe and Ed Whitson, are competing for roles as starters with five holdovers, Len Barker, Bert Blyleven, John Denny, Dan Spillner and Rick Waits.

title: Ohio State Is Defeated By James Madison, 55-48
description: Linton Townes scored 10 points during a second-half surge that led James Madison to a 55-48 upset of Ohio State in the first round of the N.C.A.A. East Regional tonight.

title: Pop Jazz; WHERE YOU CAN LISTEN TO JAZZ IN THE AFTERNOON
description: JAZZ for those who want to get an early and swinging start on the weekend has taken a firm hold in Manhattan. There are now six places where jazz can be heard Fridays at midday or at twilight, and all but two of them have come into existence only in the last month.

title: Sports of The Times; 3 Spring Visitors
description: THE pin-striped uniforms are the same, many of the numbers are the same, but the people inside them are different. When such former Yankees as Fritz Peterson, Ralph Terry and Ron Swoboda drop back for a visit, they have every reason to feel like Rip Van Winkle, just awakened from a long sleep.

title: PIANIST WITH THE CHOPIN TOUCH AT Y
description: IT would seem a marriage made in heaven. Tomorrow night at the 92d Street Y, piano music by Chopin and Debussy - composers who epitomize delicacy of sound and refinement of texture - and Ivan Moravec, a performer who has built his career on just those qualities.

title: CORPORATE FINANCIAL STRAINS
description: At no time since World War II has the financial position of the nation's corporate sector been so weak. It is not so precarious, financial experts say, that a widespread collapse is imminent, although it is possible that Braniff, International Harvester or one or more of the other major companies already in financial straits could go under.

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
