description: B-Including tax credits of $1,238,000 for the qr and $3,145,000 for the 9 mos, a pretax loss of $3,912,000 for the qr and 9 mos on the purchase of assets of Savin Associates, a foreign currency translation loss of $1.8 million for the 9 mos relating to the hedging of inventory commitments and a gain of $3 million for the 9 mos from a depreciation schedule change...C-Including tax credits of $2,241,000 for the qr and $758,000 for the 9 mos and a foreign currency translation gain of $1.5 million for the 9 mos...D-Net income

title: ART: THE MET EXHIBITS SOME OF ITS BEST PHOTOS
description: THE exhibition that Weston J. Naef has mounted at the Metropolitan Museum of Art under the title, ''Counterparts: Form and Emotion in Photographs,'' is filled with wonderful pictures. There are more than 100 of them, drawn from the entire history of the medium, and most of them are works of unquestioned mastery. Great names - from Carleton E. Watkins and Maxime Du Camp in the 19th century to Alfred Stieglitz and Man Ray in the 20th - are amply represented, and there are examples, too, of many of the most illustrious of our living artistphotographers, both established masters like Andre Kertesz and Henri Cartier-Bresson and photographers whose work is well-known to critics and collectors but not yet firmly established in the mind of the larger art public.

title: Hamilton Retains World Title
description: Scott Hamilton of Denver made seven triple jumps in a brilliant display of free skating tonight and retained the men's world figure-skating title. Hamilton, who is 23 years old, became the first American to win the title in successive years since Tim Wood, who did it in 1969 and 1970.

title: National Advertising For Used-Car Dealers
description: The wonderful idea of using national advertising to create an aura for a local businessman, which is working so well for Century 21 and its real estate brokers, will next be applied to used-car dealers.

title: AN AMERICAN REFUSAL TO CURB JUVENILE CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: A FRANCHISE BOOM IN PICTURE FRAMING
description: Ten years ago, owners of a print or painting would no sooner think of framing it themselves than they would of building their own car. Framing was the work of artisans who alone knew the mysteries of mats and moldings.

title: BIRTH CONTROL PROPOSAL
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGOAN PLANS TO SELL BREVARD CO-OPS
description: It has become clear during the last six months that, at least for the moment, the boom period of the cooperative market in New York City is past. Studies by such leading industry figures as Henry Griffo of Sulzberger-Rolfe Inc., Barbara Corcoran of the Corcoran Group and Brewster Ives of Douglas Elliman-Gibbons & Ives have confirmed the opinion that the high cost of money has calmed the frenetic buying and selling activity that flourished at the end of the 1970's.

title: U.S. HEALTH OFFICIALS ENDORSE STRONGER CIGARETTE WARNINGS
description: The Reagan Administration today endorsed putting tougher health labels on cigarette packages to warn smokers of specific disease dangers they face.

title: 'FORBIDDEN BROADWAY' SPOOFS MUSICAL THEATER
description: ONE of the biggest little hits Off Broadway is to be found up a curving flight of stairs on the Upper West Side. It is a revue called ''Forbidden Broadway,'' in which the mores of the Broadway musical theater and, particularly, the stars of current musicals are being sliced into small pieces with scalpels wielded by five talented newcomers. In ''Forbidden Broadway,'' melodies are familiar, but the lyrics take on a new slant, as a Linda Ronstadt impersonator in a ''Pirates of Penzance'' scene cries, ''Where are my 39 speakers and 49 microphones?''; a Patti LuPone, having lost the starring role in the movie version of ''Evita'' to Barbra Streisand, sings, ''Don't cry for me, Barbra Streisand; to tell the truth, I never liked you''; an Ann Miller leaps and bounces through a jumping dance as she wails, ''My smile is constructed of stone''; a Rex Harrison mutters, ''I've grown accustomed to this show, because it's the only show I know ... I've grown accustomed to the pay,'' and a Lauren Bacall, proclaims, ''I'm one of the girls who sings like a boy.''

title: Graybar Building Has 2-Alarm Fire
description: A two-alarm fire burned through a floor of the Graybar Building in midtown Manhattan yesterday evening, injuring at least one person, fire officials said.

title: 3 a Gallon
description: Atlantic Richfield, the big oil company, has announced that it will no longer honor credit cards. Credit transactions represent just 30 percent of Arco's fuel sales, but they add nearly three cents to the price of a gallon of gas.

title: EUROPEANS WEAKEN SANCTIONS AGAINST SOVIET
description: The Common Market has decided on a sharp cut in the trade sanctions that it appeared ready to impose on the Soviet Union two weeks ago to protest the military crackdown in Poland, according to diplomats.

title: At the Movies; Maggie Smith and dreams of repertory.
description: ALTHOUGH she won Academy Awards twice (for ''The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie,'' and for ''California Suite'') and was nominated two other times (for ''Othello'' and for ''Travels With My Aunt'') and is now on view in ''Evil Under the Sun,'' Maggie Smith may be the most modest movie star alive.

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago revs have been restated to reflect a gain on the sale of assets

title: Dial-a-Coach
description: If he is not able to make the 180-mile trip to Nashville tomorrow for his team's first game in the national championship tournament, then Louisville's basketball coach, Denny Crum, will help to coach the Cardinals by telephone. The 44-year-old Crum, who has been suffering from severe kidney-stone pains, left a Louisville hospital to attend the Cardinals' last home practice.

title: Seal Hunt Protesters Buzzed by Canadians
description: Protesters against Canada's annual seal hunt were buzzed by a Government helicopter today when they reached the outskirts of a giant seal herd.

title: CSX Announces Management Shifts
description: A number of management changes were announced yesterday by the CSX Corporation, the big railroad company based in Richmond, to take effect on May 1, when Prime F. Osborn, a lawyer and longtime railroader, retires at the age of 67 as chairman and co-chief executive officer. CSX, which was formed in 1980, consists of two rail systems on the East Coast: the Family Lines Rail System and the Chessie Systems Railroads

title: AUTO UNION VOTES NEW TALKS TODAY ON PACT WITH G.M.
description: Local union leaders from General Motors plants voted overwhelmingly today to resume contract talks despite the failure of an earlier round of bargaining with the company in January.

title: POLO IS NO MINOR AT SOME COLLEGES
description: Not every athlete at Texas A & M wants to be a football hero. ''I hope they find me dead on the field and have to pry my cold, stiff fingers off the mallet,'' said Larry McClure in a drawl unmistakably Texan.

title: Final Witness
description: No sane resident of Atlanta has ever defended the mob lynching of Leo Frank in 1915. But some Atlantans have believed that Frank may have been guilty, as charged, of murdering a 14-year-old girl in the pencil factory where they both worked.

title: REAGAN IS TOLD TIME IS RUNNING OUT FOR A BUDGET COMPROMISE
description: Democratic Congressional leaders appealed to President Reagan today to compromise on his budget plan and warned that time to reach an accommodation was running out.

title: SHELL OIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Royal Dutch Petroleum's shr of the group's earnings was $2,198,000,000 or $8.20a shr for the latest yr and $2,562,000,000 or $9.56 a shr for the previous yr; Shell Transport and Trading's shr of the group's earnings was $1,316,000,000 or $4.76 a shr for the latest yr and $1,650,000,000 or $5.97 a shr for the previousyr; both Royal Dutch Petroleum and Shell Transport and Trading are listed on the New York Stock Exchange

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
St. Regis Given Boiler Clearance
description: The board of the Maine Department of Environmental Protection gave permission to the St. Regis Paper Company to install a boiler, at a cost of $100 million, that will burn a combination of wood, bark, coal and treatment-plant sludge. Such a boiler is expected to save the company 500,000 barrels of oil annually.

title: GREAT EASTERN ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Metropolitan Baedeker; EXPLORING THE HISTORIC STUYVESANT SQUARE AREA
description: IT is easy to miss Stuyvesant Square, that little oasis of quiet on both sides of Second Avenue from 15th Street to 17th Street. But its quietness is not some accident of fate in sprawling, bustling New York City. As deed restrictions placed on the first houses that sprang up in the district in the 1840's show, Stuyvesant Square was designed at the start to house ''no brewery, distillery, slaughter house, blacksmith shop, forge, furnace, soap, candle, starch, varnish, vitriol, glue, ink or turpentine factory,'' or, for that matter, any ''factory for canning, dressing or preparing shins, hides or leather or any cow or livery stable or cattle yard or any other Metropolitan Baedeker dangerous, noxious or offensive establishment.'' To walk through the square on a weekend afternoon in winter is to see it plain and sense its history. A do-it-yourself walking tour might start in Stuyvesant Square Park west, in front of the statue of Peter Stuyvesant, Governor of Nieuw Amsterdam in the mid-17th century, on whose ''bouwerie,'' or farm, the square was laid out. That statue is the only feature of the west park that is different from its eastern half. As portrayed by his sculptor, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, the one-legged Stuyvesant looks very like a dancing master, hip tilted, leaning on his stick as he gazes thoughtfully in the direction of the Friends Meeting House on the southwest corner of 16th Street.

title: A REVIVED ORIENT EXPRESS WILL ROLL EAST IN MAY
description: In 1918, the German high command surrendered amid the polished woodwork, silken window shades and pink-shrouded table lamps of an Orient Express restaurant car, No. 2419 to be exact, parked on a siding near Compiegne. In 1940, Hitler got his revenge by making France's defeated generals surrender in the same car, parked at the same spot.

title: Auctions; Painting and poster sales.
description: TWO sales of 20th-century art will be among the events in the coming week at Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries, at 76th Street. In one sale, tomorrow at 2 P.M., the stars are posters by artists of the turn-of-the-century German and Austrian Secession movements. There are 30 examples, including works by Gustav Klimt, Egon Schiele, Bruno Paul, Bernard Loffler, Alfred Roller, Rudolf Kalvach, Oskar Kokoschka and Berthold Loffler. Among the most important is Kalvach's 1908 ''Kunstschau,'' which estimated to bring as much as $12,000; Loffler's 1908 ''Kunstchau,'' a preparatory gouache for a 1908 poster (up to $8,000); Schiele's ''Secession 49'' of 1918 (up to $7,500), and Kokoschka's ''Self-Portrait, Hand on Breast'' (up to $6,000).

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After tax credits of $82,000 for the qr and $429,000 for the yr...C-Net income and after tax credits of $128,000 for the qr and $324,000 for the yr; includedin the 1981 results 8is a charge of $1,062,000 resulting from the company's recently announced decision to cease operations at its Point Pleasant W.Va., polyvinyl chloride plant; the company said that a change in foreign currency accounting resulted in a charge to the 1981 earnings of $375,000 compared with a charge of $300,000 in 1980

title: SILVERWOOD INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 27
description: B-Including a gain of $4,199,469 on the sale of two surplus dairy properties inToronto and the divestment of processing and distribution operations in BritishColumbia

title: QADDAFI SAYS U.S. WON'T DETER LIBYA
description: Calling President Ronald Reagan a ''destructive person'' and a ''terrorist,'' Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that Libya would not buckle under to America's oil boycott.

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 12, 1982; The Economy
description: Businesses are scaling back their 1982 spending plans by 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported. The results of the department's January-February survey were a disappointment to the Reagan Administration, which had hoped that capital investment, encouraged by its tax incentives, would help lift the economy out of recession. The survey also showed that businesses expected sales to rise 9.9 percent, up from 8.2 percent last year. (Page D1.)

title: Birth Defects Reported in the Use of Laetrile
description: Oral doses of Laetrile, a drug for which anticancer claims have been made, cause birth defects in animals and could harm humans, a researcher says.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bjorn Borg is back swatting tennis balls after a five-month vacation. The Swedish star is in training at Monte Carlo, where his first tournament of the season will be played early next month.

title: Foes of Papal Visit Silence Anglican Prelate
description: The Most Rev. Robert Runcie, Archbishop of Canterbury, was forced to cut short a church service in Liverpool after demonstrators protesting Pope John Paul II's scheduled visit to Liverpool in May disrupted the service.

title: MURDER CONFESSION PROVOKES UPROAR
description: On the night of Oct. 10, 1980, David Coleman said, he put his .38-caliber revolver to the head of a young taxi driver and killed him.

title: HOUSE LEADERSHIP ACCUSED OF DELAY
description: All 54 Republican freshmen in the House accused the Democratic leadership today of deliberately delaying new legislation in this session of Congress, particularly on budget matters, and warned that the legislative process was ''dangerously close to faltering.''

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Results are for 13 weeks and 26 weeks for the latest periods and 14 and 27 weeks for the yr-ago periods

title: A CHASTISED 'CORNER TO THE STARS'
description: When John Belushi died last week, it was an event that had the time-honored trappings of a death in Hollywood: Intensive coverage by the news media, testimonials from famous people about the untimely death of a talented performer and even a mystery regarding the cause of his death.

title: Pabst to Acquire Pittsburgh Unit
description: The Pabst Brewing Company announced a definitive agreement had been reached for Pabst to acquire the Pittsburgh Brewing Company.

title: IN SENATE, LAST FAREWELL
description: To a stranger it might have appeared that the senators crowding around their old colleague were there to praise him for a legislative triumph. But they had come to say farewell.

title: REAGAN TO ADD MORE BLACKS TO 'NEW FEDERALISM' PANEL
description: A group of black elected officials won a commitment from President Reagan today to add some black members to his advisory group on ''new federalism'' and to take into account their fears that the federalism plan might jeopardize civil rights and assistance for members of minority groups.

title: Russians Deny Charge On Chemical Warfare
description: Soviet scientists today rebutted charges by the Reagan Administration that the Soviet Union had introduced deadly mycotoxins into Indochina as a form of biological warfare. At the same time, Yuri N. Chernyakov, head of the Foreign Ministry's press department, said a United States accusation that the Russians had killed thousands of people in Afghanistan with chemical weapons was ''a lie from beginning to end.''

title: An Attempted Coup Is Reported in Suriname
description: The Suriname radio said today that a rebel force had seized the army barracks here in an attempted coup. But the leader of this former Dutch colony in northeast South America said he still controlled the six-vessel navy and the police.

title: TV Weekend; TOUGH COP, BROADWAY EXTRAVAGANZA
description: TOMORROW night at 8, ABC-TV introduces a new series, ''T.J. Hooker,'' with the kind of hero who would have been unthinkable for television just a couple of years ago. Police Sergeant Hooker (William Shatner), like a lot of other television characters these days, yearns for the good old days when criminals knew their place and the streets were safe for law-abiding citizens. ''I've seen the past,'' Sergeant Hooker announces, ''and it works.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Charter Co. said it had signed a definitive agreement with the Surrey Broadcasting Co. of Tucson, Ariz., for the previously announced sale of six radio stations for $32 million.

title: Georgia 73, Temple 60
description: Dominique Wilkins scored with a pair of slam dunks midway through the second half to snap a tie and lead Georgia in a first-round game. Georgia (17-11) will be the host to the winner of the Maryland-Richmond game Friday night in the second round.

title: The City; Theft of $150,000 Denied by Lawyer
description: A 52-year-old lawyer pleaded not guilty to charges that he had stolen more than $150,000 from two of his clients. The lawyer, Erich Reisch of 3611 Henry Hudson Parkway, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, has an office in Manhattan at 277 Broadway at Chambers Street.

title: The U.N. Today; March 12 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Advertising; C.&W.'s Purchase in The Works
description: THE Mickelberry Corporation, now completely out of meatpacking, is on the verge of becoming the parent company - once removed - of Cunningham & Walsh, the 25th-largest American ad agency.

title: Notes on People; City Opera Turns to Broadway Jingles; Broadway Aids Opera
description: Opera and Broadway talents work together in Beverly Sills's latest effort to boost lagging ticket sales for New York City Opera productions.

title: 2 PRIVATE DENTAL SCHOOLS SEEK STATE AID INCREASE
description: The growing inability of students to pay for the rising expenses at New York State's two private dental schools -New York University and Columbia University - has led the two institutions to seek a state takeover of more than 40 percent of their schools' budgets.

title: Parrish Begs to Differ
description: Lance Parrish, the Detroit Tiger catcher, is dedicated to working out with weights. His problem is that Manager Sparky Anderson doesn't believe in it and has removed the weight-lifting equipment in the clubhouse at spring training.

title: LABOR STUDY FINDS ECONOMY OF CITY NOW 'MORE WHITE-COLLAR THAN EVER'
description: The New York City economy has shown ''considerable strength'' in the face of the national recessions of 1980 and 1981, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said yesterday.

title: A BATTLE OVER DUMPING UPSETS L.I. SOUND AREA
description: Daniel Natchez's solution is Christopher Stapelfeldt's problem and both solution and problem involve a milesquare patch of Long Island Sound within sight of this city.

title: Qaddafi and Kreisky Hold Economic Talks
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, held more economic talks with Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria today.Austrian and Libyan trade officials, meanwhile, continued negotiations over the supplying of technical training centers to Libya.

title: FOR GREENLANDERS, LONELINESS BECOMES THE NORM
description: Every Wednesday and Friday afternoon, as the regular Scandinavian Airlines System flight leaves here for Copenhagen, many of the people at this outpost on the Arctic Circle pause a moment in whatever they are doing to watch.

title: Syracuse Sets Back St. Peter's, 84 to 75
description: Syracuse moved into the second round of the National Invitation Tournament tonight with an ease that surprised even Coach Joe Boeheim.

title: ERNST & WHINNEY SUED BY U.S. ON TAX ADVICE
description: The Justice Department charged today that Ernst & Whinney, one of the nation's ''Big Eight'' accounting firms, was advising its clients to classify business property falsely to reduce their taxes.

title: G.M., ASKING 'MORE' THAN FORD, RESUMES BARGAINING
description: Negotiations on a new contract between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation resumed today and company officials said they would demand greater concessions than the union gave last month to the Ford Motor Company.

title: Tolentine Beats Power For Third Title in Row
description: Ernie Meyers, a 6-foot-4 senior, scored a team-high 20 points and grabbed a game-high 13 rebounds to lead Tolentine (26-1) to a 68-57 victory over Power Memorial and its third consecutive Catholic High Schools Athletic Association city championships last night at Fordham. Tolentine's only loss was to La Salle in the Diocesan championships Feb. 22.

title: Borg May Lift Hughes Stake
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said that it might increase its present 18.87 percent interest in the Hughes Tool Company to about 21 percent so that it could apply that much of Hughes's earnings to its own.

title: PITTSBURGH IS ELIMINATED
description: Bob Hansen made two quick baskets - one of them for a 3-point play - with a little less than five minutes remaining tonight to rally Iowa to a 70-63 victory over Northeast Louisiana in a first-round game of the N.C.A.A. West regional tournament.

title: Culture Bus a Victim of Too Few Riders; Culture Buses Dropped For Lack of Ridership
description: New York's Culture Bus service, which carried sightseers to 54 points of interest, has gone out of business, a victim of a ridership that was too low to warrant the high cost.

title: Insurance Company Settles $3.5 Million Sex Bias Lawsuit
description: United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company, the nation's eighth largest insurance concern, has settled a 5-year-old sex discrimination suit by agreeing to pay $3.5 million to female and minority employees and job applicants.

title: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After losses of $1,530,000 for the qr and $3,030,000 for the 6 mos relating to Masonite Canada Ltd C-Net income

title: The City
description: A 30-year-old social worker was fatally injured yesterday when she was struck on the head by a wrench that had fallen from an office building under construction at 51 Broadway, near Exchange Place, in lower Manhattan.

title: The City; Officer Captures Robbery Suspect
description: An off-duty police officer chased three holdup men out of a Bronx bar and captured one of them after firing three shots from his service revolver, the police said.

title: TALKS ON SECURITY ADJOURN IN MADRID
description: After 16 months of deliberations, the Madrid Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe adjourned today for eight months with East and West at loggerheads over Poland.

title: Around the Nation; Von Bulow Jurors Ask For Maid's Testimony
description: The jurors in the trial of Claus von Bulow broke their silence late in the second day of deliberation this afternoon to ask the judge to have a key portion of the trial's testimony reread. They then decided that they wanted to have dinner and to sleep on the information before returning to debate.

title: Around the Nation; California Murderer Gets Death Sentence
description: A twice-paroled sex offender, William Bonin, was sentenced today to death for 10 torture-murders that became known as the ''freeway killings.''

title: Miss Torvill and Dean Retain Ice Dancing Title
description: Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean of Britain posted another near-perfect score tonight and retained their ice dancing title in the world figure skating championships.

title: Washington Talk
description: A Welcome Change

title: TECHNOLOGY MAGAZINES' SPURT
description: When Bernard A. Goldhirsh was a hard-working engineering science major at M.I.T., he wrestled with the problem of bad vibrations on military vessels.

title: Governor Kean's Budget Debut
description: New Jersey's new Republican Governor, Thomas Kean, committed a minor political gaffe this week by giving the press the first peek at his $6.4 billion budget proposal for fiscal 1983; state Republicans took second place and the Democrats, who run the Legislature, came third.

title: FOR BETTER LIVING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $11,000 from discontinued operations

title: DELLWOOD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $430,000

title: PANEL MAY LOOK INTO ABSCAM
description: The Senate Rules Committee will meet next week to consider an investigation of a Justice Department inquiry that led to indictments and convictions of seven members of Congress.

title: SENATE BILL SEEKS A REIN ON THE U.S. IN LATIN AMERICA
description: Calling the Reagan Administration's policy on Central America ''confused and dangerous,'' two Democratic Senators proposed legislation today to require prior Congressional approval for military action and covert intelligence operations in the region.

title: Justice Stays Dismissal Of Jersey Redistricting
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the United States Supreme Court today granted a temporary stay of last week's Federal court ruling that voided New Jersey's Congressional redistricting plan.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $139,000 for the qr and $207,000 for the yr

title: Kamau, in 3-Mile Run, Sets N.C.A.A. Record
description: Gabriel Kamau, a Kenyan attending Texas-El Paso, set a meet record of 13 minutes 7.81 seconds in the threemile run as the National Collegiate Indoor Track and Field Championships started today at the Silverdome.

title: STOPPING FRAUD AND THEFT OF CREDIT CARDS
description: Americans' increasing reliance upon credit cards has created a major problem: an estimated $1 billion fraud loss to credit-card companies and consumers.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Italy's President to Visit U.S.
description: President Sandro Pertini of Italy will visit the United States from March 24 to April 1, the White House announced today. Mr. Pertini will confer on March 25 with President Reagan, who will give a state dinner in his honor at the White House that evening.

title: JERSEY BANK TIE
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today approved the merger of the United States Savings Bank, based in Newark, into the Hudson City Savings Bank of Jersey City.

title: Washington Talk
description: In an Emergency ...

title: PRESIDENT OF CBS FILMS QUITS AS MOVIE PLANS ARE REDUCED
description: CBS has yanked the reins on its theatricalfilm group today by reducing its semi-independent CBS Theatrical Films to a division of the CBS Broadcast Group.

title: DAIRYMEN URGE LOWER MILK SUPPORTS
description: With milk price supports now costing taxpayers more than $250,000 each hour of every day in the year, even the dairy farmers agree that something must be done to check the costs of this once sacrosanct farm program.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,000 for the qr and $76,000 for the 6 mos and tax credits of $252,000 for the qr and $1,333,000 for the 6 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $57,000 for the qr and $71,000 for the 6 mos and tax credits of $1,067,000 for the qr and $1,889,000 for the 6 mos; results for the latest 6 mos include a gain on the sale of real estate equal to 35 cents a shr; results for the yr-ago qr and 6 mos include income attributable to a discontinued manufacturing facility equal to 7 cents a shr

title: 'PARASITE,' A CREATURE IN 3-D
description: The star of ''Parasite'' is a larva-like creature, covered with slime. It fastens itself to several of the actors in this movie's minuscule cast, and each time it does so, the cast gets smaller. These episodes of violence are linked by a plot involving Dr. Paul Dean, the creator of a particularly virulent parasite strain.

title: DOHNANYI NAMED HEAD OF CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
description: Christoph von Dohnanyi was named music director of the Cleveland Orchestra yesterday after a meeting of the board of trustees. Mr. Dohnanyi, currently general music director and principal conductor of the Hamburg State Opera, will begin a four-year term at Cleveland with the 1984-85 season. He will relinquish his Hamburg post at that time and move with his family to Cleveland.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A back injury that has curtailed her play for much of the last two years forced Tracy Austin to withdraw from a tennis tournament next week in Boston. ... John McEnroe turned an ankle and had to quit a tournament in Brussels. ... The Cleveland Cavaliers, now directed by Bill Musselman, their fourth coach this season, lost in his debut before a home crowd of 4,577, not all of whom saw the action clearly. About 50 spectators wore paper bags over their heads as a symbol of protest over the dismal season, a practice first made popular by fans of the New Orleans Saints. ... Vladimir Salnikov of the Soviet Union set a world record of 3 minutes 49.57 seconds for the 400-meter freestyle at a dual meet against East Germany in Moscow, according to Tass, the Soviet news agency. ... Rick Middleton, the Boston Bruins' leading scorer with 84 points, including 47 goals, will be sidelined for one to three weeks with a sprained shoulder.

title: Bears Re-Sign Scott
description: James Scott, the wide receiver who was one of a half-dozen highly paid American players on the Montreal Alouettes' roster last season, went back yesterday to his old team, the Chicago Bears. Scott, a 30-year-old free agent who played with the Bears from 1976 through 1980 and whose yardage gained places him seventh among the Bears' career receivers, signed a three-year contract.

title: THE TIMES OF LONDON REPORTS ITS EDITOR HAS QUIT
description: Reporters and editors at The Times have split into two camps over the question of the paper's leadership. Rupert Murdoch, the Australian owner of The Times, is scheduled to fly to London from New York this weekend to try to resolve the impasse created by his repeated and so far futile attempts to replace his editor, Harold Evans.

title: U.S. PLAN OFFERED FOR CLEANING UP TOXIC DUMP SITES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced its ''national contingency plan'' for dealing with abandoned hazardous waste sites today.

title: GREGORY H. DOHERTY
description: Gregory Hancock Doherty, a lawyer in New York City, died yesterday at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown, N.Y. Mr. Doherty, who was a resident of North Tarrytown, was 66 years old.

title: LEGISLATORS LANGUISH IN ALBANY'S DOLDRUMS
description: ''The Legislature should abolish January and February,'' said Assemblyman Eliot L. Engel, a Bronx Democrat, as he wandered through the marble hallways of the Legislative Office Building. ''We never get anything done anyway, so why show up?''

title: Athens Church Is Bombed
description: A time bomb exploded in the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of Athens today, causing extensive damage to icons and to much of the interior of the 19th-century structure. No one was injured. A leftist group calling itself Iconoclastic Nihilists took responsibility.

title: TWO GUILTY OF FRAUD IN LEASING
description: Two men who were the principal owners of O.P.M. Leasing Services Inc. have pleaded guilty to fraud charges involving more than $200 million that the company obtained from major banks and other lending institutions for overstated equipment leases.

title: Books of The Times Besideness of the Point; QUOTATIONS FROM OTHER LIVES. By Penelope Gilliatt. 160 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $12.95.
description: There's a certain kind of jazz singing - Sarah Vaughan is a good example - in which the melody is distorted in a way that can be fully appreciated only if you know the original version. If you are not familiar with the original, you have two choices: you can try to infer it or you can come to terms with the distortions in their own right.

title: WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Declines 8.19 To Finish at 797.37
description: Fears of a large increase in the latest money supply figures, which could signal higher interest rates, sent the stock market down sharply yesterday.

title: TRANSIT AGREEMENT, AND SUSPICION
description: On Monday the State Senate is expected to approve an Assembly bill authorizing city arbitration of a new transit labor contract for New York City, an act that would remove the threat of a transit strike. That's good news to all who remember the agony of the last strike, and it also makes possible a more constructive bargain.

title: TROUBLES FORECAST FOR CITY BUDGET, LOCAL ECONOMY
description: Signs of trouble for both New York City's overall economy and the municipal budget were cited yesterday in a city report to the United States Treasury.

title: No Headline
description: VIRGINIA TECH BEATS FORDHAM, 69-58

title: TROUBLED MCLOUTH FACES FUND CUTOFF
description: McLouth said yesterday that it had been advised by the lenders on Thursday that they would not supply the financing necessary for McLouth's continued operation after March 19, and would call in $107 million in loans.

title: ICHAN GROUP ADDS TO STAKE IN FIELD'S
description: The Icahn group, aided by a major purchase by a Swiss investor, has raised its stake in the common stock of Marshall Field & Company to 29.3 percent from 23.1 percent in the last week, an amendment to Icahn's 13-D statement disclosed yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
Sensor Watches Robots' Movement in Factories
description: A sensor for reporting the position of robots or machine tools that move around industrial plants under computer control was patented this week by the staff scientists for the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Senate Panel Studying U.S. Data About Latins
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee has begun a review of United States intelligence information about Central America in hopes of producing a public report about the level of Soviet and Cuban involvement in the region, according to committee members.

title: Two Accused as Embezzlers
description: A former boarding home operator accused of abducting elderly women from Florida to Michigan has been charged with embezzling more than $60,000 from two women, prosecutors say. Lucille Walker, 60 years old, and Arnold L. Weiner, 38, a Southfield lawyer, were arraigned Thursday. Mrs. Walker is being held in Oakland County Jail awaiting trial on charges of kidnapping three elderly women from their Miami boarding home last summer and abandoning them in Detroit. Mr. Weiner was released on $10,000 bond.

title: OTTO G. SCHAEFER
description: Otto G. Schaefer, of Scarsdale, a retired vice president and director of the Meredith Publishing Company, now Meredith Corporation, of Des Moines, died Tuesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 89 years old.

title: The City; Car Chase Ends With a Fatality
description: A 24-year-old man who fled the police when they tried to pull his car over set off a chase that ended when the car went down a 40-foot embankment and into a ditch, killing the driver and critically injurying a woman who was with him, the police said.

title: Gen. E. Walton Opie, Retired Virginia Editor
description: Maj. Gen. E. Walton Opie, retired chairman, publisher and editor of The Staunton (Va.) Leader, died yesterday at King's Daughters Hospital in Staunton after a stroke.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After equity in losses of $8.1 million for the qr and $9.4 million for the yr of discontinued operations of Chromalloy American...C-Net income and after equity in loss of $271,000 of discontinued operations of Chromalloy D-After equity in income of $591,000 of discontinued operations of Chromalloy

title: O.A.U. RENEWING ITS EFFORT TO BRING PEACE TO CHAD
description: The Organization of African Unity is again trying to enforce a peace settlement in Chad despite resistance by the Government there and strains on the organization's credibility.

title: No Headline
description: Steinbrenner's new-found patience with shoddy spring play was put to a severe test tonight when the Yankees made a dozen base-running and defensive blunders in a 3-1 loss to the Atlanta Braves, but the owner was calm and cheerful afterward. Dave Revering was the worst offender when he made a bad throw on a rundown, dropped a foul pop for an error, muffed several grounders and ran the bases carelessly.

title: DIP FIRST SINCE '76
description: For the first time in six years, the Government's Producer Price Index fell last month, providing the most dramatic evidence thus far that inflation is falling.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Some Withdraw DeLorean Suits
description: A major threat to the insolvent DeLorean Motor Company was lifted when some creditors withdrew court petitions that would have forced the company into liquidation.

title: COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
JAPAN'S G.N.P. OFF 0.9%, FIRST DECLINE SINCE 1975
description: With its exports slowing significantly, Japan's economy declined by slightly less than nine-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter that ended last December, the Government reported today.

title: THE FIRST FIREBALL
description: Most physicists agree that the universe began as an immense explosion - a hot ''big bang'' - a primordial fireball from which all the matter in the universe emerged. But where did that fireball come from?

title: POLICE COUNSELING PLANS HELP OFFICERS WHO FACE TRAUMA
description: What Patrol Officer Jaye Schroeder remembers most frequently and clearly about the damp night three years ago, when her partner was shot, was kneeling beside him and staring at the bushes where she sensed his assailant hid.

title: UNITED NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes pretax gain of $4,409,000 on disposition of certain properties

title: THEATER: LOOKING BACK FROM 'VIEWING PAVILION'
description: Gus Kaikkonen's ''The Chinese Viewing Pavilion,'' presented by the Production Company of the Actors and Directors Theater, takes place not in China but on a farm near the Delaware River. Repeatedly, characters walk to the edge of the pavilion - a bandstand set with a dining table -and, squinting, they peer off into the distance, in the direction of the theater's exit.

title: EXPANSION OF NETWORK NEWS IS CALLED 'CRUCIAL' BY FRIENDLY
description: Expanding the nightly network newscasts to an hour is essential to creating an informed public in an increasingly complex world, Fred Friendly, former CBS News president, suggested this week in the third annual ''Chet Huntley Memorial Lecture.''

title: A ROSIER PAYMENTS OUTLOOK
description: The financial outlook for most of the world has improved substantially as a result of reduced petroleum consumption, falling oil prices and a withering of the balance of payments surpluses of the oil-exporting countries, a number of economists say.

title: EXECUTIVES BID REAGAN CUT DEFICIT
description: Leading businessmen personally told President Reagan today that he may have to trim military spending, raise excise taxes and delay the income tax cut scheduled for 1983 to reduce the Federal deficit and lift the economy out of the recession that began last July.

title: State Dept. Aide Sees Limit On Support for Guatemalans
description: Assistant Secretary of State Thomas O. Enders said today that the United States was not fully committed to supporting the Guatemalan Government, although he said it was a target of Cuban-backed revolution.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 23.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Proben Leads by 1 On a 64 at Inverrary
description: Mike Carrick, who caddies for Tom Kite, put it succinctly: ''No wind, no rough, good greens, low scores.'' Kite called it a ''postcard day to play golf.'' Hale Irwin added: ''With the course in such good condition, anyone who shoots outside the 60's will be far back.''

title: CONSUMMER CREDIT USE UP
description: Consumer installment debt grew by a seasonally adjusted $443 million in January, a relatively small expansion that resulted mostly from a growth in cash loans to individuals, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title:
Patents;
Magnetic Medical Diagnosis
description: WASHINGTON AMETHOD of medical diagnosis using magnetic fields, which was patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., is safer than X-ray examination, the company says.

title: Canadian Jobless Rise
description: A record 1.12 million Canadians were unemployed in February, increasing the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate to 8.6 percent, Statistics Canada said today.

title: PATENTS
description: Stacy V.Jones Speech Recognition Apparatus Improved

title: Washington Talk
description: Change of Pace

title: IN SINGAPORE, THE OPPOSITION IS A ONE MAN OPERATION
description: Joshua Benjamin Jeyaretnam speaks softly in long sentences that often stop abruptly before he makes his point. Sometimes, just weary of the defense he wages daily as the sole opposition member in Singapore's 75-member Parliament, he sits quietly behind his cluttered desk in his law office and stares at the silver-framed picture of his wife, who died in 1980.

title: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $18,000 for the qr and $196,000 for the yr

title: CALL A HACK AND FEED A GROWING LITERARY TRADITION
description: CabArt, its editors suggest, is the only literary journal in which ''hack writing'' refers to the authors, not the quality.

title: PITTWAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE CASE FOR THE 'PRIMARY PARENT'
description: Letter: On Custody Settlements The Case for the 'Primary Parent' To the Editor: Your Feb. 19 editorial ''The Fitter Parent,'' on the decision by the New York Court of Appeals that custody modifications can be based only on the ''best interests of the child'' without the need for ''extraordinary circumstances,'' is right on target.

title: No Headline
description: HISTORIAN OFFERS NEW REPORT ON PEARL HARBOR

title: REAGAN, FACING STATE OPPOSITION, THREATENS TO CUT FEDERALISM PLAN
description: A White House official said today that the Reagan Administration would cancel its offer to pay all state Medicaid costs if the nation's governors persisted in their refusal to take over Federal food stamp and welfare costs.

title: Notes on People; Deng's Pines, or, a Tree Grows in Peking; Deng's Trees
description: Last September China's leader, Deng Xiaoping, suggested that every able-bodied Chinese plant three to five trees a year in a campaign to check soil erosion, block sandstorms, provide more timber and make the environment visually pleasant.

title: KNICKS HAIL WESTPHAL'S SKILLS
description: One day recently, while the Knicks waited to learn whether Paul Westphal would be theirs, Paul Silas was asked why anyone would think they needed another shooting guard.

title: Boston College Defeats San Francisco
description: Jay Murphy, the Boston College center, scored 15 points, and John Bagley, who overcame some early foul trouble, led the Eagles a 70-66 victory over San Francisco tonight in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest regional tournament.

title: 'Barnum' May Be Closing
description: ''Barnum,'' the musical at the St. James Theater, has posted its closing notice, although the producers say it will be taken down this weekend if business improves.

title: SALVADOR ELECTION: PLEAS AND THREATS
description: With elections a little more than two weeks away, the Government and the armed forces have stepped up efforts in the last few days to reassure the Salvadoran people - threatened by the left if they vote and the right if they do not - that the voting will be free, safe and fair.

title: HORACE GREGORY, POET, CRITIC, ESSAYIST AND BIOGRAPHER, DIES
description: Horace Gregory, poet, critic, essayist, translator and biographer, who taught at Sarah Lawrence College for 26 years, died Thursday at a nursing home in Shelburne Falls, Mass. He was 83 years old.

title: Sports of The Times; Secrets of a Fallible Umpire
description: foot-4-inch, 280-pound retired umpire, was positioned behind the plate the other night. It was in a Chinese restaurant, and the plate was steamy with shrimp in black bean sauce.

title: No Headline
description: Pistons 121, Warriors 117

title: New VW Van Model
description: Volkswagen of America said today that it was introducing a luxury version of its seven-seat Vanagon van.

title: Lawyers Revise Book On Taxes for Artists
description: Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts has just published a revised edition of its ''Fear of Filing: A Beginners' Handbook on Record Keeping and Federal Taxes for Performers, Visual Artists and Writers.''

title: 7 to Give Up Profits Made On Lilly Data
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a group of seven investors with using inside information to trade in the stocks of several companies that were potential takeover targets of Eli Lilly & Company.

title: FACING CHARGES, DISTRICT 3 CHIEF QUITS SCHOOL JOB
description: The chairman of Community School Board 3 on Manhattan's Upper West Side resigned yesterday amid charges that he had misused $1,000 in board funds for such purposes as hiring limousines, purchasing liquor and paying for a cable television installation at a private residence.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $3.4 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose $3.4 billion in the week ended March 3, reversing a large part of the $5.7 billion decline during the previous six weeks.

title: SuperSonics 112, Bucks 110
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Gus Williams's 30 points, including a 20-foot jump shot at the buzzer, paced Seattle and sent Milwaukee to its fifth consecutive loss. Mickey Johnson scored 35 points for the Bucks, his high mark in three seasons.

title: Washington Talk
description: Lobbyist's Lament

title: Notes on People; Family Affair
description: When James Tocco appears as guest soloist tomorrow in Carnegie Hall, with Seymour Lipkin conducting a benefit concert for the Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem, he'll have in the audience what he calls ''my family claque.''

title: Soviet Says U.S. Missile Sale To Britain Hurts Arms Talks
description: The official Soviet press agency said today that the scheduled sale of American submarine missiles to Britain further complicated arms talks with the United States.

title: WYETH EXPANDS RECALL OF DEFECTIVE BABY FORMULA
description: Wyeth Laboratories is recalling 1.7 million more cans and bottles of infant formula that is deficient in vitamin B6, an essential nutrient for babies, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: MAGAZINE SUSPENDS COLUMN NAMING SECRET C.I.A. AGENTS
description: A magazine in a dispute over naming of covert agents of the Central Intelligence Agency says it suspended the practice in its latest issue because of pending legislation to make those disclosures a criminal offense.

title: Robert Schur, 59, Dies; Ex-City Housing Aide
description: Robert Schur, a former New York City housing official who in recent years had been a housing consultant to public agencies and private nonprofit organizations, died of a heart attack Thursday evening at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old

title: Around the Nation; Radiation Risk Formula Opposed by Reagan
description: The Reagan Administration today opposed a system based on ''attributable risks'' for compensating victims of radiation from Government nuclear tests in Nevada between 1951 and 1963.

title: SPANG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $741,123 for the qr and $511,966 for the yr...C-After a loss of $145,498 for the qr and income of $73,031 for the yr from discontinued operations

title: THOUGH THE SUBWAYS ARE CRITICIZED NOW, I RECALL THEM FONDLY
description: I recently attempted to imagine a return visit to New York City, where I grew up and lived for 30 years, but I found my mind hopping all over the city. I couldn't fasten on one setting, one address, that held my past. There were too many candidates, but there was a connection - a connecting network in fact: the subways. The IRT, IND, and BMT linked the various parts of my life.

title: Garden Cut Is Accepted By Unions
description: Madison Square Garden and a committee representing its 1,000 unionized employees announced tentative agreement yesterday on a plan to reduce costs at the Garden.

title: Payment to Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had received a partial prepayment from the sale of its Australian and New Zealand magazine operations.

title: John F. Abel, 54, Ex-Director Of Management Consultants
description: John F. Abel, former international managing director of Towers, Perrin, Foster & Crosby, a management consultant company, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Abel, who also had a home in Rehoboth Beach, Del., was 54 years old.

title: PORTMAN'S PROGRESS
description: Sydney H. Schanberg

title: TRINITY RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revs for the latest yr are net of windfall profits tax shr earnings are fully diluted

title: WEIMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $8,000...C-Net loss and after income from sold operations of $70,000 a tax credit of $398,000 and a loss of $613,000 from a subsidiary disposed of in Apr 1981...D-After a tax credit of $184,000... E-After income from sold operations of $70,000; income from operations for the period ended Dec 31 1980 were decreased by about $177,000 because of changes in accounting estimates primarily inventory adjustments; the 1981 results reflect loss by $619,000 from a subsidiary disposed of in Apr 1981; sales figures include $572,000 in 1981 yr and $616,000 for the 1980 fourth qr and $2,190,000 in 1980 yr from a subsidiary disposed of in Apr 1981

title: A FAILED GIVEAWAY MEETS A FOILED GETAWAY
description: When the siren screams, police chases, milling throngs and traffic jams had subsided around the Empire State Building yesterday at lunchtime, a passer-by asked a security guard what had happened. The guard sighed. ''What's the use?'' he said. ''If I told you, you wouldn't believe me.''

title: Pennsylvania Journal; INS AND OUSTS OF POLITICS, EDUCATION AND ART
description: One seat in the United States Senate is empty today because of the resignation Thursday of Harrison A. Williams Jr., who was convicted in the Federal Abscam investigation.

title: N.B.A. Fines 13 Players
description: For fights in games last week, the National Basketball Association yesterday fined 13 players $8,850. Ten of the fines came as a result of an incident March 7 between the Clippers and the SuperSonics.

title: Harvard, Northeastern Reach Final in Hockey
description: Harvard upset heavily-favored Clarkson, 7-1, and Northeastern rallied to defeat New Hampshire, 4-2, in the semifinal round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I playoffs tonight in Boston Garden. The winners will meet in the championship game Saturday night.

title: CAPTIVE RECANTS SALVADOR STORY, TO U.S. DISMAY
description: The Reagan Administration thought it had a persuasive witness in Orlando Jose Tardencillas Espinosa, a Nicaraguan captured last year in El Salvador while fighting with the guerrillas. He told the Salvadoran Army, and later the American Embassy, that he had been trained in Cuba and Ethiopia, then sent to El Salvador by the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Gulf to Honor Arco Credit Card
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation has invited customers of the Atlantic Richfield Company, whose credit cards will become invalid on April 15, to temporarily use their Arco cards at Gulf stations and then apply for Gulf credit.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEW LOOKS

title: A.T.&T. Refunds
description: The Federal Communications Commission, following through on a recent court decision, ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to make refunds to its long-distance competitors that could total $35 million. The decision, approved unanimously, stems from a United States Court of Appeals ruling last September striking down the first of three rate increases that A.T.& T. has applied since 1980 to the charges that its long-distance competitors pay to connect their networks to Bell System switches.

title: SOME PRECAUTIONS
description: 1. Avoid carrying more credit cards than you plan to use. 2. Don't leave credit cards in the glove compartments of cars, on furniture in hotel rooms or in desks at home - the first places thieves look.

title: HOUSING RENOVATION ISN'T STEMMING CITIES' POPULATION LOSS, CENCUS SHOWS
description: Although extensive housing renovation has been changing the face of many older American cities, it apparently has not stemmed the population losses that contributed to the general decline of central urban areas, according to new figures from the 1980 census.

title: IF 'SURROGATE FAMILIES' REPLACED FOSTER CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT A WOMAN'S GOT TO DO
description: The most encouraging news story of the season is about an act of violence, which shows you what kind of winter it's been in the news world.

title: URBAN AMENITY ZONES
description: As the Reagan Administration develops its enterprisezone proposal, which is expected to constitute the centerpiece of its urban policy, it ought to examine an innovative New York State approach to improving business districts.

title: U.S. IS HINTING AT CUT IN FUNDS TO SOUTH BRONX
description: Financing for a major South Bronx urban project may be cut, the Department of Housing and Urban Development hinted today.

title: Rain on Coast Stirs Concern About Space Shuttle's Flight
description: A half-inch of rain has left puddles on the space shuttle's desert landing strip here, but the space agency said today that at least one major runway should be dry in time for the Columbia's third flight this month.

title: Colombian Rebels Burn Buses and Set Off Bombs
description: Guerrillas, who have vowed to disrupt Sunday's national elections, burned buses, set off bombs and attacked a town's police station today, the chief of the national police said.

title: News Analysis
description: It comes as no surprise to most economists to see the inflation rate falling. That is typically what occurs during a recession, and in that respect, at least, this downturn is no different from others.

title: NUCLEAR CRISIS PLANS FOR INDIAN PT. PLANTS TERMED INADEQUATE
description: A plan to protect the nearly 300,000 people who live near Indian Point in case of a nuclear accident is inadequate and may never be workable, according to some officials at the county, town and schooldistrict level who would be responsible for carrying it out.

title: ASA LTD reports earnings for As of Feb 28
The City; Sweeping Machine Kills City Worker
description: A Sanitation Department mechanic was killed when the mechanical street sweeper he was driving down a ramp of a department garage in upper Manhattan overturned and burst into flames.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Suriname Says Coup Has Been Put Down

title:
PATENTS;
Compound to Prevent Blood Clotting Disclosed
description: A compound that keeps blood from clotting my prove valuable in treating stroke and accident victims. The compound is disclosed in patent 4,318,904, granted this week to Elliott N. Shaw and Charles A. Kettner, who did their research at Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island.

title: PENTHOUSE LOSES BID TO PRESENT OTHER ARTICLES AT LIBEL TRIAL
description: A judge today rejected an effort by Penthouse magazine to introduce a thick pile of articles from newspapers and other magazines and excerpts from books purportedly showing underworld connections at the resort La Costa.

title: Executive Weds Margery C. Baker
description: Margery Claire Baker, senior broadcast producer of the ''CBS Morning News,'' was married yesterday to James H. Maloon, chairman and chief executive officer of the Itel Corporation, a capital-equipment leasing concern based in San Francisco. State Supreme Court Justice Felice Shea performed the ceremony in the Regency Hotel.

title: Notes on People; A 7-Pound Baby Fills Out a 6-Generation Line; Great3-Grandmother
description: There was a very special reason a documentary film crew was on hand early yesterday to record the birth of a seven-pound girl in Redwood City, Calif.

title: The Economy
description: The Producer Price Index fell in February for the first time in six years, providing the most striking evidence so far that inflation is abating. The decline was just 0.1 percent, or an annual rate of 1.7 percent, but it followed an average gain of 0.4 percent in the three preceding months. Most economists had expected the index to show another modest advance. (Page 1.) The belief is spreading that the relief from inflation may remain after recovery begins. (1.)

title: MASS TRANSIT NEEDS A PUBLIC SAFETY BOARD
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Ban Urged by Maine
description: Maine became the fifth state to go on record against the nuclear arms race Thursday as the Legislature almost unanimously approved a resolution calling on Congress to advocate a mutual halt in the testing, production and deployment of nuclear weapons by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Washington Talk
description: Upbeat Outlays?

title: ROSE RESUMES HEADFIRST PACE
description: One month after straining his back in a tennis game, Pete Rose took his first batting practice swings of spring training today. But he said that he would not modify his headlong style of baseball as he neared his 41st birthday in a race against time and Ty Cobb.

title: Bridge: Mathematicians May Find Their Advantage Is Small
description: Whether it is necessary to be a good mathematician to be an effective bridge player is a question that is often asked. The answer is no, although there are some qualities of thought that are important in both fields. Reasoning, inference and analysis are all significant, and without such abilities an individual's prospects are limited.

title: A PRESIDENTIAL ATTACK ON LOW-AND MODERATE-INCOME HOUSING
description: To the Editor:

title: SIMPLIFYING NEW YORK'S COMPLEX COURT SYSTEM
description: The law and its complex and often slow-moving machinery can confound the ordinary citizen searching for justice even in the best of circumstances.

title: CELTICS SUBDUE NETS, 113-109
description: The Boston Celtics, defending champions of the National Basketball Association, laid the Nets' pretensions to rest tonight. But it was not easy.

title: WINKELMAN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
DON'T SPLIT NEW YORK CITY BY TOLLING ITS BRIDGES
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money; Danger Signs On Borrowing
description: WHILE individuals have their financial records out, struggling with the income tax, it's a good time to mull over personal finances. How much is being saved? How much is going for interest on credit cards and loans? Are red lights flashing among the personal economic indicators?

title: ELIZABETH TAYLOR: LONDON'S BIG NEWS
description: It seemed impossible that anyone would ever manage to upstage the Princess of Wales, but in the last two weeks, a 50-year-old woman with a turbulent past and an uncertain future has succeeded in doing so.

title: TRIGERE WITHOUT FRILLS
description: There are pea jackets and coats with a flurry of fox tails rippling down the front. Unlined coats in double-faced fabrics vie with Ultrasuede, which is for all seasons. There are a couple of capes - it wouldn't be a Trigere show without them - and a few fur-trimmed styles. What there isn't is any nonsense.

title: WATT CLEARS THE WAY FOR A WAR MEMORIAL TO VIETNAM VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Interior Secretary James G. Watt has cleared the way for construction of a memorial dedicated to America's 2.7 million veterans of the Vietnam War, a Government spokesman said today.

title: LORIMAR PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Broker Gets Jail in Fraud
description: George Hudson, a former stockbroker for A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in Memphis, who had pleaded guilty to misappropriating clients' funds, was given a three-and-a-half-year prison sentence yesterday in Federal District Court in Memphis.

title: DIVORCE: DOING IT YOURSELF
description: THE tobacco shop that John Parker operates at 60 Centre Street in Manhattan caters to the needs of people in a courthouse. T he tiny stand is packed with cigarettes, candy, cupcakes, pens and p antyhose. It sells diet soda and cottage cheese for low-calorie l unches. It also offers kits for low-cost divorces.

title: Around the Nation; Prosecutor Reviews File In Case Against Noguchi
description: The Los Angeles District Attorney's office today began reviewing 250 pages of charges against County Coroner Thomas Noguchi, who has been charged by the County Board of Supervisors with poor management, absenteeism and lax control of evidence.

title: MAYOR HOFFMAN'S FEAT
description: To the Editor:

title: FEWER YOUTHS MEANS GREATER TROUBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BANK (WASHINGTON, DC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest qr and yr reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translation

title: Airline Trust Immunity
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday extended the immunity granted to certain United States airlines against antitrust prosecution in connection with price-setting activities involving the International Air Transport Association. A spokesman for the board, Edgar B. Hamilton Jr., said that the immunity, which was to have expired on Monday, was being prolonged indefinitely and affected North Atlantic carriers. The action removes a possible legal barrier to imposing sweeping fare increases agreed upon by the association's 30 airlines that fly across the North Atlantic.

title: G.M. Calls Plant Report 'Premature'
description: A spokesman for the General Motors Corporation labeled as ''premature'' published reports that plants in Baltimore and Linden, N.J., are the most likely to assemble small cars should G.M. enter a joint agreement with Toyota.

title: Notes on People; A Thatcher Turmoil
description: Not long after Carol Thatcher, daughter of Britain's Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, returned to London after working five years as a newspaper reporter in Australia, she landed a good job with the London Broadcasting Company as host of a radio call-in show.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52.

title: THE RATE HAS GONE UP FOR YANKEES' UTILITY MAN
description: During the winter, when Larry Milbourne visited his hometown of Port Norris, N.J., he and his father would reminisce about last fall's playoffs, in which Milbourne, an unheralded utility infielder, had filled in ably for the injured Bucky Dent.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MARCH 13, 1982
description: International Critics of the Central America policy adopted by the Reagan Administration said it was ''confused and dangerous,'' and proposed legislation that would require prior Congressional approval for any American intervention in the region, including military action and covert intelligence operations. The opposition to the policy came from two freshmen Democratic Senators, Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut. (Page 1, Column 3.) The Caribbean economic plan proposed by the Reagan Administration was endorsed by President Franc,ois Mitterrand of France, who flew to Washington for a meeting with President Reagan. There was no indication from the public statements issued after the meeting of nearly three hours that France and the United States do not continue to hold differing views on the guerrilla war in El Salvador or on the general question of outside involvement in Central America. But President Reagan told reporters that he believed President Mitterrand ''now has a better understanding of United States policy objectives'' in Central America. (3:-5-6.)

title: Miss Horne Cancels Concert
description: Marilyn Horne has canceled her concert scheduled for tonight at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College because of illness. The concert has been rescheduled for April 4 at 8 P.M. Tonight's tickets will be honored for that performance.

title: St. John's Defeats Penn; Northeastern Gains, 63-62
description: St. Joseph's, the team that shocked top-ranked De Paul in the national collegiate basketball tournament a year ago this weekend, saw its season come to a sudden end tonight. Bryan Warrick missed three shots in the final minute, and Northeastern beat the Hawks, 63-62, in the opener of two first-round East Regional playoff games at Nassau Colisem.

title: LIEDER: LUCY SHELTON
description: In most respects, Lucy Shelton's lieder recital Thursday night at the Metropolitan Museum was a model of taste and artistry. Miss Shelton chose mostly unusual repertory deftly combined and sung conscientiously in five languages, including Russian and Czech. And her accompanist, Lambert Orkis, not only provided alert piano playing but also chipped in when called upon for a half-sung, half-spoken line in her final Ives song.

title: Tennessee Triumphs by 61-57
description: Dale Ellis scored 23 points and Michael Brooks had 16, including six consecutive free throws in the final minute, to lead Tennessee to a 61-57 triumph tonight over Southwestern Louisiana in a first-round N.C.A.A. Mideast regional game.

title: Some Safety Net
description: Whenever criticized for cutting social welfare programs, President Reagan says no, he's only slowing the growth in Government spending. No harm will come to the truly needy, those who cannot fend for themselves, he insists. His social safety net will protect them.

title: FRANCE TO BUY 51% OF I.T.T.
description: France's Socialist Government said today that it would only buy a 51 percent interest in the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's French subsidary - enough for control - but would not purchase the entire company, as originally planned.

title: MITTERRAND, IN U.S., BACKS CARIBBEAN RECOVERY PROJECT
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France made a one-day visit here today, meeting with President Reagan for nearly three hours and endorsing the Administration's economic recovery plan for the Caribbean area.

title: OVERMYER CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $524,000

title: Washington Subway System Suspends Two in Fatal Crash
description: A subway operator and a supervisor blamed for a derailment Jan. 13 that killed three persons and injured 25 have been suspended without pay and banned from ever working in a supervisory capacity.

title: RULES FOR SAFETY IN A NUCLEAR ACCIDENT
description: If there were a serious accident at either of the two nuclear plants at Indian Point, experts say, residents in the area should follow these procedures:

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL
description: CHICAGO (NFC) - Signed James Scott, wide receiver, as a free agent.; SOCCER

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 16.00-16.50**Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Sony Appeals Videotape Ruling
description: The Sony Corporation appealed to the Supreme Court to overturn a far-reaching ruling that could brand three million American families as lawbreakers for using home video recorders to tape television programs.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Eastern Utilities Associates, a holding company that through its operating units provides electric service to portions of southeastern Massachusetts and northern Rhode Island, announced a proposed public offering of 900,000 shares of public stock to be sold by an underwriting group co-managed by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. and Kidder, Peabody & Co.

title: Zimbabwe Arrests Deputy Head of Army
description: Security forces have arrested the deputy commander of Zimbabwe's Army and a prominent former national defense adviser in a continuing crackdown on people charged with subversion, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's office has announced.

title: Japan May Tax Gains on Bonds
description: In a move apparently aimed at curbing purchases of zero-coupon, deep-discount Eurobonds, Japan's Finance Ministry is considering imposing a tax on capital gains, it was reported today.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS INVESTIGATING CASE OF TEACHER CHARGED WITH ASSAULT
description: School officials said yesterday that they were investigating assault charges against an elementary school teacher who was accused by the police of injuring a 12-year-old pupil at Public School 262 in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Empire State Building does not condone the dropping of dollar bills from its observatory this afternoon or anytime.'' - Management of the Empire State Building observatory. (29:1.)

title: World Airways Loss Expected
description: World Airways suffered a net loss of as much as $15 million in 1981, the carrier said.

title: A REPUBLICAN WHO ASSAILED REAGAN
description: In the days since he stood on the nearly deserted House floor earlier this week and delivered a scathing attack on President Reagan and his policies, Representative Marc L. Marks says he has received more than 500 telephone calls, 98 percent of them praising him for speaking out.

title: HOLMES, D H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
HAWKER SIDDELEY CANADA LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $944,000 and a foreign currency translation loss of $7,373,000...C-Including a foreign currency translation gain of $3,197,000; The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: REGAN ENDS HIS G.O.P. BID FOR THE NEW YORK GOVERNORSHIP
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan ended his campaign for the Republican gubernatorial nomination today, saying that Mayor Koch's candidacy had cut off the financial support he needed and that he would run for re-election instead.

title: ARABIA THRICE OVER LIGHTLY
description: THE KINGDOM By Robert Lacey. Illustrated. 631 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95. THE HOUSE OF SAUD The Rise and Rule of the Most Powerful Dynasty in the Arab World. By David Holden and Richard Johns. Illustrated. 569 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $19.95. THE NEW ARABIANS By Peter Mansfield. Illustrated. 274 pp. Chicago: J.G. Ferguson Publishing Co. Distributed by Doubleday. $14.95.

title: MORNING SOLILOQUY OF A TURNPIKE DRIVER
description: ITRAVEL three mornings a week on the Connecticut Turnpike to S tamford, where I teach a 50-minute class at a private college. The t rip from Westport usually takes 25 minutes but on winter mornings, i t takes an hour. As I hit the traffic on the turnpike, a phrase f rom Herman Melville's short story, ''Bartleby the Scrivener,'' e choes in my mind, ''Ah, Bartleby! Ah, humanity!''

title: NOW AND THEN, CONGRESS ALSO PONDERS THE FUTURE
description: Where have all the Government's futurists gone? A decade or so ago, when a thousand scholarly flowers bloomed, few seemed as promising, or as alluring to Federal officials, as the flower of futurism. The United States seemed to overcome its antipathy to concerted planning and began seriously considering the shape the future might take. Even Congress, whose members seldom looked beyond the next election, started examining the implications of legislation in fields such as energy, the environment and social policy.

title: Anne Kelchburg Is Bride Of Edward J. Garnett Jr.
description: Anne Marie Kelchburg, public relations manager for AFIA Worldwide Insurance in New York, and Edward J. Garnett Jr., an associate with the New York law firm of Taliuaga & Karsch, were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard Devine performed the ceremony in St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: NEW ENERGY CHIEF EMPHASIZES POLICY
description: TRENTON THE state's Department of Energy, which ran into controversy under its former Commissioner, Joel R. Jacobsen, may run into more of the same under its new head, Leonard Coleman.

title: EXPORT BRIDES BIG BUSINESS IN PHILIPPINES
description: More than 3,000 Philippine women became export brides of Australians and West Germans last year, and 4,000 others went to other European countries and the United States.

title: NEIGHBORS PLANNING A WILDLIFE PRESERVE
description: NORTHVILLE IN a novel approach to open-space preservation, two neighbors here have laid plans to establish a privately held wildlife and recreational preserve on 333 rustic acres they have contracted to buy from the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title:
THE DAY THEY BARRED BEHAN FROM THE PARADE;
''I've never seen a situation so dismal that a policeman couldn't make it worse.'' BRENDAN BEHAN
description: AS HE stood on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral during last year's St. Paddy's Day parade, Terence Cardinal Cooke, a man who finds nuclear weapons tolerable and beer spilled on Fifth Avenue intolerable, cast a cold eye on the rowdies. As a result, James J. Comerford, the parade chairman, was asked to do something about the increasing number of drunks and hooligans.

title: EASTER IN GREECE: A NATIONAL FEAST
description: PAUL ANASTASI contributes to The Times from Athens. By PAUL ANASTASI

title:
Dining Out;
CHINESE HOSPITALITY IN SAYREVILLE
description: SOME time ago, we arrived at a Chinese restaurant at about 9 o'clock on a weeknight. We were told to order quickly because the place was closing. We ordered immediately, all of the courses arrived at the same time and the help, their topcoats already on, stood around waiting for us to leave.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DAY IN THE LIFE OF THE AIRCRAFT CARRIER CONSTELLATION
description: Lieut. William Miles and another F-14 pilot were flying patrol 22,000 feet above this aircraft carrier when their radar picked up two Soviet IL-38 turboprops 200 miles away.

title: MILLSTONE 2 NUCLEAR PLANT IS READY TO REOPEN
description: The Millstone 2 nuclear power plant is scheduled to resume operation late Sunday night or early Monday morning after a refueling shutdown that was extended because of steam generator problems.

title: ARGUING OVER WHO PICKS UP THE PIECES
description: Many Connecticut Republicans and businessmen refer to a plant closing measure before the General Assembly as the ''industrial hostage bill,'' considering it a sufficiently onerous shackle on commercial freedom to merit the Iranian allusion. Many Democrats and labor leaders, seeing the measure's severance pay, advance notice and training guarantees as the least a company should do before fleeing to the Sunbelt or turning belly up, prefer to call it the ''runaway shop bill.''

title: DRUG GANGS THREATEN JUDGES AND PROSECUTORS
description: Some prosecutors and judges in Florida have learned that they are part of a frightening role reversal. They have become the accused; they are, the authorities say, being convicted and sentenced to death by gangs involved in drug sales or other organized crime.

title: CHINA'S AIRLINE
description: To the Editor: I am amused to find myself defending CAAC's intra-China air service but, having experienced it - as well as short-run domestic service in Europe, Egypt, the United States and South America - I find it is the rare air carrier that offers clean, new planes, appetizing meals and no delays on these unglamorous but necessary trunk-line runs.

title: Expectations
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Eventually, Most Balloons Deflate'' (Feb. 28) Leland S. Prussia, chairman of the Bank of America, worries that ''if the wave of the 1980's turns out to be deflation, not inflation,'' many financial institutions will find themselves in a difficult position, since their balance sheets are structured on the premise of high future inflation.

title: Dining Out; SCARSDALE AREA GETS A NEW SPOT; by M. H. Reed
description: In a section of the county that has always been indadequately served by dining plaxes, particularly with those that offer carefully made, dependable fare, the appearance of Vesuvio, in Scarsdale's Colonial Village Shopping Center, is a bright addition. Open six months ago by Richard Pavia and his son John, this family-operated restaurant offers Italian cuisine against a cheerful background of brick-faced walls, Italian landscapes and tapes of Pavarotti singing his favorites. Richard Pavia, the maltre d' hotel, is a warm and knowledgeable professional who adds much to the pleasure of dining here.

title: FOR A GREETING THAT REALLY SINGS
description: The golden anniversary of the singing telegram is still a few thousand choruses of ''Happy Birthday'' away but its golden age, it appears, is now.

title: Joan Becker Engaged to Michael Sills
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Becker of Ottawa Hills, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Alaine Becker, to Michael N. Sills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Sills of New York.

title: The Americas, Beyond Demonology
description: The Reagan Administration has opened a small patch in the Central American thicket. The disclosure of sensitive surveillance data lets Americans begin to test the factual basis for their Government's ever-more threatening posture toward the leftist regime in Nicaragua. But the zealous offering of some sloppy evidence has not been reassuring. And in any case, a larger tract of darkness remains: what national interests propel these anxieties?

title: Critics' Choices
description: PHOTOGRAPHYThe dark, square prints of Robert Giard have an air of quiet menace about them. The people in his portraits do not connect with the viewer in a friendly way.

title: CLARITY ITSELF
description: Leaks are in fashion. I've been given one. It is from OE COMMUNIQUE, which is "The Professional Organizational Effectiveness/Development Publication of the United States Army." Stamped ''Secret'' and passed to the Kremlin, it might end the arms race. For anybody reading this document would conclude that America is doomed and that no outside effort will be needed to bring it toppling down.

title:
GARDENING;
A PRIMER ON GARDEN FERTILIZERS
description: BECAUSE the time is nye upon us when lawns, trees, shrubs and planting beds will require their spring application of nutrients, it is appropriate that we attempt to clarify the confusion that abounds in garden centers, with their many brands and claims.

title: For hunters: the right look, the right rooms
description: What to Wear Proper hunting attire varies somewhat from region to region and even sometimes from hunt to hunt. Riders should wear high, black riding boots, fawn or canary riding breeches and black hunt coat.
