title: PAUL THEROUX'S SUBWAY ODYSSEY
description: I am a woman over 65, and have been riding the subways daily for the last 35 years, N, E or F trains.

title: SUBWAY SIGNS OFTEN SIDETRACK RIDERS
description: When their subway train pulled into the Brooklyn Bridge station one recent day, two women who had been told by a fellow passenger that the the IRT No. 6 local would stop at Fulton Street, their destination, remained aboard. The sign on their car - incorrect - said the last stop would be Bowling Green, two stops beyond Fulton.

title: Tracy Marlow Fiance Of Sarah Starkweather
description: The engagement of Sarah Mayberry Starkweather to Tracy Arthur Marlow has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James Oliver Starkweather of Old Greenwich, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. John M. Shaheen of New York and Southampton, L.I., and Dr. Gordon V. Marlow of Madison, Wis.

title: HOUSING LAWS BEING RE-EVALUATED
description: THE lack of affordable housing on Long Island for moderate-income families has prompted officials in towns in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties to re-evaluate their local zoning and housing codes.

title: THERE'S MANY A DAISY TO ADD DAZZLE TO FLOWER BORDERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Pamela Harper is a garden photographer and lecturer. BY PAMELA HARPER

title: ON WALKWAYS
description: NEWARK OFFICIALLY, they are elevated pedestrian walkways, but the aboveground connections that link the existing Gateway projects to Pennsylvania Station here have been called catwalks, gangplanks and other, less polite, terms.

title: Children's Fashion By Andrea Skinner
description: Heads set outside: BREEZING ALONG ANCHORS AWAY Ahoy, mates! It's down to the sea again. From buccaneer to beachcomber, boys and girls will be sailing through spring and summer in clothes with a nautical, shipshape air. White teams up with red and blue, as well as soft pastels. Stripes are bold and clean, often matched with crisp prints. The outfits - appropriately practical, washable and comfortable - often pair traditional middy tops with full bloomers, Bermuda shorts or even clam diggers. CAPTION A Opposite page, left: Jump suit from Youngland, $30. At Abraham and Straus; Saks Fifth Avenue; Bullock's, Los Angeles, and Sanger Harris, Dallas. T-shirt by Terrific. Opposite page, right: Middy blouse and clam diggers from Polly Mills, $60.50. At Bergdorf Goodman; Little Bits, 1186 Madison Avenue; Auntie Barbara's, Beverly Hills, Calif.; Pattee Ann, Salem, Mass., and Young World, Deal, N.J. Sandals from Tru-Tred; socks from Ergee. CAPTION B Left: The buccaneer look from Judith of Miami, $18 each. At Gimbels; Pinch Penny Pick A Pocket, 1242 Madison Avenue; The White House, Lake Charles, La., and The Boston Store, Beaumont, Tex. Socks from Trimfit. CAPTION C Above, left: Jump suit, $36. At Patrick, 930 Madison Avenue; Show & Tell, 1205 Lexington Avenue, and Tuesday's Child, Brooklyn. Above, right: Shirt, $24, and pants, $24. Both outfits from Petite Gamine. At Peanut Butter Kids, Manhasset, L.I. Shoes from Terry. Opposite page, left: Yves Saint Laurent's playsuit, $35. At Bergdorf Goodman. Opposite page, right: Pinafore from Polly Mills, $32.

title: TOMS RIVER WANTS NO 'HORROR' SEQUEL
description: TOMS RIVER WHEN ''The Amityville Horror'' was filmed here in the fall of 1978, crowds of curiosity-seekers swarmed around Eric and Joyce Peterson's home, which had been transformed by studio carpenters into the house where murders had been committed.

title: HARD SELL
description: Not long ago a top adviser to President Reagan was outlining the gloomy situation the Administration faced in bolstering the Government of El Salvador. The picture included diminishing chances of a fair election March 28, increasing prospects of a military stalemate with the Salvador insurgents, and growing skepticism about the wisdom of Mr. Reagan's course. Asked what the Administration was doing in light of its pessimistic assessment, the adviser threw up his hands. ''We're reviewing the situation,'' he sighed. ''What does the Government always do? We're reviewing it. What would you do?''

title: A DOCUMENTARIAN FOCUSES ON MIDDLE AMERICA
THE MAYAN WAR GOD IS UNDER NEW MANAGEMENT
description: Dressed in their bright skirts and blouses, their long black hair in tight braids, a cluster of Indian women squatted in the dirt, weighing vegetables on crude scales and counting stacks of tortillas. Across the way, Indian men repaired the village church. Their gaily colored trousers, held up by wide swatches of cloth, reached to their calves. Their feet were toughened by years of walking without shoes.

title: WOMEN PAST 30 WILL CONTINUE TO HAVE CHILDREN!
description: T o the Editor: The brouhaha over the fertility of women who are past the age of 30 (''Study Shows Female Fertility Drops Sharply After Age 30,'' news story Feb. 18) may be the ultimate case of much ado about nothing. Before we all quit work and rush to the bedroom to save the American family, it's enlightening to take a close look at the original report published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Dr. Farrell Scott Malkis To Wed Ellen Lisa Katz
description: Mr. and Mrs. David K. Katz of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Lisa Katz, to Dr. Farrell Scott Malkis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Malkis of New York. The wedding is planned for summer.

title: PET CENTER TO STUDY HUMANS
description: The Animal Medical Center has received a $500,000 grant from the Vincent Astor Foundation to endow a chair for a comparative medicine program to coordinate research into diseases that occur in both humans and animals.

title: INDIA'S EMBELLISHED IMAGES
description: Fergus M. Bordewich is a freelance writer with a special interest in Asia. By Fergus M. Bordewich o a visitor encountering Calcutta for the first time, the city seems to swarm with a wonderful, if claustrophobic, energy. Automobiles, cows, gaunt men straining at rickshaws, coolies with pushcarts piled impossibly high, all jockey for space in the pitted streets, maneuvering with astonishing speed and agility.

title: China's Airline
description: To the Editor: Time was when travelers in China took days, even months, to go from one point to another on foot, in a boat, on donkeyback or riding a pushcart. R. V. Denenberg (''Tales of Flying a Paper Tiger,'' Travel, Feb. 21) was lucky to be able to reach Urumqi from Peking in a few hours, thanks to CAAC, the Chinese airline.

title: Alison V. Rand Will Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. George J. Meyerson of Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Meyerson's daughter, Alison Valentine Rand, to James P. Constantino, son of Mr and Mrs. Dominick P. Constantino of Hyde Park, N.Y.

title:
Other Business;
PHYSICIANS: THAT'LL BE 18% AND CALL ME IN THE MORNING
description: Could it be that the economic crunch has finally been felt by the medical profession? According to the American Medical Association, the trade association for the medical profession, it certainly has.

title: A NEW NUCLEAR STRATEGY
description: Besides a buildup of nuclear arms, the authors propose we take steps to limit the effect of nuclear war by increasing our civildefense and air-defense efforts. To take these steps would imply a belief that one can fight a nuclear war and win.

title: LANDMARKING DEFENDED
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Mozambique Says Rebels Are Tied to South Africa
description: Mozambique's Defense Ministry made new charges today of links between the rebel Mozambique National Resistance group and South African Army and intelligence officers. The official press agency said the charges were based on documents, released today by the ministry, that were recovered in December when the Mozambican army overran a rebel base at Garagua in the central part of the country.

title: SIGNS HINT AT ACTION ON PLANT
description: THE fate of the $135 million Hempstead Resource Recovery plant, which has been idle for the last two years, may be decided in the next few months despite the continuing debate about its viability as a solution to Hempstead Town's garbage-disposal problem.

title: MRS. WHITE IS 3-STROKE LEADER
description: Donna H. White shot a par 73 today to take a three-stroke lead over Ayako Okamoto of Japan after three rounds of the $150,000 Olympia Gold women's golf tournament.

title: No Headline
description: March 14, 1982 NONFICTION THE BLACK BOOK. Edited by Ilya Ehrenburg and Vasily Grossman. 16 THE GERMANS. By Gordon A. Craig. 10 GERMAN WRITERS IN SOVIET EXILE, 1933-1945.

title: Behind Bradley Speech
description: For two years, as the story of Abscam unfolded, Senator Bill Bradley had kept his own counsel on how he felt about the involvement of his fellow Senator from New Jersey, Harrison A. Williams.

title: LEARNING AT THE SOURCE, MEALS ON WHEELS; College Study At the Source
description: Here is a chance to study Chaucer in Canterbury, Tuscan art in Florence and Sienna, Greek myths in Crete and Sicily, African tribal cultures in Kenya, Egyptian history at sites along the Nile and Indian art, architecture and religion in Bombay, Delhi, Benares, Madras and Katmandu. Such courses, which combine study with travel, are offered by University of California Extension.

title: A DANCE COMPANY MAKES N.Y.U. ITS NEW HOME
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Aaron Cohen is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance. BY AARON COHEN

title: MAINSTREAM U.S. EVANGELICALS SURGE IN PROTESTANT INFLUENCE
description: Often overshadowed by fundamentalism and shunned by church liberals, the mainstream of evangelical Christians has emerged as the most powerful new force in American Protestantism.

title: Gallery View; IN BOSTON: FROM THE OLD WORLD TO THE NEW; BOSTON
description: To get the most out of ''Egypt's Golden Age: The Art of Living in the New Kingdom, 1558-1085 B.C.'' at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts you have to do a little imagining. You should picture, for instance, a traveler in time and space who at some undisclosed date in the future pushes on the door of a small and long-abandoned house somewhere in North America. From what he finds inside he tries to piece together the way we lived in the 1980's. And what is the evidence? In no particular order, he sees a necklace, a bottle of brand-name aspirin, a folding stool of classical design, some standard flatware, a very large pair of men's underpants, a ballpoint pen long gone dry, 14 kinds of lipstick, a defective comb, a once-frozen package of turkey Tetrazzini and a disconnected electric guitar. Add to that a random sample of old magazine covers, and your list is almost complete.

title: ONE PASSENGER'S RAILLERY OVER 'THE AMTRAK WAY'
description: ''AMERICA is getting into training,'' trills the familiar radio jingle, ''Training the Amtrak way.'' So I thought you'd like to know how I successfully negotiated rail passage from New York City to Wilmington, Del. - with a return to Rye.

title: The Nation in Summary; Jerry Brown's Senate Mode
description: It is not always easy to tell Edmund G. Brown Jr. without a scorecard. The California Governor has been much criticized as a man who tries to represent too many things to too many people, and he himself recently conceded that ''discussing too many ideas has overloaded the circuits'' and weakened his political support.

title: Film View; HELPFUL HINTS FOR THE WOULD-BE AUTHORITY
description: The point can't be made too often: It isn't absolutely necessary to to see films to be able to talk about them with authority. Still, it's not as easy to fake an authoritative manner about films as it is to appear to be up-to-date on the latest world news, which, after all, becomes yesterday's news in 24 hours. Films don't become obsolete quite as quickly. Film fashions hang on, sometimes not only for weeks but even months! That's a solemn fact of our existence.

title: PAUL THEROUX'S SUBWAY ODYSSEY
description: How appropriate that Paul Theroux's eloquent portrait of the subway ran on the most violent weekend yet in the history of the system (130 felonies)! The subway, however, is just the stage for a terrible problem that we had better focus on: What is to be done about the new generation of New Yorkers who are a motif through Mr. Theroux's article - the hordes of vicious ''schoolboy'' criminals who make our lives so fearful both below and above the ground in New York City? D.B. FELDMAN New York City ------

title: Other Business; BEVERAGES: A NEW DEPARTURE IN CANINE CUISINE
description: In the commercial, Fido didn't like the crunchy bits. He wouldn't eat his dry dog food until his master poured on water to make a delicious gravy.

title: Robin Gold Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gold of Springfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Sabrina Gold, to Oliver Abel 4th, son of Dr. and Mrs. Abel 3d of St. Louis. The wedding is planned for next August. Miss Gold is a corporate banking officer with the Bank of Montreal in New York. Mr. Abel is an assistant vice president of Philadelphia Capital Advisers, a subsidiary of the Philadelphia National Bank.

title: CHANGES IN STATE OBSCENITY LAW ARE PROPOSED
description: MORE than 50 Berlin residents are expected to attend a public hearing tomorrow to argue in favor of strengthening the state's obscenity law.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Needle Therapy
description: Acupuncture was being tried at the Haight-Ashbury Free Medical Clinic in San Francisco to help hard-core heroin addicts kick the habit, and for some it appeared to work. The treatment called for at least 21 days of acupuncture along with counseling.

title: Music; CONCERT HONORS COLLEGE
description: THERE was quite a birthday party at Wesleyan last weekend, with hundreds of would-be listeners turned away for lack of space, while the crowd in Crowell Hall stamped and cheered the premiere of Henry Brant's ''Meteor Farm.'' This extraordinary, ambitious score, officially listed as ''a spatial concert of ceremonies, commissioned by and dedicated to Wesleyan University in celebration of its 150th anniversary,'' was designed to provide a showcase for the component units of the university's World Music Program.

title: About Books and Authors
description: A Split

title: Politics; THE ADVANTAGES OF INCUMBENCY
description: HARTFORD TALKING with reporters in his office last Monday, Governor O'Neill sidestepped a question on whether he regarded the Republican gubernatorial candidates or his Democratic challenger, Ernest N. Abate, as his most formidable opponent.

title: DAVID DeWITT
description: David DeWitt, a senior engineer of the International Business Machines Corporation, died Thursday at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., where he had his home. He was 66 years old.

title: DEMOCRATS GIRD TO BATTLE KEAN ON FIRST BUDGET
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN will not formally present his first budget message to the Legislature until tomorrow. However, key elements of the $6.37 billion document were released by his top aides in two briefings last week, and Democrats in both the Senate and Assembly are already howling that homeowners will be gouged on their property taxes so that business taxes can be cut.

title: Prospects
description: OPEC's Last Waltz?

title: Chess; WILL TO WIN THE KEY ROLE
description: The will to win more than compensated for technical inaccuracy in the recent Reykjavik International Tournament. Those who were fastidious in avoiding error also avoided winning, while those who aggressively pursued every point were rewarded in plenty.

title: EINSTEIN PAPERS: A 20-YEAR PROJECT
description: PRINCETON NEW light will be shed on major scientific and political topics of the 20th century - including the quantum theory, pacifism, Zionism, academic freedom and nuclear disarmament - when Albert Einstein's papers are published, according to Herbert S. Bailey Jr. of Griggstown, director of the Princeton University Press.

title: THE 'CALIFORNIA STYLE' STRUGGLES TO MEET TIME'S TEST
description: A dozen years ago, in an America of cheap energy and 7 percent mortgages, California-style house, with their steeply pitched rooflines, glass walls, oversized windows, wooden siding and earth-tone colors, were the rage in model homes throughout the East.

title:
Children;
BRINGING UP TWO OF A KIND
description: Since our twin daughters were born in 1977, we have had an all-purpose motto around our house that sums up the situation. It has never solved a problem for us, but it helps us keep a sense of perspective.

title: LEGISLATORS NEED SENSE OF REALITY ON PLAN FOR SCHOOL FINANCING
description: WHEN the New York State Supreme Court declared the state's system of financing education unconstitutional in 1978, the Governor did what politicians are wont to do: he appointed a committee. Its mission was to recommend a school-financing method that would be ''constitutionally acceptable, fiscally responsible'' and conducive to quality education. Left @unsaid, but understood by all who were appointed, was that the plan or plans also had to be politically acceptable or risk the fate of numerous other commission recommendations - the cynical sneer of the Legislature.

title: PAROLE UNIT, IN REVERSAL, CANCELS TRIBECA MOVE
description: Citing strong community opposition, the State Division of Parole has reversed its decision to move its city headquarters from the Times Square area to the Tribeca section of lower Manhattan.

title: OUT OF A SOAP OPERA CAME HAPPINESS
description: ''THE nature of soap operas,'' said Erika Slezak of Manhasset, ''is really concerned with emotions and personalities.'' Miss Slezak knows whereof she speaks. Next Wednesday she marks her 11th anniversary as Victoria Lord Riley (of the Philadelphia Main Line Lords and the not-so-rich Rileys), the wealthy widowed newspaper publisher on the ABC Television Network serial ''One Life to Live.''

title: Baltimore Egg Farmer Slain
description: A farmer who was shot Friday night by robbers while making egg deliveries died today, the authorities said. Carville Schisler, 60 years old, who owned a farm in New Windsor, was shot in the head when he tried to escape from three young men in a west Baltimore residential neighborhood.

title: THE VOICE OF CHARTRES
description: FRANK J. PRIAL, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, recently completed an assignment in the Paris bureau. By FRANK J.PRIAL

title: U.S. INTEREST-RATE FEVER ADDS TO EUROPE'S ACHES
description: When Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, unveiled the new budget in the House of Commons last week, Britons listened carefully for news of taxes and spending. But while he had their attention, Sir Geoffrey couldn't resist tossing in a mention of the consequences of high interest rates and large budget deficits in the United States.

title: ULSTER SEEMS HEADED FOR A CATHOLIC MAJORITY
description: Residential neighborhoods in this troubled province tend to be segregated along religious lines, and the visitor can often tell, just by looking around, which side he is on.

title: TURKEY WARNS GREECE ON AEGEAN MOVES
description: Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu accused Greece today of trying to establish ''faits accomplis'' in the Aegean region, and warned that Turkey ''will not hestitate to equally retaliate.''

title: SIMULTANEOUS RECOGNITION REMAINS THE KEY TO MIDEAST PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: DISPUTE ON 'PLATO' GOES ON
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP ALTHOUGH he is surrounded by controversy, the man behind Plato's Retreat here exudes confidence. ''We're going to open,'' says Beechi, who insists that that is his real name and the only one he answers to.

title: Sources for Inuit art
description: Following are the names of some galleries in Toronto that specialize in Inuit works of art: The Guild Shop (140 Cumberland Street, 416-921-1721) The Innuit Gallery of Eskimo Art (9 Prince Arthur Street, 416-921-9985) The Mazelow Gallery (3463 Yonge Street, 416-481-7711) Gallery One (121 Scollard Street, 416-929-3103). R.V.D.

title: Around the Nation; Indians Seek to Rebury Remains of Ancestors
description: The Kumeyaay Indians have filed suit in Superior Court here for permission to exhume the remains of 20 ancestors buried in San Diego County's Cuyamaca State Park.

title: NORTHEASTERN SKATES TO A TITLE
description: Northeastern used strong checking to overpower smaller, swifter Harvard, 5-2, tonight and win its first Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I hockey championship tonight at Boston Garden.

title: LABOR COSTS CITED IN DAILY NEWS SALE
description: As the owners of The Daily News pursue their efforts to dispose of it, potential buyers are focusing on what they say has always been the central issue in the matter - controlling the paper's labor costs.

title: Headliners; The Last Word
description: There is no statute of limitation on a guilty conscience and last week, after almost 70 years, Alonzo Mann confessed. Mr. Mann was a 14-year-old office boy in 1913 when he saw Jim Conley, a janitor, carrying the limp body of Mary Phagan, also 14, toward the basement of the National Pencil Company in Atlanta. But when threatened by Mr. Conley, he remained silent while a jury, swayed by a surge of anti-Semitism and the testimony of the black janitor, convicted Leo Frank, the Jewish factory superintendent, of Miss Phagan's murder. Mr. Frank was lynched by a mob two years later in a case that inspired the resurgence of the Ku Klux Klan, the birth of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and some 50 books. Mr. Conley died in 1962, but Mr. Mann was glad he had ''told it all'' anyway. ''I just hope it does some good,'' he said.

title: Art; A JOCULAR VIEW OF THE ART WORLD
description: 50's, was already notorious by the early 60's, mostly for his ''Happenings'' and 16-millimeter films. Many movies, installations, constructions and paintings later, he has become an institution devoted to the informed mockery of art, people in the art world (himself and his family, too) and life itself.

title: Sports People; Walker Does 3:52.5
description: John Walker of New Zealand, the first man to run a mile in less than 3 minutes 50 seconds, set an Australian record for the distance when he covered a course in Adelaide in 3:52.5.

title: Three-Way Race Could Aid Moffett
description: One can accept the background data and admire the author's analysis of Connecticut's Senate contest in the article headed ''Bush Could Win in a 3-Way Race (Opinion Page, Feb. 21),'' yet I fail to find there the logic that would warrant his concluding sentence that ends ''the conservatives have good reason to be optimistic.''

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: Irish writer. A BIGAMIST'S DAUGHTER, by Alice McDermott. (Random House, $13.50.) A first novel about a young woman who works for a vanity press.

title: DIVERSITY MARKS NEW PERFORMANCES
description: they are all part of a very busy week in the county's arts. Let us begin this evening at 8 o'clock, when the 16th annual Hoff-Barthelson Baroque Festival gets under way at the newly refurbished Scarsdale High School Auditorium. The featured work will be Bach's ''Magnificat,'' performed by the faculty soprano Marina Pafur, the mezzo Marta Senn, the tenor Rodney Miller and the baritone Ronald Corrado, the festival chorus (''expanded to include participants from the community, as many as 65 or 70,'' points out Doris Gilbert, community relations consultant), and a chamber orchestra under the direction of Eugene Minor. Then on Tuesday and Friday, ensemble performances by students and members of the faculty will be held at the school, with the festival finale on March 21 moving to larger quarters at the Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, again at 8 P.M.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Doria Treasure
description: The Bank of Rome safe recovered from the sunken liner Andrea Doria was securely at rest in the shark tank at the New York Aquarium when a hint of trouble bubbled to the surface last October.

title: THE GREAT REPRESSION
description: HOW to describe the underlying condition of the American economy? Short-term, it is obviously in a recession that started last fall; but this is the second recession since 1980, the third since 1975, and many economists believe that, even if recovery begins in the second half of this year, a fourth recession is just around the corner. It's been a long sequence of recessions and weak, aborted expansions.

title: LANDMARKING DEFENDED
description: To the Editor:

title: Joan Kranzler Will Be Bride of Dr. Joel Cary Mark
description: Mrs. Jeanne Rothar of New York and Robert Kranzler of Centerport, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Kranzler, to Dr. Joel Cary Mark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Mark of Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: THE SOUND OF WORDS FOR THEIR OWN SAKE
description: ''COME back to the way things used to be,'' says the TV commercial. ''Make it Jamaica. Again!'' I have mixed feelings about this. I am the other Jamaican, a child of the middle class, some of us white, some ''colored,'' but all of us borrowing our manners and prejudices from the English. We had servants, and tea was served every afternoon on the veranda at four o'clock. After the Second World War, Jamaica was made independent of Britain. I am sure Jamaicans don't want things to be the way they used to be.

title: REAGAN CHANGING HEALTH COST PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration is abandoning major components of its plan to hold down medical costs by spurring competition, according to Administration and Congressional sources. The plan has been opposed by major businesses, organized labor, the insurance industry and medical groups.

title: DIVINE MUSSELS
description: After almost 20 years of being berated by my husband for my hubris in thinking that I could ''make eggs'' and ''make chicken,'' I am much relieved to see that ''The Rewards of Making Mussels'' similarly attributes that godlike power to Mr. Claiborne.

title: TOURNAMENT SATURDAY
description: The 1982 Eastern Basketball Championships will be played at 1, 3, 7 and 9 P.M. Saturday at Marist College in Poughkeepsie. Bronxville and Tuckahoe High Schools are the contenders from southern Westchester this year. Tickets are $3. Last year's state champions were Mount Vernon and Tuckahoe High Schools.

title: The World in Summary; Care and Feeding For Some Exiles
description: The Reagan Administration isn't giving up on Iran. Intelligence sources have told The New York Times that the Central Intelligence Agency is still spending millions of dollars on several Iranian exile groups and hoping to counter Soviet influence (which the exiles claim is growing) in case Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic fundamentalists one day lose their grip.

title: IN INTERNATIONAL LAW, ANTARCTICA IS A TWILIGHT ZONE
description: McMURDO STATION, Antarctica - Question: What is the best place to go if you wanted to eliminate one of your in-laws and get away with it? Answer: An American station in Antarctica.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. to Pay $2 Million For 'Negligent' Forecast
description: The widows of five United States Auto Club officials who were killed in a 1978 airplane crash have been awarded $2.1 million in damages.

title: WILL SUCCESS SPOIL CIRCLE REPERTORY?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jeremy Gerard is a freelance writer specializing in theater. BY JEREMY GERARD

title: Correction
description: In ''Getting Revenge on Imitations'' (Feb. 28) the company that produces Oil of Olay, among other products, was misidentified. The Company is Richardson-Vicks Inc.

title: J.C. Stapleton to Wed Betsy Carlson in May
description: Mrs. Kenneth C. Carlson of Menominee, Mich., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Betsy Maywood Carlson, to Jonathan Carroll Stapleton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Stapleton of Little Compton, R.I.

title: ON THE ROAD TO RECOVERY
description: Every traveler wants to stay healthy. If your health is not perfect to begin with, however, you do not necessarily have to stay home. Thanks to medical science, more and more people with chronic ailments are able to vacation far away with minimal inconvenience, discomfort or fear. Depending on the affliction, they usually must be cautious about such matters as diet, altitude, access to medication and the proximity of medical facilities. Yet many people with appliances affixed to their bodies after surgery, or who must be linked to a kidney dialysis machine several times a week to cleanse their blood, have found that they can still enjoy about as much travel as anybody else.

title: LOUISVILLE A WINNER
description: Oliver Robinson scored 23 points as Alabama-Birmingham took a 19-point lead in the first half today and went on to defeat Indiana, the defending national champion, 80-70, in the second round of the Mideast Regional tournament.

title: GOAL TO RESTORE OLD TEMPLE CLOSER
description: THE oldest synagogue in Connecticut, designed 106 years ago by Hartford architect George Keller, appears destined to survive the upheavals of urban redevelopment and the economic cycles of disinvestment.

title: T.V.A. DEFERS NUCLEAR PLANTS BUT DEBATES GOES ON
description: For most of the past half-century in the mid-South, there was an almost religious belief in the growth of electric power as a measure of progress, and the generating plants of the Tennessee Valley Authority were the tabernacles of the faith.

title: Food; FROM WATER TO PAN: FRESH TROUT IS SIMPLY SUPREME; by Moira Hodgson
description: Next month trout season opens in the Northeast. At this yearly ritual, fishermen of all ages try their luck in the brooks and streams. Experienced fly fisherman and samll boys with rods and fresh worms celebrate the end of winter by trying to catch this supreme sweet fish which makes such a perfect meal for one.

title: Sports People; Restaurant Is Closed
description: Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight boxing champion, has closed his restaurant and canceled all public appearances after three persons were shot and killed on Thursday at ''Smokin' Joe's Korner'' in Philadelphia. An attorney for Frazier, a one-third owner of the restaurant, said the former champion may offer a reward for the apprehension of the two gunmen, who killed two restaurant employees and a mailman in an apparent robbery attempt.

title: HOW TO MAKE A CELLO CONCERTO
description: Composing is not always the lonely occupation it seems. Consider Donald Erb's Cello Concerto which Lynn Harrell, the American cellist, is to play this Friday with Leonard Slatkin and the St. Louis Symphony. It is fitted - like so much music of the past - not just to Mr. Erb's imagination and sense of form but to the measure of a friend.

title:
GARDENING;
A PRIMER ON GARDEN FERTILIZERS
description: BECAUSE the time is nye upon us when lawns, trees, shrubs and planting beds will require their spring application of nutrients, it is appropriate that we attempt to clarify the confusion that abounds in garden centers, with their many brands and claims.

title: LEAK CAUSED UPSTATE REACTOR SPILL, U.S. SAYS
description: A partly open valve was responsible for the accidental spill of 70 gallons of slightly radioactive cooling water at the Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory last Thursday, according to Federal officials.

title: Headliners; Texas Challenge
description: Like the good guy riding into the sunset after the rustlers have been locked up, Lee P. Brown, Atlanta's Commissioner of Public Safety, is heading for Houston. Mr. Brown, who gained attention when he led the 22-month investigation that resulted in the conviction of Wayne B. Williams for two of 28 murders in Atlanta, resigned last week to become Houston's Chief of Police. The Houston job, one of his colleagues said, would be ''a helluva challenge.'' Mr. Brown, who holds a doctorate in criminology, is credited with making dramatic improvements in police-black community relations in Atlanta. The Houston Police Department's race relations record is regarded by the Justice Department as the nation's third worst.

title: 26 Hurt in Coast Accident
description: A motorist ran a stop sign and rammed into three cars and a city bus tonight, injuring 26 persons, three critically. A Fire Department spokesman, said 15 of those hurt were aboard the Southern California Rapid Transit District bus.

title: Connecticut Housing; HEAVY HOUSECLEANERS IN DEMAND
description: IN the days before the energy crunch, the ritual known as springcleaning had already begun to lessen in importance in many households. There was no longer need to go to such lengths. Few people relied anymore on open fires or stoves for their heat. So there was little buildup of soot and grime. Oil and gas were relatively clean. Thus, regular cleaning took care of most problems.

title: LET IRELAND BE A NATION ONCE AGAIN
description: ''In Ireland over the centuries, we have tried every possible formula: direct rule, indirect rule, genocide, apartheid, puppet parliaments, real parliaments, martial law, civil law, colonization, land reform, partition. Nothing has worked. The only solution we have not tried is absolute and unconditional withdrawal.'' PAUL JOHNSON Editor The Spectator, London, 1980

title: The East Enjoying N.C.A.A.
description: College basketball teams from the Northeast have enjoyed more success in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament than in the National Invitation Tournament.

title: BROOKLYN TOPPLES ROANOKE
description: Brooklyn College's basketball team continued its surprising performance in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III basketball tournament last night by beating Roanoke of Virginia, 62-59, in a tense quarterfinal game.

title: EX-JUSTICE FORTAS TO ARGUE CASE BEFORE HIGH COURT
description: Former Justice Abe Fortas is returning to the Supreme Court to argue his first case since he resigned from the Court in disgrace 13 years ago. Mr. Fortas, now in private law practice in Washington, is scheduled to appear before the Court on March 22, and he said he was in a familiar ''period of tension'' before arguing a case.

title: A MURDER IN ARGENTINA STIRS POLITICAL ACTIVISTS
description: No one in the neighborhood here where she lived knew why she was abducted nor why she was killed. They knew only that as dusk came it was better to shut the doors and keep the children inside.

title: LEGISLATORS ALLOCATE $75,000 FOR PARKS
description: THE battles over the budget for Westchester County parks, waged since December, have ended with the Committee on Budget and Appropriations of the Board of Legislators approving a plan to restore $75,000 to parks and programs that had been threatened by budget cuts.

title: SOME CONGRESSMEN SUGGEST BRINGING THE BOYS BACK HOME
description: The merits of keeping American forces in Western Europe, a periodic concern since World War II, were getting renewed attention in Washington last week. Discussion so far has been in tentative terms, but key members of Congress insist that the United States will eventually have to tell its allies that it can no longer be counted on to spend so much in their defense and to keep troops posted abroad indefinitely.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Panda Matrimony
description: Since their arrival at the National Zoo in Washington in 1972, Hsing-Hsing and Ling-Ling, the pandas given by China, have appeared to be a compatible enough couple. But zoo officials, anxious for a baby panda, have been frustrated.

title: U.S. REJECTS LATEST VIRGINIA PLAN ON REDISTRICTING
description: The Justice Department has rejected Virginia's latest plan for reapportioning the districts for the House of Delegates because it could discriminate against black voters.

title: The Region in Summary; A New View Of the Zoo
description: They don't build zoos like they used to, fortunately. Under a plan for the renovation of the Central Park Zoo reported last week, cages and bars will be gone and moats and glass will separate the inhabitants from those viewing them.

title: J. L. Smith to Wed Leslie Henderson; J. H. Green to Wed Her Sister Barbara
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Frederick Henderson of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagements of their daughters, Leslie Camille Henderson and Barbara Whitehouse Henderson, to Jeffrey Lynn Smith and Ens. Jeffry Howard Green, U.S.N., respectively.

title: WHERE LUXURY HAS NO BOUNDS
description: Developers trying to compete in the lucrative luxury condominium apartment market here are building apartments with finishes and amenities that are probably the most sumptuous offered on a large scale anywhere in the United States.

title: MISS ZAYAK TAKES WORLD SKATE TITLE
description: In a strong finish, Elaine Zayak, a 16-year-old American, rallied from seventh place with a brilliant display of free skating tonight to win the women's title at the world figure skating championships.

title: Iowa Wins 5th Straight Team Wrestling Title
description: Iowa amassed a record 131.75 points and crowned three individual champions as the Hawkeyes won their fifth straight National Collegiate Athletic Association team wrestling title tonight.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I will be in Paris from April 2 through about April 7. Could you inform me of any special events that may be happening in Paris at that time, and also what you would recommend seeing during that period? -I.W.G., Westport, Conn. Answer:A major exhibition of Jackson Pollock paintings is currently at the Pompidou Center; the exhibition runs through April 12. A new production of ''Tosca,'' conducted by Seiji Ozawa and with costumes by Yves St. Laurent, opens at the Opera March 22 and runs through April 27. An event called Paris Fashion Show - runway models in the latest ready-to-wear from French designers - is open to the public every Tuesday from 11:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M at the Club 78 (Champs Elysees 78). An admission charge of $24 a person includes the runway show, a buffet lunch, demonstrations of makeup and hairstyling as well as an audio-visual survey of the last 30 years of fashion. Reservations may be made by writing to CIR Inc. 310 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017 (212-697-6230).

title: WHAT PEPSICO PLANS FOR SITE IN SOMERS
description: SOMERS THIS rural town of 13,000 in the hills of northern Westchester is preparing for a new role as host to a big company of the kind that made ''campus'' office parks a notable feature of the ''Platinum Mile'' from Tarrytown to Rye.

title: LATE U.S. LETTER COULD COST M.T.A. $600,000
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority may have to spend an extra $600,000 for fences to keep vandals out of subway train yards because a routine letter from a Federal agency did not arrive in time last week - a month and a half after it was requested.

title: CATHOLICS WEIGH IMPACT OF VATICAN'S NEW CODE
description: Specific details of a revised legal code for the Roman Catholic Church are emerging here at the first meeting in the United States to examine a draft of the first changes in the code since 1917.

title: The Handicap That Kills the Race
description: The withdrawal of Ned Regan from the contest for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York is more than bad news. It is an ominous sign of the importance of money in the American political process.

title: SARAH TODD GRAY BETROTHED TO JOHN L. GARRETSON
description: Judge J. Rockhill Gray, senior justice of the Eastchester Town Court and Mrs. Gray, of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Todd Gray, to John Lloyd Garretson, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Baldwin Garretson of New York.

title: Malaysia Finds Pilot's Body
description: The charred remains of an American pilot have been found in the wreckage of a helicopter missing since March 3, civil aviation authorities said today. Capt. Armit Tilgner, 49 years old, the only person on board, was on a mission to bring back a hospital patient from the interior when the chartered aircraft crashed in bad weather.

title: AUDITION: A BALLET CRUCIBLE
description: It starts with a simple plie. It may end with a rejection or with a job in a ballet company. In the case of the II International Ballet Competition preliminaries being held across the United States through April 30, it could end with a gold medal and a walk down a ceremonial staircase to a trumpet fanfare. Whether a rite of passage or final, unavoidable evidence that the work one has trained so long for will always be beyond one's reach, the audition plays an important part in the ballet dancer's life.

title: HIGH AIDE SAYS U.S. SEEKS SOVIET TALKS ON SALVADOR ISSUE
description: A senior Administration official said today that the problem in El Salvador was global in nature and that the United States should involve the Soviet Union, Cuba and other Latin American nations in the search for a solution.

title: FRESH APPROACHES TO THE BAROQUE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: R.G. MAY TO WED PIPER LEE DURRELL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Durrell of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Piper Lee Durrell, to Russell George May Jr., son of Mrs. Peggy May and the late Colonel Russell May,U.S.A.F.

title: Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant
description: New work by a young writer who's both greatly gifted and prolific often points readers' minds toward the future. You finish the book and immediately begin speculating about works to come - achievements down the road that will cross the borders defined by the work at hand. Anne Tyler's books have been having this effect on me for nearly a decade. Repeatedly they've been brilliant - ''wickedly good,'' as John Updike recently described one of them. ''Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant'' is Anne Tyler's ninth novel; her career began in 1964 with a fully realized first novel (the title was ''If Morning Ever Comes,'' and there are piquant links between it and her latest book); everything I've read of hers since then - stories, novels and criticism (Anne Tyler is a first-rate critic, shrewd and self-effacing) - has been, at a minimum, interesting and well made. But in recent years her narratives have grown bolder and her characters more striking, and that's increased the temptation to brood about her direction and destination, her probable ultimate achievement.

title: Elephantine Isle
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Times Magazine March 14, 1982
description: William Safire 14 On Language The Leak Age Russell Baker 20 Sunday Observer No Business Like Dry Cleaning Joseph Lelyveld 22 South Africa's Bishop Tutu Linda Blandford 26 The New Philadelphia Sound Fergus M. Bordewich 46 India's Embellished Images A collection of recently uncovered vintage Indian photographs reveals a forgotten artistry and photography's diverse possibilities. title: RETIRED EXECUTIVES HELP NEW ENTREPRENEURS
description: When Judith Field walked into the Manhattan office of the Service Corps of Retired Executives two years ago, , all she had was years of experience writing for a large public-relations company and the dream of starting her own business.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YONKERS ''Ican remember skating from Peekskill to Haverstraw,'' Harold Brady was saying. ''Somewhere around 1927, I think it was; yes I remember skating up and down the Hudson.''

title: BROADWAY BECKONS CONNECTICUT SHOWS
description: ELLIOT MARTIN, a Broadway producer for 20 years, spotted a production of David Mamet's play ''American Buffalo'' while visiting New Haven's Long Wharf Theater last October. ''When I originally saw 'Buffalo' at Long Wharf,'' Mr. Martin said, ''I knew it was something I liked very much and wanted to do in New York.''

title: First Title Since '46 Is Last for Franklin
description: Benjamin Franklin overcame subpar shooting to beat Andrew Jackson, 52-48, yesterday and win its first Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship since 1946.

title: PLAYBOY: ITS FUTURE NOW RESTS WITH STATE
description: ATLANTIC CITY AHUGE Playboy bunny atop the 24-story Playboy Hotel and Casino tower - it is visible for miles - distinguishes the establishment from other Boardwalk casino-hotels here. However, if Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman and his Division of Gaming Enforcement have their way, Playboy would be forced to sell out and leave town.

title: Andrea Goldenberg Wed
description: Andrea Beth Goldenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Goldenberg of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Elliot Fuller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lambert Fuller of Orange, Conn.

title: A Bid for 9-mm. Guns For L.I. Police Studied
description: The Nassau County Police Commissioner said today that he would rule next week on a request from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to allow the county's 3,300 police officers to carry 9-millimeter, semi-automatic handguns.

title: Appellate Panel Says Courts Can Rule on Pay of Chaplains
description: A Federal appeals panel here has ruled that the courts have jurisdiction to decide whether it is unconstitutional for Congress to pay salaries and expenses for the chaplains of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

title: FUTURE CONFRONTS PAST IN NEWARK
description: covered floors.

title: Susan A. Briere Will Be a Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Russell O. Briere of Richmond and New Kent Courthouse, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Anne Briere, to William Foresman Shafer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Shafer of Napa, Calif.

title: BUDGET SQUEEZE MAY HALT USE OF HAWAII TELESCOPE
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration intends to stop financing its infrared telescope atop Mauna Kea, the extinct volcano on the island of Hawaii. The telescope, a 10-foot-diameter reflector, was built by the space agency for almost $15 million.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ASPECIAL cocktail party will start at 5 P.M. today at the Harrison Conference Center on Dosoris Lane in Glen Cove. ''In fact,'' said Rabbi Lawrence Kotok, ''the word party is probably inappropriate. Perhaps we should call it a gathering to raise funds to help rebuild our temple.'' Rabbi Kotok is the spiritual leader of the North Country Temple, which was destroyed by fire in mid-February.

title: C.F.T.C.'S NO.1 DEFENDER
description: WASHINGTON AS a lawyer in private practice representing some of the nation's largest commodities exchanges, Philip F. Johnson almost inevitably found himself at odds with the policies of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission.

title: ELISA ANN BOHLEN ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Bohlen of Huntington Bay, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisa Ann Bohlen, to David deNeergaard, son of Mrs. Doris de Neergaard, also of Huntington Bay, and the late Christian F. deNeergaard Jr. A June wedding is planned. Mr. deNeergaard's marriage ended in divorce.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIAL SAYS REAGAN JOB POLICIES DO NOT DISCRIMINATE
description: Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds, answering criticism by the civil rights movement, today strongly defended the Reagan Administration's rejection of preferential hiring and promotion of members of minority groups as a means of remedying racial discrimination in employment.

title: Birdsong Ponders Frustrating Season
description: In one corner of the Nets' locker room, tucked near the rear at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, stands the dressing stall of Ray Williams. Across the room, just a few feet away, is the stall of Otis Birdsong. This arrangement is not a coincidence.

title: MINOR PARTY ONCE AGAIN HAS A MAJOR EFFECT ON POLITICS
description: When word spread that Edward V. Regan would quit the campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York and settle for seeking re-election as State Comptroller, a Conservative Party leader was asked if he would claim it as a victory.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; TRADE
description: Trade paperbacks are softcover books usually sold in bookstores and at an average price higher than mass-market paperbacks. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: There are no new hard-cover fiction best sellers this week and only one new runner-up, Robert Ludlum's ''The Parsifal Mosaic.'' ''On a dark night,'' the jacket copy reads, ''along a deserted beach on Spain's Costa Brava, a blond woman races across the sand, the sounds of the crashing surf and gunfire intermingling.

title: THE ART OF TEACHING SCIENCE
description: Lewis Thomas, M.D., who won the American Book Award last year for ''The Medusa and the Snail,'' is chancellor of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and chairman of the board of the Scientists' Institute for Public Information. This article is adapted from talk given at a conference sponsored by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation. By Lewis Thomas

title: Musical 'Lola' Due March 24
description: The York Theater Company will present ''Lola,'' a new musical by Claibe Richardson and Kenward Elmslie, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, at 2 East 90th Street, March 24 through April 10. It is based on the life of Lola Montez, a 19th-century personality, who will be played, in sequence, by three actresses: Jane White, Gretchen Albrecht and Leigh Beery. The director is John Going. Mr. Richardson and Mr. Elmslie wrote the 1971 musical adaptation of ''The Grass Harp.''

title: AS OIL FLOWS, STRAINS COME TO CAMEROON
description: The President is building himself a new palace here, breaking a 20-year tradition of aversion to the kind of prestige projects that are part of Africa's landscape, and there are other signs of change.

title: Schedule of Meetings In Council This Week
description: The City Council has scheduled the following public meetings for this week: MONDAY: Committee on State Legislation, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Housing and Buildings, City Hall, noon. TUESDAY: Full Council, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. THURSDAY: Committee on Finance, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Housing and Buildings, 250 Broadway, 23d floor, 1:30 P.M.

title: The cost of a trip
description: Offshore Fishing Boats seating up to four people rent for between $200 for a half day (about four hours) to $300 for a full day (7:30 A.M. to 4 P.M.). On split-party charters chairs cost $50 and $70, respectively.

title: Business Conditions; TV REVENUES WEAKEN
description: The growth of advertising revenues for the three major television networks slowed last year, due in large part to the effects of a strike by members of the Screen Actors Guild.

title: FOR CANADA, METRIC DRIVE INCHES AHEAD
description: Protest rallies are still held, indignant letters still appear in newspapers and the opposition Progressive Conservative Party still passes resolutions.

title: FEELINGS FOR U.S. ARE STILL WARM AMONG POLES
description: Last week Malcolm Frager, the American pianist, performed at the national philharmonic hall here, and he brought down the house.

title: U.S. IS DEMANDING RETURN OF PAPERS
description: The Justice Department is demanding the return of documents about secret electronic surveillance that were made public under the Carter Administration, contending that their disclosure would result in ''identifiable damage to the national security.''

title: Von Bulow Jury Plans 4th Day of Deliberation
description: To Newport's large Irish-American community, the third day of the jury's deliberation in the trial of Claus von Bulow for attempted murder was St. Patrick's Day.

title: By Theodore W. Libbey; Music: Debuts in Review; Swensen Plays Sonata Of Bartok for the Violin
description: Joseph Swensen, a violinist studying at the Juilliard School with Dorothy Delay, made his New York recital debut at the 92d Street Y Tuesday evening. He played works by Beethoven, Brahms, Sibelius and Sarasate in the company of Jon Kimura Parker, pianist, and essayed Bartok's Sonata for solo violin.

title: No Headline
description: In ''Being Jerzy Kosinski'' (by Barbara Gelb, Feb. 21), two dates were inadvertently given for the death of Mr. Kosinski's mother. The correct date is 1973.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ When Bill Henderson appeared at Michael's Pub a year ago, it was the first time he had sung in New York since 1965 when he was with Count Basie's orchestra. For more than a decade he had been in California working primarily as an actor in films and on television.

title: SHAW TAKES CENTER STAGE, STYLISHLY
description: HERRICKS NOW in the midst of its finest season, the Nassau Repertory Theater is keeping apace with a stylish staging of a pair of slight, one-act plays by George Bernard Shaw.

title: HAMSHO IS WINNER
description: With the middleweight division looking for new faces, two well-scarred veterans reopened old wounds today. When the bleeding and brawling was over, once again Mustafa Hamsho had scored a close decision over Curtis Parker.

title: PRAGUE'S FOAMY DELIGHTS
description: HENRY KAMM is chief of the Rome bureau of The Times. BY HENRY KAMM

title: G.D. Sherwin to Wed Cynthia Ruotolo
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph William Vollmerhausen of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Vollmerhausen's daughter, Cynthia Ryan Ruotolo, to George Dyer Sherwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sherwin of Rye, N.Y., and Fayston, Vt.

title: CHANGES IN SOCIETY BROADEN THE DUTIES OF SCHOOL NURSE
description: Adults over the age of 30 may remember the school nurse as a woman who measured height and weight, bandaged skinned knees and gave them somewhere to lie down when they had a headache. But no more.

title: CALIFORNIA LAWMAKER RESIGNING 'TO COME HOME'
description: Representative John L. Burton, a 49-year-old California Democrat who has represented the ''Golden Gate district'' for nearly eight years, has decided not to run for reelection because, he says, he ''just wanted to come home.''

title:
Stamps;
INTERPEX OPENS THURSDAY AT THE COLISEUM
description: Like the first robin, the advent of INTERPEX, arriving regularly at its destined time each year, heralds the coming end of winter's dreary days.

title: TOWN IS DIVIDED OVER BUCKLEY PLANS
description: SHARON THE name of this semirural northwestern Connecticut community, settled in 1738, was chosen, according to the current Connecticut Almanac, for its biblical connotations of well-being and abundance.

title: The World in Summary
description: The United States last week stepped up its behavior-modification effort against Libyan President Muammer el-Qaddafi, banning imports of oil from his country and restricting American exports as well. Officials said the action was taken in response to Colonel Qaddafi's continued attacks against moderate regimes and support of international terrorists, not because of any one incident.

title: YANKEES PRESSING FOR STIEB
description: Trade talks between the Yankees and the Blue Jays involving Dave Stieb, Toronto's right-hander, continued with more urgency today because of increased concern by the Yankees about the condition of Rick Reuschel's sore right shoulder.

title: REAGAN BARS PENSION FREEZE
description: The Reagan Administration today rejected a Congressional proposal to freeze for two years cost-of-living increases in Social Security payments as way of reducing big budget deficits.

title: Rose Returns to 'Penzance'
description: George Rose and Tony Azito return to the cast of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' at the Minskoff Theater Tuesday night after having worked in the film version of the Gilbert and Sullivan musical in London. During their absence, George S. Irving substituted for Mr. Rose as the Major-General and David Garrison played Mr. Azito's role of the Sergeant.

title: A Double for Colorado
description: Colorado became today the first school in collegiate skiing history to win the men's and women's national team titles the same year. The women captured the title in their event today. The men's team won the championship a week ago in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: OWNER SEEMS TO WIN IN FIGHT WITH EDITOR AT TIMES OF LONDON
description: Rupert Murdoch, the owner of The Times of London, appeared today to have won a power struggle with the newspaper's editor, Harold Evans.

title: Pamela R. Dinse Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Merrell Dinse of Shelburne, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Ruth Dinse, to G. Donald Johnston 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and John's Island, Fla.

title: Sports People; Swim Record Set
description: For the second day in a row, Vladimir Salnikov of the Soviet Union broke a world swimming record in Moscow while participating in a dual match against East Germany. Salnikov, who won three gold medals during the 1980 Olympic Games, covered 1,500 meters in 14 minutes 56.35 seconds, lowering his record by almost two seconds. On Friday he set a world mark of 3:49.57 in the 400-meter freestyle.

title: Landmarking Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: Reading and Writing; 'MY DEAREST FRANZ'
description: Elias Canetti, winner of the 1981 Nobel Prize in Literature, has just published ''Kafka's Other Trial,'' an interpretation of Franz Kafka's bizarre and voluminous five-year correspondence with his fiancee Felice Bauer, whom, as we know, he never married. Though Kafka's letters have been brought out in a bulky volume, we have no direct evidence of hers, which were destroyed. She can only be inferred through him, which has been the fate of so many women. Using the available material, I have attempted to imagine one of Miss Bauer's letters, one that gathers up several of the themes that ran through their tormented courtship. * My dearest Franz,

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S BISHOP TUTU
description: Joseph Lelyveld is the chief of The Times's bureau in Johannesburg. By Joseph Lelyveld Nearly three decades ago, Daniel F. Malan, the first South African Prime Minister to propound the doctrine of apartheid, replied eagerly and copiously to a clergyman in Grand Rapids, Mich., who asked for an explanation of the severe racial laws then being enacted. Malan, an ordained minister of the Dutch Reformed Church, never doubted he was an instrument of divine will. ''The difference in color,'' he wrote, getting down quickly to the basics of black and white, ''is merely the physical manifestation of the contrast between two irreconcilable ways of life, between barbarism and civilization, between heathenism and Christianity, and finally between overwhelming numerical odds on the one hand and insignificant numbers on the other.''

title: by Aaron Wildavsky
description: Every government needs its critics. Its inconsistencies and hypocrisies need to be exposed. When criticism does its work, supporters of a particular President and political party know more about where they have fallen down, opponents know more about whether their alternatives are likely to prove preferable, and the undecided learn more about the differences between what is and what might be.

title: Michigan Family Found Shot To Death in a Burning House
description: Five members of a western Michigan family were found shot to death today at their burning rural house, Ottawa County Sheriff's officers said.

title: The Region in Summary; A Dead End for Census Appeal
description: Numbers do lie, officials of some 50 cities and states have contended, if they come from the Census Bureau. Last week, though, the United States Supreme Court declined to hear a challenge to the bureau by New York City and State, which insist that a ''disproportionate'' number of minority residents were overlooked in the 1980 tally.

title: Headliners; Coroner Attack
description: Damned when he did, Thomas T. Noguchi, the Los Angeles County medical examiner, last week seemed damned even when he didn't. Under a gag order from the Board of Supervisors for his ''headline grabbing'' comments following the deaths of William Holden and Natalie Wood, the ''coroner to the stars'' said next to nothing while investigating the death of comedian John Belushi.

title: THEATER: 'MAGISTRATE,' PINERO COMEDY
description: Arthur Wing Pinero's ''The Magistrate,'' a popular Victorian comedy about the stuffiness of upper-crust society, is a courtroom, rather than a bedroom, farce. The title judge is as guilty as the accused that he is sentencing; everyone has been disorderly. At the Hartman Theater, in a production directed by Edward Hastings, and starring Jerome Kilty and John Cullum, the play is a case of denatured Feydeau.

title: 'TALLEY'S FOLLY' AT THEATER FORUM
description: PLAINFIELD YOU will love ''Talley's Folly,'' now being given a perfect production at the New Jersey Theater Forum, but remember it was written by Lanford Wilson.

title: JULIE ANDREWS: PRIM AND IMPROPER
description: Broke and starving, she offers to sleep with her landlord in exchange for a meatball. Unable to find work as a singer, she begins to masquerade as a man, becomes successful as a fe-male impersonator, and decides she likes life better as a ''man'' anyway. Except that then she meets a real man she wants to jump into bed with, but he thinks she/he is not only male but also romantically involved with the aging homosexual she/he lives with, and - well, things get very complicated.

title: Other Business; CHILDREN'S ALLOWANCES: WHAT THE ECONOMISTS PAY
description: Every Sunday, Sara Popkin, eight years old, gets 50 cents. Her brother Neil, 11, gets $1. Their dad gives it to them for what he calls ''nonspecific expenditures.''

title: NEW FIREHOUSE GALLERY
description: GARDEN CITY THE exhibition of sculpture by Long Island and New York State artists at the new Firehouse Gallery is an affirmation of the gallery's interest in the medium as an art form. The gallery is larger and more comfortable than the old one and can handle the more assertive dimensions of sculpture more easily.

title: LAWYERS TO PROCEED ON ASBESTOS SUITS
description: ATTORNEYS say they will continue to press 300 complaints brought by workers at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton against asbestos manufacturers and suppliers - despite the acquittal Monday of the same defendants in the first of the suits.

title: F.T. Charney to Wed Jocelyn Tucker in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Tucker of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jocelyn Raina Tucker, to Felix Thomas Charney, son of Mrs. Helen P. Charney and Felix S. Charney, both of Westport.

title: Kathleen L. Lynch Bride Of Gordon W. McCoun
description: Kathleen Lucretia Lynch, an office manager for National Advanced Systems in New York, a subsidiary of National Semiconductor Inc., in Santa Clara, Calif., was married yesterday to Gordon Wickersham McCoun, an investment officer with the international services division of Citibank, N.A., in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alanson B. Houghton in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: STRIKING JERSEY TEACHERS PESSIMISTIC
description: Teachers have completed the second week of a strike here with little hope that a bargaining session scheduled for Sunday will produce a new contract.

title: Prison Strip Search Banned
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit has declared unconstitutional the stripping and searching of prison visitors in Iowa and ordered the state to stop the practice. The court held Thursday that, without probable cause, the searches were illegal and the state no longer could order them based on ''unwarranted suspicion.''

title: NEWARK MUSEUM: THE WORLD THROUGH A GRAY FLANNEL FILTER
description: NEWARK TO SOME, east may be east and west may be west, but to Robert Sussna, whose photographs are on view at the Newark Museum, they are points of departure for personal interactions between himself and landscape.

title: Elephant Goes Wild After a Performance
description: A circus elephant that had just towed a stagecoach loaded with children went berserk and ran trumpeting out of the arena, slamming into a showgirls' dressing room and trying to enter a shower stall.

title: Officer Kills Upstate Man
description: A 20-year-old Troy man was fatally wounded early today by an off-duty police officer, the police said.

title: ARE WE POOR COUNTRY COUSINS?
description: TELEPHONING me from Manhattan, the secretary of a prominent editor once inquired, ''How's the weather out there?'' Her manner seemed so terribly pompous that I couldn't resist informing her that here on Long Island the seasons were the exact reverse of those in New York City.

title: STATE SEEKING NEW LAWS TO CURB SWEATSHOPS
description: The New York State Industrial Commissioner has recommended the abolition of all industrial homework and passage of tough, protective legislation to curb sweatshops in the garment industry.

title: U.S. ELECTION COMMISSION IS RULED ABUSIVE
description: A judge has ruled in Manhattan that the Federal Election Commission abused its power by harassing a minor candidate's fund-raising committee in a primary campaign for President.

title: Jill Leslie Goldman Bride Of Lawrence A. Richards
description: Jill Leslie Goldman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Goldman of Pennington, N.J., and Lawrence Albert Richards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Richards of Dexter, Me., were married yesterday in Bernardsville, N.J. Rabbi Morton Rosenthal performed the ceremony at Stronghold, a mansion at the Gill/St. Bernard School.

title: GENERAL IS DECLARED WINNER IN GUATEMALAN VOTE
description: The Guatemalan Congress chose General Angel Anibal Guevara tonight to be the country's next President. The one-house legislature voted 39 to 13 to name General Guevara, who finished first in last Sunday's presidential election, after the deputies certified the results of the popular vote. The formal vote by Congress was necessary because the general did not win an absolute majority of the 1,074,381 votes cast.

title: Bridge; A CAST OF CHARACTERS
description: In the past half-century, a regiment of bridge authorities has studied the technique of bidding and play in minute detail. But very few have explored the character weaknesses that make their impact on the game constantly. Bridge is played by human beings, and their personal attitudes and foibles affect their performance.

title: PAUL THEROUX'S SUBWAY ODYSSEU
description: Paul Theroux illustrates so vividly that New York City's rapidtransit system is indeed a unique place where one can expect anything to happen. And it did. On Jan. 26, at the 23d Street station, waiting for the No. 1 local train, at 10:45 P.M., my boyfriend and I became engaged! Somehow, no matter how many terrible things are said about the subway, we will always harbor a soft spot for this particular form of transportation. ANNE MIKULAS PATRICK CHANG New York City

title:
DANCE;
DANCE CORPS TO PERFORM 9 WORKS
description: PURCHASE ON a recent snowy afternoon, Dean Carolyn Brown of the dance divison at the school of the arts, sat in her office at the State University of New York here and talked about the upcoming performances of the 16-member Dance Corps. The student company, which attracted capacity crowds last year, will present nine works this month in the theater of the Center for the Arts.

title: The Region in Summary; One Less Worry For Transit Users
description: Equipment failures may continue to disrupt New York City transit service, but breakdowns in labor negotiations should not - this year, at least. The State Assembly last week approved a bill that provides for binding arbitration in the event of an impasse in upcoming labor talks.

title: PARIS PUSHES DRIVE FOR ATOMIC ENERGY
description: On a ridge overlooking the English Channel west of here, an eerie incandescent blue glow can be seen in enclosed manmade ponds that contain radioactive water.

title: GREEK ORTHODOX TALKS WITH VATICAN IMPERILED
description: The Greek Orthodox Church is threatening to withdraw from unity talks with Roman Catholics because, it says, the Vatican is continuing efforts to undercut Orthodox influence.

title: E.P.A. SUED OVER DUMPING OFF FLORIDA COAST
description: A southwest Florida county has filed suit in Federal District Court here charging that Federal officials failed to carry out environmental protection regulations.

title: CHINA'S AIRLINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Fuel Bill Cut By More Than a Third
description: It's incredible that your newspaper would give such a subjective and negative ''splosh'' to an obviously beneficial program.

title: FALSE ASYLUM
description: GERMAN WRITERS IN SOVIET EXILE, 1933-1945 By David Pike. 448 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $29.50.

title: SPLIT ON POLISARIO IS THREAT TO O.A.U.
description: The decision last month by the Organization of African Unity to admit the Marxist-led Polisario Front as its 51st member has opened a split that some African officials say threatens the organization's survival.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: WHEN the four Republican candidates for Governor appeared together in Newtown last Tuesday night for a debate sponsored by the Republican Town Committee, State Representative Mae S. Schmidle of Newtown, serving as moderator, decided to break away from the usual introductions larded with biographical detail.

title: Major News in Summary; SENATOR WILLIAMS EXITS UNREPENTANT
description: HAVING apparently convinced few of his colleagues that he stood before them a man wronged, Harrison A. Williams Jr. resigned from the United States Senate last week.

title: Collioure
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Synagogue Gets Show of Yiddish Satire
description: The Yivo Institute for Jewish Research will present ''A Yiddish Tapestry: An Evening of Humor, Poetry and Satire,'' with Rita Karpinowicz and David Rogow next Saturday in the community house of the Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street.

title: Power Agency's Paper Is Criticized by Mayor
description: The State Power Authority was wrong to distribute its own newspaper to counter reporting in The Staten Island Advance on a proposed power plant, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: REACTION IS MIXED ON AVIATION PLAN
description: On Jan. 28, J. Lynn Helms, the former test pilot who heads the Federal Aviation Administration, put forward an all-encompassing plan for modernizing the nation's system of air traffic control, starting as soon as possible, at a cost of up to $15 billion by the year 2000.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN COVERT ACTIONS IN LATIN REGION
description: President Reagan has approved clandestine operations by the Central Intelligence Agency against what the Administration describes as Cuban arms supply lines in Nicaragua and elsewhere in Central America, according to Administration officials and Congressional sources.

title: IN AN AMERICAN EMPEROR'S COURT
description: THE IMPERIAL ROCKEFELLER A Biography of Nelson A. Rockefeller. By Joseph E. Persico. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.50.

title: Gene L. Wexler Fiance Of Adrienne A. Price
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel V. Price of Cherry Hill, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Adrienne Alane Price, to Gene Lawrence Wexler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Wexler of Hicksville, L.I.

title: THE MYSTERY OF THE DROPOUT COMPOSER
description: Some day the brain doctors may be able to explain to us the final mystery: why certain people are driven to build, or paint, or write, or compose - and why they go right on wanting to do so until the lid is snapped shut on them. Just the other day word arrived in the mail that Efrem Zimbalist, the violinist, had completed a new work at age 92. Tell the truth now: did you even know he was still alive, let alone that he was a composer? What drives such people? Soon, we may know. By giving the patient the right pill or jiggling his electrodes just so, neurologists will be able to turn on the faucets of creativity in any talented person. Books will be completed on schedule, scores will be turned in when promised, poems will no longer lie unfinished in desk drawers. Artistic block will have gone the way of the smallpox virus and the Black Death.

title: READERS REPLY ON ABORTION
description: The article ''Teen-Agers' Abortions Increasing on L.I.'' states that abortions have increased in Nassau County since 1971 from 5,827 to 7,399 in 1980. It is readily apparent that this is off target by several thousand abortions.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; It's All Right To Come Out Now
description: The word is out. The world did not end last week, even though all nine planets in the solar system and the Moon were on the same side of the Sun at the same time.

title: 'NEW FEDERALISM,' YES, BUT REAGAN'S PROPOSAL NEEDS MAJOR REVISION
description: President reagan has unveiled a plan for what he calls a ''new federalism,'' a major redistribution of responsibility for the financing and administration of domestic programs among the Federal and state governments. While the concept of sorting out functional and financial responsibilities between the national Government and the states has a great deal of merit, the President's proposal has the appearance of being hastily conceived and poorly designed, and is in need of substantial revisions.

title: RENTING A BOAT IN MAJORCA
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is chief of the Madrid bureau of The Times. BY JAMES M.MARKHAM

title: THE CURSE ON CIGARS
description: BARRE, Pa. ''W HAT this country needs,'' Representative James L. Nelligan told Congress late last year, ''is a good five cent cigar ... and no excise tax.'' Maybe so, but evidently that is not what the country wants. Cigar sales today are at their lowest point since 1930, when people first began keeping track. They are down 42 percent from the 1964 high point of 9 billion cigars sold. Authorities on the subject say nothing is going to revive the market before this decade is out. And it is in the lower price ranges that the blight is felt most.

title: Mary Behrends And David Clark To Wed June 19
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick V. Behrends of Westwood, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Jane Elizabeth Behrends, to David Joseph Clark, son of Mrs. Raymond C. Ploetz of New York and Minneapolis and the late Warren F. Clark.

title: Around the Nation; Farm Workers to March For the Minimum Wage
description: Five thousand people will march next week from Brownsville to San Juan, 55 miles away in extreme south Texas, to draw attention to the plight of farm workers, according to Cesar Chavez, the president of the United Farm Workers.

title: A PROFIT IS INSURED
description: THE INVISIBLE BANKERS Everything the Insurance Industry Never Wanted You to Know. By Andrew Tobias. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: The Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $15.50.

title: REPUBLICAN PARLEY BURIES DISCORD TO BACK REAGAN
description: Supporters of President Reagan, at an annual high-level but informal Republican conference, resisted critics of his budget today and voted to hail ''the progress to date'' of his economic program.

title: TOUGHER PENALTIES SOUGHT IN ABUSE OF PATIENTS
description: New York State's special prosecutor for nursing homes, health and social services has recommended new legislation that would establish criminal penalties for those convicted of physically abusing or endangering the welfare of patients in nursing homes.

title: German Book Week Set for N.Y.U. Center
description: The fourth annual German Book Week, sponsored by Deutsches Haus at New York University and the German Booksellers Association, will start next Friday and run through March 28 at 42 Washington Mews, near Eighth Street and University Place.

title: The World in Summary; New Evidence Of Chemicals
description: A couple of weeks ago, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger accused the Soviet Union of using chemical weapons in Afghanistan and said there was ''very good evidence'' to back up the allegations. Pressed for the evidence, a Pentagon aide checked high and low, then conceded ''I've got nothing.''

title: THE BETTER ALTERNATIVE TO TAX LEASING
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: DISTRUST SPLITS FAIRFIELD AND UPSTATE
description: ''THERE are so many Connecticuts,'' Odell Shepard wrote in 1939 in his book ''Connecticut Past and Present.'' Each town, he wrote, tended to be ''isolated, self-contained, independent.'' The towns were alike only in their ''deep and well-founded distrust'' of new ideas that they believed were likely to ''corrupt their morals, confuse their intelligence or, worst of all, lead on to some increase of expense.''

title: Art View; A TRUE MUSEUM RECORD; WASHINGTON
description: Not the least of the many interesting things about the National Museum of American Art - the division of the Smithsonian Institution that until recently was called the National Collection of Fine Arts - is that it conceives its role to be that of ''a museum of record,'' the record in this case being the history of American art. Exactly what this means is spelled out for us by Harry Rand, the curator and chairman of the museum's department of 20th-century painting and sculpture, in his introduction to the catalogue of the current exhibition called ''Recent Trends in Collecting'' (through March 28). At a time when museums are once again being urged to sell off works of their own collections in order to pay for new acquisitions or to meet increased costs, Mr. Rand's words are worth pondering.

title: Topics More Stations, and Service Channels
description: People who consider television a cultural wasteland may be perplexed by the decision of the Federal Communications Commission to add several thousand more stations. These new broadcasters, with a range of only a dozen miles or so, would use already assigned frequencies, but only between the areas covered by more powerful stations.

title: DANCE: MARIA BENITEZ AND THE TRIO FANTASIA
description: The theatrical showcase that Spanish dance companies used to have so regularly now seems a thing of the past. One reason is that there are fewer visiting dance companies from Spain.

title: Gerulaitis Tops Connors In Two Sets at Brussels
description: Vitas Gerulaitis defeated Jimmy Connors, 6-2, 7-5, in a semifinal match of the Belgian Indoor Tennis Championship today and will play Mats Wilander of Sweden in the final Sunday.

title: The World in Summary; Another First For Poland
description: The Communist Governments in Eastern Europe had always managed to fend off censure of their regimes by the United Nations Human Rights Commission. But three months of martial law in Poland snapped the commission's patience and last week it called on the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to make a ''thorough study of the human rights situation in Poland'' and issue a ''comprehensive report.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; The Bottom Line On Ocean Mining
description: Some 150 nations are sailing to an April 30 rendezvous with a ''law of the sea'' treaty, but without the United States. The Reagan Administration, flying the flag of free enterprise, last week offered treaty amendments that would scrap the global cartel, which the treaty would establish to curb exploitation of the sea bed's mineral wealth, in favor of a course allowing as much mining by private concerns as appears profitable.

title: A Career Betrayed
