description: The Senate's reluctance to judge the fitness of its members - a tradition but rarely a virtue - was at least understandable in the case of Harrison Williams of New Jersey. He was one of the friendliest members ever in good standing in that tight club, a powerful figure who had suddenly hit trouble.

title: JOYCEAN CELEBRATION AT YALE
description: THE 100th anniversary of the birth of James Joyce, Feb. 2, 1882, is being celebrated with an exhibition of his manuscripts, correspondence, family photographs, clippings, first editions and other memorabilia in the Beinecke Rare Book Library of Yale University, New Haven. The exhibit will be on view until March 28.

title: PAUL THEROUX'S SUBWAY ODYSSEY
description: I was disappointed that Paul Theroux made no mention of the Guardian Angels in his article. I always hope, fiercely, to see them when I ride a late night train. To be on the platform at 14th Street when the No. 6 screams in on a slant, and to see the Angels crouched low at the doors as they signal each other the length of the train - this is theater as well as protection. JULIA M. GOGGIN New York City ------

title: BIGGER BUCKS FOR SECURITY BUT HOW MUCH AND FOR WHAT?
description: WHILE Congress and the Pentagon continued to argue last week over numbers - specifically, President Reagan's $1.6 trillion, five-year defense buildup - 150 members of Congress sponsored a resolution calling upon the superpowers to ''pursue a complete halt to the nuclear weapons race.'' The Week in Review asked Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Colorado, Barry Blechman of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, and Fred C. Ikle, Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, to go behind the numbers and talk strategy. Excerpts of their discussion, with Leslie H. Gelb, national security correspondent for The New York Times, Richard Halloran, a correspondent in The Times's Washington bureau, and Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, follow.

title: ABOUT THE MUTILATED HALF
description: THE HIDDEN FACE OF EVE Women in the Arab World. By Nawal El Saadawi. Translated and Edited by Dr. Sherif Hetata. Foreword by Irene L. Gendzier. 212 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. Paper, $8.25.

title: SMALL IS STRONG AMONG COMMUNITY WEEKLIES
description: When Philadelphia police captains approach retirement, they are often assigned to the Roxborough neighborhood, where life and police work are quiet and unpressured, said Richard McCuen, publisher of the neighborhood's weekly newspaper, The Review. That changed when the new captain, an ambitious young man, launched an anticrime campaign with The Review as a major player.

title: TULSA LOSES, 78-74
description: Ricky Frazier scored 20 points to lead Missouri to a 73-69 victory over Marquette today in the second round of the Midwest Regional tournament.

title: A PICK OF GARDENS ON THE CONTINENT
description: FRED WHITSEY is the editor of ''Popular Gardening,'' an English weekly magazine. By FRED WHITSEY

title: Sports People; U.S. Skiers Excel
description: From Sweden to Czechoslovakia, in Nordic and Alpine World Cup skiing, United States competitors exceled yesterday.

title: Michael Barker to Wed Rosina Bateson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Adams H. Nickerson of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Nickerson's daughter, Rosina Otis Bateson, to Michael Barker of Washington. The wedding is planned for June in Cold Spring Harbor.

title: A TORONTO SPECIALTY: ESKIMO STONECUT PRINTS
description: R.V. DENENBERG is a writer based in the Hudson Valley. BY R.V.DENENBERG

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The book of the future? Back in 1971, one million copies of trade paperback books were sold in this country; by 1980, the number had risen to 44 million. This year, the "trades" will account for approximately 20 percent of the whole book market; by 1985, probably between 30 and 40 percent; by 1990, as much as 60 percent.

title: Topics; MORE STATIONS, AND SERVICE; Gracious Gas
description: Bored with romance novels, fatigued by ''Brideshead Revisited,'' but still hungry for gracious living? You'll find it at the gas stations of New Jersey, where a price war is raging.

title: Navy Tests New Submarine
description: The Navy successfully fired a Trident missile today from the U.S.S. Ohio, the first of a new class of Trident submarines. The 550-foot submarine was submerged 50 miles off the Florida coast for the test, said Dottie Ellingson, a spokesman at Patrick Air Force Base, and the dummy warhead hit a target area near Ascension, in the southern Atlantic Ocean 500 miles south of the equator. The Trident missile has a range of 4,500 to 6,900 miles.

title: Erik Murkoff to Wed Heidi Eisenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard F. Eisenberg of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Eisenberg, to Erik Murkoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Murkoff of Williamsville and Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: March 14, 1982
description: NONFICTION THE BLACK BOOK. Edited by Ilya Ehrenburg and Vasily Grossman. 16 THE GERMANS. By Gordon A. Craig. 10 GERMAN WRITERS IN SOVIET EXILE, 1933-1945.

title: Crafts
description: TENAFLY SCORES of vehicles fueled by imagination have converged at America House Gallery here this month for a show entitled ''Mythic Machines: A Mixed Media Motorcade.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; When Practice Isn't Perfect
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has long complained that the policy of admitting to the Supreme Court bar lawyers ''of good moral and professional character'' had come to mean admitting any lawyer who applies. The split between him and his colleagues was evident last week as the Chief Justice took the issue one step further.

title: Title to S. Connecticut
description: Southern Connecticut State won the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastics League team championship Friday night, taking first place in the parallel bars and the horizontal bar. It marked the eighth straight year that Southern Connecticut has either taken the title outright or tied for it.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; 'Head Shop' Laws Allowed to Stand
description: Are cocaine mirrors and hashish pipes merely accessories to illegal drug use or are they enticements? Arguing the latter, lawmakers in many states have tried to regulate ''head shops'' that offer such items. Last week, the Supreme Court strengthened their hand when it declined to hear challenges to laws banning the sale of drug paraphernalia in New York's Westchester County and in Nebraska.

title: A GOLDEN VOICE ON LINE
description: WHEN Clyde Newman speaks, people listen. And the reason that passengers on the Long Island Rail Road listen to Mr. Newman announce station stops is not so much what he says, but how he says it.

title: Lincoln
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
A PRIMER ON GARDEN FERTILIZERS
description: BECAUSE the time is nye upon us when lawns, trees, shrubs and planting beds will require their spring application of nutrients, it is appropriate that we attempt to clarify the confusion that abounds in garden centers, with their many brands and claims.

title: Miss Lively To Be Bride
description: Michael Lively of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. James King of Munich, West Germany, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Elizabeth Lively, to Eric Winston Edmonson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Edmondson of La Canada, Calif.

title: Washington; REAGAN AND MONROE; by James Reston
description: When President Reagan and President Mitterrand of France met the other day in the White House to discuss the problems of Central America, they did so under a portrait of James Monroe, the fifth President of the United States.

title: NOTEBOOK: MARIN LISTENS IN SILENCE
description: WHEN Jean S. Harris stood trial in the Westchester County Courthouse, she became a presence in the courtroom, directing barbed remarks toward the prosecutor, taking notes, passing them occasionally to her lawyer as he questioned witnesses, and otherwise attracting attention, often while the jury was in the room.

title: Television Weekly
description: Detective Story ''You've got to deal with the craziness of New York. If you don't have a sense of humor you can't exist here,'' said Salvatore (Sonny) Grosso, a local police officer for 20 years. He and his detective partner, Eddie (Popeye) Egan, became famous when they found a $3.5 million heroin cache in a French television personality's car. That incident prompted the movie ''The French Connection.'' And now, Mr. Grosso, who also made a brief appearance in this and other films, has created - he submitted the idea and wrote the outline - a half-hour comedy series about New York police officers, ''Baker's Dozen.'' It begins Wednesday on CBS at 9:30 P.M. and stars Ron Silver and Cindy Weintraub.

title: HOPE OF OIL KEEPS CHINA AND JAPAN AT ODDS ON ISLETS
description: Until the late 19th century, when Japan took over, this city was the capital of an independent kingdom, owing distant allegiance to China.

title:
Antiques;
OF POSTERS, POSTCARDS AND PHOTOS
description: IN RECENT years, more and more people have been paying increasing amounts of attention - and money - for objects that were ''meant to be seen by people who did not mean to see them.''

title: Yellowstone
description: To the Editor:

title: PAUL THEROUX'S SUBWAY ODYSSEY
description: Paul Theroux's Subway Odyssey

title: ORNETTE COLEMAN'S PROPHETIC JAZZ
description: Ornette Coleman, whose first new album in more than two years is being released this week by Antilles records, has consistently been ahead of his time as a jazz saxophonist, composer, and bandleader. Many musicians who are generally perceived to be ahead of their time can more accurately be said to be living in the present - they are gifted or sensitive enough to be able to understand and distill the essence of what is going on right now. But Mr. Coleman has been genuinely visionary, and this has presented problems for him. How does an artist who really anticipates the future come to terms with audiences that live in the past?

title:
Comment;
HOW NOT TO BEAT LAST YEAR'S SALES
description: THE retailer's exhortation to the troops has always been, ''Beat l ast year!'' Maybe it's not emblazoned over employee entrances, but i t's there as a daily subliminal reminder, in the same way that it's i nvisibly watermarked on all internal-use retail store forms. And p erhaps now, the words lurk somewhere in computer storage, too.

title: MAPLE SUGERING DELIGHTS HUNDREDS IN THE BRONX
description: In a clearing in the Bronx, with sap dripping into the pails and syrup boiling in the wood-smoke morning, one of the city's more unlikely events was celebrated yesterday - a Maple Sugar Festival.

title: Jean L. Nichols To Be July Bride
description: Mrs. Jane R. Nichols of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jean Louise Nichols, to Edgar Victor Turner 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Victor Turner Jr. of Darien, Conn.

title: THE I.M.F.'S IMBROGLIO IN AFRICA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya IN three African countries in less than a year, there have been strikes, or demonstrations, or riots, all pointing to an unlikely villain: the International Monetary Fund.

title: DEFINING THE NEEDY AND DISTRIBUTING THE PAIN
description: The effects of cuts in welfare, food stamps and other benefits for thousands of families have been hotly debated. At a public hearing last week, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, told Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services: ''Your proposals declare war on working welfare women. You really like to abuse these people, don't you?''

title: AMBITIOUS DISHES AT A BRASSERIE
description: BRASSERIE ST. GERMAIN in Manhasset, for many years an attractive and comfortable place for informal dining, has recently restyled its dinner menu along more ambitious culinary lines. A number of elaborate dishes, some suggesting a nouvelle cuisine influence, are now listed. This review is largely an assessment of that menu.

title: Senate Votes Panels' Funds
description: The Senate has cut annual expenses for 10 committees by a total of $357,000 and increased expenses for eight by a total of $409,000. Cuts were voted Thursday for Committees on Agriculture, Appropriations, Banking, the Budget, Commerce, Governmental Affairs, the Judiciary, Senate Rules, Small Business and Intelligence. Increases were voted for Committees on the Armed Services, Energy, the Environment, Finance, Foreign Relations, Labor, Veterans' Affairs and American Indian Affairs.

title: PEDRO RAMOS'S BIGGEST LOSS
description: PEDRO RAMOS wears his Yankee cap as proudly in prison as he did in Yankee Stadium. In his heart, he was a Yankee even before the big trade, the most wonderful day of his life. And he is still a Yankee today, serving a three-year sentence for possession of drugs and a weapon.

title: ADOPTION-CASE BILL IS TIED UP IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY THE attempt by a 63-year-old Calverton widow to adopt the 6-yearold foster child she has raised from infancy is being played out in the Legislature here, where questions are being raised about the wisdom of overturning a decision by a county social-service agency.

title: Invasion
description: To the Editor:

title: A FIRST LOOK AT FALL' 82; BY Carrie Donovan
description: Shakespeare hangs heavily over Milan, almost as if ghosts of Montagues and Capulets and all the dukes of Venice have been fluttering overhead, whispering suggestions into designers' ears and egos. Then, a time warp, and the faint feel of the 1920's, a sense of nostalgia for ladies clad in sharply soignee chemises, swoopy cocoon wraps or the fanciful ballet costumes of Leon Bakst, the great costume and set designer.

title: EVERYTHING DIFFICULT
description: THE GERMANS By Gordon A. Craig. 350 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95.

title: Mailbox; The Reality Of College Sport
description: To the Sports Editor: It is unfortunate that the speech given by Howard R. Swearer on the state of college sports (''An Ivy League President Looks at College Sports,'' The New York Times, Feb. 21, 1982) has received a hasty negative reception. The need for change in the area of college sports does not disappear with the simplistic rejection of his ideas.

title: COUNTY PREPARES TO ENFORCE LAW ON HEAD SHOPS
description: IN the wake of last Monday's action by the United States Supreme Court, Westchester officials are preparing to enforce the county's law banning the sale of ''drug paraphernalia.'' The Court refused to entertain a challenge to the State Court of Appeals ruling upholding the law.

title: Antonia Palfrey Plans Nuptials
description: Antonia Ford Palfrey, a recreational therapist at the North Fairfield Geriatric Center in Fairfield, Conn., and Richard Allan Perrini, a free-lance photographer in Northampton, Mass., plan to be married April 17 in Southboro, Mass. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mrs. John Gorham Palfrey of Brookline, Mass., mother of the bride-to-be.

title:
Business Forum;
WHY THE MICROBE MAKERS GOT STUNG
description: JUST a year or so ago, there were skeptics who said that all you n eeded to start a biotechnology company was a venture capitalist, a m icrobiologist and a mouse. But that didn't stop investors from b idding up stock prices almost threefold and providing the capital n eeded to expand the emerging biotechnology industry by an order of m agnitude.

title: Asbestosis
description: I read with shock attorney Robert E. Sweeney's article ''Asbestosis'' (Feb. 21) and its reference to my bill, H.R. 5224, which would provide workers' compensation for victims of asbestos-related diseases. Mr. Sweeney charged that my bill ''would neatly pass along to the taxpayer the duty and economic burden of compensating the injured worker and his widow.'' It appeared obvious to me that Mr. Sweeney had not seen my bill, and indeed, he had not. The bill would provide for a compensation trust fund paid for by industry, not the taxpayers.

title: EMPLOYERS INITIATE YOUTH-JOB DRIVE
description: CITING cutbacks in Federal financing and the uncertain economy, a number of major employers in the county have initiated ''Summer Jobs for Youth, Campaign 1982.''

title: Around the World; Rebel Leader's Execution Announced by Suriname
description: Army commanders announced today that Wilfred Hawker, a captured rebel leader, was executed at dawn. The report came as troops loyal to Suriname's leader, Lieut. Col. Daysi Bouterse, celebrated their suppression of an attempted coup by rightist insurgents.

title: READERS REPLY ON ABORTION
description: We believe that the recent article ''Teen-Agers' Abortions Increasing on Long Island'' gives a slightly skewed picture of the real situation re teen-age pregnancy, and though the number of pregnant teen-agers who terminated their pregnancies was on a steady rise since 1971, it decreased in 1980. The percentage of decrease in Suffolk County was greater than in Nassau, but still it decreased in both counties. In Suffolk County we have over 121,000 females between the ages of 10 and 19. Surely our statistics are significant to a ''Long Island'' story.

title: Robert S. Arnold; A Sweet Sign of Spring
description: When the days warm up to between 40 and 50 degrees but the temperature drops to below freezing at night, the sap starts to run in New England's maple trees, a sign that spring is near and that travelers will be heading into the region to see sap collected and then boiled in sugar houses.

title: Robert Shull to Wed Emily Alice Swartzentruber
description: The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. A. Orley Swartzentruber of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Alice Swartzentruber, to Robert M. Shull, son of Dr. Gilbert M. Shull of Bernardsville, N.J., and the late Karen Lunde Shull.

title: Mailbox; Aiding Brooklyn
description: To the Sports Editor: Whatever Fred Lebow may profess to know about the question of amateur versus professional running (''Politicians Should Run With Amateurs,'' The New York Times, Feb. 28, 1982), he certainly doesn't know about Brooklyn.

title: HOYAS OVERCOME FOUL PROBLEMS
description: Coach John Thompson of Georgetown had a hunch last Tuesday and began preparing his Hoyas to play Wyoming before the Cowboys had beaten Southern Cal in the first round Thursday night. Like many of Thompson's decisions, it was contrary to the standard procedure of most coaches, who will never admit to predicting a game's outcome, let alone practicing on the strength of such predictions.

title: MICHELLE A. MCCARTHY, T.J. MURPHY TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent D. McCarthy of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Aileen McCarthy, to Thomas James Murphy, son of Mrs. John J. Murphy of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Prof. Murphy, who was Dean of the School of Law at St. John's University.

title: TAX DEFAULTS CAST A PALL
description: Increasingly in the pentagonal-shaped enclave of northern Brooklyn known as Bedford-Stuyvesant, there is deep concern about the many residents, particularly the aged, who are threatened by the loss of their property because they cannot pay the taxes.

title:
Antiques;
A HISTORIC SETTING FOR ANNUAL SHOW
description: WETHERSFIELD FEW settings for antiques shows are as much in keeping with their subject, both inside and out-of-doors, as is that of the Old Wethersfield Antiques Show.

title: Stage View; A LITTLE WORKSHOP WIZARDRY
description: One of the things that startles me these days is the way people who make movies - screenwriters, directors, producers - keep referring in interviews to the problems they're having with their second and third acts. ''We haven't got a third act yet, but we'll find it'' is very much the lingo of the moment, along with ''Our first and third acts are solid, but we've got to beef up the second for sure.''

title: Major News in Summary; The Evidence Keeps Flying Out the Window
description: ''An official of the U.S. Embassy told me that they needed to demonstrate the presence of Cubans in El Salvador. They gave me an option. They said I could come here or face certain death. All my previous statements about training in Ethiopia and Cuba were false.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 28 about New York State's tentative contract with the Civil Service Employees Association incorrectly described the raises that had been negotiated. They are 9 percent for the first year, starting April 1, and 5 percent in both April and September of the remaining two years.

title: P.S.C. APPROVES CONSUMER PROTECTION RULES
description: New regulations to protect consumers in their dealings with utilities have been approved by the Public Service Commission amid charges that the commission misinterpreted the law the regulations were supposed to implement.

title:
Speaking Personally;
A LOVE SONG FOR DA (SA GAELGE)
description: AFTER a brief reunion with my father recently, I wrote, as an exercise for a creative-writing class, an essay about him. It was printed in a local newspaper, and it went something like this:

title: MONEY PROBLEMS PLAGUING SOVIET, FIGURES INDICATE
description: Evidence is growing that the Soviet Union is having a cash-flow problem with the currencies used in international trade.

title: A THREAT BY JORDAN RAISES TENSIONS IN WEST BANK
description: Jordan has announced that it will prosecute Palestinians living on the West Bank for treason, a capital crime, if they cooperate with Israeli-sponsored village leagues.

title: Northeastern Strikes Again
description: The morning after one of the most important basketball games a team from Northeastern University has ever won, Coach Jim Calhoun and three of his Huskies were changing a flat tire on their rented car. Afterward, the Huskies smiled at the thought. They are accustomed to life's small indignities by now.

title: POPE TELLS OF HIS CONCERN OVER CZECH CHURCH
description: Pope John Paul II called attention this week to the continuing difficulties of the Roman Catholic Church in Czechoslovakia as he greeted five prelates from that country.

title: THE WILLIAMS CASE IS SETTLED BUT QUESTIONS ON F.B.I. LINGER
description: As William H. Webster began his fifth year as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation a few weeks ago, he could look back on a number of accomplishments. He had, it seemed, helped create nothing less than a ''new F.B.I.,'' an agency that has generally abided by strict investigative guidelines and given new emphasis to white collar criminals and organized crime.

title: Sports People; Rose Still Aching
description: Pete Rose of the Phillies missed the first 11 days of spring training because of a muscle pull in his lower back. On Friday, he put on his uniform and took batting practice for the first time. Yesterday, he reported stiffness and soreness in his body and was excused from practice by Manager Pat Corrales.

title: Janie Beth Marcus Wed
description: Janie Beth Marcus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Marcus of Linden, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan Grund Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Phillips of Cranford, N.J. Rabbi Irving Schreier performed the ceremony at the Shackamaxon Country Club in Scotch Plains, N.J. The bride is a senior officer with the Union County Probation Department in Elizabeth, N.J. Mr. Phillips is a director of production for Polo by Ralph Lauren in New York.

title:
Camera;
ON TAKING PICTIRES OF WILD ANIMALS
Police Say Boy Tried Theft to Assist Parent
description: An 11-year-old boy who saw his mother worrying over letters threatening to turn off the heat at the family's apartment took a hammer and tried to steal the $1,000 she needed, according to the Chicago police.

title: Frances Chick Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Franklin Chick of Dover, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Caroline Chick, to Alexander Hamilton Spaulding, son of Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Augustus Spaulding of Manchester, Mass.

title: 26 Food Places Cited For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 26 food establishments last week for violations of the city's Health Code. It also listed 14 others that reopened after correcting earlier violations and seven that were closed for failure to do so. VIOLATIONS A & A Restaurant, 1109 Ave. of the Americas. La Villa, 1330 Broadway. La Crepe, 1974 Broadway. The Other End, 149 Bleecker St. Kwik Time Deli, 115 Church St. Happiness Always, 739 St. Nicholas Ave. White Wave Restaurant, 93 Second Ave. Bagel Nosh, 377 Fifth Ave. The Bagel Shop, Penn Station, Seventh Ave. Arcade. Sunset Coffee Shop, 520 Eighth Ave. Old Fashioned Donuts, 680 Eighth Ave. Your Place, 348 Ninth Ave. Paul's Pizzeria, 827 10th Ave. Beef Burger Fair, 110 E. 23d St. Molly McGuire's, 150 E. 53d St. Grecian Coffee Shop, 245 W. 29th St. Bartholomew's, 10 W. 32d St. Sabarro's, 22 W. 34th St. The Bagel Eatery, 162 W. 34th St. Asuwon Restaurant, 40 W. 36th St. Nu Topps, 150 W. 36th St. Casa Dario, 165 W. 47th St. McCann's Bar, 140 W. 51st St. Court View, 52 Court St., Brooklyn. A & S Pizza, 1794 Utica Ave., Brooklyn. Alston's Lounge, 143-06 Liberty Ave., Queens.

title: Employees Weigh Wage Cut
description: Golden West Airlines employees have agreed to a one-week pay deferral and are considering a company request for an immediate 10 percent wage cut.

title: Savings Banks
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''A Plan to Save the Savings Banks'' (Feb. 28), almost every article on the plight of both the banks and the real estate business stresses the problem of the banks being committed to low interest mortgages while paying much higher rates to depositors.

title: Around the World; China Again Warns U.S.  On Arms Sales to Taiwan
description: China's Foreign Ministry, in a new warning to the Reagan Administration, said today that Chinese-American relations would suffer ''grave consequences'' if the United States insisted on making ''long-term'' arms sales to Taiwan.

title: Sports People; Eddie Mathews Ill
description: Eddie Mathews, whose 512 career home runs helped him gain a spot in the Baseball Hall of Fame, is suffering from tuberculosis, according to the team physician for the Oakland A's. Dr. Thomas E. Richmond said that the former third baseman's condition is treatable and curable and that Mathews could be back at his job as a batting instructor in a month. Mathews, who will be treated at a hospital near Scottsdale, Ariz., underwent tests this week after X-rays detected a spot on his lung. He spent most of his 17-year career with the Braves in Boston, Milwaukee and Atlanta.

title: ISLANDERS SUFFER FIRST SHUTOUT IN 2 YEARS
description: The Islanders not only lost a hockey game tonight, but they also were shut out for the first time in more than two years when the Los Angeles Kings defeated them, 3-0, at the Forum.

title: TAXES ARE MEANT TO BE PAID-AND TO PAY OFF
description: 'The taxing power of Government must be used to provide revenues for legitimate government purposes. It must not be used to regulate the economy or bring about social change. We have tried that and surely we must be able to see it doesn't work.' -Ronald Reagan, State of the Union Message on Economic Recovery, Feb. 18, 1981

title: Guides
description: To the Editor: I was amused by letter-writer Judith Smith's dismay that Dena Kleiman in her ''Jamaica Getaway'' (Travel, Jan. 24) advised against using guides at Dunn's River Falls. I wish I had read the article before our stay in Jamaica during Christmas week.

title: New York Political Notes; CUOMO GAINING BACKING OF ANTI-KOCH COALITION
description: A labor-Liberal Party-minority coalition, similar to an alliance attempted in last year's mayoral election, is shaping up for Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and against Mayor Koch in the Democratic gubernatorial primary.

title: STAGE: GURNEY'S 'THE MIDDLE AGES'
description: The plays of A.R. Gurney Jr. have been seen on New York stages for more than a decade now, but 1982 is beginning to look like the watershed year of this writer's career. His newest work, ''The Dining Room,'' is an extended-run success at Playwrights Horizons, and now a 1977 comedy, ''The Middle Ages,'' is receiving its local premiere at the Ark Theater Company in SoHo.

title: TALLYHO IN AN IRISH ACCENT
description: STEVEN RATTNER is a Times correspondent based in London. BY STEVEN RATTNER

title: FUNNY, WIS, AND TRUE
description: DINNER AT THE HOMESICK RESTAURANT By Anne Tyler. 320 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.50.

title: Raoul Wallenberg
description: To the Editor:

title: New and Noteworthy: Paperbacks
description: The warrior's art. The fierce-looking chap practicing swordsmanship in the print to the right may soon be one of 1982's best-selling authors. He's Miyamoto Musashi (1584-1645), a Japanese samurai who killed all his opponents in more than 60 contests by the time he was 30. He then retired to a mountain cave to formulate a philosophy of ''the Way of the Sword,'' which he expounded in a book called ''Go Rin No Sho.'' Since 1974, the Overlook Press has sold 110,000 hardcover copies of it in an English translation called ''A Book of Five Rings'' ($12.95). This week it is issuing 100,000 copies of a $5.95 trade paperback edition.

title:
Investing;
FEAR A FLOOD? HOW TO BUILD YOUR ARK
description: CRASH: It's a chilling word, and the thought that the economy might s ink into something akin to the 1930's experience has provoked a s pasm of apprehension across the country in the past few weeks.

title: Politics; WHO WILL TAKE WILLIAMS'S SEAT?
description: TRENTON THE resignation of Harrison A. Williams Jr. from the United State Senate on Thursday has given Governor Kean another tough decision to make on top of the budget decisions that have occupied most of his first two months in office.

title: INSIDE A HOME FOR THE ELDERLY
description: COUNTY hospitals are old structures with worn-out floors and tired walls. The men and women in them, like the buildings, are ghosts of their former selves. Many have no relatives, and no one comes to see them except the aide who brings the food trays or helps them dress.

title: THE EVOLUTION OF STEVE REICH
description: Nothing better illustrates the volatility of fashion in the world of so-called ''serious'' music than the sudden acceptance of Steve Reich -and of the similarly minimalist composer with whom he is inevitably paired, to their common despair, Philip Glass. Only a few years ago, both Mr. Reich and Mr. Glass and their respective ensembles were confined to a few downtown galleries, performance spaces and modernist museums - as well as their well-worn circuit of European radio stations and galleries. Now Mr. Reich is overwhelmed with orchestral commissions, and Mr. Glass seems to be composing operas for everybody in sight (not American opera companies, of course, but they are almost always years behind the times).

title: GARBAGE DUMPS CLOSE TO CAPACITY
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT is facing a garbage paradox: Within four years, the state is going to run out of space in which to bury its wastes, and the only alternative on the drawing boards, garbage-to-energy incineration plants, has been stymied at every turn because too few towns will promise to supply their garbage.

title: HAPPY CHANDLER ON THE ROAD TO THE HALL OF FAME
description: A.B. (Happy) Chandler, who was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame last Wednesday was commissioner of baseball from 1946 to 1951. This article was prepared with the editorial assistance of John B. Holway. Mr. Holway is a baseball historian and author of the book ''Voices From the Great Black Baseball Leagues.'' By A.B. (HAPPY) CHANDLER

title: AT 68, GRAND MARSHAL OF THE PARADE
description: ''IT'S a day in which the Irish celebrate their culture, religion and love of freedom,'' Brother Charles B. Quinn was saying. ''It heralds the coming of spring. The parade itself is quite an event in New York - the gaiety of the marchers, the flags, the stirring pipes.''

title: 6 KILLED IN ARIZONA COLLISION OF TANKER AND CIVILIAN PLANE
description: An Air National Guard aerial tanker on a refueling flight collided with a light, civilian airplane over the desert today, destroying both planes and killing at least six people, including the entire tanker crew, officials said.

title: Business Conditions; WHY CARS DON'T SELL
description: While economists generally agree that recovery, when it comes, will be led by a revival of sorts in consumer spending, they add that bigticket items that have usually been the foundation of past rebounds are not likely to show much growth this time.

title: ELEPHANTINE ISLE
description: To the Editor: The article on the Oberoi Hotel in Aswan, Egypt, brought back many happy memories.

title: Back in Time in Scotland
description: ''We try to take our passengers back 30 years to preserve the standards of service of that time and to offer a very memorable holiday.'' So says David N. Dean of Classique Sun Saloon Luxury Coaches in Paisley, Scotland. Mr. Dean restores old buses, most of them dating from the 1940's and 50's, and uses them for tours of Scotland and its islands, ranging from three days to the Cowal Peninsula for $82 a person to eight days to the Hebrides for $360 a person.

title: Queens Captures Title In C.U.N.Y. Track Meet
description: Courtney Mapp won the 60-yard dash in 6.33 seconds and the 440-yard run in 53.24 to lead Queens College to the team title with 144 points in the City University track and field championships yesterday at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium.

title: ADOPTION LAW EXPLAINED TO CASEWORKERS
description: IN 1978, two years before the new adoption law was written, Cheryl Bradley wrote a comprehensive guidebook on the legal aspects of freeing foster-care childen for adoption. Now, to help child-welfare workers with the obligatory paperwork, family assessments and preparation for court appearances, the White Plains lawyer is on the road explaining the complex procedures.

title: The Region in Summary; Kean Floats First Budget Over Trenton
description: Candidate Thomas H. Kean promised to lower taxes and reduce state spending. Governor Thomas H. Kean proposed a $6.37 billion budget last week that did neither.

title: Best Sellers; NONFICTION
description: 1 2 8 JANE FONDA'S WORKOUT BOOK, by Jane Fonda. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An exercise book for women, seasoned with the film star's philosophy of physical well-being. 2 3 19 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Humor in cartoons and verse. 3 1 14 A FEW MINUTES WITH ANDY ROONEY, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Atheneum, $12.95.) Reflections on contemporary life by the journalist and television commentator. 4 4 5 WITNESS TO POWER, by John Ehrlichman. (Simon & Schuster, $17.50.) The gossipy memoirs of one of President Nixon's chief advisers. 5 6 8 AT DAWN WE SLEPT, by Gordon W. Prange. (McGraw-Hill, $22.95.) A fresh account of the events culminating in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. 6 10 5 WHEN BAD THINGS HAPPEN TO GOOD PEOPLE, by Harold S. Kushner. (Schocken, $10.95.) Comforting thoughts from a Massachusetts rabbi. 7 8 12 THE WALK WEST: A Walk Across America 2, by Peter and Barbara Jenkins. (Morrow, $14.95.) A newlywed couple's adventures on a trek from Louisiana to Oregon.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary
description: After a year of impatiently sharpening pencils, Senate conservatives have begun to check off items on their ''social agenda.'' Early this month, the Senate approved legislation limiting busing for school integration and the authority of Federal courts on the issue. Last week, by a vote of 10 to 7, the Senate Judiciary Committee became the first full Congressional panel to endorse an anti-abortion constitutional amendment.

title: ABRAMS OFFERS ORGANIZED-CRIME BILL
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams has proposed that the Legislature create a new category of crime designed to make it easier to prosecute those involved in organized crime.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE People keep coining new terms for the various generations of moderndance choreographers. The urge is understandable when a week of modern dance such as this presents itself.

title: The World in Summary; The Power Of the Few
description: Charles Haughey, Ireland's Prime Minister from December 1979 to June 1981, won the post again last week -but at a cost many observers considered uncomfortably high.

title: The Nation in Summary; Inflation Drop: Can It Outlast The Recession?
description: White House strategists initially hoped their unyielding ''strategy of patience'' would keep Congress drafting conflicting budget alternatives until Reaganomic recovery proved them unnecessary. Last week, they faced up to more immediate concerns. Even the welcome drop in producer prices was a reminder of how steep the recession had slid and of its threat to future prosperity. And President Reagan was given the rare chance to hear direct criticism of his economic policies, in a meeting with spokesmen for the major business corporations - many of whose officers were among candidate Reagan's prime supporters.

title: BY Barbara Delatiner; ST. PATRICK'S DAY
description: In the mid-19th century there were almost 2,000 Irish immigrants living in Nassau County. To show how these new Long Islanders celebrated their ancient holiday of St. Patrick's Day, the Old Bethpage Village Restoration today will mark the event with period music, Gaelic storytelling, the preparation of caraway seed cake and a meeting of the Erin Benevolent Association - all this from 1 to 5 P.M. at the village's Noon Inn. The restoration is on Round Swamp Road in Old Bethpage and admission is $2.75; for children, $1.50 (Nassau residents $2.25 and $1.25 respectively).

title: ILLINOIS ELECTION TO RAISE CURTAIN ON 1982 BATTLES
description: The 1982 elections start here Tuesday, as the Illinois primaries record the first effects that redistricting and recession will have on the politics of a year the Democrats no longer fear.

title: BY William Safire
description: The Leak Age KIMBLE MEAD

title: Around the World; Italian Premier Wins A Vote of Confidence
description: The squabbling parties of Italy's fiveparty coalition Government rallied behind Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini today, giving him an easy victory in a vote of confidence over his housing policy.

title: CONCERT: MINNESOTANS PLAY MOZART AND SIBELIUS
description: By JOHN ROCKWELL

title: New Jersey Guide; MARCEAU IN RED BANK
description: The name Marcel Marceau is synonymous with mime, an art that cannot be fully appreciated without being seen live. ''In 1953, I got my first glimpse of Marcel Marceau and I was overwhelmed,'' one critic wrote decades later. ''I had no idea that mime could be so deeply, so passionately, impressive, so wildly funny.''

title: New Jersey Journal
description: REPAIRING the diseased hearts of some of the poorest children on earth has always been one of the most prideful accomplishments of the Deborah Heart and Lung Center in Browns Mills, near Fort Dix.

title: U.S. EYES NEW SITE TO DUMP WASTES IN L.I. SOUND
description: THE United States Army Corps of Engineers is considering a plan to open a new site at the western end of Long Island Sound for the underwater disposal of 80,000 cubic yards of materials dredged from Mamaroneck Harbor. Other dredged ''spoils'' may be dumped there in the future, according to the plan.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: STUDY FINDS LITTLE THREAT IN LAKE ERIE DRILLING
description: The Army Corps of Engineers, which is expected to decide soon whether to allow drilling for natural gas beneath Lake Erie, has concluded that the drilling would pose little threat to the environment.

title: Elan I. Zingman, Miss Leith to Wed
description: Doris McCordic Leith of Winnetka, Ill., and Donald Leith of Denver have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Leith, to Elan I. Zingman, son of Noah Zingman of New York and Montreal and the late Mrs. Zingman.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have got to get costs under control and demonstrate we are buying efficiently.

title: CONSUMER RATES
CREATING A LITTLE BIT OF IRELAND IN THE BACKYARD
description: THE pond in front of our house reflected the gray winter sky. The water level was up because the leaking dam had been repaired and the flow in and out was just about even. Back to normal, yet I felt something was incomplete in this pleasant setting. A big piece of sculpture on the far bank of the pond was what I originally had in mind but nothing suited, and I could not envision what would look good there. After I thought about it for a long time, what was needed slowly occurred to me; it was a dormant inspiration that had origins in Ireland, and I was surprised and elated when it finally surfaced.

title: THE SCHUBERTS AND THE NEDERLANDERS HAVE A REVIVAL
description: Suddenly everybody in show business has become aware of what is being called ''the third force'' on Broadway. On March 3 it was announced in The Times that Jujamcyn Theaters had puchased the Eugene O'Neill Theater. The closing is expected to take place next month, which means that Jujamcyn will have five glittering baubles - the O'Neill, the Martin Beck, the Ritz (currently being renovated and expected to reopen in the fall), the St. James and the ANTA (which Jujamcyn has just renamed the Virginia).

title: QADDAFI ENDS 4-DAY AUSTRIA VISIT
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, ended a four-day official visit here today after a series of meetings with Austrian leaders that stirred strong domestic criticism and the displeasure of the Reagan Administration.

title: Sound; CURING SONIC CHAUVINISM
description: The mail basket is spilling over again, messing up my desk. So let's skim a couple of questions off the top. Q. My record player discriminates against women. Whenever a soprano hits a high note, the sound becomes fuzzy. I know it must be the record player because it doesn't happen when I play the radio.

title: KEYS FISHING
description: ROBERT KARNIOL is a business journalist based in Montreal. BY ROBERT KARNIOL

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ORLANDO
description: GLENN R. SINGER is a staff writer for The Post in West Palm Beach, Fla. By GLENN R.SINGER

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 6 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 2 5 7 MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $13.95.) Blackford Oakes's quest for a mole in the C.I.A. takes him to Russia. 3 2 21 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 4 4 17 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 5 3 6 THE DEAN'S DECEMBER, by Saul Bellow. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) During a deathbed vigil in Rumania, a college dean from Chicago realizes some truths about his own land. 6 6 6 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $14.95.) A woman caught between the clashing ambitions of two brothers during the springtime of this century. 7 7 26 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 8 15 19 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel.

title: A Correction
description: An incorrect picture accompanied the Long Islanders feature in last week's Long Island Weekly. Ron Alexenburg of Woodbury, founder of Handshake Records and the subject of the interview, is pictured above.

title: Cable Car Fare Rises to $1
description: A ride on the century-old cable car system here will cost $1 beginning Monday. Besides doubling the fare, the city is also installing such modern enhancements as a farecollecting robot that takes only Susan B. Anthony dollars.

title: Another Ruttman Sets Pace
description: Joe Ruttman was just 7 years old in 1952, the year that his brother, Troy, became the youngest winner of the Indianapolis 500. It's been nearly 20 years since Troy, the eldest of the Ruttman brothers, retired from racing, and now it's Joe who is carrying on the family tradition.

title: CONSIDER A BILLION GERMANS
description: HEADBIRTHS OR THE GERMANS ARE DYING OUT By Gunter Grass.Translated by Ralph Manheim. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book.136 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95.

title: KITE SHOOTS 67-132 TO TAKE INVERRARRY LEAD BY STROKE
description: Tom Kite, the current star of the professional golf tour, continued his superb play today. The red-haired Texan, who won the Bay Hill Classic last Monday, took the lead today in the second round of the Inverrary Classic with a round of 67 that included no bogeys.

title: NEW WESTBURY MALL DEBATED
description: WESTBURY A New step in the application of a developer to build a giant new shopping center here is expected this week. The center would be constructed on the south side of Old Country Road off Ellison Avenue, and the existing Ohrbach and Fortunoff stores would serve as focal points. Many residents, business people and officials have expressed opposition to the plan.

title: FEARS ABOUT DEFICIT IMPERIL EFFORT TO IMPROVE WEAPON ACQUISITIONS
description: Officials in the Defense Department say that the process by which the United States acquires weapons must be substantially improved and excess costs drastically reduced. Otherwise, they say, the public and Congress are likely to turn against the Reagan Administration's ambitious five-year program of increased military spending.

title: A New Nuclear Strategy While I share Lawrence Beilenson's and Samuel Cohen's concern with certain asymmetries between the United States and Russian arsenals as permitted under SALT II, I find little evidence to support their conclusion that the United States arsenal is inferior to that of the Soviet Union (''A New Nuclear Strategy,'' Jan. 24). Each side retains advantages and disadvantages relative to the other. For instance, the Soviet Union does retain an overall advantage in missile-throw weight. However, this advantage is more than offset by United States superiority in total warheads deployed and greater warhead survivability as a result of more diverse United States strategic force deployments.
description: I concur with the authors in their assessment that growing instabilities in the nuclear equation are caused by the spread of nuclear weapons, and serve to increase the prospects for nuclear war by accident. However, I fail to see the value in a United States strategy that relies on mobility and concealment in order to protect our society.

title: JAMES JOYCE-THE MUSIC OF HIS WORDS ON DISK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Kresh is a contributing editor of Stereo Review, where he reviews both popular and classical records, and is writing a book about spoken word recordings. By PAUL KRESH

title: CHINESE DOCTORS VISIT U.S. UNDER YALE PROGRAM
description: THROUGHOUT his childhood in China, it was common to step over the bodies of the dead and dying in the streets, recalled Dr. John McLean Morris, a professor at Yale University.

title: Photography View; THE 'FASHIONABLE' FIGURE
description: It seems paradoxical that fashion in general and fashion photographers in particular should be fascinated with the nude. Fashion, customarily defined, has to do with the adornment of the body, nudity with the absence of adornment. Yet one has only to scan recent issues of Vogue or Harper's Bazaar to see how important the naked body has become to the purveyors of contemporary style.

title: Correction
description: An incorrect picture accompanied the Connecticut Housing article in last week's issue. Raphael Podolsky, a legal aid lawyer in Hartford who was quoted in the article, is pictured above.

title: The Region in Summary; A Tough Week For Republicans
description: Edward V. Regan wasn't the only Republican candidate who bowed out last week. Caught in a ''misstatement'' that cost him his major endorsements - and his credibility -Bruce M. Caputo ended his campaign for the United States Senate.

title: Miss Douglis, S. M. Davis Are Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Avron Douglis of Silver Spring, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carole Anne Douglis, to Stephen Marshall Davis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Davis of Madison, Conn.

title: SOME QUINTESSENTIAL BRITISH GARDENS
description: RONALD BLYTHE is the author of ''The View in Winter: Reflections on Old Age.'' His other works include the anthology ''Places'' and ''Akenfield,'' the classic study of English village life. By RONALD BLYTHE

title: The Week in Business; PRODUCER PRICES AND THE PRIME RATE FALL
description: Producer prices showed their first decline in six years. The Government index dropped one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the first decline since a drop of two-tenths of 1 percent in February 1976. The White House hailed the drop as a clear sign that inflation was coming down. Private economists, however, said it also reflected the severity of the current recession.

title: Jamie Lee Goldring Engaged to Dr. Bruce R. Ross
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen A. Goldring of Kings Point, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jamie Lee Goldring, to Dr. Bruce R. Ross, son of Mrs. Stanley Ross of Kings Point and Lawrence Rubin of New York.

title: MEMPHIS STATE TOPS WAKE FOREST
description: North Carolina, unable to break away from upset-minded James Madison, used the clutch play of its all-America forward, James Worthy, at the end to earn a 52-50 victory in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's Eastern Regional.

title: Earl B. Humes, 66, Innovator In Opening Children's Camps
description: Earl B. Humes, an educator and an innovator in the development of children's camps, died Thursday at White Plains Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived in White Plains and Paul Smith's, N.Y.

title: EL SALVADOR DISPELS APATHY AT PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON FACULTY members, students and professional workers at Princeton University are coming out strongly against United States intervention in El Salvador with a flurry of political activism rarely seen on this traditionally conservative campus.

title: WILLIAM RUECKERT TO WED FLEUR MARKS
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Marks of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Fleur Alison Marks, to William Dodge Rueckert, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Rueckert of Hanover, N.H.

description: BEN A. FRANKLIN is the Middle Atlantic correspondent for The Times BY BEN A.FRANKLIN

title: Dance View; THE DNAGER OF TRYING TO EQUATE BALLET WITH BUSINESS
description: Art has been about creativity. Star-struck, some would say it was even about glamour. Boardroom statistics, until now, have rarely interested the average dancegoer, certainly not the hardcore fan. Times are changing. The little old ladies in tennis shoes who show up at stockholders' meetings may soon be turning up to debate the future of a ballet company.

title: INVITATION TO MOSCOW TO NEUTRALIZE OUR DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: READERS REPLY ON ABORTION
description: The article reported 45 abortions performed on females under 15 and 83 on 15-year-olds, as recorded by the Nassau County Health Department for 1980.

title: NICARAGUAN YOUTH IS RETURNED BY U.S.
description: A Nicaraguan who dismayed the Reagan Administration on Friday by recanting assertions of outside interference in El Salvador was turned over to the Nicaraguan Embassy early today.

title: ON BASKETBALL SLOWER THAN MOLASSES
description: IT'S time to take a stand. I enjoy slowdown basketball games and I'm not afraid to admit it. In fact, chances are that you, too, would prefer the more leisurely pace of slowdown basketball if only you gave it a chance.

title: BULLETS DEFEAT KNICKS
description: Paul Westphal scored 19 points in his debut with the Knicks last night, but it was not enough to offset a second-half collapse that led to a 109-99 victory by the Washington Bullets at Madison Square Garden.

title: NYAMBUI CAPTURES 2 TITLES
description: Suleiman Nyambui of the University of Texas-El Paso won the mile and two-mile titles in the National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor track championships for the third time in four years today, and the Miners captured the team championship for the third year in a row.

title: STOMPING ON CAMELOT
description: THE KENNEDY IMPRISONMENT A Meditation on Power. By Garry Wills. 310 pp. Boston: Atlantic/Little, Brown. $14.95.

title: Environews
description: the Association of New Jersey Environmental Commissions - since 1973, will resign in July. The association was founded in 1968 to educate community, environmental and health officers on how to advise local and county governments on ecological matters and to influence statewide issues.

title: Headliners Fat Chance
description: The ''I Love New York Diet'', co-authored by consumer advocate Bess Myerson and literary agent Bill Adler, may have been recommended by ''leading doctors from Maine to California,'' as its jacket blurb claims.

title: A NEW NUCLEAR STRATEGY
description: Mr. Beilenson and Mr. Cohen conclude their article with the sentence: ''The best hope of preventing nuclear war lies in accepting our nuclear age, instead of persisting in a hopeless effort to deny it.''

title: METS SHOWING POSITIVE SIGNS
description: ''This isn't a transition year for the Mets,'' Nelson Doubleday said, leaning back in his second-row box seat at Al Lang Stadium. ''Last year was the transition year. This year, we're competitive.''

title: SRI LANKA
description: To the Editor: In his informative article ''Sri Lanka, the Resplendent Isle'' (Travel, Feb. 14), Colin de Silva writes of the island's ''hot, tropical climate.''

title: Antiques View; A MARKETPLACE BAROMETER
description: A number of the most prominent antiques dealers are reporting increased sales and a willingness among their clientele to pay higher prices for the wares they offer. This was revealed in a survey conducted for the National Antique & Art Dealers Association of America, Inc., by Albert Sack, the antiques dealer who is a vice president of the association and of Israel Sack, Inc., the firm his father founded. Mr. Sack queried 20 members of the association about their business in the second half of 1981 when the recession began to take its toll on the art and antiques market. Many of the responses are surprisingly optimistic, and many, not surprisingly, were critical of the auction houses.

title: Dining Out; WHEN DINNER SURPASSES LUNCH
description: WESTPORT LIKE Cinderella's coach, many restaurants that are sparkling and charming by night seem to turn into pumpkins by day. Rocco's is one example of this. Diners would be best advised to go for dinner, not for lunch.

title: JAZZ: A TRIBUTE TO DUVIVIER
description: Since George Duvivier became the bassist in Lucky Millinder's orchestra 40 years ago and, shortly afterward, sold his first arrangement to Jimmie Lunceford's orchestra, he has built a very solid reputation as one of the most capable and versatile bassists in contemporary music. The esteem in which Mr. Duvivier is held both by jazz enthusiasts and by his fellow musicians was indicated by the enthusiasm of the sellout audience that filled Loeb Auditorium for a ''highlilghts in jazz'' tribute to the bassist Thursday evening and of the instrumentalists who came to play with and for him.

title: Hampton; BREAKING BARRIERS IN PRINTMAKING By HELEN A. HARRISON EAST HAMPTON
description: ONLY a couple of decades ago, artists who made prints tended to work alone, isolated from the creative mainstream by their involvement with the technical and mechanical aspects of their discipline. They also had to contend with peer prejudice against multiples, a viewpoint voiced by Franz Kline to the critic Thomas Hess in 1955:

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Festival Trio Offers Mozart and Stravinsky
description: Another bright new chamber ensemble surfaced March 6 at the 92d Street Y, this time, the Festival Trio with David Singer, clarinet, Benjamin Hudson, violin and viola, and Patricia Michaelian, piano.

title: NOW, THE ELECTRONIC NEWSLETTER
description: city rush-hour traffic.

title: HOT POTATOES TO HOLD ONTO
description: One of our favorite vegetable stories involves the so-called ''common potato.'' Legend has it that Sir Walter Raleigh once returned to Ireland from Virginia and carried with him several potatoes, which he proceeded to plant and which flourished in his garden. When they had reached maturity, he dug up a few and presented them to Queen Elizabeth's kitchen. A misunderstanding cook tossed away the tubers and served her majesty a platter of leaves. It is certainly no legend that we regard the potato - in almost any form, sauteed, deep-fried, pureed, tossed into a stew or made into a salad - as one of nature's greatest inventions. There are few vegetables that have more virtues. Potatoes are delectable served hot or cold, but the flavor of a potato depends to a great extent on the flavors and textures of the foods with which it is combined. Put it in league with a garlic-tinged sauce, a chopping of parsley, chives or scallions, or a puree of leeks or other vegetables, and there is a flavor explosion of the most refined and delectable sort. We thought of this recently in creating a series of luncheon or supper dishes with baked potatoes as a base. From childhood we have found stuffed baked potatoes, with a topping of cheese, irresistible. Why not, we wondered, blend them with an assortment of savory ingredients such as shrimp, ground pork with rosemary, or oysters and those Creole vegetables, onions, green pepper and celery? The results were all to the good. These stuffed vegetables can easily serve as appetizers before a meal or, taken on their own, can just as easily constitute a meal - a light supper, say - by themselves. Pommes de terre aux crevettes (Baked potatoes with shrimp) 4 large Idaho baking potatoes, about half a pound each 1/2 pound raw shrimp in the shell 3 tablespoons butter 1 cup coarsely diced fresh mushrooms 2 tablespoons dry Sherry wine 1/4 cup heavy cream Salt, if desired Freshly ground pepper A few drops of Tabasco 1 tablespoon freshly grated Parmesan cheese. 1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. 2. Arrange the potatoes on a baking sheet and place them in the oven. Bake one hour to one hour and 15 minutes or until done. 3. Meanwhile, shell and devein the shrimp. Cut the shrimp into small cubes. 4. Heat one tablespoon of the butter in a saucepan and add the shrimp and mushrooms. Cook, stirring, about one minute. Add the wine and stir. Remove from the heat. 5. When the potatoes are done, slice off the top of each one, about half an inch from the top. Carefully scoop out the center of each potato bottom to make a ''boat'' for stuffing. Put the scraped-out potato pulp into a saucepan or bowl and mash well and uniformly. Add this to the shrimp mixture. Add the cream and one tablespoon of butter and cook briefly, stirring. Add salt and pepper to taste and a few drops of Tabasco. Blend. 6. Fill the potato boats with the mixture, piling it up and smoothing it over. 7. Arrange the potatoes, stuffed side up, on a baking dish. Sprinkle with cheese. Melt the remaining tablespoon of butter and pour it over the potatoes. Place in the oven and bake 15 minutes. Yield: Four servings. Pommes de terre charcutiere (Baked potatoes stuffed with pork) 4 large Idaho baking potatoes, about half a pound each 5 tablespoons butter 1/4 cup finely chopped onion 1/4 cup finely chopped celery 1/3 pound very lean ground pork 2 teaspoons crumbled leaf sage or half a teaspoon ground Salt, if desired Freshly ground pepper 1/3 cup milk or use half cream 3 tablespoons finely chopped parsley 1/2 teaspoon paprika. 1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. 2. Arrange the potatoes on a baking sheet and place in the oven. Bake one hour to one hour and 15 minutes or until done. 3. Meanwhile, heat one tablespoon of the butter in a saucepan and add the onion and celery. Cook, stirring, until wilted. Add the pork, sage, salt and pepper to taste and cook, stirring down with the side of a heavy metal spoon to break up any lumps, until meat loses its raw look. 4. When the potatoes are done, slice off the top of each one, about half an inch from the top. Carefully scoop out the center of each potato bottom to make a ''boat'' for stuffing. Put the scraped-out potato pulp into the saucepan and mash well and uniformly with the meat mixture. Add the milk, three tablespoons of the butter, salt and pepper to taste and parsley and blend thoroughly. 5. Fill the potato boats with the mixture, piling it up and smoothing it over. 6. Arrange the potatoes, stuffed side up, on a baking dish. Melt the remaining tablespoon of butter and brush the tops of each potato with it. Hold a sieve over the top of each potato and sprinkle the paprika through the sieve onto the tops of the potatoes. 7. Return the potatoes to the oven and bake 15 minutes. Yield: Four servings. Pommes de terre aux huitres (Baked potatoes with oysters) 4 large Idaho baking potatoes, about half a pound each 4 tablespoons butter 1/4 cup finely chopped onion 1/4 cup finely chopped green pepper 1/4 cup finely chopped celery 1/4 cup heavy cream Salt, if desired Freshly ground pepper 1/8 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg 1/4 cup finely chopped scallions 1/2 pint shucked oysters 1 tablespoon fine fresh bread crumbs. 1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. 2. Arrange the potatoes on a baking sheet and place in the oven. Bake one hour to one hour and 15 minutes or until done. 3. Meanwhile, melt one tablespoon of the butter in a saucepan and add the onion, green pepper and celery. Cook, stirring, until wilted but still crisp. 4. When the potatoes are done, slice off the top of each one, about half an inch from the top. Carefully scoop out the center of each potato bottom to make a ''boat'' for the stuffing. Put the scrapedout potato pulp into the saucepan and mash well and uniformly with the green pepper mixture. Add the cream, two tablespoons of the butter, salt and pepper to taste, nutmeg and scallions. Blend well. 5. Cut each oyster in half (if they are large) and add them to the potato mixture. Cook, stirring, over moderate heat for about two minutes. 6. Fill the potato boats with the mixture, piling it up and smoothing it over. 7. Sprinkle the top of each potato with bread crumbs. Arrange the potatoes, stuffed side up, on a baking dish. Melt the remaining tablespoon of butter and pour it over the crumbs. Place in the oven and bake 15 minutes. Yield: Four servings.

title: AUSTERITY TAKES THE GLOW OFF AN EGALITARIAN IDEAL
description: The education cutbacks in the budget announced by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher last week came as no surprise, but the figures were no less painful for being expected. As in the United States, Britain's colleges and universities are facing severe austerity measures. On the average, they will lose 17 percent in Government funding over the next three years, which means that many departments and hundreds of professors will have to be dropped, and as many as 20,000 students will be turned away from college in the next three years.

title: 3 Children Seized in Beating
description: Three girls - two of them 9 years old and one 12 - have been taken into custody on charges of beating and knocking an elderly crippled woman out of her wheelchair because they ''wanted to get some money,'' the police said today.

title: Greece to Protest to Turkey
description: Greece will protest what it said were five violations of Greek airpsace over the island of Kastellorizo by Turkish fighter planes ''in the past 24 hours,'' a Government spokesman said Friday. The announcement came after a special meeting of the Cabinet defense committee, at which Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou presided in his capacity as Defense Minister.

title: THE DERBY ISN'T SHY OF TALENTED HOPEFULS
description: ONLY a month ago, neither crystal balls nor chart books had much to o ffer those who spend their winters trying to divine the winner of t he Kentucky Derby the following May. In Florida, the winter-book f avorite had twisted an ankle; in New York, faint-hearted runners s hipping up from Pennsylvania were winning the early stakes for D erby hopefuls; in California and the Southeast, a few sprinters tookt urns beating each other in races that usually point out superior c olts.

title: Union Making Concessions To Chicago Transit Authority
description: Members of the Amalgamated Transit Union, by a 10-to-1 margin, have voted to give up $73 million in pension contributions, guaranteeing the city two years of labor peace in return for job security and new benefits from the Chicago Transit Authority.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 14, 1982
description: International The problem of El Salvador is global and the United states should involve the Soviet Union, Cuba and other Latin American nations in the solution, a senior Reagan Administration official said. ''We have to talk to the Russians,'' he said. (Page 1, Col. 6.)

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ASSEMBLYMAN Jon S. Fossel, Republican of Ossining, made it official last weekend. He said he would not seek re-election to the Albany post this year, choosing instead to challenge Representative Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of Mamaroneck, for the 24th Congressional District seat - wherever it is eventually situated.

title: Burger and Smith Announce Federal Court Security Plan
description: In a time of increasing threats against judges, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Attorney General William French Smith have announced a plan to try to bolster Federal court security throughout the nation.

title: CAREY, NOT YET GONE, IS SOMETIMES FORGOTTEN
description: While Republicans in the State Senate negotiated with New York City lobbyists last week over a bill providing for binding arbitration in transit contract talks, Governor Carey was nowhere to be seen. His role was limited to signing a ''message of necessity'' that enabled the Legislature to do expeditiously what it already intended to do eventually - pass the bill.

title: 'GENOCIDE,' VIEW OF HOLOCAUST
description: ''Genocide,'' the Oscar-nominated documentary on the Holocaust, is intended as a reminder. Simon Wiesenthal, whose Simon Wiesenthal Center co-produced the film, introduces it with the warning ''Believe me, it can happen again.'' The closing credits offer evidence that anti-Semitism is again on the rise. Candidates from the American Nazi Party and the Ku Klux Klan have made good showings in local elections, the titles say. A 1980 West German survey found that 18 percent of those polled felt that things had been better in Hitler's day.

title: DEAF-BLIND CENTER FACES BUDGET CUTS
description: SANDS POINT AMONG the many services to the handicapped facing drastic cuts in the Reagan Administration's proposed budget is the Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths and Adults, nestled in an area here of affluent homes and estates.

title: By Sports of The Times; No. 32 Is As Good as No. 1
description: WHEN the buzzer sounded, Northeastern had upset St. Joseph's, 63-62, and now its red-and-black-uniformed players were jumping and and dancing and hugging one another while students were holding up their index fingers in the familiar ''We're No.1'' gesture. Glancing at the celebration, Fuzzy Levane, the Knicks' scout, shook his head and smiled.

title: DANCE: NEW 'FONTANELLE' BY TANDY BEAL TROUPE
description: Dancing is good. People are good when they dance. And dance is a world all its own. Judging from Thursday night's concert by Tandy Beal and Company at the Theater of the Riverside Church, these statements may be articles of faith for Miss Beal, a choreographer from Santa Cruz, Calif.

title: THE NEW PHILADELPHIA SOUND
description: Linda Blandford writes the ''American Diary'' column for The Guardian of London. By Linda Blandford utside Carnegie Hall, two posters hang side by side in boxes that have held the legendary names of music for nearly 100 years. On one, the Boston Symphony Orchestra proclaims its next concert. The paper is glossy, the artwork flamboyant, and dominating it all is a portrait of Seiji Ozawa - arms thrusting upward, face fervent. Since nothing happens by accident in the self-conscious world of classical-music salesmanship, this glamorous image must be how the Boston Symphony and its music director want to be presented to the world.

title: Blood Transfusion Is Ordered For Injured Jehovah's Witness
description: By court order, a Jehovah's Witness who was severely injured in an automobile accident has been given an emergency blood transfusion to try to save his life.

title: WOMEN PAST 30 WILL CONTINUE TO HAVE CHILDREN!
description: To the Editor:

title: T0 THE EDITOR:
description: As chief of the Newark Fire Department, I believe that some negative, false and misleading statements given to the writer of your recent three-part series on fire problems in Newark should be rebutted or clarified.

title: Howard Spielman to Wed Carol Turobiner in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Turobiner of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Rena Turobiner, to Howard Jonathan Spielman, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Irving Spielman of Fort Lee, N.J.

title: WOLVES,HAWKS,BULLS, PIGS
description: NEW SELECTED POEMS By Ted Hughes. 242 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $15.50. Paper, $6.95.

title: THE WORK OF FOUR POETS
description: HUNDREDS OF FIREFLIES Poems. By Brad Leithauser. 71 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $11.50. Paper, $5.95. GLOBE By Elizabeth Spires. 63 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $10. Paper, $5.95. ANTARCTIC TRAVELLER Poems. By Katha Pollitt. 60 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $11.50. Paper, $5.95.

title: NEW YORK STATE ADDS TO WETLANDS AND PARKS WITH TWO ACQUISITIONS
description: New York State announced the acquisition this week of two parcels of land, one through a purchase in the Catskill Mountains, the other by condemnation in Suffolk County.

title: Where to find blonder beers There may be those who would rather be in Prague in the company of a blonder beer. Visitors might try the Pilsener Urquell on tap at U Dvou Kocek (The Two Cats), at 10 Uhelny Square, where they will find fewer tourists and better food.
description: At U Kalicha, at 12 Na Bojisti, the Pilsener competes with an environment and a menu that exploit the fact that Jaroslav Hasek, the author of ''The Good Soldier Schweik,'' often repaired there.

title: Business Conditions; AMERICANS EAT LESS
description: After three years of double-digit increases, food price inflation slowed dramatically last year to 4.3 percent. One reason could be that demand for food has eased.

title: EQUALITY IN MARRIAGE AT NABISCO BRANDS
description: PERFECT symmetry rules the board room of Nabisco Brands, the food giant created last July from the merger of Nabisco and Standard Brands. Housed between walls of glass, 26 directors - 13 from each company - sit at an exceptionally large, square table. Side by side are the chairman and chief executive, Robert Schaeberle, formerly head of Nabisco, and the president and chief operating officer, F. Ross Johnson, formerly head of Standard Brands.

title: Commuters in Japan Delayed After Railway Cables Are Cut
description: About 250,000 railway commuters were affected after opponents of an expansion of Tokyo's new international airport cut railway signal cables at six places today, the police said.

title: 50 Join Florida Drug Force
description: At least 50 more Federal agents are being assigned to combat drug smuggling in southern Florida, Customs officials say.

title: A NEW LIFE FOR HISTORIC ARMORY
description: THE doors are so high that soldiers on horseback used to ride through without ducking. The floor is so strong that it has supported army tanks. The rafters are so high that circus acrobats have used them to practice on the trapeze.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: LONG ISLAND'S next-door man of the house, Mayor Koch, has been saying things about suburbs that have been causing some controversy in the neighborhood. Among other things the Mayor said, in a magazine interview, was that suburbs were ''sterile'' places to be in and, in general, that life really begins inside the city line. The Mayor, and nobody else whom we know, has never got around to defining what a suburb actually is, and that is the point before the house at this session.

title: Deborah Seward To Be May Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. George C. Seward of Scarsdale and Shelter Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Carroll Seward, to R. Thomas Coleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy K. Coleman of Harwich, Mass.

title: Connecticut Guide; ST. PATRICK'S PARADE
description: Billed since its inception in 1955 as the largest St. Patrick's Day parade between New York and Boston, this year's march in New Haven will step off at 2 P.M. today from the intersection of Chapel Street and Derby Avenue, reaching the reviewing stand before the old City Hall facade on the Green about 30 minutes later and dispersing at Whitney Avenue and Grove Street.

title: 11 FORGO TRIAL FOR LIGHTER SENTENCES IN DRUG CASE
description: Eleven men said by authorities to be members of a major international heroin-smuggling ring have been found guilty of various drug charges in an unusual proceeding in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Pavlina Dokovska In Liszt Piano Sonata
description: The Bulgarian pianist Pavlina Dokovska brought her New York debut recital to a close Thursday evening with a steely performance of Liszt's Sonata in B minor, displaying in heightened form the concentration and energy that characterized her playing throughout the Carnegie Recital Hall program.

title: Energy Audit Is First Step in Saving
description: I feel I must respond to Irene Fischl's conclusion on saving home energy (''sometimes it's best to leave things alone'') lest others be discouraged from doing what must be done to cut fuel bills (''Saving Energy the Hard Way,'' Opinion Page, Feb. 21).

title: Miss Richards And David Coit To Wed April 17
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Thorpe Lawrence Richards of Annapolis, Md., and Newcastle, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Gracie Richards, to David MacKay Coit, son of Mrs. Eileen Pyle Coit of Falmouth Foreside, Me., and Charles Armistead Coit of Portland, Me.

title: THEY SELL THE SMALL RECORD LABELS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Tim Page is classical/new music editor for The Soho News and host of a 20th-century music program on WNYC-FM. By TIM PAGE

title: READERS REPLY ON ABORTION
description: Re: The article ''Teen-Agers' Abortions Increasing on Long Island'': ''We want to make it not legal to kill an unborn child'' (statement by Charles Williamson, chairman of the Long Island Coalition for Life). Just as there is no such creature as a pregnant mother (before a pregnant woman can become a mother she has to first give birth to a live child and then she is no longer pregnant), in medical terminology there is no such creature as an unborn child.

title: NATURE, QUIET BUT WILD, HAUNTS DUNES
description: ON a cold but sunny day, only a few hardy souls are walking the solitary trails at the John F. Kennedy Wildlife Refuge, just east of the Jones Beach Marine Theater. A small white dog, tail wagging, runs here and there, sniffing at the frozen ground. After he nearly slips into a narrow ditch, his owner scoops him up and carries him under one arm.

title: WHEN A HEATING SYSTEM'S SAFETY VALVE GIVES WARNING
description: IN houses that are heated by a circulating hot water system, the homeowner is often dismayed when he suddenly finds that water is spurting out of the pressure relief valve located on one of the hot water supply pipes just above or close to the boiler. In some installations, it may be on a pipe that runs alongside the boiler. This valve is a safety device that squirts out enough water to relieve the pressure, then shuts down again. The valve has a hinged lever on top that can be flicked up and down; lifting up on this lever manually will always release some water from the valve's discharge outlet, or from the length of pipe connected to it (usually ending down near the floor). In most cases, water spurting from this valve is an indication that the expansion tank needs to be drained. This tank, usually directly over the boiler, or at least close by, is supposed to be half full of air and half full of water. The air inside is compressed by the heated water and helps to build up the required pressure inside the system without creating steam. It also acts as a cushion to compensate for expansion and contraction of the water inside the closed system as it heats up and cools off. Eventually the tank loses its air cushion and fills with water because the trapped air is gradually dissolved by the water. When this happens, the pressure in the system gets too high and the relief valve ''blows'' - squirts water out through its overflow. Another result may be poor heating efficiency in parts of the system, or it may cause several radiators to become air-bound so they cannot heat up. To prevent this, the expansion tank needs to be drained periodically. Once a year is usually enough, though some systems can go longer without needing draining. Usually you can tell when the tank needs draining by feeling the outside of the tank while the system is working; the bottom half should be quite a bit hotter than the top half. If it is uniformly hot all the way up, chances are it is full of water. (On some of the newer systems, the expansion tank never needs draining - it has a rubber diaphragm inside that keeps the water and air separated. These tanks have no drain valve and only have one pipe leading into them. If this type of tank ever does become waterlogged, because of the diaphragm's rupturing, it must be replaced completely.) To drain those tanks that need draining, here are the steps to follow: 1. Shut off the system and wait for the system to cool, then turn off the inlet, or supply, valve in the pipe leading into the tank. 2. Hold a bucket under the drain valve, or attach a hose to it, then open the valve and let the water run out until the tank is empty. 3. Close the drain valve, then open the inlet valve to allow water to enter the tank again. Start up the system and when the boiler heats up, the pressure gauge should read normal again (the needle should match the permanently set one on the gauge). On some expansion tanks, the drain valve is also a purge valve - it lets air enter the tank as the water is drained. With these you do not have to shut off the inlet valve, nor do you have to drain the tank completely. After the system has cooled, you simply drain off three or four buckets full of water, then close the drain valve and restart the system. Answering the Mail Q.
