We recently installed ''high-hat'' recessed lights in one ceiling that project up into the insulated floor of the attic. Since it is unsafe to put insulation around or over the lights, we left it off around them. Now there are cold drafts coming down from above through the holes cut in the ceiling. Do you have any idea how to cure this problem? - C.C., Wyckoff, N.J. A. Build a box over the top of the lights where they project up into the attic. Just make sure the box is large enough to allow for the heat put out by each fixture (check with the manufacturer). In addition, provide some small openings on two sides of each box so heat can escape. Some cold air may still enter through these openings when the lights are off, but much less than what comes in now. Q. My home has been painted many times with oil paint. I now want to switch to latex paint because it is easier to work with. Is this possible? - L.D.L., Southbury, Conn. A. Yes. Just make sure you get rid of any excessive chalking and/or powdering on the old paint, and that you dull down any glossy places before applying the latex paint over it. Q. I have removed wallpaper from our plastered walls and ceilings and now intend to paint. There seems to a shiny residue of sizing, or possibly some paste, remaining on the plaster. Must this all be removed and if so, would the plaster have to be sized again? - M.T., Tenafly, N.J. A. You should scrub all the residue off with hot water and detergent. Allow the plaster to dry thoroughly, then apply a coat of primer sealer, followed by the paint of your choice. Either oil or latex can be used for the final coat, but I would advise an alkyd primer sealer for the first coat.

title: LEGISLATORS ARGUE OVER REVENUE DIP
description: New York State has reported a sudden drop in revenue collections for last month, leaving the state's treasury with about $130 million less for the current fiscal year than state officials had expected.

title: SETTLEMENTS NEAR ON OLYMPICS' DEBT
description: A little more than two years after the end of the 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, the Olympic Organizing Committee there has put into the mail 620 checks totaling $8.2 million to pay off most of the bills it incurred for the Games.

title: HIGH-POWER PUSH FOR LOW-POWER TV
description: ANEW televison drama is unfolding in Westchester and other parts of the country, one that some industry observers believe may prove to be the most exciting fare in decades. It is low-power television, which is designed to bring ownership of television stations within reach of the average person, often for less cost than it takes to open a fastfood franchise.

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY PLANNING NEW AND INVITING LOOK
description: On Fifth Avenue, between the wealth and commerce of the East Side and the tawdry enticements of Times Square, stands the New York Public Library, serene and decorous in its marble splendor. For intellectuals who came of age during the Depression, it has served, in Irving Howe's words, as an avenue of ''escape from parochial limits and crowded apartments.''

title: Laura Hoffeld Is Dead at 36; Writer and Magazine Editor
description: Laura Hoffeld, a writer and editor of poetry and fiction, died Friday at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York.

title:
Numismatics;
A RICH LODE OF TERRITORIAL GOLD GOES ON SALE
description: A latter-day California Gold Rush will take place this week as dealers and collectors gather in Los Angeles for a public auction sale of numismatic material from the Old West. The sale, scheduled for Thursday through Saturday by Bowers and Ruddy Galleries Inc., will feature a collection of territorial gold assembled by Henry H. Clifford, past president of the California Historical Society.

title: THE STAGE: 'BECOMING' A UNICORN
description: Anton Gill's ''Becoming,'' at La Mama, is not so much a play as a playful party game that poses the question: Have you ever wanted to be something other than a human being?

title: Nonfiction In Brief
description: THE BLACK BOOK Edited by Ilya Ehrenburg and Vasily Grossman. 595 pp. New York: Holocaust/Schocken. $19.95.

title: Foreign Affairs; LEAKS AND STORIES
description: The press is not just reporting but making news again. It is always uncomfortable when gamekeeper and poacher trade places. But there are serious issues about national policy involved, and they have to be faced.

title: An easy trip from Paris; The New York Times/March 14, 1982
description: Too many visitors ''do'' Chartres, which is 50 miles southwest of Paris, on the way to somewhere else, usually the chateau country in the Loire Valley. But how much more rewarding it can be if one stays at least a full day. By car, Chartres is an easy one-hour trip on the autroroute from Paris. Follow the blue signs all over the city that say Orly and Lyon. Once on the autoroute stay to the right and follow the signs saying Orleans and Chartres.

title: ROCK: BLASTER, COAST QUINTET
description: On the surface, the Blasters, the Los Angeles-based rock quintet that appeared at the Mudd Club on Thursday, would appear to be the hottest 1950's rockabilly revivalists to emerge in years. With their concise blues structures and the simple blues harmonies, the group's songs are firmly rooted in the 1950's classicism of Chuck Berry, Jerry Lee Lewis and others.

title: 2 MAYORS EASE RIFT IN DIVIDED CYPRUS
description: ''I know there are people like me on the other side of the wall,'' the Mayor of Nicosia says of the barrier dividing the city into Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot sectors. ''I'm trying to break the wall.''

title: JEAN BETANCOURT TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Betancourt of Lindenhurst, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Ellen Betancourt, to Desmond Charles Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Miller of Marion, S.D.

title: TO GIVE OR NOT TO GIVE THE LANDLORD A KEY
description: Elizabeth DePaul noticed nothing amiss when she returned to her apartment in Verona, N.J. A few days later, she realized that a carafe filled with Bicentennial coins worth about $1,000 was gone.

title: SPRING CATALOGUE OF GARDENS AND EVENTS
description: Following is a partial listing of outstanding gardens in Europe, with notations of some festivals or flower shows. Austria The Austrian Horticultural Fair will take place from Sept. 3 through 6 in Tulln. Baden, a town of gardens and roses south of Vienna, contains the Spa Park (Kurpark) and the Doblhoffpark, with its thousands of roses. The Botanischer Garten in Linz displays about 4,000 different flowers and plants from all over the world. The Botanical and alpine flower garden at the University of Innsbruck contains about 1,200 kinds of flowers and specializes in those of the southern region of the Alps. Belgium The 32d Begonia Festival will be held this year in Lochristi, outside Ghent, from Aug. 28 to Aug. 30. The Gardens of the Chateau of Annevoie are near Namur, which is 39 miles south of Brussels. They are open from March 28 through November 1 from 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. During the summer there is a begonia festival. The Royal Greenhouses at the Palace of Laeken, a suburb of Brussels, are open annually to the public in May. They cover six acres in area and include more than 320,000 square feet of greenhouses. The gardens of the Rubens House are an example of an urban garden in the center of Antwerp. This classical garden is a restoration based on Rubens' own paintings. The gardens of the Chateau of Beloeil are Belgium's largest, covering 40 acres in area.

title: MARRIED PEOPLE NEED A BREAK AND HERE'S A WAY TO GET ONE
description: THE Internal Revenue Service has some good news for us married people. The income tax tables will shortly begin doing away with the ''marriage penalty'' - under which married couples pay more income tax than unmarried couples or singles.

title: PANEL PUTS LIMIT ON SHOREHAM A-PLANT TESTIMONY
description: A panel of three administrative law judges has ruled that it will not hear testimony on evacuation plans for people living more than 10 miles from the Shoreham nuclear power plant, which is being built in Suffolk County.

title: High Salvador Officer Slain in Rebel Ambush
description: The Defense Ministry has announced that a high-ranking army officer was slain in a guerrilla ambush Thursday near San Felipe, 50 miles east of the capital.

title: Gary Dennis Will Wed Merrill Louise Drapkin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold H. Drapkin of Hollis Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Merrill Louise Drapkin, to Gary L. Dennis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Dennis of Brookline, Mass.,

title: 'NO, NO, NANETTE' DANCES BACK TO 1925
description: ''NO, NO, NANETTE,'' boasts the rare distinction of having been a Broadway hit twice, in 1925 and in 1971. One reason is the delightful Vincent Youmans score that includes, among other good numbers, the standards ''Tea for Two'' and ''I Want to Be Happy.'' The second reason, at least for the 1971 version, was the presence of Ruby Keeler. Miss Keeler, not a great singer nor an exceptionally graceful dancer, somehow is the symbol of the great 30's movie musicals, and Broadway fell all over itself in welcoming her back, as it did that wonderful comic Patsy Kelly, who also appeared.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Moscow Medicine
description: Doctors told Kyle and Betty Cantrell there was no hope. Their 12-year-old son, Todd, suffering since birth from retinitis pigmentosa, could not see at night and faced the prospect of total blindness.

title: JUDGE GOES TO JAIL TO GET FACTS
description: Federal District Judge William Hoeveler spent Friday behind bars. The judge, one of three assigned to a suit seeking to eliminate overcrowding in the Dade County Jail, wanted to see for himself what life is like there.

title: Divine Mussels
description: Craig Claiborne and Pierre Franey are victims of the old shell game (''The Rewards of Making Mussels,'' Feb. 14). Shucks! I thought by now everyone knew that mussels, along with clams, oysters and scallops are mollusks, not crustaceans. Crustaceans include lobsters, crabs and shrimp. JERROLD H. MULNICK Senior Regional Shellfish Specialist Food and Drug Administration Brooklyn, N.Y. -----

title: TV View; MORE ARTS, MORE TALK ON CABLE
description: As cable television continues to expand, there's more of everything -more movies, sports, news, talk shows, toney cultural showcases and kinky sexual excursions. At times, the resulting hodgepodge can be disconcerting. Last Sunday evening, for instance, a subscriber to Manhattan Cable TV could have followed an hour of ''Strumpet City,'' a handsomely produced Irish television dramatic series being offered on CBS Cable, with a half-hour of public-access Channel D's ''Let's Talk Dirty'' that fully lived up to its title.

title: Cheryl Savits to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving A. Savits of Wallingford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cheryl Debra Savits, to Steven Michael Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Friedman of Riverdale, the Bronx. The wedding is planned for next Month.

title: West German Aide Injured
description: The Minister for Inter-German Affairs, Egon Franke, was slightly injured in an auto accident early today, the police said. Mr. Franke, 68 years old, was cut and bruised when his car collided with a truck near the Lower Saxony town of Peine. A hospital spokesman said Mr. Franke was in good condition and should be released in a few days.

title: CAMPUS RADICALS OF 60'S ARE RESHAPING STYLE OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT ON COAST
description: This seaside city of 42,000 people decided not long ago to adopt its own foreign policy. By a 2 to 1 majority, its voters approved a resolution opposing American intervention in El Salvador.

title: REPORT FROM AN OCEAN RACER
description: Since the start of the last leg of the 27,000-mile Whitbread Round-the-World Race two weeks ago off Mar del Plata, Argentina, we have sailed nearly 2,900 miles across the South Atlantic Ocean.

title: Con Ed Loses Its Fight On Dismissed Worker
description: A Consolidated Edison mechanic who was discharged in January 1981 after complaining about safety hazards at the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor will be reinstated with back pay, the company said Friday.

title: The Nation in Summary; U.S. Entering Greensboro Case
description: After months of watching from the sidelines, the Justice Department announced last week that a Federal grand jury would conduct ''a full and complete'' investigation into the gunning down of five Communist Workers Party members during a street demonstration in Greensboro, N.C.

title: CONCERT: KUBELIK'S DVORAK
description: Symphonic life has its own set of marital problems: guest conductors, for example, brandishing their large egos, and orchestras - better organized and more militant than ever - responding with suspicion.

title: G.M. Recalls 519,000 Autos To Replace Clamps on Pipes
description: The General Motors Corporation says it will recall about 519,000 of its 1982 X, J and A cars to replace clamps that could break, posing a potential fire hazard from leaking fuel.

title: Personal Finance; EASING THE PAIN OF ESTIMATED TAXES
description: THE millions of taxpayers who have labored under the burden of e stimating their income for quarterly tax payments may get a break t his year because of changes in the tax law. They may be able to put o ff paying a substantial amount of tax - retaining the use of these f unds until tax-filing time a year from now.

title: DEAR FRIEND: COME JOIN US
description: NEITHER rain nor sleet nor the bulk rate keeps my mailman from bringing occasional surprises with my bills. Just the other day he brought a first-class request from President Reagan himself asking me to make a sacrifice for my country.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
ON TO PADUA, BY WAY OF 'DALLAS'
description: HEMPSTEAD HIS handsome, all-American face hidden behind a shaggy beard and his on-camera, well-tailored suit replaced by Army fatigues, a man from ''Dallas'' (who used to be ''The Man From Atlantis'') is secretly stalking the Hofstra University campus here, hoping that his star-status-presence will go unnoticed; at least, until Thursday. For that's when Patrick Duffy opens a two-week stand playing Petrucio in an otherwise all-student production of ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' and, then, the potential adoration of soap-opera-crazy students won't interfere with the work at hand.

title:
Economic Affairs;
QUICK, PUT A TAX ON OPEC'S OIL
description: ECONOMIC policy-making, when successful, involves hard labor in a nalyzing alternatives -and good luck. There are elements of good e conomics and good luck now present in energy policy calling for a t ariff on crude oil imports. The case for a tariff is strong on both e conomic and national-security grounds. And now that world crude p rices are falling, opportunity is hammering at the door.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Lyras, Pianist, in Recital Of Schumann and Liszt
description: Panayis Lyras is a pianist who won some warm admirers with his second-place finish in the 1981 Van Cliburn Competition. He was born in Greece in 1953 and emigrated with his family to America in 1966, where he attended the Juilliard School. That school has now established an award called the Juilliard William Petschek Piano Debut, which Mr. Lyras inaugurated with a recital Tuesday night in Alice Tully Hall.

title: GREGG GRIFFIN FIANCE OF SANDRA E. HELME
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jay Ely Helme of Paoli, Pa., and Shelter Island, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Elizabeth Helme, to Gregg Ferguson Griffin, son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Harrison Griffin of Shelter Island. An August wedding is planned.

title:
ART;
TALENT AND COLOR IN ABUNDANCE
description: HUNTINGTON STANDING at the entrance to the Huntington Township Art League's 27th annual Long Island Art Exhibition at the Heckscher Museum, one is taken by the show's up-tempo mood. The three jurors, the artists Robert Birmelin and Robert White, and Kathryn Markel, director of a New York City gallery, have chosen a stimulating group of works, with a notable emphasis on color and exuberance. They have steered clear of photographic realism, preferring more subjective and painterly approaches to representation, and including a strong selection of abstractions.

title: FAR FROM TANZANIA, NYERERE LOOKS HIS BEST
description: President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania traveled to India last month to receive the 1981 Third World Prize. The award, and a speech he made setting out the case of the developing ''South'' against the industrialized ''North,'' reaffirmed Mr. Nyerere's pre-eminence as a statesman and public defender of ''the victims and the powerless in the international economy.'' A few days later, Mr. Nyerere came under a spotlight of a different hue. A Tanzanian Army officer and three others hijacked an Air Tanzania Boeing 737 and ordered it to fly to Kenya, Saudi Arabia and Greece before they surrendered in England. Along the way, they broadcast demands for Mr. Nyerere's resignation.

title: Raider-N.F.L. Trial Will Resume Monday
description: The antitrust case of the Oakland Raiders against the National Football League starts again Monday, with a smaller jury trying to decide the outcome.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Joining Tracy Austin on the sidelines, Chris Evert Lloyd has withdrawn from a tennis tournament that begins Monday in Boston. Mrs. Lloyd, the defending champion of the Avon tournament, complained of a sore right leg and a groin injury. On Friday, Miss Austin said she could not play because of a back injury. ... Leading the academic all-America basketball team selected by college sports information directors were Keith Edmonson of Purdue and David Magley of Kansas, who had perfect grade scores. Also on the team were John Paxson of Notre Dame, Randy Wittman of Indiana and Mike Kanieski of Dayton.

title: Fire Hits California Airport
description: Fire broke out early today in the south terminal at San Francisco International Airport, disrupting international flight operations for about an hour and forcing an evacuation, the authorities said. No injuries were reported in the predawn blaze.

title: Preakness Bets Set For Other Tracks
description: Pimlico Race Course and Maryland horsemen have agreed to a plan that would allow tracks across the country to take bets on the 107th running of the Preakness Stakes, a Pimlico spokesman said today.

title: REPORT REJECTS INDUSTRY'S CASE ON DEPOSIT BILL
description: A staff report to Governor Carey on legislation to require a 5-cent deposit on bottles and cans has concluded that many of the arguments advanced by the beverage industry against the bill are ''unfounded.'' Aides to the Governor said the report, a detailed analysis of cost projections by brewers, bottlers and distributors, sets the stage for a possible reversal this year of his previous opposition to the measure. The report will be released for public comment today.

title: BRITISH AIR: SHORT ON SOLUTIONS
description: When a Boeing 747 belonging to an American airline crosses the Atlantic, the luggage, cargo and mail will, as a general rule, be unloaded by six baggage handlers. To do the same job on the same kind of plane flying the same route, British Airways will dispatch a crew of 15.

title: DR. MEYER ISAAC LEFF
description: Dr. Meyer Isaac Leff, who served as a medical officer with the American Joint Distribution Committee in the early 1920's, providing emergency relief to Jewish communities in Europe, died Friday at the Miami Jewish Home for the Aged. He was 93 years old.

title: Man, 24, Dies After He Is Shot In Robbery Attempt in Queens
description: A 24-year-old Queens man died early yesterday morning after being shot during an attempted burglary, the police said. According to the police, the man, Edward Glowaski, broke into the third-floor apartment of Fred Hammer at 37-68 97th Street, in the Corona section, at about 10 P.M. Saturday. Mr. Hammer, 76 years old, fired a .32-caliber revolver once into Mr. Glowaski's chest. Mr. Glowaski, who lived at 40-17 60th Street in the Woodside section, died at 2:30 A.M yesterday in Elmhurst Hospital.

title: AVANT-GARDE: CONCERT FOR JOHN CAGE
description: AT first, it seemed a paradoxical tribute to offer a 13-hour ''Wall-to-Wall'' concert in the Symphony Space in honor of John Cage's 70th birthday. The composer has always been a gleeful iconoclast, breaking down barriers between art and life, East and West, music and noise, performer and composer.

title: Matagorda Appoints Drilling Company Head
description: Robert T. Evans Sr., 44, has been elected president of the Matagorda Drilling Company, a contract drilling operator in Corpus Christi, Tex. He succeeds Gregory E. Fourticq, 43, who continues as president and chief executive officer of the Matagorda Drilling and Exploration Company, the parent company.

title: Daimler Egypt Venture
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., the maker of Mercedes cars and trucks, based in Stuttgart, West Germany, said it had signed a preliminary agreement with the Egyptian authorities for its participation in a new company assembling Mercedes trucks in Egypt, primarily for the Egyptian market. Daimler will assume a 25.5 interest in a new Egyptian corporation to be called Mohandes National Vehicle Industries and Trading Company that will turn out 4000 trucks and 600 buses annually five years after start-up in 1983.

title: DANCE: THE NUCLEAR THREAT
description: JAMES KLOSTY sings! That, at least, seemed a major premise of ''Mr. Green, in the Ballroom, With a Lead Pipe,'' a new work by Jean Churchill performed Friday at the Newfoundland Theater. Mr. Klosty, the photographer, man about the New York dance scene and author of a very fine book on Merce Cunningham, sang credibly. He also acted the part of an obnoxious know-it-all waiter so convincingly it was hard to tell where the character left off and Mr. Klosty himself took over.

title: Pakistani Police Arrest 55 at Political Protest
description: The police made 55 arrests and used tear gas today to break up the first major street demonstration since Pakistan's military ruler banned political meetings more than two years ago. A Government statement said 200 people attended the rally that the police broke up with tear gas.

title: THEATER: A REVUE BUILT FROM NEWMAN'S MUSIC
description: IT is not every popular composer whose songs can become the successful subject of a revue. Such, unfortunately, is the case with Randy Newman, the source of ''Maybe I'm Doing It Wrong,'' an anthology that opened last night at the Astor Place Theater. Sung singly, some of the numbers are tuneful, and the director, Joan Micklin Silver, has assembled an appealing cast. However, in contrast to ''Pump Boys and Dinettes'' and other collages, there is not nearly enough musical variety or ingenuity to sustain an evening in the theater.

title: PIANO: MORAVEC PLAYS CHOPIN
description: IVAN MORAVEC played piano music by Chopin and Debussy to an overflow crowd Saturday at the 92d Street Y. The particular virtues in Mr. Moravec's personal brand of virtuosity showed in his respect for detail - his careful delineation of smaller note values and his exact coloristic sense for where the pedal belonged and where it did not. Mr. Moravec reduced five Chopin Mazurkas to a small scale, vividly capturing their moments of salonlike elegance but often avoiding their more dominant peasant extroversions. The G-sharp minor was played with great charm.

title: CYPRUS BECOMING HOME FOR FOREIGN COMPANIES
description: S.C. Johnson & Son Ltd. moved its regional sales and marketing operations to this strategically placed Mediterranean island just nine months ago, and already its sales have risen by more than 20 percent.

title: FOR ELAINE ZAYAK, CHANGE OF FORTUNE
description: Elaine Zayak, a 16-year-old high school student from Paramus, N.J., ended a long spell of costly falls Saturday night and won the world figure skating title.

title: Three of 10 Complaints Result in Ad Changes
description: Only three out of the 10 complaints resolved in February by the National Advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus ended with the dropping of either an ad claim or advertising. All seven of the other advertisers were able to support their claims.

title: G.& W. Adds Libbey Stake
description: Gulf and Western Industries said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company, the automotive and industrial glass producer, to 27.3 percent of the outstanding common stock.

title: ENSEMBLE: THE BOEHM QUINTETTE
description: THE Boehm Quintette, a wind group in its 14th season, put the resonance of the Great Hall of the Cooper Union to good use Friday night in a free concert of works by Janacek, Reinecke, Norman Dello Joio and the late Alec Wilder. The group's playing and that of their guests attained a high standard, and the fare was unusual, diverse and generally quite engaging.

title: DEBATE ON RATES PERSISTING
description: Interest rates rose substantially last week but did nothing to quell the debate in the credit markets about where they are headed in the future.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Edward J. Abramson has been named advertising director of Bride's magazine.

title: For Avis, President Who Knows the Job
description: Howard C. Miller Jr., 55 years old, will join Avis Inc., the car rental and leasing company headquartered in Garden City, L.I., today as president and chief operating officer. J. Patrick Barrett, 45, an executive vice president of Norton Simon Inc., the parent company of Avis, will continue as chief executive officer. Mr. Barrett has held that post since last August when James F. Calvano, 45, resigned as president and chief executive officer.

title: Soviet Official to Visit India
description: The Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, arrives here Monday with a military delegation that includes three deputy defense ministers and 30 top officials of the Red Army. The United News of India reported today, without giving a source, that Marshal Ustinov would conclude an agreement for India to manufacture Soviet MIG-27 jet fighters.

title: ARMS SALES TO ARABS WON'T BRING MIDEAST PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRGINIA, MINNESOTA TRIUMPH
description: Virginia only made eight of 21 free throws, but Tennessee ''choked at the foul line,'' its coach, Don DeVoe, said after Virginia won, 54-51, in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Mideast Regional tournament today at Market Square Arena.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: GUATEMALA VOTE ENDS HOPE FOR A CIVILIAN LEADER AND BRINGS CHARGES OF FRAUD
description: In this country plagued by a deepening civil war and a crumbling economy, those who hoped that a civilian would win the March 6 presidential election and end years of military rule have had their hopes dashed.

title: French Deal: I.T.T.'s View
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday that it had not yet reached an agreement with the French Government concerning the nationalization of its subsidiary, Compagnie Generale de Constructions Telephoniques, and three smaller I.T.T. companies.

title: Bruce Bell Weds Nancy M. Maurer
description: Nancy Margaret Maurer and Bruce Anthony Bell, lawyers in Albany, were married yesterday at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club. Rabbi Gene Lipsey performed the ceremony.

title: 'Johnny Jones' March 21
description: ''Little Johnny Jones,'' the George M. Cohan musical at the Alvin Theater, will now open Sunday.

title: SEOUL URGED TO EASE UP ON PRISONERS
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea is under steady pressure from the United States, Japan and France to show a more lenient attitude toward political prisoners here, according to diplomats and Korean dissident sources.

title: Brooklyn Woman Slays an Intruder
description: A woman killed an intruder when he tried to assault her during a burglary in her apartment in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: PRELATE SEEKS WALESA'S RELEASE

title: ABC-TV Holds Its Line On the 30-Second Rule
description: In the wake of the announcement by the National Association of Broadcasters that it is suspending all enforcement of its broadcast codes in light of a recent Federal Court antitrust decision, ABC-TV announced that it is holding the line on the point in question - only one product allowed in a 30-second commercial. The judge's ruling would allow more.

title: Commodities; 2d-Chance 'Lookback' Options
description: WHAT commodity trader, especially those in the gold market, doesn't wish he had a second chance to buy or sell a futures contract. If the traders could, then longs would surely opt to buy gold at a lower price and shorts would have sold bullion when prices were much higher.

title: SUSPECT HELD IN SLAYING OF WOMAN WHO WAS FOUND IN LAKE IN 1979
description: A 21-year-old man has been arrested in the murder of his high school classmate whose body was found in a Bergen County lake more than two years ago.

title: Going Out Guide
description: PHOTOGRAPHER ON FILM

title: 5 IN ROW FOR MISS NAVRATILOVA
description: Martina Navratilova won her 24th straight match today, defeating Mima Jausovec, 6-3, 6-2, in the final of a $200,000 Avon tennis tournament.

title: NO MAJOR VIOLENCE IS REPORTED AS COLOMBIANS VOTE
description: Colombians voted today in congressional, provincial and municipal elections that leftist guerrillas had threatened to disrupt. No major incidents were reported.

title: G.O.P. SUCCESS RECIPE OFTEN INCLUDES CHOWDER
description: Richard M. Nixon once described the Chowder and Marching Club as ''the most ill-organized, disorderly organization I know.''

title: News Analysis
description: When Harrison A. Williams Jr. resigned last Thursday from the United States Senate, he gave Governor Kean of New Jersey his newest political problem.

title: Killer Apparently Trapped 5 Before Slayings in Michigan
description: Five members of a rural family who were found shot to death in their burning house apparently had been trapped in the kitchen by their killer, officials said today.

title: REDISTRICTING WORRYING NEW YORK LAWMAKERS
description: Ted Weiss does not want to go to Queens. Olga A. Mendez does not want to leave Roosevelt Island. Thomas J. Bartosiewicz says, ''I kind of like Staten Island, but ...''

title: Weidenbaum Says Recession Nears End
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the recession was nearing an end and predicted that the nation's economy would begin to turn upward in the next three months.

title: HOCKEY STICK MAKER STRUGGLES IN NEWLY COMPETITIVE MARRKET
description: Hockey stick manufacturers usually operate at full production in winter, but the only laborers at work at the Northland Group factory on a recent afternoon were on the roof, chipping away with pickaxes at the remains of the previous night's ice storm.

title: BAMBERGER'S 6-MONTH PLAN
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. NOBODY says no twice to George Bamberger. Nobody ever gets the chance. ''I'll make the suggestion one time,'' says the new manager of the Mets. ''If they don't listen, I'll never tell them again.''

title: NEW YORK RETAIL SALES UP SLIM 5%
description: Retail sales in New York City continued at a slow pace in February, rising only 5 percent from February last year, a spot-check of the big retailers showed. It was also the second consecutive month in which the higher-priced, more service-oriented stores had sales gains well below their usual performances.

title: RIGHETTI HIT HARD
description: George Steinbrenner and a group of Yankee executives watched with encouragement Ken Griffey's debut in right field today and continued to consider trades that could bring Dave Stieb, the Blue Jays' right-hander, or Dave Parker, the Pirates' right fielder, to New York.

title: TV: MISS BURNETT LOOKS AT 23 YEARS OF 'EUNICE'
description: ''EUNICE,'' played by Carol Burnett on a 90-minute CBS-TV special tonight at 9:30, is a troubling television character. She was created by Dick Clair and Jenna McMahon and was a regular part of ''The Carol Burnett Show'' for five seasons. Eunice could be very funny, in a ridiculous sort of way. For that very reason, she could also be sad, even quite pathetic. She represented a departure from Miss Burnett's usual brand of clowning. She was closer to the more ambiguous creations favored by Lily Tomlin.

title: Leon Levine, Former Director Of CBS Radio Programs, Dies
description: Leon Levine, a former director of educational and public-affairs radio programs for CBS, died Wednesday at Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 77 years old and had homes in Sarasota and Manhattan.

title: ICONOCLASTIC G.O.P. SENATOR
description: At this weekend's Tidewater Conference, Senator Bob Packwood, the conference host, urged Republican legislators to mute their public criticism of the Reagan Administration.

title: Japan Trade Plan Reported
description: Foreign Minister Yoshio Sakurauchi said today that Japan is preparing new measures to ease trade friction with the United States and other trading partners, according to Japanese news reports.

title: Lopez Wins Bout
description: Eddie (The Animal) Lopez knocked out Ishaq Hussein of London in the eighth round of their scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout at the Veterans Memorial Auditorium Saturday night. Lopez, who weighed 216 pounds, now has a 25-3-2 record and Hussein, who weighed 210, is 28-7.

title: LENDL SCORES
description: Ivan Lendl downed a fellow Czechoslovak, Tomas Smid, in the final of the $300,000 Munich Open tennis tournament today, 3-6, 6-3, 6-1, 6-2.

title: 11 Killed, 20 Injured In Alps by Avalanches
description: A series of avalanches that swept down the slopes of the French Alps today in a sudden spell of warm weather killed 11 people and injured 20, the police said.

title: Ford Offers to Meet Arafat if ...
description: United States officials have been keeping a studied distance from the Palestine Liberation Organization. Yesterday, however, a former President offered to meet the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat - with a tough condition attached.

title: Darcy Golf Victor
description: Eamon Darcy of Ireland had to sink 3-foot putts on each of the last three holes today to gain a onestroke victory in the Kenya Open golf tournament.

title: No Headline
description: MONTREAL WINS, 5-2

title: Waltrip Winner In Stock Car Race
description: Darrell Waltrip posted his first victory of the season today, after an accident knocked Dale Earnhardt out of the lead in the Valleydale 500 Grand National stock car race.

title: Rain Puts Off L.P.G.A. Play
description: Rain forced postponement of today's final round of the $150,000 Olympia Gold women's golf tournament until Monday.

title: THE DEFECTS IN A COURT SYSTEM FOR YOUTH CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: DISPUTE
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was quoted today as saying he has postponed a scheduled trip to Israel because of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's insistence that he visit to Jerusalem.

title: Big Brother
description: Mark Branch, who as a junior at Massachusetts Institute of Technology was the basketball captain and the leading scorer this season, is an only-child who knows the value of counseling from older friends.

title: IRAN AFTER KHOMEINI
description: When the Ayatollah Khomeini dies and the lid blows off in Iran, the Soviet Union will be in a position to take control. All evidence points to this Russian intent to penetrate Persia; the success of the plan would mark the greatest shift in the balance of power in this generation, and the worst foreign-policy failure of the Reagan Administration.

title: Nkomo Urges Zimbabwe To End Detention Law
description: Joshua Nkomo, leader of the opposition Zimbabwe African Peoples Union Party, urged the Government today to end the practice of arrests without trial. The detention law was imposed by Prime Minister Robert Mugabe under emergency powers inherited from the former white minority Government of Ian D. Smith.

title: Phil Mahre Takes World Cup Slalom
description: Phil Mahre of the United States edged Sweden's Ingemar Stenmark by 1.59 seconds today in a World Cup slalom race.

title: PACIFIC RATES PROVOKE PROTEST
description: The soaring costs of electric power, caused in part by utilities' heavy investment in nuclear reactors, have prompted consumer protests in all three Pacific Coast states.

title: J. RICHARD BURNS
description: J. Richard Burns, general counsel to the Medical Society of the State of New York, died Friday at Huntington Hospital on Long Island. Mr. Burns, who was a resident of Huntington, was 58 years old.

title: The Editorial Notebook Depressing, but No Depression
description: Journalists speculate about it. Disgruntled Treasury officials write scenarios for it. Even President Reagan dares mention it, though only to dismiss it as impossible. This season's vision of apocalypse is depression, replacing last season's fascination with Weimar inflation.

title: SONICS TOP NETS, 98-97
description: It was a very ugly scene: The Nets had suffered through their most excruciating loss of the season, 98-97, to the Seattle SuperSonics, on a controversial call in the final seconds. And the 15,432 fans were unleashing their most demonstrative emotional display of the season against the officials, Earl Strom and Barry Rogan.

title: THE PSYCHOLOGY OF THE CULT EXPERIENCE
description: The same story makes the headlines again and again. An anguished family is trying to ''rescue'' its child, who has, the parents charge, been ''stolen'' by a cult, sometimes after only a single weekend of involvement. The parents describe the child as a humorless ''zombie'' - where formerly he or she was self-possessed, intelligent and completely ''normal.'' And, as family members begin to consult the clergy, lawyers and deprogrammers, they keep expressing confusion about exactly what has happened, and why.

title: PRESIDENT MUBARAK'S PLAUSIBLE RELUCTANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Stealth Debut

title: G.O.P. CONFERENCE OFFERS A PLEDGE ON AID FOR BLACKS
description: Republicans must reaffirm their commitment to black Americans by making it plain that the party supports shortterm government help for blacks in need as well as their long-term advancement, a group of party leaders agreed today.

title: 34 Left Homeless In East Side Fire
description: Thirty-four people were left homeless early yesterday when a threealarm fire swept through their apartment building at 315 East 95th Street, fire officials said.

title: Palestinian Official In West Bank Quits
description: A member of an Israeli-sponsored village league in the occupied West Bank resigned today, apparently as a result of pressure from Jordan, the Israel radio reported. The village leagues function as intermediaries between local farmers and Israeli occupation authorities.

title: Please Pass the Biscuits
description: As anybody who is anybody knows, one does not address one's butler as ''Mr.'' Nobody, it seems, knows this better than Josephine Louis, the wife of John Jeffry Louis Jr., the United States Ambassador to Britain.

title: DePauw Sorority Is Accused Of Bias After Rejecting Black
description: The Delta Zeta sorority has been accused of racial discrimination for not allowing a black student at DePauw University to join.

title: OUTDOORS: RECAPTURING THE LOST ART OF WALKING
description: IT is with considerable embarrassment that I confess to having lost the art of walking. An awareness of this parlous condition came from a book a friend lent me recently: ''The Art of Walking,'' edited by Edwin Mitchell and published by Loring and Musey in 1934.

title: Freed Nicaraguan Lied, Reagan Tells Reporters
description: President Reagan said today that a young Nicaraguan who recanted a confession that he had been sent by his Government to fight in El Salvador is ''a liar,'' and said he was surprised that ''no one speculated about the possibility'' that the incident ''might have been a set-up.''

title: 5 FORGOTTEN SHORTSTOPS
description: SHORTSTOP is arguably a baseball team's most important position. Without a shortstop of skill, a team is not likely to win a World Series or a pennant. Among the infielders who wear conventional gloves, a shortstop needs more range and a better arm than either a second baseman or a third baseman. And somehow a shortstop usually is responsible for calming his pitchers, if not all his teammates.

title: BROOKLYN ROLLING ON
description: Brooklyn College, which was eliminated in the semifinianls of the City University conference basketball tournament, has had more success in its second postseason tournament. The Kingsmen have become the first conference team to reach the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III playoffs.

title: Helaine Levi, a Teacher, Bride of Stuart A. Smith
description: Helaine Levi, a member of the English department of the Hunter College High School, was married yesterday in Washington to Stuart A. Smith, a lawyer.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 15, 1982
description: International U.S. ties with Cuba and Nicaragua could be normalized as a result of ideas and proposals made by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. at a meeting in New York with Foreign Minister Jorge Castaneda of Mexico, Mr. Castaneda told reporters following the meeting, his second with Mr. Haig in a week. He said the proposals could lead to a ''series of agreements'' for normalizing relations. Mr. Haig, in a separate news conference, was less specific than Mr. Castaneda but said that the meeting had been ''extremely helpful.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Egypt's President has put off his visit to Israel because of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's insistence that he also visit Jerusalem, according to a Kuwaiti newspaper. President Hosni Mubarak had wanted to visit Israel before the final Israeli withdrawal from Sinai on April 25, but the Cabinet warned him he was not welcome if he avoided Jerusalem. ''It is not protocol for a state to impose on a visiting chief of state the program of his visit,'' Mr. Mubarak said. (A1:4-5.)

title: CLOSE CIRCLE OF FRIENDS DESTROYED AT CROSSING
description: A few blocks from Chaminade High School, a group of 15-year-old girls gathered on a corner in the glare of a sunny Sunday. They were holding onto one another and crying. Up and down the streets, doors were swinging open and shut as bereaved parents and siblings visited one another.

title: The Economy
description: Producer prices are down for the first time in six years, and economists view this as a portent of lower inflation and consumer prices, which have not declined in more than 16 years. The inflation rate is expected to hold steady for the next two months. (D1.)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We feel hopeful that a process of negotiations may be starting in the Caribbean.'' - Jorge Castaneda, Foreign Minister of Mexico. (A1:6.)

title: Fewer Teen-Agers, Less Help
description: Since 1970, statistics show, the number of young people in New York City has plunged 21 percent. It's tempting to greet the news with a sigh of relief, and possibly with reduced support for programs that provide teen-agers with jobs or otherwise keep them off the streets.

title: EFFORT TO 'FREEZE' NUCLEAR ARSENALS SPREADS IN U.S.
description: A growing number of political, religious and civic groups throughout the country are coalescing into a significant movement to try to halt the nuclear weapons race between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Lawsuit on Detention Of Haitians to Be Tried
description: A lawsuit challenging the Federal policy of holding Haitian refugees in compounds while considering their status as immigrants is to come to trial Monday.

title: British Mortgage Rates
description: Britain's savings and loan associations last Friday cut mortgage rates by 1.5 percentage points, to 13.5 percent. The move followed a half-point reduction Thursday by Britain's four major banks to 13 percent from 13.5 percent in their base lending rates. The move was in line with generally declining interest rates in Europe.

title: MEXICAN SAYS HAIG HAS IDEAS TO SOLVE CARIBBEAN TENSION
description: The Foreign Minister of Mexico said yesterday that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had made proposals that could lead to ''a series of agreements'' for normalizing American relations with Cuba and Nicaragua and for ending outside support for the insurgency in El Salvador.

title: North Korean in Nicaragua
description: The North Korean Prime Minister, Li Chong Ok, arrived in Managua today for a three-day visit to discuss widening his Government's aid program to Nicaragua, the Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry said.

title: FAULTY ARGUMENTS ON CITY COUNCIL REDISTRICTING
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'NYMPH ERRANT,' '33 PORTER PLAY, ARRIVES
description: EXCEPT for those who managed to see one of the 154 performances of Cole Porter's ''Nymph Errant'' in London in 1933, this has remained the most tantilizingly mysterious of Porter shows for almost 50 years. Until last week, it had never been seen in the United States, and the closest thing to a revival in England was a 1946 production in London for which the title was changed to ''Evangeline'' and the entire Porter score was discarded, replaced by a new set of songs by three local composers and lyricists.

title: Toss-Up
description: Tim Scannell was faced with a very difficult choice last month. The 240-pound tackle on the football team at State College (Pa.)

title: Oregon State, Idaho Advance
description: Brian Kellerman's 15-foot jump shot with three seconds left bounced off the rim and then went through the net as time ran out to give Idaho a 69-67 overtime victory over Iowa in the N.C.A.A. West Regional today.

title: Market Place; Stock Index Futures
description: ''EVERYTHING'S up to date in Kansas City,'' a singer in the musical play ''Oklahoma'' assures us. ''They've gone about as fer as they can go.''

title: Juicy Juice Switch
description: Chiat/Day, New York, has another new account. It is the Fruitcrest Corporation of Garden City, L.I., which markets Juicy Juice fruit juice and previously had its account at Colarossi/Griswold-Eshleman.

title: R L Widmann Is Bride Of Prof. Daniel Harris
description: The marriage of R L Widmann of Boulder, Colo., to Daniel A. Harris took place yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Highland Park, N.J. Mayor Charles Mulhollen performed the ceremony.

title: AMERICAN LIMITS POLICY ON USE OF OTHER TICKETS
description: In a move that could hurt such troubled carriers as Braniff International Airways, American Airlines has advised travel agents that it would not honor tickets given away free or sold for minimal amounts by a carrier that went into default.

title: AFTER 39 VICTORIES, BIOLA LOSES FINAL
description: After 39 victories this season, the Biola Eagles have gone home losers. And the unheralded South Carolina-Spartanburg Rifles went home with their first National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball championship.

title: ISLANDERS A VICTIM OF ODDS
description: The Islanders tried to relax in this gambling town today, hoping for a change in their fortune. Among the things they wanted to get over was Saturday night's 3-0 loss to the Los Angeles Kings, the first time New York had been shut out in more than two years, a span covering 166 games.

title: Miles Chief Executive Adds Title of President
description: Theodor H. Heinrichs, 55, the German-born chairman and chief executive officer of Miles Laboratories Inc., will add the title of president on April 1. Miles, the health-care company best known for its production of Alka Seltzer, is a subsidiary of Bayer of West Germany.

title: Brooklyn Priest Robbed in Rectory
description: An intruder broke into St. Gregory Church in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and robbed a priest of $80, the police said. The robber, armed with a handgun, entered the Roman Catholic church at 224 Brooklyn Avenue at about 3:45 A.M. yesterday, using a rear window, according to the police.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Mary Cantwell MAE WEST: A Biography by George Eells and Stanley Musgrove. Morrow. 351 pages $15.50

title: POP: THE MAMAS AND PAPAS
description: WHEN it was announced not long ago that John Phillips was reforming the Mamas and the Papas with his daughter Mackenzie; the group's original vocalist Denny Doherty, and the 60's folk-pop singer Spanky McFarlane, one did not have high hopes.

title: Sports World Specials Irish Hoopla
description: Basketball is a thriving sport in the United States and many of the contributors to its success are people of Irish extraction. But, primarily because of unsatisfactory facilities in Ireland, it has until recently been considered a minor sport.

title: CLUTCH OF HATS APPEARS ON THE WINDY STREETS
description: No sooner does it get windy than New York's more fashionable women decide to put on their hats - for the express purpose, it would seem, of holding onto them. That seemed to be the case one day last week when a number of New Yorkers were spotted moving both with the wind and against it in fedora and gaucho, porkpie and toque.

title: Federated Acquisition
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. and The Children's Place Inc. said Friday their merger has been completed. The Delaware Chancery Court, after a hearing last Friday, allowed the merger to proceed by approving a settlement pending litigation relating to the merger. Federated paid $30.50 a share to acquire The Children's Place, which is has its headquarters in Pine Brook, N.J., the Cincinnati-based group said.

title: ISRAEL ENVOY NOTED FOR SPEAKING OUT
description: Moshe Arens, Israel's new Ambassador to the United States, has been in Washington about one month and is living up to his reputation as a plain-spoken hawk whose views on most Middle Eastern issues sometimes make Prime Minister Menachem Begin seem like a moderate.

title: BUCKS 129, JAZZ 100
description: Sidney Moncrief's 22 points and Mickey Johnson's 21 paced the Milwaukee Bucks to a 129-100 rout of the Utah Jazz today in the National Basketball Association. Milwaukee snapped a five-game losing streak and sent Utah to its 10th straight loss.

title: RIDING OUT THE RECESSION
description: For many corporate financial officers, the process of readying their companies to weather a downturn started a year or two ago: arranging for bank lines of credit, selling common stock or longterm bonds, reviewing marginal businesses and in some cases closing plants or selling them. But even for those who started early, the process continues - a nonstop effort to stay financially viable in the face of a weak economy.

title: Dr. M.M. Trapido Weds Miss Sheinblatt
description: Nancy Gail Sheinblatt, a financial analyst with the Bankers Trust Company, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Mark Trapido, a New York psychiatrist. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman performed the ceremony in the Terrace Restaurant at Butler Hall, Columbia University.

title: Soviet Reports Appointment Of Deputy Chief of the K.G.B.
description: Georgi K. Tsinev has been named first deputy chairman of the K.G.B., which runs the Soviet overseas intelligence operations and internal security force, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: Redbook to Cut Base and Rates
description: Joining its sister publication The Ladies Home Journal, which cut its circulation base 500,000 with the February issue, Redbook magazine said that it would cut its own base by the same amount, to 3.8 million, from 4.3 million, with the July issue. While that is an 11.6 percent cut in circulation, the ad rates will be cut only three percent.

title: 76ERS 128, KINGS 114
description: Julius Erving scored 30 points, including four spectacular dunk shots, to lead Philadelphia to its fifth straight triumph.

title: Question Box S. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: In the past, a National Football League team defending against an attempted field goal sometimes stationed a player directly in front of the crossbar. The player sometimes was able to jump up and knock the ball away, thus preventing a field goal. This strategy seems to have been dropped. Has the rule been changed?

title: The U.N. Today; March 15, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CUTS IN COLLEGE AID PLACING STUDENTS IN A VISE
description: Ann Purdy is a 43-year old mother of four sons, three of them in college. This year their total educational bills -$22,500 - surpass the less than $20,000 that she earns as an editorial assistant at Reader's Digest.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boarts International Inc. has named Jack F. Friedman executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Inmate Said to Flee Prison After Air Crash
description: The in-flight collision of a National Guard tanker plane and a light aircraft Saturday killed all six men in the planes. It also scattered debris at a state prison, creating confusion and enabling an inmate to escape.

title: MORE WOES FOR SLY WILLIAMS
description: Sly Williams, the Knicks' forward who has been suspended once this season, is in trouble again.

title: BEATTY WINS DIRECTORS GUILD AWARD FOR HIS WORK ON 'REDS'
description: For the second year in a row, the Directors Guild of America has given its award as best director to an actor. Warren Beatty won the 1981 prize as director of ''Reds.'' He also produced the film, starred in it and co-authored the screenplay.

title: DANCE: DAVID GORDON'S 'T.V. REEL'
description: DAVID GORDON has been experimenting with language and movement for a number of years. The comfortable look of the experiments tempts one to describe them as ''fooling around'' with words and dance, but Mr. Gordon's results have had far too much wit and disheveled elegance for that.

title: HOUSTON, MISSOURI SET FOR SHOWDOWN
description: Houston is headed to the National Collegiate Athletic Association regional semifinals for the first time since 1971, but it will have to contend with Missouri in the Tigers' home territory when they meet Friday in St. Louis.

title: HARE KRISHNA CHANT UNSETTLES SOVIET
description: The Hare Krishna movement, whose saffron-robed devotees have long been familiar in the United States, has begun making inroads in the Soviet Union, and the Kremlin does not appear to be pleased.

title: Arrows Triumph
description: Billy Gazonas scored 41 seconds into overtime, on an assist from Dragan Nikitovic, to give the New York Arrows a 4-3 victory over the Wichita Wings today. A sellout crowd of 9,196 at the Kansas Coliseum saw the Arrows take their sixth straight victory.

title: COONEY GETTING READY TO COME OUT OF LIMBO
description: GERRY COONEY hadn't shaved in two days, and now when he gave one of his playful but baleful glares his eyes were accentuated in the mask of his dark stubble.

title: Jordan, Case & McGrath Gets Selchow & Righter
description: Selchow & Righter, a maker of board games, electronic games and puzzles in Bay Shore, L.I., has moved its $1.5 million advertising account to Jordan, Case & McGrath from the J. Walter Thompson Company.

title: HOUSING NEAR A REFUGE FOR WILDLIFE IS OPPOSED
description: With the first soft spring air this month, the Canada geese and snow geese, the brant and blue-winged teal, the black ducks and the gadwall will put down at the 20,229-acre Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge here, a major stop on the Atlantic flyway, as they migrate north for the summer. The shorebirds will follow next month and the egrets, herons, ibises and warblers in May.

title: VILLANOVA, ALABAMA GAIN
description: St. John's and Northeastern went home today. And even if the Redmen had a 30-minute ride to their campus, it was not necessarily the less painful trip.

title: FINGERS EXPECTS QUICK RECOVERY
description: Rollie Fingers, Milwaukee's star reliever, said today that his separated left shoulder would not keep him out of Milwaukee's opener April 6, but Manager Buck Rodgers disagreed.

title: Advertising; Creamer To Acquire Harvey
description: THE eve of the weekend brought with it, as Fridays in adland frequently do, a rush of news of varying degrees of importance. A little acquisition here. A couple of account switches there. A publisher cutting his rate base. A new campaign or two. The usual grist.

title: Plants in Akron Accused Of Dangerous Emissions
description: Two chemical plants in this tiremanufacturing city emit quantities of a cancer-causing agent each year, according to a study made public by the National Clear Air Coalition, an umbrella group of environmental organizations.

title: NURSEMAID VERSUS MOTHER
description: THERE are two babies in Doris Prince's life - her son, Travis, who is being raised by her mother b ack home on the island of St. Vincent in the Caribbean, and Andrew, t he son of the woman who employs her as a nursemaid.

title: Michigan St. Wins Title in Hockey
description: Michigan State took a 4-0 first-period lead in its 4-1 victory over Notre Dame for the Central Collegiate Hockey Association championship and a berth in the N.C.A.A. playoffs.

title: Washington Watch; Oil-Import Fee: Little Chance
description: WASHINGTON ALTHOUGH both the White House and Congress are again weighing the pros and cons of an oil-import fee, the chances of something happening this election year are still rated slim by many analysts.

title: 1,000th 'Mo' Time' Friday
description: ''One Mo' Time,'' which opened Oct. 22, 1979, at the Village Gate, will reach its 1,000th performance Friday. The musical has a national touring company and companies in Washington and London. ''One Mo' Time,'' conceived and directed by Vernel Bagneris, is set in the Lyric Theater in New Orleans and uses music from the 1920's.

title: PHOENIX, DESPITE SEEMINGLY LIMITLESS SUPPLY OF WATER, NEEDS TO CONSERVE
description: Over the years, this city at the center of the nation's most arid region has sprawled farther and farther into the surrounding desert. It has relied for expansion on what seemed a limitless supply of water pumped from wells or carried from distant mountain reservoirs by a web of canals.

title: Cities Service To Sell Unit
description: The Cities Service Company is negotiating to sell its Copperhill-based industrial chemicals division to a Houston investor, company officials said.

title: Visualizing Progress
description: Spring training for some major league baseball teams now consists of more than physical conditioning and a return to the rudiments of batting, pitching and fielding. The St. Louis Cardinals and the Texas Rangers are also encouraging their players to adjust their mental attitudes to a winning disposition.

title: N.F.L. Pact Talks Resuming Today
description: Contract talks between representatives of the National Football League players and owners resume here Monday, with the owners expected to reject the players' demands for a fixed percentage of each team's gross profits.

title: THE BRITISH TREASURE HUNT FOR JEWELED RABBIT IS OVER
description: To the relief - or perhaps the frustration - of thousands of disappointed seekers on both sides of the Atlantic, the jeweled ''Masquerade'' rabbit has been found.

title: IRWIN TAKES GOLF BY 1 ON FINAL HOLE
description: Hale Irwin broke a three-way tie on the final hole of the Inverrary Classic today with what he called a miracle punch shot out of the trees to the green. He birdied the hole and beat Tom Kite and George Burns by one stroke.

title: GERULAITIS WINS
description: Vitas Gerulaitis captured the Belgian indoor tennis title today, beating Mats Wilander of Sweden, 4-6, 7-6, 6-2.

title: Bridge: With Good Vulnerability, One Can Get Imaginative
description: One of the most popular feats of the great Harry Houdini was to put himself in some dangerous and improbable situation, manacled in a box in a river for example, and then make a triumphant escape.

title: Bomb in Teheran Kills A Leading Clergyman
description: Assassins threw a bomb into the car of a prominent pro-Government clergyman in central Teheran today, killing the mullah and two guards, the official Iranian press agency reported.

title: Temple University Plans To Open Tokyo Branch
description: Temple University has announced a plan to open a branch in Tokyo. It would be the first American university to offer academic degrees in Japan, the school said.

title: School Is No Place to Compromise
description: New Jersey education officials have been ducking the issue of teacher training for years, even ignoring a state study that charged the system encouraged incompetence. Instead, they have cited exaggerated claims of improvements in reading and math skills to justify the status quo.

title: Nuggets 127 Warriors 101
description: DENVER (AP) - Kiki Vandeweghe scored 26 points, and Glen Gondrezick added a season-high 24 to spark Denver.

title: Canadian Jobless Rise
description: A record 1.12 million Canadians were unemployed in February, increasing the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate to 8.6 percent, Statistics Canada said.

title: N.P. KAMANIN, SOVIET GENERAL
description: Gen. Nikolai P. Kamanin, a prominent airman in the Soviet Union and the first director of astronaut training in his country's space program, is dead at the age of 73.

title: EAGLES UPSET DE PAUL
description: Boston College today silenced critics who had said it did not deserve to be in the national collegiate tournament. The Eagles turned in the biggest upset of the 44th annual championship by beating De Paul, the nation's second-ranked team, 82-75, in the second round of the Midwest regionals.

title: SEYMOUR ENTERING RACE FOR SENATE
description: Whitney North Seymour Jr., a former United States Attorney, announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate from New York, now that the original candidate has withdrawn under pressure.

title: IF WASHINGTON CARES ABOUT INDIAN RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Skier Killed in Avalanche
description: An avalanche on a rocky slope Saturday near the Arapahoe Basin Ski Area killed a skier identified as Mark Frieze, 30 years old, of Breckenridge, Colo. Lillian Ross, a spokesman for the ski area, said Mr. Frieze was skiing outside of the designated slope when the slide came.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT SUNS
description: Robert Parish scored 33 points, including 10 in a third-quarter comeback, to lead Boston to a 105-92 victory over the Phoenix Suns today. It was the Celtics' 11th straight victory.

title: EDWARD J. HANLEY, STEEL LEADER, DIES
description: Edward J. Hanley, former chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, died Saturday in Presbyterian-University Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: A Child of Industry
description: The merger of the United States Steel Corporation and Marathon Oil Company, which was approved last week, will have an unusual ramification, according to Eunice Davenport.

title: SCA Services Rejects Merger
description: Citing antitrust questions, the board of directors at SCA Services Inc. has voted against going ahead with a proposal to be acquired by Browning-Ferris Industries of Houston,

title: News Analysis
description: For the last two weeks, the Reagan Administration has conducted what senior officials acknowledge has been an intense public relations campaign designed to dispel doubts about its policies in Central America. The effort, which has relied heavily on the use of intelligence information, has produced mixed results. Until Friday, officials thought they were making significant headway. Some members of Congress, including several influential committee chairmen, came away from private intelligence briefings saying they were convinced that the Administration had strong evidence to support its charges of Soviet and Cuban involvement in Central America and of Nicaraguan aid to guerrillas in El Salvador.

title: SPECIAL OFFICERS PROTEST ON UNION
description: More than 100 special police officers seeking to publicize their demand that they no longer be represented by Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters demonstrated yesterday evening in midtown. The special officers are attached to various city agencies, such as the Health and Hospitals Corporation and the Board of Higher Education.

title: HERZOG THE DEALER GOING FOR JACKPOT
description: Which team had the best overall record in the National League's East last year: the Philadelphia Phillies, who won the first half of the split season, or the Montreal Expos, who won the second half?

title: Aspen Skiing Account Goes to Levine, Huntley
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver has become the agency for the Aspen Skiing Company, which operates five ski areas in Colorado and in Vancouver, Canada.

title: THE LANDMARKS PUZZLE: A COHESIVE ROW IS SPLIT
description: A curious chapter in New York City's landmarks history, embodied by an orphan-like Upper East Side building with wreckers' scaffolding at its base, is about to come to an end.

title: FAIRNESS IS ISSUE IN BUDGET DEBATE
description: The equity and fairness of President Reagan's economic and social program have emerged as a political issue affecting prospects for Congressional approval of his budget proposals.

title: 'Nightingale' in Previews
description: ''Nightingale,'' a musical by Charles Strouse based on Hans Christian Andersen's ''The Emperor and the Nightingale,'' is in previews for the four weeks at the First All Children's Theater, 37 West 65th Street. Sets have been designed by Oliver Smith; John Schuck will appear as guest artist. The company will perform the play April 16 at the Wolf Trap Farm Park near Washington and will open in New York the last week in April.

title: U.S. to Use Computers In More Fraud Detection
description: The Health and Human Services Department, expanding its electronic battle against fraud, is preparing a nationwide computer search of Medicaid, Medicare and welfare files for suspicious patterns.

title: ELEVATED TRACKS HAVE REDUCED RAIL ACCIDENTS
description: The construction of elevated tracks for Long Island Rail Road trains at some intersections has significantly reduced the kind of accident that took the lives of nine teen-agers in Mineola early yesterday, according to rail officials.

title: THE DEFECTS IN A COURT SYSTEM FOR YOUTH CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: PEKING SHOWS RENEWED CONCERN OVER INCREASE IN BIRTH RATE
description: The Peking leadership, showing concern that the country's birth rate is beginning to rise again, has formally warned Chinese to adhere to the strict family planning measures that it has laid down.

title: MISTRIAL DENIED FOR VON BULOW
description: A motion for a mistrial was denied today by the judge in the trial of Claus von Bulow, who is accused of attempting to murder his wife.

title: Thomas Herzog Marries Penny McNeill, Teacher
description: Penny McNeill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David McNeill of Seaside, N.C., was married yesterday in Washington to Thomas N. Herzog, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan G. Herzog of New York. The Rev. Campbell Gillon performed the ceremony in the Georgetown Presbyterian Church.

title: RANGERS, DOWN 4-1, TIED AT 5-5
description: The Rangers played about 18 minutes of near-perfect hockey in the third period last night, attacking the Washington Capitals relentlessly with a splendid display of sharp passing, swift skating and deadly shooting.

title: PROSECUTION FOR DOMESTIC SPYING REJECTED IN 1977
description: Justice Department lawyers concluded in 1977 that although the nation's intelligence agencies had engaged in electronic surveillance that might have violated the ''fundamental constitutional rights'' of American citizens, Federal prosecution was neither practical nor advisable.

title: A JAPANESE MODEL RECALLS GIACOMETTI AND PARIS
description: KAMAKURA, Japan YOU cannot miss Isaku Yanaihara. One lock of gray hair stands almost vertically on his brow as he strides through the crowds outside the station, wearing a voluminous gray kimono, his feet shod with Japanese clogs.

title: FRENCH CONSERVATIVES GAIN IN VOTE FOR LOCAL COUNCILS
description: Elections were held today in France to choose delegates for local councils, and preliminary results suggested that the conservative opposition had scored gains over President Francois Mitterrand's nine-month-old governing coalition.

title: Best Wishes
description: Ken Boyer, the former star third baseman and manager, is battling cancer at a hospital in Mexico. A fund to defray his medical expenses, that was set up by Manager Billy Martin of the Oakland A's, recently received a contribution and a letter from Irvin Muchnick of Manhattan.

title: AFRIKAANS PRESS GOADS BOTHA ON NEED FOR CHANGE
description: ''We are waiting, Mr. Botha, we are waiting!'' That note of exasperation, sounded in an article on the need for effective political change, would have been regarded as part of a dreary ritual if it had appeared in an editorial in one of the opposition English-language newspapers.

title: BARBER IS WINNER
description: Miller Barber, just two weeks shy of his 51st birthday, overcame torrential rains and a soggy course today and captured the $300,000 Vintage Invitation seniors' golf tournament.

title: SCYPION OUTSLUGGED BY GREEN
description: It was a typical middleweight fight. The winning manager had to be separated from the losing fighter by the referee. The losing manager protested the decision, and the losing fighter protested so much that he was suspended by the State Athletic Commission. There were butts and clinches and only flashes of boxing. It was a typical middleweight fight, except that the winner, James (Hard Rock) Green, does not consider himself a middleweight, nor does he look like one.

title: TRAIN KILLS 9 TEEN-AGERS ON L.I. AS VAN GOES PAST CROSSING GATE
description: Nine teen-agers in a van that apparently drove around a flashing railroad crossing gate were killed early today when a Long Island Rail Road train plowed into the van and hurled it 150 yards down the tracks, the Nassau County police said.

title: Ideology and Clean Air
description: Congress is struggling once again to revise the Clean Air Act, a task heavy with both symbol and substance. The hugely complex law, passed in 1970, is the crowning achievement of the environmental movement. President Reagan, who made regulatory reform a rallying cry of his campaign, singled out the act as a chief candidate for review. But the Administration, in its haste to unshackle industry from regulation, may have fumbled the chance to make the act more efficient.

title: JOYCE CELEBRATED AT RUTGERS, AFTER A FASHION
description: It was less a portrait of the artist than a reckoning with him. Not a symposium, exactly, though the savants and critics were there. Not a Hibernian wake, though the drinks flowed freely. It was, appropriately enough, a Joycean moment, sometimes accessible, sometimes remote, but never, never predictable.

title: ECONOMISTS EXPECT CUT IN INFLATION
description: A broad range of economists predict that February's decline in producer prices - the first drop in six years - will be reflected in consumer prices during the next couple of months as businesses sell off their inventories.

title: LOOKING THE OTHER WAY
description: Ory Bernstein, an Israeli poet and lawyer, urged his countrymen recently to do what in fact few of them do: face the reality of military rule in the occupied territories. They should stop averting their eyes, he said, from the way Israel deals with the Arab inhabitants of the West Bank and Gaza.

title: NEW ISSUES SLOWING
description: After last week's deluge of new corporate notes and bonds, when 17 issues with a face amount of $1.9 billion were sold, underwriters have scaled back their financing plans this week but warn that the volume could increase if investor demand strengthens.

title: U.N. Asserts Asia Will Need $75 Billion for Food Supplies
description: Developing countries in Asia will need as much as $75 billion in investment to insure adequate food supplies in the first half of the 1980's, according to a United Nations report issued today.

title: ON A SPRINGLIKE SUNDAY, SHOPPERS BLOSSOM ON ORCHARD STREET
description: A blustery breath of spring coursed along Orchard Street yesterday and merchants in the traditional center of Lower East Side shopping expressed pleasure at the swelling ranks of bargain hunters.

title: RULE ON REPORTING WASTE SUSPENDED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has suspended its requirement that manufacturers of hazardous wastes report each year on what happens to those wastes and is proposing instead to take an annual survey of 10 percent of the companies involved.

title: NEW FOCUS ON NARCISSISM OFFERS ANALYSTS INSIGHT INTO GRANDIOSITY AND
description: EMPTINESS By MAYA PINES

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: Results reflect a change in accounting for vacation pay benefits which decreased earnings by $13,500 for the latest qr and $10,000 for the yr ago period

title: PACIFIC COAST PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes $1,161,000 gain from the sale of land

title: LDB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $797,000 for the qr and $1,544,000 for the 6 mos

title: Trial Begins in Miami On Haitian Detention
description: A lawsuit seeking the release of about 3,000 Haitian immigrants from detention camps went to trial today in Federal District Court.

title: FUTURES BROKERAGE PLAN BY MORGAN IS OPPOSED
description: J.P. Morgan & Company's proposal to be the first bank holding company to trade in financial futures has encountered stiff opposition from some commodity brokers and dealers who fear that Morgan and other banks may lure away their customers.

title: Renault Sale in Algeria
description: Algeria has ordered 4,700 Renault trucks, the auto maker's president, Francois Zanotti, said today. The contract was signed, he added, despite an Arab League boycott of Renault because of its 46.4 percent interest in the American Motors Corporation.

title: Wrong-Way Fliers
description: Most bird watchers are thrilled to sight a bird never before seen in their area - a western warbler in Virginia, for instance, or a European finch in New England. These anomalies are usually the result of storms or gales that blow migrating birds off course. But sometimes an alien bird just shows up, with no meteorological accounting for its presence.

title: PHILADELPHIA HAS ROOMS TO SPARE IN HOTEL BOOM
description: In the days when people like W.C. Fields were knocking Philadelphia, a lot of others found something consoling. With New York and Washington an easy train ride away, many found they did not have to spend the night in any of the hotels here.

title: SOVIET GENERALS DESCEND ON NEW DELHI
description: Led by Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the 73-year-old Soviet Defense Minister, 16 senior Soviet officers arrived here to affirm the Soviet-Indian relationship as obviously as possible.

title: REAGAN AIDE SAYS HIGH RATE LEVELS IMPERIL RECOVERY
description: The Administration's chief economist said today that persistently high interest rates have jeopardized the prospects for a business recovery starting this spring and continuing through 1983 and beyond.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Systems Inc., Arlington Heights, Ill., has appointed Bruce J. Gibbs corporate controller.

title: U.S. Ends Mercedes Antitrust Suit
description: The Justice Department today abandoned an antitrust suit against Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc., saying it had decided not to oppose the company's requirement that dealers sell only company-supplied replacement parts.

title: By Sports of The Times; Old Coaches Still Endure
description: IN college basketball, the old coaches are the only constant. The players change but the old coaches endure, synonymous with their colleges. But as this year's national championship tournament awaits its regional semifinals and finals, several old coaches dominate the plot.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 16, 1982
description: International Differing views on Nicaragua were suggested by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. He made public the proposals he presented Sunday to Mexico's Foreign Minister for settling problems with Nicaragua over El Salvador, but said he had no reason to assume they would be acceptable to the Sandinist leadership. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The leftist government of Nicaragua suspended all individual rights and guarantees for 30 days because of what it said were United States ''plans of aggression against our country.'' Dainel Ortega Saavedra of the ruling Sandinist junta said the suspension of rights might be extended ''in keeping with the prevailing circumstances in the country.'' (A1:5.)

title: Transcript of statement, page A6.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. yesterday made public the proposals that he presented to the Mexican Foreign Minister Sunday for settling differences with Nicaragua over El Salvador. But Mr. Haig said there was no reason to assume they would be acceptable to the Sandinist leadership.

title: The First of 10 Missile Boats Delivered by France to Libya
description: France has delivered to Libya the first of 10 missile-firing patrol boats ordered five years ago in a $600 million contract, Defense Ministry officials said today.

title: L.I.R.R. ENGINEER: THERE WAS NO TIME TO STOP
description: The engineer of the Long Island Rail Road train that smashed into a van and killed nine teen-agers at a grade-level crossing early Sunday in Mineola, L.I., said yesterday there was no way he could have stopped in time to avoid a collision.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS ON NICARAGUA
description: Following is a transcript of a statement by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. at a news conference yesterday at the United Nations Plaza Hotel, as recorded by The New York Times: Following is a transcript of a statement by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. at a news conference yesterday at the United Nations Plaza Hotel, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: P.M. HAMILTON, 83, DIES ON THE COAST
description: Maj. Gen. Pierpont Morgan Hamilton of the Air Force, retired, who won the Medal of Honor in World War II, died March 6 in the Veterans' Hospital in Brentwood, Calif., after a brief illness. General Hamilton, 83 years old, of Santa Barbara, Calif., was also a retired industry executive.

title: SERVISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt HOW LIFE IMITATES THE WORLD SERIES. By Thomas Boswell. 296 pages. Doubleday. $14.95.

title: OAK IS NOW PLACING ITS BET ON PAY TV
description: The first bets on cable television were placed by industry giants such as Warner Communications Inc., which teamed up with the American Express Company to form Warner-Amex, and by Cox Cable, a unit of the Cox Broadcasting Corporation.

title: CHEMICAL WEAPONS MUST BE ELIMINATED
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCHIVES USERS LAMENT BUDGET CUTS
