description: Suddenly there are more than whispers in the coffered research rooms of the National Archives, the tucked-away cloisters where Alex Haley discovered some of his roots and Barbara W. Tuchman found the original decoding of a telegram urging the conclusion of a Mexican-German alliance during World War I.

title: CITY CENTER RENOVATION SET FOR SUMMER
description: The City Center, which has long been criticized for its poor sightlines, will undergo a $700,000 interior renovation next summer to correct the problem. The renovation will be paid for by a Federal grant that was saved by Congress from the Reagan Administration's attempt to freeze funds for the economic revitalization of cities.

title: Talking Business with Timothy S. Green, Gold Analyst; A Global View On Bullion
description: Gold's traditional attraction as a constant store of value in times of economic uncertainty faded when wild speculation drove its price up to a record $875 an ounce in January 1980. Since then, bullion's value has declined steadily. Yesterday afternoon, the London fixing price was $312, its lowest level since the summer of 1979, when it traded between $310 and $315.

title: President Elected, By Liberty Life
description: Stuart L. Lerner, 51 years old, has been elected president of the Liberty Life Assurance Company, a major life insurer based in Boston with more than $5 billion worth of life insurance in force. He succeeds Melvin B. Bradshaw, 59, who was appointed to the vacant post of chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer of the subsidiary of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company.

title: Steel Output Down
description: Steel production declined by 1 percent, to 1,738,000 net tons, in the week ended last Saturday compared with the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. In the corresponding week a year earlier, steel output totaled 2,568,000 tons. Capacity utilization was 59 percent last week compared with 86.7 percent in the corresponding 1981 week, the trade group said.

title: News Analysis
description: It set City Hall against a civic group, generated one of the more substantive political tempests in quite some time and provided at least two sides in the forthcoming campaign for governor with ammunition.

title: KELLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr ago results increased by $45,397 for the qr and $23,288 for the 6 mos from the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 43

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
PRAB ROBOTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
THE RAIN IN FORT WAYNE BRINGS OUT HIGH SPIRITS
description: Voluntarism is alive and well in Fort Wayne. It was not loss of Federal funds, but the worst floods since 1913 that turned out this city of 170,000.

title: STOP & SHOP COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $372,000 for the qr and $4.1 million for the yr...C-Includes $6.6 million gain from the divestiture of nineteen supermarkets in New Jersey

title: HIT OR MISS. FEDERALISM
description: Since President Reagan's ''new federalism'' would turn over the fate of many social programs to the tender mercies - and often meager resources - of state legislatures, let's take a look at one of those deliberative bodies, Mississippi's. A better laboratory for testing the possible ill effects of the President's proposal would be hard to find.

title: Torre's Early Choice
description: Manager Joe Torre of the Atlanta Braves has made an earlier-thanusual decision: Phil Niekro, the knuckleball specialist who becomes 43 years old on April 1, will open for the Braves in San Diego on April 6. Niekro has apparently recovered fully from the hamstring pull he suffered during his first week in camp. Torre also named Bob Horner, the slugging third baseman, the Braves' captain, their first team leader since Hank Aaron in 1974.

title: RECLAIMING OUR STREETS
description: We all love a parade, the adage goes, so we're going to have to mobilize the equivalent of an army brigade of law-enforcement officers to try to prevent the Vandals, Visigoths and garden-variety hooligans from taking over this year's St. Patrick's Day march tomorrow.

title: Accounts
description: * Royal Silk, Clifton, N.J., a silk shirt importer, to Warriner Mandelbaum Palladino Inc. * Fruitcrest Corporation, Garden City, L.I., to Chiat/Day Inc.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Quebec Nordiques say that all is forgiven now that Pat Hickey has reported to the team. As a consequence, Hickey won't be fined for failing to report within the 48 hours after he was assigned to Quebec by the National Hockey League on March 8.

title: Reliever Escapes Jam
description: Renie Martin, a Kansas City Royals relief pitcher, found himself in his most difficult jam Sunday night. Martin said he had just walked out of a convenience store in Fort Myers, Fla. when he saw a police car and two policemen, one of them with a shotgun pointed in his direction.

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Chase Lowers Mortgage Rate
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank lowered its mortgage rates yesterday, according to James R. Panepinto, vice president. Rates on fixed-rate mortgages on one- to four-family homes were reduced to 16 1/2 percent plus 3 points from 17 percent and 3 1/2 points.

title: Rebels Are Repulsed In Salvadoran Capital
description: Leftist guerrillas were repulsed by security forces in fierce fighting today after attacking the headquarters of the First Infantry Brigade in San Salvador and several districts in and about the capital.

title: ONE SNAG IS LEFT
description: The Casino Control Commission reserved a casino license for the Trump Organization of New York in record time today - less than two hours. But the commission rejected the company's request that its Atlantic City landlords be exempted from licensing qualifications.

title: Simplicity, NCC
description: The Simplicity Pattern Company, the nation's dominant maker of sewing patterns, announced that NCC Energy Ltd. had proposed that the merger of the two companies be delayed. NCC Energy is a London-based concern with oil, gas and mineral interests in the United States, Britain, Ireland and Australia.

title: Health Units Agree to Tie
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc. announced it had signed a definitive agreement under which its Hillhaven subsidiary would acquire National Health Enterprises Inc. for about $100 million in cash and existing debt of about $40 million.

title: THE COLUMBIA'S FIRST THREE MISSIONS
description: The countdown for the third flight of the space shuttle Columbia is scheduled to begin Thursday morning at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The launching is set for 10 A.M. Monday.

title: STOCK DOESN'T TRADE
description: Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago-based retailer, asked the New York Stock Exchange yesterday not to open trading in its stock while the board of directors considered a ''proposed extraordinary transaction.''

title: OPEC: TRYING TO BE A CARTEL
description: As the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries prepares to meet in Vienna on Friday, analysts are suggesting that the oncefeared alliance of oil-producing nations has lost its pre-eminent role in setting world oil prices, perhaps irretrievably.

title: Cartwright Is Ill
description: Bill Cartwright, the Knicks' starting center, will be lost to the team at least three days because of a strep throat. Cartwright, who is in a hospital, will miss the home game tonight against San Antonio, but the Knicks hope to have him back in time for the next game, Saturday at home against Atlanta. ... Sly Williams showed up for a Knick team photograph yesterday but then passed up practice, saying he still wasn't feeling well.

title: SOVIET SS-20 FORCE IS PUT AT 300
description: The State Department said today that the Soviet Union had deployed a total of 300 intermediate-range SS-20 missiles. That is 20 more than the United States had previously counted.

title: French Vote Strengthens Position of Socialists
description: The ruling Socialists today emerged from local elections with their position strengthened as France's leading party, but the left as a whole suffered a reverse after only nine months in power.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Last fall, the huge American Express Company brought its traveler's check and credit card divisions together into a single worldwide financial services group, with five regions. And yesterday was the first day on the job for the first president of the Europe-Middle-East-Africa region, James T. Larkin, a 50-year-old American Express executive. Mr. Larkin's appointment completes the roster of regional heads.

title: General Coffee
description: The General Coffee Corporation has purchased the coffee division of Nabisco Brands Inc. for more than $15 million. General Coffee said that the acquisition included all Chase & Sanborn labels and a 190,000-square-foot roasting, decaffeinating and packing plant in New Orleans. General Coffee said Chase & Sanborn's operations in New Orleans would continue operating with current management as part of the company's coffee division.

title: SEYMOUR A. BERGER
description: Seymour A. Berger, president of Empire Realty Inc., developer and owner of residential and commercial properties in New York City and other cities, died after a long illness Sunday at his home in Jericho, L.I. He was 67 years old.

title: Johnson Says the Alouettes Asked to Reduce His Pay
description: The financially troubled Montreal Alouettes have asked Billy (White Shoes) Johnson to take a cut in pay, Johnson said today.

title: Domestic Strike Ends
description: A follow-up: Fed up with having to serve as what she described as ''mother, cook, driver, laundress, go-fer, and money-changer,'' Mary Ellen Shaver went on strike against her children last month. She said she was through being their servant, until further notice.

title: 6 Bombs Do Minor Damage In Towns of Northern Greece
description: Six homemade bombs exploded in northern Greece over the weekend at Communist Party offices, two banks and two shops, the police announced today.

title: SUSPECT IN STOUFFER FIRE VARIED HIS ACCOUNT, INVESTIGATOR SAYS
description: The deputy police commissioner who headed the inquiry into the Stouffer's Inn fire testified today that the defendant, Luis Marin, had given the police several versions of his activities on the day of the blaze before saying that he had accidentally started it by spilling lit Sterno.

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $18,000 for the qr and $622,000 for the yr and tax credits of $111,000 for the qr and $644,000 for the yr...C-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $546,000 for the qr and $1,040, for the yr

title: LIBERALS TAKE BIG LEAD IN COLOMIBIAN ELECTIONS
description: Colombia's governing Liberal Party took a commanding lead today in returns from national elections held on Sunday, but it appeared that its prospects in presidential elections to be held in May were threatened by a party split.

title: G.M. IS ASKING FOR CONCESSIONS GRANTED BY FORD
description: The General Motors Corporation today asked the United Automobile Workers for concessions nearly identical to those the union recently granted to the Ford Motor Company.

title: Reagan Aide Explains 'Senior Official' Joke
description: On Saturday morning in Washington, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. held a meeting with a group of reporters and spoke at length about his conviction that the problem in El Salvador could not be solved in El Salvador alone, but on a ''global'' basis in which the Soviet Union, Cuba, Nicaragua and other Latin American countries had to be involved.

title: THEATER: RUDNICK'S POOR LITTLE LAMBS' OF YALE
description: THE Ivy League just hasn't been the same since ''The National Lampoon's Animal House,'' the movie that proved that fraternity boys at big non-Eastern universities are the ones who have all the hedonistic fun. But Paul Rudnick, a Yale graduate and the author of a new comedy at the Theater at St. Peter's Church, is out to get even.

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Jan 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,747,000 for the qr and $8,654,000 for the yr...C-Includes $17,650,000 extraordinary gain

title: ARCATA APPROVES $251 MILLION OFFER
description: The Arcata Corporation announced yesterday that its board had accepted a new proposal for the acquisition of the company by an investment group amounting to $251 million.

title: Jewel's Net Up 53.4%
description: The Jewel Companies, a supermarket chain, announced yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter, ended Jan. 31, rose 53.4 percent, to $34.2 million, or $2.37 a share, from $22.3 million, or $1.56, in the similar period a year earlier.

title: Bonn Blocks Money Plan
description: The European Economic Community's plans for revamping the European Monetary System ran into a snag today when West Germany rejected proposed changes in the joint currency float.

title: FOR NEW BRITISH PARTY, SCOTS OFFER TALL HURDLE
description: Through the snow and sleet of a residential neighborhood on the west side of this old industrial city last week trudged a man fearful that a dream was evaporating.

title: Out-of-Park Single
description: It wasn't that Gary Redus, a rookie outfielder for Cincinnati, wanted to take a shortcut when he hit an apparent grand-slam home run Sunday against Philadelphia, breaking a 2-2 exhibition tie in the bottom of the ninth inning. Redus just didn't see the ball go out of the park.

title: PURITAN FASHIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Held to Deadlines In School Bias Inquiries
description: A Federal District Court judge declined today to hold Education Secretary T.H. Bell in contempt of court for missing deadlines for investigating school discrimination complaints. But the judge said the department must remain under the deadlines.

title: 9 Confessions Voided In Red Brigades Case
description: A judge today threw out the confessions of nine Red Brigades terrorists accused of kidnapping Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, ruling they were made to the police under duress shortly after the suspects were arrested.

title: Alsands Seeks New Partners
description: The Alsands consortium has approached six companies about replacing the five partners that backed out of the $13 billion synthetic oil project, C. William Daniel, president of Shell Canada Ltd., told reporters. Mr. Daniel did not name the concerns or provide any details of the discussions.

title: 'Made in New York'?
description: When the people at the New York State Department of Commerce were putting together some ''Made in New York'' ads to help attract new industry to the state, they thought it would be a good idea to include the corporate logotypes of companies already operating in the Empire State.

title: PIRATES AND PURITANS AT MILAN
description: Every plane that has landed at the international airport here in the last few days has deposited, along with its load of skiers heading for nearby Alpine resorts, a host of seekers of the fashion grail. They come from North and South America, Africa and the Far East.

title: Advertising; Saatchi Acquires Compton
description: IT was a case of a lion gobbling up an elephant. In one of the surprise agency buys of this decade, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the pride of the British advertising scene, has acquired the larger Compton Communications of New York. Never before has a foreign-owned agency had such a large presence in the United States.

title: National Patent
description: The National Patent Development Corporation of New York, a maker of medical and optical products including soft contact lenses, said a Federal court in California had denied a request by Continuous Curve Contact Lens Inc., a Revlon subsidiary, for a stay of the injunction granted by the court Feb. 5 prohibiting Continuous Curve from manufacturing or distributing its Bufilcon soft contact lenses. The injunction is effective in 30 days unless Continuous Curve obtains a stay. National Patent said that the Feb. 5 ruling held that Continuous Curve had willfully and deliberately infringed its patents.

title: Chess Kupreichik of Soviet Union Finishes First in Hastings
description: A grandmaster with a reputation as only a short-distance runner went the whole stretch in the 57th Hastings International Tournament in England - Viktor Kupreichik of the Soviet Union scored 9-4 to take first place. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Kupreichik 6 1 6 9 Smyslov 3 0 10 8 Speelman 4 1 8 8 Andersson 2 0 11 7 1/2 Mestel 4 2 7 7 1/2 Lein 3 2 8 7 Rivas 4 3 6 7 Short 4 3 6 7 Taulbut 2 2 9 6 1/2 Littlewood 4 5 4 6 Chandler 2 5 6 5 Christiansen 1 5 7 4 1/2 Ree 1 5 6 4 Szabo 2 7 4 4

title: Bronx Woman, 80, Is Found Slain
description: An 80-year-old woman was found beaten to death in her eighth-floor apartment at 1290 Grand Concourse, near Claremont Park, in the Bronx.

title: NATIONAL STEEL PLANS WAGE CUT
description: The National Steel Corporation, anticipating losses in the first quarter, said yesterday that it would cut wages and other employee benefits.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Are the days and nights of equal length along the equator the year round?

title: Tulane 56 Nevada-Las Vegas 51
description: Paul Thompson scored 19 points and led a Tulane rally that overcame a 9-point second-half deficit.

title: TV FILM: 'THE GIFT OF LIFE,' MOTHERHOOD
description: JOLEEN SUTTON (Susan Dey), the wife of a small-town gas station owner and a mother of two, is watching a television talk show one day. The guest is a woman named Carol who has agreed to have a baby and sign it over to a childless couple. ''Carol, are you some kind of kook?'' the host asks. No, Carol explains, she just believes that everyone who wants children ought to have a chance to raise them. Joleen is so impressed by this that she decides to become a surrogate mother herself.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Ferocious Mr. Reagan and the Freeze
description: ''Counting counting they wer all the time. They had iron then and big fire. ... They had machines et numbers up. They fed them numbers and they fractiont out the Power of things. They had the Nos. of the rain bow and the Power of the air all workit out with counting which is how they got boats in the air and picters on the wind. ... They put in the 1 Big 1 and ... there come a flash of lite then bigger nor the woal worl and it ternt the nite to day. Then every thing gone black. Nothing only nite for years on end. ...'' That's the way civilization ended in Russell Hoban's remarkable novel, ''Riddley Walker.'' Modern literature is punctuated with other portraits of The Bomb, such as ''On the Beach'' and ''Dr. Strangelove.'' Art and science, fact and fiction have drilled it into us for years: nuclear weapons can be hazardous to our health.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
NUTRI-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Drug Trial for Doctors
description: American physicians are being asked to take a dose of their own medicine. In the next few days, 200,000 male doctors will receive a letter requesting their participation in a trial to see if two ''drugs,'' aspirin and beta carotene, can ward off the nation's leading killer diseases.

title: TOYOTA IN MERGER WITH SALES ARM
description: The Toyota Motor Company and its selling arm, the Toyota Motor Sales Company, have signed a merger agreement that will create the largest manufacturing company in Japan.

title: BRIEFING
description: Startling Comment

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: wide action?

title: Abrams Sues 5 Milk Dealers On Charges of Fixing Prices
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams today accused five milk dealers of conspiring to rig prices and markets for raw milk from almost 1,000 upstate dairy farmers.

title: PAY LESS DRUG STORES NORTHWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1981

title: EMERGING ISSUES: CRIME, ENERGY AND POLISH DEBTS
description: A few issues generally dominate the agenda on Capitol Hill, gathering, like leafy trees, the sunlight of publicity and stunting other matters struggling to receive a public hearing.

title: COMTECH TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $1,430,000 for the qr and $1,525,000 for the 6 mos and $194,414 gain for the 6 mos from the sale of land...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $41,744 for the qr and $87,732 for the 6 mos, tax benefits of $50,000 for the qr and $74,000 for the 6 mos and tax credits of $926,000 for the qr and $933,000 for the 6 mos

title: Sally Little Shoots 70-288 To Win Olympia Golf by 1
description: Sally Little shot a three-under-par 70 today, overtaking Donna H. White and winning the $150,000 Olympia Gold women's golf tournament for the second consecutive year.

title: FLAGG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Case of the Missing Cello Bows; The Missing Bows
description: As soon as he had taken two steps from the cab, Jack Rosenberg was saying yesterday, he knew he had made a mistake. By then, however, it was too late.

title: SOVIET 'YELLOW RAIN' IS REAL AND DEVASTATING
description: To the Editor:

title: HYSTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes gains from liquidation of inventories of $2.7 millio for the qr and $3 million for the yr...C-Includes gains from liquidation on inventories of $3.5 million for the qr and $4.7 million for the yr; results refllct the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 for foreign currency translation

title: The U.N. Today; March 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: SOVIET 'YELLOW RAIN' IS REAL AND DEVASTATING
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Analysis
description: The military confrontation between Palestine Liberation Organization forces and Israel along the border between Israel and Lebanon has taken on new dimensions, with the P.L.O. now able to attack most of the cities and towns in northern Israel at long range.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: IT was only 70 years ago that a heart attack was diagnosed in a living patient for the first time. The patient was a 55-year-old Chicago banker who survived for only 52 hours, and the diagnosis, confirmed by an autopsy, was made by Dr. James B. Herrick without the benefit of electrocardiograms, blood tests and other sophisticated medical tools now routinely used in cardiology. However, doctors were slow to accept the new condition, and the case report, Dr. Herrick later recalled, ''fell like a dud.''

title: Atlanta Suburb Requires Residents to Own Guns
description: An ordinance requiring heads of households to own and maintain guns and ammunition was adopted tonight by the City Council in this Atlanta suburb.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As long as I can cross the Potomac River and get out here with real people every once in a while, I'll keep the faith.'' - President Reagan, to Republicans in Montgomery, Ala. (A21:4.)

title: No Headline
description: SYRACUSE IS OUSTED BY BRADLEY

title: No Headline
description: NAME OF TIMES IS WITHDRAWN FROM COLLEGE GUIDEBOOK TITLE

title: MUBARAK SENDS WORD TO BEGIN ON DISPUTE OVER TRIP
description: President Hosni Mubarak sent his Foreign Minister to Israel today with a message for Prime Minister Menachem Begin that officials here said dealt in part with a dispute over the Egyptian leader's proposed visit to Israel this month.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $31,406 for the qr and $56,422 for the 6 mos and tax credits of $192,000 for the qr and $212,000 for the 6 mos

title: SCHENECTADY BANK GETS HARTFORD UNIT
description: The troubled Hartford Federal Savings and Loan Association, which was merged over the weekend into the Schenectady Savings Bank, began business today as Northeast Savings, a combined Connecticut and New York thrift institution.

title: WHAT DEBTS CAN DO TO MEDICAL STUDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME IN EL SALVADOR EXPRESS RAGE OVER REBELS' SABOTAGE CAMPAIGN
description: Felled power pylons, broken bridges and burned trucks mark the road between San Salvador and this city almost as regularly as the 136 white concrete roadside kilometer markers.

title: Decision by Walker Is Due
description: Herschel Walker, the Georgia running back, has called a news conference for Tuesday to announce whether he will challenge a National Football League rule prohibiting underclassmen from turning professional, school officials said today.

title: PAPERCRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BIOTECHNOLOGY SHAKEOUT IS SEEN IN CASH SQUEEZE
description: The biotechnology industry is experiencing a financial squeeze that analysts say is laying the groundwork for the disappearance of a number of smaller companies in the field, possibly by the end of the year.

title: Underwriting Rule Change to Begin Today
description: The new Securities and Exchange Commission regulation governing underwriting procedures - known as Rule 415 - is scheduled to be published today in the Federal Register, after which it becomes immediately effective for a nine-month trial period, a spokesman for the commission said yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT DENOUNCES 'PROPAGANDA' OF FOES AGAINST BUDGET PLAN
description: Before two Southern Legislatures, President Reagan today denounced a Congressional ''propaganda campaign'' that he said was designed to force him to roll back his program of income tax reductions as a means of lowering the Federal deficit.

title: Ladder Recall Renewed After Child Dies on Toy
description: The Government today announced a renewed recall of a toy ladder on which a California child was killed last month.

title: Ford Mexico Deal
description: Ford Tractor Operations, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, said it had entered an $80 million joint venture with Nacional Financiera of Mexico to produce farm tractors at Zacatecas, about 375 miles south of Mexico City, starting next year. Ford said it would retain 40 percent equity in the venture, Fabrica de Tractores Agricolas, and construction of the manufacturing complex would occur in one or two months. About 700 workers would eventually be employed at the site with capacity to produce 15,000 two-wheel-drive tractors a year.

title: MARKET PLACE
description: Municipal bonds once rivaled United States Treasury bonds in safety. Many still do, but a relative few may be no safer than a frayed seat belt in a fender bender - they are probably safe but they may not hold.

title: MOUNT ST. HELENS CONTINUES TO RUMBLE
description: Mount St. Helens will erupt, probably mildly, in one to five days, scientists said tonight after conducting tests within the volcano's crater.

title: BRITISH PUBLISHER, CITING LOSSES, CLOSES SOHO NEWS
description: The Soho News, founded nine years ago as a weekly journal of counter-cultural news and opinion for New York City, was closed yesterday by its British owners.

title: PHONE SYSTEM FAILS, ISOLATING NEW YORK CITY
description: A major failure in long-distance telephone switching equipment last night all but isolated New York City residents from the national phone system and some international systems for nearly an hour and a half, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported.

title: Permian Refund Agreement Set
description: The Energy Department said that the Permian Corporation, a unit of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, had agreed to refund $21.5 million to settle Federal allegations of overcharges dating to 1973.

title: Bill Is Introduced to Prevent U.S. Moves Against Managua
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee introduced a bill today to prevent the Reagan Administration from aiding any clandestine operation against the Sandinist Government in Nicaragua.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50** Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Small Potatoes

title: Della Martira Is Dismissed As an Assistant by Cosmos
description: Mauro Della Martira, an assistant coach with the Cosmos since last May, has been dismissed, the soccer club said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Indiana and Michigan Electric Co., a subsidiary of American Electric Power Co., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $100 million of first mortgage bonds.

title: Taking a Chance With Teen-Agers
description: A recent study of young patients at federally funded family planning clinics suggested that 25 percent would stop applying for prescription contraceptives if their parents were notified. Only 2 percent said they would stop sexual activity. Given that data, it's logical to assume that abridging doctor-patient confidentiality would risk a big jump in teen-age pregnancies. But the Reagan Administration is willing to take that risk.

title: NEW AMERICAN INDIAN JEWELRY
description: His nickname is the Eagle. He calls his wife the Fox. So when Ed and Carol Ann Ebbin formed a company to market jewelry made by American Indians, they had the perfect name for it: Eagle and Fox.

title: Briton in Arctic Trek Has a Narrow Escape
description: The leader of a two-man British expedition trying to circle the globe by the two poles narrowly escaped death in the Arctic Ocean and the team lost some equipment, organizers reported today.

title: BRENNAND-PAIGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
4 CONGRESSMEN URGE CHANGE IN BENEFIT-INCREASE FORMULA
description: An influential group of House Democrats has urged consideration of a limit on the cost-of-living increase to Social Security recipients in the 1983 fiscal year as one way to help bring down the Federal deficit.

title: AFGHAN PARTY FIGHTS ITS OWN DISUNTIY
description: The Communist Party of Afghanistan has had its first national conference since seizing power in April 1978, and it was marked by appeals for party unity and even closer ties with Moscow than it has now.

title: AN IMPRESSIVE LOBBY
description: To the Editor:

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After $382,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
MORE TOP STUDENTS SHUNNING PH.D.
description: The number of top students who earn Ph.D. degrees and become professors has been declining sharply in the United States in recent years while the number switching to more lucrative careers in business, law, medicine and engineering has been increasing.

title: CONCERT: REICH AND MUSICIANS AT THE MET MUSEUM
description: FOR about 15 years now, Steve Reich has been one of the leading composers in what has come to be identified as the Minimalist style. Almost from the beginning, his works have been characterized by repetition, overlapping metrical designs, circularity and a kind of droning monotony that some listeners find conducive to spiritual levitation and others find merely frustrating.

title: People Cuts Fare
description: People Express Airlines said that it had reduced its prices on all its flights between New York-Newark and Buffalo to $19 at all times.

title: TOYS-R-US CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes gains from the sale of property of $574,000 for the qr and $1,279,000 for the yr and $676,000 estimated loss on the planned sale or closing of some department stores and charge equal to 5 cents a shr for the yr from LIFO... C-Includes $983,000 gain from the sale of property and charge equal to 14 cents a shr fro the yr from LIFO

title: TIMES OF LONDON EDITOR QUITS AFTER DISPUTE WITH MURDOCH
description: Harold Evans, who was voted Britain's ''editor of the year'' only a few weeks ago, resigned today as editor of The Times of London after resisting for almost a week efforts by Rupert Murdoch, the newspaper's owner, to force his removal.

title: SWAN GOES 5 AND CHEERS METS
description: In his longest performance in almost one year, Craig Swan pitched five innings of one-run ball today and gave the New York Mets added hope that he had recovered after 20 months with a sore right shoulder.

title: 'Barnum' Remains Open
description: ''Barnum,'' stimulated by improved business at the box office during the weekend, will continue its run at the St. James Theater. The producers had said that they would close the musical if ticket sales did not rise.

title: 1981 DISMISSAL OF GOODY CASE SURVIVES APPEAL
description: A Federal appeals court ruled in Manhattan yesterday that it could not reverse a trial judge's decision that dismissed the conviction of Sam Goody Inc. on charges of dealing in counterfeit tapes of popular music.

title: REAGAN TO UNVEIL INNER-CITY PROPOSAL
description: After months of delay, President Reagan plans to announce next week the details of his program to revitalize blighted inner city areas by creating urban enterprise zones, a White House official said today.

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
2 at Hotel Face Charges In Fatal Fire in Houston
description: Misdemeanor charges will be filed Tuesday against a desk clerk and a resident manager of the Westchase Hilton, where 10 persons were killed in a fire nine days ago, Chief Prosecutor Marion Leach said today.

title: FELIX M. MORLEY, COLLEGE EDUCATOR AND JOURNALIST WHO WON PULITZER
description: Felix M. Morley, an educator and journalist who won the Pulitzer Prize, died Saturday night at Johns Hopkins Hospital after a short illness. He was 88 years old.

title: USE OF SUSPECT'S CONFESSION BEFORE HIS ARREST IS UPHELD
description: A New York State appeals court overturned a lower court ruling yesterday and found that a murder suspect's confession before his arrest could be used at his trial even if it was a result of ''incompetent advice'' from his lawyer.

title: Article 254870 -- No Title
description: An oil heiress was robbed of more than $1 million worth of jewelry while leaving La Guardia Airport in a limousine last night, the police said.

title: BankAmerica Note Offering
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of $500 million of zero-coupon notes.

title: PRIVATE U.S. GROUP SAYS U.N. SOMETIMES HEIGHTENS WORLD TENSIONS
description: A private group of prominent Americans said today that the United Nations sometimes heightened world tensions and that the United States should be prepared to act alone.

title: Northeastern Given Home-Ice Edge in N.C.A.A. Tourney
description: Northeastern and New Hampshire in the East and Wisconsin and North Dakota in the West were named host teams today for this weekend's quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I hockey championship.

title: 11 AT FEDERAL RESERVE ACCUSED OF STEALING $60,000 IN COINS
description: Eleven of 16 employees in the coin department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York were charged yesterday with stealing more than $60,000 in coins and currency over the past two years. It was the first major theft in the bank's history.

title: Kaiser Steel Off 13 1/2 After Deal Is Ended
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation's shares plunged 13 1/2 points yesterday, losing nearly one third of their value, in reaction to Friday's decision by Stanley Hiller Jr. and his group of investors to withdraw their $414 million offer to purchase Kaiser.

title: Theater Will Celebrate Independence of Texas
description: The American Place Theater will celebrate Texas Independence Day in a benefit May 2 that will include the cast and band of ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'' and the cast of ''Greater Tuna,'' a comedy playing in Austin, Tex. Stan Rubin and His Swing Era Big Band will play.

title: Bridge: Lapse in Memory Sets Up Drama in Swiss Team Play
description: A dramatic finale to the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss Team Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel on Sunday left the result in doubt for half an hour after the play of the last card. In a crucial match a player had forgotten his system, and a committee had to decide whether the opponents had been injured, and, if so, how to adjust the score.

title: OFFICIAL SHAPERS OF PRIVATE INVESTMENT DECISIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: PENTHOUSE TRIAL BEGINNING TO TRY THE JUDGE
description: The libel suit of the La Costa resort against Penthouse magazine is creeping through its fourth month in Superior Court here, weeks behind schedule. And if anything the pace appears to be slowing.

title: Cygna Energy Appoints Chairman and Chief
description: John E. Ward, 52, has been appointed chairman and chief executive officer of Cygna Energy Services of San Francisco, a leading engineering and consulting firm in the nuclear power industry. He was succeeded as president by John E. Roberts, 40. Ben Kacyra, 42, who was formerly chairman and chief executive, continues as chairman and president of the Cygna Corporation, the parent company that he helped to found.

title: Fixing Prices - and Antitrust Law
description: Price fixers, who usually conspire in secret, have banded together for a brazen, daylight attempt to rig the Federal antitrust laws. Spending money as freely as they collected it from overcharged customers, a few large companies are baldly seeking Congressional rescue from more than $3 billion in court judgments.

title: Hedberg Looks to Playoffs
description: Anders Hedberg looked at the five-inch scar on his left knee, flexed the leg slowly and said he might be ready to play for the Rangers by the time the Stanley Cup playoffs start.

title: Short-Term Rates Increase
description: In quiet trading at a time of great uncertainty about the direction of interest rates, prices rose slightly yesterday for debt securities due in more than five years but fell slightly for shorterterm issues.

title: 2 Dancers Have Surgery for Leg Injuries; Surgery for Dancers
description: Two prominent ballet dancers are recuperating from surgery necessitated by that prime occupational hazard in their profession, leg injuries.

title: PLY-GEM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After reductions of $15,901 for the qr and $64,663 for the yr from the conversion of certain inventories to the LIFO method of accounting

title: Mrs. Walesa Again Asks For Husband's Release
description: Danuta Walesa, the wife of the interned Solidarity leader, said today that she had appealed to Poland's military leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, for her husband's release.

title: DE ROSE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $55,000 for the qr and $205,000 for the yr...C-Includes tax credits of $45,000 for the qr and $100,000 for the yr

title: British Output Down
description: Britain's industrial output fell fourtenths of 1 percent in January, the third consecutive monthly decline, the Government reported today. Some of the January drop was attributed to wintry weather and strikes.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Filtrona Corp. said it had acquired the remaining 49 percent interest in its 51 percent owned Canadian company, a manufacturer of flexible packaging, for about $2.64 million.

title: VON BULOW JURY SIGNALS VERDICT WILL BE REACHED
description: Today, in the early afternoon of the jury's fifth day of deliberations on whether Claus von Bulow attempted to murder his wife, Judge Thomas H. Needham sent these two questions into the jury room:

title: CROWDED PREVIEWS THRUST UNIVERSAL'S 'CONAN' INTO SPOTLIGHT
description: HOLLYWOOD ''CONAN THE BARBARIAN'' - which is coming to movie theaters everywhere exactly two months from now - was publicly previewed in 30 cities Friday night. At a time when studios tend to hide their movies until the very last minute for fear of bad word-of-mouth, Universal has daringly thrust the $20 million ''Conan'' into the spotlight by not only previewing the movie but also explicitly inviting theater owners to the previews.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HOUSTON'S MAYOR AND POLICE AT ODDS
description: When Mayor Kathy Whitmire nominated Lee P. Brown, the Public Safety Commissioner of Atlanta, as Houston's police chief, she served a clear notice: She intends to bring reform to one of the nation's most troubled big-city police departments.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TOSCANINI RERUNS

title: Lefrak to Refund $400,000 in Rent
description: The Lefrak Management Company, one of the city's largest landlords, has agreed to refund about $400,000 to tenants who were overcharged on their rent, according to Attorney General Robert Abrams.

title: TV: JEAN SHEPARD ROLLS ALONG I-95
description: JEAN SHEPHERD'S street-corner reminiscences about growing up ''in that great inverted bowl of darkness, the Midwest,'' worked wonderfully well for public television a few years ago in ''The Phantom of the Open Hearth,'' presented as part of the ''Visions'' series. They do so again, tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET-TV, in ''The Great American Fourth of July ... and Other Disasters,'' this week's ''American Playhouse'' offering.

title: Fire Hits Hampshire House
description: A fire broke out in the air-conditioning system of the Hampshire House yesterday afternoon, causing some residents to complain of smoke in their rooms and damaging the air conditioning system, the Fire Department said. No one was injured, and the 36-story cooperative building at 150 Central Park South was not evacuated, said Fireman Arthur Manfredi, a department spokesman. The one-alarm blaze, which was confined to the system's fan unit in an alley on the southeast side of the building, was reported at 3:05 P.M. and declared under control at 4:07 P.M.

title: WATT ALTERS PLAN FOR OFFSHORE OIL LEASES
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt today announced revisions in his controversial proposal to open up for oil and gas exploration a billion acres off the coasts of the United States.

title: KICKING THE TV HABIT
description: When ''No TV Week'' was announced at the Glen School, 5-year-old John Donovan charged angrily out of his kindergarten class protesting to his mother: ''They can't do this. They're not the law!''

title: N.F.L. Rebuffs Players Again
description: The National Football League Management Council rejected again today the Players' Association's central demand for a percentage of the league's gross income, terming it ''probably illegal.''

title: Seales Bout Set
description: Sugar Ray Seales, who won an Olympic boxing gold medal in 1972, will meet Johnny LoCicero in the 10-round main event at the Felt Forum on March 31. Seales, who has a 51-8-4 record since turning pro, is ranked eighth among 160-pounders by the World Boxing Council.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE world didn't come to an end last week after all, despite the a pproximate syzygy of the planets. And how could it? There were f ashion shows to go to, like that of Arnold Scaasi where the dresses h ad names like Aphrodisiac and Hot Poppy. But there was a distinct f eeling everywhere of change in the fashion air. ''Everyone's in a p anic,'' said Diane Von Furstenberg. ''And they should be. Nineteen e ighty-two will be a year of cleansing for fashion. A lot of people a re going to die off.''

title: SKIER KILLED IN AVALANCHE
description: An avalanche on a rocky slope Saturday near the Arapahoe Basin Ski Area killed a skier identified as Mark Frieze, 30 years old, of Breckenridge, Colo.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 DROP 31.1%
description: The pace of new-car sales by the nation's Big Three auto manufacturers fell 31.1 percent in the first 10 days of March, the steepest decline this year, despite continuing rebate programs.

title: Marshall A. Best, 81, Editor at Viking Books
description: Marshall A. Best, senior editorial consultant to The Viking Press division of Viking Penguin Inc. in Manhattan, died Sunday at a nursing home in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 81 years old.

title: Plane Lands Safely at Kennedy After a Landing-Gear Warning
description: A Flying Tiger DC-8 cargo plane made a safe emergency landing last night on a foam-coated runway at Kennedy International Airport after a warning light in its cockpit indicated there was a malfunction in the landing gear.

title: RAYPAK INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $444,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: 16 ACCUSED OF SMUGGLING
description: Sixteen persons, including a customs official, have been indicted in Guam on charges of smuggling guns to Japan for resale, mostly to underworld figures, Federal officials say. Arrests began this month in Guan, Salpan, California and Honolulu. The guns, banned in Japan, were bought for as little as $50 and resold for up to $1,500, the officials said.

title: MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AERONCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $2.5 million charge...C-Net income

title: Harvard Plan Is Reaffirmed
description: After several weeks of student protests, Harvard University today reaffirmed its policy of divesting itself of bonds and certificates of deposit in banks that issue loans directly to the Government of South Africa.

title: DISTRICTS
description: An order by a Supreme Court Justice today created the strong probability that New Jersey voters will elect their 14 members of Congress this year on the basis of disputed district lines.

title: Lukens Steel
description: The Lukens Steel Company here said it plans to shorten its name to the Lukens Company to ''denote a broader range of business activities.'' Lukens recently took steps to acquire General Steel Industries Inc., a St. Louis-based company that produces machinery and equipment for basic industrial markets and pipe-coating materials. The company also makes glass beads for highways and designs and tests railroad suspension systems.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Car Bomb West of Belfast Kills Child and Injures 10

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including $865,000 extraordinary credit

title: Energy Bills Show Drop for February
description: For the first time in 29 months of monitoring, overall monthly energy costs for New York City residents in one month have gone down from the same month a year before, the Consumer Affairs Department said.

title: THE ART OF COOKING ASIDE, WHAT'S THE MOLECULAR STRUCTURE?
description: CREAM of tartar, added to egg whites, helps them to foam when beaten. Bread bakes faster in a glass pan than in a metal one. Vinegar added to the water keeps poached eggs from spreading into feathery tails.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS VISIT BONN TO PRESS FOR SANCTIONS
description: A United States delegation led by the Under Secretary of State for Security Assistance, James L. Buckley, met with West German officials today on the first leg of its Western European tour to discuss possible new economic sanctions against the Soviet Union.

title: FOGG ANNEX WILL BE BUILT
description: Derek Bok, president of Harvard University, and Seymour Slive, director of the Fogg Art Museum, announced yesterday that the Fogg had raised enough money to insure plans to build the $7.8 million addition to the museum.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net income including $80,000 extraordinary credit for the 9 mos

title: TEXAS GENERAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHUTTLE
description: WITH the third flight of the space shuttle Columbia imminent, and the completion of its test program expected this summer, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration now has in mind a new and equally challenging goal, the establishment of a permanent human presence in space.

title: Boy, 11, Found Hanged in Queens
description: An 11-year-old boy was found hanged yesterday afternoon in a closet in his family's two-story brick home in Woodside, Queens, the police said.

title: Loni Ackerman to Sing 'Evita' at the Broadway
description: Loni Ackerman will replace Derin Altay in the role of Eva Peron in ''Evita'' on April 5 at the Broadway Theater.

title: AMERICAN WELDING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Yr ago results adjusted for 100 percent stock divd

title: CORONER'S REPORT DISCLOSES DETAILS OF HOURS BEFORE BELUSHI'S DEATH
description: The coroner's office disclosed today that John Belushi stayed up all night drinking and taking drugs and showed signs of an overdose several hours before he was found dead in a Hollywood hotel bungalow March 5.

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 16, 1982; The Economy
description: High interest rates have jeopardized the prospects for the start of a business recovery this spring, Murray L. Weidenbaum, the Reagan Administration's chief economist, said in an interview. His comment underscored the possibility that the Administration will scale back its forecast in the revised budgetary outlook that is due next month. That would mean lower projected revenues, and a larger deficit. (Page A1.) The President said he wouldn't hesitate to use his veto to preserve his proposed spending cuts. (A1.)

title: E.E.C. Curbs Soviet Goods
description: The European Economic Community today reduced imports of 58 Soviet products to protest martial law in Poland.

title: Chacon's Wife in Suicide; Wanted Him to Quit Ring
description: The wife of Bobby Chacon, former World Boxing Council featherweight champion, shot herself to death today, the Butte County Sheriff's Department reported.

title: Argentine Rights Unit Assails Proposal on Missing People
description: A human rights watchdog group in Argentina today denounced a Government offer to review privately the thousands of cases of people who disappeared during a campaign against leftist guerrillas in the 1970's.

title: MIDWEST STRIVING TO ATTRACT INDUSTRY
description: Thermofil Inc., an engineering plastics company, has dismantled a plant in Laurens, S.C., and reassembled it in Brighton, Mich. The General Electric Company is closing a lighting fixtures plant near Orlando, Fla., and moving the machinery and 200 jobs to Mattoon, Ill. Class A.G. of West Germany is building a $26 million combine factory in Columbus, Ind.

title: POPULAR PLANNING
description: As the economic renaissance promised by Reaganomics fails to appear, calls for economic planning will be heard from leading businessmen and politicians. Will such planning, when it inevitably comes, be participatory?

title: BELANGER GRATEFUL TO DODGERS
description: In the hours before the first meeting between the Yankees and the Dodgers since the World Series, Mark Belanger strutted behind the batting cage today and showed off his new uniform.

title: TAL SMITH ENJOYING HIS OUTSIDE ROLE IN BASEBALL
description: He has no regrets. Baseball was very good to him, but Tal Smith has told seven major league teams he wouldn't do it again. Not after 23 years of working for clubs and one year of working for himself. Business is business for the 1980 major league executive of the year, and his own business is best.

title: B.P.'s Earnings Off 25% in 1981
description: The British Petroleum Company today reported a 25 percent drop in last year's earnings.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings refllct a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May 1981

title: Gretzky Ends Goal Drought
description: Wayne Gretzky ended a six-game goal-scoring drought with two tonight, and Mark Messier's 44th goal of the season in the third period gave the Edmonton Oilers a 3-3 tie with the Los Angeles Kings.

title: RUTGERS IS OVERWHELMED BY PURDUE IN N.I.T., 98-65
description: Trailing Purdue by 14 points at halftime tonight, Rutgers was forced to speed up its usually deliberate attack to try to get back in the game. But in the second half, Purdue, led by Mark Edmonson's 17 points, proved even more powerful as it overwhelmed the Scarlet Knights, 98-65, in the second round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Dow Advances 3.62, to 800.99
description: A rebound in sharply depressed technology issues helped the stock market to finish slightly higher yesterday. ''The recovery in technology stocks, indicating some shortcovering activity by traders, produced a general improvement in the market's tone,'' said Newton D. Zinder of E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: McCaffrey & McCall Chosen by Avis Unit
description: Avis Rent A Car System, a subsidiary of Avis Inc., part of Norton Simon, has named McCaffrey & McCall to handle its domestic advertising account, which last year billed about $10 million.

title: FOR TORN EL SALVADOR, COSTA RICA'S SOLUTION
description: The civil war in El Salvador is to some extent the product of existing social inequalities - and these are aggravated by Cuban and Soviet pressures to expand their zones of influence. But El Salvador's permanent political imbalance is also due to the country's disproportionately large armed forces and to an unfortunate tendency toward rigidity and authoritarianism. Democracy is not the product of a written document alone but rather of a mentality that values dialogue and negotiation - and, historically, these conditions have rarely existed in El Salvador.

title: CAREY CRITICIZES THE LEGISLATURE ON NEW BUDGET
description: Governor Carey accused the Legislature today of proposing ''fiscal gimmicks'' and said legislative ''indolence'' had made the outlook ''very grim'' for getting a state budget passed by the April 1 deadline.

title: A NONUNION TRUCKER'S RISE
description: In 1977, Sal Cotta, president of Polar Transport Inc., thought his trucking company had reached a dead end. Then the Interstate Commerce Commission, over the objections of established carriers, allowed Polar to haul freight for three more companies, giving it a total of nine, on routes mostly on the East Coast. In doing so, however, it warned Polar that as a carrier restricted to serving only certain shippers it had reached the limit of its authority.

title: SCOTT INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Sports of The Times; Doug Flynn Still Hurtin
description: WHEN Doug Flynn sings country music in the offseason, he draws from all the drinkin' songs and railroad songs and cheatin' songs. This year he is singing hurtin' songs.

title: REAGAN EASES LAW ON BIAS IN SCHOOLS
description: The Reagan Administration, shifting a longstanding position of the Federal Government, has decided to exempt from key civil rights laws those colleges where guaranteed student loans are the only form of Federal aid.

title: Stauffer Chemical
description: The Stauffer Chemical Company announced plans to shut down and scrap its vinyl chloride monomer and polyvinyl chloride resin manufacturing plant in Long Beach, Calif., because of the ''depressed economics'' of those two resin markets, and ''excessively stringent'' environmental standards in California that ''far exceeded'' Federal standards, Stauffer said.

title: Phone Failure Tied To 'Human Error'
description: ''Human error'' caused the problem that disrupted about 21,000 long-distance calls in New York City on Monday night, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said.

title: BATUS BID IS ACCEPTED BY FIELD
description: Marshall Field & Company said yesterday that it would accept a $310 million takeover offer from Batus Inc., a major retailer owned by B.A.T. Industries of London. Four years ago, the Chicago-based retailer rejected a much more generous offer from Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.

title: Magazine Agencies Watch Gallo Carefully
description: The magazine ad directors who are accustomed to getting ad schedules from Ernest and Julio Gallo, the California wine makers, are probably watching the competition for that account as eagerly as the three agencies that are involved.

title: AN ADMINISTRATION IN SEARCH OF YES-SCHOLARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Price Stability for Oil Urged
description: Ecuador's oil minister, Eduardo Ortega, said today that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should level production at 16.5 million barrels a day and that the price of crude should be maintained at $34 a barrel.

title: KEY ENERGY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRIME BACK TO 16 1 2% AT 4 BIG BANKS
description: A tentative trend toward lower interest rates was aborted yesterday as four major banks raised their prime lending rates half a percentage point, to 16 1/2 percent, reversing a downward move they made March 8.

title: 2,000 MEET TO VOICE ANGER ON L.I. RECYCLING PLANT
description: More than 2,000 Long Island residents gathered in a gymnasium at Hofstra University here tonight to voice anger and concern over a new plant that recycles garbage into electricity.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I find that monkfish is frequently on sale at my fish store. I am told that this is a new fish. Is it possible that this is a common fish to which another name has been given?

title: BROTHER OF CAREY FACING CHARGES OF EVADING TAX
description: Martin Carey, a brother of Governor Carey, has been indicted on charges of evading about $122,000 in sales taxes on gasoline sold at a chain of stations that he once controlled on Long Island, the State Attorney General's office announced today.

title: DOCUMENTARY ON VIEWS ABOUT ATOM BOMB
description: ''ONE of the most beautiful sights ever seen by man'' is the way one enthusiastic United States Army chaplain describes the detonation of an atomic bomb, an event about to be witnessed for the first time by his men in the Nevada desert.

title: NATCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 26
LEVITZ FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WOMEN CAMPAIGN FOR MORE JOBS
description: A coalition of 11 women's groups opened a national campaign today to promote more and better job opportunities for women.

title: 'Nothing to Live For'
description: ''When I found it I felt right dejected,'' the pseudonymous Ken Thomas said. ''It was all over. There was nothing to live for.''

title: Swissair Plans A-310 Delays
description: Swissair plans to invest 2.5 billion Swiss francs, or $1.33 billion, between 1982 and 1985 on aircraft fleet renewal, according to its planning director, A. Bernhardsgruetter said.

title: GENERAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; results for the first and second qr of 1981 have been restated

title: I.M.F.'S CHIEF URGES CUTS IN U.S. DEFICITS
description: The International Monetary Fund, which provides aid and advice to the world's troubled economies, commented publicly today for the first time on the United States fiscal debate, calling for tax increases and budget cuts to reduce the huge projected deficits.

title: HART FESSENDEN
description: Hart Fessenden, 85 years old, an educator and the former headmaster of the Fessenden School at West Newton, Mass., died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan.

title: THE MYTH OF THE FED
description: Interest rates have been too high for too long. Now that Congressional elections are coming, once again it's open season on the Federal Reserve.

title: Britons Head for North Pole After Narrow Escape on Ice
description: A British baronet and his companion radioed from the Arctic today that they were on the move again toward the North Pole after a near-disastrous fall through the ice.

title: RYKOFF, S E, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The shr earnings reflect 25 percent stock divd in Aug

title: Israel and Egypt Seem Close to a Border Accord
description: Israeli and Egyptian negotiators appear to be nearing a temporary solution to a border dispute that has threatened to delay Israel's withdrawal from Sinai next month, the Israeli radio reported today.

title: S.& P. Ratings Change
description: The Standard and Poor's Corporation announced yesterday what it described as minor changes in its credit ratings procedures for securities issued under the new Federal guidelines governing debt and equity underwriting.

title: WILLIAMS, W W, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotations of the Day
description: ''I can now inform you, dear comrades, that, striving to facilitate a just agreement on a major reduction of nuclear weapons by both sides in Europe, and desirous of setting a good example, the Soviet leadership has taken a decision to introduce, unilaterally, a moratorium on the development of medium-range nuclear armaments in the European part of the U.S.S.R.'' - Leonid I. Brezhnev, to convention of Soviet trade unions. (A6:1.)

title: HAUT-BRION'S AMERICAN ACCENT
description: BRION, one of the greatest wine estates of France, was down and out in 1933, along with much of the world economy. The vineyard had been ranked as a premier grand cru, or first great growth, in the Bordeaux classification of 1855, but the market for its celebrated wines had shrunk, and its proprietor had committed a tactical error. He had decided to bypass the Bordeaux wine trade and maximize profits by selling directly to stores and restaurants, eliminating the middlemen who traditionally marketed the best Bordeaux wines.

title: GREAT WEST STEEL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $1,302,000 extraordinary gain...C-Includes $1,310,000 extraordinary gain

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
SERIOUS DIPLOMACY ON NICARAGUA NEEDED
description: The Administration's public briefing provided little new data on Nicaragua's arms buildup and role in El Salvador. But the dramatic presentation of evidence did obscure possibilities for creative diplomacy with Managua. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s reiteration Monday of proposals made last August cannot be taken seriously by Nicaragua because of Washington's reported plans for covert action.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
C.I.A.'S NICARAGUA ROLE: A PROPOSAL OR A REALITY?
description: Nicaragua's assertion today that guerrillas, acting under American direction, blew up two bridges Sunday has again raised questions about what covert role the United States is playing in Central America.

title: HUNDREDS TRAPPED IN PATH TRAIN FIRE
description: Hundreds of Manhattan-bound passengers were trapped for more than an hour in a PATH train that caught fire under the Hudson River yesterday morning before rescuers led them to safety through an emergency exit at the riverbank edge of Greenwich Village.

title: RULING ON ELECTION OF COUNCIL UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court affirmed a decision declaring that New York City's system of electing two City Council members at large from each borough was unconstitutional.

title: Authors and Actors To Read Banned Works
description: Authors and actors will join forces April 5 at 8 P.M. in the Public Theater to read from works that have been banned in public schools and libraries.

title: ZIMBABWE ACTING ON MINERALS
description: Zimbabwe, which for years has depended on American, British and South African companies to market its mineral resources, is now on the verge of taking over responsibility for the sales itself.

title: Moore Is Quitting Connecticut Race
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Robin Moore, the author, said Tuesday that he was dropping out of the race for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat now held by Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and throwing his support to Prescott S. Bush of Greenwich. Mr. Bush, an insurance executive, is the brother of Vice President Bush.

title: MARUSIA SASSI
description: Marusia Toumanoff Sassi, a couturier whose designs were worn by Rosalind Russell, Greer Garson and Doris Day, among other actresses, has died of cancer at the age of 67.

title: KAUFMAN WARNS OF BUDGET IMPASSE
description: Telling Congress it must act promptly to shrink future budget deficits, Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist, said today that he could not rule out a 1930's-type depression if the lawmakers and President Reagan become locked into a fiscal-policy stalemate that drags into autumn.

title: HELIX TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $87,590 for the qr and $4.6 million for the yr

title: Sailors Warned of Race Perils
description: As an introduction to the single-handed round-the-world yacht race later this year, Robin Knox-Johnson spoke of the perils of the southern oceans yesterday at the New York Yacht Club while two of the 34 intended competitors, Judith Lawson and David White, spoke of the difficulties of finding sponsors to help defray their expenses.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What he is talking about is a situation where, two-thirds of the way through a football game, one side is ahead 50 to 10, or 50 to 0, as it would be in this case, and they want to freeze the score for the rest of the game.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 17, 1982
description: International A halt in deploying Soviet missiles in European Russia was announced by Leonid I. Brezhnev. In a Kremlin speech, the Soviet leader said that the freeze on the deployment of new medium-range nuclear weapons would continue until an arms-control agreement was reached with the United States or until NATO began installing new mediumrange nuclear missiles in Western Europe. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Washington dismissed the freeze in the deployment of Soviet nuclear missiles in Europe with unusual speed. The Reagan Administration derided the Kremlin's announcement as a ''propaganda gesture'' designed to leave the Soviet Union free to gain ''unchallenged hegemony over Europe.'' (A1:5.)

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bank of Nova Scotia said Petralgas Chemicals N.Z. Ltd. and representatives of 16 banks had signed an agreement for a one-year, $235 million syndicated loan facility.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 14
description: B-Includes a gain of $2 million on the sale of stores and a writeoff of $1.2 million

title: Steelworkers and Police Clash in Brussels
description: Fearing a loss of jobs, steelworkers armed with clubs and rocks clashed with the police here today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard THE TUGMAN'S PASSAGE. By Edward Hoagland. 208 pages. Random House. $12.50.

title: U.S. AND NICARAGUA DIFFER ON TALE OF THE RECANTER
description: Administration and Nicaraguan officials today presented differing versions of events surrounding the trip to the United States of a 19-year-old Nicaraguan who last Friday startled State Department officials by recanting his earlier assertions of Nicaraguan interference in El Salvador.

title: LOW FAT RECIPES
description: MANY people shy away from low-fat foods because they think they are not going to taste good. But the change involved is not as great as you might think. It simply means cutting down on such foods as red meat, eggs and whole-milk products and increasing the consumption of vegetables, pasta, legumes and grains, and of lemon juice, fresh herbs and spices.

title: AFGHAN PARTY SUPPORTS PURGE OF ITS DISSIDENTS
description: The national conference of Afghanistan's ruling Communist Party ended in Kabul Monday night after 841 delegates endorsed calls for purging dissidents and expropriating the estates of rich landlords.

title: British Blow Up a Car
description: The police blew up a suspicious automobile found parked today on the route along which Queen Elizabeth II was to drive to Buckingham Palace with Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman. The route was changed. A Scotland Yard spokesman said tests later showed there had been no explosives in the car.

title: Associated's Profit Rises
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which owns Lord & Taylor and other retail stores, said yesterday that its earnings rose 44 percent in the latest quarter, mainly through its acquisition of the Caldor chain.

title: TAKING THE FAT OUT OF EATING
description: PEOPLE are discovering new ways to cut down on the fat in their meals these days without going to desperate lengths to make them palatable. Indeed, they are finding out that as far as taste is concerned, many low-fat foods can be as delicious as the richest and most buttery ones. The approach is adventurous, altering not only the choice of foods but even the way they are prepared.

title: Bid to Attack Haiti Reported
description: Fifteen people were arrested today when Federal officials intercepted two boats said to have been outfitted for an invasion of the island of Haiti, according to Bill Nettles, a spokesman for the F.B.I. He said that automatic weapons were found on the boats when they were intercepted 5 to 10 miles south of Marathon, Fla., in the Florida Keys.

title: Shell May Quit Alsands
description: Shell Canada Ltd. said it may pull out of the $13 billion Alsands oil sands consortium if it is the only member of the private sector still participating at the end of the month.

title: As Ads Come to China, So Do Regulations
description: China, which is just beginning to discover advertising, has already decided to regulate it. How's that for learning fast? According to Business Asia, a newsletter published by the Business International Corporation, China's State Council recently passed legislation that will, among other things, require that indiginous agencies to be licensed by the state and that food and medicine advertising be certified by the public health authorities.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Decision File; What's in a Pizza?
description: The company had a staid name, H.N. Singer Inc. It was founded in 1942 and sold fruit juice for years. So, in 1979, when it offered franchises for distributing Hot Box Pizzas, 67 people across the country plunked down $25,000 each.

title: STIHL: A WORLD WIDE FAMILY BUSINESS
description: Andreas Stihl, founder of the world's largest chain saw manufacturer, did not want his daughter to go into the family business. Like most German men of his generation, Mr. Stihl looked askance at women in business.

title: STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After credit for tax loss carryforward of $19,000...C-Net los

title: AN INMATE COLUMNIST FIGHTS TO HALT TRANSFER
description: For 11 months, Ronald O. Simmat, inmate number 20197 in the Connecticut Correctional Institution here, has written a weekly column for a local newspaper.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THOUGH the thyroid is a tiny gland that weighs less than an ounce and produces less than one one-hundred-thousandth of an ounce of hormone each day, the size of the gland belies its influence. No organ system in the body escapes the effects of a thyroid excess or deficiency. The heart, nervous system, sweat glands, reproductive system, eyes, muscles, personality, appetite, skin -all may be affected by a thyroid abnormality.

title: Western Union Cellular Venture
description: The Western Union Corporation said it had entered its second joint venture in the cellular mobile telephone business. The company said it had invested in joint ventures with a team of three companies applying for franchises to operate mobile telephone systems in selected metropolitan areas.

title: Illness of Judge Delays MCI Award
description: A judge's illness will delay the final settlement of a $1.8 billion damage award pending against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, a Federal appeals court said.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 17, 1982; The Economy
description: Industrial production rose 1.6 percent in February after six consecutive months of progressively larger declines, the Federal Reserve Board reported. Economists said the increase reflects an easing in the unusually severe weather that depressed output in January. But it also indicates, they said, that the economy may be poised for recovery when interest rates start to fall. (Page A1.)

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago shrs outstndg adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in April 1981

title: DENVER TO NEW DELHI: A WRITER'S MOVES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- James A. Michener's latest book is ''The Covenant.'' BY JAMES A. MICHENER

title: THE FED CAN CUT INTEREST RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: OVER the years I have read a good many articles on the art of seasoning, most of them speculating on why one flavor or combination of flavors is related to a certain country. It is true that most regions I know of have one or more specialties that seem to predominate.

title: Mexican Copper Loan
description: The International Finance Corporation, a World Bank affiliate, confirmed that it was negotiating a $600 million loan to a Mexican copper mining concern, Compania Minera de Cananea.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes $420,000 extraordinary credit

title: L.I.R.R. to End Taping of Crews
description: The Long Island Rail Road has agreed to stop using concealed microphones and other devices to make covert recordings of the conversations of train engineers and conductors, the Nassau County District Attorney said.

title: CHINA SAYS REFORMS WON'T HARM TRADE
description: China sought today to reassure foreign countries and companies doing business here that the overhaul of its bureaucracy would not impair their economic or commercial dealings.

title: Joseph Julian, an Actor On Many Radio Shows
description: Joseph Julian, an actor who was featured in thousands of radio broadcasts before and after World War II and appeared on the New York stage, died last Wednesday at his home in New York City. He was 71 years old.

title: The U.N. Today; March 17, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The 1981 results restated for an accounting change

title: SONG RECITAL: ELLY AMELING
description: ELLY Ameling's afternoon of song at Carnegie Hall Sunday ranged across most of Europe - alighting briefly in England and Spain but concentrating its charms mostly on the music of the French and the Germans.

title: NICARAGUA PLACES FORCES ON ALERT
description: Nicaragua placed its armed forces on full alert today and called on the population to join a people's militia after the destruction of two bridges by ''counterrevolutionaries'' who officials here say are supported by the United States.

title: DATA THAT CAUSED CITING OF WATT WILL BE PROVIDED TO HOUSE GROUP
description: The White House agreed today to provide documents to a House committee that had already voted to cite Interior Secretary James G. Watt for contempt for refusing to comply with a subpoena for the papers.

title: CUOMO ENTERS GUBERNATORIAL RACE AGAINST KOCH
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination yesterday. Once again, he will be running against Mayor Koch, with whom he competed for Mayor in the 1977 primary and election. Mr. Cuomo lost both contests and will start this one as a generally acknowledged underdog.

title: Luggage Found In Jewel Theft
description: The luggage that was taken from an oil heiress who was robbed of more than $1 million worth of jewelry as she was leaving La Guardia Airport Monday evening was found in the Conrail freight yard in Elizabeth, N.J., the New York City police said yesterday.

title: RAINS IN CALIFORNIA CONTINUE TO PLAGUE SPACE SHUTTLE PLANS
description: More rain fell on the California desert yesterday, complicating plans for the third mission of the space shuttle Columbia and threatening a possible delay in the launching, now scheduled for Monday.

title: REZONING PASSED TO STEER BUILDING TO THE WEST SIDE
description: New York City's Planning Commission adopted new zoning regulations for midtown Manhattan yesterday that are designed to steer development away from the congested East Side and toward the south and the West Side. The regulations also limit the amount of sky space new buildings may obstruct.

title: DAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $200,000 tax credit...C-Includes $1,770,000 tax credit

title: LIFETIME COMMUNITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $289,500 tax credit...C-Includes $970,900 tax credit

title: HOUSING STARTS ROSE IN FEBRUARY
description: The housing industry revived slightly last month, with housing starts rising 6.5 percent from January's level, to an adjusted annual rate of 953,000 units, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Chrysler Unit Sold
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said that the Chrysler Corporation had completed the sale of its defense subsidiary to General Dynamics for $336.1 million, about $12.4 million less than the originally proposed agreement. General Dynamics said that the lower price reflects adjustments that have occurred since Feb.19, when Chrysler agreed to sell the tank-making unit. It gave no details of the adjustments.

title: Cessna Will Shut Plant 6 Weeks
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company will close its plant near Winfield, Kan., for six weeks starting March 29, idling 700 workers.

title: JET AMERICA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-The company began operation on Nov 16, 1981 so comparable results for the prior yr were not available

title: TRADE OFFICIAL'S MESSAGE: 'START COMPETING'
description: When President Reagan chose him to be the United States Special Trade Representative, Bill Brock, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, acknowledged that he had ''a lot to learn'' about trade. Now, only a year later, Mr. Brock is telling American businessmen that they, too, may have a lot to learn about it.

title: EX-HISTORIAN OF SOUTHAMPTON
description: William K. Dunwell, the Southampton, L.I., town historian for 43 years until his retirement last Jan. 1, died Saturday at Southampton Hospital. He was 97 years old and had lived on Elm Street in Southampton for the past 71 years.

title: Interest Rates Fall Slightly; But Experts Remain Wary
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday, but market participants were not optimistic that the declines would continue in coming days and weeks.

title: GUBERNATORIAL UNDERDOG
description: With his family behind him, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was answering questions yesterday at the formal announcement of his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor. He was asked about his opposition to the death penalty.

title: KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary gains of $6,997,000 for the qr and $7,789,000 for the yr...C-Includes $404,000 extraordinary gain

title: LIBERTY HOMES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
SOVIET FREEZE: EUROPE'S VIEW
