description: Most Western European governments and military specialists reacted cautiously today to the freeze on medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe announced by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.

title: RAMPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BRIEFS
description: * Alza Corp. said it had entered into an agreement with Allergan Pharmaceuticals Inc., a unit of SmithKline Beckman Corp., providing for the development of therapeutic systems for the ophthalmic field.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT: TOKYO'S FARM POLICY IS NOT THE PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Italian Output Off
description: Italian industrial output, seasonally adjusted, fell a provisional 1.6 percent in January after a 5.6 percent decline in December, according to the National Statistics Institute. Year-to-year seasonally adjusted output fell a provisional 1.7 percent in January, compared with a nine-tenths of 1 percent fall in December.

title: Walker Stays at Georgia
description: Georgia's all-America tailback, Herschel Walker, said today that he had decided against mounting a legal challenge to the National Football League rule that prohibits the drafting of undergraduates. His decision, announced at a news conference, meant that he would be back to play for the Bulldogs next fall, his junior season, instead of turning pro.

title: HINTS FOR COOKS
description: Here are some cooking hints for those trying to reduce fat and saturated fat in the diet:

title: 'Suffered Enough'
description: Pimlico Race Course officials said yesterday that they had readmitted to the track Ben Feliciano, a former jockey who was convicted in a race-fixing scandal and then banned from Pimlico. Chick Lang, Pimlico's general manager, said the decision to readmit Feliciano occurred after ''a zillion people called and told me he should be allowed back.

title: STANWOOD CORP reports earnings for Yr to Jan 2
description: B-Results are not available since the company changed its fiscal yr

title: SIERRA RESEARCH reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $302,000

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $66,203 for the qr and $44,800 for the 9 mos...C-Net income after $20,000 extraordinary charge for the qr and $108,000 credit for the 9 mos

title: NESTLE'S NEW FORMULA POLICY
description: Nestle S.A., the world's major supplier of infant formula, today issued its guidelines for complying with a voluntary international code that discourages unnecessary use of infant formula and encourages breast-feeding.

title: OPERA: JUDITH HADDON SINGS CIO-CIO-SAN IN 'BUTTERFLY'
description: JUDITH HADDON gave a compelling performance as Cio-Cio-San last Saturday evening in the New York City Opera's first performance this season of ''Madama Butterfly,'' singing the role for the first time with the company; also joining the cast in the performance were Judith Christin as Suzuki and William Stone as Sharpless.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Polish Paper Says Union Was Infiltrated by Spies

title: BLACK COMPANIES FOCUS OF PROGRAM AT HEUBLEIN
description: Heublein Inc., the food and beverage company, announced a $180 million program yesterday to develop minority businesses, including assistance to open 112 black-owned Kentucky Fried Chicken outlets across the country. The company also plans to increase its advertising, legal, accounting and purchasing business with blackowned concerns.

title: Account
description: * Transamerica Airlines, Oakland, Calif., to Lynch & Rockey Advertising, San Francisco.

title: Gold Margin Raised
description: The margin committee of the Commodity Exchange Inc. said yesterday that it had raised the margin requirements for gold futures, effective today. The exchange said the speculative margin will be $1,500, compared with the previous $1,250. The hedge margin will be $1,000 compared with the previous $800.

title: EMERALD HEAVEN
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH AFRICANS KILL 201 IN ANGOLA RAID
description: West Africa, March 16 (Reuters) - South African troops wiped out a major guerrilla staging post during a cross-border operation in a desolate mountain area of southwestern Angola, officers commanding the raid said today.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Economic Scene; The Mystery Of High Rates
description: THE Administration is worried that high interest rates may spoil its forecast of a business recovery starting in the April-June quarter, with strong economic growth continuing in 1983 and beyond. Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said this week, ''These interest rates are affecting the timing, speed, strength and duration of the recovery.''

title: U.S. INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT ROSE 1.6% IN FEBRUARY, FIRST GAIN SINCE JULY
description: Industrial production climbed 1.6 percent in February from the January level, the first increase in the output of the nation's factories since the recession started last July, the Government reported today.

title: Greenings
description: Along Fifth Avenue, it threatens to become the Wearin' of the Blue. There is enough official concern about rowdyism during the St. Patrick's Day Parade that extra police officers will be sent to special ''enforcement zones'' and off-duty officers are being encouraged to wear their uniforms. But for almost everyone else the color of the day is green, and the only question is how to wear it.

title: News Analysis
description: Contrary to the Administration's public position, some senior White House officials are saying privately that, for both economic and political reasons, President Reagan would be wise to strike an early compromise with Congress on the Federal budget for 1983.

title: JOHN L. SENIOR JR.
description: John L. Senior Jr., an aeronautical engineer, died Sunday at his home in Heritage Village in Southbury, Conn.

title: JEWELRY AND LEOTARDS; 1. Liquid Diet
description: What's the calorie count of the tomato juice you're drinking? Or the milk you will add to a sauce? In these days when just about everyone is diet-conscious, a handy thing to own is a glass marked to show the calories in a number of liquid foods, such as fruit juices, soft drinks like ginger ale and cola and milk (whole, skim or low fat). The glass holds 14 ounces and is marked, like a measuring cup, at different levels to indicate calories rather than ounces. The glasses are made of strong plastic and are priced at two for $6 in the Lee Bailey section at Bendel's.

title: Allied's Tender For Supron Ends
description: The Allied Corporation announced that its tender offer for up to 16.1 million common shares of the Supron Energy Corporation of Dallas expired at noon yesterday and that it had begun paying for the shares.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The National Basketball Association has fined Doug Moe, the Denver coach, $500 for protesting Lee Jones's failure to call a foul on the Suns' Craig Dykema after he charged Glen Gondrezick of the Nuggets Feb.26. On the way to the locker room, Moe lifted Kyle Macy, the Phoenix guard, off the floor and spun him around, saying, ''Is this a foul?'' ... John McEnroe, who injured his leg while playing in a World Championship Tennis tournament at Brussels last Friday, withdrew from this week's $300,000 W.C.T. tournament in Strasbourg, France. McEnroe's left leg is in a cast and he does not expect to play again until the W.C.T. finals in Dallas on April 20-26.

title: Home Starts Reported Off
description: Construction of new homes slumped sharply in the fourth quarter of 1981, a report from F.W. Dodge, a division of McGraw-Hill Information Systems, said yesterday.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Nuclear Plant Fire Rules
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld fire protection rules drawn up for nuclear power plants, but said its decision was ''reluctant'' because of the way in which the Nuclear Regulatory Commission adopted the rules.

title: Canadian Deficit Cut
description: Canada's budget deficit shrank in January to $595 million (Canadian funds) from $1.03 billion a year before, the Finance Department said today. Revenues were $4.99 billion, up from $4.35 billion, while spending totaled $5.59 billion, up from $5.39 billion. The Canadian dollar is worth about 82 cents in United States currency.

title: Republic Air's Cash Plight
description: Republic Airlines Inc. could be forced into bankruptcy court if the airline does not receive employee wage and work concessions next month, company officials say.

title: Market Place; Margin Calls: Ominous Rise
description: THIS telephone call is as welcome as a visit from an Internal Revenue Service agent and may be even more devastating. The call is from a broker, who wants more money from the customer or else one or more of the customer's holdings will be sold.

title: BRIEFING
description: Low Profile for the Summit

title: Federal Express Net Up
description: The Federal Express Corporation reported that net income in the third fiscal quarter of 1982 ended Feb. 28 increased by 16.6 percent, to $19 million, or 90 cents a share, from $16.3 million, or 79 cents a share, in the third fiscal quarter of the preceding year.

title: ST. PATRICK'S ROWDYISM IS POLICE CONCERN TODAY
description: New York's oldest ethnic celebration, the St. Patrick's Day parade, will step off from 44th Street at the customary hour of noon today on a green-striped Fifth Avenue, but several variations from tradition are planned.

title: Masters Tennis Alters Format
description: Stung by obvious flaws and continued criticism of its eight-player, round-robin format, the Volvo Masters tennis tournament will switch to a 12-player single-elimination event for 1983.

title: STAR-GLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The yr-ago figures restated to reflect acquisition of Tec Torch Company in Jan 1981

title: S.E.C Rule Published
description: The new Securities and Exchange Commission regulation governing underwriting procedures - known as Rule 415 - was published yesterday, in the Federal Register, making it immediately effective. The rule, which was adopted on Feb. 24 by the S.E.C., will dramatically speed up and simplify the registration process corporations must go through each time they want to issue new debt or equity. The rule change will be in effect for a nine-month trial period, after which the S.E.C. will assess its impact on the capital markets and determine whether to make it permanent.

title: MCDOWELL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After $382,000 extraordinary charge...C-Net income after $2.9 million extraordinary charge

title: SONOMA VINEYARDS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After tax credits of $322,000 for the qr and $572,000 for the yr...C-After tax credit of $485,000 for the qr and yr

title: Mrs. Marcos on Tenure
description: She's said it before, but the speculation just won't go away, so yesterday Imelda Marcos tried again. Her position in the Filipino Government, Mrs. Marcos said, is ''coterminous'' with that of her husband, President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: DIGITAL SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Iran Oil Plans
description: Iran will cut oil exports in the 1982-83 financial year to a level just meeting its foreign exchange needs, the Minister of State for Budget and Planning, Mohammad Taqi Banki, said. Presenting the budget for the year beginning March 21, Mr. Banki said Monday that revenue from oil exports will drop to 56.3 percent of total revenues from 79 percent five years before the 1979 revolution that overthrew the Shah.

title: TEXT OF SENATE DEMOCRAT'S MESSAGE TO REAGAN
description: Following is the text of the letter sent to President Reagan today by the Senate Democratic Conference: Dear Mr. President: At the instruction of the Senate Democratic Conference, I am writing to you about the frightening budget outlook. According to the bipartisan Congressional Budget Office, your deficits will add $390 billion to the national debt in the next three years. The deficit will be $140 billion in F.Y. 1985 alone. Deficits of this magnitude will contribute significantly to continued high interest rates which, in turn, will retard or abort economic recovery. Unless swift and effective action is taken to reduce these deficits, we will face continued recession and high unemployment, record business failures, the possible collapse of the housing, auto and thrift industries and, according to many economic forecasters, a possible depression. The country needs an immediate midcourse correction in the economic plan.

title: Funds for Marathon
description: The Boston Marathon is adding three commercial sponsors for the first time to raise more money for operations and staff, according to Will Cloney, the race director.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 16.50 18.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 15.38 15.21 14.27 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.70 12.87 12.90 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.80 12.95 12.15 7-YR. TREAS. BONDS 14.02 14.07 12.77 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.57 13.60 12.24 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 16.01 16.03 13.12 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.98 14.00 10.90 6-MONTH SAVINGS 13.212 CERTIFICATES* *Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: COMMODORE ADDS HEAD FOR CONSUMER PRODUCTS
description: Alan W. Fink, 45, who has spent about two decades selling consumer products, has joined Commodore International Ltd. as the first president of its newly formalized consumer products division. Commodore is a major manufacturer of computer systems and semiconductor components.

title: PANEL ANGERED BY FAILURE OF AIDE TO TESTIFY ON CIVIL DEFENSE PLANS
description: Members of a subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, angered by the failure of a senior Pentagon official to appear before them, refused today to permit another Defense Department official to testify about the Reagan Administration's civil defense program.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY

title: WAYS TO REDUCE FAT INTAKE
description: Some reminders for those trying to cut down on the consumption of fat: The American Heart Association recommends a limit of four to six ounces of lean meat, fish or poultry a day, two tablespoons of polyunsaturated fats and oils a day and no more than three egg yolks a week (you can eat as many whites as you like).

title: Farm Workers in Texas Begin a 100-Mile March
description: Texas farm workers, spurred by remarks by Cesar Chavez and other labor leaders, today began a 100-mile protest march against low wages.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PINIELLA IS FINED $1,000 FOR LEAVING PARK
description: Lou Piniella was fined $1,000 today, his second fine of the spring, after leaving the ball park without permission before a game in which he was scheduled to be the designated hitter against the Texas Rangers at nearby Pompano Beach.

title: TV: 'HERBIE' AND 'BAKER'S DOZEN' BEGIN
description: DETERMINED to beef up its Wednesday night schedule, CBS-TV is beginning two new weekly series tonight: ''Herbie, the Love Bug'' at 8 o'clock and ''Baker's Dozen'' at 9:30. At first glance, both seem decidedly anemic.

title: German Construction
description: Investment in the West Germany construction industry is likely to shrink 6 percent this year after an estimated decline of 3 percent last year and a rise of 4.4 percent in 1980, the I.F.O. Economic Research Institute said today.

title: HINTS ON DRESS FOR A CAPITAL SUCCESS
description: Barbara Blaes strolls into Government agencies and shudders. Too many purple polyester jackets drape bureaucratic shoulders, women wear tight pants, desks are messy, people shuffle, handshakes are limp.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Amdahl Stock Off on Report
description: The Amdahl Corporation's stock plummeted yesterday in active trading after the company announced that earnings in the first three quarters of 1982 would be lower than in 1981.

title: WHITE HOUSE DELAYS SUPPORT FOR BILL ON CIGARETTE WARNING
description: The Reagan Administration, in an apparent retreat, said today that it was still studying legislation to require new health warnings on cigarette packages and advertising.

title: Heublein Backed On General Cinema
description: A Federal court order cleared the way today for Heublein Inc., the international food and beverage company, to buy more stock in the General Cinema Corporation. The two companies have been engaged in a takeover battle.

title: NORTH KOREAN LEADER PLANS HUGE FETE FOR SON
description: Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, is preparing a lavish celebration of his 70th birthday next month to pave the way for his son's succession to the leadership, according to South Korean intelligence sources.

title: SLY WILLIAMS SUSPENDED
description: For the second time in six and a half weeks, Sly Williams, the Knicks' forward, was suspended indefinitely without pay last night. The suspension, for what the Knicks called ''violations of club policies and regulations,'' came several hours before the San Antonio Spurs overwhelmed the Knicks, 114-91, at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks, whose record dropped to 29-36, were never in the game as George Gervin, the National Basketball Association's leading scorer, and Mike Mitchell scored 33 points each.

title: 2 HANOVER BANKERS GET DIFFERENT TITLES
description: John F. McGillicuddy, chairman and chief executive officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and its main subsidiary, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, yesterday disappointed a lot of people who had expected him to name a No.2 man at the nation's fourth-largest banking organization.

title: Supermarkets General Net Up
description: The Supermarkets General Corporation, owner of the Pathmark supermarket chain, announced yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Jan. 30, 1982, increased 54.8 percent, to $14.4 million, or $1.72 a share, from $9.3 million, or $1.12 a share, in the 1980 fourth fiscal quarter.

title: DANCE: MERCE CUNNINGHAM'S 'TRAILS'Z
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM has told us many times that dancing is limited only by time, space and our imagination - all of which leaves things, so to speak, wide open.

title: Bridge: 452 Competed in Pan-Am, Largest Total in New York
description: The biggest Pro-Am game ever held in New York took place Friday night at the New York Hilton Hotel: 226 partnerships, each an expert paired with a novice, competed under the auspices of the Greater New York Bridge Association.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 13
Natural Gas Reserves
description: World natural gas reserves are sufficient to meet demand for the next 170 years, the president of the 41-nation International Gas Union said today. E. Giorgis told a trade convention that demand for natural gas had grown rapidly over the past two decades, totaling 52.5 trillion cubic feet in 1980. Mr. Giorgis said recent studies indicated total recoverable world gas reserves amounted to 9,835 trillion cubic feet, a third of which had already been proven. Over the next 40 years no more than a third of these reserves would be used, he said. Natural gas accounts for 20 percent of international primary energy demand.

title: Rep. Derwinski Loses To Friend in Illinois Vote
description: Representative Edward J. Derwinski, a 12-term member of Congress, was defeated tonight by a fellow Republican, Representative George M. O'Brien, in the Illinois primary, the first of the 1982 Congressional elections.

title: PANASONIC'S PRESIDENT PURSUES GROWTH GOALS
description: Since becoming president of the Panasonic Company at the beginning of the year, Raymond A. Gates, 62, has been away from his Secaucus, N.J., headquarters 50 percent of the time. In addition to visiting customers and attending trade shows, he has made two trips to the Tokyo headquarters of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the corporate parent. ''I think the airlines love me,'' he said yesterday.

title: Sutton Is Homesick
description: Don Sutton, the 37-year-old pitcher for the Houston Astros, is homesick. At the Astros' training camp in Cocoa, Fla., Sutton said he would welcome a trade back to the Los Angeles Dodgers because Dodger Stadium is only a 45-minute drive from Sutton's residence.

title: U.S. COMMENT ON BREZHNEV'S MOVE
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by President Reagan to a joint session of the Oklahoma State Legislature in Oklahoma City, and the text of a statement by Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, as made public by the White House: Special to the New York Times

title: McLouth Steel
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation said that its board of directors had decided to seek permision from Judge George Woods of Federal Bankruptcy Court to continue to use its cash collateral beyond this Friday and for as long ''as possible.'' Last week, lenders to the steel company, which is operating under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code, said that as of Friday they would stop financing McLouth and would call in the company's $112 million of loans.

title: Dow Declines 2.66, to 798.33
description: Weakness in technology issues cut short a rally attempt in the stock market yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped again below the 800 mark.

title: ORMAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Apple Starts Move Against Imitators
description: Apple Computer Inc. of Cupertino, Calif., said it had started investigations and legal action against what it termed ''Asian imitators'' of its Apple II computer.

title: LATIN POLICY: U.S. MISCUES
description: Nicaragua put its security forces on full alert under a state of emergency. It charged that right-wing guerrillas who blew up two bridges Sunday acted on C.I.A. orders. Page 7. By PHILIP TAUBMAN News Analysis

title: A COLLEGE CAREER OF CHEATING
description: In his four years at West Virginia University, where he was a star defensive tackle, academic life for John (Tree) Adams was a continuous string of forged themes written by friends and examination questions whose answers he paid for.

title: CENTRAL WISCONSIN BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $263,158 gain from an accounting adjustment

title: ALLAN ULLMAN
description: Allan Ullman, who had been director of the former book and education division of The New York Times, died Monday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in East Hampton.

title: A Deft Compromise on Guns
description: To the nation's gun lobbyists, the McClure-Volkmer bill is a benign effort to ease the unfortunate grip of Federal bureaucracy on struggling small businessmen who deal in firearms. To gun control supporters, it's a bit of surgery designed to eviscerate the 1968 Gun Control Act.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Ex-Kearny Mayor Gets Prison Term
description: NEWARK (AP) - A Federal judge, saying it was ''the fashion'' for some politicians to blame their corruption on Government informants, sentenced the former Mayor of Kearny to eight years in prison for extortion Tuesday.

title: U.S. Cyclist Leads
description: Greg Lemond of Los Angeles upset a group of European cyclists today and won the fourth leg of the Tirreno-Adriatico Classic to take overall command of the race.

title: Denver Firm Liquidates
description: Townsend, Bauerle & Company has become the fifth Denver penny-stock concern to undergo liquidation in the last month.

title: Bendix RCA Stake
description: The Bendix Corporation reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had paid $98.4 million for its 7.2 percent stake in the RCA Corporation. Bendix said it had 5,472,902 RCA shares, acquired on the open market between Sept.8, 1981, and March 8, 1982. Bendix said its RCA holdings included 104,002 shares that may be acquired on the conversion of 145,600 shares of RCA $2.125 cumulative convertible preference stock.

title: SENATOR CHARGES THAT NEW CURBS ON INTELLIGENCE HAMPER CONGRESS
description: A senior Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee accused the Reagan Administration today of severely restricting the flow of secret information to Congress. The Democrat, Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, said that this restrictive policy was part of a broader attempt to limit access to information.

title: Dr. David Golovensky, Rabbi in New Rochelle
description: Dr. David I. Golovensky, rabbi emeritus of Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y., and a former president of the New York Board of Rabbis, died Sunday night at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: U.S. Aide in Costa Rica Reports Plot on Envoy
description: Four suspected Latin American gunrunners captured here were apparently plotting to kidnap an American diplomat at the United States Embassy, an embassy spokesman said today.

title: U.N. Chief Welcomes Move
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar welcomed Leonid I. Brezhnev's announcement today of a freeze in deployment of nuclear missiles in Europe. A United Nations spokesman, Francois Giuliani, said the Secretary General ''welcomes every new initiative enhancing the possibility of a meaningful agreement'' on arms control.

title: BRANIFF CHAIRMAN MOVES TO PAN AM
description: John J. Casey, the chairman of the board of the Braniff International Corporation, has been elected executive vice president, operations of Pan American World Airways, C. Edward Acker, the chairman and chief operating officer of Pan Am, announced yesterday.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: By way of honoring the day's festivities, John Meehan of Manhattan points out a Hibernian curiosity. ''Among the myriad bank advertisements in New York newspapers for Individual Retirement Accounts,'' he reports, ''only those in that excellent publication, the weekly Irish Echo, spell the words out, rather than use those catchy initials: I.R.A.''

title: Winfield Struggles Again But Outlines Perspective
description: If he were a different sort of man, Dave Winfield said today - less inquisitive or more singleminded - he might be a different sort of ballplayer.

title: KOOSMAN RELISHES NEW JOB
description: Fifteen years after having joined them as a rookie in spring training, Jerry Koosman pitched against the Mets today as a 38-year-old relief pitcher for the Chicago White Sox. And neither time nor the Mets treated him kindly.

title: JURORS FIND VON BULOW GUILTY OF TRYING TWICE TO KILL WIFE
description: As Claus von Bulow sat flushed, still and expressionless, a jury today pronounced him guilty, as charged, of twice trying to kill his wealthy wife, Martha von Bulow, by injecting her with insulin.

title: DROWNING IN RIPPLES OF REAGANOMICS
description: I always thought that unemployment was something that happened to school dropouts in ghettos and to auto workers in the Midwest. Now I know that any of us can drown in the ripples of Reaganomics.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: ASSOCIATES
description: The trial of the politically powerful Mayor of Union City, William V. Musto, and seven associates, including the former head of the Board of Education, is slowly drawing to a close in Federal District Court here. Judge H. Lee Sarokin is expected to give the case to the jury toward the end of the week.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS UNITE IN WARNING REAGAN ON BUDGET
description: The 45 Democrats in the Senate unanimously told President Reagan today that ''the budget will never be balanced under your conditions,'' and offered alternative proposals, including deferring the third year of the tax cut voted by Congress last year.

title: It's Mexico's Doorstep, Too
description: If we hear Secretary Haig correctly, his Central American policy this week is to wish Mexico well in trying to broker a deal between Latin guerrillas and the Reagan Administration. That is a tall order, and he is right to add all the usual cautions. But now the Administration seems on the right track; the question is why it has taken so long to welcome Mexican involvement.

description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $7,100 for the qr and $48,042 for the yr...C-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $6,756 for the qr and $62,956 for the yr

SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes $2,015,000 extraordinary

title: THIRD WORLD REJECTS U.S. PROPOSAL TO CHANGE LAW OF THE SEA TREATY
description: The third world today rejected United States proposals to overhaul the projected treaty to exploit the oceans' mineral wealth.

title: BEHIND THE SLIPPAGE AT MARSHALL FIELD
description: A Chicago landmark, the 75-year-old flagship store of Marshall Field & Company, occupies a full block of State Street, its two famous clocks a guide to the carriage trade to which it catered. Architecturally, it is even more magnificent inside, a six-story well that is surrounded by columned balconies and topped by a Tiffany dome.

title: Haven Moses Retires
description: Haven Moses, the veteran Denver Bronco wide receiver, announced his retirement yesterday after 14 years in professional football.

title: LAKE SHORE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $339,000 tax credit...C-Net loss after $9,433,000 loss representing the company's shr of the provision for loss on the disposal of an operations

title: Graham to Moscow?
description: He's been invited to speak in two Moscow churches, but Billy Graham has not decided whether he will accept one or both of the invitations, a spokesman for the evangelist said yesterday.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
CHARLOTTE W. MURRAY
description: Charlotte Wallace Murray, a musician and former member of the choir of Riverside Church, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital. She was 97 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PRESIDENT VISITS VICTIMS OF FLOOD
description: President Reagan, following up three speeches that centered on his concern for the victims of economic distress, today visited victims of a natural disaster, the flood that has inundated parts of this Middle Western city.

title: PROBABLE DRIVER IN CRASH FATAL TO 9 HAD BEEN DRINKING, TESTS INDICATE
description: The teen-ager believed to have been at the wheel of the van that was demolished in a crash early Sunday with a train in Mineola, L.I. - in which he and eight others were killed - had drunk the equivalent of ''four or five beers'' at the time of the accident, the Nassau County Medical Examiner said last night.

title: TOP STATE COURT REFUSES TO BLOCK THEATER RAZING
description: The State Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, refused yesterday to hear an appeal to delay demolition of two midtown Manhattan theaters. It thus removed all but a single barrier to construction of the 50-story Portman hotel in the Times Square area.

title: IN CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC, A COUP OR JUST A CHARADE?
description: The military Government here says the opposition tried to overthrow it 13 days ago. The opposition says the Government instigated the attempted coup to entrench itself.

title: DATA TERMINAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUT THE CAR-THEFT INDUSTRY OUT OF BUSINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Airline Traffic Up
description: The International Air Transport Association announced yesterday that domestic and international airline traffic rose 4.8 percent in February from the same month in 1981. The group said that for the first two months of this year airline traffic increased 2.9 percent from the similar period last year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Products Corporation, Chicago, has named Richard A. Drexler to the new position of chief operating officer.

title: PORTABLE CAN OPENER
description: CANNED foods are something I try to avoid, but the canned items I do use often are tricky to open. Cans of sardines, truffles and foie gras have very difficult corners and most openers have difficulty getting around them. Few things are more infuriating than a lid that refuses to come off because it is stuck at the corners, forcing you to prize out the contents with a fork.

title: Red Brigades Leader Tells of Ties to P.L.O.
description: A Red Brigades leader who organized the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier testified today that the left-wing group had contacts with similar organizations abroad, including the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: UNDER ARCTIC ICE, A 19TH-CENTURY SHIP TANTALIZES
description: The planes came in low from the west over the barren Arctic tundra. They swung out over the ice before circling in for a bone-jarring landing on the frozen surface of the Arctic Ocean.

title: Real Estate; How Space In an Office Can 'Grow'
description: APOUND of caviar is only 14 ounces. A two-by-four is not really two i nches by four inches. And in Manhattan, a 10,000-square-foot office i s rarely 10,000 square feet.

title: GASOLINE DOLLARS DON'T TALK
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTISTRY OF LEATHER IN MILAN SHOW
description: When the pieces all come together properly, the clothes shown here have a style that cannot be surpassed. That happened this morning for the first time in the current week of fall fashion presentations. Mario Valentino showed a spectacular collection of leather and suede fashions, and the viewers went wild.

title: ADVANCE ROSS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After $364,000 loss from discontinued operations... C-After $29,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: No Headline
description: MAYOR IN GEORGIA LIKES NEW LAW REQUIRING GUNS

title: CORONA'S BROTHER BLAMED IN DEATHS
description: Defense attorneys in Juan V. Corona's retrial for the murders of 25 itinerant farm workers in 1971 have nominated his half brother, Natividad Corona, as the actual murderer.

title: BOMB KILLS WOMAN IN MOSLEM AREA OF BEIRUT
description: A car bomb exploded in a residential area of predominantly Moslem western Beirut today, killing a woman and wounding 15 other people, police sources said.

title: NEWSCASTER ANCHORED TO BIG MONEY
description: TO what extent do local news stations reward performance and presence in preference to reporting ability? A rundown of the salaries at one local station, WNBC-TV, obtained from a source familiar with the station's contracts, suggests that there are huge disparities between salaries for anchors, sportscasters and even weathermen - the most visible personalties on news programs - and the salaries paid to the reporters who gather the news.

title: New Road to Success
description: Since he came to New York in 1968, Thomas Botsaris, who was born in Greece and raised in Brazil, has paid a lot of attention to the subtleties of the restaurant business and not much to the nuances of local politics.

title: BRIDGEMARKET PLAN GETS LOCAL OFFICIALS' BACKING
description: Elected officials and community leaders in Manhattan gave their critical endorsement last night to a proposed market of restaurants and food shops beneath the Manhattan end of the Queensboro Bridge.

title: Cuisine Files Chapter 11 Bid
description: Cuisine Magazine, which moved to New York from Chicago last year, filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act yesterday, calling higher operating costs here the cause of its troubles.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After $146,000 foreign exchange loss...C-Includes $100,000 foreign exchange gain

title: New Editor at Life
description: Richard B. Stolley, who has served as managing editor of People magazine since it began publishing in 1974, has been named managing editor of Life magazine, another Time Inc. publication.

title: POLAND SAYS IT HAS PAID 1981 INTEREST TO BANKS
description: Polish bank officials have informed their Western creditor banks that they have completed payment of interest owed for 1981, removing the last obstacle to an agreement to reschedule $2.4 billion in principal Poland had failed to pay to Western banks last year.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
THE POP LIFE
description: ZOETROPE STUDIOS, Francis Ford Coppola's sprawling Hollywood movie lot, looks dark and deserted after midnight. But one night last week, faint, ghostly strains of rock-and-roll were audible from the front gate, and the sound grew louder as one strolled through the lot's alleyways, between looming soundstage and office buildings. Bonnie Raitt had rented one of Mr. Coppola's hangarlike soundstages for a few nights and was rehearsing her new rock band, in preparation for a tour that will bring her to New York's Palladium on April 25.

title: 'IT WAS A MOST UNUSUAL COOKING CLASS'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Eileen Yin-Fei Lo teaches and writes about Chinese cooking and is the author of ''The Dim Sum Book: Classic Recipes From the Chinese Teahouse.'' By EILEEN YIN-FEI LO

title: 2 TAYLOR DANCE PREMIERES SET
description: Two world premieres and a revival will highlight the Paul Taylor Dance Company's spring season at the City Center from April 13 to May 2. Mr. Taylor choreographed ''Orbs,'' the revival, in 1966. Set to Beethoven's Last Quartets, with decor by Alex Katz, ''Orbs'' will be performed in a gala opening-night benefit.

title: Reagan's Failing Tactics
description: You can always tell when an administration is drifting into serious trouble when the President begins hitting the road, attacking Congress and blaming his problems on the press. It's a sure sign that the first-year political honeymoon is over.

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are all kinds of reasons not to envy others, aside from the fact that it's unbecoming and absolutely futile. Still, it's pretty hard not to turn even a pale shade of green at the fortunate who are naturally thin, or naturally or unnaturally rich, the chocaholics with peach blossom complexions, and anyone who can decipher instruction booklets.

title: United States comments, page A6.
description: The United States dismissed Leonid I. Brezhnev's announcement today of a freeze in deployment of nuclear missiles in Europe as ''a propaganda gesture'' designed to leave the Soviet Union free to gain ''unchallenged hegemony over Europe.''

title: TAYLOR RENTAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
TRANSIT ARBITRATION BILL SIGNED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey tonight signed a bill providing for binding arbitration in talks between the New York City Transit Authority and unions representing 30,000 bus and subway workers. Earlier, the Senate passed the bill without debate by a vote of 48 to 8.

title: Millionaire Seeks Williams's Seat
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Frank Lautenberg, a millionaire businessman who has long contributed to Democratic Party campaigns, announced his candidacy for the party's nomination of a candidate for the seat vacated by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: Excerpts from speech, page A6.
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev announced today that Moscow was suspending its deployment of new nuclear missiles in European Russia. He also warned of retaliatory measures against the United States should the Atlantic alliance go through with the planned installation of new medium-range missiles in Western Europe.

title: U.S. ENVOY SEES PERIL TO AID IF SALVADOR EXTREMISTS WIN
description: Ambassador Deane R. Hinton said today that the emergence of an extremist Government from the election this month could jeopardize the continuation of American aid to El Salvador.

title: Advertising; Putting Rate Data In the Bank
description: TRY to imagine the advertising business without S.R.D.S. and the Red Books. Why, that would be worse than not having the 15 percent media commission, wouldn't it?

title: An Air Fare Newsletter To Help Keep Score
description: Louis Van Leeuwen and Marshall Barrett, who had worked together at Van Leeuwen & Partners before it went under, have been inspired by the airline fares war and the stadium sales message, ''You can't tell the players without a scorecard,'' to create a scorecard for fare discounts.

title: EXPANDED REAL ESTATE SECTION IS PLANNED FOR SUNDAY TIMES
description: The New York Times will introduce an expanded and redesigned Real Estate section on Sunday, March 28. It will include added news and features for consumers along with continued coverage of commercial real estate.

title: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Includes $545,453 capital gain...C-Includes $634,414 capital gain

title: Stage Adaptation of '8 1/2'
description: ''Nine,'' the musical adaptation of Federico Fellini's film ''8 1/2,'' will go into rehearsal today and is scheduled to open on Broadway on May 9. The play, starring Raul Julia, will be directed and choreographed by Tommy Tune. The producers are Michel Stuart and Harvey Klaris.

title: NEWFOUNDLAND VOTE: OIL ISSUE
description: Premier A. Brian Peckford of Newfoundland has called an election next month, two years before the end of his term, to strengthen his position in the province's continuing dispute with the Canadian Government over control of offshore energy resources.

title: WHY AMERICA MISSED THE 'COMPETITIVE BUS'
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: WORLD PREMIERE OF FUGARD' NEW PLAY
description: NEW HAVEN AT the end of Athol Fugard's new play, two black men foxtrot to old-time jukebox music, gliding about a deserted South African restaurant, Astaire-Rogers style. The audience, meanwhile, is in emotional ruins. While some theatergoers struggle to stand and cheer, others cringe in their seats, their heads in their hands, so devastated that they can't even look at the stage. What has happened? What have they seen? It's not easy to put together the pieces. '' 'Master Harold' ... and the Boys'' is only an anecdote, really, and it's often as warm and musical as the men's dance. But somewhere along the way it rises up and breaks over the audience like a storm.

title: Adrift In the Tropics
description: The Government's performance in the Central American mess is mysterious to me. I'm in no doubt that there are malcontents aplenty down there and they don't wish us any good, but on the other hand why should they?

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
TURKEY CONCEDES TORTURE DEATHS, REPORTS IT IS PROSECUTING OFFICIALS
description: The Government acknowledged today that 15 people had died of torture since the military takeover on Sept.12, 1980, adding that other reports were being investigated.

title: OPERA: J. PATRICK RAFTERY
description: BELLINI'S ''I Puritani,'' which opened its current run last Saturday afternoon at the New York City Opera, assembled one of the most solid and impressive casts of the new season. J. Patrick Raftery, in his City Opera debut, sang Riccardo with a powerful and commanding baritone, and both bass roles - Justino Diaz as Giorgio and Maurice Brown as Lord Walton -were scarcely less effective.

title: Careers; Counseling Dismissed Employees
description: WHILE the recession is deepening, the so-called outplacement business is booming. Outplacement involves professional third-party job guidance for an employee who is about to be dismissed. The employer pays for the service.

title: U.S. TO EMPLOY NAVY IN SOUTH FLORIDA DRUG FIGHT
description: Vice President Bush announced today that Navy destroyers would be used in a stepped-up fight against drug smuggling in south Florida.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City crept up 3 cents to $107.22 during the two-week period of March 1 to 12, according to the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs. Shoppers paid $4.53 more for the 41-item basket than during the same time last year.

title: MIKE BURKE: A HAPPY YANK IN IRELAND
description: The main road from Dublin to Galway covers 135 miles and wends its way through a few towns and many more small (By MARTIN O'SHEA, Special to the New York Times) - even minuscule - villages.

title: TETRA TECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday incorrectly identified a legislator who was quoted about the Administration's handling of Polish debts. He is Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin.

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
VIRGINIA IS A STRUGGLING TEAM
description: Virginia's basketball team appeared to be struggling in the last month of the season, winning eight games and losing two. The Cavaliers (30-3) barely got by in seven of those triumphs.

title: 'DANGEROUS GASMES' ABOUT BIRTH CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: WIENERWALD TO SELL MOST RESTAURANTS
description: Two-thirds of the worldwide Wienerwald chain of 1,550 restaurants will be sold as franchises in an attempt to improve the liquidity of the Wienerwald Group, according to its finance manager, Kurt Lichtenstein.

title: P.&G. BUYS MORTON'S DRUG UNIT
description: Procter & Gamble announced today that it had agreed to acquire the pharmaceutical division of Morton-Norwich Products Inc., the Chicago-based chemical and household products manufacturer, for $371 million in cash.

title: A Princess Visits
description: For someone who supposedly gave up show business, Princess Grace of Monaco puts on an amazing number of performances. There she was again Tuesday night, reading prose and poetry from the stage of the Chichester Festival Theater in England.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Snowfalls and freezing weather combined to clog my gutters with ice, some of which backed up under the shingles and worked its way into the overhanging soffit. As it melted, the water seeped inside and left stains on the inside walls. How can prevent this from happening in the future and how must I prepare the inside walls and ceilings for repainting? -D.K., Hillsdale, N.J.

title: GAP STORES INC, THE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-After gain from discontinued operations of $490,000

title: OPERA: PENNSYLVANIANS GIVE HAYDN'S 'ORLANDO PALADINO'
description: The Pennsylvania Opera Theater, founded in 1975, is the venturesome second company of this city. It presents three productions a year in the Trocadero Theater, which was built as an opera house at the turn of the century, became a burlesque emporium, and now, when opera isn't on the bill, is a Chinese movie house. The theater is a pleasingly intimate one for ''opera comique'' repertory, although the company plans a move to a large house, and hence grander fare, in a couple of years.

title: POLICE TRACE PISTOLS TO A ROYAL OWNER: CATHERINE THE GREAT
description: For years, the two oddly ornate flintlock pistols were stored in the New York City police property warehouse, resting among the Saturday night specials and other illegal handguns.

description: U.S. SAYS ANGOLA RAID SHOWS URGENCY ON NAMIBIA SOLUTION

title: BIPARTISAN LEGISLTION INTRODCED TO RESTRUCTURE IMMIGRATION LAWS
description: Two members of Congress, in a bipartisan initiative, today offered a long-awaited, comprehensive proposal to restructure the nation's immigration law.

title: Countdown Starts Today For 3d Columbia Flight
description: Officials today ordered the countdown for the space shuttle Columbia's third test flight to begin on schedule Thursday, although the prime runways in the California desert are too soaked with rain to permit an emergency landing.

title: FOSTER HITS TWO HOMERS
description: The Mets defeated the Cincinnati Reds today, 5-1, on resounding performances by two former Reds against their old teammates: George Foster, who hit home runs the first two times he batted, and Pat Zachry, who pitched no-hit ball for six innings.

title: WLS-TV in Chicago Switches to B.B.D.O.
description: In Chicago, Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn has been named the agency for WLS-TV, the local ABC station.

title: POLITICAL ARTIFACTS; Faking Washington
description: A million dollars plus sounds like a lot of money to spend for a stage set on which to train Secret Service agents. But what a set! The Federal Government is planning to build facades of both the White House and Blair House, and to recreate Lafayette Park in Beltsville, Md.

title: More Records for Gretzky
description: Wayne Gretzky, with three goals and two assists, set three National Hockey League marks tonight as the Edmonton Oilers routed the Pittsburgh Penguins, 10-4.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
POLICE STILL HUNT HOTEL JEWEL ROBBERS
description: It was the kind of crime befitting a motion-picture plot: Shortly after midnight last Feb. 19, three guests at the Pierre Hotel reported that they had been robbed of an estimated $1 million in jewelry and $80,000 in cash by two gunmen.

title: THE HOUSE MACE SYMBOLIZES ORDER
description: It cost just $400 and weighs just 13 pounds. But for more than a century the slender staff of ebony and silver has silently cautioned generations of lawmakers: ''Order in the House.''

title: Technology; The Computer In Restaurants
description: FAMILIAR restaurant cries like ''two eggs over easy with a side of bacon'' may soon be a thing of the past. Rather than shouting orders to cooks, restaurant waiters and waitresses are increasingly entering customers' orders into computer terminals in the dining area.

title: Petraglia Captures Lead In Long Island Bowling
description: Johnny Petraglia, who has not won on the Professional Bowlers Association tour since 1980, took a 38-pin first-round lead over Randy Lightfoot today in the $100,000 Long Island Open.

title: Canadian Conservatives End Boycott of Voting
description: A two-week paralysis of the House of Commons ended today when the opposition Progressive Conservative party agreed to participate in a vote originally scheduled for March 2.

description: B-Net income; latest yr and qr results include results of Western Kentucky Gas Co

Dow Off 2.48 as Volume Falls
description: Stock prices eased yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average closed just above its recent 22-month low. Energy and brokerage issues showed some weakness, while precious-metal, technology and airline stocks moved higher.

title: SECRECY SURROUNDS SALVADORAN TROOPS IN U.S.
description: ''Pretend we're looking in the shop window,'' one of the two young Salvadoran soldiers said. They were in town on a Sunday afternoon, with orders not to give interviews.

description: Yr-ago shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid Mar 1

NETS TURN BACK SPURS, 93-90
description: Ray Williams, who was struggling offensively through the first half and was in foul trouble in the third period, scored 14 of his 20 points in the final period tonight to help the Nets defeat the San Antonio Spurs, 93-90, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: India Expels Iraqi Aide
description: India today expelled an assistant attache at the Iraqi Consulate who shot and wounded the son of the manager of a restaurant in Bombay. A Foreign Ministry official said the attache, Abdul Razzak Khalaf, was ordered to leave India immediately.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION
description: To the Editor:

title: MORGAN STANLEY'S LINK TO S.E.C. CHIEF STUDIED
description: When the Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously last month to narrow a new rule bitterly opposed by Morgan Stanley & Company, an affiliate of the investment banking firm was in the process of retiring a $7.8 million debt it owed the commission's chairman, John S.R. Shad, according to public records.

title: FRANCE PLANS A SECOND HIGH-SPEED RAILROAD
description: France, already enjoying the world's fastest passenger trains operating at 160 miles per hour between Paris and Lyons, is now planning a second high-speed electric line.

title: Atomic Dump in Argentina?
description: Underground caverns beneath the Patagonian desert in southern Argentina may become a dumping ground for the world's nuclear waste, Vice Adm. Carlos Castro Madero, head of Argentina's nuclear program, said in an interview published today in the newspaper Clarin.

title: ADMINISTRATION REVIVES RULES ON CHEMICAL LABELS
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to issue a labeling rule for toxic substances that White House officials denounced last year, worker safety officials said today.

title: British Pay Up 10.8%
description: The average pay of British workers rose 10.8 percent in the year ended Jan. 31, the Government said today. Inflation was at a 12 percent annual rate in January.

title: FIELD RISES $1 IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Marshall Field & Company stock rose sharply yesterday in hectic trading. Wall Street analysts speculated that a takeover battle for the major Chicago retailer could develop despite Marshall Field's acceptance Tuesday of a $310 million bid by Batus Inc.

title: OCCUPIED BY ISRAEL
description: occupied West Bank - It is 15 years since Israel subjugated the West Bank and Gaza in the 1967 war. The generation that has grown up under the occupation has never known a world without military government, identity cards, checkpoints, spurious arrests, and collective punishments. Schools have been periodically shut, parents interrogated, and houses razed by Israeli bulldozers.

title: FROM MANHATTAN TO MOSCOW
description: When Idaho plays Thursday night in the West Regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament, it will have 12 players in uniform.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for As of Feb 28
NICARAGUA'S BRUTAL ABUSE OF MISKITO INDIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailing Technology Magazine Looks for Partners
description: An executive of the parent company of Technology, the glossy magazine started last year to ride the wave of interest in technical matters, said yesterday that the date of its next issue had become uncertain and that the company was talking with potential partners in an effort to obtain needed capital.

title: Premiere at New Theater
description: ''Catholic School Girls'' by Casey Kurtti will have its premiere as the initial attraction of the 199-seat Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street. Previews will begin tomorrow; the play will open March 24.

title: KRM PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: As the marathon Madrid conference on detente and human rights disbanded last week and diplomats packed their bags, there was an inevitable tendency to regard the meeting as a failure.

title: 670 U.S. SOLDIERS ARRIVE IN SINAI FOR PEACE PATROL
description: The United States sent 670 American soldiers from the 82d Airborne Division into Sharm el Sheik today to take up positions in the multinational peacekeeping force that is to patrol a strip of Sinai after Israel's withdrawal on April 25.

title: GARDENING
description: SHARPEN the mower. Get out the rake. Roll up your sleeves. The grass is getting green and gardeners know what that means. Good lawnsmanship is usually judged by how green the grass is in summer. But what most homeowners fail to realize is that root activity underground is much more important.

title: Iran to Restudy A-Power
description: Iran is to start importing nuclear technology again, according to the head of the Nuclear Technology Center at Isfahan, the Iranian National News Agency reported today. Plans for 20 nuclear power stations to be built over 20 years were shelved by Iran after the overthrow of the Shah in 1979.

title: MODERN CERAMISTS PLY AN ANCIENT TECHNIQUE
description: EARLY Roman and Greek potters painted a liquid clay known as terra sigillatta over their heavy clay wares to give the finished pieces a surface that appeared thin, shiny and delicate.

title: PLANNER WITH TENACITY
description: The chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, Herbert Jay Sturz, first saw New York from a distance, as a boy growing up in Bayonne, N.J. He saw it as a magnificent string of skyscrapers rising across the Hudson River.

title: ERODING EROSION
description: Dust storms darkening the sun in Washington, D.C., with topsoil blown from the Great Plains, an anxious farmer knee-deep in a newly carved gully - today, after a half-century and $20 billion worth of Federal programs, these memories still shape national policy aimed at combating soil erosion. But Government findings in recent years have substantially changed experts' ideas about erosion problems, and public debate over how to solve them must take those findings into account.

title: STAGE: 'LAST OF KNUCKLEMEN,' A TOUGH AUSTRALIAN WESTERN
description: ''THE LAST of the Knucklemen'' is an Australian barracks-room western about male companionship, competition and chauvinism. As directed by Peter Masterson at the American Theater of Actors, John Powers's play starts like a lesser, leisurely version of David Storey - a ragtag collection of day laborers go through their daily routine in a bunkhouse in an isolated wildcat mine in the Australian outback.

title: U.S. MAY BUY PLANT TO MAKE PLUTONIUM
description: Secretary of Energy James B. Edwards said today that the Department of Energy was considering purchasing a partially built but canceled nuclear power plant in Washington State to convert it into a facility that could produce plutonium for atomic weapons.

title: U.S. AGENCY'S HANDLING OF CONTROLLERS CRITICIZED
description: An Administration-created team of experts issued a severe indictment of the Federal Aviation Administration's handling of employee relations today.

title: OZZIE SMITH'S TURN
description: OZZIE SMITH took a primer course in moving up. Over the last two years, he watched Dave Winfield preparing to leave the San Diego Padres for big money, and then saw Winfield playing in the World Series with the Yankees.

title: President Is Elected At Parker Pen Unit
description: Manville D. Smith, 42 years old, has been elected president of the Parker Pen Company's writing instrument group, which is responsible for 31 percent of the corporation's sales and 55 percent of its earnings. He succeeds Willi F. Sieberger, 60, who resigned from the Janesville, Wis., company for personal reasons.

title: Market Place; Thrift Units And Banks
description: THE lack of action by Congress on any rescue legislation for the troubled thrift industry may well promote mergers between commercial banks and healthy savings and loan associations. This, at least, is the position taken by Marc Perkins of Raymond, James & Associates of St. Petersburg, Fla., in a bullish report just issued on selected stocks of Florida savings and loan companies.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS PENDLETON FOR RIGHTS POST
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved President Reagan's nomination of Clarence M. Pendleton Jr. as chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $439,000 for the qr and $13,920,000 for the yr...C-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $235,000 for the qr and $8,477,000 for the yr; both yrs include results from Ayr-Way Stores since Sept 7, 1980; the shr earnings restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov 1981

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WAR SAPS SALVADOR ECONOMY
description: Faced with a loss of confidence, capital flight, political uncertainty and outright destruction, the economy of El Salvador is surviving only through the international aid, most of it American, that will be pouring into the tiny nation this year.

title: MODERATE IMAGE; The leaders in profile, page A16.
description: The five guerrilla groups that are fighting to topple El Salvador's civilian-military junta are headed by Marxists who now say they are ready to accept a negotiated settlement instead of holding out for a socialist revolution.

title: BUTCHER BLOCK TABLE GETS SPECIAL FACE LIFT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores furniture for antiques dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
'Chalk Garden' Coming
description: Irene Worth and Donal Donnelly will join Constance Cummings in the cast of ''The Chalk Garden,'' which will begin performances at the Roundabout Theater's Stage One on March 30. Featured will be I.M. Hobson, Elizabeth Owens, Eunice Anderson and Sallyanne Tackus. ''The Chalk Garden'' by Enid Bagnold is being directed by John Stix.

title: CRIME CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Men Passing Time in a Hall Slain for an Unknown Reason
description: Two men were shot to death last night as they were resting on the sixth-floor landing of an apartment building in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said. Investigators last night had no idea why the men were shot.

title: 'POET LAUREATE' OF NEW YORK GIVEN HONORS POSTHUMOUSLY
description: According to advices from Albany and the State Arts Council, New York will honor its first ''poet laureate'' today. Unfortunately, the honored poet, Isabella Gardner, died last July, and, in any event, she really would not have been the official poet laureate anyway.

title: Englewood Teachers In Accord on Contract
description: Englewood teachers, aides and school secretaries, on strike since March 1, reached a tentative contract agreement today with the School Board, officials said.

title: Delta Loan Accord
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. announced yesterday that it had completed a $350 million loan agreement arranged through Citizens and Southern National Bank.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Jan 1982

title: No Headline
description: POLISH PRESS SAYS JOURNALISTS WANT PRO-COMMUNIST UNION

title: COLOMBIA CALLS FOR A NAVAL FORCE TO CUT OFF SALVADORAN REBELS
description: President Julio Cesar Turbay Ayala of Colombia called today for an inter-American naval force to block the flow of arms from Cuba and Nicaragua to guerrillas in El Salvador and other Latin American countries.

title: Not Nativist, Not Racist, Not Mean
description: A Republican Senator and a Democratic Congressman joined yesterday to introduce a rare piece of legislation: a responsible immigration bill.

title: SYSTEMS PLANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including $2.3 million extraordinary gain for the yr; the net income for the qr is operating net

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Henry Rosner, Retired Official; In City Social Services Dept.
description: Henry J. Rosner, retired assistant commissioner of New York City's Social Services Department and former assistant administrator of the city's Human Resources Administration, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He lived in Manhattan and was 73 years old.

title: Thrift Unit Merger
description: The Culver Federal Savings and Loan Association and the Coast Federal Savings and Loan, both of Los Angeles, said yesterday that they had signed a letter of intent to merge. Coast Federal, with assets of $3.3 billion, has 83 branch offices in California. Culver Federal, with five branches in southern California and another office approved but not yet opened, has assets of $191.8 million.

title: SOTHEBY'S TRIES TO OVERCOME BUSINESS PROBLEMS
description: The London auction houses have been one of the great British success stories of the last decade, with both Sotheby's and its smaller rival, Christie's, spreading their operations across the globe and increasing their sales tenfold.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH many hardware stores will cut a piece of glass to size when you need to replace a broken windowpane, most of the larger home centers no longer offer the service. Do-it-yourselfers may find it more convenient to cut glass to size on other occasions -for example, a small piece from a larger one for a picture frame or a small door pane.

title: The Missing Pearl
description: Wes Unseld, Gus Johnson, Kevin Loughery and Fred Carter were conspicuous at the Washington Bullets' annual alumni game at Landover, Md. But Earl Monroe was not.

title: SURVEY REPORTS PERIL OF CARBON MONOXIDE IN BLOOD OF SMOKERS
description: Nearly 80 percent of smokers have potentially dangerous levels of carbon monoxide in their blood, a federally financed survey reported today.

title: SENATE VOTES TO BAR IDENTIFICATION OF SECRET AGENTS
description: The Senate today joined the House of Representatives in approving an amendment that would make it illegal for individuals, including journalists, to identify American intelligence agents if they had ''reason to believe'' that the disclosure would harm American intelligence activities.

title: U.S. Envoy Presses Britain on Sanctions
description: Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley met with British officials today in his continuing quest for more sanctions against the Soviet Union. But there was no indication that he had been any more successful in London than he was earlier this week in Bonn or Paris.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Political Artifacts Curbside Diplomacy

title: POP: SWEET HONEY, A QUINTET
description: SWEET Honey in the Rock, the Washington-based black women's collective formed in 1974, has released three albums that carry blues and folk-or-iented a cappella singing to a peak of refinement. Unlike the Persuasions and 14 Carat Soul, a cappella groups that come from an urban doo-wop tradition, their roots are half in church and half in the Balkan folk-singing tradition of the Pennywhistlers, which involves long-lined nonpercussive vocalizing.

title: TRANSIT WORKERS GIVEN PROPOSALS FOR A CONTRACT
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority presented New York City's bus and subway unions with a 128-page volume of contract proposals yesterday. Among other things, they call for a three-year agreement, instead of a two-year one, and the ending of all specific work quotas.

title: CARLTON GROUP SPURNS LOBBYING LIMELIGHT
description: If the Carlton Group of business lobbyists could do so, it would return to the anonymity that cloaked it before its smashing success of last summer - enactment of accelerated depreciation tax write-offs.

title: EX-TREASURY OFFICIAL AND CAPITAL LAWYER
description: Edward H. Foley, who was Under Secretary of the Treasury in the Truman Administration, died here Tuesday night after a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

title: U.S. Panel's Report Criticizes Chicago's Housing Authority
description: A study done for the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development says that the Chicago Housing Authority is one of the worst-managed public housing agencies in the nation.

title: INVESTIGATOR OF STOUFFER'S FIRE LIED TO DEFENDANT ABOUT THE EVIDENCE
description: The police official who headed the investigation into the Stouffer's Inn fire testified today that he had attempted to have Luis Marin, the defendant, confess to arson by confronting him with a bottle of gasoline and saying falsely that it contained his fingerprints.

title: FELON BILL BACKED BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to back a Senate bill, designed to help solve the problem of violent street crime, that would allow Federal prosecution of certain crimes committed more than twice by the same person.

title: Nixon Library Offered a Home in Missouri; Nixon Library Site?
description: Since the Duke University faculty effectively blocked plans to build Richard M. Nixon's Presidential library at the North Carolina campus, aides to the former President have been looking for a nonacademic - and presumably less controversial - setting for the proposed library.

title: New Editor Takes Over At Times of London
description: Charles Douglas-Home was appointed editor of The Times of London today, ending a week-long wrangle over the management of the newspaper.

title: SUPPLY-SIDE FOREIGN POLICY
description: It's hard to remember when there was more confusion in the world about the signals sent from Washington.

title: COOKING ON THE HEARTH
description: IF you have a large old-fashioned fireplace designed for cooking, many ingenious pieces of equipment are available in blacksmiths' catalogues that will enable you to do open-hearth cooking or to have the props for an interesting and appropriate display in your fireplace.

title: A Matter of Taxes
description: When the word got around that James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, had switched his legal residence from Colorado to Wyoming last August, there was speculation that he might be considering a political race in Wyoming.

title: Mahre Twins Finish 1-2; Stenmark Places 17th
description: Steve and Phil Mahre of Yakima, Wash., celebrated a family triumph today in a World Cup giant slalom that turned into one of Ingemar Stenmark's worst defeats in years.

title: An End to Rumors
description: Lou Campanelli, James Madison University's basketball coach, had been considered a leading candidate for the coaching jobs at Seton Hall and Rice.

title: DYLEX LTD reports earnings for Yr to Jan 30
INQUIRY IS ASKED BY MACCHIAROLA IN STATE DISPUTE
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor has asked for a state investigation into the State Education Department and one of its assistant commissioners as a result of a disputed state survey of the city school system's practices in hiring teachers for the handicapped.

title: BIT OF MIST SETS TONE FOR IRISH
description: A chilling rain and police precautions transformed St. Patrick's Day in the city yesterday into the least rowdy of recent years, though possibly not the cheeriest and certainly not the sunniest.

title: French Warn Japan
description: France issued a warning to Japan today that the European Economic Community may resort to protectionist measures against Japanese products in the near future, Japanese Foreign Ministry officials said here.

title: India Takes Control of State
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government imposed direct rule on Kerala Wednesday after the coalition administration in the southern state lost its parliamentary majority and resigned.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 18, 1982
description: International A Caribbean basin aid bill that includes a request for $128 million in emergency economic assistance for El Salvador was sent to Congress by the Reagan Administration. The request would bring the total of projected economic assistance for El Salvador this year to $232.5 million. (Page A1, Column 6.) The five Salvadoran rebel groups that are trying to topple the civilian-military junta are headed by Marxists who now say they are ready to accept a negotiated settlement instead of pressing for a socialist revolution. They have drawn up a peace plan that is more moderate than any previous leftist program. (A1:3-5.)

title: CHINA NERVOUS THAT TAIWAN MAY BE WIDENING ITS TIES
description: While Chinese-American relations remain strained over the prospect of United States military sales to Taiwan, China has become apprehensive that the Nationalist regime on Taiwan may be quietly trying to improve its position with other countries that formally recognize the Peking Government.

title: Appeal Filed in Atlanta Case
description: Lawyers for Wayne B. Williams, the 23-year-old photographer convicted Feb. 27 of murdering two young blacks, have begun his appeal by requesting a new trial. The lawyers, Lynn Whatley and Alvin Binder, contended in their motion Monday that Judge Clarence Cooper erred in allowing the jury to hear evidence of 10 slayings in which Mr. Williams was not charged and in permitting prosecution experts to testify about hair and fiber tests without giving test results to the defense at least 10 days before trial.

title: NCNB to Buy Bank in Florida
description: The NCNB Corporation of North Carolina, in a substantial move to extend its banking interests in Florida, has agreed in principle to acquire Gulfstream Banks Inc. of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Pabst Dissidents Seek More Shares
description: Shareholders of the Pabst Brewing Company, led by Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis investor, have mailed proxy materials as part of their plan to gain control of the brewer. The group is dissatisfied with the current management, and has accused the board of indecisiveness in the face of severe financial problems.

title: 13,044 MEDICAL SENIORS LEARN THEIR FUTURES ON MATCH DAY
description: At Columbia University, and at 123 other medical schools across the country, yesterday was Match Day, the day when the seniors' future - at least for the next one to seven years - was decided.

title: NEGOTIATORS SEE $50 MILLION CUT IN CAREY BUDGET
description: Legislative negotiators have agreed to more than $50 million in cuts in Governor Carey's proposed budget, to some increases in professional licensing fees and to a number of other proposals to increase state revenue.

title: Pentacostal Fears Draft
description: A 19-year-old Pentecostalist Christian taking sanctuary at the United States Embassy said today that Soviet officials are trying to draft him into the army, a move that could complicate his attempt to emigrate to the United States. The Pentacostalist, Timofei Chmykhalov.

title: SALVADOR GUERRILLA IS REPORTED TO MEET ARAFAT IN LEBANON
description: One of the leaders of the rebel forces in El Salvador has paid a secret visit to Lebanon and met with Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, according to the Lebanese leftist daily As Safir.

title: CHARLES RIVER BREEDING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results for the latest qr reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. statement No 52 for foreign currency translation

title: Getting Old at 103
description: She stopped bowling a few years back, and now Dora Spangler is afraid she'll have to drop golf and take up crocheting. ''I just had to give up everything,'' Mrs. Spangler said the other day.

title: ATICO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After income of $466,000 from discontinued operations

title: Sybron to Buy Dental Units
description: The Sybron Corporation said it had signed an agreement in principle to acquire the dental manufacturing and distribution operations of the American Hospital Supply Corporation for about $90 million.

title: Bill Would Require President To Choose Nuclear Dump Site
description: The House Interior Committee voted today to require the President to designate within five years at least one permanent site for dumping the nation's growing accumulation of radioactive nuclear wastes.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Charles O'Brien, 52, has been appointed president of the pharmaceutical division of the Ciba-Geigy Corporation, which was responsible last year for $420 million of the company's total sales of almost $2 billion. He succeeds Richard J. Kogan, 40, who left to become executive vice president of the Schering-Plough Corporation's pharmaceutical operations.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Landauer Subsidiary Offers Investment Aid
description: At Landauer Associates Inc., the New York real estate consultant, a new subsidiary has been established to offer investment advice to pension funds and other institutions interested in acquiring incomeproducing real estate, such as shopping centers, office buildings and warehouses. Named to head the new unit, called Landauer Advisors, was Patrick J. Callan, 46, a senior vice president of the parent company.

title: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes investment gains equal to 2 cents a shr for the qr and 4 cents a shr for the yr...C-Includes investment gains equal to 6 cents a shr

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Head of Holly May Buy Stock
description: Trading in shares of the Holly Sugar Corporation, suspended voluntarily for three days, is to resume on the New York Stock Exchange tomorrow, but the management is considering returning Holly to private ownership, the company said today. Holly is the nation's third-largest refiner of sugar beets, with 1981 sales of $328.6 million.

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Checking Account Plan
description: The Texas Federal Savings and Loan Association said it would start offering a new high-yield checking service early in the second quarter that combines money market fund investing with interest-bearing checking. The company said that under an agreement with the Dreyfus Corporation, any money over $2,500 in a customer's account would automatically be transferred on a daily basis from a 5 1/4 percent Texas Federal checking account to the customer's choice of either Dreyfus Liquid Assets Inc. or Dreyfus Government Series funds.

title: What Do Suburbanites Have in Common?
description: Remember Roy Rowan? He was the Time Inc. man who left temporarily 10 years ago to run On the Sound magazine with the belief that people living around a body of water - of less than ocean size, of course - are united in interests. Now here comes T. Burton Kessler, president of East Coast Publications, with a dry-land version.

title: RSC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $83,000 loss for moving corporate offices and $86,600 gain on the sale of investment assets...C-Net income

title: Nicaragua Says U.S.  Violated Its Airspace
description: Nicaragua protested to the United Nations today over what it said were violations of its airspace by the United States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burger King Corporation, Miami, has appointed Herb D. Ihle executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: What Budget Compromise? When?
description: President Reagan has traveled the country to tell audiences that he's willing to compromise on his deficit-laden budget plan. But in fact he has refused even to come close.

title: 4 Held for Stealing $273,000 at Bank
description: Three men and a woman accused of stealing $273,000 from the Park Avenue branch of an Argentine bank were arrested yesterday, according to District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx.

title: Levels Steady For Gasoline
description: Supplies of distillate declined and gasoline inventories remained virtually unchanged last week, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday.

title: OPERA: NEW IL BARBIERE,' STARRING KATHERINE BATTLE
