description: WHEN the Metropolitan Opera served up its new production of Rossini's ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' on Feb. 15, Marilyn Horne's admirers expressed enthusiasm for her peformance of Rosina but had reservations elsewhere down the line. By Tuesday evening's performance, however, an entirely new cast had taken over. With some reservations, the evening was a model of what the Met should be doing with standard repertory - a delightful mixture of fresh young voices and practiced veterans, all in a spanking new production, full of concern for both tradition and innovation.

title: BRANIFF SETS LATIN ROUTE TRANSFER
description: In a move to obtain critically needed cash, Braniff International announced today that it plans to turn over most of its South American routes to Pan American World Airways for the next four years.

title: RATES STABLE IN QUIET TRADING
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday as credit market participants expressed uncertainty about the future course of interest rates.

title: VISUAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Domestic Telex
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Company and the RCA Corporation will each begin domestic telex service today to about 70 cities. Both companies received permission yesterday from the Federal Communications Commission to start their services. I.T.T. and RCA have long provided overseas telex service, but domestic service had been reserved for the Western Union Corporation until passage of a new law last December.

title: SOVIET FAVORS MEXICO'S MEDIATION OFFER
description: Mexico's offer to mediate conflicts in Central America has received qualified support from top Soviet leaders. This month, Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, criticized what he described as American threats to Cuba and Nicaragua and interference in El Salvador.

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $81,200 for the qr and $166,400 for the 6 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $80,900 for the qr and $105,900 for the 6 mos

title: 60-Second Debate
description: Paul Laxalt Republican Senator from Nevada

title: Bridge: The League Charity Game Is Set for Next Wednesday
description: The headquarters of bridge in North America is the American Contract Bridge League office in Memphis. Among the multifarious activities planned there is the Spring National Championships, which begin tomorrow in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $12,000 for th qr and $153,000 for the yr...C-Net loss after losses from disco tinued operations of $302,000 for the qr and $727,000 for the y

title: The Guns of Kennesaw
description: Darvin Purdy is Mayor of Kennesaw, Ga., and Robert Ruble is Chief of Police. The two are feeling expansive over an ordinance their City Council passed requiring all heads of households to own a gun and ammunition. It's a symbolic gesture, for the most part, a message to the criminals, Mayor Purdy suggests. And to soft-headed supporters of gun control, adds Chief Ruble.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Feb 1

title: ARGENTINES DEBATE KILLING 48,000 PENGUINS A YEAR
description: A proposal to slaughter 48,000 penguins a year has brought court suits and contradictory statements in Argentina.

title: AN E.P.A. SURRENDER ON HAZARDOUS LIQUIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailing Cuisine Magazine
description: James L. Bartlett 3d, president of Cuisine Magazine, said yesterday (one day after the magazine filed in Chapter 11) that CBS Inc., with which it has been having acquistion discusions, had made a formal offer that will be accepted this week by its owner, the Forum Communications Corporation of Santa Barbara. There were no details given on the offer.

title: Emanuel Ax to Perform
description: Emanuel Ax, winner of the first Rubinstein International Piano Competition and the 1979 Avery Fisher Prize, will give a piano recital in Carnegie Hall on April 18 at 8 P.M. The program will include works by Haydn, Schumann and Chopin and Four Mazurkas by Karol Szymanowski. Tickets are $6, $8, $10 and $12.50, through CarnegieCharge, 247-7459.

title: PAINO RECITALL: FRENCH SUITE
description: Jeffrey Kahane's choice of piano music at Alice Tully Hall Monday night said much about his musical personality even before the first note was played. The only two bravura works were the Busoni transcription of Bach's D minor Chaconne and Scherzo in E by Chopin.

title: COMMUNIST PARTY CHALLENGES MARCOS REGIME
description: An article by the jailed chairman of the Philippine Communist Party was smuggled out of his cell recently and widely circulated as part of a public relations war with the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: TV: NEW LOOK FOR A LONGER 'CBS MORNING NEWS'
description: STILL another ''all new'' version of the ''CBS Morning News'' is making its debut, this one running for two hours, beginning at 7 A.M. each weekday in direct competition with NBC's ''Today'' and ABC's ''Good Morning, America.''

title: ROUTSALAINNEN GETS 3 GOALS AS RANGERS SUBDUE FLYERS, 5-2
description: Reijo Ruotsalainen, the rookie defenseman from Finland, established himself as a Ranger hero last night, scoring three goals and setting two records as New York defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 5-2, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Texas Instruments Lays Off 2,700
description: Texas Instruments Inc., citing a slump in sales of computer components, laid off 2,700 workers, or about 3 percent of its worldwide work force. The company said its semiconductor and distributed-computing businesses have had poor sales since early 1981.

title: Saatchi-Compton Pact: Was the Price a Steal?
description: Thanks to all of the figures supplied by Saatchi & Saatchi of London to accompany the announcement of its deal to acquire Compton Communications of New York, the executives at other agencies that are engaged in the great acquisition race can do a lot of second guessing.

title: U.S. REVERSING STAND ON BURIAL OF TOXIC LIQUID
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced a reversal today of its three-week-old decision to permit burial of drums of toxic liquids in landfills designated for disposal of hazardous wastes.

title: REAGAN REQUESTS $128 MILLION IN AID FOR EL SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration sent to Congress today a Caribbean basin development assistance bill that includes a request for $128 million in emergency economic aid for El Salvador.

title: GRANGER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Includes tax credits of $441,000 for the qr and $839,000 for the 6 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $492,000 for the qr and $830,000 for the 6 mos

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net loss including $290,000 provision for possible loss on contract

title: POLITICAL ARTIFACTS; Mixed Media
description: Once, when important political figures visited New York, they would arrange sessions with newspaper editorial boards, the Council on Foreign Relations, the City Bar and maybe a couple of financial heavyweights good for campaign funds.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Key Rates
description: Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Sabena Seeks Wage Cuts
description: Sabena Belgian World Airlines, the stateowned carrier, today asked its 10,000 workers to accept wage cuts as large as 17 percent to help the financially ailing line save $21 million this year.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $433,000 for the qr and $4,414,000 for the yr and $3,371,000 gain from discontinued operations for both periods...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $316,000 for the qr and $976,000 for the yr

title: ATLANTIC CITY'S CASINOS: RESIDENTS RECITE LOSSES
description: It has been five years since casino gambling came to Atlantic City, and this week an Assembly committee came to find out what effects the gambling industry has had here.

title: U.S. Might Carry Out Libyan Gulf War Games
description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. says the Sixth Fleet will probably conduct naval exercises in the disputed Gulf of Sidra within the next six months despite warnings from the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, that they could lead to war.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS BACK BID FOR QUICK BUDGET VOTE
description: Democrats in the House of Representatives showed broad support today for a proposal by Representative James R. Jones, chairman of the Budget Committee, to bring President Reagan's budget to the House floor where, they believe, it would be overwhelmingly rejected.

title: U.S. TRUCKING DECONTROL HELD BOON FOR CANADIANS
description: Both the Interstate Commerce Commission and Congress are looking into complaints by major trucking companies that Canadians are crossing the border to take advantage of easier American trucking rules resulting from deregulation while American carriers are deterred from entering the Canadian market.

title: DESIGNS FROM VIENNA
description: ACURRENT show of drawings, textiles and embroideries from the James May collection offers some of the imaginative and sprightly designs from the Vienna Workshop, founded in 1902.

title: DESIGN CONTROL FAILURE CRITICIZED ON COAST REACTOR
description: The Pacific Gas & Electric Company failed to establish sufficient quality controls over design work at its Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant and failed to enforce all the controls that did exist, according to a consulting concern.

title: May Stores Gains 6.1%; Dayton-Hudson Up 19%
description: Two of the nation's leading retail chains yesterday reported higher earnings for the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 1981. The Dayton-Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis said that its profit in the fourth quarter ended Jan. 30 rose 19 percent, to $96.5 million, or $2 a share, from $81.2 million, or $1.70 a share, in the corresponding 1980 quarter. Sales were up 17 percent, to $1.67 billion, from $1.43 billion.

title: KENYA LAKE OUTLIVES COMEDY OF ECOLOGICAL ERRORS
description: In the beginning, so they say, was Aplocheilichthys antionrii, better known by a more pronounceable name, the small tooth carp.

title: GROWTH REALTY COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A RARE PRESIDENTIAL JOURNEY INTO PUBLIC VIEW
description: All Presidents lead an encapsulated existence, but few have lived in a more seamless containment than has President Reagan over the past 12 months.

title: IN FORT WAYNE, A STRAIN ON FLOOD DIKES AND PEOPLE
description: The first good news of the week for this city was read off a bright yellow yardstick here today: The swirling waters of the Maumee River were nearing what is expected to be their crest.

title: A WEST BANK INCIDENT
description: Occupied West Bank - Israel, Egypt and the U nited States remain formally committed to the Camp David formula ford ealing with the Palestinian problem: autonomy in the West Bank and G aza. But on the ground it is hard to maintain even the frailest b elief in the idea. An incident I happened to observe here the other d ay indicates why that is so.

title: A.C.L.U. in Dual Role Fights a Ban on Parade
description: The Connecticut chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union announced today that it would represent both the Ku Klux Klan and an antiracism group in challenging a new parade ordinance in Meriden.

title: AN INTERIM SOLUTIONL: SHORT-TERM RENTALS
description: IT is hard enough to find an apartment in Manhattan of any size at any price, with a lease of any length. In a message with a report released this month indicating that the vacancy rate fell 30 percent from 1978 to 1981, Mayor Koch said, ''As every New Yorker knows, vacant apartments in decent, safe buildings are nearly impossible to find.''

title: LOAN FROM JAPAN TO HELP THE M.T.A. BUY SUBWAY CARS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority signed a contract with a Japanese company yesterday for the purchase of 325 subway cars and announced that the deal would be financed in part by a $126 million loan from the Government of Japan.

title: Addenda
description: * Discover magazine is increasing by 11.3 percent, its circulation rate base, to 835,000, and its advertising rates, 11.3 percent, effective with the July issue.

title: SENATOR COUNTED 'FOR' WAS ABSENT
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Orange County today voided a rise in the sales tax because a State Senator who was recorded as having voted for it was not present when the vote was taken. The measure was approved last year to assist mass transit.

title: HIGHER DRINKING AGE GAINS BACKERS
description: The movement to raise the state's drinking age to 19 has gained substantial new support this year in the State Capitol.

title: PERSONAL STYLE COMES HOME-2 APARTMENTS, 2 APPROACHES
description: FOR those whose sense of home and security is inextricably linked with their perceptions of interior design, every object in the house, every decision made about its decor, is intensely personal.

title: Housing for Disabled
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I read with great interest your informative material on accessible housing for disabled people (''Adapting a House for Itzhak Perlman,'' Feb. 25). This is a major issue facing many disabled New York City residents and one that during the present housing crisis deserves serious attention.

title: A Fighter's Creed
description: Bobby Chacon knocked out Salvador Ugalde in the third round at Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday night, one day after Chacon's wife, Valorie, had shot herself to death at their 20-acre California farm. Mrs. Chacon, 31 years old and the mother of three children aged 11, 8 and 6, had opposed her husband's insistence on continuing his boxing career. According to the Butte County Sheriff's Department, she took her life after a telephone conversation in which she had asked her husband, 30, not to go through with the fight.

title: People
description: * Edwin L. Acker elected a senior vice president of the Campbell-Ewald Co., Warren, Mich.

title: Odds Favor Tax Cheats, Panel Told
description: An increase in tax fraud and unintentional errors may be costing the Treasury more than $70 billion a year, but the odds that cheaters will be caught are slimmer this year than ever, Government officials told Congress today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Armco Inc. said that it had increased its share of Oregon Metallurgical Corp. stock to 80 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: BRAND INSULATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After tax credits of $121,000 for qr and $338,015 for the yr...C-After tax credits of $251,000 for the qr and $1,139,000 for the yr

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GERMAN LESSONS

title: YOUR POSSESSIONS: PROTECTING THEM
description: YOU don't have to be a wealthy collector of art, antiques or jewels to consider a professional appraisal of your possessions. Anyone who has valuables at home, whether inherited Victorian furniture or a wedding ring, might need an appraisal to make sure of adequate insurance protection.

title: Lillian Bellison Alexanderson, A Times Reporter Since 1943
description: Lillian Bellison Alexanderson, a reporter for The New York Times since 1943, died Sunday at Cabrini Medical Center. She was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Advertising; Bringing Broadway To the Zoo
description: the Bronx Zoo.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a net gain of $4.9 million on sale of undeveloped leaseholds

title: Irish Leader Celebrates The Day With Reagan
description: Ireland's new Prime Minister celebrated St. Patrick's Day with President Reagan today and called on Britain to make ''her final withdrawal'' from the island of Ireland.

title: HENRY CASSLER
description: The Rev. Dr. Henry Cassler, a pioneer in the development of clinical training for the clergy, died Monday at his home in Gettysburg, Pa.

title: REAGAN QUOTED AS ASSAILING TV COVERAGE OF THE RECESSION
description: President Reagan was quoted today as accusing television networks of emphasizing such a ''constant downbeat'' on the economic situation that their news coverage could ''contribute psychologically'' to a slowdown in economic recovery.

title: VIOLENCE'
description: Governor Carey, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and 51 members of the Senate and House of Representatives called on Irish-Americans yesterday ''to reject the path of violence'' in Northern Ireland.

title: CANADIAN PAPERS HOAXED ON 'SOCCER TOURNEY'
description: Thousands of Canadians were thrilled in recent days to read in their newspapers about athletic heroics by an Ontario teen-ager who lead his country's junior soccer team to a World Cup championship in a tournament in Sydney, Australia.

title: G. J. Kneeland, Ex-Chairman Of St. Regis Paper, 65, Dies
description: George J. Kneeland, former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the St. Regis Paper Company, died Sunday while vacationing in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Mr. Kneeland, a longtime resident of Harrington Park, N.J., was 65 years old.

title: OPERA: BIZET'S 'LES PECHEURS DE PERLES'
description: THE City Opera's first performance this season of Bizet's ''Les Pecheurs de Perles'' on Sunday afternoon brought three singers new to the production into the principal male roles. Alan Titus appeared in the role of Zurga, Jerry Hadley sang the part of Nadir and Maurice Brown was heard as Nourabad. Also new to the company's production, directed by Cynthia Auerbach and designed by Robert O'Hearn, was the conductor, Scott Bergeson.

title: HERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks it will be written by K.C. Cole, a science writer and the author of the forthcoming book ''Between the Lines'' (Doubleday).

title: Celtics Run Streak to 13
description: Larry Bird, M.L. Carr and Gerald Henderson paced a third-period surge tonight and the Boston Celtics held off a late Atlanta rally for a 113-109 triumph over the Hawks. It was the Celtics' 13th straight victory.

title: BATUS: A MIXED RECORD IN RETAILING
description: Last July, Charles I. McCarty, president and chief executive officer of Batus Inc., was asked at an analysts' meeting if the company planned to add other retail acquisitions to its ownership of Saks Fifth Avenue and Gimbel Brothers.

title: Stadler: Fewer Outbursts, More Success
description: On rainy days, professional golfers loll around the locker room telling stories about the terrible tempers of Tommy Bolt and Tom Weiskopf. Early in his career, Craig Stadler seemed to be on his way to joining Bolt and Weiskopf as the subject of such stories.

title: Miss Jaeger Is Out
description: Andrea Jaeger, suffering from a stress fracture of the left pelvic bone, withdrew from next week's $300,000 Avon championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt HOMETOWN. By Peter Davis. 331 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Knoxville Acts to Punish Evictions by Landlords
description: The Knoxville City Council, before a crowd of 300 people, has approved an ordinance to punish landlords who evict tenants to make room for free-spending tourists attending the World's Fair, which begins May 1.

title: Piniella Upset by His Fines
description: The verbal skirmish between Lou Piniella and George Steinbrenner over Piniella's unauthorized departure before a game Tuesday and his subsequent $1,000 fine intensified today. In casual interviews, the pair disagreed about the circumstances surrounding Piniella's first penalty this spring, when he was fined $7,000 for reporting to camp overweight.

title: Suspension Challenged
description: Larry Fleisher, the general counsel of the National Basketball Players Association, said yesterday that he would meet today with Joe Moniz, the attorney for Sly Williams, to discuss their response to the indefinite suspension that the Knicks imposed on Williams Tuesday night after a series of unexcused absences.

title: Rutgers Getting Williams Memorabilia; Williams Memorabilia
description: Every time a President would sign a bill he had co-sponsored Harrison A. Williams Jr. would get another souvenir pen.

title: SEOUL REGIME IN FEAR OF 180 'CROP-DUSTERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Workers and G.M.  Report Progress in Talks
description: Bargainers for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reported substantial progress today in their talks on contract concessions.

title: RESEARCHERS REPORT NEW DIALYSIS SYSTEM USEFUL FOR DIABETICS
description: A new blood-filtering process for diabetics whose kidneys have failed may be cheaper, faster and more effective than ordinary dialysis, according to a team of Canadian doctors.

title: RITES HELD FOR 7 VICTIMS OF L.I. CRASH
description: Funeral services were held today for seven of the nine young people killed in a collision here early Sunday of an onrushing train and a van that apparently drove around a flashing railroad crossing gate.

title: TEXAS ENERGIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
COST SQUEEZE ON OIL REFINERIES
description: Caught between crude oil prices that just won't come down fast enough and refined product prices that just won't stop coming down, oil refiners across the United States are slowly but inexorably being squeezed out of business.

title: BALLET: CARACAS CHAMBER
description: The Contemporary Chamber Ballet of Caracas, which made its New York debut last Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, is aptly named. Founded in 1974 by Maria Eugenia Barrios, it consists of only five dancers: Miss Barrios, Amanda Rivera, Reva Pincusoff, Steven Cook and Offer Zaks. Yet, like chamber musicians, they perform harmoniously together.

title: DON'T HOBBLE THE DEFENSE OF THE PUBLIC INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: Brokerage Profits Slip
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its member brokerage firms that deal with the public reported an aggregrate net profit of $1.09 billion last year, the second highest ever. The record, $1.16 billion, was set in 1980. For 1981, 324 firms reported profits while 84 had losses.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After $41,000 extraordinary charge for the qr and 9 mos and $74,000 extraordinary gain for the 9 mos

title: U.S. PREPARES REPORT ON CHEMICAL WARFARE DEATHS
description: The Reagan Administration will make public a newly declassified intelligence report on Monday that it says shows Soviet involvement in the deaths of more than 6,000 Laotians, 1,000 Cambodians and 3,000 Afghans through the use of a variety of chemical warfare agents, Administration officials said today.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Temper, Temper
description: Kevin Saucier, a relief pitcher for the Detroit Tigers whose nickname, Hot Sauce, reflects his temper, took to heart a couple of adverse calls by an umpire in an exhibition game. The Los Angeles Dodgers were mounting a four-run rally in the 10th inning at Lakeland, Fla., when an umpire, Dave Pallone, called two balks on successive pitches.

title: SHAKESPEARE: HIT BROADWAY PLAYWRIGHT
description: DO you realize that if Shakespeare were alive and well and living in New York, right this minute he'd be taking home $25,000 a week in royalties?

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes $15,171,000 gain from exchange of debt and purchase of subordinated debentures

title: DANCE: JOANNA BOYCE' 'COMING OF AGE'
description: JOHANNA BOYCE is known for dances that, though gamelike, are by no means trivial, for their underlying earnestness makes one suspect that she regards dancing as a moral, as well as a physical, good. Earlier this season, in a collaboration with Arnie Zane, she raised questions of moral responsibility. And in her new ''Incidents (in Coming of Age),'' presented Sunday afternoon in the Bessie Schonberg Theater, she has tried to tell a moral tale.

title: 3 INCUMBENTS LOSE IN ILLINOIS PRIMARY
description: Three Congressional incumbents were ousted and a fourth clung to his seat by a thin margin after Tuesday's Illinois primary, the first election to follow the 1980 reapportionment.

title: ISLANDERS JUGGLE LINES AND BEAT ROCKIES
description: The Islanders completed their four-game road trip in a positive fashion tonight, scoring a 5-2 victory over the Colorado Rockies. New York won two, tied one and lost one on the trip.

title: MERLAND EXPLORATIONS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
BUDGET CUTBACKS HAMPER LOCALITIES
description: Although the chief effect of Federal budget cuts so far has been on the working poor, some important institutional changes also are beginning to emerge in state and local government. Many state and local jurisdictions are raising taxes to help offset the losses; municipal officials and interest groups are forming new coalitions, and more attention is focusing on state governments.

title: UNIFLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net income including $400,000 gain from business interruption insurance

title: A.T.&T UP 21.9% TO $1.78 BILLION NET
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that its net income in the three months ended Feb. 28 rose 21.9 percent, while revenues increased 15.8 percent.

title: DANCE: THE JOYCE TRISLER COMPANY
description: THE Joyce Trisler Danscompany keeps dancing merrily on. And once again dance is thriving in the Space at City Center. The Space, where the Trisler company opened a week's engagement Tuesday night, is the downstairs performance area in the City Center's 55th Street theater. Over the years, small dance groups have used it on occasion, and last season it was remodeled to become the home of the Dance Umbrella. Although there is no longer a Dance Umbrella, the Space remains and dance performances are scheduled there this spring.

title: Officials Seize Videotapes
description: Movie makers have stepped up their war against pirated home videotapes, according to the industry's chief investigator.

title: Playboy to Sell Two Book Units
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced that it was holding discussions to sell its book publishing and book club operations.

title: Lukens Plea On Dumping
description: The Lukens Steel Company announced today that it had received a favorable ruling from the Department of Commerce regarding its antidumping complaint against the Japan Steel Works.

title: The U.N. Today; March 18, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NETWORKS REPORTED NEAR $2 BILLION FOOTBALL CONTRACT
description: What may be the most expensive and the most important sports deal in the history of television - a new contract between the three major networks and the National Football League - is expected to be concluded this week.

title: 2 Seized in Slaying Of Diamond Cutter
description: Detectives arrested two men yesterday in connection with the murder Tuesday of a Manhattan diamond cutter.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Unless it wants a repetition of the events of 1981, it will have to drastically change its management style.'' - Management study commissioned by the Federal Aviation Administration on the agency's's dealings with air controllers. (A18:1.)

title: Bache Takeover
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., the brokerage firm, said it had agreed to acquire Elkins & Company, a regional broker.

title: BRIEFING
description: St. Patrick's Day Manna

title: POP-FUNK: KOOL & THE GANG
description: Among larger pop-funk ensembles, Kool & the Gang, who appeared at Radio City Music Hall last Friday and Saturday, are surpassed only by Earth, Wind & Fire in rhythm-and-blues versatility. Originally a raucous party band that mixed horn-based jazz with predisco chant, the group found a wider audience with a more streamlined sound under the aegis of Eumir Deodato, producer-synthesist, three years ago.

title: CRYSTAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $873,000 loss from discontinued operations for the qr and $482,000 gain from discontinued operations for the yr... C-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $916,000 for t qr and $2,609,000 for the yr

title: Collision Kills 3 in Arkansas
description: A truck and a bus carrying older people to a St. Patrick's Day party collided near here today, killing three people and injuring six. An official at Mercy Hospital of Scott County said the victims were the drivers of the truck and the bus and one of the bus passengers.

title: N.Y.U. to Raise Its Tuition 14%
description: New York University announced that its undergraduate tuition would rise next fall 14 percent to $6,634 and that dormitory fees would climb 15.7 percent to $975 a semester.

title: FENDI FURS, MISSONI MILAN
description: Carla Fendi fully expects the process to be widely copied, but it took her innovative fashion house two years to develop, and she doesn't believe any other furriers will figure it out more quickly. The secret lies in the tanning of the skins, she explained, not in the dyeing of the fur. The result is a rippling play of colors, which she likens to Impressionist paintings. The effect is achieved without cutting and piecing the skins.

title: MOZART PACT ALLOWS FOR AN ADVISER
description: A new three-year contract has been agreed to by the management of the Mostly Mozart Festival and the orchestra's representatives that would allow a permanent music adviser for the series. The agreement must still be ratified by the full membership of the orchestra. Money was the chief issue in the negotiations, but details of the agreement were not made public immediately.

title: Official Hints Shift On Tax Cut
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, hinted today that he was having second thoughts about the three-year tax cut enacted last year and that he may be moving toward endorsement of a delay in the scheduled mid-1983 tax cut, a delay that President Reagan has opposed.

title: REV. MOON FAILS TO GET NONJURY TRIAL IN TAX CASE
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon lost a battle yesterday to obtain a nonjury trial of his tax-fraud case because Federal prosecutors insisted on a jury.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: FOCUS ON GARDENS
description: New York Botanical Garden Spring Education Program, Southern Boulevard, the Bronx.

title: Drug Agency Fills Post
description: Dr. Harry M. Meyer Jr., developer of a vaccine for German measles, was named Tuesday to head the Food and Drug Administration's Bureau of Drugs. Dr. Meyer has been director of Bureau of Biologics since 1972. Arthur Hull Hayes Jr., Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said that plans were under way to merge the two bureaus.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Express Credit Corp. will offer $100 million of senior notes due in 1992 at par with 14 3/4 percent coupons, to be sold through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: CONVERTING A SUMMER HOME INTO A WINTER NUCLEUS
description: AROUND the turn of the century, when the spread of the railroads as well as widening prosperity placed a summer home by the shore within reach of many families eager to escape the steaming city, no one gave much thought to the problems of heating the rambling structures. After all, they were intended for the summer, and extending their use into winter had not yet become fashionable.

title: SKETCHES OF LEADERS OF SALVADORAN OPPOSITION FACTION
description: Salvador Cayetano Carpio Leader of the Popular Forces of Liberation. A legendary figure who is frequently called El Salvador's Ho Chi Minh, Mr. Carpio was born into a poor San Salvador family and entered politics as a labor organizer. He joined the Communist Party at the age of 28, eventually becoming its secretary general, but resigning in 1970 when it refused to take up arms. A decade later, the party followed his example by backing armed revolution. The 62-year-old Mr. Carpio, who has adopted the nom de guerre of Marcial, is considered the most orthodox Marxist-Leninist in the general command and the least enthusiastic over the prospect of a negotiated settlement. Joaquin Villalobos Leader of the People's Revolutionary Army. Born into a middle-class family in San Salvador, the 30-year-old Mr. Villalobos studied economics for three years at the National University of El Salvador before dropping out to join the guerrillas. He became the leader of his group in 1977. Although the People's Revolutionary Army has demonstrated ideological inconsistency, it is the strongest military force among the guerrillas. Mr. Villalobops is considered a skilled military strategist and a political pragmatist.

title: 'Eminent Domain' Previews
description: ''Eminent Domain,'' a new play by Percy Granger, starring Philip Bosco and Betty Miller, will start previews tomorrow at the Circle in the Square. The play about an eccentric English professor and his wife will be directed by Paul Austin.

title: STAGE: THE COCTEAU PRESENTS LEVIICK'S 'GOLEM'
description: THE Jean Cocteau Repertory is offering, in English, a classic Yiddish drama, H. Leivick's ''The Golem,'' a powerful and poetic inquiry into man and the use of violence, even in a good cause.

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 18, 1982; Companies
description: Braniff announced plans to turn over to Pan Am most of its South American routes for the next four years in return for critically needed cash. The C.A.B. voiced doubts about the accord, however, and Air Florida contested it. Under the plan, Braniff could get at least $30 million from Pan Am by next year. (Page D1.)

title: HMW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After a tax credit of $1,191,000

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HIGH PAYMENTS DETER HOME HUNTERS
description: William and Linda Grant spent a year filing through one new home after another in the Atlanta area. But because all the monthly mortgage payments seemed prohibitive, they declared themselves locked out of the market - a situation increasingly common among would-be homeowners across the nation today.

title: Tax Leasing Is Supported By Executives
description: Industry's ability to modernize and create jobs will be severely hampered if Congress yields to ''political hysteria'' and repeals tax-leasing provisions, corporate executives said today.

title: No Headline
description: Murdoch Appoints Executive At British Publishing Concern

title: IN FAIRFIELD, A FIRST TEST FOR G.O.P. CANDIDATES
description: It is 6:15 A.M. and one Republican gubernatorial candidate, Lewis B. Rome, has already bought 450 copies of the morning newspapers, has pasted Rome campaign stickers on them and is handing them out free to commuters inside the train station here.

title: A New Petition On Portman Hotel
description: A new petition seeking to halt demolition of the Helen Hayes and Morosco Theaters is to be heard today in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: A Final-Four Team Grown in Brooklyn
description: The greeting card was delivered to the gym at about the same time that the Brooklyn College basketball players began their Wednesday afternoon practice. It wished the players well and talked of how their success in reaching tonight's Final Four of the Division III National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs had ''united'' the school.

title: New Forecast On Building
description: Construction activity this year may be slower than anticipated because of the recent rise in interest rates and the deeper-thanexpected recesssion, an industry group said yesterday.

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 19, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan voiced disappointment over lagging support among business executives for his economic recovery plan. He asked a meeting of the N.A.M. to back his budget for next year. (Page A1.) The public disagrees with Mr. Reagan's unyielding budget priorities on taxes and arms spending, the New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. (A1.)

title: 3 CENTRAL BANKS REDUCE INTEREST RATES IN EUROPE
description: West Germany, Switzerland and the Netherlands cut key interest rates today in a coordinated move to stimulate investment and adjust to a decline in inflation. Bankers said the cuts demonstrated that European governments were determined to lower rates, despite the recent rebound in American rates.

title: Sports People; Williams Reinstated
description: Sly Williams, who was suspended indefinitely by the Knicks on Tuesday night for a series of unexcused absences, was fined but reinstated yesterday after his agent, Joe Moniz, and the head of the National Basketball Players Association, Larry Fleisher, had met with Eddie Donovan, the team's general manager. ''We made the point,'' said Donovan, ''that Sly must understand his responsibility to the team and adhere to club policies.'' Williams was fined a full game's salary, about $1,500.

title: PRESIDENT TERMS VIEWS OF BUSINESS A DISAPPOINTMENT
description: President Reagan expressed disappointment today over flagging support among businessmen for his economic program and called on the business community to support his budget for the 1983 fiscal year.

title: Auctions; From bottles to Buddha.
description: ORIENTAL wares ranging from Chinese snuff bottles to a Siamese Buddha will be featured next week in sales at Sotheby Parke Bernet's York Avenue galleries, at 72d Street, and at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street. Of the three auctions at Sotheby's, two involve important private collections of highly specialized material. One of them, the second part of the Bob C. Stevens collection of Chinese snuff @bottles, will be sold next Friday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. Dealers and collectors doubt that prices will continue at the high level registered in the sale of the first segment of the collection last Nov. 7 because that sale brought a flood of snuff bottles into the market, causing a softening of prices elsewhere.

title: 3 Lead T.P.C. by Shot Over New Course
description: The Tournament Players Championship, painstakingly promoted as the showpiece of the Tournament Players Association Tour, started today on its fifth venue in nine years. The tournament has at last found a place to call home, The Players Club, a course designed by Pete Dye for tournament play and owned by the players through their organization, the TPA Tour.

title: ALTAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 ARE GUILTY IN SLAYING OF OFF DUTY POLICEMAN IN '81
description: Three young men were convicted yesterday of killing a 36-year-old off-duty police officer who tried to stop a robbery at a Queens bar 14 months ago.

title: KRIZIA AND FERRE: WIT AND VISION
description: There's an easy way to tell who's in and who's not during the week of Italian fashion showings here. Almost everyone, vendors and buyers alike, lunches in the same place, the St. Andrews' Restaurant, at the fairgrounds where most of the shows take place. The designer judged to have the best collection of the day is piped to his table by a solid round of applause from the onlookers. It's a tradition. Mariuccia Mandelli and her husband, Aldo Pinto, were the first this week to hear the welcome sound. Their collection, called Krizia, had the lighthearted approach, the unexpected touches and the charm associated with the best Milan fashions and sadly absent until today.

title: ATLANTIC OIL CORP (DENVER, COLO) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Survives Crash, Dies in Fall
description: A 30-year-old Nassau County resident lost control of his car and slammed into a railing on the Throgs Neck Bridge yesterday morning, left his auto in a daze, staggered over to the bridge's guard rail and then toppled 50 feet into the icy waters of the East River, the police said. The man, Anthony Altieri, was rescued from the water within 15 minutes by the Coast Guard, but he died at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center.

title: 4 DUTCH NEWSMEN SLAIN ON A TRIP TO FILM GUERRILLAS IN EL SALVADOR
description: Four members of a Dutch television crew were killed Wednesday in a rural part of El Salvador where they had gone to film a guerrilla group.

title: NO SOVIET CASTOFFS IN MANAGUA'S ARSENAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Avnet to Distribute Two I.B.M. Lines
description: Avnet Inc., an electronic and engineering products concern, said that its Hamilton/Avnet Electronics division had signed a distribution agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to distribute two I.B.M. lines to industrial customers. Under the agreement, the Avnet unit will begin distribution on April 1 of the I.B.M. ASCII terminal and nonimpact printer line.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $219,327 for the qr and $403,253 for the yr...C-Includes $234,265 tax credit

title: Sanyo Delays Disk
description: The Sanyo Electric Company said today that it had delayed the introduction of videodisks in Japan, scheduled for next month, citing dull demand.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $965,000 for the qr and $2 million for the 6 mos...C-Includes $1.4 milli gain from discontinued operations

title: McCarthy Plans Bid To Regain Senate Seat
description: Eugene J. McCarthy, three times an unsuccessful Presidential candidate, set out today to reclaim the United States Senate seat he gave up 12 years ago.

title: JOHN CONNALLY'S BIG INTEREST, FOR NOW IS LAW
description: John B. Connally's first name is no longer ''Big,'' at least in this town. The hulking Texan who used to blow into Washington with gale force, bending tall political timber like saplings, now comes and goes like Sandburg's fog, on little cat feet. When his name does come up, it is usually in the form of a question: Whatever happened to John Connally?

title: ELECTRONIC MAIL'S SLOW START
description: After the United States Postal Service began its electronic mail service on Jan. 4, one happy customer wrote that ''neither system downtime, line noise nor software bugs'' had stayed the new service from its appointed rounds.

title: BRADLEY, GEORGIA AND OKLAHOMA TRIUMPH
description: Bradley combined the shooting of Donald Reese and Willie Scott with an effective full-court press for a 77-61 victory over Tulane last night in a quarterfinal game of the National Invitation Tournament at Peoria, Ill.

title: SAYS THE U.S. IS JUST 'A POSTMAN'
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that dangerous rifts in the Arab world and the continued Israeli occupation of the West Bank were bringing the Middle East to the brink of a new war.

title: SPRINGTIME RITUAL
description: In a rite of spring that has become as institutionalized and as fruitless as much else in the capital city, the two pandas at the National Zoo resumed the mating game today.

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 7
description: B-Net income and after gain of $203,000 from discontinued operations...C-Net income and after loss of $308,000 from discontinued operations; the 1981 sales and earnings were restated for accounting chaages and reclassifications

title: Portuguese on Greek Visit
description: The Portuguese Prime Minister, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, arrived today for a two-day official visit and talks with Greek leaders on Portugal's bid to join the European Economic Community. Greece became the tenth member of the Common Market in January 1981.

title: McLouth Creditors Extend Deadline
description: Major creditors of the ailing McLouth Steel Corporation, the nation's 11th-largest steelmaker, have agreed to allow the company to continue full operations through May 15 and partial operations through June 18 while the company searches for a buyer. The previous deadline set by creditors was today.

title: Braniff Executive Sees Benefit in Pan Am Tie
description: Robert Culp, the vice president for pricing and regulatory authority at Braniff International, says that it was a great relief for him when his airline and Pan American World Airways filed a proposal on Wednesday whereby Braniff would turn over most of its South American routes to Pan Am for the next four years.

title: Wayne State Fencers Capture N.C.A.A. Title
description: Neil Hick won the saber competition tonight and led Wayne State to its third National Collegiate Athletic Association fencing title in four years.

title: Petraglia Takes Lead In Long Island Bowling
description: Johnny Petraglia took the fourth-round lead, and Earl Anthony moved into second place tonight in the $100,000 Long Island Open professional bowling tournament.

title: IN NEWPORT, A DELICATE BALANCE ON VON BULOW
description: With Claus von Bulow gone back to New York City, his long trial over, there are parking spaces in downtown Newport for the first time in weeks. But the streets and mansions today are veiled in blowing sleet and snow, and the sad affair of Martha and Claus von Bulow has reached a gray and delicate pause between judgment and effect - and between criminal action and the civil suits that are sure to come.

title: FILM: 'DEATHTRAP' WITH MICHAEL CAINE
description: THERE hasn't been a stylish, sneaky, cat-and-mouse movie like ''Deathtrap'' since ''Sleuth.'' Actually, in the case of ''Deathtrap,'' it's cat-and-mice. Michael Caine, Christopher Reeve and Dyan Cannon play Ira Levin's trio of blithe schemers, with two of them in cahoots to bump off the third. This is only half the story, but it's all that can be described here without giving too many twists away.

title: The Dirt on T.K. Jones
description: Who is the Thomas K. Jones who is saying those funny things about civil defense? Is he only a character in ''Doonesbury''? Did he once write lyrics for Tom Lehrer's darker political ballads? Or is T.K., as he is known to friends, the peace movement's mole inside the Reagan Administration?

title: TOUGH SUBMARINER FOR NAVY'S HELM
description: When James D. Watkins was growing up in Alhambra, Calif., his mother would take him and his brother to nearby Navy ports to watch the ships come in like cows at milking time. Sometimes, she would arrange to take them aboard to dine with the officers and to talk about life on the high seas. Her influence guided both sons to the United States Naval Academy and to Navy careers.

title: TRAINS DELAYLED BY A JOB ACTION ON HUDSON LINE
description: Train service for 30,000 daily passengers on Conrail's Hudson line between New York City and Poughkeepsie was disrupted throughout the day yesterday as engineers protested new work schedule changes.

title: German Prices Up 0.2%
description: The federal statistics office said today that final figures showed that Germany's cost of living index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in the month to mid-February.

title: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After $269,000 extraordinary charge

title: News Analysis
description: With the approach of elections in El Salvador that could be critical to the debate over increased American aid to that country, a gap appears to be widening between the Reagan Administration's analysis of the Salvadoran situation and the views of many moderate Salvadorans whom Washington's policy is ostensibly designed to support.

title: MAYOR IS OUSTED IN THE WEST BANK
description: The Israeli Defense Ministry dissolved the town council of El Bireh in the West Bank today, installing an army colonel in the office of the elected Palestinian mayor.

title: Fight Set for Buffalo
description: For the first time since 1950, when the heavyweight Ezzard Charles knocked out Freddy Beshore, Buffalo will be the site of a world title fight.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP BY 0.5%
description: Americans' personal income rose fivetenths of 1 percent last month, the biggest gain since late last fall, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Inter-American Development Bank reduced to $100 million from $150 million its 7-year note offering, priced to yield 15 percent, to be sold through a Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb group.

title: Oil Imports Down 28.2%
description: Oil imports declined sharply in February, continuing a trend that began in 1979, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. In its monthly report, the institute said that 4.85 million barrels were imported daily last month, compared with 6.75 million barrels a day in February 1981, a decline of 28.2 percent.

title: METHOD USED IN CONDUCTING POLL
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from March 11 through March 15 with 1,545 adults around the United States.

title: Sun-Century Link
description: Sun Banks of Florida Inc., an Orlando-based bank holding company, said it had reached a settlement with Marvin Warner, a major shareholder of Century Banks Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that will permit Sun and Century to proceed with their previously announced merger. Sun Banks said that under the agreement, Mr. Warner, who owns 1,510,677 Century Banks shares, or about 22 percent of the total, would receive $2 million in cash from Sun Banks and $3 million in cash from Century Banks. In addition, when Sun Banks makes its formal offer for Century's stock, Mr. Warner will sell his shares for $16 a share in cash for a total of $24.2 million.

title: WHERE TO CELEBRATE THE FIRST DAY OF SPRING
description: Spring arrives tomorrow at 5:56 P.M., a time when the sun's rays fall vertically on the equator, and day and night are of equal length. Already the plant world is coming alive again. Snowdrops, crocuses and witch hazels are in bloom, maple trees and magnolias are close to popping their buds and tulip and daffodil leaves are standing tall.

title: REAGAN EVOKING RISING CONCERN, NEW POLL SHOWS
description: The American public generally disagrees with President Reagan's unyielding budget positions on taxes and arms spending and is registering sharply increased concern about his foreign policy record, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: FEDERATED UP 6.9% CARTER OFF 24.8%
description: Two of the nation's leading retailers yesterday reported higher earnings for the fourth quarter, while a third was down sharply during a period marked by recession, large sales promotions, and high interest rates.

title: Environmental Chief Named
description: Joseph T. McGough Jr., who for the last three months has been the Acting Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, was named to the post on a permanent basis by Mayor Koch.

title: AMIN'S RISE AND FALL
description: ''AMIN - THE RISE AND FALL,'' produced and directed by Sharad Patel, a Uganda-born film maker, is a suitably bloody exploitation film about the short, vicious reign of Gen. Idi Amin, dictator of Uganda from 1971, when he came to power in a military coup, until his overthrow by the Tanzanian army in 1979.

title: Bonn Security Aide Is Seized After Disclosures on Secrets
description: The federal police arrested a security official today who reportedly leaked secrets involving President Nixon and Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger to a leftist news magazine.

title: Growing Pains
description: ''THE Beast Within,'' the very foolish horror film that opens today at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters, is set in a small town in Mississippi and is about a young man who has problems. He is growing too big and too tall too fast, apparently because he is possessed, emotionally and physically, by something evil. Just what is never made clear, though the movie contains more exposition than the complete works of Ibsen.

title: Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has received a $200 million order for a 60-unit wind-turbine generator park from the Southern California Edison Company. The order will be financed by First National Capital of Detroit, which plans to buy the equipment from Westinghouse and has entered into a joint-venture pact with Manley, Bennett, McDonald & Company, investment bankers.

title: Singer Suffers Spinal Injury In Auto Crash in Philadelphia
description: Teddy Pendergrass, the rock singer, was hospitalized here today for spine injuries after he crashed his Rolls-Royce into a tree on a winding highway in the Germantown section.

title: 'Richard II' Delays Opening
description: The Circle Repertory Company's production of ''Richard II'' by William Shakespeare that was to have opened last night at the Entermedia Theater, at 189 Second Avenue, has been postponed. The play, directed by Marshall W. Mason and featuring William Hurt in the title role, will continue in previews. A new opening date will be announced soon.

title: A WASHINGTON WEEKEND SAMPLER
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson goes bowling. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige ropes steers. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger gardens. Attorney General William French Smith goes to lunch in the country.

title: No Headline
description: Foreign Editor Is Appointed By United Press International

title: The U.N. Today; March 19, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on elections to the International Court of Justice. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: WINDSOR LIFE INSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
HOUSING DISCRIMINATION: STUDY OF CITY IS UPDATED
description: Six years ago, an investigation of Manhattan apartment-renting patterns conducted jointly by The New York Times and the Open Housing Center of New York concluded that racial discrimination was ''widespread'' and that it ''works to deny many choice apartments to blacks and other minority group members despite their ability to afford them.''

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including $633,000 tax credit for the yr

title: Airlines' Loss: $3 Billion
description: The member airlines of the International Air Transport Association will lose an aggregate $3 billion this year, Armin Baltensweiler, the group's president, said today.

title: STUDIES OF WELFARE CUTS ASSESS HARM TO ELDERLY
description: President Reagan's proposals for cutting Medicare and Medicaid benefits would substantially increase the health care costs of the elderly, and his proposed cuts in food stamp benefits would remove from the rolls more than 40 percent of the elderly in New York State who use food stamps, according to two studies made public today.

title: OF BIRDS AND HUMANS: CONFLICTING MESSAGES
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Approves Head Of Rights Commission
description: The Senate confirmed the nomination of Clarence M. Pendleton Jr. today as chairman of the Federal Civil Rights Commission.

title: 'VICTOR VICTORIA,' A BLAKE EDWARDS FARCE
description: GET ready, get set and go - immediately - to the Ziegfeld Theater, where Blake Edwards today opens his chef d'oeuvre, his cockeyed, crowning achievement, his ''Duck Soup,'' his ''Charley's Aunt,'' his ''Hotel Paradisio,'' his ''Some Like It Hot,'' his urban ''As You Like It'' and maybe even his ''Citizen Kane,'' which his film resembles in no way whatsoever.

title: TOROMONT INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $185,000 special gain

title: Bahamas Strike Cripples Most Airline Service
description: About 4,000 civil servants and communications and airline employees walked off their jobs today in a one-day strike that crippled airline service to most of the Bahamas and left thousands of people without telephone service.

title: Dow Rebounds 9.42, to 805.27
description: Led by a rebound in recently depressed technology issues, the stock market yesterday staged its strongest rally in three weeks as the volume of trading accelerated.

title: WALTER, JIM, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
RIGHTS FOUND NOT VIOLATED
description: A conviction obtained in the Abscam investigation was affirmed yesterday by a Federal appeals court in a decision that said lawenforcement agents could use ''special investigative techniques to uncover insidious corruption.''

title: A BELLAMY MAYORALTY AS COLLEAGUES VIEW IT
description: Since they took office in 1978, Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy have clashed over some important issues - foster care, tax abatements for real-estate developers, police and sanitation hirings, the Charlotte Street housing project in the Bronx and the Westway highway project.

title: Irvin and Reese at Bat
description: Two former baseball stars - Monte Irvin and Pee Wee Reese - will be on hand this weekend at a baseball card show at the Armenian Church, 630 Second Avenue, near 34th Street. About 100 dealers from the United States and Canada will display thousands of cards, pins, yearbooks, autographs and other sports memorabilia, for sale or trade.

title: Broadway; 3 women sing '30's blues in a musical opening in May.
description: ''BLUES IN THE NIGHT,'' three women singing their hearts out in a sleazy hotel in Chicago in the 1930's, is scheduled to open at the Rialto Theater on May 25. The musical - no spoken words; all the dialogue is in song lyrics - will be produced by Mitchell Maxwell, Alan J. Shuster and Fred H. Krones, who also produced the successful Off Broadway play ''Key Exchange.'' They have not yet signed any of the three women, although they are negotiating now, Mr. Maxwell says, with Linda Hopkins and Debbie Shapiro to play two of them. Mr. Maxwell also said that the Brandt Organization, which owns the 499-seat Rialto, had offered ''Blues in the Night'' such a nice deal that the show could make money with a $20 top ticket price.

title: St. Louis on Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association placed St. Louis University on one year's probation today for violations in its basketball program, saying the association had been provided ''false and misleading information'' by the St. Louis coach, Ron Ekker, and others during an investigation.

title: LAW FIRM THAT WON BATTLE TO PUBLISH 'ULYSSES' IS CLOSING ITS DOORS
description: The law firm of Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst, which helped to pave the way for publication of James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' in this country and was a respected name in literary and civil-libertarian circles for more than 60 years, will cease operations on June 30.

title: 5 Western Nations Confer on Namibia
description: Assistant Secretary of State Chester A. Crocker and high-ranking officials from Britain, Canada, France and West Germany opened discussions today on how to speed up negotiations on a self-rule formula for South-West Africa, the South Africancontrolled territory that is also known as Namibia.

title: KEY TALKS START TODAY AT OPEC
description: Oil ministers of the 13 OPEC nations gathered here today for a crucial policy meeting amid uncertainty that the group could find a way to prevent the worldwide abundance of oil from forcing a general reduction in prices.

title: CENTURY BANKS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After $2.8 million charge for litigation and expenses

title: DANCE: JOYCE TRISLER GROUP'S MAINSTAYS REPLACE A PREMIERE
description: REPERTORY is the lifeblood of a performing-arts company, and the Joyce Trisler Danscompany is no exception. When injuries to leading dancers in a scheduled premiere caused the program to be changed Wednesday night, the troupe dug into its repertory and repeated some of its mainstays.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 6
Old Dominion Ousted
description: Priscilla Gary scored 18 points and Kansas State hit 15 of 18 free throws in the final six minutes to upset third-ranked Old Dominion tonight, 76-67, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Women's East Regional semifinals.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let me be honest with you, however, and tell you I've been a little disappointed lately with some in the business community who have forgotten that feeding more dollars to government is like feeding a stray pup: It just follows you home and sits on your doorstep, asking for more.'' - President Reagan. (A1:6.)

title: ENDORSEMENT ALTERS NEW ORLEANS RACE
description: The close runoff race for Mayor in this Deep South port city appeared to tilt in favor of the incumbent for a moment this week. But a surprise move that favored his challenger quickly changed the situation again.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BRIEFING
description: Rights Contender Opposed

title: REAGAN APPOINTS 2 CHIEFS OF STAFF
description: President Reagan put his imprint on a majority of the Joint Chiefs of Staff today by naming new chiefs for the Air Force and Navy.

title: THE HIGH PRICE A BORROWER MUST PAY FOR LENDERS' UNCERTAINTY
description: To the Editor:

title: In 1793, a young soldier deserted the Fort Hamilton compound, which was not yet a town but only a defensive perimeter against the Indians, to return to his sweetheart in New York. Caught a few miles downriver, he was brought back to the garrison where he was, an early chronicler noted, ''swung off without a murmur.'' In 1978, a respected citizen of Hamilton was accused of a crime few people had previously thought of as a crime and which no one wanted to talk about until the alleged incident became a public scandal - the occasion for the town to examine itself as it never had. The resemblance between the calamities is less than identical, more than coincidental. In each case the collective impulse was to get rid of someone whose presumed deed threatened what was perceived as the integrity and structure of the community.
description: I went to Hamilton not so much looking for as assuming change. The prevalence of change is a given in America. Yet what I found was an astonishing, striking, virtually genetic resemblance between Hamilton's past and its present. The desire to sell, build, expand, advertise, migrate, win, get more for the children - all of this has been in Hamilton for over one hundred fifty years. Dazzled by the vividness and clutter of technology, Hamiltonians themselves remark on how much has changed in the town. Buildings are replaced, everything runs by computer, people are ciphers. Sidewalks are no longer safe, everyone gets mad at his neighbor too easily, public officials are dishonest, kids leave town if they get an education. Yet each of these complaints echoes one in the nineteenth century. The bootlegging city marshal of the 1870's is mirrored in the sheriff who in the 1970's was convicted of embezzlement, conflict of interest, and income tax evasion. The rapid pace of change disturbed those Hamiltonians of the 1890's who longed for ''the gentler days gone by'' when families stayed together, indeed for their own youth.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After $4,264,000 foreign exchange loss...C-Includes $11,665,000 foreign exchange gain; the amounts shown as U.S. Dollars are translated from yen at the rate of 239 yen equals one U.S. dollar; the first qr of 1981 has been restated using F.A.S. No 52; shr earnings are American Depositary Share

title: IRAQ MAKES OVERTURE TO END WAR WITH IRAN
description: Iraq has made a new overture to end the 18-month-old war with Iran. With his troops apparently unable to make further military gains, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has sent a special envoy to Guinea with written proposals for President Ahmed Sekou Toure, head of a nine-member Islamic mediation mission.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Includes gains of $2,072,000 for the qr and $9,286,000 for the yr and loss equal to 8 cents a shr for the qr from the adoption of the LIFO method of accounting...C-Includes gains of $2,402,000 for the qr and $7,623,000 for the yr

title: Seeing the World in Red and Yellow
description: The issue of yellow rain continues to bubble away, casting a miasma of doubt over Soviet adherence to treaties on chemical and biological warfare, and eroding American appetite for arms control treaties of any kind. But the Administration, which defined the issue, has produced an astonishingly confusing and incomplete set of evidence.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: B-After $1,060,376 charge from inventory revaluation and writeoff of receivables...C-Includes $109,000 gain from settlement of litigation

title: Advertising; Selling Ads To Appeal To Bankers
description: PEEK through the big glass window on the ground floor of One State Street Plaza, which is about as far south as one can walk in Manhattan with dry feet. There, seated at his desk in the corner, is Ed@mund C. Burke, looking for all the world like a bank executive. Close, but no cigar.

title: FAMILY RIVALRY FLARES IN INDIA POLITICS
description: In a development reflecting the familycentered politics of India, a young state legislator was suspended from membership in Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's party Wednesday after he announced plans for a rally that would raise the standard of Maneka Gandhi, the Prime Minister's widowed daughter-in-law.

title: Bethesda Research Refinancing Set
description: The Bethesda Research Laboratories, a seven-year-old biotechnology company considered to be among the new industry's leading concerns, said yesterday that it had arranged a $5.5 million refinancing package to provide working capital.

title: BATUS RAISES OFFER FOR MARSHALL FIELD
description: Concerned that its price for Marshall Field stock was too low, Batus Inc., the American subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries of London, yesterday raised the price of its cash tender offer in an attempt to assure its acquisition of the big Chicago-based retailer.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $752,638 extraordinary gain

title: U.S. INDICATING SUPPORT FOR SALVADORAN CENTRISTS
description: With elections in El Salvador a little more than a week away, the Reagan Administration, concerned that extreme right-wing forces could gain control there, is expressing its support for the Salvadoran political center.

title: Nicaragua to Impose Tax
description: Defense Minister Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that the Government would impose a ''patriotic tax'' on businesses to finance stepped-up defense against an invasion that he said was being planned with the support of the United States Central Intelligence Agency. He said a decree would be issued within a few days.

title: Horrors of Addiction
description: THE fact that ''Christiane F.'' has been one of the biggest moneymakers in West German movie history says much more about West German audiences than it does about the film.

title: Himmler Letters Sold By an Ex-Nazi Officer
description: A collection of about 700 letters believed to have been written by Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Nazi Gestapo and the SS, or elite guard, during World War II, has been bought from a onetime Nazi officer now living in Mexico, according to a former consul for cultural affairs at the Israel Consulate here.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''W HAT a treat to see so many white shirts!'' Lachlan Murray, in town from Paris, said contentedly, looking around at the spiffy crowd. ''Nowadays in France entertaining is done mostly at home on a very low-key scale,'' said Mr. Murray, who is in public relations. ''Social life in Paris is under siege, and they're cutting down on this sort of thing.''

title: BRASS-CRAFT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHUTTLE GEAR LOADED FOR RAIL TRIP TO NEW MEXICO
description: Crews shut down landing operations for the space shuttle in the waterlogged desert here today and prepared the first of two trains to haul equipment to service the craft when it lands in New Mexico.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS SEEK TO SHIFT BUDGET ACTION TO THE HOUSE
description: In a policy reversal, Republican leaders in Congress sought today to shift the budget initiative from the Senate to the House in an attempt to put greater pressure on the White House and the Democrats to work out a budget compromise.

title: MISSISSIPPI SCHOOLS LOSE U.S. AID IN DISPUTE OVER BIAS IN BASKETBALL
description: A Mississippi school district has been told that it will be denied $186,000 a year in Federal aid because of a dispute that began over the amount of playing time given to white and black students on the high school basketball team, the school district lawyer said today.

title: PUBLISHING: KORDA TRIES A NEW TACK, THE NOVEL
description: AFTER two self-help books, a book about male chauvinism and a ''family romance'' titled ''Charmed Lives,'' Michael Korda has now written a novel. ''Worldly Goods,'' scheduled for publication by Random House in June, spans 30 years in the life of a family from Central Europe and revolves around the struggle between two conglomerates to acquire a small New York publishing house.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $18,211,000 extraordinary charge...C-Includes $900,000 tax credit

title: THE EPITAPH IS WRITTEN ON BURMESE DICTIONARY
description: One of the oddest chapters in the history of dictionary-making is ending here this spring, when half a million slips of paper, each bearing a quotation from Burmese speech or literature, are to be shipped home in oak filing cabinets to Rangoon.

title: WOMAN MAY HEAD FED BANK
description: The Federal Reserve System, for the first time in its 69-year history, has selected a woman to be president of one of its 12 regional banks, banking and other sources reported today.

title: E.E.C. Food Export Policy
description: The European Commission has asked Common Market countries to agree to a more aggressive food export policy in a move that could arouse renewed trade tensions with Washington, diplomatic sources said today.

title: STAGE: ANGUISH OF INTERNMENT AMONG JAPANESE-AMERICANS
description: WHILE other institutional theaters try to program so-called balanced seasons, Tisa Chang's Pan Asian Repertory Theater is challenging itself and theatergoers with a cycle of three plays by different authors on a single subject - the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II. That event, the confinement of 120,000 people for reasons of supposed national security, has wide-ranging moral as well as emotional implications.

title: Notes on People; Simons Drop Option on Trilling Book; Welcome Relief
description: It was with almost unadorned relief that Diana Trilling, the essayist, critic and translator, learned that Jennifer Jones and her industrialist husband, Norton Simon, had decided not to exercise their option to buy, for $1 million, movie rights to Mrs. Trilling's recent book, ''Mrs. Harris.''

title: Notes on People; Bakke to Be an Interne at the Mayo Clinic
description: Back in June 1978, the Supreme Court, in a landmark decision, ruled that Allan P. Bakke had to be admitted to a California medical school because it had discriminated against him in favor of minority students just because he was white.

title: CAMBODIAN REBELS EXAMINED FOR CHEMICAL WARFARE EFFECTS
description: An American doctor, accompanied by an official of the United States Embassy here, took blood samples today from Pol Pot guerrillas for possible evidence of exposure to chemical weapons, according to an American diplomat. Such studies, he said, have been on the increase in recent days.

title: SPORTS CHAMPS SINCE 1830'S ARE
description: CELEBRATED By IRA BERKOW

title: Holly Sugar's Shares Plunge
description: Holly Sugar Corporation stock plunged $11.25 a share in consolidated trading yesterday to $47.75. Wall Street professionals attributed the drop to the vagueness of a Wednesday announcement by Michael S. Buchsbaum, chairman of the company, that he was ''giving consideration'' to forming a group to buy Holly for ''approximately'' $65 a share.

title: At the Movies; Michael Caine and roles he wishes he got
description: MICHAEL CAINE, opening today in ''Deathtrap,'' is an easy talker, funny and refreshingly unwary of the press - although he doesn't much like lunch interviews. ''I had this lunch interview yesterday,'' he says, ''and the man told me, 'I hate Broadway plays.' And then he said, 'The only thing I hate more than Broadway plays is movies made from Broadway plays.' ''

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
REAGAN'S HEALTH PLAN
description: The proposals for health insurance that President Reagan is expected to send to Congress next month to control the spiraling costs of health care contain a provision that, though seemingly innocuous, threatens to severely weaken health insurance and thereby deprive many people of needed medical care.

title: From the Rubble of Promises
description: Remember Charlotte Street? That's the pile of rubble in the South Bronx upon which first Jimmy Carter and then Ronald Reagan proclaimed their humanity. Mr. Carter, in 1977, said he was ''impressed by the spirit of hope and determination by the people to save what they have.'' Mr. Reagan, in 1980, said he was ''impressed with the spirit of hope and determination by the people to save what they have.'' No, they did not have the same speechwriters; but they do have the same credibility problem now.

title: 'Dresser' to Close May 1
description: ''The Dresser,'' a play by Ronald Harwood about a Shakespearean actor and his dresser, will close May 1 at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

title: No Headline
description: Canucks Top Canadiens

title: Notes on People; Jody Powell Joining ABC as Commentator; Jody Powell to ABC
description: Jody Powell, who used to joust almost daily with reporters as press secretary to President Jimmy Carter, has taken yet another job with the press.

title: OPERA: 'VESPRI SICILIANI' RETURNS TO METROPOLITAN
description: ''I VESPRI SICILIANI,'' which had been absent from the Metropolitan Opera's repertory for eight seasons, returned Wednesday night in the remorselessly severe production designed by Josef Svoboda and staged by John Dexter. This has to be one of the best contemporary examples of sound dramatic ideas carried to selfdefeating extremes. Time has not softened the production's harsh edges or made its defiance of the libretto's explicit instructions seem justifiable.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on the primary elections in Illinois incorrectly identified the party of Representative Melvin Price, who was renominated. He is a Democrat.

title: TRAFALGAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
OF BIRDS AND HUMANS: CONFLICTING MESSAGES
description: To the Editor:

title: Feld Family Buys Ringling Bros.
description: Mattel Inc. said that it had sold Ringling Brothers-Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows Inc. for $22.8 million to a family that had owned the circus and has been in its management for 26 years.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Net income; shr earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1981

title: James M. Jacobson, 66, Dies; Former Pocket Books Official
description: James M. Jacobson, retired executive vice president of Pocket Books Inc., died Wednesday at his winter home in Key West, Fla. He was 66 years old and a resident of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: BELDING HEMINWAY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FINK CRITICIZES P.S.C. ON 9-MILE POINT
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink said today that the Public Service Commission had adopted questionable assumptions in order to justify the completion of the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant under construction outside Oswego.

title: REAGAN OFFERS AN 'UPBEAT' EVALUATION OF THE PRESS
description: President Reagan said today that ''the overwhelming majority'' of reporters do a fine job, and he hoped he ''didn't touch a nerve'' with his criticism of the news media.

title: Restaurants; An Italian balance, steaks in midtown.
description: AA fine balance of northern and southern Italian specialties appears on the enticing menu at Lello, the polished and sophisticated restaurant opened two years ago on 54th Street between Madison and Park Avenues. Angelo De Cicco, the Abruzzese chef who was formerly at Salta in Bocca on lower Madison Avenue, has been in charge of Lello's kitchen for the last year. Based on five recent visits, we found he has not lost his touch. There is some unusually good and elegant food here, compromised only by a few overly complicated creations that the chef and management apparently consider fashionable such as chicken with oranges and melon balls in a champagne cream sauce.

title: U.S. Investigates Group Over Nicaragua Raids
description: The Justice Department said today that it was investigating the activities of a Miami-based group called the National Liberation Army that says it has blown up six bridges in Nicaragua.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; ROMANTIC VAMPIRE NIGHT
description: Have you ever seen an ugly vampire? The Wagner Society of New York asks that question rhetorically, of course. Vampires, it notes, are doomed, cursed, lethal, scary - and sexy. Tonight at 8, at the Williams Club, 24 East 39th Street, the society will present a discussion of ''The Romantic Vampire, a Literary Motif and an Operatic Source.'' The speakers will be Richard Higginbotham, who has made a study of the vampire figure in 19th-century European literature, and Nancy Rhodes, artistic director of Encompass, the Music Theater, which produced Heinrich Marschner's opera ''Der Vampyr'' in 1980. Examples from that work will be included in the talk. A donation is suggested. Information: 666-3436. WALTON AND SANDWICHES

title: PHILHARMONIC: RAFAEL KUBELIK
description: CONDUCTORS who compose and composers who conduct seldom encounter great trouble in finding orchestras to perform their works. That lack of resistance smoothed the way, for instance, for the music of Berlioz, Mahler, Wagner, Liszt and Strauss, and has helped lesser mortals such as Wilhelm Furtwangler, Felix Weingartner and Jean Martinon, to name just a few in each category. One can only guess whether Rafael Kubelik would consider himself a conductor/composer or a composer/conductor, but in any event he is following a great tradition in seeing to it that his music gains currency.

title: AVANT-GARDE: ELECTRONICS OF RICHARD KOSTELANETZ
description: ''MY material is language,'' Richard Kostelanetz informed those who heard several of his most recent pieces for electronic tape at Roulette's SoHo loft Sunday night. The self-styled poet's tape constructions dealt, in general, with language as sound divested of some or all of its ''literal'' meaning, but made the richer, at certain points, in latent meaning.

title: Boston College's Star Is an Unlikely One
description: John Bagley, Boston College's brilliant high-scoring guard, is a player of unusual dimensions. A program lists him as 6 feet tall, but Bagley is really closer to 5-10, far shorter than most of his teammates. And with an unusually thick pair of thighs and a chunky body, he appears entirely out of place on the court, cumbersome and unwieldy.
