title: NICARAGUA READY TO TALK WITH U.S.
description: The Nicaraguan Government said today that it was ready to hold negotiations with the United States on all issues, including assertions of Sandinist arms shipments to Salvadoran rebels.

title: More Auto Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company announced plans for further plant closings next week. G.M. said it would double car plant closings to six, increasing temporary layoffs to 18,700.

title: METS SAY A TRADE IS UNLIKELY
description: Frank Cashen, the general manager of the Mets, said today that a lull had settled over trade talks and that it now seemed unlikely that the Mets would make a deal of any significance.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE LANDING SITE IS SHIFTED BECAUSE OF RAINS
description: The primary landing site for the third mission of the space shuttle Columbia was shifted today from California's Mojave Desert, which is rain-soaked, to the White Sands Missile Range in southern New Mexico, the space agency announced.

title: By Sports of The Times; Splash! Splash! Splash!
description: WHEN he was creating the Players Club golf course out of a swampy wilderness, Pete Dye had to watch for the rattlesnakes, wild boar and alligators as he followed the deer paths through the woods.

title: PROPERTY INVESTORS OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $73,000 extraordinary credit...C-Includes $1,240,000 extraordinary credit

title: A WEAKNESS CRUCIAL TO THE MARXIST STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: CHADWICK-MILLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1981 results restated to reflect the adoption of the LIFO method of accounting which reduced net income by 7 cents a shr

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Addison Bank, Dallas, has named Ben A. Cunningham president. * Bank of America has made Thomas P. Guerin Jr. a vice president.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Arnold Palmer, at age 52, is stepping up his competitive schedule and says he will play in 20 tournaments this year. ''My family talked me into it,'' said Palmer.

title: Bridge: New York Area Pairs Lead In Finals of Grand National
description: Top-ranked partnerships from the New York metropolitan area led the field into the two final sessions of the Grand National Pair Championship here this afternoon. They were contending with the other survivors of eight months of play at local and zonal levels.

title: Pillsbury Net Increases 24%
description: The Pillsbury Company yesterday reported a 24 percent rise in profits for its third fiscal quarter. Net income in the period, ended Feb. 28, was $26.9 million, or $1.24 a share, up from $21.7 million, or $1.08 a share on fewer shares, a year before.

title: Fund Assets Gain in Week
description: Assets of the nation's 178 money market mutual funds, including four newly formed general purpose funds, jumped sharply by $1.68 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record total of $189.64 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The previous high came during the week ended Jan. 20, when the total was $188.1 billion in 161 funds.

title: WILL THE K.G.B.'S CHIEF SUCCEED BREZHNEV?
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERCOLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
MORGAN LIBRARY SHOWS ITS RECENT ACQUISITIONS
description: THE Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, has just opened an exhibition devoted to some new treasures, in this case drawings, early printed books and bookbindings acquired since 1978. For regular visitors to the library's exhibitions, this is announcement enough. In terms of sheer artistic quality, as well as in historical rarity and specialized scholarly interest, the objects selected by the Morgan Library for its permanent collections have long been truly remarkable. Every connoisseur will know that this is a show not to be missed. It remains on view through April 18.

title: BOTH SIDES IN SALVADOR VYING FOR VOTES IN SLUMS
description: Inside the church, people were pointing at the thin plywood wall behind the crucifix, trying to count the bullet holes. A gaping hole had been torn by a shell in the vertical metal door slats.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Sports People; Bullets Fine Lucas
description: The Washington Bullets were having a problem with a missing man of their own. John Lucas skipped the game at Philadelphia Wednesday night and, though he met with team executives yesterday afternoon to give his reasons, his whereabouts for the preceding 24 hours went publicly unexplained.

title: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Yr-ago results restated to conform to F.A.S.B. statement No 43

title: Papal Envoy in Britain Is Received by Queen
description: Msgr. Bruno B. Heim, envoy of Pope John Paul II, presented his credentials to Queen Elizabeth II today, formally ending four and a half centuries in which the Roman Catholic Church lacked full diplomatic representation in Britain.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Includes $654,000 extraordinary gain

title: Voting Rights Are Not Quotas
description: The Reagan Administration is stepping up its opposition to a strengthened Voting Rights Act by playing on fears of racial quotas. Attorney General Smith told the United Jewish Appeal recently that if civil rights forces have their way, local governments will be forced to ''mirror the racial or language makeup'' of their constituencies.

title: State Dept. Comments
description: A State Department spokesman, Anita Stockman, said tonight of the Nicaraguan officials' statements, ''We have said several times in the past that the door was always open to normalization of relations with Nicaragua.'' She declined to elaborate.

title: DOZIER TESTIFIES AT TRIAL OF HIS ABDUCTORS
description: Confined in two steel cages, 9 of the 17 people charged in the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier are being tried in Verona, where the American officer was abducted by Red Brigades terrorists Dec. 17.

title: Reagan Sees West German
description: Franz-Josef Strauss, head of West Germany's conservative Christian Social Union, met with President Reagan today and expressed support for United States policies. ''In our political party there is no dispute against President Reagan,'' he later told reporters. Mr. Strauss, who returns home Friday after a weeklong visit to Washington, criticized Moscow's announcement this week that it would freeze its deployment of intermediate-range missiles.

title: Valentine Giamatti Dies at 71; Taught Italian at Mt. Holyoke
description: Valentine Giamatti, a retired professor of Italian at Mount Holyoke College and the father of Yale University's president, A. Bartlett Giamatti, died Wednesday in Bonita Springs Fla., where he was on vacation. He was 71 years old and lived in South Hadley.

title: Market Place; Risks Inherent In Tax Shelters
description: TAX shelters are only as good as their ingredients, and tough new tax rules have reduced the number of successful recipes. Gary M. Goldberg, president of a financial planning concern that bears his name in Spring Valley, N.Y., maintains that ''tax shelters are no longer a low-risk gamble.'' He regards this as serious since shelters are not analyzed as cautiously as other investments.

title: Trade Deficit Recorded for 4th Quarter
description: The United States recorded an $85 million deficit in its balance of payments accounts with foreign countries in 1981's fourth quarter, but still finished the year with a $6.6 billion surplus, the biggest surplus since 1975, the Government reported today.

title: TV Weekend; LEAR'S 'I LOVE LIBERTY' LEADS SPECIALS
description: IN a weekend of at least 100 stars, the list of specials is headed by ''I Love Liberty,'' the Norman Lear two-hour extravaganza that ABC-TV will present on Sunday at 9 P.M. In recent interviews, Mr. Lear, whose production credits include ''All in the Family'' and other issue-oriented situation comedies, has been playing down his running battle with such conservative groups as the Moral Majority and Coalition for Better Television. This show, he insists, is for all Americans.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday, as securities dealers tried to reduce inventories at a time of modest investor demand and high financing costs.

title: Pop Jazz; STREET SINGER RETURNS ON WINGS OF 'HEAVEN'
description: FOR more than 35 years, Arthur Tracy, who was one of the most popular stars of radio in the early 1930's as the Street Singer, has been hoping to resume his singing career. ''I'm yearning, I'm desperate to get back into show business,'' he told an interviewer in 1957.

title: Elderly Get Food In Court Accord
description: Two supermarket corporations will donate a total of $13,000 worth of food to the elderly poor under a settlement of cases in which they were charged with bribing New York City inspectors to overlook pricing or other violations at stores in Brooklyn.

title: Rockwell Workers May Be Recalled
description: The Rockwell International Corporation entered into an agreement that could lead to the recall of hundreds of its laid-off automotive employees in five Middle Western states for work on the new B-1 bomber.

title: PLANNED DEFICITS ARE CRITICIZED
description: President Reagan's Economic Policy Advisory Board, in a nearly six-hour White House session, concluded today that the budget deficits the President has proposed are too big and must be reduced.

title: Warsaw Accuses Group Of Armed Resistance
description: The Polish Government today accused opponents of organizing an armed resistance movement that it said was involved in killing a policeman, assaulting soldiers and stealing arms.

title: Notes on People; Liv Ullmann Does Her Share to Help Unicef; Helping Unicef
description: Liv Ullmann was in New York yesterday, winding up one of those promotional tours actresses are forever making. This time, however it wasn't a movie Miss Ullmann was advancing, but Unicef, the children's aid organization she seems to be promoting almost full time these days.

title: GEORGETOWN GAINS; CAVALIERS LOSE BY 68-66-GOPHERS BOW TO LOUISVILLE
description: Virginia, which struggled through the last month of the season with seven close victories and two losses in 10 games, was eliminated from the national collegiate championship tournament tonight, 68-66, by the University of Alabama-Birmingham.

title: CATALYST, AT 20, COMES OF AGE
description: The head-table guests, 62 of them, were a roll call of American business and industry. Even a random sampling was impressive: John R. Opel, chairman of IBM; Donald V. Seibert, chairman of J.C. Penney; Thornton F. Bradshaw, chief executive officer of RCA; Richard J. Ferris, chief executive officer of United Airlines; John F. McGillicuddy, president of Manufacturers Hanover; Dr. Marina Whitman, vice president of General Motors, and Paula D. Hughes, vice president of Thomson McKinnon Securities.

title: AVERY COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results restated to reflect an accounting change

title: FIGHTER PILOT AT THE TOP
description: Gen. Charles A. Gabriel, the veteran fighter pilot nominated today to head the Air Force, is ''a gentleman, very bright, very direct, has an ability to go right to the heart of an issue,'' said

title: CAREY AIDE CLEARED OF CHARGES MADE BY SENATE REPUBLICANS
description: The Albany County District Attorney has cleared Meyer S. Frucher, Governor Carey's director of employee relations, of criminal liability in connection with allegations made by the State Senate's Republican majority.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The shr earnings adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock split effective August 1981

title: DMG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $1,049,000 for the qr and $158,000 for the yr

title: ZONDERVAN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Fines Reduced, Piniella Says
description: Lou Piniella and George Steinbrenner have agreed to an adjustment in the outfielder's two fines, Piniella said tonight.

title: RANDOLPH LOST TO YANKEES
description: The finest spring training in Willie Randolph's career was cut short today when X-rays revealed that the Yankee second baseman broke a toe in Wednesday's game against the Montreal Expos.

title: Top Officers Elected At Joy Manufacturing
description: A. William Calder, 58, has been elected president of the Joy Manufacturing Company, a coal mining and industrial equipment maker, effective immediately, and chief executive officer, effective Oct.1. Andre R. Horn, 53, has been named chairman, also effective Oct.1.

title: Black Police Chief Named
description: The City of Charleston has appointed Reuban M. Greenberg, a 37-year-old state law-enforcement officer in Florida, as its police chief. He will be the first black man to hold the post.

title: Sony Earnings Grow by 4.9%
description: Sony Corporation reported yesterday that earnings rose 4.9 percent, to $87.5 million, in the three months ended Jan. 31, despite a recession that dampened demand for consumer products worldwide. Last year, Sony earned $83.4 million.

title: Computer Voting Snarls Chicago Primary
description: Amid charges of voting fraud and computer foulups, Representative Gus Savage, Democrat of Illinois, today narrowly defeated his primary election opponent, Eugene Barnes, former chairman of the Chicago Transit Authority, according to complete but unofficial returns from the Tuesday voting.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Includes a gain of $9 million or 40 cents a shr from settleme of claims against folding carton manufacturer, for the qr, and $9.5 million gain or 47 cents a shr for the 9 mos; all 1981 net figures reflect $6.9 million or 34 cents a shr charge from loss in connection with plans to clos certain vegetable processing facilities

title: Freshman Improves Villanova
description: The chocolate chip ice cream received Ed Pinckney's highest rating. He was eating the dessert outdoors, in the sun, to take advantage of a temperature that was considerably higher than it was in Villanova, Pa., today. Pinckney was not there because there is a basketball game to be played here tomorrow night.

title: DANCE: THE KATHRYN POSIN COMPANY
description: KATHRYN POSIN is a puzzler. Her Kathryn Posin Dance Company, which opened Wednesday night in the Public Theater's Martinson Hall, moves very sleekly indeed. Yet she is sometimes willing to settle for the trivial. And she can be trivial to serious and frivolous music alike.

title: SENATE VOTES BILL TO GUARD IDENTITY OF COVERT AGENTS
description: The Senate, ending a debate over the balance between press freedom and national security, approved a bill today that would make it a crime to disclose the identities of American intelligence agents involved in covert actions abroad.

title: John A. Keenan Is Dead at 73; Ex-President of Sheaffer Pen
description: John A. Keenan, retired president and chief executive officer of the W.A. Sheaffer Pen Company and the Standard Packaging Corporation, died of cancer Tuesday at Fort Madison (Iowa) Community Hospital. Mr. Keenan, who had been living in Fort Madison, was 73 years old.

title: KOCH IS BOOED AT MEETING ON S.I.
description: What began as a friendly ''town hall'' meeting between Mayor Koch and 500 Staten Island residents turned sour last night when many residents booed the Mayor for a proposal to build a coal port on the island.

title: Scot Held in Stabbing Case
description: Arthur Jackson, a 46-year-old Scot, pleaded not guilty here today to charges of attempted murder and assault with a deadly weapon on Theresa Saldana, an actress who appeared in the film ''Raging Bull.'' Miss Saldana, 27, was reported in satisfactory condition after being stabbed in the chest outside her home Monday.

title: A Mugger Slays Bronx Man, 68
description: A 68-year-old retired welder was fatally stabbed outside his Bronx apartment building Wednesday night by a young robber who fled with his wallet and an undetermined amount of money, the police reported.

title: G.N.P. MILESTONE: $3 TRILLION
description: Last Dec. 11, some of the big news of the day was: The Security Council picked a new Secretary General of the United Nations; Argentina's President was ousted by the military junta; the House approved a foreign aid bill.

title: EXCERPTS FORM THE PRESIDENT'S SPEECH TO BUSINESS ECECUTIVES
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech today to the National Association of Manufacturers:

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Financial Corp. said it had increased its stake in the Penn Central Corp. to the equivalent of 16.4 percent, or 4,788,221 common shares, including 325,000 Penn Central common shares purchased between March 8 and March 10 for a total cost of $7.4 million.

title: Sports People; Eagles Test Nehemiah
description: The Philadelphia Eagles have given a tryout to Renaldo Nehemiah, the only man to run under 13 seconds for the 110-meter high hurdles. The Eagles' personnel director, Carl Peterson, told a Philadelphia sportscaster, Mike Forrest, that Nehemiah worked out secretly Monday with the quarterback Ron Jaworski.

title: RULING COULD ALTER WAY LEGISLATURE TALLIES VOTES
description: A judge's decision voiding a rise in the state sales tax could, if upheld, require major changes in the way the State Legislature does its work and eliminate practices that have been used for decades, officials here said today.

title: GEORGETOWN GAINS; FRESNO STATE FALLS, 58-40-OREGON STATE ROUTS IDAHO
description: Georgetown and Oregon State, as expected, powered their way to semifinal victories tonight in the West Regional of the national collegiate tournament.

title: Suriname Holds Coup Figure
description: Suriname announced today that soldiers had captured the army lieutenant who led an attempted coup last week against the leftist Government of Lieut. Col. Desie Bouterse. The Government said Lieut. Surinder Rambocus was captured Wednesday but did not comment on reports he had been wounded.

title: AFTER A DEATH, PERSPECTIVE IS SOUGHT
description: The woman, a 75-year-old diabetic, died despite all the efforts to save her. After her death, John D. Arras, a philosopher on the staff of Montiefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the North Bronx, explained why he believed that the hospital's decision to try to prevent her death had been wrong. It was contrary, he said, to the woman's own wishes and to prevailing medical, ethical and legal principles.

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Includes a LIFO credit of $128,000 or 2 cents a shr for latest qr against LIFO charge of $321,000 or 5 cents a shr for earlier period...C-Includes a LIFO charge of $493,000 or 7 cents a shr for latest yr against $848,000 or 13 cents a shr for earlier yr; shr earnings for the yr ended Jan 31, 1981 have been adjusted to give retroactive effect to a 3-for-2 stock split in the form of 50 percent stock divd in July 1981

title: Essay; MISINFORMATION, PLEASE
description: For a week before the tragic death of a Dutch television team in El Salvador, State Department cable traffic between The Hague in the Netherlands and The Haig in Foggy Bottom was sizzling about ''the interview that never was'' in an Argentine newspaper. The episode illustrates how misinformation is being used to generate fear about the United States.

title: District Attorney Backs Coroner in Los Angeles
description: John Van De Kamp, the Los Angeles County District Attorney, announced today that he had found no basis to conduct a criminal investigation of the county coroner, Dr. Thomas T. Noguchi.

title: Video Game Ruling
description: A Federal judge has ordered the Magnavox Home Entertainment Center to take its K.C. Munchkin video game off the market because it was too similar to its forerunner and archrival, Pac-Man. The ruling by Federal District Judge George Leighton, made earlier this week, followed a United States Court of Appeals decision that determined the K.C. Munchkin game violated the Pac-Man copyright, held by Atari Inc. Pac-Man, made by the Midway Manufacturing Company, has been the fastest-selling and most frequently played video game in the country since its introduction a year and a half ago.

title: OFFICER BEFRIENDED SUSPECT TO GET STOUFFER CONFESSION
description: An undercover police officer testified here today that he had befriended Luis Marin, the defendant in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial, in an effort to get him to confess that he had started the fatal blaze.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Includes $58.1 million gain from the sale of shopping centers

title: LIQUOR PANEL DRAFTS ANTI-DEPOSIT RULE
description: The State Liquor Authority has proposed a rule that would prevent localities from requiring a deposit on nonrefillable beer containers.

title: Wilkinson Unit Names a President
description: K. Douglas Martin, 41 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of Wilkinson Sword Inc., the United States unit of Wilkinson Sword Group Ltd., the big British razor blade and cutlery manufacturer. The position is a new one and corresponds with the transfer of the American company's headquarters to Atlanta from Berkeley Heights, N.J.

title: 2 OPERA TROUPES REVIVED FRENCH BAROQUE MASTER
description: OUR operatic repertory is dominated by Germany and Italy. Baroque music is also the province of these two countries. But there are those who consider French Baroque music, and especially French Baroque opera, to be the rarest of pleasures. This weekend, two major stage works by the last and greatest operatic composer of the French Baroque, Jean-Philippe Rameau, can be heard in New York.

title: OPERA: 'CONTES D'HOFFMAN'
description: HOFFMANN had two new lovers at Monday night's admirable performance of ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' at the Metropolitan Opera. In the first act, the Olympia was Gwendolyn Bradley, who acted the part wittily (but the Met really ought to repaint the actual doll for the final tableau to resemble the singer).

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $3,086,000 pretax gain from the sale of operations.. C-Net loss including $3,992,000 pretax gain from the sale of operations

title: Economic Scene; New Yardstick Urged on Fed
description: MONETARISM, the economic doctrine that dominates the policy actions of the Federal Reserve, boils down to the prescription that the central bank can and should keep the ''money supply'' growing at a slow and steady rate, allowing interest rates to fluctuate freely in response to market forces.

title: WHERE TO SAMPLE MAPLE SYRUP MAKING
description: A chance to see how the Indians prepared maple syrup - and to sample it on pancakes - is being offered this weekend by the Cary Arboretum in Millbrook in central Dutchess County, a drive of less than two hours from New York City.

title: ESTHER PHILLIPS: BLUES, JAZZ AND SOUL
description: ESTHER PHILLIPS sat rocking in a chair at Fat Tuesday's, the jazz club at 17th Street and Third Avenue where she is performing through Sunday. She had flown into New York City from Los Angeles earlier in the day and said she was tired, but her pianist, George Spencer, had been rehearsing the three New York musicians who were hired to back her, and after several hours they were beginning to sound impressively tight.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: B-Includes gain equal to $1.59 a shr from the sale of shopping center investments...C-Includes gain equal to $1.05 a shr from the sale of shopping center investments

title: Eastern Seeks Braniff Routes
description: Eastern Airlines applied today for some of the Latin American routes that Braniff International has agreed to turn over to Pan American World Airways for four years, until Braniff ''returns to financial health.''

title: Books of the Times
description: By John Leonard THE CRYING HEART TATTOO. By David Martin. 330 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.50.

title: BRASS CONFERENCE DRAWS THE TALENT AT ITS PEAK
description: When the 10th annual New York Brass Conference begins at 9 this morning with the Gloria Band in a tribute to Bill Bell, the main ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel is likely to become the only place in North America with more brass than the Pentagon.

title: HOSPITALS TURN TO PHILOSOPHERS ON LIFE ISSUES
description: Several New York teaching hospitals are using philosophers in their day-to-day operations to help their medical staffs make better decisions affecting the life and death of patients.

title: ART: 'NEW WORK NEW YORK' AT THE NEW MUSEUM
description: ''NEW WORK NEW YORK'' at the New Museum, 65 Fifth Avenue between 13th and 14th Streets, is an anthology of work by six artists now active in New York. None of them has been much fussed over to date, but on this occasion their work has been installed and catalogued in exemplary fashion. The show closes on March 27, and will then take a swing through La Jolla, Calif., Tucson, Ariz., Tyler, Tex., and Edmonton, Alberta and Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

title: ART: FOR RAFAEL FERRER, THE WORLD IS FEISTY
description: THE sizable show at the Hofmann Gallery, 429 West Broadway, is the first by Rafael Ferrer to consist entirely of paintings and drawings. Well, there is one tall, three-sided structure topped with pink and blue whisk brooms that harks back to the ''tents'' and other sculptural pieces the artist has made. But paintings - a primitive nude, palm trees and some balloon-like shapes - fill each of the canvas panels. Marking another change, the humans that previously were only symbolized or implied are now the center of attention.

title: F.T.C. HEAD MAY END REVIEWS OF ADS
description: James C. Miller 3d, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that he might ask Congress to exempt advertisers entirely from a fairness standard now used by the F.T.C. to protect consumers from what it considers harmful advertising, especially on television.

title: ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes capital gains of $28,000 for the qr and $41,000 for the yr and tax credits of $63,000 for the qr and $227,000 for the yr...C-Including $111,000 capital loss for the qr and $117,000 capital gain for the yr and $428,000 tax credit

title: Colby Backs U.S. Use Of Covert Operations
description: William E. Colby, a former Director of Central Intelligence, said today that the United States was justified in using covert action to prevent another Cuban-supported government from spreading revolution to its neighbors.

title: WEINBERGER SEES TALKS WITH SOVIET ON STRATEGIC ARMS THIS SUMMER
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was in ''the final phase of intensive preparations'' for negotiations with the Soviet Union on reducing strategic arms. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, in separate comments, said he expected the talks to begin this summer.

title: Protecting Mitchell-Lama Equities
description: To the Editor:

title: BUY AN AMERICAN CAR, GET A TAX CREDIT?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW I.C.C. RAIL POLICY MAY AID LARGE CARRIERS
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission, as part of its program to eliminate unnecessary regulations and increase competition, today dropped a 30-year policy of protecting competing railroads from the marketing strategies of merged railroads, the agency said.

title: OPEC PACT TO CURB PRODUCTION OF OIL IS REPORTED CLOSE
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries appeared near agreement tonight to limit production in an effort to reduce the worldwide oversupply of oil and bolster rapidly weakening prices.

title: JONATHAN LOGAN'S COMEBACK Inc.
description: During the 1960's, Jonathan Logan was a name in many a girl's closet, the inevitable dress label for a junior miss. But as dresses fell out of favor, so did Jonathan Logan, and production stopped altogether a year ago.

title:
Patents;
Two-Way Video by Satellite
description: WASHINGTON AMETHOD of two-way video communication by satellite between widely separated earth stations was patented this week for the RCA Corporation. The inventor was identified as Alfonse Acampora, a staff member at RCA Laboratories, Princeton, N.J.

title: 2 Pandas Fail Again; Science to Take Over
description: Nature again refused to take its course today, so zookeepers decided to try to breed America's celibate pandas through artificial insemination.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday on the views of King Hussein of Jordan incorrectly described United Nations Security Council Resolution 242. The resolution, approved on Nov. 22, 1967, calls for ''withdrawal of Israeli armed forces from territories occcupied'' in the 1967 war in exchange for recognition of the right of every state in the area to live in peace within secure and recognized boundaries.

title: Around the Nation; Flash Flood Warnings In Effect in Indiana
description: Steady rain pelted already swollen rivers here today, but the waters receded and officials cautiously predicted no new surge of the flooding that has forced the evacuation of nearly 10,000 people.

title: Your Money; Some Lessons For Children
description: THE scene is a small store lined with electronic games in a suburban shopping center. Children are gathered after school, pumping quarters into the likes of Pac-Man, Astroblaster and Space Invaders.

title: MARY POPPINS AGAINST GRAVITY
description: ''It is such a shocking book,'' said the boy to me. ''Shocking?'' I protested. ''Yes,'' he insisted, ''shocking. When she went up those stair things, it gave me such a dreadful shock, I nearly jumped out of my skin. I tried and tried to do it myself but I could only slide down.''

title: THE PLUNGE IN PENNY STOCKS
description: Only 15 months ago, Denver's penny stock market was riding the crest of the Rocky Mountain energy boom. So many new brokerage firms had crowded along 17th Street, the main downtown thoroughfare, that the area came to be known as ''Wall Street West.''

title: TOP JUSTICE OFFICIALS JOIN BATTLE ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: The Reagan Administration has begun a counterattack on its critics in the civil rights movement as voting rights legislation reaches a critical stage before a Senate subcommittee.

title: NOMINEE FOR PRETORIA POST BACKS 'PEACEFUL CHANGE'
description: Herman W. Nickel, President Reagan's nominee to be the United States Ambassador to South Africa, told a Senate confirmation hearing today that he favored ''peaceful change'' in southern Africa, but his support of Reagan Administration policies in the region drew criticism from two church-related groups.

title: Washington Talk
description: What Price Criticism?

title: STRING DUET: 2 QUARTETS
description: The home team, as is customary, took the field first on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall; the visiting team, which showed up late, was from Tokyo and played well. But the winner was Mendelssohn, as the Guarneri String Quartet enlisted the aid of the Tokyo String Quartet in an ebullient performance of Mendelssohn's Octet in E-flat (Op. 20), capping a program that had opened with an early quartet by Mozart and the Quartet in G minor (Op. 27) by Grieg.

title: ALAS, THE SOHO NEWS WASN'T CAST-IRON
description: The alternative to alternative papers is dead. The Soho News ceased publication Monday, after eight and one-half years on New York stands. Although our financial situation had always been precarious, the suddenness, the finality of the death announcement came as a shock, albeit one tinged with a sense of sad relief, akin to the feeling one has when an old friend, after a lengthy and debilitating illness, finally quietly passes away.

title: U.S. Has to Honor Pact On Clinch River Plant
description: The Federal Government cannot cancel a contract for part of the work on the long-delayed Clinch River Breeder Reactor, even though the cost has doubled, Congress was told today by the General Accounting Agency.

title: COOKE SAYS 2 JUDGES IN CITY UNDERMINE HIS REFORM PLAN
description: Lawrence H. Cooke, the Chief Judge of New York State's highest court, charged yesterday that New York City's two highest appellate judges were undermining his efforts at court reform by challenging his authority to make changes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The review of the film ''Christiane F'' in Weekend yesterday gave the film's rating incorrectly. It is ''R.''

title: Sly Williams Absent Again
description: One day after his reinstatement from a suspension that the Knicks had imposed because of unexcused absences, Sly Williams missed the team's practice yesterday at LaGuardia Community College in Queens. By late afternoon, however, the matter of his repeated violation of team rules appeared to be resolved once again.

title:
PATENTS;
Turning Nuclear Waste Into a Cable for Burial
description: A nuclear waste disposal system invented by H. Richard Leuchtag, a research physicist in Galveston, Tex., includes combining the waste with glass components, then melting it and forming it into a cable.

title: IRWIN SHARES 5-WAY GOLF LEAD WITH 138
description: Hale Irwin, the two-time United States Open champion and the winner of the Inverrary Classic last Sunday, shared a one-stroke lead today with four lesser-known players in the second round of the Tournament Players Championship. He scored 68, four under par for the new Players Club course, for a 36-hole aggregate of 138.

title: PURDUE OUSTS TEXAS A&M BY 86-68
description: Russell Cross scored 26 points and Keith Edmonson had 22 as Purdue defeated Texas A & M tonight, 86-68, in the quarterfinals of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: The IRT, Made in Japan
description: First the R-46 subway cars made by Rockwell developed cracks in their undercarriages ... Then the Grumman buses proved no match for city potholes ... Now the M.T.A. goes to Japan to replace its wornout IRT fleet ... Can't Americans build anything right?

title: PLANE CRASH KILLS A GUITARIST IN OZZY OSBOURNE ROCK GROUP
description: The lead guitarist of the rock group headed by Ozzy Osbourne was killed today, along with two other persons, when a plane in which they were buzzing a mansion struck a van and crashed into the house, the authorities said.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MARCH 20, 1982
description: International Modest cuts in OPEC's oil output may result from a meeting of the ministers from the organization's 13 member countries in Vienna. Important details of how the reduced production would be shared among the member countries were still to be worked out at another session. But Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, oil minister of Saudi Arabia, told reporters that ''we have reached agreement on a ceiling of 18 million'' barrels a day. That would represent a reduction of no more than 200,000 barrels a day from the estimated current total OPEC output. (Page 1, Col. 6.) Nicaragua requested a meeting of the Security Council of the United Nations to denounce what it said was its ''imminent'' invasion by the United States or by paramilitary forces supported by the United States. Daniel Ortega Saavedra, coordinator of Nicaragua's three-man junta and one of the nine principal Sandinist commanders, requested the meeting in a letter to the Secretary General of the United Nations. (1:5.)

title: Communists in Naples Threatened by Scandal
description: A reporter for the Communist newspaper L'Unita was detained here today in a political scandal that is embarrassing the leaders of the Italian Communist Party and may cost it the mayor's office in this city.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 16.50 17.50 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 14.88 14.97 13.16 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.96 12.90 12.65 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.98 12.92 12.55 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 13.93 14.00 12.96 30-YR. TREAS BONDS 13.47 13.51 12.48 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.95 15.95 13.31 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.92 13.89 10.70 6-MONTH SAVINGS 13,212 CERTIFICATES* * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TEXAS A&M, RIDING A BOOM, SEEKS STATURE TO MATCH ITS WEALTH
description: A joke making its way around Texas not long ago had it that Texas A&M University was doubling the number of books in its library. It seems someone had already colored in the other two.

title: A Household With No Pianos to Spare
description: When Misha and Cipa Dichter were students at the Juilliard School of Music, they had to sign up for practice time on school pianos, but now that they give duo performances in concerts around the world, they have two pianos in their home.

title: OWNER OF DAILY NEWS REJECTS CITY'S OFFER OF HELP
description: The owner of The Daily News has rejected New York City's offer of tax and financing help to the newspaper, which was put up for sale after the owner said it lost $11 million last year.

title: CITY SITE WILL BE TESTED FOR TOXIC WASTE BY U.S.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will test for toxic substances next week at a landfill operated by New York City next to the Starrett City housing project in southeast Brooklyn.

title: U.S.  RAISES THE TOTAL OF MILITARY ADVISORS IN HONDURAS TO 100
description: The United States has increased the number of its military advisers in Honduras to as many as 100 since the start of the year. The State Department said the increase was meant to help enhance that country's security in the face of a military buildup in neighboring Nicaragua.

title: Tour Changes Its Name Again
description: The familiar PGA Tour logo reappeared today on the scoreboards of the Tournament Players Championship to herald a second change of name in eight months. The designation TPA Tour, which never did catch on after it was adopted last August, was retired.

title: 4.5% DROP IN G.N.P.'S RATE SEEN
description: The Commerce Department estimated today that the economy has fallen at a seasonally adjusted 4.5 percent annual rate in the current quarter, a reflection of the recession that started last July.

title: No Headline
description: CELTICS WIN 14th IN ROW

title: 2 on Nuclear Agency Assail Quake Decision
description: Two members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today criticized the commission's refusal to review the design of the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant to determine whether the California facility could withstand earthquakes.

title: 'PORKY'S' OPENS
description: Bob Clark, the writer and director of ''Porky's,'' was scheduled to begin shooting this film in 1979, but he postponed production so that he could direct ''Tribute'' first. What? How can the sentimental, sanctimonious ''Tribute'' and this bawdy new comedy be the work of the same man?

title: PRESIDENT OD HARVESTER IN ABRUPT RESIGNATION
description: Warren J. Hayford, president and chief operating officer of the International Harvester Company, has resigned abruptly, the troubled truck and equipment manufacturer said today.

title: POETRY AND SCIENCE MEET ALONG THE TRAIL OF SPRING
description: In the change of seasons, the poet hears the song of the soul. ''And the Spring arose on the garden fair,'' wrote Shelley, ''Like the spirit of Love felt everywhere.'' The scientist, however, rarely makes such a fuss at the coming of the vernal equinox.

title: POLES IN QUANDRY ON WALESA BABY
description: The baptism of Lech Walesa's baby daughter may or may not take place this Sunday and the Solidarity leader may or may not be allowed to attend, but in any case the entire event is shaping up as a problem for the martial law authorities.

title: SIMON & SCHUSTER HISTORY ON DISPLAY
description: A hand-scrawled seven-page ''confidential'' memorandum, written on the letterhead of The Boston Evening Transcript on May 20, 1923, practically sums up the history (including the dreams, the successes, the crises) of American book publishing in the last half-century. The document goes:

title: MIAMI BEACH'S VOTE ON ART DECO REGARDED AS MOVE TO COMPROMISE
description: The Miami Beach City Commission has provisionally approved an ordinance creating an Art Deco district here, but the commission also appears to have opened the way to a possible compromise between property owners and supporters of preservation of old buildings.

title: 10 Federal Employees Held
description: The police have arrested 10 employees of the Veterans Administration Medical Center here on drugselling charges. The arrests stemmed from a three-month inquiry and involved the sale of cocaine, methamphetamines and marijuana, Constable Michael Cantanese said.

title: BISHOP C.J. WELDON OF MASSACHUSETTS
description: Bishop Christopher J. Weldon of Springfield, Mass., leader of the Roman Catholic Church in western Massachusetts for 27 years, died yesterday at Mercy Hospital in Springfield. He was 76 years old.

title: A Fugitive 12 Years, Man Wins Freedom
description: A 42-year-old man who escaped from a North Carolina road gang in 1970 and was living in Trenton with his wife and two children will remain free.

title: DON'T REHIRE CONTROLLERS, AVIATION ADVISOR SAYS
description: The head of a management study group that issued a highly critical report on the Federal Aviation Administration said today that any decision to rehire the dismissed air traffic controllers would be a mistake.

title: Northeastern Ties, 2-2 In Hockey Quarterfinal
description: Northeastern tied Bowling Green, 2-2, tonight in the East quarterfinal round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament at Northeastern Arena. The teams will play again Saturday night for a berth in next weekend's finals in Providence.

title: Arcata Accepts Alb Merger Terms
description: The Arcata Corporation of Menlo Park, Calif., one of the country's largest printing companies and a major producer of redwood lumber, said it had signed a definitive agreement for its previously announced acquisition by Alb Ventures, a new corporation formed by an investor group led by Edward L. Scarff.

title: Inland Steel Debt Tied to McLouth
description: The Inland Steel Company of Chicago said that about $106 million of long-term debt could fall due in December because of a link with the ailing McLouth Steel Corporation of Detroit, which sought protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in December.

title: Ministers Ask Later Start
description: A group of ministers in this community, the site of the main campus of the University of North Carolina, wants to delay the 12:10 P.M. starting time for the East Regional basketball final, to be played Sunday in nearby Raleigh.

title: News Analysis
description: If the White House, the Democrats in Congress and the Republicans in Congress are to reach a budget compromise, ''everybody's going to have to stick their feet in the water at the same time,'' Representative Richard B. Cheney of Wyoming, chairman of the Republican Policy Committee, said today.

title: JAPANESE DETERRENTS AGAINST CIVIL SUITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Polish Government Dissolves The Journalists' Association
description: The Polish Journalists' Association, suspended under martial law more than three months ago, was dissolved by the Government today, an official announcement said.

title: Clearing Smoke About Smoke Alarms
description: The City Council, aware that more New Yorkers die from smoke than burns, passed a law last year requiring installation of smoke detectors in apartments. The detectors are effective - too effective, say some who find that toasting bread sets them off - but the law is not. Owners of only 20 percent of the city's apartments have installed detectors or asked for more time to do so.

title: BRZEZINSKI URGES REAGAN TO RALLY ALLIES
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser to President Carter, urged President Reagan today to take new initiatives to rally the West by proposing steps to ''reduce the level of East-West military confrontation'' in Europe and by offering ''a positive carrot'' of renewed Western economic aid for Poland as an inducement for Warsaw to end martial law.

title: FEBRUARY DURABLE ORDERS UP
description: A rise in orders for military equipment pushed factory orders for durable goods up 1.5 percent in February from the January level, the Government reported today. It was the first gain since November and only the second since last July, when the current recession began.

title: EFFORTS TO ADMINISTER JUSTICE CLOGGED IN CITY'S COMPUTERS
description: Despite millions of dollars spent for ambitious computer operations, authorities say New York City's criminal-justice system is still seriously hampered by missing, delayed and uncoordinated information about individual defendants and about how the system itself is working.

title: A SOUTH KOREAN FACADE OF GROWTH AND STABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: HEARING SET ON I.B.M. CASE DISMISSAL
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered a court hearing to determine if the dismissal of the Government's antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation should be overturned.

title: NEW FUND TO COMPENSATE VICTIMS OF MISAPPROPRIATION BY LAWYERS
description: People who believe that they have been victimized by dishonest lawyers are now able to seek up to $25,000 compensation for their losses from a client security fund that began soliciting claims yesterday.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 25.

title: IN NEW YORK HARBOR, SAFETY IS A COMPLEX TASK
description: The rain slanted down on the harbor as the tugboat Brian McAllister pulled alongside the 600-foot Don Salvador III, a Filipino cargo ship docked at a Brooklyn pier. It took 40 minutes, as the tug pushed and pulled, to guide the unwieldy ship safely on its way.

title: PULLING WESTWAY'S PLUG
description: Mayor Koch, who has flip-flopped so many times on Westway as a bargaining tactic at the fiscal poker table that he may give pragmatism a bad name, vowed originally that the grandiose 4.2-mile superhighway/waterfront development scheme was a mistake that would never be built. He should have stuck with that pledge, because it appears he was right.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Craig Virgin, who has won the title twice, withdrew from the world cross-country championships to be held in Rome on Sunday. Virgin has been ill with a recurring stomach virus.

title: STUDENT A SUSPECT IN TEACHER SLAYING
description: A 55-year-old teacher was shot to death today and two students were wounded by a high school senior who was later wounded by the police, the authorities said.

title: PROMOTING CHANGE IN POLAND
description: Is there a way to provide a framework or environment for political and economic change in Poland and other Eastern European countries of such a kind that the prospect of change will not automatically activate the Kremlin's most acute concerns about its possible effects on Soviet security?

title: Ajello Out of Race In Connecticut
description: Carl R. Ajello, Connecticut's Attorney General for eight years, announced that he would not seek a third term this year. Mr. Ajello, a Democrat, already had three announced challengers in the party, and his withdrawal could bring out more candidates before the state convention in July.

title: Mixed Signals at Legal Services
description: President Reagan's war of attrition against the Legal Services Corporation continues apace. Last year, he tried to shoot it clear out of the Federal budget. Congress held the damage to a telling but not fatal 25 percent cut, to $224 million. The President's new budget again proposes death.

title: Belushi Left Entire Estate to His Wife
description: Judith Jacklin Belushi, the 30-year-old wife of John Belushi, has been left his entire estate in a will filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan.

title: NATIONAL STUDY FINDS LEAD LEVELS IN BLOOD HAVE DECLINED SHARPLY
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control reported yesterday that levels of lead in the blood of a sample of United States residents appeared to have dropped 36.7 percent over a four-year period ended in 1980. The centers said that reduced use of lead as a gasoline additive might be responsible.

title: Around the World; Dozier Is Reassigned To Armor Center in U.S.
description: Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, the United States Army officer held captive by Italian leftist guerrillas for 42 days, has been reassigned to the United States, NATO announced today.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $400 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply fell $400 million in the week ended March 10. The modest drop left money supply above the Fed's annual growth target, but added to the mounting evidence that money supply growth is slowing after a $9.5 billion spurt in the first two weeks of the year.

title: Washington Talk
description: A Humbled Concorde

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: The Food and Drug Administration recently notified rubber manufacturers that it w as concerned about the widespread presence of minute quantities of a carcinogenic chemical in baby-bottle nipples.

title: Swallows Return to Mission
description: The swallows came back to Capistrano today, as they have for centuries on St. Joseph's Day, after a 7,000-mile flight from Argentina.

title: Washington Talk
description: Budget Madness

title: 2-MONTH DELAY EXPECTED IN TESTING OF PERSHING 2 MISSILE FOR EUROPE
description: The first test of the Pershing 2 nuclear missile, whose deployment in Western Europe is designed to counter the Soviet Union's arsenal of intermediate-range weapons, is likely to be delayed from April until June because of technological complications, according to authoritative Pentagon sources.

title: Around the Nation; Chicago Council Votes Ban on New Handguns
description: The Chicago City Council today approved a ban on the new registration of handguns, with Mayor Jane Byrne calling it the ''first step in a nationwide campaign'' for tighter gun controls.

title: The Talk of Poland
description: There is a strong whiff of spring in the wind that sweeps across the Vistula River. Day after day the sun pokes through the gray skies. It bathes the city in gold and steadily melts the few remaining humps of blackened snow and ice, which have retreated to the most darkly shaded corners in courtyards and parks. But Warsaw does not seem very spring-like. There are not many smiles to be seen on the faces of the mothers who push baby carriages along the promenades, the infants inside propped up and still bundled with layers of sweaters and coats as if they were facing a Siberian winter.

title: Reagan and Budget Curb
description: President Reagan, now advocating the largest deficits in history, is expected to support a proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget, Administration sources said today.

title: Bomb Kills 4 in Thai Province
description: A bomb exploded at provincial headquarters in southern Surat Thani, killing 4 people and injuring about 50, the Government said today. It said the explosion was believed to be an act of sabotage by Communist insurgents.

title: Sports of The Times; Westphal Assumes a Herculean Task
description: IN Paul Westphal's first game as a Knick, one week ago today, he created a ripple of excitement at Madison Square Garden, where in recent years the only excitement at a Knick game was when you were able to catch the eye of the ice-cream vendor.

title: 20 DEAD IN CRASH OF MILITARY PLANE
description: An Illinois National Guard aircraft crashed in a ball of fire into a muddy farm field in northern Illinois tonight, killing all 20 persons aboard, the police said.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES ANOTHER APPEAL IN PORTMAN PLAN
description: The latest legal attempt to forestall demolition of the Helen Hayes and Morosco Theaters near Times Square was rejected yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Going Out Guide
description: FLIGHTS OF FANCY

title: Pittston to Buy Burlington Unit
description: The Pittston Company said it had agreed in principle to buy the air freight unit of Burlington Northern Inc. for $177 million in cash.

title: COMPANY FOUND NEGLIGENT IN TOXIC SHOCK DISEASE SUIT
description: A Federal jury today found that the Procter & Gamble Company was negligent and offered a defective product when it put Rely tampons on the market, but it did not award any damages to a Colorado teen-ager who sued the company.

title: Price Rise in Canada
description: Consumer prices, pushed up by significant increases in the cost of food, were 11.6 percent higher in February than they were a year earlier, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. That was slightly higher than the 11.4 percent year-to-year rise recorded in January and marked the end of a threemonth decline in inflation. Higher prices for fresh produce, in part reflecting the mid-January freeze in Florida, were largely responsible.

title: U.S. REVIEWING STATE'S PLAN TO TRANSFER MEDICAID OFFICE
description: The Federal General Accounting Office is reviewing charges that the state's plan to move a privately operated Medicaid billing system with 675 jobs from New York City to Albany violated Federal contract procedures.

title: ICHAN CALLS BATUS BID 'INADEQUATE'
description: Carl C. Icahn, the financier, rejected yesterday as ''inadequate'' the sweetened bid of $30 a share offered by Batus Inc. in its tender offer to acquire Marshall Field & Company.

title: VILLANOVA ADVANCES
description: The Memphis State Tigers, who have disputed their reputation as a one-man team, almost won without their one man tonight. But with Keith Lee, the 6-foot-10-inch freshman, on the bench after his fifth foul, the Tigers missed opportunities at the end of regulation time and in overtime and lost, 70-66, to Villanova in an East Regional semifinal at Reynolds Coliseum.

title: 2 N.H.L. Coaches Out
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have won only 34 of 72 games this season and are certain to finish with their worst record in a decade. So yesterday they took the habitual step of a disappointed team - dismissing the coach.

title: Judge Overrules Ban on Klan Rally
description: A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order, forcing the City of Meriden to allow the Ku Klux Klan to demonstrate Saturday.

title: WORK ON SHUTTLE IS GOING SMOOTHLY
description: Launching crews here today continued to prepare the space shuttle Columbia for its third flight, while in Houston the astronauts spent several hours in a simulator, rehearsing new maneuvers for landing the winged spaceship at White Sands, N.M.

title: SAXOPHONE: ROTHENBERG
description: Ned Rothenberg plays the saxophone, flute and other instruments dependent on breath for sound. He improvises on these instruments borrowing techniques from other cultures.

title: REAGAN MAY BACK MORTGAGE BILL
description: President Reagan is considering support of a bill to provide an immediate $1 billion in Government mortgage subsidies for the housing industry, White House aides said today.

title: Stock Price Slump Ends Hi-Shear Deal
description: Raybestos-Manhattan Inc. and Hi-Shear Industries, citing significant changes in prices of their stocks in the month since they agreed to merge, said today that they had called off the deal.

title: Politics - the American Way - in Tennessee
description: The road to political success is bumpy at best, but in Tennessee, politicians may find the going smoother if they drive American cars. That's the message to candidates from Walter Whittemore, president of the 4,000-member Local 737 of the United Auto Workers union in Nashville, which is withholding endorsements from candidates who don't drive American cars.

title: Independence, Mo., Drops Plan for Nixon Archive
description: The City Council of Independence, Mo., has called off plans to offer backers of a proposed Richard M. Nixon Library a chance to build it in Independence.

title: INNER-CITY PHILADELPHIA LOSES ANOTHER BIG STORE
description: Katie Collins shook her head as she looked down a long row of rapidly emptying shelves of food at the Broad Street A.&P. in North Philadelphia.

title: 3 INDICTED IN FULTON MARKET CASE
description: Three businessmen were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal tax charges involving more than $1.6 million of unreported income from companies that unload fish at the Fulton Fish Market.

title: SATURDAY, MARCH 20, 1982; Energy
description: OPEC members seemed near an agreement on production cuts aimed at easing the worldwide oversupply of oil and check the decline in prices. Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, The Saudi representative, said a ceiling of 18 million barrels a day - a modest cutback of 200,000 barrels a day - had been accepted. But others said several matters, including how the cutback would be shared, remain unresolved, and talks are to continue today. (Page 1.)

title: Washington Talk
description: Byrd Signal on Israel

title: Church at Seton Hall Burns
description: St. Andrews Church, part of the seminary at Seton Hall University here, was destroyed by fire late last night, according to fire officials. There were no injuries, according to one official, Capt. Pat Giordano, who said that the cause of the fire was under investigation but that it did not seem to be of suspicious origin. The 100-year-old church is on Center Street and Sterling Drive, about half a mile from the university campus.

title: PLAYFUL BUT OMINOUS
description: Books of The Times Playful but Ominous By ANATOLE BROYARD EARWITNESS: FIFTY CHARACTERS. By Elias Canetti. 101 pages. A Contin- uum Book. The Seabury Press. $7.95.

title: AIRLINES' QUANDAR: TO OVERLOOK OR NOT
description: It is a two-sided problem, one of the most persistent in air travel today. On the one hand, dozens of passengers with confirmed reservations are turned away, or bumped, from a flight because it has been overbooked. Meanwhile, another flight, one supposedly sold out for months, takes off with dozens of empty seats.

title:
PATENTS;
A WARHEAD DETECTOR FOR CHECKING SATELLITES
description: A warhead detector patented for the Marquaret Corporation, Van Nuys, Calif., is intended primarily for use in examining orbiting satellites.

title: CHARLES GOLDSTEIN: REAL-ESTATE ATTORNEY TO THE POWERFUL
description: Over a period of years, Charles A. Goldstein has quietly but effectively translated his real-estate expertise into a position as a highly paid consultant for the Urban Development Corporation and as a personal attorney for some of the state's leading politicians.

title: COMMANDED STALINGRAD'S DEFENSE
description: Marshal Vasily I. Chuikov, who led his troops in the defense of Stalingrad that turned the fortunes of Hitler's army, died Thursday at the age of 82, his family said today.

title: Rape Charges Dropped
description: Rape charges against Greg Roberts and David Overstreet, both pro football players, were dropped today at the request of the woman who filed the complaint.

title: ARABS DIDN'T DO IT
description: To the Editor:

title: HAWAII RECALLS PESTICIDE-LACED MILK FROM STORES AND SCHOOLS
description: Hawaiians scrambled for a limited supply of ''safe milk'' today after the State Health Department withdrew pesticide-contaminated milk products from grocery shelves and school cafeterias on the island of Oahu.

title: Bridge
description: The Grand National Pair Championship, the curtain-raiser to the Spring Nationals, was won here Thursday night by two Californian experts. Their closest rivals were a Florida pair and two other Californians.

title: Carnegie Hall to Have Student Discount Rates
description: Beginning with tonight's performance of the Saint Louis Symphony concert featuring Isaac Stern as soloist, Carnegie Hall will offer high school, college and graduate students any available tickets for $3 on a first-come basis two hours before the event.

title: Bartow Builds Contender in Only 5 Years
description: Alabama-Birmingham, which began its basketball program only five years ago, is just one victory from the Final Four, the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament semifinals. That is a goal that most colleges with 50 or more years of varsity experience have never achieved.

title: AUTO UNION NEARS ACCORD WITH G.M. ON NEW CONTRACT
description: Negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation were recessed early this morning after difficulties arose over several issues. But the talks were to resume at 9 A.M. amid continued hope that an agreement was near.

title: Snipes to Test Arm in Return to Ring
description: Renaldo Snipes says that when he looked down and saw his muscle hanging out of his arm, the pain was not physical.

title: HEALTH-CARE COMPETITION'S PITFALLS
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMAN HELD IN SLAYING OF HER WEALTHY FATHER
description: A 43-year-old woman who stood to inherit hundreds of millions of dollars from her father's estate was arrested at her Upper East Side apartment yesterday on charges that she conspired with her son in the murder of her father.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: MUSIC: JAPANESE SAKUHACHI CONCERT
description: Difficult as it might seem for a Westerner to judge the finer niceties of shakuhachi playing, there could be little doubt as to the excellence of Reibo Aoki, a master of this end-blown Japanese bamboo flute who appeared Wednesday night at the Asia Society.

title: Oil Find Off Norway
description: The Norwegian state oil directorate today confirmed reports of a major oil and natural gas find in the North Sea. Industry sources said further drilling in the Norwegian sector would be needed before the extent of the find, in the Hod Field, was known. Norway currently produces about 531,000 barrels of oil daily.

title: U.N. Support Is Reported
description: Alejandro Bendana Rodriguez, Nicaragua's alternate delegate to the United Nations, said here today that his Government had indications of support from more than the nine members necessary to convene a meeting. But he indicated that Nicaragua was anticipating a strong lobbying effort against the meeting by the United States.

title: Mets' Jones Shows Signs of Old Form
description: Motorists entering town from the Sunshine Skyway no longer are greeted by the billboard put up after the 1979 World Series: ''Welcome to Bradenton, winter home of the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates.''

title: Dow Edges Up 0.38 As Volume Eases
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday in cautious trading following Thursday's broad advance that marked the strongest rally in three weeks. Semiconductor issues were among the market's better performers.

title: PATENTS
description: Chemical methods of storing thermal energy and recovering it when needed were patented this week by staff members of the Martin Marietta Corporation, Bethesda, Md. The general method involves use of ammoniated salts in two different solutions to retain and produce the energy.

title: COMMUTING BETWEEN ROLES, IN DIPLOMACY AND TV
description: Constance Towers, the musical comedy star, put her career on hold last June when she moved to Mexico City with her husband, John Gavin, the former actor whose appointment as United States Ambassador created controversy in Mexico.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. ACCEPTS THE ACCOUNT BY SALVADOR ON 4 NEWSMEN

title: Japan Car Exports
description: Japan's vehicle exports in the fiscal year 1982, which begins in April, will not rise from the current year's figure, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. It said it could not give any definite export forecast because the export environment in the United States and West Europe, its major markets, was uncertain. Japan exported about 2.3 million cars to the United States in the 1981 calendar year.

title: NICARAGUA ASKS SECURITY COUNCIL TO REBUKE U.S.
description: Nicaragua called today for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council to denounce what it described as an ''imminent'' invasion of its territory by the United States or by paramilitary groups supported and encouraged by Washington.

title: OVER EAST OF QUILBY
description: I have a lot of relatives in South Succotash and spent many golden childhood days there, so naturally I was a little put off the other day to learn that President Reagan doesn't think South Succotash amounts to much.

title: TURKISH CONTRACTORS THRIVE ON FOREIGN BUILDING PROJECTS
description: The Turkish construction company Enka is building an industrial city in Libya, a water treatment plant and pipeline in Saudi Arabia, and various factories in Iraq and Jordan.

title: Navy Flier's Death Confirmed at Last
description: The agonizing doubts of a Newburgh, N.Y., couple ended yesterday with the positive identification of the remains of their son, a Navy flier shot down over Laos 12 years ago. But the parents plan to go on with their work on behalf of others lost in action during the Vietnam War.

title: STAGE: 'JEANNE MOREAU'
description: Elinor Jones begins her new play, ''What Would Jeanne Moreau Do?'' with an ear-catching commentary on technological communication. Lynn Milgrim and Burke Pearson are playing old friends whose relationship seems to consist entirely of leaving messages on each other's telephone-answering machines. The messages become a dialogue divided by beeps, and the evening, at the WPA Theater, appears to be building into a computer-age equivalent of the epistolary play.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It simply means a period of in creased activity for all organisms.'' -Dr. Richard Forman, botanist, heralding spring. (29:5.)

title: NATO CAUTIOUS ON SOVIET CREDIT PLAN
description: Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley received what NATO sources described as a sympathetic but reserved response when he briefed the allies today on United States proposals to raise the cost of credit to the Soviet Union.

title: IN LIVERWURST, BEST IS DIFFICULT TO FIND
description: If liverwurst suddenly becomes a fashionable and trendy delicacy, it may be because of the major role it plays as a symbol in Gunter Grass's new novel, ''Headbirths or The Germans Are Dying Out.'' Throughout the book the reader is aware of a coarse, lightly smoked liver sausage that is being carried from a butcher in Schleswig to the German Ambassador in Peking, who is longing for that soothingly rich and spicy taste of home.

title: STRAUSS, IN U.S., SAYS SCHMIDT HAS HURT TIES
description: Franz Josef Strauss, a leader of West Germany's opposition Christian Democratic Union, ended a week of talks with Reagan Administration officials today on ''the worsening of German-American relations'' by asserting that the blame lay largely with the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: Around the Nation; Mount St. Helens Erupts; Mudflows Threaten
description: Mount St. Helens erupted tonight, sending a towering plume of ash and steam seven miles into the air.

title: Around the Nation; Driver Guilty of Murder In 6 Nevada Deaths
description: A woman who ran her car through a Thanksgiving Day crowd on casino row was found guilty today of six counts of first-degree murder and 23 counts of attempted murder.

title: Anthony Gets Top Spot In Long Island Bowling
description: Earl Anthony completed a comeback with a 225-213 victory over Wayne Webb of Indianapolis tonight and earned the top-seeded spot going into the final round of the $100,000 Long Island Open on the Professional Bowlers Association tour.

title: A Speedy Recovery
description: Only three and a half weeks after being stricken by hepatitis, George (Doc) Medich of the Texas Rangers pitched three shutout innings in a 4-0 exhibition-game victory over Montreal. ''Everyone told me it would be six weeks minimum before I would be up and around,'' he said.

title: Around the World; West Bank Arabs Strike Over Mayor's Dismissal
description: Occupied West Bank, March 19 (AP) - Palestinians hurled rocks and gasoline bombs in El Bireh today and began a general strike that closed most business in the occupied West Bank to protest the dismissal of El Bireh's Mayor by Israel.

title: Toronto Police Hunt for Man Who Killed 2 in a Courtroom
description: The Toronto police were searching today for a man who pulled out a revolver in a packed courtroom on Thursday and shot dead a lawyer and one of his clients minutes after they won their case.

title: Cavendes Bank Bid Rejected by Fed
description: Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. announced that the Federal Reserve Board had rejected a request by a major stockholder, C.A. Cavendes Sociedad Financiera of Venezuela, to increase its holdings of Florida National shares to 24.9 percent from 9.9 percent.

title: SOVIET SAYS IT IS EAGER TO HELP INDIA PRODUCE ARMS
description: The Soviet Defense Minister, ending a six-day visit here, said tonight that Moscow was eager to ''strengthen India's defense capabilities'' by cooperating with New Delhi in the field of weapons production.

title: Brooklyn Ousted By Potsdam, 50-49
description: Brooklyn College's surprising march to the N.C.A.A. Division III Final Four ended tonight in a 50-49 semifinal loss to Potsdam College, last year's champion, at the Calvin College Field House.

title: JIWATRAM KRIPALANI, A DISCIPLE OF GANDHI IN YEARS OF STRUGGLE
description: Jiwatram Bhagwandas Kripalani, one of the last surviving close disciples of Mohandas K. Gandhi, died today in a hospital in Ahmedabad, according to the Press Trust of India. He was 93 years old.

title: LABOR LEADER ASSESSES THE PRESIDENT
description: Depending on the poll, 43 to 48 percent of all households with union members voted for President Reagan in 1980. But now, with the President facing difficult political problems and the midterm elections less than nine months away, Washington is watching for any signs that organized labor is returning to its more traditional role of supporting Democrats.

title: NEW YORK STATE AND QUEBEC SIGN HYDROPOWER PACT
description: New York State agreed yesterday to buy a sharply increased amount of hydroelectric energy from the Province of Quebec, enabling the state to reduce its dependence on more costly electricity generated with imported oil.

title: Insurers' Earnings Off
description: The nation's property and casualty insurance industry reported after-tax earnings of $6.9 billion for 1981, down from $7.57 billion in 1980, according to the Insurance Service Office and the National Association of Independent Insurers. Last year, the industry sustained an underwriting loss - including premiums returned to policyholders as dividends - of $7.57 billion, compared with $5.99 billion in 1980, the report said.

title: Ewing Is Key Player in Final
description: He is only a freshman, but Pat Ewing, Georgetown's 7-foot center from Cambridge, Mass., has become the dominant player in the West Regional tournament of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship.

title:
PATENTS;
Cellulose Fibers for Use In Manufacturing Paper
description: Cellulose fibers for use in the manufacture of paper can be produced by microorganisms, according to patent 4,320,198, which was granted to Roy L. Mynatt of Detroit this week for a continuous cultivation process.

title: 'COLLETTE,' MUSICAL, IS CLOING IN DENVER
description: ''Colette,'' the musical version of the French writer's life, will close tonight at the Auditorium Theater in Denver. A spokesman for the show said that its book would be rewritten and its scenery and costumes stored for a possible future production.

title: SOUTH KOREAN LEADER FACING FIRST ORGANIZED OPPOSITION
description: For the first time since he took power nearly two years ago, President Chun Doo Hwan is facing some organized opposition.

title: JOSEPH DONAN, 94, A MASTER CHEF
description: Joseph Donon, a world-renowned chef who was the last student of the great French master Auguste Escoffier, died yesterday at the Newport Hospital in Rhode Island. He was 94 years old and lived in Middletown, R.I.

title: Mitsubishi-Comex Link
description: The Nonferrous International Corporation, an American subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Corporation and the Mitsubishi International Corporation of the United States, has acquired general membership in the Commodity Exchange Inc. of New York, Mitsubishi said.

title: Hagler-Hearns Date Set
description: There is at last a firm date for Marvin Hagler's long-awaited defense of the middleweight championship against Thomas Hearns. Top Rank, the promoter, announced yesterday that the two would meet on May 24. The site and television arrangements are expected to be announced at a news conference in New York on Monday. ... Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Association's heavyweight champion, will defend his title against Randy (Tex) Cobb sometime in May, according to Tapco Promotions, an El Paso-based concern.

title: PHILADELPHIA GETS POLICE HIRING PLAN
description: Mayor William J. Green, acting in response to past discrimination and current protests, has ordered the Police Department to hire 220 additional black officers over the next five years in a limited quota system.

title: Miss Mazzullo, Educator, Is Bride of H. Harry Burris
description: Mariann Mazzullo, superintendent of schools for the Mount Pleasant-Plythedale school district in Valhalla, N.Y., was married yesterday to H. Harry Burris, a partner in the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand.

title: VENUS SOIL FOUND LIKE EARTH'S
description: Preliminary analyses of the first soil samples taken of Venus, obtained by two Soviet spacecraft, indicate that the planet's rocky surface, an eerily orange-lighted windswept landscape, is chemically similar to volcanic rock on the Earth.

title: Heublein Holding
description: The General Cinema Corporation said it had increased its share of Heublein Inc. to 10.7 percent from 9.7 percent of the common stock outstanding, or 1,231,000 shares, including 220,000 shares purchased from March 12 to March 16 at prices ranging from $34 to $36 a share. The companies have been involved in a bidding war for each other's stock.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: A Deputy Becomes Carey's New Press Secretary Stephen J. Morello was appointed press secretary to Governor Carey yesterday, succeeding Jill A. Schuker, who is leaving to take a job in business.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP SLIGHTLY IN MONTH ,
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest had risen only a fraction of 1 percent in the month ended March 15.

title: MONROE, LA., WORKERS' FATE TIED TO CAR PLANT
description: When the General Motors Corporation picked this small Louisiana city as the site for a new plant to make automobile headlights, the move stirred hopes among thousands of workers in the area that better pay and benefits for all would be spurred by the company's presence.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: If there is a special circle of hell reserved for New Yorkers, it may be something like Pier 76 on the Hudson River, the long, low hangar of a building, the color of a shark's skin, to which recalcitrant cars are towed.

title: HIGHLY DESIRABLE DEAD-END JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheerleader, 16, Is Found Slain
description: The body of a 16-year-old high school cheerleader has been found in a wooded area in this Orange County town, officials said.

title: DANCE: MERCE CUNNINGHAM PRESENTS 'EVENT NO. 1'
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company presented ''Event No. 1 '' Thursday night at the City Center, which is another way of saying that some of the most unusual drama in the New York theater season came and went within a space of 105 minutes.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Korean Dissidents Burn A U.S. Mission in Pusan

title: MEXICO'S PEACE PROMOTER
description: Three days after Jorge Castaneda de la Rosa was named Foreign Minister in May 1979, Mexico broke diplomatic relations with the Nicaraguan Government of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle. It was not his doing, but it was an appropriate start to his job.

title: SCAVENGERS OF NEW YORK CITY'S TREASURY
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Is Said to Seek Help From 2 Senators
description: Aides to Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, denied today that he had agreed to introduce legislation to exempt the National Football League from antitrust laws in an effort to gain an expansion franchise for Phoenix.

title: Ex-Massachusetts Aide Starts Serving Sentence
description: The former Massachusetts Transportation Secretary entered a prison today after a judge refused to allow him to remain free while appealing his bribery-conspiracy conviction.

title: STEVENSON L. BARRETT
description: Stevenson L. Barrett, a conductor at the Chicago Lyric Opera and the Jacksonville (Fla.) Opera and a piano accompanist for Ezio Pinza, Rose Bampton, Eileen Farrell and other noted singers, died March 5 in New York. Mr. Barrett was born in Spokane, Wash., and reared in San Francisco. He taught voice privately in New York for many years.

title: WAVES OF ECONOMIC CHANGE BATTER FLAGSHIP OF UNIVERSITIES ON MICHIGAN
description: These are difficult times for the University of Michigan, a flagship of the country's public institutions. It raised itself to international prominence on the money and energy of a booming industrial economy, but its fortunes are now being shaken by the downturn that grips the state and the region.

title: REGAN SEES 'MAJOR' ADVANCE IN TWO-MAN GARBAGE TRUCKS
description: New York City's program of replacing the traditional three-man sanitation trucks with trucks needing only two workers is an ''impressive, major breakthrough'' in improving productivity that should save $7.7 million a year, according to a report by the State Comptroller.

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: England West to Stratford, south to Bath

title: The Nilometer
description: To the Editor:

title: CAN REAGAN CHANGE HIS TACTICS TO SUIT THE SEASON?
description: As the first zephyrs of spring brushed the Capital, it was a season of change at the White House, too. For one thing, the strategy of stalling the budget process until autumn, to force Congress to accept the large deficit proposed by the President has been set aside. Now, White House aides and the budget director, David A. Stockman, are passing the word - discreetly, so as not to alarm Mr. Reagan - that they want a compromise budget within the next few weeks.

title: Olson Vaults 18-8 3/4
description: Billy Olson of Abilene Christian broke the American outdoor record in the pole vault today with a vault of 18 feet 8 3/4 inches at the Bluebonnet Relays.

title: OPEC APPROVES CUT IN OIL PRODUCTION TO BOLSTER PRICES
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, moving to reduce the worldwide surplus of oil and bolster prices, agreed today to cut production by about 700,000 barrels a day. It was the first formal production agreement by the 13 OPEC members.

title: A New Look At Dinosaurs
