description: John Noble Wilford's article ''A New Look at Dinosaurs'' (Feb. 7) was highly interesting in reporting on new scientific thinking regarding the demise of dinosaurs. It also suggested a possible reason for the explosion of flowering plants (angiosperms) over the earth's surface since the end of the Cretaceous Period, roughly 65 million years ago.

title: THE LIFE OF A CONDOMINIUM COUPLE
description: ''THE Condominium Owners,'' that's what we're affectionately called by our relatives and our noncondominium owner friends. Why were we christened such an unusual name? Well, we're a young married couple who have consciously postponed assuming the financial responsibilities of raising children, and have, instead, elected to pool our entire two-income stash of savings into the purchase of a condominium.

title: FIFTH SEASON FOR MEHTA
description: The 1982-83 subscription season of the New York Philharmonic will open Sept. 16 with an all-orchestral program conducted by Zubin Mehta, musical director of the orchestra. Mr. Mehta, who will be starting his fifth year with the Philharmonic, will conduct 16 weeks during the 35-week season.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, secret agent Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 1 7 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 3 6 7 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $14.95.) A woman caught between the clashing ambitions of two brothers during the springtime of this century. 4 3 22 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 5 4 18 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 6 2 8 MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $13.95.) Blackford Oakes's quest for a mole in the C.I.A. takes him to Russia. 7 7 27 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 8 5 7 THE DEAN'S DECEMBER, by Saul Bellow.

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Portugal The Algarve's unhurried pace

title: Pryor an Unhappy Champion
description: Aaron Pryor cannot stop. The undefeated World Boxing Association junior welterweight champion warns that ''if things don't go right'' in his next two or three fights, he will retire.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Writers' clinic. You're a young writer from the Midwest whose autobiographical first novel about your relationship with your father has just been brought out by a respected hard-cover publisher. Several Big Literary Names have provided nice quotes for the jacket, and it's getting good reviews. What are its chances of being bought by a paperback house?

title: Television Week
description: Hands Across the Sea ''Q.E.D.'' is a novelty: a television series made in England with a British cast specifically for a commercial American network. Is is also Sam Waterston's first appearance in a TV adventure series.

title: State Deparment report, page 23.
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it had information that three months ago Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, ordered a step-up in arms shipments to insurgents in El Salvador in an effort to disrupt the March 28 elections there.

title: Jets' Representative Takes a Hard Line
description: Wearing a dark blue, three-piece suit and discussing real-estate deals while sitting in Buttle's, his restaurant on Hempstead Turnpike, Greg Buttle of the New York Jets hardly looked like a hard-line union leader.

title: THE PARADOXICAL PAPANDREOU
description: Nicholas Gage, a former New York Times correspondent, returned recently from Greece, where he headed The Times's Athens bureau in l977-80.By Nicholas Gage

title: Environews
description: ANEWLY FORMED chapter of the National Association of Atomic Veterans is trying to find some 9,000 men living in New Jersey who may have been exposed to radiation from nuclear weapons while in the armed services.

title: IT'S TIME TO FACE REALITY ON SCHOOL FUNDS
description: WHEN, in 1978, the New York State Supreme Court declared the state's system of financing education unconstitutional, the Governor did what politicians are wont to do: he appointed a committee. Its mission was to recommend a school financing method that would be ''constitutionally acceptable, fiscally responsible'' and conducive to quality education. Left unsaid, but understood by all who were appointed, was that the plan or plans also had to be politically acceptable or risk the fate of numerous other commission recommendations - the cynical sneer of the Legislature.

title: AN IDEOLOGICAL RETIANER
description: THE BRANDEIS/FRANKFURTER CONNECTION The Secret Political Activities of Two Supreme Court Justices. By Bruce Allen Murphy. 473 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: N.H. Walsh Will Marry Ellen Sherk
description: Mr. and Mrs. F. Allen Sherk of Branford, Conn., and Deering, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Bostwick Sherk, to Ens. Nicholas Holladay Walsh, U.S.C.G., son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Walsh of New York and Chappaquiddick, Mass.

title: OPERA: RAMEAU WORK STAGED IN PART AT PACE
description: New York's Rameau-opera weekend got under way Friday night at Pace University with a staged version of the Prologue and ''Les Incas du Perou'' from ''Les Indes Galantes'' by Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company. The final performance will take place this afternoon at 3, and at the same time in Town Hall Opera Rediviva will present the United States premiere of Rameau's ''Les Boreades,'' in concert form.

title: FREEPORT NUTURES A LEGACY
description: FIVE years after the formation of the Jose Limon Dance Company and 10 years after the death of its founder, Long Island will have an opportunity to sample the legacy left by the modern-dancer and choreographer when the company takes to the stage at Freeport High School next Saturday at 8 P.M.

title: FOOD
description: WHAT PRICE THE GLORY OF VEAL? here is, we are convinced, a definite hierarchy or pecking order for foods. Ground meat dishes - which rank high on our list of preferences - belong to the baser and lesser order of things. Veal - and again, this is highly subjective - ranks among the most aristocratic and sophisticated of meats.

title: Losing Sight of the Ball
description: We rise to denounce the charm of Ronald Reagan. The President's irrepressible cheer and courtesy take all the starch out of his social attitudes, and all the fun out of criticizing his policies.

title: VERSACE IS HAPPY IN THE N.I.T.
description: The first thing the Bradley basketball coach, Dick Versace, did when called upon to speak yesterday at Madison Square Garden was to pull a newspaper headline from his pocket that read: ''Bravo for the Big East.'' Then he put it back in his pocket and said:

title: Follow-Up on the News; High Rolling
description: Next to building housing in Atlantic City - and he was one of the largest developers of subsidized units - 62-year-old David Zarin liked to roll the ivories in one of the city's casinos. It was an example of practice not making perfect, however.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SEVILLE
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is chief of the Madrid bureau of The New York Times. BY JAMES M. MARKHAM

title:
Music;
YOUNG AUDIENCES TO OFFER SHOWCASE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK AFRICAN dances, mime, a brass quintet and a mini-carnival are just a few of the attractions that make up the Showcase of the Performing Arts, which will be presented here Saturday by Young Audiences of New Jersey.

title: The World; Turks Admit Torture Deaths
description: Many an authoritarian government has been accused of torturing its opponents, but few have felt a need to admit it. Last week, under strong pressure from West European countries and Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, the Government of Turkey confessed that, yes, 15 people in its custody had died of torture since the military took over 18 months ago.

title: OFF BROADWAY IS RIDING A CREATIVE SURGE
description: It is midnight on a Saturday night, and the cabaret at Palsson's Upstairs is crowded. The lights dim and the spotlight shimmers against the backdrop, a glittering curtain of tinsel. To the tune of ''It's Almost Like Being in Love,'' Gerard Alessandrini and Nora Mae Lyng deliver their verdict on Broadway's reliance on the tired old tried-and-true:

title: VIETNAMESE SAID TO OVERRUN CAMBODIAN BASE
description: An important anti-Communist guerrilla base at Sokh San, in Cambodia's Cardamom Mountains, has been overrun by Vietnamese troops, and thousands of Cambodian civilians have fled across the nearby border into Thailand, Western diplomats here said today.

title: The World; Bright Spot in Mideast Gloom
description: Despite some sticky moments, Israel and Egypt last week managed to keep the Sinai portion of their Camp David accords on track. Five weeks before the scheduled final handover of Sinai to Egypt, they couldn't agree on the last disputed yardage along frontiers originally drawn by Britain and Turkey in 1906.

title: MARGO A. RUBENSTEIN PLANS TO BE WED TO P.A. WINKLER
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Rubenstein have announced the engagement of their daugher, Dr. Margo Ann Rubenstein, to Peter Amil Winkler, son of Mrs. Jeanette B. Winkler of Phoenix, Ariz., and the late Charles Winkler.

title: Carolina Favored in Lacrosse
description: The lacrosse season has just begun, and by next weekend even the colleges and universities in the chilly north will have seen action. The teams are aiming at the final four spots in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament at the University of Virginia on May 29.

title: TENANT INSURANCE: HOW MUCH IS ENOUGH?
description: With the accelerating cost of personal belongings, the dramatic rise in burglaries and the broadening scope of damage and injury suits, many apartment renters are finding it increasingly necessary to purchase tenants' insurance and for much greater coverage than in the past.

title:
ANTIQUES 1840's;
FACT AND LEGEND OF WASHINGTON
description: HARTFORD IN the late 18th century, after the armies he led proved victorious, there were those who wanted to call him king and address him as Your Majesty. King George, however, was not the most popular title in the newly declared United States of America; George Washington chose instead to lead his new nation under the more republican title of President. More accustomed to handsome uniforms tailored to his own specification from fine English woolens faced with bright silk, he took the oath of office wearing a ''suit of plain brown clothes'' of Hartford manufacture.

title: 3 ARE HELD
description: Three New York City youths were arrested at gunpoint in Queens early yesterday after what the police called a predawn rampage of shooting and robbery in Queens and on Long Island that left two victims critically wounded.

title: ASSASSINS AND SLEUTHS
description: LABYRINTH By Taylor Branch and Eugene M. Propper. Illustrated. 623 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $17.95.

title: Clare J. Beverage To Be May Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald G. Beverage of Augusta, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Clare Joy Beverage, to Timothy R. Warner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Warner of Ferndale, Mich.

title: DESPITE CLOSING, HOPE IS STILL SEEN FOR EQUITY TROUPES IN COUNTY
description: EQUITY theater in the county may temporarily be a thing of the past because of the cancellation of the last three plays of the 1981-82 season of the Main Street Theater company in White Plains, Westchester's last Actors' Equity troupe. But that professional acting group's artistic director said he not only was encouraged about the future of theater as a whole in the county but also was extremely hopeful that the closing of his group would be temporary.

title: KLAN IS JEERED AT 2D MERIDEN RALLY
description: The Ku Klux Klan came to City Hall to demonstrate today, protected by 300 policemen, drowned out by scores of counter-demonstrators from two other groups and photographed as a curiosity by hundreds of onlookers.

title: THE RUMS OF THE ISLANDS
description: FRANK J. PRIAL is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times. By FRANK J. PRIAL

title: ENTREES WITH EXPERTISE
description: TO a casual observer La Marmite in Williston Park may seem the same as it has been for many years. It is not under new management and, except for an increase in the prices, the menu has hardly been revised at all. A change of chef about two years ago has made the difference.

title: Martha Paradis Wed to W.D. James
description: Martha Reid Paradis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Paradis of Washington, was married yesterday to W. Douglas James, son of Lucille Cassell James of Port Chester, N.Y., and the late William James. The Rev. Carl Nelson performed the ceremony in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: 1,800 ATTEND CONFERENCE TO AID DYSLEXIA
description: To many people who have the severest form of the language disability known as dyslexia, the task of reading a paragraph of print has been compared to making sense of alphabet soup or watching words explode on a page.

title: PUBLIC OPINION, TOO, IS RUNNING AGAINST THE WHITE HOUSE
description: ''Politics is like a love affair, and you can overplay your hand - we did it with Carter,'' observed John C. White, who as Democratic national chairman kept trying to mend the romance between President Carter and the American electorate. He, and others, failed.

title: 'FREEZE' BACKERS DEFEND CAMPAIGN
description: Jay Winik achieved in his article ''Campaign on Arms Freeze Is One-Sided'' (Opinion Page, Feb. 28) a masterpiece of doubletalk and tortured reasoning. He found a path to ''unilateral disarmament'' by envisioning such a public clamor for an end to the arms race that if Reagan or the Soviets should refuse to consider our modest proposal for a bilateral freeze, our leaders would not be able to cast the issue aside, but would have to accept unilateral disarmament. This is absurd. As is his conclusion that the clamoring itself is unilateral since we cannot possibly clamor equally in the Soviet Union. Charging that the Connecticut Freeze Campaign is undermining national security, it is as if, by this logic, even our desire to stop threatening each other with extinction will cause our extinction.

title: STATE FOSTER CARE TERMED A FAILURE AT HEARING
description: Judges, child-welfare advocates and city officials agreed at a hearing last week that the foster-care system in New York State is a failure. But there was little agreement over what to do about it.

title: THE COMPANY THAT STOPPED DETROIT
description: IN every direction, as far as the eye can see, the unmistakable imprint of Japan's largest auto maker is evident in this city that fittingly bears the company name.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Accent on the Caribbean KIMBLE MEAD

title: ABOUT ADOPTION
description: As the father of two adopted children, I found it as difficult to be objective in evaluating Alison Ward's arguments in favor of changes in our adoption laws as she obviously did in advancing them.

title: THE RIGHT HOUSE AT A RIGHT PRICE
description: Real estate brokers and homeowners are agreed that attractive houses can still be obtained in the metropolitan area at moderate prices.

title: SUGGESTIONS IN THE SEARCH FOR SOME CREDIBLE BOUTS
description: THE recent fare of professional boxing on television would lead even the casual observer to ask, ''What is going on here?'' In bouts within the last few weeks, Caveman Lee was dispatched by the first jab thrown by Marvellous Marv Hagler; Marcus Geraldo bathed ringsiders as he went down from a punch the former welterweight champion Thomas Hearns threw stepping backward, and Mustapha Wassaja, the No. 1 challenger, was battered for five rounds before the champion Michael Spinks put him away in the sixth in a light-heavyweight title bout.

title: Topic; ADVICE TO ALBANY; Three Speeds
description: Acting Justice Irving Green of Orange County should be remembered for teaching New Yorkers that they have a Legislature with three speeds: Fast, Slow and Motionless. Judge Green doesn't like Fast.

title: BETTING ON HORSES WITHOUT NAMES IN RACES YOU CAN'T SEE
description: TELL someone that you are a student of horse racing and the first thing he's apt to say is, ''Zat right? Who do ya like in the double?'' Venture to tell him that he has failed to understand, that you are serious about studying bloodlines that run all the way back through racing's effulgent past to the Byerley Turk (not a fez-capped gentleman, but one of the founding sires of the thoroughbred breed), and he will tell you he is serious about making payments on the washing machine and to the kids' orthodontist.

title: BLACK MARKET IN ARMS: STRICTLY CASH AND CARRY
description: WASHINGTON SALVADORAN guerrillas, denying Reagan Administration charges that they receive most of their military equipment from Cuba and Nicaragua, often say that they purchase supplies on the black market. ''We pay cash for weapons and ammunition in Europe, the Middle East and North America, just like everyone else,'' said Ruben Zamora, a rebel leader, in Mexico City recently. ''The problem isn't buying the arms, it's getting them transported to El Salvador.''

title: Westchester Journal
description: WHITE PLAINS bus riders who have been grumbling about the recent changes involving Routes 60 and 63 will have a chance tomorrow night to tell the county all about it.

title: AMERICA THE OBJECTIONABLE
description: TOWARDS A NEW COLD WAR Essays on the Current Crisis and How We Got There. By Noam Chomsky. 499 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $20.50. Paper, $8.95.

title: HAMMERING OUT COMPROMISE IS NEXT ON TRENTON'S AGENDA
description: After weeks of preparation, Governor Kean formally delivered his $6.37 billion budget to the New Jersey Legislature last week. Many in the State House, though, may have considered it only a rough draft.

title: Rebels Said to Defeat; Chad Government Force
description: Chad Government troops have suffered a serious setback in fighting against rebel forces led by the ousted Defense Minister, Hissen Habre, informed sources said today.

title:
Gardening;
THE RIGHT SOIL MENU FOR THE RIGHT DIET
description: BECAUSE the soils in which we grow our plants are often lacking in quantity or balance of nutrients, we must compensate by applying fertilizers.

title: SOUTHWEST: INDIAN COUNTRY
description: WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT is chief of the Denver bureau of The New York Times. By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

title: Indonesian Air Crash Kills 26
description: A P.T. Garuda Indonesia Airways jetliner with 28 people aboard crashed today at the Lampung Airport in South Sumatra, killing all but two people aboard, a spokesman for the state-owned airline said. There were no foreigners aboard, he said.

title: PRUNING ROSES NOW HOLDS THE PROMISE OF SUMMER'S BLOOM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Peter Malins is chief rosarian at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. BY PETER MALINS

title: Nancy Thomas Will Be Married May 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Grant Thomas of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Clarke Thomas, to James Addison Baker 4th, son of James A. Baker 3d of Washington and the late Mrs. Baker of Houston.

title: Joan Leslie Pavek Betrothed
description: Dorothy W. Silver of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Joan Leslie Pavek, to Joseph Leslie Overlock 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard J. Overlock of New Canaan, Conn. A June wedding is planned. The future bride is a daughter also of John D. Pavek of Eastchester, N.Y. Miss Pavek and Mr. Overlock are account executives with the New York advertising agencies of Young & Rubicam Inc., and Dancer, Fitzgerald, Sample, respectively.

title: The Society Of Jesus
description: I want to congratulate Paul Hofmann for his article ''The Jesuits'' (Feb. 14). The piece gave us a fine understanding of the order's relationship with Rome. I believe, though, that it is not possible to give an accurate picture of the Jesuits without going deeply into their tradition of education. I have been a student of the Jesuits, in high school and college, for seven years, and I say that these schools contain all the elements of the best schools - great teachers, stimulating atmosphere and good faculty.

title: JAZZ: CHET BAKER QUINTET
description: When Chet Baker first made himself known in the mid-1950's as a member of the Jerry Mulligan Quartet, he gave an impression of frailness and vulnerability - haunted eyes peering out of a shining choirboy face, a trumpet style that epitomized the hestitant, underplayed manner that characterized the California branch of cool jazz and a singing voice so small and thin and timorous that he could scarcely be heard even with a microphone.

title: TRANSLATING 'DEAD' LANGUAGES INTO LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Germany A hedonist's holiday in and around Munich

title: A CASE FOR REFUSE-DISPOSAL NO. 1
description: DISPOSAL of solid waste has been a critical problem in the county since 1952. Faced with the closing of municipal incinerators unable to meet the Clean Air Standards, many municipalities turned to the county for disposal of their garbage at the Croton dump. As this facility has neared saturation, the need for an economically and environmentally sound alternative has become imperative.

title: Madelyn C. Ross, Student Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert Ross of Syracuse, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madelyn Cameron Ross, to Spencer Stewart Griffith, son of Patricia Griffith, also of Syracuse, and the late Edwin Stewart Griffith.

title: Vanishing Trees In Huntington
description: The recent article ''The Tree That Defied the Storm'' (Opinion Page) was very interesting indeed. Ironically, I had just finished taking pictures and measurements of the remains of a giant tree trunk (five feet in diameter) that had supported a towering tree.

title: Food; NOW THAT SPRING IS HERE, STRAWBERRIES AND RHUBARB
description: ONCE strawberries, like pussy willows and crocuses, were a sure sign of spring. Now that they are in the market year-round, they are no longer the harbingers of warmer, brighter weather.

title: By Theodore W. Libbey; Music: Debuts in Review; Carlo Levi Minzi Plays Three Piano Sonatas
description: Carlo Levi Minzi, an Italian pianist, performed Beethoven's last three piano sonatas last Sunday afternoon in the Hunter College Playhouse under the auspices of the Lafayette Foundation for the Arts and Sciences. Mr. Minzi's interpretations departed in many ways from more conventional views of the music, particularly in matters of tempo. Although this proved illuminating in several instances, it undermined the pieces' structural and harmonic foundations at other points and left whole movements in a state of euphonious incoherence.

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AFC) - Signed eight free agents: Cleveland Crosby, defensive end; Joel Peters, defensive tackle; Gary Padjen, Bob Shupryt and Dave Simmons, linebackers; Bill Danehauer, offensive guard; Ken Dunek, tight end, and Sandro Vitiello, place-kicker.

title:
Speaking Personally;
ONCE GONE, YOU CAN'T GO HOME AGAIN
description: ASTRANGER came to my door on a recent morning. She was welldressed, middle-aged, smiling. She had been, she said, the original owner of the house, and she wanted to take a picture of ''her'' magnolia tree. Did I mind?

title: FOR A CHANGE WASHINGTON IS REACTING TO MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY FOR almost 50 years after the withdrawal of United States Marines from Central America, Mexico paid minimal attention to the region. When it looked south again, its support for leftist causes seemed to fit into a tradition of using foreign policy issues to assert its independence from the United States.

title: Another Way To Get to La Guardia
description: From Long Island points to La Guardia there is a cheaper, more dependable method than those mentioned in the recent article ''Travel to Airports: Costs Rise.'' It's the Long Island Rail Road.

title: WETLANDS OWNERS FIGHT STATE'S PRICE
description: BROOKHAVEN FOR 15 years, Michael Adams had a dream. A builder who lives in Dix Hills, Mr. Adams bought 13 acres in Blue Point with 830 feet of shoreline. He planned to build a motel and restaurant there with a swimming pool and jetties for the sailors to moor their boats while they dined. He also planned eventually to retire there with his wife, Nealy.

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Israel Three aspects of an ancient land

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Ireland Don't be afraid to drive on the left

title: Sound; MONEY NO OBJECT? A BUYER'S GUIDE TO LUXURIOUS COMPONENTS
description: ''Assuming your rich uncle died and left you an inheritance, what components would you buy?'' ''What rich uncle?'' I said. ''Never mind,'' my friend insisted. ''If money is no object, what would you pick?'' I had never thought about this seriously, being unable to imagine myself in a condition of reckless affluence. But when challenged to do so, I found it surprisingly easy to furnish fantasy with hardware. After all, the components are real enough, waiting in the shops for somebody with the right kind of checkbook. Still, the ingrained habit of comparing price against value stuck with me, and even on this imaginary journey into the land of luxury I found myself mainly contemplating components whose performance bore some evident relation to their high cost.

title: Kathe DeBole to Be Wed
description: Mrs. Raymond DeBole of New Hyde Park, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Kathe Anne DeBole, to Michael Christopher O'Grady Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Grady of the Bronx.

title: The World; A Few Friends From Moscow
description: Sometimes even Moscow's courtesy calls can be disconcerting. Indian leaders at Delhi Airport last week were surprised to discover that Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister they had gone to meet, was traveling with 15 other high-ranking Soviet military officers, including the naval and air chiefs and a number of lieutenant-general and major-general types.

title: THANK YOU, DEAR ISLAND
description: THE early sun is streaming in the window, and faintly, off in the distance, there's the roar of the ocean. A couple of birds hop across my deck and peer at me through the sliding glass doors, then take off into the cedars behind our house. Morning in East Hampton ... how I love it.

title: 'Reaganville' Folds Up After 4-Month Protest
description: Nine tents that had been set up in Lafayette Park across the street from the White House were taken down today, ending a four-month protest against the Reagan Administration's economic policies.

title: DEMOCRATS ASKING HELP FOR FARMERS
description: The days of the Great Depression and Herbert Hoover are being recalled with increasing frequency as Democrats in Congress seek to come in first in the race to do the most for the farmer.

title: No Headline
description: letter Scheme for Evacuation Is Fantasy at Best

title: KATHERINE IHLE BETROTHED TO HAROLD J. SWEENEY JR.
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur William Ihle of Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Frances Ihle, to Harold Joseph Sweeney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sweeney of Sea Girt, N.J.

title: REPAIRING OR REPLACING CERAMIC TILE: SOME TIPS ON CUTTING
description: WHEN making repairs to a ceramic tile wall, or when replacing some missing or damaged tiles, the do-it-yourselfer will often find it necessary to cut tiles to fit against the top of a sink or tub, or to fit into a corner floor joint. Cutting a tile may also be necessary when fitting it around a wall-mounted faucet or fixture of some kind. If there are a large number of tiles to be cut (for example, when doing an entire wall) then it would probably be worth while renting one of the special tile-cutting machines that are available from most local dealers. However, when there are only a few tiles to be cut as part of a repair or remodeling job, then the only tool required is an ordinary glass cutter - preferably a new one that has not been used very much so that the steel cutting wheel is still quite sharp. To guide the glass cutter in making a straight cut, you should use a ruler or straightedge of some kind. Better yet, use a small square if you want the cut piece to have a truly square corner. Then, holding the glass cutter almost vertical between the first two fingers and with your thumb pressing against the back side of the handle, draw the cutting wheel across the glazed surface of the tile with a single firm stroke, bearing down with a moderate but steady pressure all the while. Do not go back and forth over this score mark - go over the line of cut only once with the cutting wheel. If you go over the scored line more than once with the cutter the break will be ragged and the glazed face will likely show chip marks. After scoring, place the tile, face up, over a piece of dowel or a large bolt so that the score mark is directly over it. Then press down hard on both sides of the cut line as shown in the accompanying drawing. The tile should snap cleanly in two along the scored line. If any rough edges do result, these can be smoothed with a medium-cut file or with an abrasive stone. A file can also be used for final trimming to fit if the cut is slightly oversize, as well as to cut shallow notches or grooves in the edge when required to insure a snug fit. However, when sizable notches or grooves are required, or when a tile must be cut to fit around a curved projection (such as water pipes or faucets), then a different technique is used. First, use the glass cutter to score a curved line following the contour that you want the tile to fit against, then use the glass cutter again to score a number of closely spaced crisscross marks over the section that is to be removed. Next, use a pair of heavy pliers with straight jaws, or a pair of end-cutting nippers, to ''nibble'' away the scored section of tile, breaking away one small piece at a time until you have removed all the waste inside the scored outline. Final smoothing can be done (if necessary) by using a half-round file or round abrasive stone. Answering the Mail Q. I have a steep concrete driveway that has been undermined by mole tunnels, as well as by washouts that occurred after several heavy rains. As a result, the driveway has cracked in several places and there are many hollows under it. Is there any way these hollows can be filled in without having to replace the entire driveway? -G.H., Selden, L.I. A. I seriously doubt it. In some cases where there are minor washouts under a concrete slab you can dig down alongside it, then pack sand and gravel in from the side and backfill with earth, but from your description I think you will have to break up the old driveway in order to fill in the ground under it properly. The broken pieces of concrete can be used as fill, however, in the larger holes and cavities. Make sure you get rid of the moles before you go ahead with pouring the new concrete, and use at least four to six inches of sand and gravel to put down a good solid base under the new concrete before you pour it. Q. My dining room has painted wood paneling on the walls. I want to cover the part above the chair rail with wallpaper, leaving the paneling as is under the chair rail. However, owing to the grooves in the paneling, I have been told that before wallpaper can be put over it I would first have to apply a special lining of heavy vinyl that is made for covering cinder blocks prior to papering. This heavy vinyl material would cost more than the paper I intend to put on over it! Would it be practical to fill in the grooves with caulking or putty instead? -C.L.Z., Morris Plains, N.J. A. Caulking and putty would both be impractical; they do not dry hard, and would be difficult to smooth down properly anyway. A wood putty (powdered) or a plastic patching compound could probably be used, but this would be a quite a job and I have my doubts as to how smooth you could get the surface (bumps or ridges would show through the paper). I think your best bet may be to nail up a thin layer of hardboard first. Give this a coat of alkyd primer sealer, or shellacbase sealer, then hang your paper over this.

title: DORIS HUDSON AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Don Patrick Hudson of Charlotte, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Doris Ann Hudson, to Warren Edward Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis David Hart of Saddle River, N.J. A May 22 wedding is planned. Miss Hudson and her fiance are marketing representatives with International Business Machines.She workes in Charlotte, and her fianc is with the Cranford, N.J.,branch.

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: France High mountains and haute cuisine

title: Stage Reviewer Beaten
description: Reinvested, a 10-1 shot, took the lead at the stretch and withstood a challenge from Stage Reviewer, the 8-5 favorite, today to win the $66,900 Budweiser Derby for 3-year-olds at Tampa Bay Downs.

title: Mailbox; The Pressures Of Football
description: To the Sports Editor: Many thanks to The New York Times and Dave Anderson and George Vecsey for their columns on college athletics (The New York Times, Feb. 7, 1982).

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Greece Athens and a few days in Peloponnesus

title: A PAIR OF PRESIDENTS AT DIOR AND CHANEL
description: They don't seem to have much in common, the blond young woman of Russian-French heritage from Piqua, Ohio, and the dark-haired daughter of Italian immigrants from Sea Girt, N.J. One is reserved, happily married and hopes to have children; the other is ebullient and happily single.

title: LE GRAND NOSH DE PARIS
description: MIMI SHERATON is the restaurant critic of The New York Times. BY MIMI SHERATON

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Turkey In Istanbul, echoes of Byzantium

title:
Economic Affairs;
A MAP FOR THE ROAD FROM DUNKIRK
description: FIFTEEN months ago, a memorandum to President-elect Ronald Reagan f rom advisers David Stockman and Jack Kemp warned of a G.O.P. E conomic Dunkirk - an economy of high unemployment, volatile f inancial markets and a budget hemorrhage. Their warning was p rescient, for the policies of the Reagan Administration, conceived t o avoid just such a scenario, have indeed driven the economy to the b eaches of Dunkirk.

title: DEATH TOLL AT 27 IN CRASH OF ILLINOIS AIR GUARD JET
description: Search crews tramping through snowy fields on foot and on horseback today recovered the bodies of all 27 persons killed when a military jet crashed in a ball of fire Friday night.

title:
Gardening;
THE RIGHT SOIL MENU FOR THE RIGHT DIET
description: BECAUSE the soils in which we grow our plants are often lacking in quantity or balance of nutrients, we must compensate by applying fertilizers.

title: THE MOBILITY OF CAPITAL DISPERSES UNIONS' POWER
description: As this winter's contract talks between the United Automobile Workers and General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company demonstrated, American labor unions have hit difficult times - and the recession is not the only cause. For the unions, there was another, possibly more far-ranging factor implicit in the negotiations: the internationalization of work and the movement of jobs from America to foreign countries.

title: ART FROM THE ANCIENT SILK ROUTES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Audrey Topping is the author of ''The Splendors of Tibet.'' BY AUDREY TOPPING

title: The Region; City Planners Urge Going West - A Few Blocks
description: The streets of Manhattan's East Side may be paved with gold but the real estate boom has left many of its sidewalks dark and crowded. To steer developers west and south, the City Planning Commission last week overhauled midtown zoning regulations for the first time in 20 years.

title: Ideas and Trends; Nestle Yields On Formula Code
description: Responding to pressure from national and international organizations, Nestle S.A., which supplies 60 percent of the world's infant baby formula, last week agreed to comply with the International Code on the Marketing of Breast Milk Substitutes, which restricts the promotion of bottle feeding.

title: Leonard James Colamarino Marries Katrin B. Brenner
description: Katrin Belenky Brenner, a lawyer and assistant secretary of the Olivetti Corporation in Tarrytown, N.Y., was married at the New York Society for Ethical Culture yesterday to Leonard James Colamarino, an associate with the New York law firm of Christy & Viener. Robert Berson, a leader of the Society, officiated.

title: HILL-COUNTRY PROJECT SEEN AS HARBINGER
description: BEDMINSTER TOWNSHIP ASIZABLE new community is rising out of the bucolic foothills of the Watchung Mountains. The community - it will occupy an area surrounded by rich farmland and imposing estates - is one that social planners believe heralds a coming economic boom for New Jersey and a dramatic shift in the state's economic landscape.

title: Ideas and Trends; Argentina's Penguin Flap
description: Everybody loves a penguin, but not always for the obvious reason that penguins are cute. In Argentina, the birds have become the focus of a bitter controversy since a meat-processing company proposed to slaughter 48,000 of them a year to produce protein food concentrate.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE They now call their company the Bowyer and Bruggeman American Ballet Comedie but they are still just plain JoAnn Bruggeman and Bob Bowyer, a hilarious team that decided some years ago to put the fun back into dance. The duo has been augmented by five other dancers and several new works for an engagement this week at the downstairs Space at the City Center.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: LIMITS signs, telling youngters that they are not welcome during school hours, are sprouting up in store windows in downtown Newark. The signs are part of the city's crackdown on truants.

title: CITY URGED TO SELL BUILDINGS IT OWNS TO THEIR OCCUPANTS
description: The anticipated auctioning of occupied, New York City-owned buildings would, over time, cost the taxpayers twice as much as selling the buildings to their tenants and would result in greater displacement of the poor, according to a study by a nonprofit group that aids tenants in city-owned structures.

title: THRIFTY PLAY AREAS BUILT FROM CASTOFFS
description: TORRINGTON ZANDY THOMPSON calls his concept ''planting a playground,'' a process that he likens to an old-fashioned barn raising. It is a way, he said, for a community to get together in a ''labor of love,'' save money and end up with a playground for children.

title: Sarah T. Parnell To Marry Kenneth W. Hirsch
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Parnell of Littleton, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Tillson Parnell, to Kenneth William Hirsch, son of Mrs. Kenneth Michael Gang of Purchase, N.Y., and the late Dr. Donald Robert Hirsch.

title: PLAYLAND INSTITUTES CHANGES FOR SEASON
description: IN an effort to convert last year's $2.6 million operating loss into a profit, Playland officials have announced a new admissions policy and other changes for the season this year.

title: Topics Advice to Albany; Protections
description: For most parents, bearing children means assuming, along with a grave responsibility, a chain of worries. As the years change so do the worries, and perhaps the most tortured arrive with adolescence.

title: HIGH SOVIET OFFICIAL UNSEEN IN WEEKS
description: Andrei P. Kirilenko, once considered a possible successor to Leonid I. Brezhnev, has been absent from official duties for several weeks, and some reports say deteriorating health has eliminated him from active politics.

title: COURT BIDS LAWYERS TO TAKE CASES FREE FOR POOR IN DIVORCE
description: IN 1974, State Supreme Court Justice Joseph F. Gagliardi ruled that a lawyer could not be compelled to take a case without fee. Such a court order assigning counsel without compensation, he wrote, would violate a lawyer's constitutional right to due process of law.

title: OPERATIC TENORS WHO COURT POP SUCCESS
description: RCA's five-disk anthology of recordings by Mario Lanza, entitled ''The Mario Lanza Collection'' (CRM5-4158), will be of solace to the late American tenor's fans; indeed, this selection was partially based on a poll of Lanza fan clubs in the United Kingdom. But it also provides an opportunity to reconsider the voice and career of this remarkable, and remarkably misused, talent.

title: The Answer to Freeze Is SALT
description: As spring arrives, the talk is of freeze. Leonid Brezhnev proposes a nuclear freeze for all Europe. Senators Kennedy and Hatfield, leading 150 members of Congress, would have the freeze cover the world. They are all responding to the millions of people in Europe and the United States who wonder why the competition to build nuclear arms, threatening life everywhere, cannot simply stop. The freeze is a simplistic diplomatic formula to rally or appease that sentiment. But it is neither simple nor innocent.

title: Crafts; SACRED ART: ITS PROBLEMS DIFFER FROM THE SECULAR
description: AT BEST, art in a religious environment gives tangible form to awesomeness. At worst, it repeats stale symbols that have lost their force from overuse.

title: 'MEPHISTO' TRACKS THE DARK ASCENT OF A NAZI COLLABORATOR
description: In the strange manner of life, this is the the story of two actors whose lives are intertwined, though they never met -intertwined in the creation of a movie that opens today at Cinema I, trailing such laurels as an Academy Award nomination for best foreign film and the award for best screenplay at last year's film festival in Cannes.

title: Ex-Officer Gets 15-Year Term
description: A former Passaic police officer has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for plotting an armed robbery of a supermarket employee under police escort in which two other officers are accused of taking part. The former officer, Stefano Mazzola, 38 years old, of Passaic, was released Friday on $50,000 bail pending appeal.

title: THE EXECUTIVES WHO ARE HOOKED ON SQUASH
description: TO Michael Desaulniers, the phrase, ''on the floor'' has two d istinct meanings. It can mean the floor of the New York Commodities E xchange, where he is a broker with N.C.Z. Commodities, or it can be t he floor of a squash court, where he is the No. 1 player in North A merica, according to the World Professional Squash Association. Bothp laces are integral to his life, he says, and both are similar.

title: ABOUT ADOPTION
description: I read the Ward opinion article with anger, amazement and curiosity. I am one of the individuals in the adoption triangle, the child's ''real'' mother. I am the one who has all the joys and pains involved in raising a child. It is of my child and family that Alison Ward is speaking.

title: OWNER'S DREAM COMES TRUE
description: The top 3-year-old colt in California is a one-eyed claustrophobic. The leading Kentucky Derby prospect in Florida was a $13,500 yearling bought by two butchers from Boston. But next to Shimatoree, the leading Derby hopeful in New York, their backgrounds are positively mundane.

title: Krizaj of Yugoslavia Wins Cup Slalom Race
description: Bojan Krizaj of Yugoslavia achieved his first World Ski Cup victory of the season today, defeating Ingemar Stenmark by four-hundredths of a second in a slalom race.

title: 'FREEZE' BACKERS DEFEND CAMPAIGN
description: In his criticism of the Connecticut Freeze Campaign, Jay Winick makes a major compound error when he claims, ''The campaign ignores ...the unprecedented Soviet nuclear buildup that goes far beyond their defensive needs....'' In the first place, the Soviet nuclear buildup was not unprecedented. In every new development of nuclear arms -A-bomb, H-bomb, ICBMs, MIRVs, etc.

title: EDUCATORS EXAMINE PROGRAMS ON ARTS
description: PURCHASE REPRESENTATIVES from school districts in the metropolitan area gathered recently at a conference devoted to arts education to examine individual school efforts, including the programs run by schools in White Plains and New Rochelle. ''Budget limitations are a fact of life,'' explained Shirley Contino, the arts-in-education coordinator for the Council for the Arts in Westchester, ''and the emphasis is now on sharing information and finding alternative ways of making programs work.''

title: CANADIANS ASSAIL PARLIAMENT RULES
description: The two-week paralysis of Parliament that ended this week led to calls on all sides of the House of Commons for a revision of the procedures of what a prominent member termed a ''sick'' institution.

title: KENYA CLOSES DRAMA GROUP TIED TO A FOE
description: The Kenyan authorities have banned a small theater group in what appears to be a continuing campaign against a writer critical of the Government.

title: THE QUIET PLEASURES OF HARBOUR ISLAND
description: TAD SZULC, a former Times correspondent, is a writer who lives in Washington. By TAD SZULC

title: Iran Reports Crushing Rebels of the Fedayeen
description: The Teheran radio said today that Iranian Revolutionary Guards had crushed the leftist Fedayeen Khalq during raids in which 40 top guerrilla leaders were captured and eight rebels were killed.

title: Film View; WHODUNITS-THE FINE ART OF DOING THEM WELL
description: In its short, perfunctory entry on Agatha Christie, the Columbia Encyclopedia (second edition) states that after the publication of ''The Mysterious Affair at Styles'' in 1920, Miss Christie went on to write a number of other books featuring Hercule Poirot, the Belgian detective, ''among them 'The Murder of Roger Ackroyd,' famous for its unexpected ending.'' Miss Christie, later to become Dame Agatha, wrote many, many books, most of them immensely popular and famous for their unexpected endings.

title: STUDENT AID URGED TO OFFSET CUTS
description: IN REDDING and Wilton, local newspapers have editorialized strongly in favor of continued student aid. In Easton and New Canaan, legislators have virtually been buried under letters and phone calls pleading for action. And in Hartford, liberals and conservatives have lined up with administrators from private and public colleges behind proposals that could make Connecticut the third state to establish special bonding authorities for student aid. Illinois and Massachusetts have also approved such programs.

title: 'FREEZE' BACKERS DEFEND CAMPAIGN
description: Jay Winik's contention that the Connecticut arms freeze campaign is one-sided and advocates unilateral disarmament is simply untrue. Every statement, every activity of the freeze campaign calls strongly for a mutual, bilateral freeze.

title: REINCARNATION AND ANNIHILATION
description: THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC By Robert Ludlum. 630 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95. By EVAN HUNTER

title: Post Wins in Lacrosse
description: C.W. Post's lacrosse team made a successful debut on the Division I level with a season-opening 9-8 victory over Yale today.

title: THE SOCIETY OF JESUS
description: Opus Dei is, as Paul Hofmann states, distinguished for its ''bedrock fidelity'' to the teachings of the Holy See.

title: DEALING WITH ISRAEL
description: The Reagan Administration has an outstanding talent for dealing with Israel incorrectly.

title: THE WAY IT WAS, THE WAY IT IS
description: SHE sits in an armchair that dwarfs her small body, supported by hand-embroidered pillows that engulf her delicate frame and make her seem frailer. She has been sick for several days now and unable to eat much.

title: Jane Goldstein Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer D. Goldstein of Merrick, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Beth Goldstein, to Ronald Jay Jackson, son of Dorothy J. Jackson of Niagara Falls, N.Y., and the late Frederick Jackson. A June wedding is planned. Miss Goldstein is manager of sales promotion for Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., in New York. Mr. Jackson, a former Republican committeeman for the County of Niagara, is a business sales representative with Liberty Mutual Insurance Company in New York.

title: KATE R. ZAMMIT TO BE JUNE BRIDE
description: Mrs. Bruce E. Wallis of New York and Sarasota, Fla., and James H. Righter of Amherst, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kate Righter Zammit, to James A. Gardner of Sarasota, son of Dr. and Mrs. Karl E. Gardner of Tolono, Ill.

title: CONGRESS GIVES STATE LAWMAKERS A TAX BREAK
description: Past and present state legislators stand to save thousands of dollars each on their Federal income taxes under a new law tailored specifically to them by Congress.

title:
CAMERA;
PLANNING HELPS WHEN PHOTOGRAPHING SPORTS
description: Taking pictures of school sports and athletic events can be a rewarding and worthwhile experience for the photographer who is looking for new fields to conquer. However, in order to do this, you should try to arrange ahead of time for permission to move into or near the playing area. This can be done through an athletic department official or the school's administration office.

title: PUBLIC TEST FOR G.O.P. HOPEFULS
description: FAIRFIELD ONLY 17 of the 933 delegates to the Republican State Convention in July will be chosen here on Tuesday, but the party's candidates for United States Senate and Governor are treating the town of Fairfield as if it were New Hampshire in a Presidential election year.

title: Sports People; Nehemiah Tries Out
description: Renaldo Nehemiah is apparently looking for new hurdles to clear. Nehemiah, who holds the world outdoor record in the 110-meter hurdles, has had tryouts as a wide receiver with the Philadelphia Eagles and the Washington Redskins, and says he is trying to line up a few more.

title: Cigars
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''The Curse on Cigars'' (March 14), far from the bleak outlook portrayed, cigar sales in 1981 were the most promising in more than 10 years. Units sold totaled 3.9 billion and dollar sales rose for the second straight year.

title: Headliners; A Treasure Uncovered
description: Many of his readers may have come to suspect they were chasing a wild goose, not a gold filigreed rabbit. But artist Kit Williams really did bury a five-inch, jewel-studded hare just where hundreds of clues sprinkled throughout his best-selling children's fable, ''Masquerade,'' indicated it would be.

title: HAWAII ACTS TO CURB TIME-SHARED APARTMENTS
description: The developers of time-sharing apartments, a type of vacation home that became popular in Hawaii in the 1970's, are under attack here, accused of using harassing sales tactics and not keeping promises.

title: Nancy L. Davis Will Wed May 29
description: Dr. and Mrs. Luther Davis of Wayland, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Locke Davis, to Stuart Ashton McCrary, son of Dr. W. Ashton McCrary of Lake City, Iowa, and Marilyn F. McCrary of Des Moines.

title: THE HEAT'S ON MORGAN STANLEY
description: WHEN Morgan Stanley & Company, the most prestigious of investment banks, looks to its roots, it sees the industrial financier J. Pierpont Morgan, whose own American ancestry dates to 1636. An offspring of the House of Morgan, Morgan Stanley has grown rich as the banker to blue chip corporate America, with a client list that is the envy of Wall Street.

title: Practical Traveler; AIR FARES AT DEEPER DISCOUNTS
description: It is becoming increasingly possible for Americans to obtain air tickets, hotel rooms, cruise space and places on package tours for substantially less than the lowest advertised rates.

title: The World; More Talking and Dying for Namibia
description: Negotiations for self-rule in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, have been making progress, United States officials say. They said they have established a good working relationship with South Africa and last month, the Administration welcomed a South African general to Washington.

title: Reagan Calls on Soviet To Leave Afghanistan
description: President Reagan, in a statement marking the Afghan New Year, called on the Soviet Union today to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan and ''end this needless conflict.''

title: Lebanon Plans Special Force To Guard Foreign Embassies
description: The Lebanese Cabinet, concerned over kidnappings and threats against foreign diplomats, decided today to form a special force to help protect embassies against bombings, rocket attacks and other violence.

title: NAMIBIA REBELS ASK TALKS WITH SOUTH AFRICA
description: Guerrillas fighting for the independence of South-West Africa have called for an immediate conference with South Africa, Angop, the official Angolan news agency, reported today.

title: HIGHBROW MUSIC TO HUM
description: . Music does not require a ''good tune'' to be enjoyed and understood.

title: NETS LOSE TO PACERS AS LATE RALLY FAILS
description: Ray Williams's 3-point attempt fell short at the buzzer, ending the Nets' comeback attempt and giving the Indiana Pacers a 104-101 victory at Market Square Arena tonight.

title: REAGAN'S FIRST FRIEND'
description: Steven V. Roberts is a reporter in The Times's Washington bureau who specializes in covering Congress. By Steven V. Roberts The scene was familiar: The White House driveway. Banks of cameras and microphones. Three Republican leaders, grim-faced, emerging from a meeting with the President. Shouted questions, careful answers. And the next day, big headlines: Congressional leaders tell the President they need ''running room'' to revise his budget.

title: Prost Wins the Pole
description: Alain Prost of France, in a turbocharged Renault, won the pole position today for Sunday's Brazilian Grand Prix auto race. His time over the 3.125-mile Jacarepagua track was 1 minute 28.808 seconds, for an average speed of 126.723 miles an hour.

title: SOTHBY TROUBLES SHAKE ART WORLD
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet's cutbacks in staff and the closing of one of its auction houses in London have sent shock waves through the art and auction world in New York.

title: Other Business; WHAT TO ASK AT AN ANNUAL MEETING
description: It's annual meeting time again, the season for corporations and their shareholder-owners to sit down and communicate. It is a time for public relations operatives and companies' auditors to prepare management for what to expect in the way of shareholder questions.

title: CAN MENTAL PATIENTS SAY NO TO DRUGS?
description: Paul S. Appelbaum, M.D., is assistant professor of psychiatry and law at the University of Pittsburgh and co-author of the forthcoming ''Clinical Handbook of Psychiatry and Law.'' By Paul S. Appelbaum

title: HOVAS BETTER OREGON STATE BY 69-45
description: Georgetown was favored by a point over Oregon State today in the N.C.A.A. West Regional final, and Coach John Thompson of Georgetown said he was very nervous the night before because he, like everyone else, expected a close game.

title: 'FREEZE' BACKERS DEFEND CAMPAIGN
description: As the nuclear freeze campaign attracts more attention, as the number of petitioners increases, and as more and more governmental bodies pass freeze resolutions, the voices of the opponents become shriller and their arguments more hackneyed and standardized.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
POET SPEAKS ANEW IN A MUSICAL
description: BROOKVILLE UNTIL January when they started rehearsing ''Bird on the Wire,'' a musical being given its premiere during C.W. Post's American Arts Festival this week, few of the seven students involved in the production had even heard of Leonard Cohen, the poet and songwriter whose works are the basis of the cabaret piece.

title: AUTO PAINTER'S SUIT SAYS HE WAS POISONED ON JOB
description: For five years Kevin Novinger, a 31-year-old former automobile spray painter, has spent his days, and lately some of his nights, on the living room sofa of his home in Camp Hill, a suburb of the Pennsylvania capital here.This happens when the sedation he takes for pain lets him sleep. Otherwise, he is bedridden.

title: BREZHNEV'S MISSILE FREEZE IS STILL FAR FROM A THAW
description: PARIS LEONID I. Brezhnev gave another push to the new round of nuclear diplomacy last week with the announcement that the Soviet Union would deploy no more medium-range missiles in its western territories so long as the United States didn't proceed with plans to place new missiles in Western Europe.

title: ANTITRUST LAW IN NEED OF A MIDSTREAM FIX
description: To the Editor:

title: MANAGING AND MARKETING THE SHUTTLE
description: Cape Canaveral, Fla. - Preparations for the third flight of the space shuttle Columbia, which was scheduled to begin tomorrow, have followed a familiar pattern. A large Government team of administrators and technicians, supported by private contractors, has ministered to the spaceship since it returned from its last flight in November. When the engines ignite for liftoff, firing-room crews from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, who have directed preparatory activities here at the launch site, will hand over Columbia to Mission Control in Houston, where several hundred space agency engineers will handle operations the rest of the way.

title:
Numismatics;
EGLIT MEDAL COLLECTION TO BE SOLD IN THREE STAGES
description: The late Nathan Eglit of Chicago was known to fellow numismatists as a leading authority on medallic art and the author of numerous articles on the subject. Less well known is the scope of his personal collection of medals, but in a series of upcoming sales the extent of that collection will soon become apparent to the hobby.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Nixon and History
description: Votaries of history in San Clemente, Calif., where Richard M. Nixon had a villa when he was President, opened a museum in January 1981 dedicated to his Presidency. Within 11 months the museum, called A Bit of History, was out of business.

title: MONETARISM IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON IN the heady days just after her ascension in May 1979, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher proclaimed loudly and widely her faith in the notion that strict control of a single monetary statistic would go a long way toward producing less inflation and more economic growth.

title: NICARAGUANS FIND IT HARD TO BELIEVE WARNING THEY'RE FACING WAR AGAIN
description: Nicaraguans are responding to the Government's warning of an imminent American-backed invasion with a sense of disbelief mixed with a kind of precautionary panic. Many people here also seem to have suspended judgment on whether the Government's 30-day state of emergency is justified.

title: Method Used In Conducting Poll
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from March 11 through March 15 with 1,545 people around the United States.

title: Mailbox; Labor's Impact On Baseball in '46
description: To the Sports Editor: Happy Chandler's reminiscences about his baseball commissionership certainly make for good reading. The actions of the baseball owners in their inner sanctum have usually been as top secret as National Security meetings so it is illuminating to have Mr. Chandler tell us how he moved to thwart a player union in 1946 with an all-America ally, and how he planned to use a substitute team headed by Frankie Frisch and Honus Wagner in case of a strike.

title: CRITICISM IS MUTED ON ENERGY MEASURE
description: TRENTON ABILL containing a provision that could force the Public Service Electric and Gas Company to abandon its Hope Creek I nuclear-plant project in Salem County received surprisingly muted criticism last week from a high-ranking executive of the utility.

title: POWER AND FRIENDSHIP
description: THE END OF AN ALLIANCE James F. Byrnes, Roosevelt, Truman, and the Origins of the Cold War. By Robert L. Messer. 292 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $19.95.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Vanishing Breed PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: National Guard at 400,000
description: The Army National Guard reached a strength of 400,964 at the end of last month, its highest total in seven years, the Pentagon announced Friday.

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER Off Broadway is a mini-A. R. Gurney Jr. festival these days. Mr. Gurney's latest play, ''The Dining Room,'' is to be found at Playwrights Horizons, and an earlier one, ''The Middle Ages,'' is holding forth at The Ark Theater Company in SoHo. Though neither play is perfect, they both reveal this writer's special talent and mission. Mr. Gurney unearths the absurd humor and choked anguish that comes with being a privileged WASP in a modern America that no longer looks upon preppies and debutantes with awe.

title:
Music View;
IS MOZART'S LIFE IN HIS MUSIC?
description: In the arts, the best arguments are the ones that no one ever wins. A pair of newly published biographies of Janacek dramatize anew the dispute over whether or to what extent the expressive content of a piece of music may be tied to specific events in a composer's daily life. In other words, was Mozart feeling sad when he composed his unfinished Requiem? Probably, since he was dying at the time and seems to have known it. Can the stormy anger that one hears in certain of Beethoven's middle piano sonatas be traced to his realization that he was going deaf? Again, probably. Common sense would argue that such connections, while anything but invariably tight, do often exist. And yet you know, of course, that many musical estheticians do not agree. They would dismiss these notions as vulgar distortions of Romanticism, fit only to be used as test questions in music-appreciation courses.

title: Bold Style Wins Rebel By a Nose at Oaklawn
description: Bold Style scored his third straight victory as a 3-year-old by defeating Majesty's Prince by a nose today in the $85,700 Rebel Handicap at Oaklawn Park.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES BILL ON OIL POWERS
description: President Reagan, in a politically risky defense of free-market principles, today vetoed a bill giving him authority to allocate oil and control prices if there was a ''severe'' fuel emergency.

title: WESTCHESTER TO TAKE VISA PAYMENTS FOR SUPPORT AND ALIMONY
description: Child-support, spouse-support and alimony payments can be made by Visa credit cards, beginning Monday, under an agreement between Westchester County and the Bank of New York.

title: A FUTILE SOVIET HOPE OF PREVAILING IN IRAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Hicks Bride Of Peter Wheelwright
description: Elizabeth Stuyvesant Hicks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Livingston Hicks of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Matthiessen Wheelwright, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Jefferds Wheelwright of Camden, Me. The Rev. William McLennon, a Unitarian minister of Dorchester, Mass., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Robert Winthrop Kean in Livingston, N.J.

title: IN CRASH AFTERMATH, WHAT CHECKS ON TEEN-AGERS?
description: IN a community where a license to drive is a badge of maturity and a passport to freedom, it was every suburban parent's worst nightmare: teen-agers out for an evening of fun, a few drinks, some driving and a gamble on beating a train to a grade-level crossing.

title: The Conservatives' 'Sad Contradiction'
description: Frank Lynn's recent report that local Conservative leaders serve in patronage jobs given them by the G.O.P. (Politics column) raises serious questions regarding the real purposes of the Conservative Party. The Conservative Party was originally founded in the early 60's to counteract the leftward drift of the state Republican organization under Nelson Rockefeller. It was explicitly a check on the Republican Party, not an arm of the G.O.P.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor: Mr. Apple left out the Catellin Restaurant - a noisy, inexpensive and memorable fish restaurant with its own illustrated cookbook - in the Old Town of Stockholm.

title: CONCERT: ST. LOUIS SYMPHONY
description: The 20th century has expressed its agonies and apprehensions in many ways, and the St. Louis Symphony had two artifacts from this age of anxiety to share with its listeners at Carnegie Hall Friday night.

title: BRIEF ENCOUNTER, AFTER HALF A CENTURY
description: CHILDREN treasure ''Horton Hatches the Egg,'' the endearing Dr. Seuss classic about a maternally minded elephant that elects to hatch an untended egg. To Dr. Betty Allen of Paramus, an adoptee, her birth had about as much reality.

title: PSYCHEDELIC ROCK: IRISH U2 QUARTET
description: Among the half-dozen or so bands from the British Isles that have led a revival of droning psychedelic rock in the last two years, the Irish quartet, U2, is both the youngest and the most talented. Reducing the incantatory style of the Byrds and the Velvet Underground to a resounding two-chord minimalism, the group creates intense churchy sonorities driven at a headlong pace by the drummer, Larry Mullen.

title: SOME SIGHTS AND SOUNDS OF SPRINGTIME
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. MICKEY MANTLE poked his head out of the New York Yankees' locker room in Fort Lauderdale and beckoned to Dale Long, who once hit eight home runs in eight games in the baseball generation when Mantle was king.

title: The Region; Redistricting Stands, for Now
description: Republicans called New Jersey's new Congressional district map an example of ''blatant, arrogant gerrymandering'' and, in throwing it out this month, a Federal District Court judge seemed to agree. The Democrats, who had drawn it, countered that ''no redistricting plan comes from heaven,'' but they nevertheless appealed to a higher authority and, it appeared last week, won - at least temporarily.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Invention Logjam
description: One month after taking office in July 1981, Gerald J. Mossinghoff, the Federal Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, noted that the waiting time to get a patent from his office was nearly two years. To get a trademark took a little more than two years.

title: Canadiens 5, North Stars 1
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Mark Napier scored his 36th and 37th goals of the season to help Montreal clinch first place in the Adams Division. The Canadiens, who have lost only two of their last 29 games, have 103 points, 15 more than Boston.

title: Albany Notes; ENERGY AGENCY'S REPORT CALLED A WASTE
description: In a 96-page annual report that includes 81 photographs - 45 of which are in color - the State Energy Research and Development Authority has told the story of its accomplishments in a way that would be the envy of private corporations.

title: PETITION DRIVE FOR NUCLEAR ARMS FREEZE IS GAINING SUPPORT ON COAST
description: Organizers of a petition drive to place a proposal before California voters favoring a bilateral freeze on nuclear weapons say they expect to collect more than twice the number of signatures needed to qualify for the November ballot.

title: Miss Carder Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roberts George Carder of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Byrd Carder of Washington, to Benjamin Franklin Price Ivins 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Donald Ivins of Milwaukee.

title: Marcos Visits Saudi Arabia
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines arrived today for a three-day official visit.

title: CHINESE CATHOLICS REBUKE THE POPE
description: The leadership of China's officially sanctioned Catholic Church has denounced Pope John Paul II, accusing him of slander and blasphemy for asserting that Chinese Catholics were being persecuted.

title: THE SOCIETY OF JESUS
description: Paul Hofmann emphasized the founder's design of the order as a faithful sword of the church militant. Perinde ac cadaver (corpselike at the Pope's will) is the extreme expression of this subjugation of judgment.

title: Sarah Porter Affianced To S.W.M. Thayer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Porter of Buenos Aires have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Noel Porter, to Samuel Wistar Morris Thayer, son of Mrs. Frederick Morris Thayer Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa., and Cushing Island, Me., and the late Mr. Thayer.

title: Lake Ontario's $78,000 Fishing Derby
description: WHAT is described by its sponsors as the largest fishing contest in the United States will take place on Lake Ontario April 22 to 25. The event is the sixth annual ESLO (Empire State-Lake Ontario) trout and salmon derby that last year attracted more than 8,000 participants who competed for more than $70,000 in prizes and caught 6,753 fish.

title: BOSSY TIES LAFLEUR POINT MARK IN 3-3 TIE
description: A goal by Wayne Babych with 3 minutes 46 seconds left tonight lifted the St. Louis Blues into a 3-3 tie with the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum. It also made Coach Al Arbour, the Islanders' coach, very angry.

title: AFRIKANER FOUNDS RIGHT-WING PARTY
description: Dr. Andries P. Treurnicht, the dissident Afrikaner leader who was ousted from the governing National Party three weeks ago, drew one of the largest political crowds that white South Africa has seen in years for the founding today of his new political party.

title: NASSAU POLICE ADDING MORE CIVILIANS
description: MINEOLA BECAUSE of a four-year court-ordered freeze on the hiring of police officers, the Nassau County Police Department has undergone a major reorganization, with an infusion of nearly 1,000 civilian employees.

title: THE REBORN BACH ARIA GROUP
description: For New York listeners, this will be a weekend of rebirths. Spring, of course, began officially yesterday. Today celebrates a reawakening of a musical kind - the return to this city of the Bach Aria Group.

title: T.H.P. Whitney Jr. Weds Miss Doelger
description: The marriage of Victoria Milbank Doelger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah Milbank of Greenwich, Conn., to Thomas Handasyde Perkins Whitney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney of Boston, took place yesterday in the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour in Brookline, Mass. Canon Harold Bend Sedgwick, assisted by the Rev. George L. Blackman, performed the ceremony.

title: WINE
description: PENNY WISE, POUNDS WISER

title: 40 Are Killed and 25 Injured As Train Rams a Bus in India
description: An express passenger train crashed into a tourist bus in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh today, killing 40 people and seriously injuring 25, news reports said.

title: S.V. Langer Weds Linda Leopold
description: Linda McCracken Leopold, senior marketing manager at the Elsevier Science Publishing Company in New York, was married yesterday to Stephen V. Langer, a management and computer-systems consultant. The ceremony was performed by Surrogate Marie M. Lambert of New York County in the Harvard Club.

title: KAREN CRAWFORD BETROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Crawford of Greensburg, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Louis Crawford, to Dr. Matthew Ryan Weir, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael B. Weir of Greenwich, Conn.

title: About Adoption
description: I am a mother. Some people would call me an adoptive mother. I will not use or accept that term. I reject any qualifying words to describe my mother-self.

title: STORY OF NEWSMEN'S SLAYING IS RECONSTRUCTED IN SALVADOR
description: Four Dutch journalists who were slain Wednesday in northern El Salvador were shot to death when they and a group of guerrillas walked into an army ambush, according to information from a variety of sources.

title: New Program Is Open For Disabled's Families
description: Marjorie Slavin's article (''Special World of the Disabled's Family,'' Opinion Page, Feb. 28) may have come as a shock to the majority of families who have not gone through the anguish and critical upheaval of readjusting their lives around a disabled child. Yet it is something that we should all be aware of - especially in regard to the type of support and help available to families like those she has described so poignantly and so well.

title: PROBLEMS ARE MOUNTING IN N.C.A.A.
description: Seventeen schools are on the National Collegiate Athletic Association's probation list, equalling the highest number for a single period, ''and the list will go higher before it goes lower,'' according to David Berst, the director of the association's enforcement department.

title: WEST BANK BOY DIES AS ISRAELI FORCES FIRE ON ARAB PROTESTERS
description: Israeli troops fired into a crowd of stonethrowing Palestinian demonstrators in the occupied West Bank town of El Bireh today, killing a 17-year-old boy and wounding two teen-age girls and a 55-year-old woman.

title: The Week in Business; OIL PRODUCTION CUTS STUDIED
description: Daily oil production cuts to 18 million barrels, a decrease of about a half million barrels, were proposed by OPEC oil ministers at a meeting in Vienna on Friday, although an agreement was not reached and talks were scheduled to carry over another day. The cartel is seeking to stem a world oversupply of oil, which leaves about 2 million barrels unsold daily, and fighting to maintain the benchmark oil price at $34 a barrel.

title: Travel Advisory; Day Trips To the Arctic
description: Not so long ago, expeditions to the Arctic were measured in months of hardship but, thanks to jet aircraft, modern-day Arctic explorers can make the trip to the top of the world in a day.

title: TRAFFIC AND THE MEADOWLANDS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD IN THE last decade, thousands of new condominium homes and offices and the Sports Complex have emerged in the once-desolate marshes and wastelands of the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: NEW BEIRUT DIRECTORY SHOWS EFFECTS OF WAR
description: For the first time since 1973, a new Lebanese telephone book is being published. Its 300,000 names provide some specific clues on what has happened to people as a result of the Lebanese civil war of 1975-76 and the subsequent violence.

title: U.S. REPORTS PLOT TO SMUGGLE HELICOPTERS TO LIBYA
description: Three Californians are among seven men indicted in what the United States Customs Service says was an international plot to steal 15 sophisticated American-built Cobra helicopters and sell them to the government of Libya for more than $125 million

title: EXHIBITION AT YALE
description: For 550 years, until A.D. 256 when it fell to Persian invaders, the city of Dura prospered on the eastern edge of the Roman Empire, an important stop on the trade route from the Persian Gulf to the Mediterranean Sea and a unique blending of Christian, Semitic and Roman cultures. Buried for centuries, the city was discovered by chance in 1920 when a British soldier on patrol noticed some wall paintings among the ruins along the Euphrates River in the Syrian Desert.

title: METHODS DISPUTED IN FERTILITY STUDY
description: In a broad-ranging report on a recent French study concerning fertility in women, a New York researcher rebuts the interpretation of the study that holds that the ability to conceive children drops sharply between the ages of 30 and 36 years.

title: 'FREEZE' BACKERS DEFEND CAMPAIGN
description: The Guilford U.S.-U.S.S.R. Nuclear Arms Freeze Committee takes strong exception to the distorted conclusions drawn by Jay Winik. The freeze resolution speaks for itself and it reads as follows: ''To improve national and international security, the United States and the Soviet Union should stop the nuclear arms race. Specifically, they should adopt a mutual freeze on the testing, production and deployment of nuclear weapons and of missiles and new aircraft designed primarily to deliver nuclear weapons. This is an essential, verifiable first step toward lessening the risk of nuclear war and reducing the nuclear arsensals.''

title: Miss Wertheimer Plans May Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Franc Wertheimer of Sumner, Md., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laura Susan Wertheimer, to Andrew John Pincus, son of Mrs. Betty M. Pincus of New York and Walter H. Pincus of Washington. A May 22 wedding is planned in Washington.

title: A NEW LOOK AT DINOSAURS
description: Several years ago, my first-grade students collected about $24 to send to James Jensen so that he could continue digging for the remains of Supersaurus.

title: TEXAS-EL PASO'S USE OF FOREIGNERS RAISES QUESTIONS
description: On Feb. 21, Ted Banks resigned as track and field coach at the University of Texas at El Paso, citing budgetary cutbacks and a more lucrative business opportunity as reasons for leaving one of the country's most successful intercollegiate programs.

title: Indian Legislators in Melee
description: Legislators punched and kicked each other in a 15-minute free-for-all in the Rajasthan State Assembly today. The altercation took place after the Speaker had called for a vote on a report by the state's Business Advisory Committee and opposition lawmakers objected, demanding further debate, the United News of India reported.

title: The Region; The Race Cards Are Filling Up
description: It may be difficult for Republicans to displace Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, but they don't have to worry about finding a replacement for Bruce F. Caputo, their original choice to take on the one-term Democrat. Last week, days after Mr. Caputo bowed out following ''misstatements'' about an Army record he didn't possess, Whitney North Seymour Jr., a former United States Attorney, bowed in.

title: CHURCH BATTLING LANDMARK STATUS
description: The terra cotta eagle glaring down from the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew is a blur to those who pass by, for wind and pollution have eroded the sharpness of its chiseled beak and the details of its eye.

title:
Careful Shopper;
Imported-Tile Prices Reduced This Month
description: Carminart Inc is a direct importer with two warehouses and a retail showroom in Elmsford. Markdowns this month are 10 to 50 percent on decorative ceramic and quarry tile and marble, bathroom fixtures and accessories. The shop offers a do-it-yourself booklet for householders and will sell or rent gloves, grouting saws, notched trowels, utility knives, precision spacers, adhesives and caulks. The owners, who will also recommend contractors, say they welcomes customer calls on mid-project problems.

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Spain Detour through the heartland

title: P.L. Beilenson to Wed Helen Valerie Montag
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Montag of Atlanta and Sautee, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Valerie Montag, to Peter Lowell Beilenson, son of Representative Anthony C. Beilenson, Democrat of California, and Mrs. Beilenson of Los Angeles and Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Miss Schemel Is the Bride Of a Student
description: Susan Farley Schemel, an assistant treasurer with the Bankers Trust Company in New York, was married yesterday to Bernhard Hoffmann 3d, a student at the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed at Christ Church Methodist in Vero Beach, Fla., by the Rev. John B. O'Hara and the Rev. Thaddeus Bennett.
