title: Richard Bruns Will Marry Mary Barrett
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Marvin G. Barrett of New York and Water Mill, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ellin Barrett, to Richard S. Bruns, son of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Bruns of St. Louis.

title: Antiques View; AN ENGAGING EXIBITION OF CHINESE WARES
description: We are accustomed in recent years to highly specialized museum exhibitions which focus comprehensively, if narrowly, on a certain period, style and material of the decorative arts. For most of us, such shows offer the joys of revelation, opening doors to a deeper understanding of certain aspects of the arts with examples that are rarely, if ever, assembled for public display.

title: NUTRITION PROJECT URGES ECONOMIZING
description: A federally financed nutrition program designed to help poor families in New York City learn to maintain a healthy diet has been spending less time counting vitamins and more time budgeting grocery money since cuts were made in the food stamp program.

title: LIGHT OPERA FINDS GOOD FORTUNE
description: WHEN the composer Sir Arthur Sullivan teamed up with W. S. Gilbert in 1871 to create that distinctively different form of music, the English operetta, little did they realize the extent of light opera spinoffs that would ensue over the next century.

title: Philadelphia Ward Chief Held on Fraud Charges
description: A Democratic ward leader charged with defrauding the Federal Government of $40,000 in rent subsidies was jailed Friday on default of bail.

title: MARCEY MOLLER BETROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Moller Jr. of Wethersfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Marcey Barbara Moller, to Brian John Hickey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Hickey Jr. of West Hartford, Conn. Miss Moller, also the daughter of Barbara Hewitt Moller of East Hartford, Conn., is a paralegal in her father's law firm in Hartford. Her fiance's father is a superintendent of financial systems with C.G.-Aetna Insurance Company in Hartford.

title: Amy Lu Bamford Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bamford of Tulsa, Okla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Lu Bamford, to Dr. Jonathan S. Coblyn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin D. Coblyn of East Meadow, L.I. The wedding is planned for June. Miss Bamford is a physician's assistant in Brookline, Mass., where her fiance is a rheumatologist. He is also an assistant professor of medicine at the Harvard Medical School.

title: SPINNING AN ITALIAN YARN
description: Silk and Como have been as interwoven as woof and warp since the end of the 19th century, when Swiss spinning firms first moved to this Italian city to use the clear waters of Lake Como.

title: Prospects
description: Inflation's Tough Core

title: Other Business; A WAY TO HOLD ON TO YOUR TYPEWRITER
description: ''Computers have a tendency to get legs and walk away,'' said Jerry Pannhauser, a purchasing agent for Apple Computer Inc. of Cupertino, Calif.

title: Investing; SLACK DAYS IN THE TANGIBLES MARKET
description: OF all the marketplaces, none is as intangible as the market in t angibles - works of art, antiques, stamps, coins, Oriental ceramics o r rugs. The items involved are, by definition, relatively rare, in f inite supply, and often one of a kind. The simple profit motive is o bscured by equally compelling factors not suitable for marketplace m easurement. These might include a need to safely and conveniently m ove money across borders, to hide assets, avoid taxes or preserve c apital for retirement or survivors. And there is the ultimate buyer o f tangibles - the collector - who is motivated by personal, often s trictly emotional, considerations.

title: STUDY FAULTS KANSAS CITY BUILDING INSPECTION
description: A three-month study of how Kansas City administers its construction guidelines has disclosed ''a number of deficiencies'' with the inspection procedures in effect when two skywalks at the Hyatt Regency Hotel collapsed last July 17.

title: BUSH TAKES A WHACK AT CONNECTICUT'S 'MAVERICK' WEICKER
description: During a recent trip to Fairfield, Prescott Bush Jr. had planned to outline campaign strategy for delegates competing in the town's Republican caucus this Tuesday. He wound up giving a pep talk.

title:
LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
THE TALE OF THE ALEWIFE
description: NORTH SEA AFISH with a beery name has served up another instance in which proposed development on the Island's South Fork has bumped against an ecological system that residents wish ardently to preserve.

title: DUTCH STAGE A PROTEST AT AMERICAN EMBASSY
description: Several hundred people marched to the United States Embassy in the Hague today and burned an American flag there as protests against the Reagan Administration's policies in El Salvador continued.

title: STANFORD'S ELWAY SWINGS LIKE A YANKEE
description: Wearing Stanford University's red batting gloves and the Yankees' gray uniform with a ''96'' on the back, John Elway stepped up to the plate at Boggs Field this morning for his first swings as a professional baseball player.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Bob's Space Ship
description: While the National Aeronautics and Space Administration was spending perhaps $100 million to perfect this country's space shuttle, 63-year-old Robert C. Truax in Saratoga, Calif., was quietly building an economical alternative: Bob's ''space shuttle.''

title: 15% OF KENTUCKY MINES CALLED ILLEGAL BY OFFICIAL
description: At least 15 percent of the 1,260 underground mines in Kentucky are ''bootleg'' operations, outside the law and without permits or safety inspection and enforcement, the state's top mine safety official has told a Congressional subcommittee.

title: STEROTYPES OF SUBURBIA PUT INTO SONG
description: PORT JEFFERSON THE stereotypes of suburbia are perpetuated in a new revue, ''Suburbia: Inside the Outskirts.'' Rather than wince at a dim and slanted view of their life style, audiences are sportingly embracing it, and the show is doing turnaway business at Griswold's Cabaret, where it is being performed on Friday and Saturday nights at 10:30.

title: PUBLIC RADIO TO PRESENT SUNDAY ARTS PROGRAMS
description: National Public Radio, which has won wide praise for its news presentations, is mounting an arts program called ''The Sunday Show.'' It will be a weekly five-hour collage of live classical music and other arts events, news of the arts, interviews, criticism, commentary and behind-the-scenes documentaries.

title:
Business Forum;
A.T.&.T.: THE HOPES OF MIDDLE MANAGERS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company faces some difficult personnel problems in reorganizing its staff to accommodate the terms of the divestiture agreement reached in January with the Justice Department.

title: CONCERN OVER FLOODING
description: WITH the arrival of spring, the thoughts of many state residents may soon turn to baseball and other seasonal rites. But at the State Department of Environmental Protection, thoughts have already turned to another of the season's occurrences: flooding.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Guillermo Vilas of Argentina accepted a last-minute call from the organizers to replace John McEnroe in the $350,000 Cuore Tennis Cup tournament, which starts in Milan, Italy, tomorrow. Vilas was seeded No.2 behind Jimmy Connors, who was seeded first in the absence of McEnroe.

title:
GARDENING;
THE RIGHT SOIL MENU FOR THE RIGHT DIET
description: BECAUSE the soils in which we grow our plants are often lacking in quantity or balance of nutrients, we must compensate by applying fertilizers.

title: Crabs Caribbean
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE is the food editor of The Times. By CRAIG CLAIBORNE

title: Morial Wins 2d Term In New Orleans Runoff
description: Ernest N. Dutch Morial, the first black mayor of New Orleans, won a second term today, crediting a large voter turnout and support from all races for his defeat of a young state legislator.

title: Miss Fretwell Plans Wedding
description: Dr. Elbert K. Fretwell Jr., chancellor of the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, and Mrs. Fretwell, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Louise Fretwell, to Robert Southey Saul, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Southey Saul of Haverford, Pa.

title: Stephen Smith Is Fiance Of Victoria S. Lloyd-Rees
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Llewelyn Lloyd-Rees of Longmeadow, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Spencer Lloyd-Rees, to Stephen Kenneth Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Smith of Tonbridge, England.

title: LANDMARKS RESPONSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Conditions; FURS SALES HOLD STEADY
description: A two-week general strike by members of the United Fur and Commercial Workers of America and slower sales overseas created problems for the nation's furriers last year. The industry, which is holding its fourth international trade fair at the New York Coliseum through Wednesday, nevertheless managed to see domestic sales of garments and pelts exceed $1 billion for the first time.

title: Death Sentences for 5 Approved by Mubarak
description: President Hosni Mubarak today approved death sentences for five Moslem militants and jail terms for 17 others convicted in the Oct. 6 assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.

title:
ART;
SCULPTURE TO ADORN A RIVER'S EDGE
description: SELDEN SUFFOLK COUNTY is not noted for its public sculpture. Most of the outdoor works in the region are churchyard carvings, war memorials and monuments, only one of which, the Smithtown Bull, can be considered an outstanding piece of civic statuary.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE CREW ARRIVES AT BASE FOR CRAFT'S THIRD FLIGHT TOMORROW
description: The astronauts who will fly the space shuttle Columbia's third mission arrived here today as the countdown continued smoothly toward a scheduled launching Monday morning.

title: SNAGS DEVELOP IN TALKS ON GENERAL MOTORS PACT
description: Contract negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation remained stalled today on profit sharing and other issues, but union officials said they were prepared to continue talking through the weekend.

title: PARAMILITARY CURBS SOUGHT
description: MOST of the 2,500 or so people who live in Woodland Township, in the heart of the Pine Barrens, go about their business much the way their ancestors did. They worry about the cranberry and blueberry crops and they stop by Buzby's - the general store in Chatsworth that has been around for better than a century - to chat.

title: Darcie A. Bundy Becomes the Bride of Stuart Day
description: Darcie A. Bundy, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward S. Bundy of Cheshire, Conn., was married yesterday in New York to Stuart Day, son of Mildred Day of Buena Vista, Va. Walter Lawton, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: Sports People; Coverage Upsets Meyer
description: Ray Meyer, whose De Paul basketball team was eliminated last weekend from the N.C.A.A. tournament in its first game for the third consecutive year, says he is thinking about retiring as coach because of the way the Chicago news media have treated him. ''I guess I stepped over the ledge when we lost last Sunday,'' the 68-year-old coach said.

title: Art; WESTERN ART ON VIEW AT STATE MUSEUM
description: TRENTON ON ITS way home to Princeton, the Gund collection of western art is again playing the State Museum, having last appeared there in 1974. These 37 paintings, drawings and prints, together with 24 sculptures, were assembled by George Gund, who, until his death in 1966, was president of the Cleveland Trust Company (now the American Trust Corporation). Accompanied by an illustrated but not-too-wellorganized catalogue, the show will remain on view through April 25.

title: MUSIC: A 13TH-CENTURY PASSION PLAY
description: The medieval liturgical drama is a distant world from us today, and so it is almost inevitable that the performances being offered this weekend at the Cloisters of the Greater Passion Play from the ''Carmina Burana'' collection of 13th-century Bavarian manuscripts is a noble failure. But the nobility should be stressed along with the failure.

title: MRS. MELTON LEADS BY 5 SHOTS
description: Nancy Lopez-Melton shook off a double bogey on the ninth hole, then went on to shoot a three-underpar 69 today and take a five-shot lead over Sandra Haynie after three rounds of a $200,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Charlae Olaker Offers A Varied Soprano Bill
description: Charlae Olaker, a soprano, sang Handel, Strauss, Debussy, Dello Joio and Granados at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon. Miss Olaker brought an attractive and convincing intensity to all this music; and although there were recurring small vagaries of pitch and uncertainties of attack, these seemed more due to the stress of the occasion than to any real technical deficiency.

title: MERCURY IS FOUND IN BEACHED ANIMALS
description: ATLANTIC CITY PRIVATE tests commissioned by the Marine Mammal Stranding Center here in the last two years have disclosed unusually large amounts of mercury, a toxic metal, in the tissues of dolphins and giant sea turtles that washed ashore between New Jersey and Florida.

title: Westchester Guide; THE TEACHING OF HISTORY
description: One of the world's foremost historians, Prof. Hugh Trevor-Roper, the Lord Dacre of Glanton, Master of Peterhouse at Cambridge University, and former holder of the Regius chair at Oxford University, will speak on ''History: the State of the Art and the Craft'' at 8 P.M. Friday in the Mayflower Annex Auditorium of Iona College in New Rochelle.

title: Sports People; Mahar Is Honored
description: Buddy Mahar of Columbia University has been selected 1982 Kodak coach of the year for District II of Division I by the National Association of Basketball Coaches. Mahar directed Columbia to a 16-10 won-lost record this season after a 9-17 record last season. Mahar qualified with 14 other Division I coaches for the national honor, which will be announced next Sunday in New Orleans. ... Ernie Myers of Tolentine High School in the Bronx and Billy Thompson of Camden High School in New Jersey were selected to the first-team all-America squad by Parade magazine.

title: Tar Heels Not Taking Villanova Lightly
description: In the back of the minds of the North Carolina Tar Heels, hidden behind their own burden of maintaining a top ranking in tournament play, stood Virginia and Ralph Sampson, and the possibility that the teams could meet in a game for the national championship next weekend.

title: THOMAS W. PURCELL 3D WILL MARRY MISS STERN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Stern of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Stern, to Thomas Williamson Purcell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Purcell of Richmond.

title: KOCH IS BEGINNING CAMPAIGN UPSTATE
description: Already assured of the support of most New York City Democratic leaders, Mayor Koch was to make his first extensive campaign swing today to begin courting upstate Democratic Party leaders and public officials.

title: Robert Mansfield to Wed Robin L. Beil in October
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Randall Beil Jr. of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Lynn Beil, to Robert Alexander Mansfield, son of Jane Plumer Mansfield of Wayland, Mass., and Bruce Alexander Mansield of Wellesley, Mass.

title: Fare of the Country; FINGER-LICKIN' INDIAN CHICKEN
description: MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN is chief of the Times bureau in New Delhi. BY MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

title: HE BROUGHT THE ROBOT TO LIFE
description: DANBURY, Conn. FOUR decades ago, science fiction writer Isaac Asimov's robot stories caught the imagination of a Columbia University physics student named Joseph F. Engelberger. Sometime in 1985, a robot named in Mr. Asimov's honor is likely to be serving coffee to Mr. Engelberger and other directors of the nation's first and largest industrial robot manufacturer.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Connecticut Ballet, finding that pirouettes and prima ballerinas don't pay the rent, is bringing in the jitterbug and belly dancing instead. The New Haven-based ballet announced last month that it would have to raise $120,000 by the end of May to avoid bankruptcy. Next Saturday it will hold a ''Beggar's Bash'' fundraising event, with a swing band, ''Eight to the Bar,'' for guests to jitterbug to, and a belly dancer, Natasha Saravis. The scene may resemble ''Aida'' because, according to Sean Leabo, a spokesman for the ballet, Mrs. Saravis ''has threatened to bring two pythons and two boa constrictors.''

title: CIVILIANS TO THE RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy M. Smith Married to James A. Berge Jr.
description: Wendy Margaret Smith and James A. Berge Jr. were married yesterday at the Stamford (Conn.) Yacht Club. The Rev. James Smith, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: WHEN A BARGAIN BECOMES A TRAP
description: Two groups of old-timers occupy apartments in a building on West End Avenue. There are the older ones, in rent-controlled apartments that make up half the building, who remember when the place was truly elegant, when potted palms and thick velvet carpets adorned the lobby. Then there are the newer ones, who moved into rent-stabilized, $600-amonth two-bedroom apartments with river views in the 1970's.

title: ...AND SERVICE
description: To the Business Editor

title: Pomona Women Take Division II Basketball
description: California State Polytechnic-Pomona, paced by Carol Welch's 26 points, routed Tuskegee by 93-74 today to win the first National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II women's basketball title.

title: Italian Journalists Strike
description: Italian journalists began a 24-hour strike today in pursuit of a new contract. Italian news agencies stopped wire transmissions at 7 A.M. and radio and television journalists stopped broadcasting news items. More than 10 national dailies will be missing from newsstands Sunday.

title: Father of Kissinger Is Dead
description: Louis Kissinger, the father of former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, died Friday at his home in Washington Heights at the age of 95 years.

title: PAMELA TRACY BURDGE PLANS MAY 29 WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Spencer Burdge of New Britain, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Tracy Burdge, to Bradford Wayne Harries, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brenton W. Harries of Westfield, N.J. The wedding is planned for May 29.

title: Television Week
description: Salute to the Arts This season's public-television fund-raising campaign concludes with a three-hour salute to the performing arts called ''Gala of Stars 1982.'' It will be presented on Channel 13 at 8 P.M. on Sunday.

title: No Headline
description: While we in the Roslyn School District were pleased to see an important subject dealt with in ''Debate Heating Up on School Aid Changes,'' we feel there are additional factors that should be called to the attention of your readers. Roslyn is one of New York State's 95 flat grant school districts. Flat grant dollars now going to the so-called property-wealthy districts (other than New York City) amount to about 1 percent, $40.6 million, of the $4.2 billion in school aid paid to all 750 New York State school districts. Doing away with this assistance to the 95 flat grant districts would seriously damage the quality of their educational programs by eliminating this 15 percent of their revenues. But distributing that amount to all the remaining 655 districts in the state would increase the other districts' aid by only $14 a child, less than one-half of 1 percent of the average cost of educating a child in New York State.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A government that does not keep secrets does not receive them.'' -Dean Fischer, State Department spokesman, at briefing detailing outside help for Salvadoran guerrillas. (23:1.)

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING with the architect and the builder; TIPS ON SELECTING AN ARCHITECT
description: FOR the increasing number of people contemplating major renovation or remodeling work, the selection of an architect poses a dilemma. Unlike accountants, physicians or lawyers, architects are not wellknown enough for friends or colleagues to be much help in recommending names from which to begin to make a choice.

title: Art Sampler
description: CAN an artist paint similar landscapes over and over and not become monotonously dull? Wolf Kahn, whose paintings are on view at the Kornbluth Gallery in Fair Lawn, can.

title: JO COPELAND, A FASHION DESIGNER NOTES FOR TWO-PIECE SUIT, IS DEAD
description: Jo Copeland, the fashion designer known for her imaginative use of fabric, died yesterday morning in Manhattan of the effects of a stroke. She was in her 80's and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge; CHALLENGING 'TASKS'
description: Double-dummy problems, in which the solver is shown four hands and asked to find a complicated road to make a given number of tricks, have long been out of fashion. An alternative type of bridge-hand construction is more intriguing, less provoking and perhaps due to become popular. It is what would be called by a chess problemist a ''task'': The creator sets himself a challenge of meeting conditions that might, at first sight, seem impossible.

title: Reading and Writing; THE FICTION OF DIVORCE
description: While reading A. Alvarez's ''Life After Marriage,'' I found myself wishing that he had taken his case histories of divorce from novels rather than from life, for the novelist's imagination is more likely to be generous than the voice of someone hurt, angry and bewildered. Since divorce is so common, it seems to me that what we need is a heartening literature on the complexity, even the poetry, or the tragicomedy of the thing. It isn't all anguish - nothing ever is. There is a considerable body of literature developing now in which the novel of divorce is becoming our new Bildungsroman, an educational adventure in which the hero or heroine is followed from a picaresque or impetuous youth to responsible, or at least ironical, adulthood. The characters in these novels marry as adolescents and divorce as adults.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:We are taking our 16-year-old son to Germany this summer for a three-week holiday. We plan to drive through southern Germany after taking a Rhine cruise. Our son, who is recovering from an automobile accident, can walk with a cane for short periods of time and then needs a wheelchair. Should we rent one here and try to take it with us, or try to rent one there? Are there any general tips for such travel? - B.C., Stamford, Conn. Answer:Robert Zywicki of Whole Person Tours (137 West 32d Street, Bayonne, N.J. 07002; 201-858-3400) has visited Europe, Canada, California and Florida since becoming disabled. He suggests that you rent a wheelchair here. A lightweight folding one (a batteryoperated one may be rejected by the airline) that you can push or that your son can push himself costs $20 or $25 a month at a pharmacy or medical supply house.

title: JAPAN JOURNAL
description: ''Y our impressions of Japan?'' everybody asks when you come home. You feel like Count Smorltork in ''The Pickwick Papers,'' having visited a country for two weeks and returned home prepared to write the definitive history.

title: Senate Whip Suggests Delay In Tax Cut to Pass a Budget
description: The assistant Senate Republican leader is suggesting a three-month delay in the personal income tax reduction scheduled to take effect this summer as a way to pick up Democratic votes for a compromise budget.

title: The World; OPEC Agrees To Limits on On Production
description: The oil weapon, employed by OPEC to such devastating effect in 1973-74 and again in 1979 after the Iranian revolution, has lately turned into a boomerang. Seeking to protect their economies from further injury, oil ministers met in Vienna last week and for the first time acted like a true cartel - setting a ceiling on production as well as a floor on prices.

title: U.S.C. Faces Probation In Football, Report Says
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is expected to impose a three-year football probation on the University of Southern California that would include a two-year ban on bowl and television appearances, The Los Angeles Times reported in its Sunday issue.

title: Major News; Nicaragua Gives The Diplomacy Buttons a Push
description: Nicaragua showed last week that two can play at carrot and stick. It called for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council to publicize what it said was the danger of an ''imminent'' invasion by the United States. At the same time, it said it was ready to negotiate all differences with Washington.

title: Edgar Durbin Jr.  Weds Miss Tait
description: Mariana Barker Tait, a picture editor, was married yesterday in Summit, N.J., to Dr. Edgar Durbin Jr., a military systems analyst with the Institute of Defense Analysis in Alexandria, Va. Judge John H. Bissell of the New Jersey Superior Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Watson Fergus Tait.

title: 5 Are Stabbed in London
description: Five people were stabbed Friday night in clashes between young blacks and whites in a London housing project, the police said today. One of the five, Diana Duberry, 16 years old, was reported in serious condition at a hospital. A Scotland Yard spokesman said the fights broke out after bricks were thrown through windows of a disco in the Hackney district of East London.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: AT LARGE ON SKIS IN COLORADO
description: CLIFFORD D. MAY is an editor on The New York Times Magazine. BY CLIFFORD D.MAY

title: PALM BEACH CALM OASIS OF WEALTHY
description: A lot of people here are on the defensive. The rest of the world is giving them a hard time, they say, and they are getting tired of it.

title: HASTINGS THERAPIST TACKLES POLICE STRESS
description: THE stress-related problems of policemen and their families, an issue that has been receiving increasing attention, is of particular interest to Dr. Joyce Sichel of Hastings-on-Hudson, a therapist with a doctorate in psychology. She has been involved for 10 years in the criminal-justice system, doing research studies and developing training programs for the police, the courts and district attorneys in New York City.

title: U.S. CRACKS EDISON SAFE TO NO AVAIL
description: It was somehow fitting that, in the laboratories of the man who said that genius is 99 percent perspiration, a veteran safecracker should have spent three hours yesterday only to discover nothing.

title: QUICK EYE, KEEN EYE
description: THE TUGMAN'S PASSAGE By Edward Hoagland. 208 pp. New York: Random House. $12.50.

title: DEBUT ON DISK FOR A BEETHOVEN QUARTET
description: One of the fascinating aspects of Beethoven's work is that it shows remarkable progress in his ''inner'' hearing at precisely the time his actual hearing began to deteriorate. Just when this began is impossible to determine: While the Heiligenstadt Testament, written in 1802, is the most famous document of Beethoven's deafness, he first revealed his affliction to his friend, the physician Franz Gerhard Wegler, in June 1801. He had probably kept the awareness to himself for a couple of years before that.

title: EDWIN MOSLER JR., LED SAFE-MAKING COMPANY
description: Edwin H. Mosler Jr., former president and chief executive officer of the Mosler Safe Company, which made the vaults that guard the nation's wealth at Fort Knox, Ky., and protect the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and the Bill of Rights in Washington, died Saturday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and was a lifelong resident of Manhattan.

title: TWYLA THARP PROT EG EES STEPPING OUT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barry Laine writes frequently about dance and dancers. BY BARRY LAINE

title: WEICKER ANNOUNCES HIS CANDIDACY FOR THIRD TERM
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., formally announcing his candidacy for a third term, today vowed to take a more active role in directing the Republican state organization, with which he has often feuded.

title: GREAT BRITAIN PAYS TRIBUTE TO CHARLES DARWIN
description: The 100th anniversary of the death of Charles Darwin has been observed by Great Britain with a set of four commemoratives that show the great 19th century British naturalist and some of the creatures he studied in his search to help man understand the world around him.

title: Headliners; A Count Convicted
description: A Danish aristocrat and member of the wealthy Rhode Island seaside ''cottage'' set, Claus von Bulow is no common man. And a Newport jury decided last week that he was guilty of no common crime - he tried twice, they ruled, to murder his oil-heiress wife, Martha, by injecting her with overdoses of insulin. Mr. von Bulow sat impassively in the courtroom as he heard himself called guilty 24 times by the 12 jurors who had heard 56 witnesses testify over nine weeks in Rhode Island's longest criminal trial.

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Egypt Learning the ins and outs of a complex city

title: 8 Food Places Charged With Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited eight food establishments last week for violations of the city's Health Code. It also listed seven that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and 12 that were closed for failure to do so.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Painting flowers in watercolor on calfskin vellum is not an activity that reeks of today, as today is generally conceived. But, anachronistic or not, it gives great pleasure when it is done as deftly as it is by Rory McEwen in his curent exhibition at the Staempfli Gallery, 47 East 77th Street.

title: The Nation; Putting the Cat Back in the Bag
description: In 1979 V. James Bramford obtained a 1976 report summarizing the Government's investigation into allegations that the Central Intelligence and National Security Agencies had violated individual civil liberties and laws regulating electronic surveillance. Mr. Bramford used the Freedom of Information Act to get the report. Now the Reagan Administration wants it back, on the ground that the documents had been mistakenly declassified and contained information that could damage national security.

title: Sports of The Times; Boston College: Sublime Sublimation
description: THE voice cut through the nearly empty arena as the Boston College players took a leisurely workout early Friday evening. ''Hey, Boston College, what's the spread today?'' ''Hey, you guys trying today?'' At the edge of the court, Bobby Hunter, an assistant coach at Boston College, cautioned a few of the players: ''Don't look up. Don't pay any attention.''

title: FROM MILK WAGON TO HARNESS RACING
description: YONKERS LUCIEN FONTAINE, one of North America's most successful harnesshorse race drivers, wanted to be a milkman when he was a youth. He lived in Pointe Aux Trembles on the eastern end of Montreal Island and envied a milkman who had ''two rigs and two routes.''

title: INDIA FACING TOO MAN ENDANGERED RHINOS
description: With the still-endangered great Indian onehorned rhinoceros increasing in numbers, India is considering moving about 60 of them from their main sanctuary in the northeastern state of Assam to other parts of the country.

title: LEARNING HOW TO LIVE WITH A PEST
description: IMAGINE you are riding through New England in a train on a lovely spring evening. Suddenly the train stops halfway up a wooded hillside. As passengers crane at the windows, thick black caterpillars crawl up the sides of the train and across the windows. They clog the track with their coffee-ground droppings and leaf-swollen bodies. And the train can't get through.

title: Dining Out;
description: THERE'S a new addition to the cluster of Spanish and Portuguese restaurants in Newark. Named Don Pepe for one of its owners, it was opened three months ago by the Lopez brothers. They also run the popular Spain Restaurant in the city's nearby Ironbound section.

title: SHARING: IT'S OFTEN PERILOUS
description: Sharing the ownership of a vacation or weekend house with other family members, long-time friends, or even business partners would seem to be the solution for many buyers who could not otherwise afford a vacation house.

title: Nancy Culbertson and Paul Eddy Wed
description: Nancy C. Culbertson, daughter of Mrs. William H. Culbertson of Kent, Conn., and Ocho Rios, Jamaica, and the late Mr. Culbertson, was married yesterday in Ocho Rios to Paul Clark Eddy, son of R. Post Eddy of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Jean Q. Clark of Brookline, Mass.

title: POPE STILL PLANNING TO VISIT BRITAIN DESPITE PROTESTS
description: Organizers of Pope John Paul II's coming visit to Britain have refused to change his schedule despite demonstrations by militant Protestants in Liverpool this month and a threat of further outbursts.

title: 2 ERUPTIONS ON MOUNT ST. HELENS PROMPT EVACUATION AND WARNINGS
description: Mount St. Helens erupted for the second time in six hours today, spewing gas and ash 18,000 feet in the air. Scientists rushed to inspect the crater as it steamed and glowed from it first explosive eruptions in 17 months.

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Denmark A week's sojourn in Jutland

title: Future Events; Honors All Around
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. No Indian Giver March 23 - Recognizing the debt that the fashion industry owes to the American Indian, 20th Century Survival, a clothing company barely two years old, is underwriting a benefit for the American Indian Community House, which serves the social, economic, educational and cultural needs of an estimated 14,000 American Indians in the New York metropolitan area. An event at the agency's gallery in SoHo from 7:30 P.M. on will feature a fashion show including 20th Century's summer collection inspired by the colorful garb of the Seminoles and traditional regalia of other tribes. Guests will nibble on such American Indian fare as sweet potato pie, avocado dip, chile and fry bread; inspect the current ''Native Women Artists'' exhibition and dance to the music of the First Americans, an American Indian rock band. Tickets, $25 from 944-6462.

title: About Westchester V. Herman
description: IT is 11 o'clock and Frank Le Pore of WFAS radio is worried. In five minutes, his show will be on the air, and his guests have not yet picked the first song they want played. ''Go ahead, choose something,'' he urges Suzy West, a poised 17-year-old in angora sweater and pearls. ''Pick something that has some meaning or reminds you of an aspect of your life.''

title: SUSPECT IN UTAH SLAYING GETS PSYCHIATRIC TESTING
description: A member of the board of the New York City Ballet was being held in a psychiatric ward in Queens yesterday after being arrested on charges of having her teen-age son kill her wealthy father in Salt Lake City nearly four years ago.

title: The Region; Bottle Law Study Opens Other End
description: For a decade lobbyists have managed to beat legislation requiring deposits on beverage bottles and cans by persuading Albany that the measure would greatly harm the beverage industry in New York. That strategy may not work on this year's bottle bill - last week a staff report to the Governor said that argument was empty and such fears were ''unfounded.''

title: A PHOTOGRAPHIC RECORD OF THE HUDSON
description: THE Hudson River Museum in Yonkers is a veritable cornucopia of visual riches these days. No less than three significant new exhibitions are on view at the moment, any one of them by itself worth a visit to the museum.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor: In regard to the article about Stockholm, your readers might like to know that they can stay at dormitories of the University of Stockholm, run by students as a hotel in the summer.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
SHOWING THEIR COLORS
description: In their fancy uniforms, with their flags flying, their sabres rattling and their rifles spinning, color guards can be a sight to behold, especially when there are 62 of them gathered in one place to go through their intricate drills. And, starting at 11 A.M. at Long Beach High School on Lido Boulevard, they will provide all this action during the finals of the Eastern Seaboard Colorguard Regionals today.

title: THE HEROINE: A CONTRAPTION OF ATTITUDES
description: BODILY HARM By Margaret Atwood. 266 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.50.

title: Gallery View; ENGLISH PAINTERS AND AMERICAN DRAFTSMEN
description: Manhattan is highly compartmentalized. ''Every time I go above 14th Street,'' the composer Edgard Varese used to say when he lived on Sullivan Street, ''I feel I have to take my passport.'' And south of 14th Street the city does indeed turn on its axis as new sights, new sounds, new centers of interest and new preoccupations make themselves felt.

title: New Jersey Guide; BREL AT STOCKTON
description: When ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris'' was first performed at the Village Gate in Greenwich Village on Jan. 22, 1968, it starred Elly Stone, and her name has become entwined with its legend. Miss Stone will star in the revue again on April 3 at a benefit for Stockton State College in Pomona.

title: Other Business; THERE'S A WORD FOR A MORIBUND ECONOMY
description: Some actually use the word; others skirt around it. But in the past few weeks economists and other seers have been warning that the United States, and perhaps the rest of the industrialized world, may be rolling into a grim statistical chasm known as a depression.

title: SMALLER IS BETTER AND PRIVATE BEST FOR FARMING
description: An international relief worker visiting Vietnam last spring noticed a cartoon in a Hanoi newspaper, illustrating the attitudes of farmers ''before'' and ''after'' the Government reforms that gave farmers more incentives to produce. In the first drawing, a peasant with a cigarette dangling from his mouth is lolling behind a buffalo plowing the fields. In the second it is night, and the peasant is racing behind the buffalo with a lantern.

title: The Nation; Rights Nominee Clears a Hurdle
description: The Administration's choices for civil rights positions have had a way of stumbling into political buzz-saws, but last week one nominee took a big step toward confirmation. The Senate Judiciary Committee approved, by a show of hands, the nomination of Clarence M. Pendleton Jr. as chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: FROM RAGS TO FABRICS
description: GABRIELLE (COCO) CHANEL (1883-1971), the French couturiere who invented the simple casual style of women's clothing that today seems timelessly modern, led a richly photographed life. Edmonde Charles-Roux, the former editor of French Vogue, has compiled a lavish volume, ''Chanel and Her World'' (Vendome, $50), that is a model of pictorial biography.

title: THE SILENCE IS DEAFENING
description: IN A few months, the tenacious struggle for ratification of the equal rights amendment will end. Indeed, its prospects are dim to nonexistent.

title: Ailey Dancers Planning 2 Premieres, 2 Revivals
description: Two premieres and two revivals will highlight the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's spring season at City Center, May 4 through May 23.

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Austria Summer pleasures in a winter resort

title: Foreign Affairs; A FRENCH COLUMBUS
description: Though he's having harsh domestic problems with the fall of the franc and setbacks in local elections, President Francois Mitterrand seems relaxed about the state of the world and comfortable in his relations with the U.S.

title: The Nation; An Immigration Proposal That Gets Somewhere
description: President Ford, President Carter and the 96th Congress all studied immigration policy. So did President Reagan who, like Mr. Carter, issued legislative proposals.

title: Chess; FEAR OF THE UNFORESEEN CAN UPSET PLANS
description: The unforeseen crusher that upsets the most reasonable plan is what some top players fear. It is what makes them offer or accept draws in positions that are perhaps equal, but certainly not sterile.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT seems unlikely on the first hearing, or even on the second, but it is a fact nonetheless: In Nassau County, all but covered with houses and highways and shopping malls, 4-H programs reach more youngsters than in any other county in the nation.

title: JENNIFER GRIFFIN ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Griffin of Nanuet, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Mary Griffin, to Louis R. Frisina, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rocco A. Frisina of Braintree, Ma., nd Dennisport, Mass.

title: Enterprise Zones
description: To the Business Editor: ''The Potholed Road to Enterprise Zones'' (March 7) argues that most urban cores are unsuited to the task of benefiting from the Administration's proposed ''Enterprise Zones.'' As a director of both the New York Public Development Corporation and the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, I must disagree.

title: NEW KICKS FOR RADIO CITY'S LEGENDARY ROCKETTES
description: To many people, New York City is best symbolized by 36 pairs of shapely, high-kicking legs. They belong, of course, to the Rockettes. There have been about 5,000 of them over the years, all precision dancers who look like mirror images on stage. But beneath those feathery headdresses are blond, dark and red hair, and beneath the stage makeup are faces as different as those in any crowd. The Rockettes have ranged in age from 16 to the early 40's; some are single, some are married, some have been mothers. Over the years they have entertained an estimated 255 million persons in the place they call ''home'': Radio City Music Hall.

title: 'THE FRESH EYE OF AN ALIEN, SIR'
description: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF JOHNSON AND BOSWELL By Israel Shenker. 284 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

title: THE INVISIBLE MUSE OF 'DON JUAN'
description: THE RISE AND FALL OF A REGENCY DANDY The Life and Times of Scrope Berdmore Davies. By T. A. J. Burnett. Foreword by Bevis Hillier. Illustrated. 256 pp. Boston: Atlantic/Little, Brown. $14.95.

title: Television Week
description: Oliver's Odyssey ''You've got to put right out of your mind the fact that it's a classic,'' said Clive Donner, the British director, who has made a new version of Charles Dickens's ''Oliver Twist.'' He was voicing his concern that the classics could intimidate a director.

title: Poll Finds Americans Favor Nuclear Weapons Freeze, 3-2
description: Americans would vote for a freeze on nuclear weapons by a margin of 3 to 2 if it were on local ballots in their areas, according to a poll released today.

title: Headliners; A Carey Indicted
description: Martin Carey was perhaps the least publicized of Governor Carey's four brothers - until last week, when his name turned up on a 17-count felony indictment. The 60-year-old Mr. Carey pleaded not guilty to charges that he evaded $122,000 in sales taxes on gasoline sold by Petroleum Combustion International, a Long Island gas station chain he once controlled. Mr. Carey's lawyer suggested that if anyone had finagled with the company's taxes, it was someone to whom Mr. Carey had ''delegated responsibility for preparation and filing'' of the tax returns in question.

title: HAWKS DEFEAT KNICKS, 104-98
description: No lead is safe for the Knicks. After dominating with their outside shooting and opening a 22-point advantage with 3 minutes 23 seconds remaining in the first half, the Knicks did a quick disappearing act in the third period and lost, 104-98, to the Atlanta Hawks before a booing crowd of 10,016 last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Travel Advisory; 'World of Heroes' in Greece
description: A visit to the long-lost royal tomb of Philip II of Macedonia, father of Alexander the Great, will highlight a series of 21-day explorations of Greece entitled ''The World of Heroes.''

title: Dr. Margaret Drum Engaged to Dr. Steven Brody
description: Mr. and Mrs. Earl William Drum of Portsmouth, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Margaret Ann Drum, to Dr. Steven Andrew Brody of New York, son of Mrs. Irwin Jacoby of New York and the late Dr. Benjamin Brody of New York.

title: Ideas and Trends; No More Soho News
description: Another decision in the British publishing world last week meant one less newspaper in New York City. The Associated Newspaper Group, a British organization with interests in The American Lawyer and Esquire magazine, announced the closing of its other American enterprise, The Soho News in New York.

title: Stock Tables
description: To the Business Editor: It has become increasingly difficult to follow the New York Stock Exchange quotes for common stocks. The reason is that over the years a large number of preferred stocks have been added to the list.

title: SOUTH KOREA SEIZES 5,700 AFTER FIRE AT U.S. OFFICE; South Korea Police Seize 5,700 in Overnight Search
description: The police detained more than 5,700 people in Seoul in an overnight search for arsonists they said set fire to a United States International Communications Agency office in Pusan on Thursday.

title: TEXT OF A U.S. REPORT ON CUBAN AND NICARAGUAN ROLE IN SALVADOR REBELLION
description: Following is the text of a Government report called ''Cuban and Nicaraguan Support for the Salvadoran Insurgency,''which was made public today by the State Department: I. Introduction

title: TWO NEW PLAYS ABOUT TYHE WORLD OF BLACK SOUTH AFRICA
description: At the center of the long, narrow room, a little knot of men and women huddles in respectful silence around a nervous young couple. Vows are exchanged, then a wedding ring, after which the group erupts in a joyful song that soon has everyone in the party stamping out rhythms powerful enough to make the bare wooden floor vibrate like the head of a drum.

title: Editor's Choice
description: Irish writer. A BIGAMIST'S DAUGHTER, by Alice McDermott. (Random House, $13.50.) A first novel about a young woman who works for a vanity press.

title: HEALTH IS FOCUS OF WEEK
description: THE Health Expo, sponsored last year by WFSB-TV in Hartford and the American Red Cross, was so successful that another health-screening program has been scheduled from this Saturday to April 3 in towns throughout the state. The program is aimed at helping residents of Connecticut and parts of western Massachusetts use community health resources, its sponsors say.

title: SOUTHWEST: RED ROCK COUNTRY
description: PHYLLIS A. WHITNEY is the author of more than 50 suspense novels; the latest, ''Vermilion'' (Doubleday), is set in the red rock country of Arizona. By PHYLLIS A.WHITNEY

title: Virginia Mary Connor Bride of Brian Patrick Shay
description: Virginia Mary Connor, daughter of Mrs. Frank P. Connor of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Connor, was married yesterday to Brian Patrick Shay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Shay of Yonkers. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William R. O'Leary and the Rev. Karl D. Laird at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.

title: AT 20,TENNIS STAR SEEKS TO ADVANCE
description: WOODBURY NEIGHBORS remember Barbara Potter as an 8-year-old, tall for her age, playing tennis with her mother. The Potters (including four sons and a daughter) were into skiing, but Mrs. Potter did not ski and Barbara felt her mother was being left out. So once or twice a week the two went to the courts and had fun slamming the balls at each other.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
WHERE BUGS ARE WELCOMED
description: EWING TOWNSHIP MOST architects, developers and builders work hard to get the bugs out of their projects. But the people involved in a project in this Mercer County township are working hard to get the bugs in.

title: The Region; Looks Like Curtains
description: The next cast to bring down the house at the Morosco and Helen Hayes Theaters could be the wreckers. On Tuesday, the State Court of Appeals refused to hear an appeal by the Natural Resources Defense Council to delay demolition of the Broadway theaters to make way for the Portman hotel.

title: Business Conditions; GOING PUBLIC PICKS UP
description: With favorable changes in the tax law and revamped Securities and Exchange Commission rules on the sale of corporate equity and debt, the number of companies going public has increased dramatically over the last two years, and set a record in 1981.

title: 12 Hours of Sebring Is Won by the Pauls
description: John Paul and John Paul Jr., their powerful Porsche Turbo 935 sputtering on five cylinders for the last two hours, held on tonight and won the Coca-Cola 12 Hours of Sebring sports car race.

title: 8 COSMOS' PLAYERS NOT ON TRIP
description: The Cosmos, who closed their training camp in the Bahamas last week, will play their second exhibition game against a North American Soccer League team, the Earthquakes, in San Jose this afternoon.

title: THE NOVEL: A CONJUNCTION OF OPPOSITES
description: DISTANT RELATIONS By Carlos Fuentes. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. 225 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95.

title: U.S. WON'T OPPOSE TALKS IN U.N. BODY
description: The United States said today that it would not oppose Nicaragua's request for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council. Nicaragua, in a request Friday, said it was seeking the meeting to present charges that Washington was threatening an ''imminent'' invasion.

title: Television Week
description: That Time Clock For ordinary workers the office is a ''battleground,'' says Bruce Gilbert. He produced the 1980 film ''9 to 5,'' about three women office workers - played by Jane Fonda, Lily Tomlin and Dolly Parton - whose on-the-job revolt created better working conditions and greater efficiency - as well as some hearty laughs.

title: About Books And Authors
description: General Utility

title: BENCH HELPS TO ELIMINATE BIRMINGHAM
description: In January, the Louisville basketball team struggled through a stretch in which it lost five of six games, including four in a row. ''I guess after the way we played back in the middle of the year, nobody thought that we had a chance,'' Denny Crum, the Cardinals' coach, said today.

title: Live Reports Planned
description: On 3d Shuttle Flight By The Associated Press

title: Correspondents' Choice
description: Soviet Union Old capitals and a Siberian sidetrip

title: The 25-Year History Of Common Market
description: Following is a listing of important dates in the 25-year history of the Common Market, or, as it is formally known, the European Economic Community:

title:
GARDENING;
THE RIGHT SOIL MENU FOR THE RIGHT DIET
description: BECAUSE the soils in which we grow our plants are often lacking in quantity or balance of nutrients, we must compensate by applying fertilizers.

title: Spurs 115, Cavaliers 102
description: George Gervin scored 20 of his 41 points in the third quarter for San Antonio.

title: A Parks Commissioner Praises the Scouts
description: As a Commissioner of Parks and Recreation in the northern Westchester community of Yorktown, my interest in the article ''Groups Struggling to Protect Parks in Budget Crisis'' (Feb. 21) is more than casual.

title: ANTINUCLEAR POSITION PROVES COSTLY IN AMARILLO, HOME OF WEAPONS PLANT
description: Last spring a worker at the Pantex plant outside Amarillo, where all of the nation's nuclear warheads are assembled, made an appointment to see Bishop Leroy T. Matthiesen of the Diocese of Amarillo. The man, who was in his late 50's and had been a Pantex employee for 17 years, said he had begun to worry, as a faithful Roman Catholic, that working at the plant might be morally wrong.

title: 'SYLVIA': A POST-ROMANTIC BALLET TO HEAR
description: ''Nietszche claimed to have heard 'Carmen' 30 times in a row. We could commit ourselves to do the same for the pizzicato, adagio and coda of 'Sylvia.' '' So wrote Andre Levinson, the eminent French-Russian critic about ''Sylvia,'' a ballet first presented at the Paris Opera in 1876 and admired in 1925 by Levinson in a revival with the ballerina, Carlotta Zambelli.

title: Major News; A Harbinger Discounted
description: Not long ago, news that the nation's industrial output had risen at last might have been taken as a sign of good times ahead. But last week's Federal Reserve Board report of a 1.6 increase - the first since July, when the recession began - was greeted by more reminders of the economy's delicate condition.

title: PACT ON COURT SEATS TO BE HONORED
description: MARTIN MELLMAN, the new Nassau County Democratic leader, said last week that he would honor a bipartisan deal he inherited despite Governor Carey's refusal to abide by it.

title: WEATHER'S SUBTLE COST
description: This winter's cold spell incurred extraordinary costs. Additional use of fuel and snow-removal services and animal feed, more dead livestock and damaged crops and property, and an increase in lost working days were directly attributable to the weather. But the economy also paid for subtle biometeorological costs of weather-induced and weather-intensified ailments, disabilities, fatigue, aches and pains, low spirits, lost sleep - all ultimately diminishing alertness, performance, and productivity.

title: PUERTO RICO'S COUNTRY INNS
description: ROBERT W. STOCK is a senior editor of The New York Times Magazine. Caryl Stern, an actress and freelance writer, helped in the research and writing of this article. By ROBERT W. STOCK

title: Travel Advisory; CLUB MED, OAXACA, GOETHE; Club Med Eyes China
description: The 3-million-member Club Mediterranee, with 88 vacation villages in 26 countries, plans to build its newest resort near Canton in the People's Republic of China.

title: Maureen Demar Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Neil J. Demar of Schenectady, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Ann Demar, to Gary David Hall, son of Mrs. Richard Weber, also of Schenectady, and Dewey J. Hall of Bellaire, Tex. The wedding is planned for June 5.

title: BELGIUM'S BILL COMES DUE FOR PROPPING UP INDUSTRY
description: Belgian steelworkers rioted in the streets of Brussels, Charleroi and Liege last week protesting European Common Market orders that would wipe out 10,000 jobs in the depressed Frenchspeaking region of Wallonia, where Cockerill-Sambre, a troubled steel company, is the largest employer. Two hundred policemen were injured and strikes closed most of Belgium's steel plants. A general strike was called for this Friday, threatening to topple the precarious right-wing coalition Government.

title: GROWING OLD BLACK IS DOUBLY DIFFICULT
description: ''IF YOU are black and poor, you're in trouble,'' says Naomi Epps of the Passaic County chapter of the National Caucus on Black Aged. ''And if you're old as well, and sick, you might as well die. No one is going to help you.''

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC Nick Lowe, who is at the Palladium on Friday, called his first album ''Pure Pop For Now People.'' And although his witty, melodious, kinetic, ingeniously derivative pop music is hardly ''pure,'' it is certainly contemporary. Mr. Lowe was the Renaissance Man of British rock's New Wave in the mid-70's. He made several influential singles and albums under his own name and several more as singer and bassist with Rockpile. He produced innovative albums for other artists, most notably Elvis Costello and Graham Parker. His New Wave credentials are so impressive that most of his fans have forgotten (or forgiven) his activities during the 60's - he was a member of Brinsley Schwartz, a hippie country-rock band.

title: A NEW ROLE FOR AN OLD VETERAN
description: BAYONNE IN 1959, the World War II aircraft carrier Enterprise weighed anchor here on her final journey. She was bound for Kearny, a few miles up the Hackensack River. At a shipyard there, workmen with torches and pneumatic hammers dismantled the legendary vessel, which had taken part in virtually every sea and air battle in the Pacific.

title: PASSION AND PUNISHMENT
description: SOUTHERN DISCOMFORT By Rita Mae Brown. 249 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.50.

title: The Complexities Of School Aid
description: The debate on school aid changes is unfortunately not as clear and uncomplicated as the recent article ''Debate Heating Up on School Aid Changes'' would indicate.

title: Provincial Run-Off Vote; Held Today In France
description: President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Government urged a huge voter turnout in provincial elections on Sunday that mark a major nationwide test of his 10-month-old administration.

title: Marjorie T. Belli To Be the Bride Of Amos S. Eno
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Belli of Lawrenceville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Theresa Belli, to Amos Stewart Eno, son of Mr. and Mrs. Amos Eno of Princeton, N.J., and Hulls Cove, Me.

title: W.G. WOOD WILL WED DEBORAH CHAPIN GRAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas M. Gray Jr., of Duxbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Chapin Gray, to W. Godfrey Wood of Chestnut Hill and Nantucket, Mass., son of Mrs. Cary Potter of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Sidney B. Wood Jr., of Southampton, L. I. The wedding is planned for next June.

title: 'SUGGESTERS OF THE YEAR' SAY THE IDEAS ARE SIMPLE
description: They had been named ''Suggesters of the Year'' by their companies for simple but brilliant suggestions that saved their employers thousands of dollars a year. Now they were being honored at a luncheon after receiving cash awards from the companies. What had spurred the winners to find a better way to do things?

title: CONSUMER RATES
A Strong Quake Injures 82 in Northern Japan
description: A major earthquake hit northern Japan today, injuring at least 82 people, destroying houses and damaging roads and power lines, the Kyodo News Agency said.

title: Fever Defeats Arrows
description: The last-place Philadelphia Fever rallied from a 3-1 halftime deficit and defeated the New York Arrows, 4-3, in a Major Indoor Soccer League game today at the Spectrum.

title: 'FELT I HAD A STORY TO TELL THE WORLD'
description: ''ROCKY and I have known each other for about 36 years,'' said Ralph Corsel as he reminisced about the former middleweight boxing champion Rocky Graziano. ''One day - this must have been about five years ago - I said, 'Rocky, it's been over 20 years since your first book' -''Somebody Up There Likes Me'' -'came out.'

title: Exhibition of El Greco Set for Three U.S. Cities
description: Spain's largest retrospective in 80 years of the Greek-born painter El Greco will go on exhibition at the Prado Museum on April 2 before traveling to three American cities, the Culture Ministry said Saturday.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: DOKES STOPS THOMAS IN FIFTH FOR NO. 25
description: ''Ladies and gentlemen, the heavyweight contender Larry Frazier is missing,'' Ed Derien, the ring announcer at the Playboy Hotel and Casino, said today.

title: By Sports of The Times; A Bear Prowling Among Wildcats
description: up shirts. During the layup drill, they are identified as Ez Ed, Chill, Horse, Giz, Happy, Horse, Ski, Queen, Woody and D. But the most appropriate nickname belongs to the Wildcat known as Bear, alias John Pinone, the blond, 6-foot-8-inch, 228-pound center. His hobby is bear-watching, and on the court he's more Kodiak than Teddy.

title: MIXING JAZZ AND CLASSIC STYLES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. BY ALLAN KOZINN

title: LOOKING FOR LOVE IN VAIN
description: A WEEKEND WITH CLAUDE By Beryl Bainbridge. 152 pp. New York: George Braziller. $10.95.

title: Notre Dame to Award Medal To Former Detroit Archbishop
description: John Cardinal Dearden, the retired Archbishop of Detroit who is an advocate of greater participation by lay people in the Roman Catholic Church, has been named the 1982 recipient of the University of Notre Dame's Laetare Medal.

title: Nicaragua Denounces Honduras Over Arrest
description: Nicaragua has protested over the arrest of a Nicaraguan doctor who sought the protection of the Nicaraguan Embassy in Honduras after deserting from a rightist exile band that launches fre quent attacks into this country from Honduran territory.

title: THEATER Stamford; MUSCIAN-WRITER GETS START IN 'BARN'
description: THE Ethel Kweskin Sterling Barn Theater is located at 1349 Newfield Avenue in Stamford, and while it exists in a state where theater flourishes, it is both an unusual enterprise and a bargain to attend.

title: FREELANCERS PRESS FOR WRITERS UNION
description: PRINCETON AN ORGANIZATION calling itself the New Jersey Local of the National Writers Union held its first recruitment meeting here last week. About 75 writers from around the state attended.

title: No Headline
description: High Tech and Mocha Fudge Cake After serving mocha fudge cake with mocha frosting to my 12 housemates, who thoroughly enjoyed every bite, I have a confession to make (''The Due Process of Beating Egg Whites,'' by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, Jan. 31).

title: IS THIS ENTERTIANMENT SPECIAL PROMOTING A SPECIAL INTEREST?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Zoglin is the television critic for The Atlanta Constitution. BY RICHARD ZOGLIN

title: Mailbox; Give Rickey His Full Due
description: To the Sports Editor: It is certainly true that the former baseball commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler welcomed the integration of the major leagues (''Happy Chandler on the Road to the Hall of Fame,'' The New York Times, March 14, 1982). But that his approval was decisive, or even necessary, for integration is questionable.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS'S MORATORIUM PROPOSAL AND THE ADMINISTRATION'S REPLY
description: ACongressional resolution calling for a nuclear weapons freeze, introduced this month by 17 senators and 122 representatives, has turned out to be only the first of several such initiatives. Representative Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, for one, has prepared a detailed plan of how a moratorium might work. The text of the original resolution, introduced by Senators Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, follows.

title: Politics; WILL FLORIO SEEK SENATE SEAT?
description: TRENTON WITH the number of Democratic candidates for United States Senator already at six and showing signs of increasing, James F. Maloney, the Democratic state chairman, will begin meeting with party leaders on Tuesday to see if there is any consensus about whom they would like to support.

title: JUST WHY ARE PSEPHOLOGISTS FLOCKING TO EL SALVADOR?
description: SAN SALVADOR THERE is to be a foreign invasion of El Salvador this week, one that most Salvadorans themselves are welcoming. More than 100 foreign observers will be arriving to monitor the final days of campaigning and next Sunday's elections.

title: PLAY: 'THE SEA ANCHOR,' A BATTLE OF THE SEXES
description: Although Ted (E.A.) Whitehead's dialogue is spiced with male sexual bravado, there is a strong streak of feminism in the work of this outspoken British dramatist. He writes about double standards in and out of marriage. In his plays, men, married or single, take liberal advantage of limitless romantic opportunity. Women, no matter what their marital status, are bound by accepted codes of behavior, and even a mistress can find herself treated as restrictively as if she were a wife.

title: 'FREEZE' BACKERS DEFEND CAMPAIGN
description: There is nothing revolutionary in survival. It is perhaps the most primal of man's instincts, and yet Jay Winik's article began by stating that ''a revolutionary event of profound importance could be taking place'' in Connecticut.

title: Another Plan Offered On Nuclear Accident
description: Well, I'm sure relieved. Now I know that if there's ever an accident at Indian Point, all I have to do is find the right Emergency Response Planning Area, take a shower and eat a roast beef sandwich with potato salad.

title: PARENTS ASK AID ON SCHOOL BUS ZONE
description: ALL over Long Island, parents with children enrolled in private schools are submitting transportation requests to their local school districts to meet the April 1 deadline. Some requests will be granted but many will be turned down.

title: Deborah Boardman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. I. Munn Boardman Jr. of Burlington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Lee Boardman, to Grant Hopkins Davis, son of Ann K. Davis of Peapack, N.J., and the late C. Malcolm Davis. A June 19 wedding is planned. The future bride is an account officer at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, where Mr. Davis is a senior representative of the Manufacturers Hanover Leasing Company.

title: Susan Zadek To Be Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Engle Zadek of Baltimore, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Joy Zadek, to Stephen Frank Mandel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mandel of Darien, Conn.

title: Ideas and Trends; Editorial Discretion
description: Being voted Britain's ''editor of the year'' for reshaping The Times couldn't secure Harold Evans a place in the good graces of the London newspaper's owner, Rupert Murdoch, or on the masthead. Last week, after days of in-fighting over whether he would resign, Mr. Evans did.

title:
Antiques;
AN OLD HOUSE IN ANDOVER HAS ASSUMED A NEW ROLE
description: ANDOVER BILL and Pat Heitman have converted an ailing clapboard house - it was built in 1868 - into the Great Andover Antique Company. The house, which is situated at 124 Main Street (Route 206) in this Sussex County town, has been tastefully renovated, its deep-molded woodwork and wide plank floors having been retained.

title: MEDICIAD'S BUREAUCRATIC BLOCKADE
description: WITH a sense of defeated idealism, I made the decision a few months ago not to accept new Medicaid patients for routine examinations in the medical office my husband and I operate.

title: Stockholm
description: To the Editor: R. W. Apple Jr.'s mention of ''austere'' Swedes in his ''What's Doing in Stockholm'' (Travel, Feb. 28) recalls the story of the two Danes, the two Norwegians and the two Swedes who are wrecked on a desert island. After two weeks, the two Danes have started a cooperative movement, the two Norwegians are fighting with each other - and the two Swedes are waiting to be introduced. J. HAITCHESS New York

title: GETTING IN TOUCH WITH TEXAS
description: MOLLY IVINS is a native Texan and a columnist for The Dallas Times-Herald. By MOLLY IVINS

title: Opera on Yiddish Actor To Have Premiere at Y
description: ''Mikhoels the Wise,'' a full-length opera by Bruce Adolphe and Mel Gordon, will have its world premiere at the 92d Street Y on May 8 and 9. The opera is based on the life of Solomon Mikhoels, considered to be the greatest Yiddish actor of the 20th century.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on California politics incorrectly stated the number of brothers now serving in the House of Representatives. It omitted Representatives Philip M. Crane and Daniel B. Crane, Illinois Republicans.

title: Cassaleria Heads Field In San Felipe Handicap
description: Cassaleria, who has earned more than $300,000 in his career, will make his second start of the year Sunday in the $133,800 San Felipe Handicap at Santa Anita.

title: The Region; Made in Japan to Run in New York
description: Stung in recent years by defects in newly purchased buses and subway cars, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was prepared to go to great lengths to get a good buy on its next new set of wheels. Last week, the M.T.A. announced it would go all the way to Japan.

title: No Headline
description: U. OF D.C. CAPTURES CROWN

title: LEONARD PROBST, DRAMA CRITIC
description: Leonard Probst, drama critic and radio news producer for many years with NBC News, died of cancer Friday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 60 years old.

title: A MAJORITY IN POLL WANT U.S. TO STAY OUT OF SALVADOR WAR
description: A majority of Americans fear that the United States will become involved in El Salvador as it was in Vietnam and want the Reagan Administration to stay out of the guerrilla war in that Central American country, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: LUXURY ECONOMY
description: GASOLINE prices may be inching downward - ''stabilizing'' seems to be the word of choice - but ''economy'' and its assorted adjectives continue to loom as the major building blocks in the auto makers' lexicon, even when a manufacturer has based his reputation on performance.

title:
Dance;
EMELIN ENDS SEASON WITH TWO GROUPS
description: THE Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck will present two unusual dance events next weekend. To close the theater's dance series this season, the Dinizulu African Dancers, Drummers and Singers will offer a program of songs and dances from South Africa, Nigeria, Ghana and Sierra Leone at 8:30 P.M. Saturday. And next Sunday afternoon, the Windemere Ballet Company will celebrate its 15th anniversary with a 2 P.M. performance.

title: Stage View; WHEN THE STAGE IS JUST A PRIZE-RING
description: Once upon a time President Goheen of Princeton made a profoundly provocative remark to a graduating class. ''If you want to be 100 percent persuasive,'' he said, ''don't be more than 85 percent right.'' It strikes me, as a result of some recent theatergoing experiences, that the same advice - in slightly adapted form - might well be given to beginning playwrights. Like this. If you want to be 100 percent persuasive, dramatically speaking, don't be more than 85 percent dramatic. A play needs some room to cool off.

title: 13 Are Injured in Smoky Fire In Hotel in Downtown Boston
description: A fire that broke out on in the 82-year-old Essex Hotel today injured 13 people.

title: No Headline
description: MISS JORDON ATTAINS HER FIRST PRO FINAL

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: PRISONER WITHOUT A NAME, CELL WITHOUT A NUMBER, by Jacobo Timerman. Vintage, $2.95. An Argentine Jew and former Buenos Aires newspaper editor tells how he was kidnapped and imprisoned by a right wing paramilitary group in April 1977, tortured but not found guilty of any crime and, after 29 months, released because of widespread national and international protests. His sparely written, impassioned account is seasoned with disturbing reflections on the nature and consequences of state terrorism.

title: TV View; SUPPOSE ONE NETWORK SPECIALIZED IN HIGH QUALITY
description: Let's pretend for a moment that one of the three major television networks wanted to try something wholly original in programming. Such a notion might seem far-fetched in a business where it has long been immensely profitable to do just what the other guy is doing. But in an era of rising program costs and increasing competition from cable and other new technologies, does business as usual make sense? What if your network's spinoffs, rip-offs and remakes, soap operas and situation comedies have simply stopped commanding a competitive share of the mass audience?

title: Maryon Guthrie And Roger Noble Will Marry May 1
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Claiborne Guthrie of Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maryon Lee Guthrie, to Roger Warren Noble, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Barnes Noble of Edwards, N.Y.

title: Carol Irons Plans June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clay Irons of Oyster Bay, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Louise Irons, to Christopher Jonathan Ross, son of Charles John Mabyn Ross, New Zealand Ambassador to Peru, and Mrs. Ross of Wellington, New Zealand, and Lima.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A HEARING is scheduled Tuesday in Southampton on a local law proposed by Supervisor Martin Lang that would make it more difficult for communities in the town to incorporate as villages.

title: Westmoreland Urges
description: Wartime Censorship

title: MERCE CUNNINGHAM THE MAVERICK OF MODERN DANCE
description: Merce Cunningham likes to observe insects under microscopes and animals in zoos. Exploring movement in all its aspects is his particular concern as a modern-dance choreographer, and he is quick to see its uses where others do not. Sitting on a bench in his New York studio the other day, he springs up and is suddenly transformed into a shortstop on an imaginary baseball diamond. Cunningham darts from side to side to field an invisible ball. ''You see?'' he says triumphantly, pointing out what few baseball fans ever notice: His shortstop's feet are turned out, allowing him to move with speed in either direction. Interested in speed himself, he has never agreed with modern dance's general rejection of ballet's turned-out foot position. ''You need it for momentum,'' he says.

title: Poll Finds Skepticism Over Space Program
description: Although half the American public is ''excited'' about tomorrow's planned launching of the space shuttle, far more people believe that too much is being spent on space exploration than believe that too little is being spent, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: WARSAW REPLACES DISSOLVED ASSOCIATION OF JOURNALISTS
description: The Government's announcement last night that it had abolished the Polish Journalists' Association culminates a campaign against a group that had been a spearhead of liberal change during the days of Solidarity.

title: Of Prices...
description: To the Business Editor: As a customer of ''Cohose,'' as we still call it, for the last 20 years, since the iron pipe rack and bare bulb days, I was pleased to see ''Fleeing Brooklyn, He Makes It in Cohoes'' (March 7).

title: WHICH COMES FIRST, ARMS CONTROL OR SECURITY?
description: Debate on limiting nuclear weapons intensified last week in Washington, Europe and presumably in Moscow, where Leonid I. Brezhnev announced a freeze on medium-range missiles. Eugene V. Rostow, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, discussed the issues earlier this month with Paul Warnke, his predecessor in the Carter Administration, before the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. Here are excerpts from their remarks and replies to audience questions.

title: ABOUT FORDHAM HILL
description: To the Editor:$

title: POLISH RULERS VS. WLADYSLAW BARTOSZEWSKI, ET AL.
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY MAY CUT 7,500 BUILDINGS FROM RENT STABILIZATION ROLLS
description: Almost 3,000 more buildings are to be dropped from the New York City rent stabilization program because their owners failed to pay dues to the organization that administers it.

title:
Literary Footnote;
OTIS FERGUSON, CRITIC
description: I FIND with regret that the work and even the name of Otis Ferguson are generally unknown to readers under 60. Older persons are likely to remember the work with pleasure. Much of it dealt with swing bands or well-crafted films and, by extension, with the revival of popular culture during the 1930's, an aspect of the period that is often neglected. Otis - I can't think of him coldly as ''Ferguson'' - approached those subjects freshly, accurately, with lyrical enthusiasm and contempt for anything faked. Everything he wrote was attentively read in its time, besides leaving echoes in the work of later critics. But the author, who had volunteered as a merchant seaman, was blown up by a German bomb in the Gulf of Salerno, and his writing could only be found in the back files of magazines, chiefly The New Republic. Now, after 40 years, it is good to learn that the best of the writing, in many fields, is being collected as an ''Otis Ferguson Reader,'' which the December Press, of Chicago, will publish.

title: Cook Wins L.I. Bowling
description: Steve Cook of Roseville, Calif., scored 733 for three games and defeated Earl Anthony in the final one today to win the Long Island Open championship at Garden City Bowl.

title: FISTFULS OF MASTERPIECES
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF ISAAC BASHEVIS SINGER By Isaac Bashevis Singer. 610 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: ANOTHER STATE GOVERNMENT COLLAPSES IN INDIA
description: The President of India has ordered the dissolution of the state legislature in Assam in northeastern India following the resignation of the government there.

title: Ideas and Trends; One Step Back, One Forward At the E.P.A.
description: If the Reagan Administration has failed to make its environmental policy popular, it hasn't been for want of trying. Three weeks ago the Environmental Protection Agency suspended the ban on burying liquid-waste containers in landfills.

title: ...And Service
description: To the Business Editor: ''How Not to Beat Last Year's Sales'' (March 14) by Ralph Shaffer hit the nail on the head. Inattentive, discourteous, even rude, sales clerks fail to understand the importance of the satisfied customer, and retailers' mechanization has made it difficult to buy even the necessary items.

title: Guy S. Brossy to Marry Nannette Hutchens June 5
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward Humes Laughlin of Huntsville, Ala., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Laughlin's daughter, Nannette Flournoy Hutchens, to Guy Smith Brossy, son of Mrs. George Basarich and Francis Edward Brossy of Grosse Pointe, Mich. A June 5 wedding is planned.

title: CONGRESS WEIGHS CURB ON ARMS RACE
description: Growing public concern about the nuclear arms race between the United States and the Soviet Union has stimulated renewed Congressional interest in arms control.

title: ON THE EAST END, A RISE IN RENTS, A DROP IN RENTERS
description: FEWER people have signed leases for the summer season throughout the resort areas of Suffolk County, as compared with last year at this time. This is according to brokers who are predicting a loss in their revenues of about 12 percent by Labor Day if things don't pick up this spring.

title: Sports People; No Grounders for Rose
description: Pat Corrales, manager of the Philadelphia Phillies; Philip Marone, the team physician, and Pete Rose say they now agree on a rehabilitation program for the problem with a lower-back muscle the first baseman developed playing tennis before spring training opened. Corrales was upset when he learned that Rose took infield practice Friday at the team's training camp in Clearwater, Fla., while the Phillies were in St. Petersburg.

title: Women to Serve on Awacs
description: Air Force women will be assigned to serve aboard Airborne Warning and Control planes for the first time, Air Force Secretary Verne Orr announced Tuesday. Women have been barred from serving on Awacs planes because the jobs were classified as combat-type duties. Air Force officials said the jobs had been reclassified so that women might either fly the planes or handle some of the technical duties.

title: FORT WAYNE WATER LEVEL RECEDES DESPITE RAIN; Flood Waters Recede In Fort Wayne, Ind.
