description: Flood waters receded in most areas of the city today despite a night of steady rain, and city officials said they hoped the network of dikes would hold while they planned cleanup operations.

title: R.L.C. Frost to Marry Martha Clark Dykema
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jere H. Dykema of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Clark Dykema, to Rainer Lindon Cullum Frost, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley T. Frost of Lincoln, Mass.

title: The Nation; Secret Agents May Be More So
description: The Senate last week overruled its Judicary Committee and voted to give a freer hand to Federal prosecutors who want to clamp down on reporters and anybody else who reveal the true identity of American intelligence agents.

title: Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALLEST OF THE EAGLES IS STANDING TALL
description: Tom Davis, the coach whose Boston College basketball team is in a regional final and only three victories from a national title, is a firm believer in his assistants.

title: Personal Finance; THE NEW LOOK OF THE CREDIT UNION
description: IT may be time to take a fresh look at your company credit union. T he days when it was simply a place for assembly line workers to get a car loan or save a few dollars a week are over. Credit unions, c ooperative financial institutions composed of people with a common b ond such as the same employer, have become purveyors of s ophisticated financial services and are sometimes a few steps ahead o f their competition for the consumer's dollar - banks and thrift i nstitutions.

title: The Nation; Odd Men Out In Illinois
description: In the first primary elections since Congressional district maps were redrawn to reflect, more or less, the 1980 census, three incumbent Illinois Congressmen - two of them Republicans - apparently lost their parties' nominations last week. Republican Representative Tom Railsback faced State Senator Kenneth McMillan and lost his first challenge since he was elected in 1966; and, in an incumbent vs. incumbent battle forced by reapportionment in which Illinois lost two of its 24 Congressional seats, G.O.P. Representative George M. O'Brien beat 12-term veteran Edward J. Derwinski, a senior member of the Foreign Affairs Committee.

title:
Dining Out;
A UNION OF SEAFOOD AND PASTA
description: AFIXTURE in Port Chester for five years, The Captain and the Admiral, a pretty and cheerful restaurant enjoys local popularity and success. Like many seafood restaurants, it offers a large selection of Italian dishes, the union of pasta with seafood longestablished and felicitous. Success, however, does not always indicate excellence, and the efforts of The Captain and the Admiral averaged no more than fair.

title: DRINKING-AGE FIGHT PERSISTS
description: TRENTON HEARINGS on bills designed to raise the state's minimum drinking age to 20 or 21 are expected to begin this spring, according to State Senator Frank X. Graves Jr., Democrat of Paterson and chairman of the committee to which the measures have been assigned.

title: A Fire Breaks Out at Macy's In Rubbish in Elevator Shaft
description: A fire broke out in a pile of rubbish in an unused elevator shaft at Macy's Department Store in Herald Square yesterday, minutes after the store's 6 P.M. closing, according to the Fire Department.

title: FILM: 'PABLO PICASSO: THE LEGACY OF A GENIUS'
description: An hour and a half isn't a very long time to devote to Picasso's long and varied career, but Michael Blackwood uses the feature-length documentary format to provide a solid overview. ''Pablo Picasso: The Legacy of a Genius'' traces the artist's career plainly and chronologically, accounting for its various stages and interviewing other artists about Picasso's importance. ''How did the many styles of Picasso affect the course of art in our time?'' a narrator asks in the best museum tour-guide fashion. The film does its level-headed best to provide an answer.

title: Mary Ellen Cohen Engaged
description: Anita Cohen of Coconut Grove, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Ellen Cohen, to Dr. Allen Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Kaufman of Kings Point, L. I. The future bride, daughter also of the late Edward Cohen, is creative supervisor at Young & Rubicam Inc., a New York advertising agency. Dr. Kaufman is assistant chief of nephrology at the Bronx Veterans Administration Medical Center.

title: Title to Minnesotans
description: Women gymnasts from Gustavus Adolphus College in Minnesota were the overall winners today in the championship event of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women at Keene State College.

title: Northeastern Six And Huskies Gain
description: A goal by the sophomore wing Bob Averill 14 seconds into overtime lifted Northeastern to a 3-2 triumph over Bowling Green tonight at the Northeastern Arena and sent the Huskies to the N.C.A.A. Division I hockey semifinals.

title: Highbrow Music To Hum
description: While the ''who cares if you listen'' attitude can be traced to some composers today, there are a substantial number of composers who would welcome a large audience of interested, curious and openminded concertgoers (''Highbrow Music to Hum,'' by Bernard Holland, Jan. 31). Rather than wearing public failure ''almost as a badge,'' as Mr. Holland suggests, these composers are saddened by the fact that what they create with conviction is of little interest to most people.

title: RIDGEWOOD-GLENDALE OPENS ITS DOORS
description: The opening scene for ''All in the Family,'' a street of tidy, if tediously uniform, row houses, was filmed in Glendale, Queens, many residents contend. Although the producers of the television program decline to confirm or deny that, the residents continue to believe it.

title: Two Election Cases: A Contrast
description: In Nassau County, John T. Cain, a New York City school teacher and father of four, faced felony perjury charges, loss of his teaching job and a possible state prison sentence (''Election Challenge Leading to a Trial Neither Side Wants,'' Feb. 21) because it was alleged that in some instances, husbands or wives signed his petition as an insurgent candidate in a Republican primary against State Senator Ralph Marino on behalf of their spouses. (Mr. Cain was recently convicted of two misdemeanors, but not of a perjury charge, a felony.)

title: 18 Jehovah's; Witnesses Arrested in Nicaragua
description: Government agents arrested 18 Jehovah's Witnesses missionaries today and expelled at least 9 on charges of ''antirevolutionary activities,'' United States Embassy sources said.

title: Nordiques 3, Canucks 3
description: Marian Stastny slammed a rebound over Brodeur, the goalie, at 17:44 of the third period to gain the tie for Quebec in a game marred later by a fight between several Canucks and fans.

title: THE THINGS THAT SAY IT'S SPRING
description: ON a special evening, after the sun has shifted its mysterious passage across the imaginary border of the solstice, the peepers of spring come awake en masse to sing their celebration of the event.

title: Stage View; TWO NEW PLAYS ABOUT THE WORLD OF BLACK SOUTH AFRICA
description: NEW HAVEN In ''A Lesson from Aloes,'' a soul-searing drama about guilt, suspicion and the need for individual responsibility, Athol Fugard used the hardy, cactus-like aloe plant as a symbol of survival in a hostile environment. His new play, ''Master Harold ...and the boys,'' in its world premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater, is equally brilliant, but it represents the author in a reflective mood.

title: James Naylor 4th To Wed Dale Rice
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Grantland Rice 2d of Birmingham, Ala., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dale Snowden Rice, to James Bernard Naylor 4th, son of Mr. Naylor 3d of Pepper Pike, Ohio, and the late Mrs. Bingham Naylor.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: WRITERS AND FRIENDS By Edward Weeks. 323 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. $15.95.

title: TRANSLATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: AN ARRAY OF LOCAL TALENT
description: IT is flattering that more and more artists of international repute are including the county among their touring ports of call. Still more gratifying, however, is the fact that there is such a rich array of musical talent here. This afternoon at 3 o'clock, for instance, ''an altogether exceptional soprano, musician and lieder singer'' (to quote The Boston Globe) gives a benefit recital for the Taghkanic Chorale.

title: OWNING UNHEALTHY HOMES CAN BE A LONELY BUSINESS
description: If a toaster is defective, it can be exchanged. If a car is defective, it might be recalled. But what does a consumer do when his home becomes a defective product? The answer seems to be ''live with it,'' as homeowners are discovering with the Federal Government's recent ban on urea formaldehyde foam insulation.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 21, 1982
description: International OPEC agreed to cut oil production by about 700,000 barrels a day to reduce the worldwide surplus of oil and bolster prices. The decision by the organization's 13 ministers at their meeting in Vienna was their first formal production agreement. The reduction was greater than had been expected and included a 500,000-barrel-a-day reduction by Saudi Arabia. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title:
Comment;
IT'S JUST A RECESSION
description: ''T HE Great Repression'' (March 14) notwithstanding, what this nation is experiencing, so far, at least, is neither repression nor depression but a plain old, relatively sharp recession.

title: THE FRENCH WAY, WITH STYLE
description: WESTPORT Plus ,ca change plus c'est la meme chose. WHEN it comes to restaurants, as the French know better than anyone else, this is not necessarily true. In fact, one of the hazards of restaurant reviewing is that restaurants change all too frequently, and rarely is the change for the better.

title: ANTARCTICA YIELDS FIRST LAND MAMMAL FOSSIL
description: A team of American scientists has just returned from the Antarctic with the fossil remains of the first land mammal ever found there.

title: LUXURY SILKS ALSO HIT HOME
description: Until recently, humble but high-priced fabrics such as hand-painted canvas were all the rage in custom workshops and department stores. Today, silk - in all its unabashed luxury - is making a comeback. Isbell & Elliott Artisans hand-decorates silk with silver or 24-karat gold-leaf paint. The fabrics, which range in price from $265 to $375 per yard, are finished in varying degrees of stiffness so that they may be used as wall coverings, upholstery or curtains. Available through architects and interior designers at Donghia Textiles Inc., 979 Third Avenue.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM PRESENTS SOLO 'TANGO'
description: ''Is it porn?'' someone asked as the curtain rose on Merce Cunningham in his dance solo,''Tango,'' Friday night at the City Center. The reference was presumably to the bedroom scene being broadcast on the television set positioned onstage to the dancer's right.

title: 2 SHARE GOLF LEAD
description: Ray Floyd enlivened the third round of the Tournament Players Championship today by making his tee time with the help of a chartered jet and a helicopter, but the ground action was more significant as Bruce Lietzke and Brad Bryant tied for the lead after three rounds.

title: Sten Stovall, Myanna Larsen Engaged
description: Jorgen Ost Larsen of Klampenborg, Denmark, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Myanna Ost Larsen, to Sten Torben Stovall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stovall of New York City, Barnegat Light, N.J., and Honesdale, Pa.

title: IN COMMON MARKET AT 25, UNCERTAINTY OVER FUTURE;
description: The partnership of 10 Western European democratic countries that makes up the Common Market will be 25 years old this week. While the community has much to celebrate, it regrets some of its past and worries about its future.

title: JERSEY CASINOS TELL PANEL PROFITS ARE DIPPING
description: Casino executives told a new Assembly committee at public hearings this week that while casino revenues here had been ''astounding,'' the profitability of the industry had steadily declined and casinos needed help from the Legislature to stop the slide.

title: Rangers Win, 4-3, On 3 Goals in Third
description: The Rangers played sluggishly for most of the first two periods against the Washington Capitals tonight but managed enough sporadic bursts of energy and desperate defense to win, 4-3, at the Capital Centre.

title: RECITAL: MARILYN HORNE
description: There was a threat that Friday night's recital by Marilyn Horne at Avery Fisher Hall would turn into a cult affair when, with the program still in its infancy, a man staggered from the front row of seats ontothe stage to present Miss Horne with a bouquet.

title: CONTROVERSIAL PAINTING ON VIEW AFTER 47 YEARS
description: WHEN he became famous overnight during the Depression year of 1934, Paul Cadmus was one of hundreds of American artists producing paintings in exchange for the dole of the Public Works of Art Project, which later became part of the Works Progress Administration.

title: R.E. Planitzer Weds Ruth Fleischmann
description: Ruth Gardner Fleischmann, daughter of Mrs. Benno C. Schmidt and Peter F. Fleischmann, both of New York, was married yesterday to Russell Edward Planitzer, son of Mrs. Walter W. Planitzer of Lunenburg, Mass., and the late Mr. Planitzer. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony in St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: DODGERS WAIT FOR VALENZUELA
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers conceded today that they were likely to open the season without Fernando Valenzuela, who was 3,000 miles away and still holding out for more money with only two weeks left in spring training.

title: Abbott S. Fenichel Fiance Of Marsha Ellen Fruman
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Fruman of Newton Center, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Marsha Ellen Fruman, to Abbott Seth Fenichel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Fenichel of Smithtown, L.I. The wedding is planned for next November in Boston.

title: Susan Long Ketcham Becomes Bride Of Lloyd H. Coffin 3d in Hewlett, L.I.
description: Susan Long Ketcham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Bonbright Ketcham of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday to Lloyd Hibbert Coffin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Coffin Jr. of Naples, Fla., and Wolfboro, N.H. The ceremony was performed at Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I., by the Rev. Dr. Earle W. Pratt Jr.

title: South African Jail Bombed
description: An explosion today damaged an empty cell block that normally holds blacks accused of violating South African pass laws, the police said. They said there were no injuries in the explosion at the jail on the Cape of Good Hope peninsula near Cape Town.

title: Washington; REAGAN AND THE PRESS
description: President Reagan is sore at the television and newspaper reporters these days, and no wonder. They keep reporting what he says, which is often more harmful to his cause than the things his opponents say against him.

title: Business Conditions; AUTO OUTPUT AT A CRAWL
description: The auto industry, whose performance seems to hit new lows with frequency these days, set another record of sorts last month. Although production was up from January levels, Detroit's output was the lowest February total in 34 years, according to Automotive News, the trade publication.

title: A HAMSTER DIES, AND CHILD FACES THE SPECTER OF DEATH
description: MY 10-year-old daughter's Teddy Bear hamster recently caught what I diagnosed as pneumonia, suffered a few hours and died. When she bought him, a year and half ago, remembering that I had never seen a hamster in a veterinarian's waiting room, I wondered to myself what one did should a hamster get sick. Hamsters, it seems, are more expendable than dogs and cats. But I didn't try telling that to my daughter the night Rascal died. His death left her heartbroken.

title: A TASTE OF THE NEW AND THE OLD AT ATHENEUM
description: HARTFORD FIVE large paintings by the contemporary Italian artist, Francisco Clemente, are hanging in the Matrix Gallery at Wadsworth Atheneum through April 18. Nearby in the same museum is ''In the Antique Taste,'' a show that examines the stirrings of Neo-Classicism in 18th-century French art (through April 4).

title: THE DARK SIDE OF THE OIL GLUT
description: WASHINGTON THE Chrysler Corporation, with sales of big cars this year running 20 percent ahead of 1981 levels, is worried enough to urge a 25-cents-a-gallon tax on gasoline.

title: ISLAND GUIDEBOOKS: AN APPRAISAL
description: JO THOMAS has recently completed an assignment as Caribbean bureau chief of The New York Times. By JO THOMAS

title: GEORGETOWN RIDING A CONFIDENT ROAD
description: Two months ago, the Georgetown basketball team was riding a 13-game winning streak and had a 14-2 record. Then it lost three straight Big East Conference games, to Syracuse, Connecticut and Providence.

title: GENERAL MOTORS AND AUTO WORKERS REACH SETTLEMENT
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and General Motors Corporation reached a tentative agreement on a new contract late today after more than 37 hours of continuous bargaining.

title: Miss Jordan Wins
description: Unseeded Kathy Jordan captured her first major singles tournament today by fighting back to defeat Wendy Turnbull, 7-5, 1-6, 6-4, in the final of a $150,000 Avon event.

title: Washington Watch; Oil-Price Effect On Recovery
description: WASHINGTON SKIDDING oil prices are cheering Reagan Administration economic analysts, who are convinced that what have already been significant savings in energy bills represent a major plus for economic growth.

title: Accounts
description: * Satellite Music Network, Dallas, to Bloom Advertising Too Inc.

title: A Round for Civilization
description: No one can say what political sunspots affect the climate for terrorism, but for the moment it has turned inclement. The news is of failed kidnappings, foiled hijackings and multiple arrests as defectors betray comrades.

title: PRESIDENT'S BODYGUARDS TO GET TRAINING CENTER
description: The government will build a Hollywood-like set of the White House and other buildings for training Secret Service agents in protecting Presidents, according to spokesman for the agency.

title: Henderson & Friedlich Gets Muzak Account
description: Henderson & Friedlich is going to be doing advertising and market promotion for Muzak, the tuneful subsidiary of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company. The previous agency was Van Brunt & Company.

title: Ruling Is Awaited On Buffalo G.I.
description: BUFFALO (AP) - A ruling is expected Tuesday on Pvt. Joseph G. Christopher's mental fitness to stand trial on charges that he killed three black men with a .22-caliber weapon in September 1980.

title: Jury to Receive Musto Case Today
description: NEWARK (AP) - After four months of testimony and arguments in Federal District Court here, the racketeering trial of William V. Musto, the Mayor of Union City, and seven others is expected to go to the jury today.

title: No Headline
description: MUBARAK IS SENDING AIDE TO ISRAEL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As I see it, the bird is ready, the weather's great, we're ready, the entire team is ready.

title: WHAT THE AUTO INDUSTRY WANTS TO DO TO THE CLEAN AIR ACT
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTE ON WILL CITED IN '78 UTAH MURDER
description: A New York woman being held on charges that she had her teen-age son murder her wealthy father in Salt Lake City was criticized for her profligate spending and threatened with disinheritance in a memorandum the father wrote just months before he was killed, a business associate said yesterday.

title: CONSERVATIVE G.O.P. HELP FOR WEICKER
description: At first blush, Republican Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut would not seem the most natural of allies.

title: FIVE MORE PALESTINIANS ARE SHOT
description: Five more Palestinians were shot and wounded by Israeli soldiers in clashes today in the West Bank, an Israeli Army spokesman said, bringing to 15 the number shot since March 6.

title: Stroller With Child Dragged by Auto
description: A car speeding out of Central Park at 96th Street and Fifth Avenue ran over a stroller carrying an 18-month-old girl, wrenching the stroller from the mother's hands and dragging it and the child 13 blocks, the police said.

title: I.R.A.'S GET OFF TO SLOW START
description: Despite an advertising blitz by the nation's financial institutions, investment in Individual Retirement Accounts since the beginning of the year has been slower than hoped, if not disappointing.

title: 'Let's Win It For Coach'
description: ABOUT three weeks ago Jimmy Black, the playmaker on the North Carolina basketball team, called a meeting of his teammates in his Granville Towers dormitory room. ''This is it,'' Jimmy Black said that day. ''This is the year we're going to win the national championship for Coach Smith.''

title: Bucks Top Nets, 102 to 86
description: From any viewpoint, it was difficult to find something pleasant about the Milwaukee Bucks' 102-86 victory over the New Jersey Nets today.

title: FIRST TAPED TRIAL SET IN SLAYING CASE
description: When the murder trial of 19-year-old David Lange begins Monday in Erie County Common Pleas Court, there will be no objections to testimony, no arguments about evidence and no lengthy conferences at the judge's bench.

title: Widower of Ella Grasso Is Married in Vermont; A Vermont Wedding
description: Thomas Grasso, the husband of the late Governor of Connecticut, Ella T. Grasso, was married on Saturday to Eleanor Roosevelt Braman. Only members of the immediate families of the couple attended the wedding, which took place in Stowe, Vt.

title: PACKAGE SIGNED FOR FINANCING PORTMAN HOTEL
description: The complex package of financing for the Portman Hotel project in the Times Square area has been formally signed, and the United States Supreme Court is expected to decide today whether construction can proceed.

title: Sports World Specials; A Best Bet
description: There is a new wagering rule in effect at New York State's race tracks this year, one designed to quiet the bettors, and it had an unusual application in the first race at Aqueduct a week ago yesterday. Two horses, Frontier Gold and River Shannon, were coupled as an entry and bet down to 3-1 odds in a claiming race with a $7,000 purse.

title: Webb Account Moves To Lewis & Gilman
description: O.K. Monopoly fans, the powers that be in the Del Webb Claridge Hotel and Hi-Ho Casino, at the corner of Boardwalk and Indiana Avenue in Atlantic City, have opted to move its advertising account from Fifer Advertising in Newtown Square, Pa., to Lewis & Gilman in Philadelphia.

title: MET OPERA: FINALISTS
description: THIS year's Metropolitan Opera auditions ended yesterday afternoon on the stage of the Met with a concert by its 11 finalists. The singers were chosen from 22 semifinalists gathered from regional auditions throughout the country this season.

title: MUSIC: MISS CANTEROS, PIANIST, PLAYS BEETHOVEN AND RAVEL
description: dozen other composers Thursday in a loosely structured program at Carnegie Hall. Her choice of repertory did not always play to her strengths as a pianist, so that although the recital offered all the variety one could ask for, it did not constitute a particularly gripping or pleasurable experience.

title: EAGLES SUFFER 99-92 SETBACK
description: After a string of upsets, Boston College, the team some said had no right to be in the national collegiate tournament, was finally eliminated this afternoon.

title: NEW ORLEANS MAYOR ELECTED TO 2D TERM IN RUNOFF VOTE
description: Ernest N. Dutch Morial, the city's first black Mayor, won re-election Saturday by a surprisingly wide margin in a runoff contest.

title: Waltrip Captures Curtailed Event
description: Darrell Waltrip won the rain-interrupted Coca-Cola 500-mile Grand National stock car race at Atlanta International Raceway today when officials halted the race with 40 laps remaining.

title: THE CIRCUS MAKES FELD A 'HAPPY MAN'
description: For a person who spent $22.8 million last week, it may be surprising that Irvin Feld says that he is ''a very, very happy man.'' The 63-year-old businessman and his family, however, just bought the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus - ''The Greatest Show on Earth'' -which they owned once before and have been managing for more than 15 years.

title: NESTLE SELLS SITE IT SAID IT NEEDED TO STAY IN STATE
description: Five years after a threat by the Nestle Company to leave New York State galvanized officials into helping it with a planned move to Harrison, the company has sold the halfcompleted building that was to have become its new headquarters.

title: HARD-ROCK: LAURA BRANIGAN
description: THE success of Pat Benatar, a hard-rock singer with a cabaret background, has inspired other female singers with ''legit'' voices to try higher-powered rock singing. Following in the footsteps of Karla DeVito and Laurie Beechman, both of whom have made rockoriented albums, comes Laura Branigan, the protege of the Atlantic Records chairman, Ahmet Ertegun, who launched Bette Midler's recording career.

title: Somerset Makes Management Shifts
description: Somerset Importers, a subsidiary of Norton Simon, confirmed Friday that S.L. Sax, senior vice president, marketing and sales, and Thomas G. Murray, vice president and director of national sales, would be leaving the company.

title: Celtic Streak at 15
description: Larry Bird, who has not started since being injured two weeks ago, came off the bench today to start a third-quarter spurt that led the Celtics to their 15th consecutive victory, 123-111, over the 76ers.

title: WALESA BABY IS BAPTIZED, BUT FATHER IS NOT THERE
description: Lech Walesa's daughter, seven-week-old Maria Wiktoria, was baptized before a huge crowd in a small wooden church outside Gdansk today, but the Solidarity leader was not released from internment to attend the ceremony.

title: FAMILY PLASTIC ENTERPRISES ABOUND DESPITE ALL THE GIANTS
description: The top floor of the Garfield Manufacturing Company's warehouse is furnished with long schoolhouse-style oak desks, overhanging fluorescent lamps and the portrait of the company's founder, Frederick Bauer, an immigrant from Germany.

title: Rev. Charles Webber, 89, Dies; Pastor Active in Labor Groups
description: The Rev. Charles C. Webber, a Methodist minister active in labor groups, died Saturday at the Amsterdam Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old.

title: CREATING AN ULSTER
description: The object of Israel's policy in the West B ank and Gaza, as Government officials forthrightly say, is p ermanent effective control of the territories. An accelerating p rocess of absorption has gone far, in practical terms, toward that e nd.

title: PHILADELPHIA CRIME 'FAMILY' THRIVES AFTER TURMOIL
description: The Philadelphia ''family'' of organized crime has emerged with new leadership, growing ranks and increased wealth and power from a two-year series of slayings that began with the murder of its aging leader and continued last week with the most macabre killing yet, according to top investigative officials.

title: Bridge: Berkowitz and Lilie Share National Men's Pairs Title
description: The opening events in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here gave titles Saturday night to partnerships from New York and California.

title: Coke-Columbia Pact
description: The Coca-Cola Company said that the definitive agreement on its proposed acquisition of Columbia Pictures Industries had been signed by the management of both companies. Coca-Cola said Friday that completion of the $750 million transaction was subject to approval by stockholders of both companies, the completion of normal reviews and actions by Government agencies and the satisfaction of other conditions in the agreement.

title: STEINBRENNER CRACKS WHIP
description: An exhausted and unhappy Yankee team will assemble here Monday morning for an unusual workout ordered by George Steinbrenner, the team's owner, in the wake of today's 8-1 loss to the Baltimore Orioles.

title: UNBORN CHILDREN RECOGNIZED BY COURTS
description: To the Editor:

title: NICARAGUANS SAY INCURSIONS PROMPTED INDIANS' EVICTION
description: The Sandinist Government, which has been sharply criticized for forcibly removing some 10,000 Miskito Indians from land along the Honduran border earlier this year, is maintaining that the evictions were necessitated by growing incursions into northern Nicaragua by armed exile bands.

title: Piquet Captures Brazil Grand Prix
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil, the defending world champion driver, won the Brazilian Grand Prix today, then fainted on the winner's podium immediately after the grueling 63-lap race that covered 196.884 miles. The temperature at the Jacarepagua Raceway was 93 degrees.

title: POPE OFFERS A SPECIAL MASS FOR THE CATHOLICS OF CHINA
description: Pope John Paul II said an unusual mass in St. Peter's Basilica today on behalf of the Roman Catholics of China and afterward called on about 40,000 people in St. Peter's Square to pray that China's Catholics might again enjoy normal links with the center of their faith.

title: THE SCREEN: 'MEPHISTO,' A KLAUS MANN NOVEL
description: ''Mephisto'' was shown as part of the 1981 New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of Sept. 29. The film opens today at Cinema 1, Third Avenue and 60th Street.

title: BRONX HOUSING DEVASTATION FOUND SLOWING SUBSTANTIALLY
description: New York City officials and neighborhood activists say they are witnessing a marked slowing of the wholesale devastation that plagued the Bronx in the 1970's.

title: Girl Dies in Fire, Boy Badly Injured
description: Fire swept through a frame dwelling in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, killing a 7-year-old girl and critically injuring a 4-yearold boy, officials said.

title: Sabres 5, Canadiens 4
description: BUFFALO (UPI) - Lindy Ruff's third-period goal and a spectacular save by Don Edwards later in the period were the key plays for Buffalo.

title: Wisconsin Gains Hockey Semifinals
description: Pete Johnson scored with a second left to play today, enabling Wisconsin to beat Harvard, 4-3, and post a 10-4 two-game total-goal victory in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey playoffs. Johnson is the son of Coach Bob Johnson of Wisconsin.

title: CERTIFICATE TO BOLSTER THRIFT UNITS
description: Federal bank regulators, despite objections from some banking groups, are expected to approve on Monday a new short-term savings certificate intended to help thrift institutions and commercial banks better compete with money market funds.

title: Cheever Reading Canceled
description: The April 19 reading by the author John Cheever at the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y has been canceled because of illness. For refunds, call 427-4410.

title: TAR HEELS GET CONTROL EARLY
description: With an unusual amount of emotion for a basketball team that is accustomed to being in control of both its opponent and itself, North Carolina took hold of Villanova at the start of the East Regional championship game today and did not let go until it was time to plan another trip to the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: DARK DAYS FOR PLANE MAKERS
description: This prosperous prairie town thought it had given ''recession proof'' its true meaning. Situated where the Middle West meets the Sun Belt, Wichita breezed through the turbulent 1970's without a slump, thanks to its booming aviation and oil drilling industries.

title: HOW PRESIDENTS GET INVOLVED
description: When promising high school basketball players visit the Iona College campus in New Rochelle, there is an unusual stop to make. In addition to visiting the classroom buildings and the gymnasium, there is a talk with Brother John Driscoll, the college president. The intention is not to impress an 18-year-old. The purpose is to ask questions that Brother Driscoll feels will help an athlete understand his place at a college.

title: REAGAN ENDORSES RISE IN ATOMIC WARHEADS BY 380 OVER CARTER GOAL
description: President Reagan has endorsed a plan that calls for production over the next five years of about 380 more nuclear warheads than the level planned by the Carter Administration in its last year in office, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA AT THE TOP
description: DALLAS IT was near the end of a three-hour workout and Martina Navratilova, the champion tennis player, was serving to Gregg Manning, a young professional just starting on the men's tour. They were indoors in the green and white Brookhaven Tennis Club here.

title: ROCHESTER, STRAPPED, WEIGHS LETTING COUNTY CONTROL POLICE
description: A year ago, when this city was plunged into fiscal crisis by proposed Federal budget cuts and a court ruling against its property tax, hardly anyone took seriously an idea offered by the Chamber of Commerce: that the county government take over the city's Police Department.

title: No Headline
description: NICARAGUAN EXPULSIONS ARE PROTESTED BY U.S.

title: Harlem Y.M.C.A. Honoring Black Achievers
description: At a time when unemployment among black youths is high, black teenagers need to be reminded of the solid successes made by many black executives and professionals, whose quiet personal achievements are rarely publicized.

title: LOUIS TANNEN, 73, MAGICIAN, IS DEAD
description: Louis Tannen, a magician and magic-trick inventor who founded one of the largest and best-known magic-supply stores and mail-order businesses in the world, died Saturday at Biscayne Medical Center in North Miami Beach. He was 73 years old.

title: CRITICISM RISES ON REAGAN'S PLAN FOR 5-YEAR GROWTH OF THE MILITARY
description: President Reagan's five-year plan to expand the nation's armed forces has come under increasing attack not only from those who consider it too costly but also from critics who say the Administration has failed to justify the military need for its large budget.

title: Kaiser Is Promoted
description: It was not that he needed a promotion, let alone an additional time-consuming job, but someone had to head the Kaiser Family Foundation. And so, like his father and grandfather before him, Edgar F. Kaiser Jr., chairman of Kaiser Resources Ltd. and Kaiser Oil as well as owner of the Denver Broncos, moved up last week from vice chairman to board chairman of the Kaiser Family Foundation.

title: SURVIVORS OF HOLOCAUST SHARE THE PAINFUL PAST
description: It was a sometimes tearful, often passionate rush of memory and conviction, applause and silence. ''We have no apologies to make, that we couldn't retaliate, that we couldn't murder, that our parents did not give us the heritage of killing and of vengeance,'' said Dr. Helen N. Fagin, director of Judaic Studies at the University of Miami.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday on the wedding of Mariann Mazzullo incorrectly identified the bridegroom. He is H. Barry Burris.

title: Gettys Makes The Final 5
description: THEY have a saying at the University of Houston basketball practices: ''From headlights to tailpipes, we're all just Cougars.'' For 32 minutes yesterday, Reid Gettys was just another unused spark plug in a package on the shelf in the auto-supply store. His highoctane teammates were lurching and sputtering out on the highway.

title: Mrs. Gandhi in London
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India arrived today to open the most comprehensive show of India's culture seen in Britain and to meet Queen Elizabeth and government and opposition leaders. The eight-month festival, with nearly 30 exhibitions of art, science and costume, films and folk dancing, opens tomorrow. Mrs Gandhi was greeted at London Airport by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who visited India last April.

title: 9,000 Flood Refugees Begin Return in Indiana
description: Nine thousand refugees from Fort Wayne's weeklong flooding began returning to their muddy homes today as building inspectors made a house-to-house tour of affected neighborhoods.

title: THE EVIDENCE AGAINST HOUSING VOUCHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. MELTON 5-SHOT VICTOR
description: Nancy Lopez-Melton, who held a nine-shot lead after nine holes, faltered today with a one-over-par 73, but posted a five-shot victory in the $200,000 J & B Pro Am golf tournament.

title: 5 in Same Family Die in Plane Crash
description: Five members of a New York family were killed Sunday morning when their single-engine plane crashed into Bald Eagle Mountain near here while attempting to land in light drizzle and fog, the police said.

title: Jane Gilbert Married To Alfred Pleasanton
description: Jane Barbara Gilbert, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Rosenberg and the late Barney Gilbert, both of New York, was married yesterday at the St. Moritz Hotel to Alfred Richard Pleasanton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Pleasanton of Greenwich, Conn. New York County Judge Felice K. Shea performed the ceremony.

title: Books Of The Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt DINNER AT THE HOMESICK RESTAU- RANT. By Anne Tyler. 303 pages. Knopf. $13.50.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SHUFFLES TOP OFFICIALS
description: Tinsley H. Irvin, 48, has been elected president of Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., a major insurance brokerage firm. He succeeds John A. Bogardus Jr., 54, who has been appointed chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer. Kenneth W.S. Soubry, 62, who has been with the New York-based company for 31 years and most recently held the title of chairman, has been named vice chairman.

title: IN CAMBODIA, THAT SMILE
description: How different from all the other sunrises in our journey across the heart of Cambodia is this culminating dawn of Jayavarman's smile!

title: STRINGS: DELOS QUARTET PLAYS MOZART AND WEBERN
description: THE Delos String Quartet, which is affiliated with the University of Delaware but which tours widely, presented a solid, appealing concert Thursday night in the Abraham Goodman House. The players are technically adept and well matched, have responsive musical instincts and did honorable justice to the music performed.

title: METS BLANKED BY DODGERS
description: The Mets lost their fourth straight exhibition game today when Burt Hooton and Tom Niedenfuer held them to four hits and pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 5-0 victory.

title: SHIMATOREE TAKES BAY SHORE
description: Shimatoree surprised absolutely nobody by toying with six rivals and easily winning the $55,000 Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. But the 3-year-old colt's trainer, Dick Dutrow, was scowling in the winner's circle.

title: FATHER GREELEY: NEW NOVEL, NEW CONTROVERSY?
description: TUCSON Ariz. ALMOST from the day it was published last April, Andrew M. Greeley's ''The Cardinal Sins'' has generated a storm of criticism and controversy because of the portrait that the author, a Roman Catholic priest, painted of his church's hierarchy. The novel was on The New York Times hard-cover best-seller list for eight months, and now the paperback edition sits high on the best-seller list.

title: Sports World Specials; Help Wanted
description: Arizona State is in the process of hiring a new basketball coach and the usual proceedures in such matters will be followed. Dick Tamburo, the athletic director, has named a committee to screen the candidates and make recommendations to the university's athletic board.

title: Former Chief of C.I.A. Honored by O.S.S. Veterans; O.S.S. Veterans Award
description: The William J. Donovan Award, named for the late major general who founded the Office of Strategic Services during World War II, is given by O.S.S. veterans each year to those who have rendered singular and distinguished service to the United States, though not necessarily in the intelligence field.

title: Judge Grants Stay On St. Bart's Plan
description: A temporary stay of a plan to build a 59-story office tower on the site of the community house of St. Bartholomew's Church, at Park Avenue and 50th Street, was granted by Associate Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg of the State Court of Appeals.

title: Ketchum Executive Promotions Announced
description: Gerald J. Voros, who has been the head of the public relations unit of Ketchum Communications, Pittsburgh, has been promoted to president of the entire company.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; JAPANESE BEGIN CLEANUP AFTER EARTHQUAKE

title: HARLEM DISTRICT WILL ALLOW STUDENTS TO SELECT JUNIOR HIGH THEY'LL
description: ATTEND By GENE I. MAEROFF

title: VENTRILOQUIST: RONN LUCAS
description: SINCE Charlie McCarthy became a celebrity on Edgar Bergen's lap almost 50 years ago, ventriloquists' dummies have usually had some variation of Mr. McCarthy's round, beaming face and have played the roll of a smart-aleck, sex-conscious kid. Ronn Lucas, who is appearing in ''Sugar Babies'' at the Mark Hellinger Theater, has a dummy named Billy the Kid, who besides being in the McCarthy tradition, is taking ventriloquism to a new level. Mr. Lucas performed at a posttheater show last weekend at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street; he will return Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

title: A NUCLEAR FREEZE IS GOOD FOR AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Libya Frees 3 French Citizens It Had Sentenced for Spying
description: A French woman and her two sons, pardoned by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, after being sentenced to life imprisonment on espionage charges, have been handed over to the French Embassy in Tripoli and will return to Paris Monday, officials said today.

title: Ethiopian Is First In Cross-Country
description: Mohammed Kedir of Ethiopia won the 10th world cross-country championships today, edging Alberto Salazar of the United States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bell & Howell, Chicago, has elected Richard L. Miller, president of the microfilm products division, and Frank Perna Jr., president of the instrumentation group, to corporate vice presidents.

title: DOBRYNIN MARKING 20TH ANNIVERSARY
description: It was virtually on the eve of a scheduled summit meeting with Soviet leaders in May 1972, that President Nixon ordered the mining of Haiphong harbor and a new round of bombing against Hanoi, leaving American officials uncertain as to whether Mr. Nixon would still be welcome in Moscow.

title: RANGERS BEAT BLUES ON 7 GOALS IN ROW
description: The Rangers scored seven consecutive goals and swept to an 8-5 triumph over the St. Louis Blues last night before a crowd of 17,400 at Madison Square Garden. The victory extended the Rangers' unbeaten streak to seven games.

title: I.B.M. CASE CHALLENGER CITES POLICY CONCERNS
description: Philip N. Stern, 55, whose ''friend of the court'' motion to challenge the dismissal of the antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation was granted last Friday, thinks that his involvement in the matter goes right along with his other interests on public policy issues.

title: N.F.L. GATHERS FOR KEY MEETINGS
description: ''We are under judicial, labor and political siege,'' says Art Modell, owner of the Cleveland Browns, who has a way with words. ''We've got to get the caravan in a circle and stay unified.''

title: 1,000 Farm Workers End Protest March
description: About 1,000 farm workers and sympathizers ended a six-day, 85-mile protest march today at a Roman Catholic shrine where Cesar Chavez, the union organizer, told the crowd that growers were engaged in ''an agricultural Watergate'' to rob laborers of fair wages.

title: Sanders Is First
description: Odis Sanders of Millrose Athletic Association won by 450 yards from Jim Shields of New York Athletic Club in the second annual Brooklyn Half-Marathon yesterday at Prospect Park.

title: Carolyn Daffron Wed To Richard Weishaupt
description: Carolyn Lee Daffron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A Daffron Jr. of Sarasota, Fla., was married Saturday in Philadelphia to Richard Paul Weishaupt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Weishaupt of Jackson Heights, Queens. The ceremony was performed at Upsala Mansion in Philadelphia by the Rev. David M. Gracie.

title: People
description: * Caroline Demy has been named senior vice president, general manager of Hispania, the Hispanic Communications division of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. Inc.

title: No Headline
description: Looking down from high in the night sky, it appears as a brilliant single star beaming amid the darkness of the Canadian Arctic. As the plane descends, the single light becomes a cluster and then, suddenly, as the craft drifts down through sleet, fog and blowing snow, a whole human complex emerges on a barren moonscape below.

title: Bullets Edge Knicks, 110-109
description: Normally, Kevin Grevey's postgame comments are centered on his offense. Today, the subject was offense and defense as Grevey, the Washington Bullets' guard, played key roles in both areas to help beat the Knicks, 110-109, at the Capital Centre.

title: A Depletion of Species
description: One of the world's 5 million to 10 million species becomes extinct each day. By the end of the decade the extinction rate will approach one an hour. A million species may have vanished by the year 2000. The loss of diversity will make the world a poorer place. But the United States, a necessary leader in any effort to halt the decline, is faltering in preserving even its own threatened species.

title: WILKINS GIVES GEORGIA A SHOT
description: With Georgia trailing Virginia Tech, 20-13, in Thursday night's quarterfinal of the National Invitation Tournament here, Vern Fleming, a Bulldog guard, threw a lob pass that appeared to be headed for the outskirts of Atlanta.

title: Advertising
description: New York RS03.1Honda Campaign

title: CIVIL CASES
description: The transfer last year of 37 judges from the civil to the criminal portion of State Supreme Court in New York City is lengthening backlogs in the civil part, according to many trial lawyers.

title: FRENCH LEFT SUFFERS NEW SETBACK IN REGIONAL VOTE
description: The Government suffered a setback today when leftist candidates failed to wrest control of a majority of provincial councils from conservative forces in regional elections.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In tennis, the server hits a ball that sticks in the net. Is this a fault or a let? Also, during a volley, a player drives a ball into the net but his opponent, thinking the ball will be good, swings and touches the net with his racquet. What is the ruling?

title: CRITICS DENOUNCE FED'S POLICY
description: The failure of interest rates to fall in tandem with the encouraging declines in inflation indexes has led to a variety of complaints about the Federal Reserve's monetary policy.

title: MADELEINE PAYNE, 76, AN EDITOR
description: Madeleine Darling Payne, a fashion coordinator and magazine editor, died Friday at Palisades General Hospital in North Bergen, N.J. Mrs. Payne, a resident of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was 76 years old.

title: ABC Begins Promoting A Concept of Superadio
description: ABC has announced that it hopes to blanket the nation with radio programming in the same fashion that McDonalds has with hamburgers. With a concept that it calls Superadio scheduled to go on the air July 4, it will offer FM stations 24-hour programming, advertising and promotion for ''one monthly fee.''

title: Factions in Zimbabwe Brawl in the Streets
description: Supporters of Zimbabwe's two main political parties clashed with clubs and stones today in the first reported factional fighting since Prime Minister Robert Mugabe dismissed his junior coalition partner a month ago.

title: LOUISVILLE SHUNS STAR SYSTEM
description: Louisville has made it to the Final Four of the 44th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship without the ingredient so common to most national champions - an all-America player well known to fans around the nation.

title: Braxton Stops Martin in Sixth
description: Dwight Braxton dropped Jerry Martin twice in the second round and stopped him with a relentless assault in the sixth to retain his World Boxing Council lightheavyweight title today.

title: EARNINGS FORECASTS GO LOWER
description: With the economy sinking deeper into recession, economic forecasters are revising their estimates of corporate earnings for the first quarter of 1982, making their gloomy projections even gloomier.

title: AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENT HAS NEW PLAN FOR SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: The Agriculture Department has proposed new rules that would give local officials more freedom on how much food to serve pupils in cafeterias.

title: THE LEAKER SPEAKS
description: I cannot reveal my identity because that would g et me fired, but you know me as that unscrupulous, disloyal rascal w ho leaked the notes of Secretary of State Al Haig's staff meetings.

title: MONDAY, March 22, 1982; The Economy
description: Forecasters of first-quarter corporate profits have turned gloomier. Many economists say the drop in earnings they had projected will prove to be too optimistic in light of the deepening recession, which is squeezing profits harder than they had expected. (D1.)

title: MERCE CUNNINGHAM CHOREOGRAPHS A DANCE MOVIE
description: LONG a modern-dance innovator, Merce Cunningham has recently become a major figure in film choreography. With Charles Atlas as his director and editor, he has made several beautiful dance films. The newest and perhaps the finest is ''Channels/Inserts,'' which will be shown on a program called ''Merce at the Movies'' tonight at 8:30 at the Carnegie Hall Cinema.

title: The Editorial; Notebook A Spotlight on Prosecutors
description: For years, prosecutors have escaped public scrutiny - and no doubt preferred it that way. The prosecutors' discretion is broad. They set the final charges against criminals arrested by the police and decide what to do with a case: plea bargain, go to trial or let the offender go.

title: Michael P. McAleer Weds Diane Newman in Florida
description: Diane Newman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Newman of Cape Coral, Fla., formerly of New York, was married yesterday to Michael P. McAleer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. McAleer of Lake Worth, Fla. Rabbi Samuel Silver performed the ceremony at Manini's, a restaurant in Fort Myers, Fla.

title: Police Investigate Canuck-Fan Fight
description: The police said today they were investigating an incident in which the Vancouver Canucks' coach, Harry Neale, and some of his players went into the stands and fought with fans Saturday night at the close of the game against the Quebec Nordiques.

title: SHUTTLE IS POISED FOR LIFTOFF TODAY
description: After a remarkably trouble-free countdown, preparations for the space shuttle Columbia's third test flight shifted smoothly into the final phases tonight with the launching still scheduled for 10 A.M. Monday.

title: The Right to Name Names
description: ''Congress shall make no law,'' says the First Amendment, ''abridging the freedom of speech or of the press.'' But an angry, flag-waving Congress is making it a crime to print names the Government doesn't want published, even when they are derived from public sources. Last week the Senate refused to be outdone by the House in making the Intelligence Identities Protection Act offensive to the Bill of Rights.

title: PATE WINS GOLF WITH A SPLASH
description: Jerry Pate dived into a pond again to celebrate a tournament victory today, and this time he preceded his dive by pushing two other men into the water beside the 18th green of the Players Club.

title: SCHMIDT FOES WIN IN LOWER SAXONY
description: The Christian Democrats won a substantial victory tonight in voting for the parliament of the state of Lower Saxony, the first major election in West Germany since the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt was returned to power in 1980.

title: REPORT LINKS BUDGET CUTS TO INCREASED MALNUTRITION
description: President Reagan said today that a report suggesting his budget cuts might be responsible for an increase in child malnutrition was a ''great exaggeration.''

title: RUTGERS' WOMEN GAIN REGION FINAL
description: Rutgers jumped to a 16-4 lead and scored an 89-79 triumph over Georgia Southern today in the Eastern Regional semifinals of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women basketball tournament.

title: PATHOLOGIST IN SUFFOLK TO EXAMINE BODY OF CALIFORNIA FOOTBALL PLAYER
description: The body of Ron Settles, a college football star who was found hanged in a jail cell last June in Signal Hill, Calif., will be brought to Suffolk County, L.I., for an autopsy to be conducted by Sidney Weinberg, the Chief Medical Examiner.

title: Sports World Specials; Canoe Canoe?
description: At the age of 59, when some men are looking ahead to retirement, Verlen Kruger is more than halfway through a scheduled 28,000-mile canoe trip through the waterways of North America. Kruger, a plumber in Lansing, Mich., until he began his voyage in April 1980, has completed 17,300 miles. He and his son-in-law, Steve Landick, still have more than 10,000 miles to traverse and hope to complete their venture in November of next year.

title: WHEN A CHILD IS IN HOSPITAL
description: IT may be a temporary relationship, but the link between the family o f a child who is hospitalized and the people who care for that childi s tightly drawn. That is, in large measure, because when children b ecome sick enough to be hospitalized, their parents often stay with t hem in the hospital.

title: EUROPEAN LEGISLATORS MOVE TO INCREASE AUTHORITY;
description: Piet Dankert was raised on a farm north of here. When he was 7, the Germans blew up the dikes and flooded it. Later, he spent holidays in Germany and Sweden. He married a Frenchwoman who sold programs at the Casals festival in Prades, and then he became a Socialist defense expert in the Dutch Parliament.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1982
description: International Salvadoran rebels and a businessman, Conrado Lopez Andreu, who normally are widely apart politically, share a loathing for the Christian Democratic Party, @hich is lead by the President of the military-civilian junta, Jose Napoleon Duarte. Mr. Lopez, president of El Salvador's Chamber of Commerce, was recently given time on the guerrillas' radio station to express his opposition to the Christian Democrats, who the Reagan Administration hopes will win Sunday's elections. Mr. Duarte's party has engendered such hatred that it doubtful that it can win a majority of assembly seats and if it does there is the question of whether it could govern effectively. (A1:2-4.) The French Left suffered a setback when leftist candidates failed to gain control of a majority of provincial councils from conservative forces in regional elections. The elections were run-offs for 1,063 of 2,029 seats in 95 provincial councils that will become powerful political bodies under President Francois Mitterrand's decentralization program. (A6:1-5.)

title: Borg Uncertain On Wimbledon
description: Bjorn Borg of Sweden, who ends a fivemonth vacation from tennis with an exhibition match against Vitas Gerulaitis here Tuesday night, was quoted today as having said that he probably would not make up his mind about whether to play at Wimbledon this year ''until the very last moment.''

title: Stokowski to Be Honored
description: The American Symphony Orchestra will celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of its founder and first conductor, Leopold Stokowski, with a concert of Prokofiev's ''Alexander Nevsky,'' Rachmaninoff's ''Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini'' and the Bach-Stokowski Toccata and Fugue in D minor April 18 at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall.

title: Sports World Specials; Football Peril
description: The decision recently to award $6.3 million to a former high school football player who suffered a paralyzing injury in 1975 has many people connected with the sport wondering about the future. The spinal injury to Chris Thompson, now 21 years old, who has been a quadraplegic since the accident occurred, was only one of 41 paralyzing injuries to high school football players between 1977 and 1981, according to a tabulation by the University of North Carolina. The university's physical education department maintains national statistics on neck injuries that cause permanent paralysis.

title: TV: 'TOMORROW'S CHILD,' A MOVIE
description: THE subject of ''Tomorrow's Child,'' tonight's ABC-TV movie at 9 o'clock, is supposedly medical ethics. At fictional issue is an experiment to ''grow'' a human baby entirely outside the mother's body. Serious questions are raised about scientists playing God, about their trying to render the womb obsolete. Indications of extramedical foul play are scattered generously throughout Jerry McNeeley's script. Then, in the closing minutes, everything is resolved in a gush of cooing about the miracle of birth. The viewer will be forgiven the fleeting thought that he has been taken.

title: Inco Rating Lowered
description: The Standard and Poor's Corporation has lowered the ratings on Inco Ltd.'s senior debt to BBB- from BBB+ and commercial paper to A-3 from A-2. Standard and Poor's also said Friday that the rating on Inco United States Inc.'s commercial paper, which is guaranteed by Inco Ltd., had been reduced to A-3 from A-2.

title: KOCH VENTURES UPSTATE IN SEARCH OF BACKING BY DEMOCRATIC CHIEFS
description: Mayor Koch traveled upstate yesterday to enlist local Democratic Party support for his gubernatorial candidacy and tried once again to blunt the nettlesome effect of a magazine interview in which he derided rural life.

title: Going Out Guide
description: CONSTRUCTIONS

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Erika Hess Wins Two Cup Events
description: ALPE D'HUEZ, France, March 21 (AP) - Erika Hess of Switzerland, who won three gold medals at Schladming, scored a double triumph today by winning both a World Cup slalom and giant slalom event here.

title: No Headline
description: This quiet countryside of hills and valleys, wheat fields and olive groves, is pastoral and beautiful. On this fact, both Arabs and Jews agree. But it is the only overlapping quality in the scenes they see from their two perspectives -the Arabs from this tiny village in the valley, the Jews from their settlement of Shiloh on the hilltop.

title: Laker Ends Bid To Start Airline
description: Sir Freddie Laker, whose Laker Airways collapsed last month, said Saturday night that he had given up trying to start a new airline - at least for now.

title: STAGE: COHAN REVIVAL, 'LITTLE JOHNNY JONES'
description: BEFORE ''Little Johnny Jones'' begins, the audience is invited to rise and sing ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' to a flag that's been set up in the Alvin Theater's stage-right box. And so the flags keep unfurling right through the curtain call, at which point a gargantuan Old Glory drops from the heavens to fill the entire proscenium. Along the way, a delicate question is raised: With so many stars and stripes on view, is it treason to be bored stiff from beginning to end of ''Little Johnny Jones''? If it is, more than a few theatergoers may soon find themselves under house arrest.

title: BOYCOTT
description: Mazowsze, the Polish folk dance company, has been shunned by this city's sizable Polish community. In its six days and seven performances at the Auditorium Theatre, it played to scant audiences.

title: HIGH COURT ALUMNI: HARD AT WORK
description: Supreme Court justices may die, but they never fade away. Arthur J. Goldberg practices law and teaches for five weeks every year. Potter Stewart rides the circuit, filling in as a Federal judge. Abe Fortas returns Monday to the marble columns and red velvet drapes of the Court to argue his first case there since resigning more than a dozen years ago.

title: Iraq and Iran Claim Successes in War
description: Iraq said today that its forces killed 943 Iranians in fighting in the last 24 hours as its forces continued to advance in the Shush, Dezful and Ahwaz areas of Iran's southwestern province of Khuzestan.

title: SNIPES IN DRAW
description: Aaron Pryor kept telling his corner, ''This round,'' but that wasn't what he was telling himself today. He knew better. He knew his right arm, which Larry Holmes had to rub down in training, was sore. And he knew Miguel Montilla was giving him one tough fight.

title: Aide of Kean Appoints Own Son to a State Job
description: Carl Golden, chief spokesman for Gov. Thomas H. Kean, has hired his own 23-year-old son for a $20,000-ayear job as a public information officer in the state's Department of Labor.

title: Advance Man Is Winner
description: Advance Man scored his third consecutive victory and his first stakes success today in the $133,800 San Felipe Handicap at Santa Anita.

title: The U.N. Today; March 22, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Human Rights Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: News Analysis
description: By agreeing to reduce its output to 17.5 million barrels a day, a lower limit than had been expected, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has taken a step that raises doubts about predictions of further widespread oil price cuts.

title: Hawks 119, Pistons 111
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Eddie Johnson scored 30 points, 6 in the last two minutes, to pace the Hawks. The victory was Atlanta's third straight and eighth in 10 games.

title: Employing Futures Straddles
description: BEING a loser in the commodity market can sometimes be quite profitable. In addition, investors who couldn't care less whether the commodity futures they trade go up or down in price may also profit as long as the market moves. The reason is that in both cases the traders are operating as ''spreaders,'' rather than taking ''straight'' positions as buyers or sellers of commodities.

title: Carolyn Eve Perlmuth Becomes Bride
description: Carolyn Eve Perlmuth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Perlmuth of New York, was married yesterday at the Lotos Club to John Sykes Fetterman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Fetterman of Fort Washington, Pa. Acting State Supreme Court Justice Myriam Altman performed the ceremony.

title: ISLANDERS WIN ON BOSSY'S LATE GOAL, 3-2
description: Mike Bossy scored on a quick wrist shot with 35 seconds remaining to beat the Washington Capitals, 3-2, tonight and cured the Islanders' case of ''March flu.''

title: The Talk of Bangui
description: For the equivalent of a few dollars, the guide will show the visitor around the former emperor's palace: the bedroom, with what's left of its canopied bed, the bathroom with raised pink tub and marble walls, the bullet-proof pagoda surrounded by ornamental ponds where the emperor received his supplicants. Then, when the tour reaches the former imperial kitchen, the guide pauses before swinging back a heavy gray door set in the wall.

title: Auto Race Put Off
description: Rain forced postponement of the $109,150 Dogwood 500 Classic-Nascar National Championship doubleheader today at the Martinsville Speedway. The races were rescheduled for next Sunday.

title: Searchers Find Body Of 27th Air Crash Victim
description: Searchers today found the last of 27 victims of a fiery crash of a military tanker jet. Air Force experts are trying to learn why the plane exploded Friday night in a thunderstorm and plunged into a snowy field.

title: WABASH, MIDLAND AND D.C. TAKE TITLES
description: District of Columbia, Wabash and Midland are colleges that have something in common - each is a basketball champion. The four-year-old University of the District of Columbia won its first National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II title with a 73-63 victory over the defending champion, Florida Southern, Saturday in Springfield, Mass.

title: BANKING RATINGS DROP
description: Moody's Investors Service has downgraded, to Aa from Aaa, the longterm debt of nine large bank holding companies. In a special report about credit quality of bank holding companies, Moody's said that 15 years of inflation plus regulatory changes have weakened the earning ability of banks and reduced the credit quality of their bonds and debentures. The rating agency said that short-term debt issues of the downgraded banking companies were unchanged.

title: U.S. ACCUSED BY SALVADORAN
description: A leading Salvadoran opposition figure, Guillermo Manuel Ungo, blamed the Salvadoran junta and the United States Government today for prolongation of the civil war in El Salvador, saying that the guerrilla-led opposition had been ready for months to negotiate a peace settlement.

title: BUSY TREASURY WEEK
description: The United States Treasury is scheduled to sell $3.75 billion of four-year notes Wednesday in minimum denominations of $1,000. The note sale will retire $2.6 billion of maturing 7 7/8 percent notes and will raise an estimated $1.144 billion of new cash.

title: IN SEARCH OF A MOLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Required Reading; Bush on Israel
description: Vice President Bush, speaking to the Young Leadership Conference of the United Jewish Appeal. March 15, 1982: Today I want to clear the air of some misconceptions.

title: Prime-Time TV Plan Is Explained by ABC
description: The ABC-TV Network, which announced last January that it would increase its nightly commercial availability on prime time by one minute a night, told its affiliates last week how it plans to phase it in.

title: USE OF CABLE TELEVISION PROLIFERATING IN SUBURBS
description: As New York City officials work to complete franchise agreements that will bring cable television to the boroughs outside Manhattan, 54 separate cable systems have already signed up about a million customers in the suburbs surrounding the city.

title: Gunmen Kill American On Guatemalan Farm
description: Armed men who identified themselves as leftist guerrillas shot and killed a United States citizen at his plantation in northern Guatemala, the second American slain in five weeks, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Pakistan Tightens Curb On Public Protests
description: Pakistan's military rulers tightened restrictions today on public protests after signs in the last week of growing unrest over martial law.

title: DUTCH QUESTION SALVADOR ARMY ACCOUNT OF KILLINGS
description: The Dutch Government reaffirmed its doubts today about the Salvadoran Army's account of how four members of a Dutch television team were slain last Wednesday in northern El Salvador.

title: George Goss Jr., Ex-Member Of Board of Brass Company
description: George Augustus Goss Jr., retired vice president and board member of Scovill Inc., a brass manaufacturing and diversified home construction company of Waterbury. Conn., died Saturday at his home in Middlebury, Conn. He was 61 years old.

title: LADY BIRD JOHNSON: A TIME FOR FAMILY AND HERSELF
description: Lady Bird Johnson dislikes the term ''widow.'' ''It comes from a Sanskrit word meaning empty,'' she said, ''and I never use it, nor do I think of myself as being alone because I have a lot of family.'' There was a pause before she added, with a small smile, ''However, there comes a time when you are alone, because they all belong to each other.''

title: BROADWAY JOE, THE CELEBRATED MUTT WHO HAD HIS DAY AND MORE
description: It is coming on winter in 1975 and, what with cold, snow and ice, and especially cold, it is by no means clear that a character known as Broadway Joe will live to see the spring. This Broadway Joe is a floppy-eared mutt, part beagle, part spaniel and nobody knows what all else, and he lives in a cold, snowy place called Troy, New York.

title: No Headline
description: VILAS TOPS CONNORS IN FINAL, 0-6, 6-2, 6-4

title: DUARTE'S PARTY CAUGHT IN MIDDLE IN SALVADOR
description: Venceremos, the radio station of El Salvador's leftist rebels, recently interrupted its daily fare of heraldic calls to insurrection to give air time to some statements by Conrado Lopez Andreu, an improbable revolutionary spokesman. Mr. Lopez Andreu is the president of El Salvador's Chamber of Commerce.

title: THE PRESSURE TO PRODUCE
description: When Tommy Mont was the football coach at the University of Maryland, a head coach in his early 30's placed in charge of a program expected to compete for a national championship, there was little time for perspective. Instead, there was always another film to watch, another player to recruit, another alumnus to deal with, another game to win. Mont's perspective did not come until after he had gone.

title: WITH POLICEMAN, BOY'S LOT IS A HAPPY ONE
description: Like many of his classmates, 17-year-old Michael Buchanan likes to wear a T-shirt and jeans when he goes to Curtis High School on Staten Island. There is one major difference: The T-shirt he prefers says ''Police Department - City of New York'' on the front.

title: Gold Mining In Modern Era
description: EVEN when refined gold commands a mere $315 an ounce, the prospect of raw gold can quicken pulses. Last Friday the shares of Franklin Consolidated Mining sparkled, reaching 1 7/8 bid, up from 1 1/2 bid a day earlier. Volume was surprising for the over-the-counter market: 37,200 shares. The excitement over this obscure gold mining company reflects interest in its century-old mine to the east of the Continental Divide near Idaho Springs, Colo.

title: BRIEFING
description: Voice of the White House

title: U.S.C. PENALTY DUE
description: Southern California will decide this week whether to appeal an N.C.A.A. ruling that reportedly imposes stiff penalties on its football team, a university official said today.

title: SPACE CARAVAN SETS UP SHOP FOR SHUTTLE IN NEW MEXICO
description: Shepherding a vital caravan of sophisticated hardware, scores of space technicians and managers hastily set up camp in a remote patch of desert today to prepare for the scheduled March 29 landing of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: McGuire Wouldn't Follow Koch to Albany; McGuire Says No
description: Not all jobs, it turns out, are grander on the state level. When someone asked Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire if he planned to follow Mayor Koch to Albany in the event the Mayor was successful in his bid to become governor, the answer was an emphatic ''no.''

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Compton Gets Paine Webber
description: Compton Advertising, which will soon be a subsidairy of Saatchi & Saatchi of London, is suddenly becoming a more valuable property as it adds Paine Webber Inc. to its client list. Billings are believed to be more than $6 million.

title: Stouffer Jury Is Shown A Bottle Found at Inn
description: The jury in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial got its first look today at a soda bottle containing a small amount of a gasolinelike substance that investigators have implied might have been used to start the fire.

title: WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Dec 31
description: Results are for 16 weeks for the latest fourth qr and 17 weeks for the yr-ago fourth qr

title: N.F.L. TV PACT $2 BILLION
description: With a show of hands on the first day of their spring meetings, the owners of the National Football League's 28 teams unanimously approved today a network television contract that will enrich each club by more than $70 million over the next five seasons.

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Addendum
description: * Country Living magazine increasing both its circulation rate base, to 750,000, and its advertising rates, by 25 percent, effective with the July issue.

title: Georgia Hires Howell
description: Vince Dooley, the University of Georgia's football coach, appointed Hornsby Howell, a black coach from North Carolina A.& T., to a staff that had been all white. The appointment came after black leaders had met with Dooley and the university president, Fred Davison, to discuss a demand for a black assistant. Howell will be in charge of the scout team that runs the plays of the coming opponent against the varsity in practice.

title: EXPANDED BRAIN STUDIES PLANNED FOR NEW CENTER
description: THE Neurosciences Research Foundation, which since its founding in 1962 has been located in Jamaica Plain, Mass., under the auspices of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will move to the Rockefeller University in New York City by the end of this year.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FARBWERKE HOECHST AG reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
HAGLER-HEARNS BOUT SCHEDULED MAY 24
description: Only 10 days after a Sugar Ray Leonard fight on home television, and only 18 days before the heavyweight title bout between Larry Holmes and Gerry Cooney, Marvelous Marvin Hagler will defend his unified middleweight championship against Thomas Hearns on May 24.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's increasingly a battle between artists and technology. We have to band together to insure that New York never becomes another Pittsburgh or Seattle or Houston.''

title: BASIC FARE SAID TO BARELY COVER TAXIS' EXPENSES
description: The basic fare rate for medallion taxis - 90 cents a mile, not including the $1 ''drop charge'' imposed at the start of each trip - barely covers expenses for many cabs, according to a city-commissioned report released yesterday.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
MEN IN THE NEWS:C. GORDON FULLERTON
description: ALTHOUGH this is Gordon Fullerton's first venture in space, it is not his first experience at the controls of the space shuttle. In 1977, he was a member of one of the two crews of astronauts who piloted the prototype shuttle Enterprise in a series of approach and landing tests at Edwards Air Force Base in California. A Boeing 747 piggybacked the Enterprise to a high altitude and released it. The astronauts then steered it unpowered to a touchdown on the desert floor, duplicating the critical final minutes of a real shuttle flight.

title: BRADLEY AND PURDUE WIN, ADVANCE TO FINAL OF N.I.T.
description: The Bradley Braves, the most bitterly disappointed of the teams that were not invited to the N.C.A.A. tournament, decided to hold a party of their own last night.

title: Tax Revision in France
description: France plans to reduce the impact of the so-called professional tax on companies this year, a spokesman for Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy said today, without giving details. A statement issued after a meeting between Mr. Mauroy and Yvon Gattaz, president of the employers' federation, said that the reform would try to correct the negative effect the tax has apparently had on investment and increases in staff levels. The tax, which raised more than $2.5 billion in 1981, is based partly on total salaries paid by a company and partly on the value of its equipment and buildings.

title: At a Glance
description: Following are key facts and figures on the third test flight of the space shuttle Columbia: Launching: 11 A.M., March 22, from pad 39A at the Kennedy Space Center. Orbit: 116 times at an altitude of about 150 miles.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE general resistance of American buyers to many of the Italian c ollections they saw last week in Milan may signal a return to a morep ractical sensibility - that of wearability, which, in current retailj argon, means salability.

title: Star Gallant Is Easy Winner
description: Alonzo Couenciel knew who had won the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park today only 24 seconds into the race.

title: MILLER-WOHL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
ABRAMS URGES REORGANIZATION OF STATE P.S.C.
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams and a group of Democratic Assemblyman yesterday proposed an extensive reorganization of the State Public Service Commission to eliminate what they called a ''fundamental imbalance between the utility industry and consumers.''

title: Smoking and Drinking
description: Much statistical evidence has shown that the risks of cigarette smoking are increased if the smoker also drinks alcoholic beverages. A new study has suggested an explanation for this puzzling combination, and also hints that the risk may be enhanced if cigarette smoke and alcohol are held in the mouth together for as long as 10 seconds.

title: NONSURGICAL THERAPY FOR GUMS SPURS WIDE DEBATE
description: THE growing popularity of a nonsurgical treatment for periodontal disease has touched off a national debate among periodontists, many of whom say that the therapy, which has never been scientifically tested, may be inadequate to control the major cause of tooth loss in adult Americans.

title: 18-YEAR OLD SENDS HIS INSECTS INTO ORBIT
description: ALONG with two astronauts, other forms of life rode aboard the space shuttle as it headed into orbit yesterday - 10 moths and 10 honeybees.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Chess: Dutch Grandmaster Wins Mar del Plata Tournament
description: The Clarin International Tournament in Mar del Plata, Argentina, was a smashing success for Jan Timman, a 30-year-old Dutch grandmaster, who scored 9 1/2-3 1/2 to take first prize.

title: HUGH CROWD SQUEALS AND CLAPS AS SHUTTLE BEGINS ITS MISSION
description: More than 750,00 people squealed, clapped and whooped in jubilation today as they watched the Columbia's fiery liftoff from beaches and causeways along Florida's ''space coast.''

title: Enforcement History
description: President Theodore Roosevelt threatened in 1905 to outlaw football unless something was done to make the game safer. Answering the challenge, 62 colleges and universities formed the Intercollegiate Athletic Association of the United States on Dec. 28, 1905.

title: MILAN SHOWS: A MIX OF THE BANAL AND BEAUTIFUL
description: Some designers here are concerned that American women will be confused by the plurality of hemlines in the clothes they are showing for next fall and winter. They feel Americans are too provincial to keep more than one fashion idea in their heads at the same time.

title: Woman's Body Found in Coney I.
description: The body of an 87-year-old woman was found yesterday in her ransacked Coney Island apartment, her hands bound and her mouth stuffed with rags, the police said.

title: Nuggets' Dire Straits
description: Denver's pro basketball team, the Nuggets, are behind in their rent, and losses for the season may reach $1 million, according to Carl Scheer, the owner.

title: NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the qr and $588,000 for the yr

title: 'JOHNNY JONES' SHUTS, 'WHOREHOUSE' CLOSING
description: ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'' will close at the 46th Street Theater on Saturday night, a victim, its producer charges, of union featherbedding. Meanwhile, another musical, ''Little Johnnie Jones'' closed yesterday. The production, which starred Donnie Osmond and was capitalized at $1.2 million, opened at the Alvin Theater Sunday night after 29 previews.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a five percent stock divd paid Jan 21, 1982

title: BIO-MEDICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
