description: B-Including tax credits of $2,642,000 or 30 cents a shr for the latest yr and $1,873,000 or 22 cents a shr for the previous yr

title: Mary Leone, Ran Restaurant
description: In Manhattan for 2 Decades

title: CONTROVERSY OVER ENFORCEMENT
description: Minutes after the 1980 Dapper Dan high school all-star basketball game had ended in Pittsburgh, two N.C.A.A. enforcement officers noticed that Sam Perkins, one of the most highly recruited athletes in the game, was missing, along with the head coach from the University of San Francisco. Suspecting that an attempt had been made to hide Perkins so that other coaches would not have a chance to speak with him, the N.C.A.A. officers went to Perkins's hotel and, in true detective style, staked out the lobby.

title: THIRD TIME AROUND: THE COLUMBIA TURNS TO HIGH SCIENCE
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. WITHIN 40 minutes after the Columbia's launching yesterday, the first data from the scientific instruments on board began flowing back to the earth, signals from the most elaborate payload yet to fly in the space shuttle's cargo bay.

title: LETTER ASSAILING MEDIA COVERAGE IS CITED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch has sent Democratic politicians a copy of a letter charging that reporters sensationalized the story of the Playboy magazine interview in which he spoke scornfully of rural and suburban life.

title: UDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
CHICAGO RIVET & MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-Net loss

title: Javits Flown by U. S.  To Bethesda Hospital
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York was flown today to the United States Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md., after almost three weeks of treatment here for respiratory problems.

title: Succotash Point's Case
description: In criticizing television news coverage in an interview last week, President Reagan referred to a supposedly mythical town when he asked: ''Is it news that some fellow out in South Succotash someplace has just been laid off and that he should be interviewed nationwide?''

title: JETERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Women's Tennis Feeling Pain
description: Some players say the synthetic carpet is too hard and the balls are too soft. Others cite cold arenas and the continuous 12-week grind and resulting mental stress as reasons for the record number of injuries that have dogged the women's professional tennis tour this season.

title: VALENZUELA TO REPORT TO CAMP
description: Fernando Valenzuela said today that he would report to the Los Angeles Dodgers on Tuesday and play under the agreement the club had renewed without his consent.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: MOST of the radical school reformers of the 1960's dropped out of view as the public soured on their messages of revolutionary utopia. But Herbert Kohl, almost alone among the big-name teacher-writers of that era, survives - not only as a teacher and reformer but also as something approaching a one-man book factory. This year alone, with some help from his wife, Judith, and his 13-year-old daughter, Erica, he expects to publish eight books.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Money Market Mutual Funds table in Business Day last Friday misstated the assets of the Alex Brown Cash Reserve and the Value Line Cash Fund. Alex Brown has $559.5 million in assets and Value Line $533.4 million.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Reassigned eight players to minor league camp in Hollywood, Fla.: Ben Callahan, Pete Filson and Curt Kaufman, pitchers; Steve Balboni, Todd Demeter and Don Mattingly, first basemen; Otis Nixon, infielder, and Mike Patterson, outfielder.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $88,683 for the latest yr and $156,864 for the previous yr on the disposal of subsidiaries; rev figures represent fee income

title: Winner of Vannevar Bush Award Named; Vannevar Bush Award
description: Lee A. Dubridge, a former president of the California Institute of Technology who helped develop radar during World War II, has been named by the National Science Foundation to receive its prestigious Vannevar Bush Award.

title: PENINSULA RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Plans Made to Change the Sheik's House; Plans for Sheik's House
description: A follow-up: In the late 1970's, the Saudi Arabian Sheik Mohammed al-Fassi raised the eyebrows and outcries of his neighbors in Los Angeles when he bought a Sunset Boulevard mansion and decorated its facade and grounds with brightly painted nude statues.

title: Surrogate Retires
description: Expressing regret that, unlike the rules of the Federal judicial system, New York State law does not allow a surrogate to continue in office beyond the age of 70, Surrogate Millard L. Midonick said yesterday he was retiring.

title: Horseshoe Crabs and Vision
description: The horseshoe crab has long served as a subject for studies of the physiology of vision. But the role of vision in the animal's own behavior has seldom been investigated.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HIGH NOON

title: BOSTON BALLET: 'DON QUIXOTE,' BUT WITH ADDED DRAMA
description: BOSTON ONE of the most heartening things about the Boston Ballet's Friday night performance of ''Don Quixote'' at the Metropolitan Center was the way the company coped with an unforeseen calamity that could easily have made a shambles of the evening.

title: LUCHOW'S MOVING TO THEATER DISTRICT
description: After 100 years as a gustatory landmark on 14th Street, Luchow's, the last of Manhattan's opulent German restaurants, will move to the theater district in June.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Can odors, or the differences between odors, be measured by instruments?

title: Yank Errors Bring Extra Drill
description: Under a pink and white striped awning that provided the only shade near the practice fields at Fort Lauderdale Stadium today, Bob Watson, Oscar Gamble and Rudy May gulped Gatorade, mopped the sweat off their faces and prayed for rain.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM DISPLAYS 'GALLOPADE'
description: ''GALLOPADE'' another premiere by Merce Cunningham, is not one of his epic works. It is one of his punchy zany ones, nearly vaudeville in style. Fun, in other words.

title: BOMAINE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $898,000...C-Including a net gain of $583,000 on the sale of a plant and a tax credit of $1,262,000

title: EMBARGO NOT RULED OUT IN REAGAN FARM PLAN
description: President Reagan reiterated today his Administration's assurances that farm exports would not be used as a diplomatic weapon, except in ''extreme situations.''

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 6
description: B-Including a gain of $11.3 illion or $7.63 a shr for the qr and 36 weeks on the disposal of domestic flour milling operations

title: MOXA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Assault Charge Brought Against Canucks' Coach
description: The Quebec police said today that a complaint of bodily assault has been lodged against Coach Harry Neale of the Vancouver Canucks by a fan who attended the Saturday night game against the Quebec Nordiques.

title: Assault Trial Begins for Innis
description: The assault trial of Roy Innis, chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, began yesterday in State Supreme Court with the man he is accused of attacking testifying that Mr. Innis and ''six or seven other fellows'' had beaten him unconscious, threatened to carve the word ''thief'' into his forehead and verbally abused him for more than an hour.

title: Bridge: 3 Top Teams Are Defeated In the Vanderbilt Knockout
description: Second-round play in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship began here this afternoon with 32 teams surviving from an original 93. In the premier event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, three top teams were already on the sidelines, and the top-seeded team barely survived the first round.

title: Advertising; Looking Closely At Budgets
description: ALTHOUGH chief executives of ad agencies have many concerns these days, a major problem, especially for those with a heavy percentage of packaged-goods clients, is coming from ''the trade.'' That's how the agencies refer to supermarket chains, and these days, they report, the chains are not keeping up their inventories, willingly tolerating running out of stock rather than tying up big dollars at high interest rates.

title: Mets Win Cable Issue
description: A United States District Court judge in Syracuse has ruled that a supplier of cable television companies violated copyright laws by rebroadcasting New York Met baseball games in 1981 from WOR-TV in New York City. Judge Neal McCurn ruled in favor of Doubleday Sports Inc., which owns the Mets and holds a copyright on the games, in its suit against Eastern Microwave Inc. Doubleday had sought damages because the company re-broadcast the games without permission, and asked for $50,000 for each telecast, but Judge McCurn did not make any monetary awards in his ruling. Officials at Eastern Microwave, which contended that it had contracts with its customers to rebroadcast WOR without cutting out the Met games, said they would appeal the decision, but Met exhibition and regular-season games will not be re-broadcast until a higher court decides the case.

title: German Book Fair Planned for March 1983
description: A German Book Fair will be held at the Sheraton Center in early March 1983, the first event of its kind here. More than 150 publishing houses from West Germany will be represented.

title: Hit-Run Driver Kills Student, 17
description: A 17-year-old honors student was fatally injured by a car in the Bronx, the police said yesterday. The victim, William Carlo of the Bronx, was crossing Broadway near West 242d Street at about 2 A.M. Saturday when a car going about 50 miles an hour narrowly missed him, investigators said.

title: PANEL HEARS APPEAL TO SAVE DAILY NEWS
description: James J. Patterson, whose father was one of the founders of The Daily News, appealed yesterday to a New York State Senate committee for help in keeping the newspaper operating.

title: QUICHING HOBOKEN
description: In this town of steel-toed work shoes, shot-and-a-beer taverns and an occasional beehive hairdo, the invasion of the quiche-eaters continues.

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NOBEL WINNER URGES WIDER FORENSIC USE OF NEW INSULIN TECHNOLOGY
description: DR. WILLIAM A. BAUMAN had just finished off a carry-out Chinese shrimp and vegetable dinner when something interesting began to happen next to him on the gamma-ray counting machine in the radioimmunoassay laboratory at the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital.

title: LOUSMA: 'THIS RIDE IS A REAL BARN BURNER!'
description: Following are conversations between the astronauts in the shuttle and Mission Control at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, as recorded yesterday by the New York Times:

title: MONOSIL INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $113,000 for the latest yr and $214,000 for the previous yr

title: Lafleur Lost for Season
description: The Montreal Canadiens will finish the regular-season schedule without Guy Lafleur, their high-scoring right wing, whose injured left foot has been placed in a cast. Lafleur's foot was struck by a slap shot from a teammate, Gaston Gingras, on March 11, and he has been unable to skate since then, missing five games. A series of Xrays failed to reveal any fracture, though, and the Canadiens, who have clinched first place in the National Hockey League's Adams Division, expect Lafleur to be available for the playoffs, which begin in mid-April.

title: Call for Mike Norris
description: The Oakland A's would like the Mike Norris they had come to know, the pitcher with the fine control who won 22 games in 1980, to step forward at their training camp in Scottsdale, Ariz. This year's Norris has given up 10 walks, hit one batsman, thrown five wild pitches and made a wild pickoff throw to first base - all in six and one-third innings over three exhibition games.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption accompanying the Going Out Guide yesterday was incorrect. The picture showed Thad Jones.

title: L. JUDSON MORHOUSE, HELPED ELECT GOV. ROCKEFELLER IN 1958
description: L. Judson Morhouse, who fashioned the campaign that made Nelson A. Rockefeller the Governor of New York, died Sunday in Ticonderoga, N.Y., on his 68th birthday.

title: SELECTION OF JURORS IS BEGUN FOR MOON'S TAX-FRAUD TRIAL
description: Efforts to select a jury began yesterday for the trial of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon on tax-fraud charges that accuse him of having failed to report more than $150,000 in personal income.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for QTr to Feb 28
CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day last Tuesday understated the value of an offer to acquire the Arcata Corporation. The offer, accepted by Arcata's board, was valued at $335 million.

title: TV: GEORGE C. SCOTT IN 'OLIVER TWIST'
description: Tonight's new version of ''Oliver Twist'' on CBS-TV comes laden with a long list of imposing credits. George C. Scott stars as Fagin. The script was written by James Goldman, whose credits include an Academy Award for ''The Lion in Winter.'' And Clive Donner directed an outstanding British cast that includes Tim Curry as Bill Sikes, Timothy West as Mr. Bumble, Eileen Atkins as Mrs. Mann, Cherie Lunghi as Nancy and Michael Hordern as Mr. Brownlow. Young Richard Charles has the title role.

title: People
description: * Frank C. Perkins has joined Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn as an executive vice president.

title: SYSTEMATICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: SHANNON OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including equity in earnings of subsidiaries of $493,733 for the latest yr and $334,404 for the previous yr...C-Net income

title: BEVERLY HILLS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $348,000 for the qr and an extraordinary loss of $799,000 for the yr...C-After an extraordinary loss of $483,000

title: MEN IN THE NEWS: JACK R. LOUSMA
description: ''= I CONSIDER everything I've done for the last 20 years as training for this flight,'' Col. Jack R. Lousma of the Marine Corps said a few weeks before climbing into the space shuttle Columbia as commander of its third test mission.

title: SAX STEPS INTO DODGER INFIELD
description: The longest-running act in baseball, the Los Angeles Dodgers' infield, is undergoing its first cast change in nine years this spring. And the new member of the quartet is 22-yearold Steve Sax, a rookie who grew up in northern California idolizing the San Francisco Giants and disliking the Dodgers.

title: MARYLAND REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $9,000 for the latest qr and $7,000 for the yr-ago qr

title: CARDINAL FELICI, NOTED EXPERT ON CHURCH LAW FOR VATICAN
description: Pericle Cardinal Felici, a Vatican expert in church law, died Sunday night at the age of 70 after participating in a religious procession in the southern city of Foggia, hospital authorities said.

title: OPERA: REDIVIVA OFFERS 'ABARIS OU LES BOREADES'
description: THE choice facing the Borean queen in Rameau's last opera is named in the title: ''Abaris ou les Boreades.'' It is between the stranger Abaris, whom she loves, and the Borean suitors, whom she does not. The difficulty is that choosing the non-Borean Abaris would cost her the kingdom. It is the sort of choice, between desire and social order, that opera thrives on; it is also perfectly suited for Rameau's unpublished music, recently restored by Mary Terey-Smith.

title: COURT STAY LIFTED AND DEMOLITION BEGINS AT TWO BROADWAY THEATERS
description: Demolition of the Morosco and Helen Hayes Theaters began yesterday after the United States Supreme Court lifted a temporary stay and removed the last major impediment to construction of the 50-story Portman Hotel in the Times Square area.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 23, 1982
description: International Washington accused Moscow and its allies in Southeast Asia of having used toxins and chemical warfare agents in Laos, Cambodia and Afghanistan. The Reagan Administration presented a 32-page report detailing evidence for its accusation that more than 10,000 people had died as a result of nearly 400 chemical warfare attacks carried out in the three countries since 1975. (Page A1, Column 4.) A Palestinian teen-ager was slain and two other Arabs were wounded as the Israeli army continued to use gunfire to suppress violent demonstrations throughout the West Bank. A general strike continued for a fourth day in protest over the Government's ouster of an elected town council. (A1:3-5.)

title: EDUCATION
description: THE Supreme Court of the United States is scheduled to hear oral arguments today in the case of Amy Rowley, a deaf fourth grader from Peekskill, N.Y., to decide whether public school systems may be required to provide sign language interpreters in the classroom.

title: British Business Net Up
description: British industrial and commercial companies' profits, net of stock appreciation, rose 23 percent in the second half of 1981 compared with the first half last year, partly because of North Sea oil, central statistical office figures show.

title: DON HOLT, CANNON MILLS CHIEF
description: Don S. Holt, retired chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Cannon Mills Company, the giant textile producer, died Saturday at his home in Charlotte, N.C., of heart failure after a prolonged illness. He was 74 years old.

title: HAMILTON, N.Y.
description: NOT long ago, Ben Aldrich, who gives trumpet lessons at Colgate University, was asked to stand before a tape recorder and play the chromatic scale from a low F sharp to a high C, each tone half a second long.

title: THEATER: BISHOP'S 'JEDEDIAH KOHLER'
description: WITH John Bishop's new play, ''The Great Grandson of Jedediah Kohler,'' the Circle Repertory Company is stepping out - in more ways than one - and you can feel the troupe's liberating spirit of adventure. Not only is ''Jedediah Kohler'' being performed away from the Circle Rep's snug Sheridan Square home base - it's to be found instead at the larger Entermedia Theater on Second Avenue - but it also proves a striking esthetic departure from the kind of naturalism that has been the company's often distinguished stock in trade. Indeed, Mr. Bishop all but mocks the conventions of a work like ''Snow Orchid,'' which the Circle Rep opened only 10 days ago back home. And everyone on stage seems to be laughing with him.

title: YALE BARS A U.S. STUDY GRANT, REFUSING TO ACCOUNT FOR TIME
description: Yale University declined a $30,000 Federal grant yesterday, saying it would not comply with a Federal rule that a professor account for the use of his time.

title: ED FITZGERALD, BROADCASTER KNOWEN FOR PROGRAM WITH HIS WIFE, DIES
description: Ed Fitzgerald, who had broadcast on radio continuously for 52 years and who with his wife, Pegeen, was credited with originating husbandand-wife radio talk programs, died yesterday at his home at 40 Central Park South. He was 89 years old.

title: AT MOROSCO, GHOSTS HAUNT MEMORIES
description: Colleen Dewhurst and Jason Robards remembered the night that winds swept the Morosco stage. Geraldine Fitzgerald recalled feeling ossified, and Carole Shelley was reminded of a thief. Almost everyone talked of ghosts.

title: OPERA: 'SUSANNAH,' BY CHARLISLE FLOYD
description: CARLISLE FLOYD'S opera ''Susannah,'' which had not been performed by the City Opera since 1972, returned to the stage of the New York State Theater Sunday evening in a revival directed by Lou Galterio, with Faith Esham in the title role. The performance marked the debuts with the company of Bruce Ferden, the evening's conductor, and of Joanna Levy and Dan O'Connell, who appeared in the roles of Mrs. Ott and the square-dance caller.

title: HAMILTON BROTHERS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $3,001,000 for the qr and yr on the sale of securities...C-Including a gain on the sale of a gas recycling project in Louisiana of $10,665,000 for the qr and a securities gain of $12,367,000 for the yr

title: No Headline
description: Leaders of the National Football League Players Association, deadlocked with the league in talks aimed at a new contract, bitterly attacked management today at the opening of the union's convention.

title: TESTS
description: The Japanese subway cars that will soon replace the antiquated cars on the Broad Street line here have proved to be quick, safe and efficient, but a bit noisy, according to preliminary tests.

title: INCREASES SAID TO BE CERTAIN IN CAREY EDUCATION BUDGET
description: As the Governor and the leaders of the Legislature struggled today to reach agreement on a state budget, one thing was certain: Education at all levels will get substantially more money than Mr. Carey proposed in his original plan.

title: GLOSSER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect accounting changes

title: EXECUTIVE OF ESSEX COUNTY OUTLINES VIEWS ON SUBURBS, CITIES AND POLITICS
description: Peter Shapiro was elected Essex County Executive as an insurgent Democrat in 1978. For three years the former State Assemblyman and Harvard graduate has been resposible for adminstering basic services in New Jersey's most populous county, which includes Newark, the state's largest municipality.

title: Brain Chemicals and Fat
description: Several substances produced by the human brain seem to act as internal equivalents of morphine, and have been linked to such important brain activities as control of pain and even the expression of emotions. Now scientists have found evidence in animals that one brain opiate, beta endorphin, may contribute to obesity.

title: TV: ENGLISH GENTLEMAN DETECTIVE
description: QUENTIN E. DEVERILL is a grown-up, gentlemanly Tom Swift whose adventures this evening involve a rocket ship, an automobile and a balloon. Tonight's premiere episode of ''Q.E.D.,'' to be shown at 8 o'clock on CBS-TV, accentuates the boyishness of this gentlemanly detective.

title: Used Rockets Are Located On Schedule
description: Recovery ships quickly located the twin rocket boosters that helped hurl the space shuttle Columbia into orbit today, but they were not expected to be towed ashore until late Tuesday.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Susan Bolotin PSYCHIATRIST OF AMERICA: The Life of Harry Stack Sullivan. By Helen Swick Perry. Belknap Press/Harvard Univer- sity Press. Illustrated. 462 pages. $20.

title: CMT INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $348,000 for the qr and $1.4 million for the yr

title: Rev. Dr. John E. Large Dies in Florida at 75.
description: The Rev. Dr. John Ellis Large, retired rector of St. Boniface Episcopal Church in Sarasota, Fla., and the former rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street in Manhattan, died Saturday at the Sarasota Nursing Pavilion after an illness of several months. He was 75 years old and a resident of Sarasota.

title: By Sports of The Times; Final Four's Blue Chips
description: IF the blue-chip theory holds up, North Carolina will win the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball championship next Monday night at the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans.

title: FAMILY TRIES WITH WELFARE TO 'MAKE DO'
description: After buying necessities and paying bills, Sharon Hunt had $11 left from her welfare check. But there was an unexpected expense for her baby, Tanya.

title: SHUTTLE IS LOFTED INTO EARTH ORBIT FOR THIRD MISSION
description: Astronauts flew the space shuttle Columbia into orbit this morning for the third time, and despite one troublesome component on board, the project's officials said that the huge winged spaceship showed every sign of being able to complete its full seven-day mission.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kent State named Jim McDonald as its head basketball coach. McDonald, an assistant at Toledo for 12 seasons, succeeds the dismissed Ed Douma. ... X-rays taken of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's ankle, which the Lakers' star center injured Sunday night against Houston, were negative.

title: Campaign for Like
description: The Seven-Up Company confirmed yesterday that advertising for its new caffeine-free cola, called Like, will begin March 29 in eight test markets.

title: Still Seeking a Big Name
description: Jimmy Carter said no, Edward M. Kennedy said no, both of Georgia's Senators and its Governor said no, even former Senator Herman Talmadge said no, and so, at one time or another, have the actors Burt Reynolds and Sorrell Booke.

title: JUNIPER PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STECHER-TRAUNG-SCHMIDT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CYMATICOLOR CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr include pretax expenses of $185,000 for development of a printing process

title: BUDGET AMENDMENT WINNING WHITE HOUSE FAVOR
description: The Reagan White House is moving toward support of a proposed ''balanced budget'' amendment to the Constitution after a long period in which the President's top aides indicated that they had reservations about the idea.

title: MORTON SONTHEIMER
description: Morton Sontheimer, president of Sontheimer & Company, a New York City public-relations agency, died Friday at Mercy Catholic Hospital in Philadelphia at the age of 75 after a long illness. He was a resident of Manhattan.

title: PRICES UP ONLY 0.1% IN THE CITY
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in February, marking the third consecutive month of price stability, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, reported yesterday.

title: Miss Nelson Triumphs In Super Giant Slalom
description: Cindy Nelson of Reno won the first women's super giant slalom ski race today.

title: TV: 'MIDDLETOWN' IN VIDEO VERITE
description: ''MIDDLETOWN,'' the new six-part documentary series beginning tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET-TV, Channel 13, represents still another excursion into the always delicate form of video verite, and these essays are likely to prove just as provocative and controversial as public television's ''The American Family'' did 10 years ago.

title: FIREFIGHTER SUIT SAYS PROTECTION ISN'T ADEQUATE
description: The union that represents most of New York City's firefighters and a group of residents filed a suit in Federal District Court this week charging that the city was not providing adequate or equal fire protection in all of its communities.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday incorrectly identified some basketball players mentioned as potential first-round draft choices. The Georgetown players should have been Pat Ewing, Eric Floyd, Anthony Jones, Fred Brown and Bill Martin. The Houston players should have been Rob Williams, Akeem Abdul Olajuwon, Larry Micheaux and Clyde Drexler.

title: CHAMPAGNE SUPPLY DIPS
description: Worldwide deliveries of French champagne fell 9.9 percent last year to 159 million bottles and a further decline is likely this year, according to the Champagne Producers Federation.

title: Eugene Habas, Ex-Executive Of Mutual Funds in New York
description: Eugene J. Habas, a former New York securities adviser and executive, died Sunday at Blake Memorial Hospital in Bradenton, Fla. He was 73 years old.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Placed Brian Assel- stine, outfielder, on waivers; traded Ed Miller, outfielder, to Detroit for Roger Weaver, pitcher.  BOSTON (AL) - Cut six players: Den- nis Burtt, Jerry King and Mike Smithson, pitchers; Jack Gutierrez, shortstop, and John Licket and Marc Sullivan, catchers.  CHICAGO (AL) - Cut the following players: Steve Dillard, infielder; Ray Tor- res, outfielder, and Larry Edwards, Burt Geiger, Jim Siwy and Mike Maitland, pitchers. Sold the contract of Dave Ed- wards, catcher, to H
description: plete trade that sent Paul Mirabella to Cubs last Dec. 28. BASKETBALL SEATTLE (NBA) - Placed John John- son, forward, on waivers; reactivated Wally Walker, a forward who had been on injured-reserve list.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: By the time the sixth- and seventh-grade slaves paraded the suckling pig around the room, the fourth annual Roman banquet at the Cathedral School had degenerated to the point of remarkable authenticity.

title: Mavericks 118, Lakers 116
description: Mark Aguirre hit a 3-point field goal with seven seconds left to give Dallas its first victory over Los Angeles.

title: MUSIC: PERAHIA PLAYS SCHUMANN CONCERTO WITH PHILADELPHIANS
description: OF all the virtuoso piano concertos in the standard repertory, there is none that speaks in a more consistently yearning and introspective voice than Schumann's only essay in the genre. At least until it wakes up from its reveries in the finale and decides to go dancing, the Concerto in A minor is largely concerned with sweetness, warmth and dreams of love.

title: METS' LACK OF RUNS PUZZLES BAMBERGER
description: Despite a supposedly fierce scramble for half the jobs in the lineup, the New York Mets continued to show few fierce tendencies today. They lost for the fifth straight time and for the ninth time in 12 exhibition games. For the third time in their last four games, they did not even score.

title: Men's Shelter Suit Rejected by Judge
description: A class-action suit that had sought to close the city's shelter for homeless men on Wards Island has been dismissed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: TRUFFLES: WHY PIGS CAN SNIFF THEM OUT
description: Truffles are rare and expensive as it is. They would be far more so, were it not for the remarkable ability of pigs to sniff them out from as deep as three feet underground.

title: Sports of The Times; Barbara Potter's Best Pal
description: THE closer she moves to the top of tennis, the more Barbara Potter realizes she needs somebody in the arena who cares for her. ''I don't care if it's a coach, a boyfriend, a Svengali, a sister or brother, the top players all have somebody,'' she says. Miss Potter will be doubly blessed this afternoon as she takes on Anne Smith in the first round of the $300,000 Avon Championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech to the National Conference of Christians and Jews. It is a deep personal honor to be the fourth President and 30th American to receive the Charles Evans Hughes Gold Medal of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

title: JAZZ: FUSION OF ELLINGTON, GERSHWIN
description: IT is not often that George and Ira Gershwin come in second best in a pop-music confrontation. But in a program that Bill Henderson is singing at Michael's Pub through April 3, called ''A Fusion of Ellington and Gershwin,'' it is the Duke's songs that are the main source of excitement.

title: JEWISH CONTROVERY OVER RITE FOR GIRLS
description: IT was May 6, 1922, and the Sabbath. That morning Judith Kaplan, who was 12 1/2 years old, took the American Jewish community into new terrain: she became the first girl in this country to undergo the rite of passage known as bas mitzvah.

title: No Bail for Suspect In '78 Utah Murder
description: Frances B. Schreuder, a 43-year-old woman charged with masterminding the 1978 murder of her 76-year-old father in Salt Lake City, was ordered held without bail yesterday following an arraignment in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REVIVALS

title: FIRST DEAF LAWYER GOES BEFORE SUPREME COURT
description: In a stirring plea on behalf of a 10-yearold deaf girl from northern Westchester County, a 35-year-old graduate of Brooklyn Law School today became the first deaf lawyer to argue before the United States Supreme Court.

title: Bridge: Stayman and Team Upset Brachman in the Nationals
description: One of the world's most famous players, Sam Stayman of New York, was in action here this afternoon in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship. In the second round yesterday, he and his New York teammates, George Tornay, Saul Bronstein and Ethan Stein, scored a major upset, winning by 6 international points against the top-seeded team of Malcolm Brachman of Dallas.

title: MET OPERA: 'ENTFUHRUNG AUS DEM SERAIL' RETURNS
description: THE John Dexter-Jocelyn Herbert production of Mozart's ''Die Entfuhrung aus dem Serail,'' introduced at the Metropolitan Opera in the fall of 1979, returned to the repertory Monday night, with a new Belmonte, Pedrillo and Osmin.

title: Albert Elsasser Is Dead at 88; Princeton Professor Emeritus
description: Albert Elsasser, professor emeritus of English at Princeton University, died March 14 in Keene, N.H., where he had lived following his retirement in 1962. He was 88 years old.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: If the Knicks or the Rangers have the audacity to move out of New York, then what should we name a future replacement? Louis Phillips proposes the Kismets. ''It's the New York City team,'' he says, ''that leaves its final standings up to fate.''

title: IVY EDITORS UNITE ON SALVADOR
description: A joint declaration calling for the end of United States military aid to El Salvador was published yesterday by all but one of the student newspapers at the eight Ivy League colleges.

title: Ruling Seen Delaying Electric Plant for S.I.
description: A New York State appeals court issued a ruling yesterday that at the least is expected to delay still further the construction of a disputed coal-and-refuse-fueled power plant on Staten Island.

title: Vladimir Voinovich to Spend a Year at Princeton; Voinovich to Princeton
description: His ''The Ivankiad,'' a satire of Soviet bureaucracy, is required reading in Princeton University's undergraduate course in Russian politics, and now Vladimir Voinovich, the exiled Soviet writer, plans to spend a year as a visiting fellow in the school's Russian Studies Program.

title: Dinner-Cabaret to Aid Williamstown Theater
description: A dinner and cabaret April 4 at the Savoy will benefit the Williamstown (Mass.)

title: THE MAKING OF A FRENCH CHEF
description: MY career as a chef began in the fall of 1934, when I left my home in the village of St. Vinnemer, near Chablis, for Paris, where I was to begin an apprenticeship at Chez Tenint, a brasserie on the Place de la Republique. I was 13 years old.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SINCE a neighbor asked me recently if she might use dry white vermouth in cooking as a substitute for white wine on those rare occasions when she is out of the latter, I have conducted a few experiments with vermouth. The vermouth contains various aromatics - herbs, spices, bark of trees and so on -that give it a special flavor and character. They also impart a taste that is slightly, but noticeably, different. A dash or more of dry vermouth gives a pleasant taste to salad dressing made with oil and vinegar. It cuts the acidity of the vinegar.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Like F.D.R., may I say I'm not trying to destroy what is best in our system of humane, free government - I'm doing everything I can to save it: to slow down the destructive rate of growth in taxes and spending; to prune non-essential programs so that enough resources will be left to meet the requirements of the truly needy.'' - President Reagan. (A1:2)

title: SHAD: HARD TO BONE BUT WELL WORTH IT
description: NOW that the season for shad is with us, perhaps it's time that we paid homage to the employee of a New York fishmonger who devised a technique some years ago for boning that delicious fish. Shad has what may be the most elaborate bone structure of any fish. Because of the maddening intricacy, it was looked upon as ''trash'' fish slightly more than 50 years ago.

title: 1. Stamp of Domesticity
description: An attractive way to decorate your letter paper is with a rubber stamp that is a portrait of your house, custom-made by a company called More Madness. One of the company's artists does a portrait of the house, using a photograph as model. The drawings are well done, catching both the mood and the detail of the domicile, and you choose what you want the stamp to say and the lettering style to be used. The stamp comes mounted on clear acrylic, takes four to six weeks to complete and costs $65 prepaid. For a brochure and details, write to More Madness, P.O. Box 1274, New Canaan, Conn. 06840 or telephone 203-762-1972.

title: Bradley Coach Sets Sights on Basketball Title and Broadway
description: Dick Versace, the Bradley University basketball coach, who angrily criticized the N.C.A.A. tournament committee when the Braves were not included in the 48-team field, said yesterday that his trip to New York for the National Invitation Tournament had become a personal crusade.

title: La Caravelle's Les Quatre Oeufs au Beurre Blanc (Shad roe with caviar)
description: 1 pair shad roe 6 tablespoons butter 2 tablespoons finely chopped shallots Salt to taste, if desired Freshly ground pepper to taste 1/2 cup dry white wine 1/4 cup heavy cream 1 teaspoon lemon juice 2 tablespoons sieved hard-cooked egg 1 tablespoon black caviar, optional 1 tablespoon salmon roe (red caviar) 2 tablespoons finely chopped parsley.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: UNDERWEIGHT Americans are a sorely neglected minority, and it's not hard to understand why. Except when it is caused by an underlying disease, being significantly below ideal body weight is not associated with serious health hazards. When those who are too thin because of illness or an illness-provoking habit like cigarette smoking are eliminated from the statistics, the data show that the thinnest people live the longest.

title: Frank J. Keller, 70, a Founder Of Reference-Work Company
description: Frank J. Keller, an accountant who was a founder and former chairman of the Standard Reference Works Publishing Company, died Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix. He was 70 years old and lived in Dix Hills, L.I.

title: N.F.L. ANTITRUST BILL SET TO BE INRODUCED
description: The National Football League's legal counsel said today that a bill to exempt the league from antitrust law could be introduced in the United States Senate as early as this Friday.

title: WOLFGANG A. CASPER
description: Dr. Wolfgang A. Casper, consultant dermatologist to St. Vincent's Medical Center of Richmond on Staten Island and founder and former head of the hospital's dermatology clinic, died of a heart attack Monday at Doctors Hospital in the Concord area of the borough. He was 81 years old and lived in the Todt Hill, S.I.

title: COOKING IS BECOMING A CHOICE AMERICAN
description: CAREER By MARIAN BURROS

title: U.S. Recommends Subway Inspection
description: A Federal safety agency that investigated two recent subway derailments yesterday recommended the immediate inspection of the motors on nearly all of the city's 6,000 subway cars.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Sometime ago in Yugoslavia I dined on a fabulous soup made with yogurt, cucumbers and nuts. Have you ever heard of such a soup?

title: Tom Davis in Demand
description: Tom Davis, Boston College's coach, who took the Eagles to a regional final game in the current national collegiate tournament, is being pursued by other institutions. Although Davis is in the middle of a 10-year-contract, the athletic director, Bill Flynn, has given representatives of Wisconsin and Stanford permission to speak to Davis about employment.

title: 2 Plead Not Guilty
description: Two Syracuse University basketball players pleaded not guilty today to charges of having raped a Villanova student three weeks ago during the Big East Conference tournament here.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Rick Sutcliffe, the Cleveland Indians' right-hander, is expected to be out four to six weeks because of an injured right thumb. Sutcliffe was injured Monday when he was hit by a line drive off the bat of Ty Waller of the Chicago Cubs. ... The San Francisco Giants lost Bob Brealy, a reserve catcher, for a minimum of two weeks after Brealy fractured a bone in his shoulder while sliding into second base in an intra-squad game. ... The Seattle SuperSonics placed the veteran forward John Johnson on waivers and activated Wally Walker, who had been placed on the injured reserved list after suffering a spiral fracture of his right index finger against Los Angeles Feb. 25. ... Commissioner Larry O'Brien of the National Basketball Association has deferred payment of a $1,250 fine levied against Harvey Catchings of the Milwaukee Bucks for a Feb. 28 elbowing incident that resulted in Larry Bird receiving a fractured cheekbone. O'Brien, in finding that Catchings did not strike Bird intentionally, said he would review the fine at the end of the season.

title: City Landmarks Panel Adds 6 Sites to Its Roll
description: The Charles Scribner's Sons Building and the interior of the Pierpont Morgan Library were among six new landmarks designated yesterday by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: DAILY NEWS DROPPING U.P.I. IN MOVE TO CUT COSTS
description: The Daily News said yesterday that it was ending its use of the United Press International news service at the end of March, as part of an overall package of $1 million in cuts in newsroom costs.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE man was a determined collector, one who carefully evaluated every Bordeaux vintage and accumulated vast amounts in his cellar. He believed in buying wines when they were young and relatively inexpensive, holding them for years and then uncorking them at just the right moment. His cellar held more than 10,000 bottles and the number kept climbing, for he rarely drank any of them.

title: Hawks 107, Bullets 87
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - John Drew scored 27 points and Eddie Johnson added 25 as Atlanta got its eighth straight home victory. The Hawks took a 42-40 lead with 4:55 left in the first half and never trailed after that. Atlanta got 15 points from Drew in the third quarter and took an 85-68 lead into the fourth period.

title: Parliament Ties in Vote on Begin
description: A vote in Parliament on a motion of no confidence resulted in a tie today, prompting Prime Minister Menachem Begin to propose that he and his Cabinet resign. But the Cabinet rejected his request and voted 12 to 6 to stay in office. The vote in Parliament, tied at 58 to 58, came on three motions of no confidence over the Government's handling of recent disorders in the West Bank. But the crucial erosion of Mr. Begin's strength resulted from the defection of some right-wing legislators who are opposed to the final pullout from Sinai, scheduled for April 25. Although the tie did not legally require the Cabinet's resignation, Mr. Begin argued that Cabinet proposals would be hostage to the whims of splinter groups in Parliament unless the Government was reconstituted. Mr. Begin's coalition now controls just half of the 120 seats in Parliament. The opposition Labor Party has 48 but is given no significant chance of attracting support from the religious parties, which hold most of the balance and generally prefer Mr. Begin's politics. The Prime Minister's proposal to resign, which he could have done without Cabinet approval, was opposed by most of his key ministers, including Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Finance Minister Yoram Aridor was the only other member of Mr. Begin's Herut Party to support resignation. After the ministers held an emergency meeting tonight, the Cabinet Secretary, Aryeh Naor, announced, ''The Cabinet has just decided to reject the Prime Minister's proposal whereby he would have gone to the state President and tendered his resignation.''

title: KNICKS DEFEAT CAVALIERS
description: Campy Russell scored 17 of his 21 points in the final quarter last night to pave the way for the Knicks' 120-97 rout of the Cleveland Cavaliers at Madison Square Garden.

title: KOCH SAYS BAN ON DUMPING SLUDGE WOULD CLOSE HARBOR
description: Mayor Koch warned today that proposed legislation to prevent the dumping of sewage sludge and dredged materials into the ocean would leave New York City without a place to dispose of its sludge and would force the closing of New York Harbor.

title: Macchiarola Chooses a Successor, as Principal; Macchiarola Successor
description: Last December when Jamaica High School in Queens needed an acting principal, Frank J. Macchiarola, New York City's Schools Chancellor, didn't have to look far to find someone. He picked himself, and took over day-to-day control of the school while the search for a permanent principal continued.

title: The Nehemiah Tryouts
description: Renaldo Nehemiah, the track star who played one year of football as a quarterback in high school at Scotch Plains, N.J., is continuing to try out with National Football League teams. Nehemiah, who worked out for the Philadelphia Eagles and Washington Redskins, will next try the Oakland Raiders and San Diego Chargers.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Police Officer Francis Sheppard of the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on charges of robbing a man at gunpoint of $250 in cash and a quantity of marijuana in Brooklyn on Jan. 19. The New York State special prosecutor dealing with corruption in New York City, Thomas A. Duffy Jr., said Officer Sheppard, who is 33 years old, had been suspended without pay since March 3. ... David Garcia, 22 years old, of White Plains was arrested yesterday and charged with second-degree murder in the killing of William Carlo, a 17-year-old honor student, in the Bronx early Saturday morning. Mr. Carlo had been crossing Broadway at 242d Street when he was struck by a car, the police said. The car at first narrowly missed him and then the driver turned the car around and drove at him again, the police said. e said it had not yet determined whether the fire was accidental.

title: REFORMERS TRY TO HALT ACADEMIC ABUSE
description: With academic abuses in college sports programs occurring at an increased rate, concerned educators, lawyers, legislators and even judges are seeking ways to guarantee that athletes are not exploited and that they leave college with an education and a degree. So far, the reformers have had a limited impact on a system in which many athletes, according to records of the N.C.A.A. and various conferences, are illegally recruited and marginally educated. In some cases, athletes run out of eligibility long before they obtain degrees and in other cases they are sometimes stripped of scholarships if their performances or conduct do not suit coaches, who have the option of renewing that scholarship each year.

title: Bulls Shun McGuire
description: Al McGuire, the former Marquette coach turned television analyst, is not going to be the new coach of the Chicago Bulls or even a consultant to the team.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 24, 1982
description: International A coup in Guatemala was carried out by dissident army officers. They denounced the March 7 Presidential elections as fraudulent, installed a ruling military junta and pledged to restore ''peace and authentic democracy to Guatemala.'' In broadcasts, the group made clear it intended to block the installation of another conservative general as President on July 1. (Page A1, Column 6.) A United States-Nicaraguan accord to resume direct negotiations on their differences as a result of mediation by Mexico was reported by diplomatic sources in Managua, the Nicaraguan capital. The sources said that the talks could begin next week and might be held in Mexico City. (A1:4-5.)

title: NEWS RATINGS: NO WINNERS OR LOSERS
description: TELEVISION'S preoccupation with infinitesimal rating differences often seems absurd, but perhaps nowhere so much as in the highpitched ratings race among the three major commercial networks' evening newscasts.

title: Wally Amos, Celebrity
description: A follow-up: C. Vernon Ayers, the Mayor of Kingston, Ga., was so desperate to get a famous person to attend Kingston's annual historical festival next month that he issued a public appeal for a celebrity.

title: Rutgers Gains In A.I.A.W.
description: Terry Dorner scored 30 points and pulled down 16 rebounds tonight as Rutgers advanced to the Final Four of the Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women postseason tournament by defeating Minnesota, 83-75, at the College Avenue Gymnasium.

title: BEST BUYS
description: SPRING is finally here, with the first spring lamb arriving in the stores and vegetables such as cucumbers, peppers and greens back on the market in plentiful supply.

title: Bush Defeats Weicker At Caucus in Fairfield
description: Prescott Bush Jr. easily defeated Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in a party caucus here tonight and swept all 17 of this town's delegates to the Republican State Convention in July.

title: Eglevsky Ballet to Give Benefit on L.I. April 17
description: The Eglevsky Ballet will present ''Star-Spangled Evening,'' a benefit for the troupe, on April 17 at the DeServersky Conference Center, formerly the summer home of the duPonts, on Long Island.

title: ROBERTSON ADAPTS TO SECOND
description: On Andre Robertson's first day as a major leaguer last September, Reggie Jackson invited the infielder from Class AAA to join him for some pregame jogging at Minnesota's Metropolitan Stadium. While they ran in the outfield, Robertson recalled the other day, Jackson offered some advice about playing for the Yankees.

title: Laingen Declines a Maryland Senate Campaign; Laingen Declines
description: A group of prominent Maryland Republicans who had been trying to ''draft'' L. Bruce Laingen to run for the Senate got disappointing news yesterday.

title: Buddy Parker, 68, Led Lions to N.F.L. Titles
description: Raymond (Buddy) Parker, the coach who guided the Detroit Lions to two consecutive National Football League championships in the early 1950's, died Monday of complications after surgery for a ruptured ulcer. Mr. Parker, 68 years old, did not regain consciousness after surgery March 7.

title: Murry C. Becker Dies; A Lawyer for 65 Years
description: Murry C. Becker, a lawyer in New York for 65 years and a founding partner in 1942 of the firm now known as Becker Ross Stone DeStefano & Klein, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: CITY TO MOVE SOME STAFF AND OFFICES TO BROOKLYN
description: The Koch administration, which has been encouraging private companies to move to boroughs other than Manhattan, has taken its own advice and decided to move parts of several agencies and about 1,500 employees to Brooklyn.

title: JERSEY'S TRANSIT AGENCY PLANS 18% FARE INCREASE
description: The New Jersey Transit Corporation, which operates the state's commuter trains and buses and serves 320,000 riders, today proposed a fare increase averaging 18 percent.

title: NAPAMEDOC AUCTION OFFERING WILL NOT BE REPEATED IN JUNE
description: A further offering of the California wine that brought a record price of $24,000 for a case of 12 bottles at the Napa Valley Wine Auction last June will not be made at the Napa auction this year, according to a spokesman for the Robert Mondavi Winery, which produced the record-setting wine. ''The publicity got out of hand,'' the spokesman said.

title: ESPRESSO MACHINE
description: SOME machines - they could be called the Rolls-Royces of the kitchen - are expensive luxuries but are so well made and efficient that you feel you are spending your money wisely. The Cremina Olympia espresso is such a machine: It makes a superb cup of espresso or cappuccino in a couple of minutes with a minimum of fuss and is easy to work and maintain.

title: WARNER PLANS MOVIE OF A NEGRO ENSEMBLE PLAY
description: Movie rights to ''A Soldier's Play'' by Charles Fuller - the New York Negro Ensemble Company's highly praised, current Off Broadway drama - have been bought by Warner Bros. Norman Jewison will direct and co-produce the movie and will collaborate on the screenplay with Mr. Fuller.

title: STUDIED DIET IN HYPERACTIVITY
description: Dr. Ben F. Feingold, a pediatric allergist and author who believed that many hyperactive children could benefit from a diet that excluded all artificial colors and flavors, died yesterday at the Kaiser Foundation Hospital in San Francisco after a brief illness. He was 81 years old and entered the hospital with a bladder infection on March 7. The exact cause of death was not clear.

title: INCOME TAX CUT FOR NEW YORKERS GIANS IN ALBANY
description: The Republican-led State Senate has proposed a series of cuts in the personal income tax as part of this year's budget. And it has withdrawn its opposition to Governor Carey's proposal to prevent a series of business tax cuts enacted by Congress from taking effect automatically on state returns.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt YEARS OF UPHEAVAL. By Henry A. Kis- singer. 1,283 pages. Illustrated. Little, Brown. $24.95.

title: Hockey Fan Settles
description: A hockey fan in Pittsburgh has accepted $27,500 to settle his suit against the Rangers and a former player of theirs, Greg Polis.

title: News Analysis
description: A longtime controversy has surfaced again about the authenticity of ''The Fortune Teller,'' a painting attributed to the 17th-century French artist Georges de La Tour, owned by the Metropolitan Museum of Art since

title: CITY ASKS LINCOLN WEST TO DEFER CURRENT PLANS
description: The Koch administration, in a surprise move, has asked the developer of a prime waterfront site on Manhattan's West Side to withdraw his application.

title: G.I. Found Fit for Trial In 3 Slayings in Buffalo
description: A judge ruled today that Army Pvt. Joseph Christopher is mentally competent to stand trial in a series of slayings in the Buffalo area in the fall of 1980.

title: LUCHOW'S SYMBOL OF THE GOOD OLD DAYS
description: WHEN Theodore Roosevelt dined at Luchow's he ordered venison and a bottle of Pommard, which is hardly the standard brew in what Ludwig Bemelmans irreverently called a goulash and Wiener schnitzel emporium. Sigmund Romberg was a venison man too, but he in classic style preferred a seidel or two - or three - of Wurzburger. Old August Luchow himself was a beer man, and waiters who remembered him - he died in 1923 -recalled that there were nights when it took four waiters to get him up to his apartment above the restaurant, so filled was he with food and beer.

title: Borg Plays First Match And Looks in Shape
description: Bjorn Borg played competitive tennis for the first time in four months today, losing to Vitas Gerulaitis in an exhibition match, 6-2, 6-7, 6-2.

title: West Virginia Coach Faces N.C.A.A. Inquiry
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association plans to investigate whether the West Virginia University basketball coach, Gale Catlett, violated association rules by speaking about the recruitment of a player at a news conference in Detroit last week.

title: No Headline
description: Celtics Beat Bulls For 16th in a Row

title: BOSSY SCORES 4 IN ROUT OF CAPS
description: Sparked by Mike Bossy's four goals, three of them on second-period power plays, the Islanders routed the Washington Capitals, 8-1, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: OUTLOOK FOR FINAL FOUR: BINOCULARS
description: They are possibly the worst seats ever sold for an indoor college basketball game - a block from the court and 19 stories up. But the National Collegiate Athletic Association says it has given fair warning to some ticketholders for its championship-round games Saturday and Monday.

title: Raleigh Rajoppi, Ex-Member Of Carpenters Union's Board
description: Raleigh Rajoppi, a former member of the executive board of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, died March 17 at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Springfield, N.J.

title: Turner Gets Reprimand
description: Ted Turner, the owner of the Atlanta Hawks, who has never been accused of whispering, has received a reprimand from the National Basketball Association.

title: REAGAN SAYS 'FACTS PROVE' HE CARES ABOUT NEEDY
description: President Reagan, accepting an award for humanitarianism that some protesters said he did not deserve, declared in a speech in New York City last night that ''the facts prove'' that he really does care about the needy.

title: RECITAL: STEVEN MAYER, PIANO
description: STEVEN MAYER played an interesting program of piano music with musical intelligence and technical command last Thursday at the 92d Street Y.

title: U.S. Reacts Cautiously
description: The Reagan Administration reacted cautiously today to the tie vote on a motion of no confidence in the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin in the Israeli Parliament.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: LOS ANGELES FIVE years ago, in 1977, punk rock gained a foothold in Los Angeles. Inspired by the Ramones and by the first Sex Pistols and Clash singles from England, a small and diverse group of Los Angeles residents began putting together their own punk bands, patronizing punk shows in a stark, sleazy Hollywood nightclub called the Masque, and publishing Slash, the city's first punk-rock magazine. ''This publication was born out of curiosity and out of hope,'' an editorial in the first issue of Slash proclaimed. ''Curiosity regarding what looks like a possible rebirth of true rebel music, hope in its eventual victory over the bland products professional pop stars have been feeding us. May the punks set this rat-infested industry on fire. It sure could use a little brightness!''

title: Sampson Is Facing Familiar Decision
description: Facing his annual decision for the third time, Ralph Sampson, the 7-foot-4-inch center for Virginia, knows the routine: the season ends, the awards are accepted graciously, the questions are raised more frequently, and the deadline approaches.

title: Players Weigh Lower Prices
description: Members of the National Football League Players Association discussed today the possibility of incorporating the concept of a rollback or freeze of ticket prices into negotiations aimed at a collective bargaining agreement to replace the one that expires July 15.

title: British Yacht Disqualified
description: Victory, the British yacht that won Class C honors last month on the Southern Ocean circuit, was disqualified yesterday because of an invalid rating certificate, which had resulted in undeserved time allowances. The 44-foot sloop, owned by Trevor Bailey of London, had placed third in the overall fleet standing.

title: IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN GOING TO SCHOOL
description: IN 1946 there was only one American professional culinary school - the Culinary Institute of America, which was founded in New Haven, Conn., and moved to Hyde Park, N.Y., in 1972. Now there are dozens of schools and courses for people interested in careers as chefs, caterers and restaurant owners, and more crop up every year. Joseph Amendola, vice president of the Culinary Institute, estimates that 20 new schools will be started this year.

title: MENU COLLECTION OFFERS A TASTE OF HISTORY
description: FOR Jacques Rouet, a collection can mean the latest in designer fashion or his own penchant for accumulating things. The chairman of Christian Dior, who first became associated with the company when it was founded in 1946, he has a number of personal collections, and they are all related to gastronomy.

title: A REQUESTED RECIPE
description: In response to an article on low-fat eating in last week's Living Section, a number of readers have asked for the recipe for Paula Wolfert's creme fraiche.

title: Holmes-Cooney Fight Officially Set for June 11
description: It was officially announced yesterday that Larry Holmes will defend his World Boxing Council heavyweight championship June 11 against Gerry Cooney. Cooney said, ''Everything is back in working order and I feel great.''

title: Stemkowski Arrested
description: Pete Stemkowski, the former Ranger center, was arrested by Nassau County police yesterday and charged with having tried to arrange for the beating of a man who owed him money. According to the office of District Attorney Denis Dillon, the man whom Stemkowski tried to hire for the job, at a fee of $20,000, was an undercover Nassau officer.

title: Brooklyn Woman, 83, Strangled by a Robber
description: An 83-year-old woman was found strangled in her Brooklyn apartment yesterday afternoon, the apparent victim of a push-in type robbery, the police said.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 25, 1982
description: International A crackdown in Guatemala one day after a coup surprised many people who had expected the new military leaders to form an interim government with civilian politicians and to set speedy elections. The junta of three senior military officers who seized power Tuesday suspended the Constitution and all political activities. (Page A1, Column 6.) Abuses by Salvadoran security forces appear to be diminishing a bit, but many of the traditional excesses are continuing. Much of the international opposition to the ruling junta arises from its general failure to curb the killing of noncombatants by security forces and the paramilitary death squads linked with them. (A1:4-5.)

title: HIGH COURT RULES L.I.R.R. EMPLOYEES MAY GO ON STRIKE
description: The United States Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that employees of the state-owned Long Island Rail Road have a Federally guaranteed right to strike.

title: Gardening; NEW VEGETABLES CAN BE STARTED RIGHT FROM SEED
description: HOME gardeners can grow vegetables that are truly new - a potato from seed, a summer-winter squash, peas with edible pods and sweeter corn.

title: Bridge: Vanderbilt Field Narrows; New Yorkers Doing Well
description: The quarterfinals of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship began here this afternoon with New York players strongly in contention after Tuesday's third round in the Spring Nationals event, sponsored by the American Contract Bridge League.

title: 200 AT A SCHOOL STAGE WALKOUT OVER PRINCIPAL
description: About 200 students walked out of a high school on the Lower East Side yesterday in a dispute with their principal over problems at the school.

title: CONCERT: BACH ARIA GROUP
description: JUDGING from the performances Sunday by the Bach Aria Group at the 92d Street Y, the renowned composer was a bit of a busybody. Bach could turn out endless phrases, some with a thumping sort of seesaw glee, as in the Brandenburg Concerto No. 4; he could have some buoyant fun with timbre, as in the Trio Sonata from the Musical Offering.

title: L.I. Beach Club Named in Bias Suit
description: A privately owned beach club on Nassau County's South Shore was accused today by the State Attorney General of violating state and Federal civil-rights laws by discriminating against Jews.

title: UNION CHIEF FACING TRIAL FEARED DEAD
description: The head of the New York City carpenters' union, Theodore Maritas, has disappeared and may be ''the victim of foul play,'' a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.

title: GUSTAVE STAMM
description: Gustave Stamm, the founder of Science Digest, died here Monday at the age of 92. Mr. Stamm, the son of Swiss immigrants, was an author, publisher, merchant and humorist.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news analysis article yesterday, discussing the issue of the authenticity of the painting ''The Fortune Teller,'' omitted a word from a statement by John Brealey of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, explaining that the museum had invited CBS News to see the painting. The quotation should have read, ''The test results could not be meaningfully evaluated without simultaneous first-hand examination of the painting itself.''

title: RECITAL: RUTH GLASSER, CELLIST
description: SO many virtues were evident in Ruth Glasser's cello recital Monday at the Merkin Concert Hall that the performances should have been better than they were.

title: VALENZUELA'S BACK, AND SO IS TUMULT
description: Fernandomania was in midseason form at the Los Angeles Dodgers' spring training camp today. After three weeks of holding out for a heftier contract, Fernando Valenzuela came to Dodgertown to begin workouts and was met by a phalanx of reporters, photographers and tourists. The rest of the Dodgers watched the commotion over the 21-year-old Mexican lefthander with a mixture of bemusement, annoyance and relief. It was nothing they hadn't seen before.

title: Kings 110, Hawks 106
description: KANSAS CITY (AP) - Reggie King hit a layup with 35 seconds left, and Steve Johnson batted away Atlanta's inbounds pass at the 31-mark as Kansas City won a game that was protested by the Atlanta coach, Kevin Loughery.

title: FURNITURE POLISHES CAN BE DAMAGING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores furniture for antiques dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: PHILHARMONIC: 'HALIL,' NEW NOCTURNE BY BERNSTEIN
description: EVERY so often, like a bird laying an egg, Leonard Bernstein delivers himself of another composition. Sometimes, of course, the egg-laying simile happens to be all too apt. Mr. Bernstein, like any other composer, sometimes fails to turn out a masterpiece. What he does do, however, is to maintain a high level of artistic seriousness and professional competence. Both those qualities were evident in his ''Halil,'' which was given its New York premiere last night by the New York Philharmonic under the composer's direction.

title: Court Approves Shift of Haitians
description: A Federal judge today approved the transfer of 157 refugees from a Federal prison in Ray Brook, N.Y., to one in Florence, Ariz.

title: Bradley Beats Purdue, 67-58, for a Fourth N.I.T. Title
description: Given the opportunity to get on the soapbox one last time, the Bradley Braves reminded anyone who would listen of what they had shown between the white lines of the basketball court at Madison Square Garden. Their voices rose as they spoke last night after winning the National Invitation Tournament championship.

title: LEAKS FORCE CLOSING OF NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Nine-Mile Point One nuclear power plant will be closed for about a year because two small leaks were discovered Tuesday, a spokesman for the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced yesterday.

title: DANCE: BOB BOWYER AND JOANN BRUGGEMAN IN PARODIES
description: BOB BOWYER and JoAnn Bruggeman have brought their American Ballet Comedie gang to the downstairs Space of the City Center through Sunday - and this is good news.

title: PROFESSOR COLLECTS BUMPS ON A LOG
description: Talk about a bump on a log and you'll have Rob Roy Kelly's attention. He hunts them in the woods of Minnesota, in Pittsburgh parks, in his neighbor's backyard.

title: Flyers Bench Leach
description: Reggie Leach will not play for the Flyers for the remainder of the season, Bob McCammon, the team's assistant general manager, announced in Philadelphia. McCammon said he reached a decision ''to go with the kids'' in the remaining games and that included finding a permanent spot for winger Ilkka Sinisalo, a winger.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Whoever is elected has a responsibility to democracy. Those who come to power and forget the people make a mistake.

title: Bullets 114, Pacers 106
description: INDIANAPOLIS (UPI) - Greg Ballard and Spencer Haywood combined for 55 points to lead Washington. Ballard scored 12 of his game-high 30 points and hauled down 10 rebounds in the first half when the Bullets rebounded from a 5-point deficit to take a 14-point lead.

title: THE NEW FAMILY ALBUM: IT'S ALL ON TAPE
description: WHEN Susan Trentacoste Miller, a New York freelance photographer, decided to document her family's history, she didn't compile an album of pictures. Instead, Mrs. Miller, her parents, sister and uncle spent four hours relating their memories to a videotape camera.

title: RANGERS STRETCH STREAK TO 8
description: The Rangers, who have been scoring a lot of goals recently, tonight used two scoring bursts to subdue the Pittsburgh Penguins, 7-2.

title: GERSTEN TO PRODUCE MUSIC HALL SHOWS
description: Bernard Gersten has been named executive producer and vice president of Radio City Music Hall Productions. Mr. Gersten, formerly associate producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival and recently executive vice president of Francis Coppola's Zoetrope Studios, will be responsible for all productions at the Music Hall and at theaters around the country.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ART DECO LECTURES
description: Floating Palaces of Art Deco, McGraw-Hill Building, 1221 Avenue of the Americas (48th Street), 50th floor, 675-0400.

title: N.F.L. UNION CONCLUDES TALKS
description: The National Football League Players Association ended its three-day convention today after what appeared to be a largely successful but not perfect job of salesmanship.

title: News Analysis
description: The United States Supreme Court's refusal yesterday to make employees of the Long Island Rail Road subject to New York State labor law was a sharp blow to efforts by transit officials to strengthen management's hand at the bargaining table.

title: 3 ARRESTED IN QUEENS
description: Two police officers were wounded yesterday in Queens when a door swung open on a garage where they were investigating a burglary and a shotgun was fired at them from the dim interior.

title: Helpful Hardware; TO MAKE TRAVEL EASIER; by Barbara L. Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: SOME interesting accessories are available to make traveling a little bit easier. If, for example, you have a heavy piece of luggage without wheels, the Luggage Caddy ($25) allows you to strap on two sets of wheels, one swiveling.

title: Marietta S. Shaginyan, A Soviet Novelist, Dies
description: Marietta S. Shaginyan, a Soviet novelist who was active in literature since the first decade of the century, has died at the age of 93, the press agency Tass said today.

title: Jersey Trooper Shot by Motorist
description: A state trooper was shot in the face by the driver of a car he had stopped early today, and the state police said a 34-year-old member of a Jersey motorcycle gang had been charged with attempted murder.

title: RECORD PHONE FEE RISE APPROVED IN NEW YORK
description: A record increase in revenues of $361.5 million a year - 9.4 percent -was approved for the New York Telephone Company yesterday by the Public Service Commission. Charges for equipment were raised, but the cost of some calls in the metropolitan area was reduced.

title: AT CALIFORNIA SHOW, INNOVATIONS FROM EAST AND WEST
description: Designers, manufacturers and furniture buyers from all over the United States as well as Europe thronged to West Week 1982, the area's most important contract and residential furniture and accessories market, held last weekend in the Pacific Design Center.

title: Our Choices Are Easy
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The March 4 ''Hers'' column was disturbing. The apologetic tone grated on my rash 27-year-old nerves. More troublesome was the notion that somehow we poor unprepared women have so many difficult personal decisions in our quasi-professional lives, unlike our male counterparts.

title: Miss Navratilova Advances
description: Can anyone seriously challenge Martina Navratilova for the $100,000 top prize in the Avon women's tennis championships this week at Madison Square Garden?

title: SUFFOLK AND NASSAU JOIN SUIT OVER DUMPING IN L.I. SOUND
description: Suffolk and Nassau Counties joined the North Shore Long Island Town of Huntington yesterday in filing a suit in Federal court that seeks to bar the dumping of mud and silt dredged from harbors into eastern Long Island Sound.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS, FEARING LEHRMAN IS LOSER, TURN TO EX-U.S. ATTORNEY
description: Some leading Republicans are encouraging Paul J. Curran, the former United States Attorney, to enter the New York State gubernatorial race to head off the increasingly likely nomination of Lewis E. Lehrman, a wealthy businessman.

title: GAREY GIVING UP ON NEGOTIATIONS OVER THE BUDGET
description: Governor Carey today abandoned negotiations with the Legislature and challenged it to pass its own budget proposal - a proposal that Mr. Carey said was ''jerry-built.''

title: DOWRIES SURVIVE IN LOUISIANA TOWN
description: The wish of the late Julien de Lalande Poydras that no woman in West Baton Rouge Parish face marriage without a dowry is being honored.

title: Home Improvement
description: BECAUSE ceramic tiles are so durable and are usually easy to clean, it's not surprising that so many homes and apartments have tiled bathroom walls and shower enclosures as well as tiles in kitchens, laundry rooms and similar areas.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHELSEA

title: Nuggets 129, Spurs 115
description: DENVER (UPI) - Glen Gondrezick and Cedrick Hordges combined for 28 points to spark Denver to its seventh straight victory.

title: CABLE TV, HOME VIDEO AND CHOPPING OF MOVIES
description: ACENSOR made mincemeat out of ''Dirty Harry'' several Saturdays ago, when an outrageously overedited print was shown as a late-night television movie. This wasn't simply a case of snipping out the odd bit of colorful language here and there, or of protecting the home audience from excessive gore.

title: New Job for Beamon
description: Bob Beamon, whose long jump of 29 feet 2 1/2 inches at the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City remains a world record, has taken a position with the title of recreation specialist for the Metro-Dade Parks and Recreation Department in Miami. Beamon is to conduct clinics and supervise track events in the county. He recently resigned as track coach at York College in Queens.

title: Sinai Victim Honored
description: After a concert with the Israel Philharmonic in Tel Aviv in 1976, Leonard Bernstein was approached by the parents of Yadin Tanenbaum, a promising 19-year-old flutist who was killed in his Army tank during the fighting in Sinai in the 1973 war.

title: Preserve the Options
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Molly Haskell is undoubtedly right (''Hers,'' March 4) when she says few women succeed perfectly in all areas of their lives: job, marriage, home, friends. Most men don't either.

title: BALLET THEATER TO GIVE EIGHT NEW PRODUCTIONS
description: Eight new productions and three revivals will highlight the American Ballet Theater's eight-week engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House, opening April, 19.

title: Hers; by K.C. Cole
description: METAPHOR is truly a marvelous thing. We speak of being in tune with the times or out of tune with each other. We speak of sympathetic vibrations and being on the same wavelength. We speak of going through phases, of ideas that resonate and descriptions that ring true. I wonder how many of us know that all the time we are talking physics?

title: Nuclear Plant Mishap Is Explained by Utility
description: Friction between two tubes caused the accident on Jan. 25 at the Robert E. Ginna nuclear plant in Ontario, N.Y., officials of Rochester Gas and Electric, the plant operator, have told the Nuclear Regulatory Commisson.

title: OFFICIAL REPORTS HOW RICHMOND AIDED A CONVICT
description: Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn intervened with the Massachusetts Correction Commissioner on behalf of a prisoner who later escaped, according to new accounts by Massachusetts officials.

title: TV: WOMEN'S WOES, AS POLICE AND AS SECRETARIES
description: TWO new weekly series are getting under way this evening and, not surprisingly, one is a police action-adventure, ''Cagney & Lacey,'' on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock, and the other is a situation-comedy, ''9 to 5,'' on ABC-TV at 9.

title: BUSH TERMS FAIRFIELD VICTORY G.O.P. 'REJECTION' OF WEICKER
description: Prescott Bush Jr., who swept all 17 state convention delegates in the town of Fairfield's Republican caucus Tuesday night, said today that his victory was ''an overwhelming rejection'' of Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the party's two-term incumbent.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: KANSAS CITY (AL) - Traded Jeff Schattinger, pitcher, to the Chicago White Sox for Greg Pryor, infielder.

title: Photographer's Pledge
description: Ronald E. Galella, a freelance photographer who has devoted much of his career to taking pictures of Jacqueline Onassis and her family, promised a Federal judge yesterday that he would never again aim a camera at Mrs. Onassis or her children.

title: FILM: 'PASSE' OBSERVES THE VOLUPTUOUS YOUNG
description: ''Passe Ton Bac D'Abord'' (''Graduate First'') was shown as part of the 1981 New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of Sept. 27. The film is at the Film Forum 2, at 57 Watts Street.

title: SONNY GREER, 78, ELLINGTON DRUMMER, IS DEAD
description: Sonny Greer, the original drummer in Duke Ellington's Orchestra, who played with Mr. Ellington for more than 30 years, died Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital of cancer. Mr. Greer, who lived in Manhattan, was 78 years old.

title: CARPETING
description: A fire expert testified today in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial that gasoline poured on a piece of hotel carpet and ignited in an unofficial experiment produced a fire similar to the one seen in its earliest stages by survivors of the fire on Dec. 4, 1980.

title: YANKEES GET HOBSON
description: George Steinbrenner strongly criticized his manager, Bob Lemon, today for disregarding instructions by continuing to experiment with Dave Revering at third base even after the Yankees had obtained Butch Hobson as a backup third baseman in a trade with the California Angels.

title: METS GET EXTRA HOUR FOR BASIC TRAINING
description: After five consecutive defeats and three shutouts in their preceding four games, the Mets got the order today from their manager, George Bamberger: Report for work one hour early for the remaining week and a half of spring training and practice fundamentals.

title: MAHLER'S REWORKNG OF BEETHOVEN SURFACES
description: AHISTORIC confrontation between innovation and tradition will be re-enacted April 16 and 17 in Cincinnati when Gerhard Samuel will conduct the University of Cincinnati's orchestra in Gustav Mahler's long-buried revision of the Beethoven Ninth Symphony.

title: PLAN FOR ACTORS' NURSING HOME DIVIDES A JERSEY COMMUNITY
description: The recent celebration of the ''Night of 100 Stars,'' which marked the 100th anniversary of the Actors' Fund of America, was a happy occasion at the fund's retirement home here.

title: PIANO RECITAL: MISHA DICHTER
description: MISHA DICHTER is so cultured a pianist, so technically complete and so responsible in his application of style that it would be nice to report that his Carnegie Hall recital Sunday night was an inspiring affair.

title: HENRY SEARS, REVIVED AMERICA'S CUP RACE AFTER 21-YEAR LAPSE
description: Henry Sears, a real-estate investment executive and former commodore of the New York Yacht Club, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Chestertown, Md. He was 69 years old.
