title: Home Beat; TO MIX, NOT MATCH; by Suzanne Stein
description: LIKE many other interior designers, Vincent Wolf and Bob Patino of Patino/Wolf Associates were often asked by their clients to do table settings.

title: Schembechler No.1
description: As is often the case in Big Ten football, Michigan and Ohio State are at the top. A survey by The Columbus (Ohio) Citizen-Journal found that the Michigan has the highest-paid football coach in the conference, Bo Schembechler, who, when all the extras are added, earns $150,000 a year, or $10,000 more than Earle Bruce, the Ohio State coach.

title: 39 FOR RAY WILLIAMS
description: With Ray Williams scoring a season-high 39 points and Mike O'Koren controlling Julius Erving in the fourth quarter, the Nets defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 111-106, at the Spectrum tonight.

title: COMFORTERS NEED CARE IN CLEANING
description: WITH cold days behind us, now is the time to consider the cleaning and storage of that comforter that has served so well. Whether comforters are filled with goose down, lamb's wool or polyester fiberfill, their owners should be aware of the advantages and pitfalls of cleaning. With the rising cost of materials, a comforter damaged by improper care would be expensive to replace.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Johnny Petraglia of Manalapan, N.J., was voted into the Hall of fame of the Professional Bowlers Association by 135 writers, broadcasters and bowling officials. ... Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, will meet Jumbo Cummings and Jodie Ballard in a six-round exhibition Saturday at the Playboy Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. ... Phil Mahre of Yakima, Wash., won his second World Cup skiing title of the season yesterday, taking the giant slalom. He finished third in a race won by Pirmin Zurbriggen in 2 minutes 42.37 seconds in Sansicario, Italy.

title: Raiders Jury Picked
description: Five women and one man were selected today as the jury for retrial of the antitrust case of the Oakland Raiders and Los Angeles Coliseum against the National Football League. Two alternates selected also were women.

title: No Premiere for 'Richard'
description: The Circle Repertory Company has decided not to open its production of William Shakespeare's ''Richard II'' to the critics. The play is directed by Marshall W. Mason and stars William Hurt. It will continue in repertory with ''The Great Grandson of Jedediah Kohler'' at the Entermedia Theater until April 4.

title: Lioness Can Stay
description: Although he has gone into personal bankruptcy, Donald DeMeo has been allowed by a Federal trustee to keep his 180-pound lioness, Sheba.

title: EXTRAS VOTE TO JOIN ACTORS
description: Members of the Screen Extras Guild have approved a merger with the larger Screen Actors Guild by more than the required 60 percent plurality.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard RICHARD A. By Sol Yurick. 446 Pages. Arbor House. $14.95.

title: A BIT OF IRELAND TRANSPORTED TO VERMONT
description: QUECHEE, Vt. ''ANYTHING good, I think, grows on you,'' said Simon Pearce, an Irish potter turned glass blower. ''If you like it straight off, I think you can get tired of it.''

title: Celtics Take 17th Straight
description: Robert Parish scored 27 points and Larry Bird 25 to lead Boston Celtics to their 17th straight victory, a 136-115 decision over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: PIANISTS: DELPHIN AND ROMAIN
description: MUSIC for two pianos by the American composers Thomas Kerr and George Walker and the Panamanian-born Roque Cordero was featured on the first half of Sunday afternoon's Carnegie Hall recital by the duo-pianists Wilfrid Delphin and Edwin Romain, who earlier this season appeared for the first time as soloists with the New York Philharmonic.

title: A Racing Fan's Place of Rest
description: The ashes of an avid racing fan who died March 9 at the age of 75 will be spread at Pimlico Race Course during a special ceremony on Sunday.

title: JANE FONDA: SHE MAKES IDEAS PAY AT BOX OFFICE
description: HOLLYWOOD JANE FONDA sits in a provisional office in a drab bungalow on the 20th Century-Fox lot, hugging a gold-covered script. ''This script'' she says, ''is my baby of six years.''

title: Rent Stabilization Law Is Extended by Council
description: The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to extend for another three years legislation authorizing the city's rent-stabilization system. A spokesman for the Mayor said Mr. Koch would sign the measure.

title: HOMELESS RIDING IN SUBWAYS BEING TAKEN TO CITY SHELTERS
description: For the last 10 days, transit police officers have been ejecting the homeless from New York City subways and steering them to social service workers waiting aboveground with offers of food and shelter.

title: Design Notebook
description: THERE is something second-rate about a great city that doesn't have an obelisk. So people have always thought, at any rate. Rome has an obelisk in front of St. Peter's. Paris has an obelisk in the middle of the Place de la Concorde. London has an obelisk on the north bank of the Thames, hard by the Antarctic exploration ship Discovery. New York has an obelisk in Central Park not far from the Metropolitan Museum. Boston has a fine one, the Bunker Hill Monument, that holds its own even among later and larger structures. And what is the form of the Washington National Monument in the capital? An obelisk.

title: Jersey Rents Fort Dix Jail
description: Governor Kean signed a three-year lease with the Federal Government today to house 500 state prisoners in the Fort Dix stockade. The state will rent the Army facility for $300,000 a year, with the first prisoners expected to be transferred there by mid-June. The move is designed to ease crowding in the state prisons.

title: U.S.C. Planning Appeal
description: Southern California will appeal the penalties the N.C.A.A. is expected to impose on its football team, the university's president, Dr. James Zumberge, said today. Although the penalties have not been made public, the school is reportedly about to be barred from appearing on national or regional television or in bowl games for two years. Dr. Zumberge said the National Collegiate Athletic Association has requested that U.S.C. not disclose the report. But several published reports have said that the thrust of the investigation concerned selling of players' tickets by an assistant coach.

title: By Sports of The Times; Say It Ain't So, Fidel
description: EVEN in Fidel Castro's ''society of workers,'' money has emerged as the root of all evil among 17 as yet unidentified baseball players and coaches who have been suspended and arrested and now face trial on charges of conspiring with gamblers in a game-fixing scandal.

title: Q & A
description: Q. One room in our house is covered with knotty-pine paneling that has been up for some years. During that time the pine has become quite dark except where some pictures were hung. Is there any way I can clean and lighten the wood without sanding or removing the original finish and then refinishing? - M.C., Little Silver, N.J.

title: AT RUTGERS, A GOAL IS FULFILLED
description: The women's basketball team that Coach Theresa Shank Grentz started to cultivate at Rutgers four years ago has grown to a final four contestant.

title: Broadway; Tommy Tune and Twiggy to team in a '27 Gershwin.
description: THE score is to die for: ''He Loves and She Loves,'' '' 'Swonderful,'' ''My One and Only,'' ''You've Got What Gets Me,'' ''How Long Has This Been Going On?,'' ''Let's Kiss and Make Up,'' ''The Babbit and the Bromide'' and, if you have not already guessed, ''Funny Face.'' The show, of course, is George and Ira Gershwin's ''Funny Face,'' and when it opened the Alvin Theater in 1927, it starred Fred and Adele Astaire. When it is revived on Broadway next September, it will star Tommy Tune and Twiggy. The director is Peter Sellars, 24 years old, who has been associated with opera and with the American Repertory Theater at Harvard. The producers are Obie Bailey, who has been associated with Wall Street, and Bernard Carragher, who has been associated with journalism. The musical, which will go into rehearsal in May, is capitalized at $2.5 million.

title: Hibernia Takeover
description: The Hibernia Bancshares Corporation, the holding company for the Hibernia Bank, of San Francisco, announced that its board approved a definitive agreement to sell 80 percent of its outstanding shares to the First Pacific Group of Hong Kong for approximately $75 million, or about $75 a share. First Pacific is largely controlled by two Indonesian individuals, Liam Sioe Liong and Liem Oen Kian. Under the agreement, Hibernia's senior management will remain.

title: THEATER: 'OCCUPATIONS,' EARLY TREVOR GRIFFITHS
description: THE screenplay credit for ''Reds'' is shared by Warren Beatty and the British Marxist playwright Trevor Griffiths - strange bedfellows even by Hollywood standards - and one cannot watch the movie without wondering who wrote what. Maybe we'll never find out, but after seeing ''Occupations,'' the early Griffiths play at the 28th Street Playhouse, I'd be willing to bet that it was Mr. Beatty who dreamed up the gags about John Reed and Louise Bryant's cute pet puppy.

title: Sports of The Times; Changing Planes to the Final Four
description: IN October 1980, a young man flew from Nigeria to the United States to shop around for colleges. His ticket had been supplied by his father, a cement dealer in the capital city of Lagos.

title: CO-HOST OF 'EASY ACES' ON RADIO
description: Goodman Ace, the comic writer who furnished dozens of leading performers with funny things to say but is perhaps best known for the malapropisms he provided for his wife, died last night at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: London Fur Protest
description: Six conservationists disrupted a top fashion show today at London's Olympia Hall in protest over the modeling of fur coats. The demonstrators, supporters of the Animal Liberation Front, leaped onstage and chanted ''Murderers!'' at the audience before being escorted out by security guards.

title: MORE REHIRINGS SEEN
description: The rehiring of a dismissed air traffic controller yesterday in Texas is viewed by key Federal officials as part of a gradual process that could lead to the eventual return of several hundred of the controllers who were dismissed after an illegal strike last August.

title: A DIAMOND JIM BRADY EATING-PLACE TOUR
description: ''Traditionally, the word 'restauranteur' is wrong,'' Val Ginter, jazz musician turned architectural historian turned walking-tour leader, said the other day as he stood before the Fraunces Tavern at Broad and Pearl Streets. ''It ought to be 'restaurateur.' ''

title: STUDENTS REJOICE AT PROSPECT OF CONTINUED U.S. LOAN AID
description: Educators, financial-aid officers and students expressed optimism and relief yesterday following reports that Congress was unlikely to make any cuts in the Government-guaranteed student loan program.

title: New Head at Del Monte Designing Wide Growth
description: The Del Monte Corporation of San Francisco yesterday named Robert A. Fox, executive vice president, as president of the international foods company, effective June 1. He succeeds Warren C. Hageman, 59, who is retiring after 34 years with the company.

title: BANGLADESH GENERAL, CITING 'CORRUPTION' MAY TRY EX-LEADERS
description: The nation's new military ruler announced today that special courts would be set up to punish all guilty of corruption, with the power to impose heavy prison terms or even the death penalty.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Ensearch Corp. said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $100 million in sinking fund debentures due 2007, to be sold through a Goldman, Sachs & Co. group.

title: Bruins 5, Sabres 1
description: BOSTON (AP) - Brad Park led a three-goal first period as the Bruins won their third straight game. Boston also increased its lead over Buffalo to 5 points in the race for second place in the Adams Division.

title: Topics Waste / Chaste; High Anxiety
description: For a remarkable conjunction of the ridiculous and the sublime one need only consider the plight of Columbia's passengers.

title: 2 U.S. Companies Bought by Tilling
description: Thomas Tilling, a London-based holding company with interests in builders' supplies, vehicle retailing, construction materials and equipment, energy and industrial equipment, medical supplies, publishing and textiles said it had acquired two additional American companies for an aggregate price of $50.5 million.

title: OBESITY IN ANIMALS IS LINKED TO VIRUSES AFFECTING BRAINS
description: Scientists have reported evidence suggesting that some obesity in animals may be caused by past viral infections affecting the brain.

title: DIPLOMATS SAY HAVANA WANTS WIDE U.S. TALKS
description: Cuba is ready to discuss all aspects of the situation in the Caribbean basin with the Reagan Administration, diplomatic sources said today, but it will not withdraw support for Salvadoran rebels as a condition for such negotiations.

title: DOW GAINS 4.29
description: The stock market moved slightly higher yesterday in a session marked by gains in special situations and price declines in the airline group.

title: LABOR DEPT. TIGHTENS KEY DATA RELEASE RULES
description: The Labor Department, responding to the possibility that key economic indicators are being leaked before they are announced, said today that release procedures had been tightened.

title: COURT BLOCKS TRADING OF GINNIE MAE OPTIONS
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange suffered a legal blow today in its bid to become the pioneer exchange in the trading of options on debt instruments.

title: Auctions; Declaration for sale.
description: A RARE copy of the Declaration of Independence and the original plan for the Mason-Dixon line will be offered next Thursday at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, in one of three Americana sales scheduled next week in New York.

title: NEGOTIATIONS ON TRANSIT CONTRACT STILL FOCUSING ON SECONDARY ISSUES
description: The contracts covering 35,000 bus and subway workers in New York City expire at midnight next Wednesday, but negotiators say they are still discussing secondary matters and have not yet addressed critical economic issues.

title: OCCIDENTAL OIL GETS CHINA MINE CONTRACT
description: The Government today gave formal permission to the Occidental Petroleum Corporation to study the feasibility of developing what could become the world's largest open-pit coal mine.

title: Tumors Temporarily Shrank In Limited Study of Interferon
description: Half of a small group of people with advanced cancer had modest and temporary shrinkage in tumors when treated with synthetic human interferon, researchers have reported.

title: IN PHILADELPHIA, SCULLERS ARISE BEFORE CROCUSES
description: At the edge of sprawling Fairmount Park, on the shore overlooking the broad, smooth waters of the Schuylkill River, John B. Kelly Sr. sits frozen in midstroke, an oarsman memorialized in bronze, forever contemplating the scene of his triumphs.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A Common Pleas Court jury has awarded $1.75 million in damages to a cancer victim whose mother took the drug DES in 1960.

title: ISRAELI SERGEANT IS KILLED IN GAZA IN GRENADE ATTACK
description: An Israeli Army sergeant was killed and three other soldiers were wounded today when a hand grenade was thrown into their jeep in occupied Gaza. It was the first Israeli death in a week of rioting that has taken the lives of six Palestinian Arabs.

title: JAPAN'S MULTIBILLION OBLIGATION TO THE PENTAGON
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum is Rich in Americana and Tibetan Art
description: HOW do you run a general museum barely 10 miles from the overwhelming competition in Manhattan? You simply rise above it. You buy the best art you can, mount intelligent and attractive shows, and establish special collections not so easily seen at, say, the Metropolitan Museum of Art. That, more or less, is how the relatively small but stimulating Newark Museum has functioned since its founding in 1909, and in the process it has developed a strong identity of its own, becoming not only a Newark cultural treasure, but a national one as well.

title: Republic Steel Expects Big Loss
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, a major integrated steelmaker, told shareholders in proxy materials that it ''will incur a substantial operating loss in the first quarter.''

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt COME DAWN, COME DUSK. Fifty Years a Gamekeeper. By Norman Mursell. 149 pages. Illustrated with Photographs and Drawings by Rodger McPhail. St. Mar- tin's. $14.95.

title: Ex-Busboy Gets 8 Life Terms In Las Vegas Hilton Hotel Fire
description: A former busboy at the Las Vegas Hilton has been sentenced to eight life terms in prison with little likelihood of parole for setting a fire that killed eight persons at the hotel last year.

title: Mrs. Melton Tied at 70
description: Nancy Lopez Melton, the leading money winner on the women's golf tour this year, and Kathy Young, who has yet to post a victory, shot three-under-par 70's today and shared the first-round lead in the $175,000 Kemper Open.

title: At the Movies; The Weavers and how film came to be.
description: DOWN in the bowels of the Plaza Hotel, at Cinema 3, a theater so chic it will sell you Perrier along with your popcorn, something very unchic is going on. It's a movie about survival with honor, if you'll excuse an old-fashioned word.

title: Notes on People; Laurance Rockefeller Leaves Sloan-Kettering Post
description: ''I'm almost 72 and it's high time I started cutting down on my activities and having a little more fun,'' said Laurance S. Rockefeller, and that's why he is stepping down, after 22 years, as chairman of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, and plans to cut down on other activities, too.

title: TV Weekend; WISDOM OF JOHN HUSTON
description: THE ''Creativity With Bill Moyers'' project continues tonight at 9 on WNET-TV with an interview of the film director John Huston. Mr. Moyers ticks off a number of characteristics that might distinguish the creative person: a keen sensitivity to experience, the retention of a capacity for childlike wonder, unconventionality, discontentedness and not always being virtuous. Mr. Huston, he says, embodies nearly all of them.

title: Give Enterprise Zones a Chance
description: The hopes of inner-city neighborhoods, clouded by Federal budget cuts, finally got some sun this week. The Department of Housing and Urban Development approved a grant for the south Bronx. And President Reagan at long last presented his proposal for urban enterprise zones, a plan for using tax incentives for manufacturing to try to revive poor neighborhoods. Although serious questions remain about the proposal, a test of his faith in the idea is overdue.

title: Israeli Soldiers Move Into Sinai Settlement
description: Hundreds of Israeli troops and policemen moved into the Sinai town of Yamit today and took over homes from which soldiers had been ejected Wednesday by irate townspeople. The residents had barricaded the gateways to the town and the troops smashed through them with a bulldozer.

title: Colombia Reports Clash
description: Five leftist guerrillas were killed today in a clash with army troops in northwestern Colombia, a military communique said.

title: P.L.O. CLAIMS ROLE, THEN ISSUES DENIAL
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization today first claimed, then denied, responsibility for a grenade attack that killed an Israeli soldier.

title: Nashua Sets Ricoh Pact
description: The Nashua Corporation said it had reached a new agreement with the Ricoh Company Ltd. of Japan for the continued supply of office copy machines. The new agreement extends through 1990 and replaces one scheduled to expire in 1984.

title: Aleksandr Sidorenko; A Top Soviet Geologist
description: Aleksandr V. Sidorenko, a leading Soviet geologist and science administrator, died Tuesday in a car crash, the Soviet press agency Tass said today. He was 64 years old.

title: MOUNTING LOSS FROM TAX LEASES HINTED
description: Donald T. Regan, the Secretary of the Treasury, indicated tonight that the revenue loss from last year's taxleasing legislation might be running higher than estimated, but he also found that the leasing system was working to the advantage of small companies and ''distressed'' industries.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.

title: WITH CAMPAIGN AT AN END, SALVADOR IS SUDDENLY CALM
description: El Salvador fell into a tranquillity today that it had not seen since the beginning of election campaigning two months ago and one it wasn't fully expected to see at this moment owing to guerrilla pledges to stage pre-election disruptions.

title: A COOPERATIVE VENTURE IN COACHING
description: Kevin Taylor, a 6-foot-7-inch point guard, threw a crisp pass to George Melton, who, in Cheyney State College's basic offense, accepted the ball at the foul line. He made a strong move immediately to face the basket.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; CRUISE LINE GREETS SPRING
description: The gargoyles atop the Chrysler Building were modeled after the radiator cap of a 1929 car; someone else is buried in Grant's tomb (Mrs. Grant); the windowless New York Telephone Company building was designed for protection against nuclear fallout. These are some of the tidbits that commentators will elaborate on today as Circle Line sightseeing boats begin their 38th consecutive season of cruising around Manhattan. The price of the three-hour, 35-mile excursion is $8.50 for adults, $4 for children under 12. Refreshments are available. Boats leave from Pier 83 at the foot of West 42d Street. The schedule starts with daily cruises at 10:30 A.M. and 2:30 P.M., increasing with the season to 12 trips a day. Information: 563-3200.

title: Economic Scene; The Value Of Deficits
description: RAILING against big deficits is currently fashionable, and that is hardly surprising. The gargantuan deficits looming ahead for the 1980's scare liberals and conservatives alike.

title: HOW TO PERPETUATE HIGH INTEREST RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: RAILWAY 'BATTTLE OF GIANTS' SET
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it had approved the merger of the Norfolk & Western Railway and the Southern Railway, setting the stage for what the agency's vice chairman said would be ''a battle of giants.''

title: MAYOR SAYS CITY WILL NOT APPEAL AT-LARGE RULING
description: New York City will not appeal a Federal court ruling that its method of electing two at-large City Council members from each borough is unconstitutional, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Notes on People; Union Seeks Holiday for Elvis Presley's Birthday; Birthday Proposal
description: A couple of years ago, when public-employee unions were holding negotiations with the City of Memphis, the unions requested a paid holiday for the birthday of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Pop Jazz; NICK LOWE BRINGS HIS KIND OF ROCK TO PALLADIUM
description: ''NEW WAVE? Is that a bunch of people in pirate costumes?'' Nick Lowe, who is performing at the Palladium tonight, took time out from a preconcert sound test the other day to ponder the nature of the new rock movement that he has often been credited with inventing. ''I was always involved with musicians who were a bit weird,'' he said. ''But it's funny if people think I'm 'new wave,' whatever that means. I'm not at all.''

title: MATTHAU BACK IN SIMON'S HOLLYWOOD
description: ''I OUGHT TO BE in Pictures,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is Neil Simon's Broadway comedy perfunctorily recycled as a film by Mr. Simon, who wrote his own screenplay; Herbert Ross, who repeats his job as director, and Dinah Manoff, who won a Tony award for her stage performance and plays the role again in the film. The extra-added attractions are Walter Matthau, Ann-Margret and some glimpses of authentic Los Angeles streets, highways, yards and sidewalks.

title: Model-Train Show In Carlstadt, N.J.
description: The 50th Model Railroad Show at the New York Society of Model Engineers' building at 341 Hoboken Road, two blocks west of Route 17, in Carlstadt, N.J., will be open until Sunday at 6 P.M. The show features two minutely detailed fully landscaped train layouts, including circus, passenger, freight and trailer-truck cars; a model marine vessel being loaded; a 1908 trolley line; bridges, tunnels and a baseball stadium with a game in progress.

title: ARTHUR W. BRADLEY
description: Arthur W. Bradley, a Democratic committeeman in Nassau County, L.I., and a corporate and estate lawyer, died Wednesday in South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Baldwin, L.I.

title: REMARKS BY SANDINIST
description: Following are excerpts from remarks to the Security Council by Daniel Ortega Saavedra, leader of the Nicaraguan junta, as translated by the Nicaraguan Mission to the United Nations: The U.S. Government has entered into a period of meetings with representatives of the Mexican Government. After a round of meetings with the Mexican Foreign Minister, Don Jorge Castaneda, Mr. Alexander Haig made public a five-point proposal aimed at initiating conversations with Nicaragua following the elections scheduled for March 28th in El Salvador.

title: Restaurants; Village Italian, lively pub-tavern.
description: JIMMY DURANTE said it best. ''Did you ever have that feeling that you wanted to go, still you have the feeling that you wanted to stay?'' His measured chant came to mind on each of our four visits to the fashionably popular Il Mulino (The Water Mill), a nine-month old Italian restaurant on Third Street in the Village.

title: Funds' Assets Rise Sharply
description: Assets of the nation's 182 money market funds rose by $2.4 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record $192.06 billion, the Investment Company Institute announced yesterday. The funds reporting included three new general purpose funds and a new broker-dealer fund.

title: REUSCHEL PUT ON DISABLED LIST
description: Rick Reuschel, the right-handed pitcher bothered all spring by tendinitis in his right shoulder, was placed on the 21-day disabled list today by the Yankees, who also reassigned Tucker Ashford, a third baseman, and Andy McGaffigan, another right-handed pitcher.

title: Advertising; New Cola Short on Caffeine
description: THE Philip Morris Company, which already supplies the consuming public with tar and nicotine from its many cigarette brands, and alcohol from its Miller beer, will next be coming out on the side of the angels with a practically caffeine-free cola. It is called Like and it is being supplied by the Seven-Up Company, which Philip Morris acquired in 1978.

title: LEWIS URGES M.T.A. TO ASSUME CONTROL OF COMMUTER LINES
description: The Secretary of Transportation, Drew Lewis, said yesterday that he would seek to insure that local mass-transit authorities in the Northeast would get ''adequate funding'' if they took over operation of the Conrail commuter lines.

title: News Analysis
description: As originally conceived by the Reagan Administration, ''enterprise zones'' were to be like frontier towns in run-down urban neighborhoods, where everyone could make a buck without taxes, regulations or other controls.

title: A House in Search of Fraud
description: ''If there is a major fraud for us to focus upon,'' Representative Frederick Richmond said the other day, ''it is the fraud upon the public of repeating untrue stories.'' The Brooklyn Democrat was referring to false tales about fraud in the food stamp program, but his piety brought his own legal troubles to mind.

title: CARNEGIE HALL PLANNING A COMMERCIAL COMPLEX
description: The Carnegie Hall Corporation yesterday invited proposals for a new commercial building that would rise on the parking lot adjacent to Carnegie Hall between West 56th and 57th Streets.

title: THE NEW LOOK IN MUNICIPALS
description: State and local governments, traditionally reliant on long-term bonds to finance long-lived public projects such as sewers and schools, are turning increasingly to new kinds of short-term securities despite the increased financial risks.

title: CAROLINA RENEGES ON DEAL
description: Three black convicts who said they feared for their lives in North Carolina's Central Prison gave up the last of eight hostages today in exchange for transfers to a Federal penitentiary. The state later reneged on the arrangement.

title: COACH SAYS COLLEGES PAY STARS $10,000 A YEAR
description: One of the nation's leading college basketball coaches, Richard (Digger) Phelps of the University of Notre Dame, said today that a number of schools across the country were paying a standard rate of $10,000 a year to outstanding basketball players, in violation of intercollegiate rules.

title: STUDY ON ACID RAIN CITES LAKE CHANGE
description: Acid rain caused by industrial and power plant emissions has seriously altered the chemical balance of thousands of lakes and tributaries in the Northeast, according to a study released today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeronca Inc., Pineville, N.C., has elected to its board Barry J. Shillito, chairman of Teledyne-International.

title: Boeing Officers Took Pay Cuts
description: Lower earnings at the Boeing Company last year also cut into the salaries of its top executive officers, the company disclosed in stockholder proxy material.

title: HOW PETERBOROUGH, N.H., VOTED FOR NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: On a Monday two weeks ago, in a speech in Tennessee, President Reagan denounced a notion that had been spreading through New England and Congress like a vine: that the United States and the Soviet Union should agree to a joint freeze on nuclear arms. But the next night, the residents of this small, cultured, overwhelmingly Republican town came out of their homes in the snowy woods to declare against the President and for the freeze.

title: PIANO RECITAL: BATTERSBY
description: IN a concert, a listener needs to feel that a recitalist is playing a particular piece for a particular musical reason, that he has something to say about it, that he feels it deeply, that he wants to have it heard and shared. However far the achievement may fall short of the ideal, just the sound of a voice speaking with intention is important.

title: Rozelle on Expansion
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League said yesterday that the league is ready to add two teams if a sports bill that would exempt the league from Federal antitrust laws were passed by Congress. ''A lot of cities have talked to us about expansion,'' Rozelle said on the final day of the league's annual meeting in Phoenix, ''and we're ready to expand.

title: N. Dakota Gains Final In Hockey
description: North Dakota dominated Northeastern tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey semifinal game at Providence Civic Center for a 6-2 victory and a spot in Saturday night's championship game. North Dakota will meet the winner of Friday night's semifinal between Wisconsin and New Hampshire.

title: Newspaper Editors' Awards Go to Writers at Four Papers
description: The American Society of Newspaper Editors announced yesterday that staff writers for The Baltimore Sun, The Miami News, Newsday and The Wall Street Journal had won its Distinguished Writing Awards for 1982.

title: Canada's Oil Revenues
description: The Government could lose $22 billion to $30 billion (Canadian) in forecast energy revenues in the next five years because of the current weak market for oil, Informetrica, a forecasting firm, said here today. In its monthly review, the firm said international prices were expected to fall this year from official levels and a decline, in real or possibly nominal terms, could continue in coming years.

title: Paul R. Hessel, a Lawyer, 34, Drowns in a Diving Accident
description: Paul R. Hessel, New York corporate and tax lawyer and founding partner of the law concern of Gelberg & Abrams, drowned in a scuba diving accident off the Caribbean island of St. Vincent last Monday. Mr. Hessel, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 34 years old.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE PLAN STIRRING A DEMOCRATIC DEBATE
description: A Congressional resolution urging the United States and the Soviet Union to negotiate a freeze in their nuclear arsenals has touched off an intense debate among Democrats about the merits and politics of the proposal.

title: HOUSE CHIEFS URGE WHITE HOUSE ROLE IN SETTLING BUDGET
description: Amid mounting frustration in Congress, Democratic and Republican leaders in the House called upon the White House today to join in three-way negotiations to break the budget deadlock.

title: Fiat Chief Hospitalized
description: Giovanni Agnelli, head of the Fiat auto company, collapsed and was rushed to a hospital in this northern Italian city tonight, hospital sources reported. Doctors said the 61-year-old Mr. Agnelli had apparently suffered a heart attack.

title: UPDATING BULLETPROOF CLOTHING
description: It's being called ''protective fashion,'' and its existence, in this day and age, was probably inevitable. Bulletproof designer clothing is here and -who knows? - could score a bull's-eye as a fashion status symbol. For one thing, what other clothing comes with a $500,000 insurance policy in case of injury or death?

title: JARGON OF CORRECTION OFFICERS
description: Following are some examples of the language that correction officers have developed to describe their work:

title: Board Suspends Noguchi
description: Thomas Noguchi, the Los Angeles County Coroner, was suspended today for 30 days by the county Board of Supervisors for failure to make adeaquate answers to charges of absenteeism, poor management and improper remarks about celebrities' deaths.

title: Excerpts from testimony, page A6.
description: The Reagan Administration made clear today that while it was willing to enter into talks with Cuba on issues in the Caribbean basin and Central America, it did not believe such an approach in itself would solve the region's problems.

title: Reagan Conference Unlikely
description: President Reagan will probably not hold a news conference Monday, as he had announced, because it would compete for attention on television with the Academy Awards, the space shuttle landing and the N.C.A.A. basketball championships, Larry Speakes, the President's deputy press secretary, said today. Mr. Speakes said the session would probably be held later in the week.

title: SIMPLICITY STUDIES AUSTRALIAN VENTURE
description: The Simplicity Pattern Company, which has been the target of several takeover offers, announced yesterday that it was considering investing up to $45 million in an Australian venture.

title: BOWYER AND BRUGGEMAN TROUPE OFFERS BALLET FOR THE FUN OF IT
description: Appropriately enough, Bob Bowyer and JoAnn Bruggeman have gone underground. In the basement of the City Center on West 55th Street, on a stage called the Space, the dancers and five cohorts - the American Ballet Comedie - will examine the depths of their art this weekend. They will present some 15 works ranging from ''La Estampa de Feeta,'' which Mr. Bowyer describes as ''every Spanish dance you ever saw,'' to ''Faux Pas de Trois,'' about ''a premier dancer who has been given just too much partnering and lifting to do in a ballet.''

title: 'SAVAGE HUNT OF KING STAKH'
description: AT least the first film in the Embassy 72d Street Cinema's Soviet series, ''Love and Lies,'' was a work of some competence, warmth and charm. ''The Savage Hunt of King Stakh,'' the second installment in the series, has none of these qualities. The story it tells, of 19th-century ghosts and scoundrels in Byelorussia, is potentially of some interest. But the tale is presented in a drab and confusing fashion by film makers with only the faintest command of their craft.

title: Bunker Hill Unit Sale Off
description: The Bunker Hill Company, an ailing mining complex in Kellogg, Idaho, owned by the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, said that a deal to sell a critical part of its lead smelting operation to an unidentified Mexican company had been terminated.

title: Duquesne Makes Pitch
description: Duquesne has offered its basketball coaching job to Gary Williams of American University. Williams's four-year record at American is 72-42. The Duquesne search committee is seeking to replace Mike Rice, who was dismissed. ... Coaches at Idaho's state colleges are normally limited to one-year contracts, but Richard Gibb, president of the University of Idaho, said that Don Monson, the school's basketball coach, could probably have a multiyear contract and a raise.

title: MARX 'MOLE' UNEARTHED
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 26, 1982; International
description: France tightened curbs on the flow of money abroad in a bid to save the plunging franc from its second devaluation since the Socialists took office. The new controls, among other things, halve the time an exporter may hold foreign currency revenues outside France. The plight of the franc is a boon for Americans who want to travel in France or purchase French goods in the U.S. (Page A1.)

title: ART: BARKLEY HENDRICKS, A TALE OF TWO ARTISTS
description: THERE are two artists called Barkley Hendricks and both are visible in the show now at the ACA Galleries, 21 East 67th Street. The first and best known paints full length, realistic portraits, usually of black people. The figures stand against backgrounds that are either empty and white or defined by checkerboards, floral patterns and stretches of metal foil.

title: Capitals 4, Flyers 3
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Bob Gould and Ryan Walter scored goals in 63 seconds in the second period for a 4-1 Washington lead. Lee Norwood put a 45-foot slapshot past Pelle Lindbergh, the Flyer goalie, on a power play at 16:25 of the first period to break a 1-1 tie.

title: JERSEY JUDGE IS CONVICTED OF BRIBERY
description: A Superior Court judge in Camden County was found guilty today of soliciting and accepting bribes in return for giving lenient sentences.

title: Chief at A.B. Dick Quits for New Field
description: When an executive works for almost a quarter-century for three prominent corporations, it is not unusual for him to yearn to operate his own business. And Geoffrey R. Cross acted on such an urge this week, tendering his resignation as president and chief executive officer of the A.B. Dick Company of Chicago, to the parent concern, the General Electric Company of London.

title: PUBLISHING: THE SCRIBNER TRADITION
description: NO publisher has a richer tradition than Charles Scribner's Sons, through whose doors Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Faulkner and Wolfe passed on their visits to Maxwell Perkins, the noted editor, who greeted people at his desk wearing a felt fedora.

title: EX-SENATOR'S STAFF CLOSING OFFICE ON HILL
description: The sign on the door still reads Room 352, Mr. Williams, New Jersey. Inside, the cream walls are bare, broken only by nails where dozens of framed photographs once hung. The Government-issue red leather couch is empty and so are the chairs, once occupied by visitors waiting for an appointment.

title: 2d Autopsy of Student Finds Additional Injuries
description: A second autopsy on the body of Ron Settles, a black football player who died in the Signal Hill jail, has disclosed injuries missed by the Los Angeles County coroner, the county district attorney's office said today.

title: INVESTMENT DIVERSITY IS ASSESSED
description: The world's central banks are increasingly diversifying their currency reserves away from a dependence on the United States dollar and are becoming much more aggressive in investing their capital, sometimes even engaging in ''wild and ill-informed trading,'' according to a study released yesterday.

title: Market Place; Minicomputer Sales Outlook
description: APPLE COMPUTER was regarded as a fad stock by many when the company went public in December 1980, and rightly so. The shares were priced at $22 at a time when earnings were just 24 cents a share. That represented a price/earnings ratio of almost 100 for a three-yearold company whose success seemed anything but assured.

title: TWO BROOKLYN PRIVATE SCHOOLS TO MERGE IN THE FALL
description: The Berkeley Institute, a 97-year-old private school in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, will merge next fall with the Carroll Street School, a 15-year-old elementary school just a few blocks away.

title: LONDON RE-ENTERS MAINSTREAM OF FASHION
description: Mary Quant, who invented the miniskirt 20 years ago, is showing only calf-length skirts for fall and winter. So are the vast majority of other fashion designers here, from Stephen Linard, who is out of design school less than one year, to Jean Muir, considered the dean of British designers.

title: EXCERPTS FROM STATEMENTS ON CUBA AND CARIBBEAN BY ENDERS AND STOESSEL
description: Following are excerpts from statements by Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, before the House Appropriations subcommittee, on Administration policy toward Cuba, and by Walter J. Stoessel, Deputy Secretary of State, before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, on the Administration's Caribbean aid program: Special to the New York Times

title: Saudis Help World Bank
description: Saudi Arabia has agreed to lend the World Bank $800 million in 1982, Mohammed Abal-Khail, Saudi finance minister, said here today.

title: MATCHING WITS ON RIKERS: CORRECTION OFFICERS' EXACTING CRAFT
description: A correction officer must carry himself in a confident manner in order to insure authority over inmates, Jack D'Elia said one day. Officer D'Elia was on patrol in a corridor of the adolescent center on Rikers Island, and although he is a small man, he walked with a rolling kind of chest-out gait, like that of a seaman - almost a strut.

title: IF ISRAEL INVADED LEBANON
description: It is a strange feeling to be the ambassador of a country that, everyone tells you every day, is going to be invaded tomorrow.

title: Raider Jury Is Sworn In
description: A jury of five women and one man was sworn in today to hear the retrial of the Federal antitrust case of the Oakland Raiders and Los Angeles Coliseum against the National Football League.

title: Reagan to Face Britons On Less Hallowed Spot
description: The Government, yielding to pressure from the Labor Party opposition, announced Wednesday that President Reagan's speech during his visit here in June would not, after all, be made be in the historic Westminster Hall. Instead, he will address Members of Parliament in the Royal Gallery, a chamber with fewer historical associations and therefore less prestige.

title: STAGE: 'PAPER ANGELS,' ABOUT WEST COAST'S ELLIS I.
description: TO Chinese immigrants on Angel Island, a California equivalent of Ellis Island, detention is the only reality and ''America is just a far-off place in the mind.'' It might be months, or even years, before they are admitted to the United States - and eventually some would be sent back to China to face poverty. The waiting is filled with anger, ennui and regret.

title: CONCERT: THREE PREMIERES
description: A concert that offers three New York premieres, as the Syracuse Symphony Orchestra's program did last night at Carnegie Hall, sets up certain expectations in the listener's mind. A touch of freshness here and there, perhaps, if not an overflowing of original ideas would not be an unreasonable request. However, what the concert delivered under the baton of its music director, Christopher Keene, was a long - a very long - stroll down memory lane. All three works dealt heavily in reminiscences of musical masterworks.

title: L.I. JEWISH HOSPITAL DISRUPTED BY STRIKE
description: For 16 days, a strike by 41 nurses and 2,200 other employees of the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center has disrupted its three divisions in Nassau County and Queens.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MUSIC: KEISER'S 1717 ST. MARK PASSION
description: REINHARD Keiser is an important if obscure name in the history of opera, from the point of view of the standard repertory operagoer. Keiser (1674-1739) was a key transitional figure in German opera, one of the principal composers of the Hamburg German-Italian Baroque operatic school of the early 18th century, and hence a contemporary of and influence on Handel and Telemann.

title: Notes on People; More of Ford's Papers to Be Available; More Ford Papers
description: Gerald R. Ford announced in Washington that about five million pages of his papers would be available to researchers at the Ford Library in Ann Arbor, Mich., beginning April 5 - less than a year after the library was dedicated.

title: Coast Residents Taking Jobs in Berry Fields
description: A roundup of illegal aliens working as farmhands and high unemployment have resulted in local residents heading for the fields to pick strawberries in this area.

title: LEADERS OF COUNCIL URGE MAYOR TO AMEND BUDGET
description: The City Council leadership called on Mayor Koch yesterday to alter his budget plans so New York City would not lose nearly 1,000 police officers, sanitationmen and fire marshals through gradual attrition in the next 15 months.

title: MANAGUA LEADER AT U.N. IS A MODERATE SANDINIST
description: When Daniel Ortega Saavedra was received by President Carter just months after he helped topple the pro-American Somoza regime in July 1979, Nicaraguans were surprised to see the former guerrilla in the White House - and astonished to see him smiling.

title: Essay; LOOK NORTHWARD, EUROPE
description: In our last installment of ''The Perils of the Pipeline,'' readers were shown how the Russians had been able to induce appeasement-minded Europeans into putting up the money to build a pipeline to the Soviet gas fields, thereby providing Moscow with hard currency to buy Western defense technology while making NATO vulnerable to a gas cutoff by the Kremlin.

title: News Analysis
description: ''So long as we're limited to reports from El Salvador that run no longer than two or three minutes, we'll never convince a jury that we're doing our best,'' CBS's Bill D. Moyers said. ''Nuances get lost, subtleties get squeezed out, and the rich texture of a complicated war is sacrificed.''

title: A MOVE TO REFORM THE CITY'S RENT STABILIZATION LAW
description: Is there sufficient impetus for a significant alteration of the city's controversial rent-stabilization law? Or is such hope a chimera? Can the antagonists - tenant advocates and landlord advocates - compromise enough to support several measures now being considered by the City Council's housing committee? Or is the talk of substantive change destined to be merely a repetition of the dialogue that has been occurring between tenant and owner advocates since the rent stabilization system was created 12 years ago?

title: HARVARD NOTES DROP IN NEW APPLICATIONS FROM POOR FAMILIES
description: Harvard University today reported a sharp decline in the percentage of students from low-income families who apply for admission to the college.

title: SHORT OF CASH, NIGERIA CURBS IMPORTS
description: Nigeria, the largest producer of oil in West Africa, has in effect imposed a temporary ban on imports in a move that reflects a critical shortage of foreign exchange that has been caused by falling oil prices.

title: ART: A GOOD WAY TO LOOK AT FRENCH OLD MASTERS
description: ONE thing that Manhattan badly needs is more first-rate old master paintings on view in the dealers' galleries. In London and Paris it is taken for granted that you can drop by some place before lunch and see old paintings and drawings of high quality. But in New York it's a big production. You have to make an appointment. Unless you can afford to buy, you may feel -whether rightly or not - that the dealer wishes you hadn't come. But the gallery of an old master dealer should be like a library, in that unlimited time and open access are half the fun.

title: Wendy Montgomery Wed In Florida to Dermatologist
description: Wendy Montgomery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Lippman of Philadelphia,. was married in Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday to Dr. David Sibulkin, son of Lillian Blumberg Sibulkin and the late Samuel Sibulkin of New York.

title: French Atomic Test Reported in Pacific
description: France carried out a nuclear explosion in the Pacific last Sunday in preparation for the construction of a neutron weapon, informed sources said today.

title: LOCAL AUTO UNION LEADERS APPROVE G.M. CONTRACT
description: Leaders of union locals voted 299 to 25 today to approve a new contract with the General Motors Corporation that exchanges wage and benefit concessions for some new benefits and increased job security.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MARCH 26, 1982
description: International A willingness to begin talks with Cuba on issues in the Caribbean basin was expressed by the Reagan Administration. However, Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, also told a House hearing that mere talks alone would not suffice to ease tensions. Meanwhile, diplomats confirmed that a special State Department envoy, Gen. Vernon E. Walters, conferred with Fidel Castro for four hours in Havana this month. (Page A1, Column 6.) Cuba is ready to discuss all aspects of the situation in the Caribbean Basin with the Reagan Administration, according to diplomatic sources in Mexico City. But they said Fidel Castro had warned that Havana would not withdraw support for the Salvadoran insurgents as a condition for such negotiations. (A1:5.)

title: Notes on People; Diana Rigg Wed to Scottish Producer
description: At the Municipal Building in lower Manhattan yesterday, the British actress Diana Rigg was married to Archibald Hugh Sterling in a ceremony performed by David N. Dinkins, the City Clerk.

title: Slow Going for Fidrych
description: The comeback of 27-year-old Mark (the Bird) Fidrych as a nonroster player with the Boston Red Sox at their camp in Winterhaven, Fla., has been limited to exercising with hand weights and throwing batting practice to strengthen his arm. Manager Ralph Houk is bringing the right-hander along slowly, saying that the same enthusiasm that made Fidrych so popular when he won 19 games for the Detroit Tigers in 1976 could work against him if he were rushed back into pitching.

title: Lena Horne Still Out
description: Lena Horne, ill with the flu, has missed performances of ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music'' at the Nederlander Theater since Tuesday night. She will be out the rest of this week; her producers hope she will be well enough to return next Tuesday. The singer will have missed six performances in all, the first since she opened in the show last May.

title: For Westway, Yet Again
description: It seems inconceivable, after 10 years, that there can be new arguments for or against Westway, the subsurface highway along lower Manhattan. But the imminence of final clearance and the prospect of a new governor and perhaps mayor have rekindled the hopes of the project's opponents. While a Federal judge considers the last legal complaint - that Army engineers arbitrarily approved dredging and filling permits - they argue that time has vindicated the opposition. They are misguided.

title: Soviet Condemns Plans To Deploy Missiles
description: The Soviet Union today denounced the decision by the United States and its European allies on Wednesday to continue plans for deploying 572 Pershing 2 and cruise nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: Flak Jackets Stolen From Bronx Armory
description: Sixty Army flak jackets, which can serve as bulletproof vests, have been stolen from a National Guard armory in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: Joan Sutton Married to Oscar S. Straus
description: Joan Treble Sutton of Toronto, a columnist for The Toronto Sun, was married in New York yesterday to Oscar S. Straus of New York, a former career Foreign Service officer. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El.

title: Discount Irons Help Allin
description: What Brian (Buddy) Allin did today was blasphemy to the club professionals who sell their merchandise at list price. Allin, a touring pro golfer, walked into a discount golf shop this morning and bought a set of new irons at the ''sticker price'' of $422. Then he used them in shooting a seven-under-par 64 in the first round of the Heritage Classic.

title: Hawaii Districting Plan Voided by Federal Panel
description: A three-member Federal court panel today struck down Hawaii's reapportionment plan as unconstitutional and ordered a special master to supervise a new voting map for the state.

title: SPRING ON THE STEPS
description: When the weather permits, the steps of the Capitol form one of the major public meeting places of the capital. There, on a given spring morning, you may find a high school band playing its heart out, cheerleaders cheering, a religious zealot passing out pamphlets or a protest rally displaying petitions about to be unloaded on Congress.

title: WARNING IS ISSUED ON DRAFT SIGNUP
description: Thomas K. Turnage, the director of the Selective Service System, said today that more than 500,000 young men still had not registered for a possible military draft, and he warned that the Government would follow through on plans to prosecute some of them.

title: 'Fantasy Island' Exit
description: John Johnson, waived by the Seattle SuperSonics earlier in the week, says that he is looking to a future in the business world ''now that I have to get off Fantasy Island.'' Johnson, a 34-year-old forward, began his 12-season pro career as the top draft choice of the Cleveland Cavaliers in 1970, after he had attended Northwest Community College in Powell, Wyo., and the University of Iowa.

title: CHASING THE MYTH OF SOVIET NUCLEAR SUPERIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; WASTE CHASTE; Relativism
description: After a Cole Porter musical, ''Nymph Errant,'' was produced in London in 1933, many of its songs crossed the Atlantic, bringing a wel-come breath of elegance, wit and risque charm to ultrasophisticated prep school seniors who could afford the records. But the show itself never played in America until the Equity Library Theater mounted a production two weeks ago in its wholly inelegant theater at West 103d Street.

title: Borg Beat Gerulaitis
description: Taking another step in his comeback after a four-month layoff, Bjorn Borg of Sweden beat Vitas Gerulaitis, 7-6, 6-1, in an exhibition match tonight.

title: Greene Wants to Go
description: Ken Greene, a safety for the St. Louis Cardinals, made his reputation in football at Washington State University, and now he would like to be traded to a West Coast team. ''I've put in four years there,'' Greene, who is 25 years old, said of his days in St. Louis, ''and I think it's time to get back to where I'm more comfortable.''

title: VIRGIN ISLANDS' TROUBLES
description: It is well and good for President Reagan to offer economic assistance to the Caribbean countries, but it would be a mistake if the Administration and Congress continue to slight the serious problems of the United States Virgin Islands.

title: THE GRAPES OF CIVILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: WEINBERGER ASKS JAPANESE TO REARM
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, urged the Japanese today to acquire sufficient military power to defend their nation ''within this decade.''

title: Sony in French Deal
description: The Sony Corporation said today that it would invest 141 million francs, or about $23 million, to build a video cassette production facility near Dax in southwestern France. It said the factory, which would be its second in France, would start operating in the summer of 1983 and should produce around 10 million video cassettes in the first year and 15 million in subsequent years.

title: ART: NEO-EXPRESSIONISM OF GEORG BASELITZ
description: THE recent resurgence of figurative Expressionism in painting has clearly upset a lot of people in the art world. It has also clearly delighted a lot of people, but that, curiously enough, is one of the reasons the others are upset. The speed with which this Neo-Expressionist movement has been accepted is taken to be a mark against it. Some of those who are most disturbed, though by no means all of them, tend to be the same people who are upset by the parallel resurgence of Realism. They cannot quite forgive this reversion, as they see it, to representation in contemporary art. They act as if painting has somehow let them down.

title: NICARAGUAN URGES U.S. TO NEGOTIATE
description: Nicaragua proposed ''direct and frank'' talks with the United States today to end the crisis in Central America.

title: News's Unions Report Meeting With Owners
description: Representatives of the labor unions at The Daily News said they met for three hours yesterday with the officers of the Tribune Company, the owner of the paper, and were convinced that the company ''is doing all in its power to find a responsible buyer committed to the continuation'' of the paper.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have tried to talk with Cuba in the past and it would be wrong to rule out trying again.

title: Home Resales Rose by 2.2% In February
description: Resales of existing houses rose by 2.2 percent in February, according to figures released today by the National Association of Realtors.

title: 3 BRITISH SOLDIERS SLAIN IN BELFAST
description: Three British soldiers were killed this morning in an Irish Republican Army ambush on a crowded street in Belfast. Two civilians were also shot, but not seriously wounded, in the attack.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: YOU could tell right away that it was not your ordinary little c ocktail party: the limousines were double-parked on Fifth Avenue, a nd they stretched around the corner to 62d Street. Yes, the movers a nd shakers were out in force Wednesday night, and the occasion was H appy Rockefeller's gala in honor of Henry and Nancy Kissinger.

title: Irene Epple Wins World Cup Giant Slalom Title
description: Maria Epple of West Germany won the last giant slalom of the World Cup season today but was second to Irene Epple, her sister, in the event's final standing.

title: DEVELOPED XR-1 COPTER
description: Haviland Hull Platt, an engineer and inventor who worked in the early development of the helicopter, died yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Goodyear Layoffs
description: Almost half of the employees at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plant here will be temporarily laid off next month because of sagging sales and growing inventories, a company spokesman said. As many as 720 employees from several divisions at the plant will be furloughed at varying intervals between April 1 and April 16, said the spokesman, Ray Cunningham. There are 1,500 people employed by the company at the Topeka plant, but 354 of them have been laid off indefinitely since January.

title: MISSES NAVRATILOVA AND HANIKA ADVANCE
description: Two weeks ago, Wendy Turnbull gave Martina Navratilova her most difficult match of the year before losing in three long sets. Last night, Miss Navratilova needed only 44 minutes to reach the semifinals of the Avon tennis championships with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Miss Turnbull at Madison Square Garden.

title: Islanders Defeat Canadiens by 3-1
description: For the Islanders, tonight's game against the Montreal Canadiens was a test to see how they would react against a well disciplined team.

title: Spanish Women Cleared In Abortion Cases
description: A court today acquitted 10 women charged with having undergone illegal abortions in a test case for Spain's anti-abortion law, a remnant of the Franco era. All of the women came from working-class Bilbao families.

title: L.I.Thrift Unit Merger Delay
description: Under pressure from local Congressmen, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday gave Suffolk County's largest savings and loan association one week to work out a merger with another Long Island institution to avoid an arranged merger with a Rochester savings and loan.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Mortified and Chagrined'

title: CABARET: SYLVIA SYMS SINGS
description: SYLVIA SYMS has been singing and observing and learning since she was a teen-ager on 52d Street 40 years ago. She has known and been close to innumerable influential performers from Billie Holiday to Frank Sinatra and she has had both the need and the desire to acquire more than casual understanding of the songs she sings.

title: G.M. JOINS VENTURE TO PRODUCE ROBOTS
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would enter the robot business through a joint venture with Fujitsu Fanuc Ltd., a Japanese manufacturer of machine tool controls and robots.

title: PARIS PUTS NEW CONTROLS ON FRANC IN AN EFFORT TO AVERT DEVALUATION
description: France tightened controls on the flow of money abroad today in a bid to save the plunging franc from its second devaluation since the Socialist-led Government took office nine months ago.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest Rates Climb Slightly

title: ASTRONAUTS USE 'ARM' OF SHUTTLE IN WAVING TEST
description: With the Columbia's robot arm outstretched, waving a scientific instrument to one side and the other, the space shuttle astronauts today cruised through their fourth day in orbit and their first without new mechanical trouble.

title: Topics; WASTE CHASTE; Panda Privacy
description: Hsing-Hsing, the National Zoo's male panda and up till now an indifferent lover, showed a certain enthusiasm for Ling-Ling, the female, last week. As usual, however, Ling-Ling had a headache.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Browing-Ferris Industries said it would not pursue its attempts to acquire SCA Services Inc. because of the continuing opposition of SCA directors. Earlier this month, Browning-Ferris proposed to acquire SCA through an exchange of stock.

title: JUDGE DENIES ABSCAM PLEAS FOR NEW TRIALS OVER PERJURY
description: A Federal judge yesterday affirmed the bribery convictions of former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey and former Representative Michael J. Myers of Pennsylvania. Both had contended that a key undercover man in the Abscam investigation had perjured himself.

title: DOW TO SELL OIL ASSETS
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its United States oil and gas properties to the Apache Corporation and the Apache Petroleum Company of Minneapolis for about $400 million in cash and securities.

title: GUATEMALAN VOTE IS ANNULLED
description: Guatemala's new military rulers announced today that they had annulled the results of the March 7 elections, which they had denounced as fraudulent. But they said nothing about plans for new elections.

title: WHEN HUMAN RIGHTS TAKE A BACK SEAT
description: To the Editor:

title: N.I.T.  PREVIOUS WINNERS
description: 1938Temple 1939Long Island U. 1940Colorado 1941Long Island U. 1942West Virginia 1943St.

title: NEW YORK'S SAVOYARDS ARE A THRIVING BREED
description: BRITAIN'S D'Oyly Carte Opera Company may have lapsed into suspended animation, but Gilbert and Sullivan in New York appears to be thriving.

title: Gretzky Passes 200 Points
description: Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers scored two goals 27 seconds apart and assisted on goals by Pat Hughes and Dave Semenko tonight to become the first player in the National Hockey League to surpass 200 points in a season. Gretzky has 90 goals and 113 assists for 203 points.

title: Oneita-Nexus Tie
description: Oneita Knitting Mills and Nexus Industries said that they had agreed in principle with the principal shareholders of Nexus for Oneita to acquire about 1 million shares, or 49 percent, of the total outstanding common shares of Nexus in a transaction valued at approximately $29.2 million. Upon consummation of the purchases, Oneita intends to propose a merger or other combination with Nexus, a clothing manufacturer, on terms and conditions to be determined, the companies added.

title: Campbell to Buy Mrs. Paul's Units
description: The Campbell Soup Company said it had agreed to buy certain frozen food business assets of Mrs. Paul's Kitchens Inc. for an undisclosed price. Mrs. Paul's, which had sales of about $124 million last year, markets more than 65 frozen prepared food products.

title: PULEO PLEASES METS, BUT SWAN IS MAULED
description: With Lee Mazzilli and Dave Kingman hitting home runs, the Mets beat the Pittsburgh Pirates today, 7-1, and continued a revival that has produced 26 hits and 16 runs in two games.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS CURB ON A.T.&T.
description: With unexpected speed, a House telecommunications subcommittee unanimously approved today a bill that would place major restrictions on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company as it sheds its 22 local operating companies and moves into unregulated businesses.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Saturday about redress for people who believe that they have been victimized by dishonest lawyers incorrectly iden- tified the courts that have jurisdiction over malpratice suits. Such claims can be heard in any courts that nor- mally hear negligence cases, includ- ing the civil part of State Supreme Court or Federal Court.

title: DEMOTED LEADER IN SPACE EXPLORATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Batten, Barton Adds Spearmint
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn's Chicago office has added Wrigley Spearmint to the other brands of chewing gum it advertises for the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company.

title: Linking Dow Average To Value Line Futures
description: The new stock-index futures based on the Value Line average followed the overall price trend in the stock market yesterday by advancing 60 to 65 points, or $300 to $325 on a contract, with the active near-June delivery closing at 124.65, for a gain of 60 points on the day.

title: TOP DEMOCRAT KEEPS THE PEACE WITHOUT PIZAZZ
description: Democratic National Chairmen of earlier days like Jim Farley, Larry O'Brien and Bob Strauss were given to big cigars and often outrageous stories about the political battles and backroom deals of their political youth.

title: FIGHT OVER TOP LE MONDE POST SEEMS ENDED
description: After two years of a sputtering and at times raging internal conflict, Le Monde, France's leading newspaper, has found a compromise choice as its new editor in chief.

title: April in Portugal is Waiting Just Across the Hudson
description: THE Portuguese, intrepid seafarers who build a globe-girdling empire, dropped anchor in Newark more than 50 years ago and on this episode in their odyssey hangs a sparkling weekend for all the rest of us.

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRAT WINS A BY-ELECTION IN GLASGOW
description: Roy Jenkins, the 61-year-old former president of the Common Market, won a seat in Parliament this morning.

title: Barrett Sets Mark In N.C.A.A. Meet
description: Bill Barrett of U.C.L.A. broke his American record in the 200-yard individual medley, and Texas won its third consecutive medley-relay crown today and held the lead after the first day of the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships.

title: McDermott Pact
description: McDermott Inc., the New Orleans-based offshore oil and gas construction concern, said it had received a $150 million contract from the Statpipe Group, a consortium associated with Statoil, the Norwegian state oil company, to build part of a natural gas pipeline off western Norway. It said it expected to complete the work in 1984. The terms call for McDermott to lay about 310 miles of a 530-mile pipeline that will carry gas to Western Europe.

title: Dataquest's President Sees 'Paradoxical' Role
description: David G. Jorgensen, the 43-year-old executive vice president of Dataquest, Inc., a subsidiary of the A.C. Nielsen Company, yesterday was appointed president of Dataquest, the leading analytical concern providing market data for both the high-technology and industrial equipment fields.

title: A LEAK AT INDIAN POINT 3 VENTS RADIOACTIVE GASES
description: A small amount of radioactivity was released into the atmosphere at the Indian Point 3 nuclear plant late Wednesday night as a result of a leak in a steam generator, plant officials said today.

title: 2 ADMIT FIRING AT HOME OF SOVIET ENVOY ON L.I.
description: Two Long Island teen-agers pleaded guilty today in Nassau County District Court to firing 12 bullets last November into the Glen Cove mansion where Oleg A. Troyanovsky, the Soviet delegate to the United Natiions, lives.

title: A VENTRILOQUIST OF THE POST-CHARLIE MCCARTHY ERA
description: year-old ventriloquist with a bushy mustache and an air of patient amusement, arrived in New York last October with a 10-year plan that was running out of time.

title: REAGAN GIVES ITALIAN A STRONG WELCOME
description: In ceremonies filled with expressions of American friendship, tribute and gratitude, President Reagan welcomed President Sandro Pertini of Italy to the White House today.

title: Bridge: A Team Without a Leader Joins Vanderbilt Semifinals
description: A headless giant and a Cinderella team were among those competing in the semifinals of the Vanderbilt Knockout at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here this afternoon.

title: OVERSEER OF U.S. LATIN POLICY
description: Thomas O. Enders, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, is praised these days by some liberals and conservatives on Capitol Hill who only a few months ago viewed him as ideologically suspect.

title: News Analysis
description: Almost every party to the troubles in Central America is now saying that it is prepared to negotiate with its adversaries. But according to accounts by Administration officials and Latin American diplomats, there is far less going on than meets the eye, at least for the moment.

title: The U.N. Today; March 26, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: OTHER POSSIBLE BUDGETS
description: In the weeks since his fiscal 1983 budget was released, President Reagan has been more interested in political talk than economic progress. On Wednesday, the White House hinted that it may be willing to talk sensible economics. It would be a welcome change. Presidential anecdotes about ''sob sisters,'' ''parade walkers,'' and ''stray dogs'' have done nothing to correct high interest rates and burgeoning Federal budget deficits.

title: CECIL E. LOOMIS
description: Cecil E. Loomis, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Columbia Gas System, died Wednesday in Sarasota, Fla., after a brief illness.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The best receptionist's job in New York City may belong to Millie Ferrer, who greets much of the immediate world from behind a great black marble slab of a desk, as long as a city bus, at the entrance to the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

title: Briefing
description: When the Sap Is Rising

title: Around the World; Warsaw Court to Hear Cases Against Officials
description: Parliament, meeting in its third session since martial law was imposed, set up a court today to try past and present officials for ruining the economy.

title: Killer-Informer Given Five Years' Probation
description: Charles H. Allen, an informer on organized crime for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a confessed killer, arsonist and drug dealer, was sentenced Thursday to five years' probation for racketeering and conspiracy.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 51. 1. Colleen Dewhurst is pictured as she appeared along with many other Broadway luminaries in a real-life drama that closed after a brief, unsuccessful run. Explain.

title: DEMOCRATS ALTER DELEGATE RULES, GIVING TOP OFFICIALS MORE POWER
description: Turning away from its grass-roots emphasis of the 1970's, the Democratic National Committee voted today to put potentially decisive power to nominate its next Presidential candidate back in the hands of officeholders and party officials.

title: FLIGHT CONTINUES DESPITE FAILURES OF SHUTTLE RADIO
description: Three of the space shuttle Columbia's communications links to earth failed in the night, but the project's officials said today that backup systems were sufficient for the astronauts to continue the mission to its scheduled conclusion Monday.

title: MEXICANS WIN TOURNEY
description: Armando Manzo scored on an assist from Antonio Luna in the 79th minute to give Club America of Mexico a 2-1 victory over Comunicaciones of Guatemala in the championship game of the Coca-Cola Los Angeles Soccer Classic Thursday night. In the consolation match of the four-team tournament, the Cosmos defeated the Honduran National Team, 3-1. Julio Cesar Romero had a goal and an assist for the Cosmos, whose other goals were scored by Giorgio Chinaglia and Johan Neeskens.

title: POP: BRITISH-AMERICAN DUO
description: In one of the year's most impressive pop album debuts, the British-American duo Eye to Eye, backed by top-flight studio musicians, has blended the pointillistic pop-jazz style of Steely Dan with the sophisticated pop-funk of Chic into a high gloss sound of immaculate polish. But until the duo, consisting of the singersongwriter Deborah Berg and the keyboardist Julian Marshall, appeared at the Bottom Line on Thursday, with five other musicians, it was difficult to imagine that anyone could recapture the intricate syncopation and moody inflections of the album in a concert setting.

title: Lewis M. Hull, 84, Developer Of Aircraft Radio Equipment
description: Lewis M. Hull, a founder of Radio Frequency Laboratories in Boonton Township, N. J., and retired chairman of the former Aircraft Radio Corporation, died Wednesday at Riverside Hospital in Boonton Township. He was 84 years old and had lived in the township since 1937.

title: Around the Nation; Michigan Court Holds Election Districts Invalid
description: The Michigan Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional Michigan's 18-year-old system for redrawing legislative districts.

title: Spanish Phone Director Shot
description: The director of the telephone company in this Basque town was shot dead by two gunmen today, 17 months after his predecessor was assassinated by separatist guerrillas. The police said Enrique Cuesta Jimenez, 54 years old, was shot as he walked home from his office. Mr. Cuesta's predecessor was killed in 1980 by separatist rebels who charged that his company was involved in telephone tapping.

title: HOUSTON'S OFFENSE IS IN GOOD HANDS
description: Long before he became the point guard for the University of Houston, Lynden Rose witnessed a trespassing incident near his home in Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: Your Money; U.S. as Insurer Of Last Resort
description: THAT feeling of violation when you come home to a ransacked house or apartment is bad enough. The disaster is complete when there is no insurance on the stolen goods.

title: ENERGY GROWTH AND EGOS ARE BEHIND THE BOOM IN WESTERN ART
description: Like cowboy boots, Indian jewelry and this spring's new fashion line of prairie skirts, Western-theme art has become an increasingly popular and lucrative business in this country.

title: U.S. AIDE TO STRESS JAPAN ARMS OUTLAYS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger plans to urge Japan Saturday to double military spending and contribute more to the support of United States forces stationed here, according to officials traveling with him.

title: A 'JOKE' ABOUT ILLEGAL ALIENS STIRS CRITICS OF PRESCOTT BUSH
description: A comment on illegal aliens by Prescott Bush Jr., a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senate, has created a bit of a stir.

title: U.S. Officially Joins Sinai Observer Force
description: The United States joined the 11-nation Sinai peacekeeping force today at a signing ceremony that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said symbolized a determination ''to carry peace forward'' in the Middle East.

title: CHINA REPORTED UNYIELDING ON TAIWAN ARMS ISSUE
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's leader, told a prominent American businessman today that there was no room for compromise with the United States on the issue of American arms sales to Taiwan.

title: Celtics 125, Pistons 104
description: BOSTON (AP) - The Celtics achieved a club-record 18th straight victory as Kevin McHale scored 21 points. Boston set the mark of 17 consecutive victories in 1959-60 season.

title: Spurs 110, Lakers 105
description: SAN ANTONIO (UPI) - Mike Mitchell scored 41 points on 15-for-19 shooting and pulled down 12 rebounds to lead the Spurs.

title: Holbrook of Furman Quits Coaching Post
description: Eddie Holbrook, head basketball coach at Furman University the last four seasons, has resigned effective May 31.

title: CONNECTICUT EXPERTS SAY STATE'S AIR IS AMONG UNHEALTHIEST IN THE NATION
description: Connecticut has some of the unhealthiest air in the United States, and its air quality will get even worse if Congress approves the changes to the Clean Air Act favored by the Reagan Administration, according to numerous expert witnesses at a Congressional hearing here today.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY UNIT HAS PRODUCT TO SELL
description: Judy Boshart, the Collagen Corporation's vice president for marketing, recently ran into a glass washer from the company's laboratory when she wandered into the kitchenette for coffee. The glass washer asked for the latest quote on the company's stock.

title: News of the Theater; '7 Brides' Extends Tour
description: ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,'' which had been scheduled to reach Broadway this season, has extended its tour until late June.

title: Home Box Office Seeks To Block Hagler Fight
description: Home Box Office Inc., the cable television network, has filed suit in an effort to block the Marvin Hagler-Thomas Hearns middleweight title bout scheduled for May 24.

title: News Analysis
description: The occupied West Bank, torn by Palestinian rioting and Israeli gunfire, has now become a stage on which Israel is acting out its attitudes about its Arab neighbors.

title: Nelson, for Now, Is 4th Starter
description: Less than a month ago, Gene Nelson was battling for the fifth spot in the Yankee pitching rotation and wondering if he would start the season in New York, in another major league city, or back in Columbus, Ohio, where he pitched the second half of last season for the Class AAA team.

title: News of the Theater; 'Medea' to the Cort
description: ''Medea'' will open at the Cort Theater the first week of May.

title: U.N. Plans Parley on Elderly
description: Representatives of 34 nations will meet here next week to prepare for a United Nations conference on the problems of the elderly, the United Nations Information Services said today.

title: LONDON SEES 'FESTIVAL OF INDIA' ART
description: The ''Festival of India,'' a six-month celebration of Indian culture and art, began here this week with the opening of the most comprehensive collection of Indian painting and sculpture ever assembled anywhere.

title: L.I. Lutheran Ousts Tolentine at Buzzer
