description: Who owns New York? That was the question to be decided this weekend by the Super 16 schoolboy state basketball championship tournament, which opened today with semifinal class victories by McBurney of Manhattan, Long Island Lutheran, and New York Mills.

title: WAYWARD-CHILD CASES NEED THE FAMILY COURT
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Rechargeable Batteries For Electric Cars
description: A basic patent received this week by University Patents Inc., Norwalk, Conn., is regarded as promising novel, lightweight, rechargeable plastic batteries.

title: N. Dakota, Wisconsin in Hockey Final
description: Two teams from the Western Collegiate Hockey Association, the smallest league in the country, will play for the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship Saturday night at Providence Civic Center.

title: Fiat Raising Prices 3.5%
description: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian auto maker, announced today that it would raise prices of its automobiles by an average of 3.5 percent on April 2.

title: A Reagan Plan for the Unemployable
description: While still a candidate, Ronald Reagan campaigned vigorously against CETA, the Federal job-creation and training program for the unemployed. He called it a prime example of a ''do-good'' project that wasted money on the wrong people. The criticism was only partly warranted, but President Reagan persists in that view. So now he wants to try helping the hard-core unemployed in his own way. His approach is flawed and woefully underfunded, but it is not without promise.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEMOCRATIC COMMISSION'S REPORT ON NEW CONVENTION RULES
description: Following are excerpts from the report of the Commission on Presidential Nominations, headed by Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina, that was adopted today by the Democratic National Committee:

title: GOOD GRIEF!  ANOTHER ANTI BANDWAGON?
description: ''W hat are you freaks gonna do when the war's over - huh?'' There we are, 1968, leafleting downtown in the middle of winter (if it's the East Coast), in a windstorm (if it's Chicago), or in a chilly drizzle (if it happens to be the Pacific Northwest). We're cold, we're wet, and we wish we were home. Yet some creep is sure to drive past, splash us with his tires, and yell: ''If it weren't for the war, you rat finks would be out of business!''

title: MUSIC: THE KUIJKEN DUO
description: The Kuijken Duo, consisting of Wieland Kuijken, gambist, and Robert Kohnen, harpsichordist, offered music by Bach, Couperin, Louis Marchand and Marin Marais at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last Saturday evening.

title: Legislators Move to Repeal Their New Income Tax Break
description: Several lawmakers have begun a move to repeal a special deduction that will save a typical member of Congress about $7,500 a year in Federal income taxes.

title: Fluorocarbons Found Still Increasing in Air
description: Although the United States, Canada and some Scandinavian countries have banned routine use of fluorocarbons as spray can propellants to avoid depletion of the stratosphere's protective ozone, those substances are continuing to accumulate in the air, according to the scientist who warned of the depletion danger eight years ago.

title: Budget Office Economist Sees Weaker Recovery
description: Lawrence A. Kudlow, the top economist in the Office of Management and Budget, said today that the economic recovery in the second half of the year is not going to be as strong as the Administration has predicted.

title: MUSTO GUILTY WITH 7 OTHERS OF RACKETEERING CONSPIRACY
description: State Senator William V. Musto and seven co-defendants were found guilty tonight in Federal District Court of a racketeering conspiracy involving the extortion of $572,000 from a Hudson County construction company.

title: News Analysis
description: With election campaigns for Governor and Senator already under way, the New York State Republican Party is in such disarray that Republican leaders say privately that the party's chances of victory in November are in jeopardy.

title: Bridge: Former Mayor of Scarsdale Is Cast in a Cinderella Role
description: A bridge fairy tale, with Luella Slaner of Scarsdale, N.Y., in the role of Cinderella, reached its climax in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here last night. She and her teammates scored yet another upset victory against a favored squad and reached the final. This qualifies them for the team trials that will determine the 1983 North American world championship team.

title: THE VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: Congress is currently considering the critical question of whether to extend the Voting Rights Act of 1965. That act must be extended. And it should be extended in its tried-and-true form - neither contracted nor expanded to meet unsubstantiated contentions. That simple and straightforward position - to extend the act as is - is President Reagan's position.

title: Mets Defeat Braves and Torre
description: Joe Torre had his first encounter with the Mets tonight since they dismissed him as their manager, and neither side wasted much emotion on the reunion.

title: Rutgers and Texas In A.I.A.W. Final
description: Jennie Hall scored a career-high 24 points tonight and helped a patient Rutgers team to defeat Villanova, 83-75, and advance to the finals Sunday of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women's national basketball championship.

title: Poles' Interest Reported Paid
description: The Dresdner Bank of West Germany, the international agent for Poland's Western creditor banks, said today that Poland seemed to have met today's deadline for repaying interest owed private banks for 1981. Payment would enable the Poles to sign an agreement to reschedule $2.4 billion in principal that the Poles failed to pay last year.

title: Wheelabrator-Frye
description: Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. said its Kellogg Overseas Corporation unit had won a $350 million contract for a fertilizer complex in Indonesia.

title: A FAST BY 53 BLACKS CATCHES CAPE TOWN OFF GUARD
description: Demonstrations outside South Africa's white Parliament are strictly forbidden, but for 17 days now 53 homeless blacks have been engaged in a protest no more than a stone's throw away and the authorities have seemed uncharacteristically hesitant about how to respond.

title: FAILURE JEOPARDIZED SHUTTLE'S VOICE COMMUNICATIONS
description: While the malfunction in the space shuttle's S-band frequency radios did not leave the craft without any radio communication, it threatened the Columbia's ability to convey information on its location and presented the threat of impairing voice communication with the ground.

title: EL SALVADOR'S ELECTION: ISSUES AND CONSEQUENCES
description: National elections are being held here on Sunday that are drawing attention far beyond the borders of this tiny Central American nation. They are being conducted despite threats of violent disruption and charges that they cannot really reflect the sentiments of the Salvadoran people.

title: U.S. JAPAN TRADE SHOWDOWN
description: Less than two months after Japan took what was billed as ''bold'' action to open its markets to greater foreign competition, Washington is moving into a new phase of confrontation with Tokyo over trade policy.

title: THE DANCE: CUNNINGHAM'S 'DUETS' FOR 6 COUPLES
description: Merce Cunningham demonstrated that two can be very pleasant company when the Merce Cunningham Dance Company presented the season's first performance of ''Duets'' Tuesday night at the City Center. A set of charming dances for six couples, ''Duets'' was performed with all the vivacity it deserved.

title: Gulf Canada Sale
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. said that a subsidiary had reached agreement to sell a 49 percent interest in its Port Moody, British Columbia, refinery to Petro-Canada Ltd. for $95 million (Canadian). Gulf said the refinery processes 37,000 barrels a day. The company said that Petro-Canada would purchase its share of the working inventory and would share all operating costs while Gulf-Canada would continue to operate the facility.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about the Newark Museum gave an in- correct price for a painting by John Singleton Copley purchased in 1948. It was $15,000.

title: A DAILY REGIMEN FOR PETE ROSE
description: CLEARWATER, Fla. PETE ROSE was asked if Mike Schmidt, his Phillies' teammate and winner of the National League's Most Valuable Player award for the last two seasons, was the best player in baseball. ''He's the best one under 40,'' said Rose.

title: U.S. SETS BIG BANK MERGER
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced late yesterday that the failing New York Bank for Savings would be merged into the Buffalo Savings Bank at an estimated cost to the agency of $452 million.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MARCH 27, 1982
description: International A meeting ''at a high political level'' will be held next month between the United States and Nicaragua, Mexico's delegate announced to the United Nations Security Council. United States sources would not confirm the announcement by Porfirio Munoz Ledo, nor would Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate, However, the Foreign Minister of Nicaragua, Miguel d'Escoto, said that the Mexican account matched his understanding. (Page 1, Columns 2-4.) A compromise with the U.S. was impossible on the issue of the American arms sales to Taiwan, Deng Xiaoping, China's leader, told an American businessman, Armand Hammer, at a meeting at the Great Hall of the People in Peking. A Chinese magazine this week quoted Mr. Deng as saying that Peking was ''well prepared'' to downgrade diplomatic relations with Washington if it had to. (8:3-6.)

title: Around the World; 250,000 Italian Workers Protest Wage Levels
description: About 250,000 metalworkers demonstrated today for higher wages and job security.

title: GROUND BROKEN IN CAPITAL FOR MEMORIAL ON VIETNAM
description: A group of 125 Vietnam veterans, some of them weeping, turned a shovelful of earth each today to start construction of a black granite memorial to honor those who died in the divisive war.

title: White House Is Silent On Mock Nuclear War
description: The Reagan Administration remained silent today about whether the White House was involved in a mock nuclear crisis earlier this month.

title: ATHLETES' HANDICAP IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Remember the Gas Lines
description: The White House gave an impressive show of muscle when it stopped the Senate from overriding President Reagan's veto of the emergency oil allocation bill. But that does not resolve the issue of how to ration oil in a crisis. It would serve Congress and the President - not to mention the public - to move now toward a compromise of competing concerns.

title: BONN COUNCIL PLANNING TO BLOCK TAX INCREASE
description: West Germany's upper house of Parliament added to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's problems today when it said it would block a tax increase intended to finance a package of employment stimulants.

title: NO ACCELERANTS FOUND IN TESTS AT STOUFFER INN
description: The head of Westchester County's crime laboratory testified today in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial that tests had failed to identify any accelerants in the hotel carpet where the fatal blaze is believed to have originated.

title: SALVADORAN IN PURSUIT OF A FAIR VOTE
description: For just over a year, Dr. Jorge Bustamante has served in a post offering long hours, hard work, no pay and frequent death threats in pursuit of a goal elusive in El

title: RANGERS DEFEAT SABRES BY 8-5
description: A four-goal burst in the final period highlighted a comeback effort by the New York Rangers tonight as they defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 8-5.

title: Books of the Times
description: AS I WALKED DOWN NEW GRUB STREET. By Walter Allen. 277 pages. The University of Chicago Press. $15.

title: LEGISLATURE'S LEADERS AGREE TO HALT WESTWAY FINANCING
description: Legislative leaders agreed today to block construction of the Westway project until the Federal Government agrees in advance to pay its share of the cost even if the highway is never completed.

title: Going Out Guide
description: TOUCH OF SPRING

title: Senate's 7-Year Plan
description: With its 200th birthday just seven years away, it seemed time that someone start planning a bicentennial celebration for the United States Senate.

title: Satcom Lottery Set
description: A lottery to allocate seven costly pieces of transmission equipment on RCA's newly orbiting Satcom 4 communications satellite will be held Monday afternoon in Princeton, N.J., RCA announced yesterday.

title: News of the Theater; 'Horne' Closing June 30
description: Lena Horne, who this week missed her first performances in ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music'' because of influenza, will close her extraordinarily successful run at the Nederlander Theater on June 30, her 65th birthday. Meanwhile, the show has been booked for a national tour and probably a run in Australia, too.

title: PATENTS
description: Icebergs are to be moved through water by air bubbles, according to a method patented this week by Anthony C. Mamo of Arlington Heights, Ill. Now an independent inventor, Mr. Mamo was formerly senior staff scientist at the Borg-Warner Research Center in Des Plaines, Ill.
To the Editor:

title: Australian Visits Israel
description: Foreign Minister Anthony A. Street of Australia arrived today on an official visit. Australia is one of the countries contributing troops to the multinational force that will police the Egyptian-Israeli border after the Israelis complete their withdrawal from Sinai.

title: Former Ambassador to China Talks on Peking-Moscow Ties
description: The United States should be careful not to use China's uneasiness with the Soviet Union as a ''counterweight'' in foreign policy, says Leonard Woodcock, a former United States Ambassador to China.

title: NEW BANGLADESH REGIME ARRESTS 200
description: The nation's martial-law adminstration announced tonight that several former high Government officials and more than 200 other people had been been arrested on charges of corruption, misuse of power and antistate activities.

title: AN 'ALMOST TOTALLY NONFUNCTIONAL' A.S.P.C.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: SYNTHETIC FUEL PLANS SELECTED
description: The United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation today selected five projects in five states to compete for multimillion-dollar Federal subsidies to develop synthetic fuels.

title: Around the Nation; A.M.C. Presents Union Revised Concession Plan
description: The American Motors Corporation today presented the United Auto Workers with a second version of a request for $150 million in concessions through employee investment.

title: FOUR BOROUGHS WITH ROOM FOR 'BACK OFFICES'
description: To the Editor:

title: SYMPHONY: Y CHAMBER
description: ''Herodiade,'' one of Hindemith's more provocative scores, was given a forthright and suitably disturbing performance by Gerard Schwarz conducting the Y Chamber Symphony at the 92d Street Y last week. The only distraction was that Mallarme's text was translated into English.

title: TIMES IS SLOWED UP BY BRIEF POWER DROP DURING CON ED WORK
description: A momentary reduction in voltage last night in parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn delayed production of today's New York Times. A spokesman for Consolidated Edison, Robert Shelton, said the power reduction, just after 7:50 P.M., occurred during a switching operation for maintenance.

title: U.S. IS VAGUE ON PLANS FOR CUBA AND NICARAGUA TALKS
description: The State Department was preparing today for the next stage of its political strategy in Central America after the constituent assembly elections in El Salvador: talks with Nicaragua and possibly Cuba and the Salvadoran left.

title: Mubarak Sends a Message
description: Gen. Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, the Defense Minister, left unexpectedly for Washington today with a message to the Reagan Administration from President Hosni Mubarak that ''concerns armament agreements,'' a military spokesman said. He declined to give details.

title: Easterin' To Glory
description: With the destruction this week of two handsome old Broadway theaters to clear space for a big new hotel, the battle for Times Square is now begun.

title: News of the Theater; ANN-MARGARET IS SOUGHT FOR 'SHUBERT ALLEY' ROLE
description: Jule Styne is writing the music and Susan Birkenhead the lyrics for ''Shubert Alley,'' which is scheduled to arrive on Broadway early next season. Meanwhile, the producers - Joel Schenker and Joseph Kipness - say they are negotiating with Ann-Margret to star in the musical.

title: SUPERDOME POSES SIZABLE CHALLENGE FOR THE SHOOTERS
description: One by one, the final four teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament entered the Louisiana Superdome today and prepared for basketball games that will be played in surroundings that Dr. James Naismith could not have had in mind when the first peach basket was mounted.

title: India Considering Acquiring Improved Soviet Fighter Jets
description: India is considering acquiring an improved version of the Soviet-built MIG fighter plane, Defense Minister Ramaswamy Venkataraman said in Parliament today.

title: Nissan's U.S. Plant
description: The Nissan Motor Company Ltd. said today that it was considering seeking a dollar loan from a Japanese banking syndicate to finance its truck assembly plant in the United States.

title: Tass's U.N. Office Invaded
description: Seven Ukrainian Americans, chanting ''Freedom for the Ukraine'' and demanding the release of Ukrainian political prisoners in the Soviet Union, today invaded the United Nations bureau of the official Soviet press agency Tass.

title: THEATER: PUPPET HUMOR
description: A good Punch and Judy puppet show, such as the Ridiculous Theatrical variety concocted several years ago by Charles Ludlam, is quick, knockabout fun. Rosemary Foley's play ''Punch With Judy,'' at the Theater of the Open Eye, is lifeless, live-action tedium.

title: Two Acquitted at Trial On Cache of Marijuana
description: A public school official from Paterson, N.J., and a Manhattan bartender's helper have been acquitted in State Supreme Court in Queens on charges of possessing almost 150 pounds of marijuana that had been shipped to the United States from Nigeria.

title: Briefing
description: Second Look on Aging

title: TOKYO MUST ALSO WEIGH DOMESTIC POLITICAL ISSUES
description: There was a time when a visit to the United States by a high Government official might have appeared almost routine to the Japanese. This week, however, the Washington trip by Japan's new Minister of Foreign Affairs, Yoshio Sakurauchi, took on all the aspects of high drama.

title: Cubs Get Bump Wills
description: The Chicago Cubs completed the restructuring of the middle of their infield yesterday by acquiring Bump Wills from the Texas Rangers for Paul Mirabella, a left-handed pitcher, and cash. Wills, who has a .265 career batting average and 161 stolen bases in five seasons, is expected to start at second base. The Cubs earlier obtained Larry Bowa from the Philadelphia Phillies to play shortstop. Mirabella, who was not expected to make the Cubs' 10-man pitching staff, returns to Texas, where he began his major league career in 1978. After that season, Mirabella and Dave Righetti were among the players who came to the Yankees in the trade for Sparky Lyle. In 1979, Mirabella was traded with Chris Chambliss to the Toronto Blue Jays for Rick Cerone. The Cubs acquired Mirabella after Dallas Green became general manager and began recasting the club. ... The Cincinnati Reds, who have been using Alex Trevino, obtained recently from the Mets, as their No.1 catcher in spring training, have traded Joe Nolan to the Baltimore Orioles for Brooks Carey, a left-handed pitcher, and Dallas Williams, an outfielder. The 30-year-old Nolan batted .309 last season, but club officials were disappointed with his defensive play. Carey and Williams have been sent to the Reds' Indianapolis farm team.

title: Letter: On Research Set-Asides; The Raid on Basic Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Utah's Gymnastics Coach Optimistic
description: Greg Marsden, coach of the topranked University of Utah women's gymnastics team, accepted the position seven years ago with only one idea in mind.

title: An Ambassador Addresses the Nuclear Question; Loeb's View
description: ''I do not believe that Western Europe's instinct for survival in freedom has become so atrophied that its people are unwilling or unable to confront the hard challenges before them,'' said John L. Loeb Jr., the United States Ambassador to Denmark.

title: Gold Output Rise Seen
description: South African gold production in 1982 is expected to rise by three to eight tons from last year's 657 tons, a spokesman for the Chamber of Mines said today. Output for the first two months of 1982 fell by two tons, to 105.4 tons, from the same period of 1981, the spokesman said. He attributed the drop to a slow January start-up in the face of sharply lower gold prices.

title: AIDE SAYS REAGAN IS READY TO DISCUSS CHANGES IN BUDGET
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, said today that President Reagan was no longer committed to the budget he submitted for the fiscal year 1983 and was prepared to negotiate basic changes with Republicans and Democrats in Congress.

title: Around the World; 40 People in Bombay; Attack U.S. Consulate
description: A group of about 40 people attacked the United States Consulate in Bombay with gasoline bombs Thursday to protest American arms sales to Pakistan.

title:
Patents;
Computer Diagnoses Disorders
description: WASHINGTON ACOMPUTER for the diagnosis and treatment of nervous disorders, including those that affect vision, was patented this week for the Georgetown University Medical Center here. It measures, records and analyzes eye movements.

title: HISPANIC VOTERS IN CALIFORNIA GAINING STRENGTH IN STATE AND LOCAL POLITICS
description: California's Hispanic population, the nation's largest, has begun to assert itself politically and claim a larger role in government. And with well-organized campaigns to register voters and get out the vote, Hispanics are gaining political strength, especially at the community level.

title: Orange Grower Sees Smaller Crop
description: The American Agronomics Corporation, a major orange grove operator based in Tampa, Fla., said a preliminary assessment indicated that, because of freezing weather earlier this year, the company's 1981-82 orange crop will not exceed 2.6 million boxes, compared with 5 million for the 1980-81 season.

title: News of the Theater; Garrett Morris on Stage
description: Garrett Morris, who was on NBC-TV's ''Saturday Night Live'' for five years, will appear in ''The World of Ben Caldwell,'' which will begin at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater on April 1.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The families of the men who died in my unit have asked me the whys and hows of their deaths.

title: U.S. NONCOMMITTAL
description: The United States and Nicaragua will meet ''at a high political level'' in Mexico City next month, the Mexican Government announced today.

title: WENDY TURNBULL, ANNE SMITH GAIN
description: Anne Smith and Wendy Turnbull scored three-set victories last night and gained berths in today's semifinals of the $300,000 Avon tennis championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: SAUDIS WARN OIL BUYERS ON CUTBACKS IN NIGERIA
description: Saudi Arabia has threatened to deny crude oil supplies to any companies whose purchases of Nigerian oil fall below levels prevailing before last weekend's OPEC meeting, according to the Middle East Economic Survey.

title: 3,000 More Layoffs Set by Caterpillar
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company announced today that it planned to lay off 3,000 more workers, raising the number of United States employees on indefinite layoff to 10,000, because it expects lower 1982 sales.

title: HISTORIC PRESERVATION: ZERO FUNDING
description: The National Trust for Historic Preservation was chartered by Congress in 1949 as an educational, nonprofit organization to encourage public participation in preserving sites, buildings and objects significant in American history and culture. Operating solely on private funds in the beginning, it has received a relatively small Federal appropriation each year since 1966 to supplement private donations.

title: PROFESSIONAL GROUPS FLOCKING TO ANTINUCLEAR DRIVE
description: In an auditorium of the Harvard School of Public Health, 100 doctors, nurses and medical students watched themselves on videotape machines.

title: Los Angeles Coroner Vow to Fight Suspension
description: The Los Angeles Medical Examiner, Thomas Noguchi, suspended for alleged mismanagement and senationalizing of celebrity deaths, said today the charges were false and discriminatory. He vowed to remain in his post.

title: JULES BACKMAN, AN ECONOMIST AT N.Y.U. FOR NEARLY 50 YEARS
description: Jules Backman, an economist who taught at New York University for nearly 50 years and who for the last six years had been chairman of the board of governors of Hebrew Union College, died of a heart attack Thursday night at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Around the Nation; Jaycees Set Back Again In Effort to Bar Women
description: A Federal District judge dealt the United States Jaycees another setback today in the organizations effort to exclude women from full membership, holding that Minnesota's laws against sex discrimination were constitutional and were properly applied.

title: Artists and Architects In a Conference Today
description: Artists and architects will meet in a daylong conference today at the New School, at 66 West 12th Street.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: Briefing
description: Nader's Nay

title: BASF Net Up 1.5% in Year
description: The BASF Group, the giant West German chemical producer, said through its American affiliate yesterday that its 1981 sales rose 14.6 percent from the previous year, to $14 billion, but that profits grew only 1.5 percent.

title: LEGISLATURE HAS WAYS TO GET ITS WAY ON BUDGET
description: While Governor Carey and the legislative leaders haggle over billions of dollars in state spending, the Legislature and its staff are making scores of small spending decisions. Those decisions could have a major effect on the future of state programs and on the way those programs affect communities across the state.

title: Westinghouse Venture
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said today that it would form a 50-50 joint venture in Japan with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in June 1982 to produce core parts of gas circuit breakers for use in power plants.

title: TURKEY ASSAILS ISRAEL BUT KEEPS TIES
description: Turkey, the only active member of the Islamic Conference with diplomatic ties to Israel, has condemned the ''recent acts of annexation'' by Israel and the dismissals of elected mayors on the West Bank.

title: BULLS TROUNCE KNICKS
description: Reggie Theus scored 27 points and Orlando Woolridge added 24 to pace the Chicago Bulls to a 131-107 victory tonight over the Knicks.

title: Davis Says Trial Tests His Love of the N.F.L.
description: Al Davis, the managing general partner of the Oakland Raiders, today left not for home, but for Los Angeles, after the National Football League meetings ended Thursday.

title: Harvester Ends Caterpillar Tie
description: The International Harvester Company has eliminated the Caterpillar Tractor Company as a supplier of diesel truck engines, a company spokesman said.

title: Broadway Conductor's Turn in the Limelight; Off Broadway
description: Unlike most Broadway musical conductors, Robert Rogers of ''A Chorus Line'' is never seen by audiences because the orchestra, in which he also plays the piano, is covered by black velour.

title: Kucinich Returns
description: A follow-up: Three years after being voted out as Mayor of Cleveland, Dennis Kucinich is again seeking elective office, this time on a statewide level.

title: WHITTAKER IN NEW BID ,
description: The Whittaker Corporation, blocked earlier this month in its attempt to take over the Brunswick Corporation and its Sherwood medical products division, is seeking to buy another medical company.

title: TV REPORT RAISES ETHICS ISSUE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: A broadcast report, later retracted, that Mayor William J. Green was the target of a Federal investigation into kickbacks has led to a dispute over journalistic ethics and hints of a libel suit.

title: Arrows Beat Steamers
description: Steve Zungul scored a goal with eight seconds left to give the New York Arrows a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Steamers in a Major Indoor Soccer League game tonight at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: HIGH SCHOOL SENIOR DIES AFTER CLUBBING BY GANG
description: A senior at the High School of Music and Art who was beaten on the head by a gang with baseball bats on a subway platform in Harlem two weeks ago died Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital after extensive brain surgery.

title: SATURDAY, MARCH 27, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan is no longer committed to the budget he submitted last month and is ready to negotiate basic changes in it to reduce the projected deficit, according to Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor. His remarks were regarded as the most openly conciliatory sign so far in the budget dispute with Congress. (Page 1.)

title: PIANO: G.T. THOMPSON
description: Gregory T. Thompson, a pianist from South Carolina, played serious and substantial music last Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall, including Schubert's C minor Sonata (Op. Posth.), the Berg Sonata and Schoenberg's Six Little Pieces From Opus 19.

title: PLAY: 'THE KEYMAKER' LOOKS AT NEW YORK IN 1912
description: Looking back has become a major pastime for Americans who are uncertain about what lies ahead. In this vein, Nathan Teitel's new play, ''The Keymaker,'' done by the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y, takes us back to immigrant days in the New York of 1912, when the newcomers thought they knew the future and dared not look at the past they had cut themselves off from.

title: Federated to Buy Twin Fair Stores
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's fifth-largest retailer, has agreed to buy Twin Fair Inc.'s 14 discount department stores in western New York for an undisclosed price, Twin Fair announced.

title: U.S.-Japan Air Talks Fail
description: Daniel McKinnon, the chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said today that talks with Japan over a new air agreement had failed.

title: Mavericks 96, Kings 87
description: DALLAS (AP) - Brad Davis scored 16 second-half points, and Mark Aguirre, a rookie forward, added 13 in the second half as Dallas overcame a 9-point deficit.

title: Words Fail Him
description: Representative Frederick Richmond of Brooklyn ''will have no comment,'' says his press secretary, Michael Kahan. Throughout his public career, the 58-year-old Brooklyn Congressman has wooed the press and hunted headlines with near-religious fervor, but now he won't say a word about the shroud of scandal that seems to be wrapping itself ever tighter about him.

title: Denmark Wins Curling
description: Denmark beat Sweden, the defending champion, by 8-7 today in the final of the women's world curling championships.

title: COACHES SUPPORT STANCE BY PHELPS
description: Several college basketball coaches and one conference commissioner said today that Richard (Digger) Phelps, Notre Dame's head coach, was correct Thursday when he said that a number of colleges were paying a standard rate of $10,000 a year to outstanding players, in violation of intercollegiate rules.

title: BULLETS TOPPLE NETS BY 104-88
description: Before the game, Buck Williams was the last of the Nets players to enter the locker room. His movements were slow and his mood sullen, reflecting a recent battle with influenza. ''I feel miserable,'' he said.

title: Around the Nation; Agent Tells of Money Paid in Arrest of Boyce
description: Law officers found pancake makeup, wigs and nose-putty containers, along with a holster and ammunition, in the car of Christopher Boyce when he was arrested at Port Angeles, Wash., last year, a Federal agent testified today.

title: No Headline
description: The tournament favorite, Louisiana Tech, used balanced scoring and tenacious pressure defense to overpower Tennessee, pulling away in the second half tonight for a 69-46 victory in the semifinal round of the first N.C.A.A. Division I women's basketball championship.

title: A Chrysler Closing
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would close a Detroit plant that boxed parts for shipment overseas because the company had sold off its European, Far Eastern and South American manufacturing operations.

title: WRECKING HALTS AT THE HELEN HAYES TO SAVE ARTWORKS
description: John Portman, the Atlanta-based developer who will build a 50-story hotel near Times Square, has temporarily halted the demolition of the Helen Hayes Theater to comply with a mandate to preserve objects of historic and architectural interest.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday, with renewed weakness evident in minicomputer issues. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.71 points, to 817.92.

title: FOUNDED A HOTEL CHAIN
description: Catherine A. Dunfey, matriarch of a politically active family and founder of Dunfey Hotels, died Thursday at a Miami hospital after suffering a stroke two weeks ago. She was 87 years old.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $500 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose $500 million in the week ended March 17, a modest increase that did not cause any significant movement in interest rates.

title: No Headline
description: Nancy Lopez-Melton battled winds that gusted to 35 miles an hour and took a share of the first-round lead Thursday in the $175,000 Women's Kemper Open golf tournament.

title:
PATENTS;
Disposable Instrument Made for Blood Banks
description: John J. McMorrow of Oyster Bay, L.I., manufactures blood-bank devices. This week he got patent 4,320,787 for a scissor-type disposable instrument that can be used safely to release blood samples from tubes for testing.

title: Retrenchment At Datapoint
description: The Datapoint Corporation, the minicomputer company, said it was freezing wages for its 9,000 employees, eliminating 230 jobs by closing a Waco, Tex., manufacturing plant and scaling back operations at a California development center.

title: Texas Swimmers Take Early Lead
description: There are those who say that Texas could never have won the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming title last year if the meet was not held in the Longhorns' pool, but to Coach Eddie Reese, home-pool advantage is merely a state of mind.

title: PANEL SAYS MOST STATES FAIL ON POLICING MEDICAID FRAUD
description: A Congressional committee said today that most states had done an extremely poor job of policing Medicaid fraud, but that New York State had done a superlative job.

title: FOR NANCY JO, IT'S CANDY AND A TRIAL
description: As the 6-year-old defendant sat munching candy, a Florida Circuit Court judge today granted her attorney's request that she be tried as an adult on charges of striking a schoolmate with a stick.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Associated Madison Companies approved a previously proposed merger with the American Can Company in a stock and cash transaction valued at about $123 million.

title: Eye Donor Month and the White House; Eye-Bank History
description: Since March is being observed as Eye Donor Month by Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration Inc., its executive director, Mary Jane O'Neill, recently did some research on the history of the program, which encourages individuals to direct that, when they die, their ocular tissue be used for sight-restoring corneal transplants.

title: Jet's Boom Kills Pigs; $26,000 Is Awarded
description: Betty Davis reluctantly accepted a $26,000 settlement in her suit charging that a low-flying Air Force Phantom jet cracked a sonic boom over her farmhouse, hammering the fillings out of her teeth, killing 61 pigs and blowing her home off its foundations.

title: Briefing
description: Meese's Expert View

title: CO-STAR OF 'EASY ACES' ON RADIO
description: Goodman Ace, the comic writer who supplied dozens of leading performers with funny things to say but is perhaps best known for the malapropisms he provided for his wife, died Thursday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: FEBRUARY TRADE DEFICIT NARROWED TO $1.2 BILLION
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit tumbled to $1.2 billion in February from $5.1 billion in January, as the recession helped bring imports down at a faster pace than in any other month since the 1975 recession, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES NAMES NEW CHIEF
description: After three months of doing the work without carrying the titles, Neil Leist yesterday was appointed chairman of the board, chief executive and president of the American Bakeries Company.

title: A WALLET DISAPPEARS, AND INNOCENCE IS LOST
description: I wasn't jostled, I'm sure of that. How then did my wallet get into his hands?

title: NEW YORK TOLD TO REAPPORTION BEFORE APRIL 16
description: A special Federal court ruled yesterday that New York State must adopt a reapportionment plan by April 16 for the state's Senate, Assembly and Congressional districts.

title: VALENTINE IN 5-WAY TIE AT 137
description: As March winds blew over the second round of the Heritage Classic, Tommy Valentine said, ''It's getting kind of brutal out there.'' He might also have said it was getting kind of crowded as he and four others tied for the lead.

title: 76ers 115, Cavaliers 111
description: Andrew Toney's 3-point play and Julius Erving's two dunk shots in the last 57 seconds led Philadelphia to the victory. Maurice Cheeks led the 76ers with 21 points, and Toney added 18.

title: TWO BRINK'S SUSPECTS SEIZED IN DAWN RAIDS IN MANHATTAN
description: Two men sought as participants in the Brink's armored-car robbery in Rockland County last October were arrested at dawn yesterday in raids at opposite ends of Manhattan.

title:
PATENTS;
Molecules to Produce Vital Biochemicals
description: Molecules useful in production of such important biochemicals as insulin, human growth hormone and interferon are covered by patent 4,321,365, granted this week to one Canadian and two United States scientists. The inventors are Ray J. Wu and Chander P. Bahl, who did their research at Cornell University, and Saran A. Narang of the Canadian National Research Council in Ottawa.

title: MARTIAL ARTS CAN BE A GIRL'S BEST FRIEND
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefing
description: Dating Ins and Outs

title: Quake Is Felt in Oakland
description: An earthquake whose intensity registered 3.0 on the Richter scale shook communities in the east San Francisco Bay area at 5:24 A.M. today, the National Earthquake Information Service reported. The quake rattled dishes in Oakland and Hayward, where scientists were in the final day of a three-day seminar on the dangers of Bay Area earthquake faults. There were no reports of damage.

title: Phil Mahre Captures Special Slalom in France
description: Phil Mahre of Yakima, Wash., completing the best season of his career, won the final special slalom of the season today by edging Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden and Joel Gaspoz of Switzerland.

title: COUP, NOT JUNTA, TO BE HAILED AT GUATEMALA RALLY
description: Guatemala's political leaders announced plans today for a rally to demonstrate support for the coup that deposed the Government of Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia.

title: No Headline
description: Tom Hausman, the long-relief pitcher on the Mets for the last three years, was placed on the 21-day disabled list, retroactive to March 21. Hausman underwent surgery last August to remove bone chips from his right elbow, and has not pitched this spring while strengthening his arm. The Mets said he could rejoin the team April 12.

title: AIDE SAYS REAGAN PLAN WILL CURB MEDICAL COST AT NO RISK TO HEALTH
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, said today the Reagan Administration was committed to controlling the growth in medical costs without jeopardizing the health of Americans. But he offered few concrete details of its plans.

title: NEW DIRECTORS TO SHOW THEIR FILMS APRIL 16-28
description: Film makers from a dozen foreign countries and five independents from the United States will be represented in the 11th New Directors/New Films series April 16-28. Each film will be shown twice at the Festival Theater, 57th Street and Fifth Avenue, under the auspices of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art's film department.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutionsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Stanley, Colorado Back, Is Suspended Until Fall
description: Walter Stanley, the University of Colorado wingback who was the Big Eight Conference's leading all-purpose runner last season, has been expelled as a result of his arrest by campus police, according to Coach Chuck Fairbanks.

title: Humble Auto Inc.
description: There are good reasons to welcome the new 30-month contract between General Motors and the United Auto Workers union. With their industry facing serious competition from abroad, the highly paid auto workers are, sensibly, swallowing their pride and shrinking their wage demands. It is also good to find G.M. overcoming its reputation for cold-blooded management. The deal provides that workers give up $2 billion in wage and benefit increases in exchange for additional job security.

title: NEWARK AIRPORT: GROWING PAINS
description: DESPITE its public burial, the idea that high landing fees keep airlines away from Newark International Airport is raised and flogged again and again.

title: NEW YORK REGION CATCHING UP IN THE TECHNOLOGICAL RACE
description: WHILE several widely scattered areas of the nation have been winning the race to development of high-technology industry, the New York metropolitan area has not been left at the gate. Beginning quietly in the early 1970's, the area's growing technology complex has helped to transform the economic profile of Long Island and the developments are on the verge of moving into New York City itself.

title: U.S. AND EUROPEAN FARMERS AT WAR AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON BACK in 1963 the United States and the European Common Market fought what wags dubbed the Chicken War over European policies that discouraged imports of American poultry. The Johnson Administration retaliated by raising tariffs on a number of products that the Europeans sold in the United States, such as trucks and brandy and potato starch.

title: PUBLIC-PRIVATE TRANSIT PLAN OFFERED IN DALLAS
description: Business leaders here, including three of the city's foremost real estate developers, have unveiled a proposal for a $357 million rapid transit system that, if approved by county voters, would be financed partly by tax dollars and partly by the developers.

title: Sports People; Renee Richards's Plans
description: Renee Richards, who was known as Dr. Richard Raskind before undergoing a sex-change operation and joining the women's tennis tour in 1976, has decided to give up professional tennis and return to practicing ophthalmology. Miss Richards, who is now 47 years old, told of her plans yesterday at the East River Tennis Club, where she was coaching Andrea Leand, a promising young player. Miss Richards, who as Dr. Raskind was married and fathered a child, said she was retiring ''to be near my young son, but I'm looking forward to getting back into medicine again.''

title: THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' ON LONG ISLAND
description: HAUPPAUGE IN a time when the building industry has been in a deep slump in much of the United States, Jack Kulka has made a fortune as a construction manager for industrial buildings on the Island. Mr. Kulka, 39 years old, established the Kulka Construction Management Corporation while working out of his own home in Smithtown in 1976, telling businessmen and investors who wanted to build plants and offices that he could save them time and money. His idea was to serve as the client's agent in managing a project from design to construction, in effect replacing a general contractor.

title: Music View; THE STRANGE CASE OF A ONCE WELL-KNOWN COMPOSER
description: Does the name Louis Gruenberg mean anything to you? Probably not, unless you are old enough to remember that the Metropolitan Opera produced his ''The Emperor Jones'' in 1933 or unless you happen to have collected every recording ever made by Jascha Heifetz, who commissioned and introduced his Violin Concerto almost 40 years ago. Gruenberg, once one of the big names in American music, slipped into obscurity long before his death in 1964, an obscurity that the American Composers Orchestra may penetrate a bit on Wednesday evening when his ''The Daniel Jazz'' is performed at the Symphony Space on a program that also includes works by Jeffrey Mumford, Daniel Perlongo, Brian Fennelly and Wallingford Riegger.

title: INTERVIEW:BRENDAN GILL ON URBAN DENSITY
description: ''D ENSITY,'' said Brendan Gill, wagging an admonitory finger, ''is our friend.'' Novelist, playwright, flaneur and incorrigible civic gadfly, Mr. Gill reviews the theater for The New Yorker magazine at night to earn his keep. During the day, he is an asphalt evangelist, bent on saving this city's soul. A 40-year veteran of the urban wars, he has helped beat back waves of would-be landmark defilers, over-eager developers and misguided benefactors. Mr. Gill is former president of the Municipal Arts Society and chairman of the New York Landmarks Conservancy.

title: GUATEMALA REBELS VOW TO FIGHT DESPITE COUP
description: Guatemala's main guerrilla groups have vowed to continue their revolutionary war despite the ouster of the hard-line regime of Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia last Tuesday.

title: Food
description: ONE GOOD PIROSHKI DESERVES ANOTHER By Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey

title: Teri Solomon Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eliott V. Solomon of Old Bridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Teri Ellen Solomon, to Mark A. Levinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Levinson of Colonia, N.J. A Dec. 12 wedding is planned. Miss Solomon is a speech therapist with the Riverdale (N.J.) school district. Her fiance is a certified public accountant with the Woodbridge, N.J., firm of Eisner & Tenenbaum.

title: Last Path on the West Bank
description: Try to trace the origins of the Arab-Israeli violence on the West Bank and you are soon back in the Bible. History, not security, is the banner on both sides. Israelis claim an absolute right to settle the region no matter what its juridical status. Tens of thousands have moved among hundreds of thousands of Palestinians, who consider the territory theirs. And the Jewish settlements keep expanding, managed by ministers at least some of whom aspire to drive the Arabs out.

title: Headliners; Small-Screen Justice
description: There are no objections to overrule in the courtroom of James Lincoln McCrystal, nor are there arguments at the bench or lawyers to be held in contempt.

title: LIGHT A RIT GREENER FOR IRED MOTORISTS
description: year master plan calling for total automation and integration of the division's financial and management systems.

title: FOREIGN AID'S PURPOSE
description: A major difficulty with our foreign assistance program is that it has largely become a mechanism for helping two countries, Egypt and Israel.

title: Legal Notes; CONNECTICUT ATTORNEY GENERAL TO JOIN SAXE, BACON
description: Carl R. Ajello, the Attorney General in Connecticut for the last eight years, will soon join Saxe, Bacon & Bolan, the New York law firm of Roy M. Cohn and Thomas Bolan, a key aide to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: N.F.L. OWNERS SEEM UNITED FOR LEGAL AND LABOR CHALLENGES
description: At different times during the National Football League meetings held in Phoenix last week, two men were asked by the owners to leave the room.

title: NEW CANAAN
description: DECADES ago, and not in a moment of humility, the town fathers of N ew Canaan christened the Connecticut village the ''next station to h eaven.'' Even now, the homeowners who can afford to move in and the b usinessmen who can seize the sparse commercial space show no signs o f disagreeing with that description.

title: Television Week
description: Oscar's Magic ''The word Hollywood is magic,'' said Marty Pasetta, director of the televising of the 54th annual Academy Awards. And he will be incorporating that Hollywood magic into this year's ceremonies, which will be telecast Monday on ABC from 9 P.M. to about 12:20 A.M. from the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion of the Los Angeles Music Center.

title: TV View; THE MITFORDS: SNOBS IN LOVE
description: British television is apparently experiencing a snobbery renaissance. Granada TV has brought forth the sumptuous production of ''Brideshead Revisited,'' a tour of aristocratic drawing rooms as arranged by Evelyn Waugh, whose contempt for what he called this century's ''age of the common man'' was never less than formidable. Now, courtesy of Thames TV and beginning this evening at 9 on WNET-TV, public television will be presenting an eight-part dramatization called ''Love in a Cold Climate,'' adapted by Simon Raven from two novels by Nancy Mitford, whose own aristocratic credentials would make even her friend Mr. Waugh look common.

title: SPURNING AN OSCAR
description: When Dustin Hoffman accepted the Best Actor Academy Award in April 1980 for his work in ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' he set a sort of Hollywood high-water mark for starry-eyed self-deprecation. ''I refuse,'' he said, ''to believe that I beat Jack Lemmon, that I beat Al Pacino, that I beat Peter Sellers. I refuse to believe that Robert Duvall lost. We are part of an artistic family. In an artistic family that strives for excellence, none of you have ever lost.''

title: WARTIME BASEBALL: TRAINING AT CHOATE
description: IN March of 1943 and 1944, the Choate School in Wallingford admitted a few dozen men into its ivy-covered confines to do little else except play baseball for three weeks.

title: GYPSY MOTHS HEAD EAST
description: THE Connecticut River appears to be the dividing line for outbreaks of gypsy moth caterpillars this year. According to state entomologists, residents east of the river can expect the worst, while those who live west of the river and got the brunt of last year's defoliation will see less of it.

title: DANCE: 'GARDEN LILACS' BY UPTOWN
description: The Dance Uptown series presented old and new works performed by recent and experienced dancers at the Barnard College Gymnasium on Friday. It was a program that lived up to the series' reputation for liveliness.

title: SIX ISRAELI ARABS IN PROTEST SEIZED
description: Six Israeli Arab demonstrators were arrested today in Nazareth, as about 300 people marched, hurled rocks and burned tires on cars in solidarity with Palestinian protesters in the occupied West Bank. The West Bank itself was quieter, with demonstrations reported only from Nablus.

title:
Dining Out;
AFTER 30 YEARS, IT'S NOT A SECRET
description: IN a section of the county poor in restaurants that prepare reasonably priced decent food, Gaulin's has been doing a good job for the last 30 years on filling the gap. The restaurant offers, for the most part, a Continental menu with a strong French influence gleaned from experience in the family's native Canada. Paul and Dan Gaulin now operate the restaurant founded by their father in 1953, and their cooking skills are hardly a well-kept secret.

title: GARAMOND, BEMBO, PERPETUA
description: SELECTED ESSAYS ON THE HISTORY OF LETTER FORMS IN MANUSCRIPT AND PRINT By Stanley Morison. Edited by David McKitterick. Illustrated. 2 vols. 543 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $275.

title: TOURISM: WASHINGTON'S OTHER DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON They come to see everything from the Declaration of Independence to the Giant Pandas, and traditionally, they begin to really flock this weekend, for the opening of the Cherry Blossom Festival, which is also the kickoff of the Washington tourism season.

title: INTENSIVE STUDY SET FOR GREAT SWAMP
description: BASKING RIDGE SUPPORTED by statewide and international environmental organizations and others, biologists and naturalists have begun research to determine how heavy development around the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in recent years has damaged the ecology of the preserve.

title:
Camera;
FILING AND EDITING ALL THOSE SLIDES AND PRINTS
Kean Assails Proposal On Dumping A-Waste
description: Governor Kean says that a Reagan Administration proposal to resume dumping low-level radioactive wastes off the New Jersey coast presents ''a very severe potential health hazard.''

title: CHINA'S AIRLINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sandra Plowman Married
description: Sandra Lyn Plowman, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Howard Lee Plowman of Ardmore, Okla., was married there yesterday to Philip J. Kraus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kermit Kraus of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Charles Richardson performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church, of which the bride's father is minister. Mrs. Kraus is an analyst in the securities division of Lehman Brothers, Kuhn & Loeb Inc., in New York. The bridegroom is principal owner of the Fred Smith Heating and Plumbing Company in New York.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: A NEW ENGLAND SECRET
description: MORGAN McGINLEY contributes to the New York Times from New London, Conn. By MORGAN McGINLEY

title: WHO COVERS THE COST OF CULTURE IN MIDDLE AMERICA?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Lane Jr., an aerospace engineer based in the Dayton area, is a member the Englewood, Ohio, Fine Arts Commission. By PAUL LANE Jr. DAYTON ''It feels like we're sitting on a big egg that's beginning to hatch,'' says a grinning member of the Dayton Ballet Company. Mediumsized industrial cities in the Midwest are not expected to be cultural incubators. Old stereotypes die hard. But there are signs that a number of those good, gray middle-American cities, which once contained belching foundries and unending production lines, are seeing vast changes in their cultural appetite.

title: Ann Smith To Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lester Smith of Etna, N.H., formerly of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Wickham Smith, to John Thayer Goodhue Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue of Katonah, N.Y.

title: Talking; A HOUSE CAN BUST A BUDGET
description: AFEW years ago, when most families were spending 25 percent of t heir incomes on their homes, they had the other 75 percent to c ushion unexpected house expenses. If real estate taxes went up, theyb ought fewer clothes; if utilities went up, they cut theater-going a nd restaurants.

title: Jan Hall Engaged To John Burruss
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Anthony Hall of Sherborn and Annisquam, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jan Karen Hall, to John Crawley Burruss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Ross Burruss of Tucker, Ga.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: THE CASE OF PENNZOIL
description: One of the trail-blazers in the oil-company rush into minerals was the Houston-based Pennzoil Company. J. Hugh Liedtke, Pennzoil's chairman, recalled that in 1968 a book written by Charles F. Park Jr., a professor of hard rock minerals at Stanford University, became required reading for Pennzoil directors. The book, ''Affluence in Jeopardy,'' prophesized with some zeal that a mineral shortage was in the making.

title: CONFUSION REIGNS ON BOTTLE LAW
description: ALBANY THE Suffolk County law requiring a 5-cent deposit on all beverage containers is scheduled to take effect on Thursday, amid a cloud of confusion and uncertainty that has prolonged, if not intensified, the already fierce debate surrounding it.

title: PUTTING UP GYPSUM BOARD: PROPER NAILING IS IMPORTANT
description: WHEN nailing up gypsum board (commonly called drywall) during a remodeling job, or when it becomes necessary to make some repairs on an existing wall, it is important that the right kind of nail be used, and that it be properly recessed into the face of the wallboard in order to create a slight dimple or recess that can be filled in afterward with joint cement or spackling compound.

title: THE DANCE: COLLEGE IS OFFERING 2 PROGRAMS
description: UNION TWO programs at Kean College will offer viewers an unusual opportunity to see avant-garde dance. Eiko and Komo will perform at noon on Wednesday. Then, on April 14, also at noon, a collaboration between modern dance and jazz will be presented. Entitled ''Blow and Other Dances,'' it will feaure Pemtz Dubble, a dancer, and Jane Ira Bloom, a saxophonist.

title: SALVADOR TRYING PUBLIC RELATIONS
description: The Government of El Salvador is making a determined effort to impress the international observers who are here to monitor the fairness of Sunday's elections and, thus, to impress the world political community.

title: SHAD-FISHING AREA IN ENFIELD DECLINES
description: IN the swirling waters below the aging Enfield Dam in the northern reaches of the Connecticut River, there is a spot known to sport fishermen all over the region, and to some across the country.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: C NONFICTION 1 1 10 JANE FONDA'S WORKOUT BOOK, by Jane Fonda. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An exercise book for women, seasoned with the film star's philosophy of physical well-being. 2 3 16 A FEW MINUTES WITH ANDY ROONEY, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Atheneum, $12.95.) Reflections on contemporary life by the journalist and television commentator. 3 2 21 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Humor in cartoons and verse. 4 5 10 AT DAWN WE SLEPT, by Gordon W. Prange. (McGraw-Hill, $22.95.) A fresh account of the events culminating in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. 5 4 7 WHEN BAD THINGS HAPPEN TO GOOD PEOPLE, by Harold S. Kushner. (Schocken, $10.95.) Comforting thoughts from a Massachusetts rabbi. 6 12 4 THE I LOVE NEW YORK DIET, by Bess Myerson and Bill Adler. (Morrow, $11.50.) A seven-day plan. 7 6 7 WITNESS TO POWER, by John Ehrlichman. (Simon & Schuster, $17.50.) The gossipy memoirs of one of President Nixon's chief advisers.

title: SINAI PULLOUT TO CLOSE A LONELY U.S. OUTPOST
description: A bright orange helicopter hovers 500 feet over the bleak desert terrain, bucking slightly as the winds of an approaching sandstorm blow up the sides of the surrounding canyons.

title: Quail Plantations Deep in Georgia
description: NORMAN PARK, Ga. LESS than 15 minutes after our two English setters had been turned loose to hunt in an open stand of stately, longleaf pines on a sunny hillside, they were locked on point.

title: THREE MILE ISLAND MARKS THIRD YEAR OF BAD NEWS
description: On the third anniversary of the worst accident in three decades of commercial development of atomic power, there is such anxiety in this part of Pennsylvania about the nuclear industry that people are collecting bad news.

title:
Comment;
POLICY FOR INDUSTRY
description: ''I NDUSTRIAL policy,'' ''reindustrialization,'' or ''revitalization'' are political buzzwords, but do not answer what an industrial policy is and how to make it work. And in order to create and implement such a policy there must be a vehicle capable of making it happen.

title: 2 SOVIET OFFICIALS AFFIRM MISSILE THREAT TO U.S.
description: Two Soviet officials, one political and the other military, today affirmed Leonid I. Brezhnev's warning that deployment of new nuclear missiles in Western Europe would compel the Soviet Union to take similar, although unspecified, action against the United States.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: including spiraling inflation and a turning away from the dollar to other currencies - and strives to reassure laymen about the coming years. Our reviewer Leonard Silk praised his ''perky wit and sassy self-confidence,'' but added that his book ''lacks a unifying thesis or a clear sense of direction.'' A best seller in hard-cover.

title: DUMPING: THE ISSUE BECOMES POLITICAL
description: THE ripple effect from last week's dumping of sludge spoil in Long Island Sound within two miles of Lloyd Neck has spilled over into the Island's political arena.

title: 2 FORMER CHASE OFFICERS INDICTED ON FRAUD COUNTS
description: Two former vice presidents of the Chase Manhattan Bank were indicted here Friday by a Federal grand jury in what the authorities charge was an elaborate fraud scheme involving more than $20 million in bank loans.

title: Bridge; HEAVY HITTER
description: Almost all American boys -not to mention some girls -have a daydream in which they are playing baseball or softball and, trailing against a favored team, they step up to the plate in the ninth inning and save the day with a smashing four-run homer.

title: Ravitch Proposes Arbitration In Event of L.I.R.R. Deadlock
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has proposed that the state-owned Long Island Rail Road and its 17 unions agree to submit voluntarily to binding arbitration in the event of a deadlock in their contract talks.

title: MORRIS DANCE-A SPRING TRADITION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Alan Jones is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance. BY ALAN JONES

title: Q and A; Question:Our family is planning a trip to both Peking, the People's Republic of China, and Taipei, Taiwan, this summer with our two sons who are 12 and 16. We will be in China for three weeks and on Taiwan for one week. Which cities between New York and Peking do you suggest we make our connections in? - C. C., Armonk, N.Y.; Answer:The journey by air from New York to Peking takes about 24 hours overall and crosses 11 time zones and the international dateline. It may therefore be wiser to think in terms of which cities you would like to visit, however briefly, than to try to construct a close web of connections that will cause your family to arrive very tired and out of synchronization with local time.
description: If you fly on Pan American or CAAC, the Chinese airline, and stay overnight in either Los Angeles or San Francisco, then again in Tokyo, your body gains time to adjust to a different rhythm of waking, sleeping and eating. You would then have to leave China and make a connection in Tokyo or elsewhere nearby to get to Taiwan, since there are no direct connections between Peking and Taipei.

title: Proposition 2: A Case Against It
description: Whatever happened to the League of Women Voters since 1978 to make it reverse its former opposition to any single-disposal plant for all of Westchester County? None of the arguments made by the league in 1978 against such an installation appeared in the article ''A Case for Refuse Disposal District No. 1'' (Opinion Page, March 21). And yet the same objections, made at the time against the Wheelabrator-Frye plant proposed for Grasslands, still hold true for the present Peekskill proposal - no front end separation (without which local recycling efforts are discouraged), no shutdown alternatives to provide for accommodating continuous dumping during shutdown periods and no set figure on ultimate costs to the county (which means taxpayers!).

title: A FISHERMAN OF GUILT
description: DUTCH SHEA, JR. By John Gregory Dunne. 352 pp. New York: The Linden Press/Simon & Shuster. $15.95.

title: RAPIST ASSAULTS TWO WOMEN, THEN KILLS ONE
description: Detectives yesterday sought a man who they believe sexually assaulted two young women after luring them to an abandoned tenement in the South Bronx with promises of a job, then stabbed one to death after the other escaped by jumping out of a fifth-floor window.

title: No Headline
description: Quiet Bay, a 5-year-old colt owned by Augustin Stables and trained by Jonathan Sheppard, took the lead at the 12th and final fence and went on to a one-length victory today in the $15,000-added Carolina Cup at Springdale Race Course. Ridden by John Cushman, Quiet Bay covered the steeplechase course of 2 1/8 miles in 4 minutes 10 4/5 seconds.

title: HOW THEY SLIDE INTO COLD WORLD OF CRYOGENICS
description: ONE latter-day marvel that is no longer leaving career hunters cold is cryogenics - the science and technology of low temperatures. For a long time cryogenics, which deals with temperatures generally ranging from minus 196 centigrade to minus 270 centigrade (that's minus 321 to 454 degrees Fahrenheit), has not been the most popular of disciplines in either academia or industry. Research on reactions to extreme cold by materials such as steel, helium gas and tissue cells of the human heart has seemed long on esoterica and short on practical applications.

title: Being Jerzy Kosinski
description: Why is it that extreme suffering and pain tend to produce the most intelligent, creative and captivating individuals (''Being Jerzy Kosinski,'' by Barbara Gelb, Feb. 21)? Perhaps it is because those who have the strength to survive can somehow, afterward, divert that energy into productivity and inspiration. Jerzy Kosinski is a hero. Thank you for such an inspiring story. MEGAN CARMAN, Somerset, N.J.

title: SEASON IN THE SUN
description: By George O'Brien

title: ON THE WORTH OF JOHN ELWAY AND SPORTS
description: To the Sports Editor: With regard to the article about John Elway signing a contract with the Yankees for $140,000 (''Stanford's Elway Swings Like a Yankee,'' The New York Times, March 21 1982) for what is the equivalent of a summer job, in the same edition there were articles on the colleges losing control of their sports programs, the ''big-money changes'' in spring training and Fernando Valenzuela's holdout.

title: The Region in Summary; Portman's Progress
description: Within hours after the United States Supreme Court allowed them to, wrecking crews began mauling the Morosco and Helen Hayes Theaters into piles of rubble last week. The only question remaining about the Portman Hotel that is to occupy the site along Broadway between 45th Street and 46th Street was whether Broadway itself would be malled.

title: LOUISVILLE BOWS, 50-46
description: Finding themselves in the unusual position of having to play in a close tournament game, Georgetown's Hoyas found a way today to reach their most important test. The Hoyas were not artistically successful in their 50-46 semifinal victory over Louisville. They were merely successful.

title: KUWAIT SEARCHES FOR A GULF PEACE
description: Kuwait, a small, highly vulnerable nation wedged in between big and powerful neighbors, is dismayed by the new escalation of the Iran-Iraq war and by Iran's rejection of what is seen here as Iraqi attempts to end the conflict through negotiation.

title: 'HOUND OF BASKERVILLES' LACKS BITE
description: PORT JEFFERSON ''HORROR is prowling the moor once again.'' ''The scent of murder is in the air.'' ''I never cross the moor on a night like this.'' ''I scare easily!'' Virtually any randomly selected line from Tim Kelly's adaptation of the Sherlock Holmes mystery ''The Hound of the Baskervilles'' programs the mood and conveys the very elementary style of the piece, which is showing at Theater Three through Saturday.

title: TENANTS NEED BETTER PROTECTION ON CONVERSIONS
description: FOR many years, landlords of apartment buildings have suffered what could be argued is a deprivation of their property, as a result of regulation of rents imposed by the various rent-control laws. With the onslaught of conversions, however, these same landlords are having their ''day in court'' with tenants. If the rent-control laws proved to be a bonanza to tenants, at the expense of landlords, under the conversion laws the opposite holds true. While landlords stand to make huge profits on building conversions, tenants are oftentimes faced with the unpleasant choice of a forced purchase of their apartments on the landlord's terms, or eviction.

title: SHUTTLE MAY END TRIP ON SCHEDULE
description: After hours of concern over predicted weather conditions at the landing site, officials of the space agency decided today not to order the space shuttle Columbia back to earth a day early but to proceed with plans for a landing Monday as scheduled.

title: Activists Charge Bias In Georgia Conviction
description: Two New York civil rights activists were convicted Friday of public drunkenness and obstructing an officer in a case the couple said was racially motivated.

title: Politics; LEGISLATIVE 'REPAIRS' DOG THE ASSEMBLY
description: HARTFORD THERE is a time-honored expression in most legislative bodies that goes something like this: ''Let's pass the bill this year, and if any problems arise, we can fix it next session.''

title: Sampson Honored
description: The United States Basketball Writers Association today named Ralph Sampson, the Virginia center, as player of the year for the second straight time. Sampson, a junior, was the unanimous choice of the nine-member selection committee.

title: BEING JERZY KOSINSKI
description: When I lived in New Haven, I audited a course at Yale given by Jerzy Kosinski. He lectured in creativity and reality.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Completely Different

title: NO PYTHONS, PLEASE
description: OYSTER BAY ANYONE thinking of buying, selling or keeping a pet in the Town of Oyster Bay had better limit his choice to a dog or a cat or a handful of other equally pedestrian selections. Such exotic species as pythons, vultures, ostriches, kangaroos, alligators, gorillas and camels are forbidden under the town's recently adopted Dangerous Animals Ordinance.

title: Sports People; Bucks Lose Buckner
description: The Milwaukee Bucks, on the verge of clinching first place in the National Basketball Association's Central Division, suffered a serious loss Friday night. Quinn Buckner, a starting guard, suffered a dislocation and torn ligaments in his right thumb.

title: 3-YEAR EFFORT PUTS OPERA IN BLACK
description: THREE years after becoming general director of the Connecticut Opera Association, rescuing it in fact from near-bankruptcy, George Osborne can now point with pride to an extremely successful arts organization.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: LAW GROUP SEEN CHANGING
description: FERN SCHAIR of Scarsdale, the first woman to hold the position of executive secretary of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, says a lot of people are asking her these days: ''Does this mean the bar association is changing?'' She responds that she feels it reflects changes that have already taken place, noting that 25 percent of the association's new membership last year was made up of women.

title: RUTH STEVENS IS MARRIED TO DAVID WILLIAM OLSON
description: Ruth Stevens, a vice president of Burson-Marsteller, a New York public relations agency, and David William Olson, director of marketing in New York for Newsmaking International Inc., a public relations company based in Los Angeles, were married yesterday at the English Speaking Union. The ceremony was performed by Michael Grupp, leader of the Ethical Culture Society.

title: Fishing Proposals by Indians In Upper Michigan Approved
description: A Federal District judge has approved fishing regulations proposed by three Indian tribes in Upper Michigan, dismissing a state request to delay the ruling.

title: WHAT TO TAKE FOR THE WEEKEND
description: The idea behind a uniform is just that: uniformity. But even in identical clothing, two men with varying approaches to dressing will end up looking very different.

title: IN PURSUIT OF ELEGANCE
description: VILLA D'ESTE in Floral Park reaches for an image of elegance in its setting, appointments, service and food, but achieves it with only intermittent success. The dining rooms are overdecorated, like a stage set, in a plush turn-of-the-century gaslight style, with red walls, etched and frosted glass globes on the brass light fixtures and paintings in heavy gilt frames. Traylike service plates of silverplate remain on the table until dessert, underneath the chinaware as coasters for the various courses. In contrast to this silver, the flatware is stainless steel. Bud vases, usually containing roses, decorate each table. Although they are silver, they are so heavily tarnished from lack of polishing they look more like copper.

title: FATHER OF NEUTRON BOMB NOW REJECTS ITS USE
description: Samuel Cohen, the father of the neutron bomb, defends it on humane grounds, but agrees with its critics on one key point: He thinks it should not be deployed in defense of the nation's allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: COLLEGES ADVISED ON RESEARCH PACTS WITH INDUSTRY
description: Universities should avoid secrecy in any licensing agreements they reach with private industry, a conference of university presidents, scientists and business leaders agreed today.

title: Practical Traveler:; GROUP TOURS WITH GOOD OLD CHARLIE
description: One of the most memorable cases handled by Thomas A. Dickerson, a Manhattan attorney who specializes in travel law, involved about 250 vacationers, including himself, who paid $300 to $480 each and flew to a resort in Jamaica for the Christmas holidays of 1975.

title: NORTH DAKOTA BEATS WISCONSIN FOR TITLE
description: North Dakota won its second N.C.A.A. hockey championship in three years tonight with a 5-2 victory over Wisconsin before a crowd of 9,752 in the Providence Civic Center.

title: WITH FEWER TEAMS, THE GOAL IS BALANCE
description: The North American Soccer League, which operated with 24 franchises two years ago, will open its 16th season on Saturday with 14 teams. The reduction had been supported by the league's more established teams, especially influential franchises such as the Cosmos, Chicago and Seattle. They thought that expansion from 18 to 24 teams in 1978 was a mistake.

title: Mast Falls Off Yacht in Whitbread Race
description: Under a starless sky early this morning, the 80-foot English yacht First Cooperative cut through the dark, flat seas of the North Atlantic, driven by a 20-knot breeze that had just filled in from the east.

title: 2 More Replacements Planned for 'Amadeus'
description: Dennis Boutsikaris and Suzanne Lederer will join Frank Langella on April 13 in ''Amadeus'' at the Broadhurst Theater. Mr. Boutsikaris will replace John Pankow in the role of Mozart, and Suzanne Lederer will replace Michele Farr as the composer's wife, Constanze. Mr. Langella's role as the envious Salieri - replacing John Wood - had been announced.

title: IDAHO MOVES TO BAR INSANITY AS LEGAL DEFENSE
description: The Idaho Legislature has voted to abolish insanity as a defense for crimes, a departure from the way mentally ill suspects have been prosecuted in the United States since the mid-19th century.

title: The Nation in Summary; REagan Offers A Free-Market War on Poverty
description: President Reagan seemed determined last week to show that, for all his anecdotes about the guile of the undeserving, he is genuinely concerned about the certifiable have-nots of the land.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section of Feb. 7, 1982 about the motion picture ''Missing,'' dealing with events in Chile in the 1970's, incorrectly described the disposition of a charge against Hal Hendrix, a former I.T.T. official. He pleaded guilty to withholding information from Congress, a misdemeanor, and received a suspended sentence.

title: GUATEMALA: ANOTHER COUP
description: DESPITE the coming attractions, the military coup that opened in Guatemala last week quickly began to look like just another remake of the old classic.

title: Crafts
description: IN SETTING Jane Teller's wood sculptures against Joy Saville's quilted hangings, the Squibb Gallery in Lawrence Township has rendered a favor both to the artists and viewers. There is so much interplay between the pieces executed by these two residents of nearby Princeton that the character of one body of work helps to reveal that of the other.

title: Anita Ellen Roberts Is the Bride of Alan S. Korosy
description: Anita Ellen Roberts and Alan Steven Korosy, both of Newton, Mass., were married yesterday at the Park Plaza Hotel in Boston by Justice of the Peace William McMackin of Boston.

title: CABBAGE: INEXPENSIVE,DELICIOUS AND NUTRITIONAL
description: INSTITUTIONAL cooking has given green cabbage a bad name. But there are many enterprising ways of cooking this thrifty yet superior vegetable besides boiling it for prolonged periods in salted water.

title: The Nation in Summary; INflation Eases
description: The Administration took some solace from the latest inflation update. According to Labor Department tabulations, consumer prices rose but two-tenths of 1 percent in February, thanks to the recession and a decline in oil prices.

title: Airport Hotels
description: Tg the Editor: In regard to the story on ''Airport Hotels'' (Travel, March 7) I would like to put in some kind words for the Sheraton Frankfurt Hotel because we have found it so convenient, so practical and, above all, so comfortable.

title: LOVE AND HISTORY
description: THE BOHEMIANS John Reed and His Friends Who Shook the World. By Alan Cheuse. 358 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Apple-wood Books. $12.95.

title: BEYOND BALLOTS
description: SAN SALVADOR FOR some time, this tiny nation has been exerting a disproportionate influence in the hemisphere. Today, as El Salvador sought to ease its conflicts through elections, warring interests in the region scurried to appear equally eager for a peaceful resolution.

title: Lisa R. Turgell Is Married to Edward A. Friedland
description: Lisa Robin Turgell, an associate with the New York law firm of Brown, Wood, Ivey, Mitchell & Petty, was married yesterday to Edward Asher Friedland, a lawyer with the New York firm of Kronish, Lieb, Shainswit, Weinter & Hellman. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel and Rabbi Saul Teplitz performed the ceremony in the Harmonie Club.

title: DARTS GAINING POPULARITY AS SPORT
description: NEXT to soccer, it is the fastest growing sport in the nation, according to Leo Estes, who also pointed out that it was probably the cheapest to play.

title: All-Day Kindergarten Prompts Concern
description: As a kindergarten teacher of many years' experience, I am very concerned about the increase in all-day kindergartens (''All-Day Kindergarten Gains''). Studies made by the Gesell Institute of Human Development and the findings of the child psychiatrist David Elkind (''The Hurried Child'') are warning parents and teachers that the consequences of the short-term progress made can be quite devastating later in the child's life.

title: KRASNA 'COMEDY' OFFERED IN MONTCLAIR
