description: MONTCLAIR THE Whole Theater Company's production of Norman Krasna's ''Off-Broadway'' proves that the world may not yet be safe for democracy, but Mr. Krasna is still safe for some theatergoers.

title: TRACKING SHORT INTEREST REPORTS
description: ONE of the most misunderstood of Wall Street indicators is the r eport of short-interest activity on the New York and the American S tock Exchange that appears monthly in major newspapers. Short i nterest rose or fell, the report states, and then goes on to list p ositions in hundreds of companies, for the latest month and the p revious month.the extent to which investors are betting that stock G enerally, in a short sale, someone is selling borrowed stock, hopingt o deliver it later at a lower price. The idea is to pocket the d ifference between prices.

title: CERAMICS IS BEING MOLDED INTO MORE THAN AN ART FORM
description: THE worldwide race for new industrial materials and for energy efficiency has opened broad horizons for ceramic engineering, an ancient but until recently obscure profession that is quickly becoming one of the ''hottest'' high-technology fields.

title: U.S. BARS CHARGES AGAINST A MEXICAN
description: The Justice Department has blocked the United States Attorney in San Diego from seeking the indictment of the former head of Mexico's security police because the Central Intelligence Agency advised that he was a key American intelligence source in Central America, according to department officials.

title: The Region in Summary; Goldbricks Pave The Budget Road
description: ''The Governor has proposed, but the Legislature reposes,'' Governor Carey complained a few weeks ago when negotiations on his budget were stalled. Last week, the roles were reversed. Mr. Carey, frustrated, withdrew from the bargaining and the Legislature proposed a budget of its own.

title: Mrs. Melton and Carner Tie for Lead by a Stroke
description: Nancy Lopez-Melton shot a birdie on the final hole today and moved into a tie for the lead with JoAnne Carner after three rounds of a $175,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Drug Smugglers Get to Keep
description: Homes Bought With Profits

title: NONPROFIT SECTOR STUDIED
description: NEW HAVEN IN a comfortable, Victorian-vintage dwelling on the Yale campus, lawyers, sociologists and university students are investigating what they say is perhaps the least understood aspect of American society - the behavior of hundreds of thousands of educational, scientific, cultural or civic groups operating as nonprofit organizations.

title: DIANA AND ADMIRERS
description: MEXICO BAY By Paul Horgan. 240 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. By JOHANNA KAPLAN

title: THE PRICE OF HEALTH Examining the Medical System
description: Authorities inside and outside America's health-care industry are saying with increasing urgency that the nation's system for paying medical bills rewards profligacy and must be overhauled.

title: THE WEST BANK OCCUPATION NOW RESEMBLES ANNEXATION
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin engaged himself last week in complex struggles on two political fronts - one with his fellow legislators in the Knesset, the other, more violent, with the Palestine Liberation Organization and its supporters in the occupied West Bank. Neither he nor his opponents scored a clear victory in either case, but some new dynamics of Begin policy were put on display, and they carried implications for Israel's near future.

title: Utah Takes Its Championship in Stride
description: The Utah women's gymnastics coach, Greg Marsden, says he wasn't surprised by the manner in which his team won the first National Collegiate Athletic Association championship or by Utah's top two finishers in the all-round competition.

title: No Headline
description: It's easy to understand why President and Mrs. Reagan picked Bellerive, the home of their old Hollywood friend Claudette Colbert for their Barbados holiday starting April 7. It is a cheerful, lovely house by the sea, not grandiose but informal and restful, and at age 78 Miss Colbert is as beautiful, charming and zestful as ever she was in her stardom.

title: U.S. RADAR CALLED AID TO THE ENEMY IN A WAR
description: The usefulness of the present United States radar systems in war has been challenged by a retired Navy radar expert.Thomas S. Amlie, who served as technical director of the Naval Weapons Center at China Lake, Calif., says American radar signals could be easily detected by an enemy and ''are excellent aiming points for anyone who wants to shoot at U.S. missiles, planes, warships and ground units.'

title: BUT ITS TONE IS IN DISPUTE
description: The Voice of America got a new director last week, and maybe a new image. But those who have been close to the agency during its traumatic last six months are waiting to see if the change at the top - the appointment of John Hughes, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and former editor of The Christian Science Monitor - will be reflected in an organization caught in a tug of war between its news and propaganda functions.

title: FAMILY CURSES
description: LULLABY By Oakley Hall. 278 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95.

title: Postings; FORDHAM ANCHOR
description: The block on Fordham Road, rank with weeds and strewn with litter, is also a vision of opportunity: a place where decay encroaching from the South Bronx may be halted and a $70 million tower of commerce erected, reviving a once-proud neighborhood.

title: Collins, And Griffey A Study in Contrasts
description: Bill Brown, a play-by-play announcer for Cincinnati's WLWT-TV, stood along the first-base line with his camera crew this morning and talked about Ken Griffey and Dave Collins, the two former Reds who have spent the last few weeks learning what life is like with the Yankees.

title: THE CASE FOR COLLEGE AID
description: Michael Sovern might have mentioned the fact that children of deceased, disabled or retired workers, who up until now have received Social Security benefits to help see them through their undergraduate years, will lose those benefits after May 1982. In fact, when the youngest child in such a family reaches the age of 16, benefits will cease for that family. BARBARA R. ROBEY New York City

title: STATE POLICE BACK ANTI-PARAMILITARY BILL
description: THE State Police Superintendent, Col. Clinton L. Pagano, sees the anti-paramilitary bill now working its way through the Legislature as a tool that could assist law enforcement.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH THE MILITARY
description: Senator Hart's negative views toward management education seem misguided. In fact, almost every point in his article indicates a sophisticated grasp and use of important managerial concepts.

title: HOW ANTITRUST LAW PUNISHES A COMPANY FOR DEFENDING ITSELF
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Ellen Lang, Soprano; Guild Award Winner
description: Ellen Lang, the soprano who made her New York debut Tuesday night as winner of a Concert Artists Guild Award, impressed as a singer who might do very well in operetta. In the last two items in her program - Jerome Kern's ''All the Things You Are'' and ''Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man'' -she seemed to come into her own after singing other things commendably but seldom arrestingly.

title: Westerners Lose Electricity
description: About 750,000 California customers of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company were without electricity for up to 30 minutes today when a power line in the Pacific Northwest ''tripped out'' and overloaded a separate line to the south, the utility said. The power failure also affected parts of southern Nevada, Arizona, Texas and New Mexico. A spokesman said the Western States Coordinating System in Utah took over distribution of electricity to prevent a massive failure.

title: METS' STREAK ENDS AS EXPOS WIN IN 11
description: The New York Mets got their first look of the spring today at the Montreal Expos and found that winter had done little to erode the team that won the championship of the National League's East last year.

title: President of Italy Goes to San Francisco
description: President Sando Pertini of Italy arrived here today from Washington. He was cheered by people waving American and Italian flags when he drove through the North Beach area, a prodominantly Italian-American neighborhood of San Francisco.

title:
Dining Out;
HIGH ON THE HOG AT THE SHORE
description: WE OFTEN receive complaints from readers concerning the prices charged by New Jersey restaurants. ''New York'' prices and the feeling of being ''ripped off'' are the phrases usually used.

title: BUDGET CUTS TRIM SERVICES TO NEEDY
description: As a result of Federal budget cuts, New York City has lost a training program for the mentally ill and jobs have been eliminated for more than a thousand workers who had served meals to the elderly, acted as homemakers or counseled youth, according to the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

title: The World in Summary; Siren Song Is Heard In Tashkent
description: ''As long as Americans are scaring themselves stiff with the 'Soviet threat,' '' said a recent article in Izvestia, ''they will always be haunted by the nightmare of normalization in Soviet-Chinese relations.'' Leonid I. Brezhnev did his best last week to trouble Washington's sleep.

title: NICARAGUA: FEARS RISE
description: IN 32 months in power, Nicaragua's Sandinists have treated elections as virtually a nonsubject. They won't have any until 1985, if then.

title: TO OUR READERS
description: The Times introduces an expanded and redesigned Real Estate section today.

title: Television Week
description: Tenor Time Luciano Pavarotti has become something of a fixture on the small screen. He has appeared in a commercial for American Express, has been a guest on the Johnny Carson show and has performed in ''Live From the Met'' telecasts.

title: A Correction
description: A chart in The Week in Review of March 21 underrepresented the number of nuclear warheads deliverable by Soviet rockets, bombers and submarines. The correct total is 8,000.

title: Ballet Theater Sets 8 New Productions
description: Eight new productions and three revivals will highlight the American Ballet Theater's eight-week engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House, opening April 19.

title: ALL ABOUT THE OSCARS
description: Ihave a very strong feeling that this is going to be a watershed year for the motion picture Academy Awards - not just a changing of the guard but a shift in the earth's crust, rather as though that old Paramount mountain had finally blown its top. As we sit down to our television sets tomorrow evening, however, we're not likely to see anything so radical as that. Visually, we'll no doubt still be looking at male and female mannequins - stick people -tripping in a gingerly fashion down unnecessarily long staircases to jostle one another, and josh one another, as they breathily read the evening's nominations from a teleprompter and the voting results from envelopes they have inexpertly ripped open. The actresses will have been hammered into gowns that were apparently designed for The Tin Woodperson, their coiffures will make them unrecognizable, and the males who must cope with them will keep their cool and their distance. The proceedings, overall, will be much less fun than the theater's Tony Awards, mainly because the Tonys have access to ready-made production numbers from the best Broadway musicals while the Academy must throw together less inspired ones on the spot, and the thankyous will stammer on until the last gofer has received his due. I have a friend who maintains that if a brief announcement could be made to the effect that everyone in motion pictures is deeply grateful to his parents, one whole hour would automatically be cut from the occasion.

title: For Some in Superdome Crowd, a View From the 27th Floor
description: How high was it? ''So high that I just saw the satellite go by,'' said Thomas Donald of Memphis. ''And it was below me.'' How high was it? ''So high that I'm not going down for anything,'' said Ruby Hudson of Greensboro, N.C.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Klaus Hellwig, Pianist From West Germany
description: Klaus Hellwig brought an impressive clarity to piano music by Clementi, Beethoven, Brahms, Stravinsky, Frank Martin and Gyles Swayne at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday. In the narrower dimensions of Clementi's B-flat Sonata and the steel-like textures of Stravinsky's Three Movements from ''Petrouchka,'' this young West German's surgical brilliance was a delight.

title: Passaic resident is filling the role of honorary consul
description: PASSAIC TO Jean Claude Levy, honorary consul of Haiti in New Jersey, his title is not merely decorative. Rather, Mr. Levy, who is not a Haitian, sees himself as helping the thousands of Haitian immigrants in New Jersey who live in poverty. He considers his mission as one of assisting them in settling in a school or job.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Dinizulu and his African Dancers, Drummers and Singers will perform dance and music from across the African continent on Wednesday, Saturday and next Sunday at Theater of the Riverside Church. Tradition and its preservation will be the keynote of the program.

title: WHEN PEOPLE KILL A PEOPLE
description: GENOCIDE Its Political Use in the Twentieth Century. By Leo Kuper. 255 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $15.

title: IMPACT ON JOB MARKET: DIVIDED PREDICTIONS
description: WHENEVER technological change occurs, workers become concerned that the nature of their work might change, or even that they might lose their jobs. In the second decade of the 19th century, as the Industrial Revolution swept across Britain, protesting workers smashed machines that produced clothing and textiles. These workers, who became known as Luddites, have been portrayed ever since as mindless opponents of technological progress, though their purpose was equally to gain higher wages and resist wage reductions.

title:
GARDENING;
NOW'S THE TIME TO START SPRING CHORES
description: ALTHOUGH still a bit too chilly outdoors for relaxing on the patio, the season is upon us when we can get on with our gardening chores. The more we accomplish now, the less there remains to be done when warm weather arrives.

title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.  Hired by Morgenthau
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the 27-year-old son of the late Democratic Senator from New York, has been accepted as an assistant district attorney in the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: No Headline
description: Before Dawn, last year's champion 2-year-old filly, rallied at the top of the stretch today to win easily in the $113,000 Fair Grounds Oaks.

title: Washington; REAGAN THINKS IT OVER
description: The Reagan Administration is now at a critical point in the formulation of the policy it will present to the Soviet Union at Geneva this summer for the control of strategic nuclear weapons.

title: Antiques View; CONNOISSEURSHIP IN WINDSOR ARMCHAIRS
description: What began 20 years ago as a $60 investment in a 1750's Windsor chair -a Philadelphia comb-back design with flaking green paint - developed for Charles and Olenka Santore into a passionate pursuit of such stick-furniture. Today, the couple's quest of bow-backs, fanbacks, comb-backs, sack-backs, rod-backs and low-backs has resulted in a collection of rare and not-so-rare examples of more than 50 such chairs that fill the rooms of their Philadelphia townhouse.

title: INNIS LAWYERS SAY HE IS TARGET OF CONSPIRACY
description: The defense in the assault trial of Roy Innis, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, has charged law enforcement officials with conspiring to single out Mr. Innis and a co-defendant for prosecution.

title: THE ACQUISITIONS THAT HAVEN'T PAID OFF
description: Not so many months ago, billion-dollar takeover offers were sweeping Wall Street. Among the biggest targets were the natural resource companies and in the culmination of a decade-long infatuation with minerals, the pursuers, for the most part, were oil companies.

title: GROUP IN WATER-RATE SQUEEZE
description: THE 164 customers who are hooked up to the only private water company in Southold Town have resigned themselves to either paying a large rate increase or sinking their own wells at an estimated cost of $3,000 a well.

title:
Art;
CONTEMPORARY ARTISTS IN SUMMIT EXHIBIT
description: SUMMIT AN INTERESTING and adventurous selection of works by contemporary artists is on view at the Summit Art Center through April 8. Under the title, ''Drawing/New Directions,'' the curators of the exhibition, Sally Abbott and Ann Beason, have assembled about 50 works by artists ranging from the already famous to those as yet little known.

title: Stockholm
description: To the Editor: In connection with the article, ''What's Doing in Stockholm'' by R. W. Apple Jr.

title: Conner Leads by 1 After Couples Slips
description: A cold and windy day, uncommon on this island at this time of year, bothered some of the players during the third round of the Heritage Classic today.

title: 10,000 Join Celebration On Chapel Hill Campus
description: A crowd estimated as high as 10,000 people took to the streets of this college town today to celebrate North Carolina's 68-63 victory over Houston in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament in New Orleans.

title: Long Islanders; GIVING SPEECHES ANOTHER VOICE
description: THOMAS F. DALY 3D of Southold is a man of few words and an editor of many. In private life he is laconic. But professionally - well, that's another story.

title: EXHIBIT POINTS UP VIEWS ON CONTEXT OF A BUILDING
description: The notion that buildings in cities should pay attention to what is around them - should fit into the context, to use the currently prevailing phrase -has been achieving wider and wider acceptance. But this can mean a lot of very different things, as the work of the Office for Metropolitan Architecture, a group of young, Europeanbased architects, makes clear.

title: 39-1 Shot Wins Spiral Stakes
description: Good 'n' Dusty, a Kentucky-bred colt owned by Larry Lehmann and trained by Jasper Adams, scored a fivelength upset victory today in the $150,000 Jim Beam Spiral Stakes at Latonia Race Course. The 3-year-old bay colt paid $81.60, $27.60 and $11.60 for $2 across the board.

title: FLOODS ARE FOCUS OF DEBATE
description: GLEN COVE FACED with rate increases for Federal flood insurance in Long Island's 55 coastal communities, property owners are reacting angrily and threatening not to carry the insurance. The increases are scheduled to go into effect Thursday.

title: J.S. Masters to Marry Ens. Melissa A. Drisko
description: Col. Melville Anson Drisko Jr., U.S.A., and Mrs. Drisko of Fort Monmouth, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ens. Melissa Anne Drisko, U.S.N., to Jonathan Scott Masters, son of Mrs. Jean Masters of Mountainside, N.J., and the late Randol T. Masters.

title: Former Executive Fined In Chemical Dumping
description: A former executive of the Chemical Control Corporation has been ordered to put in one year of community service and pay a $5,000 fine for his conviction on charges of allowing toxic wastes charges of allowing toxic wastes to flow into the Elizabeth River.

title: G. W. Taylor Weds Deborah Delafield
description: Deborah Lawrence Delafield, a psychiatric nurse clinical specialist at the Coastal Community Counseling Center in Quincy, Mass., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Willis Taylor, product-development manager for the Hollingsworth & Vose Company, a manufacturer of paper products in Walpole, Mass. The Rev. Robert Malm and the Rev. Geoffrey Hahnaman performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston.

title: NO ONE STANDS OUT, BUT 1982 ROOKIES LOOK IMPRESSIVE
description: Pat Gillick, general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, surveyed the rookie class of 1982 in baseball, and reported: ''This year, there's no Fernando Valenzuela.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Rewiring the A.T.&T. Deal
description: It took seven years of wrangling to produce an antitrust settlement on which the American Telegraph and Telephone Company and the Justice Department could agree, but that does not mean the matter is closed. The settlement, in which A.T.&T. agreed to divest itself of 22 Bell system operating companies while moving into unregulated businesses, is under attack in Congress.

title: Future for Equity Seen at the Greeley
description: Although we are saddened that the Main Street Theater (or any theater) has come to grief, Equity theater in Westchester is alive and thriving at the Greeley Street Theater in Chappaqua. Our nonprofit theater had a successful run of ''A Coupla White Chicks Sitting Around Talking'' by John Ford Noonan last September, and our spring production is an original play, ''Laughing on the Outside'' by Donald R. Wilde of Briarcliff Manor and directed by Bob Giraldi of Chappaqua.

title: WEINBERGER CAUTIONS JAPANESE ON ARMS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger cautioned Japanese leaders today that unless Japanese military abilities were substantially and swiftly increased, Congressional pressures might lead to more American restrictions on Japanese imports or to the withdrawal of American military forces, a senior American official said.

title: ANGELA LOVES JOE, JOE LOVES ANGELA
description: LOVE AND WORK By Gwyneth Cravens. 342 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.50.

title: TAVERNIER'S 'WEEK'S VACATION'
description: Here are some ways that Bettrand Tavernier, in production notes for his new film ''A Week's Vacation,'' describes his film: ''A portrait of a woman against the background of almost murmured questions that concern us all, approached without didacticism.'' ''A laughing fit before you realize it's going to snow.'' ''An old man who knows a lot.'' ''A motorcycle engine more familiar than a Moliere play.'' ''A letter you read at the end of summer.''

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Whoever becomes the next basketball coach at Duquesne, succeeding Mike Rice, who was dismissed March 9, will not have to answer to John (Red) Manning, the athletic director. Nellie King, the spokesman for the committee seeking a replacement for Rice, said that the new coach would also serve as ''the athletic director of the basketball program.''

title: THEATER: 'THE LONG JOURNEY OF POPPIE NONGENA'
description: The title character in ''The Long Journey of Poppie Nongena'' begins as a simple country girl and becomes an archetypal heroine of South Africa. Her arduous journey covers 40 years of her nation's history, sweeping through the riots of Sharpeville and Soweto and on to an indefinite but unpromising future. In its American premiere at the Cubiculo under the sponsorship of the Music-Theater Group-Lenox Arts Center, ''Poppie Nongena'' is an arresting documentation of the personal effect of the policy of apartheid.

title: THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' ON LONG ISLAND
description: CENTER MORICHES WHEN a snowstorm collapsed several greenhouses he had purchased, Russell Weiss, a commercial flower grower, figured he could build sturdier ones himself. So he did, opening a manufacturing plant in Center Moriches that is now selling greenhouses throughout the world.

title: Constance O'Brien Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donal Clare O'Brien Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Constance Nancy O'Brien, to Andrew Bryant Ashforth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Adams Ashforth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title:
GARDENING;
NOW'S THE TIME TO START SPRING CHORES
description: ALTHOUGH still a bit too chilly outdoors for relaxing on the patio, the season is upon us when we can get on with our gardening chores. The more we accomplish now, the less there remains to be done when warm weather arrives.

title: Of Vandalism And Child Care
description: While all the information in the recent article ''Schools Step Up Fight on Vandalism'' is, of course, true, concerning the personal heartaches, inconveniences and tragedies vandalism may cause, most of the solutions treat the problem from a negative aspect: catch the culprit, institute punitive measures and make the school an impenetrable fortress after school hours.

title: 'CORONATION STREET' COMES TO CABLE
description: LONDON ''Coronation Street,'' which is Britain's most popular television program by far, is coming to the United States - actually, for a second try at becoming as popular with American viewers as it is with Britons.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; How Much to Help Handicapped?
description: When President Ford approved the Education for All Handicapped Children Act of 1975, establishing their right to ''free appropriate public education,'' he warned: ''It promises more than the Federal Government can deliver.'' It may also have promised more than school districts can deliver, an issue that should become clearer when the Supreme Court decides the appeal of a Westchester school district from court rulings requiring it to provide a deaf student with a sign language interpreter.

title: The Nation in Summary; Houston Police Get a New Chief
description: The swift confirmation of Lee Brown as Houston's Police Chief was not much in doubt, despite opposition in the ranks. The question is how long he'll stay.

title: SOME ARE SWAYED ON CHEMICAL WAR
description: A number of scientists and military specialists say the circumstantial evidence that chemical warfare is being waged in Laos, Cambodia and Afghanistan is becoming increasingly persuasive. They also say the Soviet Union appears to be involved.

title: English Runner Betters His Road-Race Record
description: Geoff Smith of England, who attends Providence College, successfully defended the men's title in the fifth annual Perrier 10-kilometer run by shattering his course and meet record with a time of 28 minutes 40.1 seconds yesterday at Central Park.

title: The Mafia To the Editor:$
description: Ted Morgan's review of ''Sicilian Lives'' by Danilo Dolci (Feb. 7) contains some dangerous and misleading statements about the role of the Mafia in Sicily. Mr. Morgan writes that ''the Mafia operates like a Western version of The Tammany Society.'' To compare the Mafia to Tammany Hall, the New York political organization that delivered votes and found jobs for the party faithful, tends to perpetuate the romantic myths about the Mafia in recent American writing. No one should be under the illusion that the Mafia's greatest crime, like Tammany's, is municipal graft.

title: STRINGS: ATLANTIC QUARTET
description: Things were not as they appeared during much of Thursday's League-I.S.C.M. concert in Carnegie Recital Hall. A look at the program showed that the Atlantic String Quartet was to play works by Richard Hoffmann, Sheree Clement and Roger Sessions, and that the first offering was to be Mr. Hoffmann's three-movement String Quartet No. 3, subtitled ''On revient toujours.'' So, after three movements, one readied one's hands to applaud. But the quartet began to play a fourth movement, which sounded like an exact repetition of the first. It was true that they had been a little messy with it the first time through, but this was a curious way to make amends.

title: South African Frees 8 Whites In Detention Up to 6 Months
description: Eight whites were reunited today after their release from detention under South Africa's security laws. The eight, some of whom had been held six months, were released Friday and today.

title: RECITAL: JEWISH HERITAGE BY RIVKA GOLANI-ERDESZ
description: Rivka Golani-Erdesz's program Wednesday night in the Abraham Goodman House was not exactly a mainstream crowd-pleaser. Mrs. Golani-Erdesz is a violist, which already inclines her recitals toward the austere. And this was part of the Hebrew Arts School's Heritage Concerts series, so the program consisted entirely of 20thcentury music by Jewish composers.

title: NEW YORK SUES G.M. SAYING TRANSMISSIONS WERE FAULTY
description: The General Motors Corporation has been accused by the State Attorney General of having installed defective lightweight transmissions in some of its automobiles since 1976.

title: Fernanda Toueg, H.P. Young Wed
description: Fernanda Toueg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice S. Toueg of Milan, Italy, was married yesterday to Hobart Peyton Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hobart Paul Young of Winnetka, Ill. The Rev. Thomas deBree, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Friends Meeting House in Princeton, N.J.

title: THOUSANDS IN WASHINGTON MARCH TO PROTEST U.S. POLICY IN EL SALVADOR
description: Thousands of demonstrators marched and rallied here today to protest United States policy toward El Salvador.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IN DETROIT, KEEPING A JOB IS HARD WORK
description: Spring slouched into Detroit under hooded skies, but the economic problems of this area are too severe for the thoughts of many people to turn to anything more fanciful than finding a job if they don't have one, or keeping a job if they do have one.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE NEED TO REMEMBER
description: On March 27, 40 years ago, the deportation of Jews from France to extermination camps further east was started. There are worse dates to remember, worse places in which to lay wreaths and stand in silence. But it is a bit easier to grasp what happened on the smaller scale of France and in the context of French history.

title: Hoffa Pension Funds Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court has ordered almost $500,000 in pension money to be turned over to the family of James R. Hoffa, the missing leader of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The money has been tied up for six years while Mr.Hoffa's estate, the Internal Revenue Service and union officials argued over the size of his retirement settlement. Mr. Hoffa, who disappeared in July 1975, agreed to a pension payment of $1.75 million when he resigned while serving a prison term. The court ruling Friday upheld that sum, although the revenue service had contested it.

title:
Antiques;
A WHODUNIT BY A HISTORIAN
description: WATERBURY FOR almost 50 years, in spite of obviously different details of workmanship, almost any antique furniture found in Woodbury has been ascribed to a cabinetmaker identified as Elijah Booth.

title: PIANO RECITAL: ELISHA GILGORE
description: There were a number of interesting and unusual qualities in the playing of Elisha Gilgore, pianist, at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday evening, all of which contributed to a single impression: she had something to say, and said it honestly, expressively and with extraordinary grace. The recital, Miss Gilgore's New York debut, was devoted to music of Haydn, Beethoven and Liszt.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Stephen Burns Displays Trumpet Repertory
description: When Stephen Burns played the trumpet in his debut at the 92d Street Y Tuesday night he displayed not only sonic brilliance and technical accomplishment - though both were apparent - but as a Young Concert Artists Series winner, he was also a polished musician.

title: Taxing OPEC
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Crude Solution'' (March 12) and ''Quick, Put a Tax on OPEC's Oil'' (March 14), an import tax on oil of $5 to $10 per barrel was advocated as a relatively painless way of reducing the Federal deficit.

title: JOANNA S. BLUM TO BE MARRIED
description: The engagement of Joanna Sutland Blum to David Saul Jerison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Jerison of West Lafayette, Ind., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David Meyer Blum of Owings Mills, Md. and Water Island, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A May wedding is planned.

title: U.S. PRINTING OFFICE PLANNING 3,000 FURLOUGHS
description: The Government Printing Office plans to put half its staff on part-time furloughs without pay because its work has been cut as other Federal agencies try to save money by reducing the number of pamphlets and brochures they issue.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Boat Rocker
description: John Nolan Jr. campaigned for welfare director in the town of Burrillville, R.I., on the promise that he would take a 90 percent cut in salary. Once elected in November 1980, he found it wasn't easy to refuse $9,000 of his $10,000 pay.

title: ORDINARY FAMILY, WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: WHITE HORSES By Alice Hoffman 254 pp. New York G.P. Putnam's Sons.$12.95. By ANNE TYLER

title: U.S. Finds Nurse Shortages Continue to Affect Hospitals
description: The number of nurses in active practice has increased, but a persistent shortage continues to affect hospitals and other institutions, the Government has reported.

title: TAKING FULL MEASURE OF FAURE'S APPEALING TALENT
description: On Feb. 25, 1871, Gabriel Faure, along with his friends d'Indy, Lalo, Duparc and Chabrier, formed a Societe Nationale de Musique. This was one of the principal responses of France's cultural world to the humiliating defeat by the Germans in the Franco-Prussian War of the previous year. The society's formation was recognition that France had lagged behind in both the creation and recognition of a characteristic national music.

title: LOS ANGELES
description: Winning an Academy Award means more than glory. It also means hard cash. The rule of thumb is that winning an Oscar as best picture of the year will add between $12 million and $20 million to a movie's ticket sales. One of the major acting awards will bring an extra $3 million or $4 million. The distributing studio gets roughly half of that money, in the form of film rentals.

title: SUMMER SKIN CARE
description: By Jane Ogle

title: EL SALVADOR: KEY TEST
description: FAIR or fraudulent, the conduct of today's elections will be nobody's secret. El Salvador is voting in a goldfish bowl with nearly 500 foreign reporters and officials as witnesses.

title: The World in Summary; The Evidence on 'Yellow Rain'
description: The Reagan Administration tried last week to chase away the cloud of doubt over its repeated charges that Soviet troops in Afghanistan and Moscow's allies in Southeast Asia have unleashed toxic ''yellow rain'' against their guerrilla opponents.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Twilight Zone For 'The Star'
description: The Minneapolis Tribune and the Minneapolis Star may not be quite as different as night and day, but they are more different than they will be next month. On April 5, the morning Tribune will absorb the afternoon Star, its nominal competitor; and Minneapolis, like six other cities where the identical thing has happened in the last two years, will have one all-day newspaper.

title: Stage View; IS THERE A SHOW- OR JUST AMBIANCE?
description: At the beginning of ''Pump Boys and Dinettes,'' the popular country-rock revue on Broadway, the audience is asked to hold on to its ticket stubs for a post-intermission raffle. The prize is a packet of air freshener, and the winner gets to choose the scent of his choice, Christmas tree and skunk among them. The night I attended, the winner was a startled, maybe even mortified, middleaged woman. Unlike television game-show contestants, she didn't whoop it up when she won, and she seemed less than thrilled to be dragged on stage to choose her scent. (She opted for Christmas, when surely the whole audience, eager for a laugh, was pining for skunk.) But she was a good sport: Before returning to the seat with her prize, she smiled gamely to pose with cast members for a Polaroid snapshot.

title: SCOUT LEADER TRAPPED IN A NORTH JERSEY CAVE
description: More than 12 hours after a Scoutmaster became trapped while exploring a cave in this northern New Jersey community with his troop, rescue workers were still trying to free him, the state police said.

title: Dawn Radley, Richard Dana Jr. to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Otis Radley of Cape Vincent, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dawn Elizabeth Radley, to Richard H. Dana Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dana of New York and Washington, Conn.

title: Sports People; Canuck Coach Banned
description: In one of the stiffest sentences ever assessed in the National Hockey League, the league president John Ziegler has suspended Harry Neale, the coach of the Vancouver Canucks, for 10 games, including the Canucks' first five playoff games. The action was levied because of Neale's involvement in a fracas with fans at a game in Quebec City on March 20.

title: I.B.M.'S TYPEWRITERS MISS A STROKE
description: Armonk, N.Y. - I.B.M. dominates two markets - one is computers. The other one is the ubiquitous office typewriter. There, as in computers, the giant of Armonk is losing ground - not total dollar sales, it is true, but market share.

title: No Headline
description: Eric Gill (1882-1940) was a master designer of typefaces and lettering, an inspired illustrator and engraver, a sculptor whose work glorifies the inside of Westminster Cathedral and the outside of BBC headquarters, the architect of a light and lovely church, and the author of combative tracts on art, clothes, work and religion. He was a passionate Catholic but no angel stuck in the mud; he argued that his burning eroticism was integral to his religious life and his art.

title: BILLIONS FOR DEFENSE SPURS JOB RECRUITMENT
description: LOS ANGELES BATHERS on a crowded Southern California beach the other day heard a buzzing sound above them and looked up to see an airplane overhead trailing a sign that proclaimed, ''Hughes Needs Engineers.'' It was a sign of the times here, reminiscent of the region's aerospace boom in the mid-196O's.

title: CIGARS
description: To the Business Editor: There is on the side of the package of most American cigars, in tiny type, a notice far more daunting than the health warning on cigarette packages.

title: Lisa Townson Engaged to Edward T. Meagher Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Colfax Townson of Rochester have announced the engagement of his daughter, Lisa Colfax Townson, to Edward Thomas Meagher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meagher, also of Rochester.

title: BANGLADESHI SPEAK OF DEMOCRACY IN 2 YEARS
description: The army general who Wednesday imposed martial law in Bangladesh said tonight that he hoped democracy could be restored within two years and that political activity might be permitted again in six months.

title: Rutgers Crew Wins
description: The Rutgers varsity heavyweight crew, after trailing for nearly the whole race, passed Columbia in the final 300 meters and defeated the Lions by three seats on the choppy Harlem River yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: The National Job Outlook in High-Technology Occupations
description: Is There Really a Shortage of Engineers? By Elizabeth M. Fowler

title: Sports of The Times; The Fans Are N.F.L. 'Game'
description: IN its campaign for a new collective bargaining agreement, the National Football League Players Association's slogan is ''We are the game.'' But if that's true, let the players try to continue without the club owners and the coaches, and especially without those who, more than any other group, are really the game - the fans.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NINNY'S BOAT By Clive King. Map by Ian Newsham. 243 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $9.95. (Ages 11 to 15) By NATALIE BABBITT

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SONOMA
description: WALLACE TURNER is chief of the San Francisco bureau of The Times. BY WALLACE TURNER

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The machinery in place is thoroughly sound. I don't know if it will work on Sunday.'' - Richard M. Scammon, a U.S. observer for today's election in El Salvador. (16:3.)

title: CASTRO A NON-COMMUNIST, C.I.A. SAID IN 1959
description: Soon after Fidel Castro's rise to power in 1959, Allen W. Dulles, the Director of Central Intelligence, told a Senate committee at a secret briefing that the Cuban leader did not have ''any Communist leanings,'' according to a report released today.

title: CONTEMPLATING THE HEART OF THE NUCLEAR DARKNESS
description: The grotesque images of nuclear holocaust are often locked away along with other nightmares. Recently, though, in a spate of magazine articles and books, the public is looking the creature in the face. Last week's issue of Publishers Weekly carried a list of 130 nuclear ''fear books,'' most of them published in the last two years. Leading the literary alert is ''The Fate of the Earth,'' a series of articles in The New Yorker magazine, which Alfred A. Knopf will publish next month as a book.

title: Television Week
description: Low Budget, High Praise

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Noel Lester, Pianist On Hood College Staff
description: Noel Lester, a pianist currently on the faculty of Hood College, made his New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday evening with a program that paired sonatas by Haydn and Hindemith with Schumann's Etudes Symphoniques and a selection from the Etudes (Op. 8) of Scriabin. The opening account of Haydn's Sonata in E-flat (Hob.

title: HOBOKEN AWAITS ITS FESTIVAL
description: MONTH festival of more than 225 free historical, cultural and artistic events, capped by a two-day waterfront gala, will start here next Saturday.

title: Theater; GOODSPEED TO OPEN WITH 'DAUGHTERS'
description: EAST HADDEM THE Goodspeed Opera House will open its 20th season on Tuesday with ''Lock Up Your Daughters.'' The musical, which will run through June 12, was adapted by Bernard Miles from Henry Fielding's ''Rape Upon Rape'' of 1730.

title: TALKS ON CAREERS OFFERED TO WOMEN
description: ASERIES of five free evening seminars on ''Women and the World of Work'' will begin Tuesday, the Westchester County Office for Women has announced.

title: 13 Die in Peruvian Floods
description: Thirteen people died Friday in Cuzco Province as a result of natural disasters caused by heavy rain. Five people were killed by a flood in Cirialo and eight by a landslide in Ninabamba.

title: Nigerian Ambassador Denies Reports of a Ban on Imports
description: The Nigerian Ambassador to the United States today denied reports that his country had imposed a temporary ban on all imports because of decreased oil revenue.

title: Ellen Clark Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Clark of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Lianne Clark, to Fowler McCormick Stillman Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Brown of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: Batty Bombers
description: A tale of bats in World War II keeps reverberating as we hear about modern strategic weapons. According to American Heritage magazine, military researchers once spent $2 million - a lot of money then - to tie incendiary bombs to bats so that they could set Japan afire. A dentist in Pennsylvania sold President Roosevelt on the idea in l942. A top defense researcher thought the attack could demoralize the enemy. A Harvard chemist designed a bat-borne celluloid case for napalm gel and a 15-hour timer to set it off.

title: Student Exchange: Another Source
description: The recent article ''Student Exchanges Create Extended Families'' was most helpful in apprising students and parents of the enriching possibilities that can flow from international student exchange programs. It was especially effective in depicting the joy that prompts some host families to welcome international students into their homes year after year.

title: ROAD TO RECOVERY
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Kill 4 in India At Political Clash
description: Four people were killed when policemen opened fire to break up clashes between supporters of India's opposition Janata Party and the ruling Congress Party today in Ahmadabad, 275 miles north of Bombay, the Press Trust of India news agency reported.

title: RETIREMENT OPENS THE WAY TO SECOND CAREERS
description: EAST HADDAM THE man to see in town when there's a print or painting to be framed is a former director of public information for the Celanese Corporation. When a clock isn't keeping time, a former systems analyst for the RCA Corporation is available for consultation. And if chemical waste is seeping into the water supply, the man who can get action is a former detective with the New York City Police Department.

title: SOME JOCKEYS FACE STATE DISCIPLINARY ACTION
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board will publish a report this week that recommends disciplinary action against ''certain jockeys'' for their possible involvement in race-fixing at state thoroughbred tracks in the mid-1970's, according to high-ranking Board sources.

title: PROPERTY RIGHTS IRRELEVANT TO THE ABORTION ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Allison Kezer Becomes Bride of Leighton Lobdell
description: Allison Taylor Kezer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Kezer of Shrewsbury, N.J., was married yesterday at the St. George's bythe-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J., to Leighton Danforth Lobdell, son of Mrs. Phyllis S. Lobdell of Middletown, N.J., and Leighton M. Lobdell of Monmouth Hills, N.J.

title: COMEDY CLUBS? NO LAUGHING MATTER
description: CLUBS featuring comedians are booming in suburban New Jersey communities and becoming standard weeknight entertainment for many regular patrons, who say they are hooked.

title: 'HIGH PRIESTESS OF ANGST'
description: Margaret Atwood is a national heroine in Canada. People follow her on the streest and in stores, seeking autographs and wanting to discuss the characters in her novels - most of whom are intelligent, self-absorbed modern women searching for identity. These women also suffer greatly, and as a result, some Canadian critics have dubbed her ''the high priestess of angst.''

title: Robin Freiman to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Freiman of Saratoga, Calif., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Robin Lynn Freiman, to Aaron Lepold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Lepold of New York.

title: A NEW AUTOMATION TO BRING VAST CHANGES
description: SOONER or later, many experts think, most of us will have careers that involve high technology. Even those who don't design microcircuits or genetically manipulate bacteria will be working with computers or robots in their offices and factories. For a new type of automation is taking place, one that is expected to change the world employment picture dramatically.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
DANCERS LEAP FROM LAWN TO STAGE
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON BACK in the heyday of the M-G-M musical, all Mickey Rooney had to say to Judy Garland was, ''Let's put on a show,'' and presto, a nearby barn was miraculously transformed into a theater, complete with costumes and scenery rescued from attic trunks and hordes of fresh-faced chorus boys and girls. These days, especially in real life, things are more complicated, even for ''grass-roots'' entertainment. It requires long applications for state funds and months of planning to ''put on a show.''

title: LEARNING FROM PAST ERRORS
description: WITH three reactors at the same site, much of the preparation for any accident at Millstone 3 has already been done. Of the three plants, unit 3, which will not be finished for nearly four years, has been the cause of most of the emergency calls at the site recently, but they involved construction accidents, not radiological contamination.

title: The Region in Summary; Connecticut's First Round Goes To Prescott Bush
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s aides have said affluent, conservative Fairfield, Conn. was ''Bush country,'' and voters there proved it last week in handing Prescott Bush Jr. a shutout victory in the town's Republican Party caucus. That defeat behind them, Mr. Weicker's aides insisted that his campaign for re-election to the Senate was out of the woods.

title: GONE FISHING: CATCHING A GLIMPSE OF OTHER DAYS
description: AS green life renews itself, lengthening fragile buds on the forsythia bushes and piercing the muddy earth with a profusion of multicolored crocuses, I anticipate the first stir of flounder in Hempstead Harbor. While most of us on the dock are still burdened with heavy coats and hats on those first tentative spring days in April, we are lured to the water, knowing that all we can catch is the promise of warmer days and better fishing. To fish - with or without success - is joyfully to welcome spring.

title: CONSUMER RATES
'THEY'RE MAKING IT' ON LONG ISLAND
description: BETHPAGE AN entrepreneur is by dictionary definition an organizer, a person who assumes the risk of business ventures and who, by inference, is an achiever, a money-maker. While Patrick J. Iannotta, the president of Ecolotrol Inc. of Bethpage, acknowledges that he is all of the above, he takes pains to point out that he is not solely concerned with the profit motive.

title: AN ART TO POISON CONTROL
description: THE taxing routine of medical school, with its endless hours spent reading books on microbiology and bandaging wounds in the emergency room, has not dampened the creative energies of two young medical students who are responsible for a 30-second Disney-style animation currently being aired on television.

title: CONGRESSMEN SEEKING TURF THE EXECUTIVE CALLS ITS OWN
description: Soon after Representative Elliott H. Levitas came to Congress, he was visited by a group of Atlanta businessmen who objected to a new regulation issued by the Federal Trade Commission. They had tried to argue their case with a commission official, they told their Congressman, and the bureaucrat had told them to get lost. ''They were enraged,'' the Georgia Democrat recalled. ''They had no means of holding that man accountable, and they came to me angry and frustrated.''

title: New Jersey Journal
description: BECAUSE of the recent ''deinstitutionalization'' of state mental facilities, two communities, Asbury Park and East Orange, have several thousand ex-mental patients living in converted boarding houses. One way in which East Orange is dealing with some of the problems that could arise is by ''sensitizing'' its Police Department to these members of the community.

title: TRANS-ATLANTIC TANGLE
description: ERIC PACE is a reporter on the Business Day section of The Times. BY ERIC PACE

title: Work for Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SIX PARTIES in the SALVADORAN ELECTION
description: Following are profiles of the six political groups taking part in today's elections for a constituent assembly in El Salvador. The guerrillas and their leftist political allies have refused to participate. Christian Democratic Party

title: Leslie Herrlinger Becomes a Bride
description: Leslie Todd Herrlinger, daughter of Mrs. Richard Packard Rorick of New Canaan, Conn., and Edward Franklyn Herrlinger 2d of Cincinnati and Reading, Jamaica, was married yesterday to Lynn Gordon Bailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fargason Bailey of Laguna Beach, Calif.

title: HUGE ARENA BLUNTS ACCURACY
description: Houston opened its game against North Carolina today by missing its first seven shots. The first was blocked and the other six were missed from distances of five to 20 feet. Houston lost the N.C.A.A. semifinal, 68-63.

title: TRADE
description: Trade paperbacks are softcover books usually sold in bookstores and at an average price higher than mass-market paperbacks. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH THE MILITARY?
description: I take issue with Senator Hart when he states that the current Army concept of land warfare reflects the French post-World War I doctrine of attrition, and then goes on to state that only the Germans and Russians know how to exploit firepower and maneuver.

title: UTILITY REASSURING ON POWER RESERVE
description: NEWARK WHEN the state's Board of Public Utilities authorized the Public Service Electric and Gas Company to abandon construction of its Hope Creek II nuclear-power plant in Salem County, it ordered the utility to spend $25 million over the next five years on load management, conservation and co-generation projects.

title: R. G. Malconian, Sara Landers Wed
description: Sara Major Landers, an associate manager in the real-estate investment department of the Prudential Insurance Company of America in Stamford, Conn., and Richard Gregg Malconian, a vice president in the mortgage and real-estate department of Salomon Brothers in New York, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Melvin Schlacter.

title: Vatican Opens a Display of Art Restorations
description: For the first time, the Vatican is calling attention to the work of the many artists and artisans who over the centuries have preserved and restored its artistic properties.

title: Cedar Key
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CABARET Alberta Hunter, who has joined 99-year-old Eubie Blake as one of the geriatric wonders of the entertainment world, will celebrate her 87th birthday on Thursday at the Cookery, University Place at 8th Street. She will be doing what she has been doing since she renewed her singing career there in 1977 after a 23-year lapse - clapping her hands to back up her driving beat, punching home her lyrics for emphasis and using a vocal range that still carries her from a recitative style on ''If You Can't Hold the Man You Love'' through an emotionally-expressive rendition of ''The Glory of Love'' to a big, sweeping treatment of ''Without a Song.'' She will sing two energetic shows at 9 and 11 P.M., backed by Gerald Cook on piano and Jimmy Lewis, bass, just as she does from Wednesday through Saturday every week.

title: CHINA'S AIRLINE
description: To the Editor: The article on the China airline was a delightful and accurate report of travel in China today. As a postscript, I should like to recount an experience my husband and I had last October when flying from Peking to Xian.

title: 3 Comedy Series to Bow On NBC Next Month
description: TV has announced that three comedy series will begin next month.

title: Major Contract Issues Unresolved at A.M.C.
description: A weekend of contract bargaining was forecast today by the United Automobile Workers' negotiating council at the American Motors Corporation.

title: Donna Dempsey, Gordon Calder Jr.  To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Dempsey of Glens Falls, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Marie Dempsey, to Gordon S. Calder Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Calder of Bronxville, N.Y., and Londonderry, Vt.

title: VISIBILITY CALLED NO PROBLEM IN JERSEY AIR COLLISION
description: The pilots of a helicopter and a twin-engine plane should have seen each other before they collided above the Meadowlands Sports Complex in September, an investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board said Wednesday.

title: THE BUSINESS OF VANITY AND VICE VERSA
description: IT'S called ''Eyes on Tomorrow,'' and it's the story of mighty Procter & Gamble, the people who gave the world Tide and Ivory soap. Oscar Schisgall wrote it. Ferguson/Doubleday recently published it. Going through the obligatory paces, Mr. Schisgall, in a foreword, thanks Procter & Gamble kingpins for their ''recollections and the time so generously given ....'' He also might have thanked them for their money.

title: THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' ON LONG ISLAND
description: HAUPPAUGE IN a field where leading executives traditionally have backgrounds in construction or real-estate development, Jerry Krinsky is an anomaly. Not only did he lack such a background, but also he began his business career as a salesman for a button company with no particular intention of becoming what he is today: one of the most respected industrial developers on the Island.

title: The Present Absent On Language
description: THE PRESENT ABSENT

title: HOW TO DRAW A BUSINESSMAN
description: W hen I started drawing for The New Yorker, James Geraghty, then the magazine's art director, studied my pictures with a puzzled look. ''All your people look like stockbrokers,'' he said. ''I think if you were drawing Yugoslav fishermen they would look like stock brokers in fishing outfits.''

title: 61,612 WATCH HOUSTON LOSE
description: North Carolina, which has reached the N.C.A.A. final three times in 21 years under Coach Dean Smith without winning a championship, made it again today to give Smith a fourth chance at the title.

title: Miss Salholz Wed To Eric Gelman
description: Eloise Salholz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Simon Salholz of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday at the Harkness House in Manhattan to Eric Gelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Gelman of New York. Rabbi Samuel Geffen performed the ceremony.

title: ISLANDERS CLINCH TOP SPOT
description: After playing sloppily for most of the game, the Islanders beat the Hartford Whalers, 5-4, tonight on Mike Bossy's goal with 24 seconds left.

title: Frazier and Robinson In All-Star Game Today
description: Ricky Frazier of Missouri and Oliver Robinson of Alabama-Birmingham are among 20 players who will compete in the East-West college all-star game on Sunday.

title: Dominique Alfandre and Thomas Palmer Engaged
description: Dominique Alfandre, associate press representative of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and Thomas Platt Palmer, the academy's art director, plan to be married May 1 in Washington. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the bride-to-be's parents, Priscilla B. Alfandre and Robert N. Alfandre, both of Washington.

title: THE PERFECT AUDIENCE
description: In her new book ''Living by Fiction,'' Annie Dillard says that ''the most extreme, cheerful, and fantastic view of art to which I ever subscribe is one in which the art object requires no viewer or listener - no audience whatever - in order to do what it does, which is nothing less than to hold up the universe.''

title: NEWSPAPER ADS UP
description: A weakening economy did little to curb demand for advertising space in newspapers last year. Preliminary figures from the Newspaper Advertising Bureau show that revenues in 1981 hit an all-time high of $17.4 billion, up 12.3 percent from a year earlier.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Gas vs. Gasoline
description: When the drivers of police cars and other city vehicles in Stillwater, Okla., pulled up to the municipal fuel pump last November and said, ''Gas it up,'' they meant with natural gas. The city disclosed that it had converted nine police cars, five utility trucks and 10 garbage trucks to burn either the gas or - at the flick of a switch in emergencies - gasoline.

title: ARCO PICKS AN INSIDE MAN
description: LOS ANGELES THE oil finders, as they are known, are the very best of petroleum explorers. Poring through stacks of data, they have a knack for visualizing the contours of a subterranean reservoir. ''They have something for calibrating,'' as William F. Kieschnick, president of the Atlantic Richfield Company, put it. ''It is not just punching holes in the ground, or responding to a wiggle on a seismograph.''

title: CHARTRES
description: To the Editor: Three cheers for the article on Malcolm Miller, ''The Voice of Chartres'' (Travel, March 14) by Frank J. Prial.

title: ARAB FOREIGN MINISTERS SET A MEETING IN TUNIS
description: Arab foreign ministers will meet here next week to discuss the unrest in Arab territories occupied by Israel.

title: BRIEF CUT IN VOLTAGE IN MIDTOWN DISRUPTS PRODUCTION OF TIMES
description: A momentary dip in Consolidated Edison voltage on parts of the West Side Friday night disrupted production and delayed the distribution of yesterday's editions of The New York Times.

title: Personal Finance; TAXES: RANCHING, HOUSING, JOBS
description: THE following are answers to some recent questions from readers r egarding taxes. Q: I'm looking for a job in the film industry, and wonder if n ewspapers and magazines specificially tailored to my chosen p rofession are deductible. Do I need receipts? And what about other e xpenses like telephone answering service?

title: Gomez Stops Meza in 6th to Retain Title
description: Anatomically, Wilfredo Gomez of Puerto Rico was misdirected today, or at least he had little idea of where the lower abdomen is located. But it was no anatomy lesson the World Boxing Council's superbantamweight champion gave Juan (Kid) Meza at the Playboy Hotel and Casino.

title: COSMOS ERA COULD END
description: Carlos Alberto is back at sweeper and Giorgio Chinaglia continues to score goals for the Cosmos, but for the first time in five seasons the league's most glamorous team may have difficulty winning its division.

title: Medicaid and Medicare Changing Billing System
description: Medicare and Medicaid will adopt a new single billing form that could save taxpayers, hospitals and insurers up to $65 million a year, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Richard S. Schweiker, announced Friday.

title: William Tress Will Marry Rosana M. Roig on May 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Adalberto Roig Jr., of San Juan, P.R., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosana Maria Roig, to William K. Tress, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Tress of Rio Piedras, P.R.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
NATURE'S WAY
description: With spring finally sprung, it's time again to take to the great outdoors to commune with nature. And since the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts in Roslyn Harbor is situated on a 145-acre wooded preserve, it's a fine place to start this communion. At 1:30 P.M. today, from the Educational Center, the naturalist-photographer Richard P. Meyer will lead an ''interpretive nature hike'' through some of the acreage, following up the activity with a more passive pastime: at 3:30 P.M., a multi-image slide program, ''Variations on a Natural Theme.'' Both events are free. The center is off Northern Boulevard.VOCAL VARIETY

title: Theater Mailbag; THAT CALHERN 'LEAR'
description: To the Editor:

title: Gallery View; TO THE RESCUE OF THE FOGG MUSEUM
description: When it was announced on Feb. 1 of this year that the governing board of Harvard had canceled the long-planned addition to the Fogg Art Museum there was a colossal and well-merited uproar. People all over the country had knocked themselves out for the Fogg, which is not only a repository for great works of art but a teaching instrument of the highest quality. More than $21-million dollars had been raised by private endeavor over a five-year period. That figure was all the more remarkable in that the Fogg had been given a list of lifelong supporters of Harvard whom it was forbidden to solicit in this connection.

title: WITCHERY PERVADES A JAZZ ALBUM
description: The Art Ensemble of Chicago has been together almost 15 years now - a long time for an improvising band that takes risks at every performance. The group has always been proud of its broad musical range, which encompasses free-form gambits, mainstream swinging, polyrhythmic percussion pieces, deftly satirical rock and Dixieland, and other idioms that are not so easy to categorize.

title: WHAT TO CALL A BANK
description: The First Interstate Bancorporation announced last week that it was planning to franchise its name nationwide - something that it couldn't consider until last summer when it changed its name from the United California Bank. Many banks have been shedding their regional identities, to the point now where it's difficult to know who's from where.

title: STREAMS STOCKED FOR TROUT SEASON
description: ANGLERS will be happily climbing back into the numbing, 44-degree waters of Westchester's streams on Thursday. A few fishermen will even get in over their waders on the opening day of trout season, but the crush of anglers on some streams and rivers will be eased by the restocking of yearling fish that took place last week when more than 6,000 brook, brown and rainbow trout were hauled down from a fish hatchery in the Catskills and dumped in the county's waters.

title: FOLLOWERS FLOCK TO HEAR MYSTIC'S GENTLE WORDS
description: The late afternoon sun raked over the West Side to the hotel room on 56th Street, casting a lingering light. Jiddu Krishnamurti, the 87-year-old mystic who has outlived most of his early followers from the halcyon days of the 1920's, came into the room in a brown tweed suit and sat down. Under his long lashes his eyes were serene and he smiled as if to himself.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC

title: Miss Robertson To Be June Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. James F. Robertson of Englewood, Colo., formerly of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Ann Robertson, to Francis Xavier Flinn, son of Mrs. John Hanawalt of Huntington, L. I., and the late Harry J. Flinn Jr.

title: Correction
description: The chart accompanying ''Why the Microbe Makers Got Stung'' (March 14) misrepresented the stock activity of Biotech Reserach Laboratories. The company went public in March 1981, with an initial offering price of $6.25 a share. The stock rose to $29 a share and currently sells for $9.25.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Limitations Of Digitalis
description: Dr. Robert Arnold Johnson, a Boston cardiologist, wondered why digitalis sometimes didn't work for patients with congestive heart failure. He also wondered, Dr. Johnson said last week, why more than a few colleagues didn't share his puzzlement.

title: U.S. FARMERS SAID TO FACE WORST YEAR SINCE 1930'S
description: On many an agrarian tongue is the word ''depression.'' Farm sales, the liquidation of assets to pay off debts or merely keep credit payments current, are being held in record numbers, and bankruptcies and foreclosures have soared.

title: GUILT ADMITTED IN TOXIC DUMPING AT CITY LANDFILLS
description: A former plant manager has pleaded guilty to a Federal charge involving the illegal dumping of ''millions of gallons of healththreatening and hazardous chemical wastes'' into landfills in New York City.

title: No Headline
description: Julie Miron's John Casey was a three-length winner over Brasher Doubloon, and Top The Mark Stables' Fabulous Find, a longshot, was a one-length victor over In From Dixie in the split divisions of the $110,700 Westchester Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: MOROCCAN-FRENCH RELATIONS ARE WEAKENING
description: Relations between France and its former protectorate of Morocco appear to be seriously deteriorating. The problem stems in part from what Moroccans see as a French tilt toward neighboring Algeria, Morocco's longtime adversary and a key supporter of the Marxist-led Polisario Front, a guerrilla group that is fighting Morocco for control of the Western Sahara.

title: BEYOND JUDGE'S NARROW FUNCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: March 28, 1982 NONFICTION120: DUBUFFET. By Andreas Franzke.12 ERIC GILL: Man of Flesh and Spirit. By Malcolm Yorke. 30 THE ESSENTIAL EARTHMAN: Henry Mitchell on Gardening.

title: Theater; THE GOODSPEED IS BEGINNING 20TH SEASON
description: THE Goodspeed Opera House, in East Haddam, Conn., will open its doors for its 20th season on Tuesday. The first of three shows, which plays through June 12, is ''Lock Up Your Daughters,'' adapted by Bernard Miles from Henry Fielding's ''Rape Upon Rape'' of 1730. The score is by Laurie Johnson, the lyrics by Lionel Bart. Bill Gile will direct, George Bunt will be the choreographer. The cast is headed by Susan Elizabeth Scott, Carleton Carpenter, and John Remme, a favorite with Goodspeed audiences.

title: WONDERS OF THE FIELD
description: AMONG the wonder machines that the technological revolution of the l ast 15 years has produced for medical diagnosis are the following: CAT scanners: The CAT (computerized axial tomography) uses a c omputer and X-ray beams to produce a cross-sectional image on a s creen that looks as if the person undergoing the scan were cut into l ayers. CAT scans reveal details often impossible or difficult to seei n ordinary X-rays.

title: Music; LOOK AT NEW BATON OF THE SYMPHONY
description: ''IT was a situation with a lot of pressure,'' Martin Canellakis conceded, referring to his debut with the Westchester Symphony last October. ''I found the orchestra slightly demoralized, in the sense that they were without a leader, without a sense of direction, and yet at the same time I felt a wonderful response from the players, and we were able to establish a first-rate relationship in a very short time.''

title: BRIGHT SPOT IN INFLATION
description: The industrial world's decision to fight inflation is bearing fruit, despite its adverse effects on growth and employment. According to figures published in the most recent International Monetary Fund Survey, consumer prices in industrial countries rose at a lower rate in 1981 than a year before.

title: MEDICAL MACHINERY CREATES NEW CLASS OF TECHNICIAN
description: IN 1975, Robert Lechich received his bachelor's degree in biology from Manhattan College and started looking for a career that would enable him to use his scientific training. ''I chose ultrasound technology because it looked like a great field,'' said Mr. Lechich. ''There were so many job opportunities that I knew that I would always have an interesting, well-paying job.''

title: THE GRAND OLD SPA OF BATH RECAPTURES ITS HIGH SPIRITS
description: JAN MORRIS is the author of several books, including ''Destinations'' and ''The Venetian Empire.'' By JAN MORRIS

title: Postings; IRAN'S ENIGMA
description: It is an elegant, 35-story tower of dark glass and pink granite set on Fifth Avenue at 52d Street amid some of the world's most desirable property. Its neighbors are Rockefeller Center, St. Patrick's Cathedral, Olympic Tower and many of midtown Manhattan's most glittering retail emporiums.

title: MORE EVIDENCE OF A SLOWER INFLATION RATE
description: Consumer prices rose only two-tenths of a percent in February. Inflation has been curbed lately by the recession and a drop in oil prices. If there is another small rise recorded in March, the Government may save about $1 billion on lower cost-of-living increases in Social Security due July 1.

title: BEST SELLERS FICTION
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 2 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 2 8 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 3 4 23 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 4 8 8 THE DEAN'S DECEMBER, by Saul Bellow. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) During a deathbed vigil in Rumania, a college dean from Chicago realizes some truths about his own land. 5 6 9 MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $13.95.) Blackford Oakes's quest for a mole in the C.I.A. takes him to Russia. 6 3 8 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $14.95.) A woman caught between the clashing ambitions of two brothers during the springtime of this century. 7 1 THE MOSQUITO COAST, by Paul Theroux. (Houghton Mifflin, $13.95.) A rebellious Yankee seeks to build a Utopia in the jungles of Honduras. 8 5 19 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord.

title: Conservatives Gain In French Voting
description: Conservative opposition forces control 58 of the 95 presidencies of provincial government councils after two remaining office races today.

title: 14TH ST. UPGRADING DEALT BLOW BY LUCHOW'S MOVE
description: For six years, a community group called Sweet 14 has been struggling to change the image of 14th Street as a place for peddlers of discounts and drugs.

title: Vote Kills College Shot Clock
description: College basketball coaches, in a survey, voted overwhelmingly against using a shot clock in any form, Ed Steitz, National Collegiate Athletic Association rules committee editor, said today.

title: Rita L. Ungar Becomes Bride of Nathan F. Moser
description: Rita Louise Ungar and Nathan Frederick Moser were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbis Mordecai Waxman and Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: STAYING COOL IN A JACKET
description: For greater comfort on hot days, the best new suits, jackets and dress trousers have been cut for a slightly looser silhouette. Most of the jackets are single-breasted and based on conservative English and American prototypes; they have naturally shaped shoulders and their lines loosely follow the form of the body. The waist is slightly fitted, but not constricting, producing an easy, defined shape.

title: China's Airline
description: To the Editor:

title: Connors Beats McNamara
description: Top-seeded Jimmy Connors won a thrilling third set tiebreaker to overcome Peter McNamara of Australia by 1-6, 6-2, 7-6 in a semifinal match of the $350,000 Cuore Tennis Cup tournament tonight.

title: Jeffrey Riback to Wed Marion Beth Messing
description: The engagement of Marion Beth Messing to Jeffrey E. Riback has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Messing of Brooklyn, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Riback of East Brunswick, N.J.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH THE MILITARY
description: Senator Hart states, ''The Boyd cycle requires commanders with boldness, imagination and initiative. Yet, by and large, this is not the type of person being promoted in our armed services today.''

title: VIRUS LINKED TO HUMAN CANCER IS FOUND TO RANGE THROUGH WORLD
description: A virus, suspected since 1980 of being among the causes of human cancer, has now been found to be far more widely distributed in the world than had been thought.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE / PART 2 / MARCH 28, 1982
description: 51 Season in the Sun By George O'Brien Summertime is not only a time for easy living, it's a time for easy dressing. This year, men's-wear designers and manufacturers have aimed more than ever at comfort and coolness in clothing.

title: Connecticut Guide; A BOTTLE SHOW
description: Not all bottle clubs are precincts for after-hours carousing. Nor are ''dry'' bottle clubs necessarily patronized by teetotalers. In Connecticut, for example, there is a Jim Beam Bottle Club in Bethel where the brown glass containers shaped to resemble Mr. Beam are always innocent of bourbon and often over 100 years old.

title: R.D. Shepley, Miss Handy Are Married
description: Pamela Woodbury Handy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Parker Douglas Handy of Fairfield and Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Roger Draper Shepley, son of Mrs. William Henry Fenn of Blue Hill, Me., and Robert Gardiner Shepley of Salem, Mass. The Rev. David W. Good performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: HITTING PEOPLE WHERE THEY LIVE
description: FAMOUS New Yorker magazine cover shows the mental picture the average New Yorker gets when he thinks of his city in geographical relation to the rest of the world. There's the West Side of Manhattan, the Hudson River, a thin strip of New Jersey, then China.

title: Westchester Guide; CELEBRATING SPRING
description: The Yonkers Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation will hold a spring festival beginning with an Easter egg hunt, egg carry and egg toss at 1 P.M. Saturday on the grounds of Walt Whitman Junior High School on Shore View Drive. Prizes will be awarded, chocolate will be dispensed, games will be played and the No Elephant Circus will entertain.

title: The Nation in Summary; New Stop-Sign For MX Plans
description: That strategic ''window'' President Reagan has been struggling to close may be stuck indefinitely. In a unanimous vote last week, the Senate Armed Services Committee's strategic and theater nuclear forces subcommittee agreed to stop funding for the construction of MX missiles and their temporary deployment in existing Minuteman silos.

title:
GARDENING;
NOW'S THE TIME TO START SPRING CHORES
description: ALTHOUGH still a bit too chilly outdoors for relaxing on the patio, the season is upon us when we can get on with our gardening chores. The more we accomplish now, the less there remains to be done when warm weather arrives.

title: Airlines: Foul Weather
description: Before deregulation, the controller's strike, fare wars and the recession sent the airlines reeling, a traffic increase generally led to rising revenues. No longer.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART No Italian artist since the 18th century has enjoyed the reputation of Giorgio de Chirico (1888-1978), the painter whose long, dreamlike street vistas and disquieting juxtapositions of objects set the stage for Surrealism. In the so-called ''metaphysical'' paintings of his early years -1911 to 1917 - his intensely poetic imagination transformed the arcades and be-statued squares of Italian cities into eerie hallucinations of loneliness, and in other works he made clothing dummies, with strange postures and faceless heads, engage the viewer in haunting confrontation.

title: Dining Out; A MORE AMBITIOUS VENTURE
description: DANBURY BELLA ITALIA is a remarkable success story. In 1977 when it was reviewed here, it was a modest storefront pizzeria-cum-restaurant that performed culinary wonders in limited, informal space. Homemade pastas and refined and delicate sauces contrasted with unpretentious surroundings.

title: U.S. MILITARY INTERVENTION'S SORRY RECORD
description: To the Editor:

title: MIGRANT LABOR: WHY IT'S OFTEN INDISPENSABLE
description: With a bachelor's degree and two years of graduate study in agriculture, Wilbur T. Britt Jr. is among the best-educated farmers in this state. Yet five years ago, he opted for a system that has been condemned as modern-day serfdom when he turned to migrant labor to work the 900-acre farm he and his father run.

title:
Speaking Personally;
THE YEAR THE YANKEES WENT TO ASBURY PARK
description: EVERY February and March for nearly 40 years, I've been reliving the agony and the ecstasy of my first assignment as a young sports reporter: covering the New York Yankees' spring training sessions at the Asbury Park High School Stadium.

title: MUSTO AND 7 OTHERS ARE FOUND GUILTY OF EXTORTION
description: State Senator William V. Musto and seven codefendants were found guilty in Federal Court here tonight of charges involving extortion from a Hudson County contractor. The five-month trial was the longest in the history of the Federal Court in New Jersey.

title: The German Library To Be Published in U.S.
description: One hundred volumes of German literature and thought from medieval times to the present, edited by Volkmar Sander, chairman of the German Department of New York University and of Deutsches Haus, will be brought out in the United States by the Continuum Publishing Company. The series will be called the German Library and will include introductions by prominent American authors.

title: JENKINS DOES WELL BUT IS THAT GOOD ENOUGH?
description: It had been widely advertised as the watershed byelection of postwar British politics, but the outcome last week in the Hillhead constituency of Glasgow raised more questions about the future than it answered.

title: SHOULD THERE BE DEDICATED TAXES FOR TRANSPORT?
description: NEW JERSEY'S highways are the most intensively used in the nation. Its commuter rail service is one of the most extensive, with more than 450 trains operating daily, and its buses serve more than 250,000 riders a day.

title: DETROIT'S KIRK GIBSON: THE NATURAL
