description: LAKELAND, Fla. TURNoff Route 98 into Al Kaline Drive past the palm trees into Joker Marchant Stadium, and behold the phenom, the biggest and fiercest tiger on the Detroit Tigers.

title: John McCubbin And Miss Hubbell To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Hubbell of Hilton Head Island, S.C., formerly of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Louise Hubbell, to John Peter McCubbin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. McCubbin of New York and Hilton Head Island.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Medicine in The Marketplace
description: Lawyers do it, accountants do it, psychologists more and more do it -and last week, a Supreme Court decision in effect encouraged doctors to do it too. In a 4-to-4 vote, the Court upheld an order by the Federal Trade Commission requiring the American Medical Association to permit doctors to advertise, compete for business and enter into nontraditional financial arrangements which may underbid standard fees.

title: ENGINEER SHORTAGE? WELL, THAT DEPENDS
description: EVERYONE in the field talks about a shortage of engineers - the prime movers of the engines of high technology - but like weather forecasts, nothing is certain about it, not even that there is a shortage.

title: JANET GAYNOR RECALLS THE FIRST AWARDS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. BY STEPHEN FARBER LOS ANGELES

title: Sound; FINDING YOUR HEART'S DELIGHT AMONG LOUDSPEAKERS
description: The fantasy trip, begun here last week, assumed a windfall leaving me free to pick a stereo system without regard to cost. So far, the itinerary has covered just about everything except loudspeakers. That's where I have trouble making up my mind.

title: No Headline
description: Idle reader, fresh and fair Lazing in her Sunday chair. Holy Chaucer! What's that there! The artful stance? The careful hair? The pectorals exposed to air? It's J. Kosinski, chic and bare.

title: IN DEFENSE OF AN OFFENSIVE WAR
description: WHY WE WERE IN VIETNAM By Norman Podhoretz. 240 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.50.

title: POLITICAL CONSULTANTS' CAMPAIGN ROLE IS EXPANDING
description: As New York's statewide election campaign gets under way, politicians are relying more than in the past on campaign consultants, who are moving beyond their original roles as detached specialists in advertising, polls and mailings.

title: Fashion; A PREVIEW OF FALL FROM PARIS
description: Hemlines are definitely on the way up and, without being didactic about it, everyone agrees that shorter is better. Obviously, there are other lengths and a variety of pants looks, but the neighborhood of the knee is the departure point for the new heart-shaped silhouette that soars to the shoulders and then tapers back to the knee.

title: Article 026879 -- No Title
description: More than $1.7 million worth of cargo destined for Libya has been seized on officers under the Reagan Administration's recent embargo on high-technology exports to Libya.

title: ABORTION AFFECTS MEN, TOO
description: Pamela Black is a freelance writer who occasionally works as an art assistant for this magazine. By Pamela Black al Winslow and his girlfriend, Sue Leydon, lived together for about a year in an apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side. They had occasionally discussed marriage, but when Sue discovered she was pregnant, the subject took on new meaning. Hal was stunned. But he was prepared to stand by Sue and see the pregnancy through. Without talking about it in much detail, the couple tentatively agreed to marry and have the child. Hal describes the three days that followed their decision as a halcyon time, spent basking in the early summer sun and the glow of prospective parenthood.

title:
TELECOMMUNICATIONS MOVES INTO THE HOME;
LOS ANGELES
description: LAST month, 350 southern California households had ''interactive,'' or two-way, home-information systems installed by the Times Mirror Videotex Services Company, a subsidary of the corporation that publishes The Los Angeles Times.

title: MONEY PROBLEMS
description: UNTOLD MILLIONS By Laura Z. Hobson. 272 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.50.UP NORTH By Bettz Burr. 312 pp. New York: Seaview Books. $14.50.A GREEN DESIRE By Anton Myrer. 511 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: Jane Potter Affianced
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Jane Lyon Potter, daughter of Mrs. Sheila A. Potter of Longmeadow, Mass., and Ian L. Potter of Glastonbury, Conn., to M. Francisco Palomo, son of Dr. Carmen C. Carriga of Chicago and the late Manuel M. Palomo. An August wedding is planned. Miss Potter is a publisher's representative with Holt, Rinehart & Winston in Boston. Mr. Palomo is a lawyer.

title: THERESA GRENTZ IS IN SPOTLIGHT AGAIN AS COACH OF RUTGERS
description: Theresa Shank Grentz, who played on the Immaculata College team that helped to give women's collegiate basketball national visibility a decade ago, hopes to contribute a little more to sports history Sunday afternoon.

title: About Long Island
description: GARDEN CITY IWAS wrong about these suburban kids. For the last few years I have taught the newspaper business once a week to a protean collection of students at Adelphi University.

title: HOWARD BAKER TRYING TO TAME AN UNRULY SENATE
description: Midnight had passed, and the Capitol was all but deserted, the echoes of occasional footsteps reverberating on tile floors. Outside room S230, the office of the Senate majority leader, a dozen reporters clustered, awaiting word from within where a dozen Congressional leaders were in a deadlock on a major budget item with an Administration group that included James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff; David A. Stockman, the budget director, and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan.

title: PHILIPPINE EMBROIDERY
description: ALICE VILLADOLID contributes to The Times from Manila. BY ALICE VILLADOLID

title: LOS ANGELES
description: The actors and actresses who are mentally rehearsing their acceptance speeches for Monday night's Academy Awards this weekend can expect at least three things to happen if they win an Oscar: There will be more scripts for new movies in their mail during the next few months, probably a bigger paycheck for their next picture, and, at least briefly, an ebbing of the insecurity that hounds people in an insecure business.

title: Afghan Is Named Best In Bronx County Show
description: A slate-colored Afghan hound, Ch. Blu Shah of Grandeur, owned by Roger Rechler and Mrs. James Canalizo of Dix Hills, L.I., was named best of 1,808 dogs tonight at the 60th All-Breed Show of the Bronx County Kennel Club at Nassau Coliseum.

title: P.B.A. TRUSTEE PROTESTS L.I. OFFICER'S DRIVING ARREST
description: A trustee of the Suffolk Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has sent a letter to more than 500 of his fellow police officers criticizing three superiors for arresting a former association president on a charge of driving while intoxicated.

title: TAXING OPEC
description: To the Business Editor: Prof. Paul W. MacAvoy's ''Quick, Put a Tax on OPEC's Oil'' is an example of the sort of ''Ivory Tower-Managed Economy'' thinking that is responsible for many of our current insoluble problems!

title: NINTH GRADER AIMS FOR TENNIS STARDOM
description: DIX HILLS AT 7 A.M., with sunlight streaming into her bedroom, Jennifer Fuchs stretches her 5 feet 5 inches, stares out the window and says to herself, ''This is a good day to hit 200 backhands.''

title: ARISE, GREAT SLUMBERING MOWER
description: AHHH, the lazy clouds of spring stretched out and sunning themselves on a hammock of blue sky. The gentle twitter of a lonesome robin as he flies over a freshly ground garden newly sown with seed. The leafy urgency of the maple offering his wares to an unsuspecting noble cricket. Spring is the time when all wounds are carefully bandaged, all promises are dusted off and remembered, all dreams are made fresh and golden.

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE question is when does the New York State Department of Transportation get involved in the building of a war memorial? The answer is: when it builds a road near the Yonkers City Hall.

title: HOUSING PROJECT OWNER'S PRACTICES CRITISIZED
description: First came Herman I. Kraus, then Kraus Management, Kraus Enterprises, Kraus Security System, Kraus Maintenance and, when they all needed legal help, Kraus & Kraus.

title: 2 HELD IN KIDNAPPING OF 4-YEAR-OLD GIRL
description: A 4-year-old girl who disappeared 19 months ago from her yard here has been reunited with her family, and a woman from upstate New York and her son have been arrested in the case.

title: 3 TOWNS TO VOTE ON PLAN TO SAVE LAKE WARAMAUG
description: WASHINGTON ''IF we don't do this, we're going to end up with a frog pond,'' declared John A. Marsh, Washington's First Selectman. Officials in neighboring Kent and Warren share Mr. Marsh's sentiments.

title: NEW BOARD SEEN FOR COLLEGES
description: FOR almost a decade, state legislators, educators and businessmen have struggled with scant success over a variety of reorganization plans for higher education. This spring, barring a breakdown in a general consensus that Connecticut's higher education system needs to be more cost-effective and responsive to the future job market, the General Assembly is expected to approve a new, centralized governing board with broad powers, controversial tasks and responsibility over budgets and operating policy.

title: WHY THE CAR RENTERS TRY SO HARD
description: The Hertz Corporation puts fake reservation tickets in the racks behind its rental counters, along with those of its customers who have actually reserved cars. The tickets, written in bold black ink, bear such names as R. Reagan, H. Bogart, B. Bunny and rock stars like Ronstadt, Springsteen and Wonder. But there is a darker side to Hertz's humor: The slots are filled with phony reservations because the real customers aren't there.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 28, 1982
description: International The elections in El Salvador today might be ''the most thoroughly observed elections here or maybe anywhere else,'' an official United States visitor said. The United States Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, indicated to reporters that he was taking seriously the possibility that Roberto d'Aubuisson, a former army major, could win the election. He heads the Nationalist Republican Alliance and was described in a United States Embassy profile as an ''ultra-rightist'' and called a ''pathological killer'' by former United States Ambassador, Robert E. White, in Congressional testimony. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: ENGINEERING-SCHOOL SHORTCOMINGS LEAD TO U.S. LAG
description: THE story is told that when Congress passed legislation on automobile emission control some years ago, the first thing auto makers did in Japan was to hire 2,000 more engineers. In Detroit, they hired 2,000 more lawyers. The joke has some grounding in demographic and educational statistics. Twenty of every 10,000 people in the United States are lawyers, 40 are accountants and 70 are engineers. In Japan, the comparable figures are one lawyer, three accountants -and 400 engineers.

title: The Nation in Summary; NEw Orleans Keeps a Mayor
description: Now that he's firmly in the saddle again, Ernest N. Dutch Morial, New Orleans' first black mayor, is ready to carve a few notches. After last week's lopsided runoff victory over Ron Faucheux, a conservative white representative, Mr. Morial hinted revenge on city and state Democrats who opposed his re-election.

title: What's Wrong With the Military?
description: Senator Gary Hart cites an old sociological finding: that unit cohesion is important and that soldiers fight best for and with ''buddies,'' not for causes (''What's Wrong With the Military?'' Feb. 14). Hence, he reports approvingly that the United States military is now actively considering adopting a nonrotation system, to encourage cohesion.

title: Future Events; Springtime Galas
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. In Good Company March 31 - More than 300 business and financial leaders are expected at the St. Regis Roof for the annual benefit luncheon sponsored by the finance-industry division of the New York Foundling Hospital-Center for Parent and Child Development. Peter G. Peterson, chairman of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb and former Secretary of Commerce, will receive the division's achievement award for humanitarianism. He joins such former honorees as Donald T. Regan, Secretary of the Treasury; Willard C. Butcher, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank; John F. McGillicuddy, chairman and president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and Raymond V. O'Brien Jr., chairman of the Emigrant Savings Bank. Proceeds, which in the past have run as high as $95,000, will go toward New York Foundling's annual budget of nearly $27 million. While tickets cost a mere $200 each, luncheon guests have been known to swell the coffers by writing supplementary checks.

title:
Careful Shopper;
Winter Clearance On Clothing and Shoes
description: Intuition in Armonk is clearing dressy and casual winter clothing, lingerie, lounge wear and footwear to make room for displays of spring fashions. The store's owner is in Europe buying winter wares that are not ordinarily sale-priced, but here the savings can be dramatic on luxurious fabric and styling in sizes 4 to 12.

title: A THEATER BECOMES AN ARTS CENTER
description: PEEKSKILL'S 50-year-old Paramount Theater, which was once dismissed as suitable only for flea markets or a roller disco, is about to play a new role in Westchester's cultural life. Through the efforts of city officials, the Peekskill Area Arts Council and numerous volunteers, it has been transformed into the nonprofit Peekskill Paramount Center for Performing Arts. It will open in April with an ambitious spring festival of 10 events that includes such diverse fare as a Bluegrass Festival, the Eric Hawkins Dance Company, Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee in ''Inside-Out,'' a new production of Moliere's ''A Doctor in Spite of Himself,'' and a 1950's rock-androll concert.

title: Byrd Opens Re-Election Bid
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, has opened his campaign for a fifth term by accusing his chief Republican opponent, Representative Cleveland K. Benedict, and his conservative allies of waging ''a dirty'' campaign against his re-election. The 64-year-old Senator filed Thursday as a Democratic candidate, then said at a news conference here that the National Conservative Political Action Committee, which has targeted him for defeat, has ''no interest in West Virginia.''

title: IMPROVE THE SOIL WITH PEAT MOSS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- George Taloumis is a garden photographer and writer. BY GEORGE TALOUMIS

title: TOWN PLANS COURSE ON GUN CONTROL
description: A New Jersey community is handling the problem of gun control much differently from municipalities elsewhere in the country that already have announced their plans or endorsed ordinances.

title: JOB EXPERTS SEEK WORK-NOT ONLY FOR OTHERS
description: On the days checks are passed out at state unemployment offices, the lines always seem a bit longer and the people in them a bit more desperate than they were the week before. One reason may be that hundreds of people who used to be state-employed job counselors are now looking for work themselves.

title: A LATECOMER TO OPERA WHO LOVES IT NOW
description: Some conductors talk about the various hats they wear. Bernard Haitink speaks of shoes, and to hear him tell it, he would not willingly be separated from either of them: the one that he has worn for some time, or the other one, which is still fairly new. Two shoes imply two feet, and his are firmly planted now in the worlds of concert and opera. But it was not always so.

title: ANTI-U.S. SENTIMENT IS SEEN IN KOREA
description: The burning of the American Cultural Center in Pusan by unknown arsonists on March 18 - an act seen by many Koreans as the most serious anti-American incident in South Korea in decades - is regarded by non-Communist dissidents, moderate churchmen and other Korean sources as only the latest evidence of growing anti-American sentiment among radical, non-Communist activists here.

title: Faith, Hypocrisy and Federal Pay
description: Senator Jesse Helms wants Congress to reduce the pay of top Government officials - including members of Congress - by 5 percent as a ''demonstration of good faith'' in the new austerity. He says that so far he's heard nothing but positive responses from his colleagues.

title: OPERA: MARIA PELLEGRINI
description: The New York City Opera production of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' presented a new heroine Friday evening. She was Maria Pellegrini, a soprano from Italy who has studied in Canada and now lives there.

title: THOUGHTS ON HELPING N.H.L. UNDO ITS SEIGE ON ITSELF
description: THE National Hockey League, like a hunter caught in his own snare, finds itself trapped in a maze of contradictions over the perplexing issue of violence.

title: BIG DROP FORECAST IN BLACK STUDENTS
description: Black leaders in higher education predicted today that the number of black students enrolled in American colleges would fall drastically if Congress passed the cuts in Federal aid to higher education being pursued by the Reagan Administration.

title: PRODUCTIVITY
description: To the Business Editor: I suggest that Mr. Henrici create a third plot showing the output per dollar of wages retained (that is, after tax income to the worker). I haven't done this, but I wonder whether it just might show that the productive worker is in reality receiving less per unit of real output, while the enterprise is receiving no more, simply because the nonproductive (read ''government,'' or, if you must, ''public'') sector is drawing more.

title: Landmarks Hailed
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. HOLDS UP REPORT ON GLOBAL ENVIRONMENT
description: The Reagan Administration is withholding approval of a report on the global environment by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development because it objects to the report's proposals for governmental action to solve such problems as acid rain.

title: Council Lists Sessions Scheduled at City Hall
description: The City Council has scheduled the following public meetings at City this week: MONDAY: Committee on Consumer Affairs, 10 A.M. TUESDAY: Committee on Finance, 12:30 P.M. Meeting of the full Council, 1:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY: Committee on Environmental Protection, 10 A.M. THURSDAY: Committee on State Legislation, 10 A.M. Committee on Youth Services, 1:30 P.M. FRIDAY: Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections, 10 A.M.

title:
Photography View;
REFLECTING THE SUPREMACY OF NATURE
description: Since Timothy O'Sullivan, landscape photographers have had to face up to the natural world's hostility. O'Sullivan's 19th-century views of the American West served as evidence of nature's cataclysmic tendencies and helped dispel the notion that the world was organized by a benevolent dictator with man's interests in mind. Today we see the world as O'Sullivan did. For a time photographers of this century could believe, with T.S. Eliot, that the world would end ''not with a bang, but a whimper,'' but entropy no longer seems the problem. Even as we confront our capacity for nuclear suicide, the natural world goes on spitting and wheezing and reeking its usual havoc.

title: Richard Sues Doctors
description: J.R. Richard, the Houston Astros pitcher, has charged the team physician Dr. Harold Brelsford and three Methodist Hospital staff doctors with negligence involving the stroke he suffered in 1980 and has filed a medical malpractice lawsuit in state district court.

title: Minette Bickel Married to Peter Boesel
description: Minette Chapman Bickel, chairman of Preservation Action!, a national lobbying organization for historic preservation in Washington, was married yesterday to Peter Marsh Boesel, a vice president of the RepublicBank Houston in Houston. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert Holland at the Shadyside Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh.

title: Deaf Will Get Sign Aid At Opera 'Susannah'
description: The New York City Opera will present ''Susannah'' in a sign-interpreted performance for the deaf Tuesday at 8 P.M. Two interpreters will be on the left side of the stage. All available front orchestra seats are being held for sale to the hearing-impaired.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Poached Caviar
description: With imported caviar ranging to $400 a pound, the California Fish and Game Department reported a black market in local caviar in April 1981 that threatened the low sturgeon population in San Francisco Bay. An undercover investigation led to the arrest of six men and the seizure of about $25,000 worth of caviar.

title: WEST SIDE WATERFRONT PROJECT IS FACING A SERIES OF OBSTACLES
description: The future of the proposed Lincoln West waterfront project remains uncertain, even though the developer has agreed to the Koch administration's request that he postpone his plans for several months.

title: EUROPE IN BLOOM
description: To The Editor: The article "Spring Preview: Europe in Bloom" (Travel, March 14) was a lovely way to inaugurate spring.

title: SCHOOL LUNCH PROGRAM IN CITY GAINS PUPILS DESPITE U.S. CUTS
description: Despite cuts in the Federal school lunch program and early fears that many schoolchildren would lose subsidized meals, New York City reports that the number of pupils in the program has risen slightly since last year.

title: ANOTHER WOMAN GEARS UP FOR THE INDIANAPOLIS 500
description: This afternoon when the 28 men who have qualified for the opening round of the World Series of Indy Car Racing take the green flag at Phoenix International Raceway, one woman standing along the pit wall will be watching with particularly keen interest. Desire Wilson, a South African who is the only woman to win a Formula One race, will be racing against these drivers when the the Indianapolis Motor Speedway season opens in May.

title: Guilty Plea Entered in Effort To Smuggle Planes to Libya
description: A 34-year-old man has pleaded guilty and admitted that he conspired to smuggle 15 armed Cobra military helicopters from Texas to Libya and Iraq.

title: SALVADORANS VOTE TODAY IN ELECTION U.S. CALLS CRITICAL
description: El Salvador completed preparations today for what one official United States visitor called ''the most thoroughly observed elections here and maybe anywhere else.''

title: Franklin Reaches Final
description: Benjamin Franklin, the East Harlem High School that is closing after this semester, became the first Public Schools Athletic League Class A team to win a game in the New York State Super 16 competition by beating Power Memorial, 75-65, tonight. The victory moved Franklin into the championship game Sunday against Spring Valley High.

title: BEING JERZY KOSINSKI
description: The article ''Being Jerzy Kosinski'' neglected to point out that my mother, the late Mary Weir, was divorced from Mr. Kosinski in January 1966. DAVID WEIR New York City

title: HOBOKEN'S SCHOOLS CALLED TOO POLITICAL
description: HOBOKEN IN 1978, when the state's Department of Education required all school districts to give students Minimum Basic Skills tests, what almost everyone here already knew was documented: Hoboken's school system was a disaster.

title: Cuzco
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Journal
description: THE Republican caucus in Fairfield last Tuesday attracted an unusual amount of interest from the party candidates for United States Senate and Governor and from the news media because it was the first public test of the candidates' standing among rank-and-file Republican voters.

title: HAROLD TERKEL
description: Harold Terkel, producer since 1965 of the CBS radio program ''World News Roundup,'' died Friday of cancer at his home in Levittown, L.I. He was 64 years old.

title: Leigh Grant Sets August Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Barrett Grant of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leigh Grant, to John Antony Doumlele Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Doumlele of Richmond.

title: VERYZER HEADS FOR HOME
description: ISLIP IT has been a spring of mixed emotions for Tom Veryzer, a native Long Islander who was traded to the New York Mets by the Cleveland Indians in exchange for another Long Islander, Ray Searage, a pitcher.

title:
TWO NEW COMMEMORATIVE POSTAL CARDS;
Stamps
description: The United States is commemorating a great soldier of the American Revolution and a great explorer of the vastness of the American continent on two new 13-cent postal cards to be issued during the next week and a half.

title: BLENDING THE FLAVORS OF MEXICAN HISTORY
description: FLORENCE FABRICANT is a wine and food writer based in New York. BY FLORENCE FABRICANT

title: Janet Roll Becomes Bride
description: Janet M. Roll and Peter R. Wunsch were married yesterday at the Milleridge Cottage in Jericho, L.I. Associate Town Justice William Heil of Mineola, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: Article 018109 -- No Title
description: YONKERS DORMANT for 17 years and echoing its turn-of-the-century origins, Lenoir, the stately Orrin Wightman mansion in North Yonkers, has a new lease on life. It is a $1-a-year lease to be precise, and that is the sum the Yonkers City School District will be paying its owners, the County of Westchester, for use of the 30-room granite house with its sweeping views of the Hudson and the Palisades as the new Yonkers Education and Cultural Arts Center.

title: A DAY AT THE BEACH: IS IT ALL WASHED UP?
description: EVEN though it is spring, the beach is still a wintry monochrome. The sky is a white-streaked gray, the sand is covered with a light frost in the early morning and the sea is flat and dull, refusing to display its surging power. Instead, it sends half-hearted waves to nuzzle the shore.

title: A LITTLE LATE, RED BRIGADES ADMIT 'INFANTILE EXTREMISM'
description: The mass arrests of terrorist suspects that marked the 42 days of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier's captivity have slowed down. The chorus of suspects vying to confess and accuse their friends is rising in volume.

title: CANADIAN FEARS A CONTINUED LANGUAGE BATTLE
description: Yet another generation of language conflict may be in store for Canada, in the view of the man responsible for enforcing bilingualism in a country that often does not wholeheartedly accept it.

title: UPSTATE PRODUCERS OF MAPLE SYRUP TAPPING CROP
description: Lee Cole stopped his pickup truck on a back road here and listened to the gurgling of maple sap pouring from plastic pipes into a converted stock trough.

title: NEW JERSEY NEEDS EFFICIENCY, NOT MORE EFFICIENCY STUDIES
description: TRENTON

title: More Grits
description: To the Editor:

title: 28 Die in Mexico Road Crash
description: A bus collided head-on with a trailer truck on a twisting, rain-slicked highway west of Mexico City last night, killing 28 people and injuring 22, Red Cross officials said today.

title: Sri Lanka
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiat Chief Is Said to Improve After a Heart Spasm in Italy
description: Doctors treating Gianni Agnelli, the head of Fiat, the auto maker, said today that a coronary spasm he suffered on Thursday had apparently caused no damage to his heart.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Cutting the Budget

title: LET THERE BE NEW DELHI, SAID GEORGE V
description: INDIAN SUMMER Lutyens, Baker and Imperial Delhi. By Robert Grant Irving. Illustrated. 406 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $39.95.

title: Nets Lose 6th Time In 8 Games, 123-121
description: The Nets suffered a costly setback tonight in their fight to qualify for the playoffs, losing to the Detroit Pistons, 123-121, before a crowd of 14,230 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Cigars
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Curse on Cigars'' (March 14), a cigar industry expert was quoted as saying that ''Years ago, a man sat down after a meal and enjoyed a half hour with a good cigar.

title: 7 Hurt in W. 96th St. Fire
description: Seven persons, including a child, were injured yesterday evening in a two-alarm fire at a six-story apartment building on West 96th Street, the authorities said.

title: Lisa York Gill Engaged to Walter Gray
description: Announcement has been made by Seta York McCormick of Shreveport, La., and Raymond Browning Gill Jr. of Huntsville, Ala., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa York Gill, to Walter Evans Gray, son of Frank Biddle Gray of Montevideo, Uruguay, and Blanche Fleming Gray of Memphis.

title: The Nation in Summary; SEal of Approval For G.M. Contract
description: The United Auto Workers added another chorus to the popular ''Wage Concession Blues'' last week. By a 299 to 25 vote the union's General Motors council approved a new contract with G.M. that calls for wage cutbacks and benefit concessions that could save the company $2.5 million.

title: KOCH OF U.S. CAPTURES WORLD CUP CROSS-COUNTRY SKIING TITLE
description: Bill Koch of Putney, Vt., won the Nordic World Cup cross-country ski title today by capturing the 15-kilometer final event.

title: Ensign to Wed Helaine Gould
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald W. Gould have made known the engagement of their daughter, Helaine Gould, to Ens. Robert Peter Catalano, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Catalano.

title: SIGNING UP CALLAS FOR RECORDINGS
description: The late Walter Legge, a pioneer in the making of modern classical recordings, worked with major artists of his day. His widow, Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, has collected and edited his writings in a new book, ''On and Off the Record: A Memoir of Walter Legge'' to be published by Charles Scribner's Sons on April 12. The following is an excerpt from the chapter entitled ''La Divina'' - Callas Remembered.''

title: WOMEN THRIVE IN TECHNOLOGY
description: LAST August a 27-year-old engineer applied for a job at the Hewlett-Packard Company's Integrated Circuits Processing Laboratory in Palo Alto, Calif. Although she was five months pregnant, the engineer, Guner Ayter, was promptly hired and soon began working on a computer software project.

title: EASTER MUSIC WITH FRENCH ACCENT
description: CHURCHES around the state are offering a wide variety of Easter music this year, differentiated by the national origin, period and style of the composers.

title: Sequel To the Editor:$
description: In his amiable feature on my book writing (March 7), Edwin McDowell wrote, ''The sequel (to ''Cruising Speed''), scheduled for publication this fall as 'Atlantic High,' will be based on a week last November. ...'' No, no, no.

title: Judith Leichman Wed To Marc L. Herbert
description: Judith L. Leichman, assistant director of the speech and hearing center of Hofstra University, was married yesterday to Marc L. Herbert, a software engineer with Sperry Systems Management, a division of the Sperry Company in Great Neck, L. I. Rabbis Aaron Pearl and Carl Astor performed the ceremony at Temple Shalom in Flushing, Queens.

title: THE ACTIVE LIFE
description: Even the most sedentary of men has been known to get the warmweather urge to get out and do something. For those who are housebound in winter, the sun beckons to pursue a sport or an activity, even if it is only mowing the grass.

title: CHILEAN OFFICIAL IN THE U.S. IS SAID TO HAVE BEEN INVOLVED IN TORTURE
description: A Chilean Army colonel who was compelled to leave his post as military attache in West Germany five years ago after charges that he had participated in the torture of Chilean political prisoners has taken up the same post at Chile's Embassy in Washington.

title: A VERY LONG BUT WORTHWHILE WEEK IN SPACE
description: THREE seemed the charm for the space shuttle Columbia, which last week blasted off from Cape Canaveral, Fla., for its third test flight only an hour behind schedule. The launch was a far cry from the first flight, when the inability of onboard computers to keep pace with each other delayed Columbia's liftoff for two days; and the second, when oil surges postponed the mission eight days.

title: ELEGANCE RECALLED
description: Four years ago, when Giorgio Armani showed his fall 1979 collection, there were the supple leathers, the bold knits and the innovative sportswear shapes that were by then expected of a Milanese designer. But there was also a startling new look, one that signaled to the international fashion press and store buyers a course for men's wear in the 80's.

title: Q and A; Rules for Subletting
description: Question: I have sublet an apartment and was told that though it was rent-stabilized, I would have to pay whatever the landlord charged because I was a subleasee. Is this correct?...A.J., Brooklyn Answer: No. The rent a subleasee can be charged for a rentstabilized apartment is regulated. If you rent directly from the prime tenant and the apartment is furnished, you can be charged 10 percent above the prime tenant's rent. If the apartment is not furnished, there can be no extra charge. If you rent directly from the owner, he can add to the rent the vacancy surcharge allowed under the prime tenant's lease. Thus, if the prime tenant has a two-year lease that allows a 13 percent rise, the owner can charge you an additional 13 percent. If you think you are being overcharged by either a prime tenant or a landlord, you should file a complaint with the Conciliation and Appeals Board. 666 Fifth Avenue. You can also bring suit against the offending party.

title: HOLLYWOOD'S VIDEO GAMBLE
description: There is always turmoil in Hollywood. Big-budget movies like ''Dr. Dolittle'' or ''Heaven's Gate'' collapse at the box office, dragging their studios partway down with them. A blizzard buries the Northeast or a drought parches the Southwest, crippling January - or June - theater attendance. The extravagantly expensive $15 million remake of ''Ben-Hur'' in 1959 brings M-G-M $96 million, starting an avalanche of expensive epics. ''Rocky'' costs $1 million and earns United Artists $74 million, and every studio scrambles to make inexpensive movies about the ordinary guy. Filmways buys American International Pictures; Orion swallows up Filmways. A star is born in ''Superman,'' and 10 other movies about comic-strip characters are planned; a star dies in an icy ocean at midnight, and her studio and its insurance companies fight over finishing her uncompleted movie. A dozen films fail and the man who chose to make them is swept out of his baroque office and barred from the studio lot as though his lack of luck were contagious.

title: VIDEOTAPE IS BEING USED TO RECORD WILLS
description: METUCHEN AT A conference table nearly surrounded by shelves of lawbooks, William Hackett, an attorney here, reviewed the provisions of a last will and testament for his young clients, Mr. and Mrs. Alan B. Selzerman of nearby Edison.

title: D.A. Westenberg Weds Nancy Gooden
description: Nancy Louise Gooden, a promotion assistant with the Harvard University Press in Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to David Alan Westenberg, a student at the Harvard Law School.

title: New Jersey Guide; A HERITAGE LIVES ON
description: Although Jose Limon, the Mexican-born choreographer who was acknowledged as one of the greatest figures in modern dance, died 10 years ago, his heritage lives on in the Jose Limon Dance Company.

title: Film View; SPOTTING WINNERS IN A CLOUDED CRYSTAL BALL
description: This is what the late S.J. Perelman might have called sticking one's neck on the line. It's an attempt to call the Oscar winners before they're announced tomorrow night in an atmosphere that will mix the solemnity of the annual Nobel ceremonies in Stockholm with the cheerful bad taste of the grand opening of a shopping center in Los Angeles.

title: The World in Summary; The Provinces Send a Message
description: From Napoleon to Valery Giscard d'Estaing, French leaders have regarded the provinces as politically unreliable and governed them accordingly, through departmental prefects that took orders from Paris. President Francois Mitterrand thought otherwise, but last week his plans for decentralizing power seemed to be boomeranging.

title: Texas Treasurer Indicted
description: State Treasurer Warren G. Harding has been indicted on two felony counts of official misconduct.

title: Art View; WHEN MODERNISM BECAME ORTHODOXY
description: The time has come to cast a backward glance. It was in the fall of 1965 that this writer began contributing his regular commentaries on the current art scene to the columns of this paper, and with the present article he brings his tenure as the art critic of The Times to a close. It therefore seems an appropriate moment to re-examine this very turbulent period in the history of our artistic affairs.

title: WHERE TO HEAR SOUNDS OF EASTER
description: CHURCHES countywide will offer a wide variety of Easter music this year, featuring music of different cultures, period pieces and personal composing styles. A school that has been gaining in popularity recently is the French, particularly the ''Impressionists,'' so called because they were contemporaries of the Impressionist painters of the late 19th and early 20th centuries and, like them, explored new directions.

title: Jane F. Gaertner Wed To Neil J. Philipson
description: Jane F. Gaertner, manager of events for the Foreign Policy Association in New York, was married yesterday to Neil J. Philipson, a freelance television associate director.

title: Mailbox; No Substitute For Race Track
description: To the Sports Editor: Bravo to Gloria Glasser's commentary on off-track betting (''Betting on Horses Without Names in Races You Can't See,'' The New York Times, March 21, 1982).

title: IT'S TIME TO PLANT THE BROAD BEANS
description: Sooner or later it happens to every gardener-beans are planted during a warm spell in spring, the weather turns wet and cold, the beans rot. For the impatient who want to plant beans soon, there is one answer: favas, or broad beans as they are called in England. These beans can and should be planted now or in April because they grow best when planted early.

title: TWO BRITONS RACE THE SUN TO THE NORTH POLE
description: Two British explorers are pressing toward the North Pole in a race to get there and off the ice before the spring thaw makes travel impossible.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE ESSENTIAL EARTHMAN Henry Mitchell on Gardening. By Henry Mitchell. 244 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $12.95.

title: INCREASE AMTRAK'S SUBSIDY
description: Amtrak, America's nationwide passenger-train network, needs its Federal operating subsidy of $788 million increased and restructured. This would put it on an equal footing with its air and highway competition.

title: Travel Advisory; NORDIC HERITAGE AND WESTERN WAGONS
description: Routes to Roots in Scandinavia

title: Sports of The Times; Jimmy Black's Mission
description: THE first time Jimmy Black met Dean Smith was in the family's apartment in the Bronx. ''I really was more interested in getting outside to play,'' Black recalls. ''But later that night my mother told me she liked Coach Smith more than the others.''

title: THE EXQUISITE AGONY OF LIVING IN MANHATTAN
description: THE woman is talking. The doctor is taking notes. ''I live in an apartment the size of my high school locker,'' she i s saying. ''The garbage trucks outside my window at 3 A.M. sound l ike an accident at Indian Point. The super won't fix anything, and m y rent is $600 a month. A methadone clinic is moving in downstairs. Y esterday, I saw a beautiful big apartment in Brooklyn, yet somehow Ic an't bring myself to move.''

title: CABLE TV: ROOM ON GROUND FLOOR
description: IN many fields, hiring freezes, layoffs and few promotions are the rule rather than the exception. But not in cable television. The cable industry is growing at a rapid rate, and career opportunities are many and varied.

title: Chess; FIGHTING A HOLOCAUST
description: ''Meet fire with fire,'' goes the old saying, but there are times when one is lucky just to quench it with water or anything else available. That's how Lev Alburt felt after his sixth-round game in the Reykjavik International Tournament.

title: AN INSTRUCTIVE SUCCESS STORY
description: LAST WALTZ IN VIENNA The Rise and Destruction of a Family, 1842-l942. By George Clare. 272 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.50.

title: FARMLAND MAY BECOME PARK
description: OLDWICK IN A move that surprised many, the Hunterdon County Board of Chosen Freeholders has saved a farm from possible conversion into a housing development by agreeing to purchase the necessary land for a Green Acres park.

title: REGGAE: THE THIRD WORLD AT THE RITZ
description: If the syncopated pulse of Jamaican reggae music eventually replaces rock rhythm as the dominant beat of American pop, one reason will be that groups like Third World, the Jamaican-American sextet that played the Ritz on Thursday, has convincingly demonstrated its versatility as an all-purpose pop rhythm.

title: The World in Summary; General Steps In In Bangladesh
description: In its 11 years as a nation, Bangladesh has had two political strongmen and many who wanted to be. The latest contender, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the army chief of staff, seized power last week, deposing an elected civilian President, Abdus Sattar.

title: Danceview; THE INNOVATIONS OF MARTHA HILL
description: On Friday, the New York University Presidential Citation will be awarded to Martha Hill at a ''Gala Banquet'' that, with a benefit dance concert, ends a weeklong celebration of ''50 Years of Dance in Education'' at the university. It is difficult to believe that anyone in American dance does not know who Martha Hill is, but since she is often on juries that make awards to others, it is only fitting that time be taken out, again, to honor her own achievements.

title: U.C.L.A. Sets 2d Mark and Wins Title
description: The U.C.L.A. team broke the American record in the 400-yard freestyle relay for a second time tonight and lifted the Bruins to the team title in the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's swimming and diving championships.

title: Music; AN ARRAY OF LOCAL AND GUEST TALENT
description: IT is flattering to note that more and more artists of international repute are including Connecticut cities among their touring ports of call, but more gratifying still is the fact that the state has such a rich array of resident musicians. In fact, we can go right through the week with major offerings by local artists and organizations.

title:
Westchester Youth;
EFFORTS MADE TO HELP POTENTIAL SUICIDES
description: FOUR adults were needed to restrain a suicidal 4-year-old who intended to take her life by jumping out a window. Her goal was to join her parents, who had recently died.

title: Good Bookings
description: S everal Chicago hotels are giving guests the opportunity of dipping into books about the city and books written by local authors. They have set up libraries of the volumes in drawing rooms and stocked the bookshelves in guests' rooms.

title: Headliners; Inside Le Monde
description: Two years of squabbling over who should run Le Monde has perhaps made France's leading newspaper somewhat less leading. Advertising is down, costs are soaring, circulation has not picked up and staff members say uncertainty has crept into the news columns.

title: PUNCH A TIME CLOCK? NOT FOR SCHOLARS, THANK YOU
description: In 1815, President James Madison retained a Swiss surveyor, Ferdinand Rudolph Hassler, to chart the coast of the United States - and then hired several accountants to chart Hassler. The surveyor responded with exasperation. ''Subjection of my expenditures to the control of a final account,'' he wrote to his employer, ''would subject my whole existence to the control of accounting officers, who, by their absence from the work, cannot possibly have any idea of its incidences.''

title: About Westchester
description: THE time: 10 o'clock on a Friday night. The place: a large, damp field, almost a marsh, ringed by tall trees. The sky is stippled with stars; a big, pale moon is rising. Nearby are three houses; through their windows shines a dull yellow glow.

title: Headliners; Two-to-Ten in the Corner?
description: Perhaps some Gainesville, Fla. authority will decide that Nancy Jo Burch was too young to know what she was doing last month, when she was charged with bloodying a schoolmate's nose. If not, the six-yearold could be sentenced to grow up in jail.

title: WHY L.I. HAS A STAKE IN QUEENS SUBWAY LINES
description: DURING the decade of the 1970's, for the first time in its history, the New York region stopped growing. In fact, the region's population receded during those years from its peak of 19.9 million in 1972 to 19.2 million at the end of the decade.

title: BRIDGE STARS WIN VANDERBILT TEAMS
description: The premier event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championship, the Vanderbilt knockout teams, ended here last night in a comfortable victory for a squad of stars headed by Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City. His teammates were Eddie Wold of Houston, Mike Passell and Jim Jacoby of Dallas, Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind., and Jeff Meckstroth of Columbus, Ohio.

title: THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' ON LONG ISLAND
description: KINGS PARK ''IF someone had told me years ago that I'd be heading up a business, I would have said, 'Are you crazy? I should be home cooking pasta,' '' said Sally Ann Slacke. Although Mrs. Slacke, president of Slacke Test Boring Inc. in Kings Park, always knew that she was a hard worker and might not do badly in a popularity contest, what she didn't know was where her qualities could take her. Could they transform her from ''Mrs. Inside'' (receptionist, typist and secretary) to the chief operating officer of a business operating in a traditionally male-dominated world of architects, engineers and builders?

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WITH ticket sales ''way ahead'' of last year, according to Howard Grant, general manager, the Long Island Philharmonic hopes to net more than $125,000 from Fiesta Espanola, its third annual ball, slated for Saturday at the Colonie Hill in Hauppauge.

title: Postings; SHINGLE STYLE SHOPPING ROW
description: The surf is a distant whisper and Atlantic breezes caress the dunes and scrub pine, carrying a tang of salt air through the Village of East Hampton, L.I. It is a timeless setting of saltbox houses and beach mansions, of cedar shingles that long ago weathered to silvery gray.

title: TARGET A FREEZE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMERS: A KEY TO RECOVERY?
description: While many analysts say the recession has not yet hit bottom, some evidence exists that the worst of the decline may be over, and that a recovery of sorts is taking shape.

title: CANCER RATE SPURS ANXIETY IN INDUSTRIAL BAY AREA
description: A high rate of lung cancer among white males in industrialized areas of Contra Costa County here has aroused alarm among residents and resulted in a state-financed study to determine the causes.

title: Ohio Declared Disaster Area
description: President Reagan has designated Ohio a major disaster area as a result of severe storms and flooding that began March 12 and caused extensive property damage, the White House said today. His decision means Federal aid will be made available to eligible disaster victims.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY BREEDS NEW ENTERPRISES
description: NEW career opportunities in genetic engineering, or biotechnology, will emerge over the next decade both in the science and industry, according to experts, but many of the openings may be in areas only indirectly related to biology.

title: AN ART WITH NO ART HISTORY IN IT
description: DUBUFFET By Andreas Franzke. Translated by Robert Erich Wolf. Illustrated. 282 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $95.

title: ORVIETO ACTS TO SAVE ROCK THAT HOLDS IT UP
description: This famous hilltop fortress, whose cathedral, narrow alleys, towers, restaurants, churches, palaces and wine have made it a tourist center, is fighting to keep the ground on which it stands from crumbling into the Umbrian plains below.

title: Topics; Hidden Assets
description: Moneyball

title: Oxford Oarsmen Defeat Cambridge
description: For the seventh straight year, Oxford University triumphed over Cambridge in the ''The Boat Race,'' which was held for the 128th time today along the 4 1/4-mile Thames River course from Putney Bridge to Mortlake.

title: A Public Utility Agency
description: WITH Proposition 1 in Tuesday's referendum, county voters will be deciding for the second time in 28 months whether they want to allow the county to set up a public electric-utility agency. The first time, in 1979, the voters said no. This time, proponents say there are important differences, and they predict that the vote will be favorable.

title: Headliners; Nice Try
description: Followers proclaim his divinity but, his lawyers say, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon won't win any popularity contests. In fact, they argued in Federal District Court in Manhattan last week, a poll they commissioned found the 61-year-old Korean evangelist was disliked only slightly less than the late Jim Jones, leader of the People's Temple.

title: No Headline
description: Undefeated Jeff Chandler used a powerful inside attack today to knock out Johnny Carter in the sixth round and retain the World Boxing Association bantamweight championship.

title: No Headline
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. FOOTNOTES There are two new titles on the hard-cover fiction list (''The Mosquito Coast'' and ''Happy to Be Here'') and one new runner-up, Wilbur Smith's ''Flight of the Falcon,'' which concerns the adventures of a beautiful lady missionary on the Dark Continent. Mr. Smith's ''The Delta Decision,'' a best seller in its original, cloth edition, is now on the mass paperback list.

title: The Region in Summary; On the L.I.R.R., U.S. Rules Apply
description: The labor peace that seems to have broken out between New York City transit workers and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority shows no sign of spreading to the suburbs. With contract talks between the agency and employees of the Long Island Rail Road at a standstill, the United States Supreme Court last week affirmed the workers' right to strike.

title: Miss Atkins, S.A. Barrand Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Franklin Atkins of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Wrisley Atkins, to Stephen Ayers Barrand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Percival Barrand of Ridgewood, N.J.

title:
Economic Affairs;
THE NONSENSE AMENDMENT
description: IN the near future Congress might, with the support of the A dministration, propose a constitutional amendment to the states thata ppears to require a balanced budget.

title: Postings; CLASSROOMS INTO CONDOS
description: For seven decades it was the pride of Tenafly, N.J., a red-stone school with brick arches and portico, on 3.4 wooded acres. The land at West Clinton Avenue and Tenafly Road and money for construction were donated in 1906 by John Hull Browning, president of the Northern New Jersey Railroad and a former Tenafly Mayor.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: To Return Home

title: The Case for College Aid
description: I read Michael I. Sovern's article ''The Case for Keeping U.S. Aid to Colleges'' (Feb. 7) with interest and also with a mixture of horror and anger. As the parent of two sons in professional and graduate schools, and a third who is an undergraduate student, I realize that the only way they will be able to pursue their educations now will be for my husband and me to deplete what we have managed to save during our entire married life.

title:
GARDENING;
NOW'S THE TIME TO START SPRING CHORES
description: ALTHOUGH still a bit too chilly outdoors for relaxing on the patio, the season is upon us when we can get on with our gardening chores. The more we accomplish now, the less there remains to be done when warm weather arrives.

title:
In New Jersey;
A HISTOTIC DISTRICT DRAWS BUYERS
description: ''T HE local liquor store has reduced its inventory of Thunderbird and now carries French wine.'' says Lawrence Perlaki, vice president of Joseph A. Del Forno Real Estate in Jersey City, by way of describing how a historic district designation has changed the Hamilton Park area in just a few years.

title: JAZZ: SIMONS QUINTET
description: The Bill and George Simon Quintet, a confluence of part-time jazz musicians and professionals, celebrated its first anniversary of Wednesday twilight jam sessions at Eddie Condon's, 144 West 54th Street, this week, with a gala performance that brought a stream of jazz celebrities to the club.

title: MT. OLIVE MAY LOSE LIBRARY
description: MOUNT OLIVE TOWNSHIP IN THE mid-1970's, Jane Israel led a group of fellow Mount Olive residents in founding the first public library here and, in 1979, also helped win township approval to expand it.

title:
Numismatics;
NEW MEDAL FROM IRELAND HONORS JAMES JOYCE
description: Although St. Patrick's Day is past, plenty of special doings still lie ahead in Ireland, where the late James Joyce is now being honored on the 100th anniversary of his birth. The famed Irish author will be lionized all year long in a series of special events, which includes issuing an important numismatic memento: a commemorative medal that will be put out by a prominent Dublin firm.

title: SPRING SKIING EAST AND WEST
description: CLIFFORD D. MAY is an editor on the New York Times Magazine. BY CLIFFORD D.MAY

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
POLISH MIME, NOW ON L.I., SHARES SECRETS OF HIS SKILLS
description: STONY BROOK ''WHEN you act on stage,'' said 43-year-old Rajmund Klekot, ''the psychology creates your body. You must recollect the experiences of your life. This sensitivity is your base; later you create your world from the imagination.''

title:
Antiques;
SHOW REFLECTS CHANGES IN BERGEN
description: SADDLE RIVER ALWAYS a delightful community of winding roads, farmhouses and fine country homes, the Bergen County town of Saddle River lives on the fringe of change. Nearby Woodcliff Lake and Montvale have added corporate headquarters, hotels and shopping malls, all of which have led to an influx of the busy and wealthy to the area.

title: THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' ON LONG ISLAND
description: MELVILLE IN five years, the bright color, visual effects and sharp resolution of Chyron electronic graphics have taken over the television screen. There is hardly a burst of letters or a posting of statistics that does not spring from a Chyron keyboard.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Capital reading. How's business? Ask that question of booksellers in most parts of the country nowadays and you're apt to see long faces and hear laments about inflation and high unemployment and the soaring cost of books.

title: MISSES NAVRATILOVA AND HANIKA IN FINAL
description: Wendy Turnbull's roller-coaster ride in the $300,000 Avon tennis championships ended yesterday when Sylvia Hanika beat her in a third-set tiebreaker for a berth against Martina Navratilova in today's final.

title: MARTIAL LAW HAS IMPOSED A TONE, NOT A DIRECTION
description: Three and a half months after the onset of martial law, Poland seems to be a different country. A society that was opening up in every area has turned inward and backward, fostering disillusionment, suspicion and black humor.

title: THE SPECIAL HAZARDS OF NEW YORK'S GOLF COURSES
description: ON his way to winning the Doral-Eastern Open last month, Andy Bean was faced with the problem of hitting an approach shot under a lowlimbed tree. Bean, in deference to executing a full golf swing to avoid hitting the limb on his backswing, elected to abbreviate his stroke and ''punch'' the ball to the pin. During the same tournament, Jack Nicklaus found himself facing a lie that was partially submerged under water. Television viewers watched and gallery spectators applauded as Nicklaus, sans shoes and socks, stroked a perfect shot five feet from the stick. Both golfers overcame the usual man-made traps and nature's hazards that confront every golfer during a round of golf.

title: Sunset Park Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Garbage Tax District
description: ''SHALL the resolution of the county authorizing the establishment of Refuse Disposal District No. 1 be approved?'' Voters answering that question Tuesday in 35 municipalities will also settle the issue of who will pay how much to operate the first regional plant in the county that will produce electricity by burning garbage.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Charles Abramovic Plays Piano Recital
description: In Charles Abramovic's March 20 at Carnegie Recital Hall, the pianist proved to be an intelligent and committed musician with a polished technique; but a lack of musical concentration and a few pianistic mannerisms prevented the performances from being fully satisfying.

title: WHERE ARE THE PEOPLE FOR SCHOOL BOARDS?
description: FOR quite some time now, I have been wondering why it is often difficult to get people to run for membership on local school boards in Westchester. Why the dearth of volunteers for this important civic job in a county where political and social activism appears strong?

title: CREATIVE ARTS PROGRAM HELPS 170
description: More than 170 New York artists have received $3,500 to $6,000 each as winners of 1981-82 Creative Arts Public Service Program fellowships.

title: North Stars 6, Bruins 5
description: BOSTON (AP) - Ken Solheim got his fourth goal of the season with 1:55 left as Minnesota (35-21-20) clinched first place in the Norris Division.

title: Politics; SIMON THE NEXT SENATOR?
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN, who has mailed out more than 100 letters seeking advice on whom he should appoint to succeed former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., has been receiving unsolicted pressure from Washington over the appointment.

title: CHINA'S AIRLINE
description: To the Editor: The article ''Tales of a Flying Paper Tiger'' was amusing, but I would like to share a somewhat different experience. In May 1981, on that flight from Peking to Urumqi we hadwe had a packaged-tray meal of sliced cold meats with cucumber and pickle as an appetizer, hot chicken and rice, peas, potato salad, a fresh tomato, a roll and a choice of beer or tea.

title: Topics; HIDDEN ASSETS; Kimilsungism
description: We are obligated to The Economist for the remarkable news about the supernatural gifts claimed for Kim Il Sung, the ruler of Communist North Korea. Mr. Kim can evidently confound material laws and make the very waters dance to his will.

title: LAND TRUSTS MAY COMBINE RESOURCES
description: FOR two decades, conservation-minded residents have been forming private, nonprofit organizations to acquire and preserve the state's diminishing open spaces. These land trusts, as they are called, have operated independently of one another and out of the public eye. But recent cutbacks in Federal conservation programs have inclined some of the trusts to explore ways of cooperating with each other to maximize their efforts.

title: PRODUCTIVITY
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Henrici says that since his measure of dollars-of-output-perdollar-of-compensation has been essentially stable over the years, we can conclude that in respect to ''productivity in economic ...terms,'' the nation has ''maintained a surprisingly even keel.'' Nonsense.

title: Anthony Wins, 269-235, In a Pro Bowling Final
description: Earl Anthony defeated top-seeded Frank Ellenburg, 269-235, in the final game today to win the $23,000 top prize in a Professional Bowlers Association tournament.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Panel Plays A Hunch on Student Loans
description: The fight over President Reagan's budget is far from over, but on some issues, the strength of the popular sentiment has made the outcome seem pretty clear. Last week, the House Appropriations Committee approved an extra $1.3 billion in emergency funds for the Federal student loan program on the implicit assumption that the reductions proposed by the Administration won't pass Congress this year.

title: James F. Trafidlo to Marry Elizabeth Ann Boyd in May
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Ann Boyd to James Francis Trafidlo has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Boyd of Weston and Chilmark, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Trafidlo of Needham and West Dennis, Mass.

title: Abbott Sues New York Over 'Mental Anguish'
description: Jack Henry Abbott, awaiting sentencing next month for manslaughter, is seeking $10 million in damages from New York City for ''the mental anguish and threats to his life'' he says he is suffering on Rikers Island.

title: IT'S NOT EXACTLY THE GALLUP POLL, BUT-
description: IN AN attempt to put their fingers on the pulse of South Jersey, a group of young pollsters here have found that local residents overwhelmingly favor raising the state's minimum drinking age from 19 to 21, disapprove of President Reagan's budget proposals and are split on legalized abortion.

title: BONN'S RULING PARTNERSHIP MAY DISSOLVE PREMATURELY
description: If political glaciers ever accelerate, now seems the time: The slow movement toward an end of the Bonn coalition, still uncertain, still arrestable, has nonetheless become visible to everyone.

title: THE RETURN OF FERNANDO ARRABAL
description: PARIS It cannot, literally, be the turn of Fernando Arrabal's mind that converts the procession of visitors in his Paris apartment into an anarcho-absurdist frieze. People come because they have errands, after all, or appointments, or the wrong address. But it does seem, this particular mushroom-gray morning, that the playwright's button eyes, round, frizzy beard and air of childlike eagerness incite his circumstances.

title: ROCHESTER PHILHARMONIC
description: It may be too early to call it a trend, but American symphony orchestras led by American conductors seem to be making a point of playing new works when they come to New York for showcase concerts. Yet another instance of this occurred Wednesday night when the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra led by David Zinman appeared in Carnegie Hall. The concert opened with Donald Erb's ''Sonneries for Orchestra,'' commissioned by the Rochester ensemble and completed less than four months ago.

title: TO OPEN OR NOT? WINTER NIGHTMARE OF A SUPERINTENDENT
description: FLOWERS popping, buds appearing, days warming; all are indicators that a major job hassle for a Schools Superintendent will be gone for a while. It is almost time to forget the lost sleep, the tightened stomach muscles, the gray hair that result from that toughest of decisions: do we or don't we close school because of the weather?

title: Another Viewpoint On Cutchogue Painting
description: Critics should be free to criticize; Helen Harrison therefore is entitled to her comments about Jacqueline Penney (''3 Prize-Winners Show Their Style'').

title: Francesca Gray Stewart Will Be Bride In May of Paul Thomas Cohn, Lawyer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. E. Sheldon Stewart of New York and Coconut Grove, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Francesca Gray Stewart, to Paul Thomas Cohn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Cohn of Huntington, L.I.

title: WHAT NEW UNIT FOR PRENATAL CARE MEANS TO COUNTY
description: AFTER a five-year wait, the Westchester County Medical Center has won state approval to open a $1.7 million perinatal unit that will provide care for high-risk mothers and babies in a seven-county area.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM'S 'EVENT NO. 2'
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which ends its season tonight at the City Center, has continued - as always- to be the most provocative company on the dance scene.

title: 'THEY'RE MAKING IT' ON LONG ISLAND
description: FARMINGDALE ''WHEN I was 17, I used to tell my friends that I would be a millionaire by the time I was 35,'' William F. Kelly, president and sole owner of SAI Electronics, said over liver and onions at one of his favorite restaurants near his business headquarters in Farmingdale.

title: 10-Hour Workday Experiment Is Extended for U.S. Workers
description: The House cleared the way today for hundreds of thousands of Federal workers to continue, at least temporarily, working 10-hour days in exchange for long weekends.

title: BRIGHT NEW WORLD TO REPLACE DUMP
description: LYNDHURST ONLY true visionaries can now see the eventual beauty of DeKorte State Park, perhaps the most ambitious and complex land-reclamation project in the entire Northeast. This eventual preserve in the Hackensack Meadowlands is now nothing more than low-lying marsh and wetlands, friendly only to migrating waterfowl and birds and to plateaus of old, closed garbage dumps that are hostile to all except scavenging sea gulls.

title: A HOMESEEKER'S GUIDE TO THE CITY
description: THIS is a tough year to look for an apartment or a house in New YorkC ity, but it is also a year of opportunity. The availability of r ental apartments remains low - the vacancy rate was 2.l3 percent at t he most recent count - and high mortgage rates are forcing up the c ost of cooperatives, condominiums and houses. But a b orough-byborough survey shows that many housing choices still are a vailable and that apartment and house sellers are more willing than l ast year to make deals.

title: A PLAGUE OF COYOTES
description: Peter Steinhart is a regular contributor to Audubon magazine. By Peter Steinhart

title: Mailbox; Why Hockey Will Never Be The City Game
description: To the Sports Editor: Hockey is not a New York game. Sometimes, between 92d and 93d Street seven kids - odd man is goalie - try to shoot pucks while on roller skates.

title: 15,000 West Germans Protest Nuclear Plant
description: About 15,000 people demonstrated peacefully today against plans to build a nuclear fuelr@eprocessing plant in this Bavarian town.

title: SILICON PRAIRIE, TEXAS
description: DALLAS SOME business people here like to describe this city's diversified economic base as recession-proof, but it's probably safe to assume that none of them work in the electronics industry. After years of spectacular growth, 1981 and the first quarter of 1982 proved a rude awakening for many of the best-known names in technology-related industries, and there are no immediate prospects of a sudden turnaround.

title: CHARTRES
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article on the Chartres Cathedral by Frank J. Prial, ''The Voice of Chartres'' (Travel, March 14) , but the railroad directions were wrong. All trains to Chartres from Paris leave from the Gare Montparnasse.EDWARD T. FRANCIS Livingston, N.J.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Remy Loumbrozo Plays; Parisian-Born Pianist
description: The young Parisian-born pianist Remy Loumbrozo made his New York recital debut last Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall with a program that included works of Schumann, Brahms and Jolivet.

Durham-Chapel Hill metropolitan area of North Carolina known as the Research Triangle. The General Assembly appropriated $24.4 million in July to create the center after Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. pressed for its establishment as the centerpiece of his campaign to attract electronics research and manufacturing to the state.

title: Joan M. Shlora Becomes a Bride
description: Joan Marie Shlora and George Amiel Whipple 3d, who are with Marsh & McLennan Inc., New York insurance brokers, were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Warren.

title: DRILL FINDS FLAWS IN EVACUATION PLANS
description: WATERFORD JOEY SCHLICHTING stood patiently outside the emergency decontamination center, fingering a card that said how much radiation he was supposed to have received in an accident drill, fighting a simulated fire at the Millstone 1 nuclear plant here.

title: JOINT SPIRIT OF FRUSTRATION AS THE CONGRESS PRODS REAGAN
description: Was President Reagan an ideologue who would stick to his guns even in a hopeless cause? Had last year's victories on Capitol Hill, including some in which he overrode the pessimistic advice of his Congressional allies, made him unwilling to compromise? These were some of the questions raised last week on Capitol Hill as Democrats and Republicans struggled to get the White House to the negotiating table and work out a compromise on the fiscal 1983 budget.

title: Sports People; Johnson Rejoins Sonics
description: The Seattle SuperSonics have placed John Johnson, a 12-year veteran, on the roster again.

title: REGAN CRITICIZES USE OF STATE AIRCRAFT
description: Aircraft that are supposed to be used exclusively by New York State employees for official business are being used to transport relatives and friends of Governor Carey and other state officials, according to State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: ROUTE 128, MASSACHUSETTS; SOME BUMPS ALONG THE WAY
description: BOSTON FOR New England's high-technology industries, there has been a pot of gold and a basket of computer chips at the end of the rainbow. With defense spending up, and potentially huge markets for microcomputers and computerized office equipment still untapped, the basket is still there. But at least for the moment, the pot is a little tarnished.

title: HAITIANS IN U.S. MAY BE OFFERED LAND IN BELIZE
description: A plan to resettle Haitians in the newly independent Central American nation of Belize is being discussed by the United States and the Belizean Government.

title: Missouri Businessman Ends Offer for Rockies
description: A Missouri businessman has withdrawn his offer to buy the Colorado Rockies, and a group of investors from Edmonton, Alberta, is interested in buying the franchise and keeping it in Denver.

title: THEY'RE 'MAKING IT' ON LONG ISLAND
description: COPIAGUE THIRTEEN years ago, Kenneth Rosenberg and Richard Soloway, business partners, were looking for a change. Their four-year-old business of manufacturing and selling electric guitar amplifiers, wah-wah pedals and psychedelic lights was dying along with the public's taste for flower power and acid rock.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: Irish writer. THE BRANDEIS/FRANKFURTER CONNECTION, by Bruce Allen Murphy. (Oxford University Press, $18.95.) The political alliance of the two Supreme Court Justices.

title:
Art;
A WOMAN'S WAY IN ART?
description: OLD WESTBURY The struggle of women to establish the validity of art arising from what, in a less charitable era, would have been called their "condition" is now history, but the questions raised in that struggle continue to be debated. We must still ask, for example, whether there is a specifically feminine bias toward decoration, handicraft and pattern-making, and if the use of particular materials and subjects indicated that the artist is female rather than male.

title: SRI LANKA
description: To the Editor: The article on Sri Lanka makes no reference to Adam's Peak, a ''must'' for every visitor to the country. This sacred mountain draws tens of thousands of pilgrims the year round.

title: Izumo
description: To the Editor:

title: Down on the Farm
description: Continued moderation in food price inflation may appeal to consumers, but it means more anxiety for farmers. Although the Agriculture Department's index of major product prices rose during the first two months of 1982, those were the first increases in the last 12 months.

title: Productivity
description: To the Business Editor: In ''How Not to Measure Productivity'' (March 7), Stanley B. Henrici has rediscovered that the share of national product accruing to labor is stable over time in a modern economy. This is an idea whose pedigree dates back 50 years or more, through economists such as A. Bowley, J.R. Hicks, M. Kalecki and J.M. Keynes.

title: CHALLENGING CITY TAX ASSESSMENTS
description: DESPITE a new state law aimed at making it easier for homeowners to w in reductions in their property tax assessments, the number of New Y ork City residents challenging their tax bills is far below what o fficials expected.

title: Environews
description: NOTING that rainfall in New Jersey is 40 times more acidic than normal, the American Lung Association said last week that the Federal Clean Air Act should be amended to provide adequate controls on the sources of acid rain, primarily the burning of coal by industries in the Middle West.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Adoption by Priest
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese in Chicago tried gently in November 1980 to discourage the Rev. George Clements from adopting a boy. The 49-year-old black priest, intent on dramatizing the problem of placing abandoned black children in homes, persisted, and in July 1981 Father Clements became father legally to 13-year-old Joey.

title: SILICON VALLEY; OPTIMISM RISING FOR A TURNAROUND; LOS ANGELES
description: LIKE many in the pack of high-technology greyhounds that crowd bustling industrial parks in the Southwest and along the Pacific Coast, the Intel Corporation would prefer to forget 1981. Profits slumped, the hiring schedule was tabled and vacant jobs stayed empty. There has been little change for the semiconductor manufacturer so far in 1982's first three months. But its recruiting staff is starting to limber up for a heavy schedule of interviewing this summer.

title: A Not-So-Kind Tax Cut
description: As the economy remains wallowed in its second downturn in as many years, most analysts continue to base projections of an upturn in the latter half of 1982 on the second stage of the Administration's tax cut program. However, some economists are now saying that the July 10 percent tax cut will not be sufficient.

title: The Region in Summary; Zone Defense For NJ Transit
description: The New Jersey Transit Corporation's 320,000 bus and rail commuters will have to dig deeper into their pockets come July, but perhaps not quite as deep as Governor Kean wanted. Fearful that the 25 percent fare increase Mr. Kean had sought would reduce ridership and revenues, NJ Transit last week proposed an average raise of 18 percent instead.

title: Elena DeFilippis Engaged To J. Randolph Colahan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph J. DeFilippis of River Vale, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elena Christine DeFilippis, to J. Randolph Colahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Donald Colahan of Garden City, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Art; A FESTIVAL DEVOTED TO GUNTER GRASS
description: PURCHASE THE United States does not want for art that instructs (or for academics who would have it instruct), but it may still be outranked in this respect by Germany. Current confirmation of the suspicion is on hand at Manhattanville College, where there are two print shows - one by the novelist, Gunter Grass, the other by a selection of German contemporaries (through Friday). Also under review are two exhibitions by native artists who teach - Tom Halsall, at Westchester Community College in Valhalla (through April 15), and the late George Cohen, at the Aileen Ryan Earnest Gallery in Scarsdale (Harwood Building, through Wednesday).

title: DESPITE GRISLY EVIDENCE, INDIA GLORIFIES ITS BANDITS
description: Five rural policemen, lured to a village 125 miles from here recently by the promise of dinner, were disarmed, tied to trees and shot dead by outlaws who the police said were seeking to avenge the slaying of their leader.

title: JOHN O. LOGAN
description: John O. Logan, retired president and chairman of Universal Oil Products of Des Plaines, Ill., and former executive vice president of Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, died Saturday at Good Shepherd Hospital in Barrington, Ill. Mr. Logan, who was a resident of Barrington Hills, was 71 years old.

title: States Weigh Tax Rises Of Record $6.8 Billion
description: State legislatures are considering proposals to increase taxes by $6.8 billion this year to make up for money shortages caused by the recession and Federal budget cutbacks.

title: OF 'RAP SHEETS,' COMPUTERS ALIBIS
description: To the Editor:

title: Penguins Clinch Playoff Spot
description: Jim Hamilton and Paul Gardner scored two goals apiece as the Pittsburgh Penguins defeated the Washington Capitals, 6-5, tonight and clinched a playoff berth.

title: Aid Is Arranged for Wickes
description: The Allegheny Beverage Corporation of Baltimore, one of the largest outside shareholders in the Wickes Companies of San Diego, has announced that it had arranged to borrow up to $600 million in behalf of Wickes so that the California holding company would not have to sell any operations that are currently profitable or may become so.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think we have to do it to demonstrate something to the whole world.'' - Oscar Gonzalez, voting in El Salvador. (A1:6.)

title: Carey Sassower Married To Pepe Karmel, a Writer
description: At Young Israel of Fifth Avenue yesterday, Carey Adina Sassower, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Sassower of White Plains, was married to Joseph Low Karmel, son of Alex Karmel of Washington and the late Marjorie Low Karmel.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline on Sunday incorrectly stated the rate at which medical costs in the United States are climbing. The nation's health-care bill has climbed tenfold in the last two decades, from $27 billion in 1960 to $275 billion last year.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY FOR SAN DIEGO SUMMONED TO MEET SUPERIORS
description: The United States Attorney for San Diego, William H. Kennedy, flew to Washington today for a meeting Monday with Justice Department officials to discuss the case of a suspect whose indictment in a multimillion-dollar theft ring has been blocked because of his intelligence connections.

title: THE 'CHEMISTRY' OF THE CELTICS
description: A rivalry was born in the 1959-60 season when Wilt Chamberlain, then a Philadelphia rookie, challenged Bill Russell and the Boston Celtics.

title: HAIG RETAINS HOPE OF REFORM REGIME
description: As voters in El Salvador chose a 60-member constituent assembly, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. restated the Reagan Administration's preference for a Salvadoran government committed to continuing social and economic reforms.

title: No Headline
description: Rochelle Gail Rifkin, special assistant to the president of Parfums Charles Jourdan and Parfums Van Cleef & Arpels, was married yesterday to Joel Meritt Leyden, president of Leyden Communications, a public relations and advertising agency in New York. Rabbi Maurice Aranov performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Rifkin of Baldwin Harbor, L.I. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Leyden of New York.

title: FIRST-STRIKE PROOF U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Started
description: Opening-day anglers in many areas of New York State ''will encounter tougher conditions than they have experienced in several years,'' says Commissioner Robert Flacke of the Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Gainers and Losers
description: Coleco Industries, a leading maker of games and toys, was the best performing stock on the New York Stock Exchange in the first quarter, rising 96.4 percent.
