The Texas International Company, an oil and gas exploration concern, turned in the poorest showing, dropping 65.7 percent. A list of the best and worst performers on the Big Board, the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter markets is on page D4.

title: DEFENSE FOR MUSTO SAYS JUROR WAS PRESSURED
description: The personal anguish of a juror could prove vital in the expected appeal of William V. Musto, the New Jersey State Senator and Mayor of Union City who was convicted Friday of extortion and other charges in Federal District Court in Newark, Mr. Musto's attorney said yesterday.

title: 23 Demonstrators Seized At Frankfurt Airport
description: Twenty-three people were arrested today after some 600 demonstrators threw stones, paint and other debris at policemen guarding the site of a third runway at the Rhine-Main International Airport here. The police said four people were injured.

title: STAGE: GRANGER'S 'EMINENT DOMAIN'
description: PERCY GRANGER'S ''Eminent Domain,'' at the Circle in the Square, proves at least one thing - that its exemplary star, Philip Bosco, is ready and able to play a terrific George in ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' In a sense, he already is. Mr. Granger's protagonist, like Edward Albee's, is a middle-aged college professor with a stalled career, a fractured marriage and a mysteriously absent son. Mr. Bosco's performance - cresting steadily from tweedy wooliness to lacerating wit to bourbon-fueled rage -is an expert tour through a consciousness that's only one tiny, last-ditch step ahead of final defeat.

title: RANGERS' 9-GAME UNBEATEN STREAK ENDS
description: The Rangers failed tonight to clinch second place in the Patrick Division, losing, 3-1, to the third-place Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum. The loss was the Rangers' first in 10 games and broke their five-game winning streak.

title: News Analysis
description: In the Great Tin Mystery - a $500 million business who-done-it - the clues all lead to Kuala Lumpur, the capital of the world's largest tin producer. Malaysia has neither confirmed that it was the kingpin in the plot to corner tin, nor denied that its warehouses are full of the key metal. But those who follow the trading of tin have no doubt that Malaysia was involved.

title: ECONOMIC SUMMIT AT E.E.C. TO BEGIN
description: Leaders of the 10 Common Market nations will open a two-day summit meeting Monday to discuss ways of reviving the European Economic Community's flagging economy and to grapple with events in the Middle East and Central America.

title: Advertising; Ahmanson Bolsters Its Image
description: ''T HESE days,'' said William M. Keeler, bank marketer turned insurance marketer, ''people don't want to deal with companies they don't know. That's why AllState and State Farm are eating up the business.''

title: Hanoi Communists Hear Of 'Acute Problems'
description: The Vietnamese Communist Party gathered in Hanoi this weekend for its annual congress and heard the party secretary, Le Duan, ascribe Vietnam's economic problems in part to the ''shortcomings and mistakes of the party and state agencies, from national down to grass-roots level.''

title: Leonid O. Utyosov, 86; Led a Soviet Jazz Band
description: Leonid O. Utyosov, a well-known Soviet bandleader, died this month in Moscow, according to Soviet press reports. He was 86 years old.

title: Mears Triumphs
description: Rick Mears roared away from the field for an easy victory in the Kraco 150 for Indianapolis cars at Phoenix International Raceway today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Groping Over Sex

title: CABARET: MORGANA KING AT LUSH LIFE
description: Morgana King is a puzzling performer. She is both an accomplished actress (she played Marlon Brando's wife in ''The Godfather'') and a singer with unusual range and control and an excellent grounding in jazz.

title: 'THE GERMAN PROBLEM'
description: In some American circles, there is a growing tendency to speak of ''the German problem'' as though the Federal Republic were drifting mindlessly toward the East, ignoring our wise advice, and refusing to make the sacrifices Western security requires. The Reagan Administration explains such aberrant behavior largely on the ground that, because we have not kept up our military strength, the West Germans are tempted toward neutralism out of fear that we can no longer defend them.

title: HAROLD URIS, SKYSCRAPER DEVELOPER AND PHILANTHROPIST, IS DEAD AT 76
description: Harold Uris, a philanthropist and builder who, with his brother, Percy, put up office skyscrapers that remade much of the face of Manhattan, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Uris, who was 76 years old, had been living in Palm Beach and at the Pierre Hotel in New York City.

title: ACCORD FOR DELAY IN WESTWAY FUNDS ASSAILED BY KOCH
description: The Legislature is about to pass what some view as a spend-now, pay-later budget. News analysis, page B3. By JOYCE PURNICK

title: The Price of Health Examining the Medical System Second of five articles.
description: While Americans overwhelmingly are pleased with the quality of their medical care, most appear to be willing to accept significant changes in the system to reduce costs, according to a national survey.

title: Small Israeli Opposition Party Is Supporting Begin for Now
description: Telem, a small opposition party, has agreed to abstain in a parliamentary budget vote this week, insuring the survival for the time being of the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: Market Place
description: The Search For Stocks

title: Attendants Required In City Movie Houses
description: Asserting that ''one rowdy person can spoil a movie for an entire audience,'' Simon P. Gourdine, New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, announced a rule yesterday requiring all movie theaters to have at least one attendant. The new regulation calls for ''sufficient'' personnel to ''preserve order.''

title: MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1982; The Economy
description: Middle-sized companies in most older industrial areas seem to be riding out the recession, while some larger ones are having difficulty paying their bank loans. Banks on the West Coast have run into loan problems because of the depressed housing market, which has hit real-estate developers and related industries. (Page D1.)

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: The site is Sun Devil Stadium in Phoenix. The game is a National Football League wild-card playoff game played between two northern teams the day after New Year's. One of the teams has just scored. It decides against trying for the 2-point conversion. So the team lines up on the 30-yard line and the place-kicker positions a kicking tee 47 yards away from the goal post. But no. It's too hot. One team has a commanding lead. Both coaches decide to end the game right then. Does any of this sound like the N.F.L.? Playoff games in Phoenix? A 47-yard extra point?

title: BEHIND THE GUATEMALA COUP: A GENERAL TAKES OVER AND CHANGES ITS COURSE
description: The small group of junior Guatemalan army and air force officers who led last Tuesday's coup expected a civilianmilitary junta to take power and a date for presidential elections to be announced immediately.

title: THE ROAD TO SAQQARA
description: There is a new road out of Cairo toward Saqqara, a great archeological site at the desert's edge. A year or two ago you drove through lush farm plots of grain and onions and beans. Today, for miles on both sides of the road, there are small crowded apartment blocks. The rich alluvial soil has been covered with brick and cement.

title: The Racing Lure
description: The last time he went overseas for an automobile race, his car broke down in the Sahara and it took an international rescue team six days to find him.

title: Spring Freeze Damages Carolina Apple Crop
description: A spring freeze wiped out much of the apple crop in western North Carolina and caused major damage to peaches, officials said today.

title: Connors Beaten
description: Guillermo Vilas downed Jimmy Connors for the second time in a week and won the final of a $350,000 tennis tournament today, 6-3, 6-3.

title: Driver Is Killed As Train Hits Car
description: A man was killed when a Conrail train crashed into his car at a crossing in the town of Riga.

title: Bullets 104 - Cavaliers 101
description: Greg Ballard, with 23 points, and Spencer Haywood, with 16, paced Washington as Cleveland lost its seventh straight game.

title: STUDY CITES PERIL IN WORLD AGRICULTURAL DECLINE
description: Deteriorating biological systems around the world pose a grave threat to the global economy, according to a new report issued by the Worldwatch Insitute.

title: News Analysis
description: The new martial-law administration of Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad appears to have been accepted here, if only provisionally.

title: SALVADORANS JAM POLLING STATIONS, REBELS CLOSE SOME
description: Voters, some casting their ballots to the sounds of nearby gunshots, jammed polling places across El Salvador today in elections for a constituent assembly.

title: THOUSANDS GATHER NEAR WHITE SANDS TO SEE SHUTTLE'S THIRD RETURN TO EARTH
description: Several hundred thousand people were converging on this desert basin tonight, camping along roads and disrupting the calm of the area's villages, to catch a glimpse of the space shuttle Columbia when it is scheduled to land here Monday after seven days in space.

title: Journalists Said to Assail Breakup of Polish Union
description: Fifty Polish journalists have circulated an open letter here protesting the dissolution of the Polish Journalists' Association and its replacement last Wednesday by the Association of Journalists of Peoples' Poland, informed sources said today.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA TOPPLED IN FINAL
description: Last Wednesday, after her first match in the $300,000 Avon women's tennis championships, Sylvia Hanika was asked if anyone could beat Martina Navratilova in the season-ending event. After all, Miss Navratilova had not lost a match all year.

title: No Headline
description: FRANK McGUIRE, Ben Carnevale and Bob Spear, then the head basketball coaches at North Carolina, Navy and Air Force, were sitting in a hotel room in March 1958 when McGuire mentioned he was looking for an assistant coach to replace his old friend, Buck Freeman, who was ill.

title: SENATOR LONG RELISHES MINORITY ROLE
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, who was the majority leader until the Republicans won control of the Senate in 1980, has resumed holding Saturday morning press conferences. Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who headed the Budget Committee, has been rattling fiscal china with talk of a freeze on spending.

title: LITTLE SUPRISE FELT ON RACING SCANDEL
description: Track officials and jockeys at Aqueduct expressed little surprise yesterday over the disclosure that state racing officials were considering disciplinary action against two leading riders for violations stemming from the fixing of races at New York thoroughbred tracks in the mid-1970's. Most declined public comment until the report recommending the action was officially released later this week.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH
description: The administration is looking for further trade liberalization measures by Japan in May just before the Versailles economic summit of the seven leading industrial countries.

title: Israeli Cabinet Aide Named
description: The Israeli Cabinet today named Dan Meridor secretary of the Government to succeed Aryeh Naor, who is on trial before a civil service disciplinary tribunal charged with disclosing confidential information to promote himself for a newspaper job. Mr. Naor submitted his resignation on Dec. 31 after the trial opened in Jerusalem, but he denied the matters were connected.

title: STORE PUTS STOCK IN DETROIT RIOT AREA
description: The wide new street is officially renamed Rosa Parks Boulevard, after the hero of the Selma bus boycott. But to Detroit and the people who live here, it is still 12th Street, heroic in a different way as the survivor of the Detroit riots of 1967.

title: POP-ROCK NICK LOWE AT THE PALLADIUM
description: Nick Lowe's skills as a pop-rock tunesmith are always getting obscured by one thing or another. When he was performing with Rockpile, that band's booting drive and the eclectic material done by its other lead singer, Dave Edmunds, distracted the attention from Mr. Lowe's songwriting. He made his mark as a record producer working with artists who write their own songs, and while his solo albums are a better showcase for his tunes, he has made only three albums so far.

title: TRAPPED MAN'S PLIGHT BRINGS COMMUNITY TOGETHER IN VIGIL
description: A bonfire burned into the night tonight, as it had Saturday. And dozens of Lafayette Township's 1,600 residents were still clustered around it, talking about Donald Weltner's chances and expressing hope that he could still be saved.

title: Salvador Vote Results Will Be Known Today
description: The official results of today's Salvador elections will be announced Monday afternoon after a computer count of affidavits supplied from the 14 provinces recording the number of votes in each of them. However, preliminary results were to be telexed to the capital tonight, and unofficial tabulations could be available by early Monday, authorities said.

title: CITIBANK DOCTOR GIVEN SENIOR POST
description: Some 21 years ago, when he joined Citibank as medical director, Clinton G. Weiman was the bank's one and only doctor. He ministered, with a staff of five nurses, to about 12,000 employees, mostly at Citibank's 399 Park Avenue headquarters in mid-Manhattan.

title: THEATER: MUSIC HALL SALUTES ITSELF IN 'ENCORE'
description: It was the brightest gesture of optimism to open New York's Radio City Music Hall in that dim Depression winter of December 1932, with a five-hour vaudeville show that was soon replaced by a film-andspectacle format. The economy has peaked and dipped during the intervening 50 years, but the Music Hall remains sunny side up with its new show, ''Encore,'' a tribute to itself that opened last Friday.

title: RECITAL: THE WAVERLY CONSORT
description: The Waverly Consort has sometimes been criticized for needlessly quiltlike programs - bits and pieces of music assembled into a patchwork that does an injustice to the grander spirit of whatever era the group is concerning itself with. Another common complaint has been that the group's sometimes precious approach to music should better pulse with vitality.

title: ISRAELI CABINET AFFIRMS POLICIES ON ARAB PROTEST
description: As demonstrations continued in the West Bank today, the Government affirmed its policies in the occupied territories, declaring that ''no acts of violence or disturbances of the peace or order will be tolerated.''

title: Is Ma Bell's Divorce Well Grounded?
description: At first glance, there was a compelling logic to the A.T.& T. antitrust settlement. Ma Bell is not entirely a Government-controlled public utility or a free enterprise but a mix of both. Better, then, to divide it cleanly into state-regulated natural monopolies that provide local phone service and a more versatile communications company capable of competing with the likes of I.B.M. or RCA.

title: Protesters Burn Utility Bills
description: About 75 protesters burned what they said were more than $300,000 in unpaid electric bills today to mark the third anniversary of the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant. A spokesman for the demonstrators said the group was protesting plans that would force customers of the Metropolitan Edison Company, which operates the plant, to pay for cleaning up the facility.

title: GRAND JURY TO ACT ON GIBSON IN JOB-APPOINTMENT INQUIRY
description: After a six-month investigation involving 77 witnesses, a grand jury in Newark is expected to vote Wednesday on whether to indict Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson for purportedly giving a no-show job to a former City Councilman, according to the Essex County Prosecutor.

title: Help for Wildlife
description: The mansion has just been designated an official wildlife habitat of ''exceptional merit.'' The National Wildlife Federation, which bestowed the designation on the South Carolina Governor's mansion in Columbia, was not suggesting that Gov. Dick Riley was a particularly unusual political animal.

title: FRANKLIN CAPTURES 'A' TITLE
description: Benjamin Franklin, the New York City Public Schools Athletic League champion, won the last game in the school's history today, defeating Spring Valley, 56-55, in the Class A final and becoming the first P.S.A.L. school to win a title in the New York State Super 16 competition.

title: GOLDEN POND, ' LOSER ON STAGE, WINNER ON SCREEN
description: When ''On Golden Pond'' opened on Broadway in the spring of 1979, it just managed to run three and a half months and did not make a penny. In fact, Ernest Thompson's sentimental play about the twilight summer of an elderly couple lost all but $700 of its $240,000 investment. But now, in a highly unlikely turn of events, the money loser on Broadway is becoming a big moneymaker in other places.

title: THE RISK OF A MELTDOWN
description: There is a high, increasing likelihood that someday soon, during a seemingly minor malfunction at any of a dozen or more nuclear plants around the United States, the steel vessel that houses the radioactive core is going to crack like a piece of glass. The result will be a core meltdown, the most serious kind of accident, which will injure many people, destroy the plant, and probably destroy the nuclear industry with it.

title: BANK LOAN RISKS VARY BY REGION
description: Having experienced bad times in the past, most medium-sized companies in the nation's older industrial areas are proving more resilient to high interest rates and deep recession than many newer companies in the Sun Belt, a spot check of large banks across the country indicates.

title: The U.N. Today; March 29, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Father of Hinckley Complains of Trial Delay
description: John W. Hinckley Sr., whose son shot President Reagan and three others, says he is distressed that a trial has not yet begun.

title: FINNS' NEW LEADER AFFIRMS SOVIET TIE
description: Finland's new President, Mauno Koivisto, has completed two months in office during which he has instituted a new style in the conduct of foreign policy and has successfully passed what some Finnish newspapers describe as his ''ordeal by fire.''

title: RURAL VOTERS, DESPITE FEARS, HIKE FOR MILES
description: The dusty roads outside this country's major eastern cities were awash with hundreds of people, walking and walking - sometimes for miles -to cast their ballots.

title: PARIS READY-TO-WEAR BEGINS BOLDLY
description: To open the week of French ready-to-wear showings for fall and winter, Jack Lang, the French Minister of Culture, greeted some of the 1,200 journalists and thousands of buyers here at a reception at the Louvre. Even Yves Saint Laurent attended. So did Danielle Mitterrand, the President's wife. Before the week is over, 64 designers will have shown collections.

title: To Andrew B. Wile
description: Regina Marie Burg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Burg of Freeport, L.I., was married yesterday at St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church in New York, to Andrew B. Wile, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Wile of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Arthur T. Leone and Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner of Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers, performed the ceremony.

title: HELP FOR ADOLESCENT MOTHERS
description: Nessa Darren was boiling soup on the stove and Wanda Williams was dicing fruit on a table. Santee Diaz De Leon was making a call on a red plastic toy telephone. Anthony Rodriguez was cutting up brightly colored paper and, helped by Anne Tuohy, pasting the pieces into collages on a coffee table. Two young women were fashioning yarn dolls on a lunch counter as people crisscrossed back and forth in the room in the basement of Bellevue Hospital's Child Outpatient Clinic.

title: FOR FIRST TIME SINCE '32 CRACKDOWN, DEMOCRACY IS TRYING FOR A COMEBACK
description: Fifty years ago the Salvadoran Army deposed a civilian Government that was headed by the country's last freely elected president. Since then a colonel or general has occupied the presidential palace.

title: N.C.A.A. Aide Hits at Coaches
description: Francis Bonner, a member of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I steering committee, says that coaches should have a clause in their contracts stipulating that they would be dismissed if they knowingly broke association rules.

title: Pacers 102, Bulls 101
description: INDIANAPOLIS (AP) - Clemon Johnson, the Indiana center, had 20 points and 16 rebounds.

title: CORPORATE ISSUES READY
description: Attracted by two weeks of stable prices in the Treasury market, as many as 16 corporations might sell notes or bonds this week, investment bankers said. In the next breath, they said volume might be far lower - with the certain issues being the BankAmerica Corporation's heavily advertised $500 million face amount of zero percent notes that are aimed at individual investors who are opening Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: Speak Up, Mr. Smith
description: Attorney General William French Smith has been dodging a posse of questioners who want to know what he thinks about the court-stripping bills in Congress. These are the measures that would eviscerate the power of the Federal courts in cases affecting school busing, school prayer, abortion and other contentious issues. No entreaties for comment have come from Senator Jesse Helms and other sponsors of these bills. So it has been assumed that the Attorney General harbors reservations, as he should, but remains silent for political convenience, as he should not.

title: DESPITE IMPROVED OUTLOOK FOR COLLEGE AID, EXPERTS STILL SEE RISKS
description: Students in college and graduate school can be reasonably sure that Federal aid and loan programs will not be further reduced before the school year beginning next fall, according to education experts on Capitol Hill.

title: BRIEFING
description: Nancy: Socko

title: AUTO CONNCESSION IMPACT DEBATED BY ECONOMISTS
description: Business economists and forecasters are sharply divided over the extent to which the wage concessions made by workers at the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation will be adopted by other sectors of American industry.

title: SHUTTLE CREW PREPARES FOR LANDING IN DESERT
description: The astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia, their earlier discomfort and uncertainty behind them and their weeklong mission already pronounced a success, spent today tidying up their spacecraft and preparing to bring it back to earth.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Player A in golf is on the green of a par-3 hole in one shot. Player B's tee shot also lands on the green, striking Player A's ball and knocking it into the hole. Is Player A credited with a hole in one?

title: A GROUP FOR CANCER SURVIVORS
description: THE psychological effects of cancer, a word so often uttered with d owncast eyes and followed by a funereal hush, can do as much damage a s the disease itself. Patients, upon hearing the diagnosis, often a ssume their lives are over. Friends sometimes begin to act strangelya nd then disappear. Employers are suddenly unwilling to talk about p romotions.

title: Repertory Group Given Youth Programs Grant
description: The Performing Arts Repertory Theater, which produces theater for young audiences, has received a $15,000 grant from the Ruth Mott Fund to commission and develop drama and music works that address issues for young people.

title: PLAYING VIDEO GAMES FOR FUN AND PROFIT
description: The video game designers are the minds behind the monster munchers, a breed of engineers at home amid the advancing aliens and astroblasters. They are part of a $5 billion business scrambling for young, inventive people with an affinity for games and a love of computers.

title: THE ZANY QUEST FOR NEW YORK STATE TROUT
description: THERE are some who believe that designating All Fools' Day (April 1) as the start of the trout fishing season in New York State is exceedingly apt.

title: BRINK'S DISCLOSURE IGNITES DEBATE AMONG DEFENSE LAWYERS AND PROSECUTORS
description: The disclosure by Federal authorities that they have obtained the cooperation of one of the people who ''personally participated'' in the Brink's armored-car robbery and shootout in Rockland County last Oct. 20 has enraged defense attorneys in the case, increased the possibility of Federal conspiracy indictments and given the public an unconfirmed skeletal account of the planning of the crime.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NYU DOWN The Wall Street area is where the string-pullers of the world operate from and now there is an exhibit in that downtown neighborhood where you can do some string-pulling on your own. It is called ''Arcade,'' a puppet display on view through Friday at New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration, 90 Trinity Place, just across the street from the rear of Trinity Church.

title: Record Buster
description: Records may be made to be broken, as some cracker-barrel sports philosophers have mused. But some are smashed beyond belief. Jeff Ledbetter has achieved peaks in National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball that had seemed unattainable.

title: U.S. Women Beat Chinese Gymnasts
description: The United States women's gymnastics team, paced by Julie Ann McNamara, beat the Chinese team by 192.85 points to 190.15 today in the McDonald's Classic at U.C.L.A.

title: METHOD USED TO TAKE SURVEY
description: The New York Times health care survey was based on telephone interviews conducted March 1-6 with 1,530 adults around the United States. The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT APPOINTS NEW PRESIDENT
description: Good news for the 22-month-old deMichele quadruplets of New Canaan, Conn., Jennifer, Brian, Christina and Julie: On April 1, their 35-year-old father, Robert M. deMichele, will become president of the Piedmont Management Company. The New York-based financial services holding company had a 1981 net income of $6.7 million, substantially more than the year before.

title: Blues 8, Black Hawks 3
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Brian Sutter scored a pair of goals and Bernie Federko had a goal and two assists to lead St. Louis.

title: Reaching a Peak
description: Ned Gillette, a 36-year-old skier, mountaineer and ice climber from Stowe, Vt., recognizes that there are no great peaks left in the world for him to be the first to conquer. So Gillette takes new approaches.

title: An Unforgettable Day
description: She and her husband never mention it, Nancy Reagan said, but, a year later, the memory is still ''very, very fresh, very raw,'' and apparently always will be.

title: NANCY DREW AUTHOR WROTE 200 NOVELS
description: Harriet Stratemeyer Adams, who wrote nearly 200 children's books including many of the Nancy Drew and Hardy Boys series, died Saturday evening. She was 89 years old, and lived in Pottersville and Maplewood, N.J.

title: WHO WOULD WANT TO BE A TEACHER?
description: To the Editor:

title: Member of the Club
description: As knights of old needed blacksmiths to straighten out the dents in their lances, so touring professional golfers need Lew Gibson to keep their clubs in combat condition. Most of Mr. Gibson's work is routine repair, but he enjoys an occasional emergency as when George Archer accidentally snapped the shaft of his 3-iron against a tree on an 11th hole recently. A marshal brought the club to Mr. Gibson's trailer near the clubhouse and returned it to Archer on the par-3 14th. Archer hit his tee shot with the reshafted club and made a birdie.

title: AMERICAN FOREIGN POLICY NEEDS SCHOLARS OF THE THIRD WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH STARS 5 WHALERS 2
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Third-period goals 95 seconds apart by Al MacAdam and Neil Broten lifted Minnesota.

title: THE TEAM FROM BILOXI
description: NEW ORLEANS ''EVERYBODY laughs about Biloxi,'' John Thompson said. ''Everybody thinks it's hilarious, putting my team in Biloxi.'' He was explaining why he has based his Georgetown team 90 miles east of the site of the national collegiate basketball tournament, a move that has only increased his reputation for secrecy, for isolation, for ...

title: WEINBERGER TO PRESS KOREANS' RIGHTS AND SUPPORT FOR G.I.
description: 'S IN 3-DAY VISIT By RICHARD HALLORAN

title: CITY WILL MERGE 2 HOSPITALS IN THE BRONX TO SAVE MONEY
description: Two municipal hospitals in the Bronx are to be merged under a single administration in an effort to reduce costs and provide more efficient medical care, according to the president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: On Cable Magazine's April Fool's Rumor
description: As the April issue of On Cable magazine began to reach subscribers last week, a report spread through the industry that Ted Turner's electronic empire was being gobbled up by NBC. It was sparked by the editor Peter Funt's column Up Front with the headline ''Turner Broadcasting Merges With NBC!''

title: ISRAELI ARABS PREPARING FOR STRIKE AND PROTEST
description: Leaders of the nearly 600,000 Israeli Arabs are preparing for a general strike and major demonstration in northern Israel on Tuesday to demand an end to the Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip and the formation of an independent Palestinian country.

title: John Henry Finishes 3d
description: Perrault squared accounts with John Henry today by winning the $206,200 San Luis Rey Stakes before a crowd of 59,288 at Santa Anita.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York as elected William H. Von Barden, Charles Diccianni, Colleen M. Frey, Matthew E. Gately 3d, Joseph C hatfield 2d, Terrence J. Lee, Matthew J. McDonald Jr., Henry M Milkewicz and David J. Tuccillo vice presidents.

title: WATSON TRIUMPHS ON 3D PLAYOFF HOLE, DEFEATING CONNER
description: Tom Watson won the 14th Heritage Classic today by beating Frank Conner on the third hole of a playoff. Each player felt he could have won earlier had he not missed a crucial putt.

title: FORD OFFERS MONEY FUND
description: In a move to tap the current investor interest in money market instruments, the Ford Motor Company has announced that its finance subsidiary will offer company employees an account that operates like a money market mutual fund.

title: OPERA: PRICE-HORNE DUO
description: OPERA stars have been visiting the concert stage in pairs recently - Grace Bumbry and Shirley Verrett, Placido Domingo and Tatiana Troyanos and yesterday afternoon at the Met, Leontyne Price and Marilyn Horne.

title: Siren Tests to Start At Indian Point
description: Testing will begin Monday on 23 sirens designed to warn residents of an accident at the Indian Point nuclear power plant, officials said today.

title: Article 025599 -- No Title
description: IN the beginning, Clete Boyer was hoping to raise perhaps $10,000 to subsidize his brother Ken's lung cancer medical bills. But before last night's benefit dinner in Scottsdale, Ariz., it appeared that the total surely would approach $100,000 and might even surpass it.

title: Rutgers Triumphs In A.I.A.W. Final
description: Patty Coyle scored 18 of her career-high 30 points in the second half this afternoon and helped Rutgers erase a 5-point deficit and defeat Texas, 83-77, for the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women basketball championship for Division I schools.

title: Sonics 109, Blazers 101
description: SEATTLE (UPI) - Jack Sikma and James Donaldson combined for 41 points and 29 rebounds.

title: Trade Publications In Antitrust Action
description: American Business Press, the association of trade publications, has filed a complaint with the Justice Department seeking an investigation into whether the proposed purchase on Wednesday of Production Magazine by the National Machine Tool Builders Association violates the Clayton antitrust act.

title: Sports World Specials; Help From Above
description: No, Yankee fans, despite what you may suspect, George Steinbrenner has no plans to don the hallowed pinstripes and direct his team's destinies from the bench. He has no desire to be the next manager of the Yankees. And who could blame him? Why get caught in a revolving door?

title: A BRANIFF AMERICAN AIR DUEL
description: Howard D. Putnam, Braniff International's chairman, says he can't wait to move his staff out of the modern $70 million complex to spartan quarters in a hangar at Love Field, the old airport where the airline got its start.

title: ON FIFTH AVE., A GOOD DAY TO BE GREEK
description: ''Zito Ee Ellas'' (''Long Live Greece''), Melina Mercouri cried out from the head of the the annual Greek Independence Day parade yesterday.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1982
description: International Salvadorans jammed polling places in the constituent assembly elections, some to the sound of gunfire in the background. They turned out in such numbers that the Government extended voting hours into the evening. Guerrillas kept voting places closed in Usulutan, El Salvador's third largest city, and voting was reportedly light in San Francisco Gotera, capital of the largely rebel-dominated Morazan Province. Guerrillas delayed voting in other places, but after Government control was restored, people turned out to vote. (Page A1, Column 6.) Some Salvadorans walked for miles to cast their votes. On both sides of the Pan American Highway near Ilopango, east of San Salvador, a parade of people marched to polling places past billboards exhorting ''Your vote - the solution.'' Some crossed a guerrilla roadblock to vote. Others held back, although the leader said the guerrillas would not stop voters. (A1:5.)

title: No Headline
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about the Newark Museum gave an incorrect price for a painting by John Singleton Copley purchased in 1948. It was $15,000.

title: BRIEFING
description: Squash Talk

title: QADDAFI, NOT WASHINGTON, IS PROMPTING TUNISIA'S DEFENSE EFFORT
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADA BEGINS LICENSING PAY-TV NETWORKS
description: Pay television is coming to Canada and with it the hope that the Canadian air waves will be less American. Last week, the Canadian Radio-Television and Telecommunications Commission licensed one national network of general appeal, one for culture-conscious audiences, and four regional networks. They will begin operating in April of next year and it is hoped that the profits they make will allow the emergence of national program production that will reflect Canadian values.

title: INCREASE IN RATES IS EXPECTED
description: Short-term interest rates are widely expected to rise in late March and April in tandem with large increases in the nation's money supply, but analysts disagree about whether the higher rates and money supply surge will be temporary or long-lasting.

title: N. Carolina Wins Lacrosse Classic
description: Peter Voelkel's goal with 2 minutes 20 left broke an 11-11 tie and North Carolina, defending Division I champion in the National Collegiate Atheletic Association, went on to defeat Adelphi, 14-11, today in the fifth annual Manhasset Lacrosse Classic.

title: Gubernatorial Payoff
description: It was one of those bets that governors are always making when state pride is on the line at some major sports event. For the 1981 Orange Bowl, in which Florida State met Oklahoma, Gov. Bob Graham of Florida said he would spend a day harvesting wheat in Oklahoma if Oklahoma won, and Gov. George Nigh of Oklahoma said he would spend a day picking oranges in Florida if Florida State won.

title: NETS DEFEAT KNICKS
description: The Knicks suffered through another defeat tonight, losing to the Nets, 113-106, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Afterward, Michael Ray Richardson entered the Nets' locker room and walked toward the first player he saw, Otis Birdsong, who had not been in uniform because of an injury. ''Don't do it to us like that,'' he said good-naturedly. He greeted the other Nets similarly.

title: Man and Woman Found Slain in Car
description: An argument apparently led a 17-year-old man to kill a 20-year-old woman and then commit suicide, authorities said today.

title: AMY ALCOTT WINS GOLF BY A SHOT
description: Amy Alcott birdied the 17th hole today, finished with a two-under-par 70 and scored a one-stroke victory over JoAnne Carner in the $175,000 Women's Kemper Open golf tournament.

title: Sluggish Diamond Sales Prompt New Campaign
description: A sure sign that that the diamond market needs some stimulation is the announcement from N.W. Ayer, longtime agency for De Beers Consolidated Mines, that the client is tripling its ad budget to $10.6 million and will be advertising on TV and in magazines all year instead of just pre-Christmas, when half of the diamond dollars are spent.

title: Of Stephen V. Klein
description: Laura Sue Dembicer, senior accountant of Touche Ross & Company in New York, was married yesterday to Stephen V. Klein, a third-year medical student at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Rabbi Paul R. Siegel performed the ceremony at the Terrace-on-the-Park in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Bronx Man Is Arrested In $50,000 Meat Theft
description: A four-month investigation into the hijacking of more than $1 million worth of meat in the Bronx has resulted in the arrest of a man suspected of stealing a trailer full of meat.

title: ALEXANDER NEARING A YANKEE CONTRACT
description: A year ago, after the Mets defeated the Yankees in their annual spring exhibition game, George Steinbrenner was livid and singled out Mike Griffin for his harshest criticism. He instantly banished Griffin, a pitcher, to the Yankees' farm team in Columbus.

title: SCOUT LEADER TRAPPED IN CAVE IN JERSEY BELIEVED TO HAVE DIED
description: A New Jersey Scoutmaster trapped in a crevice deep in a cave Saturday on a spelunking expedition with a Boy Scout troop was believed to have died of exposure early today despite frantic efforts by scores of rescue teams.

title: Lakers 116, Kings 111
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, playing his 1,000th professional game, and Bob McAdoo helped stymie a late Kansas City rally. The Lakers were leading by 12 points early in the fourth period when the Kings unleashed an 11-4 spree to pull to 101-98.

title: Citizen Watch Account Assigned To Ted Chin
description: The Citizen Watch Company of Lyndhurst, N.J., marketers of the Japanese-made watch, has assigned its advertising to Ted Chin & Company, the agency that helped make U.S. News & World Report famous.

title: BUYER AND SELLER SHARE MISERY AT A FARM AUCTION
description: When the first good thaw came, the widow sold the farm. That done, today she sold away the tools of her husband's trade, the tools of a farm wife's life and nearly all the possessions their work together had gained.

title: HARVARD TEACHER AND OFFICIAL
description: Dr. Stephen Kemp Bailey, an educator and public administration specialist equally at home in classrooms and government offices, died Saturday at his home in Lincoln, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 65 years old.

title: FOLLOW-UP
description: Reagan's Doctors

title: Seoul Marathon To an Australian
description: Laurie Whitty of Australia won the Seoul international marathon today in 2 hours 14 minutes 34 seconds.

title: MAGNA CARTA SAFE AS FIRES ARE SET
description: Two fires that were apparently started by arsonists broke out Saturday in the 750-year-old Salisbury Cathedral, which houses the original copy of Magna Carta, but the document was unharmed.

title: Oilers Set Mark On 2 Fast Goals
description: Dale Messier and Dave Lumley scored goals in the first 24 seconds tonight and set a National Hockey League record as the Edmonton Oilers rolled to a 6-2 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: To Stephen J. Cohen
description: In the Mariner's Chapel at the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, L.I., yesterday Janet Lynne Heilshorn was married to Stephen J. Cohen by the Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg, a Congregational minister.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Le Anne Schreiber LOVE AND WORK. By Gwyneth Cravens.342 pages. Knopf. $13.50.

title: CREATURE FROM THE BOONDOCKS
description: In the nation's capital, it is known as ''the creature from the boondocks''; among editorial writers, it is derided as a device capable of doing enormous mischief; to liberal economic savants, it is an apparition that strikes horror and loathing in fine-tuned hearts.

title: I.R.A. Kills Inspector In Ulster's Constabulary
description: Gunmen killed a full-time member of the Royal Ulster Constabulary today as he left a church service in Londonderry, the police said.

title: TOOL ORDERS FELL 41% IN FEBRUARY
description: New orders for machine tools, a barometer of the economy's wellbeing, fell 41 percent in February compared with the period last year, the National Tool Builders' Association said yesterday.

title: Guns vs. Vests in the Streets
description: Bulletproof vests made of high-tech synthetic fibers are tough enough to stop a slug and yet light and flexible enough to be worn for hours in a patrol car. Their invention was a major contribution to police work.

title: GIRL, 6, WILL NOT BE TRIED AS ADULT IN ASSAULT
description: Six-year-old Nancy Jo Burch, charged with aggravated assault, will not be taken to an adult court for jury trial after all.

title: Jays Cut Espinosa
description: The Toronto Blue Jays gave their outright release to the pitchers Nino Espinosa and Juan Berenguer, and to Ted Cox, an infielder, today. Espinosa, who is 28 years old, signed as a free agent with the Blue Jays last September and pitched only one inning. He had been with the New York Mets and Philadelphia.

title: MET OPERA: JAMIE MORRIS
description: DR. MIRACLE was the most disturbing Mephistophelean incarnation sung by James Morris in ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon.

title: North Dakota Regains Title
description: The clock was winding down and his team had the championship clinched late Saturday night, but the North Dakota hockey coach, Gino Gasparini, repeated one word to his troops: ''Discipline.''

title: Cosmos Lose, 2-1
description: Derek Spalding scored in a shootout Saturday night to lift the Chicago Sting to a 2-1 victory over the Cosmos in a Spring Cup North American Soccer League exhibition match.

title: CELTICS STREAK IS ENDED BY 76ers
description: Julius Erving, the Philadelphia 76ers' captain, called a team meeting in his hotel room Saturday. He was unhappy with the play of the 76ers, who had lost three of their previous four games.

title: DRIVE TO REVIVE SEVEN-UP CO.
description: Ever since it bought the Seven-Up Company, Philip Morris Inc. has been expected to work the same marketing magic it applied to a previous acquisition, the Miller Brewing Company.

title: Bridge:; 3 Victors Have Tense Time In Women's Quarterfinals
description: Four teams of stars battled here this afternoon in the semifinal stage of the Women's Knockout Team Championship, and three of them were breathing hard after tense quarter-final matches Saturday.

title: KEY ROLE FOR COACHES IN FINAL
description: The 44th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship game may be one of the most clinical title games in recent years, with strategy perhaps playing a bigger role than athletic skills. The two coaches, Dean Smith of North Carolina and John Thompson of Georgetown, may have a more direct part in the outcome than coaches normally do.

title: To Charles Diamond
description: Jacqueline Sara Glodstein, a social worker with the U.J.A.- Federation of Jewish Philanthropies in New York, was married yesterday to Charles Michael Diamond, who is studying for the rabbinate at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York. Rabbi Leon Spielman and Rabbi Israel Silverman performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation.

title: GENE KELLY BRINGS YOUNG DANCERS TO WHITE HOUSE
description: Gene Kelly, the dancer and singer, introduced some promising young performers at the White House today and, true to his word, he neither sang nor danced.

title: Utah Gains Title 2d Year in Row
description: Lisa Shirk of Pitt, Mary Ayotte-Law of Oregon State, and Sue Stednitz and Elaine Alfano, both of Utah, won individual titles Saturday in the final competition of the 1982 National Collegiate Athletic Association Women's Gymnastics championships.

title: Carolina 500 to Yarborough
description: Cale Yarborough, helped by a six-car crash that involved four of the top six cars with about 50 laps remaining, won the Carolina 500 stock car race today at North Carolina Motor Speedway.

title: METS OPTIMISTIC ON LONG SOUGHT TRADE
description: The ''other half'' of the Mets, those who did not go to Fort Lauderdale to challenge the Yankees, did not challenge anybody today because rainstorms canceled their exhibition game here against the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: 'WHY BOTHER STAYING IN BUSINESS?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoke, Fire and Chemical War
description: The State Department has made a serious case that chemical weapons are being used against the populations of Afghanistan, Laos and Cambodia. Just what agents are being used, and who in each case is responsible, is not yet clear, but the weight of evidence suggests that chemical warfare, outlawed by the Geneva protocol of 1925, has made another ugly reappearance in the world.

title: THE SELLING OF AN ARMS SALES POLICY
description: Describing himself as ''a quiet, inoffensive individual,'' James Lane Buckley said a few months ago that it had been a shock to find himself ''described as a malevolent instrument of a new American policy that rejoices in feeding the third world with evermore sophisticated and destabilizng weapons.''

title: Queen's Proclamation
description: Queen Elizabeth will go to Ottawa to proclaim Canada's new Constitution, which severs its lingering Colonial ties with Britain. The new Constitution, worked out by Canadian leaders last fall and approved last Thursday by the Parliament in London, will complete the process of Canadian independence that began in 1867 but was interrupted in 1931, when the national and provincial governments were unable to agree on amendments.

title: Auto Union and A.M.C.  Still Discuss Investments
description: The United Automobile Workers and the American Motors Corporation are close to agreement on an employee investment plan proposed by the company, the union's chief negotiator with the company said today.

title: Nureyev Helps Promote Japanese Vodka
description: What with the recent popularity of Russian vodka, it's not surprising that the people promoting Japan's Suntory Banzai Vodka are pleased about getting Rudolf Nureyev to say for publication, ''Is very good vodka.'' Chiat/ Day, the Los Angeles-based agency, is running the full-page black and white ad first in national May issues of Gentlemen's Quarterly, Esquire and The New Yorker and regionally in 12 other publications.

title: Soviet Jew Is Seized In Red Square Protest
description: An 18-year-old Soviet Jew was seized in Red Square today when he held up a sign demanding permission to migrate to Israel, witnesses said.

title: Capital's Mayor in Primary
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of the District of Columbia announced Saturday that he will seek re-election. His challengers in the Democratic primary on Sept. 14 include Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Carter Administration, and four City Council members: John Wilson, Betty Ann Kane, Charlene Jarvis and John Ray.

title: Becomes a Bride
description: Rebecca Winchester Wassell, daughter of Lieut. Comdr. James W. Wassell, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Wassell of Hope, N.J., was married yesterday to William Thomas Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Murphy of Lovettsville, Va.

title: THE BUDGET, ACT II
description: ''There's nothing wrong with postponing tough decisions until after the election,'' said the Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, ''as long as you admit you're postponing them.''

title: Commodities; Heating Oil Futures Lawsuit
description: WERE traders who sold short February heating oil futures contracts almost forced into a default because the buyers conspired to prevent them from delivering the fuel? Specifically, did the buyers, or longs, tie up a large number of fuel oil barges in New York harbor on the specified delivery date in an attempt to prevent the shorts from fulfilling their contract?

title: LAWYERS SAY GHOST OF NEW DEAL STILL HAUNTS POLITICS
description: It is still a mantle many wish to assume. It is also a shadow many wish to avoid. So the jaunty old New Deal shows no signs yet of losing its one enduring quality - controversy.

title: Married to Melvin Sturz
description: June G. Peikon, widow of Isaac Peikon, was married yesterday in New York to Melvin Sturz, son of Ida Sturz of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Jacob Sturz.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: BRIEFING
description: On Baker's Priorities

title: TV: PAVOROTTI GETS HIS OWN ONE-HOUR NETWORK SPECIAL
description: it's official. Tonight at 8 o'clock on ABC-TV, the Italian tenor gets his own prime-time special on commercial television. He thereby joins a still rather select group of performers ranging from Frank Sinatra, Bob Hope and Carol Burnett to Cheryl Ladd, John Schneider and the Grand Ole Opry's Minnie Pearl.

title: TWO COACHES UNDER CRITICISM SEEK THE SAME GOAL
description: NEW ORLEANS AS it turns out, the bulky, serious-looking man in the Georgetown dressing room, the former football player holding the tape recorder as Pat Ewing speaks, is not there just for the 7-foot freshman's education. He is there for Ewing's protection.

title: Democracy's Hope in Central America
description: Now to Build on El Salvador's Enthusiasm

title: U.N. Asked to Examine Central America Issue
description: France urged the United Nations today to investigate the charges made against each other by Nicaragua and the United States.

title: NORTH CAROLINA SLIPS PAST GEORGETOWN BY 63-62
description: In a brief series of frantic moments tonight, Dean Smith's critics at last received an answer that will last forever.

title: Twice 'Yes' in Westchester
description: In today's countywide referendum, Westchester voters will decide propositions dealing with electric power and waste disposal. Both merit support.

title: Steelworker Stock Proposal
description: United Steelworkers union members are being asked this week to exchange $35 million in deferred benefits for stock in the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation.

title: Treatment of a Suspect Assailed in Brink's Case
description: Defense lawyers told a Federal judge yesterday that lawenforcement authorities had illegally transferred, interrogated and mistreated a suspect who has been identified as an informant in the Brink's robbery in Rockland County last Oct. 20.

title: British Ford To Cut Prices
description: The Ford Motor Company, the only profitable major auto maker in Britain, said today that it was cutting prices by an average 4.5 percent to narrow the gap between domestic prices and those on the European continent.

title: Chess: Catalan Opening Becomes Potent Positional Weapon
description: The Catalan Opening is undergoing a series of developments at a rate faster than any other opening system. This hybrid of Queen's Gambit and king's fianchetto, once thought effete, now sports refinements that make it a potent weapon of positional pressure against the black queenside.

title: THE LEFT GROPES FOR OPTIONS
description: The democratic left - the unions, minority members, feminists, peace-movement activists, and all the other social-change constituencies - is groping toward a programmatic alternative to Ronald Reagan's policies.

title: Steel Production Down
description: The nation's steel production fell to 1.757 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a 2 percent decrease from the previous week's 1.793 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Gehl Shutdown
description: The Gehl Company, a manufacturer of farm machinery, will shut down for four weeks beginning next Monday because of high inventories and slow sales, the company said. About 1,200 factory and office workers will be affected. The company plans to reopen May 3.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 30, 1982
description: International Early returns in El Salvador indicated that the moderate Christian Democrats had won more votes than any of the five other parties in Sunday's elections, but the victors' final total would not give them a majority in the new constituent assembly. The extreme right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance led by Roberto d'Aubuisson, a controversial former army major, was in what the United States Ambassador called a ''strong second position.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) The Administration was jubilant over the apparent victory by Salvadoran moderates. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. called the voting ''a victory we have all won.'' (A1:5.)

title: ATTORNEY KEEPS JOB AFTER REMARKS ON C.I.A. LINK
description: The United States Attorney who revealed the intelligence connections of a Mexican under criminal investigation in San Diego will keep his job, according to Justice Department officials, although Congressional officials say he probably violated provisions of pending legislation aimed at protecting the identity of American intelligence agents.

title: G.M. Canada Files Insurance Claim
description: General Motors Canada Ltd. said it had filed a $65 million (Canadian) insurance claim with the Export Development Corporation, the federal agency that had insured a contract calling for G.M. to sell the Government of Iraq 12,500 1981 Chevrolet Malibus.

title: BOEING MAKES BID FOR CARGO AIRCRAFT CONTRACT
description: The Boeing Company has proposed that the Pentagon abandon a plan to buy 50 giant Lockheed C-5 transport aircraft and instead purchase a fleet of Boeing 747 jet freighters to give the military the ability to move the Rapid Deployment Force to the Middle East in a crisis.

title: Allis-Chalmers Sees Net Gain
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corpoaration, a Milwaukee-based heavy equipment manufacturer, said in its annual report that it expects to report a first-quarter net gain of $16.7 million, or $1.33 a share, from the sale of a stake in a West German joint venture.

title: OUTLOOK FOR THE LOCAL AREA
description: The vagaries of nature - a cruel winter, an unusual scarcity of predators, a shift in prevailing wind patterns and other unpredictable factors - make it impossible to precisely predict the size of this year's caterpillar infestation in any given state or area. But New York, New Jersey and Connecticut officials made some general predictions:

title: Roberts Sent to Phils
description: The Houston Astros sent Dave Roberts, a utility infielder who got a contract worth $1.1 million last year, to the Philadelphia Phillies for a minor league pitcher. ''Dave just didn't do what we wanted,'' said the general manager, Al Rosen.

title: FIVE MEN TIED TO CRIME FAMILY FACING CHARGES
description: Five men described as members of the Bonanno crime family were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday. The charges against them included conspiracy to murder rival gang members and the attempted robbery of a Manhattan town house owned by the sister of the late Shah of Iran.

title: PANEL CONSIDERS CITING LUCHOW'S AS A LANDMARK
description: The brownstone home of Luchow's, the century-old restaurant on East 14th Street that is moving to the theater district in June, is being considered for landmark designation by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 7-3
description: In the beginning at Madison Square Garden tonight momentum was swinging like a pendulum between New York's two hockey teams. For six minutes, the Rangers could get no shots, and the Islanders built a two-goal lead.

title: SPECIFIC TV SHOWS TIED TO CHILD'S ACHIEVEMENT
description: ATEAM of social scientists in California is not prepared to say that watching ''B.J. and the Bear'' made students do poorly in school, but the researchers do maintain that children who watched the show regularly were the students most likely to have low scores on standard achievement tests. The next most likely shows to have been viewed by low-achieving students were ''The Incredible Hulk'' and ''Dance Fever.''

title: Aqueduct Jockey Dies After a Spill
description: Amado Credidio Jr., a 26-year-old jockey, died of multiple head, chest and internal injuries at a hospital in Queens last night, two hours after he was hurled from his mount and trampled by his own and several following horses in the ninth and last race at Aqueduct.

title: Mayor Byrne's Choice Wins Post as Cook County Leader
description: George Dunne, who had held the chairmanship of the Cook County Democratic Party since the death of Mayor Richard Daley, lost the post Monday to an Alderman backed by Mayor Jane Byrne.

title: Mets Are Less Hopeful of Deal
description: ''If the Mets go through with the trade,'' Lee Mazzilli said today, ''it'll be the biggest mistake they ever made.''

title: SUPREME COURT BARS CASE ON JOB RIGHTS AT RELIGIOUS COLLEGES
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge to the Federal Government's authority to prohibit religious colleges from discriminating on the basis of race or sex in their hiring policies.

title: ILLEGAL-ENTRY CURBS THAT HURT CITIZENS
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Group Trading Plan
description: The Midwest Stock Exchange said today that it had asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval to become the first exchange to trade industry stock groups as a unit.

title: AMATEUR 'CAVER' TEAMS RESPOND TO RESCUE CALL
description: A nationwide network of rescue teams made up of amateur cave explorers was set into motion after a Scoutmaster became trapped in a cave here Saturday.

title: MRS. GANDHI DEFIED BY DAUGHTER-IN-LAW OVER POLITICAL PARTY
description: Sanjay Gandhi's widow addressed a poltiical meeting Sunday that had been organized by one of his close associates but that was denounced by her mother-in-law, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. After the meeting, which was in @Lucknow, she returned to her mother-in-law's home here where she lives.

title: ENVIRONMENT AGENCY WON'T RELAX RULES ON LEAD LEVELS IN GASOLINE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, in the face of strong new evidence linking lead levels in human blood with those in gasoline, has decided to drop plans to repeal regulations limiting the amount of lead in gasoline, agency officials disclosed today.

title: IN SHIFT, CAVE RESCUERS ARE EXCAVATING HILLSIDE
description: Rescue workers early today abandoned a day-long effort to tunnel to a 48-year-old Scoutmaster wedged inside an old cave here and began digging away the entire hillside housing the cave.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt WHY WE WERE IN VIETNAM. By Nor- man Podhoretz. 240 pages. Simon & Schuster. $13.50.

title: State Democratic Chief Suffers a Heart Attack
description: Dominic Baranello, the New York State Democratic chairman, had a heart attack last week and is recuperating at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital here.

title: Exxon-Sharp Deal
description: The Exxon Office Systems Company said it would market a Japanese facsimile machine in the United States and Canada. The unit, made by the Sharp Corporation, is capable of transmitting a page in less than a minute. It will supplement Exxon's aging line of Qwip facsimile machines, which take between two and six minutes to transmit a page, an Exxon spokesman, Frank Abbruscato, said.

title: ISRAEL TIGHTENS CONTROL OVER ARAB NEWSPAPERS
description: In an effort to dampen the unrest in the West Bank and to play down the political strength of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Israeli military authorities have tightened their censorship of Jerusalem's Arab newspapers and have prevented most of them from circulating outside the city.

title: Fastest Yacht Up for Sale
description: The Dutch skipper Cornelius von Reichten crossed the line first in record time today in the 27,000-mile Whitbred Round the World Race, and after celebrating with a magnum of champagne he put his 76-foot yacht, Flyer, up for sale at $900,000. Flyer had been at sea for 120 days, beating the record for the trip by 14 days.

title: HEALTH QUALITY AND COSTS: A DELICATE BALANCE
description: The Price of Health Examining the Medical System Third of five articles. By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

title: Chrysler Extends Rebate Program
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was extending its free maintenance and rebate program, which offers up to $2,000 on some vehicles, until April 10.

title: WHAT PRODUCES GREAT SKILLS? SPECIFIC PATTERN IS DISCERNED
description: THEY are all world-famous: 100 young concert pianists, Olympic swimmers, tennis players and research mathematicians who reached the top of their fields between the ages of 17 and 35. But their names are the secret of a research team at the University of Chicago that promised anonymity in order to investigate how these exceptionally talented people got where they are.

title: Senator Resists Bill on N.F.L.
description: Senator Howard Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, said today that he would start a filibuster, if necessary, to block quick Senate action on legislation that would grant antitrust exemption to the National Football League.

title: C.I.A. CHIEF URGES SCIENTISTS TO GUARD SECRECY
description: Adm. Bobby R. Inman, deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, urged the scientific community today to come forward with proposals to reduce the flow of technical information with military and industrial applications to the Soviet Union or face the prospect of Government-imposed constraints.

title: A GYPSY MOTH BROADENS ITS RANGE, LITTLE CHANCE OF CURBING SPREAD IS SEEN
description: SMALL buff-colored lumps are mottling the bark of tree trunks and limbs all over the Northeast again this spring, raising the likelihood of another massive infestation of gypsy moths. As the days grow warmer, the lumps will split open, freeing untold billions of caterpillars that will start to do the thing they do best: eat leaves.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BOOKISH

title: CHARIOTS OF FIRE,' KATHERINE HEPBURN AND HENRY FONDA
description: WIN TOP OSCARS By ALJEAN HARMETZ

title: GIVE SCHOOLS THE MONEY TO FIGHT YOUTH CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: Court to Decide on Forced Tax Sales
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Government can force a married couple to sell their home to pay off taxes owed by only one of the spouses.

title: Canada Seizes Zapata Oil Rig
description: The Zapata Corporation, a Houston-based offshore drilling concern, reported that its rig, the Zapata Scotian, had been seized by the Canadian Government and would be held until the company posted $4.5 million (Canadian) in bonds.

title: CITY OPERA TO BE ALIVE WITH THE SIGNS OF MUSIC
description: The New York City Opera, whose performance tonight of "Susannah" will be the first in the city to be interpreted in sign language, is wrestling with an unusual concept: To Give the deaf an idea of the sound of music, what clues can be provided through the "look" of music?

title: Advertising; Hotpoint To Symon, Thomas
description: SYMON, THOMAS & HILLIARD has been assigned General Electric's Hotpoint appliance account, which will be especially rewarding if and when Hotpoint decides to do some consumer advertising.

title: Another New Bodyguard for a Princess
description: Diana, the Princess of Wales, has just gotten her third bodyguard in a year, a high turnover for members of the Royal Family, which traditionally has one trusted bodyguard for years.

title: THE SHUTTLE: PERFECTION ELUDES NASA BUT CONFIDENCE GROWS
description: Last November, as the second flight of the space shuttle Columbia was ending, some of the space agency's top engineers looked back at the string of equipment failures that had afflicted the first two flights. Having just been forced to cut the second mission short because of one such failure, they conceded that they had created a machine so complex that they had not yet mastered it. So until they developed more confidence, they said, they would have to treat the space shuttle cautiously and gingerly.

title: People
description: * Thomas L. Wilcher named senior vice president of Hicks & Greist Inc.

title: JAPAN COMFIRMS ITS CURB ON AUTO EXPORTS TO U.S.
description: The Government announced today that it would restrict automobile shipments to the United States in the coming fiscal year to the past year's level of 1.68 million units, as a Foreign Ministry spokesman had predicted in Washington last week.

title: No Headline
description: An article on Detroit yesterday incorrectly identified the city in which Rosa Parks inspired a civil rights struggle. The city is Montgomery, Ala.

title: INVESTMENT UNIT SET BY CHASE
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank is planning to establish a new subsidiary for its investment banking activities that would be comparable in size to Bache Halsey Stuart Shields & Company, one of the nation's 10 largest securities concerns, the bank said yesterday.

title: 'Jimmy Dean' Will End After Sunday's Matinee
description: ''Come Back to the 5 and Dime Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean,'' written by Ed Graczyk and starring Sandy Dennis, Cher and Karen Black, will close with Sunday's matinee, after 52 performances and 12 previews at the Martin Beck Theater.

title: Dewey Selmon Traded
description: The San Diego Chargers have acquired Dewey Selmon, a linebacker, from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in exchange for a future draft choice.

title: PLIGHT OF A ONCE OPTIMISTIC FARMER IN INDIANA: BROKE AND $35 MILLION IN DEBT
description: In five thick black books full of figures is the chronicle of Eugene Smith's graceless drop from millionaire farmer to flat-broke debtor; they tell him he owes $35 million.

title: REAGAN ASKING $4.2 BILLION FOR BUILDUP OF CIVIL DEFENSE
description: The Reagan Administration disclosed plans today for a seven-year civil defense program designed to ''provide for survival of a substantial portion of the population in the event of nuclear attack.''

title: 'Annie' Cast to Entertain at the White House; 'Annie' at Easter
description: The White House has lined up the entertainment for the annual Easter Egg Roll on April 12, and once again Martin Charnin, the lyricist and director of ''Annie,'' has been asked to bring down the red-haired Annie, Daddy Warbucks and the chorus of orphans to sing.

title: FIELD BOARD SAID TO ASK FOR RISE IN BATUS OFFER
description: The directors of Marshall Field & Company yesterday sought another increase from Batus Inc. in the value of its proposal to acquire the Chicago retailer, financial sources reported.

title: Senate Unit Said to Bar Silo Use for MX Missile
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee today blocked President Reagan's plan for the interim deployment of MX missiles in existing silos, urging him to develop a permanent system as soon as possible, sources in Congress said.

title: DEJECTED THOUSANDS LEAVE LANDING SITE
description: About 50,000 dustblown and dejected spectators retreated slowly from this topsecret military base today after the Columbia's landing was canceled because of bad weather.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL LEADS COAST RACE
description: George Deukmejian, the 53-year-old Attorney General of California, who has built his political career on caution and on support of strong measures against crime, has emerged as the leading candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor.

title: PERSUADING EUROPE; Persuading Europe
description: A delegation seeking to persuade British and West German business people to ''make it in New York'' will leave for Europe in May, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: WHITE HOUSE JOINS SPENDING BATTLE
description: The White House joined the Senate leadership today in opposing any attempts to stall a temporary spending bill that is needed to finance seven departments of the Federal Government after Wednesday night.

title: S.I. POLICE SEEK PAIR WHO LEFT HOME MARCH 5
description: The police have been trying for three weeks to solve the case of a Staten Island couple who disappeared after leaving for an evening trip to Atlantic City. Their car was found the next day on a Brooklyn street.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Question of Trade

title: SPLIT ON U.S. POLICY SEEN AT E.E.C. TALKS
description: West European leaders appeared seriously divided over the best response to the world economic crisis and the strains it is producing in their relations with the Reagan Administration at the start of the Common Market's semiannual meeting today.

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 30, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan offered a five-step plan to help the housing industry in a talk before the National Association of Realtors. Under his plan, pension fund investments in the credit markets would be increased and Federal regulations on home mortgages would be eased. (Page D1.) Sales of new single-family houses dropped 11.8 percent in February. (D18.) Contracting for new construction fell 16 percent, to $8.88 billion, in February. (D18.)

title: Want Ads Off In February
description: The amount of help-wanted advertising placed in the nation's major newspapers declined again in February for the third straight month, the Conference Board said yesterday.

title: * Coradian Corp., Albany, announced that Kenneth T. Lally, president and chief executive officer, would assume the additional post of chief financial officer.
description: * Criton Corp., Bellevue, Wash., has appointed Kent R. Martin president of its Republic Electronics Inc. subsidiary in Melville, L.I.

title: EAST GERMANS WARMLY GREET JARUZELSKI
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, flew here today for a day's visit. It was his second trip abroad since he imposed martial law in Poland on Dec. 13, and like his first trip, to Moscow, was ostensibly aimed at bolstering economic cooperation.

title: Canada Gets Control Of Its Constitution
description: A bill to give Canada control over its own Constitution passed quietly into law today after Queen Elizabeth gave royal assent to the measure.

title: The U.N. Today; March 30, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the situation in Israeli-oc- cupied territories at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutionsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SUPREME COURT REFUSES TO BAR JERSEY DISTRICTS
description: The Supreme Court removed today any remaining doubt that New Jersey voters will elect their members of Congress this year according to disputed district lines adopted in January by the Democratic-controlled State Legislature.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Waived Luis Gomez, reserve shortstop, and two pitchers, Larry Bradford and Rick Matula.  BOSTON (AL) - Optioned three pitch- ers to Pawtucket farm club in Interna- tional League: Danny Parks, Brian Den- man and Dave Schoppee, all right-hand- ers.  CHICAGO (AL) - Sent Bobby Molina- ro, outfielder, to Chicago Cubs to complete deal last season that sent Lynn McGlo- then, pitcher, from Cubs to White Sox.  CHICAGO (NL) - Optioned Mel Hall, outfielder, and Scot
description: Young, pitchers, Dave Edler, infielder, Rod Allen, outfielder. Assigned to disabled list and the minors was Brian Allard, pitcher.

title: Violent Fashion
description: There is a tailor in Beverly Hills who's doing very well with bulletproof suits. And in the great tradition of those who lend their names to sheets, sunglasses and chocolates, he's also got a nice line of designer pistols.

title: CITY MUSEUM HONORS SEGAL
description: Martin E. Segal, chairman of the board of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, last night received the Museum of the City of New York's highest honor, its $24 Award. The prize commemorates the purchase price that the Dutch are reputed to have paid the Indians for Manhattan.

title: N.B.A.'s Near-Strike
description: The Kansas City Kings' failure to pay more than $50,000 in deferred salaries to Oscar Robertson and Brian Taylor, two of their former players, almost caused a strike that would have wiped out all seven National Basketball Association games Sunday. Larry Fleisher, the general counsel for the players association, was able to reach 10 of the 14 player representatives and told them not to play Sunday's games.

title: DESK-TOP FARMERS BRACE FOR A CURSE OF ABUNDANCE
description: With spring trying so hard to make its way into the nation's Farm Belt, life here in Washington is getting a little more frantic for the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, which runs one of the biggest permanent floating numbers games in town.

title: Comfort in Defeat
description: Everyone knows defeat is painful, but what dulls the pain for the defeated? The answer may well be opiate-like chemicals produced naturally in the body.

title: TAXI PANEL, AFTER YEARLONG STUDY, OFFERS 73 WAYS TO IMPROVE SERVICE
description: A wide-ranging report on the New York City taxi industry recommended yesterday that off-duty police officers be encouraged to drive cabs and that nonmedallion taxis be permitted to pick up people who hail them in some underserved areas of the city.

title: JOINT CHIEFS OF STAFF CHAIRMAN IN 1950's
description: Gen. Nathan F. Twining of the Air Force, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in the late 1950's and a commander of Allied aerial campaigns in Europe and the South Pacific in World War II, died of a heart attack yesterday at Wilford Hall Medical Center at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas. He was 84 years old.

title: RECITAL: 2 VIRTUOSOS OF CLASSICAL ARABIC MUSIC
description: AS many 20th-century composers have recognized, one way to revivify the worn Western musical tradition is to attend to other cultures' musical manners. The Alternative Museum, then, is performing a valuable service in presenting the folk musics of the Middle East, Central Asia and Greece in a concert series.

title: ISRAELI PRESIDENT WARNS ARABS NOT TO STRIKE
description: President Yitzhak Navon warned Israeli Arabs today not to participate in strikes and demonstrations in support of protests on the West Bank.

title: Hobson Reconciled To Role as Backup
description: For the first time since they began spring training seven weeks ago, the Yankees took a complete day off today. Butch Hobson didn't exactly appreciate that, but then, he hasn't been in the Yankees' spring camp all of that time.

title: Depositors' Bid For Canal Raised
description: The Depositors Corporation of Augusta, Me., has again raised its bid for the Canal Corporation of Portland, topping a rival offer by the Merrill Bankshares Company, based in Bangor.

title: Test Jet to Houston: 'Sorry, You Guys'
description: JOHN W. YOUNG (after flight over landing strip): Well, there was about two miles of visibility on Runway 17, and Runway 23 is covered up in sand.

title: Accounts
description: * Greenwood Mills Marketing Company is withdrawing its account from D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius.

title: WICKES CHANGES MANAGEMENT
description: Directors of the debt-ridden Wickes Companies have abruptly removed its longtime chief executive and several of his top aides, handing the reins today to Sanford G. Sigiloff, a specialist in salvaging troubled companies.

title: DOROTHY KATE TAYLOR
description: Dorothy Kate Taylor, who with her husband, Jacques, built the Taylor Maid Service into one of the largest residential cleaning businesses in New York City, died Sunday of a heart attack. She was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Household Names in a District Attorney's Office
description: ''They were treated like everybody else when they were interviewed,'' Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, was saying yesterday, ''and they will be treated like everyone else when they come here.''

title: Ad Agencies Called Victors in Cable Boom
description: It is inevitable that cable television will become a ''fullfledged advertising medium,'' Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst with the L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin brokerage, predicts. But does he suggest that investors buy their way into publicly held, cable-owning companies? He does not.

title: SENATE REPUBICANS BLOCKING CAREY APPOINTMENTS
description: State Senate Republicans are blocking many of Governor Carey's nominations during his final months in power, saying that they are an effort to lock into office appointees who would carry out his general philosophy long after his term ends.

title: DON'T SUBVERT HABEAS CORPUS
description: The Senate and House Judiciary Committees are considering legislation, sent to Capitol Hill by the Reagan Administration, that seeks to reform habeas corpus procedures. In reality, it would radically curtail the right to petition the Federal courts for a writ of habeas corpus. The prospect of such a law's being enacted is profoundly disturbing, for it would devalue vital constitutional protections.

title: New Separation Method
description: A method for rapid separation of chemical constituents when exposed to high voltages has been developed by a chemist in New Jersey. It is said to manifest a new type of electrochemical process that the chemist, Norman Haber, calls ''electro-molecular propulsion.''

title: ABC NEWS TALKING TO PHIL DONAHUE
description: ABC NEWS is talking with Phil Donahue about his becoming a major contributor to the network's new 1 A.M.-2 A.M. news program, which will follow ''Nightline'' beginning next fall. According to sources at ABC News, the network is interested in having Mr. Donahue do a regular interview segment before an audience - the format that Mr. Donahue now uses on his popular daily syndicated talk show.

title: Bangladesh Acts To Stop Corruption
description: President A.F.M. Ahsanuddin Choudhury called on the nation today to cooperate with the martial law authorities in stamping out corruption.

title: TRADE OFF WORLDWIDE
description: World trade stagnated last year, making its worst showing in six years, according to an international survey made public today by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: International
description: A NATO base has only lukewarm support in Iceland A2 Bonn starts land surveys for mis- sile emplacement A3 Jaruzelski visits East Berlin for the day A3 Explosive on French train kills 5 and injures 14 A3 Anglican-Roman Catholic report on unification issued A4 Around the World A5 Weinberger assures Seoul of U.S. commitment to its security A7 In India, Sanjay Gandhi's widow defies the title: Lombardi's Son Is Confronting an Image
description: With a hint of a sneer, some persons across the bargaining table refer to him as Vince Lombardi Junior. Actually, Vincent Henry Lombardi was never Junior, although he knew what it was to be enveloped by the shadow of his late father, Vincent Thomas Lombardi, one of the most charismatic figures in football.

title: Fed Bank President Appointed in Cleveland
