description: Most often when the top job changes hands at one of the Federal Reserve's 12 district banks, the new president has time to get his feet wet before plunging into national policy making.

title: Quake Kills 2 in Peru
description: Two people died in the stongest earthquake to strike Peru this year, the authorities said today. The quake registered 5.6 on the Richter scale with an epicenter near Pisco, 60 miles southeast of Lima.

title: News Analysis
description: ''Vote Defeats Violence'' read the banner headline in La Prensa Grafica, El Salvador's largest-circulation newspaper. And Salvadorans and American officials were in jubliant agreement today that Sunday's election was a resounding defeat for the leftist opposition. The parties representing the views of the guerrillas and their liberal political allies did not participate in the campaign, but some guerrillas had vowed to disrupt the voting.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF HAIG'S REMARKS ON EL SALVADOR
description: Following is a transcript of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s statement to reporters today on Sunday's election in El Salvador, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: EXPERT SAYS 'VOLATILE FUEL' WAS USED IN STOUFFER'S FIRE
description: Westchester County's chief arson investigator testified today that a ''volatile fuel, a high-grade burning material, something like gasoline'' was used in the fatal fire at Stouffer's Inn 16 months ago.

title: Q. In normal conditions, do the members of any species feed regularly on themselves?
description: A. This is a difficult question, not least because so many circumstances observed by humans are so far from ''normal conditions.'' It has been noted over and over that carnivorous fishes eat smaller members of their own species, especially their own young (and other fishes' young of the same generation). This is often seen, for instance, among guppies in aquariums, where the young cannot escape their parents beyond a tempting distance, but it is not known whether it happens in the wild, where the baby fish can seek locations out of harm's way. Again, trout are reputed to be voracious eaters of their own young, but some scientists believe this happens only when other nourishment is lacking. Reports of cannibalism among squid have been published, but have also been contested. Among invertebrates, the females of praying mantises and many spiders regularly attack and consume the males after mating. These circumstances are ''normal,'' but infrequent in the life of any particular female mantis or spider. According to Donn Rosen, curator of icthyology at the American Museum of Natural History, cannibalism as part of normal life is not known for certain to occur in any species except man, and, more particularly, among certain peoples in Papua New Guinea.

title: Backer & Spielvogel Ends Tie With Bon Jour
description: Backer & Spielvogel and Bon Jour International have ended their relationship, according to a staff memo circulated yesterday at the agency. The account, which came to the shop last May 1, once billed $6 million.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''T HE most eligible girl in the world,'' as she is being called in some New York circles, was in town to be photographed for Town & Country's June cover, and from all reports she's here for good. She is Patrizia Gucci, 19-year-old daughter of Dr. Aldo Gucci, head of the Gucci empire.

title: John Hay Whitney Left $5 Million to His Wife
description: John Hay Whitney, the investor and philanthropist who died last month at the age of 77, left $5 million and most of his personal property to his wife, according to his will and other papers filed in Nassau County Surrogate Court here.

title: KEMP KEPT BUSY DISAVOWING PRESIDENTIAL TALK
description: In his office, on Capitol Hill walks and in speeches across the country, Representative Jack Kemp is constantly pointing it out: There is no reason to believe that President Reagan will not run for re-election in 1984.

title: Bridge:
description: For all but a handful of players the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League have passed into history. But still in battle here today after surviving problems in the semifinals, were the top-ranked teams in the Women's Knockout event.

title: U.S. OIL RUSH BEGINS TO SLOW
description: After two years of the most furious deal-making and well-drilling activity in history, the American oil rush of the 1980's appears to be tailing off.

title: Talking Business with Clark of Baker International; Rise Foreseen In Oil Demand
description: At age 55, E.H. Clark Jr. has been chief executive of Baker International for 17 years and made millions for himself and the diversified oil service company with his shrewd assessments of trends in global oil pricing.

title: ON NICARAGUAN INDIANS
description: With 5,000 Miskito Indians in Honduran refugee camps and 9,000 more forcibly resettled in Nicaraguan camps, these Central American Indians have become symbols of the East-West conflict. Nicaragua's detractors portray the Miskitos as victims of international Communist expansion; its supporters see them as counter-revolutionaries, guided by right-wing Latin Americans and the Central Intelligence Agency. The Miskitos' prominence - the majority live on Nicaragua's Atlantic Coast, where they also constitute a majority of the population - has led to the uprooting of about 15 percent of them and the blurring of their legitimate disputes with the Sandinists.

title: MGM Hotel Chief To Head Tracinda
description: Fred Benninger, who helped transform MGM's Grand Hotels Inc. into one of the world's largest and most successful hotel-casino companies, has been named president of the Tracinda Corporation, a private investment company owned by Kirk Kerkorian, the reclusive financier.

title: Buffalo Savings Officer Begins New York Job
description: Thomas P. Bilbao, the 44-year-old group vice president of the Buffalo Savings Bank, has suddenly gained a lot of power over the futures of hundreds of New York City bank employees.

title: Market Place; Wrather Corp.  Is Staying Put
description: NO thought is being given now to liquidating the Wrather Corporation although a decade ago the company was considering winding up its affairs.

title: Bottle Law's Start Delayed in Suffolk
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered Suffolk County yesterday to delay implementing its new beverage-container deposit law, which had been scheduled to take effect Thursday.

title: REAGAN, UNDER PRESSURE ON ARMS, NOW FAVORS FREEZE AFTER BUILDUP
description: The Reagan Administration, seeking to counter pressure for a freeze in nuclear arms, has decided to back a freeze only after the United States overcomes what it terms a Soviet lead.

title: CENTRISTS DON'T EAT OATMEAL
description: Time was when you could tell who was a Republican and who was a Democrat. Now it's getting murky. Everyone wants to be a centrist or a pragmatist or a neo-something-or-other. President Reagan, for example, is a Neo-Federalist who is still loyal to the Republicans.

title: COWLES TO LIQUIDATE HOLDINGS
description: Cowles Communications Inc. announced yesterday that it had revived its plan of four years ago to distribute its assets to stockholders and then to dissolve the company.

title: CATHOLIC-ANGLICAN REPORT ISSUED
description: After a 12-year study, an international commission of high-ranking Anglican and Roman Catholic churchmen said today that the Pope would be the ''universal Primate'' if the two churches reunited after more than four centuries of separation.

title: PANEL AGAIN REJECTS A RULE ON DISCLOSURE OF USED-CAR DEFECTS
description: The Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation voted today to veto a Federal Trade Commission rule requiring used-car dealers to inform consumers of known mechanical defects and the availability of a warranty.

title: FORD PLANS RECALL OF ENGINE WORKERS
description: In a rare callback of furloughed auto workers, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would recall 500 hourly workers at a suburban Detroit engine plant to help increase production of engines for the auto maker's Escort and Lynx subcompact cars.

title: Interest Rates Rise Broadly
description: Short- and long-term rates rose yesterday, as the credit markets remained fearful of higher rates in coming weeks. Although higher short-term rates are expected by many to be a temporary phenomenon accompanying a late March buildup in cash at large corporations and the flow of income tax payments and refunds to individuals, other market participants are not confident enough in those forecasts to buy notes and bonds in anticipation of lower rates. Buyers' unwillingness was increased yesterday when overnight rates for bank loans in the Federal funds market rose to a high of 15 5/8 percent and traded around 15 3/8 percent most of the day.

title: LATE RISE SENDS DOW UP 5.00
description: Stock market prices rose in late trading yesterday in light trading as concern over the economy and interest rates kept many investors on the sidelines.

title: NEW HOME SALES DOWN IN FEBRUARY
description: Sales of new single-family houses tumbled 11.8 percent in February, to the second-lowest monthly rate in at least two decades, the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development reported today.

title: LIBERAL PARTY OPENS WAY FOR KOCH TO BID FOR BACKING IN RACE
description: Fending off a challenge by two Liberal Party officials, Raymond B. Harding has solidified his leadership of the party and paved the way for Mayor Koch to attempt to reconcile his differences with the Liberals and seek their endorsement for Governor.

title: DEAN SMITH FINALLY MAKES THE FINAL ONE
description: NEW ORLEANS VINDICATION came for Dean Smith, and it had to be at the expense of one of his ''personal friends,'' John Thompson. Beating John Thompson's basketball team was the only way Dean Smith could stop being the Brooklyn Dodgers of college basketball, and last night he won his personal World Series, 63-62.

title: Police Lieutenant Slain In Guatemala Ambush
description: A police official who was expected to be replaced by the new junta has been killed in an ambush, the police have disclosed.

title: HOUSING AID OFFERED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan today proposed a five-step plan to aid the housing industry by increasing the flow of pension funds into the credit markets and by easing Government regulations on home mortgages.

title: TV: NORTH DAKOTA FARMERS' MOVEMENT
description: ''NORTHERN LIGHTS,'' tonight's ''American Playhouse'' presentation on WNET-TV at 9 o'clock, was completed in 1978 and won a prize at the 1979 Cannes Film Festival as First Feature. The film comes to television with some financial aid from the North Dakota Committee for the Humanities and Prairie Public Television. It deserves all the support it can get.

title: ADOPTED BOY HEARS OF MOTHER
description: Gloria Hunsinger was reported yesterday as startled to discover that not only had she been declared deceased, but also that the son she bore 18 years ago and thought to be dead was alive and living in New York, adopted by a policeman. She said she wanted very much to see her son again.

title: Vehicle Sales By Japan Fall
description: Japan's exports of passenger cars, trucks and buses fell 10.8 percent in February from a year before, to 472,981 units, continuing a persistent downtrend in the face of overseas economic stagnation and Japan's export restrictions, the Japan Auto Manufacturers Association said today.

title: Suspect Is Seized In Police Shooting
description: The police said they surprised a suspect in the shooting of a New Jersey trooper and arrested him without a struggle at his home today.

title: Canadian Pacific Lists 11.1% Holder
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd., a diversified transportation, mining and real estate concern based in Montreal, reported that the Power Corporation held 7,952,180 common shares, or 11.1 percent, of its common shares outstanding as of Jan. 29.

title: FIERCE SANDSTORM DELAYS THE RETURN OF SPACE SHUTTLE
description: A blinding sandstorm, driven by winds reaching 55 miles an hour, raged across the space shuttle's desert landing site today and forced a one-day postponement of the Columbia's return to the earth.

title: DON'T REGULATE CABLE TV INTO AN EARLY GRAVE
description: T o the Editor: Two recent news articles in The Times point up major concern among responsible cable television operators with the pervasive economic regulations proposed by Federal, state and local authorities:

title: Begin's Coalition Wins Key Vote in Parliament
description: Israel's coalition Government, grappling with a wave of unrest in occupied Arab lands, tonight won a key parliamentary vote that apparently insured its survival until it returns Sinai to Egypt next month.

title: New Hearing Ordered On Title-Fight Rights
description: A state appeals court today ordered a new round of legal hearings to decide whether Bob Arum's Top Rank Enterprises or Triangle Productions, headed by the rival promoter Murad Muhammad, had the rights to Eddie Mustafa Muhammad's fights.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All I could think, after having been through four elections in Connecticut, is how you can get a signiicant drop in voting if you have a light mist on election day - let alone death threats, violence and a war raging.

title: SECOND COACH CITES ILLEGAL RECRUITING
description: Tex Winter today became the second major college basketball coach in five days to say that he had turned in a rival college to the National Collegiate Athletic Association for illegal recruiting.

title: DR. RAYMOND COTTER
description: Dr. Raymond Cotter, veterinarian for Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways for 25 years, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Upper Brookville, L.I. He was 54 years old. After training and racing standardbred horses in Goshen, N.Y., Dr. Cotter enrolled at Cornell Medical Veterinarian School, from which he was graduated in 1958.

title: WEINBERGER VOWS SUPPORT FOR SEOUL
description: After touring a segment of South Korea's front line today, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger returned to Seoul and renewed the Reagan Administration's commitment to South Korean security.

title: BOEING CONCERNED BY UNITED'S THREAT
description: Malcolm T. Stamper, president of the Boeing Company, said yesterday that the company was taking very seriously a threat by United Airlines to cancel orders for 20 Boeing 767 jet airliners. United said it would cancel the orders if Congress modified the law on taxleasing credits.

title: NEW YORK COURT RULES THAT JURY MAY TAKE NOTES
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that judges may permit jurors to take notes during trials in the state's courts. But the court also ruled that a judge who allowed note-taking must caution the jurors on the proper use of notes in their deliberations.

title: Nancy / Fancy; Wonderful Life
description: She was born in 1930 to an attorney named Carson Drew and his wife, who died when Nancy was 3. Had Mrs. Drew lived, her nose would have been chronically out of joint: dad dotes on his daughter.

title: VOTE IN SALVADOR GIVING PLURALITY TO DUARTE'S PARTY
description: Early results in El Salvador's elections indicated today that the moderate Christian Democrats had won more votes than any of the five other parties. However, their final total would not give them the majority needed to control the new constituent assembly.

title: French Car Production
description: French car production fell to 224,100 vehicles in February from 234,600 in January, but was 2.9 percent above the February 1981 level, the car makers' association said today. Car exports rose to 128,200 last month from 123,700 in January, and were 8 percent above February 1981.

title: 3 Seized in Murder Of Retired Officer
description: Three young Brooklyn men were charged yesterday in connection with the murder of Theodore Rodill, a 47-year-old retired police officer and limousine service operator from Washington, whose body had been found over the weekend in Brooklyn under a Manhattan Bridge abutment.

title: British TV Takeover Set
description: A fight for control of the Associated Communications Corporation, a British television and show business empire, ended today with victory for an Australian financier, Robert Holmes a Court.

title: The Senate Confirms Nickel As U.S. Envoy to South Africa
description: The Senate confirmed Herman W. Nickel today as the United States Ambassador to South Africa. Mr. Nickel, 53 years old, a journalist, has advocated increased United States investment in South Africa. Representatives of several church groups testified against Mr. Nickel at his confirmation hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, saying that they feared he would not strongly oppose the South African policy of apartheid.

title: Australian Ore Price
description: Australian iron ore suppliers and Japanese steel mills have reached basic agreement for a price rise of about 17 percent for shipments to Japan in the fiscal year starting in April, industry sources said here today. Japan imported about 133 million tons of iron ore last year, nearly half of it from Australia.

title: Reagan on TV Tomorrow
description: President Reagan will hold a nationally televised news conference at 8 P.M. Wednesday that will include a statement on talks with the Soviet Union on nuclear disarmament, the White House announced today. It will be the ninth news conference of his Presidency.

title: Clemson Under Inquiry
description: Clemson, whose football team earned the final No.1 ranking for the 1981 season, announced today that it had received an ''official inquiry'' from the National Collegiate Athletic Association into charges of recruiting violations in the school's football program.

title: HELMS PROPOSES STATES PAY FOR THEIR ERRORS ON FOOD STAMPS
description: Senator Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Agriculture Committee, said today that he would seek legislation to hold states financially responsible for all erroneous payments they make in the food stamp program.

title: EXPLOSIVE ON A FRENCH TRAIN KILLS 5 AND INJURES 14
description: A high explosive tore up the second coach of the Paris-Toulouse express tonight, killing five passengers and injuring 14 others, half of them seriously. The police said the explosion was caused either by a bomb, deliberately set off, or by explosives being transported clandestinely.

title: Atlanta Transit Chief Resigns for Houston Job
description: Alan Kiepper, general manager of the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, resigned today to become head of Houston's public transportation system.

title: Stolen Pass Haunts Brown
description: Fred Brown, Georgetown's sophomore point guard from the Bronx, sat quietly and remembered the pass that lost a championship.

title: NEW MEMBERS HONORED BY THEATER HALL OF FAME
description: A small, starry family of the Broadway theater clan gathered yesterday to honor seven new members of the Theater Hall of Fame. The hall, founded in 1971 to celebrate the greats of the American theater, is in the Uris Theater, where the ceremony was conducted.

title: ASSAULT CASE INVOLVING 6-YEAR-OLD TO BE MEDIATED
description: The parents of Nancy Jo Burch and the parents of Shirley Lynn Nickolls have agreed to take their problem to an arbitrator.

title: THE CITY
description: The City Council President, Carol Bellamy, said yesterday that she was having the legal aspects of the Westway highway project reviewed, but she declined to discuss a dispute that her opposition to the project has recently aroused.

title: RAIDER TRIAL OPENS
description: Maxwell Blecher, attorney for the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Commission, told Federal court jurors today that the primary issue in the National Football League's attempt to block a move by the Oakland Raiders to Los Angeles is the nation's system of free enterprise.

title: Queens Bus Lines Face Strike Threat
description: The Transport Workers Union warned yesterday of a possible strike at midnight tomorrow against four private bus lines in Queens unless negotiators make satisfactory progress by the deadline.

title: THE DOCTOR' WORLD
description: ONE HUNDRED years ago last week, the German physician Robert Koch reported to a meeting in Berlin his discovery of the bacillus that causes tuberculosis. That report paved the way to control of a disease that had been a scourge since ancient times. Sanitariums were built and public health campaigns began.

title: VW Price Rise
description: Volkswagenwerk said today that it had raised its car prices in West Germany by an average 3.9 percent, effective immediately. The last increase was 2.3 percent, announced in December. Car prices at VW's Audi subsidiary will rise an average 4.3 percent, also effective today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said its board had authorized the purchase of up to the total number outstanding of Allied's series D preferred shares.

title: BONN STARTS SURVEY FOR MISSILE SITES
description: A Foreign Ministry official said today that West Germany had started preparations for construction work necessary for the deployment of new United States @medium-range missiles starting in late 1983 or in 1984.

title: Alsands Decision Soon
description: Energy Minister Marc Lalonde, answering questions in Parliament, said today that he expected to have an answer by Tuesday on the future of the Alsands synthetic oil project. Five oil companies have withdrawn from the $13 billion (Canadian) project, leaving 50 percent of the equity without backing.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ''THERE are great curriculum ideas and outstanding teaching scattered all over the city,'' said Myrna Cooper in 1978 as she prepared to organize New York City's first federally supported teacher center. The center's immediate goal, she added, would be to bring those bits of success to the attention of others who are demoralized by failure.

title: BLACK LEADERS SEEKING MANHATTAN SURROGATE POST
description: A coming vacancy in the Manhattan Surrogate's Court - a prized political job - has become the quest of black political leaders. The planned resignation of Millard L. Midonick from the two-member court, which oversees hundreds of millions of dollars every year in estates, will put the $60,900-a-year post on the November ballot.

title: MONROE DOCTRINE'S BIG STICK ACROSS THE SEA
description: To the Editor:

title: South African Premier Calls for Party Congress
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha called today for the first national congress of his National Party since 1968. Mr. Botha said the Federal Council, the party's national executive group, decided unanimously at a meeting in Cape Town to hold the congress July 30-31 in Bloemfontein, capital of the Orange Free State.

title: Jordan, Case & McGrath Gets Tonka Account
description: The Tonka Corporation, the toymaker from Mound, Minn., is reassigning its advertising to Jordan, Case & McGrath. The business, billing in the neighborhood of $3.5 million, has been handled since 1977 by Campbell-Mithun of Minneapolis.

title: Digital to Offer New Products
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation plans to introduce three personal computer models in May, the company's president, Kenneth H. Olsen, told security analysts. He said the new products would be for business users, rather than for home use.

title: ASTRONAUTS MUST CHOOSE ONE OF THREE RUNWAYS
description: As the space shuttle Columbia searches for a place to land today, it has three primary options, each with strengths and drawbacks. If the shuttle lands on the concrete runway at Edwards Air Force Base in California, one of the two sites under consideration if wind conditions rule out a landing at the White Sands Missile Range, there will be no immediate way to unload its various fuels, some of which are lethal or highly volatile.

title: Reno Woman Who Killed Six With Auto Sentenced to Die
description: A jury sentenced Priscilla Ford to death today for killing six people as she drove through a crowded sidewalk on Thanksgiving Day 1980.

title: Soviet Climbers Are Set Back In Attempt on Mount Everest
description: Soviet climbers suffered a setback in their bid to scale Mount Everest's southwest face when a storm battered their camp and blew their tents away, Nepalese officials said today.

title: WAITING AND WATCHING ON HOLLYWOOD'S NIGHT
description: Susan Sarandon began her Academy Award vigil at 7 o'clock this morning by jogging a mile around Beverly Hills wearing sweat pants and a T-shirt marked ''Hollywood High School.''

title: Transient Arrested In Formaldehyde Spill
description: A transient was arrested in Oakridge, Ore., today on suspicion of removing the valves from a railroad tank car and allowing 21,000 gallons of toxic formaldehyde to spill into a ditch feeding the Russian River near here.

title: SKYSCRAPER DESIGN INNOVATOR
description: Fazlur R. Khan, the structural engineer whose innovative concepts made possible such major skyscrapers as the Sears Tower and the John Hancock Center, both in Chicago, died Saturday of a heart attack in Saudi Arabia. Mr. Khan, who had been traveling in Asia and the Middle East, was 52 years old.

title: IRAN APPEARS TO WIN KEY BATTLE POSITIONS HELD BY IRAQI FORCES
description: An eight-day offensive by Iranian forces has apparently pushed the invading Iraqi Army 24 miles back from strategic positions west of this southern Iranian city, battlefield inspections showed today.

title: 4 BIG BANKS IN CITY ASSAILED OVER LOANS FOR URBAN AREAS
description: Five years after the passage of Federal legislation requiring banks to make more loans to homeowners and businesses in lower- and middleclass urban neighborhoods, four major banks in New York City have yet to make ''significant improvement'' in complying with the act, a Queens Congressman asserted yesterday.

title: WORTHY'S BIG PLAY A MATTER OF INSTINCT
description: ''Instinct took me there,'' said James Worthy in describing why he suddenly moved out from his defensive assignment to steal a Fred Brown pass with five seconds left, the play that assured North Carolina the N.C.A.A. basketball championship.

title: Jacob W. Schwab, 89, Textile Manufacturer
description: Jacob W. Schwab, a co-founder and retired chairman of the board of United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., an international diversified textile manufacturing company with headquarters in Manhattan, died last Friday at White Plains Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: MERGER IS THE COSTLIEST CURE FOR THRIFTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Futures Drop; Computer Trades Cited
description: The financial futures market was battered yesterday, as traders reacted to the sharp price declines in the underlying Treasury bonds, bills and Government National Mortgage Association instruments.

title: U.S. Rejects Aid for Steel
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige today rejected investment incentives and other special programs for the nation's struggling steel industry, saying it must sink or swim with the rest of the economy.

title: Mother and Son Indicted In Cleveland Baby Theft
description: A mother and her grown son were indicted today for child stealing in the kidnapping of 4-year-old Denise Kay Gravely.

title: Addenda
description: * The Mickelberry Corporation announced the completion of the Cunningham & Walsh acquisition by its subsidiary Newcourt Industries.

title: READY-TO-WEAR HITS ITS STRIDE
description: Twenty years ago the burgeoning number of readyto-wear designers here declared war against the couture, contending that the custom-made clothes were outmoded and not suited to contemporary life. Out went gentility, elegance, girdles and gloves. In came an easy, raffish approach to clothes, exemplified by knitted shifts, miniskirts and T-shirts.

title: Stanford Hires Davis
description: Dr. Tom Davis, head basketball coach at Boston College for five years, is leaving to accept a similar position at Stanford University, according to several reports. The Boston radio station WRKO reported yesterday that Davis would officially be named at a news conference Tuesday in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Commercial Credit Co. of Baltimore announced an offering of $200 million of medium-term senior notes, sold by Commercial Credit Securities Inc.

title: Delinquent Mortgages Up
description: Late payments on mortgage loans rose to a 17-year record last month as recession and high interest rates continued to squeeze household budgets, a savings and loan industry group said in a report scheduled for release Tuesday.

title: LAWYER CONVICTED AT BRIBERY TRIAL
description: William A. Borders Jr., a prominent lawyer in Washington, was convicted today of soliciting a bribe and obstructing justice.

title: EX-F.C.C. OFFICIALS SSEKING A LICENSE FOR CELLULAR RADIO
description: Last year three former officials of the Federal Communications Commission broke the mold. Instead of taking jobs in law firms or the broadcast industry, they turned entrepreneur and started a communications company of their own.

title: GRANDPA JONES: LATEST SMITHSONIAN TREASURE
description: For two hours Sunday night, Grandpa Jones performed on the stage of the Baird Auditorium at the Smithsonian Institution. He clawed and flailed his banjo, jumped into the air, stamped the floor, yelped and yodeled, told cornpone jokes and sang about two dozen songs from his repertory of old-time country music. At the end, his audience of mostly city folks asked for an encore.

title: STROH OFFERS TO BUY 67% OF SCHLITZ
description: The Stroh Brewery Company of Michigan yesterday offered to buy twothirds of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Wisconsin, the nation's third-largest brewer, for nearly $325 million in cash.

title: ENERGY ISSUES FACE WESTCHESTER VOTE
description: Westchester County residents will vote Tuesday on two energy-related questions: whether to authorize creation of a municipal agency to purchase inexpensive electric power, and whether to establish a taxing district to help finance a garbage-to-energy power plant.

title: France Asks U.N. to Examine Nicaraguan and U.S. Charges
description: France urged the United Nations today to investigate the charges made against each other by Nicaragua and the United States.

title: When Roses Are Sexist, What Do You Give?
description: If it is unlikely that a business executive of either sex would mark National Secretaries Week by giving their male secretaries flowers, then how long can an advertising campaign suggesting such a remembrance escape the label sexist?

title: TWO BROKERS TAKE SAFEGUARD'S STOCK
description: Safeguard Scientifics Inc. said yesterday that two brokerage firms had assumed ownership of 54.7 percent of the company's stock because an investor could not meet margin calls on that block of stock.

title: Trainers' Hotline
description: Because the state's high schools cannot afford to hire professional athletic trainers, a hotline will be set up at the Indiana University School of Medicine to answer questions from coaches. Dr. Merrill Ritter, an orthopedic surgeon, and a consultant to most Indiana University teams, announced the plan to have professional trainers answer hotline calls from his office.

title: World Bank Sets 3 Loans
description: The World Bank today announced loans totaling $131.7 million to South Korea, Brazil and Peru to support agricultural projects.

title: ICELAND'S ELVES ARE ENLISTED IN ANTI-NATO EFFORT
description: Saying that they were looking for elves who might be endangered by American phantom jets and Awacs reconaissance planes, about 150 Icelandic leftists trooped out to this North Atlantic Treaty Organization base last weekend.

title: Mexico Volcano Erupts, Killing At Least 10
description: A volcano dormant for centuries erupted without warning today, killing at least 10 people, injuring 200 others and forcing 20,000 to flee their homes under a 120-mile shower of ash and cinder.

title: JOHN C. NEALY
description: John C. Nealy, an accountant and former assistant to the treasurer of The New York Times Company, died Sunday at his home in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness.

title: TWO WEST BANK MAYORS CALL ISRAEL POLICY DOOMED
description: Occupied West Bank, March 30 - The towns and cities of the West Bank withdrew today into a heavy mood. Most stores and schools were closed by a general strike. Many streets were deserted, giving whole towns a look of sullen abandonment, except that here and there Palestinian youths threw stones at Israeli vehicles and burned old tires, sending billows of smudgy smoke rising over stone walls and tile roofs.

title: THOMAS WAREAGLE
description: Thomas Wareagle, chief of the Osage Indian tribe of Oklahoma, died Monday at the age of 93. Mr. Wareagle was the last chief of the Osage nation. When Oklahoma became a state in 1908, the nation became a tribe. The tribe is to elect a new chief, since Mr. Wareagle's wife, Pearl, is his only survivor.

title: EMBASSY'S FIRST LADY: LIVELY PARIS PACE
description: There's a new face in the front row at many of the fashion shows here this week. The tall woman with the intense blue eyes and honey blond hair seems to be having a good time as she chats animatedly with Paloma Picasso at the Emanuel Ungaro show, or with her friend Val Cook, the fashion director of Saks-Jandel, the Washington store, at Jean-Louis Scherrer's.

title: MOSCOW'S MEANINGLESS NUCLEAR EDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. OPENS DEFENSE
description: The National Football League, contending that it would crumble if the teams ignored all its rules, opened its defense today in the retrial of the antitrust suit brought by the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Commission.

title: 6 Seized in Dutch Robbery
description: Six suspects were arrested today in a million-dollar bank robbery over the weekend, the police said. Most of the stolen goods were jewelry and securities from 70 safe deposit boxes.

title: BILL TO CUT WELFARE ROLLS CLEARED IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: The Pennsylvania Senate tonight approved a bill that could eliminate as many as 64,000 ''ablebodied'' people as recipients of state-financed general assistance welfare payments.

title: MAJOR IRAQ WITHDRAWL IS THE 2d IN 18 MONTHS
description: For the second time in the 18 months since the Iraqi-Iranian war began, Iraq has been forced to make a major withdrawal under heavy Iranian attack. This retreat appears to have aroused fears in Iraq that an Iranian invasion may be near.

title: India-Chevron Oil Deal
description: India has signed a long-term contract with the Chevron Overseas Petroleum Inc., a unit of the Standard Oil Company of California, to explore for oil in an offshore area northwest of Bombay, the Government said today. Under terms of the agreement, Chevron will drill exploratory wells 250 miles northwest of Bombay off the Gujarat coast for a maximum of five years, spending a minimum of $29 million in the first three years.

title: 4 SOILDERS KILLED AND DOZENS HURT IN ARMY AIRDROP ON COAST DESERT
description: Four Army paratroopers died and dozens were injured today when a large airdrop designed to test the Pentagon's ability to respond quickly to trouble around the world went awry in the California desert.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sugar Ray Leonard's next fight, a defense of his welterweight title against Roger Stafford on May 14 in Buffalo, will be televised live by ABC, the network announced yesterday. ... Victor Pecci of Paraguay was fined $6,000 by World Championship Tennis for his failure to appear for a W.C.T. tournament in Zurich or to forward an explanation. ... The lightweight boxer Howard Davis, a 1976 Olympic gold medalist who has fought only once in the last 15 months, will hold a news conference in New York today to announce that he will meet Angel Cruz on April 16 at the Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. ... The former star wide receiver Lionel Taylor, for 12 years an assistant coach in the National Football League, the last five with the Los Angeles Rams, joined the Oregon State staff of Coach Joe Avezzano. Taylor, most recently the Rams' offensive coordinator, was one of five Los Angeles assistants dismissed when the season ended. ... Doctors in St. Louis said surgery would not be required to treat a kidney infection that has hospitalized Craig Virgin, the world-class distance runner.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The offices of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith are in a terribly diplomatic part of town, on that long stretch of street across from the United Nations choked with Mercedes Benz automobiles bearing DPL license plates and with quiet square buildings housing organizations like the Turkish Center and the African-American Institute.

title: BATUS GETS 92% OF FIELD STOCK
description: Batus Inc., the American subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries of London, said yesterday that its tender offer for the common shares of Marshall Field & Company had been heavily oversubscribed, with Batus receiving a total of 11.1 million shares, or 92 percent of Field's outstanding stock.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES BILL ON CABLE TV LIMITATIONS
description: The House Judiciary Committee approved a bill today that would broaden the rights of television stations and producers to control use of their copyrighted programs by cable television systems.

title: Birthday Gift
description: All along, almost everyone in Britain has been expecting the birth of the Princess of Wales's first baby in June but now she has let slip the date she is actually hoping the baby will arrive -July 1, her own 21st birthday.

title: SOUTHERN BLACKS FIGHT RURAL POVERTY
description: A man who believes that rural blacks have never been emancipated is quietly and methodically organizing the Southern poor to help themselves to overcome discrimination and poverty.

title: Student at Arizona U. Charged in Campus Fires
description: A University of Arizona student, employed part time by the campus police, was charged today with arson in five campus fires this month, officials said.

title: Reagan, Class of '32, to Address Class of '82
description: Since he is doubtless the most famous graduate of Eureka College in Illinois, it follows that President Reagan will give the commencement address there. He will speak on May 9, the 50th anniversary of his graduation in 1932.

title: PAPANDREOU AND THE MILITARY: FROM ANIMOSITY TO COURTSHIP
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, once seen as a staunch opponent of Greece's traditionally rightist military, has courted the loyalty of the armed forces by appointing a new leadership, offering economic inducements and pursuing a nationalistic foreign policy.

title: White Lion in Johannesburg
description: The Johannesburg Zoo today announced the birth of the first white lion to be born in captivity.

title: SENATORS PRESS AMENDMENT TO OVERTURN THEIR TAX BREAK
description: A move to repeal a tax break that Congressmen granted themselves last December survived a key test in the Senate tonight. A motion to table, or kill, the measure was defeated by a vote of 77 to 20.

title: WORLD TRADE UNIT AT SEARS GETS CHIEF
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailing concern, announced yesterday that John F. Waddle had been appointed president of the world trading company that Sears has just formed.

title: TOXIC CHEMICAL IS FLUSHED INTO RIVER
description: In a downpour that had thwarted their efforts to shore up a makeshift dam holding back water contaminated with formaldehyde, workers today ripped out the dam and allowed the water to cascade into the Russian River.

title: Dow Spending Cut
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it had cut its capital spending program for 1982 by almost $400 million from its original plan and that it expects to spend less than $1 billion worldwide. The company said in its annual report that capital expenditures for plant and equipment totaled $1.2 billion in 1981, down slightly from each of the prior two years. Capital spending will likely be less aggressive in the future as Dow shifts its product line toward less cyclical, less capital-intensive products, it said.

title: 7 More Bodies Found Along Florida Coastline
description: Seven bodies washed ashore today, apparently bringing to nine the number who died when an aging Haitian tramp freighter broke up in the surf Monday.

title: TV: CHERYL LADD STARRING IN A NEW KIND OF SPECIAL
description: WITH everybody from Luciano Pavarotti to the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus doing a television special these days, producers are in a tizzy trying to bring innovative fillips to tired formats of star routines sprinkled with guest contributions and a couple of big production numbers. Tonight at 10:30 o'clock on ABC-TV, Don Mischer, acting as producer and director, ventures forth with ''Cheryl Ladd ... Scenes From a Special.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chemical Bank has named as vice presidents William B. Cornfield, Mary Ellen Travis, Reginald P. Smith, Thomas J. Rizzo, G. Harrison Houston 3d, Kenneth H. Ringel, Deborah Gerard Adelman, James A. Capo and Timothy T. Gannon.

title: Government's Debt to Downtown
description: Some say that the primary danger to the city of New Haven these days lies just next door, in North Haven, where developers plan a huge shopping mall equal in square footage to New Haven's entire downtown retail space. Though its sponsors say the mall will cause New Haven little harm, studies commissioned by the Department of Housing and Urban Development contend otherwise.

title: NEXT, IN EL SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration endorsed El Salvador's elections for a constituent assembly in order to legitimate President Jose Napoleon Duarte and the Christian Democratic Party. The elections, however, ended up legitimating Roberto d'Aubuisson and his extreme right-wing Arena Party. However pleased the Administration may be by the voter turnout, the success of four rightwing parties and the possibility that the Christian Democrats may be completely excluded from the new government reduces to shambles the rationale behind Mr. Reagan's policy in El Salvador.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutionsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ACTRESS'S TESTIMONY VIDEOTAPED FOR HINCKLEY'S LONG-DELAYED TRIAL
description: A year to the day after he shot President Reagan and three other men, John W. Hinckley Jr. was brought to the courtroom here today under heavy guard.

title: Western Aides to Press For Accord on Namibia
description: Senior Western officials will travel to Angola and South Africa this week in a new effort to speed up the independence of Namibia, the British Foreign Office said today.

title: Yachting Magazine Moves Headquarters
description: After 75 years of residency in New York City, Yachting magazine, a Ziff-Davis publication, is leaving its slip here and moving its headquarters to Cos Cob, Conn.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THANK goodness, April Fools' Day is tomorrow, and therefore Metropolitan Diary readers have been spared the obligatory jape that would have had to appear in this space if the column were in fact appearing on April 1. ''The traditional journalistic response to the challenge of April Fools' Day has always been deplorable,'' says Hugo Flesch, a frequent Metropolitan Diary contributor who is, curiously enough, an authority on April Fools' Day.

title: HOMOSEXUAL TAKES LEAVE OF A JOB AND OF AN AGONY
description: In more than 15 years on state and Federal payrolls, Dan J. Bradley, the departing president of the Legal Services Corporation, always worried first about keeping his secret. It survived routine background checks by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the relentless grind of the rumor mills in this city of whispers. And, despite some close calls, the chance discovery that might have sidetracked his public service career never happened.

title: Safeguard Down 5 1/4 As Trading Reopens
description: Safeguard Scientifics Inc., a data processing concern that became part of the portfolios of two major brokerage houses when an investor was unable to meet margin calls, fell nearly 50 percent yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HOW HOBOKEN BECAME MECCA FOR ROCK BANDS
description: rock band called the Individuals, enjoys showing visitors to his apartment, the bullet holes in the wall and the bloodstained crucifix above the bed. ''A prostitute had the place before me,'' he says, ''and before that a guy who ended up murdering the super.'' Across town, the Bongos, another pop-rock band, live near a coffee factory and incorporate the rhythms of its machines into their music.

title: DISTINCTIVE FOODS OF THE ITALIAN JEWS
description: EDDA SERVI MACHLIN has vivid memories of the Passover she celebrated in Italy in 1944 when she was 17 years old. She even remembers the date: April 9. ''We were partisans, living in the hills with a Catholic family, my two brothers and my sister,'' she recalled. ''We bought a kid for 16 lire and asked a farmer to slaughter it for us. We made the matzoh and haroseth, and that was it.''

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 31, 1982; The Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators dropped 0.3 percent in February, the 10th consecutive monthly decline, the Commerce Department reported. It said the new figure showed that the economy was still in recession. Officials also revised downward figures reported for December and January. Thus, a December rise of 0.6 percent became a decline of 0.8 percent and a January decline of 0.6 percent became one of 1.2 percent. (Page D1.)

title: News Analysis
description: Lawrence H. Cooke, the most powerful judge in New York State, will soon be a litigant in his own courtroom. The stage for that drama was set yesterday by the Appellate Division ruling in the case of Morgenthau v. Cooke.

title: Careers; Marketing High-Tech Products
description: THE high-technology companies are increasingly aiming at the retail markets, by offering home computer terminals, software modules and peripheral attachments.

title: Coast Guard Band: It's All Aboard
description: Adm. John B. Hayes, the Coast Guard Commandant, said today that no members of the 45-member Coast Guard band would be dismissed after all.

title: U.N. Truce Observers Return To a Post in South Lebanon
description: United Nations observers have returned to the Palestinian stronghold of Beaufort Castle in southern Lebanon, more than two years after Israeli shelling drove them to abandon the post, United Nations officials said today.

title: South Yemen Asks Death For 13 in Sabotage Case
description: The prosecution today demanded the death penalty for 13 Yemenis on trial for alleged involvement in a sabotage conspiracy.

title: WILLIAM F. GIAUQUE, NOBEL PRIZE WINNER FOR CHEMISTRY IN '49
description: William F. Giauque, a Nobel Laureate in chemistry, died Sunday at an Oakland hospital after a brief illness. He was 86 years old.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: PROFESSIONAL chefs do not make a daily habit of eating dishes made with butter and heavy cream, foie gras and all the other culinary luxuries. These dishes, such as they are for a vast majority of the public, are for special occasions even for chefs.

title: FINAL PBS 'MIDDLETOWN' SEGMENT IS WITHDRAWN
description: Peter Davis, producer of the six-part public television documentary ''Middletown,'' decided yesterday to withdraw the controversial final episode of his series rather than make changes requested by the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: WILLIAM W. PHELPS Jr.
description: William Walter Phelps Jr., a retired senior vice president of the Mellon Bank, died of a heart attack Friday while at the Fox Chapel Country Club in Pittsburgh. He was 64 years old.

title: U.S. IS TRYING TO UPSET A 'HIGH-STRUNG' ISRAEL
description: Despite uneasiness over Israeli actions in the West Bank, the Reagan Administration has chosen to avoid doing or saying anything that might give Israel cause to delay its final withdrawal from Sinai on April 25, Administration officials said today.

title: Kitchen Equipment; AN OPENER FOR CLAMS
description: BEHIND my house in East Hampton there is a bay where I love to go clam digging. I go at low tide, often at sundown, so that when I have gathered a full bucket of littleneck, cherrystone and chowder clams, I can sit down to watch the sun set over the water. To get the clams, I go down on my knees and dig them out with my hands, wearing gloves. It's much faster than using a rake and I don't hurt my hands because the bottom where the clams are buried is soft.

title: Backing for Phelps
description: Donnie Walsh, who was an assistant coach at South Carolina from 1965 to 1977, added some punch to the recent charges by Digger Phelps, the Notre Dame coach, that many collegians are paid to play. ''This was just getting started about the time I left South Carolina,'' said Walsh, now an assistant coach of the Denver Nuggets.

title: ARMY CHIEF OF STAFF URGES A BROAD REORGANIZATION
description: Gen. Edward C. Meyer, the Army Chief of Staff, has proposed sweeping changes in the organization of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that would create a more independent military advisory council for the President and the Secretary of Defense to give the civilian leadership ''the best possible advice'' on war strategy.

title: Wine Talk; CHAMPAGNE: HIGHER PRICES ARE EXPECTED
description: unless I'm thirsty.''

title: TYWO PASSOVER FEASTS IN UNUSUAL STYLES
description: WHEN the seder table is set next Wednesday night in the home of Ilana and Albert Amini, the food will suggest a Middle Eastern feast rather than what is usually recognized in this country as the traditional Passover meal.

title: CHICAGO MAXIM'S CLOSES ITS DOORS
description: Maxim de Paris, this city's version of the prominent Parisian restaurant, closed its doors Saturday night.

title: REBAL CHIEF SAYS VOTE COULD PROLONG THE WAR
description: The leader of El Salvador's main opposition coalition asserted today that the elections Sunday had served to restore the power of the local oligarchy and could intensify and prolong the civil war.

title: Harvester Acts to Bar Plant Closing
description: The International Harvester Company today asked government officials in Indiana and Ohio for help in a costcutting drive aimed at preventing the closing of one of two giant truck assembly plants.

title: JWT'S 'IRREGULARITIES' TOP $30 MILLION
description: The JWT Group, parent of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, said yesterday that ''irregularities'' previously disclosed in the agency's syndication department exceeded $30 million and that at least two clients had been billed for TV spot commercials they did not get.

title: On Dangers in Meat
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Regarding the article ''Assessing Freshness of City's Meat and Poultry'' (Feb. 17), it should be pointed out that vacuum-packing of meat and poultry creates an anaerobic medium favorable to the growth of the botulinus organism, which produces the deadly toxin that causes botulism. The meat and poultry industry favors such packing because it avoids economic loss from shrinkage and loss of weight resulting from the drying action of refrigeration. The consumer would be better advised to take meat and poultry out of airtight packaging as soon as possible, not only for enchanced freshness, flavor and texture, but also for preventing food poisoning.

title: General Tire Reports Loss
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company, citing a $57.6 million provision for plant closings, said today that it lost $34.5 million in the first quarter of 1982.

title: DANCE: VICTORIA URIS AND SUSAN MARSHALL
description: MORE than a good beginning was made by two young choreographers, Victoria Uris and Susan Marshall, who shared a program Saturday night at Pace University's Schimmel Center.

title: STATE BOARD STUDIES FATAL TRACK MISHAP
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board began an investigation yesterday into the ninth-race spill at Aqueduct on Monday that fatally injured Amado Credidio Jr., the first jockey killed at a New York thoroughbred track in 21 years.

title: Japan Steel Exports Off
description: Japan's steel exports fell 2.3 percent in February from February 1981, to 2.2 million metric tons, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard THE CHRISTMAS TREE. By Jennifer Johnston. 168 pages. William Morrow. $10.50.

title: Braniff to Begin Refinancing Talks
description: Officials of Braniff International and its 39 creditors are scheduled to begin negotiations Wednesday in an effort to find a way to refinance the airline's $733 million in debt.

title: 3 RIGHTIST PARTIES IN SALVADOR SEEK TO FORM COALITION
description: The five rightist parties that ran behind the moderate Christian Democrats in Sunday's election said today that they had joined in a caucus aimed at establishing a working majority in the new constituent assembly.

title: Peru Borrowing Plans
description: Peru plans public sector foreign borrowing this year of around $2.5 billion, compared with $1.5 billion in 1981, and is currently looking at a number of different markets, Manuel Ulloa, finance minister, said today.

title: TRUMP SEEN AS TOP BIDDER FOR NEWS
description: Donald J. Trump, the real-estate entrepreneur, has emerged as the leading bidder for The Daily News, according to aides close to him and sources close to the owner of the paper. He has told business acquaintances that he expects to complete an agreement to buy the financially troubled newspaper this week.

title: News Analysis
description: The Transport Workers Union and the New York City Transit Authority, in a break with some 45 years of history, have overhauled their collective-bargaining relationship so dramatically that leaders on both sides say there will be no subway and bus strike when the present contract expires at midnight tonight.

title: Samsung Offering
description: The Samsung Company, the trading arm of the Samsung Group of South Korea, said yesterday that it had begun issuing $25 million worth of commercial paper in the United States. It said the program had been arranged with commercial paper back-up facilities provided by Chemical Bank in New York.

title:
FULL PRODUCTION, LOCAL STABILITY;
WASHINGTON - Our national obsession with the size of the Federal deficit diverts attention from the central issue of America's economic crisis: the failure of the conservatives and liberals in both parties to offer a serious plan for sustained full employment and price stability.
description: The Federal deficit is but one factor in the economic equation - and not the most important one. Projected deficits in the $100 billion range represent a bit more than 3 percent of our giant gross national product. President Gerald R. Ford's 1976 deficit was about 4 percent; Japan's 1980 deficit was nearly 6 percent.

title: Police Quell New Rioting In Brazilian Prison
description: Policemen opened fire on inmates today to quell a new outbreak of rioting at a Sao Paulo prison less than 24 hours after a revolt that left 18 people dead.

title: TASTING CALIFORNIA'S NEW WINE
description: THE wines were mostly like unbroken codes - elusive, tightly closed, attempting to convey messages but still indecipherable for many of the 220 participants jammed around the glittering ornamental pool at the Four Seasons restaurant Monday night. No matter. It was the annual social phenomenon known as the California Vintners' Barrel Tasting, a happening of surpassing significance for East Coast oenophiles, and the actual taste of the 30 wines on the agenda was of secondary importance.

title: G.M. to Offer Loans At 12.8%
description: The General Motors Corporation said it will offer buyers of its cars 12.8 percent interest rates on car loans made through its financing unit over the next two months in an effort to stimulate dismal sales.

title: A Nation Of Loan Sharks
description: The recession hurts all right, but it also has its bright side. For instance, have you noticed what's happened to real-estate bores? I'm talking about those people who were always gloating about how rich they'd become just by buying a house.

title: IN SALVADOR, CITY ENDURES 5 DAYS OF WAR
description: Rebel forces attacked this provincial capital last Friday in their strongest military operation in two and a half years of civil war. Most previous guerrilla attacks had been against soldiers defending small, isolated villages. Hitand-run raids on larger cities rarely lasted more than a few hours.

title: WALTER HALLSTEIN, A FOUNDER OF EUROPE'S COMMON MARKET
description: Walter Hallstein, the West German lawyer and diplomat considered one of the founding fathers of the European Economic Community, has died in Stuttgart. He was 80 years old. The cause of death Monday was not disclosed.

title: OPERA: VERRETT FIDELIO
description: THE season's first ''Fidelio'' performance at the Metropolitan Opera Monday night seemed to augur great things. In the title role was Shirley Verrett, one of the day's leading sopranos, singing the role for the first time anywhere. In the pit was an internationally respected conductor, Bernard Haitink of the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra and the Glyndebourne Festival, making his Metropolitan debut. Also in his Met debut was Leif Roar, a promisingly named Danish baritone, as the villainous Don Pizarro. Promise hung in the air, in fact.

title: AFGHAN EX-AIDE BACKS REBELS
description: An Afghan diplomat who served as ambassador to London, New Delhi and delegate to the United Nations, declared himself today in support of the rebels in his country, which he fled a week ago.

title: Blue Traded to Royals
description: Vida Blue, who was one of baseball's leading left-handers when he was with Oakland, returned to the American League today when the San Francisco Giants made him the centerpiece of a six-player trade with the Kansas City Royals.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DIMINISHED CROWD SEES THE SHUTTLE COME DOWN
description: About 6,200 people, undaunted by uncertainty and delay, moved onto this Army base today and cheered the space shuttle's return to earth with shouts of ''Go Columbia!'' and ''She's beautiful!''

title: GLOBAL NEGOIATIONS ISN'T WEALTH SWAP
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FATAL MISTAKE STAYS WITH HOYAS
description: As his players quietly started to shower and dress, and replay the end of the game again and again, Coach John Thompson of Georgetown thought of a time when the school's basketball goals were more modest, its following was much smaller and its existence less frenzied.

title: CATRCHING A QUADRUPLE AND CIRCUS HISTORY
description: FOR the members of the Vazquez family, it is a bittersweet season: In a time when they have been brushed by tragedy, they find themselves on the brink of unequaled circus achievement.

title: TV-AUCTION PREVIEW
description: Selected lots from the fifth on-the-air benefit auction by WNET-TV will be on view at Sotheby's Madison Avenue galleries through Saturday. The station's auction is scheduled for April 29 through May 2.

title: News Analysis
description: The broad vote in El Salvador's elections Sunday in spite of a guerrilla sabotage campaign has won the Reagan Administration temporary respite from sharp

title: California Panel Backs A Chinese Duck Bill
description: The State Assembly's Health Committee has unanimously approved a bill to permit Chinese-style roast duck to be hung in shop windows.

title: PANEL REJECTS APACHE COPTERS
description: tank helicopter, Congressional sources said.

title: Rudy Law to White Sox
description: Rudy Law, a 25-year-old outfielder who batted .335 and stole 56 bases for the Dodgers' Triple-A farm team at Albuquerque last season, was traded by Los Angeles to the Chicago White Sox for two minor leaguers, Burt Geiger, a pitcher, and Cecil Espy, an outfielder. Law hit .260 and stole 40 bases for the Dodgers two years ago. ... The Montreal Expos sent Elias Sosa, a 31-year-old relief pitcher, to Detroit for future considerations.

title: NEW ORDERS UP BY 0.9% IN FEBRUARY
description: Orders for new manufactured goods rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, to a seasonally adjusted $158.59 billion, the first gain since November, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Mississippi Redistricting Turned Down by U.S.
description: The Justice Department today rejected the Congressional redistricitng plan passed by the Mississippi Legislature, saying that it ''dismembered'' black voting strength in violation of the Voting Rights Act.

title: SHUTTLE RETURNS AFTER 8-DAY TRIP, LANDING IN DESERT
description: The third and longest test flight of the space shuttle Columbia ended successfully today with the grace of a soaring eagle dropping out of the sky as the craft came to a smooth landing on a desert of glistening white gypsum sand.

title: STOUFFER CASE BUILT ON SPECULATION, JUDGE SAYS
description: The judge in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial told a stunned court today, after the last prosecution witness testified, that the case against the defendant was based on ''speculation.''

title: Personal Health
description: PARENTS of young children are naturally concerned when their children get sick. Illness is especially disturbing when the child is too young to tell his or her parents what hurts. Yet despite their legitimate concern, most parents don't know when to phone the doctor and what to say when they do.

title: Q and A
description: Q. Some recipes for white sauce recommend cooking it for 15 minutes or even longer; others do not. Is the long cooking time necessary?

title: RECITAL: MUIR STRING QUARTET
description: THE Muir String Quartet, winner of the 1981 Naumburg award for chamber music, performed works Saturday by Haydn, Bartok and Brahms at Washington Irving High School under the aegis of Peoples' Symphony Concerts. Long before the evening ended, it was clear not only that the group can play, but also that it has the sound, the polish and the interpretive depth to rival the best in the world.

title: The Safety Net and 1997
description: Hang in there, says the President to the poor. Give our program time to work. Meanwhile, there is his famous safety net for the truly needy. For some of the truly needy, that is. It is dawning on us from what the President's theorists say and what his budget would do that one group of people is systematically left out of the net: children.

title: 13 Woolco Stores to Close
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company, the nation's fourth-largest retailer, said it will close 13 Woolco discount department stores in three states by July 4, idling about 900 employees.

title: Nigeria Import Curbs
description: The Central Bank will probably extend for several more weeks a ban on financing for imports, banking sources said here today. Nigeria virtually suspended imports last week when, because of shrinking oil revenues, it suspended new letters of credit and the processing of applications for foreign exchange. The Government is attempting to develop a new system of restricting imports in an effort to reduce the country's balance of payments problems, the sources said.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE surest sign of spring is the price of asparagus. When it begins to drop, the forsythia show signs of blooming and the tulips planted on the island in the middle of Park Avenue are halfway out of the ground. If you shop carefully this week, you should be able to find asparagus, which are now plentiful, for as little as 99 cents a pound. (You can also find them for twice as much.) The quality could be a little better, but the weather has not been at its best for asparagus.

title: KNICKS SUSPEND ABSENT WILLIAMS FOR THE SEASON
description: Sly Williams's season ended last night. The Knick forward was suspended for the remainder of the season after he failed to show up for the game against the Indiana Pacers, which the Knicks won, 108-104, at Madison Square Garden.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * BankAmerica Corporation's $500 million issue of zero-coupon notes has been priced for offering today with yields ranging from 13.479 to 13.582 percent.

title: BUDGET PANEL DEFIES REAGAN
description: The Republican-dominated Senate Budget Committee overwhelmingly rejected President Reagan's economic forecast today as overly optimistic and began drafting its own budget for the fiscal year 1983.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend last Friday about Newark's Portuguese neighborhood gave an incorrect telephone number for the Sol-mar Restaurant. The number is (201) 344-3041.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 31, 1982
description: International The five Salvadoran rightist parties that lost to the centrist Christian Democrats in Sunday's elections said they were trying to form a working majority in the Constituent Assembly and that they hoped to establish a coalition by the time the new Assembly convenes in mid-April. A leader of the Christian Democrats, who won 41 percent of the vote, said that the right-wing move would cause ''a tremendous polarization'' of the nation. (Page A1, Column 1.) A Salvadoran rebel leader in exile warned that Sunday's elections had restored the power of the conservative oligarchy and could prolong the civil war. But the leader, Guillermo Manuel Ungo, who is president of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, renewed an offer to negotiate with the new leadership. (A12:5-6.)

title: 'MOSQUITO' FILM RIGHTS SOLD
description: ''The Mosquito Coast,'' Paul Theroux's highly praised new novel that echoes both ''The Swiss Family Robinson'' and ''Lord of the Flies,'' has been purchased for the movies by Jerome Hellman, the producer of ''Midnight Cowboy'' and ''Coming Home.'' The book was bought for $250,000 plus 5 percent of the profits of the eventual movie.

title: F.D.A. AND FRENCH DISAGREE ON PINK PEPPERCORN'S EFFECTS
description: THE supply of pink peppercorns, which has attracted the attention of American cooks, is fast diminishing in this country. The Food and Drug Administration has banned their importation on the ground that they ''can cause a severe toxic reaction.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've proven once again that when we want to we can perform splendid things and make them look easy.'' -James M. Beggs, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, after landing of space shuttle. (A22:1.)

title: SCOVEL RICHARDSON, U.S. JUDGE
description: Scovel Richardson, a judge on the United States Court of International Trade in Manhattan, died yesterday in the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Medical Center after a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: Tosco's Shale Oil Plant Gets Another U.S. Loan
description: The Tosco Corporation said today that the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation had approved $105 million in federally guaranteed loans to help finance construction of the huge Colony shale-oil project in western Colorado for the next six months. Tosco said it would draw $3 million on April 1 and begin drawing the balance in July.

title: ISRAELI ARABS FLY P.L.O. FLAGS AT RALLY
description: In a hillside cemetery surrounded by the olive groves of northern Galilee, homemade flags of the Palestine Liberation Organization fluttered today around the monument to three Israeli Arabs killed here six years ago by security forces.

title: CONNALLLY URGES PRESIDENT TO SLASH BUDGET FOR MILITARY BY $10 BILLION
description: John B. Connally, Secretary of the Treasury in the Nixon Administration, urged President Reagan today to cut military spending by as much as $10 billion as a way of putting pressure on Congress to make cuts in Federal benefit programs.

title: A Durer Discovered
description: When the Rev. William F. E. Robey became rector of the St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church in Shady Side, Md., four years ago, he noticed a dusty old print that had been hanging in the chapel for more than a quarter century.

title: Dali's 'Mere' Sets Auction Record
description: A Surrealist work by Salvador Dali that has hung over the patient's couch of a Zurich psychoanalyst for 36 years sold here Monday for $807,408. The price includes the 10 percent buyer's fee.

title: Massachusetts Property Seized in Drug Case
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., March 30 (UPI) - Federal narcotics agents and the state police have seized $1.75 million worth of Martha's Vineyard real estate they say was bought with money gained from the illegal sale of narcotics.

title: COLONIAL PENN SETS A MARKETING GOAL: REGAIN MOMENTUM
description: When the Colonial Penn Group lost its exclusive contract to sell group health insurance to members of the American Association of Retired Persons and the National Retired Teachers Association, it was a severe blow.

title: Bucks 116, 76ers 114
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Sidney Moncrief of Milwaukee scored 9 of his 23 points in overtime, including the game-winning jump shot with one second left.

title: KICKING THE HABIT
description: NEW ORLEANS OUTSIDE the North Carolina locker room, James Jordan was kicking an imaginary object up and down the corridor. What exactly was he kicking?

title: SAXON EXPECTS TO POST BIG '81 LOSS
description: Saxon Industries, a paper products and photocopier manufacturer, said yesterday that it expects to report a pretax operating loss of about $47 million in 1981 and to take an additional write-off of up to $50 million for losses on the sale of some of its units.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX OFF IN FEBRUARY
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to foreshadow economic trends, declined three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the 10th monthly drop in a row and another sign that the recession is not yet over, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: COMPROMISE ADVANCES SEA-LAW TALKS
description: A compromise to govern exploitation of the oceans' mineral wealth has eased an atmosphere of crisis here and heightened prospects that the United States and other Western industrial nations will join the rest of the world in a law-of-the-sea treaty.

title: HINCKLEY FAMILY ENDS SILENCE TO TELL OF FRUSTRATIONS AT DELAY
description: In the year since John W. Hinckley Jr. shot President Reagan, the Hinckley family has sought to keep out of the public eye in this suburban mountain community in the steep foothills west of Denver.

title: IRRADIATION: WILL IT BE THE NEW TREATMENT?
description: WASHINGTON The Food and Drug Administration is expected to publish a proposed regulation permitting the preservation of fruit, vegetables and spices by exposing them to radioactive materials.

title: POLYESTER DE RIGEUER
description: To the Editor:

title: Useful Taxes in New Jersey
description: Foreseeing a deficit of more than $500 million, New Jersey's new Republican Governor, Thomas Kean, had to swallow much of his supplyside campaign talk and call for higher taxes. But he offers to put a lot of the money to excellent use.

title: Late Rise Sends Rates Higher; Inventory Costs Cited
description: The uncertain outlook for interest rates helped keep many investors on the sidelines yesterday as rates fell modestly in morning trading but then ended higher after a surge in the last two hours of trading.

title: CRITICS SAY LACK OF INCENTIVES HURTS INSURERS' EFFORTS TO CURB MEDICAL
description: COSTS The Price of Health Examining the Medical System Fourth of five articles. By SANDRA SALMANS

title: BRIEFING
description: Bald Eagle Sightings

title: CHARLES THOMAS, EX-CHAIRMAN OF MONSANTO
description: Charles Allen Thomas, a scientist who played a key role in the development of the atom bomb in World War II and went on to become head of the Monsanto Company, died Monday at his home, Magnolia Plantation, near Albany, Ga. He was 82 years old.

title: YANKS GET ALEXANDER AND SIGN HIM TO A 4-YEAR PACT
description: The Yankees added Doyle Alexander to their pitching staff today and immediately prompted comments from some players on an ancillary issue.

title: Grand Union Cuts
description: The Grand Union Company announced plans to close its Norfolk division, which operates Big Star supermarkets in eastern Virginia and parts of Maryland and North Carolina.

title: Hearings Open on Lifting Ban on Coyote Poison
description: Environmental groups were pitted against five Western states and the United States Interior Department as the Government began hearings today on whether to lift a ban against a poison to kill coyotes.

title: SENATE BACKS REPEAL OF TAX ON BIG REALTY DEALS
description: The Senate today approved a bill that would repeal the 10 percent tax on profits from New York City real-estate transactions valued at more than $1 million. The bill would replace the old tax with new levies affecting mortgage recording and real estate transfers.

title: Advertising; Laughing With Dick And Bert
description: MOST suppliers of commercials to adland - those wooers of agencies and advertisers -frequently have to use fairly elaborate ploys to get potential customers together to make a pitch. There is much wining and dining. Elaborate presentations.

title: The President of Boeing Lobbies for Ex-Im Bank
description: Normally, Malcolm T. Stamper, president of the Boeing Corporation, is a man who avoids publicity and busies himself with making certain that the daily operations of the world's largest commercial airplane manufacturer are running smoothly.

title: DOUBTS DEVELOPING OVER BONUS SPACE ARRANGEMENTS
description: Back in 1974 at topping-off ceremonies for Fifth Avenue's Olympic Towers, city officials praised the 52-story building, referring to it as a new breed of skyscraper. Particular attention was given to Olympic Towers' innovative through-block mall, shopping arcade and three-story waterfall designed for the public's comfort and convenience.

title: D'Amato Recommends a U.S. Attorney
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato announced yesterday that he had recommended Raymond J. Dearie for nomination as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York.

title: Policeman Shot in Belfast
description: Irish Republican Army gunmen critically wounded a Belfast police officer today. Sinn Fein, the movement's political wing, said the I.R.A. was responsible for the attack in which a plainclothes officer suffered multiple gunshot wounds in the chest. Britain's domestic news agency said the officer was about to give a woman who worked at his police station a ride to work when he was gunned down.

title: EDWARD T. FLEMING
description: Edward T. Fleming, a chemist, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Bridge: Edith Kemp's Team Wins Knockout Teams Handily
description: The final event of the Spring National Championship of the American Contract Bridge League, the women's knockout teams, ended here Monday night in victory for a powerful group led by Edith Kemp of Miami Beach.

title: Shamrock Gain
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said it will have a $36 million gain in its first-quarter earnings because of the completion of a previously announced exchange of stock for its debentures held by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The exchange involved the issue of about 3 million common shares for some $97 million principal amount of debentures. It said Goldman, Sachs had sold the shares to a number of institutions.

title: CORRECTION
description: The TV Notebook column yesterday incorrectly specified the time for a forthcoming hour-long ABC news program. It is midnight to 1 A.M. The column also incorrectly gave the date that ''The CBS Morning News'' expanded to two hours from 90 minutes. It was Jan. 18.

title: Market Place; Zero-Coupon Municipals
description: GIVE Wall Street a headache like double-digit interest rates, and someone will invent an aspirin like the zero-coupon bond. J.C. Penney offered the first such bonds in April 1981, and a number of corporate issues have been issued since. The first major issues of municipal zero coupons are on the calendar next month.

title: Brady Returns to Hospital
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, returned today to George Washington University Medical Center for treatment of a blood clot in his left leg. He was shot a year ago in the attack on President Reagan. Mr. Brady was described as being in good condition and no surgery was contemplated, White House and hospital officials said.

title: CONRAIL RIDERS TRY BUSES, AND MANY ENJOY THE TRIP
description: More than 100 Westchester County commuters deserted their Conrail trains today to see if happiness could be found on a bus.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp. said it had increased its share of Vulcan Inc. to 17.6 percent of the common stock outstanding, or 376,460 shares, bought for a total of $6,165,805.

title: A MONDRIAN AUCTIONED FOR A RECORD $1 MILLION
description: A painting by Piet Mondrian was sold tonight at Sotheby's for $1,080,000, the highest price ever paid for one of the Dutch modernist's works and the highest ever paid at auction for any abstract work.

title: DUARTE ALLY SEES SETBACK FOR LEFTISTS
description: President Luis Herrera Campins of Venezuela, the Salvadoran's Government strongest Latin American supporter, said today that the large voter turnout in El Salvador Sunday was a rejection of the leftist opposition there.

title: MAYOR RETREATS ON DRIVE TO CUT TAX EXEMPTIONS
description: The Koch administration, acknowledging that its tax policies may have ''made it extremely difficult'' for some private, nonprofit groups to survive, has retreated from its program of actively questioning the tax-exempt status that many of these organizations enjoy.

title: SON'S WIDOW QUITS GANDHI HOUSEHOLD
description: Maneka Gandhi said today that she had been ''thrown out'' of the house of her mother-in-law, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, but that she hoped to be asked to return.

title: Economic Scene; For 'Current Expensing'
description: THE core of the Reagan Administration's supply-side economics was a program of tax cuts for individuals and businesses that was supposed to increase the rate of capital formation - the process of saving and investment that generates real capital equipment and lifts productivity and the rate of economic growth.

title: STAGE: 'AGNES OF GOD,' IN A CONVENT
description: WHEN Elizabeth Ashley marches forward to give the opening speech in John Pielmeier's ''Agnes of God,'' you instantly feel that you're in good hands. Miss Ashley wears a professional woman's no-nonsense suit, and there's no-nonsense authority in everything she does. Her eyes are ablaze; her voice snakes through the Music Box as insistently as the smoke of her cigarette; her monologue lays out Mr. Pielmeier's premise with brisk, eloquent efficiency.

title: News Analysis
description: Congressional opposition to President Reagan's budget and the press's concentration on his misstatements of fact have forced the White House to adopt a bolder communications strategy.

title: Discoveries; PETTICOATS, BELTS AND PLAQUES; 1. Dual Purpose
description: Bendel's has an attractive idea for those who will be wearing miniskirts this spring and summer: a midthigh petticoat made of lace to which panties are attached, so that one garment takes the place of two.
