The elastic waist keeps it anchored so that it doesn't hang below the shortest hemline. The petticoat is made by Glydons in beige, black or white nylon, priced at $17 on the store's third floor.

title: Alsands Wins More Time
description: The Alsands consortium said today that the Alberta and federal governments had agreed to pay operating costs of up to $8 million (Canadian) to keep the $13 billion synthetic fuels project alive through April.

title: STATE DEPT. AIDE CAUTIOUS ON CREDITS TO SOVIET
description: A top State Department official said today that the United States was trying to persuade its European allies that the way the West manages future credits to the Soviet Union is ''a critical strategic issue'' for the rest of the century.

title: Going Out Guide
description: LOWER WHITNEY

title: FLIGHT CHIEF IN HOUSTON
description: In the 1940's, when Eugene Kranz was in junior high school, space flight seemed to him to be a relatively simple endeavor. He wrote a class paper in those years about how man might go to the moon. There were few complications, as he envisioned it: no need for docking procedures, no need for space rendezvous. It would be easy.

title: Brazil Oil-Buying Shift
description: Brazil has temporarily suspended purchases of crude oil from its six regular suppliers and has bought four million barrels of cheaper oil on the spot market in the last month, a spokesman for the state oil company, Petroleo Brasileiro, said here today. The six, the Soviet Union, Algeria, Mexico, Venezuela, Nigeria and Libya, normally supply Brazil with about 200,000 barrels a day. The Petrobras spokesman said that the contracts had not been suspended, but that Brazil had simply stopped taking delivery of crude from these countries for the last 16 days or so.

title: UTILITY AGENCY PROPOSAL WINS WESTCHESTER VOTE
description: Westchester County voters today approved the creation of a public agency that would draw on cheap upstate hydropower from the Power Authority of the State of New York to help reduce their Consolidated Edison bills.

title: Shot Clock Wins Backing
description: Basketball coaches in the powerful Atlantic Coast Conference have approved a recommendation calling for a shot clock in A.C.C. games beginning next season. Final approval rests with the athletic directors of the conference schools.

title: IRAQIS CONFIRM TROOPS' RETREAT AS IRAN ATTACKS
description: The President of Iraq confirmed today that his troops had been forced to fall back in southwestern Iran by an Iranian offensive. The retreat, which could be a major turning point in the 18-month-old war, came during what Iran called an ''all-out offensive'' to expel the invaders.

title: Michigan to Get Relief Funds
description: President Reagan has declared Michigan a major disaster area as a result of severe storms and flooding on March 12. The designation will permit the use of Federal funds in relief and recovery efforts in designated areas of the state.

title: FOR THE NATIONAL SYMPHONY, AN UPBEAT TONE IS WELCOME
description: ''Statistics are not as clear for orchestras as for baseball teams'' says Henry Fogel, executive director of Washington's National Symphony. ''The wins, the losses and the strikeouts are not as clearly defined. It is more a matter of conjecture, opinion and public perception.''

title: TUBES AT 40 A-PLANTS ASSAILED
description: Weak steam generator tubes in 40 commercial nuclear units, including two in Connecticut, are ''virtually impossible'' to fix and are causing higher operating costs and radiation exposure for plant personnel, according to a Federal report.

title: JEWISH ACTIVIST UNBOWED AFTER SIBERIAN EXILE
description: Ida Nudel, the Jewish activist who was sentenced to four years in Siberia for hanging protest posters outside her window, returned to Moscow last week, unbowed and even more anxious to emigrate.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: IT is no fun being a patient in a hospital, and friends very often don't help much. They pop in unexpectedly, just as one is dozing with mouth open. They telephone when dinner, or what passes for it, has just been put on the bed tray. And when it comes to gifts, their imagination seems to be as barren as the Sahara. Poor old so-and-so is in the hospital? The reflex is automatic: dial the florist or dash into the nearest bookstore.

title: MANES PLANS A TRIP TO TAIWAN IN APRIL TO ATTRACT INDUSTRY
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens announced yesterday that he would head a trade mission to Taiwan next month in an effort to attract Taiwanese investors to Queens.

title: The U.N. Today; March 31, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on complaint by Nicaragua at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Silver Futures Prices Decline in Late Selling
description: Silver futures prices seesawed at the technical support line of $7 an ounce yesterday, before some late selling pushed prices down. Brokers said that once some modest carry-over buying from Monday had trailed off, the market seemed to gradually turn bearish.

title: TV: OFFBEAT VOTES MADE OSCAR NIGHT A WINNER
description: THANKS largely to the fancifulness of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences' voters, Monday night's Oscar presentation was the most exciting in recent years. When the awards show itself is something less than swift or glamorous, which was certainly the case this year, it can still come to life if the voting takes a sufficiently strange turn.

title: Jersey School Chief Fined Over Loan
description: Fred G. Burke, the New Jersey Education Commissioner, was fined $250 today on administrative conflict-of-interest charges for accepting a $25,046 loan from a friend later hired for a state job.

title: BODY OF JERSEY SCOUTMASTER IS RECOVERED FROM THE CAVE
description: The body of Donald Weltner was recovered late tonight, 81 hours after the 48-year-old Scoutmaster became wedged in a tiny, curving crevice of the limestone cave that he had been exploring with Boy Scouts from his troop last Saturday afternoon.

title: ASSESSING THE EFFECTS OF CHEMICALLY TREATED FOOD
description: WASHINGTON FEW foods these days escape some of the mass-production techniques used to retard spoilage and enhance appearance and taste. Even fresh fruit and vegetables are routinely treated with fungicides, bactericides and growth regulators, coated with plastic or wax, and then sometimes dyed to enrich or camouflage natural color.

title: Oberkfell Sidelined
description: Ken Oberkfell, the regular third baseman of the St. Louis Cardinals, broke his left thumb while diving for a ground ball in an exhibition game and is expected to miss at least the first two weeks of the regular season. His place in the starting lineup will be taken by either Dane Iorg, an outfielder who has played a bit at third base, or the reserve infielder Mike Ramsey.

title: Data General's Net Down 36%
description: The Data General Corporation, citing the continuing effects of recession and inflation, said today that its operating net income in its fiscal second quarter fell 36 percent, to $5.6 million, or 52 cents a share, from $8.8 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: JERSEY PREPARED TO TAKE CONTROL OF CONRAIL LINE
description: The New Jersey Transit Corporation said yesterday that it was prepared to run the Conrail commuter lines that carry 75,000 New Jersey passengers each day. But the state agency said the Federal Government must pay for the cost of transferring the operation.

title: Pam Kelly Honored
description: Pam Kelly, a three-time all-America center for the women's basketball team at Louisiana Tech, won the Wade Trophy yesterday as the season's top female player. The ballots to determine the selection were cast by a group of 100 coaches, athletic directors and sports information directors across the country, who were confronted by such credentials as these: a national championship for the Lady Techsters in each of the last two seasons, a team record of 143-10 during the four seasons in which Miss Kelly played and an individual scoring average this season of 20 points a game, on an average of only 23 minutes of playing time.

title: Stocks Up on Higher Volume
description: The stock market edged slightly higher yesterday in more active trading, with stocks that responded to specific news developments posting the largest price moves.

title: G.E. OFFERS DATA LINK TO IMPROVE AUTOMATION
description: The General Electric Company yesterday introduced a data transfer network intended to allow communication between computers and automated factory equipment.

title: 58 SENATORS BACK ALTERNATIVE PLAN ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: A majority of the Senate endorsed a resolution today that called upon the United States and the Soviet Union to freeze their nuclear arsenals at ''equal and sharply reduced levels,'' an approach that won general support from President Reagan.

title: Continental Air Sees Loss
description: Although its passenger load is rising, Continental Air Lines will lose money again in the first quarter because of competitive price wars, George A. Warde, president and chief executive, told shareholders today.

title: CLARIFYING AUDITORS' LIABILITY
description: A new appellate court ruling on the liability of outside auditors who fail to detect management fraud may go a long way toward clearing up a pervasive problem for the accounting industry, several lawyers for major accounting firms said yesterday.

title: WRONG PRICE FOR A WORLD ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT RULES JUDGE COOKE VIOLATED STATE CONSTITUTION ON ASSIGNMENTS
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke violated the State Constitution when he devised a plan to rotate judges without consulting other authorities.

title: Too Fine a Machine
description: With the completion of its third successful flight, Columbia almost succeeded in placing the stamp of routine on shuttling into space.

title: New Reason for Refusing Aid to Chile's Regime
description: To the Editor:

title: SWAN OF METS SEES A LENGTHY COMEBACK
description: Craig Swan conceded today that he was still a limited pitcher and predicted that he might need the entire season to complete the comeback from his shoulder injury of 20 months ago.

title: AT THE HEART OF THE JUVENILE PROBLEM: THE 'CRIMINOGENIC' FAMILY
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS FAILURES SPREADING
description: Lenny Rerek says sales at his wholesale auto parts shop were ''pretty lousy'' through the first two months of 1982. Unfortunately, he adds, lousy sales were not the biggest problem. ''Receivables are the real problem,'' he said. ''You sell people merchandise and they don't pay up within 30 days.''

title: COMMON MARKET TO INCREASE AID FOR CENTRAL AMERICANS
description: Leaders of the 10 European Common Market countries pledged today to step up financial aid for Central America and denounced Israel's treatment of Palestinians in the occupied West Bank.

title: HATCH IS ASSAILED ON ETHICS IN VESCO INQUIRY
description: John C. White, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today accused Senator Orrin G. Hatch of violating the Senate's ethics code in his investigation of a scheme designed to benefit the Libyan Government and Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier.

title: Reagan News Session To Be on TV Tonight
description: President Reagan will address questions from the press tonight at 8 P.M. The news conference will be covered live on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.

title: U.S. Steel Board Elects
description: Harold Hoopman, president and chief executive of the Marathon Oil Company, has been elected to the board of the United States Steel Corporation, it was announced today. Marathon stockholders earlier this month approved the company's $6.2 billion merger with U.S. Steel.

title: Defendant Slain Fleeing Court
description: A Rahway State Prison inmate on trial on assault and weapons charges stabbed four correction officers with a makeshift knife today, and then was fatally shot as he bolted from the courtroom.

title: FORECASTS LOWERED BY REGAN
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, in another scaling down of the Administration's economic forecasts, said today that in both the second quarter and the second half of the year the economy would be weaker than forecast just two months ago.

title: Republicans Choose Korey, Kay Agency
description: The Republican Marketing Group, made up of the Republican National Committee and the National Republican Congressional Committee, has named Korey, Kay & Partners its ad agency.

title: WIMBLEDON SIFTS BORG'S CASE
description: Wimbledon officials are discussing the possibility of exempting Bjorn Borg from having to qualify for the tournament if the Men's International Professional Tennis Council refuses to change its position on Borg's status.

title: PROFILES OF SALVADOR PARTIES SEEKING COALITION
description: Following are brief profiles of the five rightist political groups seeking to form a coalition in El Salvador and the percentage of the vote they had at the latest report. The Christian Democratic Party won 41 percent of the vote. Nationalist Republican

title: A CANAVERAL, DEJECTION AND LOOK TO THE FUTURE
description: The only things that landed on the Kennedy Space Center runway here today were a jet trainer, a few crows and several squadrons of butterflies.

title: Blast on French Train Is Attributed to a Bomb
description: The explosion on a Paris-Toulouse express train that killed five passengers and injured 27 near here Monday evening was caused by a powerful bomb, a police bomb expert said today.

title: BRITONS AND ARGENTINES SQUARING OFF
description: Britain warned today that an unauthorized Argentine incursion onto one of its south Atlantic territories had created a ''potentially dangerous'' situation.

title: TAX CREDIT RULES TIGHTENED BY STATE JOB INCENTIVE PANEL
description: The state's Job Incentive Board, whose critics have accused it of having granted millions of dollars in tax relief to businesses that did not need it, today approved rules that would make it more difficult for some companies to get tax credits.

title: 2 Convicted of Killing Detective in a Holdup
description: Two men were convicted yesterday of murdering an off-duty police detective as he tried to halt a robbery in a social club in Richmond Hill, Queens, in July 1980.

title: CARL ORFF, TEACHER AND COMPOSER OF 'CARMINA BURANA,' DEAD AT 86
description: Carl Orff, the German composer and music educator best known for his 1937 work ''Carmina Burana,'' died of cancer Monday night in a Munich, West Germany, clinic. He was 86 years old.

title: Koch and Cuomo Trade Charges in Campaigns
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Koch sniped at each other yesterday in their campaigns for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Mr. Cuomo accused Mr. Koch of ''supporting Republicans,'' and Mr. Koch chided Mr. Cuomo for refusing to be bound by the results of their Democratic primary election.

title: JAZZ SONGS: BETTY CARTER
description: BECAUSE Betty Carter has rarely performed with a full orchestra, her Bottom Line appearances last weekend with a string section augmenting her trio made it a very special occasion.

title: Former 'Silk-Scarf' Pilot Begins His Retirement
description: They were known as the silk-scarf-and-goggles bunch, men who began their careers when the aviation industry was young, and then built major airlines.

title: U.S. RATES CRITICIZED BY E.E.C. AS TALKS END
description: Leaders of the Common Market asserted today that high American interest rates were spreading recession around the world and undermining hopes of reducing unemployment.

title: NEW STYLE IN INDUSTRY FILM MAKING
description: When the topic of industrial films comes up, Albert and David Maysles begin to gnash their teeth. Within seconds, one of the brothers will have something testy to say.

title: NEW MAN AT THE U.N.
description: Javier Perez de Cuellar of Peru, the sixth Secretary General of the United Nations, has been on the job now for three months, and is still trying to figure out, like his predecessors, what the job is.

title: WEST GEMRAN UNIVERSITIES: WHAT TO CALL THEM?
description: Out past the trolley tracks, at a place where the city gives way and a suburb named Bilk takes over, sits a group of gray concrete buildings that will not be called Heinrich Heine University.
